original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, accomplished and fully enlightened.

original: Abhidhammapiṭake🔽Sammohavinodanī nāma🔽Vibhaṅga-aṭṭhakathā
analyzed: abhidhamma piṭake         vibhaṅga aṭṭhakathā
translated: In the Abhidhamma Piṭaka🔽The Clearing of Delusion🔽The Commentary on the Vibhaṅga

original: 1. Khandhavibhaṅgo
analyzed: khandha vibhaṅgo
translated: The Exposition of the Categories

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Mode of Conveying a Teaching

original: Catusaccadaso nātho, catudhā dhammasaṅgaṇiṃ;
analyzed: catusaccadasaḥ catudhā dhamma saṅgaṇim
translated: The Helper, the one of four truths, the one of fourfold recitation of the Dhamma,

original: Pakāsayitvā sambuddho, tasseva samanantaraṃ.
analyzed: pakāsayitvā sambuddhaḥ tassa iva samanantaram
translated: Having taught, the Enlightened One, immediately after that,

original: Upeto buddhadhammehi, aṭṭhārasahi nāyako;
analyzed: upetaḥ buddha dhammehi aṭṭhārasahi nāyako
translated: The Leader, endowed with the eighteen Buddha dhammas,

original: Aṭṭhārasannaṃ khandhādi-vibhaṅgānaṃ vasena yaṃ.
analyzed: vasena yam
translated: By means of the eighteen expositions beginning with the categories,

original: Vibhaṅgaṃ desayī satthā, tassa saṃvaṇṇanākkamo;🔽Idāni yasmā sampatto, tasmā tassatthavaṇṇanaṃ.
analyzed: vibhaṅgam desayī satthā tassa saṃvaṇṇanā kkamaḥ  idāni tasmā tad attha vaṇṇanaṃ
translated: The Teacher preached the Vibhaṅga. The order of the description of that🔽Has now arrived. Therefore I shall make a commentary on its meaning

original: Karissāmi vigāhetvā, porāṇaṭṭhakathānayaṃ;
analyzed: karissāmi vigāhetvā porāṇa ṭṭhakathā nayam
translated: By way of the ancient commentaries, after having analyzed it.

original: Saddhamme gāravaṃ katvā, taṃ suṇātha samāhitāti.🔽1. Pañcakkhandhā – rūpakkhandho…pe… viññāṇakkhandhoti idaṃ vibhaṅgappakaraṇassa ādibhūte
analyzed: saddhamme gāravam katvā tam suṇātha samāhitā iti  pañca kkhandhāḥ rūpa kkhandha upe viññāṇa kkhandho ti idam vibhaṅga ppakaraṇassa ādi bhūte
translated: Having paid respect to the True Idea, listen to it with concentration.

original: khandhavibhaṅge suttantabhājanīyaṃ nāma. Tattha pañcāti gaṇanaparicchedo. Tena na
analyzed: khandha vibhaṅge suttantabhājanīyam nāma tattha gaṇana paricchedo tena na
translated: The five categories are the materiality category … the consciousness category. This is called the “description of the mode of conveying a teaching” in the exposition of the categories, which is the beginning of the Vibhaṅga treatise. Herein, five is the delimitation by number. By that it is known that

original: tato heṭṭhā na uddhanti dasseti. Khandhāti paricchinnadhammanidassanaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ
analyzed: tatas heṭṭhā na uddhanti dasseti khandhā ti paricchinna dhamma nidassanam tatra ayam
translated: He shows that they do not go beyond the aggregates. The word “aggregates” is a term for a particular kind of thing.

original: khandha-saddo sambahulesu ṭhānesu dissati – rāsimhi, guṇe, paṇṇattiyaṃ, ruḷhiyanti.🔽“Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāsamudde na sukaraṃ udakassa pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ – ettakāni
analyzed: khandha saddo sambahulesu ṭhānesu dissati rāsimhi guṇe paṇṇattiyam  seyyathā api bhikkhave mahā samudde na sukaram udakassa pamāṇam gahetum ettakāni
translated: It is found in many places, in a heap, in a quality, in a concept, in a designation.

original: udakāḷhakānīti vā ettakāni udakāḷhakasatānīti vā ettakāni udakāḷhakasahassānīti vā🔽ettakāni udakāḷhakasatasahassānīti vā, atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāudakakkhandhotveva
analyzed: udaka āḷhakāni iti vā ettakāni udaka āḷhaka satāni iti vā ettakāni udaka āḷhaka sahassāni iti vā  ettakāni udaka āḷhaka sata sahassāni iti vā atha kho asaṅkhyeyyaḥ appameyyaḥ mahā udaka khandhaḥ tu eva
translated: “Bhikkhus, it is not easy to give the measure of the water in the ocean and say that there are so many gallons of water, or so many hundreds of gallons, or so many thousands of gallons, or so many hundreds of thousands of gallons.🔽But it is reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable great mass of water” .

original: saṅkhyaṃ gacchatī”tiādīsu hi rāsito khandho nāma. Nahi parittakaṃ udakaṃ udakakkhandhoti
analyzed: saṅkhyam gacchati iti ādīsu hi rāsito khandhaḥ nāma nahi parittakam udakam udaka kkhandho ti
translated: Herein, an aggregate is a heap, for a small amount of water is not called a great mass of water.

original: vuccati, bahukameva vuccati. Tathā na parittako rajo rajakkhandho, na appamattakā
analyzed: vuccati bahukam eva vuccati tathā na parittakaḥ rajaḥ raja kkhandho na appamattakā
translated: Only a large amount is. So too, a small amount of dust is not a dust-heap,🔽a small amount of cattle is not a herd of cattle,

original: gāvo gavakkhandho, na appamattakaṃ balaṃ balakkhandho, na appamattakaṃ puññaṃ puññakkhandhoti
analyzed: gāvaḥ gava kkhandhaḥ na appamattakam balam bala kkhandhaḥ na appamattakam puññam puñña kkhandhaḥ iti
translated: a small amount of strength is not a mass of strength, a small amount of merit is not a mass of merit.

original: vuccati. Bahukameva hi rajo rajakkhandho, bahukāva gavādayo gavakkhandho, balakkhandho,
analyzed: vuccati bahukam eva hi rajaḥ raja kkhandhaḥ bahukāḥ ava go ādayaḥ gava kkhandhaḥ bala kkhandhaḥ
translated: and so on. For there is much dust in a dust-heap, many cows, etc., in a cow-pen, and so on.

original: puññakkhandhoti vuccanti. “Sīlakkhandho samādhikkhandho”tiādīsu pana guṇato khandho
analyzed: puñña kkhandho ti vuccanti sīla kkhandho samādhi kkhandho ti ādīsu pana guṇato khandho
translated: In such passages as “The virtue category, the concentration category” , etc., it is a category in the sense of a heap of qualities.

original: nāma. “Addasā kho bhagavā mahantaṃ dārukkhandhaṃ gaṅgāya nadiyā sotena vuyhamāna”nti.
analyzed: nāma addasā kho bhagavā mahantam dāru khandham gaṅgāya nadiyā sotena
translated: In the passage, “The Blessed One saw a great timber log being carried away by the current of the river Ganges” ,🔽it is a log in the sense of a collection.

original: Ettha paṇṇattito khandho nāma. “Yaṃ cittaṃ mano mānasaṃ…pe… viññāṇaṃ viññāṇakkhandho”tiādīsu🔽ruḷhito khandho nāma. Svāyamidha rāsito adhippeto. Ayañhi khandhaṭṭho nāma piṇḍaṭṭho
analyzed: ettha paṇṇattito khandho nāma yam cittam manaḥ mānasam pe viññāṇam viññāṇa kkhandho ti ādīsu  ruḷhitaḥ khandhaḥ nāma rāsitaḥ adhippetaḥ ayam hi khandhaṭṭhaḥ nāma piṇḍa ṭṭho
translated: In the passage, “The mind, the mental organ, the mind that is the province of thought, the faculty of mind, the element of mind” ,🔽it is a collection in the sense of a heap.🔽Here, however, it is intended in the sense of a collection. For this “category” is a mass, a heap, a collection, a bundle.🔽Therefore it should be understood that “categories” are characterized by a collection.

original: pūgaṭṭho ghaṭaṭṭho rāsaṭṭho. Tasmā ‘rāsilakkhaṇā khandhā’ti veditabbā. Koṭṭhāsaṭṭhotipi
analyzed: pūga aṭṭhaḥ ghaṭa aṭṭhaḥ rāsa aṭṭhaḥ tasmā rāsi lakkhaṇā khandhā ti veditabbā koṭṭhāsa aṭṭhaḥ ti pi
translated: It is also permissible to say that they are characterized by a portion,

original: vattuṃ vaṭṭati; lokasmiñhi iṇaṃ gahetvā codiyamānā ‘dvīhi khandhehi dassāma, tīhi
analyzed: vattum vaṭṭati lokasmin hi iṇam gahetvā codiyamānāḥ dvīhi khandhehi dassāma tīhi
translated: for in the world they say, “We will pay with two or three portions” when they are asked to pay.

original: khandhehi dassāmā’ti vadanti. Iti ‘koṭṭhāsalakkhaṇā khandhā’tipi vattuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: khandhehi dassāma ati vadanti iti koṭṭhāsa lakkhaṇā vattum vaṭṭati
translated: Thus it is also permissible to say that “categories” are characterized by a portion.

original: Evamettha rūpakkhandhoti rūparāsi rūpakoṭṭhāso, vedanākkhandhoti vedanārāsi vedanākoṭṭhāsoti
analyzed: evam ettha rūpa kkhandho ti rūpa rāsi rūpa koṭṭhāsaḥ vedanā kkhandho ti vedanā rāsi vedanā koṭṭhāso ti
translated: So here the materiality aggregate is a mass of materiality, a collection of materiality, a heap of materiality. The feeling aggregate is a mass of feeling, a collection of feeling, a heap of feeling.

original: iminā nayena saññākkhandhādīnaṃ attho veditabbo.
analyzed: iminā nayena saññā khandha ādīnam atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning of the perception aggregate, etc., should be understood in the same way.

original: Ettāvatā sammāsambuddho yvāyaṃ “cattāro ca mahābhūtā catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādāyarūpa”nti
analyzed: ettāvatā sammāsambuddhaḥ yvā ayam cattāraḥ ca mahābhūtā catunnam ca mahābhūtānam
translated: So far the Fully Enlightened One has shown that the materiality aggregate is all the materiality classed as the four great primaries and the materiality derived by clinging from the four great primaries,

original: atītānāgatapaccuppannādīsu ekādasasu okāsesu vibhatto ‘pañcavīsati rūpakoṭṭhāsā’ti🔽ca ‘channavuti rūpakoṭṭhāsā’ti ca evaṃpabhedo rūparāsi, taṃ sabbaṃ paripiṇḍetvā rūpakkhandho
analyzed: atīta anāgata paccuppanna ādīsu ekādasasu okāsesu vibhatto pañcavīsati rūpa koṭṭhāsā ati  ca channavuti rūpa koṭṭhāsā ati ca evaṃpabhedaḥ rūpa rāsi tam sabbam paripiṇḍetvā rūpakkhandho
translated: which is distributed into twenty-five or ninety-two kinds in the eleven instances beginning with past, future, and present,

original: nāmāti dassesi. Yo panāyaṃ “sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā”ti🔽tesuyeva ekādasasu okāsesu vibhatto catubhūmikavedanārāsi, taṃ sabbaṃ paripiṇḍetvā
analyzed: nāma ati dassesi yaḥ pana ayam sukhā vedanā dukkhā vedanā adukkham asukhā vedanā ti  tesu yeva ekādasasu okāsesu vibhatto catu bhūmika vedanā rāsi tam sabbam paripiṇḍetvā
translated: and that the feeling aggregate is all the feeling classed as pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant,🔽which is distributed into four kinds in the eleven instances beginning with past, future, and present, and that the perception aggregate is all the perception classed as perception of forms, perception of sounds, etc.,

original: vedanākkhandho nāmāti dassesi. Yo panāyaṃ “cakkhusamphassajā saññā…pe… manosamphassajā
analyzed: vedanā khandho nāma ati dassesi yaḥ pana ayam cakkhu samphassa jā saññāpe manaḥ samphassa jā
translated: which is distributed into twelve kinds in the twelve instances beginning with perception of forms and ending with perception of mental objects.

original: saññā”ti tesuyeva ekādasasu okāsesu vibhatto catubhūmikasaññārāsi, taṃ sabbaṃ paripiṇḍetvā
analyzed: saññā ti tesu yeva ekādasasu okāsesu vibhattaḥ catu bhūmika saññā rāsi tam sabbam paripiṇḍetvā
translated: The aggregate of perception is distributed into eleven sections,🔽and all that is included in the fourfold perception.

original: saññākkhandho nāmāti dassesi. Yo panāyaṃ “cakkhusamphassajā cetanā…pe… manosamphassajā🔽cetanā”ti tesuyeva ekādasasu okāsesu vibhatto catubhūmikacetanārāsi, taṃ sabbaṃ paripiṇḍetvā🔽saṅkhārakkhandho nāmāti dassesi. Yo panāyaṃ “cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, sotaghānajivhākāyaviññāṇaṃ,🔽manodhātu, manoviññāṇadhātū”ti tesuyeva ekādasasu okāsesu vibhatto catubhūmikacittarāsi,
analyzed: saññā kkhandho nāma ati dassesi yaḥ pana ayam cakkhu samphassa jā cetanā pe manaḥ samphassa jā  cetanā ti tesu yeva ekādasasu okāsesu vibhatto catu bhūmika cetanā rāsi tam sabbam paripiṇḍetvā  saṅkhāra kkhandho nāma ati dassesi yaḥ pana ayam cakkhu viññāṇam sota ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇam  manaḥ dhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu uti tesu yeva ekādasasu okāsesu vibhatto catu bhūmika citta rāsi
translated: The aggregate of perception is shown by the words “perception” in the eleven instances, which is a collection of fourfold perception.🔽The aggregate of volitional formations is shown by the words “volition” in the eleven instances, which is a collection of fourfold volition.

original: taṃ sabbaṃ paripiṇḍetvā viññāṇakkhandho nāmāti dassesi.🔽Apicettha sabbampi catusamuṭṭhānikaṃ rūpaṃ rūpakkhandho, kāmāvacaraaṭṭhakusalacittādīhi
analyzed: tam sabbam paripiṇḍetvā viññāṇa kkhandho nāma ati dassesi  apica ittha sabbam pi catu samuṭṭhānikam rūpam rūpa kkhandho kāmāvacara aṭṭha kusala citta ādīhi
translated: The aggregate of consciousness is shown by the words “eye-consciousness” and the rest in the eleven instances, which is a collection of fourfold consciousness.

original: ekūnanavuticittehi sahajātā vedanā vedanākkhandho, saññā saññākkhandho, phassādayo
analyzed: ekūna navuti cittehi sahajātā vedanā vedanā khandho saññā saññā khandho phassa ādayo
translated: And here all materiality originated by the four primaries is the materiality aggregate. Feeling associated with the nineteen types of consciousness beginning with the eight kinds of sense-sphere profitable consciousness is the feeling aggregate. Perception is the perception aggregate. The remaining aggregates are as already stated.

original: dhammā saṅkhārakkhandho, ekūnanavuti cittāni viññāṇakkhandhoti. Evampi pañcasu khandhesu
analyzed: dhammā saṅkhāra kkhandho ekūnanavuti cittāni viññāṇa kkhandho ti evam pi pañcasu khandhesu
translated: The states are the formations aggregate, and the eighty-nine kinds of consciousness are the consciousness aggregate.

original: dhammaparicchedo veditabbo.
analyzed: dhamma paricchedaḥ veditabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here as to the five aggregates.

original: 1. Rūpakkhandhaniddeso
analyzed: rūpakkhandha niddeso
translated: The Description of the Materiality Aggregate

original: 2. Idāni te rūpakkhandhādayo vibhajitvā dassetuṃ tattha katamo rūpakkhandhotiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni te rūpa kkhandha ādayaḥ vibhajitvā dassetum tattha katamaḥ rūpa kkhandhaḥ ti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show them by dividing up the materiality aggregate, etc., he said, “Herein, what is the materiality aggregate? ”

original: Tattha tatthāti tesu pañcasu khandhesu. Katamoti kathetukamyatāpucchā. Rūpakkhandhoti
analyzed: tattha tattha ati tesu pañcasu khandhesu katamaḥ iti kathā itu kamya tā pucchā rūpa kkhandho ti
translated: Herein, herein in these five aggregates. What? is a question expressing a desire to speak. The materiality aggregate is …

original: pucchitadhammanidassanaṃ. Idāni taṃ vibhajanto yaṃ kiñci rūpantiādimāha. Tattha yaṃ
analyzed: pucchita dhamma nidassanam idāni tam vibhajantaḥ yam kiñci ti ādim āha tattha yam
translated: is the pointing out of the question state. Now, in order to analyse that, he said, “Any materiality whatever” . Herein,

original: kiñcīti anavasesapariyādānaṃ. Rūpanti atippasaṅganiyamanaṃ. Evaṃ padadvayenāpi rūpassa🔽anavasesapariggaho kato hoti.
analyzed: kiñci iti anavasesa pariyādānam rūpan ti atippasaṅga niyamanam evam pada dvayena api rūpassa  anavasesa pariggahaḥ kataḥ hoti
translated: any whatever is a term for the whole without remainder. Materiality is a term for the purpose of precluding the immaterial. So by the two terms the materiality is stated as the whole without remainder.

original: Tattha kenaṭṭhena rūpanti? Ruppanaṭṭhena rūpaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: tattha kena aṭṭhena rūpam ti ruppana ṭṭhena rūpam vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: Herein, in what sense is it materiality? It is materiality in the sense of deformed . For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Kiñca, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ vadetha? Ruppatīti kho, bhikkhave, tasmā rūpanti vuccati.
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave rūpam vadetha ruppati iti kho bhikkhave tasmā rūpanti vuccati
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is materiality? Whatever is extension, that is materiality.

original: Kena ruppati? Sītenapi ruppati, uṇhenapi ruppati, jighacchāyapi ruppati, pipāsāyapi
analyzed: kena ruppati sītena api ruppati uṇhena api ruppati jighacchāya api ruppati pipāsāya api
translated: By what is it molested? It is molested by cold, it is molested by heat, it is molested by hunger, it is molested by thirst,

original: ruppati, ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarisapasamphassenapi ruppati. Ruppatīti kho, bhikkhave,
analyzed: ruppati ḍaṃsa makasa vāta ātapa sarisa pa samphassena api ruppati ruppati iti kho bhikkhave
translated: it is molested by contact with gadflies, flies, wind, sun and creeping things. It is molested, bhikkhus,

original: tasmā rūpanti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: tasmāt vuccati iti
translated: therefore it is called materiality. ”

original: Tattha kinti kāraṇapucchā; kena kāraṇena rūpaṃ vadetha, kena kāraṇena taṃ rūpaṃ nāmāti
analyzed: tattha kinti kāraṇa pucchā kena kāraṇena rūpam vadetha kena kāraṇena tam rūpam nāma ati
translated: Herein, the question “By what” is a question for a reason. The meaning is: for what reason do you call it materiality, for what reason is that materiality?

original: attho. Ruppatīti ettha itīti kāraṇuddeso. Yasmā ruppati tasmā rūpanti vuccatīti attho.
analyzed: atthaḥ ruppati iti ettha iti iti kāraṇa uddesaḥ yasmā ruppati tasmā rūpanti vuccati iti attho
translated: The word “it” in the phrase “It is molested” is a demonstrative for a reason. The meaning is: because it is molested, therefore it is called materiality.

original: Ruppatīti kuppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷiyati bhijjatīti attho. Evaṃ iminā ettakena ṭhānena
analyzed: ruppati iti kuppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷiyati bhijjati iti attho evam iminā ettakena ṭhānena
translated: The meaning of “is molested” is “is troubled, is struck, is afflicted, is broken up.” So in this much of the text

original: ruppanaṭṭhena rūpaṃ vuttaṃ. Ruppanalakkhaṇena rūpantipi vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Ruppanalakkhaṇañhetaṃ.🔽Sītenapi ruppatītiādīsu pana sītena tāva ruppanaṃ lokantarikaniraye pākaṭaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: ruppana ṭṭhena rūpam vuttam ruppana lakkhaṇena rūpam ti pi vattum vaṭṭati ruppana lakkhaṇam ha etam 🔽sītena api ruppati iti ādīsu pana sītena tāva ruppanam lokantarika niraye pākaṭam
translated: materiality is stated in the sense of molested. It is also allowable to say that it is called materiality because it has the characteristic of molestation, since that is its characteristic.🔽As regards the passage beginning “It is molested by cold” , the molestation by cold is evident in the Cold-wind Hell. The molestation by heat is evident in the other eight hot hells. The molestation by hunger is evident in the Starving Ghost Realm. The molestation by thirst is evident in the Great Desert of Thirst. The molestation by contact with gadflies, flies, wind, sun and creeping things is evident in the Animal Realm and in the human and divine births.

original: tiṇṇañhi cakkavāḷānaṃ antare ekeko lokantarikanirayo nāma hoti aṭṭhayojanasahassappamāṇo,
analyzed: tiṇṇam hi cakkavāḷānam antare ekekaḥ lokantarikanirayaḥ nāma hoti aṭṭha yojana sahassa ppamāṇo
translated: For between three world-spheres there is a world-sphere of space, and between each pair of those there is a hell named ‘Intervening Space’ , which is eight thousand leagues in extent,

original: yassa neva heṭṭhā pathavī atthi, na upari candimasūriyadīpamaṇiāloko, niccandhakāro.🔽Tattha nibbattasattānaṃ tigāvuto attabhāvo hoti. Te vagguliyo viya pabbatapāde dīghaputhulehi
analyzed: yassa na iva heṭṭhā pathavī atthi na upari candima sūriya dīpa maṇi ālokaḥ nicca andhakāro  tattha nibbatta sattānam tiga avutaḥ atta bhāvaḥ hoti te vagguliyaḥ viya pabbata pāde dīgha puthulehi
translated: where there is no ground beneath and no sun or moon or lightning or gems to give light, but which is in perpetual darkness.

original: nakhehi laggitvā avaṃsirā olambanti. Yadā saṃsappantā aññamaññassa hatthapāsagatā
analyzed: nakhehi laggitvā avaṃsirāḥ olambanti yadā saṃsappantā aññamaññassa hattha pāsa gatā
translated: The beings there are three gavutas in size. They are attached by long thin tentacles like bamboo slivers to the sides of the mountains, hanging head downwards.

original: honti atha ‘bhakkho no laddho’ti maññamānā tattha byāvaṭā viparivattitvā lokasandhārake🔽udake patanti, sītavāte paharantepi pakkamadhukaphalāni viya chijjitvā udake patanti.
analyzed: honti atha bhakkhaḥ no laddhaḥ ti maññamānā tattha byāvaṭā viparivattitvā loka sandhārake  udake patanti sīta vāte paharante api pakka madhuka phalāni chijjitvā udake patanti
translated: When they move about, they think ‘We have got something to eat’ and they turn over and fall into the water that supports the world,🔽and when the cold wind blows on them they split like ripe wood-apple fruit and fall into the water.

original: Patitamattāva accantakhārena sītodakena chinnacammanhārumaṃsaaṭṭhīhi bhijjamānehi
analyzed: patita mattā ava accanta khārena sīta udakena chinna camma nhāru maṃsa aṭṭhīhi bhijjamānehi
translated: As soon as they fall in, they are cut to pieces by the razor-edged shells and their skin, flesh and blood are carried off by the water,

original: tattatele patitapiṭṭhapiṇḍi viya paṭapaṭāyamānā vilīyanti. Evaṃ sītena ruppanaṃ lokantarikaniraye
analyzed: tad tad ele patita piṭṭha piṇḍi viya paṭapaṭāyamānāḥ vilīyanti evam sītena ruppanam lokantarika niraye
translated: They melt away like lumps of oil-cake dripping on a hot pan. This is how beings are tormented by cold in the Lohakumbhī Hell.

original: pākaṭaṃ. Mahiṃsakaraṭṭhādīsupi himapātasītalesu padesesu etaṃ pākaṭameva. Tattha
analyzed: pākaṭam mahiṃsa karaṭṭha ādīsu pi hima pāta sītalesu padesesu etam pākaṭam eva tattha
translated: This is obvious in the Mahiṃsakaraṭṭha country and in other cold regions.

original: hi sattā sītena bhinnacchinnasarīrā jīvitakkhayampi pāpuṇanti.🔽Uṇhena ruppanaṃ avīcimahāniraye pākaṭaṃ. Tattha hi tattāya lohapathaviyā nipajjāpetvā pañcavidhabandhanādikaraṇakāle sattā mahādukkhaṃ anubhavanti.
analyzed: hi sattā sītena bhinna chinna sarīrāḥ jīvita kkhayam pi pāpuṇanti  uṇhena ruppanam avīcimahāniraye pākaṭam tattha hi tattāya loha pathaviyā nipajjāpetvā pañcavidha bandhana ādi karaṇa kāle sattāḥ mahā dukkham anubhavanti
translated: For there beings die of cold with their bodies split open and torn asunder.🔽This is how beings are tormented by heat in the Avīci Hell. For there, when they are made to lie down on a heated surface of iron and are bound with the fivefold strap, etc., they experience great suffering.

original: Jighacchāya ruppanaṃ pettivisaye ceva dubbhikkhakāle ca pākaṭaṃ. Pettivisayasmiñhi
analyzed: jighacchāya ruppanam petti visaye ca iva dubbhikkha kāle ca pākaṭam petti visayasmin hi
translated: This is how beings are tormented by hunger in the realm of ghosts and in times of famine. For in the realm of ghosts

original: sattā dve tīṇi buddhantarāni kiñcideva āmisaṃ hatthena gahetvā mukhe pakkhipantā🔽nāma na honti. Antoudaraṃ ādittasusirarukkho viya hoti. Dubbhikkhe kañjikamattampi
analyzed: sattā dve tīṇi buddhantarāni kiñcid eva āmisam hatthena gahetvā mukhe pakkhipantā  nāma na honti antoudaram āditta susira rukkho viya hoti dubbhikkhe kañjika mattam pi
translated: beings do not even get so much as the tip of a hair to eat for two or three Buddha eras.

original: alabhitvā maraṇappattānaṃ pamāṇaṃ nāma natthi.
analyzed: a labhitvā maraṇa pattānam pamāṇam nāma natthi
translated: Their bellies are like a burning, blazing charcoal pit. In times of famine, when they cannot get even water to drink, there is no measure of the death they experience.

original: Pipāsāya ruppanaṃ kālakañjikādīsu pākaṭaṃ. Tattha hi sattā dve tīṇi buddhantarāni
analyzed: pipāsāya ruppanam kālakañjika ādīsu pākaṭam tattha hi sattā dve tīṇi buddhantarāni
translated: The manifestation of the state of being parched with thirst is evident in the case of the waters of the Kālakañja hell, etc. For there, beings, for two or three Buddha-intervals,

original: hadayatemanamattaṃ vā jivhātemanamattaṃ vā udakabinduṃ laddhuṃ na sakkonti. ‘Pānīyaṃ
analyzed: hadaya temana mattam vā jivhā temana mattam vā udaka bindum laddhum na sakkonti pānīyam
translated: The torment of thirst is obvious in the case of the Kālakañja and other hells. For there the beings are unable to get even the amount of water that would lie on the point of a blade of grass, or even the amount that would be on the tip of a blade of grass, or even the amount that would be on the end of a hair, for two or three Buddha-intervals.🔽When they go to a river thinking, “We shall drink water,” the river becomes a bed of sand for them.

original: pivissāmā’ti nadiṃ gatānampi nadī vālikātalaṃ sampajjati. Mahāsamuddaṃ pakkhantānampi
analyzed: pivissāma iti nadim gatānam pi nadī vālikā talam sampajjati mahā samuddam pakkhantānam pi
translated: When they go to the ocean, the ocean becomes a bed of hot embers for them.

original: mahāsamuddo piṭṭhipāsāṇo hoti. Te sussantā balavadukkhapīḷitā vicaranti.
analyzed: mahā samuddaḥ piṭṭhi pāsāṇaḥ hoti te sussantāḥ balava dukkha pīḍitāḥ vicaranti
translated: They wander about, suffering great pain and distress.

original: Eko kira kālakañjikaasuro pipāsaṃ adhivāsetuṃ asakkonto yojanagambhīravitthāraṃ mahāgaṅgaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ kira kālakañjika asuraḥ pipāsam adhivāsetum a sakkontaḥ yojana gambhīra vitthāram mahā gaṅgam
translated: It is said that a certain Kālakañja demon, unable to endure thirst, entered the great river Gaṅgā, which is a league deep and wide.

original: otari. Tassa gatagataṭṭhāne udakaṃ chijjati, dhūmo uggacchati, tatte piṭṭhipāsāṇe
analyzed: otari tassa gata gata ṭṭhāne udakam chijjati dhūmaḥ uggacchati tat te piṭṭhi pāsāṇe
translated: Wherever he went, the water broke up, steamed, and became a bed of hot embers for him, as though he were walking on a bed of hot embers.

original: caṅkamanakālo viya hoti. Tassa udakasaddaṃ sutvā ito cito ca vicarantasseva ratti
analyzed: caṅkamana kālaḥ viya hoti tassa udaka saddam sutvā itas citas ca vicarantassa iva ratti
translated: Hearing the sound of the water, he wandered about here and there until the night came to an end.

original: vibhāyi. Atha naṃ pātova bhikkhācāraṃ gacchantā tiṃsamattā piṇḍacārikabhikkhū disvā
analyzed: vibhāyi atha nam pātova bhikkhācāram gacchantā tiṃsa mattā piṇḍacārika bhikkhū disvā
translated: Then thirty alms-collecting bhikkhus saw him in the morning as they were going about for alms.

original: – “ko nāma tvaṃ, sappurisā”ti pucchiṃsu. “Petohamasmi, bhante”ti. “Kiṃ pariyesasī”ti?🔽“Pānīyaṃ, bhante”ti. “Ayaṃ gaṅgā paripuṇṇā, kiṃ tvaṃ na passasī”ti? “Na upakappati,
analyzed: kaḥ nāma tvam sappurisa ati pucchiṃsu peta uham asmi bhante iti kim pariyesasi iti  pānīyam bhante ti ayam gaṅgā paripuṇṇā kim tvam na passasi iti na upakappati
translated: “What sort of person are you, good sir?” “I am a ghost, venerable sirs.” “What are you seeking?”

original: bhante”ti. “Tena hi gaṅgāpiṭṭhe nipajja, mukhe te pānīyaṃ āsiñcissāmā”ti. So vālikāpuḷine
analyzed: bhante iti tena hi gaṅgā piṭṭhe nipajja mukhe te pānīyam āsiñcissāma ati saḥ vālikā puḷine
translated: “Water, venerable sirs.” “Can’t you see that the Ganges is full?” “It does not benefit me, venerable sirs.” “Well then, lie down on the bank of the Ganges and we will pour water into your mouth.” He lay down on the sand

original: uttāno nipajji. Bhikkhū tiṃsamatte patte nīharitvā udakaṃ āharitvā āharitvā tassa🔽mukhe āsiñciṃsu. Tesaṃ tathā karontānaṃyeva velā upakaṭṭhā jātā. Tato “bhikkhācārakālo🔽amhākaṃ, sappurisa; kacci te assādamattā laddhā”ti āhaṃsu. Peto “sace me, bhante,🔽tiṃsamattānaṃ ayyānaṃ tiṃsamattehi pattehi āsittaudakato aḍḍhapasatamattampi paragalagataṃ,
analyzed: uttānaḥ nipajji bhikkhū tiṃsa matte patte nīharitvā udakam āharitvā āharitvā tassa  mukhe āsiñciṃsu tesam tathā karontānam yeva velā upakaṭṭhā jātā tatas bhikkhācāra kālo  amhākam sappurisa kacci te assāda mattā laddhā ati āhaṃsu sace me bhante  tiṃsa mattānam ayyānam tiṃsa mattehi pattehi āsitta udakataḥ aḍḍhapasata mattam pi para gala gatam
translated: spread out on his back. The monks took thirty bowls, filled them with water, and poured the water into his mouth.

original: petattabhāvato mokkho mā hotū”ti āha. Evaṃ pipāsāya ruppanaṃ pettivisaye pākaṭaṃ.
analyzed: petatta bhāvataḥ mokkhaḥ mā hotu iti āha evam pipāsāya ruppanam petti visaye pākaṭam
translated: While they were doing this, it was time for them to go for alms. Then they said, “It is time for us to go for alms, good sir. Have you had enough?” The ghost said, “Venerable sirs, if I had had enough by the time thirty bowls of water had been poured into my mouth, let me not be reborn again in the realm of ghosts.” Thus the suffering of thirst is evident in the realm of ghosts.

original: Ḍaṃsādīhi ruppanaṃ ḍaṃsamakkhikādisambabahulesu padesesu pākaṭaṃ. Ettha ca ḍaṃsāti
analyzed: ḍaṃsa ādīhi ruppanam ḍaṃsa makkhikā ādi samba bahulesu padesesu pākaṭam ettha ca ḍaṃsa ati
translated: Itching is evident in places where there are many gadflies, flies, etc. Herein, gadflies are

original: piṅgalamakkhikā, makasāti makasāva vātāti kucchivātapiṭṭhivātādivasena veditabbā.
analyzed: piṅgalamakkhikā makasā ati makasā ava vātā ti kucchi vāta piṭṭhi vāta ādi vasena veditabbā
translated: tawny flies. Itching is a kind of wind. It should be understood as the wind in the belly, the back wind, and so on.

original: Sarīrasmiñhi vātarogo uppajjitvā hatthapādapiṭṭhiādīni bhindati, kāṇaṃ karoti, khujjaṃ
analyzed: sarīrasmin hi vāta rogaḥ uppajjitvā hattha pāda piṭṭhi ādīni bhindati kāṇam karoti khujjam
translated: For when a man has a wind disease in his body, it splits his hands, feet, back, and so on, making him lame, humpbacked,

original: karoti, pīṭhasappiṃ karoti. Ātapoti sūriyātapo. Tena ruppanaṃ marukantārādīsu pākaṭaṃ.🔽Ekā kira itthī marukantāre rattiṃ satthato ohīnā divā sūriye uggacchante vālikāya
analyzed: karoti pīṭha sappim karoti tena ruppanam maru kantāra ādīsu pākaṭam  ekā kira itthī maru kantāre rattim satthatas ohīnā divā sūriye uggacchante vālikāya
translated: and crippled. Heat is the heat of the sun. Itching due to heat is evident in deserts, etc.

original: tappamānāya pāde ṭhapetuṃ asakkontī sīsato pacchiṃ otāretvā akkami. Kamena pacchiyā🔽uṇhābhitattāya ṭhātuṃ asakkontī tassā upari sāṭakaṃ ṭhapetvā akkami. Tasmimpi santatte
analyzed: tappamānāya pāde ṭhapetum a sakkontī sīsataḥ pacchim otāretvā akkami kamena pacchiyā  uṇha abhitattāya ṭhātum a sakkontī tassāḥ upari sāṭakam ṭhapetvā akkami tasmim pi santatte
translated: It is said that a certain woman who had lost her way at night in a desert put her head on the ground in the daytime when the sun rose and crawled along because she was unable to put her feet on the hot sand.🔽After a time, she was unable to bear the heat of the sand on her head, so she put her cloth on the sand and crawled along.

original: aṅkena gahitaṃ puttakaṃ adhomukhaṃ nipajjāpetvā kandantaṃ kandantaṃ akkamitvā saddhiṃ
analyzed: aṅkena gahitam puttakam adhomukham nipajjāpetvā kandantam kandantam akkamitvā saddhiṃ
translated: When that became hot, she made her child lie face downwards on her lap and crawled along, crying and weeping.

original: tena tasmiṃyeva ṭhāne uṇhābhitattā kālamakāsi.
analyzed: tena tasmiṃyā iva ṭhāne uṇhā abhitattā kālam akāsi
translated: and he died right there, being scorched by the heat.

original: Sarīsapāti ye keci dīghajātikā sarantā gacchanti. Tesaṃ samphassena ruppanaṃ āsīvisadaṭṭhādīnaṃ vasena veditabbaṃ.🔽Idāni ‘yaṃ kiñci rūpa’nti padena saṃgahitaṃ pañcavīsatikoṭṭhāsachannavutikoṭṭhāsappabhedaṃ
analyzed: sarīsapā ti ye keci dīgha jātikā sarantā gacchanti tesam samphassena ruppanam āsīvisadaṭṭha ādīnam vasena veditabbam  idāni yam kiñci padena saṃgahitam pañcavīsati koṭṭhāsa channavuti koṭṭhāsa ppabhedam
translated: As regards the creeping thing, etc., it should be understood that the breaking up of the bones, etc., is like that of the fangs, etc., of a poisonous snake.

original: sabbampi rūpaṃ atītādikoṭṭhāsesu pakkhipitvā dassetuṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannanti āha.
analyzed: sabbam pi rūpam atīta ādi koṭṭhāsesu pakkhipitvā dassetum atīta anāgata paccuppannam ti āha
translated: Now, all materiality, classed under the twenty-five or ninety-one modes by the words “whatever materiality there is,” is shown by the words “past, future, and present” after it has been included in the modes classed as past, future, and present.

original: Tato paraṃ tadeva ajjhattadukādīsu catūsu dukesu pakkhipitvā dassetuṃ ajjhattaṃ vā🔽bahiddhā vātiādi vuttaṃ. Tato paraṃ sabbampetaṃ ekādasasu padesesu pariyādiyitvā🔽dassitaṃ rūpaṃ ekato piṇḍaṃ katvā dassetuṃ tadekajjhantiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tatas param tat eva ajjhatta duka ādīsu catūsu dukesu pakkhipitvā dassetum ajjhattam vā  bahiddhā vā iti ādi vuttam tatas param sabbam petam ekādasasu padesesu  dassitam rūpam ekatas piṇḍam katvā dassetum tat ekajjha tiādi vuttaṃ
translated: Then, after it has been included in the four dyads beginning with internal and external, it is shown by the words “internal” and “external,” etc.🔽Then, after it has been included in the eleven sections, it is shown by the words “all that materiality … in brief is one thing only” after it has been made into a single heap.

original: Tattha tadekajjhanti taṃ ekajjhaṃ; abhisaññūhitvāti abhisaṃharitvā; abhisaṅkhipitvāti
analyzed: tattha tat ekajjhanti tam ekajjham abhisaññūhitvā ati abhisaṃharitvā abhisaṅkhipitvā ati
translated: Herein, that is one thing: that is one thing only, after defining it by delimitation. Having defined it by delimitation: having defined it by collecting it together. Having defined it by collecting it together: having defined it by collecting it together. Having defined it by collecting it together: having defined it by collecting it together.

original: saṅkhepaṃ katvā; idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – sabbampetaṃ vuttappakāraṃ rūpaṃ ruppanalakkhaṇasaṅkhāte
analyzed: saṅkhepam katvā idam vuttam hoti sabbam petam vutta ppakāram rūpam ruppana lakkhaṇa saṅkhāte
translated: In brief, all materiality of the kinds stated,🔽having been made into a single aggregate by the understanding that has the characteristic of being molested as its meaning, is called the materiality aggregate.

original: ekavidhabhāve paññāya rāsiṃ katvā rūpakkhandho nāmāti vuccatīti. Etena sabbampi rūpaṃ
analyzed: ekavidha bhāve paññāya rāsim katvā rūpakkhandho nāma ati vuccati iti etena sabbam pi rūpam
translated: By this it is shown that all materiality

original: ruppanalakkhaṇe rāsibhāvūpagamanena rūpakkhandhoti dassitaṃ hoti. Na hi rūpato añño
analyzed: ruppana lakkhaṇe rāsi bhāva upagamanena rūpa kkhandho ti dassitam hoti na hi rūpataḥ añño
translated: is the materiality aggregate by its becoming a single aggregate through having the characteristic of being molested as its meaning. For there is no materiality aggregate called “materiality” other than materiality.🔽And as in the case of materiality, so also in the case of feeling, etc.,

original: rūpakkhandho nāma atthi. Yathā ca rūpaṃ, evaṃ vedanādayopi vedayitalakkhaṇādīsu rāsibhāvūpagamanena.
analyzed: rūpakkhandhaḥ nāma atthi yathā ca rūpam evam vedanā ādayaḥ api vedayita lakkhaṇa ādīsu rāsi bhāva upagamanena
translated: they are the feeling aggregate, etc., by their becoming a single aggregate through having the characteristic of being felt, etc., as their meaning.

original: Na hi vedanādīhi aññe vedanākkhandhādayo nāma atthi.🔽3. Idāni ekekasmiṃ okāse pakkhittaṃ rūpaṃ visuṃ visuṃ bhājetvā dassento tattha katamaṃ
analyzed: na hi vedanā ādīhi aññe vedanā khandha ādayaḥ nāma atthi  idāni ekekasmin okāse pakkhittam rūpam visum visum bhājetvā dassento tattha katamaṃ
translated: For there are no feeling aggregates, etc., called “feeling,” etc., other than feeling, etc.

original: rūpaṃ atītantiādimāha. Tattha tatthāti ekādasasu okāsesu pakkhipitvā ṭhapitamātikāya
analyzed: rūpam atītam ti ādim āha tattha tattha ati ekādasasu okāsesu pakkhipitvā ṭhapita mātikāya
translated: Now, in order to show the materiality that is placed in each of the instances, he said, “Herein, what is materiality of the past? ” etc. Herein, herein means in the schedule set out in the eleven instances.

original: bhummaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – atītānāgatapaccuppannantiādinā nayena ṭhapitāya mātikāya
analyzed: bhummam idam vuttam hoti atīta anāgata paccuppanna nti ādinā nayena ṭhapitāya mātikāya
translated: This is what is said: in the case of the schedule set out in the way beginning, “The past, the future, and the present” ,

original: yaṃ atītaṃ rūpanti vuttaṃ, taṃ katamanti? Iminā upāyena sabbapucchāsu attho veditabbo.
analyzed: yam atītam rūpan ti vuttam tam kataman ti iminā upāyena sabba pucchāsu atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: What is called materiality in the past: what is that? The meaning should be understood in this way in all the questions.

original: Atītaṃ niruddhantiādīni padāni nikkhepakaṇḍassa atītattikabhājanīyavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttāneva.
analyzed: atītam niruddha nti ādīni padāni nikkhepa kaṇḍassa atīta ttika bhājanīya vaṇṇanāyam vuttāni eva
translated: The terms “past, ceased, changed” and so on are given in the description of the past triad in the section on the exposition of the past.

original: Cattāro ca mahābhūtāti idaṃ atītanti vuttarūpassa sabhāvadassanaṃ. Yathā cettha evaṃ🔽sabbattha attho veditabbo. Iminā idaṃ dasseti – atītarūpampi bhūtāni ceva bhūtāni
analyzed: cattāro ca mahābhūtā ti idam atītam ti vutta rūpassa sabhāva dassanam yathā ca ittha evam  sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ iminā idam dasseti atīta rūpam pi bhūtāni ca iva bhūtāni
translated: The four great entities: this is the seeing of the individual essence of the materiality called “past.” And just as here,

original: upādāya nibbattarūpañca, anāgatampi…pe… dūrasantikampi. Na hi bhūtehi ceva bhūtāni🔽upādāya pavattarūpato ca aññaṃ rūpaṃ nāma atthīti.🔽Aparo nayo – atītaṃsena saṅgahitanti atītakoṭṭhāseneva saṅgahitaṃ, ettheva gaṇanaṃ
analyzed: upādāya nibbatta rūpam ca dūra santikam pi na hi bhūtehi ca iva bhūtāni  upādāya pavatta rūpato ca aññam rūpam nāma atthi iti  aparaḥ nayaḥ atīta aṃsena saṅgahitam ti atīta koṭṭhāsena iva saṅgahitam ettha iva gaṇanam
translated: so also in all the other cases. By this he shows that past materiality is the four great entities and the materiality derived by clinging to the four great entities, and so too future materiality … far materiality … near materiality. For there is no materiality apart from the four great entities and the materiality that occurs derived by clinging to the four great entities.

original: gataṃ. Kinti? Cattāro ca mahābhūtā catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādāyarūpanti. Evaṃ sabbattha
analyzed: gatam kinti cattāro ca mahābhūtā catunnam ca mahābhūtānam evam sabbattha
translated: Another method: included in the past section: included only in the past section, counted only there. What? The four great entities and the materiality derived by clinging to the four great entities. So too in all the other cases.

original: attho veditabbo. Anāgatapaccuppannaniddesapadānipi heṭṭhā vuttatthāneva.🔽Idaṃ pana atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ nāma suttantapariyāyato abhidhammaniddesatoti duvidhaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ anāgata paccuppanna niddesa padāni pi heṭṭhā vutta tthānā eva  idam pana atīta anāgata paccuppannam nāma suttanta pariyāyataḥ abhidhamma niddesato ti duvidham
translated: the meaning should be understood. The words for the past, future, and present in the description are given in the same place below.🔽But this past, future, and present is twofold as to kind, that is to say, in the Scriptures and in the Description in the Abhidhamma.

original: Taṃ suttantapariyāye bhavena paricchinnaṃ. Paṭisandhito hi paṭṭhāya atītabhavesu
analyzed: tam suttanta pariyāye bhavena paricchinnam paṭisandhitaḥ hi paṭṭhāya atīta bhavesu
translated: In the Scriptures it is delimited by existence, for materiality that has arisen in past existences

original: nibbattaṃ rūpaṃ, anantarabhave vā nibbattaṃ hotu kappakoṭisatasahassamatthake vā,🔽sabbaṃ atītameva nāma. Cutito paṭṭhāya anāgatabhavesu nibbattanakarūpaṃ, anantarabhave
analyzed: nibbattam rūpam anantara bhave vā nibbattam hotu kappa koṭi sata sahassa matthake vā  sabbam atītam eva nāma cutitaḥ paṭṭhāya anāgata bhavesu nibbattanaka rūpam anantara bhave
translated: since the rebirth-linking moment, whether it arose in the next next existence or a hundred thousand million times a hundred thousand aeons ago,🔽is all called “past.” And materiality that is to arise in future existences, whether it will arise in the next next existence or a hundred thousand million times a hundred thousand aeons hence,

original: vā nibbattaṃ hotu kappakoṭisatasahassamatthake vā, sabbaṃ anāgatameva nāma. Cutipaṭisandhianantare🔽pavattarūpaṃ paccuppannaṃ nāma. Abhidhammaniddese pana khaṇena paricchinnaṃ. Tayo
analyzed: vā nibbattam hotu kappa koṭi sata sahassa matthake vā sabbam anāgatam eva nāma cuti paṭisandhi anantare  pavattarūpam paccuppannam nāma abhidhamma niddese pana khaṇena paricchinnam tayo
translated: is all called “future.” And materiality that occurs between the death moment and the rebirth-linking moment🔽is called “present.” But in the Description in the Abhidhamma it is delimited by the instant. For materiality has three instants,

original: hi rūpassa khaṇā – uppādo, ṭhiti, bhaṅgoti. Ime tayo khaṇe patvā niruddhaṃ rūpaṃ,
analyzed: hi rūpassa khaṇā uppādaḥ ṭhiti bhaṅgo ti ime tayaḥ khaṇe patvā niruddham rūpam
translated: that is to say, arising, presence, and dissolution. Materiality that has ceased after reaching these three instants

original: samanantaraniruddhaṃ vā hotu atīte kappakoṭisatasahassamatthake vā, sabbaṃ atītameva🔽nāma. Tayo khaṇe asampattaṃ rūpaṃ, ekacittakkhaṇamattena vā asampattaṃ hotu anāgate
analyzed: samanantara niruddham vā hotu atīte kappa koṭi sata sahassa matthake vā sabbam atītam eva  nāma khaṇe a sampattam rūpam eka citta khaṇa mattena vā a sampattam hotu anāgate
translated: Or it may be that which has just ceased, or that which is a hundred thousand koṭis of kalpas past: all that is past name-and-form.

original: kappakoṭisatasahassamatthake vā, sabbaṃ anāgatameva nāma. Ime tayo khaṇe sampattaṃ
analyzed: kappa koṭi sata sahassa matthake vā sabbam anāgatam eva nāma ime tayo khaṇe sampattam
translated: Or it may be that which is not yet present at the three instants, or that which is not yet present even for the duration of a single conscious moment, or that which is a hundred thousand koṭis of kalpas in the future: all that is future name-and-form.🔽But that which is present at the three instants is present name-and-form.

original: rūpaṃ pana paccuppannaṃ nāma. Tattha kiñcāpi idaṃ suttantabhājanīyaṃ, evaṃ santepi
analyzed: rūpam pana paccuppannam nāma tattha kiñcā api idam suttanta bhājanīyam evam sante pi
translated: Although this is a matter for the Suttanta, nevertheless

original: abhidhammaniddeseneva atītānāgatapaccuppannarūpaṃ niddiṭṭhanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: abhidhamma niddesena iva atīta anāgata paccuppanna rūpam niddiṭṭhanti veditabbam
translated: it should be understood that past, future, and present materiality is demonstrated by the exposition of the Abhidhamma.

original: Aparo nayo – idañhi rūpaṃ addhāsantatisamayakhaṇavasena catudhā atītaṃ nāma hoti.
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ idam hi rūpam addhā santati samaya khaṇa vasena catudhā atītam nāma
translated: Another method: this materiality is called past in four ways, according to period, continuity, association, and instant.

original: Tathā anāgatapaccuppannaṃ. Addhāvasena tāva ekassa ekasmiṃ bhave paṭisandhito pubbe
analyzed: tathā anāgata paccuppannam addhā vasena tāva ekassa ekasmin bhave paṭisandhito pubbe
translated: So too it is future and present. As to period, firstly, in one being’s becoming, that which is before the rebirth-linking is past;

original: atītaṃ, cutito uddhaṃ anāgataṃ, ubhinnamantare paccuppannaṃ. Santativasena sabhāgaekautusamuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: atītam cutitaḥ uddham anāgatam ubhinnam antare paccuppannam santati vasena sa bhāga eka otu samuṭṭhānam
translated: that which is after death is future; that between is present. As to continuity, that which arises together with the faculties is present;

original: ekāhārasamuṭṭhānañca pubbāpariyavasena pavattamānampi paccuppannaṃ. Tato pubbe visabhāgautuāhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: eka āhāra samuṭṭhānam ca pubba apariya vasena pavattamānam api paccuppannam tatas pubbe visabhāga otu āhāra samuṭṭhānam
translated: And that which originates from a single meal, though it occurs in a succession of past and future moments, is still present. That which originates from dissimilar temperature and air in the past before that is past.

original: atītaṃ, pacchā anāgataṃ. Cittajaṃ ekavīthiekajavanaekasamāpattisamuṭṭhānaṃ paccuppannaṃ.
analyzed: atītam pacchā anāgatam citta jam eka vīthi eka javana eka samāpatti samuṭṭhānam paccuppannam
translated: That which originates from dissimilar temperature and air in the future after that is future. That which originates from consciousness in a single physical basis, a single impulsion, a single adverting, a single attainment, is present.

original: Tato pubbe atītaṃ, pacchā anāgataṃ. Kammasamuṭṭhānassa pāṭiyekkaṃ santativasena atītādibhedo🔽natthi. Tesaññeva pana utuāhāracittasamuṭṭhānānaṃ upatthambhakavasena tassa atītādibhedo
analyzed: tatas pubbe atītam pacchā anāgatam kamma samuṭṭhānassa pāṭiyekkam santati vasena atīta ādi bhedaḥ  natthi tesaññeva pana utu āhāra citta samuṭṭhānānam upatthambhaka vasena tassa atīta ādi bhedo
translated: That which originates from consciousness in the past before that is past. That which originates from consciousness in the future after that is future. As to that which originates from kamma, there is no past, etc., classification according to continuity separately.

original: veditabbo. Samayavasena ekamuhuttapubbaṇhasāyanharattidivādīsu samayesu santānavasena
analyzed: veditabbaḥ samaya vasena eka muhutta pubbaṇha sāyanharatti divā ādīsu samayesu santāna vasena
translated: But its past, etc., classification should be understood according to the past, etc., of the temperature, nutriment, and consciousness that assist it. As to occasion: that which occurs in a continuity in such and such an occasion, whether a moment, a half-monthly occasion, a monthly occasion, a yearly occasion, a lifetime occasion, etc., is called present. That which occurred in the past in such and such an occasion is past. That which will occur in the future in such and such an occasion is future.

original: pavattamānaṃ taṃ taṃ samayaṃ paccuppannaṃ nāma. Tato pubbe atītaṃ, pacchā anāgataṃ.🔽Khaṇavasena uppādādikkhaṇattayapariyāpannaṃ paccuppannaṃ nāma. Tato pubbe atītaṃ, pacchā anāgataṃ.
analyzed: pavattamānam tam tam samayam paccuppannam nāma tatas pubbe atītam pacchā anāgatam 🔽khaṇa vasena uppāda ādi khaṇa ttaya pariyāpannam paccuppannam nāma tatas pubbe atītam pacchā anāgatam
translated: As to instant: that included in the three instants beginning with arising is called present. That included in the three instants beginning with the second is past. That not yet included in any instant is future.

original: Apica atikkahetupaccayakiccaṃ atītaṃ. Niṭṭhitahetukiccaṃ aniṭṭhitapaccayakiccaṃ paccuppannaṃ.🔽Ubhayakiccamasampattaṃ anāgataṃ. Sakiccakkhaṇe vā paccuppannaṃ. Tato pubbe atītaṃ,
analyzed: apica atikka hetu paccaya kiccam atītam niṭṭhita hetu kiccam aniṭṭhita paccaya kiccam paccuppannam  ubhaya kiccam asampattam anāgatam sa kicca khaṇe vā paccuppannam tatas pubbe atītam
translated: Furthermore, the past is that which has done its function as cause but not its function as condition; the present is that which has done its function as cause but not its function as condition;🔽the future is that which has not done either function. Or the present is that which has done its function at the moment of its existence; the past is that which did it previously;

original: pacchā anāgataṃ. Ettha ca khaṇādikathāva nippariyāyā, sesā sapariyāyā. Tāsu nippariyāyakathā
analyzed: pacchā anāgatam ettha ca nippariyāyā sesā sa pariyāyā tāsu nippariyāya kathā
translated: the future is that which will do it later. Herein, the explanation of the instant, etc., is literal, while the rest is non-literal. Of these,

original: idha adhippetā. Ajjhattadukassāpi niddesapadāni heṭṭhā ajjhattattikaniddese vuttatthāneva.
analyzed: idha adhippetā ajjhatta dukassa api niddesa padāni heṭṭhā ajjhatta ttika niddese vutta tthānā eva
translated: the literal explanation is intended here. The words denoting the internal as object are given in the description of the internal as object below .

original: Oḷārikādīni rūpakaṇḍavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttatthāneva.🔽6. Hīnadukaniddese tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānanti bahūsu sattesu sāmivacanaṃ. Aparassāpi
analyzed: oḷārikā ādīni rūpa kaṇḍa vaṇṇanāyam vutta tthānā eva  hīna duka niddese tesam tesam sattānam ti bahūsu sattesu sāmi vacanam aparassa api
translated: The gross, etc., are given in the description of the material septad.🔽In the description of the inferior pentad, “among various beings” is a word for master.

original: aparassāpīti hi vuccamāne divasampi kappasatasahassampi vadanto ettakameva vadeyya.
analyzed: aparassa api iti hi vuccamāne divasam pi kappa sata sahassam pi vadantaḥ ettakam eva vadeyya
translated: For if he were to say “of another and another,” he would be saying that for a day or for a hundred thousand eons.

original: Iti satthā dvīheva padehi anavasese satte pariyādiyanto ‘tesaṃ tesaṃ sattāna’nti
analyzed: iti satthā dvīhā iva padehi anavasese satte pariyādiyantaḥ tesam tesam sattānanti
translated: So the Exalted One, referring to all beings without exception, said “among various beings” with the two words “tesaṃ tesaṃ.”

original: āha. Ettakena hi sabbampi aparadīpanaṃ siddhaṃ hoti. Uññātanti avamataṃ. Avaññātanti
analyzed: āha ettakena hi sabbam pi apara dīpanam siddham hoti uññātanti avamatam avaññātanti
translated: “He said: ‘For this much is enough to show all the kinds of blame. ‘ ‘Unrevered’ means ‘unhonoured.’ ‘Disregarded’ means ‘honoured by being despised.’

original: vambhetvā ñātaṃ. Rūpantipi na viditaṃ. Hīḷitanti agahetabbaṭṭhena khittaṃ chaḍḍitaṃ,
analyzed: vambhetvā ñātam na viditam a gahetabba ṭṭhena khittam chaḍḍitam
translated: ‘Unknown’ means ‘not recognized.’ ‘Despised’ means ‘rejected in the sense of not being accepted,’ ‘discarded,’

analyzed: vadanti kim etena ati vācāya paribhavitam
translated: they say. ‘Contemptuously treated’ means ‘treated with contempt by words such as “What is the use of this?”’ ‘Not esteemed’ means

analyzed: hīna nti loke sammatam hīnehi vā sammatam gūtha bhakkhehi gūthaḥ viya aniṭṭhanti
translated: ‘regarded as bad in the world, or regarded as bad by the bad, as excrement is by those who eat it.’ ‘Unloved’ means

analyzed: appiyam paṭilābha tthāya vā a pariyesitam sace pi nam koci pariyeseyya pariyesatu
translated: ‘unloved, or not sought for the sake of obtaining it. Even if someone were to seek it, let him seek it.

original: Etassa pana ārammaṇassa etadeva nāmaṃ. Akantanti akāmitaṃ, nissirikaṃ vā. Amanāpanti
analyzed: etassa pana ārammaṇassa etat eva nāmam a kantanti a kāmitam nissirikam vā amanāpanti
translated: But this object has just this name. ‘Unwelcome’ means ‘unwanted,’ or ‘not desired.’ ‘Unpleasing’ means

analyzed: manasmim na appitam tādisam hi ārammaṇam manasmim na appīyati atha vā manam appāyati
translated: ‘not stored up in the mind.’ For such an object is not stored up in the mind. Or alternatively, the mind is not pleased

original: vaḍḍhetīti manāpaṃ, na manāpaṃ amanāpaṃ.
analyzed: vaḍḍheti iti manāpam na manāpam a manāpam
translated: what is pleasing is favourable, what is not pleasing is unfavourable.

original: Aparo nayo – aniṭṭhaṃ sampattivirahato. Taṃ ekantena kammasamuṭṭhānesu akusalakammasamuṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ aniṭṭham sampatti virahataḥ tam ekantena kamma samuṭṭhānesu akusala kamma samuṭṭhānam
translated: Another method: what is not wished for is the opposite of what is wished for, that is, the absence of what is wished for, namely, success. That is exclusively the unprofitable kinds of derived materiality originated by kamma.🔽What is not loved is the opposite of what is loved, that is, the absence of what is loved, namely, pleasure. What is not pleasing is the opposite of what is pleasing, that is, the absence of what is pleasing, namely, the five cords of sense desire.

original: Akantaṃ sukhassa ahetubhāvato. Amanāpaṃ dukkhassa hetubhāvato. Rūpā saddāti idamassa
analyzed: akantam sukhassa ahetu bhāvataḥ amanāpam dukkhassa hetu bhāvataḥ rūpā idam assa
translated: The words “visible forms, sounds” and so on

original: sabhāvadīpanaṃ. Imasmiñhi pade akusalakammajavasena aniṭṭhā pañca kāmaguṇā vibhattā.
analyzed: imasmin hi pade akusala kamma ja vasena aniṭṭhā pañca kāmaguṇāḥ vibhattā
translated: are a description of the individual essences. For in this case the five cords of sense desire originated by unprofitable kamma are what is not wished for.

original: Kusalakammajaṃ pana aniṭṭhaṃ nāma natthi, sabbaṃ iṭṭhameva.🔽Paṇītapadaniddeso vuttapaṭipakkhanayena veditabbo. Imasmiṃ pana pade kusalakammajavasena
analyzed: kusala kamma jam pana aniṭṭham nāma natthi sabbam iṭṭham eva
translated: But there is no such thing as what is not wished for originated by profitable kamma; all that is originated by profitable kamma is wished for.

original: iṭṭhā pañca kāmaguṇā vibhattā. Kusalakammajañhi aniṭṭhaṃ nāma natthi, sabbaṃ iṭṭhameva.
analyzed: iṭṭhā pañca kāma guṇāḥ vibhattā kusala kamma jam hi aniṭṭham nāma natthi sabbam iṭṭham eva
translated: The description of what is refined should be understood in the opposite way to the above. For in this case the five cords of sense desire originated by profitable kamma are what is wished for. But there is no such thing as what is not wished for originated by profitable kamma; all that is originated by profitable kamma is wished for.

original: Yathā ca kammajesu evaṃ utusamuṭṭhānādīsupi iṭṭhāniṭṭhatā atthi evāti imasmiṃ duke
analyzed: yathā ca kamma jesu evam utu samuṭṭhāna ādīsu pi iṭṭha aniṭṭha tā atthi eva ati imasmin duke
translated: And just as what is wished for and what is not wished for exist in what is originated by kamma, so also what is wished for and what is not wished for exist in what is originated by temperature, etc., too. So in this stanza

original: iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇaṃ paṭivibhattanti veditabbaṃ. Ayaṃ tāva ācariyānaṃ samānatthakathā.
analyzed: iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇam paṭivibhattanti veditabbam ayam tāva ācariyānam samāna attha kathā
translated: and what is desired and undesired should be understood as divided up. This is the teachers’ explanation of the meaning in agreement.

original: Vitaṇḍavādī panāha – iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ nāma pāṭiyekkaṃ paṭivibhattaṃ natthi, tesaṃ tesaṃ🔽rucivasena kathitaṃ.
analyzed: vitaṇḍa vādī pana āha iṭṭha aniṭṭham nāma pāṭiyekkam paṭivibhattam natthi tesam tesam  ruci vasena kathitam
translated: But the one who argues says this: “There is no desired and undesired divided up separately. It is said according to the liking of each one.

original: Yathāha –
analyzed: yathā āha
translated: As it is said:

original: “Manāpapariyantaṃ khvāhaṃ, mahārāja, pañcasu kāmaguṇesu agganti vadāmi. Teva, mahārāja,
analyzed: manāpa pariyantam khvā aham mahā rāja pañcasu kāmaguṇesu vadāmi mahā rāja
translated: ‘I say, great king, that the five strands of sense pleasure are the limit of what is desirable. But, great king,

original: rūpā ekaccassa manāpā honti, ekaccassa amanāpā honti. Teva, mahārāja, saddā, gandhā,
analyzed: rūpā ekaccassa manāpāḥ honti ekaccassa amanāpāḥ honti te iva mahā rāja saddāḥ gandhā
translated: these visible forms are desirable to one and undesirable to another. These sounds,

original: rasā, phoṭṭhabbā ekaccassa manāpā honti, ekaccassa amanāpā hontī”ti.
analyzed: rasāḥ phoṭṭhabbāḥ ekaccassa manāpāḥ honti ekaccassa amanāpāḥ honti iti
translated: odours, tastes, and touches are desirable to one and undesirable to another’ .

original: Evaṃ yasmā teyeva rūpādayo eko assādeti abhinandati, tattha lobhaṃ uppādeti. Eko
analyzed: evam yasmā teyā iva rūpa ādayaḥ ekaḥ assādeti abhinandati tattha lobham uppādeti ekaḥ
translated: So because of these visible forms, etc., one delights in them, welcomes them, and remains holding to them, and he generates greed for them. Another

original: kujjhati paṭihaññati, tattha dosaṃ uppādeti. Ekassa iṭṭhā honti kantā manāpā, ekassa
analyzed: kujjhati paṭihaññati tattha dosam uppādeti ekassa iṭṭhāḥ honti kantāḥ manāpāḥ ekassa
translated: hates them, feels irritation towards them, and remains hating them, and he generates hatred for them. To one they are desirable, lovely, and pleasing,

original: aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā. Eko cete ‘iṭṭhā kantā manāpā’ti dakkhiṇato gaṇhāti, eko ‘aniṭṭhā
analyzed: aniṭṭhā a kantā a manāpā ekaḥ ca ite iṭṭhā kantā manāpā ati dakkhiṇatas gaṇhāti ekaḥ aniṭṭhā
translated: to another they are undesirable, unlovely, and unpleasing. One takes them as desirable, lovely, and pleasing, and the other as undesirable, unlovely, and unpleasing.

original: akantā amanāpā’ti vāmato. Tasmā iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ nāma pāṭiyekkaṃ paṭivibhattaṃ nāma natthi.
analyzed: a kantā a manāpā ati vā amataḥ tasmai iṭṭha aniṭṭham nāma pāṭiyekkam paṭivibhattam nāma natthi
translated: Or else they are unlovely, undesirable, and disagreeable. So there is no such thing as what is lovely and what is unlovely being definitely and exclusively separate from each other.🔽For what is lovely and desirable and agreeable to people living in the border regions is extremely disgusting to people living in the Middle Country,

original: Paccantavāsīnañhi gaṇḍuppādāpi iṭṭhā honti kantā manāpā, majjhimadesavāsīnaṃ atijegucchā.🔽Tesañca moramaṃsādīni iṭṭhāni honti, itaresaṃ tāni atijegucchānīti.🔽So vattabbo – “kiṃ pana tvaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ paṭivibhattaṃ nāma natthīti
analyzed: paccanta vāsīnam hi gaṇḍuppādā api iṭṭhāḥ honti kantāḥ manāpāḥ majjhima desa vāsīnam ati jegucchā  tesam ca mora maṃsa ādīni iṭṭhāni honti itaresam tāni ati jegucchāni iti  so vattabbaḥ kim pana tvam iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇam pāṭiyekkam paṭivibhattam nāma natthi iti
translated: and vice versa.🔽He should be asked, “But do you admit that there is no such thing as what is lovely and what is unlovely being definitely and exclusively separate from each other?”

analyzed: vadesi iti āma natthi iti vadāmi puna tathā iva yāvatatiyam patiṭṭhāpetvā pañhaḥ pucchitabbo
translated: If he says, “Yes, I do,” he should be asked, “Then why do you say that there is no such thing as what is lovely and what is unlovely being definitely and exclusively separate from each other?”🔽The question should be put in this way a second and a third time.

original: – “nibbānaṃ nāma iṭṭhaṃ udāhu aniṭṭha”nti? Jānamāno “iṭṭha”nti vakkhati. Sacepi na

translated: “Is Nibbāna lovely or unlovely?” If he knows that it is lovely, he should say so. If he does not know, he should say so.

analyzed: vadeyya mā vadatu nibbānam pana ekanta eṭṭham eva nanu ekaḥ nibbānassa vaṇṇe kathiyamāne
translated: But Nibbāna is exclusively lovely. “When the praise of Nibbāna is being spoken,

analyzed: tipiṭakacūḷanāga theraḥ pana āha iṭṭha aniṭṭham nāma vipāka vasena iva paricchinnam na  javana vasena javanam pana saññā vipallāsa vasena iṭṭhasmiṃ yeva rajjati iṭṭhasmiṃ yeva
translated: But the Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷanāga said that what is desired and what is not desired is classed according to the ripening ,

original: dussati; aniṭṭhasmiṃyeva rajjati, aniṭṭhasmiṃyeva dussatī”ti. Vipākavaseneva panetaṃ

original: micchādiṭṭhikā buddhaṃ vā saṅghaṃ vā mahācetiyādīni vā uḷārāni ārammaṇāni disvā akkhīni🔽pidahanti, domanassaṃ āpajjanti, dhammasaddaṃ sutvā kaṇṇe thakenti, cakkhuviññāṇasotaviññāṇāni

Their forms are ‘inferior’ compared to those of the people of the provinces.

original: rūpaṃ paṇītaṃ nāma. Tesampi hīnaṃ; taṃ upādāya jānapadānaṃ rūpaṃ paṇītaṃ nāma. Tesampi🔽hīnaṃ; taṃ upādāya gāmabhojakānaṃ rūpaṃ paṇītaṃ nāma. Tesampi hīnaṃ; taṃ upādāya🔽janapadasāmikānaṃ rūpaṃ paṇītaṃ nāma. Tesampi hīnaṃ; taṃ upādāya padesarājūnaṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: rūpam paṇītam nāma tesam pi hīnam tam upādāya jānapadānam rūpam paṇītam nāma tesam pi  hīnam tam upādāya gāmabhojakānam rūpam paṇītam nāma hīnam tam upādāya  janapada sāmikānam rūpam paṇītam nāma hīnam tam upādāya padesa rājūnam rūpam
