Their forms are ‘inferior’ compared to those of the people of the towns.🔽The forms of the people of the towns are called ‘excellent’ compared to those of the people of the provinces. Their forms are ‘inferior’ compared to those of the people of the country.🔽The forms of the people of the country are called ‘excellent’ compared to those of the people of the towns. Their forms are ‘inferior’ compared to those of the local kings.🔽The forms of the local kings are called ‘excellent’ compared to those of the people of the country. Their forms are ‘inferior’ compared to those of the wheel-turning monarchs.

original: paṇītaṃ nāma. Tesampi hīnaṃ; taṃ upādāya cakkavattirañño rūpaṃ paṇītaṃ nāma. Tassāpi🔽hīnaṃ; taṃ upādāya bhummadevānaṃ rūpaṃ paṇītaṃ nāma. Tesampi hīnaṃ; taṃ upādāya cātumahārājikānaṃ🔽devānaṃ rūpaṃ paṇītaṃ nāma. Tesampi hīnaṃ; taṃ upādāya tāvatiṃsānaṃ devānaṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: paṇītam nāma tesam pi hīnam tam upādāya cakkavatti raññaḥ rūpam paṇītam nāma tassa api  hīnam tam upādāya bhummadevānam rūpam paṇītam nāma tesam pi hīnam tam upādāya cātumahārājikānam  devānam rūpam paṇītam nāma hīnam tam upādāya devānam rūpam
translated: The forms of the wheel-turning monarchs are called ‘excellent’ compared to those of the local kings. Their forms are ‘inferior’ compared to those of the gods of the earth.🔽The forms of the gods of the earth are called ‘excellent’ compared to those of the wheel-turning monarchs. Their forms are ‘inferior’ compared to those of the gods of the Four Great Kings.🔽The forms of the gods of the Four Great Kings are called ‘excellent’ compared to those of the gods of the earth. Their forms are ‘inferior’ compared to those of the gods of the Thirty-three. …

original: paṇītaṃ nāma…pe… akaniṭṭhadevānaṃ pana rūpaṃ matthakappattaṃ paṇītaṃ nāma.
analyzed: paṇītam nāma pe akaniṭṭhadevānam pana rūpam matthaka ppattam paṇītam nāma
translated: The forms of the Akaniṭṭha gods are called ‘excellent’ compared to those of the gods of the Thirty-three. Their forms are ‘at the peak’ and are called ‘excellent.’

original: 7. Dūradukaniddese itthindriyādīni heṭṭhā vibhattāneva. Imasmiṃ pana duke duppariggahaṭṭhena
analyzed: dūra duka niddese itthi indriya ādīni heṭṭhā vibhattāni eva imasmin pana duke duppariggaha aṭṭhena
translated: In the description of far and near, the femininity faculty, etc., are the same as those already dealt with above. But in this dyad the subtle materiality is called far because its characteristic is hard to penetrate by insight.

original: lakkhaṇaduppaṭivijjhatāya sukhumarūpaṃ dūreti kathitaṃ. Sukhapariggahaṭṭhena lakkhaṇasuppaṭivijjhatāya🔽oḷārikarūpaṃ santiketi. Kabaḷīkārāhārapariyosāne ca niyyātanaṭṭhānepi ‘idaṃ vuccati
analyzed: lakkhaṇa duppaṭivijjha tāya sukhuma rūpam dūrā iti kathitam sukha pariggaha aṭṭhena lakkhaṇa suppaṭivijjha tāya  oḷārika rūpam santikā iti kabaḷīkāra āhāra pariyosāne ca niyyātana ṭṭhāne pi idam vuccati
translated: The gross materiality is called near because its characteristic is easy to penetrate by insight.

original: rūpaṃ dūre’ti na nīyyātitaṃ. Kasmā? Duvidhañhi dūre nāma – lakkhaṇato ca okāsato
analyzed: rūpam dūra iti na nīyyātitam kasmā duvidham hi dūre nāma lakkhaṇato ca okāsato
translated: And when the food consisting of gross physical nutriment is finished, the place of its exit is not called “far materiality.” Why not? Because there are two kinds of far: far by characteristic and far by location.

original: cāti. Tattha lakkhaṇato dūreti na kathitaṃ, taṃ okāsato kathetabbaṃ. Tasmā dūreti
analyzed: ca ati tattha lakkhaṇataḥ dūrā iti na kathitam tam okāsato kathetabbam tasmā dūrā iti
translated: Herein, it is not called far by characteristic; it is called far by location. That is why it is not called far.

original: akathitaṃ. Oḷārikarūpaṃ okāsato dūreti dassetuṃ aniyyātetvāva yaṃ vā panaññampītiādimāha.
analyzed: a kathitam oḷārika rūpam okāsataḥ dūrā iti dassetum yam vā pana aññam pi iti ādim āha
translated: In order to show that gross materiality is far by location, he said, “Or any other materiality that is not near” without specifying it.

original: Santikapadaniddesepi eseva nayo. Tattha anāsanneti na āsanne, anupakaṭṭheti nissaṭe,
analyzed: santika pada niddese pi esa eva nayaḥ tattha anāsannā iti na āsanne anupakaṭṭhā iti nissaṭe
translated: The same method of explanation applies in the description of near. Herein, not near means not near at hand, not evident means not present.

original: dūreti dūramhi, asantiketi na santike. Idaṃ vuccati rūpaṃ dūreti idaṃ paṇṇarasavidhaṃ
analyzed: dūre iti dūramhi asantike iti na santike idam vuccati rūpam dūre iti idam paṇṇarasavidham
translated: ‘Far’: far away. ‘Near’: not far away. This is called ‘materiality far’: this is the fifteen kinds of subtle materiality.

original: sukhumarūpaṃ lakkhaṇato dūre, dasavidhaṃ pana oḷārikarūpaṃ yevāpanakavasena okāsato
analyzed: sukhuma rūpam lakkhaṇataḥ dūre dasavidham pana oḷārika rūpam yevāpanaka vasena okāsato
translated: But the ten kinds of gross materiality are called ‘far’ in the sense of place because of the absence of proximity.

original: dūreti vuccati. Santikapadaniddeso uttānatthoyeva.
analyzed: dūrā iti vuccati santika pada niddeso uttāna tthaḥ yeva
translated: The explanation of the word ‘near’ is self-evident.

original: Idaṃ vuccati rūpaṃ santiketi idaṃ dasavidhaṃ oḷārikarūpaṃ lakkhaṇato santike, pañcadasavidhaṃ🔽pana sukhumarūpaṃ yevāpanakavasena okāsato santiketi vuccati. Kittakato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: idam vuccati rūpam santike iti idam dasavidham oḷārika rūpam lakkhaṇato santike pañcadasavidham  pana sukhuma rūpam yevāpanaka vasena okāsato santikā iti vuccati kittakato paṭṭhāya
translated: This is called ‘materiality near’: this is the ten kinds of gross materiality. But the fifteen kinds of subtle materiality are called ‘near’ in the sense of place because of the absence of distance.

original: pana rūpaṃ okāsavasena santike nāma? Kittakato paṭṭhāya dūre nāmāti? Pakatikathāya
analyzed: pana rūpam okāsa vasena santike nāma kittakato paṭṭhāya dūre nāma ati pakati kathāya
translated: But from what point is materiality called ‘near’ in the sense of place? And from what point is it called ‘far’?

original: kathentānaṃ dvādasahattho savanūpacāro nāma hoti. Tassa orato rūpaṃ santike, parato
analyzed: kathentānam dvādasa hatthaḥ savanūpacāraḥ nāma hoti tassa oratas rūpam santike paratas
translated: When they are talking in the ordinary way, a man’s normal speaking distance is twelve hand spans. Materiality nearer than that is ‘near’;

original: dūre. Tattha sukhumarūpaṃ dūre hontaṃ lakkhaṇatopi okāsatopi dūre hoti; santike hontaṃ
analyzed: dūre tattha sukhuma rūpam dūre hontam lakkhaṇato pi okāsato pi dūre hoti santike hontam
translated: materiality further than that is ‘far.’ Therein, subtle materiality, when it is far, is far both in the sense of characteristic and in the sense of place;🔽when it is near, it is near both in the sense of characteristic and in the sense of place.

original: pana okāsatova santike hoti, na lakkhaṇato. Oḷārikarūpaṃ santike hontaṃ lakkhaṇatopi
analyzed: pana okāsato va santike hoti na lakkhaṇato oḷārika rūpam santike hontam lakkhaṇato pi
translated: But it is near in the sense of location, not in the sense of characteristic. Gross visible form is near in the sense of characteristic and in the sense of location;

original: okāsatopi santike hoti; dūre hontaṃ okāsatova dūre hoti, na lakkhaṇato.🔽Taṃ taṃ vā panāti ettha na heṭṭhimanayo oloketabbo. Heṭṭhā hi bhindamāno gato. Idha
analyzed: okāsataḥ pi santike hoti dūre hontam okāsataḥ va dūre hoti na lakkhaṇato  tam tam vā pana ati ettha na heṭṭhima nayaḥ oloketabbaḥ heṭṭhā hi bhindamānaḥ gataḥ idha
translated: when it is far it is far only in the sense of location, not in the sense of characteristic.🔽Or it is near or far in such and such a way: here the method should not be looked at in the way already given. For that has been given in the way beginning, “When the eye is the proximate cause” .

original: pana na lakkhaṇato dūraṃ bhindati, okāsato dūrameva bhindati. Upādāyupādāya dūrasantikañhi
analyzed: pana na lakkhaṇataḥ dūram bhindati okāsataḥ dūram eva bhindati upādāya upādāya dūra santikam hi
translated: Here, however, it is not the nearness in the sense of characteristic that is meant, but only the nearness in the sense of location. For what is near to what is called near; what is far from what is called far.🔽For one’s own visible form is called near; that of another is far even when it is in one’s own belly.

original: ettha dassitaṃ. Attano hi rūpaṃ santike nāma; antokucchigatassāpi parassa dūre. Antokucchigatassa🔽santike; bahiṭhitassa dūre. Ekamañce sayitassa santike; bahipamukhe ṭhitassa dūre.🔽Antopariveṇe rūpaṃ santike; bahipariveṇe dūre. Antosaṅghārāme rūpaṃ santike; bahisaṅghārāme
analyzed: ettha dassitam attanaḥ hi rūpam santike nāma antokucchi gatassa api parassa dūre antokucchi gatassa  santike bahi ṭhitassa dūre eka mañce sayitassa santike bahi pamukhe ṭhitassa dūre  antar upariveṇe rūpam santike bahi pariveṇe dūre antar saṅgha ārāme rūpam santike bahi saṅgha ārāme
translated: That in one’s own belly is near; that of another outside is far.🔽That of one lying on the same bed is near; that of one standing outside the door is far.🔽That in the inner courtyard is near; that in the outer courtyard is far. That in the inner monastery is near; that in the outer monastery is far.

original: dūre. Antosīmāya rūpaṃ santike; bahisīmāya dūre. Antogāmakhette rūpaṃ santike; bahigāmakkhette
analyzed: dūre anto sīmāya rūpam santike bahi sīmāya dūre antar gāma khette rūpam santike bahi gāma khette
translated: That within the monastery boundary is near; that outside the monastery boundary is far. That in the village field is near; that in the field outside the village is far.

original: dūre. Antojanapade rūpaṃ santike; bahijanapade dūre. Antorajjasīmāya rūpaṃ santike;🔽bahirajjasīmāya dūre. Antosamudde rūpaṃ santike; bahisamudderūpaṃ dūre. Antocakkavāḷe
analyzed: dūre antar janapade rūpam santike bahi janapade dūre antar rajja sīmāya rūpam santike  bahi rajja sīmāya dūre antar samudde rūpam santike bahi samudde rūpam dūre antar cakkavāḷe
translated: and far. A visible object in the interior of the country is near; one in the exterior of the country is far. A visible object within the boundaries of the kingdom is near;🔽one outside the boundaries of the kingdom is far. A visible object in the interior of the ocean is near; a visible object in the exterior of the ocean is far. A visible object within the world-sphere is near;

original: rūpaṃ santike; bahicakkavāḷe dūreti.
analyzed: rūpam santike bahi cakkavāḷe dūra iti
translated: a visible object outside the world-sphere is far.

original: Ayaṃ rūpakkhandhaniddeso.
analyzed: ayam rūpakkhandha niddesaḥ
translated: This is the description of the form aggregate.

original: 2. Vedanākkhandhaniddeso
analyzed: vedanā khandha niddeso
translated: . Description of the Feeling Aggregate

original: 8. Vedanākkhandhaniddesādīsu heṭṭhā vuttasadisaṃ pahāya apubbameva vaṇṇayissāma.🔽Yā kāci vedanāti catubhūmikavedanaṃ pariyādiyati. Sukhā vedanātiādīni atītādivasena
analyzed: vedanā khandha niddesa ādīsu heṭṭhā vutta sadisam pahāya apubbam eva vaṇṇayissāma  yā kāci catu bhūmika vedanam sukhā atīta ādi vasena
translated: . In the description of the feeling aggregate and the rest, we shall omit what is similar to what has been said above and shall only comment on what is new.

original: niddiṭṭhavedanaṃ sabhāvato dassetuṃ vuttāni. Tattha sukhā vedanā atthi kāyikā, atthi
analyzed: niddiṭṭha vedanam sabhāvataḥ dassetum vuttāni tattha sukhā vedanā atthi kāyikā atthi
translated: “Whatever is felt” includes the fourfold feeling of the four planes. “Pleasant feeling” and the rest are stated to show the nature of the feeling indicated by the words “whatever is felt” in terms of the past, etc. Herein, pleasant feeling is bodily or mentally originated.

original: cetasikā. Tathā dukkhā vedanā. Adukkhamasukhā pana cakkhādayo pasādakāye sandhāya
analyzed: cetasikā tathā dukkhā vedanā adukkham asukhā pana cakkha ādayo pasāda kāye sandhāya
translated: So too painful feeling. But neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is, by way of the faculties of the eye, etc.,

original: pariyāyena ‘atthi kāyikā, atthi cetasikā’. Tattha sabbāpi kāyikā kāmāvacarā. Tathā
analyzed: pariyāyena atthi kāyikā atthi cetasikā tattha sabbā api kāyikā kāmāvacarā tathā
translated: “bodily” and “mental” in the sense of a derivation. Herein, all bodily feeling is of the sense sphere. So too is mental feeling.

original: cetasikā dukkhā vedanā. Cetasikā sukhā pana tebhūmikā. Adukkhamasukhā catubhūmikā.
analyzed: cetasikā dukkhā vedanā cetasikā sukhā pana tebhūmikā adukkhamasukhā catu bhūmikā
translated: And painful feeling is mental. But pleasant feeling is of three planes. Neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is of four planes.

original: Tassā sabbappakārāyapi santativasena, khaṇādivasena ca atītādibhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: santati vasena khaṇa ādi vasena ca atīta ādi bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: And its pastness, etc., should be understood according to continuity, according to instant, and so on.

original: Tattha santativasena ekavīthiekajavanaekasamāpattipariyāpannā, ekavidhavisayasamāyogappavattā
analyzed: tattha santati vasena eka vīthi eka javana eka samāpatti pariyāpannā ekavidha visaya samāyoga ppavattā
translated: Herein, according to continuity, it is present when it is included in a single occurrence of consciousness, a single impulsion, a single attainment, and it arises in association with a single kind of object.🔽It is past before that and after that it is future. According to instant, etc., it is present when it is included in the three instants,

original: ca paccuppannā. Tato pubbe atītā, pacchā anāgatā. Khaṇādivasena khaṇattayapariyāpannā🔽pubbantāparantamajjhagatā sakiccañca kurumānā vedanā paccuppannā. Tato pubbe atītā,
analyzed: ca paccuppannā tatas pubbe atītā pacchā anāgatā khaṇa ādi vasena khaṇa ttaya pariyāpannā  pubbanta aparanta majjha gatā sa kiccañca kurumānā vedanā paccuppannā tatas pubbe atītā
translated: and it is past when it is before that and future when it is after that. And it is present when it is performing its own particular function.

original: pacchā anāgatā. Tattha khaṇādivasena atītādibhāvaṃ sandhāya ayaṃ niddeso katoti veditabbo.🔽11. Oḷārikasukhumaniddese akusalā vedanātiādīni jātito oḷārikasukhumabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: pacchā anāgatā tattha khaṇa ādi vasena atīta ādi bhāvam sandhāya ayam niddeso kato ti veditabbo  oḷārika sukhuma niddese akusalā vedanā ti ādīni jātitaḥ oḷārika sukhuma bhāvam dassetuṃ
translated: Herein, this description should be understood according to pastness, etc., according to instant, and so on.🔽In the description of gross and refined, the unprofitable kinds of feeling, etc., are stated to show the gross and refined state according to kind.

original: vuttāni. Dukkhā vedanā oḷārikātiādīni sabhāvato. Asamāpannassa vedanātiādīni puggalato.
analyzed: vuttāni dukkhā vedanā oḷārikā ti ādīni sabhāvataḥ asamāpannassa vedanā ti ādīni puggalato
translated: The painful kinds of feeling, etc., are stated according to individual essence. The feeling of one who is not attained to jhāna, etc., is stated according to person.

original: Sāsavātiādīni lokiyalokuttarato oḷārikasukhumabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ vuttāni. Tattha akusalā🔽tāva sadarathaṭṭhena dukkhavipākaṭṭhena ca oḷārikā. Kusalā niddarathaṭṭhena sukhavipākaṭṭhena
analyzed: sāsava ati ādīni lokiya lokuttarataḥ oḷārika sukhuma bhāvam dassetum vuttāni tattha akusalā  tāva sadaratha ṭhena dukkha vipāka ṭṭhena ca oḷārikā kusalā niddaratha ṭṭhena sukha vipāka ṭṭhena
translated: The terms “with resultant-nature” and so on are stated in order to show the gross and subtle states of the mundane and supramundane. Herein, the unwholesome are gross by reason of their being associated with the three roots of unwholesomeness and by reason of their having painful results. The wholesome are subtle by reason of their being associated with the three roots of wholesomeness and by reason of their having pleasant results.

original: ca sukhumā. Abyākatā nirussāhaṭṭhena avipākaṭṭhena ca sukhumā. Kusalākusalā saussāhaṭṭhena🔽savipākaṭṭhena ca oḷārikā. Abyākatā vuttanayeneva sukhumā.🔽Dukkhā asātaṭṭhena dukkhaṭṭhena ca oḷārikā. Sukhā sātaṭṭhena sukhaṭṭhena ca sukhumā.
analyzed: ca sukhumā abyākatā nirussāha ṭṭhena avipāka ṭṭhena ca sukhumā kusala akusalā saussāha ṭṭhena  sa vipāka ṭṭhena ca oḷārikā abyākatā vutta nayena iva sukhumā  dukkhā asāta ṭṭhena dukkha ṭṭhena ca oḷārikā sukhā sāta ṭṭhena sukha ṭṭhena ca sukhumā
translated: The words “with resultant” and so on are said in order to show the gross and subtle state according to the mundane and supramundane. Herein, the unprofitable is gross by reason of the state of being a cause of pain and by reason of the state of having a painful ripening. The profitable is subtle by reason of the state of being a cause of pleasure and by reason of the state of having a pleasant ripening. The indeterminate is subtle by reason of the state of being without exertion and by reason of the state of having no ripening. The profitable and the unprofitable are gross by reason of the state of being with exertion and by reason of the state of having a ripening. The indeterminate is subtle by the aforesaid method.🔽The painful is gross by reason of the state of being unsweet and by reason of the state of being painful. The pleasant is subtle by reason of the state of being sweet and by reason of the state of being pleasant.

original: Adukkhamasukhā santaṭṭhena paṇītaṭṭhena ca sukhumā. Sukhadukkhā khobhanaṭṭhena pharaṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: adukkhamasukhā santa ṭṭhena paṇīta ṭṭhena ca sukhumā sukha dukkhā khobhana ṭṭhena pharaṇa ṭṭhena
translated: The neither-painful-nor-pleasant is subtle by reason of the state of being calm and by reason of the state of being sublime. The pleasant and the painful are gross by reason of the state of being agitating and by reason of the state of being spreading.

original: ca oḷārikā. Sukhavedanāpi hi khobheti pharati. Tathā dukkhavedanāpi. Sukhañhi uppajjamānaṃ🔽sakalasarīraṃ khobhentaṃ āluḷentaṃ abhisandayamānaṃ maddayamānaṃ chādayamānaṃ sītodakaghaṭena
analyzed: ca oḷārikā sukha vedanā api hi khobheti pharati tathā dukkha vedanā api sukham hi uppajjamānam 🔽sakala sarīram khobhentam āluḷentam abhisandayamānam maddayamānam chādayamānam sītā udaka ghaṭena
translated: For the pleasant feeling agitates and spreads, and so does the painful feeling. For when the pleasant arises it does so agitating, disturbing, and pervading the whole body, as though with cool water,

original: āsiñcayamānaṃ viya uppajjati. Dukkhaṃ uppajjamānaṃ tattaphālaṃ anto pavesantaṃ viya
analyzed: āsiñcayamānam viya uppajjati dukkham uppajjamānam tatta phālam antar pavesantam viya
translated: Painful feeling arises as if it were burning outside with a flame of grass-fire.

original: tiṇukkāya bahi jhāpayamānaṃ viya uppajjati. Adukkhamasukhā pana vuttanayeneva sukhumā.
analyzed: tiṇukkāya bahi jhāpayamānam viya uppajjati adukkhamasukhā pana vutta nayena iva sukhumā
translated: Neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling arises as subtle in the way already described.🔽Feeling in one who has not attained is gross because it is distracted over various objects.

original: Asamāpannassa vedanā nānārammaṇe vikkhittabhāvato oḷārikā. Samāpannassa vedanā ekattanimitteyeva🔽caratīti sukhumā. Sāsavā āsavuppattihetuto oḷārikā. Āsavacāro nāma ekantaoḷāriko.
analyzed: asamāpannassa vedanā nānā ārammaṇe vikkhitta bhāvataḥ oḷārikā samāpannassa vedanā ekatta nimittā iya eva  carati iti sukhumā sa āsavā āsava uppatti hetutaḥ oḷārikā āsava cāraḥ nāma ekanta oḷārikaḥ
translated: Feeling in one who has attained is subtle because it occurs only in the single object of unifi ed consciousness.🔽With taints is gross because it is the cause of the arising of taints. The occurrence of taints is gross in one sense,

original: Anāsavā vuttavipariyāyena sukhumā.
analyzed: anāsavā vutta vipariyāyena sukhumā
translated: and subtle in another. Without taints is subtle in the opposite way.

original: Tattha eko neva kusalattike kovido hoti, na vedanāttike. So ‘kusalattikaṃ rakkhāmī’ti🔽vedanāttikaṃ bhindati; ‘vedanāttikaṃ rakkhāmī’ti kusalattikaṃ bhindati. Eko ‘tikaṃ
analyzed: tattha ekaḥ na iva kusala attike kovidaḥ hoti na vedanā attike so kusala attikam rakkhāmi iti  vedanā ttikam bhindati vedanā ttikam rakkhāmi iti kusala ttikam bhindati ekaḥ tikam
translated: Herein, one person is not skilled in the three kinds of profitable and in the three kinds of feeling. He breaks up the three kinds of feeling, thinking “I shall guard the three kinds of profitable.”

original: rakkhāmī’ti bhūmantaraṃ bhindati. Eko na bhindati. Kathaṃ? “Sukhadukkhā vedanā oḷārikā,
analyzed: rakkhāmi iti bhūmantaram bhindati ekaḥ na bhindati katham sukha dukkhā vedanā oḷārikā
translated: He breaks up the three kinds of profitable, thinking “I shall guard the three kinds of feeling.” Another breaks up the plane, thinking “I shall guard the three kinds of profitable and the three kinds of feeling.” Another does not break up. How? “Pleasant and painful feeling are gross,

original: adukkhamasukhā vedanā sukhumā”ti hi vedanāttike vuttaṃ. Taṃ eko paṭikkhipati – na
analyzed: adukkham asukhā vedanā sukhumā ti hi vedanā attike vuttam tam ekaḥ paṭikkhipati na
translated: for it is said in the Feeling-aggregate: “Neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is subtle” .🔽One rejects that, saying:

original: sabbā adukkhamasukhā sukhumā. Sā hi kusalāpi atthi akusalāpi abyākatāpi. Tattha kusalākusalā
analyzed: sabbā adukkhamasukhā sukhumā sā hi kusalā api atthi akusalā api abyākatā api tattha kusala akusalā
translated: “Not all neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is subtle. For that is also profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate. Herein, the profitable and unprofitable

original: oḷārikā, abyākatā sukhumā. Kasmā? Kusalattike pāḷiyaṃ āgatattāti. Evaṃ kusalattiko
analyzed: oḷārikā abyākatā sukhumā kasmā kusala attike pāḷiyam evam kusala attikaḥ
translated: are gross, and the indeterminate is subtle. Why? Because it is stated in the Thread in the profitable-aggregate section” .

original: rakkhito hoti, vedanāttiko pana bhinno.
analyzed: rakkhitaḥ hoti vedanā attiko pana bhinno
translated: So the profitable-aggregate section is safeguarded, but the feeling-aggregate section is split.🔽But as to what is said in the profitable-aggregate section, namely:

original: Kusalākusalā vedanā oḷārikā, abyākatā vedanā sukhumā”ti yaṃ pana kusalattike vuttaṃ,
analyzed: kusala akusalā vedanā oḷārikā abyākatā vedanā sukhumā iti yat pana kusala ttike vuttam
translated: “Indeterminate feeling is subtle” ,🔽one rejects that, saying:

original: taṃ eko paṭikkhipati – na sabbā abyākatā sukhumā. Sā hi sukhāpi atthi dukkhāpi adukkhamasukhāpi.
analyzed: tam ekaḥ paṭikkhipati na sabbā abyākatā sukhumā sā hi sukhā api atthi dukkhā api adukkhamasukhā api
translated: “Not all indeterminate feeling is subtle. For that is also pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant.

original: Tattha sukhadukkhā oḷārikā, adukkhamasukhā sukhumā. Kasmā? Vedanāttike pāḷiyaṃ āgatattāti.
analyzed: tattha sukha dukkhā oḷārikā adukkham asukhā sukhumā kasmā vedanā attike pāḷiyam āgata ttā ti
translated: Herein, the pleasant and painful are gross, and the neither-painful-nor-pleasant is subtle. Why? Because it is stated in the Thread in the feeling-aggregate section” .

original: Evaṃ vedanāttiko rakkhito hoti, kusalattiko pana bhinno. Kusalattikassa pana āgataṭṭhāne
analyzed: evam vedanā attikaḥ rakkhitaḥ hoti kusala attiko pana bhinno kusala attikassa pana āgata ṭṭhāne
translated: So the feeling-aggregate section is safeguarded, but the profitable-aggregate section is split. But in the place where the profitable-aggregate section is stated,

original: vedanāttikaṃ anoloketvā vedanāttikassa āgataṭṭhāne kusalattikaṃ anoloketvā kusalādīnaṃ
analyzed: vedanā ttikam anoloketvā vedanā ttikassa āgata ṭṭhāne kusala ttikam anoloketvā kusala ādīnam
translated: He does not look at the indeterminate triad in the place occupied by the three kinds of feeling.🔽He does not look at the three kinds of feeling in the place occupied by the profitable triad.🔽He does not look at the three kinds of feeling in the place occupied by the unprofitable triad.🔽He does not look at the three kinds of feeling in the place occupied by the indeterminate triad.

original: kusalattikalakkhaṇena, sukhādīnaṃ vedanāttikalakkhaṇena oḷārikasukhumataṃ kathento na bhindati nāma.
analyzed: kusala ttika lakkhaṇena sukha ādīnam vedanā ttika lakkhaṇena oḷārika sukhumatam kathentaḥ na bhindati nāma
translated: He does not look at the profitable triad in the place occupied by the unprofitable triad.🔽He does not look at the unprofitable triad in the place occupied by the profitable triad.🔽He does not look at the indeterminate triad in the place occupied by the profitable triad.🔽He does not look at the profitable triad in the place occupied by the indeterminate triad.

original: Yampi “kusalākusalā vedanā oḷārikā, abyākatā vedanā sukhumā”ti kusalattike vuttaṃ,
analyzed: yat api kusala akusalā vedanā oḷārikā abyākatā vedanā sukhumā iti kusala ttike vuttam
translated: He does not look at the unprofitable triad in the place occupied by the indeterminate triad.🔽He does not look at the indeterminate triad in the place occupied by the unprofitable triad.🔽He does not look at the profitable triad in the place occupied by the unprofitable triad.🔽He does not look at the unprofitable triad in the place occupied by the profitable triad.🔽He does not look at the indeterminate triad in the place occupied by the profitable triad.🔽He does not look at the profitable triad in the place occupied by the indeterminate triad.🔽He does not look at the unprofitable triad in the place occupied by the indeterminate triad.🔽He does not look at the indeterminate triad in the place occupied by the unprofitable triad.🔽He does not look at the profitable triad in the place occupied by the unprofitable triad.

original: tattheko ‘kusalā lokuttaravedanāpi samānā oḷārikā nāma, vipākā antamaso dvipañcaviññāṇasahajātāpi🔽samānā sukhumā nāma hotī’ti vadati. So evarūpaṃ santaṃ paṇītaṃ lokuttaravedanaṃ oḷārikaṃ🔽nāma karonto, dvipañcaviññāṇasampayuttaṃ ahetukaṃ hīnaṃ jaḷaṃ vedanaṃ sukhumaṃ nāma

translated: And that born of mind-contact has the heart-basis as its physical basis, and also has no physical basis. All is volition of the four planes. The rest is as in the case of the feeling aggregate.

original: Ayaṃ saṅkhārakkhandhaniddeso.
analyzed: ayam saṅkhāra khandha niddeso
translated: This is the description of the formations aggregate.

original: 5. Viññāṇakkhandhaniddeso
analyzed: viññāṇa kkhandha niddeso
translated: Description of the consciousness aggregate

original: 26. Viññāṇakkhandhaniddese yaṃ kiñci viññāṇanti catubhūmakaviññāṇaṃ pariyādiyati.
analyzed: viññāṇa kkhandha niddese yam kiñci viññāṇanti catu bhūmaka viññāṇam pariyādiyati
translated: In the description of the consciousness aggregate, “Any kind of consciousness” includes the consciousness of the four planes.

original: Cakkhuviññāṇantiādīni atītādivasena niddiṭṭhaviññāṇaṃ sabhāvato dassetuṃ vuttāni.
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa nti ādīni atīta ādi vasena niddiṭṭha viññāṇam sabhāvataḥ dassetum vuttāni
translated: “Eye-consciousness” and the rest are mentioned to show the consciousness described above under the past, etc., in its individual essence.

original: Tattha cakkhuviññāṇādīni pañca cakkhupasādādivatthukāneva, manoviññāṇaṃ hadayavatthukampi
analyzed: tattha cakkhu viññāṇa ādīni pañca cakkhu pasāda ādi vatthukān eva manaḥ viññāṇam hadaya vatthukam pi
translated: Herein, the five beginning with eye-consciousness have only the eye sensitive matter, etc., as their physical basis. Mind-consciousness has the heart-basis as its physical basis,

original: avatthukampi. Sabbaṃ catubhūmakaviññāṇaṃ. Sesaṃ vedanākkhandhasadisamevāti.
analyzed: avatthukam pi sabbam catu bhūmaka viññāṇam sesam vedanā khandha sadisam eva ati
translated: and also has no physical basis. All is consciousness of the four planes. The rest is as in the case of the feeling aggregate.

original: Ayaṃ viññāṇakkhandhaniddeso.
analyzed: ayam viññāṇa kkhandha niddeso
translated: This is the description of the consciousness aggregate.

original: Pakiṇṇakakathā
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā
translated: Supplementary discussion

original: Idāni pañcasupi khandhesu samuggamato, pubbāparato, addhānaparicchedato, ekuppādanānānirodhato,
analyzed: idāni pañcasu pi khandhesu samuggamataḥ pubba aparataḥ addhāna paricchedataḥ eka uppāda nānā nirodhato
translated: Now, as regards the five aggregates, there is the following method of exposition. They are classed according to the plane of existence, according to the past, etc., according to the division of the life-span, according to the arising of one and the cessation of another, according to the physical basis, according to the faculties, according to the kinds of dependence, according to the kinds of generation, according to the kinds of destiny, according to the kinds of becoming, according to the kinds of rebirth, according to the kinds of temperament, according to the kinds of action, according to the kinds of generation, according to the kinds of percipient and non-percipient, according to the kinds of material and immaterial, according to the kinds of visible and invisible, according to the kinds of resisting and non-resisting, according to the kinds of sense sphere, fine-material sphere, immaterial sphere, and neither-sphere-nor-non-sphere, according to the kinds of aggregates, bases, and elements, according to the kinds of aggregates, bases, elements, faculties, truths, dependent origination, and so on.

original: nānuppādaekanirodhato, ekuppādaekanirodhato, nānuppādanānānirodhato, atītānāgatapaccuppannato,
analyzed: na anuppāda eka nirodhataḥ ekuppāda eka nirodhataḥ na anuppāda nānā nirodhataḥ atīta anāgata paccuppannato
translated: but by past, future, and present,🔽by internal and external, by gross and subtle, by inferior and superior, by far and near,

original: ajjhattikabāhirato, oḷārikasukhumato, hīnapaṇītato, dūrasantikato, paccayato, samuṭṭhānato,
analyzed: ajjhattika bāhirataḥ oḷārika sukhumataḥ hīna paṇītataḥ dūra santikataḥ paccayataḥ samuṭṭhānato
translated: by condition, by origination,

original: parinipphannato, saṅkhatatoti soḷasahākārehi pakiṇṇakaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: parinipphannataḥ saṅkhatataḥ ti soḷasahā ākārehi pakiṇṇakam veditabbam
translated: by outcome, by formed, thus in sixteen aspects the miscellaneous should be known.

original: Tattha duvidho samuggamo – gabbhaseyyakasamuggamo, opapātikasamuggamoti. Tattha gabbhaseyyakasamuggamo🔽evaṃ veditabbo – gabbhaseyyakasattānañhi paṭisandhikkhaṇe pañcakkhandhā apacchāapure
analyzed: tattha duvidhaḥ samuggamaḥ gabbhaseyyaka samuggamo opapātika samuggamo ti tattha gabbhaseyyaka samuggamo  evam veditabbaḥ gabbhaseyyaka sattānam hi paṭisandhi kkhaṇe pañca kkhandhāḥ a pacchā apure
translated: Herein, the emergence is twofold as emergence in the womb and emergence as an apparition.🔽Herein, the emergence in the womb should be understood as follows.

original: ekato pātubhavanti. Tasmiṃ khaṇe pātubhūtā kalalasaṅkhātā rūpasantati parittā hoti.
analyzed: ekatas pātubhavanti tasmin khaṇe pātubhūtā kalala saṅkhātā rūpa santati parittā hoti
translated: For in the case of beings who are born in a womb, the five aggregates become manifest all together without distinction at the moment of their conception.🔽At that moment the material continuity called “morula” is small.

original: Khuddakamakkhikāya ekavāyāmena pātabbamattāti vatvā puna ‘atibahuṃ etaṃ, saṇhasūciyā
analyzed: khuddaka makkhikāya eka vāyāmena vatvā puna atibahum etam saṇha sūciyā
translated: It is said to be the amount that can be contained in a single movement of a small gnat. But that is too much.

original: tele pakkhipitvā ukkhittāya paggharitvā agge ṭhitabindumatta’nti vuttaṃ. Tampi paṭikkhipitvā
analyzed: tele pakkhipitvā ukkhittāya paggharitvā agge ṭhita bindumattanti vuttam tam pi paṭikkhipitvā
translated: After rejecting that,

original: ‘ekakese telato uddharitvā gahite tassa paggharitvā agge ṭhitabindumatta’nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: eka kese telataḥ uddharitvā gahite tassa paggharitvā agge ṭhita bindumattanti vuttam
translated: ‘the size of a drop of oil on the tip of a blade of grass held horizontally after being drawn out’ was stated.

original: Tampi paṭikkhipitvā ‘imasmiṃ janapade manussānaṃ kese aṭṭhadhā phālite tato ekakoṭṭhāsappamāṇo🔽uttarakurukānaṃ keso; tassa pasannatilatelato uddhaṭassa agge ṭhitabindumatta’nti🔽vuttaṃ. Tampi paṭikkhipitvā ‘etaṃ bahu, jātiuṇṇā nāma sukhumā; tassā ekaaṃsuno pasannatilatele
analyzed: tam pi paṭikkhipitvā imasmin janapade manussānam kese aṭṭhadhā phālite tatas eka koṭṭhāsa ppamāṇaḥ  uttarakurukānam kesaḥ tassa pasanna tila telataḥ uddhaṭassa agge ṭhita bindu mattanti  vuttam tam pi paṭikkhipitvā etam bahu jātiuṇṇā nāma sukhumā tassāḥ eka aṃsuno pasanna tila tele
translated: After rejecting that, ‘the size of a drop of oil on the tip of a single hair of the kind called a “head hair” in this country,🔽after being drawn out from clear sesame oil’ was stated.🔽After rejecting that, ‘the size of a drop of oil on the tip of a single hair of the kind called a “head hair” in Uttarakuru,

original: pakkhipitvā uddhaṭassa paggharitvā agge ṭhitabindumatta’nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ panetaṃ acchaṃ
analyzed: pakkhipitvā uddhaṭassa paggharitvā agge ṭhita bindu mattanti vuttam tam pana etam accham
translated: after being drawn out from clear sesame oil’ was stated. But that is too much. The hair called a “head hair” is fine. The size of a drop of oil on the tip of a single one of those hairs,🔽after being drawn out from clear sesame oil, is the size of a drop of oil on the tip of a single hair of the kind called a “body hair” in this country.

original: hoti vippasannaṃ anāvilaṃ parisuddhaṃ pasannatilatelabindusamānavaṇṇaṃ. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: hoti vippasannam anāvilam parisuddham pasanna tila tela bindu samāna vaṇṇam vuttam pi
translated: That is clear, bright, pure, and spotless, and it is the colour of clear sesame oil. And this is said:🔽“Like a drop of sesame oil

original: Tilatelassa yathā bindu, sappimaṇḍo anāvilo;
analyzed: tila telassa yathā bindu sappi maṇḍaḥ anāvilaḥ
translated: on the surface of a dish, unadulterated,

original: Evaṃ vaṇṇapaṭibhāgaṃ, kalalanti pavuccatīti.
analyzed: evam vaṇṇa paṭibhāgam kalalanti pavuccati iti
translated: So it is called “morsel” in the sense of a portion of colour.

original: Evaṃ parittāya rūpasantatiyā tīṇi santatisīsāni honti – vatthudasakaṃ, kāyadasakaṃ,
analyzed: evam parittāya rūpa santatiyā tīṇi santati sīsāni honti vatthu dasakam kāya dasakam
translated: Thus in this small continuum of materiality there are three head-continua: the decad of the physical basis, the decad of the body,

original: itthiyā itthindriyavasena purisassa purisindriyavasena bhāvadasakanti. Tattha vatthurūpaṃ,
analyzed: itthiyāḥ itthi indriya vasena purisassa purisa indriya vasena bhāva dasakanti tattha vatthu rūpam
translated: and the decad of the sex in the case of a woman, or the decad of the sex in the case of a man. Herein, the materiality of the physical basis,

original: tassa nissayāni cattāri mahābhūtāni, taṃnissitā vaṇṇagandharasojā, jīvitanti – idaṃ
analyzed: tassa nissayāni cattāri mahābhūtāni tad nissitā vaṇṇa gandha rasojā jīvitanti idam
translated: the four great essentials that are its support, the colour, odour, flavour, and nutritive essence that are supported by them, and life—

original: vatthudasakaṃ nāma. Kāyapasādo, tassa nissayāni cattāri mahābhūtāni, tannissitā vaṇṇagandharasojā,
analyzed: vatthudasakam nāma kāyapasādo tassa nissayāni cattāri mahābhūtāni tad nissitā vaṇṇa gandha rasojā
translated: these are called the decad of the physical basis. The sensitivity of the body, the four great essentials that are its support, the colour, odour, flavour, and nutritive essence that are supported by them,

original: jīvitanti – idaṃ kāyadasakaṃ nāma. Itthiyā itthibhāvo, purisassa purisabhāvo, tassa
analyzed: jīvitanti idam kāyadasakam nāma itthiyāḥ itthi bhāvo purisassa purisa bhāvo tassa
translated: and life—these are called the decad of the body. The femininity of a woman, the masculinity of a man,

original: nissayāni cattāri mahābhūtāni, tannissitā vaṇṇagandharasojā, jīvitanti – idaṃ bhāvadasakaṃ nāma.
analyzed: nissayāni cattāri mahābhūtāni tad nissitā vaṇṇa gandha rasojā jīvitan ti idam bhāvadasakam nāma
translated: the four great essentials that are their support, the colour, odour, flavour, and nutritive essence that are supported by them, and life—these are called the decad of the sex.

original: Evaṃ gabbhaseyyakānaṃ paṭisandhiyaṃ ukkaṭṭhaparicchedena samatiṃsa kammajarūpāni
analyzed: evam gabbhaseyyakānam paṭisandhiyam ukkaṭṭha paricchedena kamma ja rūpāni
translated: Thus in the case of one who is born from a womb, there are thirty-two kinds of materiality due to kamma, according to the maximum number of factors.

original: rūpakkhandho nāma hoti. Paṭisandhicittena pana sahajātā vedanā vedanākkhandho, saññā🔽saññākkhandho, saṅkhārā saṅkhārakkhandho, paṭisandhicittaṃ viññāṇakkhandhoti. Evaṃ🔽gabbhaseyyakānaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe pañcakkhandhā paripuṇṇā honti. Sace pana napuṃsakapaṭisandhi🔽hoti, bhāvadasakaṃ hāyati. Dvinnaṃ dasakānaṃ vasena samavīsati kammajarūpāni rūpakkhandho
analyzed: rūpa kkhandho nāma hoti paṭisandhi cittena pana sahajātā vedanā vedanā kkhandho saññā  saññā kkhandho saṅkhārā saṅkhāra kkhandho paṭisandhi cittam viññāṇa kkhandho ti evam  gabbhaseyyakānam paṭisandhi kkhaṇe pañca khandhāḥ paripuṇṇāḥ honti sace pana napuṃsaka paṭisandhi  hoti bhāva dasakam hāyati dvinnam dasakānam vasena kamma ja rūpāni rūpa kkhandho
translated: It is called the materiality aggregate. But the feeling associated with rebirth-linking consciousness is the feeling aggregate, the perception is the perception aggregate, the (five) aggregates beginning with volition are the formations aggregate, and the rebirth-linking consciousness itself is the consciousness aggregate. So at the moment of rebirth-linking in the case of those who are born from a womb, the five aggregates are complete. But if the rebirth-linking is that of a eunuch, the ten consisting of the two sets of five are missing. There are twenty-two kinds of materiality classed as the materiality aggregate according to the two sets of ten.🔽

original: nāma hoti. Vedanākkhandhādayo vuttappakārā evāti. Evampi gabbhaseyyakānaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe🔽pañcakkhandhā paripuṇṇā honti.🔽Imasmiṃ ṭhāne tisamuṭṭhānikappaveṇī kathetabbā bhaveyya. Taṃ pana akathetvā ‘opapātikasamuggamo’
analyzed: nāma hoti vedanā khandha ādayaḥ vutta ppakārāḥ eva ati evam pi gabbhaseyyakānam paṭisandhi khaṇe  pañca kkhandhāḥ paripuṇṇāḥ honti  imasmin ṭhāne ti samuṭṭhānika ppaveṇī kathetabbā bhaveyya tam pana a kathetvā opapātika samuggamaḥ
translated: and the materiality that is conascent with the rebirth-linking consciousness is the materiality aggregate. But the feeling that is conascent with the rebirth-linking consciousness is the feeling aggregate, the perception is the perception aggregate, the formations are the formations aggregate, and the rebirth-linking consciousness itself is the consciousness aggregate. So at the moment of rebirth-linking in the case of those who are born from a womb, the five aggregates are complete. But if the rebirth-linking is that of a eunuch, the ten formations of the life-continuum disappear. The materiality aggregate is the twenty-two kinds of materiality classed as the ten consisting of the ten bases and the two consisting of the two kinds of materiality. The feeling aggregate, etc., are as already described. So in this way too the five aggregates are complete at the moment of rebirth-linking in the case of those who are born from a womb.

original: nāma dassito. Opapātikānañhi paripuṇṇāyatanānaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe heṭṭhā vuttāni tīṇi,
analyzed: nāma dassito opapātikānam hi paripuṇṇa āyatanānam paṭisandhi kkhaṇe heṭṭhā vuttāni tīṇi
translated: Here is where the “series of triplets” should be told. But instead of telling it, the “appearance of the apparitional being” is shown. For in the case of apparitional beings whose sense bases are complete, the three stated above,

original: cakkhusotaghānajivhādasakāni cāti satta rūpasantatisīsāni pātubhavanti. Tattha cakkhudasakādīni
analyzed: cakkhu sota ghāna jivhā dasakāni ca ati satta rūpa santati sīsāni pātubhavanti tattha cakkhu dasaka ādīni
translated: Herein, the eye-flesh, etc.,

original: kāyadasakasadisāneva. Napuṃsakassa pana bhāvadasakaṃ natthi. Evaṃ paripuṇṇāyatanānaṃ
analyzed: kāya dasaka sadisānam eva napuṃsakassa pana bhāva dasakam natthi evam paripuṇṇa āyatanānam
translated: are like the body-flesh. But a eunuch has no sex-fluid. So in those with complete bases

original: opapātikānaṃ samasattati ceva samasaṭṭhi ca kammajarūpāni rūpakkhandho nāma. Vedanākkhandhādayo
analyzed: opapātikānam ca iva ca kamma ja rūpāni rūpakkhandhaḥ nāma vedanā khandha ādayaḥ
translated: there are seventy-three or sixty-one kinds of kamma-born materiality. This is called the materiality aggregate. The feeling aggregate, etc.,

original: vuttappakārā evāti. Evaṃ opapātikānaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe pañcakkhandhā paripuṇṇā honti.
analyzed: vutta ppakārāḥ eva ati evam opapātikānam paṭisandhi khaṇe pañca khandhāḥ paripuṇṇāḥ honti
translated: are as already described. So at the moment of rebirth-linking in the case of those who are spontaneously born, the five aggregates are complete.

original: Ayaṃ ‘opapātikasamuggamo’ nāma. Evaṃ tāva pañcakkhandhā ‘samuggamato’ veditabbā.
analyzed: ayam opapātika samuggamaḥ nāma evam tāva pañca kkhandhā samuggamataḥ veditabbā
translated: This is called “the emergence of those who are spontaneously born.” This is how the five aggregates should be understood “as emergence.”

original: ‘Pubbāparato’ti evaṃ pana gabbhaseyyakānaṃ apacchāapure uppannesu pañcasu khandhesu
analyzed: pubba aparato ti evam pana gabbhaseyyakānam apacchā apure uppannesu pañcasu khandhesu
translated: “As prior and subsequent”: but in the case of those who are born from a womb, the five aggregates that arise later🔽are dependent for their arising on the five aggregates that arose earlier. So which materiality produces which materiality, and which materiality produces which immateriality?

original: kiṃ rūpaṃ paṭhamaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti udāhu arūpanti? Rūpaṃ rūpameva samuṭṭhāpeti,
analyzed: kim rūpam paṭhamam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti udāhu arūpam ti rūpam rūpam eva samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: Materiality produces materiality only,

original: na arūpaṃ. Kasmā? Paṭisandhicittassa na rūpajanakattā. Sabbasattānañhi paṭisandhicittaṃ,
analyzed: na arūpam kasmā paṭisandhi cittassa na rūpa janaka ttā sabba sattānam hi paṭisandhi cittam
translated: not immateriality. Why is that? Because the rebirth-linking consciousness does not produce materiality. For the rebirth-linking consciousness of all beings,

original: khīṇāsavassa cuticittaṃ, dvipañcaviññāṇāni, cattāri arūppavipākānīti soḷasa cittāni
analyzed: khīṇāsavassa cuti cittam dvi pañca viññāṇāni cattāri arūppa vipākāni iti soḷasa cittāni
translated: The death consciousness of one whose cankers are destroyed, the two kinds of fine-material-sphere consciousness, the five kinds of sense-sphere profitable consciousness, and the four immaterial-sphere resultants: these sixteen kinds of consciousness do not cause materiality to arise.

original: rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpenti. Tattha paṭisandhicittaṃ tāva vatthuno dubbalatāya appatiṭṭhitatāya
analyzed: rūpam na samuṭṭhāpenti tattha paṭisandhi cittam tāva vatthuno dubbala tāya appatiṭṭhita tāya
translated: Herein, firstly, the rebirth-linking consciousness does not cause materiality to arise because the physical basis is weak and unstable,

original: paccayavekallatāya āgantukatāya ca rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpeti. Tattha hi sahajātaṃ vatthu
analyzed: paccaya vekalla tāya āgantuka tāya ca rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti tattha hi sahajātam vatthu
translated: because the conditions are deficient, and because it is adventitious. Herein, firstly, the conascent physical basis

original: uppādakkhaṇe dubbalaṃ hotīti vatthuno dubbalatāya rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpeti. Yathā ca
analyzed: uppāda kkhaṇe dubbalam hoti iti vatthunaḥ dubbala tāya rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti yathā ca
translated: is weak at the moment of arising, so it does not cause materiality to arise because the physical basis is weak. And just as

original: papāte patanto puriso aññassa nissayo bhavituṃ na sakkoti, evaṃ etampi kammavegakkhittattā
analyzed: papāte patantaḥ puriso aññassa nissayaḥ bhavitum na sakkoti evam etam pi kamma vega kkhitta ttā
translated: a man falling into a chasm cannot be a support for another, so too, this consciousness, being propelled by kamma-force,

original: papāte patamānaṃ viya appatiṭṭhitaṃ. Iti kammavegakkhittattā, appatiṭṭhitatāyapi
analyzed: papāte patamānam viya appatiṭṭhitam iti kamma vega kkhitta ttā appatiṭṭhita tāya api
translated: is unstable as if falling into a chasm. So it does not cause materiality to arise because it is unstable.🔽And the rebirth-linking consciousness arises neither before nor after the physical basis. So it cannot cause materiality to arise by becoming the condition for the physical basis as its predecessor. If it could, it would cause materiality to arise.

original: rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpeti.🔽Paṭisandhicittañca vatthunā saddhiṃ apacchāapure uppannaṃ. Tassa vatthu purejātaṃ🔽hutvā paccayo bhavituṃ na sakkoti. Sace sakkuṇeyya, rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeyya. Yatrāpi
analyzed: rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti 🔽paṭisandhi cittam ca vatthunā saddhim a pacchā apure uppannam tassa vatthu purejātam 🔽hutvā paccayaḥ bhavitum na sakkoti sace sakkuṇeyya rūpam samuṭṭhāpeyya yatra api
translated: But it does not do so.

original: vatthu purejātaṃ hutvā paccayo bhavituṃ sakkoti, paveṇī ghaṭiyati, tatrāpi cittaṃ🔽aṅgato aparihīnaṃyeva rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Yadi hi cittaṃ ṭhānakkhaṇe vā bhaṅgakkhaṇe🔽vā rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeyya, paṭisandhicittampi rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeyya. Na pana cittaṃ tasmiṃ🔽khaṇadvaye rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Yathā pana ahicchattakamakulaṃ pathavito uṭṭhahantaṃ
analyzed: vatthu purejātam hutvā paccayaḥ bhavitum sakkoti paveṇī tatra api cittam  aṅgataḥ a parihīnam yeva rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti yadi hi cittam ṭhāna kkhaṇe vā bhaṅga kkhaṇe  vā rūpam samuṭṭhāpeyya paṭisandhi cittam pi rūpam samuṭṭhāpeyya na pana cittam tasmin  khaṇa dvaye rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti yathā pana ahicchattaka makulam pathavitaḥ uṭṭhahantam
translated: and the materiality that is the support of the consciousness is able to be a condition for it by being prenascent. The stream is straightened. And there too the consciousness arises with materiality that is not deficient in faculties. For if it were to cause materiality to arise at the moment of its own arising or at the moment of its dissolution, then the rebirth-linking consciousness would also cause materiality to arise. But consciousness does not cause materiality to arise at these two moments. But just as a cobra’s hood, which is raised from the ground,🔽

original: paṃsucuṇṇaṃ gahetvāva uṭṭhahati, evaṃ cittaṃ purejātaṃ vatthuṃ nissāya uppādakkhaṇe🔽aṭṭha rūpāni gahetvāva uṭṭhahati. Paṭisandhikkhaṇe ca vatthu purejātaṃ hutvā paccayo🔽bhavituṃ na sakkotīti paccayavekallatāyapi paṭisandhicittaṃ rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: paṃsu cuṇṇam gahetvā ava uṭṭhahati evam cittam purejātam vatthum nissāya uppāda kkhaṇe  aṭṭha rūpāni gahetvā ava uṭṭhahati paṭisandhi kkhaṇe ca vatthu purejātam hutvā paccayaḥ  bhavitum na sakkoti iti paccaya vekalla tāya pi paṭisandhi cittam rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: The materiality that is the support of the consciousness arises only from the consciousness that is not deficient in the requisite conditions. For if the consciousness were to generate materiality at the moment of its presence or at the moment of its dissolution, then the rebirth-linking consciousness would also generate materiality. But consciousness does not generate materiality at those two moments. Just as a fan-palms seed, when it falls from the stalk, takes up soil with it and grows, so too the consciousness, at the moment of its arising, takes up the materiality that is the support and arises together with it. And at the moment of rebirth-linking the materiality that is the support is unable to be a condition as the support, and so the rebirth-linking consciousness does not generate materiality because of the deficiency of a condition.

original: Yathā ca āgantukapuriso agatapubbaṃ padesaṃ gato aññesaṃ – ‘etha bho, antogāme vo
analyzed: yathā ca āgantuka purisaḥ a gata pubbam padesam gataḥ aññesam bho antogāme vaḥ
translated: And just as a visitor to a place he has never visited before does not take others and say, “Come, let us go to the village,” so too the rebirth-linking consciousness, which is a visitor to the material support, does not generate materiality because of the deficiency of a condition.

original: annapānagandhamālādīni dassāmī’ti vattuṃ na sakkoti, attano avisayatāya appahutatāya,
analyzed: anna pāna gandha mālā ādīni dassāmi iti vattum na sakkoti attanaḥ avisaya tāya appahuta tāya
translated: He cannot say, “I will give you food, drink, scents, garlands, etc.,” because they are not within his province, they are not his province.

original: evameva paṭisandhicittaṃ āgantukanti attano āgantukatāyapi rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: evam eva paṭisandhi cittam āgantukanti rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: So too, the rebirth-linking consciousness does not generate materiality because it is a visitor and because it is not the materiality’s province.

original: Apica samatiṃsa kammajarūpāni cittasamuṭṭhānarūpānaṃ ṭhānaṃ gahetvā ṭhitānītipi paṭisandhicittaṃ
analyzed: apica kamma ja rūpāni citta samuṭṭhāna rūpānam ṭhānam gahetvā ṭhitāni iti pi paṭisandhi cittam
translated: Besides, the thirty-two kinds of materiality due to kamma do not give place to the kinds due to consciousness.

original: rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: So the rebirth-linking consciousness does not generate materiality.

original: Khīṇāsavassa pana cuticittaṃ vaṭṭamūlassa vūpasantattā na samuṭṭhāpeti. Tassa hi
analyzed: khīṇāsavassa pana cuti cittam vaṭṭa mūlassa vūpasanta ttā na samuṭṭhāpeti tassa hi
translated: But the death consciousness of one whose cankers are destroyed does not generate materiality because the root of the round is stilled. For

original: sabbabhavesu vaṭṭamūlaṃ vūpasantaṃ abhabbuppattikaṃ punabbhave paveṇī nāma natthi.🔽Sotāpannassa pana satta bhave ṭhapetvā aṭṭhameva vaṭṭamūlaṃ vūpasantaṃ. Tasmā tassa
analyzed: sabba bhavesu vaṭṭa mūlam vūpasantam abhabbuppattikam punabbhave paveṇī nāma natthi  sotāpannassa pana satta bhave ṭhapetvā aṭṭham eva vaṭṭa mūlam vūpasantam tasmā tassa
translated: the root of the round is stilled in all kinds of becoming for him, and there is no more possibility of his arising again in any kind of becoming.🔽But for a stream-enterer the root of the round is stilled in seven kinds of becoming,🔽so his death consciousness generates materiality in seven kinds of becoming. For a once-returner it is stilled in two kinds of becoming,

original: cuticittaṃ sattasu bhavesu rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, sakadāgāmino dvīsu, anāgāmino ekasmiṃ.
analyzed: cuti cittam sattasu bhavesu rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti sakadāgāminaḥ dvīsu anāgāminaḥ ekasmin
translated: and for a non-returner in one kind.

original: Khīṇāsavassa sabbabhavesu vaṭṭamūlassa vūpasantattā neva samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: khīṇa āsavassa sabba bhavesu vaṭṭa mūlassa vūpasanta ttā na iva samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: But for one whose cankers are destroyed it is stilled in all kinds of becoming, so his death consciousness does not generate materiality.

original: Dvipañcaviññāṇesu pana jhānaṅgaṃ natthi, maggaṅgaṃ natthi, hetu natthīti cittaṅgaṃ
analyzed: dvi pañca viññāṇesu pana jhāna aṅgam natthi magga aṅgam natthi hetu natthi iti citta aṅgam
translated: But in the five pairs of sense-sphere consciousness and in the two kinds of fine-material-sphere consciousness there is no jhāna factor, no path factor, and no cause,🔽so the consciousness factor is weak. Because of the weakness of the consciousness factor, they do not generate materiality.

original: dubbalaṃ hotīti cittaṅgadubbalatāya tāni rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpenti. Cattāri arūpavipākāni
analyzed: dubbalam hoti iti cittaṅga dubbala tāya tāni rūpam na samuṭṭhāpenti cattāri arūpa vipākāni
translated: The four kinds of immaterial-sphere resultant consciousness

original: tasmiṃ bhave rūpassa natthitāya rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpenti. Na kevalañca tāneva, yāni
analyzed: tasmin bhave rūpassa na atthitāya rūpam na samuṭṭhāpenti na kevalam ca tāni eva yāni
translated: do not generate materiality because there is no materiality in that existence.🔽And not only those, but also the other forty-two kinds of consciousness that arise in that existence, namely,

original: aññānipi tasmiṃ bhave aṭṭha kāmāvacarakusalāni, dasa akusalāni, nava kiriyacittāni,
analyzed: aññāni pi tasmin bhave aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusalāni dasa akusalāni nava kiriya cittāni
translated: the eight kinds of sense-sphere profitable, the ten kinds of unprofitable, the nine kinds of indeterminate,

original: cattāri āruppakusalāni, catasso āruppakiriyā, tīṇi maggacittāni, cattāri phalacittānīti
analyzed: cattāri āruppa kusalāni catasso āruppa kiriyā tīṇi magga cittāni cattāri phala cittāni iti
translated: the four kinds of fine-material-sphere profitable, the four kinds of fine-material-sphere functional, the three kinds of path consciousness, and the four kinds of fruition consciousness,

original: dvecattālīsa cittāni uppajjanti, tānipi tattha rūpassa natthitāya eva rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpenti.
analyzed: dvecattālīsa cittāni uppajjanti tāni pi tattha rūpassa natthitāya eva rūpam na samuṭṭhāpenti
translated: do not generate materiality because there is no materiality there.

original: Evaṃ paṭisandhicittaṃ rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: evam paṭisandhi cittam rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: So rebirth-linking consciousness does not generate materiality.

original: Utu pana paṭhamaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Ko esa utu nāmāti? Paṭisandhikkhaṇe uppannānaṃ
analyzed: utu pana paṭhamam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti kaḥ esa utu nāma ati paṭisandhi khaṇe uppannānam
translated: But temperature does generate materiality first. What is this “temperature”?

original: samatiṃsakammajarūpānaṃ abbhantarā tejodhātu. Sā ṭhānaṃ patvā aṭṭha rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: sama tiṃsa kamma ja rūpānam abbhantarā tejodhātu sā ṭhānam patvā aṭṭha rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: The fire element inside the thirty-two-fold and sixteen-fold kinds of materiality. When it has reached the place, it generates eight kinds of materiality.

original: Utu nāma cesa dandhanirodho; cittaṃ khippanirodhaṃ. Tasmiṃ dharanteyeva soḷasa cittāni🔽uppajjitvā nirujjhanti. Tesu paṭisandhianantaraṃ paṭhamabhavaṅgacittaṃ uppādakkhaṇeyeva🔽aṭṭha rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti. Yadā pana saddassa uppattikālo bhavissati, tadā utucittāni
analyzed: nāma ca isa dandha nirodho cittam khippa nirodham tasmin dharanteya iva soḷasa cittāni  uppajjitvā nirujjhanti tesu paṭisandhi anantaram paṭhama bhavaṅga cittam uppāda kkhaṇe yeva  aṭṭha rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti yadā pana saddassa uppatti kālaḥ bhavissati tadā utu cittāni
translated: The temperature is slow in ceasing, but the consciousness is quick in ceasing. While it is occurring, sixteen kinds of consciousness🔽arise and cease. Among them, the first life-continuum consciousness that arises next to the rebirth-linking consciousness generates eight kinds of materiality at the moment of its arising.

original: saddanavakaṃ nāma samuṭṭhāpessanti. Kabaḷīkārāhāropi ṭhānaṃ patvā aṭṭha rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: sadda navakam nāma samuṭṭhāpessanti kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ api ṭhānam patvā aṭṭha rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: But when the time comes for the sound to arise, then the temperature and the consciousness will generate the sound ennead. The nutritive essence derived from gross or fine food, when it has reached the place, generates eight kinds of materiality.

original: Kuto panassa kabaḷīkārāhāroti? Mātito. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: kutas panassa kabaḷīkāra āhāro ti mātitaḥ vuttam pi ca itam
translated: But where does its food come from? From the mother. And this is said:

original: “Yañcassa bhuñjatī mātā, annaṃ pānañca bhojanaṃ;
analyzed: yat ca assa bhuñjatī mātā annam pānam ca bhojanam
translated: “Whatever food and drink the mother takes,

original: Tena so tattha yāpeti, mātukucchigato naro”ti. ;
analyzed: tena saḥ tattha yāpeti mātukucchi gataḥ
translated: Thereby the child in the womb is nourished.”

original: Evaṃ kucchigato dārako mātarā ajjhohaṭaannapānaojāya yāpeti. Sāva ṭhānappattā aṭṭha
analyzed: evam kucchi gataḥ dārakaḥ mātarā ajjhohaṭa anna pāna ojāya yāpeti sā ava ṭhāna ppattā aṭṭha
translated: So the child in the womb is nourished by the nutritive essence in the food and drink the mother takes. And that, when it has reached the place, generates eight kinds of materiality.

original: rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti. Nanu ca sā ojā kharā? Vatthu sukhumaṃ? Kathaṃ tattha patiṭṭhātīti?
analyzed: rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti nanu ca sā ojā kharā vatthu sukhumam katham tattha patiṭṭhāti iti
translated: But is not that nutriment coarse and the physical basis subtle? How does it find support there?

original: Paṭhamaṃ tāva na patiṭṭhāti; ekassa vā dvinnaṃ vā sattāhānaṃ gatakāle patiṭṭhāti.
analyzed: paṭhamam tāva na patiṭṭhāti ekassa vā dvinnam vā satta ahānam gata kāle patiṭṭhāti
translated: At first it does not find support. It finds support after the lapse of one or two weeks.

original: Tato pana pure vā patiṭṭhātu pacchā vā; yadā mātarā ajjhohaṭaannapānaojā dārakassa
analyzed: tatas pana pure vā patiṭṭhātu pacchā vā yadā mātarā ajjhohaṭa anna pāna ojāḥ dārakassa
translated: But whether it finds support earlier or later, when the nutriment in the form of food and drink swallowed by the mother finds support in the child’s body,

original: sarīre patiṭṭhāti, tadā aṭṭha rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti.🔽Opapātikassāpi pakatipaṭiyattānaṃ khādanīyabhojanīyānaṃ atthiṭṭhāne nibbattassa tāni🔽gahetvā ajjhoharato ṭhānappattā ojā rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Eko annapānarahite araññe🔽nibbattati, mahāchātako hoti, attanova jivhāya kheḷaṃ parivattetvā gilati. Tatrāpissa
analyzed: sarīre patiṭṭhāti tadā aṭṭha rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti  opapātikassa api pakati paṭiyattānam khādanīya bhojanīyānam atthi ṭṭhāne nibbattassa tāni  gahetvā ajjhoharataḥ ṭhāna ppattā ojā rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti ekaḥ anna pāna rahite araññe  nibbattati mahā chātakaḥ hoti attanā iva jivhāya kheḷam parivattetvā gilati tatra apissa
translated: then it generates the eight kinds of materiality.🔽And in the case of one who is supernaturally born, when he is born in a place where natural food consisting of solid and liquid nutriment exists, and he takes that, the nutriment that has reached presence generates materiality.

original: ṭhānappattā ojā rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: ṭhāna ppattā ojā rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: One is born in a wilderness devoid of food and drink. He is a giant boa constrictor. He swallows a man. Then the nutriment that has reached presence generates materiality in him.

original: Evaṃ pañcavīsatiyā koṭṭhāsesu dveva rūpāni rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpenti – tejodhātu ca kabaḷīkārāhāro
analyzed: evam pañcavīsatiyā koṭṭhāsesu dve iva rūpāni rūpam samuṭṭhāpenti tejaḥ dhātu ca kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ
translated: Thus in the twenty-five modes of materiality two kinds of materiality generate materiality, namely, the fire element and physical nutriment.

original: ca. Arūpepi dveyeva dhammā rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpenti – cittañceva kammacetanā ca. Tattha
analyzed: ca arūpe pi dveyeva dhammā rūpam samuṭṭhāpenti cittam ca iva kamma cetanā ca tattha
translated: In the formless worlds two things produce materiality: mind and kamma-formation. Herein,

original: rūpaṃ uppādakkhaṇe ca bhaṅgakkhaṇe ca dubbalaṃ, ṭhānakkhaṇe balavanti ṭhānakkhaṇe🔽rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Cittaṃ ṭhānakkhaṇe ca bhaṅgakkhaṇe ca dubbalaṃ, uppādakkhaṇeyeva
analyzed: rūpam uppāda kkhaṇe ca bhaṅga kkhaṇe ca dubbalam ṭhāna kkhaṇe balavanti ṭhāna kkhaṇe  rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti cittam ṭhāna khaṇe ca bhaṅga khaṇe ca dubbalam uppāda kkhaṇe yeva
translated: materiality is weak at the moment of arising and at the moment of dissolution. It is strong at the moment of presence.🔽The moment of presence is the moment when it produces materiality. Mind is weak at the moment of presence and at the moment of dissolution. It is strong at the moment of arising.

original: balavanti uppādakkhaṇeyeva rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Kammacetanā niruddhāva paccayo hoti.
analyzed: balavanti uppāda kkhaṇe yeva rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti kamma cetanā niruddhā va paccayaḥ hoti
translated: The moment of arising is the moment when it produces materiality. The kamma-formation is a condition when it has ceased.

original: Atīte kappakoṭisatasahassamatthakepi hi āyūhitaṃ kammaṃ etarahi paccayo hoti. Etarahi
analyzed: atīte kappa koṭi sata sahassa matthake pi hi āyūhitam kammaṃ etarahi paccayaḥ hoti etarahi
translated: For even though it was performed a hundred thousand koṭis of eons ago, kamma is a condition for this present becoming. And kamma performed

original: āyūhitaṃ anāgate kappakoṭisatasahassapariyosānepi paccayo hotīti. Evaṃ ‘pubbāparato’ veditabbā.
analyzed: āyūhitam anāgate kappa koṭi sata sahassa pariyosāne pi paccayaḥ hoti iti evam pubba aparatas veditabbā
translated: now will be a condition for the future a hundred thousand koṭis of eons hence. This is how it should be understood “in terms of prior and subsequent.”

original: ‘Addhānaparicchedato’ti rūpaṃ kittakaṃ addhānaṃ tiṭṭhati? Arūpaṃ kittakanti? Rūpaṃ
analyzed: addhāna paricchedataḥ ti rūpam kittakam addhānam tiṭṭhati arūpam kittakam ti rūpam
translated: “In terms of the delimitation of the extent”: How long does materiality last? How long does the immaterial last?

original: garupariṇāmaṃ dandhanirodhaṃ. Arūpaṃ lahupariṇāmaṃ khippanirodhaṃ. Rūpe dharanteyeva
analyzed: garu pariṇāmam dandha nirodham arūpam lahu pariṇāmam khippa nirodham rūpe
translated: Materiality has a long process of evolution and a slow dissolution. The immaterial has a quick process of evolution and a quick dissolution.🔽As long as materiality lasts,

original: soḷasa cittāni uppajjitvā nirujjhanti. Taṃ pana sattarasamena cittena saddhiṃ nirujjhati.
analyzed: soḷasa cittāni uppajjitvā nirujjhanti tam pana sattarasamena cittena saddhim nirujjhati
translated: and sixteen consciousnesses arise and cease. But it ceases together with the seventeenth consciousness.

original: Yathā hi puriso ‘phalaṃ pātessāmī’ti muggarena rukkhasākhaṃ pahareyya, phalāni ca
analyzed: yathā hi purisaḥ phalam pātessāmi iti muggarena rukkha sākham pahareyya phalāni ca
translated: Just as when a man strikes a tree with a sling-stone in order to make the fruit fall, and the fruit

original: pattāni ca ekakkhaṇeyeva vaṇṭato mucceyyuṃ. Tattha phalāni attano bhārikatāya paṭhamataraṃ🔽pathaviyaṃ patanti, pattāni lahukatāya pacchā. Evameva muggarappahārena pattānañca🔽phalānañca ekakkhaṇe vaṇṭato muttakālo viya paṭisandhikkhaṇe rūpārūpadhammānaṃ ekakkhaṇe
analyzed: pattāni ca vaṇṭataḥ mucceyyum tattha phalāni attanaḥ bhārika tāya paṭhamataram  pathaviyam patanti pattāni lahuka tāya pacchā evam eva muggara ppahārena pattānam ca  phalānaṃ ca eka kkhaṇe vaṇṭataḥ mutta kālaḥ viya paṭisandhi kkhaṇe rūpa arūpa dhammānam eka kkhaṇe
translated: and the leaves fall to the ground at the same time, there the fruit, because of its greater weight,🔽falls to the ground first, and the leaves afterwards because of their lightness. So too, just as the time of the falling of the leaves and the fruit from the stalk is simultaneous with the blow from the sling-stone,

original: pātubhāvo; phalānaṃ bhārikatāya paṭhamataraṃ pathaviyaṃ patanaṃ viya rūpe dharanteyeva
analyzed: pātubhāvaḥ bhārikatāya paṭhamataram pathaviyam patanam rūpe
translated: so too, the manifestation of the material and immaterial dhammas is simultaneous with the arising of the rebirth-linking consciousness. Just as the falling of the fruit to the ground first because of its greater weight,

original: soḷasannaṃ cittānaṃ uppajjitvā nirujjhanaṃ; pattānaṃ lahukatāya pacchā pathaviyaṃ
analyzed: cittānam uppajjitvā nirujjhanam pattānam lahuka tāya pacchā pathaviyam
translated: and the falling of the leaves afterwards because of their lightness, is so the arising and ceasing of the sixteen consciousnesses while the materiality persists,

original: patanaṃ viya rūpassa sattarasamena cittena saha nirujjhanaṃ.
analyzed: patanam viya rūpassa sattarasamena cittena saha nirujjhanam
translated: and the ceasing of the materiality together with the seventeenth consciousness afterwards.

original: Tattha kiñcāpi rūpaṃ dandhanirodhaṃ garupariṇāmaṃ, cittaṃ khippanirodhaṃ lahupariṇāmaṃ,🔽rūpaṃ pana arūpaṃ arūpaṃ vā rūpaṃ ohāya pavattituṃ na sakkonti. Dvinnampi ekappamāṇāva🔽pavatti. Tatrāyaṃ upamā – eko puriso lakuṇṭakapādo, eko dīghapādo. Tesu ekato maggaṃ
analyzed: tattha kiñca api rūpam dandha nirodham garu pariṇāmam cittam khippa nirodham lahu pariṇāmam  rūpam pana arūpam arūpam vā rūpam ohāya pavattitum na sakkonti dvinnam pi eka ppamāṇā ava  upamā ekaḥ puriso lakuṇṭaka pādo ekaḥ dīgha pādo tesu ekatas maggam
translated: Herein, although materiality has slow cessation and slow transformation, and consciousness has quick cessation and quick transformation,🔽still neither is able to occur without the other. The occurrence of both is of one and the same extent. Here is a simile. A lame man and a blind man were friends. The lame man’s legs were sound for walking but his eyes were no good for seeing, while the blind man’s eyes were sound for seeing but his legs were no good for walking. The lame man mounted on the blind man’s shoulders and they became able to walk and see. So they went on a journey together.

original: gacchantesu yāva dīghapādo ekapadavāraṃ akkamati, tāva itaro pade padaṃ akkamitvā
analyzed: gacchantesu yāva dīgha pādaḥ eka pada vāram akkamati tāva itaraḥ pade padam akkamitvā
translated: As long as the blind man took one step with his leg, the lame man took one step with his leg.

original: soḷasapadavārena gacchati. Dīghapādo lakuṇṭakapādassa soḷasa padavāre attano pādaṃ🔽añchitvā ākaḍḍhitvā ekameva padavāraṃ karoti. Iti ekopi ekaṃ atikkamituṃ na sakkoti.🔽Dvinnampi gamanaṃ ekappamāṇameva hoti. Evaṃsampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Lakuṇṭakapādapuriso
analyzed: soḷasa pada vārena gacchati dīgha pādaḥ lakuṇṭaka pādassa soḷasa pada vāre attano pādam  añchitvā ākaḍḍhitvā ekam eva padavāram karoti iti ekaḥ api ekam atikkamitum na sakkoti  dvinnam pi gamanam eka ppamāṇam eva hoti evaṃsampadam idam daṭṭhabbam lakuṇṭaka pāda puriso
translated: The blind man, after taking sixteen steps with his feet, took one step with his feet after stretching and bending the lame man’s feet.🔽So neither was able to outstrip the other.🔽The walking of both was of one and the same extent. This is how it should be regarded. The blind man is like the immaterial states; the lame man is like materiality; the time when the blind man takes one step with his feet is like the time when materiality occurs with the immaterial states;

original: viya arūpaṃ; dīghapādapuriso viya rūpaṃ; dīghapādassa ekaṃ padavāraṃ akkamaṇakāle
analyzed: viya arūpam dīgha pāda purisaḥ viya rūpam dīgha pādassa ekam pada vāram akkamaṇa kāle
translated: the time when the blind man takes sixteen steps with his feet after stretching and bending the lame man’s feet is like the time when the immaterial states occur with materiality.

original: itarassa soḷasapadavāraakkamanaṃ viya rūpe dharanteyeva arūpadhammesu soḷasannaṃ🔽cittānaṃ uppajjitvā nirujjhanaṃ; dvinnaṃ purisānaṃ lakuṇṭakapādapurisassa soḷasa
analyzed: itarassa viya rūpe arūpa dhammesu  cittānam uppajjitvā nirujjhanam dvinnam purisānam lakuṇṭakapāda purisassa soḷasa
translated: and the other’s going in sixteen steps, so it is with the sixteen kinds of consciousness in the immaterial states that the material states go on occurring.

original: padavāre itarassa attano pādaṃ añchitvā ākaḍḍhitvā ekapadavārakaraṇaṃ viya rūpassa🔽sattarasamena cittena saddhiṃ nirujjhanaṃ; dvinnaṃ purisānaṃ aññamaññaṃ anohāya ekappamāṇeneva
analyzed: padavāre itarassa attano pādam añchitvā ākaḍḍhitvā eka padavāra karaṇam viya rūpassa  sattarasamena cittena saddhim nirujjhanam dvinnam purisānam aññamaññam anohāya eka ppamāṇena iva
translated: and the other’s going in sixteen steps by dragging along his foot, so it is with the material states that they cease together with the seventeenth kind of consciousness.

original: gamanaṃ viya arūpassa rūpaṃ rūpassa arūpaṃ anohāya ekappamāṇeneva pavattananti. Evaṃ
analyzed: gamanam viya arūpassa rūpam rūpassa arūpam anohāya eka pamāṇena iva evam
translated: and the two men go the same distance without one outstripping the other, so it is with the immaterial states and the material states that they occur the same distance without the immaterial states outstripping the material states or vice versa.

original: ‘addhānaparicchedato’ veditabbā.
analyzed: addhāna paricchedataḥ veditabbā
translated: This is how it should be understood as “determining the distance.”

original: ‘Ekuppādanānānirodhato’ti idaṃ pacchimakammajaṃ ṭhapetvā dīpetabbaṃ. Paṭhamañhi paṭisandhicittaṃ,
analyzed: eka uppāda nānā nirodhato ti idam pacchima kamma jam ṭhapetvā dīpetabbam paṭhamam hi paṭisandhi cittam
translated: As “arising together and ceasing together”: this should be illustrated except in the case of the last-in-life rebirth-linking consciousness. For the first consciousness is rebirth-linking;

original: dutiyaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ, tatiyaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ…pe… soḷasamaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ. Tesu ekekassa uppādaṭṭhitibhaṅgavasena
analyzed: dutiyam bhavaṅgam tatiyam bhavaṅgam pe soḷasamam bhavaṅgam tesu ekekassa uppāda ṭṭhiti bhaṅga vasena
translated: the second is life-continuum; the third is life-continuum … and so on up to … the sixteenth is life-continuum.🔽In these, the first consciousness arises, persists, and ceases, and the materiality that has the same arising, persistence, and cessation as the first consciousness arises, persists, and ceases with the first consciousness.

original: tayo tayo khaṇā. Tattha ekekassa cittassa tīsu tīsu khaṇesu samatiṃsa samatiṃsa kammajarūpāni🔽uppajjanti. Tesu paṭisandhicittassa uppādakkhaṇe samuṭṭhitaṃ kammajarūpaṃ sattarasamassa
analyzed: tayaḥ tayaḥ khaṇā tattha ekekassa cittassa tīsu tīsu khaṇesu samatiṃsa samatiṃsa kamma ja rūpāni  uppajjanti tesu paṭisandhi cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe samuṭṭhitam kamma ja rūpam sattarasamassa
translated: In each of these three moments there are thirty moments of kamma-born material instances.🔽Of these, the material instances born in the arising moment of the rebirth-linking consciousness cease in the arising moment of the seventeenth consciousness.

original: bhavaṅgacittassa uppādakkhaṇeyeva nirujjhati; ṭhitikkhaṇe samuṭṭhitaṃ ṭhitikkhaṇeyeva;
analyzed: bhavaṅga cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe yeva nirujjhati ṭhiti kkhaṇe samuṭṭhitam ṭhiti kkhaṇe yeva
translated: Those born in the life-continuum consciousness cease in the life-continuum moment.

original: bhaṅgakkhaṇe samuṭṭhitaṃ bhaṅgakkhaṇeyeva nirujjhati. Evaṃ dutiyabhavaṅgacittaṃ ādiṃ🔽katvā attano attano sattarasamena cittena saddhiṃ yojetvā nayo netabbo. Iti soḷasa
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe samuṭṭhitam bhaṅga kkhaṇe iya iva nirujjhati evam dutiya bhavaṅga cittam ādim  katvā attanaḥ attanaḥ sattarasamena cittena saddhim yojetvā nayaḥ netabbaḥ iti soḷasa
translated: Those born in the death moment cease in the death moment. So too, the second life-continuum consciousness should be taken as beginning the series.

original: tikā aṭṭhacattālīsa honti. Ayaṃ aṭṭhacattālīsakammajarūpapaveṇī nāma. Sā panesā rattiñca
analyzed: tikāḥ aṭṭhacattālīsa honti ayam aṭṭhacattālīsakammajarūpapaveṇī nāma sā panesā rattiñca
translated: The method should be extended in this way to the other sixteen consciousnesses. Thus there are forty-eight. This is called the “forty-eight-fold series of kamma-born material instances.”

original: divā ca khādantānampi bhuñjantānampi suttānampi pamattānampi nadīsoto viya ekantaṃ
analyzed: divā ca khādantānam pi bhuñjantānam pi suttānam pi pamattānam pi nadī sotaḥ viya ekantam
translated: But this series goes on uninterruptedly, like the current of a river, in one who eats and drinks, sleeps and is heedless, by day and by night.

original: pavattati yevāti. Evaṃ ‘ekuppādanānānirodhato’ veditabbā.
analyzed: pavattati yā iva ati evam eka uppāda nānā nirodhataḥ veditabbā
translated: This is how it should be understood as “having a single arising and a single cessation.”

original: ‘Nānuppādaekanirodhatā’ pacchimakammajena dīpetabbā. Tattha āyusaṃkhārapariyosāne
analyzed: na anuppāda eka nirodha tā pacchima kamma jena dīpetabbā tattha āyu saṃkhāra pariyosāne
translated: ‘Not arisen and not ceased’ should be demonstrated by the last kamma-born (process). Herein, at the end of the life-continuum

original: soḷasannaṃ cittānaṃ vāre sati heṭṭhāsoḷasakaṃ uparisoḷasakanti dve ekato yojetabbāni.
analyzed: cittānam vāre sati heṭṭhā soḷasakam upari soḷasakanti dve ekatas yojetabbāni
translated: when there are sixteen thought-moments, the sixteen moments below and the sixteen moments above should be taken together.

original: Heṭṭhāsoḷasakasmiñhi paṭhamacittassa uppādakkhaṇe samuṭṭhitaṃ samatiṃsakammajarūpaṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhā soḷasakasmin hi paṭhamacittassa uppāda kkhaṇe samuṭṭhitam sama tiṃsa kamma ja rūpam
translated: In the sixteen moments below, the materiality born of kamma that arose at the moment of arising of the first thought-

original: uparisoḷasakasmiṃ paṭhamacittassa uppādakkhaṇeyeva nirujjhati; ṭhitikkhaṇe samuṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: upari soḷasakasmim paṭhama cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe yeva nirujjhati ṭhiti kkhaṇe samuṭṭhitam
translated: cesses at the moment of arising of the first thought in the sixteen moments above; that arisen at the moment of presence🔽cesses at the moment of presence; that arisen at the moment of dissolution

original: tassa ṭhitikkhaṇeyeva bhaṅgakkhaṇe samuṭṭhitaṃ tassa bhaṅgakkhaṇeyeva nirujjhati.
analyzed: tassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe yeva bhaṅga kkhaṇe samuṭṭhitam tassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe yeva nirujjhati
translated: cesses at the moment of dissolution.

original: Heṭṭhimasoḷasakasmiṃ pana dutiyacittassa…pe… soḷasamacittassa uppādakkhaṇe samuṭṭhitaṃ🔽samatiṃsakammajarūpaṃ cuticittassa uppādakkhaṇeyeva nirujjhati; tassa ṭhitikkhaṇe
analyzed: pana soḷasama cittassa pe soḷasama cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe samuṭṭhitam  sama tiṃsa kamma ja rūpam cuti cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe yeva nirujjhati tassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe
translated: But in the sixteen moments below, the materiality born of kamma that arose at the moment of arising of the second thought,🔽and so on, up to🔽that arisen at the moment of arising of the sixteenth thought🔽cesses at the moment of arising of the death consciousness; that arisen at the moment of presence🔽cesses at the moment of presence of the death consciousness; that arisen at the moment of dissolution

original: samuṭṭhitaṃ cuticittassa ṭhitikkhaṇeyeva; bhaṅgakkhaṇe samuṭṭhitaṃ cuticittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇeyeva
analyzed: samuṭṭhitam cuti cittassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe yeva bhaṅga kkhaṇe samuṭṭhitam cuti cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe yeva
translated: cesses at the moment of dissolution of the death consciousness.

original: nirujjhati. Tato paṭṭhāya kammajarūpapaveṇī na pavattati. Yadi pavatteyya, sattā
analyzed: nirujjhati tatas paṭṭhāya kamma ja rūpa paveṇī na pavattati yadi pavatteyya sattā
translated: and then ceases. From that time on the stream of kamma-born materiality does not occur. If it did,

original: akkhayā avayā ajarā amarā nāma bhaveyyuṃ.
analyzed: akkhayāḥ avayāḥ ajarāḥ amarāḥ nāma bhaveyyuṃ
translated: beings would be imperishable, undecaying, ageless and immortal.

original: Ettha pana yadetaṃ ‘sattarasamassa bhavaṅgacittassa uppādakkhaṇeyeva nirujjhatī’tiādinā
analyzed: ettha pana yat etam sattarasamassa bhavaṅga cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe iva nirujjhati iti ādinā
translated: But here it is said in the Paṭṭhāna Commentary in the passage beginning, “At the very moment of arising of the seventeenth life-continuum consciousness it ceases”

original: nayena ‘ekassa cittassa uppādakkhaṇe uppannaṃ rūpaṃ aññassa uppādakkhaṇe nirujjhatī’ti🔽aṭṭhakathāyaṃ āgatattā vuttaṃ, taṃ “yassa kāyasaṅkhāro nirujjhati, tassa cittasaṅkhāro🔽nirujjhatī”ti? “Āmantā”ti imāya pāḷiyā virujjhati. Kathaṃ? Kāyasaṅkhāro hi cittasamuṭṭhāno
analyzed: nayena ekassa cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe uppannam rūpam aññassa uppāda kkhaṇe nirujjhati iti  aṭṭhakathāyam āgata ttā vuttam tam yassa kāya saṅkhāro nirujjhati tassa citta saṅkhāro  nirujjhati iti āmantā ati imāya pāḷiyā virujjhati katham kāya saṅkhāraḥ hi citta samuṭṭhānaḥ
translated: and ending, “The materiality that has arisen at the moment of arising of one consciousness ceases at the moment of arising of another,”🔽that “materiality that has arisen at the moment of arising of one consciousness ceases at the moment of arising of another.” But this is contradicted by the text, “When there is cessation of bodily formation, is there cessation of mental formation, or …? Yes … ”

original: assāsapassāsavāto. Cittasamuṭṭhānarūpañca cittassa uppādakkhaṇe uppajjitvā yāva aññāni
analyzed: assāsa passāsa vātaḥ citta samuṭṭhāna rūpañca cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe uppajjitvā yāva aññāni
translated: How? For bodily formation is the in-breath and out-breath, which is the materiality originated by consciousness. And that materiality originated by consciousness arises at the moment of arising of the consciousness and continues as long as the next sixteen moments of consciousness arise.

original: soḷasa cittāni uppajjanti tāva tiṭṭhati. Tesaṃ soḷasannaṃ sabbapacchimena saddhiṃ
analyzed: soḷasa cittāni uppajjanti tāva tiṭṭhati tesam soḷasannam sabbapacchimena saddhiṃ
translated: With the last of those sixteen it ceases.

original: nirujjhati. Iti yena cittena saddhiṃ uppajjati, tato paṭṭhāya sattarasamena saddhiṃ🔽nirujjhati; na kassaci cittassa uppādakkhaṇe vā ṭhitikkhaṇe vā nirujjhati, nāpi ṭhitikkhaṇe
analyzed: nirujjhati iti yena cittena saddhim uppajjati tatas paṭṭhāya sattarasamena saddhim  nirujjhati na kassaci cittassa uppāda khaṇe vā ṭhiti khaṇe vā nirujjhati na api ṭhiti khaṇe
translated: It ceases together with the mind with which it arises. Thus it ceases together with the seventeenth.

original: vā bhaṅgakkhaṇe vā uppajjati. Esā cittasamuṭṭhānarūpassa dhammatāti niyamato cittasaṅkhārena
analyzed: vā bhaṅga kkhaṇe vā uppajjati esā citta samuṭṭhāna rūpassa dhamma tā ati niyamataḥ citta saṅkhārena
translated: It does not cease at the moment of arising or at the moment of presence of any mind. Nor does it arise at the moment of presence or at the moment of dissolution of any mind. This is the nature of materiality originated by consciousness.

original: saddhiṃ ekakkhaṇe nirujjhanato “āmantā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: saddhim eka khaṇe nirujjhanataḥ āmantā iti vuttam
translated: Thus it is said that it ceases together with the formation called mind, because it is definitely subject to cessation at the same moment as that.

original: Yo cāyaṃ cittasamuṭṭhānassa khaṇaniyamo vutto kammādisamuṭṭhānassāpi ayameva khaṇaniyamo.
analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam citta samuṭṭhānassa khaṇa niyamaḥ vuttaḥ kamma ādi samuṭṭhānassa api ayam eva khaṇa niyamaḥ
translated: And the rule for the moment of materiality originated by kamma, etc., is the same as this rule for the moment of that originated by consciousness.

original: Tasmā paṭisandhicittena sahuppannaṃ kammajarūpaṃ tato paṭṭhāya sattarasamena saddhiṃ🔽nirujjhati. Paṭisandhicittassa ṭhitikkhaṇe uppannaṃ aṭṭhārasamassa uppādakkhaṇe nirujjhati.
