analyzed: tasmā paṭisandhi cittena sahuppannam kamma ja rūpam tatas paṭṭhāya sattarasamena saddhiṃ  nirujjhati paṭisandhi cittassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe uppannam aṭṭhārasamassa uppāda kkhaṇe nirujjhati
translated: Therefore the materiality originated by kamma that arises together with the rebirth-linking consciousness ceases together with the seventeenth.🔽That arisen at the moment of presence of the rebirth-linking consciousness ceases at the moment of arising of the eighteenth.

original: Paṭisandhicittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe uppannaṃ aṭṭhārasamassa ṭhānakkhaṇe nirujjhatīti
analyzed: paṭisandhi cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe uppannam aṭṭhārasamassa ṭhāna kkhaṇe nirujjhati iti
translated: That arisen at the moment of dissolution of the rebirth-linking consciousness ceases at the moment of presence of the eighteenth.

original: iminā nayenettha yojanā kātabbā. Tato paraṃ pana utusamuṭṭhānikapaveṇīyeva tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: iminā nayena ittha yojanā kātabbā tatas param pana utu samuṭṭhānika paveṇīyā iva tiṭṭhati
translated: The interpretation should be extended in this way. But after that the line of reasoning is the same as that already given.

original: ‘Nīharitvā jhāpethā’ti vattabbaṃ hoti. Evaṃ ‘nānuppādaekanirodhato’ veditabbā.
analyzed: nīharitvā jhāpetha iti vattabbam hoti evam na anuppāda eka nirodhataḥ veditabbā
translated: ‘Take it out and burn it,’ he should be told. That is how it should be understood as ‘not to be discerned as to arising and as to dissolution.’

original: ‘Ekuppādaekanirodhato’ti rūpaṃ pana rūpena saha ekuppādaṃ ekanirodhaṃ. Arūpaṃ arūpena saha ekuppādaṃ ekanirodhaṃ. Evaṃ ‘ekuppādaekanirodhato’ veditabbā.🔽‘Nānuppādanānānirodhatā’ pana catusantatirūpena dīpetabbā. Imassa hi uddhaṃ pādatalā
analyzed: eka uppāda eka nirodhato ti rūpam pana rūpena saha ekuppādam eka nirodham arūpam arūpena saha ekuppādam eka nirodham evam eka uppāda eka nirodhataḥ veditabbā  na anuppāda nānā nirodha tā pana catu santati rūpena dīpetabbā imassa hi uddham pāda talā
translated: ‘As to one arising and one dissolution’: materiality arises together with materiality and dissolves together with it. Immateriality arises together with immateriality and dissolves together with it. That is how it should be understood ‘as to one arising and one dissolution.’

original: adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantassa sarīrassa tattha tattha catusantatirūpaṃ ghanapuñjabhāvena
analyzed: adho kesa matthakā taca pariyantassa sarīrassa tattha tattha catu santati rūpam ghana puñja bhāvena
translated: ‘As to not being discerned as to arising and as to dissolution’: this should be illustrated by the fourfold continuity of materiality. For in this body from the soles of the feet on up and from the tips of the hairs down wards, in the four modes of deportment, standing and so on, the fourfold continuity of materiality occurs in the form of a compact mass.

original: vattati. Evaṃ vattamānassāpissa na ekuppādāditā sallakkhetabbā. Yathā pana upacikarāji
analyzed: vattati evam vattamānassa api issa na eka uppāda ādi tā sallakkhetabbā yathā pana
translated: And while it is occurring in this way, it should not be taken as to its arising and so on. But just as a line of ants,🔽or a line of crows,

original: vā kipillikarāji vā olokiyamānā ekābaddhā viya hoti, na pana ekābaddhā. Aññissā hi
analyzed: vā kipillika rāji vā olokiyamānā ekābaddhā viya hoti na pana ekābaddhā aññissā hi
translated: though it appears as if it were one, is nevertheless not one but many, so too this materiality should not be taken as to its arising and so on.

original: sīsasantike aññissā sīsampi udarampi pādāpi, aññissā udarasantike aññissā sīsampi
analyzed: sīsa santike aññissā sīsam pi udaram pi pādā api aññissā udara santike aññissā sīsam pi
translated: and the head of one is next to the head of another, and the belly of one is next to the belly of another, and the feet of one are next to the feet of another,

original: udarampi pādāpi, aññissā pādasantike aññissā sīsampi udarampi pādāpi honti. Evameva
analyzed: udaram pi pādā api aññissā pāda santike aññissā sīsam pi udaram pi pādā api honti evam eva
translated: and the head of one is near the head of another, the belly of one is near the belly of another, the foot of one is near the foot of another.

original: catusantatirūpānampi aññassa uppādakkhaṇe aññassa uppādopi hoti ṭhitipi bhaṅgopi,🔽aññassa ṭhitikkhaṇe aññassa uppādopi hoti ṭhitipi bhaṅgopi, aññassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe
analyzed: catu santati rūpānam pi aññassa uppāda kkhaṇe aññassa uppādo api hoti ṭhiti pi bhaṅgo api  aññassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe aññassa uppādaḥ api hoti ṭhiti pi bhaṅgaḥ api aññassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe
translated: So too, in the case of the fourfold continuity, at the moment of arising of one of the four kinds of materiality there is arising, there is presence, there is dissolution, of another;

original: aññassa uppādopi hoti ṭhitipi bhaṅgopi. Evamettha ‘nānuppādanānānirodhatā’ veditabbā.
analyzed: aññassa uppādaḥ api hoti ṭhiti pi bhaṅgo api evam ettha na anuppāda nānā nirodha tā veditabbā
translated: at the moment of presence of one there is arising, there is presence, there is dissolution, of another; at the moment of dissolution of one there is arising, there is presence, there is dissolution, of another. This is how it should be understood that “there is no arising, presence, or dissolution of any single materiality.”

original: ‘Atītādīni’ pana dūradukapariyosānāni pāḷiyaṃ āgatāneva. ‘Paccayasamuṭṭhānāni’pi
analyzed: atīta ādīni pana dūra duka pariyosānāni pāḷiyam āgatāna eva paccaya samuṭṭhānāni pi
translated: As regards the past, etc., the text of the Abhidhamma should be quoted in full:

original: “kammajaṃ, kammapaccayaṃ, kammapaccayautusamuṭṭhāna”ntiādinā nayena heṭṭhā kathitāniyeva.
analyzed: kamma jam kamma paccayam kamma paccaya otu samuṭṭhāna nti ādinā nayena heṭṭhā kathitāniyā eva
translated: “Arisen from kamma, arisen from nutriment, arisen from temperature, arisen from kamma and nutriment, arisen from kamma and temperature, arisen from kamma and temperature and nutriment” , etc., as given above.

original: Pañcapi pana khandhā parinipphannāva honti, no aparinipphannā; saṅkhatāva no asaṅkhatā;
analyzed: pañca api pana khandhā parinipphannā ava honti no a parinipphannā saṅkhatā ava no a saṅkhatā
translated: But all the five aggregates are only “fully formed,” not “unformed”; they are only “formed,” not “unformed”;

original: apica nipphannāpi hontiyeva. Sabhāvadhammesu hi nibbānamevekaṃ aparinipphannaṃ anipphannañca.🔽Nirodhasamāpatti pana nāmapaññatti ca kathanti? Nirodhasamāpatti lokiyalokuttarāti
analyzed: apica nipphannā api sa bhāva dhammesu hi nibbānam eva ekam a parinipphannam a nipphannam ca  nirodha samāpatti pana nāma paññatti ca nirodha samāpatti lokiya lokuttarā ti
translated: Furthermore, they are also produced. For in the case of states that have individual essences, only Nibbāna is not produced and is not a product.

original: vā saṅkhatāsaṅkhatāti vā parinipphannāparinipphannāti vā na vattabbā. Nipphannā pana🔽hoti samāpajjantena samāpajjitabbato. Tathā nāmapaññatti. Sāpi hi lokiyādibhedaṃ
analyzed: vā saṅkhatā asaṅkhatā ati vā parinipphannā aparinipphannā ati vā na vattabbā nipphannā pana  hoti samāpajjantena samāpajjitabbataḥ tathā nāma paññatti sā api hi lokiya ādi bhedam
translated: But is the attainment of cessation a designation? It is not to be spoken of as mundane or supramundane, or as formed or unformed, or as produced or unproduced.🔽But it is produced, not unproduced, because it must be attained by one who attains it. So too with the designation. For that is not classifiable as mundane, and so on,

original: na labhati; nipphannā pana hoti no anipphannā; nāmaggahaṇañhi gaṇhantova gaṇhātīti.
analyzed: na labhati nipphannā pana hoti no a nipphannā nāma ggahaṇam hi gaṇhantaḥ iva gaṇhāti iti
translated: but it is produced, not unproduced; for the apprehension of a name is the apprehension of one who apprehends.

original: Kamādivinicchayakathā
translated: The exposition of the analysis of sense desires, etc.,

original: Evaṃ pakiṇṇakato khandhe viditvā puna etesuyeva –
analyzed: evam pakiṇṇakataḥ khandhe viditvā punar
translated: Having thus discerned the aggregates in detail, he should again discern them thus:🔽For the purpose of distinguishing knowledge of the aggregates,

original: Khandhesu ñāṇabhedatthaṃ, kamatotha visesato;
analyzed: khandhesu ñāṇa bheda attham kamataḥ tha visesataḥ
translated: By way of sense desires, and by way of distinction,

original: Anūnādhikato ceva, upamāto tatheva ca.
analyzed: ca iva upamātaḥ tathā iva ca
translated: And by way of not too many and not too few, and by way of simile, and likewise by way of

original: Daṭṭhabbato dvidhā evaṃ, passantassatthasiddhito;
analyzed: daṭṭhabbataḥ dvidhā evam passantassa attha siddhitaḥ
translated: How they should be seen, and by way of the two, and thus the purpose of seeing is fulfilled,

original: Vinicchayanayo sammā, viññātabbo vibhāvinā.
analyzed: vinicchaya nayaḥ sammā viññātabbaḥ vibhāvinā
translated: The method of exposition should be properly understood by one who explains.

original: Tattha ‘kamato’ti idha uppattikkamo, pahānakkamo, paṭipattikkamo, bhūmikkamo, desanākkamoti bahuvidho kamo.
analyzed: tattha kamataḥ ti idha uppatti kkamaḥ pahāna kkamaḥ paṭipatti kkamaḥ bhūmi kkamaḥ desanā kkamaḥ iti bahuvidho kamo
translated: Herein, “in order” is a kind of order, which is of several kinds, as order of arising, order of abandoning, order of practice, order of plane, and order of teaching.

original: Tattha “paṭhamaṃ kalalaṃ hoti, kalalā hoti abbuda”nti evamādi uppattikkamo. “Dassanena🔽pahātabbā dhammā, bhāvanāya pahātabbā dhammā”ti evamādi pahānakkamo. “Sīlavisuddhi,
analyzed: tattha paṭhamam kalalam hoti kalalāḥ hoti evamādi uppatti kkamaḥ dassanena  pahātabbāḥ dhammā bhāvanāya pahātabbāḥ dhammā ti evamādi pahāna kkamaḥ sīla visuddhi
translated: Herein, the order of arising is the order in which dhammas arise, beginning with the kalala stage, which is as follows: “First there is kalala, then abbuda, then pesi, then ghana, then atthibhāva, then chava, then chavimatthaluṅga, then matthaluṅga, then head-hairs, body-hairs, nails, teeth, skin, and so on. ”🔽The order of abandoning is the order in which dhammas are abandoned, which is as follows: “Dhammas to be abandoned by seeing, dhammas to be abandoned by development” , and so on.🔽The order of practice is the order in which dhammas are practised, which is as follows: “Purification of virtue, purification of consciousness” , and so on.

original: cittavisuddhī”ti evamādi paṭipattikkamo. “Kāmāvacarā, rūpāvacarā”ti evamādi bhūmikkamo.
analyzed: citta visuddhi iti evamādi paṭipatti kkamaḥ kāmāvacarā rūpāvacarā iti evamādi bhūmi kkamaḥ
translated: The order of plane is the order in which dhammas belong to a certain plane, which is as follows: “Sensuous-sphere dhammas, fine-material-sphere dhammas” , and so on.

original: “Cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, cattāro sammappadhānā”ti vā “dānakathaṃ sīlakatha”nti vā evamādi🔽desanākkamo. Tesu idha uppattikkamo tāva na yujjati, kalalādīnaṃ viya khandhānaṃ
analyzed: cattāro sati paṭṭhānā cattāro sammappadhānā ti vā dāna katham sīla kathanti vā evamādi  desanā kkamaḥ tesu idha uppatti kkamaḥ tāva na yujjati kalala ādīnam viya khandhānam
translated: The order of teaching is the order in which dhammas are taught, which is as follows: “The four foundations of mindfulness, the four right endeavours” , or “Talk on giving, talk on virtue” , and so on.

original: pubbāpariyavavatthānena anuppattito; na pahānakkamo kusalābyākatānaṃ appahātabbato;
analyzed: pubba apariya vavatthānena anuppattitaḥ na pahāna kkamaḥ kusala abyākatānam a pahātabbato
translated: Herein, the order of arising is not appropriate, because the aggregates do not arise in the order in which the kalala, etc., do; nor is the order of abandoning appropriate, because the profitable and indeterminate dhammas are not to be abandoned;

original: na paṭipattikkamo akusalānaṃ appaṭipajjanīyato; na bhūmikkamo vedanādīnaṃ catubhūmakapariyāpannattā.🔽Desanākkamo pana yujjati. Abhedena hi yaṃ pañcasu khandhesu attaggāhapatitaṃ veneyyajanaṃ
analyzed: na paṭipatti kkamaḥ akusalānam a paṭipajjanīyataḥ na bhūmi kkamaḥ vedanā ādīnam catu bhūmaka pariyāpanna ttā  desanā kkamaḥ pana yujjati abhedena hi yam pañcasu khandhesu attaggāha patitam veneyya janam
translated: and not by order of plane, because feeling, etc., are included in all four planes.🔽But the order of teaching is appropriate. For the Blessed One, who is desirous of liberating the generation that has fallen into the view of self in the five aggregates,

original: samūhaghanavinibbhogadassanena attaggāhato mocetukāmo bhagavā hitakāmo tassa janassa🔽sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ cakkhuādīnampi visayabhūtaṃ oḷārikaṃ paṭhamaṃ rūpakkhandhaṃ desesi.
analyzed: samūha ghana vinibbhoga dassanena atta ggāhataḥ mocetu kāmaḥ bhagavā hita kāmaḥ tassa janassa  sukha ggahaṇa attham cakkhu ādīnam pi visaya bhūtam oḷārikam paṭhamam rūpakkhandham desesi
translated: and who is benevolent towards that generation, teaches the five aggregates in the order in which he surveys them, that is, in the order in which he first surveyed them, in order to show the generation that has fallen into the view of self in the five aggregates the mere mass as a mass and to liberate it from the view of self.🔽So first he taught the material form aggregate, which is gross and the object of the eye, etc.,🔽Then he taught the feeling aggregate, which is the experiencing of desirable and undesirable material form, etc.,

original: Tato iṭṭhāniṭṭharūpasaṃveditaṃ vedanaṃ, yaṃ vedayati taṃ sañjānātīti evaṃ vedanāvisayassa
analyzed: tatas iṭṭha aniṭṭha rūpa saṃveditam vedanam yam vedayati tam sañjānāti iti evam vedanā visayassa
translated: and the perception aggregate, which is the apprehending of the aspect of the object, as being the condition for the object’s being experienced as desirable or undesirable,🔽and the formations aggregate, which is the determining of the object, as being the condition for the occurrence of the various kinds of determinations,

original: ākāraggāhikaṃ saññaṃ, saññāvasena abhisaṅkhārake saṅkhāre, tesaṃ vedanādīnaṃ nissayaṃ🔽adhipatibhūtañca viññāṇanti evaṃ tāva ‘kamato’ vinicchayanayo viññātabbo.
analyzed: ākāraggāhikam saññam saññā vasena abhisaṅkhārake saṅkhāre tesam vedanā ādīnam nissayam 🔽adhipati bhūtam ca viññāṇan ti evam tāva kamataḥ vinicchaya nayaḥ viññātabbo
translated: and the consciousness aggregate, which is the support of feeling, etc., and is the dominant condition for them.

original: ‘Visesato’ti khandhānañca upādānakkhandhānañca visesato. Ko pana tesaṃ viseso? Khandhā tāva avisesato vuttā, upādānakkhandhā sāsavaupādānīyabhāvena visesetvā. Yathāha –
analyzed: visesato ti khandhānam ca upādāna khandhānam ca visesato kaḥ pana tesam visesaḥ khandhā tāva avisesataḥ vuttā upādāna khandhā sa āsava aupādānīya bhāvena visesetvā yathā āha
translated: ‘Especially’ means especially as regards the aggregates and the aggregates as objects of clinging. But what is the difference between them? The aggregates are stated without distinction, while the aggregates as objects of clinging are stated with the distinction of their being subject to cankers and liable to be clung to, according as it is said:

original: “Pañca, bhikkhave, khandhe desessāmi pañcupādānakkhandhe ca, taṃ suṇātha. Katame
analyzed: pañca bhikkhave khandhe desessāmi pañca upādāna khandhe ca tam suṇātha katame
translated: ‘Bhikkhus, I shall teach you the five aggregates and the five aggregates as objects of clinging. Listen and attend closely to what I shall say.

original: ca, bhikkhave, pañcakkhandhā? Yaṃ kiñci, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ…pe…🔽santike vā – ayaṃ vuccati, rūpakkhandho. Yā kāci vedanā…pe… yā kāci saññā…pe… ye
analyzed: ca bhikkhave pañca kkhandhāḥ yam kiñci bhikkhave rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam pe santike vā ayam vuccati rūpa kkhandho yā kāci vedanā pe yā kāci saññā pe ye
translated: And what, bhikkhus, are the five aggregates? Whatever kind of materiality there is, bhikkhus, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—having thus comprehended the whole of materiality with understanding, a bhikkhu should continue: ‘This is all materiality’: thus he should continue in such a way that his consciousness does not become excited.

original: keci saṅkhārā…pe… yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ …pe… santike vā – ayaṃ vuccati, viññāṇakkhandho.
analyzed: keci yam kiñci viññāṇam pe santike vā ayam vuccati viññāṇa khandho
translated: Whatever kind of feeling there is … Whatever kind of perception there is … Whatever kind of formations there are … Whatever kind of consciousness there is, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—having thus comprehended the whole of consciousness with understanding, a bhikkhu should continue: ‘This is all consciousness’: thus he should continue in such a way that his consciousness does not become excited.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, pañcakkhandhā. Katame ca, bhikkhave, pañcupādānakkhandhā?
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave pañca khandhāḥ katame ca bhikkhave pañca upādāna kkhandhāḥ
translated: These, bhikkhus, are called the five aggregates. And what, bhikkhus, are the five aggregates as objects of clinging?

original: Yaṃ kiñci, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ…pe… santike vā sāsavaṃ upādāniyaṃ – ayaṃ vuccati, rūpūpādānakkhandho.
analyzed: yam kiñci bhikkhave santike vā sa āsavam upādāniyam ayam vuccati rūpa upādāna khandho
translated: Whatever kind of materiality there is, bhikkhus, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—having thus comprehended the whole of materiality with understanding, a bhikkhu should continue: ‘This is all materiality’: thus he should continue in such a way that his consciousness does not become excited.🔽And what, bhikkhus, is the materiality aggregate as object of clinging?

original: Yā kāci vedanā…pe… yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ…pe… santike vā sāsavaṃ upādāniyaṃ – ayaṃ vuccati,
analyzed: yā kāci vedanā pe yam kiñci viññāṇaṃpe santike vā sa āsavam upādāniyam ayam vuccati
translated: Whatever feelings… Whatever perceptions… Whatever volitions… Whatever consciousness… that is subject to cankers, that induces a sense of ‘mine’, that leads to grasping – this is called

original: bhikkhave, viññāṇupādānakkhandho. Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, pañcupādānakkhandhā”ti.🔽Ettha ca yathā vedanādayo anāsavāpi sāsavāpi atthi, na evaṃ rūpaṃ. Yasmā panassa🔽rāsaṭṭhena khandhabhāvo yujjati tasmā khandhesu vuttaṃ. Yasmā rāsaṭṭhena ca sāsavaṭṭhena🔽ca upādānakkhandhabhāvo yujjati tasmā upādānakkhandhesu vuttaṃ. Vedanādayo pana anāsavāva🔽khandhesu vuttā, sāsavā upādānakkhandhesu. ‘Upādānakkhandhā’ti ettha ca upādānagocarā
analyzed: bhikkhave viññāṇa upādānakkhandho ime vuccanti bhikkhave pañca upādānakkhandhā ti  ettha ca yathā vedanā ādayaḥ anāsavā api sa āsavā api atthi na evam rūpam yasmā panassa  rāsaṭṭhena khandha bhāvaḥ yujjati tasmā khandhesu vuttam yasmā rāsaṭṭhena ca sāsavaṭṭhena  ca upādāna kkhandha bhāvaḥ yujjati tasmai upādāna kkhandhesu vuttam vedanā ādayaḥ pana anāsavā va  khandhesu vuttā sāsavā upādāna khandhesu upādāna kkhandhā ti ettha ca upādāna gocarā
translated: Any kind of feeling … Any kind of perception … Any kind of formations … Any kind of consciousness that is subject to cankers, that is liable to the contaminants, is called the aggregate of consciousness as object of clinging. These are called the five aggregates as objects of clinging” .

original: khandhā upādānakkhandhāti evamattho daṭṭhabbo. Idha pana sabbepete ekajjhaṃ katvā🔽khandhāti adhippetā.
analyzed: khandhāḥ upādāna khandhā ti evamattho daṭṭhabbo idha pana sabbe pete ekajjham katvā 🔽khandhā ati adhippetā
translated: And here, just as feeling, etc., are both free from cankers and subject to cankers, so materiality is not. But since it is suitable as an aggregate in the sense of a heap, it is mentioned among the aggregates. And since it is suitable as an aggregate in the sense of a heap and in the sense of being subject to cankers, it is mentioned among the aggregates as objects of clinging. But feeling, etc., are mentioned among the aggregates only as free from cankers. And among the aggregates as objects of clinging only those subject to cankers are mentioned. And here the meaning should be regarded in this way: the aggregates that are the domain of clinging are aggregates as objects of clinging . But here all of them together are intended as “aggregates.”

original: ‘Anūnādhikato’ti kasmā pana bhagavatā pañceva khandhā vuttā anūnā anadhikāti? Sabbasaṅkhatasabhāgekasaṅgahato,
analyzed: anūna adhikato ti kasmā pana bhagavatā pañca iva khandhāḥ vuttāḥ anūnā anadhikā ati sabba saṅkhata sa bhāga eka saṅgahato
translated: Why are only five aggregates stated by the Blessed One as neither less nor more? Because of the inclusion of all that is formed by way of the components of its nature,

original: attattaniyaggāhavatthussa etapparamato, aññesañca tadavarodhato. Anekappabhedesu
analyzed: etad paramataḥ aññesam ca tad avarodhataḥ aneka ppabhedesu
translated: Because of the limit of the basis for the assumption of self and what pertains to self, and because of the inclusion of the rest under those.

original: hi saṅkhatadhammesu sabhāgavasena saṅgayhamānesu rūpaṃ rūpasabhāgasaṅgahavasena eko
analyzed: hi saṅkhata dhammesu sa bhāga vasena saṅgayhamānesu rūpam rūpa sabhāga saṅgaha vasena ekaḥ
translated: For when formed dhammas are included by way of their common characteristics, material form is one aggregate by the inclusion of all material form under the common characteristic of congealability.

original: khandho hoti, vedanā vedanāsabhāgasaṅgahavasena eko khandho hoti. Esa nayo saññādīsupi.
analyzed: khandhaḥ hoti vedanā vedanā sa bhāga saṅgaha vasena ekaḥ khandhaḥ hoti esa nayo saññā ādīsu pi
translated: Feeling is one aggregate by the inclusion of all feeling under the common characteristic of the experience of the object’s mode. Likewise perception, etc.,

original: Tasmā sabbasaṅkhatasabhāgasaṅgahato pañceva vuttā. Etaparamañcetaṃ attattaniyaggāhavatthu🔽yadidaṃ rūpādayo pañca. Vuttañhetaṃ – “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati rūpaṃ upādāya rūpaṃ
analyzed: pañca iva vuttāḥ atta tta niyaggāha vatthu  yat idam rūpa ādayaḥ pañca vuttam ha etam rūpe kho bhikkhave sati rūpam upādāya rūpam
translated: So they are stated as five because of the inclusion of all that is formed by way of the components of its nature. And this is the limit of the basis for the assumption of self and what pertains to self, that is to say, the five beginning with material form.🔽For this is said: “When there is material form, bhikkhus, dependent on material form, bound to material form, held by material form, the view arises: ‘This is mine, this I am, this is my self.’ When there is feeling …

original: abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati – ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti. Vedanāya…
analyzed: abhinivissa evam diṭṭhi uppajjati etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati vedanāya
translated: perception … volitional formations … consciousness …

original: saññāya… saṅkhāresu…. Viññāṇe sati viññāṇaṃ upādāya viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi
analyzed: saññāya saṅkhāresu viññāṇe sati viññāṇam upādāya viññāṇam abhinivissa evam diṭṭhi
translated: “With perception … “With (volitional) processes … “With consciousness, bhikkhus, when there is consciousness, it is because there is consciousness that the perception-and-view ‘I might exist’ occurs,

original: uppajjati – ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”’ti. Tasmā attattaniyaggāhavatthussa
analyzed: uppajjati etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati tasmai atta tta niyaggāha vatthussa
translated: “If consciousness exists, because of consciousness, dependent on consciousness, such a view arises: ‘This is my self, which has perception and is subject to continuation. It is this that I am; this is my self which is subject to continuation.’ “ Therefore, since the five beginning with perception are the basis for the self-theory of the eternalist, they are stated as the highest limit of the self-theory of the eternalist.

original: etaparamatopi pañceva vuttā. Yepi caññe sīlādayo pañca dhammakkhandhā vuttā, tepi
analyzed: pañca iva vuttāḥ ye pi caññe sīla ādayo pañca dhammakkhandhāḥ vuttā te pi
translated: And the other five aggregates beginning with virtue are included in the formations aggregate.

original: saṅkhārakkhandhapariyāpannattā ettheva avarodhaṃ gacchanti. Tasmā aññesaṃ tadavarodhatopi
analyzed: saṅkhāra kkhandha pariyāpanna ttā ettha iva avarodham gacchanti tasmai aññesam tad avarodhataḥ pi
translated: Therefore, since they are included in the five aggregates, they are stated as the highest limit of the self-theory of the eternalist.

original: pañceva vuttāti. Evaṃ ‘anūnādhikato’ vinicchayanayo viññātabbo.
analyzed: pañca iva vuttā ti evam anūnādhikataḥ vinicchaya nayaḥ viññātabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be known “in terms of no excess and no deficiency.”

original: ‘Upamāto’ti ettha hi gilānasālūpamo rūpupādānakkhandho gilānūpamassa viññāṇupādānakkhandhassa🔽vatthudvārārammaṇavasena nivāsanaṭṭhānato, gelaññūpamo vedanupādānakkhandho ābādhakattā,
analyzed: upamātaḥ ti ettha hi gilāna sālu upamaḥ rūpa upādāna kkhandhaḥ gilānu upamassa viññāṇa upādāna kkhandhassa  vatthu dvāra ārammaṇa vasena nivāsana ṭṭhānataḥ gelaññu upamaḥ vedanu pādānakkhandho ābādhaka ttā
translated: “In terms of similes”: the material form aggregate is the simile for the sick ward, and the consciousness aggregate is the simile for the sick man.🔽The material form aggregate is the sick ward in the sense of being the place of abode for the other aggregates, which are the sense doors and objects. The feeling aggregate is the simile for the sick man, because it is the one that is afflicted.

original: gelaññasamuṭṭhānūpamo saññupādānakkhandho kāmasaññādivasena rāgādisampayuttavedanāsambhavā,
analyzed: gelañña samuṭṭhāna upamaḥ saññu pādāna kkhandho kāma saññā ādi vasena rāga ādi sampayutta vedanā sambhavā
translated: The perception aggregate is the simile for the origin of the sick man’s affliction, because feeling associated with greed, etc., occurs through perception of sensual desire, etc.

original: asappāyasevanūpamo saṅkhārupādānakkhandho vedanāgelaññassa nidānattā. “Vedanaṃ vedanattāya
analyzed: saṅkhāra upādāna kkhandhaḥ vedanā gelaññassa nidāna ttā vedanam vedana ttāya
translated: The form aggregate as clinging is like the resort to what is unwholesome, because it is the source of the arrow of feeling. “They feel feeling as feeling”

original: saṅkhatamabhisaṅkharontī”ti hi vuttaṃ. Tathā “akusalassa kammassa katattā upacitattā
analyzed: saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharonti iti hi vuttam tathā akusalassa kammassa kata ttā upacita ttā
translated: (S V 21), it is said. And: “Because of the performance and accumulation of unwholesome kamma,

original: vipākaṃ kāyaviññāṇaṃ uppannaṃ hoti dukkhasahagata”nti. Gilānūpamo viññāṇupādānakkhandho
analyzed: vipākam kāya viññāṇam uppannam hoti dukkha sahagatan ti gilāna upamaḥ viññāṇa upādāna kkhandho
translated: consciousness accompanied by pain arises as its fruit” (S IV 200). The consciousness aggregate as clinging is like the sick man,

original: vedanāgelaññena aparimuttattā. Apica cārakakāraṇaaparādhakāraṇakārakaaparādhikūpamā
analyzed: vedanā gelaññena a parimutta ttā apica cāraka kāraṇa aparādha kāraṇa kāraka aparādhi kūpamā
translated: because he is not free from the arrow of feeling. Furthermore, they are like the cause of illness, the offender, the one who punishes, the offender,

original: ete bhājanabhojanabyañjanaparivesakabhuñjakūpamā cāti, evaṃ ‘upamāto’ vinicchayanayo viññātabbo.🔽‘Daṭṭhabbato dvidhā’ti saṅkhepato vitthārato cāti evaṃ dvidhā daṭṭhabbato pettha
analyzed: ete bhājana bhojana byañjana parivesaka bhuñjaka upamā ca ati evam upamātaḥ vinicchaya nayaḥ viññātabbo  daṭṭhabbataḥ dvidhā iti saṅkhepataḥ vitthārato ca ati evam dvidhā daṭṭhabbato pa ittha
translated: and they are like the vessel, the food, the seasoning, the server, and the eater. Thus the method of exposition should be known “by way of simile.”

original: vinicchayanayo viññātabbo. Saṅkhepato hi pañcupādānakkhandhā āsivisūpame vuttanayena
analyzed: vinicchaya nayaḥ viññātabbo saṅkhepataḥ hi pañca upādāna khandhāḥ āsi visūpame vutta nayena
translated: “As to be seen, twofold”: here the method of exposition should be known as to be seen in brief and in detail. For in brief the five aggregates as objects of clinging are like a snake,

original: ukkhittāsikapaccatthikato, bhārasuttavasena bhārato, khajjanīyapariyāyavasena khādakato,
analyzed: ukkhitta āsika paccatthikataḥ bhāra sutta vasena bhārataḥ khajjanīya pariyāya vasena khādakato
translated: like an assassin with upraised sword, like a pit of burning embers, like a dream, like borrowed goods, like a fruit-tree, like a slaughterhouse, like a fire-brand, like a spike of thorns, like a knife, like poison, like a famine, like a disease, like being bound, like a murder, like a robber, like a stake, like a disaster, like a burden, like a dart, like a prison, like slavery, like a desert, like a stump and snares, like a torrent, like a calamity, like a tribulation, like a beryl gem, like a flower, like a fruit, like a stage, like a grass-torch, like a dream, like a borrowed thing, like a stage performance, like a gathering place, like a city, like a shop, like a tree by the roadside, like a river, like a vehicle, like a staircase, like a throne, like a flower-pond, like a public house, like a cross-roads, like a shadow, like a flash of lightning, like a water-bubble, like a mirage, like a reflection of the moon in water, like a loan, like a flash of lightning, like a city of the Gandhabbas, like a conjuring trick, like a stage performance, like a dream, like a borrowed thing, like a stage performance, like a gathering place, like a city, like a shop, like a tree by the roadside, like a river, like a vehicle

original: yamakasuttavasena aniccadukkhānattasaṅkhatavadhakato daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: yamaka sutta vasena anicca dukkha anatta saṅkhata vadhakataḥ daṭṭhabbā
translated: They should be seen as impermanent, painful, not-self, formed, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, as stated in the Twin Verses.

original: Vitthārato panettha pheṇapiṇḍo viya rūpaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, udakapubbuḷo viya vedanā, marīcikā viya saññā, kadalikkhandho viya saṅkhārā, māyā viya viññāṇaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: vitthārato pana ittha pheṇa piṇḍaḥ viya rūpam daṭṭhabbam udaka pubbuḷaḥ viya vedanā marīcikā viya saññā kadali kkhandho viya saṅkhārāḥ māyā viya viññāṇam vuttam ha etam
translated: In detail, however, material form should be seen as like a lump of froth, feeling as like a bubble, perception as like a mirage, formations as like a plantain trunk, and consciousness as like a magic trick. For this is said:🔽“Material form is like a lump of froth, Feeling is like a bubble,

original: “Pheṇapiṇḍūpamaṃ rūpaṃ, vedanā pubbuḷūpamā;🔽Marīcikūpamā saññā, saṅkhārā kadalūpamā;
analyzed: pheṇa piṇḍu upamam rūpam vedanā pubbuḷu upamā  marīcikū upamā saññā saṅkhārā kadalūpamā
translated: Perception is like a mirage, Formations are like a plantain trunk,

original: Māyūpamañca viññāṇaṃ, desitādiccabandhunā”ti. ;🔽Tattha rūpādīnaṃ pheṇapiṇḍādīhi evaṃ sadisatā veditabbā – yathā hi pheṇapiṇḍo nissārova
analyzed: viññāṇam  tattha rūpa ādīnam pheṇa piṇḍa ādīhi evam sadisa tā veditabbā yathā hi pheṇa piṇḍaḥ nissāraḥ uva
translated: And consciousness is like a magic trick, So has the Kinsman of the Sun taught.”

original: evaṃ rūpampi niccasāradhuvasāraattasāravirahena nissārameva. Yathā ca so ‘iminā pattaṃ🔽vā thālakaṃ vā karissāmī’ti gahetuṃ na sakkā, gahitopi tamatthaṃ na sādheti bhijjateva;
analyzed: evam nicca sāra dhuva sāra atta sāra virahena nissāram eva yathā ca 🔽vā thālakam vā karissāmi iti gahetum na sakkā gahitaḥ api tam attham na sādheti bhijjatā iva
translated: Herein, the similarity between material form, etc., and a lump of froth, and the rest should be understood as follows. Just as a lump of froth, though it may be big, say, as big as a man’s body, is weak, flabby, and unsubstantial, so too this material form, whether it be the four great primaries or the materiality derived by clinging from the four great primaries, is weak, flabby, and unsubstantial, because it has no core of permanence, pleasure, self, or beauty.🔽And just as a lump of froth, though it may be as big as a man’s body, is not enough even for a single mouthful for a single man, so too this material form, though it may be as big as a man’s body, is not enough even for a single mouthful for the eye faculty, and it is not even enough for the eye consciousness element.🔽And just as a lump of froth, though it may be as big as a man’s body, is not worth taking a span in the hand to pick up, and if a man should take a span in the hand to pick it up, he would only get chaff and straw, so too this material form, though it may be as big as a man’s body, is not worth taking a span in the hand to pick up, and if anyone should take a span in the hand to pick it up, he would only get skin, sinews, and bone-membrane.

original: evaṃ rūpampi ‘nicca’nti vā ‘dhuva’nti vā ‘aha’nti vā ‘mama’nti vā gahetuṃ na sakkā,
analyzed: evam vā dhuvanti vā ahanti vā mamanti vā gahetum na sakkā
translated: and it cannot be grasped as permanent, lasting, eternal, blissful, or as self or as what belongs to a self.

original: gahitampi na tathā tiṭṭhati, aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattā asubhaññeva hotīti. Evaṃ ‘pheṇapiṇḍasadisameva’ hoti.
analyzed: gahitam pi na tathā tiṭṭhati aniccam dukkham anattā a subhaññā iva hoti iti evam pheṇa piṇḍa sadisam eva hoti
translated: And when it is grasped, it does not remain so grasped but becomes impermanent, painful, not-self, and foul. Thus it is like a lump of froth.

original: Yathā vā pana pheṇapiṇḍo chiddāvachiddo anekasandhighaṭito bahūnnaṃ udakasappādīnaṃ🔽pāṇānaṃ āvāso, evaṃ rūpampi chiddāvachiddaṃ anekasandhighaṭitaṃ. Kulavasena cettha
analyzed: yathā vā pana pheṇa piṇḍaḥ chidda avachiddaḥ aneka sandhi ghaṭitaḥ bahu udaka sappa ādīnam  evam rūpam pi chidda avachiddam aneka sandhi ghaṭitam kula vasena ca itthā
translated: Or just as a lump of froth is perforated, full of holes, and is the abode of many water-insects,

original: asīti kimikulāni vasanti. Tadeva tesaṃ sūtigharampi vaccakuṭipi gilānasālāpi susānampi.
analyzed: asi iti kimi kulāni vasanti tat eva tesam sūti gharampi vacca kuṭipi gilāna sālāpi susānampi
translated: so too is materiality perforated, full of holes, and is the abode of many families of worms. For eighty families of worms live in it. And it is their place of birth, their nursery, their playground, and their charnel ground.

original: Na te aññattha gantvā gabbhavuṭṭhānādīni karonti. Evampi pheṇapiṇḍasadisaṃ. Yathā
analyzed: na te aññattha gantvā gabbha vuṭṭhāna ādīni karonti evam pi pheṇa piṇḍa sadisam yathā
translated: They do not go elsewhere to be conceived, to be born, to play, or to die. Thus it is like a lump of froth.

original: ca pheṇapiṇḍo āditova badarapakkamatto hutvā anupubbena pabbatakūṭamattopi hoti,
analyzed: ca pheṇa piṇḍaḥ āditas va badara pakka mattaḥ hutvā anupubbena pabbata kūṭa mattaḥ api hoti
translated: And just as a lump of froth, starting from a small size, gradually grows,

original: evaṃ rūpampi ādito kalalamattaṃ hutvā anupubbena byāmamattampi gomahiṃsahatthiādīnaṃ
analyzed: evam rūpam pi āditas kalala mattam hutvā anupubbena byāma mattam pi go mahiṃsa hatthi ādīnam
translated: so too does materiality, starting from the small size of the kalala, grow gradually to the size of a fathom and more in the case of elephants, bulls, and so on.

original: vasena pabbatakūṭamattampi hoti, macchakacchapādīnaṃ vasena anekayojanasatappamāṇampi.🔽Evampi pheṇapiṇḍasadisaṃ. Yathā ca pheṇapiṇḍo uṭṭhitamattopi bhijjati, thokaṃ gantvāpi,🔽samuddaṃ patvā pana avassameva bhijjati; evameva rūpampi kalalabhāvepi bhijjati,
analyzed: vasena pabbata kūṭa mattam pi hoti maccha kacchapa ādīnam vasena aneka yojana sata ppamāṇam pi  evam pi pheṇa piṇḍa sadisam yathā ca pheṇa piṇḍaḥ uṭṭhita mattaḥ api bhijjati thokam gantvā api  samuddam patvā pana avassam eva bhijjati evam eva rūpam pi kalala bhāve pi bhijjati
translated: and by the fish, turtles, etc., it is many a hundred leagues in extent.🔽And just as the foam is like a bubble, so too is materiality. And just as the bubble bursts as soon as it appears and does not last long,

original: abbudādibhāve, antarā pana abhejjamānampi vassasatāyukānaṃ vassasataṃ patvā avassameva
analyzed: abbuda ādi bhāve antarā pana a bhejjamānam pi vassa sata āyukānam vassa satam patvā a vassam eva
translated: so too materiality breaks up in the embryonic stage of kalala, and so on. Although it does not break up in the interval, when it reaches the life-span of a hundred years it breaks up without fail

original: bhijjati, maraṇamukhe cuṇṇavicuṇṇaṃ hoti. Evampi pheṇapiṇḍasadisaṃ.🔽Yathā pana pubbuḷo asāro, evaṃ vedanāpi. Yathā ca so abalo, agayhupago, na sakkā🔽taṃ gahetvā phalakaṃ vā āsanaṃ vā kātuṃ, gahitaggahitopi bhijjateva; evaṃ vedanāpi
analyzed: bhijjati maraṇa mukhe cuṇṇa vicuṇṇam hoti evam pi pheṇa piṇḍa sadisam  yathā pana pubbuḷaḥ asāraḥ evam vedanā api yathā ca so abalaḥ a gayhupagaḥ na sakkā  tam gahetvā phalakam vā āsanam vā kātum bhijjatā iva evam vedanā api
translated: at death, and it is reduced to powder. So too is materiality like a bubble.🔽And just as the water-bubble is void and feeble, so too is feeling. And just as the water-bubble is feeble and cannot be used as a raft to cross over to the further bank,

original: abalā, agayhupagā, na sakkā ‘niccā’ti vā ‘dhuvā’ti vā gahetuṃ, gahitāpi na tathā
analyzed: abalāḥ a gayhupagāḥ na sakkāḥ vā dhuvāti vā gahetum gahitā api na tathā
translated: but breaks up whether one holds on to it or not, so too feeling is feeble and cannot be held to as permanent or lasting. Whether one holds on to it or not,🔽it breaks up and perishes.

original: tiṭṭhati. Evaṃ agayhupagatāyapi vedanā ‘pubbuḷasadisā’. Yathā pana tasmiṃ tasmiṃ🔽udakabindumhi pubbuḷo uppajjati ceva nirujjhati ca, na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti; evaṃ vedanāpi🔽uppajjati ceva nirujjhati ca, na ciraṭṭhitikā hoti, ekaccharakkhaṇe koṭisatasahassasaṅkhyā
analyzed: tiṭṭhati evam vedanā pubbuḷa sadisā yathā pana tasmin tasmin  udaka bindumhi pubbuḷaḥ uppajjati ca iva nirujjhati ca na cira ṭṭhitikaḥ hoti evam vedanā api  uppajjati ca iva nirujjhati ca na cira ṭṭhitikā hoti ekaccha rakkhaṇe koṭi sata sahassa saṅkhyā
translated: So feeling is like a bubble in that it does not last long.🔽And just as a bubble arises in a particular place in the water and disappears there too, and does not arise in one place and disappear somewhere else, so too feeling arises in a particular object and disappears there too, and it does not arise in one place and disappear somewhere else.

original: uppajjitvā nirujjhati. Yathā ca pubbuḷo udakatalaṃ, udakabinduṃ, udakajallakaṃ saṅkaḍḍhitvā🔽puṭaṃ katvā gahaṇavātañcāti cattāri kāraṇāni paṭicca uppajjati; evaṃ vedanāpi vatthuṃ,
analyzed: uppajjitvā nirujjhati yathā ca pubbuḷaḥ udaka talam udaka bindum udaka jallakam saṅkaḍḍhitvā  puṭam katvā gahaṇa vātam ca ati cattāri kāraṇāni paṭicca uppajjati evam vedanā api vatthum
translated: And just as a bubble arises and ceases in a single water drop, and does not last long enough to arise and cease in a hundred or a thousand drops, so too feeling arises and ceases in a single object moment, and it does not last long enough to arise and cease in a hundred or a thousand object moments.

original: ārammaṇaṃ, kilesajālaṃ, phassasaṅghaṭṭanañcāti cattāri kāraṇāni paṭicca uppajjati.🔽Evampi vedanā pubbuḷasadisā.
analyzed: ārammaṇam kilesa jālam phassa saṅghaṭṭanam ca ati cattāri kāraṇāni paṭicca uppajjati  evam pi vedanā pubbuḷa sadisā
translated: And just as a bubble arises in dependence on four conditions, that is to say, the water, the place in the water, the water spray, and the wind, so too feeling arises in dependence on four conditions, that is to say, the physical basis, the object, the defilements, and the contact impact.🔽So feeling is like a bubble in that it does not last long.🔽Perception is like a mirage in the sense of having no core.

original: Saññāpi asārakaṭṭhena ‘marīcisadisā’. Tathā agayhupagaṭṭhena; na hi sakkā taṃ gahetvā
analyzed: saññā api asārakaṭṭhena marīci sadisā tathā agayhupagaṭṭhena na hi sakkā tam gahetvā
translated: So too, it is like a mirage in that it does not last long.

original: pivituṃ vā nhāyituṃ vā bhājanaṃ vā pūretuṃ. Apica yathā marīci vipphandati, sañjātūmivego
analyzed: pivitum vā nhāyitum vā bhājanam vā pūretum apica yathā marīci vipphandati san jātu umi vegaḥ
translated: or to drink or bathe or fill a vessel.

original: viya khāyati; evaṃ nīlasaññādibhedā saññāpi nīlādianubhavanatthāya phandati vipphandati.
analyzed: viya khāyati evam nīla saññā ādi bhedā saññā api nīla ādi anubhavana tthāya phandati vipphandati
translated: Moreover, just as the mirage moves to and fro, so too perception moves to and fro, as it were, in order to experience blue, etc.,

original: Yathā ca marīci mahājanaṃ vippalambheti, ‘paripuṇṇavāpī viya paripuṇṇanadī viya dissatī’ti
analyzed: yathā ca marīci mahā janam vippalambheti paripuṇṇa vāpī viya paripuṇṇa nadī viya dissati iti
translated: Just as the mirage deceives people, making them say, “There is a pool of water,” “There is a river,”

original: vadāpeti; evaṃ saññāpi vippalambheti, ‘idaṃ nīlakaṃ subhaṃ sukhaṃ nicca’nti vadāpeti.
analyzed: vadāpa iti evam saññā api vippalambheti idam nīlakam subham sukham niccanti vadāpa iti
translated: so too perception deceives by making one say, “This blue is beautiful,” “This is pleasant,” “This is permanent,”🔽and so on in the case of yellow, etc.,

original: Pītakādīsupi eseva nayo. Evaṃ vippalambhanenāpi marīcisadisā.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ evam vippalambhanena api marīci sadisā
translated: Thus it is like a mirage in that it deceives.

original: Saṅkhārāpi asārakaṭṭhena ‘kadalikkhandhasadisā’. Tathā agayhupagaṭṭhena. Yatheva
analyzed: saṅkhārā api asārakaṭṭhena kadali kkhandha sadisā tathā agayhupagaṭṭhena yathā iva
translated: And formations are like a plantain trunk in the sense of having no core. So too in the sense of being unobtainable when sought.

original: hi kadalikkhandhato kiñci gahetvā na sakkā gopānasīādīnamatthāya upanetuṃ, upanītampi
analyzed: hi kadali kkhandhato kiñci gahetvā na sakkā gopānasī ādīnam atthāya upanetum upanītam pi
translated: For just as nothing can be obtained from a plantain trunk by seeking for it, and what is obtained is not to be found there,

original: na tathā hoti; evaṃ saṅkhārāpi na sakkā niccādivasena gahetuṃ, gahitāpi na tathā
analyzed: na tathā hoti evam saṅkhārā api na sakkā nicca ādi vasena gahetum gahitā api na tathā
translated: so too nothing can be obtained from formations by seeking for it in terms of permanence, etc., and what is obtained is not to be found there.

original: honti. Yathā ca kadalikkhandho bahuvaṭṭisamodhāno hoti, evaṃ saṅkhārakkhandhopi bahudhammasamodhāno.🔽Yathā ca kadalikkhandho nānālakkhaṇo, aññoyeva hi bāhirāya pattavaṭṭiyā vaṇṇo, añño
analyzed: honti yathā ca kadali kkhandhaḥ bahu vaṭṭi samodhānaḥ hoti evam saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ api bahu dhamma samodhānaḥ  yathā ca kadali kkhandhaḥ nānā lakkhaṇaḥ aññaḥ yā iva hi bāhirāya pattavaṭṭiyā vaṇṇaḥ aññaḥ
translated: And just as the plantain tree is a collection of many sheaths, so too the formations aggregate is a collection of many states.🔽And just as the plantain tree has many different characteristics, for the colour of the outer skin is one thing,

original: tato abbhantarabbhantarānaṃ; evameva saṅkhārakkhandhopi aññadeva phassassa lakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: evam eva saṅkhāra kkhandho pi aññat eva phassassa lakkhaṇaṃ
translated: and the colour of the inner skin is another, so too the formations aggregate has the characteristics of contact, volition, etc.,

original: aññaṃ cetanādīnaṃ. Samodhānetvā pana saṅkhārakkhandhotveva vuccatīti. Evampi saṅkhārakkhandho
analyzed: aññam cetanā ādīnam samodhānetvā pana saṅkhāra kkhandho tu eva vuccati iti evam pi saṅkhāra kkhandho
translated: each separately. But when they are collected together they are called the formations aggregate. So the formations aggregate

original: kadalikkhandhasadiso.
analyzed: kadali khandha sadisaḥ
translated: is similar to the plantain tree in this way.

original: Viññāṇampi asārakaṭṭhena ‘māyāsadisaṃ’. Tathā agayhupagaṭṭhena. Yathā ca māyā ittarā
analyzed: viññāṇam pi asāraka ṭṭhena māyā sadisam tathā yathā ca māyā ittarā
translated: And consciousness is similar to an illusion in the sense of having no core. And it is similar to an illusion in the sense of going without stopping.

original: lahupaccupaṭṭhānā, evaṃ viññāṇaṃ. Tañhi tatopi ittaratarañceva lahupaccupaṭṭhānatarañca.
analyzed: lahu paccupaṭṭhānā evam viññāṇam tat hi tatas pi ittarataram ca iva lahu paccupaṭṭhānataram ca
translated: And just as an illusion is slight and has a deceptive appearance, so too consciousness is slight and has a deceptive appearance. For it is even slighter and has a more deceptive appearance than that.

original: Teneva hi cittena puriso āgato viya, gato viya, ṭhito viya, nisinno viya hoti. Aññadeva
analyzed: tena iva hi cittena purisaḥ āgataḥ viya gataḥ viya ṭhitaḥ viya nisinnaḥ viya hoti aññadeva
translated: For by means of it a man seems to come, to go, to stand, to sit. It is different from

original: cāgamanakāle cittaṃ, aññaṃ gamanakālādīsu. Evampi viññāṇaṃ māyāsadisaṃ. Māyā ca mahājanaṃ
analyzed: ca āgamana kāle cittam aññam gamana kāla ādīsu evam pi viññāṇam māyā sadisam māyā ca mahājanam
translated: and the consciousness that comes is different from that which goes, etc.,🔽so too consciousness is like a magical creation. And a magician deceives the general run of people,

original: vañceti, yaṃ kiñcideva ‘idaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ rajataṃ muttā’tipi gahāpeti. Viññāṇampi mahājanaṃ
analyzed: vañca iti yam kiñcid eva idam suvaṇṇam rajatam gahāpeti viññāṇam pi mahājanam
translated: making them think that what is not gold is gold, or that what is not silver is silver, or that what is not a pearl is a pearl. So too consciousness deceives the general run of people,

original: vañceti, teneva cittena āgacchantaṃ viya, gacchantaṃ viya, ṭhitaṃ viya, nisinnaṃ
analyzed: vañca iti tena iva cittena āgacchantam viya gacchantam viya ṭhitam viya nisinnam
translated: making them think that what is coming is going, that what is going, etc., is standing, sitting,

original: viya katvā gāhāpeti. Aññadeva ca āgamane cittaṃ, aññaṃ gamanādīsu. Evampi viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: viya katvā gāhāpeti aññat eva ca āgamane cittam aññam gamana ādīsu evam pi viññāṇam
translated: lying down, and so on. And the consciousness that comes is different from that which goes, etc. So too consciousness is like a magical creation.

original: māyāsadisaṃ. Visesato ca subhārammaṇampi oḷārikampi ajjhattikarūpaṃ asubhanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Vedanā tīhi dukkhatāhi avinimuttato dukkhāti saññāsaṅkhārā avidheyyato anattāti viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: māyā sadisam visesato ca subha ārammaṇam pi oḷārikam pi ajjhattika rūpam asubhanti daṭṭhabbam  vedanā tīhi dukkha tāhi a vinimuttataḥ dukkhā ati saññā saṅkhārāḥ avidheyyataḥ anattā ati viññāṇam
translated: And in particular, the internal materiality, whether beautiful or ugly, should be seen as “foul.”

original: udayabbayadhammato aniccanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: udaya bbaya dhammataḥ aniccanti daṭṭhabbam
translated: Feeling should be seen as “painful” because it is not free from the three kinds of suffering. Perception and formations should be seen as “not self” because they are not to be regarded as self. Consciousness should be seen as “impermanent” because it is subject to arising and falling.

original: ‘Evaṃ passantassatthasiddhito’ti evañca saṅkhepavitthāravasena dvidhā passato yā
analyzed: evam passantassa attha siddhito ti evam ca saṅkhepa vitthāra vasena dvidhā passataḥ yā
translated: ‘Because of the establishment of the meaning in one who sees thus’: in one who sees in this way in two ways, briefly and in detail,

original: atthasiddhi hoti, tatopi vinicchayanayo viññātabbo, seyyathidaṃ – saṅkhepato tāva
analyzed: vinicchaya nayaḥ viññātabbo seyyathīdam saṅkhepato tāva
translated: The meaning is to be known by the method of exposition, as follows.

original: pañcupādānakkhandhesu ukkhittāsikapaccatthikādibhāvena passanto khandhehi na vihaññati.
analyzed: pañca upādānakkhandhesu ukkhitta asika paccatthika ādi bhāvena passantaḥ khandhehi na vihaññati
translated: Briefly, one who sees the five aggregates as enemies with uplifted swords, etc., is not troubled by the aggregates.

original: Vitthārato pana rūpādīni pheṇapiṇḍādisadisabhāvena passanto na asāresu sāradassī🔽hoti. Visesato ca ajjhattikarūpaṃ asubhato passanto kabaḷīkārāhāraṃ parijānāti, asubhe
analyzed: vitthārato pana rūpa ādīni pheṇa piṇḍa ādi sadisa bhāvena passantaḥ na asāresu sāra dassī  hoti visesato ca ajjhattika rūpam asubhataḥ passanto kabaḷīkāra āhāram parijānāti asubhe
translated: But in detail, one who sees materiality, etc., as similar to a lump of foam, etc., is not a perceiver of the permanent in the impermanent.

original: subhanti vipallāsaṃ pajahati, kāmoghaṃ uttarati, kāmayogena visaṃyujjati, kāmāsavena🔽anāsavo hoti, abhijjhākāyaganthaṃ bhindati, kāmupādānaṃ na upādiyati. Vedanaṃ dukkhato
analyzed: vipallāsam pajahati kāma ogham uttarati kāma yogena visaṃyujjati kāma āsavena  anāsavaḥ hoti abhijjhā kāya gantham bhindati kāma upādānam na upādiyati vedanam dukkhato
translated: And in particular, one who sees internal materiality as foul abandons the perversion of perceiving beauty in the foul, crosses the bog of sensual desire, becomes detached through the sensual-desire yoke, becomes free from the canker of sensual desire, breaks the bodily tie of covetousness, and does not cling to sensual-desire clinging.

original: passanto phassāhāraṃ parijānāti, dukkhe sukhanti vipallāsaṃ pajahati, bhavoghaṃ uttarati,
analyzed: passantaḥ phassa āhāram parijānāti dukkhe vipallāsam pajahati bhava ogham uttarati
translated: One who sees feeling as painful abandons the perversion of perceiving pleasure in the painful, crosses the bog of becoming, becomes detached through the becoming yoke, becomes free from the canker of becoming, breaks the bodily tie of ill will, and does not cling to becoming clinging.

original: bhavayogena visaṃyujjati, bhavāsavena anāsavo hoti, byāpādakāyaganthaṃ bhindati,
analyzed: bhava yogena visaṃyujjati bhava āsavena anāsavaḥ byāpāda kāya gantham bhindati
translated: One who sees perception as insubstantial abandons the perversion of perceiving self in the not-self, crosses the bog of views, becomes detached through the view yoke, becomes free from the canker of views, breaks the bodily tie of grasping at views, and does not cling to clinging to a doctrine of self.

original: sīlabbatupādānaṃ na upādiyati. Saññaṃ saṅkhāre ca anattato passanto manosañcetanāhāraṃ
analyzed: sīla bbata upādānam na upādiyati saññam saṅkhāre ca anattataḥ passantaḥ manaḥ sañcetanā āhāram
translated: When he sees perception and formations as not-self, he fully understands mental volition as nutriment,

original: parijānāti, anattani attāti vipallāsaṃ pajahati, diṭṭhoghaṃ uttarati, diṭṭhiyogena
analyzed: parijānāti an attani attā ati vipallāsam pajahati diṭṭha ogham uttarati diṭṭhi yogena
translated: he abandons the perversion of perceiving self in the not-self, he crosses the flood of false view, he is detached from the bond of false view,

original: visaṃyujjati, diṭṭhāsavena anāsavo hoti, idaṃ saccābhinivesakāyaganthaṃ bhindati,
analyzed: visaṃyujjati diṭṭhāsavena anāsavaḥ hoti idam sacca abhinivesa kāya gantham bhindati
translated: he becomes taintless in regard to the taint of false view, he breaks the bodily tie of misapprehending a doctrine of self,

original: attavādupādānaṃ na upādiyati. Viññāṇaṃ aniccato passanto viññāṇāhāraṃ parijānāti,
analyzed: atta vāt upādānam na upādiyati viññāṇam aniccato passantaḥ viññāṇa āhāram parijānāti
translated: and he does not cling to the clinging aggregate of views. When he sees consciousness as impermanent, he fully understands consciousness as nutriment,

original: anicce niccanti vipallāsaṃ pajahati, avijjoghaṃ uttarati, avijjāyogena visaṃyujjati,
analyzed: anicce niccanti vipallāsam pajahati a vijjā ogham uttarati avijjā yogena visaṃyujjati
translated: he abandons the perversion of perceiving permanence in the impermanent, he crosses the flood of ignorance, he is detached from the bond of ignorance,

original: avijjāsavena anāsavo hoti, sīlabbataparāmāsakāyaganthaṃ bhindati, diṭṭhupādānaṃ na upādiyati.
analyzed: avijja āsavena anāsavaḥ hoti sīla bbata parāmāsa kāya gantham bhindati diṭṭhupādānam na upādiyati
translated: he becomes taintless in regard to the taint of ignorance, he breaks the bodily tie of misapprehending a way of life, and he does not cling to the clinging aggregate of craving.🔽Since the seeing of the aggregates

original: Evaṃ mahānisaṃsaṃ, vadhakādivasena dassanaṃ yasmā;
analyzed: evam mahā nisaṃsam vadhaka ādi vasena dassanam yasmā
translated: As a murderer, etc., has such great fruit,🔽Therefore the wise one should see the aggregates

original: Tasmā khandhe dhīro, vadhakādivasena passeyyāti.🔽Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: khandhe dhīraḥ vadhaka ādi vasena passeyya ati
translated: As a murderer, etc.🔽The Description of the Basket of Discourses

original: 2. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Basket of Higher Teachings

original: 32. Idāni abhidhammabhājanīyaṃ hoti. Tattha rūpakkhandhaniddeso heṭṭhā rūpakaṇḍe vitthāritanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: idāni abhidhamma bhājanīyam hoti tattha rūpa khandha niddesaḥ heṭṭhā rūpa kaṇḍe vitthārita nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: Now comes the exposition of the Abhidhamma. Herein, the description of the materiality aggregate should be understood in the way given in the Description of the Aggregates .

original: 34. Vedanākkhandhaniddese ekavidhenāti ekakoṭṭhāsena. Phassasampayuttoti phassena
analyzed: vedanā khandha niddese ekavidhena ati eka koṭṭhāsena phassa sampayutto ti phassena
translated: In the description of the feeling aggregate, “in one way” means by one section. Associated with contact: associated with the contact that is the cause of feeling.

original: sampayutto. Sabbāpi catubhūmikavedanā. Sahetukaduke sahetukā catubhūmikavedanā, ahetukā
analyzed: sampayuttaḥ sabbā api catu bhūmika vedanā sa hetuka duke sa hetukā catu bhūmika vedanā ahetukā
translated: All feeling is in the four planes. In the dyad with cause, feeling in the four planes has cause;

original: kāmāvacarāva. Iminā upāyena kusalapadādīhi vuttā vedanā jānitabbā. Apicāyaṃ vedanākkhandho
analyzed: iminā upāyena kusala pada ādīhi vuttā vedanā jānitabbā api ca ayam vedanā khandho
translated: that in the sense sphere has no cause. In this way feeling stated in the terms “wholesome,” etc., should be understood.

original: ekavidhena phassasampayuttato dassito, duvidhena sahetukāhetukato, tividhena jātito,🔽catubbidhena bhūmantarato, pañcavidhena indriyato. Tattha sukhindriyadukkhindriyāni
analyzed: ekavidhena phassa sampayuttataḥ dassitaḥ duvidhena sa hetuka ahetukato tividhena jātitaḥ  catubbidhena bhūmantarato pañcavidhena indriyato tattha sukha indriya dukkha indriyāni
translated: Moreover, this feeling aggregate is shown in one way as associated with contact, in two ways as with cause and without cause, in three ways as classed according to the three kinds of feeling,

original: kāyappasādavatthukāni kāmāvacarāneva. Somanassindriyaṃ chaṭṭhavatthukaṃ vā avatthukaṃ
analyzed: kāya pasāda vatthukāni kāmāvacarān eva somanassindriyam chaṭṭha vatthukam vā a vatthukam
translated: in four ways as classed according to the four planes, and in five ways as classed according to the five aggregates. Herein, the pleasure faculty and the joy faculty are only in the sense sphere and have as their basis the confidence faculty. The gladness faculty has the sixth as its basis or it has no basis.

original: vā tebhūmakaṃ. Domanassindriyaṃ chaṭṭhavatthukaṃ kāmāvacaraṃ. Upekkhindriyaṃ cakkhādicatuppasādavatthukaṃ
analyzed: vā tebhūmakam domanassindriyam chaṭṭha vatthukam kāmāvacaram upekkhindriyam cakkhu ādi catu pasāda vatthukam
translated: and that of the mental is of the three planes. The sor-row faculty has the sixth base as its physical basis and is of the sense sphere. The equanimity faculty has the four sensitive faculties of the eye, etc., as its physical basis

original: chaṭṭhavatthukaṃ avatthukañca catubhūmakaṃ. Chabbidhena vatthuto dassito. Tattha🔽purimā pañca vedanā pañcappasādavatthukā kāmāvacarāva chaṭṭhā avatthukā vā savatthukā vā catubhūmikā.
analyzed: chaṭṭhavatthukam avatthukam ca catu bhūmakam chabbidhena vatthutaḥ dassito tattha  purimā pañca vedanā pañca ppasāda vatthukā chaṭṭhā avatthukā vā sa vatthukā vā catu bhūmikā
translated: and the sixth base as its physical basis and has no physical basis. It is of the four planes. It is shown by way of physical basis in six ways. Herein,🔽the first five feelings have the five sensitive faculties as their physical basis and are of the sense sphere. The sixth has no physical basis or has the six bases as its physical basis and is of the four planes.

original: Sattavidhena tattha manosamphassajā bhedato dassitā, aṭṭhavidhena tattha kāyasamphassajā🔽bhedato, navavidhena sattavidhabhede manoviññāṇadhātusamphassajā bhedato, dasavidhena
analyzed: sattavidhena tattha manaḥ samphassa jā bhedataḥ dassitā aṭṭhavidhena tattha kāya samphassa jā  bhedataḥ navavidhena sattavidha bhede manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu samphassa jāḥ bhedataḥ dasavidhena
translated: Herein, the pleasure faculty is shown by way of division as twofold, that born of mental pleasure and that born of fine-material-sphere happiness. The joy faculty is shown by way of division as twofold, that born of mental joy and that born of immaterial-sphere happiness. The equanimity faculty is shown by way of division as twofold, that born of equanimity and that born of equanimity-happiness. The pain faculty is shown by way of division as twofold, that born of bodily pain and that born of bodily discomfort. The sorrow faculty is shown by way of division as twofold, that born of grief and that born of mental distress.🔽Herein, the pleasure faculty is shown by way of division as threefold, that born of the three kinds of happiness. The joy faculty is shown by way of division as threefold, that born of the three kinds of mental pleasure. The equanimity faculty is shown by way of division as threefold, that born of the three kinds of equanimity. The pain faculty is shown by way of division as threefold, that born of the three kinds of bodily discomfort. The sorrow faculty is shown by way of division as threefold, that born of the three kinds of mental distress.

original: aṭṭhavidhabhede manoviññāṇadhātusamphassajā bhedato. Etesu hi sattavidhabhede manosamphassajā🔽manodhātusamphassajā, manoviññāṇadhātusamphassajāti dvidhā bhinnā. Aṭṭhavidhabhede
analyzed: aṭṭhavidha bhede manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu samphassa jāḥ bhedataḥ etesu hi sattavidha bhede manaḥ samphassa jāḥ 🔽manaḥ dhātu samphassa jā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu samphassa jā ti dvidhā bhinnā aṭṭhavidha bhede
translated: Herein, the pleasure faculty is shown by way of division as fourfold, that born of the four kinds of happiness. The joy faculty is shown by way of division as fourfold, that born of the four kinds of mental pleasure. The equanimity faculty is shown by way of division as fourfold, that born of the four kinds of equanimity. The pain faculty is shown by way of division as fourfold, that born of the four kinds of bodily discomfort. The sorrow faculty is shown by way of division as fourfold, that born of the four kinds of mental distress.🔽Herein, the pleasure faculty is shown by way of division as fivefold,

original: tāya saddhiṃ kāyasamphassajāpi sukhā dukkhāti dvidhā bhinnā. Navavidhabhede sattavidhe
analyzed: tāya saddhim kāya samphassa jā api sukhā dukkhā ati dvidhā bhinnā navavidha bhede sattavidhe
translated: And with that, the pleasure and pain born of body-contact are also divided into two kinds. In the ninefold division,

original: vuttā manoviññāṇadhātusamphassajā kusalādivasena tidhā bhinnā. Dasavidhabhede aṭṭhavidhe
analyzed: vuttā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu samphassa jā kusala ādi vasena tidhā bhinnā dasavidha bhede aṭṭhavidhe
translated: the kinds born of mind-contact classed as profitable, etc., are divided into three kinds. In the tenfold division, the eight kinds

original: vuttā manoviññāṇadhātusamphassajā kusalādivaseneva tidhā bhinnā.
analyzed: vuttā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu samphassa jā kusala ādi vasena iva tidhā bhinnā
translated: are divided into three kinds only as profitable, etc.

original: Kusalattiko cettha kevalaṃ pūraṇatthameva vutto. Sattavidhaaṭṭhavidhanavavidhabhedesu🔽pana nayaṃ dātuṃ yuttaṭṭhāne nayo dinno. Abhidhammañhi patvā tathāgatena nayaṃ dātuṃ
analyzed: kusalattikaḥ ca ittha kevalam pūraṇa attham eva vutto sattavidha aṭṭhavidha navavidha bhedesu  pana nayam dātum yutta ṭṭhāne nayaḥ dinnaḥ abhidhammañ hi patvā tathāgatena nayam dātum
translated: But the profitable, etc., are mentioned here only to fill out the scheme. In the sevenfold, eightfold, and ninefold divisions,

original: yuttaṭṭhāne nayo adinno nāma natthi. Ayaṃ tāva dukamūlake eko vāro.
analyzed: yutta ṭṭhāne nayaḥ adinno nāma natthi ayam tāva duka mūlake ekaḥ vāro
translated: the method is given only where it is appropriate to do so. For there is nothing in the Abhidhamma that the Tathāgata has not given the method for. This is the first chapter called that on the dyads.

original: Satthā hi imasmiṃ abhidhammabhājanīye vedanākkhandhaṃ bhājento tike gahetvā dukesu
analyzed: satthā hi imasmin abhidhamma bhājanīye vedanā khandham bhājentaḥ tike gahetvā dukesu
translated: The Master, in this Abhidhamma basket, when he analyses the feeling aggregate, takes the triads and includes them in the dyads,

original: pakkhipi, duke gahetvā tikesu pakkhipi, tike ca duke ca ubhatovaḍḍhananīhārena āhari;
analyzed: pakkhipi duke gahetvā tikesu pakkhipi tike ca duke ca ubhatovaḍḍhana nīhārena āhari
translated: takes the dyads and includes them in the triads, and he brings them up by the method of progressive inclusion.

original: sattavidhena, catuvīsatividhena, tiṃsavidhena, bahuvidhenāti sabbathāpi bahuvidhena🔽vedanākkhandhaṃ dassesi. Kasmā? Puggalajjhāsayena ceva desanāvilāsena ca. Dhammaṃ
analyzed: sattavidhena catuvīsatividhena tiṃsavidhena bahuvidhena ati sabbathā api bahuvidhena  vedanā khandham dassesi kasmā puggala jhāsayena ca iva desanā vilāsena ca dhammaṃ
translated: He showed the feeling aggregate in many ways, in seven ways, in twenty-four ways, in thirty ways, in many ways.🔽Why? Because of the inclinations of the individuals and because of the charm of the teaching.

original: sotuṃ nisinnadevaparisāya hi ye devaputtā tike ādāya dukesu pakkhipitvā kathiyamānaṃ🔽paṭivijjhituṃ sakkonti, tesaṃ sappāyavasena tathā katvā desesi. Ye itarehi ākārehi
analyzed: sotum nisinna deva parisāya hi ye deva puttā tike ādāya dukesu pakkhipitvā kathiyamānam  paṭivijjhitum sakkonti tesam sappāya vasena tathā katvā desesi ye itarehi ākārehi
translated: For in the assembly of gods who had sat down to listen to the Dhamma, there were some gods who were able to penetrate the teaching when it was given in the form of a triad with the dyads inserted,🔽so he taught it in that way for their benefit. There were others who were able to penetrate the teaching when it was given in the other forms,

original: kathiyamānaṃ paṭivijjhituṃ sakkonti, tesaṃ tehākārehi desesīti. Ayamettha ‘puggalajjhāsayo’.
analyzed: kathiyamānam paṭivijjhitum sakkonti tesam tehi ākārehi desesi iti ayam ettha puggala jjhāsayaḥ
translated: so he taught it in those other ways. This is the ‘inclination of the individuals.’

original: Sammāsambuddho pana attano mahāvisayatāya tike vā dukesu pakkhipitvā, duke vā tikesu🔽ubhatovaḍḍhanena vā, sattavidhādinayena vā, yathā yathā icchati tathā tathā desetuṃ
analyzed: sammāsambuddhaḥ pana attanaḥ mahā visaya tāya tike vā dukesu pakkhipitvā duke vā tikesu  ubhatas vaḍḍhanena vā sattavidha ādinayena vā yathā yathā icchati tathā tathā desetum
translated: But the Fully Enlightened One, because of the greatness of his knowledge, is able to teach in whatever way he likes, whether by inserting the dyads in the triads or the triads in the dyads,

original: sakkoti. Tasmāpi imehākārehi desesīti ayamassa ‘desanāvilāso’.
analyzed: sakkoti tasmā api imehi ākārehi desesi iti ayam assa desanā vilāso
translated: or by increasing both, or by the method of the seven ways, and so on. Therefore he taught it in these ways too. This is the ‘charm of the teaching.’

original: Tattha tike ādāya dukesu pakkhipitvā desitavāro dukamūlako nāma. Duke ādāya tikesu🔽pakkhipitvā desitavāro tikamūlako nāma. Tike ca duke ca ubhato vaḍḍhetvā desitavāro
analyzed: tattha tike ādāya dukesu pakkhipitvā desitavāraḥ dukamūlakaḥ nāma duke ādāya tikesu  pakkhipitvā desita vāro tikamūlakaḥ nāma tike ca duke ca ubhatas vaḍḍhetvā desita vāro
translated: Herein, the method of teaching by taking the three and putting them in the dyads is called “based on dyads.” The method of teaching by taking the dyads and putting them in the triads is called “based on triads.” The method of teaching by increasing both the triads and the dyads is called “based on triads and dyads.”🔽

original: ubhatovaḍḍhitako nāma. Avasāne sattavidhenātiādivāro bahuvidhavāro nāmāti ime tāva cattāro mahāvārā.🔽Tattha dukamūlake dukesu labbhamānena ekekena dukena saddhiṃ tikesu alabbhamāne vedanāttikapītittikasanidassanattike
analyzed: ubhatovaḍḍhitakaḥ nāma avasāne sattavidhena ati ādi vāraḥ bahuvidhavāraḥ nāma ati ime tāva cattāraḥ mahā vārā  tattha duka mūlake dukesu labbhamānena ekekena dukena saddhim tikesu a labbhamāne
translated: Herein, the method of teaching by taking the three from the first dyad and inserting them in the dyads is called “based on dyads.” The method of teaching by taking the dyads and inserting them in the three is called “based on triads.” The method of teaching by increasing both triads and dyads is called “both increased.” The method of teaching beginning with “sevenfold” is called “multiple.” These are the four main methods.

original: apanetvā, sese labbhamānake ekūnavīsati tike yojetvā, dutiyadukapaṭhamattikayojanavārādīni🔽navavārasatāni paññāsañca vārā honti. Te sabbepi pāḷiyaṃ saṃkhipitvā tattha tattha
analyzed: apanetvā sese labbhamānake ekūnavīsati tike yojetvā dutiya duka paṭhama ttika yojana vāra ādīni  nava vāra satāni paññāsañca vārāḥ honti te sabbe pi pāḷiyam saṃkhipitvā tattha tattha
translated: Herein, in the method based on dyads, the three triads beginning with feeling, joy, and perception, which are not found in the dyads, are omitted, and the remaining nineteen triads are combined with the one dyad found in the dyads. The method of combining the second dyad with the first triad, etc.,

original: dassetabbayuttakaṃ dassetvā vuttā. Asammuyhantena pana vitthārato veditabbā.
analyzed: dassetabba yuttakam dassetvā vuttā asammuyhantena pana vitthārataḥ veditabbā
translated: makes nine hundred and fifty methods. All these are included in the text, and what is suitable to be shown here and there has been shown. But they should be understood in detail without confusion.

original: Tikamūlakepi tikesu labbhamānena ekekena tikena saddhiṃ dukesu alabbhamāne paṭhamadukādayo
analyzed: tika mūlake pi tikesu labbhamānena ekekena tikena saddhim dukesu a labbhamāne paṭhama duka ādayaḥ
translated: In the Triad-duad, too, the first duad, etc., are omitted, leaving the remaining duads that occur with the single triad that occurs among the triads,

original: duke apanetvā, sese labbhamānake sahetukadukādayo paññāsa duke yojetvā, paṭhamattikadutiyadukayojanavārādīni🔽navavārasatāni paññāsañca vārā honti. Tepi sabbe pāḷiyaṃ saṅkhipitvā tattha tattha
analyzed: duke apanetvā sese labbhamānake sa hetuka duka ādayo paññāsa duke yojetvā paṭhama ttika dutiya duka yojana vāra ādīni  nava vāra satāni paññāsañca vārāḥ honti te pi sabbe pāḷiyam saṅkhipitvā tattha tattha
translated: and the fifty duads that occur with the remaining triads are combined, making the first triad-second duad combination, etc.,🔽which make nine hundred and fifty combinations. All these are stated in the text by abbreviation, showing only what is necessary in each place.

original: dassetabbayuttakaṃ dassetvā vuttā. Asammuyhantena pana vitthārato veditabbā.
analyzed: dassetabba yuttakam dassetvā vuttā asammuyhantena pana vitthārataḥ veditabbā
translated: But they should be known in detail without confusion.

original: Ubhatovaḍḍhitake duvidhabhede dutiyadukaṃ tividhabhede ca paṭhamatikaṃ ādiṃ katvā
analyzed: ubhatovaḍḍhitake duvidha bhede dutiya dukam tividha bhede ca paṭhama tikam ādim katvā
translated: In the two kinds of Dual Increase, the second duad in the twofold division and the first triad in the threefold division are taken as the first

original: labbhamānehi ekūnavīsatiyā dukehi labbhamāne ekūnavīsatitike yojetvā dutiyadukapaṭhamatikayojanavārādayo🔽ekūnavīsativārā vuttā. Esa dukatikānaṃ vasena ubhatovaḍḍhitattā ubhatovaḍḍhitako
analyzed: labbhamānehi ekūnavīsatiyā dukehi labbhamāne ekūnavīsati tike yojetvā dutiya duka paṭhama tika yojana vāra ādayo  ekūnavīsati vārāḥ vuttāḥ esa dukatikānam vasena ubhatovaḍḍhita ttā ubhatovaḍḍhitako
translated: and combined with the nineteen duads that occur with the nineteen triads that occur, making the second duad-first triad combination, etc.,🔽which make nineteen combinations. This is called the third great chapter called “Dual Increase”

original: nāma tatiyo mahāvāro.
analyzed: nāma tatiyaḥ mahāvāraḥ
translated: because of the increase in both ways, that is, by duads and by triads.

original: Bahuvidhavārassa sattavidhaniddese ādito paṭṭhāya labbhamānesu ekūnavīsatiyā tikesu
analyzed: bahuvidha vārassa sattavidha niddese āditaḥ paṭṭhāya labbhamānesu ekūnavīsatiyā tikesu
translated: In the twenty-one triads that can be extracted from the twenty-two terms beginning with the first of the seven terms,

original: ekekena saddhiṃ catasso bhūmiyo yojetvā ekūnavīsati sattavidhavārā vuttā. Catuvīsatividhaniddesepi
analyzed: ekekena saddhim catasso bhūmiyaḥ yojetvā ekūnavīsati sattavidha vārā vuttā catuvīsatividha niddese pi
translated: four planes are combined with each one, making twenty-one septad-sets. In the twenty-four terms,

original: tesaṃyeva tikānaṃ vasena ekūnavīsativārā vuttā. Tathā bahuvidhavāre cāti. Tiṃsavidhavāro
analyzed: tesam yeva tikānam vasena ekūnavīsati vārā vuttā tathā bahuvidha vāre ca ati tiṃsavidha vāro
translated: twenty-one sets are stated according to the same triads. So too in the many- kinds-of-sets. The thirty-two terms

original: ekoyevāti sabbepi aṭṭhapaññāsa vārā honti. Ayaṃ tāvettha vāraparicchedavasena pāḷivaṇṇanā.
analyzed: ekoya iva āti sabbe pi aṭṭha paññāsa vārāḥ honti ayam tāva ettha vāra pariccheda vasena pāḷi vaṇṇanā
translated: are only one set. So all the sets amount to fifty-eight. This, firstly, is the commentary on the text according to the method of determining the sets.

original: Idāni atthavaṇṇanā hoti. Tattha sattavidhaniddeso tāva uttānatthoyeva. Catuvīsatividhaniddese
analyzed: idāni attha vaṇṇanā hoti tattha sattavidha niddeso tāva catuvīsatividha niddese
translated: Now comes the explanation of the meaning. Herein, the seven-terms description has an obvious meaning. In the twenty-four terms,

original: cakkhusamphassapaccayā vedanākkhandho atthi kusaloti kāmāvacaraaṭṭhakusalacittavasena
analyzed: cakkhu samphassa paccayā vedanā kkhandho atthi kusalaḥ ti kāmāvacara aṭṭha kusala citta vasena
translated: “There is a feeling aggregate that is a condition for eye-contact” is to be understood according to the eight kinds of sense-sphere profitable consciousness.

original: veditabbo. Atthi akusaloti dvādasaakusalacittavasena veditabbo. Atthi abyākatoti
analyzed: veditabbaḥ atthi akusalo ti dvādasa akusala citta vasena veditabbaḥ atthi abyākato ti
translated: “There is a feeling aggregate that is a condition for unprofitable eye-contact” is to be understood according to the twelve kinds of unprofitable consciousness.🔽“There is a feeling aggregate that is a condition for indeterminate eye-contact” is to be understood according to the four kinds of indeterminate consciousness.

original: tisso manodhātuyo, tisso ahetukamanoviññāṇadhātuyo, aṭṭha mahāvipākāni, dasa kāmāvacarakiriyāti
analyzed: tissaḥ manaḥ dhātuyo tissaḥ ahetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyo aṭṭha mahā vipākāni dasa kāmāvacara kiriyā ati
translated: and the three mind-element, and the three root-causeless mind-consciousness-elements, and the eight great fruitions, and the ten functional of the sense-desire-world.

original: catuvīsatiyā cittānaṃ vasena veditabbo.
analyzed: catuvīsatiyā cittānam vasena veditabbo
translated: It should be understood by means of these twenty-four kinds of consciousness.

original: Tattha aṭṭha kusalāni dvādasa akusalāni ca javanavasena labbhanti. Kiriyamanodhātu
analyzed: tattha aṭṭha kusalāni dvādasa akusalāni ca javana vasena labbhanti kiriya manaḥ dhātu
translated: Herein, the eight profitable and the twelve unprofitable are obtained by way of impulsion. The functional mind-element🔽is obtained by way of adverting. The two fruition mind-elements

original: āvajjanavasena labbhati. Dve vipākamanodhātuyo sampaṭicchanavasena, tisso vipākamanoviññāṇadhātuyo🔽santīraṇatadārammaṇavasena, kiriyāhetukamanoviññāṇadhātu voṭṭhabbanavasena, aṭṭha
analyzed: āvajjana vasena labbhati dve vipāka manaḥ dhātuyo sampaṭicchana vasena tisso vipāka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyo
translated: are obtained by way of receiving. The three fruition mind-consciousness-elements🔽are obtained by way of determining and by way of the registration of that. The functional root-caused mind-consciousness-element is obtained by way of determining and by way of the registration of that. The eight

original: mahāvipākacittāni tadārammaṇavasena, nava kiriyacittāni javanavasena labbhanti. Sotaghānajivhākāyadvāresupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: mahā vipāka cittāni tad ārammaṇa vasena nava kiriya cittāni javana vasena labbhanti sota ghāna jivhā kāya dvāresu pi esa eva nayo
translated: great fruition consciousnesses are obtained by way of the registration of that. The nine functional consciousnesses are obtained by way of impulsion. This is the method in the case of the ear, nose, tongue and body doors.

original: Manodvāre pana atthi kusaloti catubhūmakakusalavasena kathitaṃ, atthi akusaloti dvādasaakusalavasena.
analyzed: manaḥ dvāre pana atthi kusalo ti catu bhūmaka kusala vasena kathitam atthi akusalo ti dvādasa akusala vasena
translated: But in the case of the mind door, “there is profitable” is said by way of the profitable of four planes, and “there is unprofitable” is said by way of the twelve unprofitable.

original: Atthi abyākatoti ekādasannaṃ kāmāvacaravipākānaṃ, dasannaṃ kiriyānaṃ, navannaṃ rūpāvacarārūpāvacarakiriyānaṃ,
analyzed: atthi ekādasannam kāmāvacara vipākānam dasannam kiriyānam navannam rūpāvacara arūpāvacara kiriyānam
translated: There is indeterminate: eleven kinds of sense-sphere resultant, ten kinds of sense-sphere functional, nine kinds of fine-material and immaterial functional,

original: catunnaṃ sāmaññaphalānanti catuttiṃsacittuppādavasena kathitaṃ. Tattha catubhūmakakusalañceva
analyzed: catunnam sāmañña phalānam ti catuttiṃsa cittuppāda vasena kathitam tattha catu bhūmaka kusalam ca iva
translated: and the four kinds of fruition consciousness. This is said with reference to the forty-three kinds of consciousness. Herein, the profitable and unprofitable of the four planes are found as javanas.

original: akusalañca javanavasena labbhati. Kiriyato ahetukamanoviññāṇadhātu āvajjanavasena,
analyzed: akusalam ca javana vasena labbhati kiriyataḥ ahetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu āvajjana vasena
translated: The functional consciousness without root-cause is found as advertence.

original: ekādasa vipākacittāni tadārammaṇavasena, tebhūmakakiriyā ceva sāmaññaphalāni ca javanavaseneva
analyzed: ekādasa vipāka cittāni tad ārammaṇa vasena tebhūmaka kiriyā ca iva sāmañña phalāni ca javana vasena iva
translated: The eleven kinds of resultant consciousness are found as registration. The functional of the three planes and the fruitions are found as javanas.

original: labbhanti. Tāni sattavidhādīsu yattha katthaci ṭhatvā kathetuṃ vaṭṭanti. Tiṃsavidhe
analyzed: labbhanti tāni sattavidha ādīsu yattha katthaci ṭhatvā kathetum vaṭṭanti tiṃsavidhe
translated: They are allowable to be spoken of in any one of the seven ways.🔽But when they are expounded in the thirty-two ways they are easy to understand.

original: pana ṭhatvā dīpiyamānāni sukhadīpanāni hontīti tiṃsavidhasmiṃyeva ṭhatvā dīpayiṃsu.
analyzed: pana ṭhatvā dīpiyamānāni sukha dīpanāni honti iti tiṃsavidhasmin eva ṭhatvā
translated: So they expounded them in the thirty-two ways.

original: Etāni hi sabbānipi cittāni cakkhudvāre upanissayakoṭiyā, samatikkamavasena, bhāvanāvasenāti
analyzed: etāni hi sabbāni api cittāni cakkhu dvāre upanissaya koṭiyā samatikkama vasena bhāvanā vasena ati
translated: For all these kinds of consciousness are allowable to be spoken of in the eye door as a condition by way of decisive support, by way of surmounting, and by way of development.

original: tīhākārehi labbhanti. Tathā sotadvāramanodvāresupi. Ghānajivhākāyadvāresu pana samatikkamavasena,
analyzed: tīhākārehi labbhanti tathā sota dvāra manaḥ dvāresu pi ghāna jivhā kāya dvāresu pana samatikkama vasena
translated: They are obtained in three ways. So too in the case of the ear door and the mind door. But in the case of the nose, tongue, and body doors, they are obtained by surmounting.

original: bhāvanāvasenāti dvīhevākārehi labbhantīti veditabbāni. Kathaṃ? Idha bhikkhu vihāracārikaṃ
analyzed: bhāvanā vasena ati dvīhā iva ākārehi labbhanti iti veditabbāni katham idha bhikkhu vihāra cārikam
translated: They are obtained in three ways. So too in the case of the ear door and the mind door. But in the case of the nose, tongue, and body doors they should be understood as obtained in two ways, that is to say, by surmounting and by developing. How? Here a bhikkhu, while going on a walking tour,

original: caramāno kasiṇamaṇḍalaṃ disvā ‘kiṃ nāmeta’nti pucchitvā ‘kasiṇamaṇḍala’nti vutte
analyzed: caramāno kasiṇa maṇḍalam disvā kim nāma etat ti pucchitvā kasiṇa maṇḍalam ti vutte
translated: sees a kasiṇa disk and asks, “What is this?” When he is told, “It is a kasiṇa disk,”

original: puna ‘kiṃ iminā karontī’ti pucchati. Athassa ācikkhanti – ‘evaṃ bhāvetvā jhānāni
analyzed: puna kim iminā karonti iti pucchati athassa ācikkhanti evam bhāvetvā jhānāni
translated: he asks, “What is it used for?” Then they tell him, “Having developed it in this way, one produces jhāna,

original: uppādetvā, samāpattipadaṭṭhānaṃ vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā, arahattaṃ pāpuṇantī’ti. Ajjhāsayasampanno
analyzed: uppādetvā samāpatti padaṭṭhānam vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pāpuṇanti iti ajjhāsaya sampannaḥ
translated: and having made that the basis for insight, one attains arahantship.”

original: kulaputto ‘bhāriyaṃ eta’nti asallakkhetvā ‘mayāpi esa guṇo nibbattetuṃ vaṭṭati, na
analyzed: kula puttaḥ bhāriyam etat ti a sallakkhetvā mayā api esa guṇaḥ nibbattetum vaṭṭati na
translated: The clansman who has the requisite knowledge thinks, “This is a difficult thing,” and without considering it further he thinks, “It is proper for me to produce that attainment too,

original: kho pana sakkā esa nipajjitvā niddāyantena nibbattetuṃ, āditova vīriyaṃ kātuṃ sīlaṃ
