analyzed: kho pana sakkā esa nipajjitvā niddāyantena nibbattetum āditas va vīriyam kātum sīlam
translated: for it is not possible to produce it by lying down and going to sleep. It is the rule that one must first make an effort.”

original: sodhetuṃ vaṭṭatī’ti cintetvā sīlaṃ sodheti. Tato sīle patiṭṭhāya dasa palibodhe upacchinditvā,
analyzed: sodhetum vaṭṭati iti cintetvā sīlam sodheti tato sīle patiṭṭhāya dasa palibodhe upacchinditvā
translated: and he thinks, “It is right for me to purify virtue,” and he purifies virtue. Then, having established himself in virtue, he cuts off the ten impediments,

original: ticīvaraparamena santosena santuṭṭho, ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ vattapaṭivattaṃ katvā, kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ti cīvara paramena santosena santuṭṭhaḥ ācariya upajjhāyānam vatta paṭivattam katvā kammaṭṭhānam
translated: and being satisfied with the bliss of fewness of wishes, he is content with the triple robe and a seat in the open, and he does the duties to his teachers and preceptors and learns the meditation subject,

original: uggaṇhitvā, kasiṇaparikammaṃ katvā, samāpattiyo uppādetvā, samāpattipadaṭṭhānaṃ vipassanaṃ🔽vaḍḍhetvā, arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tattha sabbāpi parikammavedanā kāmāvacarā, aṭṭhasamāpattivedanā🔽rūpāvacarārūpāvacarā, maggaphalavedanā lokuttarāti evaṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ catubhūmikavedanānibbattiyā
analyzed: uggaṇhitvā kasiṇa parikammam katvā samāpattiyaḥ uppādetvā samāpatti padaṭṭhānam vipassanam  vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti tattha sabbā api parikamma vedanā kāmāvacarā aṭṭha samāpatti vedanā  rūpāvacara arūpāvacarā magga phala vedanā lokuttarā ti evam cakkhu viññāṇam catu bhūmika vedanā nibbattiyā
translated: and he performs the preliminary work on a kasiṇa and arouses the jhānas, and he develops insight based on the jhānas,🔽and he reaches Arahantship. Herein, all the feeling that occurs in the preliminary work is of the sense sphere. The feeling in the eight attainments is of the fine-material sphere and the immaterial sphere. The feeling in the path and fruition is supramundane. So eye-consciousness is a powerful condition for the production of feeling in four planes.

original: balavapaccayo hotīti catubhūmikavedanā cakkhusamphassapaccayā nāma jātā. Evaṃ tāva
analyzed: balava paccayaḥ hoti iti catu bhūmika vedanā cakkhu samphassa paccayā nāma jātā evam tāva
translated: Thus feeling is called “due to eye-contact.”

original: ‘upanissayavasena’ labbhanti.
analyzed: upanissaya vasena labbhanti
translated: This is how they are “as decisive-support.”

original: Cakkhudvāre pana rūpe āpāthagate ‘iṭṭhe me ārammaṇe rāgo uppanno, aniṭṭhe paṭigho,
analyzed: cakkhu dvāre pana rūpe āpātha gate iṭṭhe me ārammaṇe rāgaḥ uppannaḥ aniṭṭhe paṭigho
translated: But when a visible datum has appeared in the eye’s focus, lust is aroused in one who is lustful if the object is pleasing, aversion in one who is hostile if the object is unpleasing,

original: asamapekkhanāya moho, vinibandhassa pana me māno uppanno, parāmaṭṭhassa diṭṭhi, vikkhepagatassa
analyzed: a samapekkhanāya mohaḥ vinibandhassa pana me mānaḥ uppanno parāmaṭṭhassa diṭṭhi vikkhepa gatassa
translated: and delusion when there is no expectation of getting it. When it is bound up with me, conceit arises. When it is clung to, a view arises. When it is distracted,

original: uddhaccaṃ, asanniṭṭhāgatassa vicikicchā, thāmagatassa anusayo uppanno’ti pariggahe🔽ṭhito kulaputto attano kilesuppattiṃ ñatvā ‘ime me kilesā vaḍḍhamānā anayabyasanāya
analyzed: uddhaccam a sanniṭṭhā gatassa vicikicchā thāma gatassa anusayaḥ uppanno ti pariggahe  ṭhitaḥ kula puttaḥ attanaḥ kilesa uppattim ñatvā ime me kilesāḥ vaḍḍhamānāḥ anaya byasanāya
translated: agitation arises. When it is undecided, uncertainty arises. When it is persisted in, a latent tendency arises.’ When he has discerned thus,

original: saṃvattissanti, handa ne niggaṇhāmī’ti cintetvā ‘na kho pana sakkā nipajjitvā niddāyantena🔽kilese niggaṇhituṃ; āditova vīriyaṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭati sīlaṃ sodhetu’nti heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva
analyzed: saṃvattissanti handa ne niggaṇhāmi iti cintetvā na kho pana sakkā nipajjitvā niddāyantena  kilese niggaṇhitum āditas va vīriyam kātum vaṭṭati sīlam sodhetum ti heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva
translated: the clansman stands firm. After knowing the arising of his defilements, he thinks, ‘If these defilements of mine increase, they will lead to my harm and suffering for a long time. Let me restrain them.’ He does not think, ‘Let me lie down and sleep and restrain the defilements.’

original: paṭipajjitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tattha sabbāpi parikammavedanā kāmāvacarā, aṭṭhasamāpattivedanā
analyzed: paṭipajjitvā arahattam pāpuṇāti tattha sabbā api parikamma vedanā kāmāvacarā aṭṭha samāpatti vedanā
translated: He thinks, ‘It is proper to make effort from the beginning and purify virtue.’ He practices the ten courses of wholesome kamma in the way already described and reaches Arahantship. Herein, all the feelings that are the preliminary work and the feelings of the eight attainments are of the sense sphere.

original: rūpāvacarārūpāvacarā, maggaphalavedanā lokuttarāti evaṃ rūpārammaṇe uppannaṃ kilesaṃ
analyzed: rūpāvacara arūpāvacarāḥ magga phala vedanā lokuttarā ati evam rūpa ārammaṇe uppannam kilesam
translated: The feelings of the path and of fruition are supramundane. So when a defilement arises with a visible datum as object,

original: samatikkamitvā gatāti catubhūmikavedanā cakkhusamphassapaccayā nāma jātā. Evaṃ ‘samatikkamavasena’ labbhanti.
analyzed: samatikkamitvā gatā ati catu bhūmika vedanā cakkhu samphassa paccayā nāma jātā evam samatikkama vasena labbhanti
translated: and the feeling that has gone beyond that is called “due to eye-contact.” So they are found “by surmounting.”

original: Cakkhudvāre pana rūpe āpāthagate eko evaṃ pariggahaṃ paṭṭhapeti – ‘idaṃ rūpaṃ kiṃ
analyzed: cakkhu dvāre pana rūpe āpātha gate ekaḥ evam pariggaham paṭṭhapeti idam rūpam kim
translated: But when an object comes into focus in the eye door, one man begins the discernment thus: “What is this materiality dependent on?”

original: nissita’nti? Tato naṃ ‘bhūtanissita’nti ñatvā cattāri mahābhūtāni upādārūpañca rūpanti
analyzed: nissitanti tatas nam bhūta nissitanti ñatvā cattāri mahābhūtāni
translated: Then, having found out that it is dependent on the great primaries, he discerns the four great primaries and the materiality derived by elements as “materiality,”

original: pariggaṇhāti, tadārammaṇe dhamme arūpanti pariggaṇhāti. Tato sappaccayaṃ nāmarūpaṃ
analyzed: pariggaṇhāti tad ārammaṇe dhamme arūpam ti pariggaṇhāti tatas sa paccayam nāma rūpam
translated: and he discerns the immaterial dhammas that have that as their object as “mentality.” Then, having discerned mentality-materiality with its conditions,

original: parigaṇhitvā tīṇi lakkhaṇāni āropetvā vipassanāpaṭipāṭiyā saṅkhāre sammasitvā arahattaṃ
analyzed: parigaṇhitvā tīṇi lakkhaṇāni āropetvā vipassanā paṭipāṭiyā saṅkhāre sammasitvā arahattam
translated: he imputes the three characteristics to the object of his discernment, and he reaches Arahantship by comprehending formations in the way of insight.

original: pāpuṇāti. Tattha sabbāpi parikammavedanā kāmāvacarā, aṭṭhasamāpattivedanā rūpāvacarārūpāvacarā,🔽maggaphalavedanā lokuttarāti evaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ sammasitvā nibbattitāti ayaṃ vedanā
analyzed: pāpuṇāti tattha sabbā api parikamma vedanā kāmāvacarā aṭṭha samāpatti vedanā rūpāvacara arūpāvacarā  magga phala vedanā lokuttarā ti evam rūpa ārammaṇam sammasitvā nibbattitā ati ayam vedanā
translated: Herein, all the feeling that is preliminary work is of the sense sphere. The feeling of the eight attainments is of the fine-material sphere and the immaterial sphere.

original: cakkhusamphassapaccayā nāma jātā. Evaṃ ‘bhāvanāvasena’ labbhanti.
analyzed: cakkhu samphassa paccayāḥ nāma jātāḥ evam bhāvanā vasena labbhanti
translated: The feeling of the paths and fruits is supramundane. So when he has discerned materiality with its conditions and has reached Arahantship, this feeling is called “due to eye-contact.” So they are found “by development.”

original: Aparo bhikkhu suṇāti – ‘kasiṇaparikammaṃ kira katvā samāpattiyo uppādetvā samāpattipadaṭṭhānaṃ🔽vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇantī’ti. Ajjhāsayasampanno kulaputto ‘bhāriyaṃ🔽eta’nti asallakkhetvā ‘mayāpi esa guṇo nibbattetuṃ vaṭṭatī’ti purimanayeneva paṭipajjitvā🔽arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tattha sabbāpi parikammavedanā kāmāvacarā, aṭṭhasamāpattivedanā
analyzed: aparaḥ bhikkhu suṇāti kasiṇa parikammam kira katvā samāpattiyaḥ uppādetvā samāpatti padaṭṭhānam  vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pāpuṇanti iti ajjhāsaya sampannaḥ kula putto bhāriyam  etat ti a sat lakkhetvā mayā api esa guṇaḥ nibbattetum vaṭṭati iti purima nayena iva paṭipajjitvā  arahattam pāpuṇāti tattha sabbā api parikamma vedanā kāmāvacarā aṭṭha samāpatti vedanā
translated: Another hears that by doing the kasiṇa exercise and developing the jhānas, and then by developing insight based on the jhānas, and so on,🔽he reached Arahantship. The clansman with a tendency to over-exertion, not discerning the true facts, thinks, “That is easy for me to do,” and he over-exerts himself and🔽reaches Arahantship. Herein, all the feeling in the doing of the preliminary work belongs to the fine-material sphere, and the feeling in the eight jhānas belongs to the immaterial sphere,

original: rūpāvacarārūpāvacarā, maggaphalavedanā lokuttarāti evaṃ sotaviññāṇaṃ catubhūmikavedanā🔽nibbattiyā balavapaccayo hotīti catubhūmikavedanā sotasamphassapaccayā nāma jātā.
analyzed: rūpāvacara arūpāvacarā magga phala vedanā lokuttarā ti evam sota viññāṇam catu bhūmika vedanā  nibbattiyāḥ balava paccayaḥ hoti iti catu bhūmika vedanā sota samphassa paccayā nāma jātā
translated: Another hears that by doing the preliminary work on a kasiṇa and then developing the jhānas and insight based on that kasiṇa, and so on, he reached Arahantship. The clansman with a tendency to faith, not discerning that this is difficult, thinks, “I too can produce this attainment,” and he practices accordingly and reaches Arahantship. Herein, all the feeling that is the preliminary work is of the sense sphere; the feeling that is the eight attainments is of the fine-material sphere and the immaterial sphere; and the feeling that is the path and the fruit is supramundane. So the consciousness of the ear has the power to cause the arising of feeling in four planes. Feeling that arises with the ear as its condition is called “arisen through the ear door.”

original: Evaṃ tāva ‘upanissayavasena’ labbhanti.
analyzed: evam tāva upanissaya vasena labbhanti
translated: This is how they are “by way of decisive support.”

original: Sotadvāre pana sadde āpāthagateti sabbaṃ cakkhudvāre vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: sota dvāre pana sadde āpātha gatā iti sabbam cakkhu dvāre vutta nayena iva veditabbam evam
translated: But when a sound comes into the focus of the ear, all should be understood in the way already described under the eye door.

original: saddārammaṇe uppannaṃ kilesaṃ samatikkamitvā gatāti catubhūmikavedanā sotasamphassapaccayā
analyzed: sadda ārammaṇe uppannam kilesam samatikkamitvā gatā ati catu bhūmika vedanā sota samphassa paccayā
translated: and the feeling that arises with the mind-element and mind-consciousness-element as its condition is called “mental feeling” .

original: nāma jātā. Evaṃ ‘samatikkamavasena’ labbhanti.
analyzed: nāma jātāḥ evam samatikkama vasena labbhanti
translated: Thus it is “obtainable by surmounting.”

original: Sotadvāre pana sadde āpāthagate eko evaṃ pariggahaṃ paṭṭhapeti – ayaṃ saddo kiṃ nissitoti
analyzed: sota dvāre pana sadde āpātha gate ekaḥ evam pariggaham paṭṭhapeti ayam saddo kim nissito ti
translated: But when a sound has come into the focus of the ear, one who makes the determination should do so thus: “This sound is dependent on what?”

original: sabbaṃ cakkhudvāre vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Evaṃ saddārammaṇaṃ sammasitvā nibbattitāti
analyzed: sabbam cakkhu dvāre vutta nayena iva veditabbam evam sadda ārammaṇam sammasitvā nibbatti tā ti
translated: All should be understood in the way already stated under the eye base.🔽Thus, after comprehending the sound object, the feeling that arises is called “mental feeling” .

original: ayaṃ vedanā sotasamphassapaccayā nāma jātā. Evaṃ ‘bhāvanāvasena’ labbhanti.🔽Ghānajivhākāyadvāresu pana gandhārammaṇādīsu āpāthagatesu ‘iṭṭhe me ārammaṇe rāgo
analyzed: ayam vedanā sota samphassa paccayāḥ nāma jātāḥ evam bhāvanā vasena labbhanti  ghāna jivhā kāya dvāresu pana gandha ārammaṇa ādīsu āpātha gatesu iṭṭhe me ārammaṇe rāgaḥ
translated: Thus it is “obtainable by development.”

original: uppanno’ti sabbaṃ cakkhudvāre vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Evaṃ gandhārammaṇādīsu uppannaṃ
analyzed: uppannaḥ ti sabbam cakkhu dvāre vutta nayena iva veditabbam evam gandha ārammaṇa ādīsu uppannam
translated: But when an odour, flavour or tangible object has come into focus in the nose, tongue or body, one should understand all in the way already stated under the eye base, thus: “If the object is a desirable one, greed arises in me” .

original: kilesaṃ samatikkamitvā gatāti catubhūmikavedanā ghānajivhākāyasamphassapaccayā nāma
analyzed: kilesam samatikkamitvā gatā ati catu bhūmika vedanā ghāna jivhā kāya samphassa paccayā nāma
translated: Thus, after surmounting the defilement that arose in regard to the odour object, etc.,🔽the feeling that arises is called “mental feeling” .

original: jātā. Evaṃ tīsu dvāresu ‘samatikkamavasena’ labbhanti.🔽Ghānadvārādīsu pana gandhādīsu āpāthagatesu eko evaṃ pariggahaṃ paṭṭhapeti – ‘ayaṃ🔽gandho, ayaṃ raso, idaṃ phoṭṭhabbaṃ kiṃ nissita’nti sabbaṃ cakkhudvāre vuttanayeneva
analyzed: jātāḥ evam tīsu dvāresu samatikkama vasena labbhanti  ghāna dvāra ādīsu pana gandha ādīsu āpātha gatesu ekaḥ evam pariggaham paṭṭhapeti ayam  gandhaḥ ayam rasaḥ idam phoṭṭhabbam kim nissitan ti sabbam cakkhu dvāre vutta nayena iva
translated: So they are obtained by surmounting in the three doors.🔽But when an odour, etc., comes into the focus of the nose, tongue, or body, then only one of these three kinds of knowledge arises thus: ‘This odour, this flavour, this tangible object is the support for this consciousness.’ All should be understood as in the case of the eye door.

original: veditabbaṃ. Evaṃ gandhārammaṇādīni sammasitvā nibbattitāti ayaṃ vedanā ghānajivhākāyasamphassapaccayā
analyzed: veditabbam evam gandha ārammaṇa ādīni sammasitvā nibbatti tā ati ayam vedanā ghāna jivhā kāya samphassa paccayā
translated: So these feelings called ‘arisen from nose-, tongue-, and body-contact’ are obtained by insight.

original: nāma jātā. Evaṃ ‘bhāvanāvasena’ labbhanti.🔽Manodvāre pana tīhipi ākārehi labbhanti. Ekacco hi jātiṃ bhayato passati, jaraṃ byādhiṃ
analyzed: nāma jātāḥ evam bhāvanā vasena labbhanti  manaḥ dvāre pana tīhi pi ākārehi labbhanti ekaccaḥ hi jātim bhayataḥ passati jaram byādhim
translated: So they are obtained by development.

original: maraṇaṃ bhayato passati, bhayato disvā ‘jātijarābyādhimaraṇehi muccituṃ vaṭṭati,
analyzed: maraṇam bhayataḥ passati bhayataḥ disvā jāti jarā byādhi maraṇehi muccitum vaṭṭati
translated: But in the mind door they are obtained in all three ways. For someone sees becoming as a terror in the three kinds of becoming, and he sees birth, ageing, disease, and death as a terror. Seeing them as a terror, he thinks, ‘It is right to be delivered from birth, ageing, disease, and death.🔽But it is not possible to be delivered from birth, ageing, disease, and death by lying down sleeping.

original: na kho pana sakkā nipajjitvā niddāyantena jātiādīhi muccituṃ, āditova vīriyaṃ kātuṃ
analyzed: na kho pana sakkā nipajjitvā niddāyantena jāti ādīhi muccitum āditas va vīriyam kātum
translated: I must make an effort from the beginning.

original: sīlaṃ sodhetuṃ vaṭṭatī’ti cintetvā cakkhudvāre vuttanayeneva paṭipajjitvā arahattaṃ
analyzed: sīlam sodhetum vaṭṭati iti cintetvā cakkhu dvāre vutta nayena iva paṭipajjitvā arahattam
translated: He thinks, “I must purify my virtue,” and he practices the way stated in the case of the eye door. He reaches Arahantship.

original: pāpuṇāti. Tattha sabbāpi parikammavedanā kāmāvacarā, aṭṭhasamāpattivedanā rūpāvacarārūpāvacarā,
analyzed: pāpuṇāti tattha sabbā api parikamma vedanā kāmāvacarā aṭṭha samāpatti vedanā rūpāvacara arūpāvacarā
translated: Herein, all the feelings that are the preliminary work and the feelings that are the eight attainments are of the sense sphere and fine-material sphere.

original: maggaphalavedanā lokuttarāti evaṃ jātijarābyādhimaraṇaṃ catubhūmikavedanānibbattiyā
analyzed: magga phala vedanā lokuttarā ti evam jāti jarā byādhi maraṇam catu bhūmika vedanā nibbattiyā
translated: The feelings that are the path and the fruits are supramundane. So the feelings of the four planes are a condition for the arising of birth, ageing, sickness, and death,

original: balavapaccayo hotīti catubhūmikavedanā manosamphassapaccayā nāma jātā. Evaṃ tāva
analyzed: balava paccayaḥ hoti iti catu bhūmika vedanā manaḥ samphassa paccayā nāma jātā evam tāva
translated: which are of the four planes. So the feelings of the four planes are called a condition by means of conditionality.

original: ‘upanissayavasena’ labbhanti.
analyzed: upanissaya vasena labbhanti
translated: This is how they are found as a condition by means of conditionality.

original: Manodvāre pana dhammārammaṇe āpāthagateti sabbaṃ cakkhudvāre vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.🔽Evaṃ dhammārammaṇe uppannaṃ kilesaṃ samatikkamitvā gatāti catubhūmikavedanā manosamphassapaccayā
analyzed: manaḥ dvāre pana dhamma ārammaṇe āpātha gata iti sabbam cakkhu dvāre vutta nayena iva veditabbam  evam dhamma ārammaṇe uppannam kilesam samatikkamitvā gatā ati catu bhūmika vedanā manaḥ samphassa paccayā
translated: But when an object has come into the focus of the mind door, all should be understood in the way already stated in the case of the eye door.

original: nāma jātā. Evaṃ ‘samatikkamavasena’ labbhanti.
analyzed: nāma jātāḥ evam samatikkama vasena labbhanti
translated: So the feelings of the four planes are called a condition by means of conditionality. This is how they are found as a condition by means of conditionality.

original: Manodvāre pana dhammārammaṇe āpāthagate eko evaṃ pariggahaṃ paṭṭhapeti – ‘etaṃ dhammārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ dvāre pana dhamma ārammaṇe āpātha gate ekaḥ evam pariggaham paṭṭhapeti etam dhamma ārammaṇam
translated: But when an object has come into the focus of the mind door, one man sets about the investigation thus: “This object

original: kiṃ nissita’nti? ‘Vatthunissita’nti. ‘Vatthu kiṃ nissita’nti? ‘Mahābhūtāni nissita’nti.
analyzed: kim nissitanti vatthu nissitanti vatthu kim nissitanti mahābhūtāni nissitanti
translated: “What is it supported by?” “It is supported by a physical basis.” “What is the physical basis supported by?” “It is supported by the four great entities.”🔽He discerns the four great entities and the form derived from them as “form,”

original: So cattāri mahābhūtāni upādārūpañca rūpanti pariggaṇhāti, tadārammaṇe dhamme arūpanti
analyzed: so cattāri mahābhūtāni upādā rūpañca rūpanti pariggaṇhāti tad ārammaṇe dhamme arūpanti
translated: and he discerns the mental phenomena associated with them as “name.”

original: pariggaṇhāti. Tato sappaccayaṃ nāmarūpaṃ pariggaṇhitvā tīṇi lakkhaṇāni āropetvā vipassanāpaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: pariggaṇhāti tatas sappaccayam nāma rūpam pariggaṇhitvā tīṇi lakkhaṇāni āropetvā vipassanā paṭipāṭiyā
translated: Then, having discerned mentality-materiality with its conditions, having defined the three characteristics in the order stated in the discernment of dependent origination,

original: saṅkhāre sammasitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tattha sabbāpi parikammavedanā kāmāvacarā,
analyzed: saṅkhāre sammasitvā arahattam pāpuṇāti tattha sabbā api parikamma vedanā kāmāvacarā
translated: having comprehended formations, he attains Arahantship. Herein, all the feelings that are the result of the development are of the sense sphere.

original: aṭṭhasamāpattivedanā rūpāvacarārūpāvacarā, maggaphalavedanā lokuttarāti evaṃ dhammārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭha samāpatti vedanā rūpāvacara arūpāvacarā magga phala vedanā lokuttarā ti evam dhamma ārammaṇam
translated: The eight attainments are of the fine-material sphere and the immaterial sphere. The feelings that are the paths and fruits are supramundane. Thus he comprehends the object as a mental datum.🔽Having comprehended it thus, he attains Arahantship. This is the “mind-contact-born idea that has arisen” .

original: sammasitvā nibbattitāti ayaṃ vedanā manosamphassapaccayā nāma jātā. Evaṃ ‘bhāvanāvasena’
analyzed: sammasitvā nibbattitā ti ayaṃ vedanā manaḥ samphassa paccayā nāma jātā evam bhāvanā vasena
translated: This is how the “idea” comes to be in the sense of development.

original: labbhanti. Yā panetā sabbesampi catuvīsatividhādīnaṃ vārānaṃ pariyosānesu cakkhusamphassajā
analyzed: labbhanti yā pana itā sabbesam pi catuvīsatividha ādīnam vārānam pariyosānesu cakkhu samphassa jā
translated: But the feeling that arises in the last of all the twenty-four kinds of cases, namely,

original: vedanā…pe… manosamphassajā vedanāti cha cha vedanā vuttā, tā sampayuttapaccayavasena vuttāti.
analyzed: vedanā pe manaḥ samphassa jā vedanā ti cha cha vedanā vuttā tā sampayutta paccaya vasena vuttā ati
translated: The six kinds of feeling stated as eye-contact-born feeling … mind-contact-born feeling are stated by association condition.

original: Ayaṃ vedanākkhandhaniddeso.🔽Saññākkhandhādayopi iminā upāyena veditabbā. Kevalañhi saññākkhandhaniddese tikesu
analyzed: ayam vedanā khandha niddeso  saññā khandha ādayaḥ api iminā upāyena veditabbā kevalañ hi saññā khandha niddese tikesu
translated: This is the description of the feeling aggregate.

original: vedanāttikapītittikāpi labbhanti, dukesu ca sukhasahagatadukādayopi. Saṅkhārakkhandhaniddese🔽phassassāpi saṅkhārakkhandhapariyāpannattā phassasampayuttoti avatvā cittasampayuttoti
analyzed: vedanā attika pītittikā api labbhanti dukesu ca sukha sahagata duka ādayaḥ api saṅkhāra khandha niddese  phassassa api saṅkhāra kkhandha pariyāpanna ttā phassa sampayuttaḥ ti avatvā citta sampayuttaḥ ti
translated: The perception aggregate, etc., should be understood in the same way. Only in the description of the perception aggregate the three kinds of perception stated as pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant are found in the triads and the pleasant, painful, etc., are found in the dyads. In the description of the formations aggregate,

original: vuttaṃ. Dukesu cettha hetudukādayopi labbhanti. Tikā saññākkhandhasadisā eva. Viññāṇakkhandhaniddese
analyzed: vuttam dukesu ca ittha hetu duka ādayaḥ api labbhanti tikā saññā kkhandha sadisā eva viññāṇa kkhandha niddese
translated: since contact is included in the formations aggregate, it is not said to be associated with contact but is said to be associated with consciousness. And in the dyads here the causes, etc., are found. The triads are the same as in the case of the perception aggregate. In the description of the consciousness aggregate,

original: cakkhusamphassajādibhāvaṃ avatvā cakkhuviññāṇantiādi vuttaṃ. Na hi sakkā viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu samphassa ja ādi bhāvam avatvā cakkhu viññāṇam tiādi vuttam na hi sakkā viññāṇam
translated: instead of saying “born of eye-contact,” etc., it is said “eye-consciousness,” etc. For it is not possible to demonstrate consciousness

original: manosamphassajanti niddisituṃ. Sesamettha saññākkhandhe vuttasadisameva. Imesaṃ pana
analyzed: manaḥ samphassa janti niddisitum sesam ettha saññā kkhandhe vutta sadisam eva imesam pana
translated: as “born of mind-contact.” The rest here is the same as in the case of the perception aggregate.

original: tiṇṇampi khandhānaṃ niddeseyeva vedanākkhandhaniddesato atirekatikadukā laddhā. Tesaṃ
analyzed: tiṇṇam pi khandhānam niddeseya iva vedanā khandha niddesato atireka tika dukā laddhā tesam
translated: and the three aggregates are included in the aggregate of feeling, which is mentioned separately.🔽

original: vasena vārappabhedo veditabboti.
analyzed: vasena vāra ppabhedaḥ veditabbo ti
translated: The answer-analysis should be understood as the analysis of the three aggregates in the Description of Feeling, which is given in excess of the two or three lines given in the Description of the Aggregates.

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Abhidhamma.

original: 3. Pañhāpucchakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañhāpucchaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the questioner

original: 150. Idāni pañhāpucchakaṃ hoti. Tattha pañhāpucchane pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ “katikusalā?
analyzed: idāni pañhāpucchakam hoti tattha pañhāpucchane pañcannam khandhānam kati kusalā
translated: Now the questioner comes in. Herein, in the question, “How many of the five aggregates are profitable?

original: Katiakusalā? Katiabyākatā”tiādinā nayena yaṃ labbhati, yañca na labbhati, taṃ sabbaṃ
analyzed: kati akusalā kati abyākatā ati ādinā nayena yam labbhati yam ca na labbhati tam sabbam
translated: How many are unprofitable? How many are indeterminate?” and so on, what is possible and what is impossible should be understood.

original: pucchitvā vissajjane “rūpakkhandho abyākato”tiādinā nayena yaṃ labbhati tadeva uddhaṭanti
analyzed: pucchitvā vissajjane rūpakkhandho abyākataḥ ti ādinā nayena yam labbhati tat eva uddhaṭanti
translated: And in the answer, “The material form aggregate is indeterminate,” and so on, only what is possible is stated.

original: veditabbaṃ. Yattha yattha ca ‘eko khandho’ti vā ‘dve khandhā’ti vā paricchedaṃ akatvā
analyzed: veditabbam yattha yattha ca ekaḥ khandhaḥ iti vā dve khandhā ati vā paricchedam a katvā
translated: And wherever the question is put in terms of “one aggregate,” “two aggregates,” and so on, without any limitation,

original: “siyā uppannā, siyā anuppannā”tiādinā nayena tanti ṭhapitā, tattha tattha pañcannampi
analyzed: siyā uppannā siyā anuppannā ati ādinā nayena tanti ṭhapitā tattha tattha pañcannam pi
translated: there the answer is given in terms of “five aggregates” and so on.

original: khandhānaṃ gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Seso tesaṃ tesaṃ khandhānaṃ kusalādivibhāgo heṭṭhā
analyzed: khandhānam gahaṇam veditabbam sesaḥ tesam tesam khandhānam kusala ādi vibhāgaḥ heṭṭhā
translated: The rest of the profitable and unprofitable analysis of the aggregates should be understood as given below.

original: dhammasaṅgahaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttoyeva.🔽Ārammaṇattikesu pana cattāro khandhā pañcapaṇṇāsa kāmāvacaradhamme ārabbha rajjantassa
analyzed: dhammasaṅgahaṭṭhakathā ayam vuttaḥ yā iva  ārammaṇa attikesu pana cattāro khandhā pañca paṇṇāsa kāmāvacara dhamme ārabbha rajjantassa
translated: This is stated in the Dhammasanganī Commentary.

original: dussantassa muyhantassa saṃvarantassa sammasantassa paccavekkhantassa ca parittārammaṇā🔽honti, sattavīsati rūpārūpāvacaradhamme ārabbha rajjantassa dussantassa muyhantassa
analyzed: dussantassa muyhantassa saṃvarantassa sammasantassa paccavekkhantassa ca paritta ārammaṇā  honti satta vīsati rūpa arūpa avacara dhamme ārabbha rajjantassa dussantassa muyhantassa
translated: But in the case of the object-determinations, the four aggregates are a limited object for one who is greedy, hating, deluded, restrained, comprehending, or reviewing in regard to the fifty-five kinds of sense-desire element.🔽They are a great object for one who is greedy, hating, deluded, restrained, or comprehending in regard to the twenty-seven kinds of fine-material and immaterial dhammas.

original: saṃvarantassa pariggahaṃ paṭṭhapentassa mahaggatārammaṇā, maggaphalanibbānāni paccavekkhantassa
analyzed: saṃvarantassa pariggaham paṭṭhapentassa mahaggata ārammaṇāḥ magga phala nibbānāni paccavekkhantassa
translated: They are an immeasurable object for one who is reviewing the path, fruition, and Nibbāna.

original: appamāṇārammaṇā, paññattiṃ paccavekkhaṇakāle navattabbārammaṇāti.🔽Teyeva sekkhāsekkhānaṃ maggapaccavekkhaṇakāle maggārammaṇā honti, maggakāle sahajātahetunā
analyzed: appamāṇa ārammaṇā paññattim paccavekkhaṇa kāle navattabba ārammaṇā ti  te yeva sekkha asekkhānam magga paccavekkhaṇa kāle magga ārammaṇāḥ honti magga kāle sahajāta hetunā
translated: They are a non-existent object for one who is reviewing the determinations.🔽The same are a path object for the trainee and the adept when they are reviewing the path. At the time of the path they are path- originated by way of the path as conascence cause.

original: maggahetukā, maggaṃ garuṃ katvā paccavekkhaṇakāle ārammaṇādhipatinā maggādhipatino,
analyzed: magga hetukāḥ maggam garum katvā paccavekkhaṇa kāle ārammaṇa adhipatinā magga adhipatino
translated: When they are reviewing the path giving it prominence, they are path- dominated by way of the object-predominance.

original: vīriyajeṭṭhakaṃ vā vīmaṃsajeṭṭhakaṃ vā maggaṃ bhāventassa sahajātādhipatinā maggādhipatino,
analyzed: vīriya jeṭṭhakam vā vīmaṃsa jeṭṭhakam vā maggam bhāventassa sahajāta adhipatinā magga adhipatino
translated: When he develops the path headed by energy or by investigation, the path dominants are the dominants by co-nascence and by predominance.

original: chandajeṭṭhakaṃ pana cittajeṭṭhakaṃ vā bhāventassa navattabbārammaṇā nāma honti.
analyzed: chanda jeṭṭhakam pana citta jeṭṭhakam vā bhāventassa nava ttabba ārammaṇāḥ nāma honti
translated: But when he develops the path headed by zeal or by consciousness, they are called “having a non-dealt-with object.”

original: Atītāni pana khandhadhātuāyatanāni ārabbha rajjantassa dussantassa muyhantassa saṃvarantassa🔽pariggahaṃ paṭṭhapentassa atītārammaṇā honti, anāgatāni ārabbha anāgatārammaṇā honti,
analyzed: atītāni pana khandha dhātu āyatanāni ārabbha rajjantassa dussantassa muyhantassa saṃvarantassa  pariggaham paṭṭhapentassa atīta ārammaṇāḥ honti anāgatāni ārabbha anāgata ārammaṇāḥ honti
translated: But when he is greedy, deluded, or conceited about past aggregates, elements, and sense bases,🔽they are past objects. When he is greedy, deluded, or conceited about future ones, they are future objects.

original: paccuppannāni ārabbha paccuppannārammaṇā honti, paññattiṃ vā nibbānaṃ vā paccavekkhantassa
analyzed: paccuppannāni ārabbha paccuppanna ārammaṇāḥ honti paññattim vā nibbānam vā paccavekkhantassa
translated: When he is greedy, deluded, or conceited about present ones, they are present objects. When he reviews a description or Nibbāna,

original: navattabbārammaṇā honti.
analyzed: nava ttabba ārammaṇāḥ honti
translated: they are non-dealt-with objects.

original: Tathā attano khandhadhātuāyatanāni ārabbha rajjantassa dussantassa muyhantassa saṃvarantassa
analyzed: tathā attano khandha dhātu āyatanāni ārabbha rajjantassa dussantassa muyhantassa saṃvarantassa
translated: Similarly, when he is greedy, deluded, or conceited about his own aggregates, elements, and sense bases,

original: pariggahaṃ paṭṭhapentassa ajjhattārammaṇā honti, paresaṃ khandhadhātuāyatanāni ārabbha
analyzed: pariggaham paṭṭhapentassa ajjhatta ārammaṇāḥ honti paresam khandha dhātu āyatanāni ārabbha
translated: they are internal objects. When he is greedy, deluded, or conceited about others’ aggregates, elements, and sense bases,

original: evaṃ pavattentassa bahiddhārammaṇā, paṇṇattinibbānapaccavekkhaṇakālepi bahiddhārammaṇāyeva,
analyzed: evam pavattentassa bahiddhā ārammaṇā paṇṇatti nibbāna paccavekkhaṇa kāle pi bahiddhā ārammaṇāya eva
translated: When he is contemplating in this way, the object is external. At the time of reviewing the described Nibbāna, the object is also external.

original: kālena ajjhattaṃ kālena bahiddhā dhammesu evaṃ pavattentassa ajjhattabahiddhārammaṇā,
analyzed: kālena ajjhattam kālena bahiddhā dhammesu evam pavattentassa ajjhatta bahiddhā ārammaṇā
translated: When he is contemplating in this way sometimes internally and sometimes externally, the object is internal and external.

original: ākiñcaññāyatanakāle navattabbārammaṇāti veditabbā.
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatana kāle veditabbā
translated: At the time of the base consisting of nothingness, the object is not to be discerned.

original: Iti bhagavā imaṃ khandhavibhaṅgaṃ suttantabhājanīyādivasena tayo parivaṭṭe nīharitvā
analyzed: iti bhagavā imam khandha vibhaṅgam suttanta bhājanīya ādi vasena tayo parivaṭṭe nīharitvā
translated: So the Blessed One, having taken this exposition of the aggregates by way of the three turnings of the Thread, the fourfold discernment, etc.,🔽and having shown it by way of the exposition,

original: bhājento dassesi. Tīsupi hi parivaṭṭesu ekova paricchedo. Rūpakkhandho hi sabbattha
analyzed: bhājentaḥ dassesi tīsu pi hi parivaṭṭesu ekaḥ iva paricchedaḥ rūpa kkhandho hi sabbattha
translated: in all three turnings there is only one section. For the material aggregate is in all cases

original: kāmāvacaroyeva. Cattāro khandhā catubhūmakā lokiyalokuttaramissakā kathitāti.
analyzed: cattāraḥ khandhā catu bhūmakā lokiya lokuttara missakā kathitā ati
translated: in the sense sphere only. The four aggregates are in the four planes and are said to be mixed mundane and supramundane.

original: Sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sammoha vinodaniyā vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The Commentary on the Exposition in the Description of the Clearing Up of the Obscurations

original: Khandhavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽2. Āyatanavibhaṅgo
analyzed: khandha vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  āyatana vibhaṅgaḥ
translated: The exposition of the aggregates is ended.🔽The Exposition of the Bases

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Thread’s Requisites

original: 154. Idāni tadanantare āyatanavibhaṅganiddese suttantabhājanīyaṃ tāva dassento dvādasāyatanāni cakkhāyatanaṃ rūpāyatanantiādimāha. Tattha pāḷimuttakena tāva nayena –
analyzed: idāni tad anantare āyatana vibhaṅga niddese suttanta bhājanīyam tāva dassentaḥ dvādasa āyatanāni cakkhāyatanam rūpāyatana nti ādim āha tattha pāḷimuttakena tāva nayena
translated: Now, in the description of the bases that follows next, he first of all gives the Thread’s own version in the passage beginning “The twelve bases: the eye base, the form base” . Herein, firstly, the exposition by the method of the text is this:

original: Atthalakkhaṇatāvatva, kamasaṅkhepavitthārā;
analyzed: attha lakkhaṇa tāva tva kama saṅkhepa vitthārā
translated: Meaning, characteristic, and so on,🔽And also number, and likewise,🔽How they are to be seen, and also,

original: Tathā daṭṭhabbato ceva, viññātabbo vinicchayo.🔽Tattha visesato tāva cakkhatīti cakkhu; rūpaṃ assādeti, vibhāveti cāti attho. Rūpayatīti
analyzed: tathā daṭṭhabbataḥ ca iva viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ  tattha visesato tāva cakkhati iti cakkhu rūpam assādeti vibhāveti ca ati atthaḥ rūpayati iti
translated: How they are to be known:

original: rūpaṃ; vaṇṇavikāraṃ āpajjamānaṃ hadayaṅgatabhāvaṃ pakāsetīti attho. Suṇātīti sotaṃ.
analyzed: rūpam vaṇṇa vikāram āpajjamānam hadayaṅgata bhāvam pakāseti iti attho suṇāti iti sotam
translated: Herein, firstly, the eye is so called with the -ak- added 1 because it sees 2 ; the meaning is that it enjoys and discerns visible forms. The visible-form base is so called with the -a added because it is visible 3 ; the meaning is that it makes known the state of being in the heart when it is undergoing a change of colour. The ear is so called with the -a added because it hears ;

original: Sappatīti saddo; udāhariyatīti attho. Ghāyatīti ghānaṃ. Gandhayatīti gandho; attano🔽vatthuṃ sūcayatīti attho. Jīvitaṃ avhāyatīti jivhā. Rasanti taṃ sattāti raso; assādentīti
analyzed: sappati iti saddaḥ udāhariyati iti atthaḥ ghāyati iti ghānam gandhayati iti gandhaḥ attanaḥ  vatthum sūcayati iti atthaḥ jīvitam avhāyati iti jivhāḥ rasanti tam rasaḥ assādenti iti
translated: Sound is so called with the -a added because it is sounded ; the meaning is that it is uttered. The nose is so called with the -a added because it smells ;🔽Odour is so called with the -a added because it smells out 1 its own physical support, the meaning is. The tongue is so called with the -a added because it tastes ;

original: attho. Kucchitānaṃ sāsavadhammānaṃ āyoti kāyo. Āyoti uppattideso. Phusīyatīti phoṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ kucchitānam sāsava dhammānam āyo ti kāyaḥ āyo ti uppatti deso phusīyati iti phoṭṭhabbam
translated: Flavour is so called with the -a added because it is savoured by creatures; the meaning is that it is enjoyed. The body is so called with the -a added because it is the arrival-place 1 for the foulness-of-ideas called “ the body’s” ; the meaning is that it is the place of origin. The tangible-data base is so called with the -a added because it is touched ;

original: Manatīti mano. Attano lakkhaṇaṃ dhārayantīti dhammā.
analyzed: manati iti manaḥ attanaḥ lakkhaṇam dhārayanti iti dhammā
translated: It cognizes, thus it is mind . It bears its own characteristic, thus it is a mental datum .

original: Avisesato pana āyatanato, āyānaṃ tananato, āyatassa ca nayanato āyatananti veditabbaṃ.🔽Cakkhurūpādīsu hi taṃtaṃdvārārammaṇā cittacetasikā dhammā sena sena anubhavanādinā
analyzed: avisesato pana āyatanataḥ āyānam tananataḥ āyatassa ca nayanataḥ āyatananti veditabbam  cakkhu rūpa ādīsu hi taṃ taṃ dvāra ārammaṇā citta cetasikā dhammā anubhavana ādinā
translated: But in general it should be understood that a sense base is so called because it is a spreading out , because it is a stretching , and because it is a leading of what is spread out .

original: kiccena āyatanti uṭṭhahanti ghaṭṭenti vāyamantīti vuttaṃ hoti. Te ca pana āyabhūte🔽dhamme etāni tanonti vitthārentīti vuttaṃ hoti. Idañca anamatagge saṃsāre pavattaṃ
analyzed: kiccena āyatanti uṭṭhahanti ghaṭṭenti vā āyamanti iti vuttam hoti te ca pana āya bhūte  dhamme etāni tanonti vitthārenti iti vuttam hoti idam ca an amatagge saṃsāre pavattam
translated: For in the case of eye and visible data, etc., the states of consciousness and its concomitants that occur in the various doors and objects spread out , arise, come into being, in the various doors and objects,

original: atīva āyataṃ saṃsāradukkhaṃ yāva na nivattati tāva nayanteva, pavattayantīti vuttaṃ🔽hoti. Iti sabbepi me dhammā āyatanato āyānaṃ tananato āyatassa ca nayanato ‘āyatanaṃ
analyzed: atīva āyatam saṃsāra dukkham yāva na nivattati tāva nayantā iva pavattayanti iti vuttam  hoti iti sabbe api me dhammāḥ āyatanataḥ āyānam tananataḥ āyatassa ca nayanataḥ āyatanam
translated: and they stretch , extend, those states that are the spreaders out,

original: āyatana’nti vuccanti.
analyzed: āyatanam iti vuccanti
translated: and they lead them, cause them to occur, it is said. And so all these states are called “sense bases” because they are spreadings out , because they are stretchings , and because they are leadings of what is spread out .

original: Apica nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena, ākaraṭṭhena, samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṭṭhena, sañjātidesaṭṭhena,
analyzed: apica nivāsa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena ākara ṭṭhena samosaraṇa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena sañjāti desa ṭṭhena
translated: Moreover, they are called “sense bases” in the sense of a place of keeping , in the sense of a store, in the sense of a meeting place, in the sense of a birthplace,

original: kāraṇaṭṭhena ca āyatanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tathā hi loke “issarāyatanaṃ vāsudevāyatana”ntiādīsu
analyzed: kāraṇa ṭṭhena ca āyatanam veditabbam tathā hi loke issara āyatanam vāsudeva āyatana nti ādīsu
translated: And it should be understood that the bases are so called in the sense of cause. For in ordinary usage such passages as “The king’s court” , “Vāsudeva’s court” ,🔽show that a place where a king or Vāsudeva is is called his “court” . And in such passages as “The court of gold, the court of silver” ,

original: nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ āyatananti vuccati. “Suvaṇṇāyatanaṃ rajatāyatana”ntiādīsu ākaro. Sāsane
analyzed: nivāsa ṭṭhānam āyatananti vuccati suvaṇṇāyatanam rajatāyatana nti ādīsu ākaraḥ sāsane
translated: the word is used in the sense of a figure. In the scriptures it is used in the sense of a place of resort in such passages as “The birds resort to the delightful lake” ,

original: pana “manorame āyatane sevanti naṃ vihaṅgamā”tiādīsu samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ. “Dakkhiṇāpatho🔽gunnaṃ āyatana”ntiādīsu sañjātideso. “Tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati
analyzed: pana manorame āyatane sevanti nam vihaṅgamāti ādīsu samosaraṇa ṭhānam dakkhiṇāpatho  gunnam āyatana nti ādīsu sañjā atidesaḥ tatra tatra iva sakkhibhabbatam pāpuṇāti sati
translated: in the sense of a place of origin in such passages as “The southern region is the court of the horses” ,

original: satiāyatane”tiādīsu kāraṇaṃ.🔽Cakkhurūpādīsu cāpi te te cittacetasikā dhammā nivasanti tadāyattavuttitāyāti cakkhādayo🔽nesaṃ nivāsanaṭṭhānaṃ. Cakkhādīsu ca te ākiṇṇā taṃ nissitattā tadārammaṇattā cāti
analyzed: kāraṇam  cakkhu rūpa ādīsu ca api te te citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ nivasanti tad āyatta vutti tāya ati cakkhu ādayaḥ  na īsam nivāsana ṭṭhānam cakkha ādīsu ca te ākiṇṇā tam nissita ttā tad ārammaṇa ttā ca ati
translated: and in the sense of a cause in such passages as “He attains the ability to be a witness here and now of the deathless state that is unborn, unoriginated, not made or fashioned, and which, they say, is our refuge here and our resort in the world beyond” .🔽And in the case of eye and visible data, etc., too, the states of consciousness and its concomitants that occur in dependence on them dwell there, thus the eye, etc., are their “dwelling” .🔽And they are the figure of the eye, etc., because they are dependent on them and because they have them as their object.

original: cakkhādayo nesaṃ ākaro. Cakkhādayo ca nesaṃ samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ, tattha tattha vatthudvārārammaṇavasena
analyzed: cakkhu ādayo ākaro cakkhu ādayo ca nesam samosaraṇa ṭhānam tattha tattha vatthu dvāra ārammaṇa vasena
translated: And the eye, etc., are their place of meeting, because they occur in association with the eye, etc., in the sense of physical basis, door, and object.

original: samosaraṇato. Cakkhādayo ca nesaṃ sañjātideso; taṃ nissayārammaṇabhāvena tattheva
analyzed: samosaraṇato cakkha ādayo ca na isam tam nissaya ārammaṇa bhāvena tattha eva
translated: and as the place of meeting. And the eye, etc., are the place of birth of these states, because they arise there by way of the support and object conditions.

original: uppattito. Cakkhādayo ca nesaṃ kāraṇaṃ, tesaṃ abhāve abhāvatoti. Iti nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena,
analyzed: uppattitaḥ cakkha ādayo ca nesam kāraṇam tesam abhāve abhāvato ti iti nivāsa ṭṭhena
translated: And the eye, etc., are the cause of these states, because they are absent when these are absent.🔽So these states are called bases because of the meaning of abode,

original: ākaraṭṭhena, samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṭṭhena, sañjātidesaṭṭhena, kāraṇaṭṭhenāti imehi kāraṇehi🔽ete dhammā ‘āyatanaṃ āyatana’nti vuccanti. Tasmā yathāvuttenatthena cakkhu ca taṃ
analyzed: ākara ṭṭhena samosaraṇa ṭhāna ṭṭhena sañjā atidesa ṭṭhena kāraṇa ṭṭhena ati imehi kāraṇehi  ete dhammā āyatanam āyatananti vuccanti tasmai yathā vuttena atthena cakkhu ca taṃ
translated: because of the meaning of source, because of the meaning of place of meeting, because of the meaning of place of birth, and because of the meaning of cause.🔽Thus “eye” is a base and “base” is a meaning,🔽and so it is called the eye base. And so with the rest up to “mental object” is a base and “base” is a meaning,

original: āyatanañcāti cakkhāyatanaṃ…pe… dhammā ca te āyatanañcāti dhammāyatananti evaṃ tāvettha🔽‘atthato’ viññātabbo vinicchayo.🔽‘Lakkhaṇato’ti cakkhādīnaṃ lakkhaṇatopettha viññātabbo vinicchayo. Tāni ca pana nesaṃ lakkhaṇāni heṭṭhā rūpakaṇḍaniddese vuttanayeneva veditabbāni.
analyzed: āyatanam ca ati cakkhu āyatanam pe dhammā ca te āyatanam ca ati dhamma āyatanam ti evam tau ettha  atthataḥ viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ  lakkhaṇato ti cakkha ādīnam lakkhaṇato upa ittha viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ tāni ca pana nesam lakkhaṇāni heṭṭhā rūpa kaṇḍa niddese vutta nayena iva veditabbāni
translated: and so it is called the mental-object base. This, in the first place, is how the exposition should be known “as to meaning.”🔽As to characteristic: the exposition should be known here “as to characteristic” of the eye, etc., too. And their characteristics should be understood in the way given in the Description of the Bases in the Paṭṭhāna.🔽As to delimitation: this is a term for the individual essence.

original: ‘Tāvatvato’ti tāvabhāvato. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – cakkhādayopi hi dhammā eva. Evaṃ sati
analyzed: tāva tvataḥ ti tāva bhāvataḥ idam vuttam hoti cakkha ādayaḥ api hi dhammāḥ eva evam sati
translated: The eye, etc., are only states, and so is a base. So in that sense

original: dhammāyatanamicceva avatvā kasmā dvādasāyatanāni vuttānīti ce? Cha viññāṇakāyuppattidvārārammaṇavavatthānato.
analyzed: dhammāyatanam iccā iva avatvā kasmā dvādasa āyatanāni vuttāni iti ce cha viññāṇa kāya uppatti dvāra ārammaṇa vavatthānato
translated: Because they are the defining of the doors and objects for the arising of the six kinds of consciousness.

original: Idha channaṃ viññāṇakāyānaṃ dvārabhāvena ārammaṇabhāvena ca vavatthānato ayameva🔽tesaṃ bhedo hotīti dvādasa vuttāni. Cakkhuviññāṇavīthipariyāpannassa hi viññāṇakāyassa
analyzed: idha channam viññāṇa kāyānam dvāra bhāvena ārammaṇa bhāvena ca vavatthānataḥ ayam eva  tesam bhedaḥ hoti iti dvādasa vuttāni cakkhu viññāṇa vīthi pariyāpannassa hi viññāṇa kāyassa
translated: For the difference between them is that this is the defining of the six kinds of consciousness as doors and as objects.

original: cakkhāyatanameva uppattidvāraṃ, rūpāyatanameva cārammaṇaṃ. Tathā itarāni itaresaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhāyatanam eva uppatti dvāram rūpāyatanam eva ca ārammaṇam tathā itarāni itaresam
translated: That is why twelve are stated. For the kind of consciousness included in the eye-consciousness group has only the eye base as its door for arising and only the visible-data base as its object. So too the others with the others.

original: Chaṭṭhassa pana bhavaṅgamanasaṅkhāto manāyatanekadesova uppattidvāraṃ, asādhāraṇañca🔽dhammāyatanaṃ ārammaṇanti. Iti channaṃ viññāṇakāyānaṃ uppattidvārārammaṇavavatthānato
analyzed: chaṭṭhassa pana uppatti dvāram asādhāraṇam ca  dhamma āyatanam ārammaṇanti iti channam viññāṇa kāyānam uppatti dvāra ārammaṇa vavatthānato
translated: But the sixth has only one part of the mind base, called the life-continuum mind, as its door for arising, and the mental-data base is its object, which is not shared by the others.

original: dvādasa vuttānīti. Evamettha ‘tāvatvato’ viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: dvādasa vuttāni iti evam ettha tāva tvataḥ viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: So they are stated as twelve because they define the doors and objects for the arising of the six kinds of consciousness. This is how the exposition should be known here as to extent.

original: ‘Kamato’ti idhāpi pubbe vuttesu uppattikkamādīsu desanākkamova yujjati. Ajjhattikesu
analyzed: kamataḥ ti idha api pubbe vuttesu uppatti kkama ādīsu desanā kkamaḥ uva yujjati ajjhattikesu
translated: As to order: here too only the order of teaching, which is that stated in the first chapter, is appropriate.

original: hi āyatanesu sanidassanasappaṭighavisayattā cakkhāyatanaṃ pākaṭanti paṭhamaṃ desitaṃ.🔽Tato anidassanasappaṭighavisayāni sotāyatanādīni. Atha vā dassanānuttariyasavanānuttariyahetubhāvena
analyzed: hi āyatanesu sa nidassana sa paṭigha visaya ttā cakkha āyatanam pākaṭanti paṭhamam desitam  tatas anidassana sappaṭigha visayāni sotāyatana ādīni atha vā dassana anuttariya savana anuttariya hetu bhāvena
translated: The eye base is taught first because it is obvious, since it has a visible physical object as its domain.

original: bahūpakārattā ajjhattikesu cakkhāyatanasotāyatanāni paṭhamaṃ desitāni. Tato ghānāyatanādīni
analyzed: bahu upakāra ttā ajjhattikesu cakkhāyatana sotāyatanāni paṭhamam desitāni tatas ghānāyatana ādīni
translated: Or alternatively, the eye and ear bases are taught first among the internal bases because they are of much help as the cause for the unsurpassed seeing and hearing.🔽Then the three beginning with the nose base.

original: tīṇi. Pañcannampi gocaravisayattā ante manāyatanaṃ. Cakkhādīnaṃ pana gocarattā tassa
analyzed: tīṇi gocara visaya ttā ante mana āyatanam cakkha ādīnam pana gocara ttā tassa
translated: The mind base is taught last because it is the domain of all five.🔽But the visible-data base, etc., are taught immediately next to the eye base, etc., because they are the domains of those.

original: tassa anantarāni bāhiresu rūpāyatanādīni. Apica viññāṇuppattikāraṇavavatthānatopi
analyzed: tassa anantarāni bāhiresu rūpa āyatana ādīni api ca viññāṇa uppatti kāraṇa vavatthānataḥ pi
translated: Or again, this order should be understood as due to the delimitation of the cause for the arising of consciousness.

original: ayameva tesaṃ kamo veditabbo. Vuttañhetaṃ “cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ…pe…
analyzed: ayam eva tesam kamaḥ veditabbaḥ vuttam ha etam cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇam pe
translated: For this is said: “Dependent on the eye and forms eye-consciousness arises” , and so on down to

original: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇa”nti evaṃ ‘kamato’pettha viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: manam ca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manaḥ viññāṇan ti evam kamataḥ upa ittha viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: “dependent on the mind and mental objects mind-consciousness arises” .🔽This is how the exposition should be known here “as to order. ”

original: ‘Saṅkhepavitthārā’ti saṅkhepato hi manāyatanassa ceva dhammāyatanekadesassa ca nāmena, tadavasesānañca āyatanānaṃ rūpena saṅgahitattā dvādasāpi āyatanāni nāmarūpamattameva honti.
analyzed: saṅkhepa vitthārā ti saṅkhepataḥ hi manāyatanassa ca iva dhammāyatana ekadesassa ca nāmena tad avasesānam ca āyatanānam rūpena saṅgahita ttā dvādasā api āyatanāni nāma rūpa mattam eva honti
translated: ‘Briefly and in detail’: for in brief the twelve bases are only mentality and materiality, since the mind base and the part of the mental-data base consisting of the three kinds of feeling are included under the name, and the remaining bases are included under materiality.

original: Vitthārato pana ajjhattikesu tāva cakkhāyatanaṃ jātivasena cakkhupasādamattameva,🔽paccayagatinikāyapuggalabhedato pana anantappabhedaṃ. Tathā sotāyatanādīni cattāri.🔽Manāyatanaṃ tebhūmakakusalākusalavipākakiriyaviññāṇabhedena ekāsītippabhedaṃ, vatthupaṭipadādibhedato🔽pana anantappabhedaṃ. Rūpagandharasāyatanāni samuṭṭhānabhedato catuppabhedāni, saddāyatanaṃ
analyzed: vitthārato pana ajjhattikesu tāva cakkhāyatanam jāti vasena cakkhu pasāda mattam eva  paccaya gati nikāya puggala bhedato pana ananta ppabhedam tathā sotāyatana ādīni cattāri  manāyatanam tebhūmaka kusala akusala vipāka kiriya viññāṇa bhedena ekāsīti ppabhedam vatthu paṭipadā ādi bhedato  pana ananta ppabhedam rūpa gandha rasa āyatanāni samuṭṭhāna bhedato catu pabhedāni sadda āyatanam
translated: But in detail, the eye base is only eye sensitivity as to species;🔽but it is of infinite variety as to the different kinds of beings, destinies, abodes of beings, modes of origin, and individuals. So too the ear base, and so on.

original: dvippabhedaṃ. Sabhāgavisabhāgabhedato pana sabbānipi anantappabhedāni. Phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ
analyzed: dvi ppabhedam sabhāga visabhāga bhedato pana sabbāni api ananta ppabhedāni phoṭṭhabbāyatanam
translated: The mind base is of eighty-nine kinds as the consciousnesses of the three planes, profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate, and of kamma-result, and of functional consciousness. But it is of infinite variety as to the different kinds of physical basis, path, and so on. The form, odour, and taste bases are each of four kinds as to primary and secondary, and as to realm of existence. The sound base is of two kinds as to primary and secondary. But all are of infinite variety as to the different kinds of primary and secondary, and so on. The tangible-data base is of eleven kinds as the eleven kinds of tangibles.

original: pathavīdhātutejodhātuvāyodhātuvasena tippabhedaṃ, samuṭṭhānato catuppabhedaṃ, sabhāgavisabhāgato🔽anekappabhedaṃ. Dhammāyatanaṃ tebhūmakadhammārammaṇavasena anekappabhedanti. Evaṃ
analyzed: pathavī dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu vasena tippabhedam samuṭṭhānato catuppabhedam sabhāga visabhāgato  aneka ppabhedam dhammāyatanam tebhūmaka dhamma ārammaṇa vasena aneka ppabhedam ti evam
translated: The earth element, fire element, and air element are each of three kinds, and they are of four kinds according to source.🔽They are of many kinds according to similarity and dissimilarity.🔽The mental data base is of many kinds according to the states of the three planes as object.

original: saṅkhepavitthārā viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: saṅkhepa vitthārā viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is how the exposition should be known🔽as to brief and detailed.

original: ‘Daṭṭhabbato’ti ettha pana sabbānevetāni āyatanāni anāgamanato aniggamanato ca daṭṭhabbāni.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbato ti ettha pana sabbān eva etāni āyatanāni anāgamanataḥ aniggamanataḥ ca daṭṭhabbāni
translated: As to how to be seen: all these bases should be seen as to non-coming and non-going.

original: Na hi tāni pubbe udayā kutoci āgacchanti, nāpi uddhaṃ vayā kuhiñci gacchanti; atha🔽kho pubbe udayā appaṭiladdhasabhāvāni, uddhaṃ vayā paribhinnasabhāvāni, pubbantāparantavemajjhe
analyzed: na hi tāni pubbe udayā kutoci āgacchanti na api uddham vayā kuhiñci gacchanti atha  kho pubbe udayā a paṭiladdha sabhāvāni uddham vayā paribhinna sabhāvāni pubbanta aparanta vemajjhe
translated: For they do not come from anywhere before reappearing, nor do they go to anywhere after disappearing.🔽But rather, before reappearance they are non-existent as to individual essence, and after disappearance they are disintegrated as to individual essence.

original: paccayāyattavuttitāya avasāni pavattanti. Tasmā anāgamanato aniggamanato ca daṭṭhabbāni.
analyzed: paccaya āyatta vutti tāya avasāni pavattanti tasmai an āgamanataḥ a niggamanataḥ ca daṭṭhabbāni
translated: They occur in dependence on conditions, and so they are void. That is why they should be seen as to non-coming and non-going.

original: Tathā nirīhato abyāpārato ca. Na hi cakkhurūpādīnaṃ evaṃ hoti – ‘aho vata amhākaṃ
analyzed: tathā nirīhataḥ abyāpārato ca na hi cakkhu rūpa ādīnam evam hoti aho vata amhākam
translated: And likewise as to non-hastening and non-purposive action. For it is not the case that eye and visible data, etc., think: “Let us go and make eye-consciousness, etc., to arise.”

original: sāmaggiyā viññāṇaṃ nāma uppajjeyyā’ti, na ca tāni viññāṇuppādanatthaṃ dvārabhāvena🔽vatthubhāvena ārammaṇabhāvena vā īhanti, na byāpāramāpajjanti; atha kho dhammatāvesā
analyzed: sāmaggiyā viññāṇam nāma uppajjeyyāti na ca tāni viññāṇa uppādana ttham dvāra bhāvena  vatthu bhāvena ārammaṇa bhāvena vā īhanti na byāpāram āpajjanti atha kho dhamma tā āvesā
translated: ‘May consciousness arise in dependence on the six bases,’ but those six bases do not wish for consciousness to arise, nor do they make an effort (to that end), nor do they incite (consciousness to arise), nor do they instigate (consciousness to arise),🔽but it is the nature of things that consciousness should arise in dependence on the six bases.

original: yaṃ cakkhurūpādīnaṃ sāmaggiyaṃ cakkhuviññāṇādīni sambhavanti. Tasmā nirīhato abyāpārato
analyzed: yam cakkhu rūpa ādīnam sāmaggiyam cakkhu viññāṇa ādīni sambhavanti tasmai nirīhataḥ a byāpārataḥ
translated: “If the coming together of these things were to give rise to consciousness, would that consciousness be dependent on conditions or not?” They do not wish for it to arise, nor do they make an effort for it to arise, either as a door for the arising of consciousness or as a basis or object. They do not wish for it or make an effort, but it is the nature of things that eye-consciousness, etc., arise when there is the coming together of eye and visible form, etc. Therefore they should be seen as not wishing and not making an effort.

original: ca daṭṭhabbāni. Apica ajjhattikāni suññagāmo viya daṭṭhabbāni dhuvasubhasukhattabhāvavirahitattā,🔽bāhirāni gāmaghātakacorā viya ajjhattikānaṃ abhighātakattā. Vuttañhetaṃ – “cakkhu,
analyzed: ca daṭṭhabbāni apica ajjhattikāni suñña gāmaḥ viya daṭṭhabbāni dhuva subha sukhatta bhāva virahita ttā  bāhirāni gāma ghātaka corāḥ viya ajjhattikānam abhighātaka ttā vuttam ha etam cakkhu
translated: Moreover, the internal sense bases should be seen as an empty village because they are devoid of permanence, pleasure, health, and substantiality;🔽the external sense bases should be seen as robbers who attack the village because they attack the internal sense bases. original: bhikkhave, haññati manāpāmanāpehi rūpehīti vitthāro. Apica ajjhattikāni cha pāṇakā
analyzed: bhikkhave haññati manāpa amanāpehi rūpehi iti vitthāraḥ apica ajjhattikāni cha pāṇakā
translated: Moreover, the internal sense bases should be seen as the six living beings,

original: viya daṭṭhabbāni, bāhirāni tesaṃ gocarā viyāti. Evampettha ‘daṭṭhabbato’ viññātabbo vinicchayoti.
analyzed: viya daṭṭhabbāni bāhirāni tesam gocarāḥ viya ati evam pa ittha daṭṭhabbataḥ viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ ti

original: Idāni tesaṃ vipassitabbākāraṃ dassetuṃ cakkhuṃ aniccantiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha cakkhu
analyzed: idāni tesam vipassitabba ākāram dassetum cakkhuṃ aniccan ti ādi āraddham tattha cakkhu
translated: Now, in order to point out the aspect to be seen in them, the passage beginning with “The eye is impermanent” is stated. Herein:

analyzed: tāva hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena aniccanti veditabbam aparehi pi catūhi kāraṇehi aniccam

original: Tadeva paṭipīḷanaṭṭhena dukkhaṃ. Yasmā vā etaṃ uppannaṃ ṭhitiṃ pāpuṇāti, ṭhitiyaṃ
analyzed: tat eva paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena dukkham yasmai vai etam uppannam ṭhitim pāpuṇāti ṭhitiyam

translated: because of being a basis for suffering, and because it is opposed to pleasure.

original: mā jiratu, jarappataṃ mā bhijjatūti imesu tīsu ṭhānesu kassaci vasavattibhāvo natthi,
analyzed: mā jiratu jarappatam mā bhijjatu iti imesu tīsu ṭhānesu kassaci vasa vatti bhāvaḥ natthi

original: anattalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāsambuddho hi anattalakkhaṇaṃ dassento aniccena vā dasseti,
analyzed: anatta lakkhaṇam sammāsambuddhaḥ hi anatta lakkhaṇam dassentaḥ aniccena vā dasseti
translated: the characteristic of not-self. For the Fully Enlightened One, in showing the characteristic of not-self, shows it either as impermanent or as painful or as not-self.

original: dukkhena vā, aniccadukkhehi vā. Tattha “cakkhu, attāti yo vadeyya, taṃ na upapajjati.🔽Cakkhussa uppādopi vayopi paññāyati. Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati ‘attā
analyzed: dukkhena vā anicca dukkhehi vā tattha cakkhu attā ati yaḥ vadeyya tam na upapajjati  cakkhussa uppādaḥ api vayaḥ api paññāyati yassa kho pana uppādaḥ api vayaḥ api paññāyati attā
translated: the characteristic of not-self. For when the Fully Enlightened One shows the characteristic of not-self, he shows it either by what is impermanent or by what is painful or by what is impermanent and painful. Herein, when he said ‘ If anyone were to say “The eye is self,” that would not be tenable.

original: me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti. Tasmā taṃ na upapajjati – cakkhu
analyzed: me uppajjati ca veti ca ati iccassa evam āgatam hoti tasmā tam na upapajjati cakkhu
translated: The arising and falling away of eye are discerned. But if the arising and falling away of eye were discerned, it would not be tenable that “My self arises and falls away” . That is why it is not tenable to say “The eye is self” .

original: attāti yo vadeyya iti cakkhu anattā”ti. Imasmiṃ sutte aniccena anattalakkhaṇaṃ dassesi.
analyzed: attā iti yaḥ vadeyya iti cakkhu anattā ati imasmim sutte aniccena anatta lakkhaṇam dassesi
translated: Thus the eye is not-self’ , he showed the characteristic of not-self by what is impermanent in this sutta.

original: “Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, anattā. Rūpañca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, na yidaṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: rūpam bhikkhave anattā rūpam ca hi idam bhikkhave attā abhavissa na yidam rūpam
translated: ‘ Materiality, bhikkhus, is not self. Now, if this materiality were self, this materiality

analyzed: yasmai ca kho bhikkhave rūpam anattā tasmai rūpam ābādhāya saṃvattati na ca labbhati
translated: But precisely because materiality is not self, materiality leads to affliction, and it is not possible to have of materiality:

analyzed: rūpe evam me rūpam hotu evam me rūpam mā ahosi iti imasmin sutte dukkhena anatta lakkhaṇam
translated: In the sutta, “Let my material form be thus; let my material form not be thus,” he showed the characteristic of not-self by means of suffering.

analyzed: dassesi rūpam bhikkhave aniccam yat aniccam tat dukkham yat dukkham tat anattā

analyzed: yat anattā tam na itam mama na iso ham asmi na mā iso attā ati ādīsu anicca dukkhehi anatta lakkhaṇam
translated: what is not self is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.” In this way he showed the characteristic of not-self by means of impermanence and suffering.

original: dassesi. Kasmā? Aniccadukkhānaṃ pākaṭattā.

translated: For when a man falls on a stump or a thorn or something of the sort and his skin is broken, he says, “Oh, how impermanent things are!”

original: Evaṃ aniccaṃ pākaṭaṃ nāma. Attabhāvasmiṃ pana gaṇḍapiḷakādīsu vā uṭṭhitāsu khāṇukaṇṭakādīhi
analyzed: evam aniccam pākaṭam nāma atta bhāvasmim pana gaṇḍa piḷaka ādīsu vā uṭṭhitāsu khāṇu kaṇṭaka ādīhi
translated: Thus impermanence is obvious. But when boils, abscesses, etc., appear on his body or he is wounded by stumps, thorns, etc.,

analyzed: vā viddhāsu aho dukkhan ti vadanti evam dukkham pākaṭam nāma anatta lakkhaṇam apākaṭam

analyzed: andhakāram avibhūtam duppaṭivijjham duddīpanam duppaññāpanam anicca dukkha lakkhaṇāni

Mahiddhikā hi mahānubhāvā tāpasaparibbājakā🔽sarabhaṅgasatthārādayopi ‘aniccaṃ dukkha’nti vattuṃ sakkonti, ‘anattā’ti vattuṃ na🔽sakkonti. analyzed: uppādāḥ vā tathāgatānam anuppādāḥ vā paññāyanti anatta lakkhaṇam vinā buddha ppādāḥ na  paññāyati buddha uppādeya iva paññāyati mahiddhikāḥ hi mahā anubhāvā tāpasa paribbājakā  sarabhaṅga satthāra ādayaḥ api aniccam dukkham ti vattum sakkonti anattā ati vattum na  sakkonti sace hi te sampatta parisāya anattā ati vattum sakkuṇeyyum sampatta parisāya  magga phala paṭivedhaḥ bhaveyya anatta lakkhaṇa paññāpanam hi aññassa kassaci avisayaḥ  sabbaññu buddhānam eva visayaḥ evam etam anatta lakkhaṇam apākaṭam tasmā satthā anatta lakkhaṇam
translated: whether or not a Perfect One arises. Without the arising of a Buddha, the characteristic of not-self is not discerned, but with the arising of a Buddha it is discerned.
