original: dassento aniccena vā dassesi, dukkhena vā, aniccadukkhehi vā. Idha pana taṃ aniccadukkhehi🔽dassesīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: dassentaḥ aniccena vā dassesi dukkhena vā anicca dukkhehi vā idha pana tam anicca dukkhehi 🔽dassesi iti veditabbam
translated: whether or not the Buddhas arise. The characteristic of not-self is not evident without the arising of a Buddha; it becomes evident only with the arising of a Buddha. For there were powerful and mighty seers and wanderers, such as the teacher Sarabhangha, who were able to declare “Impermanent is all that is formed,” “Painful is all that is formed,” and “All dhammas are not-self,” but they were unable to declare “All dhammas are not-self.” For if they had been able to declare this to the assembly that had come to them, then the members of that assembly would have attained the paths and fruits. For the proclamation of the characteristic of not-self is not within the province of anyone else; it is within the province of the all-knowing Buddhas alone. Thus this characteristic of not-self is not evident. Therefore the Exalted One, in revealing the characteristic of not-self, revealed it either through the characteristic of impermanence or through the characteristic of pain or through both the characteristics of impermanence and pain. Here, however, it should be understood that he revealed it through the characteristics of impermanence and pain.

original: Imāni pana lakkhaṇāni kissa amanasikārā appaṭivedhā, kena paṭicchannattā, na upaṭṭhahanti?
analyzed: imāni pana lakkhaṇāni kissa amanasikārā appaṭivedhā kena paṭicchanna ttā na upaṭṭhahanti
translated: But why do these characteristics not appear when their respective aspects are not given attention and penetrated, and by what are they obscured?

original: Aniccalakkhaṇaṃ tāva udayabbayānaṃ amanasikārā appaṭivedhā, santatiyā paṭicchannattā,🔽na upaṭṭhāti. Dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanassa amanasikārā appaṭivedhā, iriyāpathehi
analyzed: anicca lakkhaṇam tāva udayabbayānam a manasikārā appaṭivedhā santatiyā paṭicchanna ttā  na upaṭṭhāti dukkha lakkhaṇam abhiṇha sampaṭipīḷanassa a manasikārāḥ a paṭivedhāḥ iriyāpathehi
translated: The characteristic of impermanence does not appear because the rise and subsidence are not given attention and penetrated, and it is obscured by continuity.🔽The characteristic of pain does not appear because the frequent oppression is not given attention and penetrated, and it is obscured by postures.

original: paṭicchannattā, na upaṭṭhāti. Anattalakkhaṇaṃ nānādhātuvinibbhogassa amanasikārā🔽appaṭivedhā, ghanena paṭicchannattā, na upaṭṭhāti. Udayabbayaṃ pana pariggahetvā
analyzed: paṭicchanna ttā na upaṭṭhāti anatta lakkhaṇam nānā dhātu vinibbhogassa a manasikārā  appaṭivedhā ghanena paṭicchanna ttā na upaṭṭhāti udaya bbayam pana pariggahetvā
translated: The characteristic of not-self does not appear because the analysis of the various elements is not given attention and penetrated, and it is obscured by compactness.

original: santatiyā vikopitāya aniccalakkhaṇaṃ yāthāvasarasato upaṭṭhāti. Abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanaṃ
analyzed: santatiyā vikopitāya anicca lakkhaṇam yāthāvasa rasataḥ upaṭṭhāti abhiṇha sampaṭipīḷanam
translated: But when the rise and subsidence are discerned and continuity is interrupted, the characteristic of impermanence appears as it actually is.

original: manasikatvā iriyāpathe ugghāṭite dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ yāthāvasarasato upaṭṭhāti. Nānādhātuyo
analyzed: manasikatvā iriyāpathe ugghāṭite dukkha lakkhaṇam yāthāvasarasataḥ upaṭṭhāti nānā dhātuyo
translated: And when frequent oppression is given attention and the postures are uncovered, the characteristic of pain appears as it actually is.

original: vinibbhujitvā ghanavinibbhoge kate anattalakkhaṇaṃ yāthāvasarasato upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: vinibbhujitvā ghana vinibbhoge kate anatta lakkhaṇam yāthāvasarasataḥ upaṭṭhāti
translated: And when the various elements are analysed and compactness is broken down, the characteristic of not-self appears as it actually is.

original: Ettha ca aniccaṃ aniccalakkhaṇaṃ, dukkhaṃ dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ, anattā anattalakkhaṇanti
analyzed: ettha ca aniccam anicca lakkhaṇam dukkham dukkha lakkhaṇam anattā anatta lakkhaṇanti
translated: And here the impermanent should be understood as the characteristic of impermanence, the painful as the characteristic of pain, and the not-self as the characteristic of not-self.

original: ayaṃ vibhāgo veditabbo. Tattha aniccanti khandhapañcakaṃ. Kasmā? Uppādavayaññathattabhāvā,
analyzed: ayam vibhāgaḥ veditabbo tattha aniccanti khandha pañcakam kasmā
translated: Herein, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are impermanent. Why? Because of arising and falling and change in what is present.

original: hutvā abhāvato vā; uppādavayaññathattaṃ aniccalakkhaṇaṃ, hutvā abhāvasaṅkhāto ākāravikāro
analyzed: hutvā abhāvataḥ vā uppāda vayaññathattam anicca lakkhaṇam hutvā abhāva saṅkhātaḥ ākāra vikāro
translated: Or because of non-existence after having been. Arising, falling and change are the characteristic of impermanence. Or the mode and alteration called non-existence after having been is the characteristic of impermanence.

original: vā. “Yadaniccaṃ taṃ dukkha”nti vacanato pana tadeva khandhapañcakaṃ dukkhaṃ. Kasmā?
analyzed: vā yat aniccam tam dukkhan ti vacanato pana tat eva khandha pañcakam dukkham kasmā
translated: But the same five aggregates as objects of clinging are painful because of the words, “What is impermanent is painful” . Why?

original: Abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanato; abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanākāro dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ. “Yaṃ dukkhaṃ taṃ
analyzed: abhiṇha sampaṭipīḷanataḥ abhiṇha sampaṭipīḷana ākāraḥ dukkha lakkhaṇam yat dukkham tam
translated: Because of frequent oppression. The mode of frequent oppression is the characteristic of pain.

original: anattā”ti pana vacanato tadeva khandhapañcakaṃ anattā. Kasmā? Avasavattanato; avasavattanākāro
analyzed: anattā ati pana vacanato tat eva khandha pañcakam anattā kasmai avasavattanataḥ avasavattana ākāro
translated: But the same five aggregates as objects of clinging are not-self because of the words, “What is painful is not-self” . Why? Because of non-domination. The mode of non-domination is the characteristic of not-self.

original: anattalakkhaṇaṃ. Iti aññadeva aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattā, aññāni aniccadukkhānattalakkhaṇāni.
analyzed: anatta lakkhaṇam iti aññat eva aniccam dukkham anattā aññāni anicca dukkha anatta lakkhaṇāni
translated: So impermanence, pain, and not-self are one thing, and the characteristics of impermanence, pain, and not-self are another.

original: Pañcakkhandhā, dvādasāyatanāni, aṭṭhārasa dhātuyoti idañhi sabbampi aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: pañca kkhandhāḥ dvādasa āyatanāni aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo ti idam hi sabbam pi aniccam dukkham
translated: The five aggregates, the twelve bases, and the eighteen elements are all impermanent, painful,

original: anattā nāma. Vuttappakārākāravikārā aniccadukkhānattalakkhaṇānīti.
analyzed: anattā nāma vutta ppakāra ākāra vikārāḥ anicca dukkha anatta lakkhaṇāni iti
translated: and not-self. They are impermanent, painful, and not-self in the way already described.

original: Saṅkhepato panettha dasāyatanāni kāmāvacarāni, dve tebhūmakāni. Sabbesupi sammasanacāro kathitoti veditabbo.
analyzed: saṅkhepato pana ittha dasa āyatanāni kāmāvacarāni dve tebhūmakāni sabbesu pi sammasana cāro kathito ti veditabbo
translated: In brief, ten of the bases belong to the sense sphere, and two to the three planes. The method of interpretation should be understood as given above.

original: Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
translated: The exposition of the Suttanta method.

original: 2. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā🔽155. Abhidhammabhājanīye yathā heṭṭhā vipassakānaṃ upakāratthāya “cakkhāyatanaṃ rūpāyatana”nti
analyzed: abhidhamma bhājanīye yathā heṭṭhā vipassakānam upakāra atthāya cakkhāyatanam rūpāyatananti
translated: The exposition of the Abhidhamma method

original: yugalato āyatanāni vuttāni, tathā avatvā ajjhattikabāhirānaṃ sabbākārato sabhāvadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: yugalataḥ āyatanāni vuttāni tathā avatvā ajjhattika bāhirānam sabba ākārato sabhāva dassana attham
translated: In the Abhidhamma method, the bases are not given in pairs as in the Suttanta method, in order to show the internal and external bases in all their aspects and in their individual essences.

original: “cakkhāyatanaṃ sotāyatana”nti evaṃ ajjhattikabāhiravavatthānanayena vuttāni.
analyzed: cakkhāyatanam sotāyatanan ti evam ajjhattika bāhira vavatthāna nayena vuttāni
translated: Instead, they are given by distinguishing the internal and external bases: “The eye base, the ear base” .

original: 156. Tesaṃ niddesavāre tattha katamaṃ cakkhāyatanantiādīni heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva veditabbāni.
analyzed: tesam niddesa vāre tattha katamam cakkha āyatana nti ādīni heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva veditabbāni
translated: In the description of these bases, the answers to the questions “What, bhikkhus, is the eye base?” and so on should be understood in the way given above.

original: 167. Yaṃ panetaṃ dhammāyatananiddese “tattha katamā asaṅkhatā dhātu? Rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo
analyzed: yam pana itam dhamma āyatana niddese tattha katamā asaṅkhatā dhātu rāga kkhayaḥ dosa kkhayo
translated: But as to what is said in the description of the base consisting of ideas as follows: “Herein, what is the unformed element? It is the destruction of greed, the destruction of hatred,🔽the destruction of delusion” , its meaning is as follows.

original: mohakkhayo”ti vuttaṃ, tatrāyamattho – asaṅkhatā dhātūti asaṅkhatasabhāvaṃ nibbānaṃ.🔽Yasmā panetaṃ āgamma rāgādayo khīyanti, tasmā rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayoti
analyzed: moha kkhayaḥ ti vuttam tatra ayam atthaḥ asaṅkhatā dhātū ti asaṅkhata sabhāvam nibbānam  yasmā pana itam āgamma rāga ādayaḥ khīyanti tasmā rāga kkhayaḥ dosa kkhayaḥ moha kkhayo ti
translated: The unformed element is Nibbāna, which has the nature of being unformed.

original: vuttaṃ. Ayamettha ācariyānaṃ samānatthakathā.
analyzed: vuttam ayam ettha ācariyānam samāna attha kathā
translated: But since greed, etc., are destroyed by arriving at it, therefore it is said that the destruction of greed, the destruction of hatred, the destruction of delusion is the unformed element. This is the teachers’ agreed explanation of the meaning here.

original: Vitaṇḍavādī panāha – ‘pāṭiyekkaṃ nibbānaṃ nāma natthi, kilesakkhayova nibbāna’nti.
analyzed: vitaṇḍa vādī pana āha pāṭiyekkam nibbānam nāma natthi kilesa khayaḥ va nibbānanti
translated: But the one who argues from the texts says that there is no Nibbāna apart from the destruction of defilements, which is called Nibbāna.

original: ‘Suttaṃ āharā’ti ca vutte “nibbānaṃ nibbānanti kho, āvuso sāriputta, vuccati; katamaṃ
analyzed: suttam āhara ati ca vutte nibbānam nibbānanti kho āvuso sāriputta vuccati katamam
translated: And when asked, “Quote a text,” he quotes this sutta: “‘Nibbāna, Nibbāna,’ it is said, friend Sāriputta.🔽What now is Nibbāna?

original: nu kho, āvuso, nibbānanti? Yo kho, āvuso, rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayo – idaṃ
analyzed: nu kho āvuso nibbānam ti yaḥ kho āvuso rāga khayaḥ dosa kkhayaḥ moha kkhayaḥ idam
translated: The destruction of greed, the destruction of hatred, the destruction of delusion—

original: vuccati nibbāna”nti etaṃ jambukhādakasuttaṃ āharitvā ‘iminā suttena veditabbaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ
analyzed: vuccati nibbānam ti etam jambukhādaka suttam āharitvā iminā suttena veditabbam pāṭiyekkam
translated: this is said to be Nibbāna” . And he concludes: “This is to be understood by this sutta as follows:

original: nibbānaṃ nāma natthi, kilesakkhayova nibbāna’nti āha. So vattabbo – ‘kiṃ pana yathā
analyzed: nibbānam nāma natthi kilesa khayaḥ va nibbānanti āha saḥ vattabbaḥ kim pana yathā
translated: “There is no Nibbāna, only the destruction of defilements is Nibbāna.”

original: cetaṃ suttaṃ tathā attho’ti? Addhā vakkhati – ‘āma, natthi suttato muñcitvā attho’ti.
analyzed: ca itam suttam tathā attho ti addhā vakkhati āma natthi suttataḥ muñcitvā attho ti
translated: He should be asked, “But is the meaning of this sutta as you say it is?” He will certainly say, “Yes, there is no meaning apart from the sutta.”

original: Tato vattabbo – ‘idaṃ tāva te suttaṃ ābhataṃ; anantarasuttaṃ āharā’ti. Anantarasuttaṃ
analyzed: tatas vattabbaḥ idam tāva te suttam ābhatam anantara suttam āharāti anantara suttam
translated: He should then be asked, “This sutta has been quoted; now quote the next one.”

original: nāma – “arahattaṃ arahattanti, āvuso sāriputta, vuccati; katamaṃ nu kho, āvuso, arahattanti?
analyzed: nāma arahattam arahattanti āvuso sāriputta vuccati katamam nu kho āvuso arahattanti
translated: The next sutta is: “‘Arahatship, arahatship’ is said, friend Sariputta. What now is arahatship?

original: Yo kho, āvuso, rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayo – idaṃ vuccati arahatta”nti idaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ kho āvuso rāga khayaḥ dosa khayaḥ moha kkhayaḥ idam vuccati arahattam ti idam
translated: The destruction of lust, the destruction of hatred, the destruction of delusion: this is called arahatship.”

original: tassevānantaraṃ ābhatasuttaṃ.🔽Imasmiṃ pana naṃ ābhate āhaṃsu – ‘nibbānaṃ nāma dhammāyatanapariyāpanno dhammo, arahattaṃ
analyzed: tassa iva anantaram ābhata suttam  imasmin pana nam ābhate āhaṃsu nibbānam nāma dhamma āyatana pariyāpannaḥ dhammaḥ arahattam
translated: This is the next sutta that should be quoted.🔽But when this sutta is quoted, they say, “Nibbana is a state included in the mental-data base, while arahatship is the four immaterial aggregates.

original: cattāro khandhā. Nibbānaṃ sacchikatvā viharanto dhammasenāpati nibbānaṃ pucchitopi
analyzed: cattāro khandhāḥ nibbānam sacchikatvā viharantaḥ dhamma senāpati nibbānam pucchitaḥ pi
translated: When the General of the Dhamma was dwelling having realized Nibbāna,

original: arahattaṃ pucchitopi kilesakkhayameva āha. Kiṃ pana nibbānañca arahattañca ekaṃ udāhu
analyzed: arahattam pucchitaḥ api kilesa kkhayam eva āha kim pana nibbānam ca arahattam ca ekam udāhu
translated: and when asked about arahatship, he replied only about the destruction of defilements. But is Nibbāna the same as arahatship or is it different?

original: nāna’nti? ‘Ekaṃ vā hotu nānaṃ vā. Ko ettha tayā atibahuṃ cuṇṇīkaraṇaṃ karontena attho’?
analyzed: ekam vā hotu nānam vā kaḥ ettha tayā ati bahum cuṇṇīkaraṇam karontena attho
translated: Let it be either the same or different. What is the use of your making such a fuss about it?

original: ‘Na tvaṃ ekaṃ nānaṃ jānāsīti. Nanu ñāte sādhu hotī’ti evaṃ punappunaṃ pucchito vañcetuṃ
analyzed: na tvam ekam nānam jānāsi iti nanu ñāte sādhu hoti iti evam punappunam pucchitaḥ vañcetum
translated: ‘You do not know whether it is the same or different. Would it not be good if you knew?’ Thus questioned again and again, he was unable to deceive them,

original: asakkonto āha – ‘rāgādīnaṃ khīṇante uppannattā arahattaṃ rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayo’ti
analyzed: a sakkontaḥ āha rāga ādīnam khīṇa nte uppanna ttā arahattam rāga kkhayaḥ dosa kkhayaḥ moha kkhayaḥ ti
translated: and he said: ‘When the destruction of lust, hate and delusion has occurred, that is called the destruction of lust, the destruction of hate, and the destruction of delusion.’

original: vuccatīti. Tato naṃ āhaṃsu – ‘mahākammaṃ te kataṃ. Lañjaṃ datvāpi taṃ vadāpento etadeva🔽vadāpeyya. Yatheva ca te etaṃ vibhajitvā kathitaṃ, evaṃ idampi sallakkhehi – nibbānañhi
analyzed: vuccati iti tatas naṃ āhaṃsu mahā kammam te katam lañjam etat eva  vadāpeyya yathā iva ca te etam vibhajitvā kathitam evam idam api sallakkhehi nibbānam hi
translated: Then they said: ‘You have made a great blunder. Even if you had given a bribe, you would have been made to say only this.

original: āgamma rāgādayo khīṇāti nibbānaṃ rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayoti vuttaṃ. Tīṇipi
analyzed: āgamma rāga ādayo khīṇā ti nibbānam rāga kkhayaḥ dosa kkhayaḥ moha kkhayo ti vuttam tīṇi pi
translated: And just as you have explained this by dividing it up, so you should consider this too: for Nibbāna is said to be the destruction of lust, the destruction of hate, and the destruction of delusion because lust, hate and delusion are destroyed in Nibbāna.

original: hi etāni nibbānasseva adhivacanānī’ti.
analyzed: hi etāni nibbānassa iva adhivacanāni iti
translated: For all three terms are synonyms for Nibbāna.’

original: Sace evaṃ vutte saññattiṃ gacchati iccetaṃ kusalaṃ; no ce, bahunibbānatāya kāretabbo.🔽Kathaṃ? Evaṃ tāva pucchitabbo – ‘rāgakkhayo nāma rāgasseva khayo udāhu dosamohānampi?
analyzed: sace evam vutte saññattim gacchati icca etam kusalam no ce bahu nibbāna tāya kāretabbaḥ  katham evam tāva pucchitabbaḥ rāga kkhayaḥ nāma rāgassa iva khayaḥ udāhu dosa mohānam pi
translated: If he agrees, it is well. If not, he should be told to go away because of his many absences.🔽How? He should be asked thus: “Now, is the destruction of lust the destruction of hate and delusion too?🔽Is the destruction of hate the destruction of lust and delusion too? Is the destruction of delusion the destruction of lust and hate too?

original: Dosakkhayo nāma dosasseva khayo udāhu rāgamohānampi? Mohakkhayo nāma mohasseva khayo🔽udāhu rāgadosānampī’ti? Addhā vakkhati – ‘rāgakkhayo nāma rāgasseva khayo, dosakkhayo
analyzed: dosa khayaḥ nāma dosassa iva khayaḥ udāhu rāga mohānam pi moha khayaḥ nāma mohassa iva khayaḥ  udāhu rāga dosānam pi iti addhā vakkhati rāga kkhayaḥ nāma rāgassa iva khayaḥ dosa kkhayo
translated: ” He will certainly say, “The destruction of lust is the destruction of lust itself,

original: nāma dosasseva khayo, mohakkhayo nāma mohasseva khayo’ti.
analyzed: nāma dosassa iva khayaḥ moha kkhayaḥ nāma mohassa iva khayaḥ ti
translated: the destruction of hate is the destruction of hate itself, the destruction of delusion is the destruction of delusion itself.”

original: Tato vattabbo – ‘tava vāde rāgakkhayo ekaṃ nibbānaṃ hoti, dosakkhayo ekaṃ, mohakkhayo
analyzed: tatas vattabbaḥ tava vāde rāga kkhayaḥ ekam nibbānam hoti dosa kkhayaḥ ekam moha kkhayaḥ
translated: Then he should be told: “In your doctrine the destruction of lust is one Nibbāna, the destruction of hate is another Nibbāna, the destruction of delusion is another Nibbāna.

original: ekaṃ; tiṇṇaṃ akusalamūlānaṃ khaye tīṇi nibbānāni honti, catunnaṃ upādānānaṃ khaye
analyzed: ekam tiṇṇam akusala mūlānam khaye tīṇi nibbānāni honti catunnam upādānānam khaye
translated: With the destruction of the three unprofitable roots there are three Nibbānas. With the destruction of the four kinds of clinging there are four Nibbānas.

original: cattāri, pañcannaṃ nīvaraṇānaṃ khaye pañca, channaṃ taṇhākāyānaṃ khaye cha, sattannaṃ
analyzed: cattāri pañcannam nīvaraṇānam khaye pañca channam taṇhā kāyānam khaye cha sattannam
translated: With the destruction of the five hindrances there are five Nibbānas. With the destruction of the six kinds of craving there are six Nibbānas. With the destruction of the seven kinds of consciousness there are seven Nibbānas. With the destruction of the eight worldly conditions there are eight Nibbānas. With the destruction of the nine roots of existence there are nine Nibbānas. With the destruction of the ten kinds of existence there are ten Nibbānas.

original: anusayānaṃ khaye satta, aṭṭhannaṃ micchattānaṃ khaye aṭṭha, navannaṃ taṇhāmūlakadhammānaṃ
analyzed: anusayānam khaye satta aṭṭhannam micchattānam khaye aṭṭha navannam taṇhā mūlaka dhammānam
translated: There are seven for the destruction of the underlying tendencies, eight for the destruction of the eight wrongnesses, nine for the destruction of the nine causes of dispute,

original: khaye nava, dasannaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ khaye dasa, diyaḍḍhakilesasahassassa khaye pāṭiyekkaṃ
analyzed: khaye nava dasannam saṃyojanānam khaye dasa diyaḍḍha kilesa sahassassa khaye pāṭiyekkam
translated: ten for the destruction of the ten fetters, and for the destruction of the two thousand and two hundred kinds of defilement there are two thousand and two hundred.

original: pāṭiyekkaṃ nibbānanti bahūni nibbānāni honti. Natthi pana te nibbānānaṃ pamāṇanti.
analyzed: pāṭiyekkam nibbānanti bahūni nibbānāni honti natthi pana te nibbānānam pamāṇanti
translated: But there is no measure of the kinds of Nibbāna.

original: Evaṃ pana aggahetvā nibbānaṃ āgamma rāgādayo khīṇāti ekameva nibbānaṃ rāgakkhayo
analyzed: evam pana aggahetvā nibbānam āgamma rāga ādayo khīṇā ti ekam eva nibbānam rāga kkhayo
translated: But without taking it that way, you can take it that there is only one Nibbāna, which is called the destruction of lust,

original: dosakkhayo mohakkhayoti vuccati. Tīṇipi hetāni nibbānasseva adhivacanānīti gaṇha’.
analyzed: dosa khayaḥ moha kkhayaḥ ti vuccati tīṇi pi ha etāni nibbānassa iva adhivacanāni iti gaṇha
translated: the destruction of hate, and the destruction of delusion, when lust, hate, and delusion are destroyed in the Nibbāna element. And you can take it that all three terms are synonyms for the Nibbāna element.

original: Sace pana evaṃ vuttepi na sallakkheti, oḷārikatāya kāretabbo. Kathaṃ? ‘Andhabālā🔽hi acchadīpimigamakkaṭādayopi kilesapariyuṭṭhitā vatthuṃ paṭisevanti. Atha nesaṃ
analyzed: sace pana evam vutte pi na sallakkheti oḷārika tāya kāretabbaḥ katham andha bālā  hi accha dīpi miga makkaṭa ādayaḥ api kilesa pariyuṭṭhitāḥ vatthum paṭisevanti atha na īsam
translated: But if he still does not understand even when it is put this way, he should be made to understand by the gross way. How? ‘For, you fool,🔽even blind, foolish animals like deer and monkeys, who are obsessed by defilements, still manage to have intercourse with a mate at the right time.

analyzed: nāma honti oḷārikam vata te nibbānam thūlam kaṇṇehi piḷandhitum na sakkā ati evam  pana aggahetvā nibbānam āgamma rāga ādayo khīṇā ti ekam eva nibbānam rāga kkhayaḥ dosa kkhayaḥ
translated: and they think, “How gross and gross- seeming is your Nibbāna! It is so gross that it cannot even be grasped with the ears! ”

original: mohakkhayoti vuccati. Tīṇipi hetāni nibbānasseva adhivacanānīti gaṇha’.🔽Sace pana evaṃ vuttepi na sallakkheti, gotrabhunāpi kāretabbo. Kathaṃ? Evaṃ tāva
analyzed: moha khayaḥ ti vuccati tīṇi pi ha etāni nibbānassa iva adhivacanāni iti gaṇha  sace pana evam vutte pi na sallakkheti gotrabhunā api kāretabbaḥ katham evam tāva
translated: But without taking it that way, you should take it thus: “The defilements are exhausted in Nibbāna. So Nibbāna is called the exhaustion of lust, the exhaustion of hatred, the exhaustion of delusion. And all three of these terms are synonyms for Nibbāna.”

original: pucchitabbo – ‘tvaṃ gotrabhu nāma atthīti vadesī’ti? ‘Āma vadāmī’ti. ‘Gotrabhukkhaṇe🔽kilesā khīṇā, khīyanti, khīyissantī’ti? Na khīṇā, na khīyanti; apica kho khīyissantīti.
analyzed: pucchitabbaḥ tvam gotrabhu nāma atthi iti vadesi iti vadāmi iti gotrabhukkhaṇe  kilesā khīṇā khīyanti khīyissanti iti na khīṇāḥ na khīyanti apica kho khīyissanti iti
translated: If he still does not understand when it is put this way, then it should be demonstrated by the path of the first jhāna. How? He should be asked thus: “You say that there is a state called the path of the first jhāna. Is it a condition for the defilements or not? If it is, then it is not the path of the first jhāna, and you have no right to call it such. But if it is not, then the defilements are exhausted in the path of the first jhāna, and it is not tenable to say that the defilements are exhausted in Nibbāna.”🔽If he still does not understand when it is put this way, then it should be demonstrated by the state of the first jhāna. How? He should be asked thus: “You say that there is a state called the first jhāna. Is it a condition for the defilements or not? If it is, then it is not the first jhāna, and you have no right to call it such. But if it is not, then the defilements are exhausted in the first jhāna, and it is not tenable to say that the defilements are exhausted in Nibbāna.”

original: ‘Gotrabhu pana kiṃ ārammaṇaṃ karotī’ti? ‘Nibbānaṃ’. ‘Tava gotrabhukkhaṇe kilesā na
analyzed: gotrabhu pana kim ārammaṇam karoti iti nibbānam tava gotrabhu khaṇe kilesāḥ na
translated: If he still does not understand when it is put this way, then it should be demonstrated by the state of change-of-lineage. How? If they are, then it is not tenable to say that the defilements are exhausted in Nibbāna. But if they are not, then what is the difference between the state of change-of-lineage and Nibbāna? For the defilements are exhausted in both.”

analyzed: nibbānam paññapesi appahīnesu anusayesu anusaya ppahānam nibbānam paññapesi taṃ  te na sameti evam pana aggahetvā nibbānam āgamma rāga ādayaḥ khīṇāti ekam eva nibbānam

translated: nor does the skin know, ‘I am spread over a body.’ These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing.

analyzed: ete dhammā iti tacaḥ nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suñño
translated: So ‘skin’ is a term for a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void,

original: nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.
analyzed: nissattaḥ thaddhaḥ pathavī dhātu uti
translated: without life-faculty, rigid earth element.

original: Maṃsaṃ aṭṭhisaṅghāṭaṃ anulimpitvā ṭhitaṃ. Tattha yathā mahāmattikāya littāya bhittiyā🔽na bhitti jānāti ‘ahaṃ mahāmattikāya littā’ti, nāpi mahāmattikā jānāti ‘mayā mahābhitti🔽littā’ti, evameva na aṭṭhisaṅghāṭo jānāti ‘ahaṃ navamaṃsapesisatappabhedena maṃsena
analyzed: maṃsam aṭṭhi saṅghāṭam anulimpitvā ṭhitam tattha yathā mahā mattikāya littāya bhittiyā  na bhitti jānāti aham mahā mattikāya na api mahā mattikā jānāti mayā mahā bhitti  littā ati evam eva na aṭṭhi saṅghāṭaḥ jānāti aham nava maṃsa pesisa tappa bhedena maṃsena
translated: and the flesh is smeared over the framework of bones. Herein, just as, when a great wall is plastered with thick clay,

original: litto’ti, nāpi maṃsaṃ jānāti ‘mayā aṭṭhisaṅghāṭo litto’ti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā🔽ete dhammā. Iti maṃsaṃ nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño
analyzed: littaḥ ti na api maṃsam jānāti mayā aṭṭhi saṅghāṭaḥ littaḥ ti aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitā  ete dhammāḥ iti maṃsam nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suñño
translated: the wall does not know, “I am plastered with thick clay,” nor does the thick clay know, “I plaster a wall,” so too, the framework of bones does not know, “I am smeared over with flesh consisting of nine hundred pieces of flesh,”

original: nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.🔽Nhāru sarīrabbhantare aṭṭhīni ābandhamānā ṭhitā. Tattha yathā vallīhi vinaddhesu🔽kuṭṭadārūsu na kuṭṭadārūni jānanti ‘mayaṃ vallīhi vinaddhānī’ti, nāpi valliyo jānanti
analyzed: nissattaḥ thaddhaḥ pathavī dhātu uti 🔽nhāru sarīra abbhantare aṭṭhīni ābandhamānā ṭhitā tattha yathā vallīhi vinaddhesu 🔽kuṭṭadārūsu na kuṭṭadārūni jānanti mayam vallīhi vinaddhāni iti na api valliyaḥ jānanti
translated: nor does the flesh know, “I am smeared over a framework of bones.” These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called flesh is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: ‘amhehi kuṭṭadārūni vinaddhānī’ti, evameva na aṭṭhīni jānanti ‘mayaṃ nhārūhi ābaddhānī’ti,
analyzed: amhehi kuṭṭadārūni vinaddhāni iti evam eva na aṭṭhīni jānanti mayam ābaddhāni iti
translated: so too, the bones do not know, “We are bound together by sinews,”

original: nāpi nhārū jānanti ‘amhehi aṭṭhīni ābaddhānī’ti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā🔽ete dhammā. Iti nhāru nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño
analyzed: na api nhārū jānanti amhehi aṭṭhīni ābaddhāni iti aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitā  ete dhammā iti nhāru nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suñño
translated: nor do the sinews know, “We are bound together by bones.”🔽These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing.

original: nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.
analyzed: nissattaḥ thaddhaḥ pathavī dhātu uti
translated: So what are called sinews are a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.🔽In the bones, the heel bone supports the ankle bone,

original: Aṭṭhīsu paṇhikaṭṭhi gopphakaṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhitaṃ. Gopphakaṭṭhi jaṅghaṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā
analyzed: aṭṭhīsu paṇhika ṭṭhi gopphaka ṭṭhim ukkhipitvā ṭhitam gopphaka ṭṭhi jaṅgha ṭṭhim ukkhipitvā
translated: the ankle bone supports the shin bone,🔽the shin bone supports the thigh bone,🔽the thigh bone supports the hip bone,

original: ṭhitaṃ. Jaṅghaṭṭhi ūruṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhitaṃ. Ūruṭṭhi kaṭiṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhitaṃ.🔽Kaṭiṭṭhi piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhitaṃ. Piṭṭhikaṇṭako gīvaṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhito.
analyzed: ṭhitam jaṅgha ṭṭhi ūru ṭṭhim ukkhipitvā ṭhitam ūru ṭṭhi kaṭi ṭṭhim ukkhipitvā ṭhitam  kaṭiṭṭhi piṭṭhi kaṇṭakam ukkhipitvā ṭhitam piṭṭhi kaṇṭakaḥ gīvaṭṭhim ukkhipitvā ṭhitaḥ
translated: the hip bone supports the backbone,🔽the backbone supports the neck bone,

original: Gīvaṭṭhi sīsaṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhitaṃ. Sīsaṭṭhi gīvaṭṭhike patiṭṭhitaṃ. Gīvaṭṭhi piṭṭhikaṇṭake
analyzed: gīva ṭṭhi sīsa ṭṭhim ukkhipitvā ṭhitam sīsa ṭṭhi gīva ṭṭhike patiṭṭhitam gīva ṭṭhi piṭṭhi kaṇṭake
translated: the neck bone supports the skull. The skull rests on the neck bone.

original: patiṭṭhitaṃ. Piṭṭhikaṇṭako kaṭiṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhito. Kaṭiṭṭhi ūruṭṭhike patiṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: patiṭṭhitam piṭṭhikaṇṭakaḥ kaṭiṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhitaḥ kaṭiṭṭhi ūruṭṭhike patiṭṭhitam
translated: the spine is set on the hip-bone. The hip-bone is set on the thigh-bone.

original: Ūruṭṭhi jaṅghaṭṭhike patiṭṭhitaṃ. Jaṅghaṭṭhi gopphakaṭṭhike patiṭṭhitaṃ. Gopphakaṭṭhi
analyzed: ūruṭṭhi jaṅgha ṭṭhike patiṭṭhitam jaṅgha ṭṭhi gopphaka ṭṭhike patiṭṭhitam gopphaka ṭṭhike
translated: The thigh-bone is set on the shin-bone. The shin-bone is set on the ankle-bone. The ankle-bone

original: paṇhikaṭṭhike patiṭṭhitaṃ.🔽Tattha yathā iṭṭhakadārugomayādisañcayesu na heṭṭhimā heṭṭhimā jānanti ‘mayaṃ uparime🔽uparime ukkhipitvā ṭhitā’ti, nāpi uparimā uparimā jānanti ‘mayaṃ heṭṭhimesu heṭṭhimesu
analyzed: paṇhika ṭṭhike patiṭṭhitam  tattha yathā iṭṭhaka dāru gomaya ādi sañcayesu na heṭṭhimāḥ heṭṭhimāḥ jānanti mayam uparime  uparime ukkhipitvā ṭhitā ati na api uparimāḥ uparimāḥ jānanti mayam heṭṭhimesu heṭṭhimesu
translated: is set on the heel-bone.

original: patiṭṭhitā’ti, evameva na paṇhikaṭṭhi jānāti ‘ahaṃ gopphakaṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhita’nti,🔽na gopphakaṭṭhi jānāti ‘ahaṃ jaṅghaṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhita’nti, na jaṅghaṭṭhi jānāti
analyzed: patiṭṭhitā ati evam eva na paṇhika ṭṭhi jānāti aham gopphaka ṭṭhim ukkhipitvā ṭhitanti  na gopphakaṭṭhi jānāti aham jaṅgha ṭṭhim ukkhipitvā ṭhitanti na jaṅgha ṭṭhi jānāti
translated: Herein, just as, in the case of the mass of bricks, timber, etc., the lower ones do not know, “We are supporting those above us,” nor do the upper ones know, “We are supported by those below us,” so too, the heel-bone does not know, “I support the ankle-bone,”🔽nor does the ankle-bone know, “I am supported by the heel-bone,” nor does the shin-bone know,

original: ‘ahaṃ ūruṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhita’nti, na ūruṭṭhi jānāti ‘ahaṃ kaṭiṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā
analyzed: aham ūruṭṭhim ukkhipitvā ṭhitanti na ūruṭṭhi jānāti aham kaṭiṭṭhim ukkhipitvā
translated: “I support the thigh-bone,” nor does the thigh-bone know, “I am supported by the shin-bone,” nor does the hip-bone know, “I support the spine,”

original: ṭhita’nti, na kaṭiṭṭhi jānāti ‘ahaṃ piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhita’nti, na piṭṭhikaṇṭako🔽jānāti ‘ahaṃ gīvaṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhito’ti, na gīvaṭṭhi jānāti ‘ahaṃ sīsaṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā
analyzed: ṭhitanti na kaṭiṭṭhī jānāti aham piṭṭhi kaṇṭakam ukkhipitvā ṭhitanti na piṭṭhi kaṇṭakaḥ  jānāti aham gīvaṭṭhim ukkhipitvā ṭhitaḥ iti na gīvaṭṭhi jānāti aham sīsaṭṭhim ukkhipitvā
translated: the spine doesn’t know, ‘I’m standing on the hipbone.’🔽The hipbone doesn’t know, ‘I’m standing on the thighbone.’

original: ṭhita’nti, na sīsaṭṭhi jānāti ‘ahaṃ gīvaṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhita’nti, na gīvaṭṭhi jānāti🔽‘ahaṃ piṭṭhikaṇṭake patiṭṭhita’nti, na piṭṭhikaṇṭako jānāti ‘ahaṃ kaṭiṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhito’ti,🔽na kaṭiṭṭhi jānāti ‘ahaṃ ūruṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhita’nti, na ūruṭṭhi jānāti ‘ahaṃ jaṅghaṭṭhimhi
analyzed: ṭhitanti na sīsaṭṭhi jānāti aham gīvaṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhitanti na gīvaṭṭhi jānāti  aham piṭṭhi kaṇṭake patiṭṭhitanti na piṭṭhi kaṇṭakaḥ jānāti aham kaṭiṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhitoti  na kaṭiṭṭhi jānāti aham ūruṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhitanti na ūruṭṭhi jānāti aham jaṅgha ṭṭhimhi
translated: The thighbone doesn’t know, ‘I’m standing on the shinbone.’🔽The shinbone doesn’t know, ‘I’m standing on the anklebone.’

original: patiṭṭhita’nti, na jaṅghaṭṭhi jānāti ‘ahaṃ gopphakaṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhita’nti, na gopphakaṭṭhi🔽jānāti ‘ahaṃ paṇhikaṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhita’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā
analyzed: patiṭṭhitanti na jaṅgha ṭṭhi jānāti aham gopphaka ṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhitanti na gopphaka ṭṭhi 🔽jānāti aham paṇhi kaṭṭhimhi patiṭṭhitanti aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitā
translated: The anklebone doesn’t know, ‘I’m standing on the heelbone.’🔽They don’t deliberate and reflect on one another,

original: ete dhammā. Iti aṭṭhi nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño
analyzed: ete dhammā iti aṭṭhi nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suñño
translated: These are the bones. So what is called bones is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.🔽Aṭṭhimiñjaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ aṭṭhīnaṃ abbhantare ṭhitaṃ. Tattha yathā veḷupabbādīnaṃ anto🔽pakkhittesu sinnavettaggādīsu na veḷupabbādīni jānanti ‘amhesu vettaggādīni pakkhittānī’ti,🔽nāpi vettaggādīni jānanti ‘mayaṃ veḷupabbādīsu ṭhitānīti, evameva na aṭṭhīni jānanti
analyzed: nissattaḥ thaddhaḥ pathavī dhātu uti  aṭṭhimiñjam tesam tesam aṭṭhīnam abbhantare ṭhitam tattha yathā veḷu pabba ādīnam antaḥ  pakkhittesu sinna vettagga ādīsu na veḷu pabba ādīni jānanti amhesu vettagga ādīni pakkhittāni iti  na api vettagga ādīni jānanti mayam veḷu pabba ādīsu ṭhitāni iti evam eva na aṭṭhīni jānanti
translated: These are the bones. So what is called bones is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.🔽Bone Marrow Bone marrow is to be found inside the various bones. Herein, just as, when a pile of millet seeds, etc., is put into a trough of water, the trough of water does not know, “A pile of millet seeds, etc., is put into me,”

original: ‘amhākaṃ anto aṭṭhimiñjaṃ ṭhita’nti, nāpi aṭṭhimiñjaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ aṭṭhīnaṃ anto🔽ṭhita’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti aṭṭhimiñjaṃ nāma
analyzed: amhākam antar aṭṭhimiñjam ṭhitanti na api aṭṭhimiñjam jānāti aham aṭṭhīnam antar  ṭhitam ti aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti aṭṭhimiñjam nāma
translated: nor does the pile of millet seeds, etc., know, “I am put into a trough of water,” so too, the bones do not know, “Bone marrow is inside us,”

original: imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.
analyzed: imasmin sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto thaddhaḥ pathavī dhātū ti
translated: nor does the bone marrow know, “I am inside bones.” These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called bone marrow is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: Vakkaṃ galavāṭakato nikkhantena ekamūlena thokaṃ gantvā dvidhā bhinnena thūlanhārunā
analyzed: vakkam galavāṭakataḥ nikkhantena eka mūlena thokam gantvā dvidhā bhinnena thūla nhārunā
translated: The gullet is the passage for the food and drink swallowed.🔽It is a single tube, and after going down a short way it divides into two, like the main vein of a young palmyra fruit.

original: vinibaddhaṃ hutvā hadayamaṃsaṃ parikkhipitvā ṭhitaṃ. Tattha yathā vaṇṭupanibaddhe🔽ambaphaladvaye na vaṇṭaṃ jānāti ‘mayā ambaphaladvayaṃ upanibaddha’nti, nāpi ambaphaladvayaṃ
analyzed: vinibaddham hutvā hadaya maṃsam parikkhipitvā ṭhitam tattha yathā  amba phala dvaye na vaṇṭam jānāti mayā amba phala dvayam na api amba phala dvayam
translated: The kidney is fastened to the flesh of the heart by a single root issuing from the gullet-pouch and dividing into two after going a short way, like a coarse sinew.🔽It is situated surrounding the heart’s flesh. Herein, just as, when a pair of mango fruits is fastened by a stalk, the stalk does not know, “A pair of mango fruits is fastened by me,”

original: jānāti ‘ahaṃ vaṇṭena upanibaddha’nti, evameva na thūlanhāru jānāti ‘mayā vakkaṃ upanibaddha’nti,
analyzed: jānāti aham vaṇṭena evam eva na jānāti mayā vakkam upanibaddhanti
translated: nor do the mango fruits know, “We are fastened by a stalk,” so too, the coarse sinew does not know, “A kidney is fastened by me,”

original: nāpi vakkaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ thūlanhārunā upanibaddha’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā
analyzed: na api vakkam jānāti aham thūla nhārunā upanibaddha nti aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitā
translated: nor does the kidney know, “I am fastened by a coarse sinew.” These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing.

original: ete dhammā. Iti vakkaṃ nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño🔽nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.
analyzed: ete dhammā iti vakkam nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suñño  nissattaḥ thaddhaḥ pathavī dhātu uti
translated: So what is called kidney is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: Hadayaṃ sarīrabbhantare uraṭṭhipañjaramajjhaṃ nissāya ṭhitaṃ. Tattha yathā jiṇṇasandamānikapañjarabbhantaraṃ
analyzed: hadayam sarīra abbhantare uraṭṭhi pañjara majjham nissāya ṭhitam tattha yathā jiṇṇa sandamānika pañjara bbhantaram
translated: The heart is situated in the middle of the cage of ribs inside the body, leaning against the backbone. Herein, just as, when a cage of bamboo staves is smeared inside and out with clay, the staves do not know, “We are surrounded by clay inside and out,”🔽nor does the clay know, “A cage of bamboo staves is surrounded by me inside and out,” so too, the flesh, etc., do not know, “We surround a heart.”

original: nissāya ṭhapitāya maṃsapesiyā na jiṇṇasandamānikapañjarabbhantaraṃ jānāti ‘maṃ nissāya🔽maṃsapesi ṭhapitā’ti, nāpi maṃsapesi jānāti ‘ahaṃ jiṇṇasandamānikapañjarabbhantaraṃ🔽nissāya ṭhitā’ti, evameva na uraṭṭhipañjarabbhantaraṃ jānāti ‘maṃ nissāya hadayaṃ
analyzed: nissāya ṭhapitāya maṃsapesiyā na jiṇṇa sandamānika pañjara abbhantaram jānāti mam nissāya  maṃsapesi ṭhapitā ati na api maṃsapesi jānāti aham jiṇṇa sandamānika pañjara bbhantaram  nissāya ṭhitā ati evam eva na uraṭṭhi pañjara abbhantaram jānāti mam nissāya hadayam
translated: nor does the piece of meat know, ‘I am placed leaning against the inside of the old bag-shaped water filter.’ So too, the inside of the rib cage does not know, ‘The heart is leaning against me,’

original: ṭhita’nti, nāpi hadayaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ uraṭṭhipañjarabbhantaraṃ nissāya ṭhita’nti.🔽Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti hadayaṃ nāma imasmiṃ sarīre🔽pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.
analyzed: na api hadayam jānāti aham uraṭṭhi pañjara abbhantaram nissāya ṭhitanti  aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti hadayam nāma imasmim sarīre  pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto thaddho pathavī dhātū ti
translated: nor does the heart know, ‘I am leaning against the inside of the rib cage.’

original: Yakanaṃ antosarīre dvinnaṃ thanānaṃ abbhantare dakkhiṇapassaṃ nissāya ṭhitaṃ. Tattha🔽yathā ukkhalikapālapassamhi lagge yamakamaṃsapiṇḍe na ukkhalikapālapassaṃ jānāti
analyzed: ya kanam antosarīre dvinnam tha nānam abbhantare dakkhiṇa passam nissāya ṭhitam tattha 🔽yathā ukkhali kapāla passamhi lagge yamaka maṃsa piṇḍe na ukkhali kapāla passam jānāti
translated: These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called the heart is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: ‘mayi yamakamaṃsapiṇḍo laggo’ti, nāpi yamakamaṃsapiṇḍo jānāti ‘ahaṃ ukkhalikapālapasse🔽laggo’ti, evameva na thanānaṃ abbhantare dakkhiṇapassaṃ jānāti ‘maṃ nissāya yakanaṃ
analyzed: mayi yamaka maṃsa piṇḍaḥ laggo ti na api yamaka maṃsa piṇḍaḥ jānāti aham ukkhali kapāla passe  laggo ti evam eva na tha nānam abbhantare dakkhiṇa passam jānāti mam nissāya ya kanam
translated: nor does the pair of flesh-cakes know, ‘We are stuck to the sides of the trough.’ So too, the right side in the interior of the belly does not know, ‘The liver is stuck to me’;

original: ṭhita’nti, nāpi yakanaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ thanānaṃ abbhantare dakkhiṇapassaṃ nissāya ṭhita’nti.🔽Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti yakanaṃ nāma imasmiṃ sarīre🔽pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.
analyzed: na api yakanam jānāti aham tha nānam abbhantare dakkhiṇa passam nissāya ṭhitanti  aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti yakanam nāma imasmim sarīre  pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto thaddho pathavī dhātū ti
translated: nor does the liver know, ‘I am stuck to the right side in the interior of the belly.’

original: Kilomakesu paṭicchannakilomakaṃ hadayañca vakkañca parivāretvā ṭhitaṃ, apaṭicchannakilomakaṃ🔽sakalasarīre cammassa heṭṭhato maṃsaṃ pariyonandhitvā ṭhitaṃ. Tattha yathā pilotikapaliveṭhite🔽maṃse na maṃsaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ pilotikāya paliveṭhita’nti, nāpi pilotikā jānāti ‘mayā
analyzed: kilomakesu paṭicchanna kilomakam hadayam ca vakkam ca parivāretvā ṭhitam a paṭicchanna kilomakam 🔽sakala sarīre cammassa heṭṭhatas maṃsam pariyonandhitvā ṭhitam tattha yathā pilotika paliveṭhite 🔽maṃse na maṃsam jānāti aham pilotikāya na api pilotikā jānāti mayā
translated: These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called the liver is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: maṃsaṃ paliveṭhita’nti, evameva na vakkahadayāni sakalasarīre maṃsañca jānāti ‘ahaṃ🔽kilomakena paṭicchanna’nti, nāpi kilomakaṃ jānāti ‘mayā vakkahadayāni sakalasarīre🔽maṃsañca paṭicchanna’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti kilomakaṃ
analyzed: maṃsam evam eva na sakala sarīre maṃsam ca jānāti aham  kilomakena na api kilomakam jānāti mayā sakala sarīre  maṃsam ca paṭicchannanti aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti kilomakam
translated: and the flesh does not know, ‘I am covered by the skin,’ so too, the kidneys and heart do not know, ‘We are in the whole body, in the flesh,’

original: nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.
analyzed: nāma imasmin sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto thaddhaḥ pathavī dhātu uti
translated: nor does the flesh know, ‘I am in the whole body, in the kidneys and heart.’ These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called flesh is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: Pihakaṃ hadayassa vāmapasse udarapaṭalassa matthakapassaṃ nissāya ṭhitaṃ. Tattha🔽yathā koṭṭhakamatthakapassaṃ nissāya ṭhitāya gomayapiṇḍiyā na koṭṭhakamatthakapassaṃ🔽jānāti ‘gomayapiṇḍi maṃ nissāya ṭhitā’ti, nāpi gomayapiṇḍi jānāti ‘ahaṃ koṭṭhakamatthakapassaṃ
analyzed: pihakam hadayassa vāma passe udara paṭalassa matthaka passam nissāya ṭhitam tattha  yathā koṭṭhaka matthaka passam nissāya ṭhitāya gomaya piṇḍiyā na koṭṭhaka matthaka passam  jānāti gomaya piṇḍi mam nissāya ṭhitā ati na api gomaya piṇḍi jānāti aham koṭṭhaka matthaka passam
translated: The spleen is to be found near the left side, attached to the interior of the ribs.🔽Herein, just as, when a lump of cowdung is attached to the interior of a wall-niche, the wall-niche does not know, ‘A lump of cowdung is attached to me,’🔽nor does the lump of cowdung know, ‘I am attached to a wall-niche,’ so too, the interior of the ribs does not know, ‘A spleen is attached to me,’

original: nissāya ṭhitā’ti, evameva na udarapaṭalassa matthakapassaṃ jānāti ‘pihakaṃ maṃ nissāya
analyzed: nissāya ṭhitā ati evam eva na udara paṭalassa matthaka passam jānāti pihakam mam nissāya
translated: nor does the spleen know, ‘I am attached to the interior of the ribs.’

original: ṭhita’nti, nāpi pihakaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ udarapaṭalassa matthakapassaṃ nissāya ṭhita’nti.
analyzed: na api pihakam jānāti aham udara paṭalassa matthaka passam nissāya ṭhitanti
translated: nor does the liver know, ‘I am situated on the upper side of the stomach.’

original: Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti pihakaṃ nāma imasmiṃ sarīre
analyzed: aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti pihakam nāma imasmim sarīre
translated: These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what are called the liver and the spleen

original: pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.
analyzed: pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto thaddho pathavī dhātū ti
translated: are a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: Papphāsaṃ sarīrabbhantare dvinnaṃ thanānaṃ abbhantare hadayañca yakanañca uparichādetvā
analyzed: papphāsam sarīra abbhantare dvinnam abbhantare hadayam ca yakanam ca upari chādetvā
translated: The lungs are to be found inside the body, between the two breasts, covering the heart and kidneys

original: olambantaṃ ṭhitaṃ. Tattha yathā jiṇṇakoṭṭhabbhantare olambamāne sakuṇakulāvake na🔽jiṇṇakoṭṭhabbhantaraṃ jānāti ‘mayi sakuṇakulāvako olambamāno ṭhito’ti, nāpi sakuṇakulāvako🔽jānāti ‘ahaṃ jiṇṇakoṭṭhabbhantare olambamāno ṭhito’ti, evameva na sarīrabbhantaraṃ
analyzed: olambantam ṭhitam tattha yathā jiṇṇa koṭṭhabbha antare olambamāne sakuṇa kulāvake na  jiṇṇa koṭṭhabbhantaram jānāti mayi sakuṇa kulāvakaḥ olambamānaḥ ṭhitaḥ iti na api sakuṇa kulāvakaḥ  jānāti aham jiṇṇa koṭṭhabbhantare olambamānaḥ ṭhitaḥ iti evam eva na sarīra bbhantaram
translated: and hanging down. Just as, when a piece of meat is put on a spit over a fire,🔽the end next to the skewer does not know, ‘I am close to the skewer,’ nor does the skewer know, ‘A piece of meat is next to me’;🔽so too, the end of the lungs next to the heart and kidneys does not know, ‘I am next to the heart and kidneys,’

original: jānāti ‘mayi papphāsaṃ olambamānaṃ ṭhita’nti, nāpi papphāsaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ evarūpe
analyzed: jānāti mayi papphāsam olambamānam ṭhitanti na api papphāsam jānāti aham evarūpe
translated: nor do the heart and kidneys know, ‘The end of a lung is next to us.’

original: sarīrabbhantare olambamānaṃ ṭhita’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā.🔽Iti papphāsaṃ nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto
analyzed: sarīra abbhantare olambamānam ṭhitan ti aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammā  iti papphāsam nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto
translated: These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing.

original: thaddho pathavīdhātūti.🔽Antaṃ galavāṭakato karīsamaggapariyante sarīrabbhantare ṭhitaṃ. Tattha yathā lohitadoṇikāya🔽obhujitvā ṭhapite chinnasīsadhamanikaḷevare na lohitadoṇi jānāti ‘mayi dhamanikaḷevaraṃ
analyzed: pathavī dhātu uti  antam galavāṭakato karīsa magga pariyante sarīra abbhantare ṭhitam tattha yathā lohitadoṇikāya  obhujitvā ṭhapite chinna sīsa dhamani kaḷevare na lohita doṇi jānāti mayi dhamani kaḷevaram
translated: So what is called the large intestine is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: ṭhita’nti, nāpi dhamanikaḷevaraṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ lohitadoṇikāyaṃ ṭhita’nti, evameva
analyzed: na api dhamanika ḷevaram jānāti aham evam eva
translated: The bowel is to be found inside the physical frame between the stomach and the excrement passage. Herein, just as, when a piece of meat is put inside a dog’s stomach and covered up with its intestines, the dog’s stomach does not know “A piece of meat is put in me”🔽nor does the piece of meat know “I am in a dog’s stomach,” so too

original: na sarīrabbhantaraṃ jānāti ‘mayi antaṃ ṭhita’nti, nāpi antaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ sarīrabbhantare
analyzed: na sarīra bbhantaram jānāti mayi antam na api antam jānāti aham sarīra bbhantare
translated: the physical frame does not know “A bowel is in me”

original: ṭhita’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti antaṃ nāma imasmiṃ
analyzed: ṭhita nti aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti antam nāma imasmin
translated: nor does the bowel know “I am in a physical frame.” These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called the bowel is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.🔽Antaguṇaṃ antantare ekavīsati antabhoge bandhitvā ṭhitaṃ. Tattha yathā pādapuñchanarajjumaṇḍalakaṃ
analyzed: sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto thaddho pathavī dhātū ti  anta guṇam anta antare ekavīsati anta bhoge bandhitvā ṭhitam yathā pāda puñchana rajju maṇḍalakam
translated: A particular part of the physical frame, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: sibbetvā ṭhitesu rajjukesu na pādapuñchanarajjumaṇḍalakaṃ jānāti ‘rajjukā maṃ sibbetvā🔽ṭhitā’ti, nāpi rajjukā jānanti ‘mayaṃ pādapuñchanarajjumaṇḍalakaṃ sibbetvā ṭhitā’ti,🔽evameva na antaṃ jānāti ‘antaguṇaṃ maṃ ābandhitvā ṭhita’nti, nāpi antaguṇaṃ jānāti
analyzed: sibbetvā ṭhitesu rajjukesu na pāda puñchana rajju maṇḍalakam jānāti rajjukā mama sibbetvā  ṭhitā ati nā api rajjukāḥ jānanti mayam pāda puñchana rajju maṇḍalakam sibbetvā ṭhitā ati  evam eva na antam jānāti anta guṇam mama ābandhitvā na api anta guṇam jānāti
translated: The bowel is to be found inside the body, binding together the twenty-one coils of the intestines. Herein, just as, when a bundle of wet sticks is bound together by a wet creeper, the creeper does not know “A bundle of wet sticks is bound together by me”🔽nor does the bundle of wet sticks know “We are bound together by a creeper,” so too, the bowel does not know “A twenty-one-coiled intestine is bound together by me”

original: ‘ahaṃ antaṃ bandhitvā ṭhita’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā.🔽Iti antaguṇaṃ nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto
analyzed: aham antam bandhitvā ṭhitanti aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammā  iti anta guṇam nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto
translated: nor does the twenty-one-coiled intestine know “I am bound together by a bowel.” These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing.

original: thaddho pathavīdhātūti.
analyzed: pathavī dhātu uti
translated: So what is called bowel is a particular part of this body that is without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: Udariyaṃ udare ṭhitaṃ asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṃ. Tattha yathā suvānadoṇiyaṃ ṭhite suvānavamathumhi🔽na suvānadoṇi jānāti ‘mayi suvānavamathu ṭhito’ti, nāpi suvānavamathu jānāti ‘ahaṃ🔽suvānadoṇiyaṃ ṭhito’ti, evameva na udaraṃ jānāti ‘mayi udariyaṃ ṭhita’nti, nāpi udariyaṃ🔽jānāti ‘ahaṃ udare ṭhita’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti
analyzed: udariyam udare ṭhitam asita pīta khāyita sāyitam tattha yathā suvāna doṇiyam ṭhite suvāna vamathumhi  na suvāna doṇi jānāti mayi suvāna vamathu ṭhitaḥ iti na api suvāna vamathu jānāti aham  suvāna doṇiyam evam eva na udaram jānāti mayi udariyam na api udariyam  jānāti aham udare ṭhitanti aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti
translated: The stomach-contents are what is eaten, drunk, chewed and tasted that is situated in the stomach.🔽Herein, just as, in a cesspit for ordure, the ordure does not know, “I am situated in a cesspit for ordure,” nor does the cesspit for ordure know, “Ordure is situated in me,” so too, the stomach does not know, “Stomach-contents are situated in me,” nor does the stomach-contents know, “I am situated in a stomach.” These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing.

original: udariyaṃ nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.🔽Karīsaṃ pakkāsayasaṅkhāte aṭṭhaṅgulaveḷupabbasadise antapariyosāne ṭhitaṃ. Tattha🔽yathā veḷupabbe omadditvā pakkhittāya saṇhapaṇḍumattikāya na veḷupabbaṃ jānāti ‘mayi
analyzed: udariyam nāma imasmin sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto thaddhaḥ pathavī dhātū ti 🔽karīsam pakka āsaya saṅkhāte aṭṭhaṅgula veḷu pabba sadise anta pariyosāne ṭhitam tattha 🔽yathā veḷu pabbe omadditvā pakkhittāya saṇha paṇḍu mattikāya na veḷu pabbam jānāti mayi
translated: The belly-lining is to be found inside the belly, and it lines the belly like a glove fits the hand. Herein, just as when a glove is put on the hand the hand does not know “A glove is on me” nor does the glove know “I am on the hand,” so too, the belly does not know “A lining is in me” nor does the lining know “I am in the belly”; these things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called belly-lining is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: paṇḍumattikā ṭhitā’ti, nāpi paṇḍumattikā jānāti ‘ahaṃ veḷupabbe ṭhitā’ti, evameva
analyzed: paṇḍu mattikā ṭhitā ati na api paṇḍu mattikā jānāti aham veḷu pabbe ṭhitā ati evam eva
translated: nor does the red chalk know, ‘I am standing on a rock face.’🔽

original: na pakkāsayo jānāti ‘mayi karīsaṃ ṭhita’nti, nāpi karīsaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ pakkāsaye🔽ṭhita’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti karīsaṃ nāma imasmiṃ🔽sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.🔽Matthaluṅgaṃ sīsakaṭāhabbhantare ṭhitaṃ. Tattha yathā purāṇalābukaṭāhe pakkhittāya🔽piṭṭhapiṇḍiyā na lābukaṭāhaṃ jānāti ‘mayi piṭṭhapiṇḍi ṭhitā’ti, nāpi piṭṭhapiṇḍi🔽jānāti ‘ahaṃ lābukaṭāhe ṭhitā’ti, evameva na sīsakaṭāhabbhantaraṃ jānāti ‘mayi matthaluṅgaṃ
analyzed: na pakka āsayaḥ jānāti mayi karīsam na api karīsam jānāti aham pakka āsaye  ṭhita nti aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti karīsam nāma imasmin  sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto thaddho pathavī dhātū ti  mattha luṅgam sīsa kaṭāha abbhantare ṭhitam tattha yathā purāṇa lābu kaṭāhe pakkhittāya  piṭṭhapiṇḍiyā na lābu kaṭāham jānāti mayi piṭṭhapiṇḍī ṭhitā ati na api piṭṭhapiṇḍī  jānāti aham lābu kaṭāhe ṭhitā ati evam eva na sīsa kaṭāha bbhantaram jānāti mayi mattha luṅgam
translated: nor does the clay know, ‘I am on the surface of the stone.’ So too,

original: ṭhita’nti, nāpi matthaluṅgaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ sīsakaṭāhabbhantare ṭhita’nti. Aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: na api mattha luṅgam jānāti aham sīsa kaṭāha bhantare ṭhitanti aññam aññam
translated: the receptacle for digested food does not know, ‘Dung is in me,’ nor does the dung know, ‘I am in a receptacle for digested food.’ These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called dung is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti matthaluṅgaṃ nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko
analyzed: ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti matthaluṅgam nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekko
translated: These things are devoid of appropriation and reviewing. So head hairs, body hairs, teeth, nails, etc., are a particular part of this body,

original: koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto thaddho pathavīdhātūti.
analyzed: koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto thaddhaḥ pathavī dhātū ti
translated: unconscious, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: Yaṃ vā panaññampīti iminā āpokoṭṭhāsādīsu tīsu anugataṃ pathavīdhātuṃ lakkhaṇavasena yevāpanakaṃ pathaviṃ katvā dasseti.🔽Bāhirapathavīdhātuniddese ayoti kāḷalohaṃ. Lohanti jātilohaṃ, vijātilohaṃ, kittimalohaṃ,
analyzed: yam vā pana aññam pi iti iminā āpokoṭṭhāsa ādīsu tīsu anugatam pathavī dhātum lakkhaṇa vasena yevāpanakam pathavim katvā dasseti  bāhira pathavī dhātu niddese kāḷa loham lohanti jāti loham vijāti loham kittima loham
translated: Or whatever else there is of earth element in addition to that is to be understood as the earth element in the sense of the characteristic of cohesion.

original: pisācalohanti catubbidhaṃ. Tattha ayo, sajjhu, suvaṇṇaṃ, tipu, sīsaṃ, tambalohaṃ,
analyzed: pisāca lohanti catubbidham tattha ayaḥ sajjhu suvaṇṇam tipu sīsam tamba loham
translated: In the description of the external earth element, “Iron” is black iron. “Metals” are of four kinds: natural, artificial, meteoric, and alluvial.

original: vekantakanti imāni satta jātilohāni nāma. Nāganāsikalohaṃ vijātilohaṃ nāma. Kaṃsalohaṃ,
analyzed: imāni satta jātilohāni nāma nāga nāsika loham vijātiloham nāma kaṃsa loham
translated: Herein, the seven kinds of natural metals are called natural metals. They are iron, copper, gold, tin, lead, silver, and “cat’s eye” gem.

original: vaṭṭalohaṃ, ārakūṭanti tīṇi kittimalohāni nāma. Morakkhakaṃ, puthukaṃ, malinakaṃ,
analyzed: vaṭṭaloham ārakūṭanti tīṇi kittimalohāni nāma morakkhakam puthukam malinakam
translated: The metal found in the trunk of the nāga is called artificial metal. The three kinds of artificial metals are brass, bell-metal, and white copper.🔽The eight kinds of alluvial metals are called alluvial metals. They are morekhaka, puthuka, malinaka,

original: capalakaṃ, selakaṃ, āṭakaṃ, bhallakaṃ, dūsilohanti aṭṭha pisācalohāni nāma. Tesu
analyzed: capalakam selakam āṭakam bhallakam dūsilohanti aṭṭha pisācalohāni nāma tesu
translated: capalaka, selaka, āṭaka, bhallaka, and dūsiloh.

original: pañca jātilohāni pāḷiyaṃ visuṃ vuttāneva. Tambalohaṃ, vekantakalohanti imehi pana🔽dvīhi jātilohehi saddhiṃ sesaṃ sabbampi idha lohanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Tipūti setatipu. Sīsanti kāḷatipu. Sajjhūti rajataṃ. Muttāti sāmuddikamuttā. Maṇīti
analyzed: pañca jātilohāni pāḷiyam visum tamba loham vekantaka lohanti imehi pana  dvīhi jātilohehi saddhim sesam sabbam pi idha lohanti veditabbam  rajatam muttā ati sāmuddikamuttā maṇī iti
translated: Bronze, bell-metal, white copper, lead, and gold.

original: ṭhapetvā pāḷiāgate veḷuriyādayo seso jotirasādibhedo sabbopi maṇi. Veḷuriyoti vaṃsavaṇṇamaṇi.🔽Saṅkhoti sāmuddikasaṅkho. Silāti kāḷasilā, paṇḍusilā, setasilātiādibhedā sabbāpi
analyzed: ṭhapetvā pāḷi āgate veḷuriya ādayo sesaḥ joti rasa ādi bhedo sabbaḥ api maṇi veḷuriyaḥ ti vaṃsa vaṇṇa maṇi  saṅkho ti sāmuddika saṅkhaḥ silā ati kāḷasilā paṇḍusilā setasilā ati ādi bhedā sabbā api
translated: “Rotten timber” is timber that is rotten inside or outside. “Timber” is any kind of timber, such as sāla, sāli, etc., that is used for building purposes. “Bamboo” is any kind of bamboo, such as black bamboo, etc., that is used for building purposes. “Grass” is any kind of grass, such as durva grass, etc., that is used for building purposes. “Cow dung” is the dung of any kind of cow, such as the dung of the baliya cow, etc. “Mud” is any kind of mud, such as red mud, black mud, etc.

original: medo jānāti ‘ahaṃ sakalasarīre jaṅghādīsu vā maṃsaṃ nissāya ṭhito’ti. Aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: medaḥ jānāti aham sakala sarīre jaṅghā ādīsu vā maṃsam nissāya ṭhitaḥ ti aññam aññam
translated: nor does the fat know, “I am next to flesh in the whole body or in the calves, etc.” These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing.

original: ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti medo nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso
analyzed: ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti medaḥ nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāso
translated: These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what are called fats are a particular component of this body,

original: acetano abyākato suñño nissatto patthinnasneho patthinnayūsabhūto ābandhanākāro āpodhātūti.🔽Assu yadā sañjāyati tadā akkhikūpake pūretvā tiṭṭhati vā paggharati vā. Tattha yathā🔽udakapuṇṇesu taruṇatālaṭṭhikūpakesu na taruṇatālaṭṭhikūpakā jānanti ‘amhesu udakaṃ🔽ṭhita’nti, nāpi udakaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ taruṇatālaṭṭhikūpakesu ṭhita’nti, evameva na🔽akkhikūpakā jānanti ‘amhesu assu ṭhita’nti, nāpi assu jānāti ‘ahaṃ akkhikūpakesu
analyzed: acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto patthinna snehaḥ patthinna yūsa bhūtaḥ ābandhana ākāraḥ āpodhātu uti  assu yadā sañjāyati tadā akkhikūpake pūretvā tiṭṭhati vā paggharati vā tattha yathā  udaka puṇṇesu taruṇa tālaṭṭhi kūpakesu na taruṇa tālaṭṭhi kūpakāḥ jānanti amhesu udakam  na api udakam jānāti aham taruṇa tālaṭṭhi kūpakesu evam eva na  akkhikūpakāḥ jānanti amhesu assu ṭhitanti na api assu jānāti aham akkhikūpakesu
translated: These states are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called fat is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: ṭhita’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti assu nāma imasmiṃ🔽sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto yūsabhūto ābandhanākāro āpodhātūti.
analyzed: ṭhitanti aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti nāma imasmin 🔽sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissattaḥ yūsa bhūtaḥ ābandhana ākāraḥ āpodhātu uti
translated: Tears are in the eye sockets. When they are produced they fill the eye sockets and either remain there or flow out. Herein, just as, in young palmyra nuts with no hole in them the water does not know, “I am in young palmyra nuts with no hole in them,” nor do the young palmyra nuts with no hole in them know, “Water is in us,” so too, the eye sockets do not know, “Tears are in us,” nor does the tear know, “I am in eye sockets.” These states are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called tears is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: Vasā aggisantāpādikāle hatthatalahatthapiṭṭhipādatalapādapiṭṭhināsapuṭanalāṭaaṃsakūṭesu🔽ṭhitavilīnasneho. Tattha yathā pakkhittatele ācāme na ācāmo jānāti ‘maṃ telaṃ ajjhottharitvā
analyzed: vasā aggi santāpa ādi kāle hattha talahattha piṭṭhi pāda tala pāda piṭṭhi nāsa puṭa na lāṭa aṃsa kūṭesu  ṭhita vilīna snehaḥ tattha yathā pakkhitta tele ācāme na ācāmaḥ jānāti mam telam ajjhottharitvā
translated: It is to be found in the palms of the hands, backs of the hands, soles of the feet, backs of the feet, nose, forehead, and on the points of the shoulders,

original: ṭhita’nti, nāpi telaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ ācāmaṃ ajjhottharitvā ṭhita’nti, evameva na hatthatalādippadeso
analyzed: na api telam jānāti aham ācāmam ajjhottharitvā ṭhitanti evam eva na hattha tala ādi ppadeso
translated: where it is like oil spread on those places. Herein, just as, when rice gruel with milk and sugar is boiling, the milk does not know, “I am in rice gruel,” nor does the rice gruel know, “I have milk in me,”

original: jānāti ‘maṃ vasā ajjhottharitvā ṭhitā’ti, nāpi vasā jānāti ‘ahaṃ hatthatalādippadese🔽ajjhottharitvā ṭhitā’ti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti vasā
analyzed: jānāti mam vasā ajjhottharitvā ṭhitā ati na api vasā jānāti aham hattha tala ādi ppadese  ajjhottharitvā ṭhitā ati aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti vasā
translated: so too, the palm of the hand, etc., does not know, “Fat is in me,”

original: nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto yūsabhūto🔽ābandhanākāro āpodhātūti.
analyzed: nāma imasmin sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissattaḥ yūsa bhūto  ābandhana ākāraḥ
translated: nor does the fat know, “I am in the palm of the hand, etc.” These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called fat is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, liquid water element in the mode of cohesion.🔽Spittle is to be found in the gullet or on the tongue.

original: Kheḷo tathārūpe kheḷuppattipaccaye sati ubhohi kapolapassehi orohitvā jivhāya tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: kheḷo tathārūpe kheḷa uppatti paccaye sati ubhohi kapola passehi orohitvā jivhāya tiṭṭhati
translated: When there is a need for it, such as when one is going to taste something, it trickles down from the spittle receptacle on the roof of the mouth.

original: Tattha yathā abbocchinnaudakanissande nadītīrakūpake na kūpatalaṃ jānāti ‘mayi udakaṃ🔽santiṭṭhatī’ti, nāpi udakaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ kūpatale santiṭṭhāmī’ti, evameva na jivhātalaṃ🔽jānāti ‘mayi ubhohi kapolapassehi orohitvā kheḷo ṭhito’ti, nāpi kheḷo jānāti ‘ahaṃ🔽ubhohi kapolapassehi orohitvā jivhātale ṭhito’ti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā
analyzed: yathā abba ucchinna odaka nissande nadī tīra kūpake na kūpa talam jānāti mayi udakam  santiṭṭhati iti na api udakam jānāti aham kūpa tale santiṭṭhāmi iti evam eva na jivhā talam  jānāti mayi ubhohi kapola passehi orohitvā kheḷaḥ ṭhitaḥ ti na api kheḷaḥ jānāti aham  ubhohi kapola passehi orohitvā jivhā tale ṭhitaḥ ti aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitā
translated: Herein, just as the surface of the pool does not know, “Water stands on me,”🔽nor does the water know, “I stand on the surface of a pool,” so too, the surface of the tongue does not know,🔽“Spittle trickling down from both cheeks is on me,” nor does the spittle know, “I trickle down from both cheeks and am on the surface of a tongue.”🔽They are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing.

original: ete dhammā. Iti kheḷo nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño🔽nissatto yūsabhūto ābandhanākāro āpodhātūti.
analyzed: ete dhammā iti kheḷaḥ nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suñño  nissattaḥ yūsa bhūtaḥ ābandhana ākāraḥ āpodhātu iti
translated: Herein, just as, when a pool on the bank of a river is not cut off from the current by a weir, etc., the surface of the pool does not know, “Water flows on to me from the river” nor does the water flowing on from the river know, “I flow on to the pool,” so too, the surface of the tongue does not know, “Spittle trickling down from both cheeks is on me” nor does the spittle trickling down from both cheeks know, “I am on the surface of the tongue.” These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called spittle is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: Siṅghāṇikā yadā sañjāyati tadā nāsāpuṭe pūretvā tiṭṭhati vā paggharati vā. Tattha
analyzed: siṅghāṇikā yadā sañjāyati tadā nāsāpuṭe pūretvā tiṭṭhati vā paggharati vā
translated: Snot is to be found filling the nostril cavities or dripping out of them. Herein,🔽just as, when a bag is full of dung, the bag does not know, “Dung is in me,”

original: yathā pūtidadhibharitāya sippikāya na sippikā jānāti ‘mayi pūtidadhi ṭhita’nti, nāpi
analyzed: yathā pūti dadhi bharitāya sippikāya na sippikā jānāti mayi pūti dadhi na api
translated: nor does the dung know, “I am in a bag,”

original: pūtidadhi jānāti ‘ahaṃ sippikāya ṭhita’nti, evameva na nāsāpuṭā jānanti ‘amhesu siṅghāṇikā
analyzed: pūti dadhi jānāti aham sippikāya evam eva na nāsāpuṭāḥ jānanti amhesu siṅghāṇikā
translated: The rotten curd does not know, “I am standing in the trough,” so too, the nostrils do not know, “Snot is in us,”

original: ṭhitā’ti, nāpi siṅghāṇikā jānāti ‘ahaṃ nāsāpuṭesu ṭhitā’ti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā🔽ete dhammā. Iti siṅghāṇikā nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato
analyzed: ṭhitā ati nā api siṅghāṇikā jānāti aham nāsā puṭesu ṭhitā ati aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitā  ete dhammāḥ iti siṅghāṇikā nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato
translated: nor does the snot know, “I am in nostrils.” These things are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing.

original: suñño nissatto yūsabhūto ābandhanākāro āpodhātūti.
analyzed: suññaḥ nissattaḥ yūsa bhūtaḥ ābandhana ākāraḥ āpodhātu uti
translated: So what are called snot are a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, rigid earth element.

original: Lasikā aṭṭhikasandhīnaṃ abbhañjanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā asītisatasandhīsu ṭhitā. Tattha🔽yathā telabbhañjite akkhe na akkho jānāti ‘maṃ telaṃ abbhañjitvā ṭhita’nti, nāpi🔽telaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ akkhaṃ abbhañjitvā ṭhita’nti, evameva na asītisatasandhayo jānanti
analyzed: lasikā aṭṭhika sandhīnam abbhañjana kiccam sādhayamānā asīti sata sandhīsu ṭhitā tattha  yathā tela bbhañjite akkhe na akkhaḥ jānāti mama telam abbhañjitvā na api  telam jānāti aham akkham abbhañjitvā ṭhitanti evam eva na asīti sata sandhayaḥ jānanti
translated: Grease is to be found in the eighty-four thousand joints serving the function of lubricating the bones’ joints. Herein,🔽just as, when a wheel hub is well soaked in grease, the spokes do not know, “Grease trickles down on us,”🔽nor does the grease know, “I am trickling down on the spokes,” so too, the eighty-four thousand joints do not know,

original: ‘lasikā amhe abbhañjitvā ṭhitā’ti, nāpi lasikā jānāti ‘ahaṃ asītisatasandhayo abbhañjitvā
analyzed: lasikā amhe ap bhañjitvā ṭhitā ati na api lasikā jānāti aham asi iti sata sandhayaḥ ap bhañjitvā
translated: “Grease is in us,” nor does the grease know, “I am in eighty-four thousand joints,”

original: ṭhitā’ti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammā. Iti lasikā nāma imasmiṃ
analyzed: ṭhitā ati aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammāḥ iti lasikā nāma imasmiṃ
translated: ‘are established’ means that these things are devoid of mutual contact and review.

original: sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto yūsabhūto ābandhanākāro āpodhātūti.🔽Muttaṃ vatthissa abbhantare ṭhitaṃ. Tattha yathā candanikāya pakkhitte adhomukhe🔽ravaṇaghaṭe na ravaṇaghaṭo jānāti ‘mayi candanikāraso ṭhito’ti, nāpi candanikāraso
analyzed: sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissattaḥ yūsa bhūtaḥ ābandhana ākāraḥ āpodhātu uti  muttam vatthissa abbhantare ṭhitam tattha yathā candanikāya pakkhitte adhomukhe  ravaṇa ghaṭe na ravaṇa ghaṭaḥ jānāti mayi candanikā rasaḥ ṭhitaḥ iti na api candanikā rasaḥ
translated: They are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing. So what is called urine is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, liquid water element in the mode of cohesion.

original: jānāti ‘ahaṃ ravaṇaghaṭe ṭhito’ti, evameva na vatthi jānāti ‘mayi muttaṃ ṭhita’nti,
analyzed: jānāti aham ravaṇa ghaṭe ṭhitaḥ iti evam eva na jānāti mayi muttam ṭhitanti
translated: It is held in the bladder inside the belly. Herein, just as, when a pot with a porous base is set in a cesspool, the pot does not know, “Cesspool water is under me,” nor does the cesspool water know, “I am under a pot with a porous base,” so too, the belly does not know, “Urine is inside me,”

original: nāpi muttaṃ jānāti ‘ahaṃ vatthimhi ṭhita’nti. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā🔽ete dhammā. Iti muttaṃ nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño
analyzed: na api muttam jānāti aham vatthimhi ṭhitan ti aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitā  ete dhammā iti muttam nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suñño
translated: nor does the urine know, “I am inside a belly.” They are devoid of mutual concern and reviewing.

original: nissatto yūsabhūto ābandhanākāro āpodhātūti. Yaṃ vā panāti avasesesu tīsu koṭṭhāsesu
analyzed: nissattaḥ yūsa bhūtaḥ ābandhana ākāraḥ āpodhātu uti yam vā pana ati avasesesu tīsu koṭṭhāsesu
translated: So what is called urine is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, liquid water element in the mode of cohesion. Or alternatively, what is called urine is a particular component of this body, without thought, indeterminate, void, not a living being, liquid water element in the mode of cohesion, which is found in the remaining three components.

original: āpodhātuṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.🔽Bāhiraāpodhātuniddese mūlaṃ paṭicca nibbatto raso mūlaraso nāma. Khandharasādīsupi🔽eseva nayo. Khīrādīni pākaṭāneva. Yathā pana bhesajjasikkhāpade evamidha niyamo natthi.
analyzed: āpodhātum sandhāya vuttam  bāhira āpodhātu niddese mūlam paṭicca nibbattaḥ rasaḥ mūla rasaḥ nāma khandha rasa ādīsu pi  esa iva nayaḥ khīra ādīni pākaṭāni eva yathā pana bhesajja sikkhāpade evam idha niyamaḥ natthi
translated: and the water element is meant.🔽In the description of the external water element, the juice that is produced in dependence on the root is called “root juice.” So too with the stem juice, etc.

original: Yaṃ kiñci khīraṃ khīrameva. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Bhummānīti āvāṭādīsu ṭhitaudakāni.
analyzed: yam kiñci khīram khīram eva sesesu pi esā iva nayaḥ bhummāni iti āvāṭa ādīsu ṭhita audakāni
translated: Milk, etc., are obvious. But there is no such restriction here as in the case of the training precept on medicines, where “milk” means milk only. The same method applies in the case of the rest. “Water in the earth” is water that is in wells, etc.

original: Antalikkhānīti pathaviṃ appattāni vassodakāni. Yaṃ vā panāti himodakakappavināsakaudakapathavīsandhārakaudakādīni
analyzed: antalikkhāni iti pathavim appattāni vassa udakāni yam vā panāti hima udaka kappa vināsaka audaka pathavī sandhāraka audaka ādīni
translated: “Water in the sky” is rain water that has not yet reached the earth. “Or any other” includes snow, hail, the water that causes the destruction of the eon, the water that supports the earth, and so on.

original: idha yevāpanakaṭṭhānaṃ paviṭṭhāni.🔽175. Tejodhātuniddese tejanavasena tejo. Tejova tejobhāvaṃ gatattā tejogataṃ. Usmāti🔽uṇhākāro. Usmāva usmābhāvaṃ gatattā usmāgataṃ. Usumanti caṇḍausumaṃ. Tadeva usumabhāvaṃ
analyzed: idha yevāpanakaṭṭhānam paviṭṭhāni  tejaḥ dhātu niddese tejana vasena tejaḥ tejaḥ uva tejaḥ bhāvam tejaḥ gatam  uṇhā kāraḥ usmā avaḥ usmā bhāvam usumanti caṇḍausumam tat eva usuma bhāvam
translated: “Or any other” includes water that has entered the body.🔽In the description of the fire element, “fire” is in the sense of the state of burning. “The state of burning” is the fire itself, since it has become the state of burning. “Heat” is🔽the form of heat. “The state of heat” is heat itself, since it has become the state of heat. “Warmth” is intense heat. “The state of warmth” is warmth itself,

original: gatattā usumagataṃ. Yena cāti yena tejogatena kuppitena. Santappatīti ayaṃ kāyo santappati,
analyzed: gata ttā usuma gatam yena ca ati yena tejaḥ gatena kuppitena santappati iti ayam kāyaḥ santappati
translated: since it has become the state of warmth. “By which” is by which state of burning that has arisen. “Is heated” means that this body is heated.

original: ekāhikajarādibhāvena usumajāto hoti. Yena ca jīrīyatīti yena ayaṃ kāyo jīrīyati,
analyzed: ekāhika jarā ādi bhāvena yena ca jīrīyati iti yena ayam kāyaḥ jīrīyati
translated: By which it decays: by which this body decays,🔽and it comes to have a deficiency of faculties, loss of strength, wrinkles, grey hairs, and so on.

original: indriyavekallataṃ balaparikkhayaṃ valipalitādibhāvañca pāpuṇāti. Yena ca pariḍayhatīti
analyzed: indriya vekalla tam bala parikkhayam vali palita ādi bhāvañca pāpuṇāti yena ca pariḍayhati iti
translated: By which it is burnt up:

original: yena kuppitena ayaṃ kāyo ḍayhati, so ca puggalo ‘ḍayhāmi ḍayhāmī’ti kandanto satadhotasappigosītacandanādilepanañceva🔽tālavaṇṭavātañca paccāsīsati. Yena ca asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṃ sammā pariṇāmaṃ gacchatīti🔽yenetaṃ asitaṃ vā odanādi, pītaṃ vā pānakādi, khāyitaṃ vā piṭṭhakhajjakādi, sāyitaṃ
analyzed: yena kuppitena ayam kāyaḥ ḍayhati saḥ ca puggalaḥ ḍayhāmi ḍayhāmi iti kandanto satadhā uta sappi go sīta candana ādi lepanam ca iva  tālavaṇṭa vātam ca yena ca asita pīta khāyita sāyitam sammā pariṇāmam gacchati iti  yena itam asitam vā odana ādi pītam vā pānaka ādi khāyitam vā piṭṭhakhajjaka ādi sāyitam
translated: by which, when it is angry, this body is burnt up, and that person cries out, “I am burning, I am burning,” and longs for a hundred tubs of cold water,🔽cold ointments of sandalwood mixed with water, and so on,🔽and for a breeze from fans.🔽By which what is eaten, drunk, chewed and tasted gets completely digested:

original: vā ambapakkamadhuphāṇitādi sammā paripākaṃ gacchati, rasādibhāvena vivekaṃ gacchatīti
analyzed: vā amba pakka madhu phāṇita ādi sammā paripākam gacchati rasa ādi bhāvena vivekam gacchati iti
translated: by which this food eaten, such as rice, and drink drunk, such as beverages, and so on, and what is chewed, such as pastries, and what is tasted, such as mango fruit, honey, molasses, and so on, gets completely digested, gets separated into essence and so on.🔽This is the meaning.

original: attho. Ettha ca purimā tayo tejodhātū catusamuṭṭhānā, pacchimo kammasamuṭṭhānova.🔽Ayaṃ tāvettha padasaṃvaṇṇanā.
analyzed: ettha ca purimā tayo tejodhātū catu samuṭṭhānā pacchimo kamma samuṭṭhānaḥ va 🔽ayam tau ettha pada saṃvaṇṇanā
translated: And here the first three fire elements are of fourfold origination, while the last one is kamma-originated only.

original: Idaṃ pana manasikāravidhānaṃ – idha bhikkhu ‘yena santappati, ayaṃ imasmiṃ sarīre
analyzed: idam pana manasikāra vidhānam idha bhikkhu yena santappati ayam imasmin sarīre
translated: Now, the method of attending to it is this: Here a bhikkhu gives his attention thus: “In this body

original: pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto paripācanākāro tejodhātū’ti manasi
analyzed: pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto paripācana ākāro tejodhātu uti manasi
translated: there is, in the east, the earth element that has been taken up, without making it into a self or into ‘my self’ or ‘I am’ or ‘mine,’ as a mere phenomenon of a certain nature, that is, as a mere phenomenon of the earth element.🔽In this body there is, in the south … in the west … in the north, the earth element that has been taken up …

original: karoti; ‘yena jīrīyati, yena pariḍayhati, yena asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṃ sammā pariṇāmaṃ🔽gacchati, ayaṃ imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato suñño nissatto
analyzed: karoti yena jīrīyati yena pariḍayhati yena asita pīta khāyita sāyitam pariṇāmam  gacchati ayam imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ abyākato suññaḥ nissatto
translated: In this body there is, below … above … across, the earth element that has been taken up …🔽In this body there is the earth element that is seen, heard, sensed, cognized, reached, traversed, and examined by the mind, that has been taken up …🔽In this body there is the earth element that will vanish, that has been taken up …🔽In this body there is the earth element that has vanished, that has been taken up …

translated: In this body there is the earth element that is not, that has been taken up …🔽In this body there is the earth element that is, that has been taken up …🔽In this body there is the earth element that is, that has been taken up, without making it into a self or into ‘my self’ or ‘I am’ or ‘mine,’ as a mere phenomenon of a certain nature, that is, as a mere phenomenon of the earth element.”
