translated: Or alternatively, he gives his attention to it as “the earth element” in all its aspects, and to it as a phenomenon in all its aspects, and to it as “impermanent,” and to it as “subject to suffering,” and to it as “subject to change,” and to it as “not self,” and to it as “not delighting in it,” and to it as “fading away,” and to it as “vanishing,” and to it as “devoid of delight,” and to it as “dangerous,” and to it as “subject to destruction,” and to it as “subject to vanishing,” and to it as “subject to arising,” and to it as “subject to cessation,” and to it as “calm,” and to it as “superior,” and to it as “peaceful,” and to it as “secluded,” and to it as “having no core,” and to it as “innumerable,” and to it as “not self.”🔽In the description of the

original: Indaggīti asaniaggi. Aggisantāpoti jālāya vā vītaccikaṅgārānaṃ vā santāpo. Sūriyasantāpoti🔽ātapo. Kaṭṭhasannicayasantāpoti kaṭṭharāsiṭṭhāne santāpo. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Yaṃ
analyzed: indaggī iti aggi santāpā uti jālāya vā vā santāpaḥ sūriya santāpā uti  ātapo kaṭṭha sannicaya santāpo ti kaṭṭha rāsi ṭṭhāne santāpo sesesu pi esa iva nayaḥ yaṃ
translated: “Fire of lightning” is the fire of lightning. “Heat of fire” is the heat of the flame or of the embers. “Heat of the sun” is the heat of the sun’s rays. “Heat of a wood-pile” is the heat in a heap of wood. The same method applies to the rest.

original: vā panāti petaggi kappavināsaggi nirayaggiādayo idha yevāpanakaṭṭhānaṃ paviṭṭhā.
analyzed: vā pana ati petaggi kappa vināsaggi nirayaggi ādayaḥ idha paviṭṭhā
translated: The fire of lightning is the lightning’s flame. The fire of the sun’s heat is the heat of the sun’s rays. The fire of the mass of wood is the heat in a heap of wood or in embers without flame. The rest are obvious. Or else the fire of the gods is the fire of the gods of the Four Kings’ heaven, etc., the fire of the asuras is the fire of the asura demons, the fire of the serpent-spirits is the fire of the serpent-spirits, the fire of men is the fire of men, the fire of the animal-spirits is the fire of the animal-spirits, the fire of the ghosts is the fire of the ghosts, the fire of the Kappa-destruction is the fire of the aeon’s destruction, the fire of hell is the fire of the hells, etc., which have entered the wood that is to be dried out.

original: 176. Vāyodhātuniddese vāyanavasena vāyo. Vāyova vāyobhāvaṃ gatattā vāyogataṃ. Thambhitattaṃ🔽rūpassāti avinibbhogarūpassa thambhitabhāvo. Uddhaṅgamā vātāti uggārahikkādi pavattakā🔽uddhaṃ ārohanavātā. Adhogamā vātāti uccārapassāvādinīharaṇakā adho orohanavātā. Kucchisayā🔽vātāti antānaṃ bahivātā. Koṭṭhāsayā vātāti antānaṃ antovātā. Aṅgamaṅgānusārino vātāti
analyzed: vāyo dhātu niddese vāyana vasena vāyo vāyo iva vāyu bhāvam vāyu gatattā vāyu gatam  rūpassa ati avinibbhoga rūpassa thambhita bhāvaḥ uddhaṅgamāḥ vātā ati uggāra hikkā ādi pavattakā  uddham ārohana vātāḥ adhogamāḥ vātāti uccāra passāvādinī haraṇakāḥ adhas orohana vātā kucchi sayā  vātāti antānam bahivātā koṭṭhāsayā vātāti antānam antovātāḥ aṅgam aṅga anusārinaḥ vātāti
translated: In the description of the air element: Air by its swaying is the air element. It is called “gone to the air element” because it has become the air element. Stiffness is the stiffness of undissipated matter.

original: dhamanijālānusārena sakalasarīre aṅgamaṅgāni anusaṭā samiñjanapasāraṇādinibbattakā
analyzed: dhamani jāla anusārena sakala sarīre aṅgam aṅgāni samiñjana pasāraṇa ādi nibbattakā
translated: The winds that move upwards are the winds that occur in vomiting, belching, etc., and that move upwards. The winds that move downwards are the winds that move downwards carrying off excrement, urine, etc. The winds in the belly are the winds in the intestines that move outwards. The winds in the bowels are the winds in the intestines that move inwards. The winds that course through all the limbs are the winds that produce flexing, extending, etc., and that move through the whole body following the network of nerves.

original: vātā. Satthakavātāti sandhibandhanāni kattariyā chindantā viya pavattavātā. Khurakavātāti🔽khurena viya hadayaṃ phālanavātā. Uppalakavātāti hadayamaṃsameva uppāṭanakavātā.🔽Assāsoti antopavisananāsikāvato. Passāsoti bahinikkhamananāsikāvato. Ettha ca purimā
analyzed: vātā satthaka vātā ati sandhibandhanāni kattariyā chindantā viya pavatta vātā khuraka vātā ati  khurena hadayam phālana vātāḥ uppalaka vātāḥ ati hadayam aṃsam eva uppāṭanaka vātāḥ  assāso ti anta upavisana nāsikāvato passāso ti bahi nikkhamana nāsikāvato ettha ca purimā
translated: Winds. Winds that move up and down: winds that move up and down in the stomach, etc., like bellows bellows.

original: sabbe catusamuṭṭhānā, assāsapassāsā cittasamuṭṭhānāva. Ayamettha padavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: sabbe catu samuṭṭhānāḥ assāsa passāsā citta samuṭṭhānā ca ayam ettha pada vaṇṇanā
translated: Winds that cut: winds that cut up the flesh, etc., like a saw. Winds that carry off: winds that carry off the body’s waste matter, etc., like a water-carrying wind. Winds that distribute: winds that distribute nourishment to the whole body, like a fan. Winds that go out: winds that go out through the nine orifices, like a wind that carries off refuse. Winds that go out below: winds that go out through the anus, like a water-carrying wind. Winds that go out above: winds that go out through the mouth and nose, like a fan. Winds that go out all round: winds that go out through the pores of the body, like a wind that carries off refuse. In-breath: wind that enters through the nostrils. Out-breath: wind that goes out through the nostrils. And here all the winds except the in-breath and the out-breath are of fourfold origination, while the in-breath and the out-breath are consciousness-originated only. This is the commentary on the wordings here.

original: Idaṃ pana manasikāravidhānaṃ – idha bhikkhu uddhaṅgamādibhede vāte uddhaṅgamādivasena🔽pariggahetvā ‘uddhaṅgamā vātā nāma imasmiṃ sarīre pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāso acetano abyākato
analyzed: idam pana manasikāra vidhānam idha bhikkhu uddhaṅgama ādi bhede vāte uddhaṅgama ādi vasena  pariggahetvā uddhaṅgamāḥ vātāḥ nāma imasmim sarīre pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ acetanaḥ a byākato
translated: But the method of attending to them is this. Here a bhikkhu discerns the winds classed as “upgoing” and so on, as “upgoing winds,” and so on.

original: suñño nissatto vitthambhanākāro vāyodhātū’ti manasi karoti. Sesesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: suññaḥ nissattaḥ vitthambhana ākāraḥ vāyodhātu uti manasi karoti sesesu pi esā iva nayo
translated: “The winds that go upwards are a particular part of this body consisting in the air element that is void, non-nutritive essence, and directionally uniform, and it is without cognitive series, without life, without awareness, and it is not a person.” He gives his attention to them in this way “going upwards,” and so on. The same method applies in the case of the winds that go downwards, and so on.

original: Yaṃ vā panāti sese vāyokoṭṭhāse anugatā vātā idha yevāpanakaṭṭhānaṃ paviṭṭhā.
analyzed: yam vā panāti sese vāyokoṭṭhāse anugatāḥ vātāḥ idha yevāpanaka ṭṭhānam paviṭṭhā
translated: Or else, the winds that go upwards are the winds in the upper part of the body, and the winds that go downwards are the winds in the lower part.

original: Bāhiravāyodhātuniddese puratthimā vātāti puratthimadisato āgatā vātā. Pacchimuttaradakkhiṇesupi🔽eseva nayo. Sarajā vātāti saha rajena sarajā. Arajā vātāti rajavirahitā suddhā arajā🔽nāma. Sītāti sītautusamuṭṭhānā sītavalāhakantare samuṭṭhitā. Uṇhāti uṇhautusamuṭṭhānā🔽uṇhavalāhakantare samuṭṭhitā. Parittāti mandā tanukavātā. analyzed: bāhira vāyo dhātu niddese puratthimā vātā ati puratthima disataḥ āgatā vātā pacchima uttara dakkhiṇesu pi  saha rajena sa rajā arajā vātāti raja virahitā suddhā arajā  nāma sītā ati sīta otu samuṭṭhānā sīta valāhaka antare samuṭṭhitā uṇhā ati uṇha otu samuṭṭhānā  uṇha valāhaka ntare samuṭṭhitā parittā ati mandā tanuka vātā adhimattā ati balava vātā  kāḷā ati kāḷa valāhaka antare samuṭṭhitā yehi abbha āhataḥ chavi vaṇṇo kāḷakaḥ hoti tesam  etam eke verambha vātā ati yojanataḥ upari vāyana vātā pakkha vātā ati
translated: In the description of the external air element, winds coming from the east are winds that have come from the eastern direction. So too with the west, north and south. Dusty winds are winds with dust. Dustless winds are winds without dust. Cold winds are winds that have arisen in the cold season and in the cold-weather sky. Hot winds are winds that have arisen in the hot season and in the hot-weather sky. Gentle winds are weak, thin winds. Strong winds are powerful winds. Black winds are winds that have arisen in the black-rain weather. Some say that this is a term for the winds that blow in the black-rain weather, by which one’s complexion becomes dark and sallow. Verambha winds are winds that blow above a league. Winged winds are winds that have arisen in the wing weather.

original: antamaso makkhikāyapi pakkhāyūhanasamuṭṭhitā vātā. Supaṇṇavātāti garuḷavātā. Kāmañca🔽imepi pakkhavātāva ussadavasena pana visuṃ gahitā. Tālavaṇṭavātāti tālapaṇṇehi vā

translated: In the description of the external air element, winds from the east are winds that have come from the eastern direction. So too with the winds from the west, north, and south. Dusty winds are winds with dust. Dustless winds are winds without dust. Cold winds are winds that have arisen in the cold season and in the cold-weather sky. Hot winds are winds that have arisen in the hot season and in the hot-weather sky. Gentle winds are weak, thin winds. Strong winds are powerful winds. Black winds are winds that have arisen in the black-rain weather. Some say that this is a term for the winds that blow over a charnel ground. Winds that blow over charnel grounds are winds that blow over charnel grounds. Winds that blow over the sky are winds that blow over the sky. Winds that blow over the earth are winds that blow over the earth. Winds that blow over the ocean are winds that blow over the ocean. Winds that blow over the forest are winds that blow over the forest. Winds that blow over the leaves are winds that blow over the leaves of such trees as the tāla.

original: aññena vā kenaci maṇḍalasaṇṭhānena samuṭṭhāpitā vātā. Vidhūpanavātāti bījanapattakena🔽samuṭṭhāpitā vātā. Imāni ca tālavaṇṭavidhūpanāni anuppannampi vātaṃ uppādenti, uppannampi
analyzed: aññena vā kenacid maṇḍala saṇṭhānena samuṭṭhāpitāḥ vātāḥ vidhūpana vātā ati bījana pattakena  samuṭṭhāpitāḥ vātāḥ imāni ca tālavaṇṭa vidhūpanāni anuppannam pi vātam uppādenti uppannam pi
translated: or by any other kind of circular motion. The wind of a fan is the wind set up by a fan. These two kinds of wind, the wind from a palm leaf and the wind from a fan, cause wind to arise where there was none before, and they also fan wind that has arisen.

original: parivattenti. Yaṃ vā panāti idha pāḷiāgate ṭhapetvā sesavātā yevāpanakaṭṭhānaṃ paviṭṭhā.🔽177. Ākāsadhātuniddese appaṭighaṭṭanaṭṭhena na kassatīti ākāso. Ākāsova ākāsabhāvaṃ
analyzed: parivattenti yam vā pana ati idha pāḷi āgate ṭhapetvā sesa vātāḥ yevāpanaka ṭhānam paviṭṭhā  ākāsa dhātu niddese a paṭighaṭṭana ṭṭhena na kassati iti ākāsaḥ ākāsa uva ākāsa bhāvam
translated: and by any other kind of circular motion. “Wind from a fan” is wind set up by a fan. “Wind from a bellows” is wind set up by a bellows. These winds from a palm leaf and from a bellows cause wind to arise where there was none, and they turn it where there was some. “Or any other kind of wind” includes all the other kinds of wind mentioned in the texts, such as the “wind of the aeon” .🔽In the description of the space element, it is “not impinged upon” because it is not obstructed by anything. It is “space” because it is not impinged upon. It is “in space” because it has become the space element. It is “unimpeded” because it cannot be obstructed. It is “unimpededness” because it has become the state of being unimpeded.

original: gatattā ākāsagataṃ. Aghaṭṭanīyatāya aghaṃ. Aghameva aghabhāvaṃ gatattā aghagataṃ.🔽Vivaroti antaraṃ. Tadeva vivarabhāvaṃ gatattā vivaragataṃ. Asamphuṭṭhaṃ maṃsalohitehīti🔽maṃsalohitehi nissaṭaṃ. Kaṇṇacchiddantiādi pana tasseva pabhedadassanaṃ. Tattha kaṇṇacchiddanti
analyzed: ākāsa gatam a ghaṭṭanīya tāya agham agham eva agha bhāvam gatattā agha gatam  antaram tat eva vivara bhāvam vivara gatam a samphuṭṭham  maṃsa lohitehi nissaṭam kaṇṇa chid danti ādi pana tassa iva pabheda dassanam tattha kaṇṇa chid danti
translated: “An opening” is an interval. It is “in an opening” because it has become the state of being an opening. “Not contacted by the body or by matter” is not contacted by flesh or blood.

analyzed: kaṇṇasmim chiddam vivaram maṃsa lohitehi a samphuṭṭha ukāsaḥ sesesu pi esa iva nayaḥ yena ati
translated: “The opening of the ear” and so on is the showing of its different aspects. Herein, “the opening of the ear” is the hole in the ear. “The opening of the eye” is the hole in the eye. “The opening of the nose” is the hole in the nose. “The space in the stomach” is the space in the stomach. “The space in the bowels” is the space in the bowels. “The space in the gullet” is the space in the gullet. “The space in the limbs” is the space in the fingers, toes, etc. “The space in the joints” is the space in the joints of the fingers, toes, etc. “The space in the head” is the space in the skull. “The space in the mouth” is the space in the mouth. “The space in the nostrils” is the space in the nostrils. “The space in the jaws” is the space in the jaws. “The space in the lips” is the space in the lips. “The space in the tongue” is the space in the tongue. “The space in the teeth” is the space in the teeth. “The space in the cheeks” is the space in the cheeks. “The space in the throat” is the space in the throat. “The space in the gullet” is

original: yena vivarena etaṃ asitādibhedaṃ ajjhoharaṇīyaṃ ajjhoharati, anto paveseti. Yatthāti
analyzed: yena vivarena etam asita ādi bhedam ajjhoharaṇīyam ajjhoharati antar paveseti yattha ati
translated: The ‘by which’ is the opening by which he swallows the food of the four kinds of nutriment. The ‘in which’ is

original: yasmiṃ antoudarapaṭalasaṅkhāte okāse etadeva catubbidhaṃ ajjhoharaṇīyaṃ tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: yasmin antar udara paṭala saṅkhāte okāse etat eva catubbidham ajjhoharaṇīyam tiṭṭhati
translated: in the place called the ‘belly-pit’.

original: Yenāti yena vivarena sabbampetaṃ vipakkaṃ kasaṭabhāvaṃ āpannaṃ nikkhamati, taṃ udarapaṭalato
analyzed: yena ati yena vivarena sabbampetam vipakkam kasaṭa bhāvam āpannam nikkhamati tam udara paṭalataḥ

analyzed: yāva karīsa maggā vidatthi catur aṅgula mattam chiddam maṃsa lohitehi a samphuṭṭham nissaṭam  ākāsa dhātu uti veditabbam yam vā panāti ettha camma antaram maṃsa antaram nhāru antaram
translated: which is a hole extending from there down to the rectum, and is the size of a bamboo tube, unblocked by flesh and blood, and is empty.🔽Or whatever other space element there is apart from that is to be understood as the space element in the interstices between the skin, the flesh, the sinews, the bones, the bone marrow, and the internal organs,

original: aṭṭhintaraṃ lomantaranti idaṃ sabbaṃ yevāpanakaṭṭhānaṃ paviṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhintaram lomantaram ti idam sabbam yevāpanakaṭṭhānam paviṭṭham

analyzed: bāhiraka ākāsa dhātu niddese asamphuṭṭham catūhi mahābhūtehi iti catūhi mahābhūtehi nissaṭam
translated: In the description of the external space element, ‘unblocked by the four great entities’ means unblocked by the four great entities.

original: bhittichiddakavāṭachiddādikaṃ veditabbaṃ. Iminā yasmiṃ ākāse parikammaṃ karontassa
analyzed: bhitti chidda kavāṭa chidda ādikam veditabbam iminā yasmin ākāse parikammam karontassa
translated: It is to be understood as the holes in walls, in doors, and so on. By this, the space element in which one who is doing the preliminary work on the kasiṇa should be included,

original: catukkapañcakajjhānāni uppajjanti taṃ kathitaṃ.
analyzed: catukka pañcaka jjhānāni uppajjanti tat kathitam
translated: The four and five jhānas are produced, and that is told.

original: 178. Viññāṇadhātuniddese cakkhuviññāṇasaṅkhātā dhātu cakkhuviññāṇadhātu. Sesāsupi
analyzed: viññāṇa dhātu niddese cakkhu viññāṇa saṅkhātā dhātu cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu sesāsu pi
translated: In the description of the consciousness element, the element called eye-consciousness is the eye-consciousness element. The same method applies in the case of the rest.

original: eseva nayo. Iti imāsu chasu dhātūsu pariggahitāsu aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo pariggahitāva
analyzed: nayo iti imāsu chasu dhātūsu pariggahitāsu aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo pariggahitāva
translated: So when these six elements are discerned, the eighteen elements are discerned too.

original: honti. Kathaṃ? Pathavītejovāyodhātuggahaṇena tāva phoṭṭhabbadhātu gahitāva hoti,🔽āpodhātuākāsadhātuggahaṇena dhammadhātu, viññāṇadhātuggahaṇena tassā purecārikapacchācārikattā
analyzed: honti katham pathavī tejaḥ vāyo dhātu ggahaṇena tāva phoṭṭhabba dhātu gahitā ava hoti  āpodhātu ākāsadhātu ggahaṇena dhammadhātu viññāṇadhātu ggahaṇena tassā purecārika pacchācārika ttā
translated: How? By the inclusion of the earth, fire, and air elements, the tangible-data element is included too.🔽By the inclusion of the water element and the space element, the mental-data element is included. By the inclusion of the consciousness element, the mind element is included too, since it is the forerunner and follower of that.

original: manodhātu gahitāva hoti. Cakkhuviññāṇadhātuādayo sutte āgatā eva. Sesā nava āharitvā
analyzed: manaḥ dhātu gahitā ava hoti cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu ādayo sutte āgatāḥ eva sesāḥ nava āharitvā
translated: The eye-consciousness element, etc., are mentioned in the texts themselves. The rest are to be shown by implication as follows.

original: dassetabbā. Cakkhuviññāṇadhātuggahaṇena hi tassā nissayabhūtā cakkhudhātu, ārammaṇabhūtā
analyzed: dassetabbā cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu ggahaṇena hi tassāḥ nissaya bhūtā cakkhu dhātu ārammaṇa bhūtā
translated: By the inclusion of the eye-consciousness element, the eye base and the visible-data base, which are its support and its object respectively, are included too.

original: rūpadhātu ca gahitāva honti. Evaṃ sotaviññāṇadhātuādiggahaṇena sotadhātuādayoti aṭṭhārasāpi
analyzed: rūpa dhātu ca gahitā ava honti evam sota viññāṇa dhātu ādi gahaṇena sota dhātu ādayo ti aṭṭhārasā api
translated: So by the inclusion of the ear-consciousness element, etc., the ear base, etc., are included too. Thus the eighteen elements are included too.

original: gahitāva honti. Tāsu dasahi dhātūhi rūpapariggaho kathito hoti. Sattahi arūpapariggaho.
analyzed: gahitā ava honti tāsu dasahi dhātūhi rūpa pariggaho kathitaḥ hoti sattahi arūpa pariggaho
translated: and they are included in the eighteen elements.🔽The apprehending of materiality is done by ten elements, and the apprehending of the immaterial is done by seven elements.

original: Dhammadhātuyā siyā rūpapariggaho, siyā arūpapariggaho. Iti aḍḍhekādasahi dhātūhi
analyzed: dhammadhātuyā siyā rūpa pariggaho siyā arūpa pariggaho iti aḍḍha ekādasahi dhātūhi
translated: The apprehending of materiality and the immaterial is done by eleven and a half elements.

original: rūpapariggaho, aḍḍhaṭṭhadhātūhi arūpapariggahoti rūpārūpapariggaho kathito hoti.
analyzed: rūpa pariggahaḥ aḍḍha aṭṭhadhātūhi arūpa pariggaho ti rūpa arūpa pariggahaḥ kathitaḥ hoti
translated: The apprehending of materiality is done by eleven and a half elements, and the apprehending of the immaterial is done by seven and a half elements.

original: Rūpārūpaṃ pañcakkhandhā. Taṃ hoti dukkhasaccaṃ. Taṃsamuṭṭhāpikā purimataṇhā samudayasaccaṃ.
analyzed: rūpa arūpam pañca kkhandhā tam hoti dukkha saccam tad samuṭṭhāpikā purima taṇhā samudaya saccam
translated: Materiality and the immaterial are the five categories. They are the truth of suffering. The craving that originates them is the truth of origin.

original: Ubhinnaṃ appavatti nirodhasaccaṃ. Taṃpajānano maggo maggasaccanti idaṃ catusaccakammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽aṭṭhārasadhātuvasena abhiniviṭṭhassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā matthakaṃ pāpetvā nigamanaṃ
analyzed: ubhinnam appavatti nirodha saccam taṃ pajānanaḥ maggaḥ magga saccanti idam catu sacca kammaṭṭhānam  aṭṭhārasa dhātu vasena abhiniviṭṭhassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā matthakam pāpetvā nigamanam
translated: The non-occurrence of both is the truth of cessation. The understanding of that is the truth of the path. This is the meditation subject of the Four Truths.

original: kathitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: kathitam ti veditabbam
translated: It should be understood that the exposition of the meditation subject of the Four Truths is concluded with the attainment of Arahantship by the bhikkhu who is devoted to the meditation subject of the eighteen elements.

original: 179. Idāni dutiyachakkaṃ dassento aparāpi cha dhātuyotiādimāha. Tattha sukhadhātu
analyzed: idāni dutiya chakkam dassentaḥ tattha sukha dhātu
translated: . Now, in order to show the second tetrad, he says, “There are, besides, six elements,” and so on. Herein, the pleasant element is the pleasant feeling.

original: dukkhadhātūti kāyappasādavatthukāni sukhadukkhāni sappaṭipakkhavasena yugaḷakato🔽dassitāni. Sukhañhi dukkhassa paṭipakkho, dukkhaṃ sukhassa. Yattakaṃ sukhena pharitaṭṭhānaṃ🔽tattakaṃ dukkhaṃ pharati. Yattakaṃ dukkhena pharitaṭṭhānaṃ tattakaṃ sukhaṃ pharati.
analyzed: dukkha dhātū ti kāya ppasāda vatthukāni sukha dukkhāni sa paṭipakkha vasena yugaḷakato  dassitāni sukham hi dukkhassa paṭipakkhaḥ dukkham sukhassa yattakam sukhena pharita ṭṭhānam  tat takam dukkham pharati yat takam dukkhena pharita ṭṭhānam tat takam sukham pharati
translated: The “pleasure element” and the “pain element” are shown in pairs as opposites, in the way beginning, “Pleasure and pain are the pleasure element and the pain element” . For pleasure is the opposite of pain, and pain is the opposite of pleasure. As much as is pervaded by pleasure is pervaded by pain, and as much as is pervaded by pain is pervaded by pleasure.

original: Somanassadhātu domanassadhātūti idampi tatheva yugaḷakaṃ kataṃ. Somanassañhi domanassassa🔽paṭipakkho, domanassaṃ somanassassa. Yattakaṃ somanassena pharitaṭṭhānaṃ tattakaṃ🔽domanassaṃ pharati. Yattakaṃ domanassena pharitaṭṭhānaṃ tattakaṃ somanassaṃ pharati.🔽Upekkhādhātu avijjādhātūti idaṃ pana dvayaṃ sarikkhakavasena yugaḷakaṃ kataṃ. Ubhayampi
analyzed: somanassa dhātu domanassa dhātu uti idam pi tathā iva yugaḷakam katam somanassam hi domanassassa  paṭipakkhaḥ domanassam somanassassa yattakam somanassena pharita ṭṭhānam tattakam  domanassam pharati yattakam domanassena pharita ṭṭhānam tattakam somanassam pharati  upekkhā dhātu avijjā dhātu uti idam pana dvayam sa rikkhaka vasena yugaḷakam katam ubhayam pi
translated: The “joy element” and the “grief element” are shown in the same way. For joy is the opposite of grief, and grief is the opposite of joy. As much as is pervaded by joy is pervaded by grief, and as much as is pervaded by grief is pervaded by joy.

original: hetaṃ avibhūtattā sarikkhakaṃ hoti. Tattha sukhadukkhadhātuggahaṇena taṃ sampayuttā
analyzed: a vibhūta ttā sarikkhakam hoti tattha sukha dukkha dhātu ggahaṇena tam sampayuttā
translated: The “equanimity element” and the “ignorance element” are shown in pairs as similar. For both of them are similar in being undiscerned. Herein, by the words “pleasure element” and “pain element” the associated states are included too.

original: kāyaviññāṇadhātu, vatthubhūtā kāyadhātu, ārammaṇabhūtā phoṭṭhabbadhātu ca gahitāva
analyzed: kāya viññāṇa dhātu vatthu bhūtā kāya dhātu ārammaṇa bhūtā phoṭṭhabba dhātu ca gahitā ava
translated: The body- element and the tangible-object element are included in the inclusion of the body-consciousness element.

original: honti. Somanassadomanassadhātuggahaṇena taṃ sampayuttā manoviññāṇadhātu gahitā hoti.
analyzed: honti somanassa domanassa dhātu ggahaṇena tam sampayuttā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu gahitā hoti
translated: The mind-consciousness element associated with joy and grief is included in the inclusion of the joy and grief elements.

original: Avijjādhātuggahaṇena dhammadhātu gahitā. Upekkhādhātuggahaṇena cakkhusotaghānajivhāviññāṇadhātumanodhātuyo,🔽tāsaṃyeva vatthārammaṇabhūtā cakkhudhāturūpadhātuādayo ca gahitāti evaṃ aṭṭhārasapi
analyzed: avijjā dhātu gahaṇena dhammadhātu gahitā upekkhā dhātu gahaṇena cakkhu sota ghāna jivhā viññāṇa dhātu manaḥ dhātuyo  tāsam yeva vattha ārammaṇa bhūtā cakkhu dhātu rūpa dhātu ādayo ca gahitā ati evam aṭṭhārasa pi
translated: The idea element is included in the inclusion of the ignorance element. The eye-, ear-, nose-, and tongue-consciousness elements and the mind element are included in the inclusion of the equanimity element,🔽and the eye-, visible-object-, ear-, sound-, nose-, odour-, tongue-, flavour-, body-, and tangible-object elements that are their respective bases and objects are also included. So all eighteen elements are included in these.

original: dhātuyo gahitāva honti. Idāni tāsu dasahi dhātūhi rūpapariggahotiādi sabbaṃ heṭṭhā
analyzed: dhātuyaḥ gahitāḥ ava honti idāni tāsu dasahi dhātūhi rūpa pariggaha uti ādi sabbam heṭṭhā
translated: Now, the whole of what was said above beginning with “The materiality aggregate is included in ten elements” should be understood in this way.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Evampi ekassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā matthakaṃ pāpetvā
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbam evam pi ekassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā matthakam pāpetvā
translated: And so it should be understood that the conclusion is stated in this way by extending it as far as arahatship in the case of a single bhikkhu.

original: nigamanaṃ kathitaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ. Tattha katamā sukhadhātu yaṃ kāyikaṃ sātanti
analyzed: nigamanam kathitam hoti iti veditabbam tattha katamā sukha dhātu yam kāyikam
translated: Herein, what is the pleasure element? The pleasure that is bodily … .

original: ādīni heṭṭhā vuttanayāneva.
analyzed: ādīni heṭṭhā vutta nayāna eva
translated: This should be understood in the way already given .

original: 181. Tatiyachakke kāmoti dve kāmā – vatthukāmo ca kilesakāmo ca. Tattha kilesakāmaṃ🔽sandhāya kāmapaṭisaṃyuttā dhātu kāmadhātu, kāmavitakkassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Vatthukāmaṃ sandhāya🔽kāmoyeva dhātu kāmadhātu, kāmāvacaradhammānametaṃ nāmaṃ. Byāpādapaṭisaṃyuttā dhātu🔽byāpādadhātu, byāpādavitakkassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Byāpādova dhātu byāpādadhātu, dasaāghātavatthukassa
analyzed: tatiya chakke kāmo ti dve kāmā vatthu kāmo ca kilesa kāmo ca tattha kilesa kāmaṃ  sandhāya kāma paṭisaṃyuttā dhātu kāma dhātu kāma vitakkassa itam nāmam vatthu kāmam sandhāya  kāmoyā iva dhātu kāmadhātu kāmāvacara dhammānam etam nāmam byāpāda paṭisaṃyuttā dhātu  byāpāda dhātu byāpāda vitakkassa etam nāmam byāpādaḥ uva dhātu byāpāda dhātu dasa āghāta vatthukassa
translated: In the third triad, “sense desires” are of two kinds: sense desires as defilements and sense desires as objects. Herein, the element associated with sense-desire is the sense-desire element, which is a name for sense-desire thinking . The element consisting in sense desires is the sense-desire element, which is a name for the states belonging to the sense-desire realm . The element associated with ill will is the ill-will element, which is a name for ill-will thinking . The element consisting in ill will is the ill-will element, which is a name for the ten grounds for annoyance .

original: paṭighassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Vihiṃsā paṭisaṃyuttā dhātu vihiṃsādhātu, vihiṃsāvitakkassetaṃ🔽nāmaṃ. Vihiṃsāyeva dhātu vihiṃsādhātu, parasattavihesanassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Ayaṃ pana heṭṭhā🔽anāgatattā evaṃ atthādivibhāgato veditabbā – vihiṃsanti etāya satte, vihiṃsanaṃ vā🔽etaṃ sattānanti vihiṃsā. Sā viheṭhanalakkhaṇā, karuṇāpaṭipakkhalakkhaṇā vā; parasantāne
analyzed: paṭighassa etam nāmam vihiṃsā paṭisaṃyuttā dhātu vihiṃsā dhātu vihiṃsā vitakkassa etam 🔽nāmam vihiṃsāya iva dhātu vihiṃsā dhātu para satta vihesanassa itam nāmam ayam pana heṭṭhā 🔽anāgata ttā evam attha ādi vibhāgataḥ veditabbā vihiṃsanti etāya satte vihiṃsanam vā 🔽etam sattānan ti vihiṃsā sā viheṭhana lakkhaṇā karuṇā paṭipakkha lakkhaṇā vā para santāne
translated: In the third triad: “sense desires” are of two kinds: sense desires as defilements and sense desires as objects. Herein, the sense-desire element associated with sense desires is the sense-desire element as defilement, which is a name for sense-desire thinking . The sense-desire element as object is the sense-desire element as object, which is a name for the states belonging to the sense-desire range. The ill will element associated with ill will is the ill will element as defilement, which is a name for ill-will thinking. The ill will element as object is the ill will element as object, which is a name for the ten grounds for annoyance. The harmfulness element associated with harmfulness is the harmfulness element as defilement, which is a name for harmfulness thinking. The harmfulness element as object is the harmfulness element as object, which is a name for the harming of other creatures. But this is to be understood in the way beginning with the meaning as follows: it harms creatures, or it is that by means of which they harm, thus it is harmfulness . Its characteristic is annoyance, or its characteristic is the opposite of pity. Its function is to afflict. It is manifested as the state of afflicting.

original: ubbegajananarasā, sakasantāne karuṇāviddhaṃsanarasā vā; dukkhāyatanapaccupaṭṭhānā;🔽paṭighapadaṭṭhānāti veditabbā. Nekkhammaṃ vuccati lobhā nikkhantattā alobho, nīvaraṇehi🔽nikkhantattā paṭhamajjhānaṃ, sabbākusalehi nikkhantattā sabbakusalaṃ. Nekkhammapaṭisaṃyuttā
analyzed: ubbega janana rasā saka santāne karuṇā viddhaṃsana rasā vā dukkha āyatana paccupaṭṭhānā  paṭigha padaṭṭhānā ti veditabbā nekkhammam vuccati lobhāḥ nikkhanta ttā alobho nīvaraṇehi  nikkhanta ttā paṭhamajjhānam sabba akusalehi nikkhanta ttā sabba kusalam nekkhamma paṭisaṃyuttā
translated: Its function is to cause one to shrink back, or its function is to break up the continuity of one’s own continuity. It is manifested as a painful object.

original: dhātu nekkhammadhātu, nekkhammavitakkassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Nekkhammameva dhātu nekkhammadhātu,🔽sabbassāpi kusalassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Abyāpādapaṭisaṃyuttā dhātu abyāpādadhātu, abyāpādavitakkassetaṃ🔽nāmaṃ. Abyāpādova dhātu abyāpādadhātu, mettāyetaṃ nāmaṃ. Avihiṃsāpaṭisaṃyuttā dhātu
analyzed: dhātu nekkhamma dhātu nekkhamma vitakkassa etam nāmam nekkhammam eva dhātu nekkhamma dhātu  sabbassa api kusalassa etam nāmam a byāpāda paṭisaṃyuttā dhātu a byāpāda dhātu a byāpāda vitakkassa etam  nāmaṃ dhātu a byāpāda dhātu nāmaṃ a vihiṃsā paṭisaṃyuttā dhātu
translated: It is to be understood as having resistance. Non-ill will is non-greed, since it has gone out from greed; it is the first jhāna, since it has gone out from the hindrances; it is all profitable, since it has gone out from all unprofitable things. The element associated with non-ill will is the non-ill-will element. This is a term for the non-ill-will thought. Non-ill will itself as an element is the non-ill-will element.🔽This is a term for all profitable things. The element associated with non-cruelty is the non-cruelty element. This is a term for the non-cruelty thought. Non-cruelty itself as an element is the non-cruelty element. This is a term for loving-kindness.

original: avihiṃsādhātu, avihiṃsā vitakkassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Avihiṃsāva dhātu avihiṃsādhātu, karuṇāyetaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: a vihiṃsā dhātu a vihiṃsā vitakkaḥ etam nāmam a vihiṃsā ava dhātu a vihiṃsā dhātu karuṇāya itam nāmam
translated: The element associated with non-coveting is the non-coveting element. This is a term for the non-coveting thought. Non-coveting itself as an element is the non-coveting element. This is a term for compassion.

original: 182. Idāni tamevatthaṃ dassetuṃ tattha katamā kāmadhātūti padabhājanaṃ āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: idāni tam eva attham dassetum tattha katamā kāmadhātu uti pada bhājanam āraddham
translated: Now, in order to show that same meaning, the text is begun with the words, “Herein, what is the sense-desire element?”

original: Tattha paṭisaṃyuttoti saṃpayogavasena paṭisaṃyutto. Takko vitakkotiādīni vuttatthāneva.🔽Viheṭhetīti bādheti, dukkhāpeti. Heṭhanāti pāṇippahārādīhi bādhanā, dukkhuppādanā.
analyzed: tattha paṭisaṃyutto ti saṃpayoga vasena paṭisaṃyuttaḥ takkaḥ vitakkaḥ iti ādīni vutta tthāni eva  viheṭheti iti bādheti heṭhanā ati pāṇi pahāra ādīhi bādhanā dukkha uppādanā
translated: Herein, associated means associated by conjoining. Applied thought, sustained thought, etc., are in the place stated.🔽Afflicts means torments, causes pain. Affliction means tormenting, causing pain, by blows with the hand, etc.

original: Balavaheṭhanā viheṭhanā. Hiṃsanti etāyāti hiṃsanā. Balavahiṃsanā vihiṃsanā. Rosanāti
analyzed: balava heṭhanā viheṭhanā hiṃsanti etāyāḥ ati hiṃsanā balava hiṃsanā vihiṃsanā rosanā ati
translated: Great affliction is great affliction. It harms by this, thus it is harm. Great harm is great harm. It angers, thus it is anger.

original: ghaṭṭanā. Virosanāti balavaghaṭṭanā. Sabbattha vā ‘vi’ upasaggena padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ.
analyzed: ghaṭṭanā virosanā ati balava ghaṭṭanā sabbattha vā vi upasaggena padam vaḍḍhitam
translated: Great anger is great anger. It strikes, thus it is striking. Great striking is great striking. In all these words the prefix vi is added to the words.

original: Upahananti etenāti upaghāto, paresaṃ upaghāto parūpaghāto.
analyzed: upahananti etena ati upaghātaḥ paresam upaghātaḥ para upaghātaḥ
translated: It afflicts by this, thus it is affliction. Affliction of others is affliction of others.

original: Mettāyanti etāyāti metti. Mettāyanākāro mettāyanā. Mettāya ayitassa mettāsamaṅgino
analyzed: mettāyanti etāyāti metti mettāyana ākāraḥ mettāyanā mettāya ayitassa mettā samaṅginaḥ
translated: It is loving-kindness because of loving-kindliness. Loving-kindness is the state of loving-kindness. The state of one possessing loving-kindness is loving-kindness.

original: bhāvo mettāyitattaṃ. Byāpādena vimuttassa cetaso vimutti cetovimutti. Ettha ca purimehi
analyzed: bhāvaḥ byāpādena vimuttassa cetasaḥ vimutti cetaḥ vimutti ettha ca purimehi
translated: The deliverance of mind by which one is delivered from ill will is deliverance of mind. And here

original: tīhi upacārappattāpi appanāpatāpi mettā kathitā, pacchimena appanāpattāva.
analyzed: tīhi upacāra ppattā api appanā patā api mettā kathitā pacchimena
translated: Loving kindness is said to be reached by three jhānas and also by access;🔽and by the last it is reached by absorption only.

original: Karuṇāyanti etāyāti karuṇā. Karuṇāyanākāro karuṇāyanā. Karuṇāya ayitassa karuṇāsamaṅgino🔽bhāvo karuṇāyitattaṃ. Vihiṃsāya vimuttassa cetaso vimutti cetovimutti. Idhāpi purimanayeneva
analyzed: karuṇāyanti etāyā ati karuṇā karuṇāyana ākāraḥ karuṇāyanā karuṇāya ayitassa karuṇā samaṅginaḥ  bhāvaḥ vihiṃsāya vimuttassa cetasaḥ vimutti cetaḥ vimutti idha api purima nayena iva
translated: Compassion: it is compassion because of the compassion in it. The mode of compassion is the mode of compassion. The state of one who has compassion is the state of one who has compassion in him.🔽The liberation of the mind is the liberation of the mind of one liberated from annoyance. Here too the distinction should be understood as that of access and absorption,

original: upacārappanābhedo veditabbo. Ubhayatthāpi ca pariyosānapade mettākaruṇāti cetovimuttivisesanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: upacāra ppanā bhedaḥ veditabbaḥ ubhayattha api ca pariyosāna pade mettā karuṇā ti cetaḥ vimutti visesana attham vuttam
translated: and in both places the words loving kindness and compassion are stated for the purpose of specifying the liberation of the mind.

original: Ettha ca kāmavitakko sattesupi uppajjati saṅkhāresupi. Ubhayattha uppannopi kammapathabhedova.
analyzed: ettha ca kāma vitakkaḥ sattesu pi uppajjati saṅkhāresu pi ubhayattha uppannaḥ pi kamma patha bhedaḥ va
translated: And here the thought of sensual pleasure arises in beings and in formations. And though it arises in both, it is only when it arises in beings that it breaks the path.

original: Byāpādo pana sattesu uppannoyeva kammapathaṃ bhindati, na itaro. Vihiṃsāyapi eseva
analyzed: byāpādaḥ pana sattesu uppannaḥ yeva kamma patham bhindati na itaraḥ esā iva
translated: But ill will breaks the path only when it arises in beings, not when it arises in formations. The same

original: nayo. Ettha ca duvidhā kathā – sabbasaṅgāhikā ceva asambhinnā ca. Kāmadhātuggahaṇena
analyzed: nayaḥ ettha ca duvidhā kathā sabba saṅgāhikā ca iva asambhinnā ca kāmadhātu ggahaṇena
translated: applies to annoyance. And here there are two kinds of discussion: that which includes all and that which does not.

original: hi byāpādavihiṃsādhātuyopi gahitā. Kāmadhātuyāyeva pana nīharitvā nīharitvā dvepi
analyzed: hi gahitā
translated: for the elements of ill will and cruelty are also included. But in the case of the sense-desire element, two are excluded each time.

original: etā dassitāti. Ayaṃ tāvettha sabbasaṅgāhikakathā. Ṭhapetvā pana byāpādavihiṃsādhātuyo
analyzed: etā dassitā ati ayam tāva ettha sabba saṅgāhika kathā ṭhapetvā pana byāpāda vihiṃsā dhātuyo
translated: for the elements of ill will and cruelty are included in the element of sensual desire. But the two elements are shown by excluding them from the sensual-desire element. This is the “all-inclusive” talk here. But when the element of ill will and the element of cruelty are left out,

original: sesā sabbāpi kāmadhātu evāti. Ayaṃ asambhinnakathā nāma. Nekkhammadhātuggahaṇenāpi🔽abyāpādaavihiṃsādhātuyo gahitāyeva. Nekkhammadhātuto pana nīharitvā nīharitvā tadubhayampi
analyzed: sesā sabbā api kāmadhātu eva ati ayam asambhinnakathā nāma nekkhamma dhātu ggahaṇena api  abyāpāda avihiṃsā dhātuyaḥ gahitāya iva nekkhamma dhātuto pana nīharitvā nīharitvā tat ubhayam pi

analyzed: aṭṭhārasa aṭṭhārasa katvā sabbāni api tāni aṭṭhārasakāni ekajjham abhisaṅkhipitvā aṭṭhārasa iva

translated: it is the primary elements that are called “dhātu” in the sense of “they cause the perishing of beings” (vidahanti) and in the sense of “they are borne by beings” (dhīyante). For the mundane

translated: The medium and superior eye, etc., are the elements that are medium and superior. But in the strict sense of the words, the unprofitable

original: dhammadhātumanoviññāṇadhātuyo hīnadhātu. Lokiyā kusalābyākatā ubhopi cakkhudhātuādayo
analyzed: dhammadhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyaḥ hīna dhātu lokiyā kusalā abyākatā ubho pi cakkhu dhātu ādayaḥ
translated: idea element and mind-consciousness element are the element that is inferior. The profitable and indeterminate mundane eye element, etc.,

original: ca majjhimadhātu. Lokuttarā pana dhammadhātumanoviññāṇadhātuyo paṇītadhātu. Pathavītejovāyodhātuyo
analyzed: ca majjhima dhātu lokuttarā pana dhammadhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyo paṇīta dhātu pathavī tejaḥ vāyo dhātuyo
translated: are the element that is medium. But the supramundane idea element and mind-consciousness element are the element that is superior. The earth, fire, and air elements

original: phoṭṭhabbadhātuyeva. Āpodhātu ākāsadhātu ca dhammadhātuyeva. Viññāṇadhātu cakkhuviññāṇādisattaviññāṇadhātusaṅkhepoyeva.
analyzed: phoṭṭhabba dhātu yā iva āpodhātu ākāsa dhātu ca dhamma dhātu yā iva viññāṇa dhātu cakkhu viññāṇa ādi satta viññāṇa dhātu saṅkhepo yā iva
translated: are the tangible-data element only. The water element is the idea element only. The consciousness element is a mere summary term for the seven consciousness elements beginning with the eye-consciousness element.

original: Sattarasa dhātuyo dhammadhātuekadeso ca saṅkhatadhātu. Asaṅkhatadhātu pana dhammadhātuekadesova.🔽Anekadhātunānādhātuloko pana aṭṭhārasadhātuppabhedamattamevāti. Iti sabhāvato vijjamānānaṃ
analyzed: sattarasa dhātuyaḥ dhammadhātu ekadeso ca saṅkhata dhātu asaṅkhata dhātu pana dhammadhātu ekadesaḥ uva  aneka dhātu nānā dhātu loko pana aṭṭhārasa dhātu pabheda mattam eva ati iti sabhāvataḥ
translated: The seventeen elements and one part of the element of mental data are the formed element. The unformed element is one part of the element of mental data only.

original: sabbadhātūnaṃ tadantogadhattā aṭṭhāraseva vuttāti.
analyzed: sabba dhātūnam tad anta gadha ttā aṭṭhārasā iva vuttā iti
translated: The world of many elements and various elements is merely the eighteen elements distinguished. So it is because they are included in the eighteen that only eighteen are mentioned of all the elements that exist in the true individual essence.

original: Apica vijānanasabhāve viññāṇe jīvasaññīnaṃ jīvasaññāsamūhanatthampi aṭṭhāraseva vuttā.🔽Santi hi sattā vijānanasabhāve viññāṇe jīvasaññino. Tesaṃ cakkhusotaghānajivhākāyaviññāṇamanoviññāṇadhātubhedena
analyzed: apica vijānana sabhāve viññāṇe jīva saññīnam jīva saññā samūhana ttham pi aṭṭhārasā iva vuttā  santi hi sattā vijānana sabhāve viññāṇe jīva saññinaḥ tesam cakkhu sota ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇa manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhedena
translated: Besides, they are mentioned as eighteen in order to dispel the perception of a soul in consciousness, which has the true individual essence of cognizing, in those who perceive a soul.🔽For there are beings who perceive a soul in consciousness, which has the true individual essence of cognizing.

original: tassā anekattaṃ, cakkhurūpādipaccayāyattavuttitāya aniccatañca pakāsetvā dīgharattānusayitaṃ
analyzed: tassāḥ aneka ttam cakkhu rūpa ādi paccaya āyatta vutti tāya anicca tat ca pakāsetvā dīgha ratta anusayitam
translated: To them the Blessed One, who was desirous of dispelling the perception of a soul that had long lain latent in them by revealing the manifoldness of that consciousness, which is classed as eye-, ear-, nose-, tongue-, body-, and mind-consciousness elements, and its impermanence,

original: jīvasaññaṃ samūhanitukāmena bhagavatā aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo pakāsitā. Kiñca bhiyyo? Tathā
analyzed: jīva saññam samūhanitu kāmena bhagavatā aṭṭhārasa dhātuyaḥ pakāsitā kiñca bhiyyo tathā
translated: revealed the eighteen elements, desiring to dispel the perception of a soul. And what is more,🔽according to the dispositions of those who are teachable,

original: veneyyajjhāsayavasena; ye ca imāya nātisaṅkhepavitthārāya desanāya veneyyā sattā,
analyzed: veneyya ajjhāsaya vasena ye ca imāya na ati saṅkhepa vitthārāya desanāya veneyyā sattā
translated: those beings who are teachable by this teaching, which is not too condensed nor too diffuse,

original: tadajjhāsayavasena ca aṭṭhāraseva pakāsitā.
analyzed: tad ajjhāsaya vasena ca aṭṭhārasā iva pakāsitā
translated: and it is only these eighteen that are taught according to the intention of the text.

original: Saṅkhepavitthāranayena tathā tathā hi,
analyzed: saṅkhepa vitthāra nayena tathā tathā hi
translated: For in brief and in detail

original: Dhammaṃ pakāsayati esa yathā yathāssa;🔽Saddhammatejavihataṃ vilayaṃ khaṇena,
analyzed: dhammam pakāsayati yathā yathā assa  saddhamma teja vihatam vilayam khaṇena
translated: he teaches the Dhamma in such and such a way🔽As the darkness in the hearts of beings to be trained

original: Veneyyasattahadayesu tamo payātīti.
analyzed: veneyya satta hadayesu tamaḥ payāti iti
translated: is dispelled by the radiance of his faith in the True Idea.

original: Evamettha ‘tāvatvato’ veditabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: evam ettha tāva tvataḥ veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is how the exposition should be understood here as to the “measure” .

original: ‘Saṅkhato’ti cakkhudhātu tāva jātito eko dhammotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati cakkhupasādavasena.🔽Tathā sotaghānajivhākāyarūpasaddagandharasadhātuyo sotapasādādivasena. Phoṭṭhabbadhātu🔽pana pathavītejovāyovasena tayo dhammāti saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Cakkhuviññāṇadhātu kusalākusalavipākavasena
analyzed: saṅkhato ti cakkhu dhātu tāva jātitaḥ ekaḥ dhammo tvā iva saṅkham gacchati cakkhu pasāda vasena  tathā sota ghāna jivhā kāya rūpa sadda gandha rasa dhātuyo sota pasāda ādi vasena phoṭṭhabba dhātu  pana pathavī tejaḥ vāyaḥ vasena tayo dhammā ati saṅkham gacchati cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu kusala akusala vipāka vasena
translated: As to “conditioned”: the eye element, firstly, is reckoned as a single state as the eye sensitivity.🔽So too the ear, nose, tongue, and body elements as the ear, nose, tongue, and body sensitivities. The visible-data element,🔽sound element, odour element, flavour element, and tangible-data element are reckoned as three states as the earth, fire, and air elements respectively. The eye-consciousness element is reckoned as two states as profitable and unprofitable resultant.

original: dve dhammāti saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Tathā sotaghānajivhākāyaviññāṇadhātuyo. Manodhātu
analyzed: dve dhammā ati saṅkham gacchati tathā sota ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇa dhātuyaḥ manaḥ dhātu
translated: So too the ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body-consciousness elements. The mind element is reckoned as three states as the five-door adverting, profitable and unprofitable resultant.

original: pana pañcadvārāvajjanakusalākusalavipākasampaṭicchanavasena tayo dhammāti saṅkhaṃ
analyzed: pana pañca dvāra āvajjana kusala akusala vipāka sampaṭicchana vasena tayaḥ dhammā ati saṅkham
translated: The mind-consciousness element is reckoned as four states as the five-door adverting, profitable, unprofitable, and functional consciousnesses.

original: gacchati. Dhammadhātu tiṇṇaṃ arūpakkhandhānaṃ, soḷasannaṃ sukhumarūpānaṃ, asaṅkhatāya
analyzed: gacchati dhammadhātu tiṇṇam arūpa khandhānam soḷasannam sukhuma rūpānam asaṅkhatāya
translated: goes. The element of mental objects is of the three immaterial aggregates, of the sixteen subtle forms, of the unformed element,

original: ca dhātuyā vasena vīsatidhammāti saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Manoviññāṇadhātu sesakusalākusalābyākataviññāṇavasena🔽chasattatidhammāti saṅkhaṃ gacchatīti evamettha ‘saṅkhato’ veditabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: ca dhātuyāḥ vasena vīsati dhammā ati saṅkham gacchati manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu sesa kusala akusala abyākata viññāṇa vasena  cha sattati dhammā ati saṅkham gacchati iti evam ettha saṅkhataḥ veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: The element of mental data is reckoned as twenty ideas, namely, the three immaterial aggregates, the sixteen kinds of subtle materiality, and the unformed element. The mind-consciousness element is reckoned as sixty-six ideas, namely, the remaining profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate consciousnesses. This is how the exposition should be known here as to the formed.

original: ‘Paccayā’ti cakkhudhātuādīnaṃ cakkhuviññāṇadhātuādīsu paccayato veditabbo vinicchayo. So panetesaṃ paccayabhāvo niddesavāre āvi bhavissati.🔽‘Daṭṭhabbā’ti daṭṭhabbatopettha vinicchayo veditabboti attho. Sabbā eva hi saṅkhatā
analyzed: paccayā ti cakkhu dhātu ādīnam cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu ādīsu paccayataḥ veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ saḥ pana etesam paccaya bhāvaḥ niddesa vāre bhavissati  daṭṭhabbā ti daṭṭhabba tā upa ittha vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ iti attho sabbā eva hi saṅkhatā
translated: As to conditions: the exposition should be known here as to conditions by way of the eye-element, etc., as conditions for eye-consciousness-element, and so on. But the way in which they are conditions will be made clear in the Description of the Faculties .

original: dhātuyo pubbantāparantavivittato, dhuvasubhasukhattabhāvasuññato, paccayāyattavuttito
analyzed: dhātuyaḥ pubba anta apara anta vivittataḥ dhuva subha sukhatta bhāva suññataḥ paccaya āyatta vuttitaḥ
translated: As to how they are to be seen: the meaning is that the exposition should be known here as to how they are to be seen. For all formed elements are to be seen as void of a beginning and end, as void of lastingness and ease and beauty and self, and as existing only by dependence on conditions.🔽And in particular the eye element is to be seen as like a ball of foam,

original: ca daṭṭhabbā. Visesato panettha bheritalaṃ viya cakkhudhātu daṭṭhabbā, daṇḍo viya
analyzed: ca daṭṭhabbā visesataḥ pana ittha bheri talam viya cakkhu dhātu daṭṭhabbā daṇḍaḥ viya
translated: the ear element as like a bubble,🔽the nose element as like a mirage,🔽the tongue element as like a dream,🔽the body element as like a stump,🔽and the mind element as like a mere magical illusion.

original: rūpadhātu, saddo viya cakkhuviññāṇadhātu. Tathā ādāsatalaṃ viya cakkhudhātu, mukhaṃ🔽viya rūpadhātu, mukhanimittaṃ viya cakkhuviññāṇadhātu. Atha vā ucchutilāni viya cakkhudhātu,🔽yantacakkayaṭṭhi viya rūpadhātu, ucchurasatelāni viya cakkhuviññāṇadhātu. Tathā adharāraṇī
analyzed: rūpa dhātu saddaḥ viya cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu tathā ādāsa talam viya cakkhu dhātu mukham  viya rūpa dhātu mukha nimittam viya cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu atha vā ucchutilāni viya cakkhu dhātu  viya rūpa dhātu ucchu rasa telāni viya cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu tathā adharāraṇī
translated: the eye-consciousness element is like the sound. Likewise, the eye element is like the surface of a looking glass, the visible-data element is like the face,🔽the eye-consciousness element is like the reflection of the face. Or the eye element is like the bristles, the visible-data element is like the saw’s teeth,🔽the eye-consciousness element is like the sparks. Likewise, the eye element is like the lower fire-stick,🔽

original: viya cakkhudhātu, uttarāraṇī viya rūpadhātu, aggi viya cakkhuviññāṇadhātu. Esa nayo sotadhātuādīsupi.
analyzed: viya cakkhu dhātu uttarāraṇī viya rūpa dhātu aggi viya cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu esa nayo sota dhātu ādīsu pi
translated: The eye-consciousness element is like the sound. So too, the eye element is like the surface of a looking glass, the visible-data element is like the face, and the eye-consciousness element is like the reflection of the face in the looking glass. Or the eye element is like the husks of the rice, the visible-data element is like the rice grains, and the eye-consciousness element is like the husks of the rice grains. So too, the eye element is like the lower fire-stick, the visible-data element is like the upper fire-stick, and the eye-consciousness element is like the fire. This is the way in the case of the ear element, etc., too.

original: Manodhātu pana yathāsambhavato cakkhuviññāṇadhātuādīnaṃ purecarānucarā viya daṭṭhabbā.🔽Dhammadhātuyā vedanākkhandho sallamiva sūlamiva ca daṭṭhabbo; saññāsaṅkhārakkhandhā
analyzed: manaḥ dhātu pana yathāsambhavato cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu ādīnam purecara anucarā viya daṭṭhabbā  dhammadhātuyā vedanā kkhandho sallam iva sūlam iva ca daṭṭhabbo saññā saṅkhāra kkhandhā
translated: But the mind element should be regarded as the forerunner and follower of the eye-consciousness element, etc., according as appropriate.

original: vedanāsallasūlayogā āturā viya; puthujjanānaṃ vā saññā āsādukkhajananato rittamuṭṭhi
analyzed: vedanā salla sūla yogāḥ āturāḥ viya puthujjanānam vā saññā āsā dukkha jananato
translated: The feeling aggregate should be regarded as the pain and the boil in the mental data base, the perception and formations aggregates as the sicknesses due to the pain and the boil, or the perception aggregate as the empty fist, the formations aggregate as the delusion of a toy, and the consciousness aggregate as the snake.

original: viya, ayathābhuccanimittaggāhakato vanamigo viya; saṅkhārā paṭisandhiyaṃ pakkhipanato
analyzed: viya ayathābhucca nimitta ggāhakataḥ vana migaḥ viya saṅkhārāḥ paṭisandhiyam pakkhipanato
translated: like a man who throws himself on a charcoal pit,🔽like thieves pursued by the king’s men,

original: aṅgārakāsuyaṃ khipanakapuriso viya, jātidukkhānubandhanato rājapurisānubandhacorā🔽viya, sabbānatthāvahassa khandhasantānassa hetuto visarukkhabījāni viya; rūpaṃ nānāvidhūpaddavanimittato
analyzed: aṅgārakāsuyam khipanaka purisaḥ viya jāti dukkha anubandhanataḥ rāja purisa anubandha corā  viya sabbānattha āvahassa khandha santānassa hetutaḥ visa rukkha bījāni viya rūpam nānā vidhū paddava nimittato
translated: like the seeds of a poisonous tree,

original: khuracakkaṃ viya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: khura cakkam viya daṭṭhabbam
translated: and form should be seen as a razor wheel.

original: Asaṅkhatā pana dhātu amatato santato khemato ca daṭṭhabbā. Kasmā? Sabbānatthapaṭipakkhabhūtattā.
analyzed: asaṅkhatā pana dhātu amatataḥ santataḥ khemataḥ ca daṭṭhabbā kasmā sabba anattha paṭipakkha bhūta ttā
translated: But the unformed element should be seen as deathless, as peace, as security. Why? Because it is the opposite of all misfortune.

original: Manoviññāṇadhātu gahitārammaṇaṃ muñcitvāpi aññaṃ gahetvāva pavatanato vanamakkaṭo
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu gahita ārammaṇam muñcitvā api aññam gahetvā ava pava tanataḥ vana makkaṭaḥ
translated: The mind-consciousness element should be seen as a forest monkey,

original: viya, duddamanato assakhaḷuṅko viya, yatthakāmanipātito vehāsaṃ khittadaṇḍo viya,
analyzed: viya duddamanataḥ assa khaḷuṅkaḥ viya yattha kāma nipātitaḥ vehāsam khitta daṇḍaḥ viya
translated: as a wild horse, as a stick thrown up into the air,

original: lobhadosādinānappakārakilesayogato raṅganaṭo viya daṭṭhabboti.
analyzed: lobha dosa ādi nānappakāra kilesa yogataḥ raṅga naṭaḥ viya daṭṭhabbo ti
translated: and as an actor, because it is associated with various defilements such as greed and hate.

original: 184. Niddesavāre cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe cāti idañca dvayaṃ paṭicca aññañca kiriyāmanodhātuñceva
analyzed: niddesa vāre cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca ati idam ca dvayam paṭicca aññañca kiriyā manas dhātuñca iva
translated: In the section on the description, “With eye and visible data as condition” means with this pair and also with the other functional mind element and

original: sampayuttakhandhattayañcāti attho. Cakkhuviññāṇadhātuyā hi cakkhu nissayapaccayo
analyzed: sampayutta khandha ttayam ca ati attho cakkhu viññāṇa dhātuyāḥ hi cakkhu nissaya paccayo
translated: the three aggregates associated with it. For the eye is the support condition for eye-consciousness element,

original: hoti, rūpaṃ ārammaṇapaccayo, kiriyamanodhātu vigatapaccayo, tayo arūpakkhandhā sahajātapaccayo.
analyzed: rūpam ārammaṇa paccayo kiriya manaḥ dhātu vigata paccayo tayo arūpa khandhā sahajāta paccayo
translated: visible data are its object condition, the functional mind element is its disappearance condition, and the three immaterial aggregates are its conascence condition.

original: Tasmā esā cakkhuviññāṇadhātu ime cattāro paṭicca uppajjati nāma. Sotañca paṭiccātiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: tasmai esā cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu ime cattāro paṭicca uppajjati nāma sotam ca paṭicca ati ādīsu pi esa eva nayo
translated: So this eye-consciousness element is said to arise with these four as its condition. The same method applies in the case of the ear, etc.

original: Niruddhasamanantarāti niruddhāya samanantarā. Tajjā manodhātūti tasmiṃ ārammaṇe jātā
analyzed: niruddha samanantarā ati niruddhāya samanantarā tad jā manaḥ dhātu iti tasmin ārammaṇe jātā
translated: “With cessation immediately before”: with cessation immediately before that. “The mind element that has that as its object”: the mind element that has arisen with that as its object.🔽It is of two kinds, being either profitable or unprofitable resultant. Its function is receiving.

original: kusalākusalavipākato duvidhā manodhātu sampaṭicchanakiccā. Sabbadhammesu vā pana
analyzed: kusala akusala vipākataḥ duvidhā manaḥ dhātu sampaṭicchana kiccā sabba dhammesu vā pana
translated: Or alternatively,

original: paṭhamasamannāhāroti etesu cakkhuviññāṇādīsu sabbadhammesu uppajjamānesu paṭhamasamannāhāro;
analyzed: paṭhama samannāhāro ti etesu cakkhu viññāṇa ādīsu sabba dhammesu uppajjamānesu paṭhama samannāhāro
translated: “The first adverting” is the first adverting among all these states beginning with eye-consciousness that arise.

original: cakkhuviññāṇadhātuādīnaṃ vā ārammaṇasaṅkhātesu sabbadhammesu paṭhamasamannāhāroti
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu ādīnam vā ārammaṇa saṅkhātesu sabba dhammesu paṭhama samannāhāraḥ ti
translated: Or the first adverting is to be understood as the five beginning with eye-consciousness element in the case of all states classed as object of the five beginning with eye-consciousness element.

original: ayamettha attho veditabbo. Etena pañcadvārāvajjanakiccā kiriyamanodhātu gahitāti veditabbā.🔽Manodhātuyāpi uppajjitvā niruddhasamanantarāti ettha pi-kāro sampiṇḍanattho. Tasmā
analyzed: ayam ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ etena kiriya manaḥ dhātu gahitā iti veditabbā  manaḥ dhātuyā api uppajjitvā niruddha samanantarā ti ettha pikāro sampiṇḍana attho tasmā
translated: And by this it should be understood that the functional mind element whose function is adverting in the five doors is included.🔽And in the phrase “immediately next to the cessation of the mind element that has arisen” the word “and” has the meaning of “also.” So the meaning here should be understood as follows:

original: manodhātuyāpi manoviññāṇadhātuyāpīti ayamettha attho veditabbo. Tena yā ca vipākamanodhātuyā🔽uppajjitvā niruddhāya samanantarā uppajjati santīraṇakiccā vipākamanoviññāṇadhātu,
analyzed: manaḥ dhātuyā api manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā api iti ayam ettha atthaḥ veditabbo tena yā ca vipāka manaḥ dhātuyā  uppajjitvā niruddhāya samanantarā uppajjati santīraṇa kiccā vipāka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: “Immediately next to the cessation of the mind element, that is to say, of the resultant mind element that has arisen, there arises the resultant mind-consciousness element whose function is receiving;🔽immediately next to the cessation of that there arises the functional mind-consciousness element whose function is registering;🔽immediately next to the cessation of that there arises the mind-consciousness element whose function is determining;

original: yā ca tassā uppajjitvā niruddhāya samanantarā uppajjati voṭṭhabbanakiccā kiriyamanoviññāṇadhātu,🔽yā ca tassā uppajjitvā niruddhāya samanantarā uppajjati javanakiccā manoviññāṇadhātu
analyzed: yā ca tassāḥ uppajjitvā niruddhāya samanantarā uppajjati voṭṭhabbana kiccā kiriya manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu  yā ca tassāḥ uppajjitvā niruddhāya samanantarā uppajjati javana kiccā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: immediately next to the cessation of that there arises the mind-consciousness element whose function is impulsion;

original: – tā sabbāpi kathitā hotīti veditabbā. Manañca paṭiccāti bhavaṅgamanaṃ. Dhamme cāti
analyzed: tā sabbā api kathitā hoti iti veditabbā manam ca paṭicca ati bhavaṅgamanam dhamme ca ati
translated: all these are included in the words ‘immediately next to the cessation of the mind element that has arisen.’ And the words ‘Mind and mental factors’ include the life-continuum mind and the states associated with it. The words ‘Mind and mental data’ include the mind and its associated states that arise as the object of the life-continuum mind.

original: catubhūmikadhammārammaṇaṃ. Uppajjati manoviññāṇanti sahāvajjanakaṃ javanaṃ nibbattati.
analyzed: catu bhūmika dhamma ārammaṇam uppajjati manaḥ viññāṇam ti saha āvajjanakam javanam nibbattati
translated: “Mind-consciousness arises” means impulsion consciousness arises.

original: Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne hatthe gahitapañhaṃ nāma gaṇhiṃsu. Mahādhammarakkhitatthero kira🔽nāma dīghabhāṇakābhayattheraṃ hatthe gahetvā āha – ‘paṭiccāti nāma āgataṭṭhāne āvajjanaṃ
analyzed: imasmin pana ṭhāne hatthe gahitapañham nāma gaṇhiṃsu mahādhammarakkhita thero kira  nāma dīghabhāṇaka abhayattheram hatthe gahetvā āha paṭicca ati nāma āgata ṭṭhāne āvajjanam
translated: But at this point they took up the question of the hand. The Elder Mahādhammarakkhita, it seems,🔽took the Elder Abhaya, a reciter of the Digha Nikāya, by the hand and said, “‘Reviving’ is not to be done as a separate adverting, but it is to be done as a mere touching of the life-continuum.”

original: visuṃ na kātabbaṃ, bhavaṅganissitakameva kātabba’nti. Tasmā idha manoti sahāvajjanakaṃ
analyzed: visum na kātabbam bhavaṅga nissitakam eva kātabbanti tasmai idha manoti sahāvajjanakam
translated: So here the “mind” is the life-continuum that is the basis for the adverting;

original: bhavaṅgaṃ. Manoviññāṇanti javanamanoviññāṇaṃ. Imasmiṃ pana abhidhammabhājanīye soḷasa
analyzed: bhavaṅgam manaḥ viññāṇanti javana manaḥ viññāṇam imasmin pana abhidhamma bhājanīye soḷasa
translated: “mind-consciousness” is the impulsion consciousness. But in this Abhidhamma section,

original: dhātuyo kāmāvacarā, dve catubhūmikā lokiyalokuttaramissakā kathitāti.
analyzed: kāma avacarā dve catu bhūmikā lokiya lokuttara missakā kathitā ati
translated: sixteen elements are dealt with, namely, the sense-desire-element, the two of the fourfold element, and the mundane and supramundane mixed ones.

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Abhidhamma section.

original: 3. Pañhāpucchakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañhāpucchaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the question

original: 185. Pañhāpucchake aṭṭhārasannaṃ dhātūnaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayānusāreneva kusalādibhāvo
analyzed: pañhāpucchake dhātūnam heṭṭhā vutta naya anusārena iva kusala ādi bhāvaḥ
translated: In the case of the eighteen elements, the profitable, etc., state of the eighteen elements should be understood in the way already stated under the faculties.

original: veditabbo. Ārammaṇattikesu pana cha dhātuyo parittārammaṇāti idaṃ pana pañcannaṃ
analyzed: veditabbaḥ ārammaṇa attikesu pana cha dhātuyo paritta ārammaṇā ti idam pana pañcannam
translated: As regards the objects, the six elements are of limited objects. This is said🔽with reference to the occurrence of the five beginning with eye-consciousness

original: cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ manodhātuyā ca ekantena pañcasu rūpārammaṇādīsu pavattiṃ sandhāya
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam manaḥ dhātuyā ca ekantena pañcasu rūpa ārammaṇa ādīsu pavattim sandhāya
translated: and of mind element in the five beginning with visible data.

original: vuttaṃ. Dve dhātuyoti vuttānaṃ pana dhammadhātumanoviññāṇadhātūnaṃ manāyatanadhammāyatanesu
analyzed: vuttam dve dhātuyo ti vuttānam pana dhammadhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātūnam mana āyatana dhammāyatanesu
translated: But the two elements called “mental-data element” and “mind-consciousness element”🔽should be understood to have limited objects, etc., according to the way in which the mind base and the mental-data base are described.

original: vuttanayeneva parittārammaṇāditā veditabbā. Iti imasmimpi pañhāpucchake soḷasa dhātuyo
analyzed: vutta nayena iva paritta ārammaṇa ādi tā veditabbā iti imasmim pi pañhāpucchake soḷasa dhātuyaḥ
translated: So in this question and answer the sixteen elements are said to be🔽in the sense sphere, and the two in the four planes, and they are mixed mundane and supramundane.

original: kāmāvacarā, dve catubhūmikā lokiyalokuttaramissakā kathitā. Evamayaṃ dhātuvibhaṅgopi
analyzed: kāmāvacarā dve catu bhūmikā lokiya lokuttara missakā kathitā evam ayam dhātu vibhaṅgaḥ api
translated: So this exposition of the elements is

original: teparivaṭṭaṃ nīharitvāva bhājetvā desitoti.
analyzed: nīharitvā ava bhājetvā
translated: taught by dividing it up after taking it out in successive rounds.

original: Sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sammoha vinodaniyā vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the commentary on the exposition in the “Description of the Kinds of Bondage”

original: Dhātuvibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Saccavibhaṅgo
analyzed: dhātu vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  sacca vibhaṅgaḥ
translated: The exposition of the elements is ended.🔽The exposition of the truths

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Suttantabhajanīya

original: 189. Idāni tadanantare saccavibhaṅge cattārīti gaṇanaparicchedo. Ariyasaccānīti paricchinnadhammanidassanaṃ. Dukkhaṃ ariyasaccantiādimhi pana uddesavāre –
analyzed: idāni tad anantare sacca vibhaṅge cattāri iti gaṇana paricchedaḥ ariya saccāni iti paricchinna dhamma nidassanam dukkham ariya sacca nti ādimhi pana uddesa vāre
translated: Now, in the Saccavibhaṅga , which comes next, the section on the number is “four” . The words ariyasaccas means “noble truths” .🔽The exposition should be known🔽By way of analysis, of teaching,

original: Vibhāgato nibbacana-lakkhaṇādippabhedato;
analyzed: vibhāgataḥ nibbacana lakkhaṇa ādi ppabhedataḥ
translated: Of characteristic, etc., of kinds,🔽Of meaning, of the words, of order,🔽Of non-excess and non-deficiency,🔽And also by way of function,🔽In the case of the noble truths,

original: Atthatthuddhārato ceva, anūnādhikato tathā.🔽Kamato ariyasaccesu, yaṃ ñāṇaṃ tassa kiccato;🔽Antogadhānaṃ pabhedo, upamāto catukkato.
analyzed: attha ttha uddhārataḥ ca iva an ūna adhikataḥ tathā  kamataḥ ariya saccesu yam ñāṇam tassa kiccataḥ  pabhedaḥ upamātaḥ catukkato
translated: And by way of what is included,🔽By way of analysis of kinds,🔽By way of similes, and by way of groups,🔽By way of voidness, of the fourfold,

original: Suññatekavidhādīhi, sabhāgavisabhāgato;
analyzed: suññata ekavidha ādīhi sabhāga visabhāgataḥ
translated: And so on, by way of what is similar and dissimilar.🔽The exposition should be known

original: Vinicchayo veditabbo, viññunā sāsanakkame.🔽Tattha ‘vibhāgato’ti dukkhādīnañhi cattāro cattāro atthā vibhattā tathā avitathā
analyzed: vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ viññunā sāsana kkame  tattha vibhāgato ti dukkha ādīnam hi cattāro cattāro atthāḥ vibhattā tathā a vitathā
translated: By one who is discerning in the dispensation.🔽Herein, by way of analysis: the four meanings of each of the truths have been analyzed thus, “They are not otherwise, not otherwise,” and so on, and they should be penetrated by those who would penetrate the truths. As it is said: “The meaning of oppression is the meaning of suffering;

original: anaññathā, ye dukkhādīni abhisamentehi abhisametabbā. Yathāha, “dukkhassa pīḷanaṭṭho,
analyzed: anaññathā ye dukkha ādīni abhisamentehi abhisametabbāḥ yathā āha dukkhassa pīḷana ṭṭho
translated: the meaning of being formed is the meaning of suffering; the meaning of burning is the meaning of suffering; the meaning of change is the meaning of suffering. These are the four meanings of suffering as suffering.🔽And the meaning of accumulation is the meaning of the origin; the meaning of burning is the meaning of the origin; the meaning of bond is the meaning of the origin; the meaning of impediment is the meaning of the origin. These are the four meanings of the origin as origin.

original: saṅkhataṭṭho, santāpaṭṭho, vipariṇāmaṭṭho – ime cattāro dukkhassa dukkhaṭṭhā tathā
analyzed: saṅkhata ṭṭho santāpa ṭṭho vipariṇāma ṭṭho ime cattāro dukkhassa dukkha aṭṭhā tathā
translated: And the meaning of dispassion is the meaning of cessation; the meaning of seclusion is the meaning of cessation; the meaning of being unformed is the meaning of cessation; the meaning of escape is the meaning of cessation. These are the four meanings of cessation as cessation.🔽And the meaning of outlet is the meaning of the path; the meaning of escape is the meaning of the path; the meaning of seeing is the meaning of the path; the meaning of predominance is the meaning of the path. These are the four meanings of the path as path.

original: avitathā anaññathā. Samudayassa āyūhanaṭṭho, nidānaṭṭho, saṃyogaṭṭho, palibodhaṭṭho…pe…
analyzed: a vitathā an aññathā samudayassa āyūhana ṭho nidāna ṭho saṃyoga ṭṭho palibodha ṭṭho upe
translated: The meaning of accumulation, the meaning of source, the meaning of bond, the meaning of hindrance, …

original: nirodhassa nissaraṇaṭṭho, vivekaṭṭho, asaṅkhataṭṭho, amataṭṭho…pe… maggassa niyyānaṭṭho,
analyzed: nirodhassa nissaraṇa ṭhaḥ viveka ṭṭhaḥ asaṅkhata ṭṭhaḥ amata ṭṭho upe maggassa niyyāna ṭṭho
translated: The meaning of escape, the meaning of seclusion, the meaning of the unformed, the meaning of the deathless, … the meaning of outlet,

original: hetvaṭṭho, dassanaṭṭho, ādhipateyyaṭṭho – ime cattāro maggassa maggaṭṭhā tathā avitathā
analyzed: hetu aṭṭhaḥ dassana aṭṭhaḥ ādhipateyya aṭṭhaḥ ime cattāro maggassa magga aṭṭhā tathā avitathā
translated: the meaning of cause, the meaning of seeing, the meaning of predominance, are the four meanings of the path as path. They are not otherwise than that, not wrong” .

original: anaññathā”ti. Tathā “dukkhassa pīḷanaṭṭho, saṅkhataṭṭho, santāpaṭṭho, viparināmaṭṭho,🔽abhisamayaṭṭho”ti evamādi. Iti evaṃ vibhattānaṃ catunnaṃ catunnaṃ atthānaṃ vasena
analyzed: anaññathā ti tathā dukkhassa pīḷana ṭho saṅkhata ṭṭho santāpa ṭṭho viparināma ṭṭho  evamādi iti evam vibhattānam catunnam catunnam atthānam vasena
translated: And similarly, “The meaning of torment, the meaning of the formed, the meaning of burning, the meaning of change,

original: dukkhādīni veditabbānīti. Ayaṃ tāvettha vibhāgato vinicchayo veditabbo.🔽‘Nibbacanalakkhaṇādippabhedato’ti ettha pana ‘nibbacanato’ tāva idha ‘du’iti ayaṃ
analyzed: dukkha ādīni veditabbāni iti ayam tāva ettha vibhāgataḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo  nibbacana lakkhaṇa ādi ppabhedato ti ettha pana nibbacanato tāva ayaṃ
translated: the meaning of penetration” , and so on. So they should be understood as the four truths in the various senses thus. This, firstly, is how the exposition should be known here “as to analysis.”🔽As to the characteristic of deliverance, etc., here the word “dukkha” is found to be used in the sense of “little” , for they call a child who has little flesh “dukkhu” .

original: saddo kucchite dissati; kucchitañhi puttaṃ duputtoti vadanti. ‘Khaṃ’saddo pana tucche;
analyzed: saddaḥ kucchite dissati kucchitam hi puttam du putto ti vadanti khaṃsaddaḥ pana tucche
translated: The word “khaṇa” is found in the sense of “worthless” ,

original: tucchañhi ākāsaṃ khanti vuccati. Idañca paṭhamasaccaṃ kucchitaṃ anekaupaddavādhiṭṭhānato,
analyzed: tuccham hi ākāsam khanti vuccati idam ca paṭhama saccam kucchitam aneka opaddava adhiṭṭhānato
translated: for empty space is called “empty.” And this first truth is called “empty” because it is the basis for many calamities,

original: tucchaṃ bālajanaparikappitadhuvasubhasukhattabhāvavirahitato. Tasmā kucchitattā tucchattā
analyzed: tuccham tuccha tā
translated: and it is called “void” because it is devoid of the permanence, beauty, pleasure, and self that foolish ordinary people suppose it to possess. Therefore it is called “void” and “empty”🔽and “painful” because of its voidness and emptiness.

original: ca dukkhanti vuccati. ‘Saṃ’iti ca ayaṃ saddo “samāgamo sameta”ntiādīsu saṃyogaṃ dīpeti;
analyzed: ca dukkhanti vuccati saṃ iti ca ayam saddaḥ samāgamaḥ sametanti ādīsu saṃyogam dīpeti
translated: And the word “sam” in the compound dukkha-samudaya is a word that shows conjunction, as in the expressions “samāgamo sameta” ,🔽and the word “u” is a word that shows arising, as in the expression “uppannaṃ udita” .

original: ‘u’iti ayaṃ saddo “uppannaṃ udita”ntiādīsu uppattiṃ. ‘Aya’saddo pana kāraṇaṃ dīpeti.
analyzed: u iti ayam saddaḥ uppannam udita nti ādīsu uppattim aya saddaḥ pana kāraṇam dīpeti
translated: But the word “aya” shows a cause.

original: Idañcāpi dutiyasaccaṃ avasesapaccayasamāyoge sati dukkhassuppattikāraṇaṃ. Iti dukkhassa
analyzed: idam ca api dutiya saccam avasesa paccaya samāyoge sati dukkhassa uppatti kāraṇam iti dukkhassa
translated: And this second truth is the cause for the arising of pain when there is conjunction with the remaining conditions. Thus

original: saṃyoge uppattikāraṇattā dukkhasamudayanti vuccati.🔽Tatiyasaccaṃ pana yasmā ‘ni’saddo abhāvaṃ ‘rodha’saddo ca cārakaṃ dīpeti, tasmā abhāvo
analyzed: saṃyoge uppatti kāraṇa ttā dukkha samudayanti vuccati  tatiya saccam pana yasmā nisaddaḥ abhāvam rodha saddaḥ ca cārakam dīpeti tasmā abhāvaḥ
translated: it is called “the arising of pain” because it is the cause for the arising of pain when there is conjunction with the remaining conditions.🔽But the third truth is called “the cessation of pain” because the word “ni” shows non-existence,

original: ettha saṃsāracārakasaṅkhātassa dukkharodhassa sabbagatisuññattā, samadhigate vā tasmiṃ
analyzed: ettha saṃsāra cāraka saṅkhātassa dukkha rodhassa sabba gati suññattā samadhigate vā tasmin
translated: and the word “rodha” shows a prison. The non-existence here is the cessation of the prison of pain called the round of rebirths. Or, when that is attained,

original: saṃsāracārakasaṅkhātassa dukkharodhassa abhāvo hoti tappaṭipakkhattātipi dukkhanirodhanti🔽vuccati, dukkhassa vā anuppādanirodhapaccayattā dukkhanirodhanti. Catutthasaccaṃ🔽pana yasmā etaṃ dukkhanirodhaṃ gacchati ārammaṇavasena tadabhimukhībhūtattā, paṭipadā
analyzed: saṃsāra cāraka saṅkhātassa dukkha rodhassa abhāvaḥ hoti dukkha nirodhan ti  vuccati dukkhassa vā anuppāda nirodha paccaya ttā dukkha nirodhanti catuttha saccam  pana yasmai etam dukkha nirodham gacchati ārammaṇa vasena tad abhimukhībhūta ttā paṭipadā
translated: The absence of the suffering-mass called the round of rebirths is called “the cessation of suffering” because it is the opposite of suffering, or because it is the condition for the non-arising of suffering.

original: ca hoti dukkhanirodhappattiyā, tasmā dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti vuccati.
analyzed: ca hoti dukkha nirodha ppattiyā tasmā dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati vuccati
translated: The fourth truth is called “the way leading to the cessation of suffering” because it leads to the cessation of suffering by making that cessation its object, and because it is the way to reach the cessation of suffering.

original: Yasmā panetāni buddhādayo ariyā paṭivijjhanti, tasmā ariyasaccānīti vuccanti. Yathāha
analyzed: yasmai pana itāni buddha ādayaḥ ariyā paṭivijjhanti tasmai ariya saccāni iti vuccanti yathā āha
translated: But they are called noble truths because they are penetrated by noble persons, the Buddhas, etc.,

original: – “catārimāni, bhikkhave, ariyasaccāni. Katamāni…pe… imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri🔽ariyasaccāni. Ariyā imāni paṭivijjhanti, tasmā ariyasaccānīti vuccantī”ti. Apica
analyzed: catārimāni bhikkhave ariya saccāni katamāni pe imāni kho bhikkhave cattāri  ariya saccāni ariyāḥ imāni paṭivijjhanti tasmai ariya saccāni iti vuccanti iti apica
translated: as is said: “Bhikkhus, these are the four noble truths. What four? The noble truth of suffering … the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering. These are the four noble truths. The noble ones penetrate these, that is why they are called noble truths” .🔽Moreover, they are called noble truths because they are the truths of the noble ones,

original: ariyassa saccānītipi ariyasaccāni. Yathāha – “sadevake, bhikkhave, loke…pe… sadevamanussāya
analyzed: ariyassa saccāni iti pi ariya saccāni yathā āha sa devake bhikkhave lokepe sa deva manussāya
translated: as is said: “Bhikkhus, in the world with its gods, its Maras, and its Brahmas, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, with its gods and men, the Blessed One is the noble one, and the Dhamma is the noble, that is why they are called noble truths” .

original: tathāgato ariyo, tasmā ariyasaccānīti vuccantī”ti. Atha vā etesaṃ abhisambuddhattā🔽ariyabhāvasiddhitopi ariyasaccāni. Yathāha – “imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ
analyzed: tathāgataḥ ariyaḥ tasmai ariya saccāni iti vuccanti iti atha vā etesam abhisambuddha ttā  ariya bhāva siddhitaḥ api ariya saccāni yathā āha imesam kho bhikkhave catunnam ariya saccānam
translated: and the Noble One is the Tathāgata, therefore they are called Noble Truths.🔽Or alternatively, they are Noble Truths because they are the truths of the Noble Ones,

original: yathābhūtaṃ abhisambuddhattā tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho ‘ariyo’ti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: yathābhūtam abhisambuddha ttā tathāgataḥ araham sammāsambuddhaḥ ariyaḥ iti vuccati iti
translated: for it is said: “It is because of the full-understanding of these four noble truths as they actually are that the Tathāgata is called ‘accomplished,’ ‘fully enlightened,’ ‘a worthy one,’ and ‘an Enlightened One’ ” .

original: Apica kho pana ariyāni saccānītipi ariyasaccāni; ariyānīti tathāni avitathāni avisaṃvādakānīti
analyzed: apica kho pana ariyāni saccāni iti pi ariya saccāni ariyāni iti tathāni avitathāni a visaṃvādakāni iti
translated: Besides, they are called Noble Truths because they are truths of the noble ones ; the meaning is that they are the same for them and not otherwise,

original: attho. Yathāha – “imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri ariyasaccāni tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni,
analyzed: atthaḥ yathā āha imāni kho bhikkhave cattāri ariya saccāni tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni
translated: for it is said: “These four noble truths are the same for all noble ones and not otherwise,

original: tasmā ariyasaccānīti vuccantī”ti. Evamettha nibbacanato vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: tasmai ariya saccāni iti vuccanti iti evam ettha nibbacanataḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: therefore they are called noble truths” . This is how the exposition should be understood here as to derivation.

original: Kathaṃ ‘lakkhaṇādippabhedato’? Ettha hi bādhanalakkhaṇaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ, santāpanarasaṃ,
analyzed: katham lakkhaṇa ādi ppabhedataḥ ettha hi bādhana lakkhaṇam dukkha saccam santāpana rasam
translated: As to character and the rest: here the truth of suffering has the characteristic of afflicting. Its function is to burn.

original: pavattipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Pabhavalakkhaṇaṃ samudayasaccaṃ, anupacchedakaraṇarasaṃ, palibodhapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Santilakkhaṇaṃ nirodhasaccaṃ, accutirasaṃ, animittapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Niyyānalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: pavatti paccupaṭṭhānam pabhava lakkhaṇam samudaya saccam an upaccheda karaṇa rasam palibodha paccupaṭṭhānam  santi lakkhaṇam nirodha saccam accu tirasam animitta paccupaṭṭhānam niyyāna lakkhaṇam
translated: and its manifestation is as appearance. The origination-truth has the characteristic of illumination; its function is to cause non-cessation; its manifestation is as obstruction.

original: maggasaccaṃ, kilesappahānakaraṇarasaṃ, vuṭṭhānapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Apica pavattipavattakanivattinivattakalakkhaṇāni🔽paṭipāṭiyā. Tathā saṅkhatataṇhāasaṅkhatadassanalakkhaṇāni cāti evamettha ‘lakkhaṇādippabhedato’
analyzed: magga saccam kilesa ppahāna karaṇa rasam vuṭṭhāna paccupaṭṭhānam apica pavatti pavattaka nivatti nivattaka lakkhaṇāni  paṭipāṭiyā tathā saṅkhata taṇhā asaṅkhata dassana lakkhaṇāni ca ati evam ettha lakkhaṇa ādi ppabhedato
translated: The cessation-truth has the characteristic of peace; its function is to cause the ending of death; its manifestation is as the signless. The path-truth has the characteristic of leading out; its function is to cause the abandoning of defilements; its manifestation is as escape. Furthermore, the characteristics of occurrence, what occurs, turning away, and what turns away,

original: vinicchayo veditabbo.🔽‘Atthatthuddhārato cevā’ti ettha pana atthato tāva ko saccaṭṭhoti ce? Yo paññācakkhunā🔽upaparikkhamānānaṃ māyāva viparītako, marīcīva visaṃvādako, titthiyānaṃ attāva anupalabbhasabhāvo
analyzed: vinicchayaḥ veditabbo  attha attha uddhārato ca iva ati ettha pana atthato tāva ko saccaṭṭhaḥ ti ce yo paññācakkhunā  upaparikkhamānānam māyā iva viparītakaḥ marīci iva visaṃvādakaḥ titthiyānam anupalabbha sabhāvaḥ
translated: are respectively those of the first, second, third, and fourth truths. Likewise the characteristics of the formed, craving, and the unformed, insight, are respectively those of the first, second, and third truths. This is how the exposition should be known here as to the classification of characteristics, etc.🔽As to the meaning of the word and so on: here, as to meaning, what is the meaning of truth? It is not a meaning that is deceptive like a magical creation, or a meaning that is misleading like a mirage, or a meaning that is non-existent like the self of the sectarians,

original: ca na hoti; atha kho bādhanapabhavasantiniyyānappakārena tacchāviparītabhūtabhāvena
analyzed: ca na hoti atha kho bādhana pabhava santi niyyāna ppakārena tacchā viparīta bhūta bhāvena
translated: when it is investigated with the eye of understanding. On the contrary, it is a meaning that is real, not deceptive, not misleading, existent, and it is a meaning that is not otherwise,

original: ariyañāṇassa gocaro hotiyeva; esa aggilakkhaṇaṃ viya, lokapakati viya ca tacchāviparītabhūtabhāvo
