analyzed: ariya ñāṇassa gocaraḥ esa aggi lakkhaṇam viya loka pakati viya ca tacchā viparīta bhūta bhāvo
translated: It is the province of noble knowledge. It should be understood to have the meaning of truth in the sense of being the way things are, in the sense of being the nature of existing things, as the characteristic of the foremost, as the nature of the world.🔽As it is said: “Bhikkhus, this is suffering” — this is factual, not unfactual;

original: saccaṭṭhoti veditabbo. Yathāha – “idaṃ dukkhanti kho, bhikkhave, tathametaṃ avitathametaṃ🔽anaññathameta”nti vitthāro. Apica –
analyzed: saccaṭṭhaḥ ti veditabbaḥ yathā āha idam dukkhan ti kho bhikkhave tatham etam avitatham etam  anaññatham etat ti vitthāraḥ api ca
translated: this is the truth, not the untruth. And in detail:🔽Since suffering is not negated,

original: Nābādhakaṃ yato dukkhaṃ, dukkhā aññaṃ na bādhakaṃ;
analyzed: na ābādhakam yatas dukkham dukkhāḥ aññam na bādhakam
translated: And nothing else negates it,🔽It is considered true

original: Bādhakattaniyāmena, tato saccamidaṃ mataṃ.
analyzed: bādhaka tta niyāmena tatas saccam idam matam
translated: By the principle of negation.🔽Since suffering is not from another,

original: Taṃ vinā nāññato dukkhaṃ, na hoti na ca taṃ tato;
analyzed: tam vinā na aññatas dukkham na hoti na ca tam tatas
translated: Nor is it without a cause,🔽It is considered true

original: Dukkhahetuniyāmena, iti saccaṃ visattikā.
analyzed: dukkha hetu niyāmena iti saccam visattikā
translated: By the principle of causality.🔽Since there is no peace apart from Nibbāna,

original: Nāññā nibbānato santi, santaṃ na ca na taṃ yato;
analyzed: na aññāḥ nibbānataḥ santi santam na ca na tam yatas
translated: And Nibbāna is not without peace,🔽It is considered true

original: Santabhāvaniyāmena, tato saccamidaṃ mataṃ.
analyzed: santa bhāva niyāmena tatas saccam idam matam
translated: By the principle of peace.🔽Since there is no escape apart from the path,

original: Maggā aññaṃ na niyyānaṃ, aniyyāno na cāpi so;
analyzed: maggāḥ aññam na niyyānam aniyyānaḥ na ca api so
translated: And the path is not without escape,🔽It is considered true

original: Tacchaniyyānabhāvattā, iti so saccasammato.🔽Iti tacchāvipallāsa-bhūtabhāvaṃ catūsupi;
analyzed: iti saḥ sacca sammato  iti tad śāvi pallāsa bhūta bhāvam catūsupi
translated: By the principle of escape.🔽Thus the wise declare🔽The meaning of truth in the four noble truths🔽To be the way things are, the nature of existing things,

original: Dukkhādīsvavisesena, saccaṭṭhaṃ āhu paṇḍitāti.
analyzed: āhu paṇḍita ati
translated: Without distinction in suffering and the rest.

original: Evaṃ ‘atthato’ vinicchayo veditabbo.🔽Kathaṃ ‘atthuddhārato’? Idhāyaṃ ‘sacca’saddo anekesu atthesu dissati, seyyathidaṃ
analyzed: evam atthataḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo  katham attha uddhārataḥ idha ayam sacca saddaḥ anekesu atthesu dissati seyyathīdam
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here as to meaning.🔽As to the derivation of the word: the word sacca occurs in many meanings, as follows.🔽In such passages as “Speak what is factual, not what is not factual” , it is truthfulness of speech.

original: – “saccaṃ bhaṇe, na kujjheyyā”tiādīsu vācāsacce. “Sacce ṭhitā samaṇabrāhmaṇā cā”tiādīsu
analyzed: saccam bhaṇe na kujjheyya ati ādīsu vācā asacce sacce ṭhitā samaṇa brāhmaṇā ca ati ādīsu
translated: In such passages as “Monks and divines stand on truth” , it is truthfulness of abstinence.

original: viratisacce. “Kasmā nu saccāni vadanti nānā, pavādiyāse kusalāvadānā”tiādīsu diṭṭhisacce.
analyzed: virati sacce kasmai nu saccāni vadanti nānā kusala avadāna ati ādīsu diṭṭhi sacce
translated: In such passages as “Why do they speak of truths as four, skilled in the exposition of the aggregates? ” , it is truthfulness of view.

original: “Ekañhi saccaṃ na dutiyamatthī”tiādīsu paramatthasacce nibbāne ceva magge ca. “Catunnaṃ
analyzed: ekam hi saccam na dutiyam atthi iti ādīsu paramattha sacce nibbāne ca iva magge ca catunnam
translated: In such passages as “For truth is one, there is no second, ” it is the ultimate truth, namely, Nibbāna and the path.

original: ariyasaccānaṃ kati kusalā”tiādīsu ariyasacce. Svāyamidhāpi ariyasacce vattatīti evamettha
analyzed: ariya saccānam kati kusala ati ādīsu ariya sacce svāyam idha api ariya sacce vattati iti evam ettha
translated: In such passages as “How many of the four noble truths are wholesome? ” , it is noble truth.

original: ‘atthuddhārato’pi vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: attha uddhārataḥ pi vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: And here too it is noble truth that is intended. This is how the exposition should be known here🔽as to the derivation of the word.

original: ‘Anūnādhikato’ti kasmā pana cattāreva ariyasaccāni vuttāni, anūnāni anadhikānīti
analyzed: anūna adhikato ti kasmā pana cattāri eva ariya saccāni vuttāni anūnāni anadhikāni iti
translated: As to the number: why are only four noble truths stated, neither more nor less?

original: ce? Aññassāsambhavato, aññatarassa ca anapaneyyabhāvato; na hi etehi aññaṃ adhikaṃ
analyzed: ce aññassa asambhavataḥ aññatarassa ca an apaneyya bhāvataḥ na hi etehi aññam adhikam
translated: Because there is no other beyond these and because there is no omitting any of these. For there is nothing more than these and nothing can be omitted from them.

original: vā etesaṃ vā ekampi apanetabbaṃ sambhoti. Yathāha – “idha, bhikkhave, āgaccheyya
analyzed: vā etesam vā ekam pi apanetabbam yathā āha idha bhikkhave āgaccheyya
translated: or they can be removed from them. As it is said: “Here, bhikkhus, a recluse or a brahmin might come and say thus:

original: samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘netaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, aññaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yaṃ samaṇena🔽gotamena desitaṃ. Ahametaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ ṭhapetvā aññaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ
analyzed: samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā na itam dukkham ariya saccam aññam dukkham ariya saccam yam samaṇena  gotamena desitam aham etam dukkham ariya saccam ṭhapetvā aññam dukkham ariya saccaṃ
translated: ‘This is not the noble truth of suffering as taught by the recluse Gotama. The noble truth of suffering is something else, which I will proclaim to be the noble truth of suffering.’ It is impossible, bhikkhus, it cannot happen, that by this method he could remove the noble truth of suffering proclaimed by the recluse Gotama.

original: paññapessāmī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī”tiādi. Yathā cāha – “yo hi koci, bhikkhave,
analyzed: paññapessāmi iti na itam ṭhānam vijjati itiādi yathā ca āha yaḥ hi koci bhikkhave
translated: And if he were to say: ‘I will set aside the noble truth of suffering as proclaimed by the recluse Gotama and will proclaim another noble truth of suffering,’ it is impossible, bhikkhus, that he could do so.” And so on.

original: samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃ vadeyya ‘netaṃ dukkhaṃ paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, yaṃ samaṇena🔽gotamena desitaṃ. Ahametaṃ dukkhaṃ paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ paccakkhāya aññaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā evam vadeyya na itam dukkham paṭhamam ariya saccam yam samaṇena  gotamena desitam aham etam dukkham paṭhamam ariya saccam paccakkhāya aññam dukkham
translated: And as it is said: “Bhikkhus, it is impossible that a recluse or a brahmin could point to any other noble truth of suffering than that taught by me, saying:

original: paṭhamaṃ ariyasaccaṃ paññapessāmī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī”tiādi.
analyzed: paṭhamam ariya saccam paññapessāmi iti na itam ṭhānam vijjati itiādi
translated: ‘This is the noble truth of suffering as taught by the recluse Gotama. I will set aside this noble truth of suffering as taught by the recluse Gotama and will proclaim another noble truth of suffering.’ It is impossible, bhikkhus, that he could do so.” And so on.

original: Apica pavattimācikkhanto bhagavā sahetukaṃ ācikkhi, nivattiñca saupāyaṃ. Iti pavattinivattitadubhayahetūnaṃ
analyzed: apica pavattim ācikkhantaḥ bhagavā sa hetukam ācikkhi nivattim ca sa upāyam iti pavatti nivatti tad ubhaya hetūnam
translated: Moreover, the Exalted One taught the round of rebirths together with its cause and the cessation of the round together with the means to that cessation. Thus he taught the round, the cessation of the round, and the cause of both the round and its cessation.

original: etapparamato cattāreva vuttāni. Tathā pariññeyya pahātabba sacchikātabba bhāvetabbānaṃ,
translated: and so they are stated in no more than four ways. Likewise, in the way of what is to be fully understood, what is to be abandoned, what is to be realized, and what is to be developed,🔽and in the way of craving, the object of craving, the cessation of craving, and the way to the cessation of craving,

original: taṇhāvatthutaṇhātaṇhānirodhataṇhānirodhupāyānaṃ, ālayālayarāmatāālayasamugghātaālayasamugghātūpāyānañca
analyzed: taṇhā vatthu taṇhā taṇhā nirodha taṇhā nirodha upāyānam ālaya ālaya rāma tā ālaya samugghāta ālaya samugghāta upāyānam ca
translated: and in the way of cleaving, cleaving to sensual pleasures, delight, and the uprooting of cleaving, and the way to the uprooting of cleaving,

original: vasenāpi cattāreva vuttānīti. Evamettha ‘anūnādhikato’ vinicchayo veditabbo.🔽‘Kamato’ti ayampi desanākkamova. Ettha ca oḷārikattā sabbasattasādhāraṇattā ca suviññeyyanti
analyzed: vasena api cattāraḥ eva vuttāni iti evam ettha anūna adhikataḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo  kamato ti ayam pi desanā kkamaḥ uva ettha ca oḷārika ttā sabba satta sādhāraṇa ttā ca su viññeyyanti
translated: they are stated in no more than four ways. This is how the exposition should be known here “in brief and in detail.”

original: dukkhasaccaṃ paṭhamaṃ vuttaṃ, tasseva hetudassanatthaṃ tadanantaraṃ samudayasaccaṃ,
analyzed: dukkha saccam paṭhamam vuttam tassa iva hetu dassana ttham tad anantaram samudaya saccam
translated: As to order: this is also just the order of teaching. And here the truth of suffering is stated first because it is gross, because it is common to all living beings, and because it is easily recognized.🔽The truth of origin is stated next because it is the cause of that.

original: hetunirodhā phalanirodhoti ñāpanatthaṃ tato nirodhasaccaṃ, tadadhigamupāyadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: hetu nirodhā phala nirodhā ti ñāpana ttham tatas nirodha saccam tad adhigama upāya dassana ttham
translated: The truth of cessation is stated next in order to make known that when the cause ceases the fruit must cease too.🔽The truth of the path is stated last in order to show the way to attain that.

original: ante maggasaccaṃ. Bhavasukhassādagadhitānaṃ vā sattānaṃ saṃvegajananatthaṃ paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: ante magga saccam vā sattānam saṃvega janana attham paṭhamam
translated: Or alternatively, the truth of suffering is stated first in order to arouse urgency in beings who are infatuated with the pleasure in existence.

original: dukkhamāha. Taṃ neva akataṃ āgacchati, na issaranimmānādito hoti, ito pana hotīti
analyzed: dukkham āha tam na iva a katam āgacchati na issara nimmānāt itas hoti itas pana hoti iti
translated: That is not obtained without doing, nor does it come about through the creation of a supreme being, etc., but it comes about from this.

original: ñāpanatthaṃ tadanantaraṃ samudayaṃ. Tato sahetukena dukkhena abhibhūtattā saṃviggamānasānaṃ
analyzed: ñāpana ttham tad anantaram samudayam tatas sa hetukena dukkhena abhibhūta ttā saṃvigga mānasānam
translated: and immediately after that the origin, for the purpose of showing the cause of the suffering. Then, since they are agitated in mind because of the suffering with its cause,🔽

original: dukkhanissaraṇagavesīnaṃ nissaraṇadassanena assāsajananatthaṃ nirodhaṃ. Tato nirodhādhigamatthaṃ
analyzed: dukkha nissaraṇa gavesīnam nissaraṇa dassanena assāsa janana attham nirodham tatas nirodha adhigama attham
translated: and then the origin, for the purpose of making known. Then the cessation, for the purpose of arousing interest by showing the escape for those whose minds are affected by suffering with its cause. Then the path, for the purpose of attaining cessation by those who seek the escape from suffering. This is how the exposition should be known here as to order.

original: nirodhasampāpakaṃ magganti evamettha ‘kamato’ vinicchayo veditabbo.🔽‘Ariyasaccesu yaṃ ñāṇaṃ tassa kiccato’ti saccañāṇakiccatopi vinicchayo veditabboti
analyzed: nirodha sampāpakam magganti evam ettha kamataḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo  ariya saccesu yam ñāṇam tassa kiccato ti sacca ñāṇa kiccataḥ pi vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ ti
translated: As to function: the exposition should be known here as to function by way of the function of the knowledge of the Truths.

original: attho. Duvidhañhi saccañāṇaṃ – anubodhañāṇañca paṭivedhañāṇañca. Tattha anubodhañāṇaṃ🔽lokiyaṃ anussavādivasena nirodhe magge ca pavattati. Paṭivedhañāṇaṃ lokuttaraṃ nirodhārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ duvidham hi sacca ñāṇam anubodha ñāṇañca paṭivedha ñāṇañca tattha anubodha ñāṇam  lokiyam anussava ādi vasena nirodhe magge ca pavattati paṭivedha ñāṇam lokuttaram nirodha ārammaṇam
translated: For there are two kinds of knowledge of the Truths: knowledge of the Truths by direct experience and knowledge of the Truths by inference. Herein, knowledge of the Truths by direct experience🔽occurs in the world-transcending path, which is the direct experience of the four Truths. Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.🔽Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.🔽Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.

original: katvā kiccato cattāripi saccāni paṭivijjhati. Yathāha – “yo, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ passati🔽dukkhasamudayampi so passati, dukkhanirodhampi passati, dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadampi
analyzed: katvā kiccato cattāri pi saccāni paṭivijjhati yathā āha yaḥ bhikkhave dukkham passati 🔽dukkha samudayam pi so passati dukkha nirodham pi passati dukkha nirodha gāminim paṭipadam pi
translated: Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.🔽Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.🔽Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.🔽Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.🔽Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.🔽Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.🔽Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.🔽Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference of the four Truths by way of the world-transcending path.🔽Knowledge of the Truths by inference occurs in the world, which is the inference

original: passatī”ti sabbaṃ vattabbaṃ. Yaṃ panetaṃ lokiyaṃ, tattha dukkhañāṇaṃ pariyuṭṭhānābhibhavanavasena
analyzed: passati iti sabbam vattabbam yam pana itam lokiyam tattha dukkha ñāṇam pariyuṭṭhāna abhibhavana vasena
translated: As to the mundane knowledge, the knowledge of suffering, occurring as the overcoming of obsession,

original: pavattamānaṃ sakkāyadiṭṭhiṃ nivatteti, samudayañāṇaṃ ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ, nirodhañāṇaṃ🔽sassatadiṭṭhiṃ, maggañāṇaṃ akiriyadiṭṭhiṃ; dukkhañāṇaṃ vā dhuvasubhasukhattabhāvarahitesu
analyzed: pavattamānam sakkāya diṭṭhim nivatteti samudaya ñāṇam uccheda diṭṭhim nirodha ñāṇam  sassata diṭṭhim magga ñāṇam akiriya diṭṭhim dukkha ñāṇam vā dhuva subha sukhatta bhāva rahitesu
translated: stops the view of individuality; the knowledge of origination stops the view of annihilation; the knowledge of cessation stops the view of eternity;

original: khandhesu dhuvasubhasukhattabhāvasaññāsaṅkhātaṃ phale vippaṭipattiṃ, samudayañāṇaṃ
analyzed: khandhesu dhuva subha sukhatta bhāva saññā saṅkhātam phale vippaṭipattim samudaya ñāṇam
translated: and the knowledge of the path stops the view of non-causality. Or the knowledge of suffering stops the perversion consisting in the perception of permanence, beauty, pleasure, and self, in regard to the aggregates, which are impermanent, ugly, painful, and not self;

original: issarappadhānakālasabhāvādīhi loko pavattatīti akāraṇe kāraṇābhimānappavattaṃ hetumhi🔽vippaṭipattiṃ, nirodhañāṇaṃ arūpalokalokathūpikādīsu apavaggaggāhabhūtaṃ nirodhe🔽vippaṭipattiṃ, maggañāṇaṃ kāmasukhallikaattakilamathānuyogappabhede avisuddhimagge
analyzed: issara ppadhāna kāla sabhāva ādīhi loko pavattati iti akāraṇe kāraṇa abhimāna ppavattam hetumhi  vippaṭipattim nirodha ñāṇam arūpa loka loka thūpika ādīsu apavagga ggāha bhūtam nirodhe  vippaṭipattim magga ñāṇam kāma sukhallika atta kilamatha anuyoga ppabhede a visuddhi magge
translated: the knowledge of origination stops the perversion consisting in the misapprehension of a cause, which occurs as the belief that the world is created by an Overlord, a Supreme Being, Time, Nature, or an Atom;🔽the knowledge of cessation stops the perversion consisting in the misapprehension of an ending, which occurs as the belief that the world ends with the breaking up of the body;

original: visuddhimaggaggāhavasena pavattaṃ upāye vippaṭipattiṃ nivatteti. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: visuddhi magga ggāha vasena pavattam upāye vippaṭipattim nivatteti tena itam vuccati
translated: and the knowledge of the path stops the perversion consisting in the misapprehension of the path, which occurs as the belief that the way to purify a person is by the way of lust.

original: Loke lokappabhave, lokatthagame sive ca tadupāye;
analyzed: loke loka ppabhave lokattha game sive ca tad upāye
translated: In the world, in the world’s arising, in the world’s passing away, in the pleasant, and in the means to that.

original: Sammuyhati tāva naro, na vijānāti yāva saccānīti.
analyzed: sammuyhati tāva naraḥ na vijānāti yāva saccāni iti
translated: In the world, in the world’s becoming, In the world’s passing, and in the bliss And in the means thereto, A man is deluded, so long as He does not know the Truths.

original: Evamettha ‘ñāṇakiccato’pi vinicchayo veditabbo.🔽‘Antogadhānaṃ pabhedā’ti dukkhasaccasmiñhi, ṭhapetvā taṇhañceva anāsavadhamme ca,
analyzed: evam ettha ñāṇa kiccataḥ pi vinicchayaḥ veditabbo  antogadhānam dukkha saccasmin hi ṭhapetvā taṇham ca iva anāsava dhamme ca
translated: Thus the exposition should be understood here as to the function of knowledge.

original: sesā sabbadhammā antogadhā; samudayasacce chattiṃsa taṇhāvicaritāni; nirodhasaccaṃ
analyzed: sesā sabba dhammā antogadhā samudaya sacce chattiṃsa taṇhā vicaritāni nirodha saccam
translated: As to the inclusion of the various kinds in each: in the case of the truth of suffering, all states except craving and the unformed element are included; in the case of the truth of origination, the thirty-six modes of behaviour of craving are included; in the case of the truth of cessation,

original: asammissaṃ; maggasacce sammādiṭṭhimukhena vīmaṃsiddhipādapaññindriyapaññābaladhammavicayasambojjhaṅgāni.
analyzed: a sammissam magga sacce sammādiṭṭhi mukhena vīmaṃsi ddhipāda paññindriya paññā bala dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅgāni
translated: cessation without remainder is included; in the case of the truth of the path, right view is included under the heading of the investigation-of-states enlightenment factor, the energy-concentration- and-joy-factors under the heading of the energy enlightenment factor, the tranquillity- and-purity-factors under the heading of the tranquillity enlightenment factor, and the equanimity enlightenment factor under the heading of the equanimity enlightenment factor.🔽Right intention is included under the three kinds of renunciation-wish, etc.,

original: Sammāsaṅkappāpadesena tayo nekkhammavitakkādayo, sammāvācāpadesena cattāri vacīsucaritāni,
analyzed: sammā saṅkappa apadesena tayaḥ nekkhamma vitakka ādayaḥ sammā vācā apadesena cattāri vacī su caritāni
translated: Right speech is included under the four kinds of verbal good conduct,🔽right action under the three kinds of bodily good conduct,

original: sammākammantāpadesena tīṇi kāyasucaritāni, sammāājīvamukhena appicchatā santuṭṭhitā
analyzed: sammā kammanta apadesena tīṇi kāya su caritāni sammā ājīva mukhena appiccha tā santuṭṭhi tā
translated: and right livelihood under fewness of wishes and contentment,

original: ca, sabbesaṃyeva vā etesaṃ sammāvācākammantājīvānaṃ ariyakantasīlattā sīlassa ca
analyzed: ca sabbesam yeva vā etesam sammā vācā kammanta ājīvānam ariya kanta sīla ttā sīlassa ca
translated: or all these last three are included under virtue, which is loved by noble ones.

original: saddhāhatthena paṭiggahetabbattā tesaṃ atthitāya ca atthibhāvato saddhindriyasaddhābalachandiddhipādā,
analyzed: saddhā hatthena paṭiggahetabba ttā tesam atthitāya ca atthi bhāvato saddhi indriya saddhā bala chandi ddhipādā
translated: and because they are to be taken hold of by the hand of faith, and because they exist in the sense of being present, they are the faith faculty, the faith power, and the faith enlightenment factor.

original: sammāvāyāmāpadesena catubbidhasammappadhānavīriyindriyavīriyabalavīriyasambojjhaṅgāni,🔽sammāsatiapadesena catubbidhasatipaṭṭhānasatindriyasatibalasatisambojjhaṅgāni, sammāsamādhiapadesena
analyzed: sammāvāyāma apadesena catubbidha sammappadhāna vīriyindriya vīriya bala vīriya sambojjhaṅgāni  sammā sati apadesena catubbidha sati paṭṭhāna sati indriya sati bala sati sambojjhaṅgāni sammā samādhi apadesena
translated: The right endeavour is the four right endeavours, the energy faculty, the energy power, and the energy enlightenment factor.🔽The right mindfulness is the four foundations of mindfulness, the mindfulness faculty, the mindfulness power, and the mindfulness enlightenment factor. The right concentration is the three concentrations with thought and with investigation, etc.,

original: savitakkasavicārādayo tayo tayo samādhī, cittasamādhisamādhindriyasamādhibalapītipassaddhisamādhiupekkhāsambojjhaṅgāni
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicāra ādayo tayo tayo samādhī citta samādhi samādhi indriya samādhi bala pīti passaddhi samādhi upekkhā sambojjhaṅgāni
translated: the concentration faculty, the concentration power, the rapture enlightenment factor, the tranquillity enlightenment factor, and the equanimity enlightenment factor.

original: antogadhānīti. Evamettha ‘antogadhānaṃ pabhedā’pi vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: antogadhāni iti evam ettha antogadhānam vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here as to inclusion and as to analysis.

original: ‘Upamāto’ti bhāro viya hi dukkhasaccaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, bhārādānamiva samudayasaccaṃ,
analyzed: upamātaḥ ti bhāraḥ viya hi dukkha saccam daṭṭhabbam bhāra ādānam iva samudaya saccam
translated: As to simile: the truth of suffering should be seen as a burden, the truth of origin as the taking up of the burden,

original: bhāranikkhepanamiva nirodhasaccaṃ, bhāranikkhepanūpāyo viya maggasaccaṃ; rogo viya
analyzed: bhāra nikkhepanam iva nirodha saccam bhāra nikkhepana upāyaḥ viya magga saccam rogaḥ viya
translated: the truth of cessation as the setting down of the burden, and the truth of the path as the means to the setting down of the burden. As a disease,

original: ca dukkhasaccaṃ, roganidānamiva samudayasaccaṃ, rogavūpasamo viya nirodhasaccaṃ,
analyzed: ca dukkha saccam roga nidānam iva samudaya saccam roga vūpasamaḥ viya nirodha saccam
translated: and the truth of suffering is like the disease, the truth of origin is like the cause of the disease, the truth of cessation is like the cure of the disease,

original: bhesajjamiva maggasaccaṃ; dubbhikkhamiva vā dukkhasaccaṃ, dubbuṭṭhi viya samudayasaccaṃ,
analyzed: bhesajjam iva magga saccam dubbhikkham iva vā dukkha saccam viya samudaya saccam
translated: and the truth of the path is like the medicine. Or the truth of suffering is like a famine, the truth of origin is like the cause of the famine,

original: subhikkhamiva nirodhasaccaṃ, suvuṭṭhi viya maggasaccaṃ. Apica verīveramūlaverasamugghātaverasamugghātupāyehi,
analyzed: subhikkham iva nirodha saccam viya magga saccam apica verī vera mūla vera samugghāta vera samugghāta upāyehi
translated: the truth of cessation is like the end of the famine, and the truth of the path is like the means to its end. Or again, they can be understood by comparing the truth of suffering to an enemy, the truth of origin to the root of the enemy, the truth of cessation to the cutting off of the enemy, and the truth of the path to the means to its cutting off;

original: visarukkharukkhamūlamūlupacchedatadupacchedupāyehi, bhayabhayamūlanibbhayatadadhigamupāyehi,
analyzed: visa rukkha rukkha mūla mūla upaccheda tad upaccheda upāyehi bhaya bhaya mūla nibbhaya tad adhigama upāyehi
translated: or by comparing the truth of suffering to a poisonous tree, the truth of origin to the root of the tree, the truth of cessation to the cutting off of the tree, and the truth of the path to the means to its cutting off; or by comparing the truth of suffering to fear, the truth of origin to the cause of fear, the truth of cessation to the absence of fear, and the truth of the path to the means to its attainment;

original: orimatīramahoghapārimatīrataṃsampāpakavāyāmehi ca yojetvāpetāni upamāto veditabbānīti.
analyzed: ca upamātaḥ veditabbāni iti
translated: or by comparing the truth of suffering to this shore of a great expanse of water, the truth of origin to the current, the truth of cessation to the other shore, and the truth of the path to the effort to reach the other shore.

original: Evamettha ‘upamāto’ vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam ettha upamātaḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here “as to simile.”

original: ‘Catukkato’ti atthi cettha dukkhaṃ na ariyasaccaṃ, atthi ariyasaccaṃ na dukkhaṃ,
analyzed: catukkato ti atthi ca ittha dukkham na ariya saccaṃ atthi ariya saccam na dukkham
translated: As to the fours: here there is suffering that is not noble truth, and there is noble truth that is not suffering,

original: atthi dukkhañceva ariyasaccañca, atthi neva dukkhaṃ na ariyasaccaṃ. Esa nayo samudayādīsu.
analyzed: atthi dukkham ca iva ariya saccaṃ ca atthi na iva dukkham na ariya saccaṃ esa nayaḥ samudaya ādīsu
translated: and there is suffering that is noble truth, and there is what is neither suffering nor noble truth. So too with origin, etc.

original: Tattha maggasampayuttā dhammā sāmaññaphalāni ca “yadaniccaṃ taṃ dukkha”nti vacanato
analyzed: tattha magga sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ sāmañña phalāni ca yat aniccam tat dukkhan ti vacanato
translated: Herein, the states associated with the path and the fruits of asceticism are “what is impermanent is painful” .🔽

original: saṅkhāradukkhatāya dukkhaṃ na ariyasaccaṃ. Nirodho ariyasaccaṃ na dukkhaṃ. Itaraṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāra dukkha tāya dukkham na ariya saccam nirodhaḥ ariya saccam na dukkham itaram
translated: Herein, the states associated with the path and the fruits of asceticism are suffering in the sense of suffering due to formations because of the words, “What is impermanent is suffering” .

original: pana ariyasaccadvayaṃ siyā dukkhaṃ aniccato, na pana yassa pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ
analyzed: pana ariya sacca dvayam siyā dukkham aniccataḥ na pana yassa pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyam
translated: But cessation is not suffering, and the other two truths

original: vussati tathatthena. Sabbākārena pana upādānakkhandhapañcakaṃ dukkhañceva ariyasaccañca🔽aññatra taṇhāya. Maggasampayuttā dhammā sāmaññaphalāni ca yassa pariññatthaṃ bhagavati
analyzed: vussati tathatthena sabba ākārena pana upādāna khandha pañcakam dukkham ca iva ariya saccañca  aññatra taṇhāya magga sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ sāmañña phalāni ca yassa bhagavati
translated: are not suffering in the sense of the noble truth of suffering. But the five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering in all ways and also a noble truth,🔽apart from craving. The states associated with the path and the fruits of asceticism are not suffering in the sense of the noble truth of suffering, nor are they not a noble truth, because the life of purity under the Blessed One is lived for the purpose of fully understanding them.

original: brahmacariyaṃ vussati tathatthena neva dukkhaṃ na ariyasaccaṃ. Evaṃ samudayādīsupi
analyzed: brahmacariyam tathatthena na iva dukkham na ariya saccam evam samudaya ādīsu pi
translated: So too with the origin, etc.,

original: yathāyogaṃ yojetvā ‘catukkato’pettha vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: yathāyogam yojetvā vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: which should be construed in the appropriate way. This is how the exposition should be understood here as to the fourfold method.

original: ‘Suññatekavidhādīhī’ti ettha suññato tāva paramatthena hi sabbāneva saccāni vedakakārakanibbutagamakābhāvato suññānīti veditabbāni. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: suññatā ekavidha ādīhi iti ettha suññatas tāva paramatthena hi sabbān eva saccāni vedaka kāraka nibbuta gamaka abhāvato suññāni iti veditabbāni tena itam vuccati
translated: ‘In the fourfold way of emptiness’ : firstly, as to emptiness of self, all the four Truths should be understood as empty in the ultimate sense, because of the absence of a feeler, a doer, one who goes to the world beyond, and a self. Hence it is said:

original: Dukkhameva hi na koci dukkhito, kārako na kiriyāva vijjati;
analyzed: dukkham eva hi na koci dukkhitaḥ kārakaḥ na kiriyā ava vijjati
translated: For there is only suffering, and no sufferer; there is only action, and no doer;

original: Atthi nibbuti na nibbuto pumā, maggamatthi gamako na vijjatīti.
analyzed: atthi nibbuti na nibbutaḥ pumā maggam atthi gamakaḥ na vijjati iti
translated: There is only extinction, and no extinct one; there is only the path, and no one who goes by it.

original: Atha vā –
analyzed: atha vā
translated: Or alternatively:

original: Dhuvasubhasukhattasuññaṃ, purimadvayamattasuññamamatapadaṃ;
analyzed: dhuva subha sukhatta suññam purima dvaya matta suññam amata padam
translated: The first two are empty of permanence, beauty, pleasure, and self; the third of self and what pertains to self;

original: Dhuvasukhaattavirahito, maggo iti suññato tesu.🔽Nirodhasuññāni vā tīṇi, nirodho ca sesattayasuñño. Phalasuñño vā ettha hetu samudaye🔽dukkhassābhāvato magge ca nirodhassa, na phalena sagabbho pakativādīnaṃ pakati viya.
analyzed: dhuva sukha atta virahitaḥ maggaḥ iti tesu  nirodha suññāni vā tīṇi nirodho ca sesa ttaya suñño phala suñño vā ettha hetu samudaye  dukkhassa abhāvataḥ magge ca nirodhassa na phalena sa gabbhaḥ pakati vādīnam pakati viya
translated: The path is empty of permanence and pleasure; and the fourth is empty of self.🔽Or else the three Truths are empty of cessation, and cessation is empty of the remaining three. Or the Path is empty of the fruit, because of the absence of suffering and its origin in the Path, and of cessation in the fruit, like the absence of the natural properties of a tree in a man who is not a tree.

original: Hetusuññañca phalaṃ dukkhasamudayānaṃ nirodhamaggānañca asamavāyā, na hetusamavetaṃ
analyzed: hetu suññam ca phalam dukkha samudayānam nirodha maggānam ca asamavāyāḥ na hetu samavetam
translated: And the fruit is empty of the cause, because of the absence of the cause in the fruit, like the absence of the natural properties of a tree in the sapling.

original: hetuphalaṃ hetuphalasamavāyavādīnaṃ dviaṇukādīni viya. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: hetu phalam dvi aṇuka ādīni tena itam vuccati
translated: and the cause and fruit are void of each other, like the dyad of atoms, according to those who maintain that cause and fruit are a unity. Hence it is said:

original: Tayamidha nirodhasuññaṃ, tayena tenāpi nibbuti suññā;
analyzed: tayam idha nirodha suññam tayena tena api nibbuti suññā
translated: Herein, cessation is void of that, And by that too is void that peace;

original: Suñño phalena hetu, phalampi taṃ hetunā suññanti.
analyzed: suññaḥ phalena hetu phalampi tam hetunā suññanti
translated: The cause is void of fruit, And fruit is void of cause.

original: Evaṃ tāva ‘suññato’ vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam tāva suññataḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: This, in the first place, is how the exposition should be known here as to voidness.

original: ‘Ekavidhādīhī’ti sabbameva cettha dukkhaṃ ekavidhaṃ pavattibhāvato, duvidhaṃ nāmarūpato,
analyzed: ekavidha ādīhi iti sabbam eva ca ittha dukkham ekavidham pavatti bhāvataḥ duvidham nāma rūpataḥ
translated: As to singlefold and so on: all this suffering is singlefold as to its state of being occurrence, twofold as mentality-materiality,

original: tividhaṃ kāmarūpārūpūpapatibhavabhedato, catubbidhaṃ catuāhārabhedato, pañcavidhaṃ
analyzed: tividham catubbidham catu āhāra bhedataḥ pañcavidham
translated: trifold as rebirth-process becoming, sensual-desire becoming, and fine-material becoming, fourfold as to the four nutriments, fivefold as to the five aggregates as objects of clinging,🔽sixfold as to the six bases in oneself, sevenfold as to the seven stations of consciousness, eightfold as to the eight worldly ideas, ninefold as to the nine grounds for laziness, and tenfold as to the ten kinds of existence.

original: pañcupādānakkhandhabhedato. Samudayopi ekavidho pavattakabhāvato, duvidho diṭṭhisampayuttāsampayuttato,
analyzed: pañca upādāna kkhandha bhedataḥ samudayaḥ api ekavidhaḥ pavattaka bhāvataḥ duvidhaḥ diṭṭhi sampayutta asampayuttato
translated: And the origin is singlefold as to its state of being occurrence, twofold as to being associated and unassociated with false view,

original: tividho kāmabhavavibhavataṇhābhedato, catubbidho catumaggappaheyyato, pañcavidho
analyzed: tividhaḥ kāma bhava vibhava taṇhā bhedato catubbidhaḥ catu magga ppaheyyato pañcavidhaḥ
translated: trifold as to craving for sense desires, craving for becoming, and craving for non-becoming, fourfold as to what is to be abandoned by the four paths, fivefold as to the five kinds of delighting in,🔽sixfold as to the six classes of craving, sevenfold as to the seven kinds of craving, eightfold as to the eight kinds of craving, ninefold as to the nine roots of craving, and tenfold as to the ten kinds of craving.

original: rūpābhinandanādibhedato, chabbidho chataṇhākāyabhedato. Nirodhopi ekavidho asaṅkhatadhātubhāvato,
analyzed: rūpa abhinandana ādi bhedataḥ chabbidhaḥ chat aṇhā kāya bhedataḥ nirodhaḥ api ekavidhaḥ asaṅkhata dhātu bhāvato
translated: And cessation is singlefold as to its state of being the unformed element,

original: pariyāyena pana duvidho saupādisesaanupādisesato, tividho bhavattayavūpasamato, catubbidho
analyzed: pariyāyena pana duvidhaḥ saupādisesa anupādisesato tividhaḥ bhavat taya vūpasamataḥ catubbidhaḥ
translated: But in another way it is twofold as with and without residue left, threefold as the stilling of the three kinds of becoming, fourfold as to be reached by the four paths,

original: catumaggādhigamanīyato, pañcavidho pañcābhinandanavūpasamato, chabbidho chataṇhākāyakkhayabhedato.
analyzed: catu magga adhigamanīyataḥ pañcavidhaḥ pañca abhinandana vūpasamataḥ chabbidhaḥ cha taṇhā kāya kkhaya bhedataḥ
translated: fivefold as the stilling of the five kinds of delight, and sixfold as the abandoning of the six bodies of craving.

original: Maggopi ekavidho bhāvetabbato, duvidho samathavipassanābhedato dassanabhāvanābhedato🔽vā, tividho khandhattayabhedato. Ayañhi sappadesattā nagaraṃ viya rajjena nippadesehi
analyzed: maggaḥ api ekavidhaḥ bhāvetabbataḥ duvidhaḥ samatha vipassanā bhedataḥ dassana bhāvanā bhedato  vā tividhaḥ khandha ttaya bhedataḥ ayan hi sappadesa ttā nagaram viya rajjena nippadesehi
translated: The path is singlefold as what should be developed. It is twofold as serenity and insight, or as seeing and developing.🔽Or it is threefold as the three aggregates. For it is included by the three aggregates, like a city by the countryside, since it has a similar location.

original: tīhi khandhehi saṅgahito. Yathāha –🔽“Na kho, āvuso visākha, ariyena aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena tayo khandhā saṅgahitā. Tīhi
analyzed: tīhi khandhehi saṅgahitaḥ yathā āha  na kho āvuso visākha ariyena aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena tayaḥ khandhā saṅgahitā tīhi
translated: As it is said:🔽“Friend Visākha, the three aggregates are not included by the noble eightfold path.

original: ca kho, āvuso visākha, khandhehi ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saṅgahito. Yā cāvuso visākha,
analyzed: ca kho āvuso visākha khandhehi ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo saṅgahitaḥ yā ca āvuso visākha
translated: But the noble eightfold path is included by the three aggregates.

original: sammāvācā, yo ca sammākammanto, yo ca sammāājīvo – ime dhammā sīlakkhandhe saṅgahitā;
analyzed: sammā vācā yaḥ ca sammā kammantaḥ yaḥ ca sammā ājīvo ime dhammā sīla kkhandhe saṅgahitā
translated: Friend Visākha, right speech, right action, and right livelihood are included by the virtue aggregate;

original: yo ca sammāvāyāmo, yā ca sammāsati, yo ca sammāsamādhi – ime dhammā samādhikkhandhe
analyzed: yā ca sammā vāyāmaḥ yā ca sammā sati yaḥ ca sammā samādhi ime dhammā samādhi kkhandhe
translated: Right endeavour, right mindfulness, and right concentration are included in the concentration aggregate.

original: saṅgahitā; yā ca sammādiṭṭhi, yo ca sammāsaṅkappo – ime dhammā paññākkhandhe saṅgahitā”ti.
analyzed: saṅgahitā yā ca sammādiṭṭhi yaḥ ca sammāsaṅkappo ime dhammā paññā kkhandhe saṅgahitā ati
translated: And right view and right thought are included in the understanding aggregate.”

original: Ettha hi sammāvācādayo tayo sīlameva. Tasmā te sajātito sīlakkhandhena saṅgahitā.
analyzed: ettha hi sammāvācā ādayo tayo sīlam eva tasmā te sajātitaḥ sīla kkhandhena saṅgahitā
translated: Herein, the three beginning with right speech are virtue. So they are included in the virtue aggregate because of having the same characteristics.

original: Kiñcāpi hi pāḷiyaṃ sīlakkhandheti bhummena niddeso kato, attho pana karaṇavaseneva
analyzed: kiñca api hi pāḷiyam sīlakkhandha iti bhummena niddeso kataḥ atthaḥ pana karaṇa vasena iva
translated: And although the exposition in the text is by way of the term “aggregate,” the meaning should be understood according to the function.

original: veditabbo. Sammāvāyāmādīsu pana tīsu samādhi attano dhammatāya ārammaṇe ekaggabhāvena🔽appetuṃ na sakkoti, vīriye pana paggahakiccaṃ sādhente satiyā ca apilāpanakiccaṃ
analyzed: veditabbaḥ sammāvāyāma ādīsu pana tīsu samādhi attanaḥ dhammatāya ārammaṇe ekagga bhāvena  appetum na sakkoti vīriye pana paggaha kiccam sādhente satiyā ca apilāpana kiccam
translated: But as regards the three beginning with right endeavour, concentration cannot by its own nature cause occurrence in the object as unity;

original: sādhentiyā laddhūpakāro hutvā sakkoti.
analyzed: sādhentiyāḥ laddha upakāraḥ hutvā sakkoti
translated: but when energy has fulfilled its function of exertion and mindfulness has fulfilled its function of non-forgetting, then it can.

original: Tatrāyaṃ upamā – yathā hi nakkhattaṃ kīḷissāmāti uyyānaṃ paviṭṭhesu tīsu sahāyesu
analyzed: tatra ayam upamā yathā hi nakkhattam kīḷissāma ati uyyānam paviṭṭhesu tīsu sahāyesu
translated: Here is a simile. Suppose there were three friends who had entered a park,

original: eko supupphitaṃ campakarukkhaṃ disvā hatthaṃ ukkhipitvāpi gahetuṃ na sakkuṇeyya.🔽Athassa dutiyo onamitvā piṭṭhiṃ dadeyya. So tassa piṭṭhiyaṃ ṭhatvāpi kampamāno gahetuṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ su pupphitam campaka rukkham disvā hattham ukkhipitvā api gahetum na sakkuṇeyya  athassa dutiyaḥ onamitvā piṭṭhim dadeyya saḥ tassa piṭṭhiyam ṭhatvā api kampamānaḥ gahetum
translated: and a second one, bending down, would give him his back, and he, standing on the second one’s back, would still be unable to pick the flowers as he wanted,

original: na sakkuṇeyya. Athassa itaro aṃsakūṭaṃ upanāmeyya. So ekassa piṭṭhiyaṃ ṭhatvā ekassa🔽aṃsakūṭaṃ olubbha yathāruci pupphāni ocinitvā piḷandhitvā nakkhattaṃ kīḷeyya. Evaṃsampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: na sakkuṇeyya athassa itaraḥ aṃsakūṭam upanāmeyya saḥ ekassa piṭṭhiyam ṭhatvā ekassa  aṃsakūṭam olubbha yathāruci pupphāni ocinitvā piḷandhitvā nakkhattam kīḷeyya evaṃsampadam idam daṭṭhabbam
translated: and a third one would hold out his shoulder, and he, standing on the second one’s back and holding on to the third one’s shoulder, would pick the flowers as he wanted, make a bouquet, and come down.

original: Ekato uyyānaṃ paviṭṭhā tayo sahāyā viya hi ekato jātā sammāvāyāmādayo tayo dhammā,
analyzed: ekatas uyyānam paviṭṭhā tayo sahāyāḥ viya hi ekatas jātā sammāvāyāma ādayo tayo dhammā
translated: So too, the three things, right effort and the rest, are like the three friends who went to the park together.

original: supupphitacampakarukkho viya ārammaṇaṃ, hatthaṃ ukkhipitvāpi gahetuṃ asakkonto viya
analyzed: su pupphita campaka rukkhaḥ viya ārammaṇam hattham ukkhipitvā api gahetum a sakkontaḥ viya
translated: The object is like the tree in full blossom. Concentration is like the man who, though he raises his hand, is still unable to pick the flowers as he wants.

original: attano dhammatāya ārammaṇe ekaggabhāvena appetuṃ asakkonto samādhi, piṭṭhiṃ datvā
analyzed: attanaḥ dhamma tāya ārammaṇe ekagga bhāvena appetum asakkontaḥ samādhi piṭṭhim datvā
translated: It is unable to make the mind enter into absorption with unification upon the object by its own individual essence.🔽Restraint of the mind is like the second friend who gives his back.

original: onatasahāyo viya vāyāmo, aṃsakūṭaṃ datvā ṭhitasahāyo viya sati. Yathā tesu ekassa
analyzed: onata sahāyaḥ viya vāyāmaḥ aṃsakūṭam da tvā ṭhita sahāyaḥ viya sati yathā tesu ekassa
translated: Restraint of the mental factors is like the third friend who holds out his shoulder.🔽Just as, when the man standing on the second one’s back and holding on to the third one’s shoulder picks the flowers as he wants, makes a bouquet, and comes down, so too, when the mind is steadied in concentration with the help of restraint of the mental factors, then, with the help of restraint of the mind, it enters into absorption with unification upon the object by its own individual essence.

original: piṭṭhiyaṃ ṭhatvā ekassa aṃsakūṭaṃ olubbha itaro yathāruci pupphaṃ gahetuṃ sakkoti,
analyzed: piṭṭhiyam ṭhatvā ekassa aṃsakūṭam olubbhe itaraḥ yathāruci puppham gahetum sakkoti
translated: and the other climbs on to his shoulders and picks the flowers as he wishes,

original: evameva vīriye paggahakiccaṃ sādhente satiyā ca apilāpanakiccaṃ sādhentiyā laddhūpakāro
analyzed: evam eva vīriye paggaha kiccam sādhente satiyā ca apilāpana kiccam sādhentiyā laddha upakāraḥ
translated: so too, when energy has fulfilled its function of exerting, and mindfulness its function of non-forgetting,

original: samādhi sakkoti ārammaṇe ekaggabhāvena appetuṃ. Tasmā samādhiyevettha sajātito samādhikkhandhena
analyzed: samādhi sakkoti ārammaṇe ekagga bhāvena appetum tasmā samādhi yā iva itthā sajātitaḥ samādhi kkhandhena
translated: concentration can keep to the object with one-pointedness. That is why concentration is included here only as concentration,

original: saṅgahito. Vāyāmasatiyo pana kiriyato saṅgahitā honti.
analyzed: saṅgahitaḥ pana saṅgahitāḥ honti
translated: which is of the same kind as the concentration factor of the Noble Eightfold Path, while energy and mindfulness are included as energy and mindfulness factors of the path.

original: Sammādiṭṭhisammāsaṅkappesupi paññā attano dhammatāya ‘aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattā’ti ārammaṇaṃ🔽nicchetuṃ na sakkoti, vitakke pana ākoṭetvā ākoṭetvā dente sakkoti. Kathaṃ? Yathā🔽hi heraññiko kahāpaṇaṃ hatthe ṭhapetvā sabbabhāgesu oloketukāmo samānopi na cakkhutaleneva
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappesu pi paññā attanaḥ dhamma tāya aniccam dukkham anattā ati ārammaṇaṃ  nicchetum na sakkoti vitakke pana ākoṭetvā ākoṭetvā dente sakkoti katham yathā  hi heraññikaḥ kahāpaṇam hatthe ṭhapetvā sabba bhāgesu oloketu kāmo samānaḥ api na cakkhu talena iva
translated: Understanding, too, cannot by its own nature discern an object as impermanent, painful, and not-self;🔽but when applied thought has beaten the object up, as it were, and brought it to a standstill, then it can. How?🔽Just as a gold-beater, when he wants to look at the thinness or thickness of a gold leaf, does not look at it where it is folded over, but where it is spread out;

original: parivattetuṃ sakkoti, aṅgulipabbehi pana parivattetvā parivattetvā ito cito ca oloketuṃ
analyzed: parivattetum sakkoti aṅguli pabbehi pana parivattetvā parivattetvā itas ca itas ca oloketum
translated: so too, when a man wants to look at the thinness or thickness of applied thought, he does not look at it where it is interrupted, but where it is spread out.

original: sakkoti; evameva na paññā attano dhammatāya aniccādivasena ārammaṇaṃ nicchetuṃ sakkoti,🔽abhiniropanalakkhaṇena pana āhananapariyāhananarasena vitakkena ākoṭentena viya parivattentena
analyzed: sakkoti evam eva na paññā attanaḥ dhamma tāya anicca ādi vasena ārammaṇam nicchetum sakkoti  abhiniropana lakkhaṇena pana āhanana pariyāhanana rasena vitakkena ākoṭentena viya parivattentena
translated: So too, understanding is unable to discern an object as impermanent, etc., by its own individual essence.

original: viya ca ādāya ādāya dinnameva nicchetuṃ sakkoti. Tasmā idhāpi sammādiṭṭhiyeva sajātito🔽paññākkhandhena saṅgahitā, sammāsaṅkappo pana kiriyato saṅgahito hoti. Iti imehi
analyzed: ca ādāya ādāya dinnam eva nicchetum sakkoti tasmai idha api sammādiṭṭhiyā iva sajātitaḥ  paññā kkhandhena saṅgahitā sammāsaṅkappaḥ pana kiriyataḥ saṅgahitaḥ hoti iti imehi
translated: But it is able to discern it by taking it up again and again, as it were, by striking it, as it were, and by turning it over, as it were, with applied thought, which has the characteristic of striking and the function of turning over.

original: tīhi khandhehi maggo saṅgahaṃ gacchati. Tena vuttaṃ – “tividho khandhattayabhedato”ti.
analyzed: tīhi khandhehi maggaḥ saṅgaham gacchati tena vuttam tividhaḥ khandha ttaya bhedato ti
translated: So here too right view is included in the understanding aggregate, and right thought in the aggregate of formations. Thus the path is included in three aggregates. Hence it was said above: “In three aggregates, by the division of the three aggregates” .

original: Catubbidho sotāpattimaggādivasena.
analyzed: catubbidhaḥ sotāpatti magga ādi vasena
translated: It is fourfold as the path of stream-entry, and so on.

original: Apica sabbāneva saccāni ekavidhāni avitathattā abhiññeyyattā vā, duvidhāni lokiyalokuttarato
analyzed: apica sabbāneva saccāni ekavidhāni avitatha ttā abhiññeyya ttā vā duvidhāni lokiya lokuttarato
translated: Again, all the truths are singlefold as to their non-differentiation as to their being what should be directly known by direct knowledge. They are twofold as mundane and supramundane,

original: saṅkhatāsaṅkhatato ca, tividhāni dassanabhāvanāhi pahātabbato appahātabbato nevapahātabbanāpahātabbato
analyzed: saṅkhata asaṅkhatataḥ ca tividhāni dassana bhāvanāhi pahātabbataḥ appahātabbataḥ na iva pahātabbana apahātabbataḥ
translated: as formed and unformed, and so on. They are threefold as to be given up through vision of suffering, etc., as not to be given up, and as neither to be given up nor not to be given up.

original: ca, catubbidhāni pariññeyyādibhedatoti. Evamettha ‘ekavidhādīhi’ vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: ca catubbidhāni pariññeyya ādi bhedataḥ ti evam ettha ekavidha ādīhi vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here as to the singlefold, etc.,

original: ‘Sabhāgavisabhāgato’ti sabbāneva ca saccāni aññamaññaṃ sabhāgāni avitathato attasuññato dukkarapaṭivedhato ca. Yathāha –
analyzed: sabhāga visabhāgato ti sabbān eva ca saccāni aññam aññam sabhāgāni avitathataḥ atta suññataḥ dukkara paṭivedhato ca yathā āha
translated: As to similar and dissimilar: all the truths are similar to each other as not being a self, as being void, and as being hard to penetrate,

original: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, ānanda, katamaṃ nu kho dukkarataraṃ vā durabhisambhavataraṃ vā🔽– yo dūratova sukhumena tālacchiggaḷena asanaṃ atipāteyya poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ avirādhitaṃ,
analyzed: tam kim maññasi ānanda katamam nu kho dukkarataram vā durabhisambhavataram vā  yaḥ dūratas uva su khumena tāla chiggaḷena asanam atipāteyya a virādhitam
translated: according as it is said: “What do you think, Ānanda? Which is the more difficult to do,

original: yo vā sattadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭivijjheyyā”ti? “Etadeva, bhante,
analyzed: yaḥ vā sattadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭim paṭivijjheyya ati etat eva bhante
translated: or to hit a mustard seed placed on the tip of a finger, or to penetrate the tip of an eyebrow split a hundred times with the point of a blade of kuśa grass?”

original: dukkaratarañceva durabhisambhavatarañca – yo sattadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭiṃ
analyzed: dukkaratarañca iva durabhisambhavatarañca yaḥ sattadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭiṃ
translated: “It is more difficult, venerable sir, to penetrate the tip of an eyebrow split a hundred times with the point of a blade of kuśa grass,”

original: paṭivijjheyyā”ti. “Tato kho te, ānanda, duppaṭivijjhataraṃ paṭivijjhanti ye idaṃ
analyzed: paṭivijjheyya iti tatas kho te ānanda duppaṭivijjhataram paṭivijjhanti ye idam
translated: “But, Ānanda, they penetrate what is more difficult to penetrate than that,🔽namely, the tip of an eyebrow split a hundred times with the point of a blade of kuśa grass,

original: dukkhanti yathābhūtaṃ paṭivijjhanti…pe… ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṃ paṭivijjhantī”ti.🔽Visabhāgāni salakkhaṇavavatthānato. Purimāni ca dve sabhāgāni duravagāhatthena gambhīrattā🔽lokiyattā sāsavattā ca, visabhāgāni phalahetubhedato pariññeyyappahātabbato ca. Pacchimānipi🔽dve sabhāgāni gambhīratthena duravagāhattā lokuttarattā anāsavattā ca, visabhāgāni

original: lokiyalokuttarato. Dutiyatatiyāni cāpi sabhāgāni nevasekkhānāsekkhabhāvato, visabhāgāni
analyzed: lokiya lokuttarataḥ dutiya tatiyāni ca api sabhāgāni nevasekkha anāsekkha bhāvataḥ visabhāgāni
translated: As to mundane and supramundane. And the second and third are similar in being neither in training nor beyond training.🔽They are dissimilar

original: sārammaṇānārammaṇato.🔽Iti evaṃ pakārehi, nayehi ca vicakkhaṇo;
analyzed: sa ārammaṇa anārammaṇato  iti evam pakārehi nayehi ca vicakkhaṇaḥ
translated: as to object and no object.🔽So by these and other such divisions🔽and classifications, the wise should know

original: Vijaññā ariyasaccānaṃ, sabhāgavisabhāgatanti.🔽Suttantabhājanīyauddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vijaññāḥ ariya saccānam sabhāga visabhāga tanti  suttantabhājanīya oddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The four noble Truths as similar and dissimilar.🔽The commentary on the exposition of the Suttas, the Basket, and the summary is ended.

original: 1. Dukkhasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: THE DESCRIPTION OF THE TRUTHS

original: Jātiniddeso🔽190. Idāni saṅkhepato uddiṭṭhāni dukkhādīni vibhajitvā dassetuṃ ayaṃ tattha katamaṃ🔽dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ jātipi dukkhāti niddesavāro āraddho. Tattha jāti veditabbā, jātiyā🔽dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo; jarā, maraṇaṃ, soko, paridevo, dukkhaṃ, domanassaṃ, upāyāso,
analyzed: jāti niddeso  idāni saṅkhepataḥ uddiṭṭhāni dukkha ādīni vibhajitvā dassetum ayam tattha katamam  dukkham ariya saccam jāti pi dukkhā ati niddesa vāraḥ āraddho tattha jāti veditabbā jātiyā  dukkhaṭṭhaḥ veditabbo jarā maraṇam sokaḥ paridevaḥ dukkham domanassam upāyāsaḥ
translated: THE DESCRIPTION OF BIRTH

original: appiyasampayogo, piyavippayogo veditabbo; appiyasampayogassa piyavippayogassa dukkhaṭṭho
analyzed: appiya sampayogaḥ piya vippayogaḥ veditabbaḥ appiya sampayogassa piya vippayogassa dukkhaṭṭho
translated: Now, in order to show the truths briefly stated by the words “The noble truth of suffering” and so on, the section beginning, “Herein, what is the noble truth of suffering? Birth is suffering” is begun. Herein, birth should be understood; the meaning of suffering as birth should be understood; aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair should be understood; the meaning of suffering as sorrow, etc., should be understood;

original: veditabbo; icchā veditabbā, icchāya dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo; khandhā veditabbā, khandhānaṃ
analyzed: veditabbaḥ icchā veditabbā icchāya dukkhaṭṭhaḥ veditabbaḥ khandhāḥ veditabbā khandhānaṃ
translated: desire should be known, the state of stress in desire should be known; the components should be known,

original: dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo.
analyzed: dukkhaṭṭhaḥ veditabbo
translated: and desire should be known, and the meaning of suffering in desire should be known, and the aggregates should be known, and the meaning of suffering in the aggregates should be known.

original: Tattha dukkhassa ariyasaccassa kathanatthāya ayaṃ mātikā – idañhi dukkhaṃ nāma anekaṃ
analyzed: tattha dukkhassa ariya saccassa kathana atthāya ayam mātikā idam hi dukkham nāma anekam
translated: Herein, this is the Schedule for the purpose of explaining the Noble Truth of Suffering: for this so-called suffering is of many a kind,

original: nānappakāraṃ, seyyathidaṃ – dukkhadukkhaṃ, vipariṇāmadukkhaṃ, saṅkhāradukkhaṃ, paṭicchannadukkhaṃ,
analyzed: nānappakāram seyyathidam dukkha dukkham vipariṇāma dukkham saṅkhāra dukkham paṭicchanna dukkham
translated: of various kinds, namely suffering as suffering, suffering as change, suffering as a formed thing, suffering that is concealed,

original: appaṭicchannadukkhaṃ, pariyāyadukkhaṃ, nippariyāyadukkhanti.🔽Tattha kāyikacetasikā dukkhavedanā sabhāvato ca nāmato ca dukkhattā ‘dukkhadukkhaṃ’
analyzed: appaṭicchanna dukkham pariyāya dukkham nippariyāya dukkham ti  tattha kāyika cetasikā dukkha vedanā sabhāvato ca nāmato ca dukkha ttā dukkha dukkham
translated: suffering that is unconcealed, suffering that is limited, and suffering that is unlimited.

original: nāma. Sukhavedanā vipariṇāmena dukkhuppattihetuto ‘vipariṇāmadukkhaṃ’ nāma. Upekkhāvedanā
analyzed: nāma sukha vedanā vipariṇāmena dukkha uppatti hetutaḥ vipariṇāma dukkham nāma upekkhā vedanā
translated: Herein, bodily and mental painful feeling is called “suffering as suffering” because of its nature as suffering and because of its being called “suffering”. Pleasant feeling is called “suffering as change” because it is a cause for the production of suffering through change.

original: ceva avasesā ca tebhūmakā saṅkhārā udayabbayapīḷitattā ‘saṅkhāradukkhaṃ’ nāma. Tathā
analyzed: ca iva avasesā ca tebhūmakā saṅkhārā udaya bbaya pīḷita ttā saṅkhāradukkham nāma tathā
translated: And the formed things of the three planes, together with the feeling of equanimity, are called “suffering as a formed thing” because they are afflicted by the suffering of arising and falling away.

original: pīḷanaṃ pana maggaphalānampi atthi. Tasmā ete dhammā dukkhasaccapariyāpannattena
analyzed: pīḷanam pana magga phalānam pi atthi tasmai ete dhammā dukkha sacca pariyāpanna ttena
translated: But the path and fruit are also afflicted in the same way. Therefore these ideas are included in the Truth of Suffering because they are included in the suffering of the formed.

original: saṅkhāradukkhaṃ nāmāti veditabbā. Kaṇṇasūladantasūlarāgajapariḷāhadosajapariḷāhādi
analyzed: saṅkhāra dukkham nāma ati veditabbā kaṇṇa sūla danta sūla rāga ja pariḷāha dosa ja pariḷāha ādi
translated: This is what should be understood as the suffering of formations.

original: kāyikacetasiko ābādho pucchitvā jānitabbato upakkamassa ca apākaṭabhāvato ‘paṭicchannadukkhaṃ’🔽nāma, apākaṭadukkhantipi vuccati. Dvattiṃsakammakāraṇādisamuṭṭhāno ābādho apucchitvāva
analyzed: kāyika cetasikaḥ ābādhaḥ pucchitvā jānitabbataḥ upakkamassa ca apākaṭa bhāvataḥ paṭicchanna dukkham  nāma apākaṭa dukkham tipi vuccati dvattiṃsa kamma kāraṇa ādi samuṭṭhānaḥ ābādhaḥ a pucchitvā ava
translated: Bodily and mental affliction such as earache, toothache, fever caused by bile, fever caused by phlegm, etc.,🔽is called “concealed suffering” because it has to be found out by asking, and because the approach to it is not obvious.🔽It is also called “unobvious suffering.” Affliction arisen from the thirty-two bodily parts, etc.,

original: jānitabbato upakkamassa ca pākaṭabhāvato ‘appaṭicchannadukkhaṃ’ nāma, pākaṭadukkhantipi
analyzed: jānitabbataḥ upakkamassa ca pākaṭa bhāvataḥ appaṭicchannadukkham nāma pākaṭa dukkham ti pi
translated: is called “unconcealed suffering” because it can be found out without asking, and because the approach to it is obvious.

original: vuccati. Ṭhapetvā dukkhadukkhaṃ sesaṃ dukkhasaccavibhaṅge āgataṃ jātiādi sabbampi
analyzed: vuccati ṭhapetvā dukkha dukkham sesam dukkha sacca vibhaṅge āgatam jāti ādi sabbam pi
translated: It is also called “obvious suffering.” All the rest of the things beginning with birth mentioned in the analysis of the truth of suffering in the Dukanipata,

original: tassa tassa dukkhassa vatthubhāvato ‘pariyāyadukkhaṃ’ nāma. Dukkhadukkhaṃ ‘nippariyāyadukkhaṃ’ nāma.
analyzed: tassa tassa dukkhassa vatthu bhāvato pariyāyadukkham nāma dukkha dukkham nippariyāyadukkham nāma
translated: except for the suffering of pain, are called “limited suffering” because they are the basis for this or that kind of suffering. The suffering of pain is called “unlimited suffering.”

original: Tattha pariyāyadukkhaṃ nippariyāyadukkhanti imasmiṃ padadvaye ṭhatvā dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ
analyzed: tattha pariyāya dukkham nippariyāya dukkhanti imasmim pada dvaye dukkham ariya saccam
translated: Herein, the noble truth of suffering should be understood

original: kathetabbaṃ. Ariyasaccañca nāmetaṃ pāḷiyaṃ saṅkhepatopi āgacchati vitthāratopi. Saṅkhepato🔽āgataṭṭhāne saṅkhepenapi vitthārenapi kathetuṃ vaṭṭati. Vitthārato āgataṭṭhāne pana
analyzed: kathetabbam ariya saccam ca nāma etam pāḷiyam saṅkhepataḥ api āgacchati vitthārataḥ api saṅkhepataḥ  āgata ṭṭhāne saṅkhepena api vitthārena api kathetum vaṭṭati vitthārataḥ āgata ṭṭhāne pana
translated: and it should be expounded. But this Noble Truth does not occur in the text either in brief or in detail. Where it occurs in brief🔽it may be expounded in brief or in detail. But where it occurs in detail

original: vitthāreneva kathetuṃ vaṭṭati, na saṅkhepena. Taṃ idaṃ imasmiṃ ṭhāne vitthārena āgatanti
analyzed: vitthārena iva kathetum vaṭṭati na saṅkhepena tam idam imasmin ṭhāne vitthārena
translated: it may be expounded only in detail, not in brief. Since it occurs in detail here,🔽it should be expounded in detail. So what was said in the Description of Terms

original: vitthāreneva kathetabbaṃ. Tasmā yaṃ taṃ niddesavāre “tattha katamaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ?
analyzed: vitthārena iva kathetabbam tasmai yam tam niddesa vāre tattha katamam dukkham ariya saccaṃ
translated: beginning with “Herein, what is the Noble Truth of Suffering?🔽Birth is suffering” , and so on, namely,

original: Jātipi dukkhā”tiādīni padāni gahetvā “jāti veditabbā, jātiyā dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha jātiādīni tāva “tattha katamā jāti? Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhi
analyzed: jāti api dukkhā atiādīni padāni gahetvā jāti veditabbā jātiyā dukkhaṭṭhaḥ veditabba utiādi  vuttam tattha jāti ādīni tāva tattha katamā jāti yā tesam tesam sattānam tamhi
translated: “Birth should be known, the meaning of suffering in birth should be known” , etc.,

original: tamhi sattanikāye jāti sañjātī”ti imassa pana padabhājanīyassa vasena veditabbāni.
analyzed: tamhi satta nikāye jāti sañjāti iti imassa pana padabhājanīyassa vasena veditabbāni
translated: Herein, firstly, birth and so on should be understood according to the analysis of the terms beginning with “Herein, what is birth? It is the birth, taking birth, descent , being born, coming to birth, multiple birth, appearance of the aggregates, acquisition of the sense bases, of those beings in that being class” .

original: 191. Tatrāyaṃ atthavaṇṇanā – tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānanti ayaṃ saṅkhepato anekesaṃ sattānaṃ
analyzed: tatra ayam attha vaṇṇanā tesam tesam sattānam ti ayam saṅkhepataḥ anekesam sattānam
translated: . Here is a commentary on the meaning. Of those beings in that being class : this is in brief🔽.

original: sādhāraṇaniddeso. Yā devadattassa jāti, yā somadattassa jātīti evañhi divasampi kathiyamāne🔽neva sattā pariyādānaṃ gacchanti, na sabbaṃ aparatthadīpanaṃ sijjhati. Imehi pana
analyzed: sādhāraṇa niddesaḥ yā devadattassa jāti yā somadattassa jāti iti evam hi divasam pi kathiyamāne  na iva sattā pariyādānam gacchanti na sabbam aparattha dīpanam sijjhati imehi pana
translated: then even if it were being done day after day,

original: dvīhi padehi na koci satto apariyādinno hoti, na kiñci aparatthadīpanaṃ na sijjhati.
analyzed: dvīhi padehi na koci sattaḥ a pariyādinnaḥ hoti na kiñci aparattha dīpanam na sijjhati
translated: no being would ever be left out, and yet all the rest would not be accomplished. But with these two terms no being is left out, and yet all the rest is accomplished.🔽Hence it was said above: “The kind of birth that any being has” .

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattāna”nti. Tamhi tamhīti ayaṃ jātigativasena anekesaṃ
analyzed: tena vuttam yā tesam tesam sattānam ti tamhi tamhi iti ayam jāti gati vasena anekesam
translated: This is a description of what is common to the many kinds of beings according to their kind.

original: sattanikāyānaṃ sādhāraṇaniddeso. Sattanikāyeti sattānaṃ nikāye, sattaghaṭāyaṃ sattasamūheti attho.
analyzed: satta nikāyānam sādhāraṇa niddesaḥ satta nikāya iti sattānam nikāye satta ghaṭā ayam satta samūhā iti attho
translated: The “kind of being” is the kind of beings, the class of beings, the collection of beings.

original: Jātīti ayaṃ jātisaddo anekattho. Tathā hesa “ekampi jātiṃ, dvepi jātiyo”ti ettha
analyzed: jāti iti ayam jāti saddaḥ aneka atthaḥ tathā ha esa ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ iti ettha
translated: The word “birth” has many meanings. For it is found in the sense of becoming in such passages as “One birth, two births” ,

original: bhave āgato. “Atthi visākhe, nigaṇṭhā nāma samaṇajātikā”ti ettha nikāye. “Tiriyā
analyzed: bhave āgataḥ atthi visākhe nigaṇṭhā nāma samaṇa jātikā ati ettha nikāye tiriyā
translated: in the sense of a class in such passages as “There are, Visākhā, certain ascetics called Niganthas, a class of religious wanderers” ,

original: nāma tiṇajāti nābhiyā uggantvā nabhaṃ āhacca ṭhitā ahosī”ti ettha paññattiyaṃ. “Jāti
analyzed: nāma tiṇa jāti nābhiyāḥ uggantvā nabham āhacca ṭhitā ahosi iti ettha paññattiyam
translated: in the sense of a kind in such passages as “There was a kind of grass called tiriya which grew to the sky and stood there touching it” ,🔽and in the sense of appearance in such passages as “The appearance of Buddhas is rare in the world” .

original: dvīhi khandhehi saṅgahitā”ti ettha saṅkhatalakkhaṇe. “Yaṃ, bhikkhave, mātukucchimhi
analyzed: dvīhi khandhehi saṅgahitā ti ettha saṅkhata lakkhaṇe yam bhikkhave mātukucchimhi
translated: “are included in two aggregates” is in the characteristic of the formed.

original: paṭhamaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ, paṭhamaṃ viññāṇaṃ pātubhūtaṃ, tadupādāya sāvassa jātī”ti🔽ettha paṭisandhiyaṃ. “Sampatijāto, ānanda, bodhisatto”ti ettha pasūtiyaṃ. “Anupakkuṭṭho
analyzed: paṭhamam cittam uppannam paṭhamam viññāṇam pātubhūtam tat upādāya sā avassa jātī iti  ettha paṭisandhiyam sampatijātaḥ ānanda bodhisatto ti ettha pasūtiyam an upakkuṭṭhaḥ
translated: and it is included in two aggregates” , it is in the characteristic of the formed. “Bhikkhus, the first thought that arose and occurred in the mother’s womb was the result of action” ,

original: jātivādenā”ti ettha kule. “Yatohaṃ, bhagini, ariyāya jātiyā jāto”ti ettha ariyasīle.
analyzed: jāti vādena ati ettha kule yatas uham bhagini ariyāya jātiyā ettha ariya sīle
translated: it is in rebirth-linking. “Ānanda, the Bodhisatta was born” , it is in birth. “He was not reproved for the assertion of his birth” , it is in family. “Sister, since I was born of the Noble Birth” , it is in the Noble One’s virtue.

original: Idha panāyaṃ savikāresu paṭhamābhinibbattakkhandhesu vattati. Tasmā jāyamānakavasena
analyzed: idha pana ayam sa vikāresu paṭhama abhinibbatta khandhesu vattati tasmā jāyamānaka vasena
translated: But here it is in the first aggregates that are produced with their modifications. Therefore it is in the sense of being born that it is called birth .

original: jātīti idamettha sabhāvapaccattaṃ. Sañjāyanavasena sañjātīti upasaggena padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ.🔽Okkamanavasena okkanti. Jāyanaṭṭhena vā jāti, sā aparipuṇṇāyatanavasena yuttā. Sañjāyanaṭṭhena
analyzed: jāti iti idam ettha sabhāva paccattam sañjāyana vasena sañjāti iti upasaggena padam vaḍḍhitam  okkamana vasena okkanti jāyana ṭṭhena vā sā aparipuṇṇa āyatana vasena yuttā sañjāyana ṭṭhena
translated: This is its individual essence. The word is extended by the prefix sam- to mean “having been born” .

original: sañjāti, sā paripuṇṇāyatanavasena yuttā. Okkamanaṭṭhena okkanti, sā aṇḍajajalābujavasena
analyzed: sañjāti sā paripuṇṇa āyatana vasena yuttā okkamana ṭṭhena okkanti sā aṇḍa ja jalābu ja vasena
translated: It is in the sense of coming out that it is called coming out . Or alternatively, it is in the sense of being born that it is called birth , and that applies to the case of the incomplete bases. It is in the sense of being born again that it is called coming out to birth , and that applies to the case of the complete bases. It is in the sense of coming out that it is called coming out , and that applies to the case of the egg-born and womb-born.

original: yuttā. Te hi aṇḍakosañca vatthikosañca okkamanti, okkamantāpi pavisantā viya paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: yuttā te hi aṇḍa kosam ca vatthi kosam ca okkamanti okkamantā api pavisantā viya paṭisandhim
translated: They are appropriate to the egg-born and the womb-born, for they enter the egg-shell and the womb respectively, and they take rebirth-linking as they enter.

original: gaṇhanti. Abhinibbattanaṭṭhena abhinibbatti. Sā saṃsedajaopapātikavasena yuttā. Te
analyzed: gaṇhanti abhinibbattana ṭṭhena abhinibbatti sā saṃseda ja opapātika vasena yuttā te
translated: It is generation in the sense of generation. It is appropriate to the moisture-born and the spontaneously born,

original: hi pākaṭā eva hutvā nibbattanti. Ayaṃ tāva sammutikathā.
analyzed: hi pākaṭāḥ eva hutvā nibbattanti ayam tāva sammuti kathā
translated: for they are generated visibly. This, firstly, is the conventional explanation.

original: Idāni paramatthakathā hoti. Khandhā eva hi paramatthato pātubhavanti, na sattā. Tattha
analyzed: idāni paramattha kathā hoti khandhāḥ eva hi paramatthataḥ pātubhavanti na sattā tattha
translated: Now here is the ultimate one. For it is only aggregates that become manifest ultimately, not living beings.

original: ca khandhānanti ekavokārabhave ekassa, catuvokārabhave catunnaṃ, pañcavokārabhave🔽pañcannaṃ gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Pātubhāvoti uppatti. Āyatanānanti ettha tatra tatra
analyzed: ca khandhānanti ekavokāra bhave ekassa catuvokāra bhave catunnam pañcavokāra bhave  pañcannam gahaṇam veditabbam ettha tatra tatra
translated: And here the aggregates should be understood as one aggregate in the case of rebirth in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming,🔽and as five aggregates in the case of rebirth in the sensual kind of becoming.🔽As to the bases: here the inclusion should be understood according to the bases that are generated here and there.

original: uppajjamānāyatanavasena saṅgaho veditabbo. Paṭilābhoti santatiyaṃ pātubhāvoyeva;
analyzed: uppajjamāna āyatana vasena saṅgahaḥ veditabbo paṭilābhaḥ ti santatiyam
translated: As to acquisition: this is just the manifestation in a continuity;🔽for it is only those that are manifesting that are called “acquired.”

original: pātubhavantāneva hi tāni paṭiladdhāni nāma honti. Ayaṃ vuccati jātīti ayaṃ jāti nāma
analyzed: pātubhavantānā iva hi tāni paṭiladdhāni nāma honti ayam vuccati jātī iti ayam jātī nāma
translated: This is called birth:

original: kathiyati. Sā panesā tattha tattha bhave paṭhamābhinibbattilakkhaṇā, nīyyātanarasā,
analyzed: kathiyati sā pana isā tattha tattha bhave paṭhama abhinibbatti lakkhaṇā nīyyātana rasā
translated: It is spoken of. And it has the characteristic of first generation of material body in the various kinds of becoming. Its function is to bring about the manifestation of the material body.

original: atītabhavato idha ummujjanapaccupaṭṭhānā, phalavasena dukkhavicittatāpaccupaṭṭhānā vā.
analyzed: atīta bhavataḥ idha ummujjana paccupaṭṭhānā phala vasena dukkha vicitta tā paccupaṭṭhānā vā
translated: It is manifested as the manifestation of the material body from the past becoming. Or alternatively, it is manifested as the diversity of suffering in the fruit.

original: Idāni ‘jātiyā dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo’ti ayañhi jāti sayaṃ na dukkhā, dukkhuppattiyā🔽pana vatthubhāvena dukkhāti vuttā. Kataradukkhassa panāyaṃ vatthūti? Yaṃ taṃ bālapaṇḍitasuttādīsu
analyzed: idāni jātiyāḥ dukkhaṭṭho veditabbaḥ ti ayañhi jāti sayam na dukkhā dukkha uppattiyā  pana vatthu bhāvena dukkhā ati vuttā katara dukkhassa pana ayam vatthu iti yam tam bāla paṇḍita sutta ādīsu
translated: Now, the meaning of suffering as birth should be understood. For this birth is not itself suffering, but it is called suffering because it is the footing for the arising of suffering.🔽And what is the footing for what? It is the footing for the suffering that is shown by the Blessed One in the Bālapaṇḍita Sutta , etc.,

original: bhagavatāpi upamāvasena pakāsitaṃ āpāyikaṃdukkhaṃ, yañca sugatiyaṃ manussaloke gabbhokkantimūlakādibhedaṃ
analyzed: bhagavatā api upamā vasena pakāsitam āpāyikaṃ dukkham yat ca sugatiyam manussa loke gabbha ukkanti mūlaka ādi bhedam
translated: with the simile of the charcoal pit, and for the suffering that arises in the human world in a happy destiny, which is classed as beginning with descent into the womb.

original: dukkhaṃ uppajjati, tassa sabbassāpi esā vatthu. Tatridaṃ gabbhokkantimūlakādibhedaṃ
analyzed: dukkham uppajjati tassa sabbassa api esā vatthu tatra idam gabbha ukkanti mūlaka ādi bhedam
translated: This is the footing for all that. Herein, the suffering classed as beginning with descent into the womb is as follows.

original: dukkhaṃ – ayañhi satto mātukucchimhi nibbattamāno na uppalapadumapuṇḍarīkādīsu nibbattati.
analyzed: dukkham ayam hi sattaḥ mātukucchimhi nibbattamānaḥ na uppala paduma puṇḍarīka ādīsu nibbattati
translated: For this being, when it is being born in the mother’s womb, is not born in a blue, red or white lotus flower, etc.,

original: Atha kho heṭṭhā āmāsayassa upari pakkāsayassa udarapaṭalapiṭṭhikaṇḍakānaṃ vemajjhe
analyzed: atha kho heṭṭhā āma āsayassa upari pakka āsayassa udara paṭala piṭṭhi kaṇḍakānam vemajjhe
translated: in the midst of the belly between the lower belly and the intestines,

original: paramasambādhe tibbandhakāre nānākuṇapagandhaparibhāvite asuciparamaduggandhapavanavicarite🔽adhimattajegucche kucchippadese pūtimacchapūtikummāsacandanikādīsu kimi viya nibbattati.
analyzed: parama sambādhe tibbandhakāre nānā kuṇapa gandha paribhāvite asuci parama duggandha pavana vicarite  adhimatta jegucche kucchi ppadese pūtimaccha pūti kummāsa candanikā ādīsu kimi viya nibbattati
translated: in a place that is extremely cramped and foul-smelling with various kinds of stench, and is pervaded by a stench of ordure that is worse than any other,🔽in a place that is dark like a black stone and covered with the slime of the womb.

original: So tattha nibbatto dasa māse mātukucchisambhavena usmanā puṭapākaṃ viya paccamāno
analyzed: saḥ tattha nibbattaḥ dasa māse mātukucchi sambhavena usmanā puṭapākam viya paccamāno
translated: And there he is cooked like a pudding in a bag by the heat generated by the mother’s food, drink, etc.,

original: piṭṭhapiṇḍi viya sediyamāno samiñjanapasāraṇādirahito adhimattaṃ dukkhaṃ paccanubhotīti.
analyzed: piṭṭhapiṇḍi viya sediyamāno samiñjana pasāraṇa ādi rahitaḥ adhimattam dukkham paccanubhoti iti
translated: and he is pressed like a cake on a griddle by the growth of the womb, and he suffers exceeding great pain, unable to move or to stretch a limb or to change his posture.

original: Idaṃ tāva ‘gabbhokkantimūlakaṃ’ dukkhaṃ.
analyzed: idam tāva gabbha ukkanti mūlakam dukkham
translated: This is the suffering due to “descent into the womb.”

original: Yaṃ pana so mātu sahasā upakkhalanagamananisīdanauṭṭhānaparivattanādīsu surādhuttahatthagato
analyzed: yam pana saḥ mātu sahasā upakkhalana gamana nisīdana oṭṭhāna parivattana ādīsu
translated: But when the mother suddenly moves about, sits down or gets up, or moves in any way like a cow with a halter in her nose

original: eḷako viya ahiguṇṭhikahatthagato sappapotako viya ca ākaḍḍhanaparikaḍḍhanaodhunananiddhunanādinā
analyzed: eḷakaḥ viya ahi guṇṭhika hattha gataḥ sappa potakaḥ viya ca ākaḍḍhana parikaḍḍhana odhunana niddhunana ādinā
translated: that has been hit, or like a snake’s young in a snake’s coil that has been trodden on,

original: upakkamena adhimattaṃ dukkhamanubhavati, yañca mātu sītudakapānakāle sītanarakūpapanno🔽viya, uṇhayāgubhattādiajjhoharaṇakāle aṅgāravuṭṭhisamparikiṇṇo viya, loṇambilādiajjhoharaṇakāle
analyzed: upakkamena adhimattam dukkham anubhavati yat ca mātu sīta udaka pāna kāle sīta naraka upapannaḥ  viya uṇha yāgu bhatta ādi ajjhoharaṇa kāle aṅgāra vuṭṭhi samparikiṇṇaḥ viya loṇambila ādi ajjhoharaṇa kāle
translated: and when the mother drinks cold water, he suffers as if he were plunged in an icy pool,🔽and when she eats hot food, curry and boiled rice, etc., he suffers as if he were immersed in a pit of coals,🔽and when she drinks salt water, etc., he suffers as if he were being subjected to the ‘molten bronze test’,

original: khārāpaṭicchakādikammakāraṇappatto viya tibbaṃ dukkhamanubhoti – idaṃ ‘gabbhapariharaṇamūlakaṃ’ dukkhaṃ.
analyzed: khārā paṭicchaka ādi kamma kāraṇa ppattaḥ viya tibbam dukkham anubhoti idam gabbha pariharaṇa mūlakam dukkham
translated: This is the suffering rooted in the carrying of the embryo.

original: Yaṃ panassa mūḷhagabbhāya mātuyā mittāmaccasuhajjādīhipi adassanārahe dukkhuppattiṭṭhāne
analyzed: yam panassa mūḷha gabbhāya mātuyā a dassana arahe dukkha uppatti ṭṭhāne
translated: But when the mother is indisposed and cannot be seen by friends, acquaintances, and relatives, who are therefore offended,🔽and when she is afflicted with the suffering that arises from cutting, breaking, etc.,

original: chedanaphālanādīhi dukkhaṃ uppajjati – idaṃ ‘gabbhavipattimūlakaṃ’ dukkhaṃ. Yaṃ vijāyamānāya
analyzed: chedana phālana ādīhi dukkham uppajjati idam gabbha vipatti mūlakam dukkham yam vijāyamānāya
translated: This is the suffering rooted in the delivery. But when the mother is giving birth,

original: mātuyā kammajehi vātehi parivattetvā narakapapātaṃ viya atibhayānakaṃ yonimaggaṃ
analyzed: mātuyā kamma jehi vātehi parivattetvā naraka papātam viya ati bhayānakam yonimaggaṃ
translated: the child, being turned by the mother’s karmically generated winds, enters the fearful passage that is like a hell-pit,

original: paṭipātiyamānassa paramasambādhena yonimukhena tāḷacchiggaḷena viya nikkaḍḍhiyamānassa
analyzed: paṭipātiyamānassa parama sambādhena yonimukhena tāḷa chiggaḷena viya nikkaḍḍhiyamānassa
translated: and is drawn out through the opening of birth, which is extremely narrow, as if through the mouth of a keyhole.

original: mahānāgassa narakasattassa viya ca saṅghāṭapabbatehi vicuṇṇiyamānassa dukkhaṃ uppajjati
analyzed: mahā nāgassa naraka sattassa viya ca saṅghāṭa pabbatehi vicuṇṇiyamānassa dukkham uppajjati
translated: And when he is being crushed by the mountain-like folds of skin, his suffering is like that of a great snake.

original: – idaṃ ‘vijāyanamūlakaṃ’ dukkhaṃ. Yaṃ pana jātassa taruṇavaṇasadisassa sukumārasarīrassa
analyzed: idam vijāyana mūlakam dukkham yam pana jātassa taruṇa vaṇa sadisassa su kumāra sarīrassa
translated: This is suffering rooted in birth. But when he is born and his tender body is like a wound,

original: hatthaggahaṇanhāpanadhovanacoḷaparimajjanādikāle sūcimukhakhuradhāravijjhanaphālanasadisaṃ
analyzed: hattha ggahaṇa nhāpana dhovana coḷa parimajjana ādi kāle sūci mukha khura dhāra vijjhana phālana sadisam
translated: and he suffers as if being pierced and split by needles when he is handled, bathed, washed, rubbed with cloths, and so on,

original: dukkhaṃ uppajjati – idaṃ mātukucchito ‘bahi nikkhamanamūlakaṃ’ dukkhaṃ. Yaṃ tato
analyzed: dukkham uppajjati idam mātukucchitaḥ bahi nikkhamana mūlakam dukkham yam tatas
translated: this is suffering rooted in the departure from the mother’s womb.

original: paraṃ pavattiyaṃ attanāva attānaṃ vadhantassa, acelakavatādivasena ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyuttassa,
analyzed: param pavattiyam attanāva attānam vadhantassa acelakavat ādi vasena ātāpana paritāpana anuyogam anuyuttassa
translated: After that, in the course of existence, there is suffering for one who torments himself and for one who torments himself and others, for one who is devoted to the practice of torturing himself and others,🔽for one who does not eat, for one who hangs himself up, and for one who is angry and does not eat.

translated: and the word “decay” is used to show the function of causing the state of decay. So these three

translated: and that path is not the water, etc., itself, so too

translated: This is how it should be understood as the description of ageing. Herein, since the life span of one who has reached ageing wastes away, ageing is called “the wasting of life” by a figurative use of effect for cause.

analyzed: paṭhamam eva khīra dantāḥ nāma uṭṭhahanti na te thirā tesu pana patitesu puna dantāḥ

analyzed: pana paṭhamam eva tambā api honti kāḷakā api setā api chavi pana sa lohitikā hoti vaḍḍhantānam  vaḍḍhantānam odātānam odāta bhāvo kāḷakānam kāḷaka bhāvo paññāyati jarā vātena pana  pahaṭa kāle vaḷim gaṇhāti sabbam pi sassam vapita kāle setam hoti pacchā nīlam jarā vātena
translated: they are copper-coloured at first, then black, then white. The skin

original: pana pahaṭakāle paṇḍukaṃ hoti. Ambaṅkurenāpi dīpetuṃ vaṭṭati eva. Ayaṃ vuccati jarāti🔽ayaṃ jarā nāma kathiyati. Sā panesā khandhaparipākalakkhaṇā, maraṇūpanayanarasā,
analyzed: pana pahaṭa kāle paṇḍukam hoti ambaṅkurena api dīpetum vaṭṭati eva ayam vuccati jarāti  ayam jarā nāma kathiyati sā pana isā khandha paripāka lakkhaṇā maraṇa upanayana rasā

original: yobbanavināsapaccupaṭṭhānā.

translated: This is what is called ageing. It is characterized by the maturing of the aggregates. Its function is to bring about death. It is manifested as the destruction of youth.

original: Yobbanassa vināsena, balassa upaghātato.

translated: Because of the failure of the senses,🔽Because of the failure of children and wife,🔽Because of the failure of oneself,

analyzed: vippavāsā sata ādīnam putta dārehi attano
translated: Because of the failure of servants,🔽Because of the failure of wealth,🔽Because of the failure of relatives,🔽Because of the failure of friends,🔽Because of the failure of kinsmen,🔽Because of the failure of neighbours,
