analyzed: ca iva bhīyyaḥ  pappoti dukkham yam macco kāyikam mānasam tathā
translated: Because of the failure of companions,🔽Because of the failure of country,🔽Because of the failure of the world,🔽Because of the failure of the body,🔽Because of the failure of life,

original: Sabbametaṃ jarāhetu, yasmā tasmā jarā dukhāti.
analyzed: sabbam etam jarā hetu yasmai tasmai jarā
translated: Because of the failure of beauty,🔽Because of the failure of strength,🔽Because of the failure of happiness,🔽Because of the failure of health,🔽Because of the failure of virtue,🔽Because of the failure of wisdom,🔽Because of the failure of faith,🔽Because of the failure of energy,🔽Because of the failure of mindfulness,🔽Because of the failure of concentration,🔽Because of the failure of understanding,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good way,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good conduct,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good speech,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good thought,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good action,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good avoidance of action,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good view,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good adherence,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good craving,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good lust,🔽Because of the failure of the world’s good hatred,🔽Because of the

original: Maraṇaniddeso
analyzed: maraṇa niddeso
translated: Description of death

original: 193. Maraṇaniddese cavanakavasena cuti; ekacatupañcakkhandhāya cutiyā sāmaññavacanametaṃ.
analyzed: maraṇa niddese cavanaka vasena cuti eka catu pañca kkhandhāya cutiyā sāmañña vacanam etam
translated: In the description of death, “passing away” is death as the act of passing away; it is a term for the passing away of one or four or five aggregates.

original: Cavanatāti bhāvavacanena lakkhaṇanidassanaṃ. Bhedoti cutikhandhānaṃ bhaṅguppattiparidīpanaṃ.
analyzed: cavana tā ti bhāva vacanena lakkhaṇa nidassanam bhedaḥ ti cuti khandhānam bhaṅguppatti paridīpanam
translated: “Breaking up” is the manifestation of the characteristic of breaking up by means of a term for a state. “Dissolution” is the manifestation of the occurrence of the breaking up of the aggregates that have passed away.

original: Antaradhānanti ghaṭassa viya bhinnassa bhinnānaṃ cutikhandhānaṃ yena kenaci pariyāyena
analyzed: antaradhānam ti ghaṭassa viya bhinnassa bhinnānam cuti khandhānam yena kenacid pariyāyena
translated: “Vanishing” is the manifestation of the non-existence of a location of the aggregates that have passed away and broken up by some means or other,

original: ṭhānābhāvaparidīpanaṃ. Maccu maraṇanti maccusaṅkhātaṃ maraṇaṃ. Kālo nāma antako,
analyzed: ṭhāna abhāva paridīpanam maccu saṅkhātam maraṇam kālaḥ nāma antakaḥ
translated: like a broken pot. “Death” is death called “death” . “Time” is the end;

original: tassa kiriyā kālakiriyā. Ettāvatā sammutiyā maraṇaṃ dīpitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tassa kiriyā kāla kiriyā ettāvatā sammutiyā maraṇam dīpitam hoti
translated: the act of that is “the act of time” . So far death as convention has been indicated.

original: Idāni paramatthena dīpetuṃ khandhānaṃ bhedotiādimāha. Paramatthena hi khandhāyeva
analyzed: idāni paramatthena dīpetum khandhānam bheda uti ādim āha paramatthena hi khandhāya iva
translated: Now, in order to indicate it in the ultimate sense, he says, “The breaking up of the aggregates” , etc. For in the ultimate sense it is the aggregates that break up,

original: bhijjanti, na satto nāma koci marati. Khandhesu pana bhijjamānesu satto marati bhinnesu
analyzed: bhijjanti na sattaḥ nāma koci marati khandhesu pana bhijjamānesu sattaḥ marati bhinnesu
translated: not a being called “a person” that dies. But when the aggregates are breaking up, there is the expression “a being dies,” and when they have broken up, there is the expression “a being has died.”

original: matoti vohāro hoti. Ettha ca catupañcavokāravasena khandhānaṃ bhedo, ekavokāravasena
analyzed: vohāro hoti ettha ca catu pañca vokāra vasena khandhānam bhedaḥ eka vokāra vasena
translated: And here the breaking up of the aggregates is according to the fourfold and fivefold method.

original: kaḷevarassa nikkhepo; catuvokāravasena vā khandhānaṃ bhedo, sesadvayavasena kaḷevarassa
analyzed: kaḷevarassa nikkhepo catuvokāra vasena vā khandhānam bhedo sesa dvaya vasena kaḷevarassa
translated: Or else, the ‘breaking up’ is the breaking up of the aggregates in the fourfold way, and the ‘casting aside’ is the casting aside of the corpse in the other two ways.

original: nikkhepo veditabbo. Kasmā? Bhavadvayepi rūpakāyasaṅkhātassa kaḷevarassa sambhavato.
analyzed: nikkhepaḥ veditabbo kasmā bhava dvaye pi rūpa kāya saṅkhātassa kaḷevarassa sambhavato
translated: Why? Because in the two kinds of becoming there is the occurrence of the corpse called the material body.

original: Yasmā vā cātumahārājikādīsu khandhā bhijjanteva, na kiñci nikkhipati, tasmā tesaṃ
analyzed: yasmai vā cātumahārājika ādīsu khandhāḥ bhijjantā iva na kiñci nikkhipati tasmai tesam
translated: Or else, in the case of the gods of the Four Kings, etc., there is only the breaking up of the aggregates, and there is no casting aside of anything.

original: vasena khandhānaṃ bhedo. Manussādīsu kaḷevarassa nikkhepo. Ettha ca kaḷevarassa nikkhepakaraṇato
analyzed: vasena khandhānam bhedaḥ manussa ādīsu kaḷevarassa nikkhepaḥ ettha ca kaḷevarassa nikkhepa karaṇato
translated: Therefore the ‘breaking up’ is in their case, and the ‘casting aside’ is in the case of human beings, etc.

original: maraṇaṃ “kaḷevarassa nikkhepo”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Jīvitindriyassa upacchedoti iminā indriyabaddhasseva maraṇaṃ nāma hoti, anindriyabaddhassa
analyzed: maraṇam kaḷevarassa nikkhepaḥ ti vuttam  jīvitindriyassa upacchedaḥ ti iminā indriya baddhassa iva maraṇam nāma hoti an indriya baddhassa
translated: And here death is called the ‘casting aside of the corpse’ because it is the means of casting aside the corpse.🔽By the words ‘the severance of the life faculty’ he shows that death is only of that which is bound up with faculties, and that there is no such thing as the death of that which is not bound up with faculties.

original: maraṇaṃ nāma natthīti dasseti. ‘Sassaṃ mataṃ, rukkho mato’ti idaṃ pana vohāramattameva.
analyzed: maraṇam nāma natthi iti dasseti sassam matam rukkho mato ti idam pana vohāra mattam eva
translated: But the expressions ‘the crop is dead,’ ‘the tree is dead’ are mere conventional expressions.

original: Atthato pana evarūpāni vacanāni sassādīnaṃ khayavayabhāvameva dīpenti. Idaṃ vuccati
analyzed: atthataḥ pana evarūpāni vacanāni sassa ādīnam khaya vaya bhāvam eva dīpenti idam vuccati
translated: In the ultimate sense, such expressions only signify the destruction and decay of the crop, etc.

original: maraṇanti idaṃ sabbampi maraṇaṃ nāma kathiyati.
analyzed: maraṇanti idam sabbam pi maraṇam nāma kathiyati
translated: All this is called death.

original: Apicettha khaṇikamaraṇaṃ, sammutimaraṇaṃ, samucchedamaraṇanti ayampi bhedo veditabbo.🔽Tattha ‘khaṇikamaraṇaṃ’ nāma pavatte rūpārūpadhammānaṃ bhedo. ‘Tisso mato, phusso
analyzed: apica ittha khaṇika maraṇam sammuti maraṇam samuccheda maraṇam ti ayam pi bhedaḥ veditabbo  tattha khaṇika maraṇam nāma pavatte rūpa arūpa dhammānam bhedaḥ tissaḥ mataḥ phussaḥ
translated: And here there should be understood the following distinctions: momentary death, death as a social convention, death as annihilation.

original: mato’ti idaṃ ‘sammutimaraṇaṃ’ nāma. Khīṇāsavassa appaṭisandhikā kālakiriyā ‘samucchedamaraṇaṃ’🔽nāma. Imasmiṃ panatthe sammutimaraṇaṃ adhippetaṃ. Jātikkhayamaraṇaṃ, upakkamamaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: idam sammutimaraṇam nāma khīṇāsavassa appaṭisandhikā kālakiriyā samuccheda maraṇam  nāma imasmin pana atthe sammuti maraṇam adhippetam jāti khaya maraṇam upakkama maraṇam
translated: Herein, the dissolution of formed mental and physical phenomena in their moment is called momentary death. The saying ‘Tisso mato, phusso mato’ is called death as a social convention. The dying of one whose cankers are destroyed without a remainder is called death as annihilation.🔽But in this context death as a social convention is intended. The words ‘death of one whose life is exhausted’ and ‘death of one whose merit is exhausted’ are also names for it.

original: sarasamaraṇaṃ, āyukkhayamaraṇaṃ, puññakkhayamaraṇantipi tasseva nāmaṃ. Tayidaṃ cutilakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: sa rasa maraṇam āyu khaya maraṇam puñña kkhaya maraṇam ti pi tassa iva nāmam tayidam cuti lakkhaṇam
translated: And it has three characteristics,

original: viyogarasaṃ, vippavāsapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽‘Maraṇassa dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo’ti ettha pana idampi sayaṃ na dukkhaṃ, dukkhassa
analyzed: viyoga rasam vippavāsa paccupaṭṭhānam  maraṇassa dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo ti ettha pana idam api sayam na dukkham dukkhassa
translated: the taste of separation, and manifestation as separation.🔽‘The meaning of pain should be understood in the case of death’ : here, too, this is not itself pain, but it is said to be pain because it is a basis for pain.

original: pana vatthubhāvena dukkhanti vuttaṃ. Maraṇantikāpi hi sārīrikā vedanā, paṭivāte gahitā
analyzed: pana vatthu bhāvena dukkhanti vuttam maraṇa antikā api hi sārīrikā vedanā paṭivāte gahitā
translated: For bodily pain reaches its peak in the case of death,

original: ādittatiṇukkā viya, sarīraṃ nidahanti. Narakanimittādīnaṃ upaṭṭhānakāle balavadomanassaṃ
analyzed: viya sarīram nidahanti naraka nimitta ādīnam upaṭṭhāna kāle balava domanassam
translated: They burn the body as a burning grass torch. When the signs of hell, etc., appear, strong grief arises. So this should be understood as suffering in the sense that it is a basis for these two kinds of suffering.

original: uppajjati. Iti imesaṃ dvinnampi dukkhānaṃ vatthubhāvena dukkhanti veditabbaṃ. Api ca –
analyzed: uppajjati iti imesam dvinnam pi dukkhānam vatthu bhāvena dukkhanti veditabbam api ca
translated: Moreover:

original: Pāpassa pāpakammādi, nimittamanupassato;🔽Bhaddassāpasahantassa, viyogaṃ piyavatthukaṃ.
analyzed: pāpassa pāpa kamma ādi nimittam anupassataḥ  bhaddassa apasahantassa viyogam piya vatthukam
translated: When he sees the sign of evil,🔽And when he cannot bear the good,🔽And when he grieves that what is dear🔽Has changed and gone away,

original: Mīyamānassa yaṃ dukkhaṃ, mānasaṃ avisesato;
analyzed: mīyamānassa yam dukkham mānasam avisesato
translated: And when there is the suffering🔽That comes from being conscious,🔽And when there is the suffering

original: Sabbesañcāpi yaṃ sandhi-bandhanacchedanādikaṃ.
analyzed: yam sandhibandhana chedana ādikam
translated: That comes from cutting up the flesh,🔽And when there is the suffering

original: Vitujjamānamammānaṃ, hoti dukkhaṃ sarīrajaṃ;
analyzed: vitujjamāna mammānam hoti dukkham sarīra jam
translated: That comes from the body’s hurt,🔽Because it cannot be endured,

original: Asayhamappaṭikāraṃ, dukkhassetassidaṃ yato;
analyzed: asayham appaṭikāram dukkhassa itassa idam yatas
translated: And cannot be helped,🔽This suffering, it should be said,

original: Maraṇaṃ vatthu tenetaṃ, dukkhamicceva bhāsitanti.
analyzed: maraṇam vatthu tena itam dukkham iccā iva bhāsitanti
translated: Has death for its occasion.

original: Apica imāni jātijarāmaraṇāni nāma imesaṃ sattānaṃ vadhakapaccāmittā viya otāraṃ gavesantāni
analyzed: apica imāni jāti jarā maraṇāni nāma imesam sattānam vadhaka pacca amittāḥ viya otāram gavesantāni
translated: Moreover, these things called birth, ageing, and death go about seeking an opportunity in these beings as enemies seeking an opportunity in a man.

original: vicaranti. Yathā hi purisassa tīsu paccāmittesu otārāpekkhesu vicarantesu eko vadeyya
analyzed: vicaranti yathā hi purisassa tīsu pacca amittesu otāra apekkhesu vicarantesu ekaḥ vadeyya
translated: For just as when a man has three enemies, and while he is on the watch against them they go about seeking an opportunity in him, one says to the other,

original: – “ahaṃ asukaaraññassa nāma vaṇṇaṃ kathetvā etaṃ ādāya tattha gamissāmi, ettha mayhaṃ🔽dukkaraṃ natthī”ti. Dutiyo vadeyya “ahaṃ tava etaṃ gahetvā gatakāle pothetvā dubbalaṃ🔽karissāmi, ettha mayhaṃ dukkaraṃ natthī”ti. Tatiyo vadeyya – “tayā etasmiṃ pothetvā
analyzed: aham asuka araññassa nāma vaṇṇam kathetvā etam ādāya tattha gamissāmi ettha mayham  dukkaram natthi iti dutiyaḥ vadeyya aham tava etam gahetvā gata kāle pothetvā dubbalam  karissāmi ettha mayham dukkaram natthi iti tatiyaḥ vadeyya tayā etasmim pothetvā
translated: “I will go there, taking him with me, after praising that forest. I have no difficulty in that.” The second would say, “When I have taken him and gone there, I will torment him and weaken him. I have no difficulty in that.” The third would say, “After you have tormented him and weakened him,

original: dubbale kate tiṇhena asinā sīsacchedanaṃ nāma mayhaṃ bhāro hotū”ti. Te evaṃ vatvā tathā kareyyuṃ.🔽Tattha paṭhamapaccāmittassa araññassa vaṇṇaṃ kathetvā taṃ ādāya tattha gatakālo viya
analyzed: dubbale kate tiṇhena asinā sīsacchedanam nāma mayham bhāraḥ hotu uti te evam vatvā tathā kareyyuṃ  tattha paṭhama paccāmittassa araññassa vaṇṇam kathetvā tam ādāya tattha gata kālaḥ viya
translated: “I will go there and praise the forest, and I will bring him back. That is no difficulty for me.” The second would say, “When you have brought him back, I will torment him and weaken him. That is no difficulty for me.” The third would say, “When you have tormented him and weakened him, then it will be my task to cut off his head with a sharp sword.” They would agree to this and do it.

original: suhajjañātimaṇḍalato nikkaḍḍhitvā yattha katthaci nibbattāpanaṃ nāma jātiyā kiccaṃ.
analyzed: suhajja ñāti maṇḍalataḥ nikkaḍḍhitvā yattha katthaci nibbattāpanam nāma jātiyā kiccaṃ
translated: Herein, the first enemy’s bringing him back after praising the forest is like birth’s bringing beings back from the place of death and establishing them in the various kinds of destination.

original: Dutiyassa pothetvā dubbalakaraṇaṃ viya nibbattakkhandhesu nipatitvā parādhīnamañcaparāyaṇabhāvakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: dutiyassa pothetvā dubbala karaṇam viya nibbatta kkhandhesu nipatitvā para adhīna mañca parāyaṇa bhāva karaṇam
translated: The second’s tormenting and weakening him is like the aggregates’ falling into the various orders of beings and making them subject to the various kinds of suffering.

original: jarāya kiccaṃ. Tatiyassa tiṇhena asinā sīsacchedanaṃ viya jīvitakkhayapāpanaṃ maraṇassa🔽kiccanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: jarāya kiccam tatiyassa tiṇhena asinā sīsa chedanam viya jīvita khaya pāpanam maraṇassa  kiccam ti veditabbam
translated: and old age is the work of death. And death is to be understood as the work of death in the way in which the third man’s beheading was the work of the sharp sword.

original: Apicettha jātidukkhaṃ sādīnavamahākantārappaveso viya daṭṭhabbaṃ. Jarādukkhaṃ tattha🔽annapānarahitassa dubbalyaṃ viya daṭṭhabbaṃ. Maraṇadukkhaṃ dubbalassa iriyāpathapavattane
analyzed: api ca ittha jāti dukkham sādīnava mahā kantāra ppavesaḥ viya daṭṭhabbam jarā dukkham tattha  anna pāna rahitassa dubbalyam viya daṭṭhabbam maraṇa dukkham dubbalassa iriyāpatha pavattane
translated: Moreover, here the suffering of birth should be regarded as like being made to enter a great forest infested with dangers,🔽the suffering of old age as like the weakness of one who is without food and drink in that forest,

original: vihataparakkamassa vāḷādīhi anayabyasanāpādanaṃ viya daṭṭhabbanti.
analyzed: vihata parakkamassa vāḷa ādīhi anaya byasana āpādanam viya daṭṭhabbanti
translated: and the suffering of death as like the bringing about of misfortune and calamity by wild beasts, etc., to one who is weak and whose progress is impeded in trying to get out of the forest.

original: Sokaniddeso🔽194. Sokaniddese byasatīti byasanaṃ; hitasukhaṃ khipati viddhaṃsetīti attho. Ñātīnaṃ🔽byasanaṃ ñātibyasanaṃ; corarogabhayādīhi ñātikkhayo ñātivināsoti attho. Tena ñātibyasanena
analyzed: soka niddeso  soka niddese byasati iti byasanam hita sukham khipati viddhaṃseti iti atthaḥ ñātīnam  byasanam ñāti byasanam cora roga bhaya ādīhi ñāti kkhayaḥ ñāti vināsaḥ ti attho tena ñāti byasanena
translated: The Description of Sorrow

original: phuṭṭhassāti ajjhotthaṭassa abhibhūtassa samannāgatassāti attho. Sesesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: phuṭṭhassa ati ajjhotthaṭassa abhibhūtassa samannāgatassa ati attho sesesu pi esa eva nayo
translated: In the description of sorrow, the word byasana is derived from the verb bhyasati . The meaning is that it hurls away and destroys what is good and beneficial. The misfortune of kinsmen is ñātibyasana . The meaning is the loss of kinsmen, the destruction of kinsmen, through thieves, sickness, fear, and so on. Afflicted by the misfortune of kinsmen means oppressed, overcome, possessed. The same method of explanation applies in the other cases.

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso – bhogānaṃ byasanaṃ bhogabyasanaṃ; rājacorādivasena bhogakkhayo
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ bhogānam byasanam bhoga byasanam rāja cora ādi vasena bhoga kkhayaḥ
translated: But there is this difference: the destruction of the enjoyments is the destruction of enjoyments; the exhaustion of enjoyments by kings, thieves, etc., is what is meant.

original: bhogavināsoti attho. Rogoyeva byasanaṃ rogabyasanaṃ; rogo hi ārogyaṃ byasati vināsetīti🔽byasanaṃ. Sīlassa byasanaṃ sīlabyasanaṃ; dussīlyassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Sammādiṭṭhiṃ vināsayamānā
analyzed: bhoga vināso ti attho rogoyā iva byasanam roga byasanam rogaḥ hi ārogyam byasati vināseti iti  byasanam sīlassa byasanam sīla byasanam dussīlyaḥ etam nāmam sammādiṭṭhim vināsayamānā
translated: The destruction of health is the destruction of health; for sickness destroys and ruins health,🔽thus it is a destruction. The destruction of virtue is the destruction of virtue; this is a name for unvirtuousness. The destruction of view is the destruction of view; for a view that arises destroying right view is a destruction.

original: uppannā diṭṭhiyeva byasanaṃ diṭṭhibyasanaṃ. Ettha ca purimāni dve anipphannāni, pacchimāni
analyzed: uppannā diṭṭhiyā iva byasanam diṭṭhi byasanam ettha ca purimāni dve anipphannāni pacchimāni
translated: And here the first two are unarisen,

original: tīṇi nipphannāni tilakkhaṇabbhāhatāni. Purimāni ca tīṇi neva kusalāni na akusalāni.
analyzed: tīṇi nipphannāni purimāni ca tīṇi na iva kusalāni na akusalāni
translated: and the last three are arisen, struck down by the three characteristics. And the first three are neither profitable nor unprofitable.

original: Sīladiṭṭhibyasanadvayaṃ akusalaṃ.🔽Aññataraññatarenāti gahitesu vā yena kenaci aggahitesu vā mittāmaccabyasanādīsu yena
analyzed: sīla diṭṭhi byasana dvayam akusalam  aññatara ññatarena ati gahitesu vā yena kenaci aggahitesu vā mitta amacca byasana ādīsu yena
translated: The two, the destruction of virtue and the destruction of view, are unprofitable.🔽By one or other of these means: whether the others are included or not, among the included, the destruction of friends and companions, etc., by one or another of them.

original: kenaci. Samannāgatassāti samanubandhassa aparimuccamānassa. Aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammenāti
analyzed: kenaci samannāgatassa ati samanubandhassa a parimuccamānassa aññatara aññatarena dukkha dhammena ati
translated: Endowed: possessed, not freed from. By one or other of the kinds of painful things:

original: yena kenaci sokadukkhassa uppattihetunā. Sokoti socanakavasena soko; idaṃ tehi kāraṇehi🔽upajjanakasokassa sabhāvapaccattaṃ. Socanāti socanākaro. Socitattanti socitabhāvo.🔽Antosokoti abbhantare soko. Dutiyapadaṃ upasaggavasena vaḍḍhitaṃ. So hi abbhantare
analyzed: yena kenacid soka dukkhassa uppatti hetunā sokaḥ oti socanaka vasena sokaḥ idam tehi kāraṇehi  upajjanaka sokassa sabhāva paccattam socanā ati socanā karaḥ socitattam socita bhāvo  antosoko ti abbhantare sokaḥ dutiya padam upasagga vasena vaḍḍhitam saḥ hi abbhantare
translated: by any cause of the arising of sorrow and grief. Sorrow is sorrow by the state of sorrowing. This is the individual essence of sorrow that arises by those causes. Sorrows: he makes sorrow. Sorrowfulness: the state of being sorrowful.

original: sukkhāpento viya parisukkhāpento viya uppajjatīti “antosoko antoparisoko”ti vuccati.
analyzed: sukkhāpentaḥ viya parisukkhāpentaḥ viya uppajjati iti antosoko antoparisoko ti vuccati
translated: Inner sorrow: sorrow inside. The second word is extended by prefixing a preposition. For this arises as if it were drying up inside, as if it were drying up completely, and so it is said, “inner sorrow, inner complete sorrow.”

original: Cetaso parijjhāyanāti cittassa jhāyanākāro. Soko hi uppajjamāno aggi viya cittaṃ
analyzed: cetasaḥ cittassa jhāyana ākāraḥ sokaḥ hi uppajjamānaḥ aggi viya cittam
translated: Afflicting the mind: the state of afflicting the mind. For sorrow, arising, afflicts the mind as fire does,🔽it burns the mind, it makes one say, “My mind is burning, nothing is clear to me.”

original: jhāpeti paridahati, “cittaṃ me jhāmaṃ, na me kiñci paṭibhātī”ti vadāpeti. Dukkhito🔽mano dummano, tassa bhāvo domanassaṃ. Anupaviṭṭhaṭṭhena sokova sallanti sokasallaṃ.
analyzed: jhāpeti paridahati cittam me jhāmam na me kiñci paṭibhāti iti vadāpeti dukkhitaḥ  manaḥ dummanaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ domanassam an upaviṭṭha ṭṭhena sokaḥ uva sallanti soka sallam
translated: The state of being distressed,

translated: For when a man is in pain because of the cutting of hands and feet and ears and nose, and when he is lying in the Anathapindika Hall with a bowl of scraps in front of him,🔽then as the maggots emerge from his mouth and crawl over his body, strong bodily pain arises;

original: Janayati yasmā tasmā, dukkhanti visesato vuttanti.
analyzed: janayati yasmā tasmā dukkhanti visesataḥ vuttanti

translated: But those who are overwhelmed by mental pain tear their hair, beat their breasts, roll to and fro,🔽throw themselves down, take to lying on ashes and chaff, hang themselves with a rope,

analyzed: chinna papātam papatanti sattham āharanti visam khādanti rajjuyā ubbandhanti aggim  pavisanti tam tam viparītam vatthum tathā tathā vippaṭisārinaḥ pariḍayhamāna cittā
translated: throw themselves off a cliff, take poison,🔽and set fire to themselves. And those who are remorseful about this or that wrong-doing think about it in this or that way with minds burning with remorse. This is how the source of both kinds of pain should be understood.

original: cintenti. Evaṃ domanassassa ubhinnampi dukkhānaṃ vatthubhāvo veditabbo. Apica –

translated: In the description of upāyāsa , upāyāsa is in the sense of “down-pressing” . It is the weariness of the mind that occurs in the mode of sinking and slouching.

original: nāmaṃ. Balavaṃ āyāso upāyāso. Āyāsitabhāvo āyāsitattaṃ. Upāyāsitabhāvo upāyāsitattaṃ.
analyzed: nāmam balavat āyāsaḥ upāyāsaḥ āyāsita bhāvaḥ āyāsi tattam upāyāsita bhāvaḥ upāyāsi tattam
translated: Name. Strong affliction is upāyāsa. The state of being afflicted is āyāsitatta. The state of being greatly afflicted is upāyāsitatta.

original: Ayaṃ vuccati upāyāsoti ayaṃ upāyāso nāma kathiyati. So panesa byāsattilakkhaṇo, nitthunanaraso,
analyzed: ayam vuccati upāyāsaḥ ti ayam upāyāsaḥ nāma kathiyati saḥ pana isa byāsatti lakkhaṇaḥ nitthunana raso
translated: This is called upāyāsa: this upāyāsa is described as “name.” Its characteristic is affliction. Its function is to afflict. It is manifested as the state of being afflicted.

original: visādapaccupaṭṭhāno.🔽‘Upāyāsassa dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo’ti ettha pana ayampi sayaṃ na dukkho, ubhinnampi🔽dukkhānaṃ vatthubhāvena dukkhoti vutto. analyzed: visāda paccupaṭṭhānaḥ  upāyāsassa dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo ti ettha pana ayam pi sayam na dukkhaḥ ubhinnam pi  dukkhānam vatthu bhāvena dukkho ti vuttaḥ kupitena hi raññā issariyam a chinditvā hata putta bhātikānam  āṇatta vadhānam bhayena aṭavim pavisitvā nilīnānam mahā visāda pattānam dukkha ṭṭhānena  dukkha seyyāya dukkha nisajjāya balavam kāya dukkham uppajjati ettakāḥ no ñātakāḥ ettakā
translated: It is the root of despair.

original: bhogā naṭṭhā’ti cintentānaṃ balavadomanassaṃ uppajjati. Iti imesaṃ dvinnampi dukkhānaṃ🔽vatthubhāvena dukkhoti veditabboti. Apica –

translated: The meaning of pain should be understood in the case of upāyāsa: this is not painful in itself, but it is called painful because it is the basis for both kinds of pain. Moreover,

original: Cittassa paridahanā, kāyassa visādanā ca adhimattaṃ;

translated: The burning of the mind and the drying up of the body are excessive.

analyzed: yam dukkham upāyāsaḥ janeti dukkhaḥ tatas vutto  ettha ca mandagginā tela ādīnam pākaḥ viya sokaḥ tikkhagginā paccamānassa  bhājanataḥ bahi nikkhamanam viya paridevaḥ bahi nikkhanta avasesassa nikkhamitum pi

analyzed: antobhājaneya iva yāva parikkhayā pākaḥ viya upāyāsaḥ daṭṭhabbo  appiya sampayoga niddeso  appiya sampayoga niddese yassa ati ye assa aniṭṭhā ati apariyesitā pariyesitā vā  hontu a pariyesitāḥ vā nāmam eva etam amanāpa ārammaṇānam manasmim na kamanti na pavisanti iti
translated: Despair is like the cooking in the inner vessel itself until exhaustion of the remainder of the oil, etc., that has overflowed and is incapable of overflowing again.🔽The Description of Unpleasant Contact with the Unlovable

original: akantā. Manasmiṃ na appiyanti, na vā manaṃ vaḍḍhentīti amanāpā. Rūpātiādi tesaṃ sabhāvanidassanaṃ.
analyzed: a kantāḥ manasmim na na vā manam vaḍḍhenti iti amanāpāḥ rūpa ati ādi tesam sabhāva nidassanaṃ
translated: In the description of unpleasant contact with the unlovable, “Whose” : of whom. “Unlovely” : unloved. “Unlovable” : not loved. “Unlovely” : not pleasing. “Unlovable” : not pleasing the mind. “Form” , etc., is the indication of their individual essences.

original: Anatthaṃ kāmenti icchantīti anatthakāmā. Ahitaṃ kāmenti icchantīti ahitakāmā. Aphāsukaṃ🔽dukkhavihāraṃ kāmenti icchantīti aphāsukakāmā. Catūhi yogehi khemaṃ nibbhayaṃ vivaṭṭaṃ
analyzed: anattham kāmenti icchanti iti anattha kāmāḥ ahitam kāmenti icchanti iti ahita kāmāḥ a phāsukam  dukkha vihāram kāmenti icchanti iti a phāsuka kāmā catūhi yogehi khemam nibbhayam vivaṭṭam
translated: They wish to make harm, thus they are “wishers of harm.” They wish to make what is unbeneficial, thus they are “wishers of unbeneficial.” They wish to make an abode of suffering, a state of discomfort,🔽thus they are “wishers of discomfort.” They are “bound by four bonds” in that they are bound by the four bonds consisting of the false view of individuality, etc.,🔽

original: na icchanti, sabhayaṃ vaṭṭameva nesaṃ kāmenti icchantīti āyogakkhemakāmā.🔽Apica saddhādīnaṃ vuddhisaṅkhātassa atthassa akāmanato tesaṃyeva hānisaṅkhātassa🔽anatthassa ca kāmanato anatthakāmā. Saddhādīnaṃyeva upāyabhūtassa hitassa akāmanato🔽saddhāhāniādīnaṃ upāyabhūtassa ahitassa ca kāmanato ahitakāmā. Phāsukavihārassa akāmanato🔽aphāsukavihārassa ca kāmanato aphāsukakāmā. Yassa kassaci nibbhayassa akāmanato bhayassa
analyzed: na icchanti sa bhayam vaṭṭam eva kāmenti icchanti iti āyogakkhema kāmāḥ  apica saddhā ādīnam vuddhi saṅkhātassa atthassa akāmanataḥ tesam yeva hāni saṅkhātassa  anatthassa ca kāmanataḥ anattha kāmā saddhā ādīnam yeva upāya bhūtassa hitassa akāmanataḥ  saddhā hāni ādīnam upāya bhūtassa ahitassa ca kāmanataḥ ahita kāmā phāsuka vihārassa a kāmanataḥ  a phāsuka vihārassa ca kāmanataḥ a phāsuka kāmā yassa kassaci nibbhayassa a kāmanataḥ bhayassa
translated: They wish to make harm, thus they are wishers of harm. They wish to make what is unbeneficial, thus they are wishers of unbeneficial. They wish to make an abode of discomfort, a dwelling of pain, thus they are wishers of discomfort. They do not wish for the safe, the fearless, the open, the free from bondage, which is the four bonds, but they wish to make the fearful, the bondage, thus they are wishers of bondage.

original: ca kāmanato ayogakkhemakāmāti evampettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: ca kāmanataḥ a yogakkhema kāmā ti evam pa ittha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: Moreover, they are wishers of harm because they do not wish for the benefit called the increase of faith, etc., and they wish for the harm called their decrease. They are wishers of unbeneficial because they do not wish for the beneficial which is the means to faith, etc., and they wish for the unbeneficial which is the means to the decrease of faith, etc. They are wishers of discomfort because they do not wish for an abode of comfort and they wish for an abode of discomfort. They are wishers of bondage because they do not wish for the fearless of anyone and they wish for fear. This is how the meaning should be regarded here.

original: Saṅgatīti gantvā saṃyogo. Samāgamoti āgatehi saṃyogo. Samodhānanti ṭhānanisajjādīsu
analyzed: saṅgatī iti gantvā saṃyogaḥ samāgamaḥ iti āgatehi saṃyogaḥ ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu
translated: Contact is contact by going. Meeting is contact by coming. Encounter is co-existence in the same place, in the same house, etc.🔽Association is co-existence in the same action.

original: sahabhāvo. Missībhāvoti sabbakiccānaṃ sahakaraṇaṃ. Ayaṃ sattavasena yojanā. Saṅkhāravasena
analyzed: sahabhāvaḥ missībhāvaḥ ti sabba kiccānam sahakaraṇam ayam satta vasena yojanā saṅkhāra vasena
translated: This is the method of interpretation according to the seven kinds of contact.🔽But what is found according to the method of interpretation according to formations can be taken.

original: pana yaṃ labbhati taṃ gahetabbaṃ. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ appiyasampayogo nāma kathiyati.
analyzed: pana yam labbhati tam gahetabbam ayam vuccati iti ayam appiya sampayogaḥ nāma kathiyati
translated: This is called: this is called “association with the unloved.”

original: So aniṭṭhasamodhānalakkhaṇo, cittavighātakaraṇaraso, anatthabhāvapaccupaṭṭhāno.
analyzed: so aniṭṭha samodhāna lakkhaṇo citta vighāta karaṇa raso anattha bhāva paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: Its characteristic is association with the undesirable. Its function is to cause mental pain. It is manifested as a state of misfortune.🔽It is not a single state called “unloved.”

original: So atthato eko dhammo nāma natthi. Kevalaṃ appiyasampayuttānaṃ duvidhassāpi dukkhassa🔽vatthubhāvato dukkhoti vutto. Aniṭṭhāni hi vatthūni samodhānagatāni vijjhanachedanaphālanādīhi
analyzed: so atthataḥ ekaḥ dhammo nāma natthi kevalam appiya sampayuttānam duvidhassa api dukkhassa  vatthu bhāvataḥ dukkho ti vutto aniṭṭhāni hi vatthūni samodhāna gatāni vijjhana chedana phālana ādīhi
translated: It is simply a basis for the two kinds of pain that are associated with the unloved.🔽It is called “painful” because it is a basis for the two kinds of pain. For undesirable objects, when they come into contact, cause bodily pain by piercing, cutting, burning, etc.,

original: kāyikampi dukkhaṃ uppādenti, ubbegajananato mānasampi. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: kāyikam pi dukkham uppādenti ubbega jananataḥ mānasam pi tena itam vuccati
translated: and mental pain by arousing fear. Hence it is said:

original: Disvāva appiye dukkhaṃ, paṭhamaṃ hoti cetasi;
analyzed: disvāva appiye dukkham paṭhamam hoti cetasi
translated: “When one sees the unloved, Pain first arises in the mind;

original: Tadupakkamasambhūta-matha kāye yato idha.
analyzed: tad upakkama sambhūtam atha kāye
translated: Then from the fear that arises, Pain in the body too is found.”

original: Tato dukkhadvayassāpi, vatthuto so mahesinā;
analyzed: tatas dukkha dvayassa api vatthutaḥ saḥ mahesinā
translated: From the two kinds of suffering too,

original: Dukkho vuttoti viññeyyo, appiyehi samāgamoti.
analyzed: dukkhaḥ vuttaḥ ti viññeyyaḥ appiyehi samāgamaḥ ti
translated: That meeting with the unloved is suffering should be understood.

original: Piyavippayoganiddeso🔽200. Piyavippayoganiddeso vuttapaṭipakkhanayena veditabbo. Mātā vātiādi panettha🔽atthakāme sarūpena dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha mamāyatīti mātā. Piyāyatīti pitā. Bhajatīti🔽bhātā. Tathā bhaginī. Mettāyantīti mittā, minantīti vā mittā; sabbaguyhesu anto pakkhipantīti🔽attho. Kiccakaraṇīyesu sahabhāvaṭṭhena amā hontīti amaccā. Ayaṃ amhākaṃ ajjhattikoti
analyzed: piya vippayoga niddeso  piya vippayoga niddesaḥ vutta paṭipakkha nayena veditabbaḥ mātā vā ti ādi pana ittha  attha kāme sarūpena dassetum vuttam tattha mamāyati iti mātā piyāyati iti pitā bhajati iti  bhātā tathā bhaginī mettāyanti iti mittā minanti iti vā mittā sabbaguyhesu antar pakkhipanti iti  atthaḥ kicca karaṇīyesu sahabhāva ṭṭhena amāḥ honti iti amaccāḥ ayam amhākam ajjhattikaḥ ti
translated: The Description of the Unloved

original: evaṃ jānanti ñāyantīti vā ñātī. Lohitena sambandhāti sālohitā. Evametāni padāni atthato🔽veditabbāni. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ piyehi vippayogo nāma kathiyati. So iṭṭhavatthuviyogalakkhaṇo,🔽sokuppādanaraso, byasanapaccupaṭṭhāno.
analyzed: evam jānanti ñāyanti iti vā ñātī lohitena sālohitāḥ evam etāni padāni atthato 🔽veditabbāni ayam vuccati iti ayam piyehi vippayogaḥ nāma kathiyati saḥ iṭṭha vatthu viyoga lakkhaṇo 🔽soka uppādana rasaḥ byasana paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: The description of the unloved should be understood in the opposite way to the loved. Herein, the mother is so called because she bears one , the father because he begets one , the brother because he breathes together with one , the sister because she is of the same blood as one , the friend because he loves one , or because he is one who is friendly , the meaning of mittā being the same as that of mitta ; the counsellor is one who is in common with one in the performance of duties , the relative is one who is known as such because he is known thus “He is ours” or because he is recognized thus “He is ours” ; the blood-relation is one who is related by blood. This is how the words should be understood in their etymological meaning. This is called: this meeting with the unloved is called. Its characteristic is separation from a loved object. Its function is to cause sorrow. It is manifested as adversity.

original: So atthato eko dhammo nāma natthi. Kevalaṃ piyavippayuttānaṃ duvidhassāpi dukkhassa🔽vatthubhāvato dukkhoti vutto. Iṭṭhāni hi vatthūni viyujjamānāni sarīrassa sosanamilāpanādibhāvena
analyzed: so atthataḥ ekaḥ dhammo nāma natthi kevalam piya vippayuttānam duvidhassa api dukkhassa  vatthu bhāvataḥ dukkho ti vuttaḥ iṭṭhāni hi vatthūni viyujjamānāni sarīrassa sosana milāpana ādi bhāvena
translated: But in fact there is no such thing as a single state called “suffering.” It is only the two kinds of suffering, namely, that due to being affected by what is unloved and that due to separation from what is loved,🔽that are called “suffering” because they are the basis for the two kinds of suffering. For when the objects that are loved are separated from, they cause bodily and mental suffering in the form of the wasting of the body, the appearance of wrinkles, etc.,

original: kāyikampi dukkhaṃ uppādenti, ‘yampi no ahosi, tampi no natthī’ti anusocāpanato mānasampi. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: kāyikam pi dukkham uppādenti yam pi no ahosi tam pi no natthi iti mānasam pi tena itam vuccati
translated: and the sorrow of thinking, “What was ours is no more,” respectively. Hence it is said:

original: Ñātidhanādiviyogā, sokasarasamappitā vitujjanti;
analyzed: ñāti dhana ādi viyogā vitujjanti
translated: “Sorrow’s flood, grief’s mighty stream, From loss of loved ones overwhelm;

original: Bālā yato tato yaṃ, dukkhoti mato piyaviyogoti.
analyzed: bālāḥ yatas tatas yam dukkhaṃ ti mataḥ piya viyogo ti
translated: The fool, wherever he may be, Is sure to suffer misery.”

original: Icchāniddeso🔽201. Icchāniddese jātidhammānanti jātisabhāvānaṃ jātipakatikānaṃ. Icchā uppajjatīti🔽taṇhā uppajjati. Aho vatāti patthanā. Na kho panetaṃ icchāya pattabbanti yaṃ etaṃ
analyzed: icchā niddeso  icchā niddese jāti dhammānam ti jāti sabhāvānam jāti pakatikānam icchā uppajjati iti  taṇhā uppajjati aho vata ati patthanā na kho pana etam icchāya pattabbanti yam etam
translated: The Description of Desire

original: “aho vata mayaṃ na jātidhammā assāma, na ca vata no jāti āgaccheyyā”ti evaṃ pahīnasamudayesu
analyzed: aho vata mayam na jāti dhammāḥ assāma na ca vata no jāti āgaccheyya ati evam pahīna samudayesu
translated: In the description of desire, “subject to birth” means having the nature of birth, having birth as their normal state. “Desire arises” means craving arises. “Oh that we were not subject to birth” is the wish. “But that is not to be gained by wishing” means that it is not to be gained by craving. “For what is subject to birth is just this birth” is the abandoning of the origin.

original: sādhūsu vijjamānaṃ ajātidhammattaṃ, parinibbutesu ca vijjamānaṃ jātiyā anāgamanaṃ🔽icchitaṃ, taṃ icchantassāpi maggabhāvanāya vinā apattabbato anicchantassa ca bhāvanāya🔽pattabbato na icchāya pattabbaṃ nāma hoti. Idampīti etampi; upari sesāni upādāya
analyzed: sādhūsu vijjamānam a jāti dhamma ttam parinibbutesu ca vijjamānam jātiyāḥ anāgamanam  icchitam tam icchantassa api magga bhāvanāya vinā a pattabbataḥ an icchantassa ca bhāvanāya  pattabbataḥ na icchāya pattabbam nāma hoti idam pi iti etam pi upari sesāni upādāya
translated: and the state of non-arising of the unborn in the past and the state of non-coming of birth in the future in those who have attained extinction,🔽and he does not get it without developing the path, and he gets it when he develops the path, though he does not want it. So what is not to be got by wanting is not to be got. This is what is called “what one wants is not to be got” .

original: pikāro. Yampicchanti yenapi dhammena alabbhaneyyaṃ vatthuṃ icchanto na labhati, taṃ
analyzed: pikāraḥ yam picchanti yena api dhammena alabbhaneyyam vatthum icchantaḥ na labhati tam
translated: “This too” : the rest are called “this too” because they are included under the above.🔽And what is not to be got should be understood as “wanting what is not to be got is suffering” .

original: alabbhaneyyavatthuicchanaṃ dukkhanti veditabbaṃ. Jarādhammānantiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: dukkhan ti veditabbam jarā dhamma ananti ādīsu pi esa eva nayo
translated: The same method of explanation applies to “subject to sickness” , etc.

original: Evamettha alabbhaneyyavatthūsu icchāva “yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkha”nti vuttā.
analyzed: evam ettha alabbhaneyya vatthūsu icchāva yam piccham na labhati tam pi dukkhanti vuttā
translated: So it is in regard to what is not to be got that “what one wants is not to be got” is stated.

original: Sā alabbhaneyyavatthuicchanalakkhaṇā, tappariyesanarasā, tesaṃ appattipaccupaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: sā a labbha neyya vatthu icchana lakkhaṇā tad pariyesana rasā tesam appatti paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: Its characteristic is wanting what is not to be got. Its function is to seek what is not to be got. It is manifested as the non-acquisition of what is not to be got.

original: Dvinnaṃ pana dukkhānaṃ vatthubhāvato dukkhāti vuttā. Ekacco hi rājā bhavissatīti
analyzed: dvinnam pana dukkhānam vatthu bhāvataḥ dukkhā ati vuttā ekaccaḥ hi rājā bhavissati iti
translated: It is called “suffering” because it is the basis for two kinds of suffering. For someone thinks, “I shall be a king” ,

original: sambhāvito hoti. So chinnabhinnagaṇena parivārito pabbatavisamaṃ vā vanagahanaṃ vā
analyzed: sambhāvitaḥ hoti so chinna bhinna gaṇena parivāritaḥ pabbata visamam vā vana gahanam vā
translated: He is surrounded by a group of people with torn and dirty robes. He goes to a mountain wilderness or a forest wilderness,

original: pavisati. Atha rājā taṃ pavattiṃ ñatvā balakāyaṃ peseti. So rājapurisehi nihataparivāro
analyzed: pavisati atha rājā tam pavattim ñatvā balakāyam peseti saḥ rāja purisehi nihata parivāraḥ
translated: and he is surrounded by a crowd of broken and defeated men. Then the king hears of it and sends out an army. He is surrounded by the king’s men and is killed,

original: sayampi laddhappahāro palāyamāno rukkhantaraṃ vā pāsāṇantaraṃ vā pavisati. Tasmiṃ🔽samaye mahāmegho uṭṭhahati, tibbandhakārā kāḷavaddalikā hoti. Atha naṃ samantato
analyzed: sayam pi laddha pahāraḥ palāyamānaḥ rukkha antaram vā pāsāṇa antaram vā pavisati tasmin  samaye mahā meghaḥ uṭṭhahati tibbandhakārā kāḷavaddalikā hoti atha nam samantataḥ
translated: or he is wounded and escapes and enters a wood or a jungle.🔽Then a great storm arises, with thick darkness and lightning flashes.🔽Then all round him black ants and other creatures surround him and bite him.

original: kāḷakipillikādayo pāṇā parivāretvā gaṇhanti. Tenassa balavakāyadukkhaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: kāḷa kipillika ādayaḥ pāṇā parivāretvā gaṇhanti tena assa balava kāya dukkham uppajjati
translated: He suffers great physical pain.

original: ‘Maṃ ekaṃ nissāya ettakā ñātī ca bhogā ca vinaṭṭhā’ti cintentassa balavadomanassaṃ
analyzed: mam ekam nissāya ettakā ñātī ca bhogā ca vinaṭṭhāti cintentassa balava domanassaṃ
translated: And he thinks, ‘It is because of me that so many kinsmen and possessions have been destroyed,’ and he suffers great mental pain.🔽So this craving should be understood as pain because it is the source of these two kinds of pain.

original: uppajjati. Iti ayaṃ icchā imesaṃ dvinnampi dukkhānaṃ vatthubhāvena dukkhāti veditabbā. Apica –🔽Taṃ taṃ patthayamānānaṃ, tassa tassa alābhato;
analyzed: uppajjati iti ayam icchā imesam dvinnam pi dukkhānam vatthu bhāvena dukkhā ati veditabbā apica  tam tam patthayamānānam tassa tassa alābhato
translated: And besides:🔽The pain that creatures here experience

original: Yaṃ vighātamayaṃ dukkhaṃ, sattānaṃ idha jāyati.
analyzed: yam vighāta mayam dukkham sattānam idha jāyati
translated: As sorrow born of want of wished-for things,

original: Alabbhaneyyavatthūnaṃ, patthanā tassa kāraṇaṃ;
analyzed: a labbha neyya vatthūnam patthanā tassa kāraṇam
translated: The reason why he did not is the fact that they are unobtainable.

original: Yasmā tasmā jino dukkhaṃ, icchitālābhamabravīti.
analyzed: yasmai tasmai jinaḥ dukkham icchita lābham abravīti
translated: Therefore the Jina said that suffering is to be desired and obtained.

original: Upādānakkhandhaniddeso🔽202. Upādānakkhandhaniddese saṃkhittenāti desanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Dukkhañhi ettakāni
analyzed: upādāna kkhandha niddesaḥ  upādāna kkhandha niddese saṃkhittena ati desanam sandhāya vuttam dukkham hi ettakāni
translated: The Description of the Aggregations as Clinging

original: dukkhasatānīti vā ettakāni dukkhasahassānīti vā ettakāni dukkhasatasahassānīti vā
analyzed: dukkha satāni iti vā ettakāni dukkha sahassāni iti vā ettakāni dukkha sata sahassāni iti vā
translated: In the Description of the Aggregations as Clinging, in brief: this is said with reference to the teaching. For suffering cannot be summarized thus, “There are so many hundreds of kinds of suffering,” or “There are so many thousands of kinds of suffering,” or “There are so many hundreds of thousands of kinds of suffering,”

original: saṃkhipituṃ na sakkā, desanā pana sakkā, tasmā “dukkhaṃ nāma aññaṃ kiñci natthi,
analyzed: saṃkhipitum na sakkā desanā pana sakkā tasmā dukkham nāma aññam kiñci natthi
translated: but it can be taught, and so, “There is no other suffering than this;

original: saṃkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā”ti desanaṃ saṅkhipento evamāha. Seyyathidanti
analyzed: saṃkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhā ati desanam saṅkhipentaḥ evam āha seyyathidam ti
translated: in brief, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering,” he summarizes the teaching and says, “And what, bhikkhus, are the five aggregates as objects of clinging? They are as follows.”

original: nipāto; tassa te katameti ceti attho. Rūpūpādānakkhandhotiādīnaṃ attho khandhavibhaṅge vaṇṇitoyeva.
analyzed: nipātaḥ tassa te katame iti ca iti atthaḥ rūpa upādāna khandha uti ādīnam atthaḥ khandha vibhaṅge
translated: Seyyathidaṃ is a particle; the meaning is, “What are they?” The meaning of the aggregates as form, etc., has already been explained in the Description of the Aggregates .

original: ‘Khandhānaṃ dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo’ti ettha pana –
analyzed: khandhānam dukkhaṭṭho veditabbo ti ettha pana
translated: As regards the words, “The meaning of the aggregates as suffering should be understood” ,

original: Jātippabhutikaṃ dukkhaṃ, yaṃ vuttaṃ idha tādinā;
analyzed: jāti ppabhutikam dukkham yam vuttam idha ta ādinā
translated: The suffering beginning with birth, which was stated by the one of such a nature,

original: Avuttaṃ yañca taṃ sabbaṃ, vinā ete na vijjati.
analyzed: avuttam yat ca tam sabbam vinā ete na vijjati
translated: And all that was not stated, that does not exist apart from these.

original: Yasmā tasmā upādāna-kkhandhā saṅkhepato ime;
analyzed: yasmai tasmai upādāna khandhā saṅkhepataḥ ime
translated: Therefore the groups of conceiving Are these in brief;

original: Dukkhāti vuttā dukkhanta-desakena mahesinā.
analyzed: dukkhā ti vuttā dukkhanta desakena mahesinā
translated: The Great Sage has said that they are Ill.

original: Tathā hi indhanamiva pāvako, lakkhamiva paharaṇāni, gorūpamiva ḍaṃsamakasādayo, khettamiva
analyzed: tathā hi indhanam iva pāvakaḥ lakkham iva paharaṇāni go rūpam iva ḍaṃsa makasa ādayo khettam iva
translated: For just as fire does to fuel, or a blow does to the body, or gadflies and flies, etc., do to a cow’s body, or weeds, etc., do to a field, or

original: lāvakā, gāmaṃ viya gāmaghātakā, upādānakkhandhapañcakameva jātiādayo nānappakārehi
analyzed: lāvakāḥ gāmam viya gāma ghātakāḥ upādānakkhandha pañcakam eva jāti ādayaḥ nānappakārehi
translated: villagers do to a king, so too, birth, etc., do to the five aggregates as objects of clinging in various ways.

original: bādhayamānā, tiṇalatādīni viya bhūmiyaṃ, pupphaphalapallavādīni viya rukkhesu, upādānakkhandhesuyeva
analyzed: bādhayamānā tiṇa latā ādīni viya bhūmiyam puppha phala pallava ādīni viya rukkhesu upādāna kkhandhesu yeva
translated: And just as the grass, sticks, etc., on the ground, or the flowers, fruits, and foliage in the trees, are produced in dependence on the earth and trees, so too, the various kinds of suffering are produced in dependence on the aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: nibbattanti. Upādānakkhandhānañca ādidukkhaṃ jāti, majjhedukkhaṃ jarā, pariyosānadukkhaṃ
analyzed: nibbattanti upādāna khandhānaṃ ca ādi dukkham jāti majjhedukkham jarā pariyosāna dukkham
translated: And the beginning suffering of the aggregates as objects of clinging is birth, the middle suffering is ageing, and the end suffering is death.

original: maraṇaṃ. Māraṇantikadukkhābhighātena pariḍayhamānadukkhaṃ soko, tadasahanato lālappanadukkhaṃ
analyzed: maraṇam māraṇa antika dukkha abhighātena pariḍayhamāna dukkham sokaḥ tad asahanataḥ lālappana dukkham
translated: The suffering of being heated by the impact of the suffering that ends in death is sorrow. The suffering of lamentation due to being unable to bear that is despair.

original: paridevo. Tato dhātukkhobhasaṅkhātaaniṭṭhaphoṭṭhabbasamāyogato kāyassa ābādhanadukkhaṃ
analyzed: paridevaḥ tatas dhātu kkhobha saṅkhāta aniṭṭha phoṭṭhabba samāyogataḥ kāyassa ābādhana dukkham
translated: The suffering of the affliction of the body due to the impact of the suffering that ends in despair is pain.

original: dukkhaṃ. Tena bādhiyamānānaṃ puthujjanānaṃ tattha paṭighuppattito cetobādhanadukkhaṃ🔽domanassaṃ. Sokādivuḍḍhiyā janitavisādānaṃ anutthunanadukkhaṃ upāyāso. Manorathavighātappattānaṃ
analyzed: dukkham tena bādhiyamānānam puthujjanānam tattha paṭigha uppattitaḥ cetaḥ bādhana dukkham  domanassam soka ādi vuḍḍhiyā janita visādānam an utthunana dukkham upāyāsaḥ manoratha vighāta ppattānam
translated: and that is suffering. The suffering of mental pain is the pain that arises in ordinary people who are afflicted by that suffering, because of the arising of resistance to it.

original: icchāvighātadukkhaṃ icchitālābhoti evaṃ nānappakārato upaparikkhiyamānā upādānakkhandhāva
analyzed: icchā vighāta dukkham icchitā lābhaḥ ti evam nānā pakārataḥ upaparikkhiyamānāḥ upādāna kkhandhāḥ ava
translated: The suffering of despair is the pain that arises in those who are despondent because of the increase of sorrow, etc., because of the non-excitement of the mind. The suffering of change is the pain that arises in those who are disappointed because of the frustration of their wishes, because of the frustration of their desire. The suffering of suffering is the pain that arises in those who are afflicted by the suffering of suffering, because of the frustration of their desire for the non-occurrence of suffering. Thus the aggregates as objects of clinging, when investigated in these various ways, are suffering.

original: dukkhāti yadetaṃ ekamekaṃ dassetvā vuccamānaṃ anekehi kappehi na sakkā asesato vattuṃ,
analyzed: dukkhā iti yat etam ekam ekam dassetvā vuccamānam anekehi kappehi na sakkā asesataḥ vattum
translated: Now, this teaching, which is given by showing each of these kinds of suffering, cannot be told in full even in many aeons,

original: taṃ sabbampi dukkhaṃ ekajalabindumhi sakalasamuddajalarasaṃ viya yesu kesuci pañcasu
analyzed: tam sabbam pi dukkham eka jala bindumhi sakala samudda jala rasam viya yesu kesuci pañcasu
translated: but the Blessed One has shown all that suffering in brief in any one of the five aggregates as objects of clinging, just as the taste of the ocean water is in one drop of it.

original: upādānakkhandhesu saṅkhipitvā dassetuṃ “saṃkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā”ti bhagavā avocāti.
analyzed: upādānakkhandhesu saṅkhipitvā dassetum saṃkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhā ati bhagavā avoca ati
translated: Thus the Blessed One said: “In brief, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering” .

original: Dukkhasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽2. Samudayasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dukkha sacca niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the truth of suffering is ended.🔽The truth of the origin

original: 203. Samudayasaccaniddese yāyaṃ taṇhāti yā ayaṃ taṇhā. Ponobbhavikāti punabbhavakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: samudaya sacca niddese yā ayam taṇhā ati yā ayam taṇhā ponobbhavikā ati punabbhava karaṇam
translated: In the description of the truth of the origin , “Taṇhā ponobbhavikā” is craving that generates renewed existence.

original: punobbhavo, punobbhavo sīlamassāti ponobbhavikā. Apica punabbhavaṃ deti, punabbhavāya🔽saṃvattati, punappunaṃ bhave nibbattetīti ponobbhavikā. Sā panesā punabbhavassa dāyikāpi🔽atthi adāyikāpi, punabbhavāya saṃvattanikāpi atthi asaṃvattanikāpi, dinnāya paṭisandhiyā🔽upadhivepakkamattāpi. Sā punabbhavaṃ dadamānāpi adadamānāpi, punabbhavāya saṃvattamānāpi
analyzed: punobbhavaḥ punobbhavaḥ sīlam assa ati ponobbhavikā apica punabbhavam deti punabbhavāya  saṃvattati punappunam bhave nibbatteti iti ponobbhavikā sā pana esā punabbhavassa dāyikā api  atthi a dāyikā api punabbhavāya saṃvattanikā api atthi a saṃvattanikā api dinnāya paṭisandhiyā  upadhi vepakka mattā api sā punabbhavam dadamānā api a dadamānā api punabbhavāya saṃvattamānā api
translated: and it is the source of renewed existence, thus it is renewed existence. Or alternatively, it gives renewed existence, it leads to renewed existence, it causes renewed existence again and again, thus it is renewed existence. And this is a giver of renewed existence,🔽it is not a non-giver; it leads to renewed existence, it does not fail to lead to renewed existence; it is a giving of renewed existence, it is not a non-giving of renewed existence. But it is a giver of renewed existence in the sense of giving rebirth-linking when it has been given, and in the sense of merely causing renewed existence when it has not been given. And it leads to renewed existence in the sense of causing rebirth-linking when it has been given,🔽and in the sense of causing renewed existence when it has not been given.

original: asaṃvattamānāpi, dinnāya paṭisandhiyā upadhivepakkamattāpi ponobbhavikā evāti nāmaṃ🔽labhati. Abhinandanasaṅkhātena nandirāgena sahagatāti nandirāgasahagatā, nandirāgena🔽saddhiṃ atthato ekattameva gatāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tatratatrābhinandinīti yatra yatra🔽attabhāvo tatratatrābhinandinī, rūpādīsu vā ārammaṇesu tatratatrābhinandinī; rūpābhinandinī
analyzed: a saṃvattamānā api dinnāya paṭisandhiyā upadhi vepakka mattā api ponobbhavikā eva ati nāmam 🔽labhati abhinandana saṅkhātena nandi rāgena sahagatā ati nandi rāga sahagatā nandi rāgena 🔽saddhim atthataḥ ekattam eva gatā ati vuttam hoti tatra tatra abhinandinī iti yatra yatra 🔽tatra tatra abhinandinī rūpa ādīsu vā ārammaṇesu tatra tatra abhinandinī rūpa abhinandinī
translated: and rebirth is his, thus it is “rebirth-linking” . Furthermore, it gives rebirth, it leads to rebirth, it is reborn again and again, thus it is “rebirth-linking” . But this rebirth-linking is both that which gives rebirth and that which does not give rebirth, and it is both that which leads to rebirth and that which does not lead to rebirth, and it is that which is merely the occurrence of attachment after rebirth-linking has been given. And although it gives rebirth and does not give rebirth, and although it leads to rebirth and does not lead to rebirth, and although it is merely the occurrence of attachment after rebirth-linking has been given, it still gets the name “rebirth-linking” . Associated with joy and with greed for enjoyment: associated with the joy and greed for enjoyment that are called “delight” . It delights here and there: it delights here and there in the various kinds of individual existence, or it delights here and there in the various kinds of objects such as visible forms, etc.

Craving for existence is craving for becoming; it is craving arisen by way of longing for existence, accompanied by the eternalist view.

original: rūpārūpabhavarāgassa ca jhānanikantiyā cetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Vibhave taṇhā vibhavataṇhā;🔽ucchedadiṭṭhisahagatassa rāgassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.🔽Idāni tassā taṇhāya vatthuṃ vitthārato dassetuṃ sā kho panesātiādimāha. Tattha uppajjatīti
analyzed: rūpa arūpa bhava rāgassa ca adhivacanam vibhave taṇhā vibhava taṇhā  uccheda diṭṭhi sahagatassa rāgassa itam adhivacanaṃ  idāni tassā taṇhāya vatthum vitthārataḥ dassetum sā kho pana isā iti ādim āha tattha uppajjati iti
translated: The meaning is that it delights in visible-data, sound, odour, flavour, and tangible-data, and in ideas. Seyyathidaṃ = “such as this.” The meaning is: “what?” Kāmataṇhā = craving for sense desires. Craving in the sense desires is craving for sense desires. This is a term for the defilement consisting of the five strands of sense pleasure. Craving in being is craving for being. This is a term for lust for the fine-material and immaterial kinds of being that arise with the eternity view. Craving for non-being is craving for non-being. This is a term for lust accompanied by the annihilation view.

original: 3. Nirodhasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā

analyzed: tassāḥ uppatti dassitā tattha iva abhāvam dassetum sā kho pana isā iti ādim āha tattha yathā
translated: The arising of it has been shown. In order to show its non-existence there, he said: “But, bhikkhus, that delight is unestablished in the world, not to be found.” Herein, just as

original: puriso khette jātaṃ tittaalābuvalliṃ disvā aggato paṭṭhāya mūlaṃ pariyesitvā chindeyya,
analyzed: purisaḥ khette jātam titta alābu vallim disvā aggataḥ paṭṭhāya mūlam pariyesitvā chindeyya
translated: The arising of it has been shown. Now in order to show its non-existence there, he said, “But, bhikkhus, that craving … “ . Herein, just as a man, having seen a wild vine growing in a field, would search for its root, cutting it from the top,🔽and it would gradually wither away and come to nothing,

original: sā anupubbena milāyitvā appavattiṃ gaccheyya. Tato tasmiṃ khette tittaalābu niruddhā🔽pahīnāti vucceyya. Evameva khette tittaalābu viya cakkhādīsu taṇhā. Sā ariyamaggena🔽mūlacchinnā nibbānaṃ āgamma appavattiṃ gacchati. Evaṃ gatā pana tesu vatthūsu khette
analyzed: sā anupubbena milāyitvā appavattim gaccheyya tatas tasmin khette titta alābu niruddhā  pahīnā ati vucceyya evam eva khette titta alābu viya cakkha ādīsu taṇhā sā ariya maggena  mūlacchinnā nibbānam āgamma appavattim gacchati evam gatā pana tesu vatthūsu khette
translated: then in that field the wild vine would be said to have been stopped and abandoned,🔽so too, craving in the eye, etc., is like the wild vine in the field. That, cut off at the root by the noble path, comes to nothing on arriving at extinction. And when it has done so, it is not evident in the bases as the wild vine is in the field.

original: tittaalābu viya na paññāyati. Yathā ca aṭavito core ānetvā nagarassa dakkhiṇadvāre🔽ghāteyyuṃ, tato aṭaviyaṃ corā matāti vā māritāti vā vucceyyuṃ; evameva aṭaviyaṃ corā
analyzed: titta alābu viya na paññāyati yathā ca aṭavito core ānetvā nagarassa dakkhiṇa dvāre  ghāteyyum tatas aṭaviyam corāḥ matā ati vā māritā ati vā vucceyyum evam eva aṭaviyam corāḥ
translated: And just as if they were to bring thieves caught in the act from the hinterlands and execute them at the southern gate,

original: viya yā cakkhādīsu taṇhā, sā dakkhiṇadvāre corā viya nibbānaṃ āgamma niruddhattā
analyzed: viya yā cakkha ādīsu taṇhā sā dakkhiṇa dvāre corāḥ viya nibbānam āgamma niruddhattā
translated: and then it would be said that the thieves had been executed in the town, so too, craving in the eye, etc., is like the thieves in the hinterlands. That, like the thieves at the southern gate, is stopped by the noble path and comes to nothing on arriving at extinction.

original: nibbāne niruddhā. Evaṃ niruddhā pana tesu vatthūsu aṭaviyaṃ corā viya na paññāyati.
analyzed: nibbāne niruddhā evam niruddhā pana tesu vatthūsu aṭaviyam corāḥ viya na paññāyati
translated: and in Nibbāna they cease. But though they cease there, they are not evident there, like thieves in a deserted forest.

original: Tenassā tattheva nirodhaṃ dassento “cakkhuṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā
analyzed: tena assā tattha eva nirodham dassento cakkhum loke piya rūpam sāta rūpam ettha isā taṇhā
translated: So, showing their cessation there, he said: “In the eye there is a form dear and agreeable … Herein that craving …

original: pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhatī”tiādimāha. Sesamettha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: pahīyamānā pahīyati ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati iti ādim āha sesam ettha uttānattham eva ati
translated: ceases … and comes to have” . The rest is evident in meaning.

original: Nirodhasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Maggasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nirodha sacca niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the truth of cessation is ended.

original: 205. Maggasaccaniddese ayamevāti aññamaggapaṭikkhepanatthaṃ niyamanaṃ. Ariyoti taṃtaṃmaggavajjhehi
translated: In the description of the truth of the path, “this is the only way”: this is a definition for the purpose of precluding other ways. “Noble”: it is noble because it is far from defilements that are to be avoided by the various paths,

original: kilesehi ārakattā ariyabhāvakarattā ariyaphalapaṭilābhakarattā ca ariyo. Aṭṭhaṅgāni
analyzed: kilesehi ārakattā ariya bhāva karattā ariya phala paṭilābha karattā ca ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgāni
translated: because it causes the state of being noble, and because it causes the attainment of the noble fruit. It has eight factors,

original: assāti aṭṭhaṅgiko. Svāyaṃ caturaṅgikā viya senā, pañcaṅgikaṃ viya tūriyaṃ aṅgamattameva
analyzed: assa ati caturaṅgikā viya senā pañcaṅgikam viya tūriyam aṅgam attam eva
translated: thus it is the Noble Eightfold Path. This is merely a factor, like a four-division army or a five-part drum,

original: hoti, aṅgavinimutto natthi. Nibbānatthikehi maggīyati, nibbānaṃ vā maggati, kilese
analyzed: hoti aṅga vinimuttaḥ natthi nibbānatthikehi maggīyati nibbānam vā maggati kilese
translated: and there is nothing apart from the factors. It is called “path” because it is gone by those who seek Nibbāna, or because it causes Nibbāna,

original: vā mārento gacchatīti maggo. Seyyathidanti so katamoti ceti attho.🔽Idāni aṅgamattameva maggo hoti, aṅgavinimmutto natthīti dassento sammādiṭṭhi…pe…
analyzed: vā mārentaḥ gacchati iti maggo so katamaḥ iti ca iti attho  idāni aṅga mattam eva maggaḥ hoti aṅga vinimmuttaḥ natthi iti dassento sammādiṭṭhipe
translated: and he goes by means of it, thus it is a path . What is that? is the meaning of seyyathidaṃ .🔽Now, in order to show that the path is only a component factor and that there is no path apart from the component factors, he said: Right view …

original: sammāsamādhīti āha. Tattha sammā dassanalakkhaṇā sammādiṭṭhi. Sammā abhiniropanalakkhaṇo
analyzed: sammāsamādhi iti āha tattha sammā dassana lakkhaṇā sammā diṭṭhi sammā abhiniropana lakkhaṇaḥ
translated: … right concentration. Herein, right view has the characteristic of seeing rightly.🔽Right thought has the characteristic of rightly directing .🔽Right speech has the characteristic of rightly including .

original: sammāsaṅkappo. Sammā pariggahalakkhaṇā sammāvācā. Sammā samuṭṭhāpanalakkhaṇo sammākammanto.
analyzed: sammā saṅkappaḥ sammā pariggaha lakkhaṇā sammā vācā sammā samuṭṭhāpana lakkhaṇo sammā kammanto
translated: Right action has the characteristic of rightly originating .🔽Right livelihood has the characteristic of rightly purifying .🔽Right effort has the characteristic of rightly exerting .

original: Sammā vodānalakkhaṇo sammāājīvo. Sammā paggahalakkhaṇo sammāvāyāmo. Sammā upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇā
analyzed: sammā vodāna lakkhaṇo sammāājīvaḥ sammā paggaha lakkhaṇo sammāvāyāmaḥ sammā upaṭṭhāna lakkhaṇā
translated: Right mindfulness has the characteristic of rightly attending .

original: sammāsati. Sammā samādhānalakkhaṇo sammāsamādhi.🔽Tesu ca ekekassa tīṇi tīṇi kiccāni honti, seyyathidaṃ – sammādiṭṭhi tāva aññehipi
analyzed: sammā sati sammā samādhāna lakkhaṇaḥ sammāsamādhi  tesu ca ekekassa tīṇi tīṇi kiccāni honti seyyathidam sammādiṭṭhi tāva aññehi pi
translated: Right concentration has the characteristic of rightly concentrating .

original: attano paccanīkakilesehi saddhiṃ micchādiṭṭhiṃ pajahati, nirodhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti,
analyzed: attano paccanīka kilesehi saddhim micchādiṭṭhim pajahati nirodham ārammaṇam karoti
translated: And each of these has three functions. Right view, for instance, abandons wrong view together with its associated states and the kinds of resultant consciousness that originate with it, and it makes the non-arising of the unarisen rightness with the same associations a condition for the arousing of the unarisen rightness with the same associations, and it makes the non-arising of the unarisen wrongness with the same associations a condition for the maintenance of the arisen rightness with the same associations.

original: sampayuttadhamme ca passati tappaṭicchādakamohavidhamanavasena asammohato. Sammāsaṅkappādayopi
analyzed: sampayutta dhamme ca passati tad paṭicchādaka moha vidhamana vasena asammohataḥ sammāsaṅkappa ādayaḥ pi
translated: and he sees the states associated with it by way of the removal of the delusion that conceals them.🔽Right thought, etc.,

original: tatheva micchāsaṅkappādīni ca pajahanti, nirodhañca ārammaṇaṃ karonti. Visesato panettha🔽sammāsaṅkappo sahajātadhamme abhiniropeti, sammāvācā sammā pariggaṇhāti, sammākammanto🔽sammā samuṭṭhāpeti, sammāājīvo sammā vodāpeti, sammāvāyāmo sammā paggaṇhāti, sammāsati
analyzed: tathā iva micchāsaṅkappa ādīni ca pajahanti nirodham ca ārammaṇam karonti visesato pana ittha  sammā saṅkappaḥ sahajāta dhamme abhiniropeti sammā vācā sammā pariggaṇhāti sammā kammanto  sammā samuṭṭhāpeti sammā ājīvaḥ sammā vodāpeti sammā vāyāmaḥ sammā paggaṇhāti sammā sati
translated: abandon wrong thought, etc., and make cessation their object. But in particular,🔽right thought impels the states that are conascent with it; right speech, right action, and right livelihood are its purification;

original: sammā upaṭṭhāti, sammāsamādhi sammā padahati.🔽Apicesā sammādiṭṭhi nāma pubbabhāge nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā hoti, maggakāle ekakkhaṇā
analyzed: sammā upaṭṭhāti sammā samādhi sammā padahati  apica isā sammādiṭṭhi nāma pubbabhāge nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā hoti magga kāle ekakkhaṇā
translated: right effort is its exertion; right mindfulness is its establishment; and right concentration is its foundation.

original: ekārammaṇā, kiccato pana dukkhe ñāṇantiādīni cattāri nāmāni labhati. Sammāsaṅkappādayopi
analyzed: eka ārammaṇā kiccataḥ pana dukkhe ñāṇa nti ādīni cattāri nāmāni labhati sammāsaṅkappa ādayaḥ pi
translated: As to the rest, right view is of various moments and various objects in the earlier stage, but at the time of the path it is of a single moment and a single object. But as to function, it gets the four names beginning with “knowledge of suffering.”

original: pubbabhāge nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā honti, maggakāle ekakkhaṇā ekārammaṇā. Tesu sammāsaṅkappo
analyzed: pubbabhāge nānā akkhaṇāḥ nānā ārammaṇāḥ honti magga kāle eka kkhaṇāḥ eka ārammaṇā tesu sammāsaṅkappaḥ
translated: Right thought, etc., are of various moments and various objects in the earlier stage, but at the time of the path they are of a single moment and a single object. Herein, right thought

original: kiccato nekkhammasaṅkappotiādīni tīṇi nāmāni labhati. Sammāvācādayo tayo pubbabhāge
analyzed: kiccataḥ nekkhamma saṅkappa uti ādīni tīṇi nāmāni labhati sammāvācā ādayo pubba bhāge
translated: The three beginning with renunciation of sense desires get their names from their function.🔽The three beginning with right speech are abstentions and also intentions at different moments and with different objects in the prior stage,

original: nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā viratiyopi honti cetanāyopi, maggakkhaṇe pana viratiyova.🔽Sammāvāyāmo sammāsatīti idampi dvayaṃ kiccato sammappadhānasatipaṭṭhānavasena cattāri
analyzed: nānā akkhaṇāḥ nānā ārammaṇāḥ viratiyaḥ api honti cetanāyaḥ api magga kkhaṇe pana viratiyaḥ uva  sammā vāyāmaḥ sammā satī iti idam pi dvayam kiccato sammappadhāna sati paṭṭhāna vasena cattāri
translated: but at the moment of the path they are only abstentions.🔽The two, right effort and right mindfulness, get their names as the four right endeavours and the four foundations of mindfulness respectively, both from their function.

original: nāmāni labhati. Sammāsamādhi pana pubbabhāgepi maggakkhaṇepi sammāsamādhiyeva.
analyzed: nāmāni labhati sammāsamādhi pana pubbabhāge pi magga kkhaṇe pi
translated: But right concentration is right concentration both in the prior stage and at the moment of the path.

original: Iti imesu aṭṭhasu dhammesu bhagavatā nibbānādhigamāya paṭipannassa yogino bahūpakārattā
analyzed: iti imesu aṭṭhasu dhammesu bhagavatā nibbāna adhigamāya paṭipannassa yoginaḥ bahu upakāra ttā
translated: So right view is taught first by the Blessed One in these eight things because it is helpful to the yogin who is practising for the realization of Nibbāna,

original: paṭhamaṃ sammādiṭṭhi desitā. Ayañhi “paññāpajjoto paññāsattha”nti ca vuttā. Tasmā
analyzed: paṭhamam sammādiṭṭhi desitā ayam hi paññāpajjotaḥ paññā satthanti ca vuttā tasmā
translated: for this is called “the light of understanding” and “the sword of understanding” .

original: etāya pubbabhāge vipassanāñāṇasaṅkhātāya sammādiṭṭhiyā avijjandhakāraṃ viddhaṃsetvā
analyzed: etāya pubba bhāge vipassanā ñāṇa saṅkhātāya sammādiṭṭhiyā avijja andhakāram viddhaṃsetvā
translated: So in the prior stage the yogin, by means of right view called insight knowledge, destroys the darkness of ignorance,🔽and then, by slaying the thieves of defilements, he reaches Nibbāna in safety. Hence it was said:

original: kilesacore ghātento khemena yogāvacaro nibbānaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tena vuttaṃ “nibbānādhigamāya
analyzed: kilesa core ghātentaḥ khemena yogāvacaraḥ nibbānam pāpuṇāti tena vuttam nibbāna adhigamāya
translated: “For the realization of Nibbāna

original: paṭipannassa yogino bahūpakārattā paṭhamaṃ sammādiṭṭhi desitā”ti.
analyzed: paṭipannassa yoginaḥ bahu upakāra attā paṭhamam sammādiṭṭhi desitā ati
translated: Translation: paṭipannassa yogino bahūpakārattā paṭhamaṃ sammādiṭṭhi desitā”ti |

original: Sammāsaṅkappo pana tassā bahūpakāro, tasmā tadanantaraṃ vutto. Yathā hi heraññiko
analyzed: sammāsaṅkappo pana tassāḥ bahu upakāraḥ tasmā tad anantaram vuttaḥ yathā hi heraññiko
translated: sammāsaṅkappo pana tassā bahūpakāro, tasmā tadanantaraṃ vutto | yathā hi heraññiko

original: hatthena parivattetvā parivattetvā cakkhunā kahāpaṇaṃ olokento ‘ayaṃ kūṭo, ayaṃ cheko’ti
analyzed: hatthena parivattetvā parivattetvā cakkhunā kahāpaṇam olokento ayam kūṭaḥ ayam cheko ti
translated: hatthena parivattetvā parivattetvā cakkhunā kahāpaṇaṃ olokento ‘ayaṃ kūṭo, ayaṃ cheko’ti

original: jānāti, evaṃ yogāvacaropi pubbabhāge vitakkena vitakketvā vipassanāpaññāya olokayamāno
analyzed: jānāti evam yogāvacaraḥ api pubba bhāge vitakkena vitakketvā vipassanā paññāya olokayamāno
translated: jānāti, evaṃ yogāvacaropi pubbabhāge vitakkena vitakketvā vipassanāpaññāya olokayamāno

original: ‘ime dhammā kāmāvacarā, ime dhammā rūpāvacarādayo’ti jānāti. Yathā vā pana purisena
analyzed: ime dhammā kāma avacarā ime dhammā rūpāvacara ādayo ti jānāti yathā vā pana purisena
translated: ‘ime dhammā kāmāvacarā, ime dhammā rūpāvacarādayo’ti jānāti | yathā vā pana purisena

original: koṭiyaṃ gahetvā parivattetvā parivattetvā dinnaṃ mahārukkhaṃ tacchako vāsiyā tacchetvā
analyzed: koṭiyam gahetvā parivattetvā parivattetvā dinnam mahā rukkham tat śakaḥ vāsiyā tat śetvā
translated: koṭiyaṃ gahetvā parivattetvā parivattetvā dinnaṃ mahārukkhaṃ tacchako vāsiyā tacchetvā

original: kamme upaneti, evaṃ vitakkena vitakketvā vitakkatvā dinnadhamme yogāvacaro paññāya
analyzed: kamme upaneti evam vitakkena vitakketvā vitakkatvā dinna dhamme yogāvacaro paññāya
translated: kamme upaneti, evaṃ vitakkena vitakketvā vitakketvā dinnadhamme yogāvacaro paññāya

original: ‘ime dhammā kāmāvacarā, ime dhammā rūpāvacarā’tiādinā nayena paricchinditvā kamme
analyzed: ime dhammā kāma avacarāḥ ime dhammāḥ rūpa avacarāḥ ati ādinā nayena paricchinditvā kamme
translated: ‘ime dhammā kāmāvacarā, ime dhammā rūpāvacarā’tiādinā nayena paricchinditvā kamme

original: upaneti. Tena vuttaṃ ‘sammāsaṅkappo pana tassā bahūpakāro, tasmā tadanantaraṃ vutto”ti.
analyzed: upanā iti tena vuttam sammāsaṅkappo pana tassā bahu upakāro tasmā tad anantaram vuttaḥ iti
translated: So it is said: ‘Right thought is a great help to it, and that is why it is mentioned next’ .

original: Svāyaṃ yathā sammādiṭṭhiyā, evaṃ sammāvācāyapi upakārako. Yathāha – “pubbe kho, gahapati, vitakketvā vicāretvā pacchā vācaṃ bhindatī”ti. Tasmā tadanantaraṃ sammāvācā vuttā.
analyzed: su ayam yathā sammādiṭṭhiyā evam sammāvācāya api upakārakaḥ yathā āha pubbe kho gahapati vitakketvā vicāretvā pacchā vācam bhindati iti tasmā tad anantaram sammāvācā vuttā
translated: And this right thought is a help to right speech too, as it is said: ‘Householder, after thinking and pondering, one then speaks’ . That is why right speech is mentioned next.

original: Yasmā pana ‘idañcidañca karissāmā’ti paṭhamaṃ vācāya saṃvidahitvā loke kammante payojenti, tasmā vācā kāyakammassa upakārikāti sammāvācāya anantaraṃ sammākammanto vutto.
analyzed: yasmai pana idam ca idam ca karissāma ati paṭhamam vācāya saṃvidahitvā loke kammante payojenti tasmai vācā kāya kammassa upakārikā ati sammāvācāya anantaram sammākammantaḥ vutto
translated: But since they first make a verbal agreement to do this or that and then in the world they set about the work, speech is a help to bodily work. That is why right action is mentioned next to right speech.

original: Catubbidhaṃ pana vacīduccaritaṃ, tividhaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ pahāya ubhayaṃ sucaritaṃ
analyzed: catubbidham pana vacī duccaritam tividham kāya duccaritam pahāya ubhayam su caritam
translated: But since one who is fulfilling the fourfold verbal good conduct and the threefold bodily good conduct

original: pūrentasseva yasmā ājīvaṭṭhamakasīlaṃ pūrati, na itarassa, tasmā tadubhayānantaraṃ sammāājīvo vutto.
analyzed: pūrentassa iva yasmai ājīva ṭṭhamaka sīlam pūrati na itarassa tasmai tad ubhaya anantaram sammāājīvaḥ vutto
translated: fulfils the eighth branch of the noble ones’ way of living, which is purification of livelihood, and not any other, that is why right livelihood is mentioned next to the two,

original: Evaṃ suddhājīvena ‘parisuddho me ājīvo’ti ettāvatā paritosaṃ akatvā suttappamattena
analyzed: evam suddhājīvena parisuddhaḥ me ājīvaḥ ti ettāvatā paritosam a katvā su tappa mattena
translated: and so, having purified his livelihood thus, he should not be satisfied with that alone, thinking ‘My livelihood is purified’, but he should go on to

original: viharituṃ na yuttaṃ, atha kho sabbairiyāpathesu idaṃ vīriyamārabhitabbanti dassetuṃ
analyzed: viharitum na yuttam atha kho sa bairiyāpathesu idam vīriyam ārabhitabbanti dassetum
translated: It is not proper to live without it. But it is proper to live with it in all postures. In order to show this,

original: tadanantaraṃ sammāvāyāmo vutto.
analyzed: tad anantaram sammāvāyāmaḥ vutto
translated: right effort is mentioned next.

original: Tato āraddhavīriyenāpi kāyādīsu catūsu vatthūsu sati suppatiṭṭhitā kātabbāti dassanatthaṃ tadanantaraṃ sammāsati desitā.
analyzed: tatas āraddhavīriyena api kāya ādīsu catūsu vatthūsu sati suppatiṭṭhitā kātabbā ati dassana ttham tad anantaram sammāsati desitā
translated: Then, after one has begun to make effort, mindfulness should be well established in the four foundations beginning with the body. In order to show this, right mindfulness is taught next.

original: Yasmā pana evaṃ suppatiṭṭhitā sati samādhissa upakārānupakārānaṃ dhammānaṃ gatiyo
analyzed: yasmā pana evam su patiṭṭhitā sati samādhissa upakāra anupakārānam dhammānam gatiyaḥ
translated: But when mindfulness is well established in this way, it is able to investigate the conditions that are helpful and harmful to concentration and

original: samanvesitvā pahoti ekattārammaṇe cittaṃ samādhātuṃ, tasmā sammāsatianantaraṃ sammāsamādhi desitoti veditabbo.
analyzed: samanvesitvā pahoti ekatta ārammaṇe cittam samādhātum tasmā sammā sati anantaram sammāsamādhi desito ti veditabbo
translated: to direct the mind to a single object. Therefore right concentration should be understood as taught next after right mindfulness.

original: Sammādiṭṭhiniddese “dukkhe ñāṇa”ntiādinā catusaccakammaṭṭhānaṃ dassitaṃ. Tattha purimāni
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi niddese dukkhe ñāṇa nti ādinā catu sacca kammaṭṭhānam dassitam tattha purimāni
translated: In the description of right view, the four foundations of mindfulness, beginning with “knowledge of suffering,” are shown. Herein, the first

original: dve saccāni vaṭṭaṃ, pacchimāni vivaṭṭaṃ. Tesu bhikkhuno vaṭṭe kammaṭṭhānābhiniveso
analyzed: dve saccāni vaṭṭam pacchimāni vivaṭṭam tesu bhikkhunaḥ vaṭṭe kammaṭṭhāna abhinivesaḥ
translated: two truths are the round of rebirths, and the last two are the escape from the round. The bhikkhu’s application of the foundation of mindfulness is

original: hoti, vivaṭṭe natthi abhiniveso. Purimāni hi dve saccāni “pañcakkhandhā dukkhaṃ,
analyzed: hoti vivaṭṭe natthi abhiniveso purimāni hi dve saccāni pañca kkhandhāḥ dukkham
translated: to the round, not to the escape. For the first two truths are the five aggregates as objects of clinging, which are suffering,🔽and the origin of that suffering is the origin of the five aggregates.

original: taṇhā samudayo”ti evaṃ saṅkhepena ca “katame pañcakkhandhā? Rūpakkhandho”tiādinā
analyzed: taṇhā samudayo ti evam saṅkhepena ca katame pañca kkhandhāḥ rūpa kkhandhaḥ ti ādinā
translated: and craving is its origin” .

original: nayena vitthārena ca ācariyassa santike uggaṇhitvā vācāya punappunaṃ parivattento🔽yogāvacaro kammaṃ karoti; itaresu pana dvīsu saccesu “nirodhasaccaṃ iṭṭhaṃ kantaṃ
analyzed: nayena vitthārena ca ācariyassa santike uggaṇhitvā vācāya punappunam parivattento  yogāvacaro kammam karoti itaresu pana dvīsu saccesu nirodha saccam iṭṭham kantam
translated: And he does so in brief and in detail from the teacher. Having done so, he recites it again and again by heart.🔽In the case of the other two truths, he does the preliminary work by learning: “The cessation truth is desirable, lovely,  agreeable, and the path truth is desirable, lovely, agreeable” .

original: manāpaṃ, maggasaccaṃ iṭṭhaṃ kantaṃ manāpa”nti evaṃ savaneneva kammaṃ karoti. So evaṃ
analyzed: manāpam maggasaccam iṭṭham kantam manāpanti evam savanena iva kammam karoti saḥ evam
translated: Doing the preliminary work in this way,

original: kammaṃ karonto cattāri saccāni ekena paṭivedhena paṭivijjhati, ekābhisamayena abhisameti;🔽dukkhaṃ pariññāpaṭivedhena paṭivijjhati, samudayaṃ pahānapaṭivedhena, nirodhaṃ sacchikiriyapaṭivedhena,
analyzed: kammam karonto cattāri saccāni ekena paṭivedhena paṭivijjhati eka abhisamayena abhisameti  dukkham pariññā paṭivedhena paṭivijjhati samudayam pahāna paṭivedhena nirodham sacchikiriya paṭivedhena
translated: he penetrates the four truths with a single penetration and realizes them with a single realization.🔽He penetrates suffering with the penetration of full understanding, he penetrates origination with the penetration of abandoning, he penetrates cessation with the penetration of realizing, and he penetrates the path with the penetration of developing.

original: maggaṃ bhāvanāpaṭivedhena paṭivijjhati; dukkhaṃ pariññābhisamayena…pe… maggaṃ bhāvanābhisamayena abhisameti.
analyzed: maggam bhāvanā paṭivedhena paṭivijjhati dukkham pariññā abhisamayena pe maggam bhāvanā abhisamayena abhisameti
translated: He realizes suffering with the realization of full understanding, … he realizes the path with the realization of developing.

original: Evamassa pubbabhāge dvīsu saccesu uggahaparipucchāsavanadhāraṇasammasanapaṭivedho🔽hoti, dvīsu savanapaṭivedhoyeva; aparabhāge tīsu kiccato paṭivedho hoti, nirodhe🔽ārammaṇapaṭivedho. Tattha sabbampi paṭivedhañāṇaṃ lokuttaraṃ, savanadhāraṇasammasanañāṇaṃ🔽lokiyaṃ kāmāvacaraṃ, paccavekkhaṇā pana pattasaccassa hoti. Ayañca ādikammiko. Tasmā🔽sā idha na vuttā. Imassa ca bhikkhuno pubbe pariggahato ‘dukkhaṃ parijānāmi, samudayaṃ🔽pajahāmi, nirodhaṃ sacchikaromi, maggaṃ bhāvemī’ti ābhogasamannāhāramanasikārapaccavekkhaṇā
analyzed: evam assa pubba bhāge dvīsu saccesu uggaha paripucchā savana dhāraṇa sammasana paṭivedhaḥ  hoti dvīsu aparabhāge tīsu kiccato paṭivedho hoti nirodhe  ārammaṇa paṭivedhaḥ tattha sabbam pi paṭivedha ñāṇam lokuttaram savana dhāraṇa sammasana ñāṇam  lokiyam kāmāvacaram paccavekkhaṇā pana pattasaccassa hoti ayaṃ ca ādikammikaḥ tasmā  sā idha na vuttā imassa ca bhikkhuno pubbe pariggahataḥ dukkham parijānāmi samudayam  pajahāmi nirodham sacchikaromi maggam bhāvemi iti ābhoga samannāhāra manasikāra paccavekkhaṇā
translated: So in the earlier stage there is penetration by learning, asking, and insight in the case of the first two truths,🔽and by learning and insight in the case of the last two. In the later stage there is penetration by function in the case of the first three truths,🔽and by object in the case of the fourth. Herein, all the knowledge of penetration is supramundane. The knowledge of learning, remembering, and insight🔽is mundane and belongs to the sense sphere. But the reviewing is in one who has reached the truths. And this bhikkhu is a beginner.🔽Therefore it is not mentioned here. And this bhikkhu has previously discerned the four noble truths by comprehension in the way beginning, “I discern suffering, I discern the origin of suffering … I discern the way leading to the cessation of suffering” .🔽🔽

original: natthi, pariggahato paṭṭhāya hoti; aparabhāge pana dukkhaṃ pariññātameva hoti…pe…🔽maggo bhāvitova hoti.
analyzed: natthi pariggahato paṭṭhāya hoti aparabhāge pana dukkham pariññātam eva hoti pe 🔽maggaḥ bhāvito va hoti
translated: So in the earlier stage there is penetration by learning, asking, and insight in the case of the first two truths, and by learning and insight in the case of the last two. In the later stage there is penetration by function in the case of the first three truths, and by object in the case of the fourth. Herein, all the knowledge of penetration is supramundane. The knowledge of learning, remembering, and insight is mundane and belongs to the sense sphere. The reviewing is that of one who has reached Arahantship. But this bhikkhu is only a beginner.
