analyzed: yam paṭicca phalam eti saḥ paccayaḥ paṭicca ati na vinā tena tam a paccakkhitvā iti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning of condition is that of being helpful. It is a condition because it is helpful.🔽The meaning of “it comes” is that it arises and occurs.

original: Etīti uppajjati ceva pavattati cāti attho. Api ca upakārakaṭṭho paccayaṭṭho. Avijjā
analyzed: eti iti uppajjati ca iva pavattati ca ati atthaḥ api ca upakāraka ṭṭhaḥ paccaya ṭṭhaḥ avijjā
translated: Moreover, the meaning of condition is the meaning of being helpful.

original: ca sā paccayo cāti avijjāpaccayo. Tasmā avijjāpaccayā.
analyzed: ca sā paccayaḥ ca ati avijjā paccayo tasmai avijjā paccayā
translated: It is ignorance and a condition, thus it is ignorance-condition. Therefore, with ignorance as condition.

original: Saṅkhatamabhisaṅkharontīti saṅkhārā. Apica avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārasaddena
analyzed: saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharonti iti saṅkhārāḥ api ca avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra saddena
translated: They form the formed, thus they are formations. Moreover, formations have ignorance as condition, and formations that have come into existence through ignorance.

original: āgatasaṅkhārā cāti duvidhā saṅkhārā. Tattha puññāpuññāneñjābhisaṅkhārā tayo, kāyavacīcittasaṅkhārā
analyzed: āgata saṅkhārā ca ati duvidhā saṅkhārā tattha puñña apuñña aneñja abhisaṅkhārā tayo kāya vacī citta saṅkhārā
translated: Thus there are two kinds of formations. Herein, the three kinds of formations, namely, meritorious, demeritorious, and imperturbable formations, and the three kinds of formations, namely, bodily, verbal, and mental formations,

original: tayoti ime cha avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā. Te sabbepi lokiyakusalākusalacetanāmattameva honti.
analyzed: tayo ti ime cha avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā te sabbe pi lokiya kusala akusala cetanā mattam eva honti
translated: are the six kinds of formations with ignorance as condition. All of them are simply mundane wholesome and unwholesome volition.

original: Saṅkhatasaṅkhāro, abhisaṅkhatasaṅkhāro, abhisaṅkharaṇasaṅkhāro, payogābhisaṅkhāroti
analyzed: saṅkhata saṅkhāraḥ abhisaṅkhata saṅkhāraḥ abhisaṅkharaṇa saṅkhāraḥ payoga abhisaṅkhāraḥ iti
translated: The formed formation, the formed formation as formed, the formation as forming, and the formation as exertion.

original: ime pana cattāro saṅkhārasaddena āgatasaṅkhārā. Tattha “aniccā vata saṅkhārā”tiādīsu🔽vuttā sabbepi sappaccayā dhammā ‘saṅkhatasaṅkhārā’ nāma. Kammanibbattā tebhūmakā
analyzed: ime pana cattāro saṅkhāra saddena āgata saṅkhārā tattha aniccāḥ vata saṅkhārā ti ādīsu  vuttā sabbe api sa paccayāḥ dhammāḥ saṅkhatasaṅkhārāḥ nāma kamma nibbattā tebhūmakā
translated: But these four kinds of formations that are included under the heading of the word “formation” are all included in the following three kinds:🔽All formed things with conditions are called “formed formations.”🔽The material and immaterial dhammas of the three planes that are produced by kamma are called “formed formations as formed.”

original: rūpārūpadhammā ‘abhisaṅkhatasaṅkhārā’ti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttā. Tepi “aniccā vata saṅkhārā”ti
analyzed: rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ abhisaṅkhata saṅkhārā ti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttā te pi aniccāḥ vata saṅkhārā ti
translated: They are also included in the verse, “Impermanent, alas, are formations … .”

original: ettheva saṅgahaṃ gacchanti. Visuṃ pana nesaṃ āgataṭṭhānaṃ na paññāyati. Tebhūmakakusalākusalacetanā🔽pana ‘abhisaṅkharaṇakasaṅkhāro’ti vuccati. Tassa “avijjāgatoyaṃ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo
analyzed: ettha iva saṅgaham gacchanti visum pana nesam āgata ṭṭhānam na paññāyati tebhūmaka kusala akusala cetanā  pana abhisaṅkharaṇaka saṅkhāro ti vuccati tassa a vijjā gataḥ yam bhikkhave purisa puggalo
translated: But they are not found separately in the texts.🔽The profitable and unprofitable volition of the three planes is called “the formation as forming.”

original: puññañce abhisaṅkharotī”tiādīsu āgataṭṭhānaṃ paññāyati. Kāyikacetasikaṃ pana vīriyaṃ
analyzed: puññañce abhisaṅkharoti itiādīsu āgata ṭṭhānam paññāyati kāyika cetasikam pana vīriyam
translated: It is found in the texts in such passages as “Monks, this person is overcome by ignorance and deluded about the profitable and unprofitable, about what is coarse and refined, about the blameable and the blameless, about the unprofitable and the profitable.🔽He forms the formation of merit, he forms the formation of demerit, he forms the formation of the imperturbable” .

original: ‘payogābhisaṅkhāro’ti vuccati. So “yāvatikā abhisaṅkhārassa gati, tāvatikaṃ gantvā
analyzed: payoga abhisaṅkhāraḥ ti vuccati saḥ yāvatikā abhisaṅkhārassa gati tāvatikam gantvā
translated: Bodily and mental energy is called “the formation as exertion.” It is found in such passages as “Having gone to the end of exertion” .

original: akkhāhataṃ maññe aṭṭhāsī”tiādīsu āgato.🔽Na kevalañca eteyeva, aññepi “saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjantassa kho, āvuso visākha,
analyzed: akkhāhatam maññe aṭṭhāsi iti ādīsu āgataḥ  na kevalam ca ete yeva aññe pi saññā vedayita nirodham samāpajjantassa kho āvuso visākha
translated: and so on.

original: bhikkhuno paṭhamaṃ nirujjhati vacīsaṅkhāro, tato kāyasaṅkhāro, tato cittasaṅkhāro”tiādinā
analyzed: bhikkhuno paṭhamam nirujjhati vacī saṅkhāro tato kāya saṅkhāro tato citta saṅkhāro tiādinā
translated: And not only these, but also many other formations are included under the heading of “formations” in such passages as: “Friend Visāka, when a bhikkhu enters upon the cessation of perception and feeling, first his verbal formations cease, then his bodily formations, then his mental formations” .

original: nayena saṅkhārasaddena āgatā anekasaṅkhārā. Tesu natthi so saṅkhāro, yo saṅkhatasaṅkhāre
analyzed: nayena saṅkhāra saddena āgatāḥ aneka saṅkhārā tesu na atthi so saṅkhāro yaḥ saṅkhata saṅkhāre
translated: Among these, there is no formation that does not come under the heading of “formed” .

original: saṅgahaṃ na gaccheyya. Ito paraṃ saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇantiādīsu yaṃ vuttaṃ taṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṅgaham na gaccheyya itas param saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam ti ādīsu yat vuttam tat vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: What is said in the following sections beginning with “With formations as condition, consciousness” should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Avutte pana vijānātīti viññāṇaṃ. Namatīti nāmaṃ. Ruppatīti rūpaṃ. Āye tanoti, āyatañca
analyzed: a vutte pana vijānāti iti viññāṇam namati iti nāmam ruppati iti rūpam āye tanoti āyatam ca
translated: But “consciousness” is what cognizes ; “mentality” is what bows down ; “materiality” is what is molested ; “sense base” is what extends ;

original: nayatīti āyatanaṃ. Phusatīti phasso. Vedayatīti vedanā. Paritassatīti taṇhā. Upādiyatīti
analyzed: nayati iti āyatanam phusati iti phassaḥ vedayati iti vedanā paritassati iti taṇhā upādiyati iti
translated: “contact” is what touches ; “feeling” is what feels ; “craving” is what thirsts ; “clinging” is what clings ;

original: upādānaṃ. Bhavati bhāvayati cāti bhavo. Jananaṃ jāti. Jīraṇaṃ jarā. Maranti etenāti
analyzed: upādānam bhavati bhāvayati ca ati bhavaḥ jananam jāti jīraṇam jarā maranti etena ati
translated: “becoming” is what comes to be and what causes to come to be ; “birth” is the being born ; “ageing” is the ageing ; “death” is what causes to die ;

original: maraṇaṃ. Socanaṃ soko. Paridevanaṃ paridevo. Dukkhayatīti dukkhaṃ; uppādaṭṭhitivasena
analyzed: maraṇam socanam soko paridevanam paridevaḥ dukkhayati iti dukkham uppāda ṭṭhiti vasena
translated: and death. The sorrowing is sorrow. The lamenting is lamentation. It oppresses is suffering. Or it breaks in two by arising and by destruction is what is meant.

original: vā dvedhā khaṇatīti dukkhaṃ. Dummanassa bhāvo domanassaṃ. Bhuso āyāso upāyāso.🔽Sambhavantīti nibbattanti. Na kevalañca sokādīheva, atha kho sabbapadehi ‘sambhavantī’ti🔽saddassa yojanā kātabbā. Itarathā hi “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”ti vutte kiṃ karontīti
analyzed: vā dvedhā khaṇati iti dukkham dummanassa bhāvaḥ domanassam bhusaḥ āyāsaḥ upāyāsaḥ  sambhavanti iti nibbattanti na kevalañca soka ādīhi iva atha kho sabba padehi sambhavanti iti  saddassa yojanā kātabbā itarathā hi avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ati vutte kim karonti iti
translated: It breaks in two is suffering. The state of having mental disquiet is grief. The state of having bodily disquiet is despair.

original: na paññāyeyyuṃ. “Sambhavantī”ti pana yojanāya sati “avijjā ca sā paccayo cāti avijjāpaccayo;
analyzed: na paññāyeyyum sambhavanti iti pana yojanāya sati avijjā ca sā paccayaḥ ca ati avijjā paccayo
translated: They come into being is they are generated. And not only by sorrow, etc., but the word ‘come into being’ should be construed with all the terms. For otherwise, when it is said ‘With ignorance as condition there are formations,’ it would not be known what they do. But when the construction is made in this way, then it is discerned that ‘ignorance is a condition and these are conditioned states,

original: tasmā avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā sambhavantī”ti paccayapaccayuppannavavatthānaṃ kataṃ
analyzed: tasmai avijjā paccayāḥ saṅkhārāḥ sambhavanti iti paccaya paccaya uppanna vavatthānam katam
translated: so with ignorance as condition there are formations.’ So the distinction between condition and conditioned state is made.

original: hoti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: hoti esa nayo sabbattha
translated: This is the method in all cases.

original: Evanti niddiṭṭhanayanidassanaṃ. Tena avijjādīheva kāraṇehi, na issaranimmānādīhīti
analyzed: evam ti niddiṭṭha naya nidassanam tena avijjā ādīhi iva kāraṇehi na issara nimmāna ādīhi iti
translated: Thus is the indication of the method stated. By ignorance, etc., as causes, not by a divine creator, etc., is what is meant.

original: dasseti. Etassāti yathāvuttassa. Kevalassāti asammissassa sakalassa vā. Dukkhakkhandhassāti
analyzed: dassa iti etassa ati yathā vuttassa kevalassa ati asammissassa sakalassa vā dukkha kkhandhassa ati
translated: he shows. Of this: of what has been said. Entire: unmixed, or complete. Mass of suffering:

original: dukkhasamūhassa, na sattassa, na sukhasubhādīnaṃ. Samudayoti nibbatti. Hotīti sambhavati.
analyzed: dukkha samūhassa na sattassa na sukha subha ādīnam samudayo ti nibbatti hoti iti sambhavati
translated: aggregate of suffering, not of a being, not of pleasure, beauty, and so on. Origin: generation. Comes to be: comes into existence.

original: Evamettha atthato viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: evam ettha atthataḥ viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: Thus the exposition should be known here as to meaning.

original: ‘Lakkhaṇādito’ti avijjādīnaṃ lakkhaṇādito, seyyathidaṃ – aññāṇalakkhaṇā avijjā, sammohanarasā,
analyzed: lakkhaṇa āditaḥ ti avijjā ādīnam lakkhaṇa āditaḥ sā iyyathidam aññāṇa lakkhaṇā avijjā sammohana rasā
translated: As to characteristic, etc.: the characteristic, etc., of ignorance, and so on, are as follows. The characteristic of ignorance is unknowing; its function is to confuse;

original: chādanapaccupaṭṭhānā, āsavapadaṭṭhānā. Abhisaṅkharaṇalakkhaṇā saṅkhārā, āyūhanarasā,
analyzed: chādana paccupaṭṭhānāḥ āsava padaṭṭhānāḥ abhisaṅkharaṇa lakkhaṇāḥ saṅkhārāḥ āyūhana rasāḥ
translated: its manifestation is concealment; its proximate cause is defilement. The characteristic of formations is forming; their function is accumulating;

original: cetanāpaccupaṭṭhānā, avijjāpadaṭṭhānā. Vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ viññāṇaṃ, pubbaṅgamarasaṃ,
analyzed: cetanā paccupaṭṭhānā avijjā padaṭṭhānā vijānana lakkhaṇam viññāṇam pubbaṅgama rasam
translated: their manifestation is volition; their proximate cause is ignorance. The characteristic of consciousness is cognizing; its function is to precede ;

original: paṭisandhipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, saṅkhārapadaṭṭhānaṃ, vatthārammaṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ vā. Namanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi paccupaṭṭhānam saṅkhāra padaṭṭhānam vattha ārammaṇa padaṭṭhānam vā namana lakkhaṇam
translated: its manifestation is rebirth-linking; its proximate cause is formations, or its proximate cause is the physical basis and object. The characteristic of mentality is bending on ;

original: nāmaṃ, sampayogarasaṃ, avinibbhogapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, viññāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: nāmam sampayoga rasam avinibbhoga paccupaṭṭhānam viññāṇa padaṭṭhānam ruppana lakkhaṇam
translated: its function is associating; its manifestation is non-division; its proximate cause is consciousness. The characteristic of materiality is being molested ;

original: rūpaṃ, vikiraṇarasaṃ, abyākatapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, viññāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Āyatanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: rūpam vikiraṇa rasam abyākata paccupaṭṭhānam viññāṇa padaṭṭhānam āyatana lakkhaṇam
translated: Materiality has the characteristic of being molested. Its function is to be scattered. It is manifested as the sign of the unformed. Its proximate cause is consciousness. The characteristic of the sense bases is that they are doors.

original: saḷāyatanaṃ, dassanādirasaṃ, vatthudvārabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, nāmarūpapadaṭṭhānaṃ.
translated: Materiality has the characteristic of being molested. Its function is to be scattered. It is manifested as the unmanifest. Its proximate cause is consciousness. The characteristic of the sixfold base is seeing, etc. Its function is to be the door of the physical basis. It is manifested as the physical basis and the door. Its proximate cause is mentality-materiality.

original: Phusanalakkhaṇo phasso, saṅghaṭṭanaraso, saṅgatipaccupaṭṭhāno, saḷāyatanapadaṭṭhāno.🔽Anubhavanalakkhaṇā vedanā, visayarasasambhogarasā, sukhadukkhapaccupaṭṭhānā, phassapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: phusana lakkhaṇo phassaḥ saṅghaṭṭana raso saṅgati paccupaṭṭhāno saḷāyatana padaṭṭhāno  anubhavana lakkhaṇā vedanā visaya rasa sambhoga rasā sukha dukkha paccupaṭṭhānā phassa padaṭṭhānā
translated: The characteristic of contact is touching. Its function is impingement. It is manifested as the coming together. Its proximate cause is the sixfold base.🔽The characteristic of feeling is experiencing. Its function is to enjoy an object. It is manifested as pleasure and pain. Its proximate cause is contact.

original: Hetulakkhaṇā taṇhā, abhinandanarasā, atittibhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā, vedanāpadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: hetu lakkhaṇā taṇhā abhinandana rasā atitti bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā vedanā padaṭṭhānā
translated: The characteristic of craving is being the cause. Its function is to delight. It is manifested as non-contentment. Its proximate cause is feeling.

original: Gahaṇalakkhaṇaṃ upādānaṃ, amuñcanarasaṃ, taṇhādaḷhattadiṭṭhipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, taṇhāpadaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: gahaṇa lakkhaṇam upādānam amuñcana rasam taṇhā daḷha tta diṭṭhi paccupaṭṭhānam taṇhā padaṭṭhānam
translated: The characteristic of assuming is grasping. Its function is not to let go. It is manifested as the firmness of craving and views. Its proximate cause is craving.

original: Kammakammaphalalakkhaṇo bhavo, bhāvanabhavanaraso, kusalākusalābyākatapaccupaṭṭhāno,
analyzed: kamma kamma phala lakkhaṇaḥ bhavaḥ bhāvana bhavana raso kusala akusala abyākata paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: The characteristic of becoming is action and the result of action. Its function is to bring into existence. It is manifested as the wholesome, the unwholesome, and the indeterminate.

original: upādānapadaṭṭhāno. Jātiādīnaṃ lakkhaṇādīni saccavibhaṅge vuttanayeneva veditabbāni.
analyzed: upādāna padaṭṭhānaḥ jāti ādīnam lakkhaṇa ādīni sacca vibhaṅge vutta nayena iva veditabbāni
translated: Its proximate cause is assuming. The characteristics, etc., of birth, etc., should be understood in the way stated in the Description of the Truths .

original: Evamettha lakkhaṇāditopi viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: evam ettha lakkhaṇa āditaḥ pi viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here “as to character and so on.”

original: ‘Ekavidhādito’ti ettha avijjā aññāṇādassanamohādibhāvato ekavidhā, appaṭipattimicchāpaṭipattito
analyzed: ekavidha āditaḥ ti ettha avijjā aññāṇa dassana moha ādi bhāvataḥ ekavidhā appaṭipatti micchā paṭipattitaḥ
translated: As to the singlefold, etc., here ignorance is singlefold as unknowing, non-seeing, delusion, etc.;🔽it is twofold as non-practice and wrong practice;🔽it is threefold as associated with the three kinds of feeling;

original: duvidhā tathā saṅkhārāsaṅkhārato, vedanāttayasampayogato tividhā, catusaccaappaṭivedhato🔽catubbidhā, gatipañcakādīnavacchādanato pañcavidhā, dvārārammaṇato pana sabbesupi
analyzed: duvidhā tathā saṅkhāra asaṅkhārataḥ tividhā catur acca appaṭivedhato  catubbidhā gati pañcaka ādīnava chādanato pañcavidhā dvāra ārammaṇato pana sabbesu pi
translated: it is fourfold as non-penetration of the four truths;

original: arūpadhammesu chabbidhatā veditabbā.🔽Saṅkhārā sāsavavipākadhammadhammādibhāvato ekavidhā, kusalākusalato duvidhā tathā
analyzed: arūpa dhammesu chabbidha tā veditabbā  saṅkhārā sa āsava vipāka dhamma dhamma ādi bhāvataḥ ekavidhā kusala akusalataḥ duvidhā tathā
translated: it is fivefold as concealing the danger in the five kinds of destinies; but as to doors and objects it should be understood as sixfold in all immaterial states.🔽 Formations are singlefold as states subject to cankers, states with ripening, states that are ideas, etc.;

original: parittamahaggatahīnamajjhimamicchattaniyatāniyatato, tividhā puññābhisaṅkhārādibhāvato,
analyzed: tividhā puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādi bhāvataḥ
translated: they are twofold as profitable and unprofitable; likewise as limited and exalted, as inferior, medium, and medium-to-superior, as determinate and indeterminate, and as kamma-result and not kamma-result; they are threefold as the kinds of accumulation of merit, etc.;

original: catubbidhā catuyonisaṃvattanato, pañcavidhā pañcagatigāmito.
analyzed: catubbidhā catu yoni saṃvattanataḥ pañcavidhā pañca gati gāmitaḥ
translated: they are fourfold as the four kinds of generation of kamma-result; they are fivefold as the five kinds of destiny.

original: Viññāṇaṃ lokiyavipākādibhāvato ekavidhaṃ, sahetukāhetukādito duvidhaṃ, bhavattayapariyāpannato
analyzed: viññāṇam lokiya vipāka ādi bhāvataḥ ekavidham sa hetuka ahetuka āditaḥ duvidham bhava taya pariyāpannato
translated: Consciousness is singlefold as mundane and as ripening; it is twofold as with root-cause and without root-cause, etc.; it is threefold as included in the three kinds of becoming;

original: vedanāttayasampayogato ahetukaduhetukatihetukato ca tividhaṃ, yonigativasena catubbidhaṃ pañcavidhañca.
analyzed: ca tividham yoni gati vasena catubbidham pañcavidham ca
translated: It is threefold as associated with the three kinds of feeling, and as root-causeless, single-rooted, and twofold-rooted. It is fourfold and fivefold according to the kinds of destiny and rebirth- linking.

original: Nāmarūpaṃ viññāṇasannissayato kammapaccayato ca ekavidhaṃ, sārammaṇānārammaṇato duvidhaṃ, atītādito tividhaṃ, yonigativasena catubbidhaṃ pañcavidhañca.
analyzed: nāma rūpam viññāṇa sannissayato kamma paccayato ca ekavidham sārammaṇa anārammaṇataḥ duvidham atīta āditaḥ tividham yoni gati vasena catubbidham pañcavidham ca
translated: Mentality-materiality is singlefold as the support for consciousness and as the condition for kamma. It is twofold as with object and without object. It is threefold as past, etc. It is fourfold and fivefold according to the kinds of destiny and rebirth-linking.

original: Saḷāyatanaṃ sañjātisamosaraṇaṭṭhānato ekavidhaṃ, bhūtappasādaviññāṇādito duvidhaṃ,
analyzed: saḷāyatanam sañjāti samosaraṇa ṭhānataḥ ekavidham bhūta ppasāda viññāṇa āditaḥ duvidham
translated: The sixfold base is singlefold as the place of rebirth-linking and of descent into the womb. It is twofold as the eye sensitive matter, etc., and as the mind-element and the mind-consciousness element.

original: sampattāsampattanobhayagocarato tividhaṃ, yonigatipariyāpannato catubbidhaṃ pañcavidhañcāti
analyzed: tividham yoni gati pariyāpannataḥ catubbidham pañcavidham ca ati
translated: It is threefold as the objective fields of the three kinds of faculties, namely, those that are capable, those that are incapable, and those that are neither. It is fourfold and fivefold according to the kinds of destiny and rebirth-linking.

original: iminā nayena phassādīnampi ekavidhādibhāvo veditabboti. Evamettha ekavidhāditopi🔽viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: iminā nayena phassa ādīnam pi ekavidha ādi bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ ti evam ettha ekavidha āditaḥ pi  viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: So too with contact, etc., which should be understood in this way as singlefold, and so on. This is how the exposition should be known here “as to singlefold, etc.”

original: ‘Aṅgānañca vavatthānā’ti sokādayo cettha bhavacakkassa avicchedadassanatthaṃ vuttā.
analyzed: aṅgānam ca soka ādayo ca ittha bhava cakkassa a viccheda dassana ttham vuttā
translated: As to the defining of the factors: grief, etc., are mentioned here in order to show that the wheel of existence is unbroken.

original: Jarāmaraṇabbhāhatassa hi bālassa te sambhavanti. Yathāha – “assutavā, bhikkhave,
analyzed: jarā maraṇa abbha āhatassa hi bālassa te sambhavanti yathā āha assutavā bhikkhave
translated: For they occur in a fool who is struck down by ageing and death, according as it is said: “Bhikkhus, the uninstructed worldling experiences fear

original: puthujjano sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati🔽urattāḷiṃ kandati sammohamāpajjatī”ti. Yāva ca tesaṃ pavatti tāva avijjāyāti punapi🔽avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārāti sambandhameva hoti bhavacakkaṃ. Tasmā tesampi jarāmaraṇeneva🔽ekasaṅkhepaṃ katvā dvādaseva paṭiccasamuppādaṅgānīti veditabbāni. Evamettha aṅgānaṃ
analyzed: puthujjanaḥ sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati  urat tāḷim kandati sammoham āpajjati iti yāva ca tesam tāva avijjāya ati puna api  avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ati sambandham eva hoti bhava cakkam tasmā tesam pi jarā maraṇena iva  eka saṅkhepam katvā dvādasa iva paṭiccasamuppāda aṅgāni iti veditabbāni evam ettha aṅgānam
translated: When an ordinary man is touched by painful bodily feeling, he sorrows, grieves and laments, he weeps beating his breast and becomes distraught. ’ And so long as the process of this goes on, so long is it ignorance. And so the Wheel of Becoming, with its twelve factors, is a mere concatenation of conditions. Therefore, with the inclusion of aging-and-death, the twelve factors of the dependent origination should be understood as follows:🔽🔽

original: vavatthānatopi viññātabbo vinicchayo. Ayaṃ tāvettha uddesavāravasena saṅkhepakathā.
analyzed: vavatthānataḥ api viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ ayam tāva ettha uddesa vāra vasena saṅkhepa kathā
translated: When a worldling is touched by painful bodily feeling, he sorrows, grieves and laments, he weeps beating his breast and becomes distraught. ” And as long as this process goes on, so long is there ignorance. And so the Wheel of Becoming, with its twelve factors, is linked up in a beginningless round of rebirths. Therefore, with the words “Aging and death,” the twelve factors of the dependent origination should be understood to be included in two. Thus should the exposition be known here by way of the determination of the factors. This, firstly, is the brief treatment here in the section on the brief set of questions.

original: Uddesavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: uddesa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the brief set of questions is ended.

original: Avijjāpadaniddeso
analyzed: avijjā pada niddeso
translated: The exposition of ignorance

original: 226. Idāni niddesavāravasena vitthārakathā hoti. “Avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā”ti hi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idāni niddesa vāra vasena vitthāra kathā hoti avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti hi vuttam
translated: Now there is the detailed explanation in the section on the detailed set of questions. “With ignorance as condition there are formations” is said.

original: Tattha avijjāpaccayesu saṅkhāresu dassetabbesu yasmā putte kathetabbe paṭhamaṃ pitā
analyzed: tattha avijjā paccayesu saṅkhāresu dassetabbesu yasmā putte kathetabbe paṭhamam pitā
translated: Herein, when the formations with ignorance as condition are to be shown, the father should be mentioned first when sons are to be mentioned.

original: kathīyati. Evañhi sati ‘mittassa putto, dattassa putto’ti putto sukathito hoti. Tasmā
analyzed: kathīyati evam hi sati mittassa putto dattassa putto ti putto su kathitaḥ hoti tasmā
translated: Therefore,

original: desanākusalo satthā saṅkhārānaṃ janakatthena pitusadisaṃ avijjaṃ tāva dassetuṃ tattha🔽katamā avijjā? Dukkhe aññāṇantiādimāha.🔽Tattha yasmā ayaṃ avijjā dukkhasaccassa yāthāvasarasalakkhaṇaṃ jānituṃ passituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ
analyzed: desanā kusalaḥ satthā saṅkhārānam janaka tthena pitu sadisam avijjam tāva dassetum tattha  katamā avijjā dukkhe aññāṇa nti ādim āha  tattha yasmai ayam avijjā dukkha saccassa yāthāvasa rasa lakkhaṇam jānitum passitum paṭivijjhitum
translated: the Teacher, who is skilled in teaching, first shows ignorance, which is like a father in being the progenitor of formations, in order to show the meaning of origination.

original: na deti, chādetvā pariyonandhitvā ganthetvā tiṭṭhati, tasmā “dukkhe aññāṇa”nti vuccati.🔽Tathā yasmā dukkhasamudayassa dukkhanirodhassa dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya yāthāvasarasalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: na deti chādetvā pariyonandhitvā ganthetvā tiṭṭhati tasmā dukkhe aññāṇanti vuccati  tathā yasmai dukkha samudayassa dukkha nirodhassa dukkha nirodha gāminiyā paṭipadāya yāthāvasa rasa lakkhaṇam
translated: Herein, ignorance is called “not knowing suffering” because it does not give knowledge of the specific nature of the truth of suffering as it actually is, does not give seeing, does not give discernment, does not give vision, but on the contrary conceals, covers up, hides, and misleads with regard to the specific nature of the truth of suffering as it actually is.

original: jānituṃ passituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ na deti, chādetvā pariyonandhitvā ganthetvā tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: jānitum passitum paṭivijjhitum na deti chādetvā pariyonandhitvā ganthetvā tiṭṭhati
translated: Similarly, it is called “not knowing the origin of suffering” … “not knowing the cessation of suffering” … “not knowing the way leading to the cessation of suffering” because it does not give knowledge of the specific nature of the truths of the origin of suffering, of the cessation of suffering, and of the way leading to the cessation of suffering as they actually are, does not give seeing, does not give discernment, does not give vision, but on the contrary conceals, covers up, hides, and misleads with regard to the specific nature of the truths of the origin of suffering, of the cessation of suffering, and of the way leading to the cessation of suffering as they actually are.

original: tasmā dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya aññāṇanti vuccati. Imesu catūsu ṭhānesu suttantikapariyāyena
analyzed: tasmā dukkha nirodha gāminiyā paṭipadāya aññāṇanti vuccati imesu catūsu ṭhānesu suttantika pariyāyena
translated: In the four instances, according to the method of the sutta, ignorance is called “not knowing” because it does not give knowledge of the specific nature of the four truths as it actually is.

original: aññāṇaṃ avijjāti kathitaṃ.🔽Nikkhepakaṇḍe pana abhidhammapariyāyena “pubbante aññāṇa”nti aparesupi catūsu ṭhānesu🔽aññāṇaṃ gahitaṃ. Tattha pubbanteti atīto addhā, atītāni khandhadhātuāyatanāni. Aparanteti🔽anāgato addhā, anāgatāni khandhadhātuāyatanāni. Pubbantāparanteti tadubhayaṃ. Idappaccayatāti
analyzed: aññāṇam avijjā ti kathitam  nikkhepa kaṇḍe pana abhidhamma pariyāyena pubbante aññāṇanti aparesu pi catūsu ṭhānesu  aññāṇam gahitam tattha pubbante ti atītaḥ addhā atītāni khandha dhātu āyatanāni aparante ti  anāgataḥ addhā anāgatāni khandha dhātu āyatanāni pubbanta aparantā iti tat ubhayam idappaccaya tā ati
translated: and ignorance is called unknowing.🔽But in the section on the outcome it is stated in the Abhidhamma way as “ unknowing about the past” .

original: saṅkhārādīnaṃ kāraṇāni avijjādīni aṅgāni. Paṭiccasamuppannadhammāti avijjādīhi nibbattā🔽saṅkhārādayo dhammā. Tatrāyaṃ avijjā yasmā atītānaṃ khandhādīnaṃ yāthāvasarasalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāra ādīnam kāraṇāni avijjā ādīni aṅgāni paṭicca samuppanna dhammā ati avijjā ādīhi nibbattā  saṅkhāra ādayaḥ dhammā tatra ayam avijjā yasmai atītānam khandha ādīnam yāthāvasa rasa lakkhaṇam
translated: And unknowing is stated in the other four places too. Herein, “about the past” is the past extent, that is, past aggregates, bases, and elements. “About the future” is the future extent, that is, future aggregates, bases, and elements. “About the past and future” is both of them. “About conditions” is the conditions, that is, the factors of ignorance, etc., of determinations, and so on. “About conditionally-arisen things” is the things, that is, the determinations, and so on, produced by ignorance, and so on.

original: jānituṃ passituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ na deti, chādetvā pariyonandhitvā ganthetvā tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: jānitum passitum paṭivijjhitum na deti chādetvā pariyonandhitvā ganthetvā tiṭṭhati
translated: Herein, this ignorance does not give the eye of understanding, does not give the eye of direct-knowledge, does not give knowledge and vision as it actually is of the aggregates, elements, and sense bases in the past, and so it conceals, conceals, conceals, and stands, as it were, blocking the way.

original: tasmā “pubbante aññāṇa”nti vuccati. Tathā yasmā anāgatānaṃ khandhādīnaṃ, atītānāgatānaṃ
analyzed: tasmā pubba ante aññāṇanti vuccati tathā yasmā anāgatānam khandha ādīnam atīta anāgatānam
translated: Therefore it is said that it is “ unknowing about the past.” Likewise it does not give the eye of understanding, does not give the eye of direct-knowledge, does not give knowledge and vision as it actually is of the aggregates, elements, and sense bases in the future, and so it conceals, conceals, conceals, and stands, as it were, blocking the way.

original: khandhādīnaṃ idappaccayatāya ceva paṭiccasamuppannadhammānañca yāthāvasarasalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: khandha ādīnam idappaccaya tāya ca iva paṭiccasamuppanna dhammānam ca yāthāvasa rasa lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of the specific nature of the aggregates, etc., as conditions for this and that, and of the things that originate interdependently, as they really are,

original: jānituṃ passituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ na deti, chādetvā pariyonandhitvā ganthetvā tiṭṭhati,🔽tasmā idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti vuccati. Imesu aṭṭhasu
analyzed: jānitum passitum paṭivijjhitum na deti chādetvā pariyonandhitvā ganthetvā tiṭṭhati  tasmai idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti vuccati imesu aṭṭhasu
translated: It does not give scope for knowing, seeing and penetrating the specific characteristics of the aggregates, etc., as they are in actuality and as they are in specific conditional relations. It conceals, hides, and veils them.🔽Therefore it is called “ignorance” in regard to the specific conditional relations and the conditionally arisen states.

original: ṭhānesu abhidhammapariyāyena aññāṇaṃ avijjāti kathitaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhānesu abhidhamma pariyāyena aññāṇam avijjā ti kathitam
translated: In these eight instances, ignorance is said to be the non-penetration of the Dhamma by way of the Abhidhamma.

original: Evaṃ kiṃ kathitaṃ hoti? Kiccato ceva jātito ca avijjā kathitā nāma hoti. Kathaṃ?
analyzed: evam kim kathitam hoti kiccato ca iva jātitaḥ ca avijjā kathitā nāma hoti katham
translated: What is said here? Ignorance is said in terms of function and in terms of origination. How?

original: Ayañhi avijjā imāni aṭṭha ṭhānāni jānituṃ passituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ na detīti kiccato
analyzed: ayam hi avijjā imāni aṭṭha ṭhānāni jānitum passitum paṭivijjhitum na deti iti kiccato
translated: This ignorance does not give scope for knowing, seeing and penetrating these eight instances. Therefore it is said in terms of function.🔽And it arises in these eight instances. Therefore it is said in terms of origination.

original: kathitā; uppajjamānāpi imesu aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu uppajjatīti jātitopi kathitā. Evaṃ kathetvā
analyzed: kathitā uppajjamānā api imesu aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu uppajjati iti jātitaḥ api kathitā evam kathetvā
translated: Having said this,

original: puna “yaṃ evarūpaṃ aññāṇaṃ adassana”ntiādīni pañcavīsati padāni avijjāya lakkhaṇaṃ dassetuṃ gahitāni.
analyzed: puna yam evarūpam aññāṇam adassana nti ādīni pañcavīsati padāni avijjāya lakkhaṇam dassetum gahitāni
translated: the next twenty-five terms beginning with “non-penetration, non-seeing” are given in order to show the characteristics of ignorance.

original: Tattha yasmā ayaṃ avijjā imehi aṭṭhahi padehi kathitāpi puna pañcavīsatiyā padehi🔽lakkhaṇe akathite sukathitā nāma na hoti, lakkhaṇe pana kathiteyeva sukathitā nāma🔽hoti. Yathā puriso naṭṭhaṃ goṇaṃ pariyesamāno manusse puccheyya – “api, ayyā, setaṃ🔽goṇaṃ passatha, rattaṃ goṇaṃ passathā”ti? Te evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – “imasmiṃ raṭṭhe setarattānaṃ
analyzed: tattha yasmai ayam avijjā imehi aṭṭhahi padehi kathitā api puna pañcavīsatiyā padehi  lakkhaṇe a kathite su kathitā nāma na hoti lakkhaṇe pana kathitā iya iva su kathitā nāma  hoti yathā purisaḥ naṭṭham goṇam pariyesamānaḥ manusse puccheyya api ayyā setam  goṇam passatha rattam goṇam passatha ati te evam vadeyyuṃ imasmin raṭṭhe seta rattānam
translated: Herein, although this ignorance has been stated in these eight terms, still it is not well stated unless it is stated in terms of its characteristic. But when it is stated in terms of its characteristic, then it is well stated.🔽Just as when a man has lost a cow and is looking for it, he asks people, “Have you seen a cow? Is there a cow?,” and they say, “There is no cow here, there is no cow here,” but when they see one they say, “Here is a cow, here is a cow,” so too, although this ignorance has been stated in these eight terms, still it is not well stated unless it is stated in terms of its characteristic. But when it is stated in terms of its characteristic, then it is well stated.🔽Just as when a man has lost a cow and is looking for it, he asks people, “Have you seen a white cow? Have you seen a red cow?” and they say, “There is no white cow here, there is no red cow here,” but when they see one they say, “Here is a white cow, here is a red cow,” so too, although this ignorance has been stated in these eight terms, still it is not well stated unless it is stated in terms of its characteristic. But when it is stated in terms of its characteristic, then it is well stated.

original: goṇānaṃ anto natthi, kiṃ te goṇassa lakkhaṇa”nti? Atha tena ‘saṅghāṭi’ vā ‘naṅgalaṃ’🔽vāti vutte goṇo sukathito nāma bhaveyya; evameva yasmā ayaṃ avijjā aṭṭhahi padehi🔽kathitāpi puna pañcavīsatiyā padehi lakkhaṇe akathite sukathitā nāma na hoti, lakkhaṇe🔽pana kathiteyeva sukathitā nāma hoti. Tasmā yānassā lakkhaṇadassanatthaṃ pañcavīsati
analyzed: goṇānaṃ antaḥ natthi kim te goṇassa lakkhaṇanti atha tena saṅghāṭi vā naṅgalam 🔽vā ati vutte goṇaḥ su kathitaḥ nāma bhaveyya evam eva yasmai ayam avijjā aṭṭhahi padehi 🔽kathitā api puna pañcavīsatiyā padehi lakkhaṇe a kathite su kathitā nāma na hoti lakkhaṇe 🔽pana kathitā iya iva sukathitā nāma hoti tasmā lakkhaṇa dassana attham pañcavīsati
translated: Herein, although this ignorance is stated in these eight terms, still it is not well stated unless it is stated in the twenty-five terms beginning with the characteristic. But when it is stated in the twenty-five terms beginning with the characteristic, then it is well stated. Just as when a man has lost a white cow and is asking people, “Have you seen a white cow? Have you seen a black cow?” and they say to him, “There are no white or black cows in this kingdom at all. What sort of cow are you looking for?” and then when he says, “It has a dewlap and a hump,” or “It has a harness and a yoke,” the cow is well stated; so too, although this ignorance is stated in eight terms, still it is not well stated unless it is stated in the twenty-five terms beginning with the characteristic. But when it is stated in the twenty-five terms beginning with the characteristic, then it is well stated. So in order to show its characteristic, etc., twenty-five terms beginning with the characteristic are stated.

original: padāni kathitāni, tesampi vasena veditabbā.🔽Seyyathidaṃ – ñāṇaṃ nāma paññā. Sā atthatthaṃ kāraṇakāraṇaṃ catusaccadhammaṃ viditaṃ
analyzed: padāni kathitāni tesam pi vasena veditabbā  sā iyyathidam ñāṇam nāma paññā sā atthattham kāraṇa kāraṇam catu sacca dhammam viditam
translated: The words are stated thus. They should be understood in this way too.

original: pākaṭaṃ karoti. Ayaṃ pana avijjā uppajjitvā taṃ viditaṃ pākaṭaṃ kātuṃ na detīti ñāṇapaccanīkato🔽aññāṇaṃ. Dassanantipi paññā. Sāpi taṃ ākāraṃ passati. Avijjā pana uppajjitvā taṃ
analyzed: pākaṭam karoti ayam pana avijjā uppajjitvā tam viditam pākaṭam kātum na deti iti ñāṇa paccanīkato  aññāṇam dassanan ti pi paññā sā api tam ākāram passati avijjā pana uppajjitvā tam
translated: That is to say, knowledge is understanding. It makes known and evident the meaning that is, the four noble truths, which is the reason for the reason. But ignorance, arising, does not allow that to be known and evident. So ignorance is the opposite of knowledge.🔽Seeing is also understanding. It sees that aspect. But ignorance, arising, does not allow that to be seen. So ignorance is non-seeing.

original: passituṃ na detīti adassanaṃ. Abhisamayotipi paññā. Sā taṃ ākāraṃ abhisameti. Avijjā🔽pana uppajjitvā taṃ abhisametuṃ na detīti anabhisamayo. Anubodho sambodho paṭivedhotipi🔽paññā. Sā taṃ ākāraṃ anubujjhati sambujjhati paṭivijjhati. Avijjā pana uppajjitvā
analyzed: passitum na deti iti a dassanam paññā sā tam ākāram abhisameti avijjā  pana uppajjitvā tam abhisametum na deti iti anabhisamayaḥ anubodhaḥ sambodhaḥ paṭivedhaḥ tipi  paññā sā tam ākāram anubujjhati sambujjhati paṭivijjhati avijjā pana uppajjitvā
translated: Penetrating is also understanding. It penetrates that aspect. But ignorance, arising, does not allow that to be penetrated. So ignorance is non-penetration.

original: taṃ anubujjhituṃ saṃbujjhituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ na detīti ananubodho asambodho appaṭivedho.
analyzed: tam anubujjhitum saṃbujjhitum paṭivijjhitum na deti iti ananubodhaḥ asambodhaḥ appaṭivedhaḥ
translated: Realizing, fully understanding, breaking through are also understanding. It realizes, fully understands, breaks through that aspect. But ignorance, arising, does not allow that to be realized, fully understood, broken through. So ignorance is non-realization, non-full-understanding, non-breaking-through.

original: Saṅgāhanātipi paññā. Sā taṃ ākāraṃ gahetvā ghaṃsitvā gaṇhāti. Avijjā pana uppajjitvā🔽taṃ gahetvā ghaṃsitvā gaṇhituṃ na detīti asaṅgāhanā. Pariyogāhanātipi paññā. Sā taṃ🔽ākāraṃ ogāhitvā anupavisitvā gaṇhāti. Avijjā pana uppajjitvā taṃ ogāhitvā anupavisitvā
analyzed: paññā sā tam ākāram gahetvā ghaṃsitvā gaṇhāti avijjā pana uppajjitvā  tam gahetvā ghaṃsitvā gaṇhitum na deti iti a saṅgāhanā pariyogāhanā atipi paññā sā tam  ākāram ogāhitvā an upavisitvā gaṇhāti avijjā pana uppajjitvā tam ogāhitvā an upavisitvā
translated: Understanding is also called “comprehending” because it comprehends, grasps, and holds that aspect. But ignorance, arising, does not give up that aspect, does not let it go, and so it is called “non-comprehending.” Understanding is also called “penetrating” because it penetrates and enters into that aspect. But ignorance, arising, does not let it penetrate and enter into that aspect,🔽and so it is called “non-penetrating.”🔽

original: gaṇhituṃ na detīti apariyogāhanā. Samapekkhanātipi paññā. Sā taṃ ākāraṃ samaṃ sammā🔽ca pekkhati. Avijjā pana uppajjitvā taṃ samaṃ sammā ca pekkhituṃ na detīti asamapekkhanā.🔽Paccavekkhaṇātipi paññā. Sā taṃ ākāraṃ paccavekkhati. Avijjā pana uppajjitvā taṃ🔽paccavekkhituṃ na detīti apaccavekkhaṇā. Nāssā kiñci kammaṃ paccakkhaṃ atthi, sayañca
analyzed: gaṇhitum na deti iti a pariyogāhanā samapekkhanā atipi paññā sā tam ākāram samam sammā  ca pekkhati avijjā pana uppajjitvā tam samam sammā ca pekkhitum na deti iti asamapekkhanā  paccavekkhaṇā atipi paññā sā tam ākāram paccavekkhati avijjā pana uppajjitvā tam  paccavekkhitum na deti iti apaccavekkhaṇā na assā kiñci kammam paccakkham atthi sayam ca
translated: Understanding is also called “comprehending” . It comprehends, grasps, and holds the mode of appearance. But ignorance, having arisen, does not allow the mode of appearance to be comprehended, grasped, and held. Thus it is called “non-comprehending.” Understanding is also called “penetrating” . It penetrates, enters into, and grasps the mode of appearance. But ignorance, having arisen, does not allow the mode of appearance to be penetrated, entered into, and grasped. Thus it is called “non-penetrating.” Understanding is also called “contemplating” . It contemplates, considers, and examines the mode of appearance. But ignorance, having arisen, does not allow the mode of appearance to be contemplated, considered, and examined. Thus it is called “non-contemplating.”

original: apaccavekkhitvā kataṃ kammanti apaccakkhakammaṃ. Dummedhabhāvatāya dummejjhaṃ. Bālabhāvatāya bālyaṃ.
analyzed: a paccavekkhitvā katam kammanti a paccakkha kammam dummedha bhāvatāya dummejjham bāla bhāvatāya bālyam
translated: Understanding is also called “reviewing” . It reviews the mode of appearance. But ignorance, having arisen, does not allow the mode of appearance to be reviewed. Thus it is called “non-reviewing.” There is no action that is not reviewed by it; and it is called “non-reviewing of action” because it performs action without reviewing. It is “foolishness” because of stupidity. It is “foolishness” because of childishness.

original: Sampajaññantipi paññā. Sā atthatthaṃ kāraṇakāraṇaṃ catusaccadhammaṃ sammā pajānāti.
analyzed: paññā sā attha ttham kāraṇa kāraṇam catu sacca dhammam sammā pajānāti
translated: Understanding is also wisdom. It understands rightly the meaning, the cause, the reason, the nature, the characteristic, the fruit, the source, the escape, the giving up, the abandoning, the demolishing, the drying up, the cessation, the stilling, the penetration, the dispassion, the fading away, the stopping, the giving up, the renunciation, the meaning and the Dhamma of the Four Noble Truths.

original: Avijjā pana uppajjitvā taṃ ākāraṃ pajānituṃ na detīti asampajaññaṃ. Mohanavasena
analyzed: avijjā pana uppajjitvā tam ākāram pajānitum na deti iti asampajaññam mohana vasena
translated: But ignorance does not give up the arising of that understanding of the meaning, etc., and so it is non-understanding.🔽It is delusion by delusion,🔽delusion by delusion, confusion by confusion,🔽ignorance by ignorance,

original: moho. Pamohanavasena pamoho. Sammohanavasena sammoho. Avindiyaṃ vindatītiādivasena
analyzed: mohaḥ pamohana vasena pamohaḥ sammohana vasena sammohaḥ vindati iti ādi vasena
translated: delusion of the round by the round, entanglement by entanglement,🔽and underlying tendency by underlying tendency.🔽It is ignorance because it arises again and again without being abandoned.

original: avijjā. Vaṭṭasmiṃ ohanati osīdāpetīti avijjogho. Vaṭṭasmiṃ yojetīti avijjāyogo. Appahīnavasena🔽punappunaṃ uppajjanato ca avijjānusayo. Magge pariyuṭṭhitacorā addhike viya kusalacittaṃ🔽pariyuṭṭhāti gaṇhāti vilumpatīti avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṃ. Yathā nagaradvāre palighasaṅkhātāya🔽laṅgiyā patitāya antonagare manussānaṃ bahinagaragamanampi bahinagare manussānaṃ
analyzed: avijjā vaṭṭasmim ohanati osīdāpeti iti avijjoghaḥ vaṭṭasmim yojeti iti avijjā yogo appahīna vasena  punappunam uppajjanataḥ ca avijjā anusayaḥ magge pariyuṭṭhita corāḥ addhike viya kusala cittam  pariyuṭṭhāti gaṇhāti vilumpati iti avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam yathā nagara dvāre paligha saṅkhātāya  laṅgiyā patitāya antar nagare manussānam bahi nagara gamanam pi bahi nagare manussānam
translated: It is ignorance because it seizes and takes possession of and plunders profitable cognizance as thieves do a highway, lying in wait for it.

original: antonagarapavesanampi pacchijjati, evameva yassa sakkāyanagare ayaṃ patitā tassa
analyzed: antar nagara pavesanam pi pacchijjati evam eva yassa sakkāya nagare ayam patitā tassa
translated: Just as when a bolt called a “bar” is fixed in the door of a city, it prevents people inside the city from going outside the city and it prevents people outside the city from coming in, so too, when this is fixed in the town of selfhood it prevents the profitable ideas of the world of men from going to the world of the gods, etc., and it prevents the profitable ideas of the world of the gods, etc., from coming to the world of men.

original: nibbānasampāpakaṃ ñāṇagamanaṃ pacchijjatīti avijjālaṅgī nāma hoti. Akusalañca taṃ
analyzed: nibbāna sampāpakam ñāṇa gamanam pacchijjati iti avijjālaṅgī nāma hoti akusalam ca tam
translated: and the knowledge-process that leads to the attainment of Nibbāna is cut off, he is called “enveloped in ignorance.” It is unprofitable,

original: mūlañca, akusalānaṃ vā mūlanti akusalamūlaṃ. Taṃ pana na aññaṃ, idhādhippeto mohoti
analyzed: mūlam ca akusalānam vā mūlanti akusala mūlam tam pana na aññam idha adhippeto moho ti
translated: and it is a root, or it is a root of the unprofitable, thus it is an unprofitable root. But that is not what is intended here. Delusion is intended here,

original: moho akusalamūlaṃ. Ayaṃ vuccati avijjāti ayaṃ evaṃlakkhaṇā avijjā nāmāti vuccati.
analyzed: mohaḥ akusala mūlam ayam vuccati avijjā ati ayam evaṃlakkhaṇā avijjā nāma ati vuccati
translated: thus it is said: “This is called ignorance.” This is how the characteristic of ignorance should be understood.

original: Evaṃ pañcavīsatipadavasena avijjāya lakkhaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam pañcavīsati pada vasena avijjāya lakkhaṇam veditabbam
translated: This is how the characteristic of ignorance should be understood as consisting of twenty-five terms.

original: Evaṃlakkhaṇā panāyaṃ avijjā dukkhādīsu aññāṇanti vuttāpi dukkhasaccassa ekadeso hoti,
analyzed: evaṃlakkhaṇā pana ayam avijjā dukkha ādīsu aññāṇan ti vuttā api dukkha saccassa eka desaḥ hoti
translated: But although this ignorance, so characterized, is called “non-penetration in regard to suffering, etc.,” it is part of the truth of suffering,

original: sahajātā hoti, taṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, chādeti; samudayasaccassa na ekadeso hoti, sahajātā
analyzed: sahajātā hoti tam ārammaṇam karoti chādeti samudaya saccassa na eka desaḥ hoti sahajātā
translated: it is conascent with it, it makes that its object, and it conceals it. It is not part of the truth of origin, but it is conascent with it,

original: hoti, taṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, chādeti; nirodhasaccassa neva ekadeso hoti, na sahajātā,
analyzed: hoti tam ārammaṇam karoti chādeti nirodha saccassa na iva eka desaḥ hoti na sahajātā
translated: it makes that its object, and it conceals it. It is neither part of the truth of cessation, nor is it conascent with it,

original: na taṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, kevalaṃ chādeti; maggasaccassāpi na ekadeso, na sahajātā,
analyzed: na tam ārammaṇam karoti kevalam chādeti magga saccassa api na eka desaḥ na sahajātā
translated: nor does it make that its object; it merely conceals it. Nor is it part of the truth of the path, nor is it conascent with it,🔽nor does it make that its object;

original: na taṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, kevalaṃ chādeti. Dukkhārammaṇatā avijjā uppajjati, tañca🔽chādeti. Samudayārammaṇatā avijjā uppajjati, tañca chādeti. Nirodhārammaṇatā avijjā
analyzed: na tam ārammaṇam karoti kevalam chādeti dukkha ārammaṇa tā avijjā uppajjati tat ca  chādeti samudaya ārammaṇa tā avijjā uppajjati tat ca chādeti nirodha ārammaṇa tā avijjā
translated: He does not make that the object, he merely conceals it. Ignorance arises with the object of suffering, and he conceals that. Ignorance arises with the object of origin, and he conceals that. Ignorance arises with the object of cessation,

original: nuppajjati, tañca chādeti. Maggārammaṇatā avijjā nūppajjati, tañca chādeti.
analyzed: nuppajjati tat ca chādeti magga ārammaṇa tā avijjā nūppajjati tat ca chādeti
translated: and he conceals that. Ignorance arises with the object of the path, and he conceals that.

original: Dve saccā duddasattā gambhīrā. Dve saccā gambhīrattā duddasā. Apica kho pana dukkhanirodhaṃ
analyzed: dve saccā duddasa ttā gambhīrā dve saccā gambhīra ttā duddasā apica kho pana dukkha nirodham
translated: Two Truths are difficult to see because they are profound. Two Truths are profound because they are difficult to see. Furthermore, the Noble Truth of the Cessation of Suffering

original: ariyasaccaṃ gambhīrañceva duddasañca. Tattha dukkhaṃ nāma pākaṭaṃ, lakkhaṇassa pana
analyzed: ariya saccam gambhīram ca iva duddasam ca tattha dukkham nāma pākaṭam lakkhaṇassa pana
translated: is both profound and difficult to see. Herein, suffering is obvious, but because of the difficulty in seeing its characteristic,

original: duddasattā gambhīraṃ nāma jātaṃ. Samudayepi eseva nayo. Yathā pana mahāsamuddaṃ manthetvā
analyzed: duddasa ttā gambhīram nāma jātam samudaye pi eṣa iva nayaḥ yathā pana mahā samuddam manthetvā
translated: it is called profound. The same method applies to origin. Just as it is a burden to drain the great ocean of its water,

original: ojāya nīharaṇaṃ nāma bhāro, sinerupādato vālikāya uddharaṇaṃ nāma bhāro, pabbataṃ
analyzed: ojāya nīharaṇam nāma bhāraḥ sineru pādataḥ vālikāya uddharaṇam nāma bhāraḥ pabbatam
translated: or to remove the sand from the base of Sineru, or to squeeze out the juice from a mountain,

original: pīḷetvā rasassa nīharaṇaṃ nāma bhāro; evameva dve saccāni gambhīratāya eva duddasāni,
analyzed: pīḷetvā rasassa nīharaṇam nāma bhāraḥ evam eva dve saccāni gambhīra tāya eva duddasāni
translated: so too, the two Truths are difficult to see because they are profound.

original: nirodhasaccaṃ pana atigambhīrañca atiduddasañcāti. Evaṃ duddasattā gambhīrānaṃ gambhīrattā
analyzed: nirodha saccam pana ati gambhīram ca ati duddasam ca ati evam duddasa ttā gambhīra ttā
translated: So it is owing to the difficulty of seeing that the four noble truths are called “deep” and “hard to see.”

original: ca duddasānaṃ catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ paṭicchādakaṃ mohandhakāraṃ ayaṃ vuccati avijjāti.
analyzed: ca duddasānam catunnam ariya saccānam paṭicchādakam moha andhakāram ayam vuccati avijjāti
translated: The darkness of delusion that conceals the four noble truths that are thus hard to see is called ignorance.

original: Avijjāpadaniddeso.
analyzed: avijjā pada niddeso
translated: The description of ignorance is ended.

original: Saṅkhārapadaniddeso
analyzed: saṅkhāra pada niddeso
translated: The description of formations

original: Saṅkhārapade heṭṭhā vuttasaṅkhāresu saṅkhārasaddena āgatasaṅkhāre anāmasitvā avijjāpaccayā
analyzed: saṅkhāra pade heṭṭhā vutta saṅkhāresu saṅkhāra saddena āgata saṅkhāre an āmasitvā avijjā paccayā
translated: In the section on formations, without singling out the formations that have already been mentioned below in the passage beginning, “With ignorance as condition there are formations” ,

original: saṅkhāreyeva dassento tattha katame avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā? Puññābhisaṅkhārotiādimāha.
analyzed: dassentaḥ tattha katame avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā puñña abhisaṅkhārā iti ādim āha
translated: he shows only the formations with ignorance as condition, saying, “Herein, what are the formations with ignorance as condition? Formations of merit, etc.”

original: Tattha punāti attano kārakaṃ, pūreti cassa ajjhāsayaṃ, pujjañca bhavaṃ nibbattetīti🔽puñño. Abhisaṅkharoti vipākaṃ kaṭattārūpañcāti abhisaṅkhāro. Puññova abhisaṅkhāro
analyzed: tattha punāti attanaḥ kārakam pūreti cassa ajjhāsayam pujjam ca bhavam nibbatteti iti  puññaḥ abhisaṅkharoti vipākam kaṭattā rūpam ca ati abhisaṅkhāro puññaḥ eva abhisaṅkhāro
translated: Herein, it purifies , thus it is merit . It is merit and it is a formation, thus it is a formation of merit .

original: puññābhisaṅkhāro. Puññapaṭipakkhato apuñño. Apuññova abhisaṅkhāro apuññābhisaṅkhāro.
analyzed: puñña abhisaṅkhāro puñña paṭipakkhataḥ apuññaḥ apuññaḥ uva abhisaṅkhāraḥ apuñña abhisaṅkhāro
translated: It is the opposite of merit, thus it is demerit . It is demerit and it is a formation, thus it is a formation of demerit .

original: Na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Āneñjameva abhisaṅkhāro, āneñjañca bhavaṃ abhisaṅkharotīti āneñjābhisaṅkhāro.
analyzed: na iñjati iti āneñjam āneñjam eva abhisaṅkhāraḥ āneñjam ca bhavam abhisaṅkharoti iti āneñja abhisaṅkhāraḥ
translated: It is unmoved: thus it is unmoving. The formation itself is unmoving, or it forms unmoving becoming, thus it is a formation of the unmoving.

original: Kāyena pavattito, kāyato vā pavatto, kāyassa vā saṅkhāroti kāyasaṅkhāro. Vacīsaṅkhāracittasaṅkhāresupi eseva nayo.🔽Tattha paṭhamattiko parivīmaṃsanasuttavasena gahito. Tattha hi “puññañce saṅkhāraṃ🔽abhisaṅkharoti, puññūpagaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ. Apuññañce saṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, apuññupagaṃ
analyzed: kāyena pavattitaḥ kāyataḥ vā pavatto kāyassa vā saṅkhāro ti kāya saṅkhāraḥ vacī saṅkhāra citta saṅkhāresu pi eṣa eva nayaḥ  tattha paṭhama ttikaḥ parivīmaṃsana sutta vasena gahito tattha hi saṅkhāraṃ  abhisaṅkharoti puñña upagam hoti viññāṇam a puññam ce saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti a puñña upagam
translated: It is formed by the body, or it is formed from the body, or it is a formation of the body, thus it is bodily formation. So too with the other two.

original: hoti viññāṇaṃ. Āneñjañce saṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, āneñjupagaṃ hoti viññāṇa”nti vuttaṃ.🔽Dutiyattiko tadanantarassa vibhaṅgasuttassa vasena gahito, sammādiṭṭhisuttapariyāyena
analyzed: hoti viññāṇam āneñjam ce saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti āneñja upagam hoti viññāṇan ti vuttam  dutiya ttiko tad anantarassa vibhaṅga suttassa vasena gahito sammādiṭṭhi sutta pariyāyena
translated: Herein, the first is included by the “Investigation” sutta, for there it is said: “If he forms a formation of merit, his consciousness goes to merit; if he forms a formation of demerit, his consciousness goes to demerit; if he forms an imperturbable formation, his consciousness goes to the imperturbable” .

original: gahitotipi vattuṃ vaṭṭatiyeva. Tattha hi “tayome, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā. Katame tayo?
analyzed: gahitā iti pi vattum vaṭṭatiyā iva tattha hi tayo me bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ katame tayo
translated: The second is included by the immediately following “Analysis” sutta, and it is also allowable to include it by the “Right View” sutta. For there it is said: “Bhikkhus, there are these three formations. What three?

original: Kāyasaṅkhāro, vacīsaṅkhāro, cittasaṅkhāro”ti vuttaṃ. Kasmā panetesaṃ suttānaṃ vasena
analyzed: kāya saṅkhāro vacī saṅkhāro citta saṅkhāro ti vuttam kasmā pana itesam suttānam vasena
translated: But why are they taken in this way according to these suttas?

original: te gahitāti? Ayaṃ abhidhammo nāma na adhunākato, nāpi bāhirakaisīhi vā sāvakehi vā
analyzed: te gahitā ati ayam abhidhammaḥ nāma na adhunākataḥ na api bāhirakaisīhi vā sāvakehi vā
translated: This Abhidhamma is not something newly made, nor was it spoken by outsiders or disciples or🔽deities. It was spoken by the Omniscient One. For in the Abhidhamma and in the Suttanta

original: devatāhi vā bhāsito. Sabbaññujinabhāsito pana ayaṃ. Abhidhammepi hi suttepi ekasadisāva
analyzed: devatāhi vā bhāsito sabbaññu jina bhāsito pana ayam abhidhamme pi hi sutte pi eka sadisā ava
translated: the meaning is the same.

original: tanti niddiṭṭhāti imassatthassa dīpanatthaṃ.
analyzed: tat ti niddiṭṭhā ti imassa atthassa dīpana tham
translated: The purpose of the words “as shown” is to show that the meaning is the same.🔽Now, in order to point out those formations by way of their different kinds, he said, “Herein, what is a meritorious formation? ” .

original: Idāni te saṅkhāre pabhedato dassetuṃ tattha katamo puññābhisaṅkhārotiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: idāni te saṅkhāre pabhedataḥ dassetum tattha katamo puñña abhisaṅkhāraḥ ti ādim āha tattha
translated: Herein,

original: kusalā cetanāti aniyamato catubhūmikacetanāpi vuttā. Kāmāvacarā rūpāvacarāti niyamitattā
analyzed: kusalā cetanā ati catu bhūmika cetanā api vuttā kāmāvacarā rūpāvacarā ati
translated: “A profitable volition” is said without restriction, and so it includes the volition of the four planes. But since it is restricted by the words “of the sense sphere and of the fine-material sphere”

original: pana aṭṭha kāmāvacarakusalacetanā, pañca rūpāvacarakusalacetanāti terasa cetanā puññābhisaṅkhāro
analyzed: pana aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusala cetanā pañca rūpāvacara kusala cetanā ati terasa cetanā puñña abhisaṅkhāro
translated: it is the thirteen volitions, namely, the eight profitable volitions of the sense sphere and the five profitable volitions of the fine-material sphere, that are called “a meritorious formation.”

original: nāma. Dānamayātiādīhi tāsaṃyeva cetanānaṃ puññakiriyavatthuvasena pavatti dassitā.
analyzed: nāma dāna maya ati ādīhi tāsam yeva cetanānam puñña kiriya vatthu vasena pavatti dassitā
translated: The words “as giving, etc.,” show how those same volitions occur by way of the bases of meritorious deeds.

original: Tattha aṭṭha kāmāvacarāva dānasīlamayā honti. Bhāvanāmayā pana terasapi. Yathā hi🔽paguṇaṃ dhammaṃ sajjhāyamāno ekaṃ dve anusandhigatepi na jānāti, pacchā āvajjanto🔽jānāti; evameva kasiṇaparikammaṃ karontassa paguṇajjhānaṃ paccavekkhantassa paguṇakammaṭṭhānañca
analyzed: tattha aṭṭha dāna sīla mayāḥ honti bhāvanā mayāḥ yathā hi  paguṇam dhammam sajjhāyamānaḥ ekam dve anusandhi gate pi na jānāti pacchā āvajjanto  jānāti evam eva kasiṇa parikammam karontassa paguṇa jhānam paccavekkhantassa paguṇa kammaṭṭhānañca
translated: Herein, the eight kinds of kamma consisting of giving and virtue are of the sense sphere only. But those consisting of development are of thirteen kinds.🔽For just as when one is reciting a text that is unfamiliar, one does not know even one or two consecutive clauses, but later on, when one has taken up the recitation, one does know them, so too, when one is doing the preliminary work for a kasiṇa, and when one is reviewing the jhāna that has become familiar, and when one is giving attention to the meditation subject that has become familiar, then the development is accompanied by knowledge.

original: manasikarontassa ñāṇavippayuttāpi bhāvanā hoti. Tena vuttaṃ “bhāvanāmayā pana terasapī”ti.🔽Tattha dānamayādīsu “dānaṃ ārabbha dānamadhikicca yā uppajjati cetanā sañcetanā cetayitattaṃ🔽– ayaṃ vuccati dānamayo puññābhisaṅkhāroti. Sīlaṃ ārabbha…pe… bhāvanaṃ ārabbha bhāvanamadhikicca
analyzed: manasikarontassa ñāṇa vippayuttā api bhāvanā hoti tena vuttam bhāvanā mayā pana terasa pi iti  tattha dāna maya ādīsu dānam ārabbha dānam adhikicca yā uppajjati cetanā sañcetanā cetayitattam  ayam vuccati dāna mayaḥ puñña abhisaṅkhāro ti sīlam bhāvanam ārabbha bhāvanam adhikicca
translated: That is why it was said above, “But those consisting of development are of thirteen kinds.”

original: yā uppajjati cetanā sañcetanā cetayitattaṃ – ayaṃ vuccati bhāvanāmayo puññābhisaṅkhāro”ti
analyzed: yā uppajjati cetanā sañcetanā cetayitattam ayam vuccati bhāvanā mayaḥ puñña abhisaṅkhāro ti
translated: Herein, in the case of the kinds consisting of giving, etc., “The volition, the will, the act of willing, that occurs when he is giving a gift is what is called the meritorious volition consisting of giving” . “The volition, the will, the act of willing, that occurs when he is undertaking virtue is what is called the meritorious volition consisting of virtue” . “The volition, the will, the act of willing, that occurs when he is doing the development of concentration is what is called the meritorious volition consisting of development” .

original: ayaṃ saṅkhepadesanā.
analyzed: ayam saṅkhepa desanā
translated: This is the brief treatment.

original: Cīvarādīsu pana catūsu paccayesu rūpādīsu vā chasu ārammaṇesu annādīsu vā dasasu🔽dānavatthūsu taṃ taṃ dentassa tesaṃ uppādanato paṭṭhāya pubbabhāge pariccāgakāle
analyzed: cīvara ādīsu pana catūsu paccayesu rūpa ādīsu vā chasu ārammaṇesu anna ādīsu vā dasasu  dāna vatthūsu tam tam dentassa tesam uppādanato paṭṭhāya pubba bhāge pariccāga kāle
translated: But in the case of the four requisites beginning with robes, or in the case of the six kinds of objects beginning with visible objects, or in the case of the ten objects of giving beginning with food,🔽when he gives any one of them, from the time when he produces the thought of giving, at the time of giving,🔽

original: pacchā somanassacittena anussaraṇe cāti tīsu kālesu pavattā cetanā dānamayā nāma.🔽Sīlaṃ paripūraṇatthāya pana ‘pabbajissāmī’ti vihāraṃ gacchantassa pabbajantassa manorathaṃ🔽matthakaṃ pāpetvā ‘pabbajito vatamhi, sādhu suṭṭhū’ti āvajjantassa pātimokkhaṃ saṃvarantassa🔽cīvarādayo paccaye paccavekkhantassa āpāthagatesu rūpādīsu cakkhudvārādīni saṃvarantassa
analyzed: pacchā somanassa cittena anussaraṇe ca ati tīsu kālesu pavattā cetanā dāna mayā nāma  sīlam paripūraṇa atthāya pana pabbajissāmi iti vihāram gacchantassa pabbajantassa manoratham  matthakam pāpetvā pabbajitaḥ vatamhi sādhu suṭṭhu iti āvajjantassa pātimokkham saṃvarantassa  cīvara ādayo paccaye paccavekkhantassa āpātha gatesu rūpa ādīsu cakkhu dvāra ādīni saṃvarantassa
translated: But in the case of the four requisites beginning with robe-cloth, or in the case of the six kinds of objects beginning with visible objects, or in the case of the ten objects of giving beginning with food, the volition that occurs in the three instances, namely, in the prior stage of producing them, in the actual giving, and in the subsequent recollection with gladness, is called “of giving.”

original: ājīvaṃ sodhentassa ca pavattā cetanā sīlamayā nāma. Paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttena vipassanāmaggena🔽cakkhuṃ aniccato dukkhato anattato bhāventassa rūpe…pe… dhamme, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ…pe…
analyzed: ājīvam sodhentassa ca pavattā cetanā sīla mayā nāma paṭisambhidā ayam vuttena vipassanā maggena 🔽cakkhum aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ anattataḥ bhāventassa rūpa pe dhamme cakkhu viññāṇaṃpe
