translated: But since one who has not abandoned ignorance develops the supramundane, it is a condition for that too in the way of surmounting,

original: paccayo hoti. Avijjāvatoyeva hi kusalāyūhanaṃ hoti, na itarassa. Tattha tebhūmakakusale
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti avijjāvato yeva hi kusala āyūhanam hoti na itarassa tattha tebhūmaka kusale
translated: for it is only the profitable rooted in ignorance that is productive of kamma, not the other. Herein,

original: sammohavasenapi samatikkamabhāvanāvasenapi āyūhanaṃ labbhati; lokuttare samucchedabhāvanāvasenāti.
analyzed: sammoha vasena api samatikkama bhāvanā vasena api āyūhanam labbhati lokuttare samuccheda bhāvanā vasena ati
translated: in the case of the profitable of the three planes, the productive is found in the way of delusion and in the way of development that surmounts, but in the case of the supramundane it is found in the way of cutting off and in the way of development.

original: Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.🔽Ayaṃ pana viseso – yathā heṭṭhā ekekakusale catunnaṃ catukkānaṃ vasena nava soḷasakā
analyzed: sesam vutta nayam eva  ayam pana visesaḥ yathā heṭṭhā ekeka kusale catunnam catukkānam vasena nava soḷasakā
translated: The rest is as already stated.

original: laddhā, tathā idha na labbhanti. Kasmā? Avijjāya avigatasampayuttaaññamaññapaccayābhāvato.
analyzed: laddhā tathā idha na labbhanti kasmai avijjāya avigata sampayutta aññamañña paccaya abhāvato
translated: But there is this difference. While in the case of the profitable of the three planes there are nine and sixteen kinds respectively, as already stated under the four tetrads in the case of each kind, that is not so here. Why? Because ignorance is neither a conascence nor a conjoined or related condition.

original: Upanissayavasena panettha paṭhamacatukkameva labbhati. Tampi paṭhamavārameva dassetvā
analyzed: upanissaya vasena pana ittha paṭhama catukkam eva labbhati tat pi paṭhama vāram eva dassetvā
translated: And that is shown in the first section.

original: saṃkhittaṃ. Nīharitvā pana dassetabbanti.🔽Avijjāmūlakakusalaniddesavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: saṃkhittam nīharitvā pana dassetabbanti  avijjā mūlaka kusala niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: But it should be shown by extracting it and setting it out separately.🔽The description of profitable kamma-result is finished.

original: Kusalamūlakavipākaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kusala mūlaka vipāka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of unprofitable kamma-result

original: 343. Idāni abyākatesupi apareneva nayena paccayākāraṃ dassetuṃ katame dhammā abyākatātiādi
analyzed: idāni abyākatesu pi aparena iva nayena paccaya ākāram dassetum katame dhammāḥ abyākata atiādi
translated: Now, in order to show the way of condition by another method even in the case of the indeterminate, “What are the indeterminate states? ” is begun.

original: āraddhaṃ. Tattha kusalamūlapaccayāti idampi upanissayapaccayataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: āraddham tattha kusala mūla paccayā ti idam pi upanissaya paccaya tam sandhāya vuttam
translated: Herein, root-cause condition is said with reference to decisive-support condition.

original: Kusalavipākassa hi kusalamūlaṃ, akusalavipākassa ca akusalamūlaṃ upanissayapaccayo
analyzed: kusala vipākassa hi kusala mūlam akusala vipākassa ca akusala mūlam upanissaya paccayaḥ
translated: For a profitable root is a condition as decisive-support for a profitable kamma-resultant, and an unprofitable root is a condition as decisive-support for an unprofitable kamma-resultant.

original: hoti; nānākkhaṇikakammapaccaye pana vattabbameva natthi. Tasmā esa upanissayapaccayena
analyzed: hoti nānākkhaṇika kamma paccaye pana vattabbam eva natthi tasmai esa upanissaya paccayena
translated: But there is nothing to be said about it as a condition by way of being kamma condition of a different kind.🔽So it is a condition as decisive-support condition🔽and as kamma condition of a different kind. That is why in the Description of Conditions it is said:

original: ceva nānākkhaṇikakammapaccayena ca paccayo hoti. Teneva niddesavāre “tattha katamaṃ
analyzed: ca iva nānākkhaṇika kamma paccayena ca paccayaḥ hoti tena iva niddesa vāre tattha katamam
translated: “Herein, what is a root-cause condition?

original: kusalamūla”nti avibhajitvā “tattha katamo kusalamūlapaccayā saṅkhāro”ti vibhattaṃ.
analyzed: kusala mūlanti a vibhajitvā tattha katamo kusala mūla paccayā saṅkhāro ti vibhattam
translated: but without distinguishing the wholesome roots, it is distinguished by “Herein, what is the formation conditioned by the wholesome roots?”

original: Akusalavipākepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: akusala vipāke pi esā iva nayo
translated: The same method applies in the case of the unprofitable resultants.

original: Avijjāmūlakakusalaniddese viya ca imasmimpi vipākaniddese paṭhamaṃ paccayacatukkameva🔽labbhati. Tampi paṭhamavāraṃ dassetvā saṃkhittaṃ. Tasmā ekekasmiṃ vipākacitte ekamekasseva
analyzed: avijjā mūlaka kusala niddese viya ca imasmim pi vipāka niddese paṭhamam paccaya catukkam eva  labbhati tam pi paṭhama vāram dassetvā saṃkhittam tasmai eka ekasmim vipāka citte ekam ekassa iva
translated: And just as in the description of the wholesome rooted in ignorance, so here in the description of the resultants, only the first of the four conditions, namely, decisive-support condition,🔽is applicable. And that is shown in the first section, which is then abbreviated. So the method of the wholesome rooted in ignorance and the method of the unprofitable rooted in ignorance should be understood respectively in each case according to the four conditions

original: catukkassa vasena kusalamūlamūlake akusalamūlamūlake ca naye vārappabhedo veditabbo.🔽Kiriyādhammānaṃ pana yasmā neva avijjā na kusalākusalamūlāni upanissayapaccayataṃ
analyzed: catukkassa vasena kusala mūla mūlake akusala mūla mūlake ca naye vāra ppabhedaḥ veditabbo  kiriyā dhammānam pana yasmā na eva avijjā na kusala akusala mūlāni upanissaya paccaya tam
translated: in each of the resultant consciousnesses.

original: labhanti, tasmā kiriyavasena paccayākāro na vuttoti.
analyzed: labhanti tasmā kiriya vasena paccaya ākāraḥ na vuttaḥ ti
translated: But the method of conditionality in the case of the functional is not stated because the functions do not obtain decisive-support condition either through ignorance or through the wholesome and unprofitable roots.

original: Evamesa –🔽Akusalakusalābyākata-dhammesu anekabhedato vatvā;
analyzed: evam esa  akusala kusala abyākata dhammesu aneka bhedataḥ vatvā
translated: So this method,🔽Having stated the unprofitable, the profitable, and the indeterminate,🔽The conditionality of the profitable and the unprofitable,

original: Kusalākusalānaṃ pana, vipāke ca upanissayavasena.
analyzed: kusala akusalānam pana vipāke ca upanissaya vasena
translated: And also of their results, by way of decisive-support,

original: Puna ekadhāva vutto, vādippavarena paccayākāro;
analyzed: puna ekadhā ava vuttaḥ vādi ppavarena paccaya ākāro
translated: Is stated again in one way by the supreme teacher.

original: Dhammappaccayabhede, ñāṇassa pabhedajananatthaṃ.
analyzed: dhamma ppaccaya bhede ñāṇassa pabheda janana attham
translated: In the analysis of conditions for the ideas, for the purpose of generating the analysis of knowledge.

original: Pariyattisavanacintana-paṭipattikkamavivajjitānañca;
analyzed: pariyatti savana cintana paṭipatti kkama vivajjitānam ca
translated: And for those who are devoid of learning, reflection, practice, and progress in the scriptures,

original: Yasmā ñāṇapabhedo, na kadācipi hoti etasmiṃ.🔽Pariyattisavanacintana-paṭipattikkamato sadā dhīro;
analyzed: yasmai etasmin  sadā dhīraḥ
translated: Since the analysis of knowledge never occurs in them.🔽The wise man should always,

original: Tattha kayirā na haññaṃ, karaṇīyataraṃ tato atthīti.
analyzed: tattha kayirā na haññam karaṇīyataram tatas atthi iti
translated: By means of learning, reflection, practice, and progress in the scriptures, do what is to be done there, for there is nothing more important than that.

original: Ayaṃ pana paccayākāro suttantaabhidhammabhājanīyavasena dveparivaṭṭameva nīharitvā bhājetvā dassito hoti.
analyzed: ayam pana paccaya ākāraḥ suttanta abhidhamma bhājanīya vasena dve parivaṭṭam eva nīharitvā bhājetvā dassitaḥ hoti
translated: But this method of conditionality is shown by taking it twice in succession, by way of the scriptures and the Abhidhamma, and by dividing it up.

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā
translated: The Abhidhamma Method

original: Sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sammoha vinodaniyā vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the Commentary on the Vibhanga called Sammohavinodani

original: Paṭiccasamuppādavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppāda vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of dependent origination is ended.

original: 7. Satipaṭṭhānavibhaṅgo
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna vibhaṅgaḥ
translated: The Vibhanga on the Arousing of Mindfulness

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyaṃ uddesavāravaṇṇanā🔽355. Idāni tadanantare satipaṭṭhānavibhaṅge cattāroti gaṇanaparicchedo. Tena na tato
analyzed: idāni tad anantare sati paṭṭhāna vibhaṅge cattāro ti gaṇana paricchedo tena na tatas
translated: The Method in the Scriptures: The Exposition of the Mode of Conveying a Numerical Category

original: heṭṭhā na uddhanti satipaṭṭhānaparicchedaṃ dīpeti. Satipaṭṭhānāti tayo satipaṭṭhānā
analyzed: heṭṭhā naḥ uddhanti sati paṭṭhāna paricchedam dīpeti sati paṭṭhānā ati tayo sati paṭṭhānā
translated: Now, in the Vibhanga on the Arousing of Mindfulness, which comes next, there are four, is the delimitation by number. By that it is not less than that, nor is it more, is what is meant. It shows the delimitation of the arousing of mindfulness. The arousings of mindfulness are three.

original: – satigocaropi, tidhā paṭipannesu sāvakesu satthuno paṭidhānunayavītivattatāpi, satipi.
analyzed: sati gocaraḥ api tidhā paṭipannesu sāvakesu satthuno sati pi
translated: and the object of mindfulness is also the four noble persons who have entered on the way, and the Teacher’s non-transgression of the training precepts is also the object of mindfulness.

original: “Catunnaṃ, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desessāmi. Taṃ suṇātha…pe…
analyzed: catunnam bhikkhave satipaṭṭhānānam samudayam ca atthaṅgamam ca desessāmi tam suṇāthape
translated: “Bhikkhus, I will teach you the origin and the passing away of the four foundations of mindfulness. Listen and attend closely to what I shall say” .

original: ko ca, bhikkhave, kāyassa samudayo? Āhārasamudayā kāyassa samudayo”tiādīsu hi satigocaro
analyzed: kaḥ ca bhikkhave kāyassa samudayaḥ āhāra samudayā kāyassa samudayaḥ ti ādīsu hi sati gocaraḥ
translated: Herein, the object of mindfulness is called “the foundation of mindfulness” in such passages as “What is the origin of the body? The body’s origin is nutriment” .

original: satipaṭṭhānanti vuccati. Tathā “kāyo upaṭṭhānaṃ, no sati. Sati upaṭṭhānañceva sati
analyzed: satipaṭṭhānanti vuccati tathā kāyaḥ upaṭṭhānam no sati sati upaṭṭhānam ca iva sati
translated: And in such passages as “The body is the establishment , not the mindfulness. Mindfulness is both the establishment and the mindfulness” .

original: cā”tiādīsu. Tassattho – patiṭṭhāti asminti paṭṭhānaṃ. Kā patiṭṭhāti? Sati. Satiyā
analyzed: ca ati ādīsu tassa atthaḥ patiṭṭhāti asmin ti paṭṭhānam kā patiṭṭhāti satī satiyā
translated: Herein, the meaning is this: it is an establishment since it establishes , i.e., it is a support, a ground, for that . What is established? Mindfulness.

original: paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ, padhānaṃ ṭhānanti vā paṭṭhānaṃ; satiyā paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ🔽hatthiṭṭhānaassaṭṭhānādīni viya.
analyzed: paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam padhānam ṭhānanti vā paṭṭhānam satiyā paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam  hatthi ṭṭhāna assa ṭṭhāna ādīni viya
translated: The establishment of mindfulness is the establishment for mindfulness. Or the establishment of mindfulness is the establishment in mindfulness, like the going of Devadatta and the going of Yajñadatta .

original: “Tayo satipaṭṭhānā yadariyo sevati, yadariyo sevamāno satthā gaṇaṃ anusāsitumarahatī”ti
analyzed: tayo sati paṭṭhānā yat ariyaḥ sevati yat ariyaḥ sevamāno satthā gaṇam anusāsitum arahati iti
translated: “There are these three foundations of mindfulness that the Noble One cultivates, cultivating which the Noble One is a teacher fit to instruct a group” .

original: ettha tidhā paṭipannesu sāvakesu satthuno paṭighānunayavītivattatā satipaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: ettha tidhā paṭipannesu sāvakesu satthuno paṭigha anunaya vītivatta tā sati paṭṭhānan ti
translated: The Teacher’s transcending of resistance and approval towards disciples who have entered upon the three ways is mindfulness occupied with the body.

original: vuttā. Tassattho – paṭṭhapetabbato paṭṭhānaṃ, pavattayitabbatoti attho. Kena paṭṭhapetabbatoti?🔽Satiyā; satiyā paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ. “Cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā
analyzed: vuttā tassa atthaḥ paṭṭhapetabbataḥ paṭṭhānam pavattayitabbataḥ ti attho kena paṭṭhapetabbataḥ ti  satiyā satiyā paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam cattāro sati paṭṭhānāḥ bhāvitāḥ bahulīkatā
translated: Herein, the teacher’s transcending of resentment and approval in regard to disciples who have entered upon the three ways is called “establishment of mindfulness” . Its meaning is this. It is establishment because it is what is to be established , because it is what is to be made to occur , is what is meant. By what is it to be established?

original: satta bojjhaṅge paripūrentī”tiādīsu pana satiyeva satipaṭṭhānanti vuccati. Tassattho
analyzed: satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti itiādīsu pana satiyā iva sati paṭṭhānan ti vuccati tassa attho
translated: By mindfulness . Mindfulness is establishment ; thus it is establishment of mindfulness . But in such passages as “The four establishments of mindfulness, developed and repeatedly practiced, bring the seven factors of enlightenment to fulfilment” , it is mindfulness itself that is called “establishment of mindfulness” . Its meaning is this.

original: – patiṭṭhātīti paṭṭhānaṃ, upaṭṭhāti okkanditvā pakkhanditvā pavattatīti attho; satiyeva
analyzed: patiṭṭhāti iti paṭṭhānam upaṭṭhāti okkanditvā pakkhanditvā pavattati iti attho satiyā eva
translated: It establishes , thus it is establishment ; it occurs by jumping down and landing on , is what is meant. Mindfulness itself is establishment in the sense of establishing ;

original: paṭṭhānaṭṭhena satipaṭṭhānaṃ; athavā saraṇaṭṭhena sati, upaṭṭhānaṭṭhena paṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Iti sati ca sā paṭṭhānañcātipi satipaṭṭhānaṃ. Idamidha adhippetaṃ. Yadi evaṃ, kasmā
analyzed: paṭṭhāna ṭṭhena sati paṭṭhānam athavā saraṇa ṭṭhena satī upaṭṭhāna ṭṭhena paṭṭhānam  iti sati ca sā sati paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam idam idha adhippetam yadi evam kasmā
translated: or alternatively, mindfulness is in the sense of remembering , establishment is in the sense of establishing .🔽So it is both mindfulness and establishment that is why it is called “establishment of mindfulness” . This is what is intended here. If that is so, why is the plural form “establishments of mindfulness” used?

original: satipaṭṭhānāti bahuvacanaṃ katanti? Satiyā bahuttā; ārammaṇabhedena hi bahukā tā satiyoti.
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānā iti bahuvacanam satiyā bahuttā ārammaṇa bhedena hi bahukā tā satiyā ti
translated: Because of the plurality of mindfulnesses ; for there are many mindfulnesses according to the different objects.

original: Kasmā pana bhagavatā cattārova satipaṭṭhānā vuttā, anūnā anadhikāti? Veneyyahitattā.
analyzed: kasmā pana bhagavatā cattāro va sati paṭṭhānā vuttāḥ anūnā anadhikā ati veneyya hita ttā
translated: But why are only four foundations of mindfulness stated by the Blessed One, neither less nor more? —Because of the disciples’ welfare.

original: Taṇhācaritadiṭṭhicaritasamathayānikavipassanāyānikesu hi mandatikkhavasena dvidhā
analyzed: taṇhā carita diṭṭhi carita samatha yānika vipassanā yānikesu hi manda tikkha vasena dvidhā
translated: For the four foundations of mindfulness are the path to enlightenment for disciples of all three kinds, namely, those of the faith-follower type, those of the Dhamma-follower type, and those who are ordinarily called “those resolved on faith” and “those resolved on views” .

original: pavattesu mandassa taṇhācaritassa oḷārikaṃ kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ visuddhimaggo,🔽tikkhassa sukhumaṃ vedanānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ. Diṭṭhicaritassapi mandassa nātippabhedagataṃ🔽cittānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ visuddhimaggo, tikkhassa atippabhedagataṃ dhammānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: pavattesu mandassa taṇhā caritassa oḷārikam kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam visuddhi maggo  tikkhassa sukhumam vedanā anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam diṭṭhi caritassa api mandassa na ati ppabheda gatam  citta anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam visuddhi maggo tikkhassa ati pabheda gatam dhamma anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam
translated: Of these, the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body is the path to enlightenment for those of the faith-follower type who are of low acumen and for those of the Dhamma-follower type who are of low acumen and of the type ordinarily called “those resolved on faith.”🔽The foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of feelings is the path to enlightenment for those of the faith-follower type who are of keen acumen and for those of the Dhamma-follower type who are of keen acumen and of the type ordinarily called “those resolved on views.”🔽The foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the mind is the path to enlightenment for those of the faith-follower type who are of low acumen and for those of the Dhamma-follower type who are of low acumen and of the type ordinarily called “those resolved on faith.”

original: Samathayānikassa ca mandassa akicchena adhigantabbanimittaṃ paṭhamaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: samatha yānikassa ca mandassa a kicchena adhigantabba nimittam paṭhamam satipaṭṭhānam
translated: The foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of mental objects is the path to enlightenment for those of the faith-follower type who are of keen acumen and for those of the Dhamma-follower type who are of keen acumen and of the type ordinarily called “those resolved on views.”🔽The first foundation of mindfulness is the path to enlightenment for those of the type ordinarily called “those resolved on faith” who are of low acumen and who are of the vehicle of faith and for those of the type ordinarily called “those resolved on views” who are of low acumen and who are of the vehicle of faith.

original: visuddhimaggo, tikkhassa oḷārikārammaṇe asaṇṭhahanato dutiyaṃ. Vipassanāyānikassāpi
analyzed: visuddhi maggo tikkhassa oḷārika ārammaṇe a saṇṭhahanataḥ dutiyam vipassanāyānikassa api
translated: The second foundation of mindfulness is the path to enlightenment for those of the type ordinarily called “those resolved on faith” who are of keen acumen and for those of the type ordinarily called “those resolved on views” who are of keen acumen and who are of the vehicle of faith.

original: mandassa nātippabhedagatārammaṇaṃ tatiyaṃ, tikkhassa atippabhedagatārammaṇaṃ catutthaṃ.
analyzed: mandassa na ati pabheda gata ārammaṇam tatiyam tikkhassa ati pabheda gata ārammaṇam catuttham
translated: The third is the object of one of sluggish intelligence, which is not very varied; the fourth is the object of one of keen intelligence, which is very varied.

original: Iti cattārova vuttā, anūnā anadhikāti.🔽Subhasukhaniccaattabhāvavipallāsappahānatthaṃ vā. Kāyo hi asubho. Tattha subhavipallāsavipallatthā
analyzed: iti cattāro va vuttāḥ anūnā anadhikā ati  vā kāyaḥ hi asubhaḥ tattha
translated: So they are stated as four, neither less nor more.🔽Or alternatively, they are stated as four for the purpose of abandoning the fourfold perversion, namely, perversion of perception, of consciousness, of view, and of craving.🔽For the body is foul, and beings are perverted by perversion of perception in regard to it,

original: sattā. Tesaṃ tattha asubhabhāvadassanena tassa vipallāsassa pahānatthaṃ paṭhamaṃ🔽satipaṭṭhānaṃ vuttaṃ. Sukhaṃ, niccaṃ, attāti gahitesupi ca vedanādīsu vedanā dukkhā,
analyzed: sattā tesam tattha asubha bhāva dassanena tassa vipallāsassa pahāna attham paṭhamam  sati paṭṭhānam vuttam sukham niccam attā ati gahitesu pi ca vedanā ādīsu vedanā dukkhā
translated: thinking it is fair. The first foundation of mindfulness is stated for the purpose of abandoning that perversion by showing them the foulness in the body.

original: cittaṃ aniccaṃ, dhammā anattā. Etesu ca sukhaniccaattabhāvavipallāsavipallatthā sattā.
analyzed: cittam aniccam dhammāḥ anattāḥ etesu ca sukha nicca atta bhāva vipallāsa vipallatthā sattā
translated: And in regard to feeling, which is assumed to be pleasant, and in regard to consciousness, which is assumed to be permanent, and in regard to ideas, which are assumed to be self, beings are perverted by perversion of consciousness, by perversion of view, and by perversion of craving, respectively.

original: Tesaṃ tattha dukkhādibhāvadassanena tesaṃ vipallāsānaṃ pahānatthaṃ sesāni tīṇi vuttānīti.
analyzed: tesam tattha dukkha ādi bhāva dassanena tesam vipallāsānam pahāna attham sesāni tīṇi vuttāni iti
translated: The remaining three foundations of mindfulness are stated for the purpose of abandoning those perversions by showing them the pain in feeling, the impermanence in consciousness, and the not-selfhood in all ideas.

original: Evaṃ subhasukhaniccaattabhāvavipallāsappahānatthaṃ vā cattārova vuttā anūnā anadhikāti
analyzed: evam subha sukha nicca atta bhāva vipallāsa ppahāna attham vā cattāro va vuttāḥ anūnā anadhikā ti
translated: So they are stated as four for the purpose of abandoning the fourfold perversion, namely, perversion of perception, of consciousness, of view, and of craving, neither less nor more.

original: veditabbā. Na kevalañca vipallāsapahānatthameva, atha kho caturoghayogāsavaganthaupādānaagatippahānatthampi
analyzed: veditabbā na kevalam ca vipallāsa pahāna attham eva atha kho catur ogha yoga āsava gantha upādāna agati ppahāna attham pi
translated: should be known. And not only for the purpose of abandoning the four perversions, but also for the purpose of abandoning the four diseases, the four fires, the four bonds, the four ties, the four floods, the four knots, the four clingings, and the four wrongnesses.

original: catubbidhāhārapariññatthañca cattārova vuttāti veditabbā. Ayaṃ tāva pakaraṇanayo.
analyzed: catubbidha āhāra pariñña ttham ca cattāro va vuttā ati veditabbā ayam tāva pakaraṇa nayo
translated: and they should be understood as four because they are the means for the full-understanding of the four kinds of nutriment. This, in the first place, is the method of the text.

original: Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “saraṇavasena ceva ekattasamosaraṇavasena ca ekameva satipaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pana saraṇa vasena ca iva ekatta samosaraṇa vasena ca ekam eva sati paṭṭhānam
translated: But in the commentary it is said that they are one in being the refuge and in being the convergence of unity,

original: ārammaṇavasena cattāroti etadeva vuttaṃ. Yathā hi catudvāre nagare pācīnato āgacchantā
analyzed: ārammaṇa vasena cattāro ti etat eva vuttam yathā hi catu dvāre nagare pācīnatas āgacchantā
translated: and four in being objects. What is meant is this: just as people coming from the east, taking the goods produced in the east, enter the city by the eastern gate and go no farther than the city,

original: pācīnadisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā pācīnadvārena nagarameva pavisanti, dakkhiṇato,🔽pacchimato, uttarato āgacchantā uttaradisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā uttaradvārena🔽nagarameva pavisanti, evaṃ sampadamidaṃ veditabbaṃ. Nagaraṃ viya hi nibbānamahānagaraṃ,
analyzed: pācīna disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā pācīna dvārena nagaram eva pavisanti dakkhiṇatas  pacchimatas uttaratas āgacchantāḥ uttara disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā uttara dvārena  nagaram eva pavisanti evam sampadam idam veditabbam nagaram viya hi nibbāna mahā nagaram
translated: and those coming from the south, north, and west do likewise,

original: dvāraṃ viya aṭṭhaṅgiko lokuttaramaggo. Pācīnadisādayo viya kāyādayo.
analyzed: dvāram viya aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ lokuttara maggo pācīna disā ādayaḥ viya kāya ādayaḥ
translated: so too, the four foundations of mindfulness should be understood as the city and the four kinds of objects as the four gates. For just as the city is the refuge for those who have entered it, so too, the foundation of mindfulness that is concentration is the refuge for those who have entered it.🔽And just as the city is the convergence of unity for those who have entered it, since there is no distinction of east, west, etc., in the case of those who have gone there, so too, the foundation of mindfulness that is concentration is the convergence of unity for those who have entered it, since there is no distinction of lust, hate, and so on, in the case of those who have gone there.

original: Yathā pācīnato āgacchantā pācīnadisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā pācīnadvārena nagarameva
analyzed: yathā pācīnataḥ āgacchantā pācīna disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā pācīna dvārena nagaram eva
translated: Just as those coming from the east take up goods in the eastern direction and enter the city by the eastern gate,

original: pavisanti, evaṃ kāyānupassanāmukhena āgacchantā cuddasavidhena kāyānupassanaṃ bhāvetvā🔽kāyānupassanābhāvanānubhāvanibbattena ariyamaggena ekaṃ nibbānameva osaranti. Yathā🔽dakkhiṇato āgacchantā dakkhiṇadisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇadvārena nagarameva🔽pavisanti, evaṃ vedanānupassanāmukhena āgacchantā navavidhena vedanānupassanaṃ bhāvetvā
analyzed: pavisanti evam kāya anupassanā mukhena āgacchantā cuddasavidhena kāya anupassanam bhāvetvā  kāya anupassanā bhāvanā anubhāva nibbattena ariya maggena ekam nibbānam eva osaranti yathā  dakkhiṇatas āgacchantāḥ dakkhiṇa disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā dakkhiṇa dvārena nagaram eva  pavisanti evam vedanā anupassanā mukhena āgacchantāḥ navavidhena vedanā anupassanam bhāvetvā
translated: Just as those coming from the east enter the city by the eastern gate, taking with them the goods they have acquired in the eastern direction, so too, those who come by the way of contemplation of the body enter Nibbāna by the way of contemplation of the body, having developed the fourteen aspects of contemplation of the body and having generated the noble path that has arisen through the power of the development of contemplation of the body.

original: vedanānupassanābhāvanānubhāvanibbattena ariyamaggena ekaṃ nibbānameva osaranti. Yathā
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā bhāvanā anubhāva nibbattena ariya maggena ekam nibbānam eva osaranti yathā
translated: Just as those coming from the south enter the city by the southern gate, taking with them the goods they have acquired in the southern direction, so too, those who come by the way of contemplation of feeling enter Nibbāna by the way of contemplation of feeling, having developed the nine aspects of contemplation of feeling and having generated the noble path that has arisen through the power of the development of contemplation of feeling.

original: pacchimato āgacchantā pacchimadisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā pacchimadvārena nagarameva
analyzed: pacchimatas āgacchantā pacchima disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā pacchima dvārena nagaram eva
translated: Just as those coming from the west enter the city by the western gate, taking with them the goods they have acquired in the western direction, so too, those who come by the way of contemplation of mind enter Nibbāna by the way of contemplation of mind, having developed the six aspects of contemplation of mind and having generated the noble path that has arisen through the power of the development of contemplation of mind.

original: pavisanti, evaṃ cittānupassanāmukhena āgacchantā soḷasavidhena cittānupassanaṃ bhāvetvā
analyzed: pavisanti evam citta anupassanā mukhena āgacchantā soḷasavidhena citta anupassanam bhāvetvā
translated: and they come by the way of contemplation of cognizance, and after developing the contemplation of cognizance in the sixteen ways,

original: cittānupassanābhāvanānubhāvanibbattena ariyamaggena ekaṃ nibbānameva osaranti. Yathā
analyzed: citta anupassanā bhāvanā anubhāva nibbattena ariya maggena ekam nibbānam eva osaranti yathā
translated: they all descend to extinction by the noble path generated by the power of the contemplation of cognizance.

original: uttarato āgacchantā uttaradisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā uttaradvārena nagarameva
analyzed: uttaratas āgacchantāḥ uttara disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā uttara dvārena nagaram eva
translated: Just as those coming from the north take the goods produced in the north and enter the city by the northern gate,

original: pavisanti, evaṃ dhammānupassanāmukhena āgacchantā pañcavidhena dhammānupassanaṃ bhāvetvā
analyzed: pavisanti evam dhamma anupassanā mukhena āgacchantā pañcavidhena dhamma anupassanam bhāvetvā
translated: so those who come by the way of contemplation of mental objects develop the contemplation of mental objects in the five ways,

original: dhammānupassanābhāvanānubhāvanibbattena ariyamaggena ekaṃ nibbānameva osarantīti.
analyzed: dhamma anupassanā bhāvanā anubhāva nibbattena ariya maggena ekam nibbānam eva osaranti iti
translated: and they all descend to extinction by the noble path generated by the power of the contemplation of mental objects.

original: Evaṃ saraṇavasena ceva ekattasamosaraṇavasena ca ekameva satipaṭṭhānaṃ ārammaṇavasena
analyzed: evam saraṇa vasena ca iva ekatta samosaraṇa vasena ca ekam eva sati paṭṭhānam ārammaṇa vasena
translated: So it should be understood that the four foundations of mindfulness are stated thus in terms of refuge and in terms of the single descent into unity,

original: cattāroti vuttāti veditabbā.
analyzed: cattāraḥ iti vuttā iti veditabbā
translated: but in terms of object they are four.

original: Idha bhikkhūti ettha kiñcāpi bhagavatā devaloke nisīditvā ayaṃ satipaṭṭhānavibhaṅgo
analyzed: idha bhikkhu iti ettha kiñcā api bhagavatā deva loke nisīditvā ayam sati paṭṭhāna vibhaṅgo
translated: Herein, bhikkhus: here the Blessed One, after descending from the world of the gods, was staying in the World of Men at the Gotamaka shrine between the twin sal trees in the sal-grove of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā.

original: kathito, ekabhikkhupi tattha bhagavato santike nisinnako nāma natthi. Evaṃ santepi
analyzed: kathitaḥ eka bhikkhu pi tattha bhagavato santike nisinnakaḥ nāma natthi evam sante pi
translated: And not a single bhikkhu was sitting there in the Blessed One’s presence. Nevertheless,

original: yasmā ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhikkhū bhāventi, bhikkhugocarā hi ete, tasmā idha
analyzed: yasmai ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhikkhū bhāventi bhikkhu gocarāḥ hi ete tasmai idha
translated: since these four foundations of mindfulness are being developed by bhikkhus, and since they are the province of bhikkhus,🔽the Exalted One addresses the bhikkhus here.

original: bhikkhūti ālapati. Kiṃ panete satipaṭṭhāne bhikkhūyeva bhāventi, na bhikkhunīādayoti?
analyzed: bhikkhū iti ālapati kim pana ete satipaṭṭhāne bhikkhūya iva bhāventi na bhikkhunī ādayo ti
translated: But why are only bhikkhus and not bhikkhunīs, etc., capable of developing these foundations of mindfulness?

original: Bhikkhunīādayopi bhāventi. Bhikkhū pana aggaparisā. Iti aggaparisattā idha bhikkhūti
analyzed: bhikkhunī ādayaḥ api bhāventi bhikkhū pana agga parisā iti agga parisattāḥ idha bhikkhū ti
translated: Bhikkhunīs, etc., are also capable of developing them. But bhikkhus are the chief community. Thus the Exalted One addresses the bhikkhus here as the chief community.

original: ālapati. Paṭipattiyā vā bhikkhubhāvadassanato evamāha. Yo hi imaṃ paṭipattiṃ paṭipajjati,
analyzed: ālapati paṭipattiyāḥ vā bhikkhu bhāva dassanataḥ evam āha yaḥ hi imam paṭipattim paṭipajjati
translated: Or he speaks thus in order to show that one becomes a bhikkhu by undertaking this practice. For one who undertakes this practice

original: so bhikkhu nāma hoti. Paṭipannako hi devo vā hotu manusso vā, bhikkhūti saṅkhaṃ gacchatiyeva. Yathāha –
analyzed: saḥ bhikkhu nāma hoti paṭipannakaḥ hi devaḥ vā hotu manusso vā bhikkhu iti saṅkham gacchatiyā iva yathā āha
translated: is called a bhikkhu. Whether he is a god or a human being who has entered upon the practice, he is called a bhikkhu. As it is said:

original: “Alaṅkato cepi samañcareyya,
analyzed: alaṅkato cepi samañcareyya
translated: “Though he be decked with ornaments,

original: Santo danto niyato brahmacārī;
analyzed: santaḥ dantaḥ niyataḥ brahmacārī
translated: If he is peaceful, controlled, restrained, and lives the spiritual life,

original: Sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍaṃ,
analyzed: sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍam
translated: Having laid aside the rod against all beings—

original: So brāhmaṇo so samaṇo sa bhikkhū”ti. ;
analyzed: saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ saḥ samaṇaḥ sa bhikkhu iti
translated: He is a brahman, he is a bhikkhu, he is a monk” .

original: Kāyānupassanāuddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kāya anupassanā uddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Direction for Contemplating the Body

original: Ajjhattanti niyakajjhattaṃ adhippetaṃ. Tasmā ajjhattaṃ kāyeti attano kāyeti attho.
analyzed: ajjhattam nti niyaka jjhattam adhippetam tasmai ajjhattam kāye iti attano kāye iti attho
translated: “Internal” is intended as one’s own . Thus the meaning is: “one’s own body.”

original: Tattha kāyeti rūpakāye. Rūpakāyo hi idha aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ kesādīnañca dhammānaṃ samūhaṭṭhena,
analyzed: tattha kāya iti rūpa kāye rūpa kāyaḥ hi idha aṅga paccaṅgānam kesa ādīnam ca dhammānam samūhaṭṭhena
translated: Herein, “body” is the material body. For the material body is intended here in the sense of a collection of parts and components, of head-hairs, body-hairs, etc.,

original: hatthikāyaassakāyarathakāyādayo viya, kāyoti adhippeto. Yathā ca samūhaṭṭhena evaṃ
analyzed: hatthi kāya assa kāya ratha kāya ādayaḥ viya kāyaḥ ti adhippetaḥ yathā ca samūha aṭṭhena evam
translated: like the body of an army, the body of a tree, etc. And just as it is a collection, so too

original: kucchitānaṃ āyaṭṭhena. Kucchitānañhi paramajegucchānaṃ so āyotipi kāyo. Āyoti uppattideso.🔽Tatrāyaṃ vacanattho – āyanti tatoti āyo. Ke āyanti? Kucchitā kesādayo. Iti kucchitānaṃ
analyzed: āya ṭṭhena kucchitānam hi parama jegucchānam saḥ kāyaḥ uppatti deso  tatra ayam vacana attho āyanti ke āyanti kucchitā kesa ādayo iti
translated: it is a source for what is contemptible, for all such things as urine and excrement. For it is a source in the sense of a place of origin for what is contemptible, for what is extremely detestable.

original: kesādīnaṃ āyoti kāyo.
analyzed: kesa ādīnam
translated: Herein, the word-meaning is this: āyanti etasmāti āyo . What is it that comes? The contemptible things, head-hairs, etc. So the body is a source for what is contemptible, for head-hairs, etc.

original: Kāyānupassīti kāyaṃ anupassanasīlo, kāyaṃ vā anupassamāno kāyeti ca vatvāpi puna
analyzed: kāya anupassī iti kāyam anupassana sīlaḥ kāyam vā anupassamānaḥ kāya iti ca vatvā api punar
translated: “One who contemplates the body”: one who is possessed of the contemplation of the body, or one who is contemplating the body. Although he said “the body” already,

original: kāyānupassīti dutiyaṃ kāyaggahaṇaṃ asammissato vavatthānaghanavinibbhogādidassanatthaṃ
analyzed: kāya anupassī ti dutiyam kāya ggahaṇam a sammissataḥ vavatthāna ghana vinibbhoga ādi dassana tham
translated: he repeats the word “body” in “one who contemplates the body” in order to show that it is the body that is to be discerned by specific and general characteristics, by the method of front and back, etc., and by the method of the anatomical parts, etc.

original: katanti veditabbaṃ. Tena na kāye vedanānupassī cittadhammānupassī vā; atha kho kāye🔽kāyānupassī yevāti kāyasaṅkhāte vatthusmiṃ kāyānupassanākārasseva dassanena asammissato
analyzed: katam ti veditabbam tena na kāye vedanā anupassī citta dhamma anupassī vā atha kho kāye  kāya anupassī yeva āti kāya saṅkhāte vatthusmim kāya anupassanā ākārassa iva dassanena a sammissato
translated: This should be understood. So he is not contemplating feeling in the body, or contemplating consciousness in the body, or contemplating mind in the body, but rather he is contemplating the body in the body.🔽Thus it is shown that the delimitation of the body as a particular object is by means of the seeing of the aspect of contemplation of the body.🔽He is not contemplating a single state free from the limbs and secondary limbs of the body,

original: vavatthānaṃ dassitaṃ hoti. Tathā na kāye aṅgapaccaṅgavinimuttaekadhammānupassī, nāpi🔽kesalomādivinimuttaitthipurisānupassī. Yopi cettha kesalomādiko bhūtupādāyasamūhasaṅkhāto
analyzed: vavatthānam dassitam hoti tathā na kāye aṅga paccaṅga vinimutta eka dhamma anupassī na api  kesa loma ādi vinimutta aitthi purisa anupassī yaḥ api ca ittha kesa loma ādikaḥ bhūta upādāya samūha saṅkhātaḥ
translated: nor is he contemplating a woman or a man free from the hair of the head, etc.,🔽or the body consisting of the aggregate of elements and bases beginning with hair of the head, etc.

original: kāyo, tatthāpi na bhūtupādāyavinimuttaekadhammānupassī; atha kho rathasambhārānupassako🔽viya aṅgapaccaṅgasamūhānupassī, nagarāvayavānupassako viya kesalomādisamūhānupassī,
analyzed: kāyaḥ tattha api na bhūta upādāya vinimutta eka dhamma anupassī atha kho ratha sambhāra anupassakaḥ  viya aṅga paccaṅga samūha anupassī nagara avayava anupassakaḥ viya kesa loma ādi samūha anupassī
translated: He is not contemplating a single state free from the elements and bases, but rather he is contemplating the aggregate of limbs and secondary limbs as one, like one who sees a chariot by the aggregate of its parts,🔽or the aggregate of hair of the head, etc., as one, like one who sees a city by the aggregate of its parts,

original: kadalikkhandhapattavaṭṭivinibhuñjako viya rittamuṭṭhiviniveṭhako viya ca bhūtupādāyasamūhānupassīyevāti
analyzed: kadali kkhandha patta vaṭṭi vinibhuñjakaḥ viya ritta muṭṭhi viniveṭhakaḥ viya ca bhūta upādāya samūha anupassīya iva ati
translated: or the aggregate of elements and bases as one, like one who eats a plantain trunk by the aggregate of its layers, or like one who takes a handful of sesamum seeds as a handful.

original: nānappakārato samūhavasena kāyasaṅkhātassa vatthuno dassanena ghanavinibbhogo dassito
analyzed: nānā pakārataḥ samūha vasena kāya saṅkhātassa vatthunaḥ dassanena ghana vinibbhogaḥ dassitaḥ
translated: The penetration of solidity is shown by the seeing of the “body” as a collection in the various ways.

original: hoti. Na hettha yathāvuttasamūhavinimutto kāyo vā itthī vā puriso vā añño vā koci
analyzed: hoti na ha ittha yathāvutta samūha vinimutto kāyo vā itthī vā purisaḥ vā añño vā koci
translated: For no “body” is seen apart from the collection in the various ways described, nor any woman or man or any other such thing.

original: dhammo dissati. Yathāvuttadhammasamūhamatteyeva pana tathā tathā sattā micchābhinivesaṃ
analyzed: dhammo dissati pana tathā tathā sattā micchā abhinivesam
translated: But only in the mere collection of states described in the various ways do beings settle down on it in various ways through wrong view,🔽wrong knowledge, wrong belief, wrong resolve, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong concentration.

original: karonti. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: karonti tena āhu porāṇā
translated: That is why the Ancients said:

original: “Yaṃ passati na taṃ diṭṭhaṃ, yaṃ diṭṭhaṃ taṃ na passati;
analyzed: yam passati na tam diṭṭham yam diṭṭham tam na passati
translated: “What he sees is not seen; What’s seen is not seen.

original: Apassaṃ bajjhate mūḷho, bajjhamāno na muccatī”ti.
analyzed: a passam bajjhate mūḍhaḥ bajjhamānaḥ na muccati iti
translated: The fool, deluded, is caught; Being caught, he is not freed.”

original: Ghanavinibbhogādidassanatthanti vuttaṃ. Ādisaddena cettha ayampi attho veditabbo
analyzed: ghana vinibbhoga ādi dassana atthan ti vuttam ādi saddena ca ittha ayam pi atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The meaning of the words “in order to show the penetration of solidity, etc.” should be understood in this way. But the words “and so on” include this meaning too, namely that

original: – ayañhi etasmiṃ kāye kāyānupassīyeva, na aññadhammānupassī. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Yathā
analyzed: ayam hi etasmin kāye kāya anupassī iva na añña dhamma anupassī kim vuttam hoti yathā
translated: he is only a contemplator of the body in the body, not a contemplator of any other thing. What is meant?🔽Just as those who see water in a mirage are not contemplators of anything other than a mirage, so too

original: anudakabhūtāyapi marīciyā udakānupassino honti, na evaṃ aniccadukkhānattaasubhabhūteyeva
analyzed: anudaka bhūtāya api marīciyā udaka anupassinaḥ honti na evam anicca dukkha anatta asubha bhūteya eva
translated: he is not a contemplator of anything other than what is impermanent, painful, not-self, and foul.

original: imasmiṃ kāye niccasukhaattasubhabhāvānupassī; atha kho kāyānupassī aniccadukkhānattaasubhākārasamūhānupassīyevāti
analyzed: imasmin kāye nicca sukha atta subha bhāva anupassī atha kho kāya anupassī anicca dukkha anatta asubha ākāra samūha anupassīya iva ati
translated: and he contemplates the body as permanent, blissful, and self, then he is contemplating the body as a collection of the aspects of impermanence, pain, and not-self.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Atha vā yvāyaṃ mahāsatipaṭṭhāne “idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato
analyzed: vuttam hoti atha vā yvā ayam mahā sati paṭṭhāne idha bhikkhave bhikkhu arañña gataḥ
translated: Or alternatively, the body that is stated in the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta in the way beginning, “When he has gone to the forest, or to the foot of a tree, or to an empty place” ,

original: vā…pe… so satova assasatī”tiādinā nayena assāsapassāsādicuṇṇakajātaaṭṭhikapariyosāno🔽kāyo vutto, yo ca “idhekacco pathavīkāyaṃ aniccato anupassati, tathā āpokāyaṃ, tejokāyaṃ,🔽vāyokāyaṃ, kesakāyaṃ, lomakāyaṃ, chavikāyaṃ, cammakāyaṃ, maṃsakāyaṃ, rudhirakāyaṃ,
analyzed: vāpe saḥ sataḥ va assasati itiādinā nayena assāsa passāsa ādi cuṇṇaka jāta aṭṭhika pariyosānaḥ  kāyaḥ vuttaḥ yaḥ ca idha ekaccaḥ pathavīkāyam aniccataḥ anupassati tathā āpokāyam tejaḥkāyam  vāyokāyam kesa kāyam lomakāyam chavikāyam camma kāyam maṃsa kāyam rudhira kāyam
translated: and ending, “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out experiencing the head hairs, body hairs, teeth, nails, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney, heart, liver, midriff, spleen, lungs, bowels, entrails, gorge, dung, head hairs, body hairs, and skin’ ” ,

original: nhārukāyaṃ, aṭṭhikāyaṃ, aṭṭhimiñjakāya”nti paṭisambhidāyaṃ kāyo vutto, tassa sabbassa
analyzed: nhārukāyam aṭṭhi kāyam aṭṭhimiñjakāyanti paṭisambhidā ayam kāyaḥ vutto tassa sabbassa
translated: and the body that is stated in the Paṭisambhidā in the way beginning, “One contemplates the earth body as impermanent; thus one contemplates; one contemplates the water body … the fire body … the air body … the head hairs and body hairs body … the skin body … the flesh body … the sinews body … the bones body … the bone marrow body … the liver body … the midriff body … the spleen body … the kidneys body … the heart body … the pleura body … the undigested food body … the excrement body … the bladder body … the dung body … the brain body … the tears body … the grease body … the spittle body … the snot body … the oil of the joints body … the fatty tissue body … the bile body … the phlegm body … the pus body … the blood body … the sweat body … the breath body … the voice body … the heat body … the life body as impermanent” ,🔽all of which is included in this very body,

original: imasmiṃyeva kāye anupassanato kāye kāyānupassīti evampi attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: imasmin yeva kāye anupassanato kāye kāya anupassī iti evam pi atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: should be regarded as the meaning of “contemplating the body in the body.”

original: Atha vā kāye ahanti vā mamanti vā evaṃ gahetabbassa kassaci ananupassanato, tassa
analyzed: atha vā kāye ahanti vā mamanti vā evam gahetabbassa kassaci an anupassanataḥ tassa
translated: Or alternatively, he is a contemplator of the body in the body because he does not contemplate anything as “the body” or as “mine” that could be apprehended as such.

original: tasseva pana kesalomādikassa nānādhammasamūhassa anupassanato kāye kesādidhammasamūhasaṅkhāte
analyzed: tassa iva pana kesa loma ādikassa nānā dhamma samūhassa anupassanato kāye kesa ādi dhamma samūha saṅkhāte
translated: But since he contemplates the collection of states called head-hairs, body-hairs, etc., which is the mere aggregate of various states, he is called “one who contemplates the body as a body” .

original: kāyānupassīti evamattho daṭṭhabbo. Apica “imasmiṃ kāye aniccato anupassati, no niccato”tiādinā🔽anukkamena paṭisambhidāyaṃ āgatanayassa sabbasseva aniccalakkhaṇādino ākārasamūhasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: kāya anupassī iti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ apica imasmin kāye aniccataḥ anupassati no niccataḥ tiādinā  anukkamena paṭisambhidāyam āgata nayassa sabbassa iva anicca lakkhaṇa ādinaḥ ākāra samūha saṅkhātassa
translated: Again, the meaning can be regarded as follows: he contemplates the body as impermanent, not as permanent, and so on, in the way stated in the Paṭisambhidā.

original: kāyassa anupassanatopi kāye kāyānupassīti evampi attho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Tathā hi ayaṃ kāye kāyānupassanāpaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno bhikkhu imaṃ kāyaṃ aniccānupassanādīnaṃ
analyzed: kāyassa anupassanataḥ pi kāye kāya anupassī iti evam pi atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  tathā hi ayam kāye kāya anupassanā paṭipadam paṭipannaḥ bhikkhu imam kāyam anicca anupassanā ādīnam
translated: Thus he is called “one who contemplates the body as a body” because he contemplates the body as a collection of aspects such as impermanence, etc.

original: sattannaṃ anupassanānaṃ vasena aniccato anupassati no niccato, dukkhato anupassati
analyzed: sattannam anupassanānam vasena aniccataḥ anupassati no niccatas dukkhataḥ anupassati
translated: For when a bhikkhu is practising the way of insight by means of contemplation of the body as a body, he contemplates this body as impermanent, not as permanent, by means of the seven contemplations beginning with contemplation of rise and fall,🔽as painful, not as pleasant,

original: no sukhato, anattato anupassati no attato, nibbindati no nandati, virajjati no rajjati,
analyzed: no sukhataḥ anattataḥ anupassati no attataḥ nibbindati no nandati virajjati no rajjati
translated: as not self, not as self, he becomes dispassionate, not desirous, he causes greed to fade away, not to grow,

original: nirodheti no samudeti, paṭinissajjati no ādiyati. So taṃ aniccato anupassanto niccasaññaṃ
analyzed: nirodheti no samudeti paṭinissajjati no ādiyati saḥ tam aniccataḥ anupassantaḥ nicca saññam
translated: He abandons, does not accumulate; he relinquishes, does not grasp. As he contemplates thus “impermanent,” he abandons the perception of permanence;

original: pajahati, dukkhato anupassanto sukhasaññaṃ pajahati, anattato anupassanto attasaññaṃ🔽pajahati, nibbindanto nandiṃ pajahati, virajjanto rāgaṃ pajahati, nirodhento samudayaṃ
analyzed: pajahati dukkhataḥ anupassantaḥ sukha saññam pajahati anattataḥ anupassantaḥ atta saññam  pajahati nibbindantaḥ nandim pajahati virajjantaḥ rāgam pajahati nirodhentaḥ samudayam
translated: as he contemplates thus “painful,” he abandons the perception of pleasure; as he contemplates thus “not-self,” he abandons the perception of self;

original: pajahati, paṭinissajjanto ādānaṃ pajahatīti veditabbo.🔽Viharatīti catūsu iriyāpathavihāresu aññataravihārasamāyogaparidīpanametaṃ, ekaṃ
analyzed: pajahati paṭinissajjantaḥ ādānam pajahati iti veditabbo  viharati iti catūsu iriyāpatha vihāresu aññatara vihāra samāyoga paridīpanam etam ekam
translated: as he contemplates thus “abandoning,” he abandons the perception of grasping.

original: iriyāpathabādhanaṃ aparena iriyāpathena vicchinditvā apatamānaṃ attabhāvaṃ harati pavattetīti attho.
analyzed: iriyāpatha bādhanam aparena iriyāpathena vicchinditvā a patamānam atta bhāvam harati pavatteti iti attho
translated: He dwells: this shows that he is associated with one of the four kinds of dwelling in the postures. The meaning is that he carries on, he conducts himself, without letting his body fall down owing to the obstruction of one posture by another.

original: Bahiddhā kāyeti parassa kāye. Ajjhattabahiddhā kāyeti kālena attano kāye, kālena
analyzed: bahiddhā kāye iti parassa kāye ajjhatta bahiddhā kāye iti kālena attano kāye kālena
translated: In another’s: in another’s body. In one’s own and in another’s: sometimes in one’s own body,

original: parassa kāye. Paṭhamanayena hi attano kāye kāyapariggaho vutto, dutiyanayena parassa
analyzed: parassa kāye paṭhama nayena hi attano kāye kāya pariggaho vuttaḥ dutiya nayena parassa
translated: sometimes in another’s. For in the first way the contemplation of one’s own body is stated, and in the second that of another’s.

original: kāye, tatiyanayena kālena attano kālena parassa kāye. Ajjhattabahiddhā pana ghaṭitārammaṇaṃ🔽nāma natthi. Paguṇakammaṭṭhānassa pana aparāparaṃ sañcaraṇakālo ettha kathito. Ātāpīti🔽kāyapariggāhakavīriyasamāyogaparidīpanametaṃ. So hi yasmā tasmiṃ samaye yaṃ taṃ vīriyaṃ
analyzed: kāye tatiya nayena kālena attanaḥ kālena parassa kāye ajjhatta bahiddhā pana ghaṭita ārammaṇam  nāma natthi paguṇa kammaṭṭhānassa pana apara aparam sañcaraṇa kālaḥ ettha kathitaḥ ātāpī iti  kāya pariggāhaka vīriya samāyoga paridīpanam etam saḥ hi yasmai tasmin samaye yam tam vīriyam
translated: and in the third way, in his own time and in another’s time. But there is no such thing as a mixed object of adverting. What is meant here is the time of moving from one to the other in the case of one who is not yet adept. He is ardent: this shows the association of the energy that investigates the body. For at that time that energy is associated with the adverting.🔽🔽

original: tīsu bhavesu kilesānaṃ ātāpanato ātāpoti vuccati, tena samannāgato hoti, tasmā ātāpīti vuccati.🔽Sampajānoti kāyapariggāhakena sampajaññasaṅkhātena ñāṇena samannāgato. Satimāti kāyapariggāhikāya
analyzed: tīsu bhavesu kilesānaṃ ātāpanato ātāpo ti vuccati tena samannāgataḥ hoti tasmai ātāpī iti vuccati  sampajānoti kāya pariggāhakena sampajañña saṅkhātena ñāṇena samannāgataḥ satimā ati kāya pariggāhikāya
translated: and in the third way, in his own time and in another’s time. But there is no such thing as a mixed object of adverting. What is meant here is the time of his going from one meditation subject to another. He is ardent: this shows the presence of the energy that is the adverting of the body. For it is called “ardour” because it burns up defilements in the three kinds of becoming. He is possessed of that, thus he is ardent.🔽He is fully aware: he is possessed of the knowledge called “full awareness,” which is the full awareness of the body. He is mindful: he is possessed of the mindfulness that is the adverting of the body.

original: satiyā samannāgato. Ayaṃ pana yasmā satiyā ārammaṇaṃ pariggahetvā paññāya anupassati,
analyzed: satiyā samannāgataḥ ayam pana yasmā satiyā ārammaṇam pariggahetvā paññāya anupassati
translated: But although he adverts to the object with mindfulness, he contemplates it with understanding.

original: na hi sativirahitassa anupassanā nāma atthi, tenevāha – “satiñca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave,
analyzed: na hi sati virahitassa anupassanā nāma atthi tena iva āha satim ca khvā aham bhikkhave
translated: For there is no contemplation without mindfulness. That is why it is said: “Bhikkhus, I do not say that there is contemplation of feelings, perceptions, or thoughts apart from mindfulness of them” .

original: sabbatthikaṃ vadāmī”ti, tasmā ettha “kāye kāyānupassī viharatī”ti ettāvatā kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānakammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Atha vā yasmā anātāpino antosaṅkhepo antarāyakaro hoti, asampajāno upāyapariggahe
analyzed: sabbatthikam vadāmi iti tasmai ettha kāye kāya anupassī viharati iti ettāvatā kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhāna kammaṭṭhānam  vuttam hoti atha vā yasmai anātāpinaḥ antosaṅkhepaḥ antarāya karaḥ hoti asampajānaḥ upāya pariggahe
translated: I declare it to be of universal application” . So it is of the meditation subject stated here as far as the words “He lives contemplating the body as a body” .

original: anupāyaparivajjane ca sammuyhati, muṭṭhassatī upāyāpariccāge anupāyāpariggahe ca🔽asamatthova hoti, tenassa taṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ na sampajjati; tasmā yesaṃ dhammānaṃ ānubhāvena
analyzed: an upāya parivajjane ca sammuyhati muṭṭha ssatī upāya a pariccāge an upāya a pariggahe ca  asamatthaḥ eva hoti tena assa tat kammaṭṭhānam na sampajjati tasmai yesam dhammānam ānubhāvena
translated: Or alternatively, since one who is not ardent is slack in his application, one who is not fully aware is confused about the means of doing and avoiding , and one who is not mindful is incapable of relinquishing the means and avoiding the non-means,

original: taṃ sampajjati tesaṃ dassanatthaṃ “ātāpī sampajāno satimā”ti idaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Iti kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ sampayogaṅgañca dassetvā idāni pahānaṅgaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: tam sampajjati tesam dassana attham ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā iti idam vuttan ti veditabbam  iti kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam sampayoga aṅgam ca dassetvā idāni pahāna aṅgam dassetuṃ
translated: his meditation subject does not succeed through the influence of those things. So it should be understood that this is said in order to show those things through the influence of which it does succeed.🔽So when he has shown the meditation subject and the factors of success, he now said,

original: vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassanti vuttaṃ. Tattha vineyyāti tadaṅgavinayena vā vikkhambhanavinayena
analyzed: vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassan ti vuttam tattha vineyya ti tad aṅga vinayena vā vikkhambhana vinayena
translated: “Abandoning the five hindrances” in order to show the factors of abandoning.

original: vā vinayitvā. Loketi ettha yvāyaṃ ajjhattādibhedo kāyo pariggahito sveva idha loko
analyzed: vā vinayitvā loka iti ettha yvā ayam ajjhatta ādi bhedo kāyo pariggahito su eva idha loko
translated: and he has expelled covetousness and grief in the world.🔽The “world” here is the body that has been apprehended as divided into internal and external.

original: nāma. Tasmiṃ loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ vinayitvāti attho. Yasmā panettha abhijjhāgahaṇena
analyzed: nāma tasmin loke abhijjhā domanassam vinayitvā ati atthaḥ yasmā pana itthā abhijjhā gahaṇena
translated: The meaning is that he has expelled covetousness and grief in the world.

original: kāmacchando, domanassaggahaṇena byāpādo saṅgahaṃ gacchati, tasmā nīvaraṇapariyāpannabalavadhammadvayadassanena
analyzed: kāmacchandaḥ domanassa ggahaṇena byāpādaḥ saṅgaham gacchati tasmai nīvaraṇa pariyāpanna balava dhamma dvaya dassanena
translated: But since covetousness is included in sensual desire and grief in ill will,

original: nīvaraṇappahānaṃ vuttaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ.🔽Visesena cettha abhijjhāvinayena kāyasampattimūlakassa anurodhassa, domanassavinayena
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ppahānam vuttam hoti iti veditabbam  visesena ca ittha abhijjhā vinayena kāya sampatti mūlakassa anurodhassa domanassa vinayena
translated: the abandoning of the hindrances should be understood to be stated by the seeing of the two powerful states included in the hindrances.🔽And here, by the abandoning of covetousness, the compliance that has the excellence of the body as its ground is abandoned;🔽by the abandoning of grief, the resistance that has the deficiency of the body as its ground is abandoned.

original: kāyavipattimūlakassa virodhassa, abhijjhāvinayena ca kāye abhiratiyā, domanassavinayena🔽kāyabhāvanāya anabhiratiyā, abhijjhāvinayena kāye abhūtānaṃ subhasukhabhāvādīnaṃ
analyzed: kāya vipatti mūlakassa virodhassa abhijjhā vinayena ca kāye abhiratiyā domanassa vinayena  kāya bhāvanāya anabhiratiyā abhijjhā vinayena kāye abhūtānam subha sukha bhāva ādīnam
translated: By the abandoning of covetousness, delight in the body is abandoned;🔽by the abandoning of grief, the lack of delight in the development of the body is abandoned.

original: pakkhepassa, domanassavinayena kāye bhūtānaṃ asubhāsukhabhāvādīnaṃ apanayanassa ca
analyzed: pakkhepassa domanassa vinayena kāye bhūtānaṃ asubha asukha bhāva ādīnam apanayanassa ca
translated: By the abandoning of covetousness, the superimposition of the unbeautiful as beautiful, the unpleasurable as pleasurable, etc., in the body is abandoned;🔽by the abandoning of grief, the denial of the real beauty, pleasure, etc., in the body is abandoned.

original: pahānaṃ vuttaṃ. Tena yogāvacarassa yogānubhāvo yogasamatthatā ca dīpitā hoti. Yogānubhāvo
analyzed: pahānam vuttam tena yogāvacarassa yoga anubhāvaḥ yoga samattha tā ca dīpitā hoti yoga anubhāvaḥ
translated: This is called “abandoning.” And by this the power of the meditator’s yoga, his ability in yoga, is shown.

original: hi esa yadidaṃ anurodhavirodhavippamutto, aratiratisaho, abhūtapakkhepabhūtāpanayanavirahito🔽ca hoti. Anurodhavirodhavippamutto cesa aratiratisaho abhūtaṃ apakkhipanto bhūtañca
analyzed: hi esa yat idam anurodha virodha vippamuttaḥ arati rati sahaḥ abhūta pakkhepa bhūta apanayana virahitaḥ  ca hoti anurodha virodha vippamutto ca esa arati rati sahaḥ abhūtam apakkhipantaḥ bhūtam ca
translated: For this is the power of yoga that he is free from approval and resistance, that he endures pleasure and pain, and that he is without misrepresentation and without overestimation.

original: anapanento yogasamattho hotīti.
analyzed: an apanentaḥ yoga samattho hoti iti
translated: Being free from approval and resistance, enduring pleasure and pain, not misrepresenting and not overestimating, he is able in yoga.🔽Another method: in the clause “Contemplating the body as a body” the subject of meditation is stated. In the clause “ardent” the meditator’s conduct in regard to the body is stated.

original: Aparo nayo – “kāye kāyānupassī”ti ettha anupassanāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ vuttaṃ. Viharatīti🔽ettha vuttavihārena kammaṭṭhānikassa kāyapariharaṇaṃ. Ātāpītiādīsu ātāpena sammappadhānaṃ,🔽satisampajaññena sabbatthikakammaṭṭhānaṃ, kammaṭṭhānapariharaṇūpāyo vā; satiyā vā
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ kāye kāya anupassī iti ettha anupassanāya kammaṭṭhānam vuttam viharati iti  ettha vutta vihārena kammaṭṭhānikassa kāya pariharaṇam ātāpī iti ādīsu ātāpena sammappadhānam  sati sampajaññena sabbatthika kammaṭṭhānam kammaṭṭhāna pariharaṇa upāyaḥ vā satiyā vā
translated: In the clause “ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful” the four foundations of mindfulness are stated. In the clause “having put aside covetousness for the world” the four right endeavours are stated.

original: kāyānupassanāvasena paṭiladdhasamatho, sampajaññena vipassanā, abhijjhādomanassavinayena
analyzed: kāya anupassanā vasena paṭiladdha samathaḥ sampajaññena vipassanā abhijjhā domanassa vinayena
translated: In the clause “he dwells” the four bases for spiritual power are stated. In the clause “having put away covetousness and grief” the four jhānas are stated. In the clause “having completely transcended the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception” the four immaterial states are stated. In the clause “he dwells” the four paths are stated. In the clause “having known thus” the four fruits are stated. In the clause “having known thus he knows” the four discriminations are stated. In the clause “having known thus he sees” the four states of awareness-release, etc., are stated. In the clause “having known thus he enters upon” the four fruitions of asceticism are stated. In the clause “having known thus he realizes” the four kinds of knowledge of the way out are stated. In the clause “having known thus he is released” the four kinds of perfect knowledge are stated. In the clause “having known thus he is released in the destruction of craving” the four kinds of understanding are stated. In the clause “having known thus he is released in the destruction of craving” the four kinds of understanding are stated. In the clause “having known thus he is released in the destruction of craving” the four kinds of understanding are stated. In the clause “having known thus he is released in the destruction of craving” the four kinds of understanding are stated. In the clause “having known thus he is released in the destruction of craving” the four kinds of understanding are stated. In the clause “having known thus he is released in the destruction of craving” the four

original: bhāvanāphalaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Ayaṃ tāva kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānuddesassa atthavaṇṇanā.🔽Vedanānupassanādiuddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhāvanā phalam vuttanti veditabbam ayam tāva kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhāna uddesassa attha vaṇṇanā  vedanā anupassanā ādi uddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The fruit of development should be understood as stated. This, firstly, is the commentary on the clause “Contemplation of the body as a body.”

original: Vedanānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānuddesādīsupi ajjhattādīni vuttanayeneva veditabbāni. Etesupi🔽hi attano vedanādīsu, parassa vedanādīsu, kālena attano kālena parassa vedanādīsūti🔽tividho pariggaho vutto. Vedanāsu vedanānupassītiādīsu ca vedanādīnaṃ punavacane
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā sati paṭṭhānuddesa ādīsu pi ajjhatta ādīni vutta nayena iva veditabbāni etesu pi  hi attanaḥ vedanā ādīsu parassa vedanā ādīsu kālena attanaḥ kālena parassa vedanā ādīsu iti  tividhaḥ pariggahaḥ vuttaḥ vedanāsu vedanā anupassī itiādīsu ca vedanā ādīnam punavacane
translated: As regards the clause “Ardent, clearly comprehending, mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world,” etc., “ardent” is as already explained under the first tetrad.🔽As regards the clause “He abides contemplating the body as a body,” etc., the “body” is the four-fold body, etc., as already stated.

original: payojanaṃ kāyānupassanāyaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Vedanāsu vedanānupassī, citte
analyzed: payojanam kāya anupassanā ayam vutta nayena iva veditabbam vedanāsu vedanā anupassī citte
translated: Herein, the “four-fold body” is the material body, the feeling body, the perception body, and the formation body.

original: cittānupassī, dhammesu dhammānupassīti ettha pana vedanāti tisso vedanā. Tā ca lokiyā🔽eva; cittampi lokiyaṃ, tathā dhammā. Tesaṃ vibhāgo niddesavāre pākaṭo bhavissati.
analyzed: citta anupassī dhammesu dhamma anupassī ti ettha pana vedanā ati tissaḥ vedanā tā ca lokiyā 🔽eva cittam pi lokiyam tathā dhammā tesam vibhāgaḥ niddesa vāre pākaṭaḥ bhavissati
translated: The “four-fold perception” is the perception of the material body, the perception of the feeling body, the perception of the perception body, and the perception of the formation body.🔽The “four-fold contemplation” is contemplation of the body as a body, contemplation of feeling as feeling, contemplation of perception as perception, and contemplation of the formations as formations.🔽The “four-fold observation” is observation of the body as a body, observation of feeling as feeling, observation of perception as perception, and observation of the formations as formations.

original: Kevalaṃ panidha yathā vedanā anupassitabbā tathā anupassanto “vedanāsu vedanānupassī”ti
analyzed: kevalam yathā vedanā anupassitabbā tathā anupassantaḥ vedanāsu vedanā anupassī iti
translated: But when he is contemplating in this way how feeling is to be contemplated, he is said to be “contemplating in himself the feelings as feelings” .🔽The same method of explanation applies to the contemplation of consciousness and mental states.

original: veditabbo. Esa nayo cittadhammesu. Kathañca vedanā anupassitabbāti? Sukhā tāva vedanā
analyzed: veditabbaḥ esa nayaḥ citta dhammesu kathañca vedanā anupassitabbā ati sukhā tāva vedanā
translated: And how is feeling to be contemplated? Firstly, pleasant feeling

original: dukkhato, dukkhā sallato, adukkhamasukhā aniccato. Yathāha –
analyzed: dukkhataḥ dukkhā sallataḥ adukkham asukhā aniccataḥ yathā āha
translated: is to be contemplated as pain, painful feeling as a dart, and neither- painful-nor-pleasant feeling as impermanent. As it is said:🔽“He who sees pain in pleasant feeling,

original: “Yo sukhaṃ dukkhato adda, dukkhamaddakkhi sallato;
analyzed: yaḥ sukham dukkhataḥ adda dukkham addakkhi sallataḥ
translated: And sees a dart in painful feeling,

original: Adukkhamasukhaṃ santaṃ, addakkhi naṃ aniccato;
analyzed: adukkham asukham santam addakkhi nam aniccataḥ
translated: And sees that neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is impermanent,

original: Sa ve sammadaso bhikkhu, upasanto carissatī”ti. ;🔽Sabbā eva cetā dukkhātipi anupassitabbā. Vuttañcetaṃ – “yaṃ kiñci vedayitaṃ taṃ dukkhasminti🔽vadāmī”ti. Sukhadukkhatopi ca anupassitabbā, yathāha – “sukhā kho, āvuso visākha,
analyzed: sa ve sammadasaḥ bhikkhu upasantaḥ carissati iti  sabbāḥ eva cetāḥ dukkha atipi anupassitabbā vuttam ca itam yam kiñci vedayitam tam dukkhasmin ti  vadāmi iti sukha dukkhataḥ api ca anupassitabbā yathā āha sukhā kho āvuso visākha
translated: That bhikkhu, seeing rightly, is truly calm” .🔽And all three kinds of feeling can be contemplated as pain too. For this is said: “Whatever is felt is felt in accordance with pain” .🔽And they can be contemplated as pleasure too, for this is said: “Pleasant feeling, friend Visākha, is to be directly known as pain; painful feeling is to be directly known as a dart; neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is to be directly known as impermanent” . All this should be quoted in detail.

original: vedanā ṭhitisukhā, vipariṇāmadukkhā”ti sabbaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ. Apica aniccādisattānupassanāvasenapi
analyzed: vedanā ṭhiti sukhā vipariṇāma dukkhā ti sabbam vitthāretabbam apica anicca ādi satta anupassanā vasena api
translated: And again, they can be contemplated as impermanent, and so on.

original: anupassitabbā. Sesaṃ niddesavāreyeva pākaṭaṃ bhavissati.🔽Cittadhammesupi cittaṃ tāva ārammaṇādhipatisahajātabhūmikammavipākakiriyādinānattabhedānaṃ
analyzed: anupassitabbā sesam niddesa vāreya iva pākaṭam bhavissati  citta dhammesu pi cittam tāva
translated: The rest will be clear in the description of the contemplation of dissolution.

original: aniccādinupassanānaṃ niddesavāre āgatasarāgādibhedānañca vasena anupassitabbaṃ. Dhammā🔽salakkhaṇasāmaññalakkhaṇānaṃ suññatādhammassa aniccādisattānupassanānaṃ niddesavāre
analyzed: anicca ādi nupassanānam niddesa vāre āgata sa rāga ādi bhedānam ca vasena anupassitabbam dhammāḥ  sa lakkhaṇa sāmañña lakkhaṇānam suñña tā dhammassa anicca ādi satta anupassanānam niddesa vāre
translated: As to mental objects: firstly, mind is to be contemplated as impermanent, and so on, as to its variety of kinds as object of contemplation, that is to say, as associated with greed, etc., as given in the description of the contemplation of impermanence, etc., and as to its variety of kinds as object of contemplation, that is to say, as consisting of result, as kamma-born, as in a single continuity, and so on, as given in the description of the contemplation of the modes of materiality.

original: āgatasantāsantādibhedānañca vasena anupassitabbā. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva. Kāmañcettha
analyzed: āgata santa asanta ādi bhedānam ca vasena anupassitabbā sesam vutta nayam eva kāmañca ittha
translated: Mental data are to be contemplated as impermanent, and so on, as to their variety of kinds as object of contemplation, that is to say, as the specific characteristics, as the general characteristics, as the idea of void, and as to their variety of kinds as object of contemplation, that is to say, as the continuity of the signless, and so on, as given in the description of the contemplation of the modes of materiality.🔽The rest is as already stated.

original: yassa kāyasaṅkhāte loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ pahīnaṃ, tassa vedanādilokesupi taṃ pahīnameva.
analyzed: yassa kāya saṅkhāte loke abhijjhā domanassam pahīnam tassa vedanā ādi lokesu pi tam pahīnam eva
translated: But although covetousness and grief have been abandoned in the world consisting of the material life-principle, nevertheless they are stated as objects of contemplation in the case of the world consisting of feeling, and so on, because they are not abandoned in the world consisting of feeling, and so on.

original: Nānāpuggalavasena pana nānācittakkhaṇikasatipaṭṭhānabhāvanāvasena ca sabbattha vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nānā puggala vasena pana nānā citta khaṇika sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā vasena ca sabbattha vuttam
translated: And they are stated thus in order to show the abandoning of them there too.

original: Yato vā ekattha pahīnaṃ, sesesupi pahīnaṃ hoti. Tenevassa tattha pahānadassanatthampi
analyzed: yatas vai ekattha pahīnam sesesu pi pahīnam hoti tena iva assa tattha pahāna dassana attham pi
translated: Or alternatively, they are stated thus in order to show that when they have been abandoned in one of the worlds consisting of the material life-principle, etc., they are also abandoned in the rest.

original: evaṃ vuttanti veditabbanti.
analyzed: evam vuttan ti veditabbanti
translated: So it should be understood that they are stated thus in order to show their abandoning there too.

original: Uddesavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Kāyānupassanāniddesavaṇṇanā🔽356. Idāni seyyathāpi nāma cheko vilīvakārako thūlakilañjasaṇhakilañjacaṅkoṭakapeḷāpuṭādīni
analyzed: uddesa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  kāya anupassanā niddesa vaṇṇanā  idāni seyyathā api nāma chekaḥ thūla kilañja saṇha kilañja caṅkoṭaka peḷā puṭa ādīni
translated: Description of the recitation section is finished.

original: upakaraṇāni kattukāmo ekaṃ mahāveḷuṃ labhitvā catudhā chinditvā tato ekekaṃ veḷukhaṇḍaṃ🔽gahetvā phāletvā taṃ taṃ upakaraṇaṃ kareyya, yathā vā pana cheko suvaṇṇakāro nānāvihitaṃ
analyzed: upakaraṇāni kattu kāmaḥ ekam mahā veḷum labhitvā catudhā chinditvā tatas ekekam veḷu khaṇḍam  gahetvā phāletvā tam tam upakaraṇam kareyya yathā vā pana chekaḥ suvaṇṇakāraḥ nānā vihitam
translated: Contemplation of the body. Now, just as a clever master dyer and his assistant, wanting to dye a hundred or a thousand cloths of various kinds, such as linen, cotton, silk, and woolen cloths, would first prepare the dye vats, which have been heated with a fragrant wood such as agarwood, and when the vats were bubbling and steaming well, they would dye the cloths, and the cloths would become well dyed, thoroughly steeped, and well rinsed in the dye; and the master dyer would think, “These cloths are well dyed, thoroughly steeped, and well rinsed in the dye, and the dye will not fade and soil my vats”;

original: piḷandhanavikatiṃ kattukāmo suparisuddhaṃ suvaṇṇaghaṭikaṃ labhitvā catudhā bhinditvā🔽tato ekekaṃ koṭṭhāsaṃ gahetvā taṃ taṃ piḷandhanaṃ kareyya, evameva bhagavā satipaṭṭhānadesanāya
analyzed: piḷandhana vikatim kattu kāmaḥ su parisuddham suvaṇṇa ghaṭikam labhitvā catudhā bhinditvā  tatas ekekam koṭṭhāsam gahetvā tam tam piḷandhanam kareyya evam eva bhagavā sati paṭṭhāna desanāya
translated: or just as a clever goldsmith or his apprentice, wanting to bake a hundred or a thousand pieces of gold, would prepare a furnace, and having done so, would light the fire, and when the furnace was bubbling and steaming well, he would bake the pieces of gold, and the pieces of gold would become well baked, thoroughly heated, and well cleaned in the furnace; and the goldsmith would think, “These pieces of gold are well baked, thoroughly heated, and well cleaned in the furnace, and the furnace will not soil my pieces of gold”;

original: sattānaṃ anekappakāraṃ visesādhigamaṃ kattukāmo ekameva sammāsatiṃ “cattāro satipaṭṭhānā
analyzed: sattānam aneka ppakāram visesa adhigamam kattu kāmo ekam eva sammāsatim cattāraḥ sati paṭṭhānā
translated: so too, the Blessed One, wanting to bring about the attainment of various kinds of distinction in beings by teaching the foundations of mindfulness, first taught the four foundations of mindfulness, which are the “fragrant wood” for heating the dye vats of the four noble paths and the four noble fruits, and which are the “furnace” for baking the pieces of gold of the four noble paths and the four noble fruits.

original: – idha bhikkhu ajjhattaṃ kāye kāyānupassī viharatī”tiādinā nayena ārammaṇavasena
analyzed: idha bhikkhu ajjhattam kāye kāya anupassī viharati itiādinā nayena ārammaṇa vasena
translated: And the four foundations of mindfulness are the “fragrant wood” for heating the dye vats of the four noble paths and the four noble fruits in this way: when a bhikkhu develops the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body, he abandons desire for the body;🔽when he develops the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of feelings, he abandons desire for the sixfold base;🔽when he develops the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of consciousness, he abandons desire for the six sense bases;🔽when he develops the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of mental objects, he abandons desire for the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: catudhā bhinditvā tato ekekaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā vibhajanto kathañca bhikkhu ajjhattaṃ🔽kāyetiādinā nayena niddesavāraṃ vattumāraddho.🔽Tattha kathañcātiādi vitthāretuṃ kathetukamyatāpucchā. Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepattho
analyzed: catudhā bhinditvā tatas ekekam satipaṭṭhānam gahetvā vibhajantaḥ katham ca bhikkhu ajjhattam  kāya iti ādinā nayena niddesa vāram vattum āraddhaḥ  tattha kathañca atiādi vitthāretum kathā itu kamya tā pucchā ayam pana ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ
translated: Having divided it into four, he began the exposition-section with the words “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu abide contemplating the body as a body?”

original: – kena ca ākārena kena pakārena bhikkhu ajjhattaṃ kāye kāyānupassī viharatīti? Sesapucchāvāresupi🔽eseva nayo. Idha bhikkhūti imasmiṃ sāsane bhikkhu. Ayañhettha idha-saddo ajjhattādivasena
analyzed: kena ca ākārena kena pakārena bhikkhu ajjhattam kāye kāya anupassī viharati iti sesa pucchāvāresu pi  esa iva nayaḥ idha bhikkhu iti imasmin sāsane bhikkhu ayam ha ittha idha saddaḥ ajjhatta ādi vasena
translated: Herein, “And how” is a question expressing a desire to tell, namely, “In what way, in what manner does a bhikkhu abide contemplating the body as a body?” The same method of explanation applies in the other questions in the exposition-section.

original: sabbappakārakāyānupassanānibbattakassa puggalassa sannissayabhūtasāsanaparidīpano🔽aññasāsanassa tathābhāvapaṭisedhano ca. Vuttañhetaṃ – “idheva, bhikkhave, samaṇo…pe…
analyzed: sabbappakāra kāya anupassanā nibbattakassa puggalassa sannissaya bhūta sāsana paridīpano  añña sāsanassa tathābhāva paṭisedhano ca vuttam ha etam idha iva bhikkhave
translated: Herein, “bhikkhu” is a bhikkhu in this Dispensation. The word “here” shows that the Dispensation is the support for the person who has produced the contemplation of the body in all its aspects by means of the internal and the rest,🔽and it precludes the idea that the same is to be found in other dispensations. For this is said: “It is here, bhikkhus, that a recluse could be found …

original: suññā parappavādā samaṇebhi aññehī”ti. Tena vuttaṃ “imasmiṃ sāsane bhikkhū”ti.
analyzed: suññā parappavādā samaṇebhi aññehi iti tena vuttam imasmin sāsane bhikkhu iti
translated: Other recluses’ dispensations are void of recluses” . That is why it was said above “a bhikkhu in this Dispensation” .

original: Ajjhattaṃ kāyanti attano kāyaṃ. Uddhaṃ pādatalāti pādatalato upari. Adho kesamatthakāti
analyzed: ajjhattam kāyanti attano kāyam uddham pāda talā ati pāda talataḥ upari adho kesamatthakā ati
translated: In the body in oneself: in one’s own body. Above the soles of the feet: above the soles of the feet. Below the

original: kesaggato heṭṭhā. Tacapariyantanti tiriyaṃ tacaparicchinnaṃ. Pūraṃ nānappakārassa
analyzed: kesaggataḥ heṭṭhā taca pariyantam tiriyam taca paricchinnam pūram nānappakārassa
translated: tips of the hair: below the tips of the hair of the head. Round about enclosed by the skin: enclosed all round by the skin. Full of various kinds of

original: asucino paccavekkhatīti nānappakārakesādiasucibharito ayaṃ kāyoti passati. Kathaṃ?
analyzed: asucino paccavekkhati iti nānappakāra kesa ādi asuci bharitaḥ ayam kāyo ti passati katham
translated: impurity: filled with various kinds of impurity beginning with head hairs. How?🔽There are in this body head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney, heart, liver, midriff, spleen, lungs, bowels, entrails, gorge, dung, brain, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, fluid of the joints, urine, and womb, and there are in this body various kinds of impurity such as these.

original: Atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā…pe… muttanti. Tattha atthīti saṃvijjanti. Imasminti yvāyaṃ
analyzed: atthi imasmin kāye kesāpe muttanti tattha atthi iti saṃvijjanti imasmin ti yvā ayam
translated: Herein, there are means they exist. In this means in this body

original: uddhaṃ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tiriyaṃ tacapariyanto pūro nānappakārassa asucinoti🔽vuccati tasmiṃ. Kāyeti sarīre. Sarīrañhi asucisañcayato kucchitānaṃ kesādīnañceva🔽cakkhurogādīnañca rogasatānaṃ āyabhūtato kāyoti vuccati.
analyzed: uddham pāda talāḥ adho kesamatthakā tiriyam taca pariyanto pūraḥ nānappakārassa  vuccati tasmim kāya iti sarīre sarīram hi kesa ādīnam ca iva  cakkhu roga ādīnam ca roga satānam āya bhūtato kāyo ti vuccati
translated: which is called “full of various kinds of impurity above the soles of the feet and below the tips of the hair and round about enclosed by the skin.”🔽Body means in the physical frame. For the physical frame is called “body” because it is a collection of impurities and because it is the origin of such diseases as eye disease, etc.,

original: Kesā lomāti ete kesādayo dvattiṃsākārā. Tattha atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā, atthi imasmiṃ
analyzed: kesāḥ loma ati ete kesa ādayaḥ dvattiṃsa ākārā tattha atthi imasmin kāye kesāḥ atthi imasmin
translated: Head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney, heart, liver, midriff, spleen, lungs, bowels, entrails, gorge, dung, brain, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, fluid of the joints, urine, and womb: these are the thirty-two aspects beginning with head hairs.

original: kāye lomāti evaṃ sambandho veditabbo. Imasmiñhi pādatalato paṭṭhāya upari, kesamatthakā
analyzed: kāye loma ati evam sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ imasmin hi pāda talataḥ paṭṭhāya upari kesamatthakā
translated: The construction of the sentence should be understood thus: “In this body there are head-hairs, body-hairs, etc.”

original: paṭṭhāya heṭṭhā, tacato paṭṭhāya tiriyantatoti ettake byāmamatte kaḷevare sabbākārenapi
analyzed: paṭṭhāya heṭṭhā tacataḥ paṭṭhāya tiriyantato ti ettake byāma matte kaḷevare sabba ākārena api
translated: For when one searches the whole of this body, from the soles of the feet upwards and from the tips of the hairs downwards, and from the skin inwards,

original: vicinanto na koci kiñci muttaṃ vā maṇiṃ vā veḷuriyaṃ vā agaruṃ vā kuṅkumaṃ vā kappūraṃ🔽vā vāsacuṇṇādiṃ vā aṇumattampi sucibhāvaṃ passati, atha kho paramaduggandhajegucchaṃ🔽assirīkadassanaṃ nānappakāraṃ kesalomādibhedaṃ asuciṃyeva passati. Tena vuttaṃ –
analyzed: vicinantaḥ na koci kiñci muttam vā maṇim vā veḷuriyam vā agarum vā kuṅkumam vā kappūram  vā vāsa cuṇṇa ādim vā aṇumattam pi suci bhāvam passati atha kho parama duggandha jeguccham  assirīka dassanam nānappakāram kesa loma ādi bhedam asuciṃ yeva passati tena vuttam
