translated: one does not see even the minutest particle of what is pure, such as a pearl, a gem, lapis lazuli, aloes, saffron,🔽camphor, or sandalwood paste, but on the contrary one sees only what is impure, extremely malodorous and disgusting, and consisting of various kinds of hair, etc.

original: atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā lomā…pe… muttanti. Ayamettha padasambandhato vaṇṇanā.🔽Imaṃ pana kammaṭṭhānaṃ bhāvetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇitukāmena kulaputtena āditova catubbidhaṃ
analyzed: atthi imasmin kāye kesāḥ lomāpe muttanti ayam ettha pada sambandhataḥ vaṇṇanā  imam pana kammaṭṭhānam bhāvetvā arahattam pāpuṇitu kāmena kula puttena āditas va catubbidham
translated: Hence it is said: “In this body there are head-hairs, body-hairs, and so on up to: urine.” This is the commentary on the words of the text under the heading of word-analysis.

original: sīlaṃ sodhetvā suparisuddhasīle patiṭṭhitena, yvāyaṃ dasasu palibodhesu palibodho
analyzed: sīlam sodhetvā su parisuddha sīle patiṭṭhitena yvā ayam dasasu palibodhesu palibodhaḥ
translated: When a clansman who is intent on attaining arahatship by developing this meditation subject has purified his mind of the hindrances, he should next purify it of the five corruptions of insight .

original: atthi taṃ upacchinditvā, paṭikkūlamanasikārakammaṭṭhānabhāvanāya paṭhamajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā,
analyzed: atthi tam upacchinditvā paṭikkūla manasikāra kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanāya paṭhama jhānam nibbattetvā
translated: and having abandoned that, he should develop the first jhāna by means of the meditation subject consisting in the contemplation of what is un-lovely.

original: jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā, arahattaṃ anāgāmiphalādīsu vā aññataraṃ
analyzed: jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam anāgāmi phala ādīsu vā aññataram
translated: Then, after making the jhāna his basis, he should instigate insight, and he should reach and confirm Arahantship or one of the paths and fruits beginning with that of non-returner.

original: pattassa sabbantimena paricchedena sāṭṭhakathāya pāḷiyā kataparicayassa tantiācariyassāpi🔽kalyāṇamittassa santike uggahetabbaṃ. Visuddhaṃ tathārūpaṃ kalyāṇamittaṃ ekavihāre
analyzed: pattassa sabba antimena paricchedena sa aṭṭhakathāya pāḷiyā kata paricayassa tanti ācariyassa api  kalyāṇa mittassa santike uggahetabbam visuddham tathārūpam kalyāṇa mittam eka vihāre
translated: When he has done this, he should learn the text of the whole of the nine- book Discussion of the Issues from a teacher who has already learned it.🔽If he cannot find a teacher of that kind in a single monastery, he should go where such a teacher lives and learn it.

original: alabhantena tassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā uggahetabbaṃ. Tattha catubbidhasīlavisodhanañceva
analyzed: a labhantena tassa vasana ṭṭhānam gantvā uggahetabbam tattha catubbidha sīla visodhanam ca eva
translated: The purification of virtue in the four ways,

original: palibodho ca palibodhupacchedo ca ācariyassa santikaṃ upasaṅkamanavidhānañca sabbampi
analyzed: palibodho ca palibodha upacchedo ca ācariyassa santikam upasaṅkamana vidhānañca sabbam pi
translated: the hindrance that is an obstruction, the severing of the obstruction, and the directions for approaching the teacher,

original: visuddhimagge vitthārato kathitaṃ. Tasmā taṃ tattha kathitanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: visuddhi magge vitthārato kathitam tasmā tam tattha kathita nayena iva veditabbam
translated: are all given in detail in the Path of Purification, so they should be understood by him in the way already given there.

original: Ācariyena pana kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathentena tividhena kathetabbaṃ. Eko bhikkhu pakatiyā
analyzed: ācariyena pana kammaṭṭhānam kathentena tividhena kathetabbam ekaḥ bhikkhu pakatiyā
translated: When the teacher is expounding the meditation subject, he should expound it in three ways.

original: uggahitakammaṭṭhāno hoti. Tassa ekaṃ dve nisajjavāre sajjhāyaṃ kāretvā kathetabbaṃ.🔽Eko santike vasitvā uggaṇhitukāmo hoti. Tassa āgatāgatavelāya kathetabbaṃ. Eko uggaṇhitvā
analyzed: uggahita kammaṭṭhānaḥ hoti tassa ekam dve nisajjavāre sajjhāyam kāretvā kathetabbam  ekaḥ santike vasitvā uggaṇhitu kāmo hoti tassa āgata āgata velāya kathetabbam ekaḥ uggaṇhitvā
translated: He has learnt the meditation subject. He should be taught after having him recite it once or twice in each sitting.🔽One wants to live near him and learn it. He should be taught at the time he comes.

original: aññattha gantukāmo hoti. Tassa nātipapañcaṃ nātisaṅkhepaṃ katvā nijjaṭaṃ niggaṇṭhikaṃ
analyzed: aññattha gantu kāmo hoti tassa na ati papañcam na ati saṅkhepam katvā nijjaṭam niggaṇṭhikam
translated: One wants to learn it and then go elsewhere. He should be taught the meditation subject without too much elaboration or too briefly, with the tangle unravelled, the knots untied, and the sticks removed.

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathetabbaṃ. Kathentena kiṃ ācikkhitabbanti? Sattadhā uggahakosallaṃ
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam kathetabbam kathentena kim ācikkhitabban ti sattadhā uggaha kosallam
translated: What should be taught? The seven kinds of skill in learning

original: dasadhā ca manasikārakosallaṃ ācikkhitabbaṃ.🔽Tattha vacasā manasā vaṇṇato saṇṭhānato disato okāsato paricchedatoti evaṃ sattadhā
analyzed: dasadhā ca manasikāra kosallam ācikkhitabbam  tattha vacasā manasā vaṇṇataḥ saṇṭhānataḥ disataḥ okāsataḥ paricchedato ti evam sattadhā
translated: and the ten kinds of skill in giving attention should be taught.🔽Herein, the seven kinds of skill in learning should be taught thus:🔽as to letter, as to syllable, as to phrasing, as to meaning, as to not in haste, as to not slurring, as to not confusing.

original: uggahakosallaṃ ācikkhitabbaṃ. Imasmiñhi paṭikkūlamanasikārakammaṭṭhāne yopi tipiṭako
analyzed: uggaha kosallam ācikkhitabbam imasmin hi paṭikkūla manasikāra kammaṭṭhāne yaḥ api tipiṭako
translated: For in this meditation subject of attention to repulsiveness, even one who is a master of the three Vedas

original: hoti, tenapi manasikārakāle paṭhamaṃ vācāya sajjhāyo kātabbo. Ekaccassa hi sajjhāyaṃ
analyzed: hoti tena api manasikāra kāle paṭhamam vācāya sajjhāyaḥ kātabbaḥ ekaccassa hi sajjhāyam
translated: should, when giving attention to it, first recite it verbally. For some people the meditation subject becomes evident to them as they recite it verbally.

original: karontasseva kammaṭṭhānaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti, malayavāsīmahādevattherassa santike uggahitakammaṭṭhānānaṃ🔽dvinnaṃ therānaṃ viya. Thero kira tehi kammaṭṭhānaṃ yācito ‘cattāro māse imaṃ evaṃ
analyzed: karontassa iva kammaṭṭhānam pākaṭam hoti malaya vāsī mahādeva therassa santike uggahita kammaṭṭhānānam  dvinnam therānam viya thero kira tehi kammaṭṭhānam yācito cattāraḥ māse imam evam
translated: As he does so, the meditation subject becomes clear to him, as it did to the two elders who learned the meditation subject in the presence of the Elder Malayagiri.🔽The elder, it seems, was asked for a meditation subject. He gave them the thirty-two-fold aspect version of the meditation subject consisting of the thirty-two aspects of the four elements, saying, “You must prepare it in this way for four months.”

original: sajjhāyaṃ karothā’ti dvattisākārapāḷiṃ adāsi. Te, kiñcāpi tesaṃ dve tayo nikāyā paguṇā,
analyzed: sajjhāyam karotha ati dvattisa ākāra pāḷim te kiñca api tesam dve tayaḥ nikāyā paguṇā
translated: Although they had already mastered two or three Nikāyas,

original: padakkhiṇaggāhitāya pana cattāro māse dvattiṃsākāraṃ sajjhāyantāva sotāpannā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: padakkhiṇa ggāhitāya pana cattāraḥ māse dvattiṃsa ākāram sajjhāyantā ava sotāpannāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: they were only stream-enterers after preparing the thirty-two-fold aspect version of the meditation subject consisting of the thirty-two aspects of the four elements for four months.

original: Tasmā kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathentena ācariyena antevāsiko vattabbo – ‘paṭhamaṃ tāva vācāya🔽sajjhāyaṃ karohī’ti. Karontena ca tacapañcakādīni paricchinditvā anulomapaṭilomavasena🔽sajjhāyo kātabbo. “Kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco”ti hi vatvā puna paṭilomato “taco dantā
analyzed: tasmā kammaṭṭhānam kathentena ācariyena antevāsikaḥ vattabbaḥ paṭhamam tāva vācāya  sajjhāyam karohi iti karontena ca taca pañcaka ādīni paricchinditvā anuloma paṭiloma vasena  sajjhāyaḥ kātabbo kesāḥ lomā nakhāḥ dantāḥ tacaḥ iti hi vatvā puna paṭilomato tacaḥ dantāḥ
translated: So when a teacher is expounding a meditation subject, he should tell the pupil to prepare it first by recitation.🔽And in preparing it by recitation, he should prepare it by recitation in forward and reverse order after discerning the fivefold skin and so on. For he should recite, “Head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin,” and in reverse order, “Skin, teeth, nails, hairs, body hairs.”

original: nakhā lomā kesā”ti vattabbaṃ. Tadanantaraṃ vakkapañcake “maṃsaṃ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṃ
analyzed: nakhāḥ lomā kesā ti vattabbam tad anantaram vakka pañcake maṃsam nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjam

original: vakka”nti vatvā puna paṭilomato “vakkaṃ aṭṭhimiñjaṃ aṭṭhi nhāru maṃsaṃ taco dantā🔽nakhā lomā kesā”ti vattabbaṃ. Tato papphāsapañcake “hadayaṃ yakanaṃ kilomakaṃ pihakaṃ
analyzed: vakkanti vatvā puna paṭilomataḥ vakkam aṭṭhimiñjam aṭṭhi nhāru maṃsam tacaḥ dantā  nakhā lomā kesā ti vattabbam tatas papphāsa pañcake hadayam yakanam kilomakam pihakam
translated: and so on in reverse order: “kidneys, bone marrow, bones, sinews, flesh, skin, teeth,🔽nails, head hair, body hair, and so on.🔽Then, after the five in the chest, “heart, liver, midriff, spleen,

original: papphāsa”nti vatvā puna paṭilomato “papphāsaṃ pihakaṃ kilomakaṃ yakanaṃ hadayaṃ vakkaṃ
analyzed: papphāsanti vatvā puna paṭilomataḥ papphāsam pihakam kilomakam yakanam hadayam vakkam
translated: lungs,” and so on in reverse order: “lungs, spleen, midriff, liver, heart, kidneys,🔽bone marrow, bones, sinews, flesh, skin, teeth, nails,

analyzed: aṭṭhimiñjam aṭṭhi nhāru maṃsam tacaḥ dantāḥ nakhāḥ lomā kesā ti vattabbam  tatas imam tantim an āruḷham pi paṭisambhidā magge āgatam mattha luṅgam karīsa avasāne tantim
translated: head hair, body hair, and so on.🔽Then, after the brain, which is not included in the text of the Thread, but which is given in the Path of Discrimination, and which is added to the end of the dung,

analyzed: vatvā puna paṭilomataḥ matthaluṅgam karīsam udariyam antaguṇam antam papphāsam pihakam

original: kilomakaṃ yakanaṃ hadayaṃ vakkaṃ aṭṭhimiñjaṃ aṭṭhi nhāru maṃsaṃ taco dantā nakhā🔽lomā kesā”ti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: kilomakam yakanam hadayam vakkam aṭṭhimiñjam aṭṭhi nhāru maṃsam tacaḥ dantāḥ nakhāḥ 🔽lomā kesā ti vattabbam
translated: nails, head hair, body hair, and so on.

analyzed: tatas meda chakke pittam semham pubbaḥ lohitam sedaḥ medaḥ iti vatvā puna paṭilomataḥ medaḥ  sedaḥ lohitam pubbaḥ semham pittam matthaluṅgam karīsam udariyam antaguṇam antam papphāsam

analyzed: pihakam kilomakam yakanam hadayam vakkam aṭṭhimiñjam aṭṭhi nhāru maṃsam tacaḥ dantā  nakhāḥ lomā kesā ti vattabbam  tatas mutta chakke assu vasā kheḷaḥ siṅghāṇikā lasikā mutta nti vatvā puna paṭilomataḥ  muttam lasikā siṅghāṇikā kheḷaḥ vasāḥ assu medaḥ sedaḥ lohitam pubbo semham pittam matthaluṅgam
translated: liver, midriff, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs,  reticulum,  mesentery, gorge, dung, gorge, gorge-stuffing, bowels,  wind,🔽liver, midriff, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs,  reticulum,  mesentery, gorge, dung, gorge, gorge-stuffing, bowels,  wind,🔽liver, midriff, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs,  reticulum,  mesentery, gorge, dung, gorge, gorge-stuffing, bowels,  wind,🔽liver, midriff, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs,  reticulum,  mesentery, gorge, dung, gorge, gorge-stuffing, bowels,  wind,🔽liver, midriff, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs,  reticulum,  mesentery, gorge, dung, gorge, gorge-stuffing, bowels,  wind,🔽liver, midriff, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs,  reticulum,  mesentery, gorge, dung, gorge, gorge-stuffing, bowels,  wind,🔽liver, midriff, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs,  reticulum,  mesentery, gorge, dung, gorge, gorge-stuffing, bowels,  wind,🔽liver, midriff, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs,  reticulum,  mesentery, gorge, dung, gorge, gorge-stuffing, bowels,  wind,

analyzed: karīsam udariyam antaguṇam antam papphāsam pihakam kilomakam yakanam hadayam vakkam 🔽aṭṭhimiñjam aṭṭhi nhāru maṃsam tacaḥ dantāḥ nakhāḥ lomā kesā ati evam kāla satam pi kāla sahassam pi
translated: liver, midriff, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs,  reticulum,  mesentery, gorge, dung, gorge, gorge-stuffing, bowels,  wind,🔽liver, midriff, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs,  reticulum,

original: kālasatasahassampi vācāya sajjhāyo kātabbo. Vacasā sajjhāyena hi kammaṭṭhānatanti
analyzed: kāla sata sahassam pi vācāya sajjhāyaḥ kātabbaḥ vacasā sajjhāyena hi
translated: and recite it a hundred or a thousand times. For the meditation subject is recited in order to master it.

original: paguṇā hoti; na ito cito ca cittaṃ vidhāvati; koṭṭhāsā pākaṭā honti, hatthasaṅkhalikā🔽viya khāyanti, vatipādapanti viya ca khāyanti. Yathā ca pana vacasā, tatheva manasāpi🔽sajjhāyo kātabbo. Vacasā sajjhāyo hi manasā sajjhāyassa paccayo hoti. Manasā sajjhāyo🔽lakkhaṇapaṭivedhassa paccayo hoti. Lakkhaṇapaṭivedho maggaphalapaṭivedhassa paccayo hoti.
analyzed: paguṇā hoti na itas citas ca cittam vidhāvati koṭṭhāsā pākaṭāḥ honti hattha saṅkhalikā  viya khāyanti ca khāyanti yathā ca vacasā tathā iva manasā api  sajjhāyaḥ kātabbaḥ vacasā sajjhāyaḥ hi manasā sajjhāyassa paccayaḥ hoti manasā sajjhāyaḥ  lakkhaṇa paṭivedhassa paccayaḥ hoti lakkhaṇa paṭivedhaḥ magga phala paṭivedhassa paccayaḥ hoti
translated: And he should recite the meditation subject to himself a hundred times, a thousand times. For by reciting the meditation subject to himself the meditation subject becomes familiar to him, his mind does not run wild in all directions, the parts of the meditation subject become evident to him, they lie open to consciousness as if brought out into the open, and they seem as if placed in his hand.🔽And as by reciting it to himself, so also by reciting it aloud. For reciting it aloud is a condition for reciting it to oneself, and reciting it to oneself is a condition for comprehending the characteristic. Comprehending the characteristic is a condition for penetration of the sign, and penetration of the sign is a condition for the appearance of the material body as it is in itself.

original: ‘Vaṇṇato’ti kesādīnaṃ vaṇṇo vavatthapetabbo. ‘Saṇṭhānato’ti tesaṃyeva saṇṭhānaṃ vavatthapetabbaṃ.🔽‘Disato’ti imasmiṃ sarīre nābhito uddhaṃ uparimā disā, adho heṭṭhimā disā. Tasmā
analyzed: vaṇṇataḥ ti kesa ādīnam vaṇṇaḥ vavatthapetabbo saṇṭhānataḥ ti tesam yeva saṇṭhānam vavatthapetabbam  disatas ti imasmin sarīre nābhitas uddham uparimāḥ disāḥ adhas heṭṭhimāḥ disā tasmā
translated: As to colour: the colour of the head hairs, etc., should be defined. As to shape: their shape should be defined.🔽As to direction: in this physical frame the direction above is the upper direction, the direction below is the lower direction. So the directions should be defined thus: “This part is in the upper direction,” “This part is in the lower direction.”

original: “ayaṃ koṭṭhāso imissā nāma disāyā”ti disā vavatthapetabbā. ‘Okāsato’ti “ayaṃ koṭṭhāso
analyzed: ayam koṭṭhāso imissā nāma disāya ati disā vavatthapetabbā okāsato ti ayam koṭṭhāso
translated: As to location: the location of each part should be defined thus: “This part is on the head-hairs’ location,” etc.

original: imasmiṃ nāma okāse patiṭṭhito”ti evaṃ tassa tassa okāso vavatthapetabbo. ‘Paricchedato’ti🔽sabhāgaparicchedo visabhāgaparicchedoti dve paricchedā. Tattha “ayaṃ koṭṭhāso heṭṭhā
analyzed: imasmin nāma okāse patiṭṭhito ti evam tassa tassa okāsaḥ vavatthapetabbo paricchedato ti  sabhāga paricchedo visabhāga paricchedo ti dve paricchedā tattha ayam koṭṭhāsaḥ heṭṭhā
translated: and so on. ‘By delimitation’:🔽there are two kinds of delimitation, by the similar and by the dissimilar. Herein, as to delimitation by the similar, this part is delimited above and below by the other parts of the head-hairs, and so on.🔽

original: ca upari ca tiriyañca iminā nāma paricchinno”ti evaṃ sabhāgaparicchedo veditabbo.
analyzed: ca upari ca tiriyan ca iminā nāma paricchinno ti evam sa bhāga paricchedaḥ veditabbo
translated: “It is established in this place.” The delimitation by the similar should be understood as follows: “This part is delimited below and above and around by this.”

original: “Kesā na lomā, lomāpi na kesā”ti evaṃ amissīkatavasena visabhāgaparicchedo veditabbo.🔽Evaṃ sattadhā uggahakosallaṃ ācikkhantena pana “idaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ asukasmiṃ sutte
analyzed: kesāḥ na lomā loma api na kesā ti evam amissīkata vasena visa bhāga paricchedaḥ veditabbo  evam sattadhā uggaha kosallam ācikkhantena pana idam kammaṭṭhānam asukasmim sutte
translated: The delimitation by the dissimilar should be understood as follows: “Head hairs are not body hairs; body hairs are not head hairs.”

original: paṭikkūlavasena kathitaṃ, asukasmiṃ dhātuvasenā”ti ñatvā ācikkhitabbaṃ. Idañhi mahāsatipaṭṭhāne
analyzed: paṭikkūla vasena kathitam asukasmin dhātu vasena ati ñatvā ācikkhitabbam idam hi mahāsati paṭṭhāne
translated: When the skill in learning in the seven ways has been pointed out in this way, the teacher should point out the meditation subject by saying, “This meditation subject is taught in such-and-such a sutta,” and he should point out the sutta too: for this meditation subject is taught only in the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta,🔽and it is taught there only as foulness, not as elements.

original: paṭikkūlavaseneva kathitaṃ, mahāhatthipadopama -mahārāhulovāda -dhātuvibhaṅgesu dhātuvasena
analyzed: paṭikkūla vasena iva kathitam mahā hatthi pada upama mahā rāhulovāda dhātu vibhaṅgesu dhātu vasena
translated: But in the Mahāhatthipadopama, Mahā-Rāhulovāda, and Dhātuvibhaṅga Suttas it is taught as elements.

original: kathitaṃ. Kāyagatāsatisutte pana yassa vaṇṇato upaṭṭhāti, taṃ sandhāya cattāri jhānāni
analyzed: kathitam kāyagata asati sutte pana yassa vaṇṇataḥ upaṭṭhāti tam sandhāya cattāri jhānāni
translated: In the Kāyagatāsati Sutta it is taught as both foulness and elements, for it is said there:🔽“Now, bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is practising the body-contemplation on the body, if thieves should carry him off and say to him, ‘We will cut your body to pieces with sharp saws,’ he should conclude thus: ‘Perception and attention accompanied by joy have arisen in me, and one of two kinds of thoughts has arisen, either thoughts of sensual desire or thoughts of ill will. These thoughts are born of this body-contemplation and they will lead to its abandonment.’ He should abandon that perception and that attention and should advert to another object.

original: vibhattāni. Tattha dhātuvasena kathitaṃ vipassanākammaṭṭhānaṃ hoti, paṭikkūlavasena
analyzed: vibhattāni tattha dhātu vasena kathitam vipassanā kammaṭṭhānam hoti paṭikkūla vasena
translated: and “repulsive” in the sense of the loathsome,🔽and it is called “the meditation subject of mindfulness of breathing” in the sense of the mode of conascentness.

original: kathitaṃ samathakammaṭṭhānaṃ. Tadetaṃ idha samathakammaṭṭhānaṃ avisesato sabbasādhāraṇavasena
analyzed: kathitam samatha kammaṭṭhānam tat etam idha samatha kammaṭṭhānam avisesataḥ sabba sādhāraṇa vasena
translated: And this meditation subject is called “the meditation subject of foulness” in the sense of the mode of object.

original: kathitanti vadantiyevāti.🔽Evaṃ sattadhā uggahakosallaṃ ācikkhitvā “anupubbato, nātisīghato, nātisaṇikato, vikkhepapaṭibāhanato,🔽paṇṇattisamatikkamanato, anupubbamuñcanato, appanāto, tayo ca suttantā”ti evaṃ dasadhā
analyzed: kathitam iti  evam sattadhā uggaha kosallam ācikkhitvā anupubbataḥ na ati sīghataḥ na ati saṇikataḥ vikkhepa paṭibāhanato  paṇṇatti samatikkamanataḥ anupubba muñcanataḥ appanātaḥ tayo ca suttantā ti evam dasadhā
translated: So it is said.🔽Having thus explained the sevenfold skill in learning, he should explain the tenfold skill in giving attention as follows:🔽as to order, not too quickly, not too slowly, preventing the hindrances,

original: manasikārakosallaṃ ācikkhitabbaṃ. Tattha ‘anupubbato’ti idañhi sajjhāyakaraṇato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: manasikāra kosallam ācikkhitabbam tattha anupubbato ti idam hi sajjhāya karaṇato paṭṭhāya
translated: surmounting the concept, giving up too much interest, giving up under-interest, surmounting the sign, giving up too much attention, giving up under-attention, and the three suttantas.

original: anupaṭipāṭiyā manasikātabbaṃ, na ekantarikāya. Ekantarikāya hi manasikaronto yathā
analyzed: anupaṭipāṭiyā manasikātabbam na ekantarikāya ekantarikāya hi manasikarontaḥ yathā
translated: Herein, as to order: this should be given attention in proper order, starting from the recitation, not in the reverse order.

original: nāma akusalo puriso dvattiṃsapadaṃ nisseṇiṃ ekantarikāya ārohanto kilantakāyo patati,
analyzed: nāma akusalaḥ puriso dvattiṃsa padam nisseṇim ekantarikāye ārohantaḥ kilanta kāyo patati
translated: For one who gives attention to it in the reverse order is like an unskilled man who climbs a ladder rung by rung in the reverse order and falls down with his body in pain.

original: na ārohanaṃ sampādeti; evameva bhāvanāsampattivasena adhigantabbassa assādassa anadhigamā
analyzed: na ārohanam sampādeti evam eva bhāvanā sampatti vasena adhigantabbassa assādassa an adhigamā
translated: and he cannot get up, so too, because of the failure of development,

original: kilantacitto patati, na bhāvanaṃ sampādeti.
analyzed: patati na bhāvanam sampādeti
translated: he falls down with his mind exhausted and cannot get up.

original: Anupubbato manasikarontenāpi ca ‘nātisīghato’ manasikātabbaṃ. Atisīghato manasikaroto🔽hi yathā nāma tiyojanaṃ maggaṃ paṭipajjitvā okkamanavissajjanaṃ asallakkhetvā sīghena🔽javena sattakkhattumpi gamanāgamanaṃ karoto purisassa kiñcāpi addhānaṃ parikkhayaṃ
analyzed: anupubbataḥ manasikarontena api ca na ati sīghataḥ manasikātabbam ati sīghataḥ manasikaroto  hi yathā nāma ti yojanam maggam paṭipajjitvā okkamana vissajjanam a sallakkhetvā sīghena  javena satta kkhattum pi gamana āgamanam karoto purisassa kiñcā api addhānam parikkhayam
translated: And he should not give his attention to it too quickly.

original: gacchati, atha kho pucchitvāva gantabbaṃ hoti; evameva kevalaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariyosānaṃ
analyzed: gacchati atha kho pucchitvā ava gantabbam hoti evam eva kevalam kammaṭṭhānam pariyosānam
translated: For if he does, then just as a man who has set out on a three-league journey might go two leagues at a stretch and fall down exhausted at the end of the first league, so too, though the meditation subject has reached its conclusion,

original: pāpuṇāti, avibhūtaṃ pana hoti, na visesaṃ āvahati. Tasmā nātisīghato manasikātabbaṃ.
analyzed: pāpuṇāti avibhūtam pana hoti na visesam āvahati tasmā na ati sīghataḥ manasikātabbam
translated: it is not penetrated and it does not yield any distinction. So he should not give his attention to it too quickly.

original: Yathā ca nātisīghato evaṃ ‘nātisaṇikato’pi. Atisaṇikato manasikaroto hi yathā nāma
analyzed: yathā ca na ati sīghataḥ evam na ati saṇikataḥ api ati saṇikataḥ manasikarotaḥ hi yathā nāma
translated: And just as he should not give his attention to it too quickly, so also he should not give his attention to it too slowly.

original: tadaheva tiyojanaṃ maggaṃ gantukāmassa purisassa antarāmagge rukkhapabbatagahanādīsu
analyzed: tadahā iva ti yojanam maggam gantu kāmassa purisassa antarāmagge rukkha pabbata gahana ādīsu
translated: Just as a man who wants to go a journey of three leagues and who delays on the way at the foot of trees, on hills, in forests, and so on,

original: vilambamānassa maggo parikkhayaṃ na gacchati, dvīhatīhena pariyosāpetabbo hoti; evameva
analyzed: vilambamānassa maggaḥ parikkhayam na gacchati dvīhatīhena pariyosāpetabbaḥ hoti evam eva
translated: does not cover the journey but needs two or three days to complete it, so too

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariyosānaṃ na gacchati, visesādhigamassa paccayo na hoti.🔽‘Vikkhepapaṭibāhanato’ti kammaṭṭhānaṃ vissajjetvā bahiddhā puthuttārammaṇe cetaso
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam pariyosānam na gacchati visesa adhigamassa paccayaḥ na hoti  vikkhepa paṭibāhanato ti kammaṭṭhānam vissajjetvā bahiddhā puthuttā ārammaṇe cetasaḥ
translated: the meditation subject does not reach its culmination, and it is not a condition for distinction.

original: vikkhepo paṭibāhitabbo. Appaṭibāhato hi yathā nāma ekapadikaṃ papātamaggaṃ paṭipannassa🔽purisassa akkamanapadaṃ asallakkhetvā ito cito ca vilokayato padavāro virajjhati,
analyzed: vikkhepaḥ paṭibāhitabbaḥ a paṭibāhataḥ hi yathā nāma eka padikam papāta maggam paṭipannassa  purisassa akkamana padam a sallakkhetvā itas citas ca vilokayataḥ pada vāraḥ virajjhati
translated: ‘By warding off distraction’: distraction is the scattering of the mind outward when the meditation subject is being attended to, by taking cognizance of objects such as forms, sounds, and so on, that lie in the external sense- sphere. For when there is distraction outward, the meditation subject

original: tato sataporise papāte patitabbaṃ hoti; evameva bahiddhā vikkhepe sati kammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽parihāyati, paridhaṃsati. Tasmā vikkhepapaṭibāhanato manasikātabbaṃ.
analyzed: tatas sataporise papāte patitabbam hoti evam eva bahiddhā vikkhepe sati kammaṭṭhānam 🔽parihāyati paridhaṃsati tasmai vikkhepa paṭibāhanataḥ manasikātabbam
translated: is neglected and abandoned, just as a man who does not watch where he is going and looks this way and that way instead falls into a chasm two hundred or three hundred fathoms deep. Therefore it should be given attention ‘by warding off distraction.’

original: ‘Paṇṇattisamatikkamanato’ti yā ayaṃ “kesā lomā”ti ādikā paṇṇatti taṃ atikkamitvā
analyzed: paṇṇatti sama tikkamanataḥ ti yā ayam kesāḥ loma iti ādikā paṇṇatti tam atikkamitvā
translated: ‘By transcending the determinations’: by transcending the determinations beginning with ‘head hairs, body hairs’

original: paṭikkūlanti cittaṃ ṭhapetabbaṃ. Yathā hi udakadullabhakāle manussā araññe udapānaṃ
analyzed: paṭikkūlanti cittam ṭhapetabbam yathā hi udaka dullabha kāle manussāḥ araññe udapānam
translated: the mind should be steadied on the foulness. For just as when men are short of water in a time of drought and they see a well in a wood

original: disvā tattha tālapaṇṇādikaṃ kiñcideva saññāṇaṃ bandhitvā tena saññāṇena āgantvā nhāyanti
analyzed: disvā tattha tāla paṇṇa ādikam kiñcid eva saññāṇam bandhitvā tena saññāṇena āgantvā nhāyanti
translated: and tie a palm-leaf or something like that to a stick in order to find the place again, and then they go and bathe in the water and drink it,

original: ceva pivanti ca, yadā pana tesaṃ abhiṇhasañcārena āgatāgatapadaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti, tadā
analyzed: ca iva pivanti ca yadā pana tesam abhiṇha sañcārena āgata āgata padam pākaṭam tadā
translated: and when the path to the place has become worn by their constant coming and going,

original: saññāṇena kiccaṃ na hoti, icchiticchitakkhaṇe gantvā nhāyanti ceva pivanti ca; evameva🔽pubbabhāge ‘kesā lomā’ti paṇṇattivasena manasikaroto paṭikkūlabhāvo pākaṭo hoti.
analyzed: saññāṇena kiccam na hoti icchiticchita khaṇe gantvā nhāyanti ca iva pivanti ca evam eva  pubbabhāge kesāḥ loma ti paṇṇatti vasena manasikaroto paṭikkūla bhāvaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti
translated: then there is no need for them to go by the sign, and they go whenever they want and bathe and drink as they want; so too,🔽when he brings to mind head hairs, body hairs, etc., as determinations in the earlier stage, the foulness becomes evident to him.

original: Atha ‘kesā lomā’ti paṇṇattiṃ samatikkamitvā paṭikkūlabhāveyeva cittaṃ ṭhapetabbaṃ.
analyzed: atha kesāḥ loma ati paṇṇattim samatikkamitvā paṭikkūla bhāveya iva cittam ṭhapetabbam
translated: Then he should steady his mind on the foulness itself by transcending the determinations ‘head hairs, body hairs’.

original: ‘Anupubbamuñcanato’ti yo yo koṭṭhāso na upaṭṭhāti, taṃ taṃ muñcantena anupubbamuñcanato
analyzed: anupubba muñcanato ti yaḥ yaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ na upaṭṭhāti tam tam muñcantena anupubba muñcanato
translated: ‘By successive leaving’: by successive leaving in this way, that is, by leaving out whatever part does not appear.

original: manasikātabbaṃ. Ādikammikassa hi ‘kesā’ti manasikaroto manasikāro gantvā ‘mutta’nti🔽imaṃ pariyosānakoṭṭhāsameva āhacca tiṭṭhati. ‘Mutta’nti ca manasikaroto manasikāro
analyzed: manasikātabbam ādikammikassa hi kesāti manasikarotaḥ manasikāraḥ gantvā muttan ti  imam pariyosāna koṭṭhāsam eva āhat ca tiṭṭhati muttanti ca manasikarotaḥ manasikāro
translated: For when a beginner gives his attention to head hairs, his attention goes as far as the end of the series and stops at ‘urine’.🔽And when he gives his attention to ‘urine’, his attention🔽

original: gantvā ‘kesā’ti imaṃ ādikoṭṭhāsameva āhacca tiṭṭhati. Athassa manasikaroto keci koṭṭhāsā🔽upaṭṭhahanti, keci na upaṭṭhahanti. Tena ye ye upaṭṭhahanti tesu tesu tāva kammaṃ🔽kātabbaṃ, yāva dvīsu upaṭṭhitesu tesampi eko suṭṭhutaraṃ upaṭṭhahati. Evaṃ upaṭṭhitaṃ🔽pana tameva punappunaṃ manasikarontena appanā uppādetabbā.🔽Tatrāyaṃ upamā – yathā hi dvattiṃsatālake tālavane vasantaṃ makkaṭaṃ gahetukāmo luddo
analyzed: gantvā kesā ti imam ādi koṭṭhāsam eva āhacca tiṭṭhati athassa manasikaroto keci koṭṭhāsā  upaṭṭhahanti keci na upaṭṭhahanti tena ye ye upaṭṭhahanti tesu tesu tāva kammaṃ  kātabbam yāva dvīsu upaṭṭhitesu tesam pi ekaḥ suṭṭhutaram upaṭṭhahati evam upaṭṭhitam  pana tam eva punappunam manasikarontena appanā uppādetabbā  tatra ayam upamā yathā hi dvattiṃsa tālake tāla vane vasantam makkaṭam gahetu kāmaḥ luddaḥ
translated: He should do so in this way. For when a beginner gives his attention to head hairs, his attention goes no further than that but remains fixed on the word “head hairs” as the last of the thirty-two parts of the body. And when he gives his attention to the last part, the “brain,” his attention goes no further than that but remains fixed on the word “brain” as the first of the thirty-two parts of the body. So when he gives his attention to the parts of the body, some parts present themselves to him and others do not. He should do his work on those that present themselves until two appear quite clearly to him. Then he should give attention to them again and again, and he should arouse desire to see them by thinking, “I will see the colour of the head hairs, I will see the colour of the body hairs,” and so on. He should arouse desire to see them and see them again and again.

original: ādimhi ṭhitatālassa paṇṇaṃ sarena vijjhitvā ukkuṭṭhiṃ kareyya; atha so makkaṭo paṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: ādimhi ṭhita tālassa paṇṇam sarena vijjhitvā ukkuṭṭhim kareyya atha saḥ makkaṭaḥ paṭipāṭiyā
translated: Here is a simile. Suppose a man wanted to catch two monkeys out of a troop of thirty-two, so he climbed a tree and pulled out the first nest he came to and then the last, and the two monkeys fell into his hands because they were caught between his pulling out the first and last nests. So too, when he gives attention to the parts of the body, some parts present themselves to him and others do not. He should do his work on those that present themselves until two appear quite clearly to him. Then he should give attention to them again and again, and he should arouse desire to see them by thinking, “I will see the colour of the head hairs, I will see the colour of the body hairs,” and so on. He should arouse desire to see them and see them again and again.

original: tasmiṃ tasmiṃ tāle patitvā pariyantatālameva gaccheyya; tatthapi gantvā luddena tatheva🔽kate puna teneva nayena āditālaṃ āgaccheyya; so evaṃ punappunaṃ paṭipāṭiyā gacchanto
analyzed: tasmin tasmin tāle patitvā pariyanta tālam eva gaccheyya gantvā luddena tathā iva  kate puna tena iva nayena āditālam āgaccheyya saḥ evam punappunam paṭipāṭiyā gacchantaḥ
translated: and after falling on this or that palm tree it would go on to the next one, and after going there and being thrown down by the man in the same way,🔽it would come back in the same way to the first palm tree, and so on, going round and round in this way,

original: ukkuṭṭhukkuṭṭhiṭṭhāneyeva uṭṭhahitvā puna anukkamena ekasmiṃ tāle nipatitvā tassa
analyzed: uṭṭhahitvā puna anukkamena ekasmin tāle nipatitvā tassa
translated: it would stand up only at the place where it had stood before, and then after descending in due course on to one palm tree,

original: vemajjhe makuḷatālapaṇṇasūciṃ daḷhaṃ gahetvā vijjhiyamānopi na uṭṭhaheyya, evaṃsampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Tatridaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – yathā hi tālavane dvattiṃsatālā, evaṃ imasmiṃ kāye dvattiṃsa🔽koṭṭhāsā; makkaṭo viya cittaṃ; luddo viya yogāvacaro; makkaṭassa dvattiṃsatālake
analyzed: vemajjhe makuḷa tāla paṇṇa sūcim daḷham gahetvā vijjhiyamānaḥ api na uṭṭhaheyya evaṃsampadam idam daṭṭhabbam  tatra idam opamma saṃsandanam yathā hi tāla vane dvattiṃsa tālāḥ evam imasmin kāye dvattiṃsa  koṭṭhāsāḥ makkaṭaḥ viya cittam luddaḥ viya yogāvacaraḥ makkaṭassa dvattiṃsa tālake
translated: it would pierce with the sharp point of a palm leaf a stalk in the middle of it and would not stand up even though it was being pierced, so it is with this .

original: tālavane nivāso viya yogino cittassa dvattiṃsakoṭṭhāsake kāye ārammaṇavasena anusaṃcaraṇaṃ;
analyzed: tālavane nivāsaḥ viya yogino cittassa dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsake kāye ārammaṇa vasena anusaṃcaraṇam
translated: Here is the correlation of the similes: Just as there are thirty-two palm trees in the palm grove, so there are thirty-two parts in this body. The monkey is like the mind. The man is like the meditator. The monkey’s living in the palm grove of thirty-two palm trees is like the meditator’s keeping to the thirty-two parts of the body as object.

original: luddena ādimhi ṭhitatālassa paṇṇaṃ sarena vijjhitvā ukkuṭṭhiyā katāya makkaṭassa🔽tasmiṃ tasmiṃ tāle patitvā pariyantatālagamanaṃ viya yogino ‘kesā’ti manasikāre āraddhe
analyzed: luddena ādimhi ṭhita tālassa paṇṇam sarena vijjhitvā ukkuṭṭhiyā katāya makkaṭassa  tasmin tasmin tāle patitvā pariyanta tāla gamanam yogino manasikāre āraddhe
translated: Just as the monkey, after piercing the leaf of the palm at the beginning with his beak, went on to the next one, and so on, until he reached the last one,🔽so too, when the meditator begins by giving attention to the head hairs,

original: paṭipāṭiyā gantvā pariyosānakoṭṭhāse eva cittassa saṇṭhānaṃ; puna paccāgamanepi eseva
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā gantvā pariyosāna koṭṭhāse eva cittassa saṇṭhānam puna paccāgamane pi esā eva
translated: he goes through the successive parts and ends by establishing the consciousness in the toenails;🔽and when he comes back again, he does so in the same way.

original: nayo; punappunaṃ paṭipāṭiyā gacchamānassa makkaṭassa ukkuṭṭhukkuṭṭhiṭṭhāne uṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nayo punappunam paṭipāṭiyā gacchamānassa makkaṭassa ukkuṭṭhukkuṭṭhi ṭhāne uṭṭhānam
translated: Just as the monkey, when he had gone through in one direction, stopped at the place where he had started from,

original: viya punappunaṃ manasikaroto kesuci kesuci upaṭṭhitesu anupaṭṭhahante vissajjetvā
analyzed: viya punappunam manasikaroto kesuci kesuci upaṭṭhitesu an upaṭṭhahante vissajjetvā
translated: so too, when the meditator gives attention again and again, and some parts become evident to him and some do not, he should leave aside those that do not and establish his consciousness on those that do.

original: upaṭṭhitesu parikammakaraṇaṃ; anukkamena ekasmiṃ tāle nipatitvā tassa vemajjhe makuḷatālapaṇṇasūciṃ🔽daḷhaṃ gahetvā vijjhiyamānassāpi anuṭṭhānaṃ viya avasāne dvīsu upaṭṭhitesu yo suṭṭhutaraṃ
analyzed: upaṭṭhitesu parikamma karaṇam anukkamena ekasmin tāle nipatitvā tassa vemajjhe makuḷa tāla paṇṇa sūcim  daḷham gahetvā vijjhiyamānassa api anuṭṭhānam viya avasāne dvīsu upaṭṭhitesu yaḥ suṭṭhutaram
translated: Just as the monkey, when he had stopped there, took a firm grip with his forepaws on the leaf of the palm in the middle, the point of the leaf-needle being directed downwards,🔽and though he was pierced, he did not move,

original: upaṭṭhāti tameva punappunaṃ manasikaritvā appanāya uppādanaṃ.
analyzed: upaṭṭhāti tam eva punappunam manasikaritvā appanāya uppādanam
translated: so too, when the meditator has ended by establishing the consciousness on the two parts, whichever two are the most evident to him, he should give attention again and again to those two and so eventually arouse absorption.

original: Aparāpi upamā – yathā nāma piṇḍapātiko bhikkhu dvattiṃsakulaṃ gāmaṃ upanissāya vasanto
analyzed: aparā api upamā yathā nāma piṇḍapātikaḥ bhikkhu dvattiṃsa kulam gāmam upanissāya vasantaḥ
translated: Another simile: Suppose a monk living in dependence on a village with thirty-two families🔽were to get two alms offerings on his first visit to a family, and then give up,

original: paṭhamagehe eva dve bhikkhā labhitvā parato ekaṃ vissajjeyya; punadivase tisso labhitvā
analyzed: paṭhama gehe eva dve bhikkhāḥ labhitvā paratas ekam vissajjeyya puna divase tissaḥ labhitvā
translated: and on the next day were to get three and give up two,

original: parato dve vissajjeyya; tatiyadivase ādimhiyeva pattapūraṃ labhitvā āsanasālaṃ gantvā
analyzed: paratas dve vissajjeyya tatiya divase ādimhiyā iva patta pūram labhitvā āsana sālam gantvā
translated: and on the third day were to get a bowlful and then go to the refectory and eat it.

original: paribhuñjeyya, evaṃsampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Dvattiṃsakulagāmo viya hi dvattiṃsākāro;🔽piṇḍapātiko viya yogāvacaro; tassa taṃ gāmaṃ upanissāya vāso viya yogino dvattiṃsākāre
analyzed: paribhuñjeyya evaṃsampadam idam daṭṭhabbam dvattiṃsa kula gāmaḥ viya hi dvattiṃsa ākāro  piṇḍapātikaḥ viya yogāvacaro tassa tam gāmam upanissāya vāsaḥ viya yoginaḥ dvattiṃsa ākāre
translated: The thirty-two families are like the thirty-two aspects,🔽the monk is like the meditator,🔽his living in dependence on the village is like the meditator’s making a preliminary study of the thirty-two aspects,

original: parikammakaraṇaṃ; paṭhamagehe dve bhikkhā labhitvā parato ekissā vissajjanaṃ viya🔽dutiyadivase tisso labhitvā parato dvinnaṃ vissajjanaṃ viya ca manasikaroto manasikaroto
analyzed: parikamma karaṇam paṭhama gehe dve bhikkhāḥ labhitvā paratas ekissā vissajjanam viya  dutiya divase tissaḥ labhitvā paratas dvinnam vissajjanam viya ca manasikarotaḥ manasikarotaḥ
translated: his getting two alms offerings on his first visit to a family and then giving up is like the meditator’s giving up when the meditation subject does not appear as he gives attention to it by way of one of the aspects,🔽and his getting three on the next day and giving up two is like his giving up when it does not appear as he gives attention by way of another aspect,

original: anupaṭṭhahante anupaṭṭhahante vissajjetvā upaṭṭhitesu upaṭṭhitesu yāva koṭṭhāsadvaye
analyzed: an upaṭṭhahante an upaṭṭhahante vissajjetvā upaṭṭhitesu upaṭṭhitesu yāva koṭṭhāsa dvaye
translated: and his getting a bowlful on the third day is like the meditator’s giving attention to the aspect in which it does appear, and when it appears in two or three parts,🔽he should

original: parikammakaraṇaṃ; tatiyadivase ādimhiyeva pattapūraṃ labhitvā āsanasālāyaṃ nisīditvā
analyzed: parikamma karaṇam tatiya divase ādimhiyā iva pattapūram labhitvā āsana sālāyam nisīditvā
translated: The preliminary work is like the first day’s work. The arousing of absorption is like the second day’s work. And the maintaining of it is like the third day’s work.

original: paribhogo viya dvīsu yo suṭṭhutaraṃ upaṭṭhahati tameva punappunaṃ manasikaritvā appanāya uppādanaṃ.
analyzed: paribhogaḥ viya dvīsu yaḥ suṭṭhutaram upaṭṭhahati tam eva punappunam manasikaritvā appanāya uppādanam
translated: The maintaining of it is like the third day’s work. The maintaining of it is like the third day’s work.

original: ‘Appanāto’ti appanākoṭṭhāsato. Kesādīsu ekekasmiṃ koṭṭhāse appanā hotīti veditabbāti ayamettha adhippāyo.🔽‘Tayo ca suttantā’ti adhicittaṃ, sītibhāvo, bojjhaṅgakosallanti ime tayo suttantā vīriyasamādhiyojanatthaṃ veditabbāti ayamettha adhippāyo. Tattha –
analyzed: appanātaḥ ti appanā koṭṭhāsato kesa ādīsu ekekasmin koṭṭhāse appanā hoti iti veditabbā ti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ  tayo ca suttantā ti adhicittam sīti bhāvaḥ bojjhaṅga kosallanti ime tayo suttantā vīriya samādhi yojana attham veditabbā ti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ tattha
translated: ‘From absorption’: from the stage of absorption. The meaning is that absorption should be understood as occurring in each part beginning with the head hairs.

original: “Adhicittamanuyuttena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā tīṇi nimittāni kālena kālaṃ manasikātabbāni…kālena🔽kālaṃ samādhinimittaṃ manasikātabbaṃ, kālena kālaṃ paggahanimittaṃ manasikātabbaṃ,🔽kālena kālaṃ upekkhānimittaṃ manasikātabbaṃ. Sace, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto
analyzed: adhicittam anuyuttena bhikkhave bhikkhunā tīṇi nimittāni kālena kālam manasikātabbāni anikālena 🔽kālam samādhi nimittam manasikātabbam kālena kālam paggaha nimittam manasikātabbam 🔽kālena kālam upekkhā nimittam manasikātabbam sace bhikkhave adhicittam anuyuttaḥ
translated: ‘And three suttantas’: the meaning is that the three suttantas, namely, the Adhicitta Sutta , the Sītibhāva Sutta , and the Kosalla Sutta , should be understood as being for the purpose of combining energy and concentration. Herein:

original: bhikkhu ekantaṃ samādhinimittaṃyeva manasikareyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ cittaṃ kosajjāya saṃvatteyya.
analyzed: bhikkhu ekantam samādhi nimittam yeva manasikareyya ṭhānam tam cittam kosajjāya saṃvatteyya
translated: If a monk only focused on the sign of concentration, his mind would tend to laziness.

original: Sace, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu ekantaṃ paggahanimittaṃyeva manasikareyya,
analyzed: sace bhikkhave adhicittam anuyuttaḥ bhikkhu ekantam paggaha nimittam yeva manasikareyya
translated: If a monk only focused on the sign of exertion,

original: ṭhānaṃ taṃ cittaṃ uddhaccāya saṃvatteyya. Sace, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu
analyzed: ṭhānam tam cittam uddhaccāya saṃvatteyya sace bhikkhave adhicittam anuyuttaḥ bhikkhu
translated: his mind would tend to agitation. If a monk only focused on the sign of equanimity,

original: ekantaṃ upekkhānimittaṃyeva manasikareyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ cittaṃ na sammāsamādhiyeyya
analyzed: ekantam upekkhā nimittam yeva manasikareyya ṭhānam tam cittam na sammāsamādhiyeyya
translated: his mind would not become rightly concentrated for the ending of defilements.

original: āsavānaṃ khayāya. Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ🔽samādhinimittaṃ, paggahanimittaṃ, upekkhānimittaṃ manasikaroti, taṃ hoti cittaṃ mudu
analyzed: āsavānam khayāya yatas ca kho bhikkhave adhicittam anuyuttaḥ bhikkhu kālena kālam  samādhi nimittam paggaha nimittam upekkhā nimittam manasikaroti tam hoti cittam mudu
translated: But when a monk from time to time focuses on the sign of concentration, the sign of exertion, and the sign of equanimity,

original: ca kammaniyañca pabhassarañca, na ca pabhaṅgu, sammā samādhiyati āsavānaṃ khayāya.
analyzed: ca kammaniyam ca pabhassaram ca na ca pabhaṅgu sammā samādhiyati āsavānam khayāya
translated: his mind becomes malleable, wieldy, and bright, not brittle, rightly concentrated for the ending of defilements.

original: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā ukkaṃ bandhati, ukkaṃ
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave suvaṇṇakāraḥ vā suvaṇṇakāra antevāsī vā ukkam bandhati ukkam
translated: “It’s like a goldsmith or goldsmith’s apprentice who puts gold in the furnace and

original: bandhitvā ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpeti, ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpetvā saṇḍāsena jātarūpaṃ gahetvā ukkāmukhe
analyzed: bandhitvā ukkā mukham ālimpa iti ukkā mukham ālimpetvā saṇḍāsena jātarūpam gahetvā ukkā mukhe
translated: and he heats it in the furnace,🔽and he takes it out of the furnace and cools it in water,

original: pakkhipeyya, ukkāmukhe pakkhipitvā kālena kālaṃ abhidhamati, kālena kālaṃ udakena🔽paripphoseti, kālena kālaṃ ajjhupekkhati. Sace, bhikkhave, suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī
analyzed: pakkhipeyya ukkā mukhe pakkhipitvā kālena kālam abhidhamati kālena kālam udakena  paripphoseti kālena kālam ajjhupekkhati sace bhikkhave suvaṇṇakāraḥ vā suvaṇṇakāra antevāsī
translated: and he heats it again, and he cools it again, and he looks on with equanimity at it.🔽If the goldsmith or the apprentice

original: vā taṃ jātarūpaṃ ekantaṃ abhidhameyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ jātarūpaṃ ḍaheyya. Sace, bhikkhave,
analyzed: vā tam jātarūpam ekantam abhidhameyya ṭhānam tam jātarūpam ḍaheyya sace bhikkhave
translated: heats it too much, it would burn and if it burned, it would be spoilt for the purpose for which it was intended.

original: suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā taṃ jātarūpaṃ ekantaṃ udakena paripphoseyya,
analyzed: suvaṇṇakāraḥ vā suvaṇṇakāra antevāsī vā tam jātarūpam ekantam udakena paripphoseyya
translated: If the goldsmith or the apprentice🔽cools it too much, it would not become malleable and wieldy for working.

original: ṭhānaṃ taṃ jātarūpaṃ nibbāyeyya. Sace, bhikkhave, suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī
analyzed: ṭhānam tat jātarūpam nibbāyeyya sace bhikkhave suvaṇṇakāraḥ vā suvaṇṇakāra antevāsī
translated: If the goldsmith or the apprentice

original: vā taṃ jātarūpaṃ ekantaṃ ajjhupekkheyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ jātarūpaṃ na sammā paripākaṃ gaccheyya.
analyzed: vā tam jātarūpam ekantam ajjhupekkheyya ṭhānam tam jātarūpam na sammā paripākam gaccheyya
translated: looks on with equanimity at it too much, it would not become malleable and wieldy for working.

original: “Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā taṃ jātarūpaṃ kālena
analyzed: yatas ca kho bhikkhave suvaṇṇakāraḥ vā suvaṇṇakāra antevāsī vā tam jātarūpam kālena
translated: “But when the goldsmith or the apprentice

original: kālaṃ abhidhamati, kālena kālaṃ udakena paripphoseti, kālena kālaṃ ajjhupekkhati,
analyzed: kālam abhidhamati kālena kālam udakena paripphoseti kālena kālam ajjhupekkhati
translated: He blows on it from time to time, he looks on at it from time to time,

original: taṃ hoti jātarūpaṃ mudu ca kammaniyañca pabhassarañca, na ca pabhaṅgu, sammā upeti
analyzed: tam hoti jātarūpam mudu ca kammaniyam ca pabhassaram ca na ca pabhaṅgu sammā upeti
translated: and that gold becomes malleable, wieldy, and luminous, it is not brittle, and is ready to be worked.

original: kammāya; yassā yassā ca piḷandhanavikatiyā ākaṅkhati – yadi paṭṭikāya yadi kuṇḍalāya
analyzed: kammāya yassā yassā ca piḷandhana vikatiyā ākaṅkhati yadi paṭṭikāya yadi kuṇḍalāya
translated: Whatever sort of ornament he has in mind to make—whether a bracelet, earrings, a necklace, or a golden garland—

original: yadi gīveyyakāya yadi suvaṇṇamālāya, tañcassa atthaṃ anubhoti.
analyzed: yadi gīveyyakāya yadi suvaṇṇa mālāya tat ca assa attham anubhoti
translated: he succeeds in accomplishing his purpose.

original: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyuttena…pe… sammā samādhiyati āsavānaṃ khayāya;
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave sammā samādhiyati āsavānam khayāya
translated: “So too, bhikkhus, when the mind is immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilements, pliable, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability—it is wieldy in penetration.

original: yassa yassa ca abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṃ abhininnāmeti abhiññā sacchikiriyāya,
analyzed: yassa yassa ca abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittam abhininnāmeti abhiññā sacchikiriyāya
translated: Whatever qualities should be fully understood by direct knowledge, his mind inclines to the realization of those qualities by direct knowledge.

original: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane”ti idaṃ suttaṃ adhicittanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tatra tatra iva sakkhibhabbatam pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane iti idam suttam adhicittam ti veditabbam
translated: Whatever qualities should be developed, his mind inclines to the development of those qualities.” This sutta should be understood as the one dealing with the higher mind.

original: “Chahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu bhabbo anuttaraṃ sītibhāvaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
analyzed: chahi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu bhabbaḥ anuttaram sīti bhāvam sacchikātum
translated: “Bhikkhus, possessing six qualities, a bhikkhu is able to realize the supreme coolness.

original: Katamehi chahi? Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ niggahetabbaṃ tasmiṃ🔽samaye cittaṃ niggaṇhāti, yasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ paggahetabbaṃ tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ🔽paggaṇhāti, yasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ sampahaṃsitabbaṃ tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ sampahaṃseti,🔽yasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ ajjhupekkhitabbaṃ tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ ajjhupekkhati, paṇītādhimuttiko
analyzed: katamehi chahi idha bhikkhave bhikkhu yasmin samaye cittam niggahetabbam tasmin  samaye cittam niggaṇhāti yasmin samaye cittam paggahetabbam tasmin samaye cittam  paggaṇhāti yasmin samaye cittam sampahaṃsitabbam tasmin samaye cittam sampahaṃseti  yasmin samaye cittam ajjhupekkhitabbam tasmin samaye cittam ajjhupekkhati paṇīta adhimuttikaḥ
translated: What are the six? Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu on an occasion when the mind should be restrained, restrains the mind; on an occasion when the mind should be exerted, he exerts the mind; on an occasion when the mind should be encouraged, he encourages the mind; on an occasion when the mind should be looked on at with equanimity, he looks on at the mind with equanimity; he is resolved upon the superior;

original: ca hoti nibbānābhirato ca. Imehi kho, bhikkhave, chahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu🔽bhabbo anuttaraṃ sītibhāvaṃ sacchikātu”nti idaṃ suttaṃ sītibhāvoti veditabbaṃ.🔽Bojjhaṅgakosallaṃ pana “evameva kho, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ samaye līnaṃ cittaṃ hoti,
analyzed: ca hoti nibbāna abhirataḥ ca imehi kho bhikkhave chahi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu  bhabbaḥ anuttaram sīti bhāvam sacchikātunti idam suttam sīti bhāvaḥ ti veditabbam  bojjhaṅgakosallam pana evam eva kho bhikkhave yasmin samaye līnam cittam hoti
translated: What are the six? Here a bhikkhu on an occasion when his cognizance should be suppressed suppresses it; on an occasion when his cognizance should be exerted he exerts it; on an occasion when his cognizance should be encouraged he encourages it; on an occasion when his cognizance should be looked on at with equanimity he looks on at it with equanimity; he is resolved upon the sublime; he delights in extinction. A bhikkhu possessing these six ideas is able to realize the supreme coolness. This Thread should be known as the supreme coolness.

original: akālo tasmiṃ samaye passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāyā”ti saṃyuttamahāvagge bojjhaṅgasaṃyutte āgatameva.
analyzed: akālaḥ tasmin samaye passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya ati saṃyutta mahā vagge bojjhaṅga saṃyutte āgatam eva
translated: But the skill in the enlightenment factors is given in the Great Chapter in the Connected Discourses on the Enlightenment Factors thus: “So too, bhikkhus, when cognizance is slack, that is the wrong time to develop the tranquillity enlightenment factor, the concentration enlightenment factor, and the equanimity enlightenment factor” .

original: Iti idaṃ sattavidhaṃ uggahakosallaṃ suggahitaṃ katvā imañca dasavidhaṃ manasikārakosallaṃ
analyzed: iti idam sattavidham uggaha kosallam suggahitam katvā imam ca dasavidham manasikāra kosallam
translated: and having well defined this skill in attention in its tenfold aspect,

original: suṭṭhu vavatthapetvā tena yoginā ubhayakosallavasena kammaṭṭhānaṃ sādhukaṃ uggahetabbaṃ.🔽Sace panassa ācariyena saddhiṃ ekavihāreyeva phāsu hoti, evaṃ vitthārena akathāpetvā
analyzed: suṭṭhu vavatthapetvā tena yoginā ubhaya kosalla vasena kammaṭṭhānam sādhukam uggahetabbam  sace panassa ācariyena saddhim phāsu hoti evam vitthārena a kathāpetvā
translated: the meditator should take up the meditation subject after learning it thoroughly in both its skills.🔽But if he finds it convenient to live with the teacher in the same monastery, he need not have it expounded in detail in this way.🔽He can have it expounded in successive stages as he makes progress in it while devoting himself to it.

original: kammaṭṭhānamanuyuñjantena visesaṃ labhitvā uparūpari kathāpetabbaṃ. Aññattha vasitukāmena
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam anuyuñjantena visesam labhitvā upari upari kathāpetabbam aññattha vasitu kāmena
translated: But if he wants to live elsewhere,

original: yathāvuttena vidhinā vitthārato kathāpetvā punappunaṃ parivattetvā sabbaṃ gaṇṭhiṭṭhānaṃ🔽chinditvā kammaṭṭhānabhāvanāya ananurūpaṃ senāsanaṃ pahāya mahāvāsatādiaṭṭhārasadosavajjite🔽anurūpe vihāre viharantena khuddakapalibodhupacchedaṃ katvā yo tāva rāgacarito hoti,
analyzed: yathā vuttena vidhinā vitthārato kathāpetvā punappunam parivattetvā sabbam gaṇṭhi ṭṭhānam  chinditvā kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanāya ananurūpam senāsanam pahāya  anurūpe vihāre viharantena khuddaka pali bodha upacchedam katvā yaḥ tāva rāga caritaḥ
translated: he should have it expounded in detail in the way described, and he should turn it over and over,🔽and he should sever all doubts about all the difficult passages. Then he should leave a monastery that is unsuitable for the development of concentration and go to live in one that is suitable, avoiding the eighteen unsuitable kinds of dwelling and taking one that has the eighteen qualities of a suitable dwelling.

original: tena yasmā rāgo pahātabbo, tasmā paṭikkūlamanasikāre parikammaṃ kātabbaṃ.
analyzed: tena yasmā rāgaḥ pahātabbaḥ tasmā paṭikkūla manasikāre parikammam kātabbam
translated: And he should sever the lesser impediments. Now, firstly, one who is of greedy temperament should practice the contemplation of foulness in order to abandon greed.🔽He should do the preliminary work on the contemplation of a decaying corpse.

original: Karontena pana kesesu tāva nimittaṃ gahetabbaṃ. Kathaṃ? Ekaṃ vā dve vā kese luñcitvā
analyzed: karontena pana kesesu tāva nimittam gahetabbam katham ekam vā dve vā kese luñcitvā
translated: But when he is doing the contemplation, he should first apprehend the sign in the head hairs. How?🔽Having combed them out with his fingers, he should place them on the palm of his hand and observe their colour thus: “The colour of these head hairs is not uniform;

original: hatthatale ṭhapetvā vaṇṇo tāva vavatthapetabbo. Chinnaṭṭhānepi kese oloketuṃ vaṭṭati;🔽udakapatte vā yāgupatte vā oloketumpi vaṭṭatiyeva. Kāḷakakāle disvā kāḷakāti manasikātabbā;
analyzed: hattha tale ṭhapetvā vaṇṇo tāva vavatthapetabbo chinna ṭṭhāne pi kese oloketum vaṭṭati  udaka patte vā yāgu patte vā oloketum pi vaṭṭatiyā iva kāḷaka kāle disvā kāḷakā ati manasikātabbā
translated: it is not all of one colour,” and he should define their colour by its individual essence thus: “These are black; these are grey; these are white.” He can also look at them in the place where they are, after cutting them;🔽and he can also look at them in a bowl or a pot of water. When he sees them in the black season, he should give attention to them as “black”;

original: setakāle setāti. Missakakāle pana ussadavasena manasikātabbā honti. Yathā ca kesesu,🔽evaṃ sakalepi tacapañcake disvāva nimittaṃ gahetabbaṃ. Evaṃ nimittaṃ gahetvā sabbakoṭṭhāsesu
analyzed: seta kāle setāti missaka kāle pana ussada vasena manasikātabbāḥ honti yathā ca kesesu  evam sakale api taca pañcake disvā va nimittam gahetabbam evam nimittam gahetvā sabba koṭṭhāsesu
translated: when in the grey season, to them as “grey”; when in the mixed season, he should give attention to them by distinguishing them thus: “This is black; this is grey; this is white.” And just as he does this with the head hairs,🔽so too with all the remaining parts of the body. Having apprehended the sign in this way, he should define it in all aspects thus: “The head hairs are in the head, the body hairs on the body, and so on.🔽He should define their colour, shape, direction, location, and delimitation.

original: vaṇṇasaṇṭhānadisokāsaparicchedavasena vavatthapetvā vaṇṇasaṇṭhānagandhaāsayokāsavasena🔽pañcadhā paṭikkūlato vavatthapetabbā.
analyzed: vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna disā ukāsa pariccheda vasena vavatthapetvā vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna gandha āsayokāsa vasena  pañcadhā paṭikkūlataḥ vavatthapetabbā
translated: He should define their colour thus: “The colour of the head hairs is black, the colour of the body hairs is black, the colour of the head hairs is dark brown, the colour of the body hairs is dark brown, the colour of the head hairs is tawny, the colour of the body hairs is tawny, the colour of the head hairs is white, the colour of the body hairs is white.”

original: Tatrāyaṃ sabbakoṭṭhāsesu anupubbakathā – kesā tāva pakativaṇṇena kāḷakā addāriṭṭhakavaṇṇā,
analyzed: tatra ayam sabba koṭṭhāsesu anupubba kathā kesā tāva pakati vaṇṇena kāḷakā addāriṭṭhaka vaṇṇā
translated: He should define their shape thus: “The shape of the head hairs is coiled, the shape of the body hairs is coiled, the shape of the head hairs is bent, the shape of the body hairs is bent, the shape of the head hairs is curved, the shape of the body hairs is curved, the shape of the head hairs is twisted, the shape of the body hairs is twisted.”🔽He should define their direction thus: “The direction of the head hairs is upwards, the direction of the body hairs is upwards.”🔽He should define their location thus: “The head hairs are on the upper part of the physical frame, the body hairs are on the upper part of the physical frame.”🔽He should define their delimitation thus: “The head hairs are delimited above by the unmanifest potentiality

original: saṇṭhānato dīghavaṭṭalikā tulādaṇḍasaṇṭhānā, disato uparimadisāya jātā, okāsato ubhosu
analyzed: saṇṭhānataḥ dīgha vaṭṭalikā tulā daṇḍa saṇṭhānā disataḥ uparima disāya jātā okāsataḥ ubhosu
translated: As to shape, they are the shape of long round measuring rods. As to direction, they lie in the upper direction. As to location, they are fixed in the openings in the scalp

original: passesu kaṇṇacūḷikāhi, purato nalāṭantena, pacchato galavāṭakena paricchinnā. Sīsakaṭāhaveṭhanaṃ🔽allacammaṃ kesānaṃ okāso. Paricchedato kesā sīsaveṭhanacamme vīhaggamattaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: passesu kaṇṇa cūḷikāhi puratas nala aṭantena pacchatas galavāṭakena paricchinnā sīsa kaṭāha veṭhanam  alla cammam kesānam okāsaḥ paricchedataḥ kesā sīsa veṭhana camme vīhagga mattam pavisitvā
translated: at the two sides, in front at the forehead, and at the back at the nape of the neck. The place on the head where the hair is combed over and oiled is the place for the hair.🔽As to delimitation, they are bounded below by the surface of their own roots, which are fixed by entering to the extent of a rice grain into the openings in the scalp,

original: patiṭṭhitena heṭṭhā attano mūlatalena, upari ākāsena, tiriyaṃ aññamaññena paricchinnā.
analyzed: patiṭṭhitena heṭṭhā attanaḥ mūla talena upari ākāsena tiriyam aññamaññena paricchinnā
translated: above by space, and all round by each other.

original: Dve kesā ekato natthīti ayaṃ sabhāgaparicchedo.
analyzed: dve kesā ekatas natthi iti ayam sa bhāga paricchedaḥ
translated: There are no two hairs together. This is the delimitation by the similar.

original: ‘Kesā na lomā, lomā na kesā’ti evaṃ avasesehi ekatiṃsakoṭṭhāsehi amissīkatā kesā nāma pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāsoti ayaṃ visabhāgaparicchedo. Idaṃ kesānaṃ vaṇṇādito vavatthāpanaṃ.
analyzed: kesāḥ na lomā lomāḥ na kesā ti evam avasesehi ekatiṃsa koṭṭhāsehi amissīkatā kesā nāma pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāso ti ayam visa bhāga paricchedaḥ idam kesānam vaṇṇa āditaḥ vavatthāpanam
translated: ‘Hair is not body hair; body hair is not hair’—thus they are not mixed up with the remaining thirty-one parts, and so they are a separate part called ‘hair.’ This is the delimitation by the dissimilar. This is how he defines hair by colour and the rest.

original: Idaṃ pana tesaṃ vaṇṇādivasena pañcadhā paṭikkūlato vavatthāpanaṃ – kesā ca nāmete
analyzed: idam pana tesam vaṇṇa ādi vasena pañcadhā paṭikkūlataḥ vavatthāpanam kesā ca nāma ete
translated: But as to how to define it by the five kinds of ugliness headed by colour: ‘And this hair on the head is not the property of anyone who could be called mine” or “I,”

original: vaṇṇatopi paṭikkūlā, saṇṭhānatopi gandhatopi āsayatopi okāsatopi paṭikkūlā. Manuññepi🔽hi yāgupatte vā bhattapatte vā kesavaṇṇaṃ kiñci disvā ‘kesamissakamidaṃ, haratha🔽na’nti jigucchanti. Evaṃ kesā vaṇṇato paṭikkūlā. Rattiṃ bhuñjantāpi kesasaṇṭhānaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇataḥ api paṭikkūlā saṇṭhānataḥ api gandhataḥ api āsayataḥ api okāsataḥ api paṭikkūlā manuññe pi  hi yāgu patte vā bhatta patte vā kesa vaṇṇam kiñci disvā kesa missakam idam haratha  nanti jigucchanti evam kesāḥ vaṇṇataḥ paṭikkūlāḥ rattim bhuñjantā api kesa saṇṭhānam
translated: They are repulsive in colour, shape, smell, habitat, and location.🔽Even in what is good, if one sees a hair in a bowl of rice gruel or in a bowl of boiled rice, one is disgusted and says, “This is mixed with hair; take it away.” So they are repulsive in colour.

original: akkavākaṃ vā makacivākaṃ vā chupitvāpi tatheva jigucchanti. Evaṃ saṇṭhānato paṭikkūlā.
analyzed: akkavākam vā makacivākam vā chupitvā api tathā iva jigucchanti evam saṇṭhānataḥ paṭikkūlā
translated: Even when eating at night, if one gets a hair in one’s mouth, one is disgusted even with the food one has not yet eaten. So they are repulsive in shape.

original: Telamakkhanapupphadhūmādisaṅkhāravirahitānañca kesānaṃ gandho paramajeguccho hoti,
analyzed: tela makkhana puppha dhūma ādi saṅkhāra virahitānam ca kesānam gandho parama jegucchaḥ hoti
translated: The smell of hair that is not treated with ointments, flowers, scents, etc., is extremely disgusting,🔽and it is even more disgusting when burnt in a fire.

original: tato jegucchataro aggimhi pakkhittānaṃ. Kesā hi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānato appaṭikkūlāpi siyuṃ,
analyzed: tatas jegucchataraḥ aggimhi pakkhittānam kesāḥ hi vaṇṇa saṇṭhānataḥ a paṭikkūlāḥ api siyum
translated: For although hair may not be repulsive in colour and shape,

original: gandhena pana paṭikkūlāyeva. Yathā hi daharassa kumārassa vaccaṃ vaṇṇato haḷiddivaṇṇaṃ,
analyzed: gandhena pana paṭikkūlāya iva yathā hi daharassa kumārassa vaccam vaṇṇataḥ haḷiddi vaṇṇam
translated: it is certainly repulsive in smell. Just as a baby’s excrement is the colour of turmeric🔽and the shape of a piece of turmeric,

original: saṇṭhānatopi haliddipiṇḍasaṇṭhānaṃ; saṅkhāraṭṭhāne chaḍḍitañca uddhumātakakāḷasunakhasarīraṃ
analyzed: saṇṭhānataḥ pi haliddi piṇḍa saṇṭhānam saṅkhāra ṭṭhāne chaḍḍitam ca uddhumātaka kāḷa su nakha sarīram
translated: and a bloated, dead dog’s body is the colour of a rain cloud

original: vaṇṇato tālapakkavaṇṇaṃ, saṇṭhānato vaṭṭetvā vissaṭṭhamudiṅgasaṇṭhānaṃ, dāṭhāpissa
analyzed: vaṇṇataḥ tāla pakka vaṇṇam saṇṭhānataḥ vaṭṭetvā vissaṭṭham udiṅga saṇṭhānam dāṭhāpissa
translated: As to colour, it is the colour of a ripe palm-fruit; as to shape, it is the shape of a twisted piece of gutta in the shape of a coil; as to direction, it lies in the upper direction; as to location, it is set in the jaw between the two eyes, for it is fixed there with a network of bones’ ends like a spike in a wooden framework.

original: sumanamakuḷasadisāti ubhayampi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānato siyā appaṭikkūlaṃ, gandhena pana paṭikkūlameva;🔽evaṃ kesāpi siyuṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānato appaṭikkūlā, gandhena pana paṭikkūlā evāti.🔽Yathā pana asuciṭṭhāne gāmanissandena jātāni sūpeyyapaṇṇāni nāgarikamanussānaṃ jegucchāni🔽honti aparibhogāni, evaṃ kesāpi pubbalohitamuttakarīsapittasemhādinissandena jātattā
analyzed: sumana makuḷa sadisā ti ubhayam pi vaṇṇa saṇṭhānato siyā appaṭikkūlam gandhena pana paṭikkūlam eva  evam kesā api siyum vaṇṇa saṇṭhānato appaṭikkūlāḥ gandhena pana paṭikkūlāḥ eva ati  yathā pana asuci ṭṭhāne gāma nissandena jātāni sūpeyya paṇṇāni nāgarika manussānam jegucchāni  honti a paribhogāni evam kesā api pubba lohita mutta karīsa pitta semha ādi nissandena jāta ttā
translated: As to colour, it is the colour of a palm- kernel. As to shape, it is the shape of a twisted piece of gutta percha. As to direction, it lies in the upper direction. As to location, it is fixed to the inside of the skull- bone, which is the upper side of the brain-pan, all round the brain, in five layers like the leaves of the bread-fruit in the seed. And the brain is to be found inside the skull-bone, which is the upper side of the brain-pan, like the white flesh of the inside of a ripe bread-fruit🔽. The teeth are white by nature. As to shape, they are the shape of beans set out in a mould. As to direction, they lie in the upper direction. As to location, they are fixed by a length of four inches in the jaw bones, which are the upper side of the gums, in two rows. The upper teeth number twenty-four, the lower teeth number twenty-four, making forty-four teeth in all. And the teeth are to be found in the jaw bones, which are the upper side of the gums, like the white flowers of the ironwood tree set in a wooden frame.

original: atijegucchāti idaṃ nesaṃ ‘āsayato’ pāṭikulyaṃ. Ime ca kesā nāma gūtharāsimhi uṭṭhitakaṇṇikaṃ🔽viya ekattiṃsakoṭṭhāsarāsimhi jātā. Te susānasaṅkāraṭṭhānādīsu jātasākaṃ viya, parikhādīsu🔽jātakamalakuvalayādipupphaṃ viya ca asuciṭṭhāne jātattā paramajegucchāti idaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: idam nesam āsayato pāṭikulyam ime ca kesāḥ nāma gūtha rāsimhi uṭṭhita kaṇṇikam 🔽viya ekattiṃsa koṭṭhāsa rāsimhi jātā te susāna saṅkāra ṭṭhāna ādīsu viya parikha ādīsu 🔽jāta kamala kuvalaya ādi puppham viya ca asuci ṭṭhāne jāta ttā parama jegucchā ati idam tesam
translated: But just as the leaves of the bread-fruit tree that grow in a village cesspit are disgusting to the townspeople and cannot be used, so too, the head hairs and body hairs grow out of the secretion of the earth- element in the form of the rootlets of the tangle of rotting vegetation that is the physical frame, and so they are extremely disgusting. This is their repulsiveness ‘as to habitat.’ And these head hairs and body hairs are born in the thirty-one lacquering vats of the physical frame like bits of lacquer in a lacquer-ware factory. They are extremely disgusting because they are born in an impure place like the vegetables that grow in a charnel-ground midden, like the water lilies, lotuses, etc., that grow in drains, etc.,

original: ‘okāsato’ pāṭikkūlyaṃ.🔽Yathā ca kesānaṃ, evaṃ sabbakoṭṭhāsānaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānagandhāsayokāsavasena pañcadhā
analyzed: okāsataḥ pāṭikkūlyam  yathā ca kesānam evam sabba koṭṭhāsānam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna gandha asayokāsa vasena pañcadhā
translated: ‘As to location’: the repulsive aspect of the location.

original: paṭikkūlatā vavatthapetabbā. Vaṇṇasaṇṭhānadisokāsaparicchedavasena pana sabbepi visuṃ🔽visuṃ vavatthapetabbā.
analyzed: paṭikkūla tā vavatthapetabbā vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna disā ukāsa pariccheda vasena pana sabbe pi visum  visum vavatthapetabbā
translated: And as with the head hairs, so with all the parts of the body, the repulsive- ness should be defined in the five ways as to colour, shape, odour, habitat, and location. But all of them should be defined separately as to colour, shape, direction, location, and delimitation.

original: Tattha lomā tāva pakativaṇṇato na kesā viya asambhinnakāḷakā, kāḷapiṅgalā pana honti;
analyzed: tattha lomā tāva pakati vaṇṇataḥ na kesāḥ viya asambhinna kāḷakā kāḷa piṅgalā pana honti
translated: Herein, firstly, as to colour: the body hairs are not, like the head hairs, pure black; they are black and tawny.🔽As to shape: they are the shape of long thin sticks.

original: saṇṭhānato onataggatālamūlasaṇṭhānā; disato dvīsu disāsu jātā; okāsato ṭhapetvā kesānaṃ
analyzed: saṇṭhānataḥ ona tagga tāla mūla saṇṭhānāḥ disataḥ dvīsu disāsu jātāḥ okāsataḥ ṭhapetvā kesānam
translated: As to direction: they lie in the upper direction.

original: patiṭṭhitokāsañca hatthapādatalāni ca yebhuyyena avasesasarīraveṭhanacamme jātā;🔽paricchedato sarīraveṭhanacamme likkhāmattaṃ pavisitvā patiṭṭhitena heṭṭhā attano
analyzed: patiṭṭhita ukāsam ca hattha pāda talāni ca yebhuyyena avasesa sarīra veṭhana camme jātā  paricchedataḥ sarīra veṭhana camme likkhāmattam pavisitvā patiṭṭhitena heṭṭhā attanaḥ
translated: As to location: they grow on the whole of the skin of the body except for the face, the surfaces of the hands and feet, and the callosities.

original: mūlatalena, upari ākāsena, tiriyaṃ aññamaññena paricchinnā. Dve lomā ekato natthi.
analyzed: mūla talena upari ākāsena tiriyam aññamaññena paricchinnā dve lomā ekatas natthi
translated: As to delimitation: they are bounded below by the surface of their own roots, which are fixed by entering to the extent of the minutest particle into the inner skin that envelops the body of living beings, and above by space, and all round by each other. There is no overlapping of one by another.

original: Ayaṃ tesaṃ sabhāgaparicchedo. Visabhāgaparicchedo pana kesasadisoyeva.
analyzed: ayam tesam sabhāga paricchedaḥ visabhāga paricchedaḥ pana
translated: This is their similar grouping. As to dissimilar grouping, they are similar to the head hairs and so on.

original: Nakhāti vīsatiyā nakhapaṭṭānaṃ nāmaṃ. Te sabbepi vaṇṇato setā; saṇṭhānato macchasakalikasaṇṭhānā;🔽disato pādanakhā heṭṭhimadisāya jātā, hatthanakhā uparimadisāyāti dvīsu disāsu jātā;🔽okāsato aṅgulīnaṃ aggapiṭṭhesu patiṭṭhitā; paricchedato dvīsu disāsu aṅgulikoṭimaṃsehi,
analyzed: nakhā ti vīsatiyā nakhapaṭṭānam nāmam te sabbe pi vaṇṇato setā saṇṭhānataḥ macchasakalika saṇṭhānā  disatas pāda nakhāḥ heṭṭhima disāya jātāḥ hattha nakhā uparima disāya ati dvīsu disāsu jātā  okāsataḥ aṅgulīnam agga piṭṭhesu patiṭṭhitā paricchedataḥ dvīsu disāsu aṅguli koṭim aṃsehi
translated: Nails: this is the name for the twenty nails. As to colour, they are white; as to shape, they are the shape of the blade of a razor;🔽as to direction, the nails of the feet are in the lower direction, and those of the hands are in the upper direction;

original: anto aṅgulipiṭṭhimaṃsena, bahi ceva agge ca ākāsena, tiriyaṃ aññamaññena paricchinnā.
analyzed: antar aṅguli piṭṭhim aṃsena bahi ca iva agge ca ākāsena tiriyam aññamaññena paricchinnā
translated: as to location, they are fixed on the tips of the fingers and toes; as to delimitation, they are bounded by what appertains to nails …

original: Dve nakhā ekato natthi. Ayaṃ nesaṃ sabhāgaparicchedo. Visabhāgaparicchedo pana kesasadisoyeva.
analyzed: dve nakhā ekatas natthi ayam nesam sabhāga paricchedaḥ visabhāga paricchedo pana
translated: There are no two nails together. This is their similar grouping. As to dissimilar grouping, they are similar to the head hairs and so on.

original: Dantāti paripuṇṇadantassa dvattiṃsa dantaṭṭhikāni. Tepi vaṇṇato setā; saṇṭhānato
analyzed: danta ati paripuṇṇa dantassa dvattiṃsa dantaṭṭhikāni te pi vaṇṇato setā saṇṭhānato
translated: Teeth: in one whose teeth are complete there are thirty-two tooth bones. As to colour, they are white; as to shape,

original: anekasaṇṭhānā. Tesañhi heṭṭhimāya tāva dantapāḷiyā majjhe cattāro dantā mattikāpiṇḍe
analyzed: aneka saṇṭhānā tesam hi heṭṭhimāya tāva dantapāḷiyāḥ majjhe cattāro dantāḥ mattikā piṇḍe
translated: they are of various shapes. For in the lower jaw there are four middle teeth the shape of the fruit of the Indian beech,

original: paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapitaalābubījasaṇṭhānā. Tesaṃ ubhosu passesu ekeko ekamūlako ekakoṭiko
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapita alābu bīja saṇṭhānā tesam ubhosu passesu ekekaḥ eka mūlakaḥ eka koṭiko
translated: and they are placed in order. They are the shape of a pumpkin seed. On both sides of them there is one with one root and one tip,

original: mallikamakuḷasaṇṭhāno. Tato ekeko dvimūlako dvikoṭiko yānakaupatthambhanikasaṇṭhāno.
analyzed: mallika makuḷa saṇṭhānaḥ tatas ekekaḥ dvi mūlakaḥ dvi koṭikaḥ yānaka upatthambhanika saṇṭhānaḥ
translated: the shape of a jasmine bud. Then there is one with two roots and two tips, the shape of a support for a carriage pole.

original: Tato dve dve timūlā tikoṭikā. Tato dve dve catumūlā catukoṭikāti. Uparimapāḷiyāpi🔽eseva nayo. Disato uparimadisāya jātā. Okāsato dvīsu hanukaṭṭhikesu patiṭṭhitā. Paricchedato
analyzed: tatas dve dve ti mūlā ti koṭikā tatas dve dve catu mūlā catu koṭikā ati uparima pāḷiyā api  esa iva nayaḥ disataḥ uparima disāya jātā okāsataḥ dvīsu hanu kaṭṭhikesu patiṭṭhitā paricchedato
translated: Then there are two with three roots and three tips, then two with four roots and four tips. In the same way with the next section.

original: heṭṭhā hanukaṭṭhike patiṭṭhitena attano mūlatalena, upari ākāsena, tiriyaṃ aññamaññena🔽paricchinnā. Dve dantā ekato natthi. Ayaṃ nesaṃ sabhāgaparicchedo. Visabhāgaparicchedo
analyzed: heṭṭhā hanu kaṭṭhike patiṭṭhitena attanaḥ mūla talena upari ākāsena tiriyam aññamaññena  paricchinnāḥ dve dantāḥ ekatas natthi ayam nesam sabhāga paricchedaḥ visabhāga paricchedo
translated: By direction they lie in the upper direction. By location they are fixed to the two jawbones. As to delimitation, they are bounded below by the surface of their own roots fixed to the two jawbones, above by space, and all round by each other.

original: pana kesasadisoyeva.
analyzed: pana kesa sadisā uyā iva
translated: There is no single tooth without a root. This is the delimitation by the similar; but the delimitation by the dissimilar is the same as that of the head-hairs and so on.

original: Tacoti sakalasarīraṃ veṭhetvā ṭhitacammaṃ. Tassa upari kāḷasāmapītādivaṇṇā chavi
analyzed: tacā uti sakala sarīram veṭhetvā ṭhita cammam tassa upari kāḷa sāma pīta ādi vaṇṇā chavi
translated: Skin 101. This is the outer skin that covers the whole body. On top of it there is the cuticle, which is black, yellow, red, or white in colour,

original: nāma, yā sakalasarīratopi saṅkaḍḍhiyamānā badaraṭṭhimattā hoti. Taco pana vaṇṇato🔽setoyeva. So cassa setabhāvo aggijālābhighātapaharaṇapahārādīhi viddhaṃsitāya chaviyā
analyzed: nāma yā sakala sarīrataḥ pi saṅkaḍḍhiyamānā badaraṭṭhimattā hoti taco pana vaṇṇato  so cassa seta bhāvaḥ aggi jāla abhighāta paharaṇa pahāra ādīhi viddhaṃsitāya chaviyā
translated: and when it is pulled out it is the size of a jujube kernel all over the body. As to colour, the skin is white

original: pākaṭo hoti. Saṇṭhānato sarīrasaṇṭhānova hoti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo.🔽Vitthārato pana pādaṅgulittaco kosakārakakosasaṇṭhāno. Piṭṭhipādattaco puṭabandhaupāhanasaṇṭhāno.🔽Jaṅghattaco bhattapuṭakatālapaṇṇasaṇṭhāno. Ūruttaco taṇḍulabharitadīghatthavikasaṇṭhāno.
analyzed: pākaṭaḥ hoti saṇṭhānataḥ sarīra saṇṭhānaḥ upa hoti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ  vitthārato pana kosakārakakosa saṇṭhāno piṭṭhi pāda ttaco puṭabandha upāhana saṇṭhāno  jaṅghattacaḥ bhatta puṭaka tāla paṇṇa saṇṭhānaḥ ūruttacaḥ taṇḍula bharita dīghatthavika saṇṭhānaḥ
translated: only. But when the outer cuticle is destroyed by fire, etc., its whiteness becomes evident. As to shape, it is the shape of the body. This, in the first place, is the general treatment.🔽But in detail: the skin of the toes is the shape of a betel-leaf tube; the skin of the backs of the feet is the shape of a pair of sandals;🔽the skin of the calves is the shape of a pair of bellows; the skin of the generative organ is the shape of a dog’s scrotum; the skin of the abdomen is the shape of a bag full of kidney beans;

original: Ānisadattaco udakapūritapaṭaparissāvanasaṇṭhāno. Piṭṭhittaco phalakonaddhacammasaṇṭhāno.🔽Kucchittaco vīṇādoṇikonaddhacammasaṇṭhāno. Urattaco yebhuyyena caturassasaṇṭhāno.
analyzed: udaka pūrita paṭa parissāvana saṇṭhāno piṭṭhittaco phalakonaddha camma saṇṭhāno  kucchittacaḥ vīṇā doṇikā naddha camma saṇṭhānaḥ urattacaḥ yebhuyyena catur assa saṇṭhānaḥ
translated: the skin of the back is the shape of a wooden plank; the skin of the chest is the shape of a wooden panel; the skin of the two upper arms is the shape of a pair of bamboo poles; the skin of the hands is the shape of a pair of tongs;

original: Ubhayabāhuttaco tūṇīronaddhacammasaṇṭhāno. Piṭṭhihatthattaco khurakosakasaṇṭhāno,
analyzed: ubhaya bāhu ttacaḥ tūṇīra unaddha camma saṇṭhāno piṭṭhi hattha ttacaḥ khura kosaka saṇṭhāno
translated: the skin of the backs of the fingers is the shape of a betel-leaf tube; the skin of the neck is the shape of a necklace; the skin of the head is the shape of a bowl turned upside down and fitting on the neck.

original: phaṇakatthavikasaṇṭhāno vā. Hatthaṅgulittaco kuñcikākosakasaṇṭhāno. Gīvattaco galakañcukasaṇṭhāno.
analyzed: phaṇakatthavika saṇṭhānaḥ vā kuñcikā kosaka saṇṭhānaḥ gīva ttacaḥ gala kañcuka saṇṭhānaḥ
translated: Or it is the shape of a fan-leaf. The skin of the fingers is the shape of a key-box. The skin of the throat is the shape of a goitre.

original: Mukhattaco chiddāvacchiddo kīṭakulāvakasaṇṭhāno. Sīsattaco pattatthavikasaṇṭhānoti.
analyzed: mukha ttacaḥ chidda avacchiddaḥ kīṭa kulāvaka saṇṭhāno sīsa ttacaḥ patta thavika saṇṭhānaḥ ti
translated: The skin of the face is the shape of a honeycomb with holes here and there. The skin of the head is the shape of a fan-leaf.

original: Tacapariggaṇhakena ca yogāvacarena uttaroṭṭhato paṭṭhāya upari mukhaṃ ñāṇaṃ pesetvā🔽paṭhamaṃ tāva mukhaṃ pariyonandhitvā ṭhitacammaṃ vavatthapetabbaṃ. Tato nalāṭaṭṭhicammaṃ.
analyzed: taca pariggaṇhakena ca yogāvacarena uttara uṭṭhataḥ paṭṭhāya upari mukham ñāṇam pesetvā  paṭhamam tāva mukham pariyonandhitvā ṭhita cammam vavatthapetabbam tatas nalāṭa ṭṭhi cammam
translated: And the meditator who discerns the skin should send his consciousness up from the top of the head,🔽first defining the head-skin that covers the head, then the skull-skin,

original: Tato thavikāya pakkhittapattassa ca thavikāya ca antarena hatthamiva sīsaṭṭhikassa🔽ca sīsacammassa ca antarena ñāṇaṃ pesetvā aṭṭhikena saddhiṃ cammassa ekābaddhabhāvaṃ🔽viyojentena sīsacammaṃ vavatthapetabbaṃ. Tato khandhacammaṃ. Tato anulomena paṭilomena
analyzed: tatas thavikāya pakkhitta pattassa ca thavikāya ca antarena hattham iva sīsaṭṭhikassa  ca sīsa cammassa ca antarena ñāṇam pesetvā aṭṭhikena saddhim cammassa ekābaddha bhāvam  viyojentena sīsa cammam vavatthapetabbam tatas khandha cammam tatas anulomena paṭilomena
translated: and then, as though he were pushing the fan-leaf of the skull into the fan-leaf of the skin of the head,🔽he should separate the skin from the skull and define the head-skin. Then the trunk-skin. Then the back-skin in the forward and reverse order.

original: ca dakkhiṇahatthacammaṃ. Atha teneva nayena vāmahatthacammaṃ. Tato piṭṭhicammaṃ.
analyzed: ca dakkhiṇa hattha cammam atha tena iva nayena vāma hattha cammam tatas piṭṭhi cammam
translated: Then the right arm-skin. Then the left arm-skin in the same way. Then the back-skin.

original: Taṃ taṃ vavatthapetvā anulomena ca paṭilomena ca dakkhiṇapādacammaṃ. Atha teneva🔽nayena vāmapādacammaṃ. Tato anukkameneva vatthiudarahadayagīvacammāni vavatthapetabbāni.
analyzed: tam tam vavatthapetvā anulomena ca paṭilomena ca dakkhiṇa pāda cammam atha tena iva  nayena vāma pāda cammam tatas anukkamena iva vatthi udara hadaya gīva cammāni vavatthapetabbāni
translated: Having defined it thus, he defines the skin of the right foot by following it upwards and by following it downwards. Then in the same way the skin of the left foot. Then in due order the skin of the calf, the skin of the thigh, the skin of the buttock, the skin of the belly, the skin of the back, the skin of the chest, the skin of the two arms, the skin of the two forearms, the skin of the two elbows, the skin of the two shoulders, the skin of the neck, the skin of the head, the skin of the face, the skin of the scalp.

original: Atha gīvācammānantaraṃ heṭṭhimahanucammaṃ vavatthapetvā adharoṭṭhapariyosānaṃ pāpetvā
analyzed: atha gīvā camma anantaram heṭṭhima hanu cammam vavatthapetvā adhara uṭṭha pariyosānam pāpetvā
translated: Having defined the skin of the neck next to the skin of the head, he should bring it down to the end of the lower lip and stop.

original: niṭṭhapetabbaṃ. Evaṃ oḷārikoḷārikaṃ pariggaṇhantassa sukhumampi pākaṭaṃ hoti.🔽Disato dvīsu disāsu jāto. Okāsato sakalasarīraṃ pariyonandhitvā ṭhito. Paricchedato
analyzed: niṭṭhapetabbam evam oḷārika uḷārikam pariggaṇhantassa sukhumam pi pākaṭam hoti  disatas dvīsu disāsu jātaḥ okāsataḥ sakala sarīram ṭhitaḥ paricchedato
