original: yoginā nāsāpuṭe pūretvā ṭhitavaseneva pariggaṇhitabbā. Paricchedato siṅghāṇikābhāgena🔽paricchinnā. Ayamassa sabhāgaparicchedo. Visabhāgaparicchedo pana kesasadisova.
analyzed: yoginā nāsāpuṭe pūretvā ṭhita vasena iva pariggaṇhitabbā paricchedato siṅghāṇikā bhāgena  paricchinnā ayam assa sabhāga paricchedaḥ visabhāga paricchedo pana kesa sadisaḥ uva
translated: The yogin should apprehend it by the method of standing with the nostrils filled. As to delimitation, it is bounded by what appertains to snot …

original: Lasikāti sarīrasandhīnaṃ abbhantare picchilakuṇapaṃ. Sā vaṇṇato kaṇikāraniyyāsavaṇṇā.🔽Saṇṭhānato okāsasaṇṭhānā. Disato dvīsu disāsu jātā. Okāsato aṭṭhisandhīnaṃ abbhañjanakiccaṃ🔽sādhayamānā asītisatasandhīnaṃ abbhantare ṭhitā. Yassa cesā mandā hoti, tassa uṭṭhahantassa
analyzed: lasikā ati sarīra sandhīnam abbhantare picchila kuṇapam sā vaṇṇataḥ kaṇikāra niyyāsa vaṇṇā  saṇṭhānataḥ okāsa saṇṭhānāḥ disataḥ dvīsu disāsu jātāḥ okāsataḥ aṭṭhi sandhīnam abbhañjana kiccam  sādhayamānā asīti sata sandhīnam abbhantare ṭhitā yassa ca isā mandā hoti tassa uṭṭhahantassa
translated: Grease 10 is the slimy ordure inside the joints of the bones. As to colour, it is the colour of the juice of red lead.🔽As to shape, it is the shape of its location. As to direction, it arises in the two directions. As to location, situated inside the hundred and eighty joints, performing the function of lubricating the joints of the bones,

original: nisīdantassa abhikkamantassa paṭikkamantassa sammiñjantassa pasārentassa aṭṭhikāni
analyzed: nisīdantassa abhikkamantassa paṭikkamantassa sammiñjantassa pasārentassa aṭṭhikāni
translated: in one whose grease is deficient, when he gets up or sits down, goes forward or backward, bends or stretches, his bones creak together,

original: kaṭakaṭāyanti, accharāsaddaṃ karonto viya vicarati, ekayojanadviyojanamattampi addhānaṃ
analyzed: kaṭakaṭāyanti accha rāsaddam karontaḥ viya vicarati eka yojana dvi yojana mattam pi
translated: and he moves about making a crackling noise like that of burning stalks of rice-husk. He can go a distance of a league or two leagues

original: gatassa vāyodhātu kuppati, gattāni dukkhanti. Yassa pana bahukā hoti tassa uṭṭhānanisajjādīsu
analyzed: gatassa vāyodhātu kuppati gattāni dukkhanti yassa pana bahukā hoti tassa uṭṭhāna nisajja ādīsu
translated: Or if he has gone a long distance, his body-elements do not get upset and his limbs do not ache.🔽But if he has much, his bones do not creak when he moves his limbs,

original: na aṭṭhīni kaṭakaṭāyanti, dīghampi addhānaṃ gatassa na vāyodhātu kuppati, na gattāni
analyzed: na aṭṭhīni kaṭakaṭāyanti dīgham pi addhānam gatassa na vāyodhātu kuppati na gattāni
translated: and if he has gone a long distance, his body-elements do not get upset and his limbs do

original: dukkhanti. Paricchedato lasikābhāgena paricchinnā. Ayamassa sabhāgaparicchedo. Visabhāgaparicchedo pana kesasadisova.
analyzed: paricchedataḥ lasikā bhāgena paricchinnā ayam assa sabhāga paricchedaḥ visabhāga paricchedaḥ pana kesa sadisaḥ uva
translated: not ache. As to delimitation, it is bounded by what appertains to grease …

original: Muttanti vaṇṇato māsakhārodakavaṇṇaṃ. Saṇṭhānato adhomukhaṭhapitaudakakumbhantaragataudakasaṇṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: muttanti vaṇṇataḥ māsa khāra udaka vaṇṇam saṇṭhānataḥ adhomukha ṭhapita audaka kumbha antara gata odaka saṇṭhānam
translated: Urine 10. As to colour, it is the colour of water in which meat has been washed. As to shape, it is the shape of water in a turned-up tub.

original: Disato heṭṭhimāya disāya jātaṃ. Okāsato vatthissa abbhantare ṭhitaṃ. Vatthi nāma
analyzed: disataḥ heṭṭhimāya disāya jātam okāsataḥ vatthissa abbhantare ṭhitam vatthi nāma
translated: As to direction, it lies in the lower direction. As to location, it is to be found inside the bladder. The bladder

original: vatthipuṭo vuccati, yattha seyyathāpi nāma candanikāya pakkhitte amukhe ravaṇaghaṭe
analyzed: vatthipuṭaḥ vuccati yattha seyyathā api nāma candanikāya pakkhitte amukhe ravaṇa ghaṭe
translated: is called the “urine receptacle.” Just as, when rain water falls on a higher level and flows down to fill a lower-level pot that is breached,

original: candanikaraso pavisati, na cassa pavisanamaggo paññāyati; evameva sarīrato muttaṃ
analyzed: candanika rasaḥ pavisati na cassa pavisana maggo paññāyati evam eva sarīrataḥ muttam
translated: the water does not stay there but flows out, so too, when the urine in the bladder has reached its full measure,

original: pavisati, na cassa pavisanamaggo paññāyati, nikkhamanamaggo pana pākaṭo hoti; yamhi🔽ca muttassa bharite ‘passāvaṃ karomā’ti sattānaṃ āyūhanaṃ hoti. Paricchedato vatthiabbhantarena🔽ceva muttabhāgena ca paricchinnaṃ. Ayamassa sabhāgaparicchedo. Visabhāgaparicchedo pana kesasadisova.🔽Evañhi kesādike koṭṭhāse vaṇṇasaṇṭhānadisokāsaparicchedavasena vavatthapetvā anupubbato
analyzed: pavisati na cassa pavisana maggo paññāyati nikkhamana maggo pana pākaṭaḥ hoti yamhi  ca muttassa bharite passāvam karoma ati sattānam āyūhanam hoti paricchedataḥ vatthi abbhantarena  ca iva mutta bhāgena ca paricchinnam ayam assa sabhāga paricchedaḥ visabhāga paricchedo pana kesa sadisā uva  evam hi kesa ādike koṭṭhāse vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna disā ukāsa pariccheda vasena vavatthapetvā anupubbato
translated: and the way he enters is not evident, but the way he comes out is evident, and the place where he is stored is evident, and the place where he is collected is evident, that is to say, the place where, when he is released, people gather to make a urinal for him. As to delimitation, it is bounded by what appertains to urine …🔽This is how he defines urine by colour, shape, direction, location, and delimitation. Next to that he defines feces, which is in the receptacle for undigested food, by colour as ‘the colour of cut bamboo’ or ‘the colour of a dead spider’ or ‘the colour of a dead cockroach’ or ‘the colour of a dead louse’ according as it resembles one of these,

original: nātisīghato nātisaṇikatotiādinā nayena vaṇṇasaṇṭhānagandhāsayokāsavasena pañcadhā
analyzed: na ati sīghataḥ na ati saṇikataḥ iti ādinā nayena vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna gandha asayokāsa vasena pañcadhā
translated: and by shape as ‘the shape of a dog’s hobble’ or ‘the shape of a key’ or ‘the shape of a spider’s web’ or ‘the shape of a cockroach’s nest’ or ‘the shape of a louse’s nest’ according as it resembles one of these. As to direction, it is in the lower direction. As to location, it is to be found in the receptacle for undigested food.🔽 Translation: When it is inside, the way it enters is not evident, but the way it comes out is evident, and the place where it is stored is evident, and the place where it is collected is evident, that is to say, the place where, when it is released, people gather to make a urinal for it. As to delimitation, it is bounded by what appertains to urine …🔽When he has defined the component head hairs in this way by colour, shape, direction, location, and delimitation, he again and again brings to mind the repulsiveness of the body as a whole in the way already described.🔽Next to that he defines the component body hairs, which are to be found on the inner skin that envelops the body and on the outer skin that covers it, by colour as ‘black, or the colour of sesame seeds or mung beans or ripe kála fruit,’ according as the case may be.

original: ‘paṭikkūlā paṭikkūlā’ti manasikaroto paṇṇattisamatikkamavasena, seyyathāpi cakkhumato🔽purisassa dvattiṃsavaṇṇānaṃ kusumānaṃ ekasuttagaṇṭhitaṃ mālaṃ olokentassa sabbapupphāni
analyzed: paṭikkūlā paṭikkūlā ati manasikaroto paṇṇatti samatikkama vasena seyyathā api cakkhumataḥ 🔽purisassa dvattiṃsa vaṇṇānam kusumānam eka sutta gaṇṭhitam mālam olokentassa sabba pupphāni
translated: And by shape as ‘the shape of muñja grass roots or the shape of thread or the shape of yam shoots,’ according as they are coiled like muñja grass roots, or straight like thread, or pointing upwards like yam shoots. As to direction, they are in the upper direction. As to location,

original: apubbāpariyamiva pākaṭāni honti, evameva “atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā”ti imaṃ kāyaṃ olokentassa
analyzed: apubba apariyam iva pākaṭāni honti evam eva atthi imasmin kāye kesā ati imam kāyam olokentassa
translated: Translation: tathā imasmiṃ kāye kesāti imaṃ kāyaṃ olokentassa

original: sabbe te dhammā apubbāpariyamiva pākaṭā honti. Tena vuttaṃ manasikārakosallakathāyaṃ
analyzed: sabbe te dhammā apubba apariyam iva pākaṭāḥ honti tena vuttam manasikāra kosallakathāyam
translated: sabbe te dhammā apubbāpariyamiva pākaṭā honti | tena vuttaṃ manasikārakosallakathāyaṃ:

original: “ādikammikassa hi ‘kesā’ti manasikaroto manasikāro gantvā ‘mutta’nti imaṃ pariyosānakoṭṭhāsameva āhacca tiṭṭhatī”ti.
analyzed: ādikammikassa hi kesāti manasikarotaḥ manasikāraḥ gantvā muttanti imam pariyosāna koṭṭhāsam eva āhacca tiṭṭhati iti
translated: “ādikammikassa hi kesāti manasikaroto manasikāro gantvā muttaṃ nāma pariyosānakoṭṭhāsaṃ āhacca tiṭṭhatī”ti |

original: Sace pana bahiddhāpi manasikāraṃ upasaṃharati, athassa evaṃ sabbakoṭṭhāsesu pākaṭībhūtesu
analyzed: sace pana bahiddhā api manasikāram upasaṃharati athassa evam sabba koṭṭhāsesu pākaṭībhūtesu
translated: sace pana bahiddhāpi manasikāraṃ upasaṃharati, athassa evaṃ sabbaṭṭhānesu pākaṭībhūtesu

original: āhiṇḍantā manussatiracchānādayo sattākāraṃ vijahitvā koṭṭhāsarāsivaseneva upaṭṭhahanti;
analyzed: āhiṇḍantāḥ manussa tiracchāna ādayaḥ satta ākāram vijahitvā koṭṭhāsa rāsi vasena iva upaṭṭhahanti
translated: manussatiracchānayādisu āhiṇḍantesu sattākāraṃ vijahitvā koṭṭhāsarāsivaseneva upaṭṭhānaṃ labhati |

original: tehi ca ajjhohariyamānaṃ pānabhojanādi koṭṭhāsarāsimhi pakkhipiyamānamiva upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: tehi ca ajjhohariyamānam pāna bhojana ādi koṭṭhāsa rāsimhi pakkhipiyamānam iva upaṭṭhāti
translated: tehi ca ajjhohariyamānaṃ pānabhojanādikaṃ koṭṭhāsarāsimhi pakkhipiyamānamiva upaṭṭhāti |

original: Athassa anupubbamuñcanādivasena ‘paṭikūlā paṭikūlā’ti punappunaṃ manasikaroto anukkamena appanā uppajjati.
analyzed: athassa anupubba muñcana ādi vasena paṭikūlā paṭikūlā ati punappunam manasikarotaḥ anukkamena appanā uppajjati
translated: athassa anupubbamuñcanādivasena paṭikūlaṃ paṭikūlanti punappunaṃ manasikaroto anukkamena appanā uppajjati |

original: Tattha kesādīnaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānadisokāsaparicchedavasena upaṭṭhānaṃ uggahanimittaṃ,
analyzed: tattha kesa ādīnam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna disa ukāsa pariccheda vasena upaṭṭhānam uggaha nimittam
translated: Herein, the appearance of the head hairs, etc., as to their colour, shape, direction, location, and delimitation is the learning sign.🔽The appearance of them as repulsiveness in all aspects is the counterpart sign.

original: sabbākārato paṭikūlavasena upaṭṭhānaṃ paṭibhāganimittaṃ. Taṃ punappunaṃ āvajjentassa
analyzed: sabba ākārataḥ paṭikūla vasena upaṭṭhānam paṭibhāga nimittam tam punappunam āvajjentassa
translated: As he adverts again and again to that sign and gives his attention to it,

original: manasikarontassa takkāhataṃ vitakkāhataṃ karontassa cattāro khandhā paṭikūlārammaṇā🔽honti, paṭhamajjhānavasena appanā pavattati. Pubbabhāge parikammaupacāracittāni savitakkasavicārāni
analyzed: manasikarontassa takka āhatam vitakka āhatam karontassa cattāro khandhāḥ paṭikūla ārammaṇā  honti paṭhama jhāna vasena appanā pavattati pubbabhāge parikamma aupacāra cittāni sa vitakka sa vicārāni
translated: then the four mental aggregates that occur in the consciousnesses of adverting, etc., have repulsiveness as their object,🔽and absorption arises in the form of the first jhāna.🔽In the earlier stage the access unification is accompanied by applied thought and the rest, and it has as its object the sign of foulness.

original: sappītikāni somanassasahagatāni paṭikūlanimittārammaṇāni; appanāpi savitakkasavicārā
analyzed: sappītikāni somanassa sahagatāni paṭikūla nimitta ārammaṇāni appanā api sa vitakka sa vicārā
translated: The absorption unification is accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought, happiness and bliss, and it has as its object the sign of foulness.

original: sappītikā somanassasahagatāva. Bhūmantarena pana mahaggatā rūpāvacarā honti. Paṭikkūlepi
analyzed: sappītikā somanassa sahagatā ava bhūma antarena pana mahaggatāḥ rūpāvacarāḥ honti paṭikkūle pi
translated: But in the higher plane it is exalted, and it is of the fine-material sphere.

original: ca etasmiṃ ārammaṇe ānisaṃsadassāvitāya somanassaṃ uppajjati, ekattārammaṇabaleneva
analyzed: ca etasmin ārammaṇe ānisaṃsa dassāvitāya somanassam uppajjati ekatta ārammaṇa balena iva
translated: And in this case joy arises because of seeing the benefits in the object of repulsiveness,🔽or it arises through the mere unification of mind.

original: vā taṃ uppajjati. Dutiyajjhānādīni panettha na nibbattanti. Kasmā? Oḷārikattā. Idañhi
analyzed: vā tam uppajjati dutiya jhāna ādīni pana ittha na nibbattanti kasmai oḷārika ttā idam hi
translated: But the second jhāna, etc., do not arise here. Why? Because of its grossness.

original: ārammaṇaṃ oḷārikaṃ. Vitakkabalenevettha cittekaggatā jāyati, na vitakkasamatikkamenāti.
analyzed: ārammaṇam oḷārikam vitakka balena iva ittha citta ekagga tā jāyati na vitakka samatikkamena ati
translated: and the object is gross. Here the unification of mind arises only through the force of applied thought, not by transcending applied thought.

original: Ayaṃ tāva samathavasena kammaṭṭhānakathā.
analyzed: ayam tāva samatha vasena kammaṭṭhāna kathā
translated: This, firstly, is the explanation of the meditation subject as concentration.

original: Avisesato pana sādhāraṇavasena evaṃ veditabbaṃ – idañhi kammaṭṭhānaṃ bhāvetukāmena🔽kammaṭṭhānaṃ uggahetvā sajjhāyakāle eva kesādīnaṃ vaṇṇanimittasaṇṭhānanimittadisānimittaokāsanimittaparicchedanimittāni
analyzed: avisesataḥ pana sādhāraṇa vasena evam veditabbam idam hi kammaṭṭhānam bhāvetu kāmena  kammaṭṭhānam uggahetvā sajjhāya kāle eva kesa ādīnam vaṇṇa nimitta saṇṭhāna nimitta disā nimitta okāsa nimitta pariccheda nimittāni
translated: But it should be understood generally as follows. One who wants to develop this meditation subject should🔽learn the meditation subject from a teacher, and then at the time of his private meditation he should first of all pay homage to the Enlightened One, the Teacher, the Law, and the Order, and then he should make the wish, “Let the Enlightened One, the Teacher, be pleased,” and so on.

original: vācāya pothetvā pothetvā ekekakoṭṭhāse ‘ayaṃ etaṃsarikkhako’ti tividhena sajjhāyo
analyzed: vācāya pothetvā pothetvā ekeka koṭṭhāse ayam tividhena sajjhāyaḥ
translated: After that, he should either recite the meditation subject or get someone else to recite it, and he should define the parts thus, “This meditation subject is of such a kind, such a nature, such a characteristic, such a manifestation, such a location,” and he should review it again and again with all the aspects of the meditation subject thus.

original: kātabbo. Kathaṃ? Tacapañcake tāva heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva anulomato pañcāhaṃ, paṭilomato🔽pañcāhaṃ, anulomapaṭilomato pañcāhanti addhamāsaṃ sajjhāyo kātabbo. Tato ācariyassa
analyzed: kātabbaḥ katham taca pañcake tāva heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva anulomataḥ pañca aham paṭilomataḥ  pañca aham anuloma paṭilomataḥ pañca ahanti addha māsam sajjhāyaḥ kātabbo tatas ācariyassa
translated: How? First of all, he should recite the five parts of the skin pentad in the forward order in the way already described,🔽and then in the reverse order, and then in the forward and reverse order, thus making it his recitation and making it his meditation topic for a fortnight. Then he should go to the teacher

original: santikaṃ gantvā vakkapañcakaṃ uggaṇhitvā tatheva addhamāsaṃ sajjhāyo kātabbo. Tato
analyzed: santikam gantvā vakka pañcakam uggaṇhitvā tathā iva addha māsam sajjhāyaḥ kātabbo tatas
translated: and learn the five parts of the flesh pentad, and he should recite it and make it his meditation topic for a fortnight in the same way.

original: te dasapi koṭṭhāse ekato katvā addhamāsaṃ. Puna papphāsapañcakādīsupi ekekaṃ uggaṇhitvā
analyzed: te koṭṭhāse ekatas katvā addha māsam puna ekekam uggaṇhitvā
translated: He should then combine the ten sections and rehearse them for a fortnight. Then he should learn the five sections beginning with the lungs and rehearse them for a fortnight.

original: addhamāsaṃ. Tato te pañcadasapi koṭṭhāse addhamāsaṃ. Matthaluṅgapañcakaṃ addhamāsaṃ.🔽Tato tevīsati koṭṭhāse addhamāsaṃ. Medachakkaṃ addhamāsaṃ. Tato te chabbīsatipi koṭṭhāse
analyzed: addha māsam koṭṭhāse addha māsam matthaluṅga pañcakam addha māsam  tato tevīsati koṭṭhāse addha māsam meda chakkam addha māsam tato te chabbīsati pi koṭṭhāse
translated: Then he should rehearse all fifteen sections for a fortnight. Then he should rehearse the five sections on the liver for a fortnight.🔽Then he should rehearse the twenty-three sections for a fortnight. Then he should rehearse the six sections on the bowels for a fortnight. Then he should rehearse all twenty-nine sections

original: ekato katvā addhamāsaṃ. Muttachakkaṃ addhamāsaṃ. Tato sabbepi dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāse
analyzed: ekatas katvā addha māsam mutta chakkam addha māsam tatas sabbe pi dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāse
translated: combined for a fortnight. Then he should rehearse the six sections on the gorge for a fortnight. Then he should rehearse all thirty-two sections

original: ekato katvā addhamāsanti evaṃ cha māse sajjhāyo kātabbo.
analyzed: ekatas katvā evam cha māse sajjhāyaḥ kātabbo
translated: combined for a fortnight. This rehearsal should be done in six months.

original: Tattha – upanissayasampannassa sappaññassa bhikkhuno kammaṭṭhānaṃ uggaṇhantasseva
analyzed: tattha upanissaya sampannassa sappaññassa bhikkhuno kammaṭṭhānam uggaṇhantassa eva
translated: Herein, when a bhikkhu endowed with the requisite conditions is learning the meditation subject,

original: koṭṭhāsā upaṭṭhahanti, ekaccassa na upaṭṭhahanti. Tena ‘na upaṭṭhahantī’ti vīriyaṃ
analyzed: koṭṭhāsāḥ upaṭṭhahanti ekaccassa na upaṭṭhahanti tena na upaṭṭhahanti iti vīriyam
translated: the parts of the skeleton sometimes appear to him and sometimes they do not. He must not relax his effort thinking, “They do not appear to me.”

original: na vissajjetabbaṃ. Yattakā koṭṭhāsā upaṭṭhahanti tattake gahetvā sajjhāyo kātabbo.
analyzed: na vissajjetabbam yattakā koṭṭhāsāḥ upaṭṭhahanti tattake gahetvā sajjhāyaḥ kātabbaḥ
translated: He should continue the rehearsal with as many parts as appear to him.

original: Evaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathentena pana neva paññavato na mandapaññassa vasena kathetabbaṃ,
analyzed: evam kammaṭṭhānam kathentena pana na iva paññavataḥ na manda paññassa vasena kathetabbam
translated: But when he is teaching the meditation subject in this way, he should not teach it to one who is very wise or to one who is very stupid.

original: majjhimapaññassa vasena kathetabbaṃ. Majjhimapaññassa hi vasena ācariyā chahi māsehi
analyzed: majjhima paññassa vasena kathetabbam majjhima paññassa hi vasena ācariyā chahi māsehi
translated: He should teach it to one of middling ability. For the teachers have set the limit at six months for one of middling ability.

original: paricchinditvā tantiṃ ṭhapayiṃsu. Yassa pana ettāvatāpi koṭṭhāsā pākaṭā na honti,
analyzed: paricchinditvā tantim ṭhapayiṃsu yassa pana ettāvatā api koṭṭhāsāḥ pākaṭāḥ na honti
translated: But if the meditation subject is still not clear to one after that,

original: tena tato parampi sajjhāyo kātabbo eva; no ca kho aparicchinditvā, cha cha māse paricchinditvāva kātabbo.🔽Sajjhāyaṃ karontena vaṇṇo na paccavekkhitabbo, na lakkhaṇaṃ manasikātabbaṃ, koṭṭhāsavaseneva
analyzed: tena tatas param pi sajjhāyaḥ kātabbo eva no ca kho a paricchinditvā cha cha māse paricchinditvā ava kātabbo  sajjhāyam karontena vaṇṇaḥ na paccavekkhitabbaḥ na lakkhaṇam manasikātabbam koṭṭhāsa vasena iva
translated: he should continue the preliminary work even further, but not beyond a year, and he should do it by taking six or seven or eight or nine or ten or eleven or twelve terms.🔽When he does the preliminary work, he should not review the colour, nor should he give attention to the characteristic. He should do the preliminary work

original: sajjhāyo kātabbo. Ācariyenāpi ‘vaṇṇavasena sajjhāyaṃ karohī’ti niyametvā na kathetabbaṃ.
analyzed: sajjhāyaḥ kātabbaḥ ācariyena api vaṇṇa vasena sajjhāyam karohi iti niyametvā na kathetabbam
translated: by means of the term “in-breath” and “out-breath” only. And the teacher should not say, “Do the preliminary work by means of the colour,” or “Do it by means of the sign.”

original: Niyametvā kathite ko dosoti? Sampattiyampi vipattisaññāāpajjanaṃ. Sace hi ācariyena
analyzed: niyametvā kathite kaḥ dosaḥ ti sampattiyam pi vipatti saññā āpajjanam sace hi ācariyena
translated: What is wrong with teaching it by specifying it in this way? It is that success is not common to all.🔽If the teacher teaches it by specifying it in this way, then the pupil’s perception is of success as specified, and when he goes to do the work by himself, he cannot do it because he has no success. So he thinks, “The meditation subject is defective,” and he gives it up.

original: ‘vaṇṇavasena sajjhāyaṃ karohī’ti vutte imassa bhikkhuno tathā karontassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽vaṇṇato na upaṭṭhāti, paṭikūlavasena vā dhātuvasena vā upaṭṭhāti, athesa ‘na idaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇa vasena sajjhāyam karohi iti vutte imassa bhikkhunaḥ tathā karontassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ  vaṇṇataḥ na upaṭṭhāti paṭikūla vasena vā dhātu vasena vā upaṭṭhāti atha isa naḥ idam
translated: If he is told, “Do the meditation subject as a colour,” and it appears to him as a colour,

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ vilakkhaṇa’nti saññī hoti, ācariyena kathitameva kappetvā gaṇhāti. ‘Paṭikūlavasena
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam vilakkhaṇanti saññī hoti ācariyena kathitam eva kappetvā gaṇhāti paṭikūla vasena
translated: but not as a meditation subject, then he should know that this meditation subject is not clear to him. He should take it as taught by the teacher and go on developing it.

original: sajjhāyaṃ karohī’ti vuttepi sace tassa tathā karontassa paṭikkūlato na upaṭṭhāti,🔽vaṇṇavasena vā dhātuvasena vā upaṭṭhāti, athesa ‘nayidaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ vilakkhaṇa’nti
analyzed: sajjhāyam karohi iti vutte pi sace tassa tathā karontassa paṭikkūlataḥ na upaṭṭhāti  vaṇṇa vasena vā dhātu vasena vā upaṭṭhāti atha isa na idam kammaṭṭhānam vilakkhaṇanti
translated: If he is told, “Do the meditation subject as repulsive,” and it appears to him as repulsive,

original: saññī hoti, ācariyena kathitameva kappetvā gaṇhāti. ‘Dhātuvasena taṃ sajjhāyaṃ karohī’ti
analyzed: saññī hoti ācariyena kathitam eva kappetvā gaṇhāti dhātu vasena tam sajjhāyam karohi iti
translated: but not as a meditation subject, then he should know that this meditation subject is not clear to him. He should take it as taught by the teacher and go on developing it.

original: vuttepi sace tassa tathā karontassa dhātuto na upaṭṭhāti, vaṇṇavasena vā paṭikūlavasena
analyzed: vutte pi sace tassa tathā karontassa dhātutaḥ na upaṭṭhāti vaṇṇa vasena vā paṭikūla vasena
translated: If he is told, “Do the meditation subject as elements,” and it appears to him as elements,

original: vā upaṭṭhāti, athesa ‘nayidaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ vilakkhaṇa’nti saññī hoti, ācariyena kathitameva
analyzed: vā upaṭṭhāti atha isa na yidam kammaṭṭhānam vilakkhaṇanti saññī hoti ācariyena kathitam eva
translated: but not as a meditation subject, then he should know that this meditation subject is not clear to him. He should take it as taught by the teacher and go on developing it.

original: kappetvā gaṇhāti. Ayaṃ ācariyena niyametvā kathite doso.
analyzed: kappetvā gaṇhāti ayam ācariyena niyametvā kathite doso
translated: He takes it up by the method of definition. This is the fault in the teacher’s method of teaching.

original: Kinti pana vattabbo hotīti? ‘Koṭṭhāsavasena sajjhāyaṃ karohī’ti vattabbo. Kathaṃ?🔽‘Kesakoṭṭhāso lomakoṭṭhāsoti sajjhāyaṃ karohī’ti vattabbo. Sace panassa evaṃ koṭṭhāsavasena🔽sajjhāyaṃ karontassa vaṇṇato upaṭṭhāti, athānena ovādācariyassa ācikkhitabbaṃ – ‘ahaṃ
analyzed: kinti pana vattabbo hoti iti koṭṭhāsa vasena sajjhāyam karohi iti vattabbaḥ katham  kesa koṭṭhāsaḥ loma koṭṭhāsaḥ ti sajjhāyam karohi iti vattabbo sace panassa evam koṭṭhāsa vasena  sajjhāyam karontassa vaṇṇataḥ upaṭṭhāti atha anena ovāda ācariyassa ācikkhitabbaṃ aham
translated: But how should it be done? ‘Do the meditation subject by the method of the parts.’ How?🔽‘Do the meditation subject by the method of the parts, taking the head hairs as head hairs, the body hairs as body hairs, and so on.’ If, when he does the meditation subject by the method of the parts,

original: dvattiṃsākāraṃ koṭṭhāsavasena sajjhāyaṃ karomi; mayhaṃ pana vaṇṇato upaṭṭhātī’ti.
analyzed: dvattiṃsa ākāram koṭṭhāsa vasena sajjhāyam karomi mayham pana vaṇṇataḥ upaṭṭhāti iti
translated: the colour appears to him, then he should tell the teacher who gives him advice thus, ‘I do the meditation subject by the method of the parts, but the colour appears to me.’

original: Ācariyena ‘kammaṭṭhānaṃ viya akammaṭṭhānaṃ, vilakkhaṇaṃ eta’nti na visaṃvādetabbaṃ.
analyzed: ācariyena kammaṭṭhānam viya akammaṭṭhānam vilakkhaṇam etat ti na visaṃvādetabbam
translated: The teacher should not deceive him by saying, ‘That is not the meditation subject; it is a wrong sign,’

original: ‘Sādhu, sappurisa, pubbe tayā vaṇṇakasiṇe parikammaṃ katapubbaṃ bhavissati. Etadeva🔽kammaṭṭhānaṃ tuyhaṃ sappāyaṃ. Vaṇṇavaseneva sajjhāyaṃ karohī’ti vattabbo. Tenapi
analyzed: sādhu sappurisa pubbe tayā vaṇṇa kasiṇe parikammam kata pubbam bhavissati etat eva  kammaṭṭhānam tuyham sappāyam vaṇṇa vasena iva sajjhāyam karohi iti vattabbaḥ tena api
translated: but should say, ‘Good man, you must have done the preliminary work on the colour kasiṇa before;

original: vaṇṇavaseneva sajjhāyo kātabbo.
analyzed: vaṇṇa vasena iva sajjhāyaḥ kātabbaḥ
translated: this meditation subject is suitable for you; do the meditation subject by the method of the colour.’ He should do the meditation subject by the method of the colour.

original: So evaṃ karonto ajjhattaṃ nīlakaṃ pītakaṃ lohitakaṃ odātakanti cattāri vaṇṇakasiṇāni🔽labhati. Kathaṃ? Tassa hi kesalomapittesu ceva akkhīnañca kāḷakaṭṭhāne vaṇṇaṃ ‘nīlaṃ
analyzed: saḥ evam karontaḥ ajjhattam nīlakam pītakam lohitakam odātakam ti cattāri vaṇṇa kasiṇāni  labhati katham tassa hi kesa loma pittesu ca iva akkhīnam ca kāḷaka ṭṭhāne vaṇṇam nīlam
translated: As he does so, he acquires the four colour kasiṇas, blue, yellow, red and white.

original: nīla’nti manasikarontassa catukkapañcakajjhānāni uppajjanti; jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā🔽vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Medasmiṃ pana akkhīnañca pītakaṭṭhāne
analyzed: nīlanti manasikarontassa catukka pañcaka jhānāni uppajjanti jhānam pādakam katvā  vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti medasmin pana akkhīnam ca pītakaṭṭhāne
translated: How? When he brings to mind the colour in the head hairs, body hairs, teeth and nails, in the bile, phlegm, pus and blood, and in the black part of the eyes, and he does so as ‘blue, blue,’ the fourfold and fivefold jhānas arise in him. After that, making the jhāna his basis, he applies his attention to insight, and he reaches Arahantship.

original: vaṇṇaṃ ‘pītakaṃ pītaka’nti manasikarontassa catukkapañcakajjhānāni uppajjanti; jhānaṃ🔽pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Maṃsalohitesu pana akkhīnañca🔽rattaṭṭhāne vaṇṇaṃ ‘lohitakaṃ lohitaka’nti manasikarontassa catukkapañcakajjhānāni
analyzed: vaṇṇam pītakam pītakam ti manasikarontassa catukka pañcaka jjhānāni uppajjanti jhānam  pādakam katvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti maṃsa lohitesu pana akkhīnam ca  ratta ṭṭhāne vaṇṇam lohitakam lohitakam ti manasikarontassa catukka pañcaka jjhānāni
translated: When he brings to mind the colour in the flesh, in the liver, in the kidney, in the heart, in the spleen, in the lungs, in the bowels, in the mesentery, in the gorge, in the dung, and in the yellow part of the eyes, and he does so as ‘yellow, yellow,’ the fourfold and fivefold jhānas arise in him. After that, making the jhāna his basis, he applies his attention to insight, and he reaches Arahantship.

original: uppajjanti; jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Nakhadantacammaaṭṭhīsu
analyzed: uppajjanti jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti nakha danta camma aṭṭhīsu
translated: When he brings to mind the colour in the blood, in the bile, in the brain, in the urine, and in the red part of the eyes, and he does so as ‘red, red,’ the fourfold and fivefold jhānas arise in him. After that, making the jhāna his basis, he applies his attention to insight, and he reaches Arahantship.🔽When he brings to mind the colour in the bones, in the marrow, in the skin, in the flesh, in the veins, in the sinews, and in the nails, and he does so as ‘white, white,’ the fourfold and fivefold jhānas arise in him.

original: pana akkhīnañca paṇḍaraṭṭhāne vaṇṇaṃ ‘odātaṃ odāta’nti manasikarontassa catukkapañcakajjhānāni🔽uppajjanti, jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Idaṃ
analyzed: pana akkhīnam ca paṇḍara ṭṭhāne vaṇṇam odātam odātanti manasikarontassa catukka pañcaka jjhānāni  uppajjanti jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti idam
translated: But if he brings to mind the colour in the white parts of the eyes, the fourfold or fivefold jhāna arises in him in the way already described.

original: vaṇṇavasena abhiniviṭṭhassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā nigamanaṃ.
analyzed: vaṇṇa vasena abhiniviṭṭhassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā nigamanam
translated: And by developing insight based on that jhāna he reaches Arahantship. This is the working out in detail of the case of a bhikkhu who is devoted to the colour aspect.

original: Aparassa koṭṭhāsavasena sajjhāyaṃ karontassa paṭikūlato upaṭṭhāti. Athānena ovādācariyassa
analyzed: aparassa koṭṭhāsa vasena sajjhāyam karontassa paṭikūlataḥ upaṭṭhāti atha anena ovāda ācariyassa
translated: But if, while he is doing his recitation in this way by parts, what appears is only foulness, then he should tell his recitation teacher.

original: ācikkhitabbaṃ. Ācariyena ‘kammaṭṭhānaṃ viya akammaṭṭhānaṃ, vilakkhaṇaṃ eta’nti na
analyzed: ācikkhitabbam ācariyena kammaṭṭhānam viya akammaṭṭhānam vilakkhaṇam etat ti na
translated: The teacher should not deceive him by saying, “The meditation subject is not good,” or “The characteristics are not clear.”

original: visaṃvādetabbaṃ. ‘Sādhu, sappurisa, pubbe tayā paṭikūlamanasikāre yogo kato bhavissati.
analyzed: visaṃvādetabbam sādhu sappurisa pubbe tayā paṭikūla manasikāre yogaḥ kataḥ bhavissati
translated: He should say, “Good man, obviously you have already done the preliminary work of making your mind malleable.

original: Etadeva kammaṭṭhānaṃ tuyhaṃ sappāyaṃ. Paṭikūlavaseneva sajjhāyaṃ karohī’ti vattabbo.
analyzed: etat eva kammaṭṭhānam tuyham sappāyam paṭikūla vasena iva sajjhāyam karohi iti vattabbo
translated: This meditation subject is suitable for you. Do your recitation in terms of foulness only.”

original: Tenapi paṭikūlavasena sajjhāyo kātabbo. Tassa kesā nāma ‘ajaññā duggandhā jegucchā
analyzed: tena api paṭikūla vasena sajjhāyaḥ kātabbo tassa kesā nāma ajaññā duggandhā jegucchā
translated: And he should do his recitation in terms of foulness. For the hair of the head is called “not-knowing” and “stinking,” and it is repulsive.

original: paṭikūlā’ti evaṃ paṭikūlavasena sajjhāyaṃ karontassa paṭikūlārammaṇe paṭhamajjhānaṃ
analyzed: paṭikūlā ati evam paṭikūla vasena sajjhāyam karontassa paṭikūla ārammaṇe paṭhama jhānam
translated: When he does the meditation subject thus as “repulsive” in the sense of “unlovely”, the first jhāna arises in him in the “unlovely” as object.

original: nibbattati. So jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Idaṃ
analyzed: nibbattati so jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti idam
translated: Having made that jhāna the basis for insight, he reaches Arahantship.

original: paṭikūlavasena abhiniviṭṭhassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā nigamanaṃ.
analyzed: paṭikūla vasena abhiniviṭṭhassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā nigamanam
translated: This is the conclusion of the bhikkhu devoted to the meditation subject of the “unlovely” as far as Arahantship.

original: Aparassa koṭṭhāsavasena sajjhāyaṃ karontassa dhātuto upaṭṭhāti. Dhātuto upaṭṭhahantaṃ
analyzed: aparassa koṭṭhāsa vasena sajjhāyam karontassa dhātutaḥ upaṭṭhāti dhātutaḥ upaṭṭhahantam
translated: When another does the meditation subject thus as “elements”, it appears as elements to him.

original: kīdisaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhātīti? Kesā tāva vammikamatthake jātakunthatiṇakāni viya hutvā🔽upaṭṭhahanti. Lomā purāṇagāmaṭṭhāne jātadabbatiṇakāni viya. Nakhā daṇḍakesu ṭhapitamadhukaphalaṭṭhikosakā🔽viya. Dantā mattikāpiṇḍe pavesetvā ṭhapitaalābubījāni viya. Taco vīṇāpabbake pariyonaddhaallagocammaṃ
analyzed: kīdisam hutvā upaṭṭhāti iti kesā tāva vammika matthake jāta kuntha tiṇakāni viya hutvā  upaṭṭhahanti lomā purāṇa gāma ṭṭhāne jāta dabba tiṇakāni viya nakhāḥ daṇḍakesu ṭhapita madhuka phala ṭṭhi kosakā  viya dantāḥ mattikā piṇḍe pavesetvā ṭhapita alābu bījāni viya tacaḥ vīṇā pabbake pariyonaddha allago cammam
translated: How does it appear as elements?

original: viya, maṃsaṃ bhittiyaṃ anulittamattikā viya. Nhāru dabbasambhārabaddhavallī viya.
analyzed: viya maṃsam bhittiyam anulitta mattikā viya nhāru dabba sambhāra baddha vallī viya
translated: The head hairs appear as the earth element, the body hairs as grass and sticks, the nails as pebbles and stones, the teeth as gravel, the skin as the clay covering, the flesh as the water element, the sinews as mosses and liverworts, the bones as the earth element, the heart as the water element, the kidneys as the fire element, the liver as the earth element, the midriff as the air element, the spleen as the earth element, the lungs as the earth element, the bowels as the water element, the entrails as the earth element, the gorge as the fire element, the dung as the earth element.🔽The head hairs are like the kuntha grass and tiṇa grass growing on an ant-hill,🔽the body hairs like the grass and sticks growing in an old temple, the nails like the husks of madhuka fruits stuck on to a stick,🔽the teeth like the grains of sand in an ant-hill, the skin like the clay covering the ant-hill, the flesh like the water element, the sinews like the creepers,

original: Aṭṭhi ussāpetvā ṭhapitabhittidabbasambhāro viya. Aṭṭhimiñjaṃ mahāveḷumhi pakkhittaseditavettaggaṃ🔽viya. Vakkaṃ, hadayaṃ, yakanaṃ, kilomakaṃ, pihakaṃ, papphāsanti ime cha koṭṭhāsā🔽sūnakāragharaṃ viya hutvā upaṭṭhahanti. Dvattiṃsahatthaṃ antaṃ lohitadoṇiyaṃ saṃvellitvā🔽ṭhapitagharasappo viya. Antaguṇaṃ pādapuñchanake sibbitarajjukā viya. Udariyaṃ parissāvane🔽sithilabandhataṇḍulaṃ viya. Karīsaṃ veṇupabbe pakkhittapaṇḍumattikā viya. Matthaluṅgaṃ
analyzed: ussāpetvā ṭhapita bhitti dabba sambhāraḥ viya aṭṭhimiñjam mahā veḷumhi pakkhitta sedita vettaggam  viya vakkam hadayam yakanam kilomakam pihakam papphāsanti ime cha koṭṭhāsā  sūnakāra gharam viya hutvā upaṭṭhahanti dvattiṃsa hattham antam lohita doṇiyam saṃvellitvā  ṭhapita ghara sappaḥ viya anta guṇam pāda puñchanake sibbita rajjukā viya udariyam parissāvane  sithila bandha taṇḍulam viya karīsam veṇu pabbe pakkhitta paṇḍu mattikā viya mattha luṅgam
translated: The marrow is like a plaster ornament on a wall made by putting up a framework of sticks and plastering it over. The bone-marrow is like a bamboo tube thrust into a big bamboo.

original: omadditvā ṭhapitā cattāro taṇḍulapiṭṭhapiṇḍā viya. Dvādasavidhā āpodhātu paṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: ṭhapitā cattāro taṇḍula piṭṭha piṇḍāḥ viya dvādasavidhāḥ āpodhātu paṭipāṭiyā
translated: The six parts, namely, the liver, the heart, the kidneys, the lungs, the spleen, and the intestines, are like a slaughter-house. The twelve-fathom long bowel is like a snake thirty-six feet long laid out straight. The mesentery is like the rope binding a corpse. The abdomen is like a bag full of grease. The excrement is like the clay in a cesspit. The brain is like four lumps of cooked rice placed in a skull and left there to rot.

original: ṭhapitesu dvādasasu udakasarāvakesu pūritaudakaṃ viya hutvā upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: ṭhapitesu dvādasasu udaka sarāvakesu pūrita odakam viya hutvā upaṭṭhāti
translated: The twelvefold water element is like twelve pots of water placed in a row.

original: Athānena ovādācariyassa ācikkhitabbaṃ. Ācariyena ‘kammaṭṭhānaṃ viya akammaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: atha anena ovāda ācariyassa ācikkhitabbam ācariyena kammaṭṭhānam viya akammaṭṭhānam
translated: Then he should tell the teacher what he has seen. The teacher should say, “That is not the meditation subject;

original: vilakkhaṇaṃ eta’nti na visaṃvādetabbaṃ. ‘Sādhu, sappurisa, pubbe tayā dhātumanasikāre🔽yogo kato bhavissati. Etadeva kammaṭṭhānaṃ tuyhaṃ sappāyaṃ. Dhātuvaseneva sajjhāyaṃ
analyzed: vilakkhaṇam etat ti na visaṃvādetabbam sādhu sappurisa pubbe tayā dhātu manasikāre  yogo kataḥ bhavissati etat eva kammaṭṭhānam tuyham sappāyam dhātu vasena iva sajjhāyam
translated: He should not be disappointed, thinking, “This is not the way it is described.” He should be told, “It is good that you have already done the preliminary work on the elements. This meditation subject is suitable for you. Do the meditation subject in the way of elements.”

original: karohī’ti vattabbo. Tenapi dhātuvasena sajjhāyo kātabbo.
analyzed: karohi iti vattabbo tena api dhātu vasena sajjhāyaḥ kātabbo
translated: He should do the meditation subject in the way of elements.

original: Tatridaṃ manasikāramukheneva sajjhāyavidhānaṃ – idha bhikkhu ‘kesā sīsaṃ pariyonaddhitvā🔽ṭhitacamme jātā. Te na jānanti ‘mayaṃ sīsaṃ pariyonaddhitvā ṭhitacamme jātā’ti; sīsaṃ
analyzed: tatra idam manasikāra mukhena iva sajjhāya vidhānam idha bhikkhu kesā sīsam pariyonaddhitvā  ṭhita camme jātā te na jānanti mayam sīsam pariyonaddhitvā ṭhita camme jātā ati sīsam
translated: Here is the way of doing the meditation subject by way of attention to repulsiveness: Here a bhikkhu considers head hairs as follows: “Head hairs are not a single, compact piece of head hairs, but head hairs are multiple, with pores of the body originating separately, each pore of the body being one thing and another pore of the body being another thing.

original: pariyonaddhitvā ṭhitacammampi na jānāti ‘kesā mayi jātā’ti; acetanā ete abyākatā🔽suññā thaddhā patthinnā pathavīdhātu esā’ti manasikaroti. ‘Lomā sarīraṃ pariyonahanacamme
analyzed: pariyonaddhitvā ṭhita cammam pi na jānāti kesāḥ mayi jātāḥ ati acetanāḥ ete abyākatā  suññā thaddhā patthinnā pathavī dhātu esā ati manasikaroti lomā sarīram pariyonahana camme
translated: They do not know ‘We are on the head hairs,’ nor do the head hairs know ‘They are on us.’ These are just elements, that is, head hairs are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element, without thought, morally indeterminate, without consciousness, without intention, inert, and prone to destruction. They are not a living being, not a person, not a woman, not a man, not an animal, not a spirit, not a god, not a human being. They are simply an element that is a collection of conjoined and accumulated43 material dhammas called ‘head hairs.’ ”🔽He considers body hairs as follows: “Body hairs are not a single, compact piece of body hairs, but body hairs are multiple, with pores of the body originating separately, each pore of the body being one thing and another pore of the body being another thing.

original: jātā. Te na jānanti ‘mayaṃ sarīraṃ pariyonahanacamme jātā’ti. Sarīraṃ pariyonahanacammampi
analyzed: jātā te na jānanti mayam sarīram pariyonahana camme jātā ati sarīram pariyonahana cammam pi
translated: They do not know ‘We are on the body hairs,’ nor do the body hairs know ‘They are on us.’ These are just elements, that is, body hairs are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element, without thought, morally indeterminate, without consciousness, without intention, inert, and prone to destruction. They are not a living being, not a person, not a woman, not a man, not an animal, not a spirit, not a god, not a human being. They are simply an element that is a collection of conjoined and accumulated material dhammas called ‘body hairs.’ ”

original: na jānāti ‘lomā mayi jātā’ti etepi acetanā. Nakhā aṅgulīnaṃ aggesu jātā. Te na jānanti
analyzed: na jānāti lomā mayi jātā ati ete api acetanāḥ nakhāḥ aṅgulīnam aggesu jātā te na jānanti
translated: He does not know, ‘Hair has grown on me.’ These are also insentient.🔽The nails are on the tips of the fingers and toes. They do not know,

original: ‘mayaṃ aṅgulīnaṃ aggesu jātā’ti. Aṅgulīnaṃ aggānipi na jānanti ‘nakhā amhesu jātā’ti.
analyzed: mayam aṅgulīnam aggesu jātā ati aṅgulīnam aggāni api na jānanti nakhāḥ amhesu jātā ati
translated: ‘We are on the tips of fingers and toes.’ And the tips of the fingers and toes do not know, ‘Nails are on us.’

original: Etepi acetanā. Dantā hanukaṭṭhike jātā. Te na jānanti ‘mayaṃ hanukaṭṭhike jātā’ti.🔽Hanukaṭṭhikampi na jānāti ‘dantā mayi jātā’ti. Etepi acetanā. Taco na jānāti ‘sarīraṃ
analyzed: ete api acetanāḥ dantāḥ hanu kaṭṭhike jātā te na jānanti mayam hanu kaṭṭhike jātā ati  hanu kaṭṭhikam pi na jānāti dantāḥ mayi jātāḥ ati ete pi acetanā tacaḥ na jānāti sarīram
translated: These are also insentient. The teeth are in the jawbones. They do not know, ‘We are in jawbones.’🔽And the jawbones do not know, ‘Teeth are in us.’ These are also insentient. The skin does not know, ‘The body is covered by me.’

original: mayā pariyonaddha’nti. Sarīrampi na jānāti ‘ahaṃ tacena pariyonaddha’nti. Ayampi🔽acetano. Maṃsaṃ na jānāti ‘mayā sarīraṃ anulitta’nti. Sarīrampi na jānāti ‘ahaṃ maṃsena
analyzed: mayā pariyonaddhanti sarīram pi na jānāti aham tacena pariyonaddhanti ayam pi  acetanaḥ maṃsam na jānāti mayā sarīram sarīram anulittanti sarīram pi na jānāti aham maṃsena
translated: And the body does not know, ‘I am covered by skin.’ This is also🔽insentient. The flesh does not know, ‘I spread over the body.’ And the body does not know, ‘I am spread over with flesh.’ This is also

original: anulitta’nti. Idampi acetanaṃ. Nhāru na jānāti ‘ahaṃ aṭṭhipuñjaṃ ābandhitvā ṭhita’nti.
analyzed: idam pi acetanam nhāru na jānāti aham aṭṭhi puñjam ābandhitvā ṭhitanti
translated: insentient. The sinews do not know, ‘Having bound together the bones, we stand.’

original: Aṭṭhipuñjopi na jānāti ‘nhārujālenāhaṃ ābaddho’ti. Idampi acetanaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhipuñjaḥ api na jānāti nhāru jālena aham ābaddhaḥ iti idam api acetanam
translated: And the bones do not know, ‘I am bound together by a network of sinews.’ This is also insentient.

original: Sīsaṭṭhi na jānāti ‘ahaṃ gīvaṭṭhike patiṭṭhita’nti. Gīvaṭṭhikampi na jānāti ‘mayi
analyzed: na jānāti aham gīvaṭṭhike patiṭṭhitanti gīvaṭṭhikam pi na jānāti mayi
translated: The head-bone does not know, ‘I rest on the neck-bone.’🔽Nor does the neck-bone know, ‘A head-bone rests on me.’🔽The neck-bone does not know, ‘I rest on the backbone.’

original: sīsaṭṭhikaṃ patiṭṭhita’nti. Gīvaṭṭhi na jānāti ‘ahaṃ piṭṭhikaṇṭake ṭhita’nti. Piṭṭhikaṇṭaṭṭhikopi
analyzed: sīsa ṭṭhikam patiṭṭhitanti na jānāti aham piṭṭhi kaṇṭake ṭhitanti piṭṭhi kaṇṭa ṭṭhikaḥ api
translated: Nor does the backbone know, ‘A neck-bone rests on me.’🔽The backbone does not know, ‘I rest on the hip-bone.’🔽Nor does the hip-bone know, ‘A backbone rests on me.’🔽The hip-bone does not know, ‘I rest on the thigh-bone.’🔽Nor does the thigh-bone know, ‘A hip-bone rests on me.’🔽The thigh-bone does not know, ‘I rest on the shin-bone.’🔽Nor does the shin-bone know, ‘A thigh-bone rests on me.’

original: kaṭiṭṭhikaṃ ūruṭṭhikaṃ jaṅghaṭṭhikaṃ gopphakaṭṭhikaṃ na jānāti ‘ahaṃ paṇhikaṭṭhike🔽patiṭṭhita’nti. Paṇhikaṭṭhikampi na jānāti ‘ahaṃ gopphakaṭṭhikaṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhitanti…pe…
analyzed: kaṭi ṭṭhikam ūru ṭṭhikam jaṅgha ṭṭhikam gopphaka ṭṭhikam na jānāti aham paṇhika ṭṭhike  patiṭṭhitanti paṇhika ṭṭhikam pi na jānāti aham gopphaka ṭṭhikam ukkhipitvā ṭhitanti pe
translated: The shin-bone does not know, ‘I rest on the ankle-bone.’🔽Nor does the ankle-bone know, ‘A shin-bone rests on me.’🔽The ankle-bone does not know, ‘I rest on the heel-bone.’🔽Nor does the heel-bone know, ‘An ankle-bone rests on me.’🔽The neck-bone does not know, ‘I rest on the head-bone.’

original: gīvaṭṭhikaṃ na jānāti ‘ahaṃ sīsaṭṭhikaṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhita’nti.
analyzed: gīva ṭṭhikam na jānāti aham sīsa ṭṭhikam ukkhipitvā ṭhitanti
translated: Nor does the head-bone know, ‘A neck-bone rests on me.’

original: Paṭipāṭiyā aṭṭhīni ṭhitāni koṭiyā,
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā aṭṭhīni ṭhitāni koṭiyā
translated: The bones are arranged in order, each on its own place,

original: Anekasandhiyamito na kehici;
analyzed: aneka sandhi yamitaḥ na kehici
translated: In this body with many joints, but not by any person.

original: Baddho nahārūhi jarāya codito,
analyzed: baddhaḥ jarāya coditaḥ
translated: Bound by sinews, urged on by aging,

original: Acetano kaṭṭhakaliṅgarūpamo.
analyzed: acetanaḥ kaṭṭha kaliṅga rūpamaḥ
translated: It is insentient, like a block of wood.🔽‘This bone-marrow is insentient, indeterminate, and empty;

original: ‘Idampi acetanaṃ. Aṭṭhimiñjaṃ; vakkaṃ…pe… matthaluṅgaṃ acetanaṃ abyākataṃ suññaṃ
analyzed: idam api acetanam aṭṭhimiñjam vakkaṃpe matthaluṅgam acetanam abyākatam suññam
translated: The kidney is insentient, indeterminate, and empty;

original: thaddhaṃ patthinnaṃ pathavīdhātū’ti manasikaroti. ‘Pittaṃ semhaṃ…pe… muttaṃ acetanaṃ
analyzed: thaddham patthinnam pathavī dhātu uti manasikaroti pittam acetanam
translated: He gives attention to the water element in the way already described.

original: abyākataṃ suññaṃ yūsagataṃ āpodhātū’ti manasikaroti.
analyzed: a byākatam suññam yūsa gatam āpodhātu iti manasikaroti
translated: He gives attention to bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, spittle, snot, oil of the joints, and urine in the way already described.

original: Ime dve mahābhūte pariggaṇhantassa udare ussadā tejodhātu pākaṭā hoti, nāsāya ussadā
analyzed: ime dve mahābhūte pariggaṇhantassa udare ussadā tejodhātu pākaṭā hoti nāsāya ussadā
translated: As he gives attention to these two great primaries, the fire element in his stomach, which is known as the “up-going element,” becomes evident to him, and the air element in his nostrils becomes evident to him as the “down- going element.”

original: vāyodhātu pākaṭā hoti. Ime cattāro mahābhūte pariggaṇhantassa upādārūpaṃ pākaṭaṃ🔽hoti. Mahābhūtaṃ nāma upādārūpena paricchinnaṃ, upādārūpaṃ mahābhūtena. Yathā ātapo
analyzed: vāyodhātu pākaṭā hoti ime cattāraḥ mahābhūte pariggaṇhantassa upādā rūpam pākaṭam  mahābhūtam nāma upādā rūpena paricchinnam upādā rūpam mahābhūtena yathā
translated: As he gives attention to these four great primaries, derived matter becomes evident to him.

original: nāma chāyāya paricchinno, chāyā ātapena; evameva mahābhūtaṃ upādārūpena paricchinnaṃ,
analyzed: nāma chāyāya ātapena evam eva mahābhūtam upādā rūpena paricchinnam
translated: The great primaries are delimited by derived matter, and derived matter is delimited by the great primaries. Just as heat is delimited by shade and shade by heat, so too the great primaries are delimited by derived matter and derived matter by the great primaries.

original: upādārūpaṃ mahābhūtena. Athassa evaṃ “cattāri mahābhūtāni tevīsati upādārūpāni rūpakkhandho”ti🔽rūpakkhandhaṃ pariggaṇhantassa āyatanadvāravasena arūpino khandhā pākaṭā honti. Iti
analyzed: upādā rūpam mahābhūtena athassa evam cattāri mahābhūtāni tevīsati upādā rūpāni rūpa kkhandhaḥ ti 🔽rūpa kkhandham pariggaṇhantassa āyatana dvāra vasena arūpino khandhāḥ pākaṭāḥ honti iti
translated: Then, when he has discerned the mental body thus, “The four great primaries and the twenty-four kinds of derived matter are the materiality aggregate,”🔽the immaterial aggregates become evident to him through the six bases of the immaterial aggregates.

original: rūpārūpapariggaho pañcakkhandhā honti, pañcakkhandhā dvādasāyatanāni honti, dvādasāyatanāni
analyzed: rūpa arūpa pariggahaḥ pañca khandhāḥ honti pañca khandhāḥ dvādasa āyatanāni honti dvādasa āyatanāni
translated: The description of mentality-materiality is the five aggregates, the five aggregates are the twelve bases, the twelve bases are the eighteen elements.

original: aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo hontīti khandhāyatanadhātuvasena yamakatālakandhaṃ phālento viya🔽dve koṭṭhāse katvā nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapeti.
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa dhātuyaḥ honti iti khandha āyatana dhātu vasena yamaka tāla kandham  dve koṭṭhāse katvā nāma rūpam vavatthapeti
translated: Thus he defines mentality-materiality by dividing it into the three aggregates, the twelve bases, and the eighteen elements, as if breaking a single creeper into three parts.🔽“This mentality-materiality is not born without cause, nor without conditions.

original: So “idaṃ nāmarūpaṃ na ahetu na appaccayā nibbattaṃ, sahetu sappaccayā nibbattaṃ.
analyzed: so idam nāma rūpam na ahetu na appaccayā nibbattam sa hetu sa paccayā nibbattam
translated: It is born with a cause, with conditions.🔽What is its cause? What are its conditions?”

original: Ko panassa hetu? Ko pana paccayo”ti upaparikkhanto “avijjāpaccayā taṇhāpaccayā kammapaccayā
analyzed: kaḥ pana assa hetu kaḥ pana paccayaḥ ti upaparikkhantaḥ avijjā paccayā taṇhā paccayā kamma paccayā
translated: As he examines this question, he comes to understand the condition in this way: “With ignorance as condition there are formations; with formations as condition, consciousness; with consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality;🔽with mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold base; with the sixfold base as condition, contact; with contact as condition, feeling; with feeling as condition, craving; with craving as condition, clinging; with clinging as condition, existence; with existence as condition, birth; with birth as condition, ageing, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair come to be.🔽Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.”🔽He defines the condition in the past thus.

original: āhārapaccayā cā”ti tassa paccayaṃ vavatthapetvā “atītepi paccayā ceva paccayasamuppannadhammā
analyzed: āhāra paccayā ca ati tassa paccayam vavatthapetvā atīte pi paccayā ca iva paccaya samuppanna dhammā
translated: “In the future too, with ignorance as condition there will be formations; with formations as condition, consciousness; with consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality;

original: ca anāgatepi etarahipi paccayā ceva paccayasamuppannadhammā ca, tato uddhaṃ satto
analyzed: ca anāgate pi etarahi pi paccayā ca iva paccaya samuppanna dhammā ca tatas uddham satto
translated: with mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold base; with the sixfold base as condition, contact; with contact as condition, feeling; with feeling as condition, craving; with craving as condition, clinging; with clinging as condition, existence; with existence as condition, birth; with birth as condition, ageing, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair come to be.🔽Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.”

original: vā puggalo vā natthi, suddhasaṅkhārapuñjo evā”ti – evaṃ tīsu addhāsu kaṅkhaṃ vitarati.
analyzed: vā puggalaḥ vā na atthi suddha saṅkhāra puñjaḥ eva ati evam tīsu addhāsu kaṅkham vitarati
translated: He defines the condition in the future thus.

original: Ayaṃ pana vipassanāsaṅkhārasallakkhaṇā ñātapariññā nāma.
analyzed: ayam pana vipassanā saṅkhāra sallakkhaṇā ñātapariññā nāma
translated: This insight is called full-understanding as the known in the discerning of formations.

original: Evaṃ saṅkhāre sallakkhetvā ṭhitassa pana bhikkhussa dasabalassa sāsane mūlaṃ otiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: evam saṅkhāre sallakkhetvā ṭhitassa pana bhikkhussa dasabalassa sāsane mūlam otiṇṇam
translated: When a bhikkhu has stood thus discerning formations, he has taken a firm root in the Master’s Dispensation,

original: nāma hoti, patiṭṭhā laddhā nāma, cūḷasotāpanno nāma hoti niyatagatiko. Tathārūpaṃ
analyzed: nāma hoti patiṭṭhā laddhā nāma cūḷasotāpanno nāma hoti niyata gatikaḥ tathārūpam
translated: he has gained a footing. He is called a “stream-enterer” with a fixed destiny headed for enlightenment.

original: pana utusappāyaṃ, puggalasappāyaṃ, bhojanasappāyaṃ, dhammasavaṇasappāyaṃ labhitvā🔽ekāsane ekapallaṅkavaragato tīṇi lakkhaṇāni āropetvā vipassanāpaṭipāṭiyā saṅkhāre
analyzed: pana utu sappāyam puggala sappāyam bhojana sappāyam dhamma savaṇa sappāyam labhitvā  eka āsane eka pallaṅka vara gataḥ tīṇi lakkhaṇāni āropetvā vipassanā paṭipāṭiyā saṅkhāre
translated: But when he has obtained a suitable climate, suitable person, suitable food, and suitable Dhamma-hearing,

original: sammasanto arahattaṃ gaṇhātīti idaṃ dhātuvasena abhiniviṭṭhassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā nigamanaṃ.
analyzed: sammasantaḥ arahattam gaṇhāti iti idam dhātu vasena abhiniviṭṭhassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā nigamanam
translated: and he has taken up the three characteristics in a single seat, and he is comprehending formations in the order in which they arise, he reaches Arahantship. This is the conclusion for a bhikkhu who has penetrated to the signless in the mode of elements, up to Arahantship.

original: Yassa pana neva vaṇṇato upaṭṭhāti na paṭikūlato na suññato tena ‘na me upaṭṭhātī’ti
analyzed: yassa pana na iva vaṇṇataḥ upaṭṭhāti na paṭikūlataḥ na suññataḥ tena na me upaṭṭhāti iti
translated: But if it does not appear to him in colour or in the repulsive or in the signless way,

original: na kammaṭṭhānaṃ vissajjetvā nisīditabbaṃ, koṭṭhāsamanasikāreyeva pana yogo kātabbo.
analyzed: na kammaṭṭhānam vissajjetvā nisīditabbam koṭṭhāsa manasikāreya iva pana yogaḥ kātabbaḥ
translated: then he should not give up the meditation subject, thinking “It does not appear to me.” He should sit down in the same place and apply himself to the perception of sectors.

original: Porāṇakattherā kira ‘koṭṭhāsamanasikārova pamāṇa’nti āhaṃsu. Iccassa punappunaṃ koṭṭhāsavasena🔽sajjhāyaṃ karontassa koṭṭhāsā paguṇā honti. Kadā pana paguṇā nāma hontīti? Yadā ‘kesā’ti🔽āvajjitamatte manasikāro gantvā ‘matthaluṅga’nti antimakoṭṭhāse patiṭṭhāti, ‘matthaluṅga’nti
analyzed: porāṇaka ttherā kira koṭṭhāsa manasikāraḥ uva pamāṇam ti āhaṃsu iccassa punappunam koṭṭhāsa vasena  sajjhāyam karontassa koṭṭhāsā paguṇāḥ honti kadā pana paguṇāḥ nāma honti iti yadā  āvajjita matte manasikāraḥ gantvā mattha luṅganti antima koṭṭhāse patiṭṭhāti mattha luṅganti
translated: As he does his recollecting again and again by means of the parts,🔽the parts become familiar to him. But when are they familiar?🔽When attention goes to the “hairs of the head” as soon as he adverts, and it remains established on the last part, that is, on “the upper part of the head consisting of bone,”

original: āvajjitamatte manasikāro āgantvā ‘kesā’ti ādikoṭṭhāse patiṭṭhāti.
analyzed: āvajjita matte manasikāraḥ āgantvā kesāti ādi koṭṭhāse patiṭṭhāti
translated: and when attention goes to the first part, that is, to the “hairs of the head,” as soon as he adverts, and it remains established on the “hairs of the body,”

original: Athassa yathā nāma cakkhumato purisassa dvattiṃsavaṇṇānaṃ pupphānaṃ ekasuttaganthitaṃ🔽mālaṃ olokentassa paṭipāṭiyā vā pana nikhāte dvattiṃsavatipāde paṭikkamitvā olokentassa
analyzed: athassa yathā nāma cakkhumataḥ purisassa dvattiṃsa vaṇṇānaṃ pupphānaṃ eka sutta ganthitaṃ  mālam olokentassa paṭipāṭiyā vā pana nikhāte dvattiṃsavati pāde paṭikkamitvā olokentassa
translated: then they are familiar to him. Just as when a man with good sight looks at a garland of flowers with thirty-two flowers, each of two colours, strung on a single thread,🔽or as when he looks at a set of thirty-two rafters of a building each of two colours, placed end to end,

original: paṭipāṭiyāva dvattiṃsavaṇṇāni pupphāni vatipādā vā pākaṭā honti, evameva dvattiṃsa
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā ava dvattiṃsa vaṇṇāni pupphāni vati pādāḥ vā pākaṭāḥ honti evam eva dvattiṃsa
translated: then the thirty-two flowers or rafters become evident to him in their individual colours and positions,

original: koṭṭhāsā upaṭṭhahanti, vicarantā tiracchānagatāpi manussāpi sattāti na upaṭṭhahanti,
analyzed: koṭṭhāsāḥ upaṭṭhahanti vicarantā tiracchāna gatā api manussā api sattā ati na upaṭṭhahanti
translated: so too, the thirty-two parts become evident to him in their individual forms. But animals and human beings do not become evident as “living beings.”

original: koṭṭhāsāti upaṭṭhahanti, khādanīyabhojanīyaṃ koṭṭhāsantare pakkhippamānaṃ viya hoti.🔽Koṭṭhāsānaṃ paguṇakālato paṭṭhāya tīsu mukhesu ekena mukhena vimuccissati. Kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: koṭṭhāsā ti upaṭṭhahanti khādanīya bhojanīyam koṭṭhāsa antare pakkhippamānam viya hoti  koṭṭhāsānam paguṇa kālataḥ paṭṭhāya tīsu mukhesu ekena mukhena vimuccissati kammaṭṭhānam
translated: The stomach is the receptacle for the food. The food is like what is put into the middle of a basket.🔽From the time of the stomach’s proficiency onwards, the meditation subject appears in one of the three ways, either through colour, or through the sign of in-breath and out-breath, or through voidness.

original: vaṇṇato vā paṭikūlato vā suññato vā upaṭṭhāti. Yathā nāma pūve pacitukāmā itthī madditvā🔽ṭhapitapiṭṭhato yaṃ yaṃ icchati taṃ taṃ pacati, yathā vā pana same bhūmippadese ṭhapitaṃ🔽udakapūraṃ kumbhaṃ yato yato āvijjhanti tato tatova udakaṃ nikkhamati; evameva koṭṭhāsānaṃ🔽paguṇakālato paṭṭhāya tīsu mukhesu ekena mukhena vimuccissati. Ākaṅkhamānassa vaṇṇato,
analyzed: vaṇṇataḥ vā paṭikūlataḥ vā suññataḥ vā upaṭṭhāti yathā nāma pūve pacitu kāmā itthī madditvā  ṭhapita piṭṭhataḥ yam yam icchati tam tam pacati yathā vā pana same bhūmi ppadese ṭhapitam  udaka pūram kumbham yatas yatas āvijjhanti tatas tatas va udakam nikkhamati evam eva koṭṭhāsānam  paguṇa kālataḥ paṭṭhāya tīsu mukhesu ekena mukhena vimuccissati ākaṅkhamānassa vaṇṇataḥ
translated: Just as a woman who wants to bake flat cakes, after kneading the dough,🔽bakes whatever kind she wants, or just as water that is poured on to an even site from a container with a hole in it comes out through the hole, so too, from the time of the stomach’s proficiency onwards, the meditation subject appears in one of the three ways, either through colour, or through the sign of in-breath and out-breath, or through voidness.

original: ākaṅkhamānassa paṭikūlato, ākaṅkhamānassa suññato kammaṭṭhānaṃ upaṭṭhahissatiyeva.
analyzed: ākaṅkhamānassa paṭikūlataḥ ākaṅkhamānassa suññataḥ kammaṭṭhānam upaṭṭhahissati yeva
translated: If he wants it to appear through colour, it appears through colour. If he wants it to appear through the sign of in-breath and out-breath, it appears through the sign of in-breath and out-breath. If he wants it to appear through voidness, it appears through voidness.

original: Ayaṃ ettako uggahasandhi nāma. Imasmiṃ uggahasandhismiṃ ṭhatvā arahattaṃ pattā bhikkhu
analyzed: ayam ettakaḥ uggaha sandhi nāma imasmin uggaha sandhismin ṭhatvā arahattam pattā bhikkhu

translated: and it is beyond counting.

analyzed: yassa pana uggaha sandhismim kammaṭṭhānam na upaṭṭhāti tena kammaṭṭhānam uggahetvā
translated: If the meditation subject does not become clear to one who is learning it in this way, then, after learning it,

analyzed: sace yattha ācariyaḥ vasati saḥ āvāsaḥ sappāyaḥ hoti icca etam kusalam no ce sappāya ṭṭhāne  vasitabbam vasantena aṭṭhārasa vihāra dose vajjetvā pañcaṅga samannāgate senāsane
translated: if the place where he is staying is a suitable one, well and good; if not, then he should

original: vasitabbaṃ, sayampi pañcaṅgasamannāgatena bhavitabbaṃ. Tato pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantena
analyzed: vasitabbam sayam pi pañcaṅga samannāgatena bhavitabbam tatas pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantena
translated: stay in a suitable place. And while he is staying there, he should avoid the eighteen grounds for laziness, and he should stay in a lodging suitable for a bhikkhu who is an arahant, that is to say, possessing five factors.

original: rattiṭṭhānaṃ vā divāṭṭhānaṃ vā pavisitvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikātabbaṃ.
analyzed: ratti ṭṭhānam vā divāṭṭhānam vā pavisitvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikātabbam
translated: After that, in the evening he should sit in the place for sitting, or walking up and down, or walking slowly, and he should give attention to the meditation subject.

original: Kathaṃ? Ādito tāva heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva anupubbato manasikātabbaṃ, na ekantarikā.
analyzed: katham āditas tāva heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva anupubbataḥ manasikātabbam na ekantarikā
translated: How? At first he should give his attention to it in the order of the enumeration, not in the reverse order.🔽For one who gives his attention to it in the order of the enumeration is like a man who mounts a flight of steps, and he has no difficulty in doing so.

original: Anupubbato manasikaronto hi dvattiṃsapadaṃ nisseṇiṃ padapaṭipāṭiyā akkamanto pāsādaṃ🔽āruyha pāsādānisaṃsaṃ anubhavanakapuriso viya ‘kesā lomā’ti paṭipāṭiyā kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: anupubbataḥ manasikarontaḥ hi dvattiṃsa padam nisseṇim pada paṭipāṭiyā akkamantaḥ pāsādam 🔽āruyha pāsāda ānisaṃsam anubhavanaka purisaḥ viya kesā loma ati paṭipāṭiyā kammaṭṭhānam
translated: But one who gives his attention to it in the reverse order is like a man who tries to mount a flight of steps in the reverse order;

original: manasikaronto kammaṭṭhānato ca na parihāyati, pāsādānisaṃsasadise ca nava lokuttaradhamme🔽anubhavati. Anupubbato manasikarontenāpi ca nātisīghato nātisaṇikato manasikātabbaṃ.
analyzed: manasikaronto kammaṭṭhānato ca na parihāyati pāsāda ānisaṃsa sadise ca nava lokuttara dhamme  anubhavati anupubbataḥ manasikarontena api ca na ati sīghataḥ na ati saṇikataḥ manasikātabbam
translated: and he does not fall away from the meditation subject. He experiences the nine earth kasiṇas as a reward for the meditation subject.🔽And he who develops it in this way should not give his attention to it too rapidly or too slowly.

original: Atisīghato manasikarontassa hi kiñcāpi kammaṭṭhānaṃ paguṇaṃ hoti, avibhūtaṃ pana
analyzed: ati sīghataḥ manasikarontassa hi kiñcā api kammaṭṭhānam paguṇam hoti avibhūtam pana
translated: For if he gives his attention to it too rapidly, the meditation subject becomes confused though familiar.

original: hoti. Tattha opammaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva.
analyzed: hoti tattha opammam heṭṭhā vuttam eva
translated: The simile here should be understood as that of the man who tried to frighten the king with a snake .

original: Atisaṇikato manasikarontassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariyosānaṃ na gacchati, antarāva osakkitabbaṃ
analyzed: ati saṇikataḥ manasikarontassa kammaṭṭhānam pariyosānam na gacchati antarāva osakkitabbam
translated: And if he gives his attention to it too slowly, the meditation subject does not reach culmination, but there is a risk of his losing interest in it.

original: hoti. Yathā hi puriso tiyojanaṃ maggaṃ sāyaṃ kacchaṃ bandhitvā paṭipanno nikkhantaṭṭhānato🔽paṭṭhāya sītalacchāyaṃ disvā vissamati, ramaṇīyaṃ vālikatalaṃ disvā piṭṭhiṃ pasāreti,
analyzed: hoti yathā hi purisaḥ ti yojanam maggam sāyam kaccham bandhitvā paṭipannaḥ nikkhanta ṭṭhānataḥ  paṭṭhāya sītala chāyam disvā vissamati ramaṇīyam vālika talam disvā piṭṭhim pasāreti
translated: Suppose a man set out on a three-league journey, walking by day only and sleeping at night;🔽he would see a cool lake on the way and bathe and cool himself, or he would see a delightful stretch of woodland and rest there awhile enjoying the beauty of the trees, the flowers, the birds, and so on,

original: vanapokkharaṇiṃ disvā pānīyaṃ pivati nhāyati, pabbataṃ disvā āruyha pabbatarāmaṇeyyakaṃ
analyzed: vana pokkharaṇim disvā pānīyam pivati nhāyati pabbatam disvā āruyha pabbata rāmaṇeyyakam
translated: or he would see a mountain and climb it, enjoying the view from the top, and then go on;

original: passati, taṃ antarāyeva sīho vā byaggho vā dīpi vā hanati, corā vā pana viluppanti
analyzed: passati tam antarāya iva sīhaḥ vā byagghaḥ vā dīpi vā hanati corāḥ vā pana viluppanti
translated: If he sees it, then if a lion, a tiger, a leopard kills it on the way, or thieves carry it off,🔽

original: ceva hananti ca; evameva atisaṇikaṃ manasikarontassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariyosānaṃ na
analyzed: ca iva hananti ca evam eva ati saṇikam manasikarontassa kammaṭṭhānam pariyosānam na
translated: If he does, a lion or a tiger or a leopard kills him on the way, or thieves plunder him and kill him. So too, if he gives too much attention, the meditation subject does not reach its conclusion;

original: gacchati, antarāva osakkitabbaṃ hoti.🔽Tasmā nātisīghaṃ nātisaṇikaṃ ekadivasaṃ tiṃsavāre manasikātabbaṃ; pātova dasa vāre,
analyzed: gacchati antarāva osakkitabbam hoti  tasmā na ati sīgham na ati saṇikam eka divasam tiṃsa vāre manasikātabbam pātova dasa vāre
translated: it fails on the way.

original: majjhanhike dasavāre, sāyanhe dasa vāre sajjhāyo kātabbo, no kātuṃ na vaṭṭati. Yathā🔽hi pātova uṭṭhāya mukhaṃ no dhovituṃ na vaṭṭati, khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ no khādituṃ
analyzed: majjhanhike dasa vāre sāyanhe dasa vāre sajjhāyaḥ kātabbaḥ no kātum na vaṭṭati yathā  hi uṭṭhāya mukham no dhovitum na vaṭṭati khādanīyam bhojanīyam no khāditum
translated: So he should give attention neither too quickly nor too slowly. He should do it in thirty parts in one day, ten times in the morning, ten times in the middle of the day, and ten times in the evening.

original: no bhuñjituṃ na vaṭṭati; etaṃ pana vaṭṭeyya; idameva ekantena no kātuṃ na vaṭṭati;
analyzed: no bhuñjitum na vaṭṭati etam pana vaṭṭeyya idam eva ekantena no kātum na vaṭṭati
translated: It is not improper to do it more than that, but it is improper to do it less. For just as it is improper for one who has got up at dawn not to wash his face, and improper for one who has started to eat not to finish the meal, so too, this is improper to do less than that.

original: karonto mahantaṃ atthaṃ gahetvā tiṭṭhati. Yathā hi ekassa purisassa tīṇi khettāni;
analyzed: karontaḥ mahantam attham gahetvā tiṭṭhati yathā hi ekassa purisassa tīṇi khettāni
translated: But it is proper to do more. For one who does so is one who takes great pains. Suppose a man has three fields,

original: ekaṃ khettaṃ aṭṭhakumbhaṃ deti, ekaṃ soḷasa, ekaṃ dvattiṃsa; tena tīṇipi khettāni
analyzed: ekam khettam aṭṭha kumbham deti ekam soḷasa ekam dvattiṃsa tena tīṇi pi khettāni

original: paṭijaggituṃ asakkontena dve chaḍḍetvā ekaṃ dvattiṃsakumbhadāyakameva paṭijaggitabbaṃ;
analyzed: paṭijaggitum a sakkontena dve chaḍḍetvā ekam dvattiṃsa kumbha dāyakam eva paṭijaggitabbam
translated: If he cannot look after all three, he should abandon two and look after the one given for thirty-two pots.

original: tattheva kasanavapananiddānādīni kātabbāni; tadevassa itaresu dvīsu uṭṭhānakadāyaṃ
analyzed: tattha iva kasana vapana niddāna ādīni kātabbāni tat evassa itaresu dvīsu uṭṭhānaka dāyam
translated: He should plough and sow it and so on right there. That will serve as his labour for the other two.

original: dassati; evameva sesaṃ mukhadhovanādikammaṃ chaḍḍetvāpi ettheva kammaṃ kātabbaṃ,
analyzed: dassati evam eva sesam mukha dhovana ādi kammam chaḍḍetvā api ettha iva kammam kātabbam
translated: In the same way, he should abandon the other work such as washing the face and do the work right there.

original: no kātuṃ na vaṭṭati. Karonto mahantaṃ atthaṃ gaṇhitvā tiṭṭhatīti ettāvatā majjhimā
analyzed: no kātum na vaṭṭati karontaḥ mahantam attham gaṇhitvā tiṭṭhati iti ettāvatā majjhimā
translated: It is not that he should not do it. He should do it, but he should do it after considering the greater benefit.

original: paṭipadā nāma kathitā.🔽Evaṃ paṭipannenāpi vikkhepo paṭibāhitabbo. Kammaṭṭhānañhi vissajjetvā citte bahiddhā
analyzed: paṭipadā nāma kathitā  evam paṭipannena api vikkhepaḥ paṭibāhitabbaḥ kammaṭṭhānam hi vissajjetvā citte bahiddhā

original: vikkhepaṃ gacchante kammaṭṭhānato parihāyati, vaṭṭabhayaṃ samatikkamituṃ na sakkoti.
analyzed: vikkhepam gacchante kammaṭṭhānataḥ parihāyati vaṭṭa bhayam samatikkamitum na sakkoti
translated: Even one who practices in this way should ward off distraction. For when the meditation subject is neglected and the mind goes out in distraction, he falls away from the meditation subject and is unable to surmount the fear of the round.

analyzed: kumbhīla makara gāha rakkhasa samuṭṭhitāya gambhīra giri kandarāya upari eka padikam

translated: he falls away from his meditation subject and is unable to cross over the fear of the round.

analyzed: viya saṃsāraḥ tassa kumbhīla ādīhi daṭṭha kālaḥ viya vaṭṭamūlakāni mahā dukkhāni eka padika daṇḍaka setu

original: āpannakālo viya imassa bhikkhuno kammaṭṭhānaṃ vissajjetvā bahiddhā vikkhittacittassa🔽kammaṭṭhānato parihāyitvā vaṭṭabhayaṃ samatikkamituṃ asamatthabhāvo veditabbo.

analyzed: manasikātabbam kesāḥ loma iti paṇṇattim vissajjetvā paṭikūlam paṭikūlanti sati

analyzed: ṭhapetabbā paṭhamaṃ yeva pana paṭikūlato na upaṭṭhāti yāva na upaṭṭhāti tāva paṇṇatti

original: na vissajjetabbā. Yadā upaṭṭhāti tadā paṇṇattiṃ vissajjetvā ‘paṭikūla’nti manasikātabbaṃ.
analyzed: na vissajjetabbā yadā upaṭṭhāti tadā paṇṇattim vissajjetvā paṭikūlanti manasikātabbam
translated: When it does appear, the description should be given and attention should be given to it as “repulsive.”

original: Karontena ca heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva pañcahākārehi paṭikūlato manasikātabbā. Tacapañcakasmiñhi
analyzed: karontena ca heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva pañcahā akārehi paṭikūlataḥ manasikātabbā taca pañcakasmin hi
translated: And when he does so, he should give his attention to it as repulsive in the five ways already described .

original: vaṇṇasaṇṭhānagandhāsayokāsavaseneva pañcavidhampi pāṭikūlyaṃ labbhati. Sesesupi yaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna gandha asayokāsa vasena iva pañcavidham pi pāṭikūlyam labbhati sesesu pi yam
translated: For repulsiveness in five ways is found in the five parts beginning with the head hairs, namely, by colour, shape, odour, habitat, and location.

original: yaṃ labbhati, tassa tassa vasena manasikāro pavattetabbo.
analyzed: yam labbhati tassa tassa vasena manasikāraḥ pavattetabbaḥ
translated: And attention should be given to it in each case according to whichever is applicable.

original: Tattha kesādayo pañca koṭṭhāsā subhanimittaṃ rāgaṭṭhāniyaṃ iṭṭhārammaṇanti saṅkhaṃ
analyzed: tattha kesa ādayo pañca koṭṭhāsā subha nimittam rāga ṭṭhāniyam iṭṭha ārammaṇanti saṅkham
translated: Herein, the five parts beginning with the head hairs are called “a sign of the beautiful” , “a basis for lust,” and “a desirable object” .

original: gatā. Ye keci rajjanakasattā nāma, sabbe te imesu pañcasu koṭṭhāsesu rajjanti. Ayaṃ
analyzed: gatāḥ ye keci rajjanakasattāḥ nāma sabbe te imesu pañcasu koṭṭhāsesu rajjanti ayam
translated: And all beings who are lustful are so in regard to these five parts.🔽But this bhikkhu reaches absorption in “repulsiveness” in the place where the multitude are lustful.

original: pana bhikkhu mahājanassa rajjanaṭṭhāne ‘paṭikūla’nti appanaṃ pāpeti. Tattha appanāppattito
analyzed: pana bhikkhu mahājanassa rajjana ṭṭhāne paṭikūlanti appanam pāpeti tattha appana appattito
translated: Herein,

original: paṭṭhāya parato akilamantova appanaṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya paratas a kilamantaḥ iva appanam pāpuṇāti
translated: and he reaches absorption without trouble.

original: Tatridaṃ opammaṃ – yathā hi cheko dhanuggaho rājānaṃ ārādhetvā satasahassuṭṭhānakaṃ🔽gāmavaraṃ labhitvā sannaddhapañcāvudho tattha gacchanto antarāmagge dvattiṃsa core
analyzed: tatra idam opammam yathā hi chekaḥ dhanuggahaḥ rājānam ārādhetvā sata sahassu ṭṭhānakam  gām avaram labhitvā sannaddha pañcāvudhaḥ tattha gacchantaḥ antara āmagge dvattiṃsa core
translated: Here is a simile. Suppose a clever archer first propitiated a king with a gift of a hundred thousand and then,🔽equipped with his five weapons, went to a place where there were thirty-two robbers,

original: disvā tesu pañcacorajeṭṭhake ghāteyya; tesaṃ ghātitakālato paṭṭhāya tesu dve ekamaggaṃ🔽paṭipajjamānā nāma na honti; evaṃsampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Dhanuggahassa rājānaṃ ārādhetvā
analyzed: disvā tesu pañca cora jeṭṭhake tesam ghātita kālato paṭṭhāya tesu dve eka maggaṃ  paṭipajjamānāḥ nāma na honti evaṃsampadam idam daṭṭhabbam dhanuggahassa rājānam ārādhetvā
translated: and after killing the five chief robbers, from the time of their killing onwards there were no longer two or three going along the same path,🔽so too, this bhikkhu should be regarded.

original: gāmavaraṃ laddhakālo viya hi imassa bhikkhuno ācariyasantike kammaṭṭhānaṃ uggahetvā
analyzed: gāma varam laddha kālaḥ viya hi imassa bhikkhuno ācariya santike kammaṭṭhānam uggahetvā
translated: For the time when the archer first propitiated the king and received the grant of a village is analogous to the time when this bhikkhu received the meditation subject from his teacher and went to live in the jungle.

original: ṭhitakālo; dvattiṃsa corā viya dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsā; pañca corajeṭṭhakā viya kesādayo
analyzed: ṭhita kālaḥ dvattiṃsa corāḥ dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsā pañca kesa ādayaḥ
translated: The thirty-two robbers are analogous to the thirty-two aspects. The five chief robbers are analogous to the head hairs, etc.,

original: pañca; corajeṭṭhakānaṃ ghātitakālo viya imassa bhikkhuno sabbasattānaṃ rajjanaṭṭhāne
analyzed: pañca cora jeṭṭhakānam ghātita kālaḥ viya imassa bhikkhuno sabba sattānam rajjana ṭṭhāne
translated: and the time of their killing is analogous to the time when this bhikkhu, in the place where beings are greedy, etc.,

original: tacapañcake ‘paṭikūla’nti appanāya pāpitakālo; sesacorānaṃ pāṇippahāreneva palāyitakālo
analyzed: taca pañcake paṭikūlanti appanāya pāpita kālo sesa corānam pāṇi pahārena iva palāyita kālo
translated: The time for attaining absorption in the case of the five-part version is when he has reached the repulsive in the skin and the rest are driven off by the mere touch of his hand, as it were.

original: viya sesakoṭṭhāsesu akilamantasseva appanāppatti veditabbā.
analyzed: viya sesa koṭṭhāsesu a kilamantassa iva appanā appatti veditabbā
translated: He should understand that absorption is reached without his tiring himself over the remaining parts.

original: Evaṃ paṇṇattiṃ samatikkamantena ca anupubbamuñcanato manasikāro pavattetabbo – kese🔽manasikarontena manasikaronteneva kesesu sāpekkhena hutvā lomesu sati pesetabbā.
analyzed: evam paṇṇattim samatikkamantena ca anupubba muñcanataḥ manasikāraḥ pavattetabbaḥ kese  manasikarontena manasikarontena iva kesesu sāpekkhena hutvā lomesu sati pesetabbā
translated: And he should bring about the occurrence of the sign in this way, surmounting the concept by means of the sign, and by means of surmounting the sign by means of the concept.🔽When he is giving his attention to head hairs, he should give his attention to them only as “hair,” without adding any such qualifying phrase as “repulsive” or “beautiful.”🔽He should give his attention to them only as “head hairs,” without adding any such phrase as “this is mine” or “this is another’s.”

original: Yāva lomā na upaṭṭhahanti tāva ‘kesā kesā’ti manasikātabbā. Yadā pana lomā upaṭṭhahanti🔽tadā kese vissajjetvā lomesu sati upaṭṭhapetabbā. Evaṃ nakhādīsupi manasikāro pavattetabbo.

translated: He should give his attention to them only as “in the head,” without adding any such phrase as “on the head” or “in the body.”🔽He should give his attention to them only as “in the place where the head is,” without adding any such phrase as “in the world” or “in a place.”🔽He should give his attention to them only as “in the place where the head is found,” without adding any such phrase as “in the world” or “in a place.”

analyzed: tatra idam opammam yathā hi jalūkā gacchamānā yāva puratas patiṭṭham na labhati tāva

original: pacchato naṅguṭṭhena gahitaṭṭhānaṃ na muñcati; yadā pana purato patiṭṭhaṃ labhati
analyzed: pacchatas naṅguṭṭhena gahita ṭṭhānam na muñcati yadā pana puratas labhati
translated: He should give his attention to them only as “in the place where the head is found,” without adding any such phrase as “in the world” or “in a place.”

original: tadā naṅguṭṭhaṃ ukkhipitvā mukhena gahitaṭṭhāne ṭhapeti; evameva kese manasikarontena🔽manasikaronteneva kesesu sāpekkhena hutvā lomesu sati pesetabbā. Yāva lomā na upaṭṭhahanti🔽tāva ‘kesā kesā’ti manasikātabbā. Yadā lomā upaṭṭhahanti tadā kese vissajjetvā lomesu
analyzed: tadā naṅguṭṭham ukkhipitvā mukhena gahita ṭṭhāne ṭhapeti evam eva kese manasikarontena  manasikarontena iva kesesu sāpekkhena hutvā lomesu sati pesetabbāḥ yāva lomā na upaṭṭhahanti  tāva kesā kesā ti manasikātabbā yadā lomā upaṭṭhahanti tadā kese vissajjetvā lomesu
translated: Then he raises the tuft and puts it back in the place where he has held it with his mouth. So too, when he is giving his attention to head hairs,🔽he should give his attention to them only as present in himself, not as belonging to another. original: sati upaṭṭhapetabbā. Evaṃ nakhādīsupi manasikāro pavattetabbo.🔽Evaṃ pavattentena appanā hotīti vuttamanasikārakosallaṃ sampādetabbaṃ. Kathaṃ?
