analyzed: sajjhāya sotā anusārena gantvā mattha luṅge patiṭṭhāti mattha luṅganti āvajjita matte
translated: He should give his attention to them by delimitation only as ‘Hairs of the head’ in the place where the hairs of the head are to be found.🔽He should give his attention to them by delimitation only as ‘Hairs

original: sajjhāyasotānusārena āgantvā kesesu patiṭṭhāti. Manasikarontassa manasikarontassa
analyzed: sajjhāya sota anusārena āgantvā kesesu patiṭṭhāti manasikarontassa manasikarontassa
translated: and it settles down on the hair. But when he gives his attention to it,

original: pana so so koṭṭhāso upaṭṭhāti. Sati samādhināpi tiṭṭhamānā pavattati. Tena yo yo🔽koṭṭhāso adhikataraṃ upaṭṭhāti tattha tattha dviguṇena yogaṃ katvā appanā pāpetabbā.
analyzed: pana so so koṭṭhāsaḥ upaṭṭhāti sati samādhinā api tiṭṭhamānā pavattati tena yaḥ yaḥ  koṭṭhāsaḥ adhikataram upaṭṭhāti tattha tattha dviguṇena yogam katvā appanā pāpetabbā
translated: the part that he gives his attention to becomes evident. And it goes on occurring as long as he does so with mindfulness and understanding. He should reach absorption by doing intensive development of whichever part becomes evident to him.

original: Evaṃ appanāya pāpitakālato paṭṭhāya sesakoṭṭhāsesu akilamanto appanaṃ pāpeti. Tattha
analyzed: evam appanāya pāpita kālato paṭṭhāya sesa koṭṭhāsesu a kilamantaḥ appanam pāpeti tattha
translated: After he has thus reached absorption, he can reach it again without trouble in any other part. Herein,

original: tālavanamakkaṭova opammaṃ.
analyzed: tālavana makkaṭa uvaḥ opammam
translated: the simile of the monkey in the palm grove is relevant.

original: Apicettha evampi yojanā veditabbā – dvattiṃsatālakasmiñhi tālavane makkaṭo paṭivasati.🔽Taṃ gahetukāmo luddo koṭiyaṃ ṭhitatālamūle ṭhatvā ukkuṭṭhimakāsi. Mānajātiko makkaṭo
analyzed: api ca ittha evam pi yojanā veditabbā dvattiṃsa tālakasmin hi tāla vane makkaṭaḥ paṭivasati  tam gahetu kāmaḥ luddaḥ koṭiyam ṭhita tāla mūle ṭhatvā ukkuṭṭhima kāsi māna jātikaḥ makkaṭaḥ
translated: And the construction here can also be understood in this way: A monkey lives in a palm grove with thirty-two palms.🔽A hunter who wants to catch it stands at the foot of the palm that the monkey is in, at the base of the lowest frond, and makes a hissing sound. The monkey, which is greedy for palm fruits, jumps out on to the next palm.

original: taṃ taṃ tālaṃ laṅghitvā pariyantatāle aṭṭhāsi. Luddo tatthapi gantvā ukkuṭṭhimakāsi.
analyzed: tam tam tālam laṅghitvā pariyanta tāle aṭṭhāsi luddo tattha api gantvā ukkuṭṭhi makāsi
translated: The hunter moves round to the front of that palm and makes the same sound. The monkey jumps to yet another palm.

original: Makkaṭo puna tatheva purimatāle patiṭṭhāsi. So aparāparaṃ anubandhiyamāno kilamanto
analyzed: makkaṭaḥ puna tathā iva purima tāle so apara aparam kilamanto
translated: The monkey again stood on the first branch as before.🔽The hunter followed him again and again. The monkey became tired.

original: tassa tasseva tālassa mūle ṭhatvā ukkuṭṭhukkuṭṭhikāle uṭṭhahitvā gacchanto gacchanto
analyzed: tassa tassa iva tālassa mūle ṭhatvā ukkuṭṭhukkuṭṭhi kāle uṭṭhahitvā gacchantaḥ gacchantaḥ
translated: He stood at the foot of the same palm tree, and when the time came for the sun to rise, he went on and on.

original: atikilamanto ekassa tālassa makuḷapaṇṇasūciṃ daḷhaṃ gahetvā dhanukoṭiyā vijjhitvā
analyzed: ati kilamantaḥ ekassa tālassa makuḷa paṇṇa sūcim daḷham gahetvā dhanu koṭiyā vijjhitvā
translated: He became very tired. He seized a leaf-needle of a palm fruit very firmly, and he shot it with the bow-string.

original: gaṇhantopi na palāyati.
analyzed: gaṇhantaḥ api na palāyati
translated: He did not run away even when he was caught.

original: Tattha dvattiṃsa tālā viya dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsā; makkaṭo viya cittaṃ; luddo viya yogāvacaro;🔽luddena tālamūle ṭhatvā ukkuṭṭhikāle mānajātikassa makkaṭassa palāyitvā pariyantakoṭiyaṃ🔽ṭhitakālo viya anamatagge saṃsāravaṭṭe ca nānārammaṇesu vaḍḍhitacittassa ‘kesā’ti
analyzed: tattha dvattiṃsa tālāḥ viya dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsāḥ makkaṭaḥ viya cittam luddaḥ viya yogāvacaro  luddena tāla mūle ṭhatvā ukkuṭṭhi kāle māna jātikassa makkaṭassa palāyitvā pariyanta koṭiyam  ṭhita kālaḥ viya anamatagge saṃsāra vaṭṭe ca nānā ārammaṇesu vaḍḍhita cittassa
translated: Herein, the thirty-two palm trees are like the thirty-two parts of the body; the monkey is like the mind; the hunter is like the meditator;🔽the time when the hunter stood at the foot of the palm tree and the monkey, being proud, ran away and stood at the end of the bow-string is like the time when the mind, which has grown in various objects in the round of rebirths without beginning,

original: āvajjitamatte sajjhāyasotānusārena gantvā matthaluṅge patiṭṭhānaṃ; pariyantakoṭiyaṃ
analyzed: āvajjita matte sajjhāya sota anusārena gantvā matthaluṅge patiṭṭhānam pariyantakoṭiyam
translated: has stood at the top of the head as soon as it has been brought to the hair by the power of the repetition and the hearing of the scriptures.

original: ṭhatvā ukkuṭṭhe orimakoṭiṃ āgamanakālo viya ‘matthaluṅga’nti āvajjitamatte sajjhāyasotānusārena
analyzed: ṭhatvā ukkuṭṭhe orima koṭim āgamana kālaḥ āvajjita matte sajjhāya sotā anusārena
translated: and the time when, after standing, he comes back to the starting point after walking up and down is like the time when, after adverting to the “top-knot” as “disgusting,”

original: gantvā kesesu patiṭṭhānaṃ; aparāparaṃ anubandhiyamānassa kilamantassa ukkuṭṭhukkuṭṭhiṭṭhāne
analyzed: gantvā kesesu patiṭṭhānam apara aparam anubandhiyamānassa kilamantassa ukkuṭṭha ukkuṭṭhi ṭhāne
translated: he goes by the repetition of the recitation text and comes to rest on the head hairs.

original: uṭṭhānakālo viya manasikarontassa manasikarontassa tasmiṃ tasmiṃ koṭṭhāse upaṭṭhahante🔽satiyā patiṭṭhāya patiṭṭhāya gamanaṃ; dhanukoṭiyā vijjhitvā gaṇhantassāpi apalāyanakālo
analyzed: uṭṭhāna kālaḥ viya manasikarontassa manasikarontassa tasmin tasmin koṭṭhāse upaṭṭhahante  satiyā patiṭṭhāya patiṭṭhāya gamanam dhanu koṭiyā vijjhitvā gaṇhantassa api a palāyana kālo
translated: The time when, after going on and on, he becomes tired and sits down on the starting point of the up and down walking is like the time when, after giving attention, the mindfulness that has been established in each part by giving attention🔽goes on to the next part.

original: viya yo koṭṭhāso adhikataraṃ upaṭṭhāti, tasmiṃ dviguṇaṃ manasikāraṃ katvā appanāya pāpanaṃ.
analyzed: viya yaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ adhikataram upaṭṭhāti tasmin dviguṇam manasikāram katvā appanāya pāpanam
translated: The time when, after taking the bow shot, he does not run away is like the time when, after giving attention to the part that is most evident, he gives it twice the attention and brings it to absorption.

original: Tattha appanāya pāpitakālato paṭṭhāya sesakoṭṭhāsesu akilamantova appanaṃ pāpessati.
analyzed: tattha appanāya pāpita kālato paṭṭhāya sesa koṭṭhāsesu a kilamantaḥ iva appanam pāpessati
translated: Herein, from the time when he brings it to absorption, he will bring it to absorption in the rest of the parts without tiring.

original: Tasmā ‘paṭikūlaṃ paṭikūla’nti punappunaṃ āvajjitabbaṃ samannāharitabbaṃ, takkāhataṃ
analyzed: tasmai paṭikūlam paṭikūlanti punappunam āvajjitabbam samannāharitabbam takka āhatam
translated: So he should advert again and again to “disgusting, disgusting,” and he should give attention to it and review it with insight.

original: vitakkāhataṃ kātabbaṃ. Evaṃ karontassa cattāro khandhā paṭikūlārammaṇā honti, appanaṃ🔽pāpuṇāti. Pubbabhāgacittāni parikammaupacārasaṅkhātāni savitakkasavicārānīti sabbaṃ🔽heṭṭhā vuttasadisameva. Ekaṃ pana koṭṭhāsaṃ manasikarontassa ekameva paṭhamajjhānaṃ
analyzed: vitakka āhatam kātabbam evam karontassa cattāro khandhāḥ paṭikūla ārammaṇāḥ honti appanam  pāpuṇāti pubbabhāga cittāni parikamma aupacāra saṅkhātāni sa vitakka sa vicārāni iti sabbam  heṭṭhā vutta sadisam eva ekam pana koṭṭhāsam manasikarontassa ekam eva paṭhamajjhānam
translated: He should do so with a sense of urgency. When he does so, the four aggregates are the object of his repugnance. He reaches absorption.🔽The preliminary-work consciousnesses and the access consciousnesses are called “with applied thought and sustained thought.” All the rest is as already explained.

original: nibbattati. Pāṭiyekkaṃ manasikarontassa dvattiṃsa paṭhamajjhānāni nibbattanti. Hatthe
analyzed: nibbattati pāṭiyekkam manasikarontassa dvattiṃsa paṭhamajjhānāni nibbattanti hatthe
translated: When he gives attention to one part, only one first jhāna arises. When he gives attention to each part, thirty-two first jhānas arise.

original: gahitapañhāvatthu pākatikameva.🔽So taṃ nimittanti so bhikkhu taṃ kammaṭṭhānanimittaṃ. Āsevatīti sevati bhajati. Bhāvetīti

analyzed: nimittataḥ lakkhaṇataḥ dhātutaḥ atha suññataḥ
translated: As to element, and also as to voidness,

original: Khandhādito ca viññeyyo, kesādīnaṃ vinicchayo.🔽Tattha ‘nimittato’ti dvattiṃsākāre saṭṭhisataṃ nimittāni, yesaṃ vasena yogāvacaro🔽dvattiṃsākāraṃ koṭṭhāsato pariggaṇhāti, seyyathidaṃ – kesassa vaṇṇanimittaṃ, saṇṭhānanimittaṃ,

original: dvattiṃsākāraṃ lakkhaṇato manasikaroti, seyyathidaṃ – kese thaddhattalakkhaṇaṃ, ābandhattalakkhaṇaṃ,

original: uṇhattalakkhaṇaṃ, vitthambhanalakkhaṇanti cattāri lakkhaṇāni honti. Lomādīsupi eseva nayo.

original: dhātuyo honti, yāsaṃ vasena yogāvacaro dvattiṃsākāraṃ dhātuto pariggaṇhāti, seyyathidaṃ🔽– kese kakkhaḷatā pathavīdhātu, ābandhanatā āpodhātu, uṇhatā tejodhātu, vitthambhanatā

translated: The meditator discerns the thirty-two aspects in the modes of these elements, that is to say:

original: vāyodhātūti catasso dhātuyo honti. Lomādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: catassaḥ dhātuyaḥ honti esa iva nayo
translated: in the head-hairs the hardness is the earth element, the cohesion is the water element, the heat is the fire element, and the distension is the air element. There are four elements. The same method applies in the case of the body-hairs, and so on.

original: ‘Suññato’ti dvattiṃsākāre channavuti suññatā honti, yāsaṃ vasena yogāvacaro dvattiṃsākāraṃ🔽suññato vipassati, seyyathidaṃ – kesā suññā attena vā attaniyena vā niccena vā dhuvena
analyzed: dvattiṃsa ākāre channavuti suññatāḥ honti yāsam vasena yogāvacaraḥ dvattiṃsa ākāram  suññataḥ vipassati sā iyyathidam kesā suññā attena vā attaniyena vā niccena vā dhuvena
translated: ‘In the modes of voidness’: in the thirty-two aspects there are ninety-six kinds of voidness by means of which the meditator contemplates the thirty-two aspects as void. They are as follows:🔽Head-hairs are void of a self or of the property of a self or of permanence or of lastingness or of eternalness or of non-subjectness to change.

original: vā sassatena vā avipariṇāmadhammena vāti. Kese tāva attasuññatā, attaniyasuññatā,
analyzed: vā vā a vipariṇāma dhammena vā ati kese tāva atta suñña tā atta niya suñña tā
translated: Head-hairs are void of a self, void of the property of a self,

original: niccabhāvasuññatāti tisso suññatā honti. Lomādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: nicca bhāva suññatā ti tissaḥ suññatāḥ honti loma ādīsu pi esa iva nayo
translated: The three kinds of emptiness are emptiness of permanence, emptiness of lastingness, and emptiness of eternalness. The same method applies to the head hairs and so on.

original: ‘Khandhādito’ti dvattiṃsākāre kesādīsu khandhādivasena pariggayhamānesu kesā kati

original: khandhā honti, kati āyatanāni, kati dhātuyo, kati saccāni, kati satipaṭṭhānānītiādinā🔽nayena pettha vinicchayo viññātabbo.🔽357. Evaṃ ajjhattādibhedato tividhena kāyānupassanaṃ vitthārato dassetvā idāni “kāyānupassī
analyzed: khandhāḥ honti kati āyatanāni kati dhātuyo kati saccāni kati sati paṭṭhānāni itiādinā  nayena pa ittha vinicchayaḥ viññātabbaḥ  evam ajjhatta ādi bhedataḥ tividhena kāya anupassanam vitthārataḥ dassetvā idāni kāya anupassī
translated: by asking questions such as these: How many aggregates, how many bases, how many elements, how many truths, how many foundations of mindfulness, etc., are the head hairs?

analyzed: bhāvanā phalam vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: and the abandoning of covetousness and grief is said to be the “fruit of development.”

original: Kāyānupassanāniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kāya anupassanā niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the description of the contemplation of the unattractive is finished.

original: Vedanānupassanāniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Contemplation of feelings

original: 363. Vedanānupassanāniddesepi heṭṭhā vuttasadisaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Sukhaṃ
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā niddese pi heṭṭhā vutta sadisam vutta nayena iva veditabbam sukham
translated: . In the description of the contemplation of feelings, what is stated should be understood in the way already stated. “Pleasant” . . .

original: vedanaṃ vedayamānotiādīsu pana sukhaṃ vedananti kāyikaṃ vā cetasikaṃ vā sukhaṃ vedanaṃ🔽vedayamāno ‘ahaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānātīti attho. Tattha kāmaṃ uttānaseyyakāpi
analyzed: vedanam vedayamānaḥ ti ādīsu pana sukham vedananti kāyikam vā cetasikam vā sukham vedananti  vedayamānaḥ aham sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti iti attho tattha kāmam uttānaseyyakā api
translated: As regards the words “he feels a pleasant feeling” and so on, the meaning is that he knows “I feel a pleasant bodily or mental feeling.”

original: dārakā thaññapivanādikāle sukhaṃ vedayamānā ‘sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmā’ti pajānanti,🔽na panetaṃ evarūpaṃ jānanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Evarūpañhi jānanaṃ sattūpaladdhiṃ nappajahati,
analyzed: dārakā thañña pivana ādi kāle sukham vedayamānā sukham vedanam vedayāma ati pajānanti  na pana etat evarūpam jānanam sandhāya vuttam evarūpam hi jānanam sattu upaladdhim na ppajahati
translated: Herein, of course, even infants at the breast know “I feel a pleasant feeling” when they are feeling a pleasant feeling by sucking milk and so on,

original: sattasaññaṃ na ugghāṭeti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā vā na hoti. Imassa
analyzed: satta saññam na ugghāṭeti kammaṭṭhānam vā sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā vā na hoti imassa
translated: but that is not the kind of knowing meant here. For that is not the kind of knowing that abandons the assumption of a being, that strips off the perception of a being, that is a meditation subject, that is the development of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: pana bhikkhuno jānanaṃ sattūpaladdhiṃ pajahati, sattasaññaṃ ugghāṭeti, kammaṭṭhānañceva
analyzed: pana bhikkhuno jānanam sattu upaladdhim pajahati satta saññam ugghāṭeti kammaṭṭhānam ca iva
translated: But this bhikkhu’s knowing abandons the assumption of a being, strips off the perception of a being, is a meditation subject, and is the development of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā ca hoti. ‘Idañhi ko vedayati, kassa vedanā, kiṃ kāraṇā vedanā’ti
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā ca hoti idam hi kaḥ vedayati kassa vedanā kim kāraṇā vedanā ati
translated: For this is said: “Who feels? Whose is this feeling? Why is there a feeling? ”

original: evaṃ sampajānavediyanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: evam sampajāna vediyanam sandhāya vuttam
translated: This is said with reference to clear knowing of feeling.

original: Tattha ko vedayatīti? Na koci satto vā puggalo vā vedayati. Kassa vedanāti? Na kassaci
analyzed: tattha kaḥ vedayati iti na koci sattaḥ vā puggalaḥ vā vedayati kassa vedanā ati na kassaci
translated: Herein, who feels? No being or person feels. Whose feeling is it? It is not anyone’s.

original: sattassa vā puggalassa vā vedanā. Kiṃ kāraṇā vedanāti? Vatthuārammaṇā ca panesā vedanā.
analyzed: sattassa vā puggalassa vā vedanā kim kāraṇā vedanā ati vatthu ārammaṇā ca pana isā vedanā
translated: Herein, who feels? No being or person feels. Whose feeling is it? It is not the feeling of any being or person. Why is it called feeling? It is called feeling because it is the experiencing of an object.

original: Tasmā esa evaṃ pajānāti – ‘taṃ taṃ sukhādīnaṃ vatthuṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā vedanāva vedayati;🔽taṃ pana vedanāpavattiṃ upādāya ‘ahaṃ vedayāmī’ti vohāramattaṃ hotī’ti. Evaṃ vatthuṃ
analyzed: tasmai esaḥ evam pajānāti tam tam sukha ādīnam vatthum ārammaṇam katvā vedanā ava vedayati  tam pana vedanā pavattim upādāya aham vedayāmi iti vohāra mattam hoti iti evam vatthum
translated: Therefore he understands thus: “It is only feeling that feels, making its object the various kinds of object such as the pleasant;🔽but because of the occurrence of feeling the mere expression ‘I feel’ comes into being.”🔽Thus, when he discerns that “It is only feeling that feels, making its object the various kinds of object,”

original: ārammaṇaṃ katvā vedanāva vedayatīti sallakkhento ‘esa sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti
analyzed: ārammaṇam katvā vedanā ava vedayati iti sallakkhentaḥ esa sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti
translated: he should be understood to discern “I am experiencing a pleasant feeling”

original: pajānātīti veditabbo, cittalapabbate aññataro thero viya.🔽Thero kira aphāsukakāle balavavedanāya nitthunanto aparāparaṃ parivattati. Tameko
analyzed: pajānāti iti veditabbaḥ cittalapabbate aññataro theraḥ viya  theraḥ kira a phāsuka kāle balava vedanāya nitthunantaḥ apara aparam parivattati tam ekaḥ
translated: like the elder at Cittalapabbata.🔽The elder, it seems, was rolling about here and there uttering cries of pain because of a painful and racking sickness. A certain novice said to him, “Venerable sir, which part of your body hurts?”

original: daharo āha – “kataraṃ vo, bhante, ṭhānaṃ rujatī”ti? “Āvuso, pāṭiyekkaṃ rujanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: daharaḥ āha kataram vaḥ bhante ṭhānam rujati iti āvuso pāṭiyekkam rujana ṭṭhānaṃ
translated: “Friend, there is no particular place where it does not hurt.

original: nāma natthi; vatthuṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā vedanāva vedayatī”ti. “Evaṃ jānanakālato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: nāma natthi vatthum ārammaṇam katvā vedanā ava vedayati iti evam jānana kālataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: “No, venerable sir, there is no such person. It is only feeling that feels, and that is the basis for the designation ‘person.’ ”🔽“Is it allowable to consent to it, venerable sir?”🔽“I consented, friend.”

original: adhivāsetuṃ vaṭṭati no, bhante”ti. “Adhivāsemi, āvuso”ti. “Adhivāsanā, bhante, seyyo”ti.
analyzed: adhivāsetum vaṭṭati no bhante iti adhivāsemi āvuso iti adhivāsanā bhante seyyā iti
translated: “It is better to consent, venerable sir.”

original: Thero adhivāsesi. Vāto yāva hadayā phālesi. Mañcake antāni rāsīkatāni ahesuṃ. Thero
analyzed: theraḥ adhivāsesi vātaḥ mañcake antāni rāsīkatāni ahesum theraḥ
translated: The elder consented, and the wind tore his bowels right up to his heart. His entrails were heaped up on the bed.🔽He showed them to the novice, saying, “Friend, is this enough consenting?”

original: daharassa dassesi – “vaṭṭatāvuso, ettakā adhivāsanā”ti? Daharo tuṇhī ahosi. Thero
analyzed: daharassa dassesi vaṭṭati avuso ettakā adhivāsanā ti daharaḥ tuṇhī ahosi theraḥ
translated: The novice was silent. The elder

original: vīriyasamādhiṃ yojetvā sahapaṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ pāpuṇitvā samasīsī hutvā parinibbāyi.🔽Yathā ca sukhaṃ, evaṃ dukkhaṃ…pe… nirāmisaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṃ
analyzed: vīriya samādhim yojetvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattam pāpuṇitvā samasīsī hutvā parinibbāyi  yathā ca sukham evam nirāmisam adukkham asukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ nirāmisam
translated: concentrated his mind with energy and attained Arahantship together with the discriminations. He attained Nibbāna with his head.🔽And so with the painful and with the neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.🔽“He understands thus: ‘I am experiencing a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling. ’”

original: adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti. Iti bhagavā rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathetvā
analyzed: adukkham asukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti iti bhagavā rūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathetvā
translated: Having thus taught the meditation subject consisting in the material septuple kammaṭṭhāna

original: arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathento vedanāvasena kathesi. Duvidhañhi kammaṭṭhānaṃ – rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: arūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathentaḥ vedanā vasena kathesi duvidham hi kammaṭṭhānam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam
translated: There are two kinds of meditation subject: the meditation subject consisting in materiality and the meditation subject consisting in the immaterial.

original: arūpakammaṭṭhānañca; rūpapariggaho arūpapariggahotipi etadeva vuccati. Tattha bhagavā🔽rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathento saṅkhepamanasikāravasena vā vitthāramanasikāravasena vā
analyzed: arūpa kammaṭṭhānam ca rūpa pariggaho arūpa pariggaho ti pi etat eva vuccati tattha bhagavā  rūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathento saṅkhepa manasikāra vasena vā vitthāra manasikāra vasena vā
translated: Herein, the Blessed One,🔽when teaching the meditation subject of the four elements, taught the defining of the four elements either as a brief meditation subject or as an extensive one.

original: catudhātuvavatthānaṃ kathesi. Tadubhayampi visuddhimagge sabbākārato dassitameva.
analyzed: catu dhātu vavatthānam kathesi tat ubhayam pi visuddhi magge sabba ākārataḥ dassitam eva
translated: And both of these have been given in full in the Path of Purity.

original: Arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ pana kathento yebhuyyena vedanāvasena kathesi. Tividho hi arūpakammaṭṭhāne🔽abhiniveso – phassavasena, vedanāvasena, cittavasenāti. Kathaṃ? Ekaccassa hi saṃkhittena
analyzed: arūpa kammaṭṭhānam pana kathentaḥ yebhuyyena vedanā vasena kathesi tividhaḥ hi arūpa kammaṭṭhāne  abhinivesaḥ phassa vasena vedanā vasena citta vasena ati katham ekaccassa hi saṃkhittena
translated: But when teaching the meditation subject of foulness, he taught it almost entirely as a brief meditation subject.🔽For in the case of foulness there are three ways of applying the mind: by way of contact, by way of feeling, and by way of the mind.

original: vā vitthārena vā pariggahite rūpakammaṭṭhāne tasmiṃ ārammaṇe cittacetasikānaṃ paṭhamābhinipāto
analyzed: vā vitthārena vā pariggahite rūpa kammaṭṭhāne tasmim ārammaṇe citta cetasikānam paṭhama abhinipātaḥ
translated: How? When someone has defined the meditation subject of the four elements either in brief or in detail,🔽the first impact of his consciousness on the object, which occurs as he adverts to the object, is called contact.

original: taṃ ārammaṇaṃ phusanto uppajjamāno phasso pākaṭo hoti. Ekaccassa taṃ ārammaṇaṃ anubhavantī
analyzed: tam ārammaṇam phusantaḥ uppajjamānaḥ phassaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti ekaccassa tam ārammaṇam anubhavantī
translated: The arising of the consciousness that experiences the object is called feeling.

original: uppajjamānā vedanā pākaṭā hoti. Ekaccassa taṃ ārammaṇaṃ pariggahetvā vijānantaṃ uppajjamānaṃ
analyzed: uppajjamānā vedanā pākaṭā hoti ekaccassa tam ārammaṇam pariggahetvā vijānantam uppajjamānam
translated: and the arising feeling is evident.

original: viññāṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti.
analyzed: viññāṇam pākaṭam hoti
translated: In another, consciousness is evident as he cognizes the object by apprehending it.

original: Tattha yassa phasso pākaṭo hoti, sopi ‘na kevalaṃ phassova uppajjati; tena saddhiṃ🔽tadevārammaṇaṃ anubhavamānā vedanāpi uppajjati, sañjānamānā saññāpi, cetayamānā cetanāpi,
analyzed: tattha yassa phassaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti saḥ api na kevalam phassaḥ uva uppajjati tena saddhim  tat eva ārammaṇam anubhavamānā vedanā api uppajjati sañjānamānā saññā api cetayamānā cetanā api
translated: Herein, he who has evident contact discerns only the five with contact, thinking: ‘Not only does contact arise, but with it

original: vijānanamānaṃ viññāṇampi uppajjatī’ti phassapañcamakeyeva pariggaṇhāti. Yassa vedanā
analyzed: vijānana mānam viññāṇam pi uppajjati iti phassa pañcamakeya iva pariggaṇhāti yassa vedanā
translated: there also arise feeling experiencing that object, perception perceiving it, volition volitionally forming it, and consciousness cognizing it.’

original: pākaṭā hoti, sopi ‘na kevalaṃ vedanāva uppajjati; tāya saddhiṃ tadevārammaṇaṃ phusamāno🔽phassopi uppajjati, sañjānanamānā saññāpi, cetayamānā cetanāpi, vijānanamānaṃ viññāṇampi
analyzed: pākaṭā hoti saḥ api na kevalam uppajjati tāya saddhim tat eva ārammaṇam phusamānaḥ  phassaḥ api uppajjati sañjānana mānā saññā api cetayamānā cetanā api vijānana mānam viññāṇam pi
translated: He who has evident feeling discerns only the five with contact, thinking: ‘Not only does feeling arise, but with it there also arise contact contacting that object,🔽perception perceiving it, volition volitionally forming it, and consciousness cognizing it.’

original: uppajjatī’ti phassapañcamakeyeva pariggaṇhāti. Yassa viññāṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti, sopi
analyzed: uppajjati iti pariggaṇhāti yassa viññāṇam pākaṭam hoti saḥ api
translated: He who has evident consciousness discerns only the five with contact, thinking:

original: ‘na kevalaṃ viññāṇameva uppajjati; tena saddhiṃ tadevārammaṇaṃ phusamāno phassopi
analyzed: na kevalam viññāṇam eva uppajjati tena saddhim tat eva ārammaṇam phusamānaḥ phassaḥ api
translated: ‘Not only consciousness arises, but also contact, which is the touching of the object together with that consciousness,

original: uppajjati, anubhavamānā vedanāpi, sañjānanamānā saññāpi, cetayamānā cetanāpi uppajjatī’ti
analyzed: uppajjati anubhavamānā vedanā api sañjānanamānā saññā api cetayamānā cetanā api uppajjati iti
translated: and feeling, which is the experiencing of that, and perception, which is the perceiving of it, and volition, which is the willing of it, all arise.’

original: phassapañcamakeyeva pariggaṇhāti.
analyzed: phassa pañcamakeya iva pariggaṇhāti
translated: He discerns only the five with contact as their fifth.

original: So ‘ime phassapañcamakā dhammā kiṃnissitā’ti upadhārento ‘vatthunissitā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: saḥ ime phassa pañcamakāḥ dhammāḥ kiṃnissitā ati upadhārentaḥ vatthu nissitā ati pajānāti
translated: When he investigates, ‘With what as their support do these five with contact as their fifth occur? ‘ he discerns, ‘They occur with a physical basis.’

original: Vatthu nāma karajakāyo; yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “idañca pana me viññāṇaṃ etthasitaṃ,🔽etthapaṭibaddha”nti. So atthato bhūtāni ceva upādārūpāni ca. Evamettha vatthu rūpaṃ,🔽phassapañcamakā nāmanti nāmarūpameva passati. Rūpañcettha rūpakkhandho, nāmaṃ cattāro
analyzed: vatthu nāma karaja kāyaḥ yam sandhāya vuttam idam ca pana me viññāṇam etthasitam  ettha paṭibaddhanti saḥ atthataḥ bhūtāni ca iva upādā rūpāni ca evam ettha vatthu rūpam  phassa pañcamakāḥ nāmanti nāma rūpam eva passati rūpam ca ittha rūpa kkhandho nāmam cattāro
translated: The physical basis is the body of the four great elements, in reference to which it is said, ‘And this my consciousness is dependent on and bound up with this body’ .🔽So the physical basis is the materiality aggregate, and the five with contact as their fifth are the four immaterial aggregates. Thus he sees only mentality-materiality.🔽The materiality here is the materiality aggregate, and the mentality is the four immaterial aggregates.

original: arūpino khandhāti pañcakkhandhamattaṃ hoti. Nāmarūpavinimuttā hi pañcakkhandhā pañcakkhandhavinimuttaṃ
analyzed: arūpino khandhā ti pañca kkhandha mattam hoti nāma rūpa vinimuttāḥ hi pañca kkhandhāḥ pañca kkhandha vinimuttam
translated: So there are only five aggregates. For apart from the five aggregates there are no mentality-materiality,

original: vā nāmarūpaṃ natthi.
analyzed: vā nāma rūpam na atthi
translated: and apart from mentality-materiality there are no five aggregates.

original: So ‘ime pañcakkhandhā kiṃhetukā’ti upaparikkhanto ‘avijjādihetukā’ti passati; tato
analyzed: saḥ ime pañca kkhandhā kiṃhetukā ati upaparikkhantaḥ avijjā ādi hetukā ati passati tatas
translated: He sees that the five aggregates have ignorance as their cause.

original: paccayo ceva paccayuppannañca idaṃ; añño satto vā puggalo vā natthi; suddhasaṅkhārapuñjamattamevāti🔽sappaccayanāmarūpavasenava tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā vipassanāpaṭipāṭiyā ‘aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: paccayaḥ ca iva paccaya uppannam ca idam aññaḥ satto vā puggalo vā natthi suddha saṅkhāra puñja mattam eva ati  sappaccaya nāma rūpa vasena iva ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā vipassanā paṭipāṭiyā aniccam dukkham
translated: Then he discerns that this is a condition and a conditionally-arisen state, and that there is no other being or person. It is just a heap of pure formations.

original: anattā’ti sammasanto vicarati. So ‘ajja ajjā’ti paṭivedhaṃ ākaṅkhamāno tathārūpe
analyzed: anattā ati sammasantaḥ vicarati saḥ ajja ajja iti paṭivedham ākaṅkhamānaḥ tathārūpe
translated: He thus applies the three characteristics by way of the mentality-materiality with its conditions, and he continues to discern “impermanent, painful, not-self.”

original: divase utusappāyaṃ, puggalasappāyaṃ, bhojanasappāyaṃ, dhammasavanasappāyaṃ vā labhitvā🔽ekapallaṅkena nisinnova vipassanaṃ matthakaṃ pāpetvā arahatte patiṭṭhāti. Evaṃ imesaṃ
analyzed: divase utu sappāyam puggala sappāyam bhojana sappāyam dhamma savana sappāyam vā labhitvā  eka pallaṅkena nisinnaḥ uva vipassanam matthakam pāpetvā arahatte patiṭṭhāti evam imesam
translated: He who wishes to attain penetration today or tomorrow obtains the requisites of climate, etc.,

original: tiṇṇampi janānaṃ yāva arahattā kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tiṇṇam pi janānam yāva arahattā kammaṭṭhānam kathitam hoti
translated: and sitting in one session he brings insight to its culmination and reaches Arahantship. Thus the meditation subject of these three men is explained up to Arahantship.

original: Idha pana bhagavā arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathento vedanāvasena kathesi. Phassavasena vā
analyzed: idha pana bhagavā arūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathentaḥ vedanā vasena kathesi phassa vasena vā
translated: But here the Blessed One, in teaching the immaterial meditation subject, taught it by way of feeling.

original: hi viññāṇavasena vā kathiyamānaṃ na pākaṭaṃ hoti, andhakāraṃ viya khāyati. Vedanāvasena
analyzed: hi viññāṇa vasena vā kathiyamānam na pākaṭam hoti andhakāram viya khāyati vedanā vasena
translated: For when it is described in terms of consciousness, it is not evident, it appears as if in darkness. But when it is described in terms of feeling, it is evident.🔽And why? Because the arising of feeling is evident. For the arising of pleasant and painful feeling

original: pana pākaṭaṃ hoti. Kasmā? Vedanānaṃ uppattipākaṭatāya. Sukhadukkhavedanānañhi uppatti🔽pākaṭā. Yadā sukhaṃ uppajjati, sakalasarīraṃ khobhentaṃ maddantaṃ pharamānaṃ abhisandayamānaṃ🔽satadhotasappiṃ khādāpayantaṃ viya, satapākatelaṃ makkhāpayamānaṃ viya, udakaghaṭasahassena
analyzed: pana pākaṭam hoti kasmā vedanānam uppatti pākaṭa tāya sukha dukkha vedanānam hi uppatti  pākaṭā yadā sukham uppajjati sakala sarīram khobhentam maddantam pharamānam abhisandayamānam  satadhā uta sappim khādāpayantam viya sata pāka telam makkhāpayamānam viya udaka ghaṭa sahassena
translated: is evident. When pleasure arises, it arises as if it were shaking, agitating, and thrilling the whole body, as if it were pouring in, as if it were filling the whole body,

original: pariḷāhaṃ nibbāpayamānaṃ viya, ‘aho sukhaṃ! Aho sukhanti’! Vācaṃ nicchārayamānameva
analyzed: pariḷāham nibbāpayamānam viya aho sukham aho sukhanti vācam nicchārayamānam eva
translated: as if it were making the whole body drunk, as if it were making the whole body float, as if it were making the whole body cool, as if it were making the whole body fresh, as if it were making the whole body young, as if it were making the whole body frisky, as if it were making the whole body happy, as if it were making the whole body dance, as if it were making the whole body roll about drunk, as if it were making the whole body float away, as if it were making the whole body expand, as if it were making the whole body grow, as if it were making the whole body float with joy, as if it were making the whole body float with happiness, as if it were making the whole body float with delight, as if it were making the whole body float with satisfaction, as if it were making the whole body float with rapture, as if it were making the whole body float with bliss, as if it were making the whole body float with pleasure.

original: uppajjati. Yadā dukkhaṃ uppajjati, sakalasarīraṃ khobhentaṃ maddantaṃ pharamānaṃ🔽abhisandayamānaṃ tattaphālaṃ pavesentaṃ viya, vilīnatambalohena āsiñcantaṃ viya,
analyzed: uppajjati yadā dukkham uppajjati sakala sarīram khobhentam maddantam pharamānam  abhisandayamānam tatta phālam pavesentam viya vilīna tamba lohena āsiñcantam viya
translated: And when pain arises, it arises as if it were burning, scorching, and consuming the whole body, as if it were pouring in, as if it were filling the whole body,

analyzed: dukkhanti vippalāpayamānam eva uppajjati iti sukha dukkha vedanānam uppatti pākaṭā hoti  adukkham asukhā pana duddīpanā andhakārā avibhūtā sā sukha dukkhānam apagame sāta asāta paṭikkhepa vasena

analyzed: majjhatta ākāra bhūtā adukkham asukhā vedanā ati nayataḥ gaṇhantassa pākaṭā hoti yathā

analyzed: itas oruḷhaḥ majjhe piṭṭhi pāsāṇe iminā padesena gataḥ bhavissati iti nayataḥ jānāti  evam āruḷha ṭṭhāne padam viya hi sukhāya vedanāya uppatti pākaṭā hoti oruḷha ṭṭhāne

original: padaṃ viya dukkhāya vedanāya uppatti pākaṭā hoti. ‘Ito āruḷho, ito oruḷho, majjhe
analyzed: padam viya dukkhāya vedanāya uppatti pākaṭā hoti itas āruḷhaḥ itas oruḷhaḥ majjhe

original: evaṃ gato’ti nayato gahaṇaṃ viya sukhadukkhānaṃ apagame sātāsātapaṭikkhepavasena
analyzed: evam gataḥ ti nayataḥ gahaṇam viya sukha dukkhānam apagame sāta asāta paṭikkhepa vasena

analyzed: evam bhagavā paṭhamam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathetvā pacchā arūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathento

translated: and he showed the formless meditation subject by turning it into feeling.

original: vedanāvasena vinivattetvā dassesi.
analyzed: vedanā vasena vinivattetvā dassesi
translated: And just as he did so in the various instances, so too in this analysis of the foundations of mindfulness he first expounded the meditation subject of foulness and afterwards showed the formless meditation subject by turning it into feeling.

original: Tattha sukhaṃ vedanantiādīsu ayaṃ aparopi pajānanapariyāyo – sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmīti🔽pajānātīti sukhavedanākkhaṇe dukkhāya vedanāya abhāvato sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno🔽‘sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. Tena yā pubbe bhūtapubbā dukkhā vedanā, tassā
analyzed: tattha sukham vedanam ti ādīsu ayam aparaḥ api pajānana pariyāyaḥ sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti  pajānāti iti sukha vedanā khaṇe dukkhāya vedanāya abhāvataḥ sukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ  sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti tena yā pubbe bhūta pubbā dukkhā vedanā tassā

analyzed: idāni abhāvataḥ imissā ca sukhāya itas paṭhamam abhāvataḥ vedanā nāma aniccā addhuvā
translated: And because there is no painful feeling then, and because there was no pleasant feeling before this, he knows thus: “Feeling is impermanent, painful, subject to change.”

original: vipariṇāmadhammāti itiha tattha sampajāno hoti. Vuttampi cetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: vipariṇāma dhammā ti iti ha tattha sampajānaḥ hoti vuttam pi ca itam bhagavatā
translated: And this is said by the Blessed One:

analyzed: yasmin aggivessana samaye dukkhaṃpe adukkham asukham vedanam vedeti na iva tasmin  samaye sukham vedanam vedeti na dukkham vedanam vedeti adukkham asukhaṃ yā iva tasmin
translated: On the occasion, Aggivessana, on which one feels a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, one does not feel a pleasant feeling or a painful feeling; on that occasion one feels only a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.

original: samaye vedanaṃ vedeti. Sukhāpi kho, aggivessana, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā🔽khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā. Dukkhāpi kho…pe… adukkhamasukhāpi

translated: A pleasant feeling, Aggivessana, is impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.

original: kho, aggivessana, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā…pe… nirodhadhammā. Evaṃ passaṃ, aggivessana,
analyzed: kho aggivessana vedanā aniccā saṅkha tāpe nirodha dhammā evam passam aggivessana

analyzed: sutavā ariya sāvako sukhāya api vedanāya nibbindati dukkhāya api vedanāya nibbindati
translated: the well-taught noble disciple becomes disenchanted with pleasant feeling, disenchanted with painful feeling, disenchanted with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.

original: adukkhamasukhāyapi vedanāya nibbindati, nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati, vimuttasmiṃ🔽vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti; ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ
analyzed: adukkham asukhāya api vedanāya nibbindati nibbindam virajjati virāgā vimuccati vimuttasmin  vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti khīṇā jāti vusitam brahmacariyam katam karaṇīyam na aparam
translated: He becomes dispassionate towards neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling,🔽through dispassion he is released, in release there is the knowledge of release, he understands: ‘Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no returning to this state of being.’🔽

original: itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
analyzed: itthattāya ati pajānāti iti
translated: and he becomes dispassionate towards neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling, and through dispassion he is released, and with release there is the knowledge that he is released, and he knows that destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.”

original: Sāmisaṃ vā sukhantiādīsu sāmisā sukhā nāma pañcakāmaguṇāmisanissitā cha gehassitasomanassavedanā;
analyzed: sa āmisam vā sukham ti ādīsu sāmisā sukhā nāma pañca kāmaguṇa āmisa nissitā cha geha ssita somanassa vedanā
translated: “Pleasant with sensuality” and so on: sensual-desire-rooted pleasant feeling is the six kinds of happiness based on sensual desires.

original: nirāmisā sukhā nāma cha nekkhammassitasomanassavedanā; sāmisā dukkhā nāma cha gehassitadomanassavedanā;🔽nirāmisā dukkhā nāma cha nekkhammassitadomanassavedanā; sāmisā adukkhamasukhā nāma
analyzed: nirāmisā sukhā nāma cha nekkhamma ssita somanassa vedanā sāmisā dukkhā nāma cha gehassita domanassa vedanā  nirāmisāḥ dukkhāḥ nāma cha nekkhammassita domanassa vedanāḥ sāmisāḥ adukkhamasukhāḥ nāma
translated: Non-sensual-desire-rooted pleasant feeling is the six kinds of happiness based on renunciation. Sensual-desire-rooted unpleasant feeling is the six kinds of grief based on sensual desires.🔽Non-sensual-desire-rooted unpleasant feeling is the six kinds of grief based on renunciation. Sensual-desire-rooted neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling is the six kinds of unconcern based on sensual desires.

original: cha gehasitaupekkhāvedanā; nirāmisā adukkhamasukhā nāma cha nekkhammassitaupekkhāvedanā.
analyzed: cha gehasita aupekkhā vedanāḥ nirāmisāḥ adukkhamasukhāḥ nāma cha nekkhammassita aupekkhā vedanāḥ
translated: Non-sensual-desire-rooted neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling is the six kinds of unconcern based on renunciation.

original: Tāsaṃ vibhāgo uparipaṇṇāse pāḷiyaṃ āgatoyeva. So taṃ nimittanti so taṃ vedanānimittaṃ.
analyzed: tāsam vibhāgaḥ upari paṇṇāse pāḷiyam saḥ tam so tam vedanā nimittam
translated: The exposition of these should be understood according to the texts in the Peṭaka. “That sign”: that feeling as a sign.

original: Bahiddhā vedanāsūti parapuggalassa vedanāsu. Sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamānanti parapuggalaṃ🔽sukhavedanaṃ vedayamānaṃ. Ajjhattabahiddhāti kālena attano kālena parassa vedanāsu🔽cittaṃ upasaṃharati. Imasmiṃ vāre yasmā neva attā, na paro niyamito; tasmā vedanāpariggahamattameva
analyzed: bahiddhā vedanāsu iti para puggalassa vedanāsu sukham vedanam vedayamānanti para puggalam  sukha vedanam vedayamānam ajjhatta bahiddhā ati kālena attanaḥ kālena parassa vedanāsu  cittam upasaṃharati imasmin vāre yasmai na iva attā na paraḥ tasmai vedanā pariggaham attam eva
translated: “In the external” means in the feelings of another person. “One who is experiencing pleasant feeling” means another person who is experiencing pleasant feeling. “In the internal and the external” means he directs his mind to his own feelings at one time and to those of another person at another time. In this tetrad, since neither oneself nor another is limited, the practice is limited to the mere discerning of feelings.

original: dassetuṃ “idha bhikkhu sukhaṃ vedanaṃ sukhā vedanā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Sesamettha uttānameva.
analyzed: dassetum idha bhikkhu sukham vedanam sukhā vedanā tiādi vuttam sesam ettha uttānam eva
translated: “Externally in another’s feelings”: in another person’s feelings. “One who feels a pleasant feeling”: a person who is feeling a pleasant feeling. “Internally and externally”: sometimes in his own feelings, sometimes in another’s feelings. In this section since neither he nor another is specified, it is said: “Here a bhikkhu … a pleasant feeling … a pleasant feeling” in order to show that it is only the feelings that are to be discerned. The rest is clear.

original: Imasmiṃ pana pabbe suddhavipassanāva kathitāti.
analyzed: imasmin pana pabbe suddha vipassanā ava kathitā ti
translated: But in this stanza only pure insight is spoken of.

original: Vedanānupassanāniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Cittānupassanāniddesavaṇṇanā🔽365. Cittānupassanāniddesepi heṭṭhā vuttasadisaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Sarāgaṃ
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā          citta anupassanā niddese pi heṭṭhā vutta sadisam vutta nayena iva veditabbam sa rāgam
translated: The description of the contemplation of feelings is ended.

original: Idaṃ pana yasmā sammasanaṃ na dhammasamodhānaṃ, tasmā idha ekapadepi lokuttaraṃ na
analyzed: idam pana yasmai sammasanam na dhamma samodhānam tasmai idha eka pade pi lokuttaram na

analyzed: padesu nippariyāyena na labbhanti iti na gahitāni sesāni cattāri akusala cittāni na eva  purima padam na pacchima padam bhajanti sa dosanti duvidham domanassa sahagatam vīta dosanti
translated: because they are not literally so. The remaining four unprofitable consciousnesses do not belong to either the first or the last term.

analyzed: lokiya kusala abyākatam sesāni dasa akusala cittāni na iva purima padam na pacchima padam  bhajanti samohanti vicikicchā sahagatam ca iva uddhacca sahagatam ca ati duvidham yasmā
translated: With grief is twofold with grief and with worry. Without grief is mundane profitable and indeterminate. The remaining ten unprofitable consciousnesses do not belong to either the first or the last term.

original: pana moho sabbākusalesu uppajjati, tasmā sesānipi idha vaṭṭanti eva. Imasmiṃ yeva🔽hi duke dvādasākusalacittāni pariyādiṇṇānīti. Vītamohanti lokiyakusalābyākataṃ. Saṃkhittanti
analyzed: pana mohaḥ sabba akusalesu uppajjati tasmā sesāni api idha vaṭṭanti eva imasmin yeva 🔽hi duke dvādasa akusala cittāni pariyādiṇṇāni iti vīta mohanti lokiya kusala abyākatam saṃkhittanti
translated: With delusion is twofold with uncertainty and with agitation. But since delusion arises in all unprofitable consciousness, the remaining kinds are included here too. original: thinamiddhānupatitaṃ. Etañhi saṅkuṭitacittaṃ nāma. Vikkhittanti uddhaccasahagataṃ.

translated: and “overwhelmed by sloth and torpor” is the state of mind that is contracted. “Distracted” is that associated with agitation.

translated: This is the state of mind that is distracted.

translated: “Without residue” is the fine-material and immaterial kinds. Herein, the fine-material kind is with residue,

original: arūpāvacarameva. Samāhitanti yassa appanāsamādhi upacārasamādhi vā atthi. Asamāhitanti🔽ubhayasamādhivirahitaṃ. Vimuttanti tadaṅgavikkhambhanavimuttīhi vinimuttaṃ. Avimuttanti
analyzed: arūpāvacaram eva samāhitanti yassa appanā samādhi upacāra samādhi vā atthi asamāhitanti  ubhaya samādhi virahitam vimuttanti tad aṅga vikkhambhana vimuttīhi vinimuttam a vimuttam
translated: and the immaterial kind is without residue. “Concentrated” is that in which there is absorption concentration or access concentration. “Unconcentrated” is🔽that devoid of both kinds of concentration. “Liberated” is that not liberated by the liberation of suppression of the hindrances. “Unliberated” is

original: ubhayavimuttirahitaṃ; samucchedapaṭippassaddhinissaraṇavimuttīnaṃ pana idha okāsova
analyzed: ubhaya vimutti rahitam samuccheda paṭippassaddhi nissaraṇa vimuttīnam pana idha okāsaḥ uva
translated: that devoid of both kinds of liberation. But there is no opportunity here for the liberations of suppression, of cancelling out, and of removal.

original: natthi. Sarāgamassa cittanti sarāgaṃ assa cittaṃ. Sesaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayattā uttānatthameva.
analyzed: natthi sa rāgam assa cittanti sa rāgam assa cittam sesam heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā uttāna attham eva
translated: “With greed” is that in which there is greed. The rest is evident in meaning since it is already given in the description of the first triad.

original: Imasmimpi pabbe suddhavipassanāva kathitāti.
analyzed: imasmim pi pabbe suddha vipassanā ava kathitā ti
translated: In this section too only pure insight is taught.

original: Cittānupassanāniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: citta anupassanā niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Description of contemplation of consciousness is ended.

original: Dhammānupassanāniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: Description of contemplation of mental objects🔽.

original: Nīvaraṇapabbavaṇṇanā🔽367. Ettāvatā yasmā kāyānupassanāya rūpakkhandhapariggahova kathito, vedanānupassanāya🔽vedanākkhandhapariggahova cittānupassanāya viññāṇakkhandhapariggahova tasmā idāni🔽sampayuttadhammasīsena saññāsaṅkhārakkhandhapariggahampi kathetuṃ dhammānupassanaṃ
analyzed: nīvaraṇa pabba vaṇṇanā  ettāvatā yasmai kāya anupassanāya rūpa kkhandha pariggahaḥ uva kathitaḥ vedanā anupassanāya  vedanā kkhandha pariggahaḥ uva citta anupassanāya viññāṇa kkhandha pariggahaḥ uva tasmai idāni  sampayutta dhamma sīsena saññā saṅkhāra kkhandha pariggaham pi kathetum dhamma anupassanam
translated: The origin of the hindrances🔽.🔽So far only the material form aggregate has been pointed out in the case of the contemplation of the body, only the feeling aggregate in the case of the contemplation of feeling, only the consciousness aggregate in the case of the contemplation of consciousness. Therefore now, in order to point out the discernment of the perception and formations aggregates by way of the mental-data aggregate that accompanies them, he said, “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu dwell contemplating mental objects in mental objects by way of the six internal and external bases” , showing the contemplation of mental objects.

original: dassento kathañca bhikkhūtiādimāha. Tattha santanti abhiṇhasamudācāravasena saṃvijjamānaṃ.
analyzed: dassentaḥ katham ca bhikkhu iti ādim āha tattha santanti abhiṇha samudācāra vasena saṃvijjamānam
translated: Herein, existent means present by frequent occurrence.

original: Asantanti asamudācāravasena vā pahīnattā vā avijjamānaṃ. Yathā cāti yena kāraṇena
analyzed: asantanti asamudācāra vasena vā pahīna ttā vā avijjamānam yathā ca ati yena kāraṇena
translated: Non-existent means not present either because of absence of occurrence or because of having been abandoned.

original: kāmacchandassa uppādo hoti. Tañca pajānātīti tañca kāraṇaṃ pajānāti. Iminā nayena
analyzed: kāmacchandassa uppādaḥ hoti tat ca pajānāti iti tat ca kāraṇam pajānāti iminā nayena
translated: And he understands how the arising of the unarisen hindrance of sensual desire comes to be: he understands by what kind of cause the arising of the unarisen hindrance of sensual desire comes to be.🔽And he understands how the abandoning of the arisen hindrance of sensual desire comes to be: he understands by what kind of cause the abandoning of the arisen hindrance of sensual desire comes to be.🔽And he understands how the non-arising of the abandoned hindrance of sensual desire in the future will come to be: he understands by what kind of cause the non-arising of the abandoned hindrance of sensual desire in the future will come to be.

original: sabbapadesu attho veditabbo.
analyzed: sabba padesu atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in each instance.

original: Tattha subhanimitte ayonisomanasikārena kāmacchandassa uppādo hoti. Subhanimittaṃ
analyzed: tattha subha nimitte ayoniso manasikārena kāmacchandassa uppādaḥ hoti subha nimittam
translated: Herein, lust arises in one who gives inattentive mental attention to a sign of the lovely.

original: nāma subhampi subhanimittaṃ, subhārammaṇampi subhanimittaṃ. Ayonisomanasikāro nāma🔽anupāyamanasikāro uppathamanasikāro, anicce niccanti vā dukkhe sukhanti vā anattani🔽attāti vā asubhe subhanti vā manasikāro. Taṃ tattha bahulaṃ pavattayato kāmacchando
analyzed: nāma subham pi subha nimittam subha ārammaṇam pi subha nimittam a yonisaḥ manasikāraḥ nāma  an upāya manasikāraḥ uppatha manasikāraḥ anicce niccanti vā dukkhe sukhanti vā anattani  attā ati vā asubhe vā manasikāro tam tattha bahulam pavattayataḥ kāmacchandaḥ
translated: A sign of the lovely is either the lovely itself or a sign of the lovely.

original: uppajjati. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: uppajjati tena āha bhagavā
translated: Inattentive mental attention is either attention by a wrong method or attention that is off the mark. Attention to what is impermanent as permanent, to what is painful as pleasant, to what is not self as self, to what is foul as lovely, is inattentive mental attention. When that is repeatedly practiced, lust arises. Hence the Blessed One said:

original: “Atthi, bhikkhave, subhanimittaṃ. Tattha ayonisomanasikārabahulīkāro – ayamāhāro anuppannassa vā kāmacchandassa uppādāya, uppannassa vā kāmacchandassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāyā”ti.
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave subha nimittam tattha a yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ayam āhāraḥ anuppannassa vā kāmacchandassa uppādāya uppannassa vā kāmacchandassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya ati
translated: “Bhikkhus, there is a sign of the lovely. The repeated practice of inattentive mental attention on that is a condition, by the state of dominance conditionality, for the arising of unarisen lust and for the increase and expansion of arisen lust” .

original: Asubhanimitte pana yonisomanasikārenassa pahānaṃ hoti. Asubhanimittaṃ nāma asubhampi
analyzed: asubha nimitte pana yoni soma nasikārena assa pahānam hoti asubha nimittam nāma asubham pi
translated: But its abandoning comes about in one who gives close attention to a sign of the foul. A sign of the foul is either the foul itself or a sign of the foul.

original: asubhanimittaṃ, asubhārammaṇampi asubhanimittaṃ. Yonisomanasikāro nāma upāyamanasikāro🔽pathamanasikāro, anicce aniccanti vā dukkhe dukkhanti vā anattani anattāti vā asubhe
analyzed: asubha nimittam asubha ārammaṇam pi asubha nimittam yonisomanasikāraḥ nāma upāya manasikāro  patha manasikāraḥ anicce aniccanti vā dukkhe dukkhanti vā anattani anattāti vā asubhe
translated: The sign of foulness: foulness is the object, and also the sign of foulness.🔽Wise attention: attention by way of the means, attention by way of the path, attention to the impermanent as impermanent, attention to suffering as suffering, attention to the non-self as non-self, attention to foulness as foulness,

original: asubhanti vā manasikāro. Taṃ tattha bahulaṃ pavattayato kāmacchando pahīyati. Tenāha bhagavā –🔽“Atthi, bhikkhave, asubhanimittaṃ. Tattha yonisomanasikārabahulīkāro ayamanāhāro anuppannassa vā kāmacchandassa uppādāya, uppannassa vā kāmacchandassa bhiyyobhāvāya, vepullāyā”ti.🔽Apica cha dhammā kāmacchandassa pahānāya saṃvattanti – asubhanimittassa uggaho, asubhabhāvanānuyogo,
analyzed: vā manasikāro tam tattha bahulam pavattayato kāmacchandaḥ pahīyati tena āha bhagavā  atthi bhikkhave asubha nimittam tattha yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ayam anāhāraḥ anuppannassa vā kāmacchandassa uppādāya uppannassa vā kāmacchandassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya ati  apica cha dhammā kāmacchandassa pahānāya saṃvattanti asubha nimittassa uggahaḥ asubha bhāvanā anuyogo
translated: The sign of foulness is the object of foulness too. Repeated attention is attention by way of a method, attention by way of a path, attention to what is impermanent as impermanent, to what is painful as painful, to what is not-self as not-self, to foulness as foulness. When he gives repeated attention thus, lust is abandoned in him. Hence it is said: “Bhikkhus, there is the sign of foulness. Repeated attention to that sign is the nutriment for the arising of the unarisen enlightenment factor of equanimity and for the fulfilment by development of the arisen enlightenment factor of equanimity” .

original: indriyesu guttadvāratā, bhojane mattaññutā, kalyāṇamittatā, sappāyakathāti. Dasavidhañhi
analyzed: indriyesu gutta dvāra tā bhojane mattaññu tā kalyāṇa mitta tā sappāya kathā ati dasavidham hi
translated: Besides, six things lead to the abandoning of lust: learning the sign of foulness, practice in the perception of foulness, guarding of the doors of the sense faculties, moderation in eating, good friendship, and talk conducive to this . For when he learns the sign of foulness, his lust for the sign of beauty is abandoned. When he practices the perception of foulness, his lust for the visible-form element is abandoned. When he guards the doors of the sense faculties, his lust for contact is abandoned. When he is moderate in eating, his lust for nutriment is abandoned. When he has good friends, his lust for society is abandoned. And when he talks talk conducive to this, his lust for talk is abandoned.

original: asubhanimittaṃ uggaṇhantassāpi kāmacchando pahīyati, bhāventassāpi; indriyesu pihitadvārassāpi;
analyzed: asubha nimittam uggaṇhantassa api kāmacchandaḥ pahīyati bhāventassa api indriyesu pihita dvārassa api
translated: and also for one who is learning the meditation subject of foulness and for one who is developing it.

original: catunnaṃ pañcannaṃ ālopānaṃ okāse sati udakaṃ pivitvā yāpanasīlatāya bhojane mattaññunopi. Tena vuttaṃ –
analyzed: catunnam pañcannam ālopānam okāse sati udakam pivitvā yāpana sīla tāya bhojane mattaññunā api tena vuttam
translated: and also for one who is continent in his use of the four requisite-conditions and the five, and who is moderate in his food. Hence it was said:🔽“Having eaten four or five mouthfuls less,

original: “Cattāro pañca ālope, abhutvā udakaṃ pive;
analyzed: cattāraḥ pañca ālope a bhutvā udakam pive
translated: He should drink water and be content;🔽That is enough for the bhikkhu’s comfort

original: Alaṃ phāsuvihārāya, pahitattassa bhikkhuno”ti. ;
analyzed: alam phāsu vihārāya pahitattassa bhikkhuno ti
translated: Who has mindfulness well established” .

original: Asubhakammikatissattherasadise asubhabhāvanārate kalyāṇamitte sevantassāpi kāmacchando
analyzed: asubha kammika tissatthera sadise asubha bhāvanā rate kalyāṇa mitte sevantassa api kāmacchando
translated: and also for one who frequents the company of good friends who are devoted to the development of foulness meditation, such as the Elder Tissa, the worker in foulness.

original: pahīyati; ṭhānanisajjādīsu dasaasubhanissitasappāyakathāyapi pahīyati. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: pahīyati ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu pahīyati tena vuttam
translated: and also for one who talks about what is suitable, having as its support the ten kinds of foulness, in the places where he normally talks, sits, etc. Hence it was said:🔽“Six things lead to the abandoning of lust” .

original: “cha dhammā kāmacchandassa pahānāya saṃvattantī”ti. Imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnassa
analyzed: cha dhammā kāmacchandassa pahānāya saṃvattanti iti imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnassa
translated: But when lust is abandoned by these six things,

original: kāmacchandassa arahattamaggena āyatiṃ anuppādo hotīti pajānāti.
analyzed: kāmacchandassa arahatta maggena āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti iti pajānāti
translated: he knows that it is abandoned by the path of arahatship.

original: Paṭighanimitte ayonisomanasikārena pana byāpādassa uppādo hoti. Tattha paṭighampi
analyzed: paṭigha nimitte ayoniso manasikārena pana byāpādassa uppādaḥ hoti tattha paṭigham pi
translated: Ill will arises through unwise attention to the sign of resistance.

original: paṭighanimittaṃ nāma; paṭighārammaṇampi paṭighanimittaṃ. Ayonisomanasikāro sabbattha
analyzed: paṭigha nimittam nāma paṭigha ārammaṇam pi paṭigha nimittam ayoniso manasikāraḥ sabbattha
translated: The sign of resistance is the object of resistance too. Wrong reflection is the same in all cases.

original: ekalakkhaṇova. Taṃ tasmiṃ nimitte bahulaṃ pavattayato byāpādo uppajjati. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: eka lakkhaṇaḥ uva tam tasmin nimitte bahulam pavattayataḥ byāpādaḥ uppajjati tena āha bhagavā
translated: When he frequently gives attention to that sign, ill will arises in him. Hence the Blessed One said:

original: “Atthi, bhikkhave, paṭighanimittaṃ. Tattha ayonisomanasikārabahulīkāro – ayamāhāro anuppannassa vā byāpādassa uppādāya, uppannassa vā byāpādassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāyā”ti.
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave paṭigha nimittam tattha a yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ayam āhāraḥ anuppannassa vā byāpādassa uppādāya uppannassa vā byāpādassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya ati
translated: “Bhikkhus, there is the sign of resistance. The non-preponderance of wrong reflection there is a condition, I say, for the arising of ill will” .🔽But its abandoning comes about through the outlet of loving-kindness,

original: Mettāya pana cetovimuttiyā yonisomanasikārenassa pahānaṃ hoti. Tattha mettāti vutte
analyzed: mettāya pana cetaḥ vimuttiyā yoniso manasikārena assa pahānam hoti tattha mettā ati vutte
translated: When “loving-kindness” is said,

original: appanāpi upacāropi vaṭṭati; cetovimuttīti appanāva. Yonisomanasikāro vuttalakkhaṇova.
analyzed: appanā api upacāraḥ api vaṭṭati cetaḥ vimutti iti appanā va yoniso manasikāro vutta lakkhaṇaḥ va
translated: both absorption and access are allowable; but when “deliverance of mind” is said, only absorption is allowable. Right reflection has the same characteristic in all cases.

original: Taṃ tattha bahulaṃ pavattayato byāpādo pahīyati. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: tam tattha bahulam pavattayataḥ byāpādaḥ pahīyati tena āha bhagavā
translated: When he frequently gives attention to that, ill will is abandoned in him. Hence the Blessed One said:

original: “Atthi, bhikkhave, mettācetovimutti. Tattha yonisomanasikārabahulīkāro – ayamāhāro anuppannassa vā byāpādassa uppādāya, uppannassa vā byāpādassa bhiyyobhāvāya, vepullāyā”ti.
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave mettā cetaḥ vimutti tattha yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ayam āhāraḥ anuppannassa vā byāpādassa uppādāya uppannassa vā byāpādassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya ati
translated: “Bhikkhus, there is the case where one abides much in the perception of the sphere of nothingness.🔽“And what, bhikkhus, is the nutriment for the arising of unarisen ill will and for the increase and expansion of arisen ill will?

original: Apica cha dhammā byāpādassa pahānāya saṃvattanti – mettānimittassa uggaho, mettābhāvanānuyogo,
analyzed: apica cha dhammā byāpādassa pahānāya saṃvattanti mettā nimittassa uggahaḥ mettā bhāvanā anuyogo
translated: “There are, bhikkhus, six things that lead to the abandoning of ill will.🔽The taking up of the signless; the cultivation of the signless;🔽the reflection on what one has heard; the frequent reflection;

original: kammassakatāpaccavekkhaṇā, paṭisaṅkhānabahulīkatā, kalyāṇamittatā, sappāyakathāti.🔽Odissakānodissakadisāpharaṇānañhi aññataravasena mettaṃ uggaṇhantassāpi byāpādo pahīyati.
analyzed: kammassaka tā paccavekkhaṇā paṭisaṅkhāna bahulīkatā kalyāṇa mitta tā sappāya kathā ati  odissaka anodissaka disāpharaṇānam hi aññatara vasena mettam uggaṇhantassa api byāpādaḥ pahīyati
translated: the companionship of good people; and talk that is conducive to this.🔽For one who takes up the signless, who cultivates the signless,

original: Odhiso anodhiso disāpharaṇavasena mettaṃ bhāventassāpi. ‘Tvaṃ etassa kuddho kiṃ karissasi,
analyzed: odhisaḥ anodhisaḥ disā pharaṇa vasena mettam bhāventassa api tvam etassa kuddhaḥ kim karissasi
translated: ill will is abandoned. For one who reflects on what one has heard, who frequently reflects,🔽ill will is abandoned. For one who has good friends, companions, and associates,🔽ill will is abandoned. For one who talks in a way that is conducive to this,

original: kimassa sīlādīni vināsetuṃ sakkhissasi? Nanu tvaṃ attano kammena āgantvā attano kammeneva
analyzed: kim assa sīla ādīni vināsetum sakkhissasi nanu tvam attano kammena āgantvā attano kammena iva
translated: ill will is abandoned.🔽“Bhikkhus, there are six things that lead to the abandoning of denigration.

original: gamissasi? Parassa kujjhanaṃ nāma vītaccitaṅgāratattaayosalākagūthādīni gahetvā parassa
analyzed: gamissasi parassa kujjhanam nāma gahetvā parassa
translated: What will he do to you? Anger is like a man who, out of a desire to strike another, takes a burning charcoal brazier, a torch of hay, a pot of oil, or a pan of coals, and goes to the other.

original: paharitukāmatāsadisaṃ hoti. Esopi tava kuddho kiṃ karissati? Kiṃ te sīlādīni vināsetuṃ
analyzed: paharitu kāma tā sadisam hoti esaḥ api tava kuddhaḥ kim karissati kim te sīla ādīni vināsetum
translated: What can he do to you? Can he destroy your virtue, etc.?

original: sakkhissati? Esa attano kammenāgantvā attano kammeneva gamissati; appaṭicchitapaheṇakaṃ
analyzed: sakkhissati esa attano kammena āgantvā attano kammena iva gamissati appaṭicchita paheṇakam
translated: He will come by his own action and go by his own action. Like an uninvited guest, like a clod or a stick thrown up by the force of the wind,

original: viya paṭivātakhittarajomuṭṭhi viya ca etassevesa kodho matthake patissatī’ti. Evaṃ🔽attano ca parassa ca kammassakataṃ paccavekkhatopi, ubhayakammassakataṃ paccavekkhitvā🔽paṭisaṅkhāne ṭhitassāpi, assaguttattherasadise mettābhāvanārate kalyāṇamitte sevantassāpi🔽byāpādo pahīyati; ṭhānanisajjādīsu mettānissitasappāyakathāyapi pahīyati. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: viya paṭivāta khitta rajaḥ muṭṭhi viya ca etassa iva esa kodhaḥ matthake patissati iti evam  attanaḥ ca parassa ca kammassakatam paccavekkhato pi ubhaya kammassakatam paccavekkhitvā  paṭisaṅkhāne ṭhitassa api mettā bhāvanā rate kalyāṇa mitte sevantassa api  byāpādaḥ pahīyati ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu mettā nissita sappāya kathāya api pahīyati tena vuttam
translated: like a pot dashed to pieces against a rock, so will he fall upon his own head. ’

original: “cha dhammā byāpādassa pahānāya saṃvattantī”ti. Imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnassa
analyzed: cha dhammā byāpādassa pahānāya saṃvattanti iti imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnassa
translated: Thus anger is abandoned by reviewing one’s own and others’ actions, by reviewing the fruit of one’s own and others’ actions, by reviewing the nearness of the inevitable, by reviewing the nearness of death, by reviewing the uncertainty of the time of death, by reviewing the uselessness of friends and kinsmen, by reviewing what must be faced by one’s own self alone, by reviewing the fruit of the breach of morality, by reviewing the danger in sensual pleasures, by reviewing the danger in the world, by reviewing the danger in gain, by reviewing the danger in family life, by reviewing the danger in praise, by reviewing the danger in honour, by reviewing the danger in blame, by reviewing the danger in suffering, by reviewing the danger in sickness, by reviewing the danger in old age, by reviewing the danger in death, by reviewing the danger in the kinds of becoming, by reviewing the danger in the kinds of generation, by reviewing the danger in the kinds of destiny, by reviewing the danger in the kinds of appearance, by reviewing the danger in the kinds of plane, by reviewing the danger in the kinds of rebirth, by reviewing the danger in the kinds of misfortune, by reviewing the danger in the kinds of defilement, by reviewing the danger in the kinds of suffering, by reviewing the danger in the world, by reviewing the danger in the world of kamma, by reviewing the danger in the world of formations, by reviewing the danger in the world of suffering, by reviewing the danger in the world of defilement, by reviewing the danger in the world of rebirth, by reviewing the danger in the world of death, by reviewing the danger in the world of birth, by reviewing the danger in the world of old age, by reviewing the danger in the world of sickness, by reviewing the danger in the world of defilement, by reviewing the danger in the world of kamma,

original: byāpādassa anāgāmimaggena āyatiṃ anuppādo hotīti pajānāti.
analyzed: byāpādassa anāgāmi maggena āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti iti pajānāti
translated: He understands how non-arising of the fetter of ill will comes to be in the future.

original: Aratītiādīsu ayonisomanasikārena thinamiddhassa uppādo hoti. Arati nāma ukkaṇṭhitatā.
analyzed: arati itiādīsu a yoniso manasikārena thinam iddhassa uppādaḥ hoti arati nāma ukkaṇṭhita tā
translated: In the case of discontent, etc., torpor and lethargy arise through unwise attention. Discontent is dissatisfaction.🔽Sluggishness is heaviness of the body. Yawning is contortion of the body.

original: Tandī nāma kāyālasiyatā. Vijambhikā nāma kāyavināmanā. Bhattasammado nāma bhattamucchā
analyzed: tandī nāma vijambhikā nāma kāyavināmanā bhattasammadaḥ nāma bhattamucchā
translated: Satiety after eating is a state of the body that has eaten too much.

original: bhattapariḷāho. Cetaso līnattaṃ nāma cittassa līnākāro. Imesu aratiādīsu ayonisomanasikāraṃ
analyzed: bhatta pariḷāho cetasaḥ līnattam nāma cittassa līna ākāraḥ imesu arati ādīsu a yoniso manasikāram
translated: Depression of mind is a state of depression in consciousness. When there is much unwise attention to these things,

original: bahulaṃ pavattayato thinamiddhaṃ uppajjati. Tenāha bhagavā –

translated: torpor and lethargy arise. Hence the Blessed One said:

analyzed: atthi bhikkhave arati tandī vijambhikā bhatta sammadaḥ cetasaḥ ca līnattam tattha  a yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ayam āhāraḥ anuppannassa vā thinamiddhassa uppādāya
translated: “Bhikkhus, there is discontent, sluggishness, yawning, satiety after eating, and depression of mind.

analyzed: uppannassa vā thinamiddhassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya ati

original: Ārambhadhātuādīsu pana yonisomanasikārenassa pahānaṃ hoti. Ārambhadhātu nāma paṭhamārambhavīriyaṃ.🔽Nikkamadhātu nāma kosajjato nikkhantattā tato balavataraṃ. Parakkamadhātu nāma paraṃ
analyzed: ārambha dhātu ādīsu pana yonisoma nasikārena assa pahānam hoti ārambha dhātu nāma paṭhama ārambha vīriyam  nikkamadhātu nāma kosajjataḥ nikkhanta ttā tatas balavataram parakkamadhātu nāma param
translated: But it is abandoned by right reflection on the elements of instigation, etc.,🔽The element of instigation is the first kind of energy.

original: paraṃ ṭhānaṃ akkamanato tatopi balavataraṃ. Imasmiṃ tippabhede vīriye yonisomanasikāraṃ
analyzed: param ṭhānam akkamanataḥ tatas pi balavataram imasmin tippabhede vīriye yoni so manasikāram
translated: The element of exertion is stronger than that because it has gone out from idleness. The element of launching forth is stronger than that because it launches forth further still.🔽When he gives much attention to right reflection on these three kinds of energy,

analyzed: bahulam thinam iddham pahīyati tena āha bhagavā
translated: sloth and torpor are abandoned in him. Hence the Blessed One said:

original: “Atthi, bhikkhave, ārambhadhātu, nikkamadhātu, parakkamadhātu. Tattha yonisomanasikārabahulīkāro🔽– ayamanāhāro anuppannassa vā thinamiddhassa uppādāya, uppannassa vā thinamiddhassa
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave ārambha dhātu nikkama dhātu parakkama dhātu tattha yoni so manasikāra bahulīkāro  ayam anāhāraḥ anuppannassa vā thinamiddhassa uppādāya uppannassa vā thinamiddhassa
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are the element of instigation, the element of exertion, and the element of launching forth.🔽When attention is frequently given to them,

original: bhiyyobhāvāya, vepullāyā”ti.
analyzed: bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya ati
translated: that is a condition for the non-arising of the unarisen sloth and torpor and for the disappearance of the arisen sloth and torpor” .🔽Besides, six things lead to the abandoning of sloth and torpor:

analyzed: apica cha dhammā thinamiddhassa pahānāya saṃvattanti ati bhojane nimitta ggāhaḥ iriyāpatha samparivattana tā

original: ālokasaññāmanasikāro, abbhokāsavāso, kalyāṇamittatā, sappāyakathāti. Āharahatthaka🔽bhuttavamitaka tatravaṭṭaka alaṃsāṭaka kākamāsakabhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhāne
analyzed: āloka saññā manasikāro abbhokāsa vāso kalyāṇa mitta tā sappāya kathā ati āharahatthaka  bhutta vamitaka tatravaṭṭaka alaṃsāṭaka kākamāsaka bhojanam bhuñjitvā ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhāne
translated: The sign of light, directing of cognizance to light, living in the open, good friends, and helpful talk.🔽After eating, he should not lie down or indulge in day-sleep.

original: nisinnassa hi samaṇadhammaṃ karoto thinamiddhaṃ mahāhatthī viya ottharantaṃ āgacchati.
analyzed: nisinnassa hi samaṇa dhammam karoto thinam iddham mahā hatthī viya ottharantam āgacchati
translated: For when he sits down in the place where he is to spend the night or in the place where he is to spend the day, and does his ascetic’s duties, then drowsiness and sleep come upon him like a great elephant lowering its ear.

original: Catupañcaālopaokāsaṃ pana ṭhapetvā pānīyaṃ pivitvā yāpanasīlassa bhikkhuno taṃ na
analyzed: catu pañca āla upaokāsam pana ṭhapetvā pānīyam pivitvā yāpana sīlassa bhikkhuno tam na
translated: But that does not happen to a bhikkhu who is moderate in eating and who has the habit of keeping active by pacing up and down, etc.,

original: hotīti atibhojane nimittaṃ gaṇhantassāpi thinamiddhaṃ pahīyati. Yasmiṃ iriyāpathe
analyzed: hoti iti ati bhojane nimittam gaṇhantassa api thinam iddham pahīyati yasmin iriyāpathe
translated: and who, after taking two or three mouthfuls, drinks water and then carries on. It is abandoned also in one who changes over from the posture in which it arises to some other one.

original: thinamiddhaṃ okkamati tato aññaṃ parivattentassāpi, rattiṃ candālokadīpālokaukkāloke
analyzed: thinam iddham okkamati tatas aññam parivattentassa api rattim canda āloka dīpa āloka okkāloke

analyzed: divā sūriya ālokam manasikarontassa api abbhokāse vasantassa api mahā kassapa tthera sadise

analyzed: pahīna thinamiddhe kalyāṇa mitte sevantassa api thinamiddham pahīyati ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu
translated: It is abandoned in one who, instead of lying down,

analyzed: pahīyati tena vuttam cha dhammā thinamiddhassa
translated: and by talk that is appropriate to the ascetic practice.🔽That is why it was said above: “Six ideas lead to the abandoning of stiffness and torpor” .

original: pahānāya saṃvattantī”ti. Imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnassa thinamiddhassa arahattamaggena🔽āyatiṃ anuppādo hotīti pajānāti.🔽Cetaso avūpasame ayonisomanasikārena uddhaccakukkuccassa uppādo hoti. Avūpasamo nāma
analyzed: pahānāya saṃvattanti iti imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnassa thinamiddhassa arahatta maggena  āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti iti pajānāti  cetasaḥ avūpasame a yoniso manasikārena uddhacca kukkuccassa uppādaḥ hoti avūpasamaḥ nāma
translated: And he understands how the abandoning of the stiffness and torpor that have thus been interrupted comes about through the Arahant path.🔽When there is no quieting of the cognizance, then restlessness and remorse come about through unwise attention.🔽“No quieting” is a state of non-quieting, which is in fact restlessness and remorse.

analyzed: pavattayataḥ uddhacca kukkuccam uppajjati tena āha bhagavā
translated: That is why the Blessed One said:

translated: “Bhikkhus, there is a quieting of the cognizance. When there is much unwise attention to that,

analyzed: an uppannassa vā uddhacca kukkuccassa uppādāya uppannassa vā uddhacca kukkuccassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya ati

analyzed: samādhi saṅkhāte pana cetasaḥ vūpasame yoniso manasikārena assa pahānam hoti tena āha bhagavā
translated: But its abandoning comes about through the tranquillizing of the cognizance called concentration, with proper attention. Hence the Blessed One said:

original: “Atthi, bhikkhave, cetaso vūpasamo. Tattha yonisomanasikārabahulīkāro – ayamanāhāro
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave cetasaḥ vūpasamaḥ tattha yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ayam anāhāraḥ
translated: “There is, bhikkhus, tranquillizing of cognizance. There, with much development of proper attention,

original: anuppannassa vā uddhaccakukkuccassa uppādāya, uppannassa vā uddhaccakukkuccassa bhiyyobhāvāya, vepullāyā”ti.
analyzed: an uppannassa vā uddhacca kukkuccassa uppādāya uppannassa vā uddhacca kukkuccassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya ati
translated: this is a condition for the arising of unarisen agitation and worry, and for the increase and expansion of arisen agitation and worry” .

original: Apica cha dhammā uddhaccakukkuccassa pahānāya saṃvattanti – bahussutatā, paripucchakatā,
analyzed: apica cha dhammā uddhacca kukkuccassa pahānāya saṃvattanti bahu ssuta tā paripucchaka tā
translated: Besides, six things lead to the abandoning of agitation and worry: much learning, questioning,

analyzed: vinaye pakataññu tā vuḍḍha sevi tā kalyāṇa mitta tā bāhu saccena api hi
translated: readiness in the Discipline, attendance on elders, good friendship, and suitable talk. For when one has learned much

analyzed: ekam vā dve vā tayaḥ vā cattāraḥ vā pañca vā nikāye pāḷi vasena ca attha vasena ca uggaṇhantassa api
translated: and has taken up the mnemonic scriptures with their associated teachings, then either by learning one or two or three or four or five Collections as texts or by learning the whole of the nine-factored Dhamma,

original: uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīyati. Kappiyākappiyaparipucchābahulassāpi, vinayapaññattiyaṃ
analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccam pahīyati kappiya akappiya paripucchā bahulassa api vinaya paññattiyam
translated: agitation and worry are abandoned. And when one is ready in the Discipline,
