translated: whether he gets alms or not, he is a bhikkhu. The word bhikkhu is a derivation from the word bhikkhā.

original: bhikkhūti attho. Bhikkhācariyaṃ ajjhupagatoti buddhādīhi ajjhupagataṃ bhikkhācariyaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu iti atthaḥ bhikkhā cariyam ajjhupagataḥ ti buddha ādīhi ajjhupagatam bhikkhā cariyam
translated: The meaning is: one who has undertaken the life of one who begs. He has undertaken the life of one who begs: the life of one who begs has been undertaken by the Enlightened One and the rest.

original: ajjhupagatattā bhikkhācariyaṃ ajjhupagato nāma. Yo hi koci appaṃ vā mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ
analyzed: ajjhupagata ttā bhikkhā cariyam ajjhupagataḥ nāma yaḥ hi koci appam vā mahantam vā bhogakkhandham
translated: He is called one who has undertaken the life of one who begs because he has undertaken it. For whoever, whether it be little or much,

original: pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, kasigorakkhādīhi jīvitakappanaṃ hitvā liṅgasampaṭicchaneneva
analyzed: pahāya agārasmaā anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ kasi gorakkha ādīhi jīvita kappanam hitvā liṅga sampaṭicchanena iva
translated: has abandoned the mass of his possessions and has gone forth from the home life into homelessness, and has given up the means of livelihood based on deceit, etc.,

original: bhikkhācariyaṃ ajjhupagatoti bhikkhu. Parappaṭibaddhajīvikattā vā vihāramajjhe kājabhattaṃ🔽bhuñjamānopi bhikkhācariyaṃ ajjhupagatoti bhikkhu. Piṇḍiyālopabhojanaṃ nissāya pabbajjāya
analyzed: bhikkhācariyam ajjhupagataḥ ti bhikkhu para paṭibaddha jīvika ttā vā vihāra majjhe kāja bhattam  bhuñjamānaḥ api bhikkhācariyam ajjhupagataḥ ti bhikkhu piṇḍiyāla upabhojanam nissāya pabbajjāya
translated: and has undertaken the life of one who begs merely by accepting the distinguishing marks of a bhikkhu, is called a bhikkhu. Or alternatively, he is a bhikkhu because he has undertaken the life of one who begs since he has gone forth by generating the aspiration for the going forth that has as its support the life of one who begs,🔽even though he eats in the midst of the community the food given by the state or by a guild, etc.

original: ussāhajātattā vā bhikkhācariyaṃ ajjhupagatoti bhikkhu.
analyzed: ussāha jāta ttā vā bhikkhācariyam ajjhupagataḥ ti bhikkhu
translated: Or he is a bhikkhu because he has undertaken the life of one who begs since he has gone forth by generating the aspiration for the going forth that has as its support the life of one who begs by gleaning and scraps,

original: Agghaphassavaṇṇabhedena bhinnaṃ paṭaṃ dhāretīti bhinnapaṭadharo. Tattha satthakacchedanena
analyzed: aggha phassa vaṇṇa bhedena bhinnam paṭam dhāreti iti bhinna paṭadharaḥ tattha satthaka chedanena
translated: He wears a robe that is cut up, that is, divided, by the price, the touch, or the colour.🔽Herein, the division by price should be understood as follows.

original: agghabhedo veditabbo. Sahassagghanakopi hi paṭo satthakena khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ chinno
analyzed: aggha bhedaḥ veditabbaḥ sahassa gghanakaḥ api hi paṭaḥ satthakena khaṇḍākhaṇḍikam chinnaḥ
translated: A robe worth a thousand coins, if cut up into pieces by a knife,

original: bhinnaggho hoti, purimagghato upaḍḍhampi na agghati. Suttasaṃsibbanena phassabhedo
analyzed: bhinnagghaḥ hoti purimagghataḥ upaḍḍham pi na agghati sutta saṃsibbanena phassa bhedaḥ
translated: is divided by price, for it is not worth even half its former price.🔽The division by touch should be understood as follows.

original: veditabbo. Sukhasamphassopi hi paṭo suttehi saṃsibbito bhinnaphasso hoti, kharasamphassataṃ
analyzed: veditabbaḥ sukha samphassaḥ api hi paṭaḥ suttehi saṃsibbitaḥ bhinna phassaḥ hoti khara samphassa tam
translated: A robe of pleasant touch, if sewn with strings,🔽becomes divided by touch, for it acquires a harsh touch.

original: pāpuṇāti. Sūcimalādīhi vaṇṇabhedo veditabbo. Suparisuddhopi hi paṭo sūcikammato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: pāpuṇāti sūci mala ādīhi vaṇṇa bhedaḥ veditabbaḥ su parisuddhaḥ api hi paṭaḥ sūci kammataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: The division by colour should be understood as follows.

original: sūcimalena, hatthasedamalajallikādīhi, avasāne rajanakappakaraṇehi ca bhinnavaṇṇo
analyzed: sūci malena hattha seda mala jallikā ādīhi avasāne rajana kappa karaṇehi ca bhinna vaṇṇaḥ
translated: A robe that is quite pure, if it is dyed with indigo and so on,🔽becomes divided by colour, for it loses its original colour.

original: hoti, pakativaṇṇaṃ vijahati. Evaṃ tīhākārehi bhinnapaṭadhāraṇato bhinnapaṭadharoti
analyzed: hoti pakati vaṇṇam vijahati evam tīhā ākārehi bhinna paṭa dhāraṇataḥ
translated: So he is called a “wearer of cut robes” because he wears a robe that is cut up in these three ways.

original: bhikkhu. Gihīvatthavisabhāgānaṃ vā kāsāvānaṃ dhāraṇamatteneva bhinnapaṭadharoti bhikkhu.
analyzed: bhikkhu gihī vattha visabhāgānam vā kāsāvānam dhāraṇa mattena iva bhinna paṭa dharoti bhikkhu
translated: Or alternatively, he is a “wearer of cut robes” because he wears the yellow robes that are unlike the lay people’s robes, merely by wearing which he is called a bhikkhu.

original: Bhindati pāpake akusale dhammeti bhikkhu. Sotāpattimaggena pañca kilese bhindatīti🔽bhikkhu. Sakadāgāmimaggena cattāro, anāgāmimaggena cattāro, arahattamaggena aṭṭha🔽kilese bhindatīti bhikkhu. Ettāvatā cattāro maggaṭṭhā dassitā. Bhinnattāti iminā
analyzed: bhindati pāpake akusale dhamme ti bhikkhu sotāpatti maggena pañca kilese bhindati iti  bhikkhu sakadāgāmi maggena cattāraḥ anāgāmi maggena cattāraḥ arahatta maggena aṭṭha  kilese bhindati iti bhikkhu ettāvatā cattāro maggaṭṭhāḥ dassitāḥ bhinna ttā ati iminā
translated: He breaks up evil, unprofitable ideas, thus he is a bhikkhu. He breaks up five defilements by means of the Stream-Entry Path,🔽thus he is a bhikkhu. He breaks up four by means of the Once-Return Path, four by means of the Non-Return Path, and eight by means of the Arahant Path,🔽thus he is a bhikkhu. And at this point the four kinds of path-level have been demonstrated. By the word “broken up”🔽

original: pana cattāro phalaṭṭhā. Sotāpanno hi sotāpattimaggena pañca kilese bhinditvā ṭhito.🔽Sakadāgāmī sakadāgāmimaggena cattāro, anāgāmī anāgāmimaggena cattāro, arahā arahattamaggena🔽aṭṭha kilese bhinditvā ṭhito. Evamayaṃ catubbidho phalaṭṭho bhinnattā pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ
analyzed: pana cattāro phala ṭṭhā sotāpannaḥ hi sotāpatti maggena pañca kilese bhinditvā ṭhitaḥ  sakadāgāmī sakadāgāmi maggena cattāraḥ anāgāmī anāgāmi maggena cattāraḥ arahā arahatta maggena  aṭṭha kilese bhinditvā ṭhitaḥ evam ayam catubbidhaḥ phala ṭṭhaḥ bhinnattā pāpakānam akusalānam
translated: He breaks up evil, unprofitable ideas, thus he is a bhikkhu. He breaks up five defilements by means of the Stream Entry Path, thus he is a bhikkhu. He breaks up four by means of the Once-Return Path, four by means of the Non-Return Path, and eight by means of the Adept’s Path, thus he is a bhikkhu. And in this way the four fruitions of the paths are shown. But by “having broken up” he is a bhikkhu in the sense of having stood by breaking up the five defilements by means of the Stream Entry Path.

original: dhammānaṃ bhikkhu nāma.
analyzed: dhammānam bhikkhu nāma
translated: The Once-Returner has stood by breaking up four by means of the Once-Return Path, the Non-Returner has stood by breaking up four by means of the Non-Return Path, and the Adept has stood by breaking up eight by means of the Adept’s Path. So this bhikkhu is one who has stood by breaking up evil, unprofitable ideas, in this way he is a bhikkhu.

original: Odhiso kilesānaṃ pahānāti ettha dve odhī – maggodhi ca kilesodhi ca. Odhi nāma sīmā,
analyzed: odhiso kilesānam pahānāti ettha dve odhī maggodhi ca kilesodhi ca odhi nāma sīmā
translated: By the abandoning of fetters by analysis: here there are two kinds of analysis, namely path-analysis and defilement-analysis. Analysis is a boundary,

original: mariyādā. Tattha sotāpanno maggodhinā odhiso kilesānaṃ pahānā bhikkhu. Tassa hi catūsu
analyzed: mariyādā tattha sotāpannaḥ magga udhinā odhisaḥ kilesānam pahānā bhikkhu tassa hi catūsu
translated: is the boundary. Herein, one who has entered the stream is a bhikkhu who has abandoned defilements by means of the path of a stream-enterer. For he has abandoned the five lower fetters,

original: maggesu ekeneva odhinā kilesā pahīnā, na sakalena maggacatukkena. Sakadāgāmīanāgāmīsupi
analyzed: maggesu ekena iva odhinā kilesā pahīnā na sakalena magga catukkena sakadāgāmī anāgāmīsu pi
translated: Herein, one who has entered upon the way to the fruit of stream-entry is a bhikkhu by virtue of the abandoning of defilements by means of the path. For his defilements are abandoned by means of one of the four paths, not by means of the whole set of four paths. The same method applies in the cases of the once-returner and the non-returner.

original: eseva nayo. Sotāpanno ca kilesodhināpi odhiso kilesānaṃ pahānā bhikkhu. Tassa hi🔽pahātabbakilesesu odhināva kilesā pahīnā, na sabbena sabbaṃ. Arahā pana anodhisova
analyzed: esa iva nayo sotāpannaḥ ca kilesa udhinā api odhiso kilesānam pahānā bhikkhu tassa hi  pahātabba kilesesu odhinā ava kilesāḥ pahīnāḥ na sabbena sabbam arahā pana
translated: And one who has entered upon the way to the fruit of stream-entry is also a bhikkhu by virtue of the abandoning of defilements by means of the path of seeing. For his defilements are abandoned by means of the path of seeing, not by means of the path of development.

original: kilesānaṃ pahānā bhikkhu. Tassa hi maggacatukkena anodhināva kilesā pahīnā, na ekāya🔽maggasīmāya. Pahātabbakilesesu ca anodhisova kilesā pahīnā. Ekāpi hi kilesasīmā ṭhitā
analyzed: kilesānam pahānā bhikkhu tassa hi magga catukkena anodhinā ava kilesāḥ pahīnāḥ na ekāya  magga sīmāya pahātabba kilesesu ca kilesāḥ pahīnāḥ ekā api hi kilesa sīmā ṭhitā
translated: But the Arahant is a bhikkhu by virtue of the abandoning of defilements without having entered upon a way. For his defilements are abandoned by means of the whole set of four paths, not by means of one path only. And in the case of the defilements to be abandoned by the path of development, he is a bhikkhu by virtue of the abandoning of defilements without having entered upon a way. For he has abandoned all the defilements without leaving any of them left to be abandoned by the path of development.

original: nāma natthi. Evaṃ so ubhayathāpi anodhiso kilesānaṃ pahānā bhikkhu.
analyzed: nāma natthi evam so ubhayathā api anodhisaḥ kilesānam pahānā bhikkhu
translated: And he is a bhikkhu by virtue of the abandoning of defilements without having entered upon a way in the case of the defilements to be abandoned by the path of seeing. For he has abandoned all the defilements without leaving any of them left to be abandoned by the path of seeing. For there is no such thing as a single defilement left to be abandoned by the path of seeing. So he is a bhikkhu by virtue of the abandoning of defilements without having entered upon a way in both instances.

original: Sekkhoti puthujjanakalyāṇakena saddhiṃ satta ariyā. Tisso sikkhā sikkhantīti sekkhā.
analyzed: sekkho ti puthujjana kalyāṇakena saddhim satta ariyā tisso sikkhā sikkhanti iti sekkhā
translated: “Learner” : the seven noble persons together with the good worldling. They are learners because they learn what ought to be learned.

original: Tesu yo koci sekkho bhikkhuti veditabbo. Na sikkhatīti asekkho. Sekkhadhamme atikkamma
analyzed: tesu yaḥ koci sekkhaḥ bhikkhuti veditabbaḥ na sikkhati iti asekkhaḥ sekkha dhamme atikkamma
translated: Any one of these who is a bhikkhu should be understood as a “learner.” One who does not train is a “non-learner.”

original: aggaphale ṭhito tato uttari sikkhitabbābhāvato khīṇāsavo asekkhoti vuccati. Avaseso
analyzed: agga phale ṭhito tatas uttari sikkhitabba abhāvataḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ asekkho ti vuccati avasesaḥ
translated: One who has gone beyond the states of the learner and is established in the supreme fruit is called a “non-learner” because he has no more training to do.

original: puthujjanabhikkhu tisso sikkhā neva sikkhati, na sikkhitvā ṭhitoti nevasekkhanāsekkhoti veditabbo.
analyzed: puthujjana bhikkhu tissaḥ sikkhāḥ na iva sikkhati na sikkhitvā ṭhitaḥ ti nevasekkhanāsekkho ti veditabbo
translated: The remaining bhikkhu, who is an ordinary man, is neither training nor established in training; he should be understood as neither a learner nor a non-learner.

original: Sīlaggaṃ samādhiggaṃ paññaggaṃ vimuttagganti idaṃ aggaṃ patvā ṭhitattā aggo bhikkhu🔽nāma. Bhadroti apāpako. Kalyāṇaputhujjanādayo hi yāva arahā tāva bhadrena sīlena
analyzed: sīla ggam samādhi ggam paññaggam vimutta ggam ti idam aggam patvā ṭhita ttā aggaḥ bhikkhu  nāma bhadroti apāpakaḥ kalyāṇa puthujjana ādayaḥ hi arahā tāva bhadrena sīlena
translated: The bhikkhu who is called “foremost” is so called because he is established in the foremost position, that is, in the foremost position of virtue, concentration, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom.

original: samādhinā paññāya vimuttiyā vimuttiñāṇadassanena ca samannāgatattā bhadro bhikkhūti🔽saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti. Maṇḍo bhikkhūti pasanno bhikkhu; sappimaṇḍo viya anāvilo vippasannoti
analyzed: samādhinā paññāya vimuttiyāḥ vimutti ñāṇa dassanena ca samannāgata ttā bhadraḥ bhikkhu iti  saṅkhyam gacchanti maṇḍaḥ bhikkhu iti pasannaḥ bhikkhu sappi maṇḍaḥ viya anāvilaḥ vippasannaḥ ti
translated: The bhikkhu who is called “good” is so called because he is endowed with the good things of virtue, concentration, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom.

original: attho. Sāroti tehiyeva sīlasārādīhi samannāgatattā, nīlasamannāgamena nīlo paṭo viya,
analyzed: attho sāro ti tehiyeva sīla sāra ādīhi samannāgata ttā nīla samannāgamena nīlaḥ paṭaḥ viya
translated: The bhikkhu who is called “radiant” is so called because he is radiant with the radiance of faith, like a cloth radiant with saffron.🔽The bhikkhu who is called “firm” is so called because he is endowed with the firmness of virtue, concentration, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom, like a cloth that is firm with the firmness of flax.

original: sāro bhikkhūti veditabbo. Vigatakilesapheggubhāvato vā khīṇāsavova sāroti veditabbo.🔽Tattha ca “bhindati pāpake akusale dhammeti bhikkhu, odhiso kilesānaṃ pahānā bhikkhu,
analyzed: sāraḥ bhikkhu iti veditabbaḥ vigata kilesa pheggu bhāvataḥ vā khīṇa āsavaḥ uva sāraḥ ti veditabbo  tattha ca bhindati pāpake akusale dhamme iti bhikkhu odhisaḥ kilesānaṃ pahānā bhikkhu
translated: “Worthy” should be understood as “one who has destroyed the corruptions” .

original: sekkho bhikkhū”ti imesu tīsu ṭhānesu satta sekkhā kathitā. “Bhinnattā pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ🔽dhammānanti bhikkhu, anodhiso kilesānaṃ pahānā bhikkhu, asekkho bhikkhu, aggo bhikkhu,
analyzed: sekkhaḥ bhikkhu iti imesu tīsu ṭhānesu satta sekkhā kathitā bhinnattā pāpakānam akusalānam  dhammānanti bhikkhu anodhisaḥ kilesānaṃ pahānā bhikkhu asekkhaḥ bhikkhu aggaḥ bhikkhu
translated: And here in the three passages beginning, “He is a bhikkhu because he has split the head of the evil one, the unprofitable” , “He is a bhikkhu because he has split the head of the evil one, the unprofitable, by the abandoning of defilements” , and “He is a bhikkhu because he has split the head of the evil one, the unprofitable, by the abandoning of defilements” , seven kinds of trainers are mentioned.🔽In the five passages beginning, “He is a bhikkhu because he has split the head of the evil one, the unprofitable, by the abandoning of defilements” , only the corruption-free bhikkhu is mentioned.

original: maṇḍo bhikkhū”ti imesu pañcasu ṭhānesu khīṇāsavova kathito. “Nevasekkhanāsekkho”ti🔽ettha puthujjanova kathito. Sesaṭṭhānesu puthujjanakalyāṇako, satta sekkhā, khīṇāsavoti
analyzed: maṇḍaḥ bhikkhu iti imesu pañcasu ṭhānesu khīṇāsavaḥ uva kathitaḥ nevasekkha nāsekkhaḥ ti  ettha puthujjanaḥ eva kathito sesa ṭṭhānesu puthujjana kalyāṇako satta sekkhā khīṇa āsavo ti
translated: In the passage, “He is a bhikkhu because he is neither a trainer nor one beyond training” , only the worldling is mentioned.

original: ime sabbepi kathitā.
analyzed: ime sabbe api kathitā
translated: In the remaining passages all these are mentioned: the worldling of virtue, the seven kinds of trainers, and the corruption-free bhikkhu.

original: Evaṃ samaññādīhi bhikkhuṃ dassetvā idāni upasampadāvasena dassetuṃ samaggena saṅghenātiādimāha.
analyzed: evam samaññā ādīhi bhikkhum dassetvā idāni upasampadā vasena dassetum samaggena saṅghena ati ādim āha
translated: Having thus shown the bhikkhu by means of the synonyms beginning with “agreement,” he now said, “By a unanimous Order” in order to show him by means of the higher ordination.

original: Tattha samaggena saṅghenāti sabbantimena paricchedena pañcavaggakaraṇīye kamme yāvatikā🔽bhikkhū kammappattā, tesaṃ āgatattā chandārahānaṃ chandassa āhaṭattā sammukhībhūtānañca🔽appaṭikkosanato ekasmiṃ kamme samaggabhāvaṃ upagatena. Ñatticatutthenāti tīhi anussāvanāhi🔽ekāya ca ñattiyā kātabbena. Kammenāti dhammikena vinayakammena. Akuppenāti vatthuñattianussāvanasīmāparisasampattisampannattā
analyzed: tattha samaggena saṅghena ati sabbantimena paricchedena pañcavagga karaṇīye kamme yāvatikā  bhikkhū kamma ppattā tesam āgata ttā chanda arahānam chandassa āhaṭa ttā sammukhībhūtānam ca  a paṭikkosanataḥ ekasmim kamme samagga bhāvam upagatena ñatti catutthena ati tīhi anussāvanāhi  ekāya ca ñattiyā kātabbena kammena ati dhammikena vinaya kammena akuppena ati vatthu ñatti anussāvana sīmā parisa sampatti sampanna ttā
translated: Herein, with a unanimous Order: with an Order that has become unanimous in the sense of having come together in one resolution for a transaction that requires the formation of a quorum of five or more according to the size of the transaction,🔽and in the sense of the consent of those who are present having been brought about and of those who are not present not being transgressed.🔽With a transaction requiring one motion and one announcement: with a transaction that is one that should be done by one motion and one announcement.🔽With a transaction that is irreversible: with a transaction that is irreversible, that is, that should not be transgressed, in the sense of the completeness of the ground, the announcement, the territory, and the assembly.

original: akopetabbataṃ appaṭikkositabbataṃ upagatena. Ṭhānārahenāti kāraṇārahena satthusāsanārahena.
analyzed: a kopetabbatam appaṭikkositabbatam upagatena ṭhāna arahena ati kāraṇa arahena satthu sāsana arahena
translated: Worthy of a seat: worthy of a reason, worthy of the Master’s Dispensation.

original: Upasampanno nāma uparibhāvaṃ samāpanno, pattoti attho. Bhikkhubhāvo hi uparibhāvo.
analyzed: upasampannaḥ nāma upari bhāvam samāpannaḥ patto ti attho bhikkhu bhāvaḥ hi upari bhāvaḥ
translated: One who has been initiated: one who has reached the higher estate, the meaning is, who has obtained it. For the state of a bhikkhu is the higher estate.

original: Tañcesa yathāvuttena kammena samāpannattā upasampannoti vuccati. Etena yā imā ehibhikkhūpasampadā,
analyzed: tat ca isa yathā vuttena kammena samāpanna ttā upasampannaḥ ti vuccati etena yā imā ehi bhikkhu upasampadā
translated: And because he has reached that by means of the transaction described in the way already stated, he is called “one who has been initiated.” By this it is shown that the “initiation by come bhikkhuship” and the “initiation by invitation to come” are one and the same.

original: saraṇāgamanūpasampadā, ovādapaṭiggahaṇūpasampadā, pañhabyākaraṇūpasampadā, garudhammapaṭiggahaṇūpasampadā,🔽dūtenūpasampadā, aṭṭhavācikūpasampadā, ñatticatutthakammūpasampadāti aṭṭha upasampadā🔽vuttā, tāsaṃ ñatticatutthakammūpasampadā, dūtenūpasampadā, aṭṭhavācikūpasampadāti
analyzed: saraṇa āgamana upasampadā ovāda paṭiggahaṇa upasampadā pañha byākaraṇa upasampadā garu dhamma paṭiggahaṇa upasampadā  dūtena upasampadā aṭṭha vācikūpasampadā ñatti catuttha kammūpasampadā ati aṭṭha upasampadā  vuttā tāsam ñatti catuttha kamma upasampadā dūtena upasampadā aṭṭha vācikūpasampadā ti
translated: Ordination by going for refuge and by the undertaking of the precepts, ordination by answering questions, ordination by giving answers, ordination by undertaking the training precepts,🔽ordination by messenger, ordination by eight announcements, ordination by a resolution of the Sangha consisting of a motion and one announcement.

original: imā tissova thāvarā. Sesā buddhe dharamāneyeva ahesuṃ. Tāsu upasampadāsu imasmiṃ
analyzed: imā tissaḥ uva thāvarā sesāḥ buddhe ahesum tāsu upasampadāsu imasmin
translated: Of these eight kinds of ordination, three are permanent: ordination by a resolution of the Sangha consisting of a motion and one announcement, ordination by a resolution of the Sangha consisting of a motion and three announcements, and ordination by messenger. The other five were only valid during the time of the Buddha.

original: ṭhāne ayaṃ ñatticatutthakammūpasampadāva adhippetā.
analyzed: ṭhāne ayam adhippetā
translated: Of these kinds of ordination, it is ordination by a resolution of the Sangha consisting of a motion and one announcement that is referred to here.

original: 511. Pātimokkhasaṃvaraniddese pātimokkhanti sikkhāpadasīlaṃ. Tañhi, yo naṃ pāti rakkhati,
analyzed: pātimokkha saṃvara niddese pātimokkham ti sikkhāpada sīlam tat hi yaḥ nam pāti rakkhati
translated: In the description of the restraint by the Pāṭimokkha, “Pāṭimokkha” is the virtue of the training precepts. For one who observes it guards it,

original: taṃ mokkheti mocayati āpāyikādīhi dukkhehi, tasmā pātimokkhanti vuttaṃ. Sīlaṃ patiṭṭhātiādīni
analyzed: tam mokkha iti mocayati āpāyika ādīhi dukkhehi tasmā pātimokkham ti vuttam sīlam patiṭṭhā ti ādīni
translated: it frees him from the suffering of the states of loss, and so on. That is why it is called the Pāṭimokkha. “The virtue is established” and so on are synonyms for it.

original: tasseva vevacanāni. Tattha sīlanti kāmañcetaṃ saha kammavācāpariyosānena ijjhanakassa
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanāni tattha sīlanti saha kamma vācā pariyosānena ijjhanakassa
translated: Herein, virtue is successful for one who is successful in the observance of the training precepts.

original: pātimokkhassa vevacanaṃ, evaṃ santepi dhammato etaṃ sīlaṃ nāma pāṇātipātādīhi vā🔽viramantassa vattappaṭipattiṃ vā pūrentassa cetanādayo dhammā veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ
analyzed: pātimokkhassa vevacanam evam sante pi dhammataḥ etam sīlam nāma pāṇa atipāta ādīhi vā  viramantassa vatta paṭipattim vā pūrentassa cetanā ādayaḥ dhammāḥ veditabbāḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: And it is a synonym for the Pāṭimokkha.

original: paṭisambhidāyaṃ “kiṃ sīla”nti? Cetanā sīlaṃ, cetasikaṃ sīlaṃ, saṃvaro sīlaṃ, avītikkamo sīla”nti.
analyzed: paṭisambhidā ayam kim sīlanti cetanā sīlam cetasikam sīlam saṃvaraḥ sīlam a vītikkamaḥ sīlanti
translated: But even so, it should be understood as the states of consciousness and its concomitants in one who abstains from killing living things, etc., or in one who fulfils the practice of the duties. For this is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “What is virtue? The volition of refraining is virtue; the mental factor of refraining is virtue; restraint is virtue; non- transgression is virtue” .

original: Tattha cetanā sīlaṃ nāma pāṇātipātādīhi vā viramantassa vattapaṭipattiṃ vā pūrentassa🔽cetanā. Cetasikaṃ sīlaṃ nāma pāṇātipātādīhi viramantassa virati. Apica cetanā sīlaṃ
analyzed: tattha cetanā sīlam nāma pāṇātipāta ādīhi vā viramantassa vatta paṭipattim vā pūrentassa  cetanā cetasikam sīlam nāma pāṇātipāta ādīhi viramantassa virati apica cetanā sīlam
translated: Herein, the volition of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc., or in one who fulfils the practice of the duties.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc. Moreover, the volition of refraining is virtue in one who abandons killing living things, etc.;🔽the mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.

original: nāma pāṇātipātādīni pajahantassa satta kammapathacetanā. Cetasikaṃ sīlaṃ nāma “abhijjhaṃ🔽pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharatī”tiādinā nayena saṃyuttamahāvagge vuttā anabhijjhāabyāpādasammādiṭṭhidhammā.
analyzed: nāma pāṇa atipāta ādīni pajahantassa satta kamma patha cetanā cetasikam sīlam nāma abhijjham 🔽pahāya vigata abhijjhena cetasā viharati iti ādinā nayena saṃyutta mahāvagge vuttāḥ anabhijjhā abyāpāda sammādiṭṭhi dhammā
translated: The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.🔽The mental factor of refraining is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc.

original: Saṃvaro sīlanti ettha pañcavidhena saṃvaro veditabbo – pātimokkhasaṃvaro, satisaṃvaro,
analyzed: saṃvaro sīlanti ettha pañcavidhena saṃvaraḥ veditabbo pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ sati saṃvaro
translated: Herein, restraint should be understood as fivefold: restraint by the Pātimokkha, restraint by mindfulness,

original: ñāṇasaṃvaro, khantisaṃvaro, vīriyasaṃvaroti. Tassa nānākaraṇaṃ visuddhimagge vuttaṃ.🔽Avītikkamo sīlanti samādiṇṇasīlassa kāyikavācasiko avītikkamo. Ettha ca saṃvarasīlaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa saṃvaro khanti saṃvaro vīriya saṃvaro ti tassa nānākaraṇam visuddhi magge vuttam  avītikkamaḥ sīlanti samādiṇṇa sīlassa kāyika vācasikaḥ avītikkamaḥ ettha ca saṃvara sīlam
translated: restraint by knowledge, restraint by patience, and restraint by energy. The difference between these kinds of restraint is given in the Visuddhimagga .🔽Non-transgression is the non-transgression of one who has undertaken the precepts of virtue. Herein, restraint of the mind is virtue as restraint;

original: avītikkamasīlanti idameva nippariyāyato sīlaṃ; cetanā sīlaṃ cetasikaṃ sīlanti pariyāyato sīlanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: avītikkama sīlanti idam eva nippariyāyataḥ sīlam cetanā sīlam cetasikam sīlanti pariyāyataḥ sīlanti veditabbam
translated: non-transgression of the precepts of virtue is virtue as non-transgression. But in the ultimate sense, volition is virtue; virtue is mental; virtue is a state of consciousness.

original: Yasmā pana pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlena bhikkhu sāsane patiṭṭhāti nāma, tasmā taṃ ‘patiṭṭhā’ti
analyzed: yasmā pana pātimokkha saṃvara sīlena bhikkhu sāsane patiṭṭhāti nāma tasmā tam patiṭṭhāti
translated: But since it is by means of virtue as restraint by the Pātimokkha that a bhikkhu is established in the Dispensation, it is called “the foundation” .

original: vuttaṃ; patiṭṭhahati vā ettha bhikkhu, kusaladhammā eva vā ettha patiṭṭhahantīti
analyzed: vuttam patiṭṭhahati vā ettha bhikkhu kusala dhammāḥ eva vā ettha patiṭṭhahanti iti
translated: Or alternatively, a bhikkhu is established in it, or wholesome states are established in it,

original: patiṭṭhā. Ayamattho –
analyzed: patiṭṭhā ayam atthaḥ
translated: therefore it is the foundation. The meaning is this:🔽“The wise one, established well in virtue,

original: “Sīle patiṭṭhāya naro sapañño, cittaṃ paññañca bhāvayaṃ;
analyzed: sīle patiṭṭhāya naro sa pañño cittam paññam ca bhāvayaṃ
translated: Developing consciousness and understanding,🔽The ardent one, the watchful bhikkhu,

original: Ātāpī nipako bhikkhu, so imaṃ vijaṭaye jaṭa”nti ca. ;
analyzed: ātāpī nipakaḥ bhikkhu saḥ imam vijaṭaye jaṭanti ca
translated: Will surely disentangle this tangle” .

original: “Patiṭṭhā, mahārāja, sīlaṃ sabbesaṃ kusaladhammāna”nti ca “sīle patiṭṭhitassa kho, mahārāja, sabbe kusalā dhammā na parihāyantī”ti ca ādisuttavasena veditabbo.
analyzed: patiṭṭhā mahā rāja sīlam sabbesam kusala dhammānam ti ca sīle patiṭṭhitassa kho mahā rāja sabbe kusalāḥ dhammāḥ na parihāyanti iti ca ādi sutta vasena veditabbaḥ
translated: “Morality is the foundation, sire, of all profitable states” , and “When a man is established in morality, sire, all profitable states do not decline” .

original: Tadetaṃ pubbuppattiatthena ādi. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: tat etam pubbuppatti atthena ādi vuttam pi ca itam
translated: And this is the meaning of “beginning” in the sense of prior condition. For this is said:

original: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, uttiya, ādimeva visodhehi kusalesu dhammesu. Ko cādi kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ? Sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ diṭṭhi ca ujukā”ti.
analyzed: tasmā ati ha tvam uttiye ādim eva visodhehi kusalesu dhammesu kaḥ ca ādi kusalānam dhammānam sīlam ca su visuddham diṭṭhi ca ujukā ati
translated: “Therefore, Udayin, purify the beginning of wholesome states. And what is the beginning of wholesome states? Right view is the beginning of wholesome states” .

original: Yathā hi nagaravaḍḍhakī nagaraṃ māpetukāmo paṭhamaṃ nagaraṭṭhānaṃ sodheti, tato aparabhāge
analyzed: yathā hi nagara vaḍḍhakī nagaram mā apetu kāmaḥ paṭhamam nagara ṭṭhānam sodheti tatas apara bhāge
translated: Just as a town-planner, who wants to build a town, first of all clears the site for the town,

original: vīthicatukkasiṅghāṭakādiparicchedena vibhajitvā nagaraṃ māpeti; evameva yogāvacaro
analyzed: vīthi catukka siṅghāṭaka ādi paricchedena vibhajitvā nagaram mā āpeti evam eva yogāvacaraḥ
translated: and then, after dividing it up into streets and quarters, builds the town, so too the meditator

original: āditova sīlaṃ visodheti, tato aparabhāge samathavipassanāmaggaphalanibbānāni sacchikaroti.
analyzed: āditas va sīlam visodheti tatas apara bhāge samatha vipassanā magga phala nibbānāni sacchikaroti
translated: first of all purifies his morality, and then, after dividing it up into the jhānas, paths, fruits, and Nibbāna, he realizes them.

original: Yathā vā pana rajako paṭhamaṃ tīhi khārehi vatthaṃ dhovitvā parisuddhe vatthe yadicchakaṃ
analyzed: yathā vā pana rajakaḥ paṭhamam tīhi khārehi vattham dhovitvā parisuddhe vatthe yadicchakam
translated: Or just as a dyer first of all cleans the cloth thoroughly, and then dyes it with whatever colour he wishes,

original: raṅgajātaṃ upaneti; yathā vā pana cheko cittakāro rūpaṃ likhitukāmo āditova bhittiparikammaṃ
analyzed: raṅga jātam upaneti yathā vā pana chekaḥ cittakāraḥ rūpam likhitu kāmaḥ āditas va bhitti parikammam
translated: Just as a clever painter, wishing to paint a picture, first prepares his palette,

original: karoti, tato aparabhāge rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti; evameva yogāvacaro āditova sīlaṃ visodhetvā
analyzed: karoti tatas apara bhāge rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti evam eva yogāvacaraḥ āditas va sīlam visodhetvā
translated: and only later produces the picture, so too the meditator first purifies his virtue,

original: aparabhāge samathavipassanādayo dhamme sacchikaroti. Tasmā sīlaṃ “ādī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: apara bhāge samatha vipassanā ādayaḥ dhamme sacchikaroti tasmā sīlam ādi iti vuttam
translated: and only later realizes the states beginning with concentration. That is why virtue is called the “base.”

original: Tadetaṃ caraṇasarikkhatāya caraṇaṃ. Caraṇāti hi pādā vuccanti. Yathā hi chinnacaraṇassa🔽purisassa disaṃgamanābhisaṅkhāro na jāyati, paripuṇṇapādasseva jāyati; evameva yassa
analyzed: tat etam caraṇa sarikkhatāya caraṇam caraṇa ati hi pādāḥ vuccanti yathā hi chinna caraṇassa  purisassa disaṃgamana abhisaṅkhāraḥ na jāyati paripuṇṇa pādassa iva jāyati evam eva yassa
translated: And this virtue is called the “base” because it is the forerunner of the good states beginning with concentration, just as the foot is the forerunner of walking, and so on.🔽For just as a man whose foot is cut off cannot walk,🔽so too, when a man’s virtue is broken, his knowledge, which is like walking, does not occur.

original: sīlaṃ bhinnaṃ hoti khaṇḍaṃ aparipuṇṇaṃ, tassa nibbānagamanāya ñāṇagamanaṃ na sampajjati.🔽Yassa pana taṃ abhinnaṃ hoti akkhaṇḍaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ tassa nibbānagamanāya ñāṇagamanaṃ
analyzed: sīlam bhinnam hoti khaṇḍam a paripuṇṇam tassa nibbāna gamanāya ñāṇa gamanam na sampajjati  yassa pana tat abhinnam hoti akkhaṇḍam paripuṇṇam tassa nibbāna gamanāya ñāṇa gamanam
translated: But when a man’s virtue is unbroken, his knowledge occurs.

original: sampajjati. Tasmā sīlaṃ “caraṇa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sampajjati tasmā sīlam caraṇan ti vuttam
translated: That is why virtue is called the “base.”

original: Tadetaṃ saṃyamanavasena saṃyamo, saṃvaraṇavasena saṃvaro. Ubhayenāpi sīlasaṃyamo
analyzed: tat etam saṃyamana vasena saṃyamaḥ saṃvaraṇa vasena saṃvaraḥ ubhayena api sīla saṃyamaḥ
translated: This is restraint in the sense of restraining, in the sense of holding back, in the sense of keeping under control.🔽

original: ceva sīlasaṃvaro ca kathito. Vacanattho panettha saṃyameti vītikkamavipphandanaṃ,🔽puggalaṃ vā saṃyameti, vītikkamavasena tassa vipphandituṃ na detīti saṃyamo. Vītikkamassa
analyzed: ca iva sīla saṃvaro ca kathitaḥ vacana atthaḥ pana ittha saṃyama iti vītikkama vipphandanam  puggalam vā saṃyameti vītikkama vasena tassa vipphanditum na deti iti saṃyamaḥ vītikkamassa
translated: This is restraint in the sense of restraining, in the sense of restraining from transgression, and it is also restraint in the sense of restraining, in the sense of restraining by restraint. Both meanings are included in the expression “restraint of virtue” .

original: pavesanadvāraṃ saṃvarati pidahatītipi saṃvaro. Mokkhanti uttamaṃ mukhabhūtaṃ vā.🔽Yathā hi sattānaṃ catubbidho āhāro mukhena pavisitvā aṅgamaṅgāni pharati, evaṃ yoginopi
analyzed: pavesana dvāram saṃvarati pidahati iti pi saṃvaraḥ uttamam mukha bhūtam vā  yathā hi sattānam catubbidhaḥ āhāraḥ mukhena pavisitvā aṅgam aṅgāni pharati evam yoginaḥ api
translated: The meaning of the words is this: It restrains , i.e., it restrains the occurrence of transgression, or it restrains the person, i.e., it does not allow him to transgress. It restrains , i.e., it restrains, it closes, the door to the occurrence of transgression. It is the foremost , i.e., it is the best, the most excellent, the chief.

original: catubhūmakakusalaṃ sīlamukhena pavisitvā atthasiddhiṃ sampādeti. Tena vuttaṃ “mokkha”nti.
analyzed: catubhūmaka kusalam sīla mukhena pavisitvā attha siddhim sampādeti tena vuttam mokkha nti
translated: Just as the four kinds of nutriment enter the various limbs and bring them to growth when they have entered by way of the mouth, so too this virtue of the four grades brings success in the achievement of the various kinds of profitable ends when it has entered by way of the door of the mouth. Hence it is said: “It is the foremost .”

original: Pamukhe sādhūti pāmokkhaṃ; pubbaṅgamaṃ seṭṭhaṃ padhānanti attho. Kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ🔽samāpattiyāti catubhūmakakusalānaṃ paṭilābhatthāya pāmokkhaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ seṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: pamukhe sādhu iti pāmokkham pubbaṅgamam seṭṭham padhānanti attho kusalānam dhammānaṃ 🔽samāpattiyā ati catu bhūmaka kusalānam paṭilābha atthāya pāmokkham pubbaṅgamam seṭṭham
translated: It is the foremost , i.e., it is the best, the most excellent, the chief. It is the foremost , i.e., it is the best, the most excellent, the chief, the foremost, the leader, the forerunner, of profitable states.

original: padhānanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: padhānam ti veditabbam
translated: should be understood as the pre-eminent.

original: Kāyiko avītikkamoti tividhaṃ kāyasucaritaṃ. Vācasikoti catubbidhaṃ vacīsucaritaṃ.
analyzed: kāyikaḥ avītikkamaḥ tividham kāya su caritam vācasikaḥ iti catubbidham vacī su caritam
translated: The bodily non-transgression is the three kinds of good bodily conduct. The verbal is the four kinds of good verbal conduct.

original: Kāyikavācasikoti tadubhayaṃ. Iminā ājīvaṭṭhamakasīlaṃ pariyādāya dasseti. Saṃvutoti
analyzed: kāyika vācasikaḥ ti tat ubhayam iminā ājīva ṭhamaka sīlam pariyādāya dasseti saṃvutaḥ ti
translated: The bodily and verbal is both of these. By this he shows that he has mastered the virtue of the eighth factor of the rightnesses, namely, right livelihood.

original: pihito; saṃvutindriyo pihitindriyoti attho. Yathā hi saṃvutadvāraṃ gehaṃ “saṃvutagehaṃ
analyzed: pihitaḥ saṃvuta indriyaḥ pihita indriyaḥ ti atthaḥ yathā hi saṃvuta dvāram geham saṃvuta geham
translated: The restrained is the covered, the meaning being the covered faculties, the closed faculties. For just as a house with closed doors is called a “closed house,”

original: pihitageha”nti vuccati, evamidha saṃvutindriyo “saṃvuto”ti vutto. Pātimokkhasaṃvarenāti
analyzed: pihita gehanti vuccati evam idha saṃvut indriyo saṃvuto ti vutto pātimokkha saṃvarena ati
translated: a “covered house,” so here the one with covered faculties is called “restrained.”

original: pātimokkhena ca saṃvarena ca, pātimokkhasaṅkhātena vā saṃvarena. Upetotiādīni vuttatthāneva.
analyzed: pātimokkhena ca saṃvarena ca pātimokkha saṅkhātena vā saṃvarena upetaḥ iti ādīni vutta tthāni eva
translated: The restraint of the Pāṭimokkha is the restraint by the Pāṭimokkha or the restraint called the Pāṭimokkha. Endowed is as already explained.

original: 512. Iriyatītiādīhi sattahipi padehi pātimokkhasaṃvarasīle ṭhitassa bhikkhuno iriyāpathavihāro kathito.
analyzed: iriyati iti ādīhi sattahi api padehi pātimokkha saṃvara sīle ṭhitassa bhikkhuno iriyāpatha vihāro kathito
translated: The seven terms beginning with “walks” show the deportment and behavior of a bhikkhu who is established in the virtue of restraint by the Pāṭimokkha.

original: 513. Ācāragocaraniddese kiñcāpi bhagavā samaṇācaraṃ samaṇagocaraṃ kathetukāmo “ācāragocarasampannoti
analyzed: ācāra gocara niddese kiñca api bhagavā samaṇa ācaram samaṇa gocaram kathetu kāmaḥ ācāra gocara sampannaḥ ti
translated: In the description of conduct and resort, although the Blessed One was desirous of teaching the conduct of an ascetic and the resort of an ascetic, he said “endowed with conduct and resort”

original: atthi ācāro, atthi anācāro”ti padaṃ uddhari. Yathā pana maggakusalo puriso maggaṃ
analyzed: atthi ācāro atthi anācāro ti padam yathā pana magga kusalaḥ puriso maggaṃ
translated: Just as a man skilled in the way of a caravan,🔽when he has pointed out the way to a man who is in doubt about it,

original: acikkhanto ‘vāmaṃ muñca dakkhiṇaṃ gaṇhā’ti paṭhamaṃ muñcitabbaṃ sabhayamaggaṃ uppathamaggaṃ
analyzed: a cikkhantaḥ vāmam muñca dakkhiṇam gaṇhāti paṭhamam muñcitabbam sa bhaya maggam uppatha maggam
translated: first points out the wrong way, saying ‘This is not the way’, and then points out the right way, saying ‘This is the way’;

original: ācikkhati, pacchā gahetabbaṃ khemamaggaṃ ujumaggaṃ; evameva maggakusalapurisasadiso🔽dhammarājā paṭhamaṃ pahātabbaṃ buddhappaṭikuṭṭhaṃ anācāraṃ ācikkhitvā pacchā ācāraṃ
analyzed: ācikkhati pacchā gahetabbam khema maggam uju maggam evam eva magga kusala purisa sadisaḥ  dhamma rājā paṭhamam pahātabbam buddha paṭikuṭṭham anācāram ācikkhitvā pacchā ācāram
translated: so too the Blessed One, who is like a man skilled in the way of a caravan,

original: ācikkhitukāmo “tattha katamo anācāro”tiādimāha. Purisena hi ācikkhitamaggo sampajjeyya🔽vā na vā, tathāgatena ācikkhitamaggo apaṇṇako, indena vissaṭṭhaṃ vajiraṃ viya, avirajjhanako🔽nibbānanagaraṃyeva samosarati. Tena vuttaṃ – “puriso maggakusaloti kho, tissa, tathāgatassetaṃ
analyzed: ācikkhitu kāmaḥ tattha katamaḥ anācāraḥ ti ādim āha purisena hi ācikkhita maggaḥ sampajjeyya  vā na vā tathāgatena ācikkhita maggaḥ apaṇṇakaḥ indena vissaṭṭham vajiram viya a virajjhanakaḥ  nibbāna nagaram yeva samosarati tena vuttam puriso magga kusalaḥ ti kho tissa tathāgatassa etam
translated: first pointed out the wrong conduct that should be abandoned, saying ‘This is wrong conduct’, and then pointed out the right conduct that should be undertaken, saying ‘This is right conduct’.🔽For a way pointed out by a man might or might not be the right one,🔽but a way pointed out by a Perfect One is necessarily the right one, and it leads infallibly to the city of Nibbāna, like a ploughshare driven by the strength of a yoke of oxen.

original: adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā”ti.
analyzed: adhivacanam arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa ati
translated: That is why it is said: ‘The man skilled in the way of a caravan is a designation for the Tathāgata, accomplished and fully enlightened’ .

original: Yasmā vā sasīsaṃ nahānena pahīnasedamalajallikassa purisassa mālāgandhavilepanādivibhūsanavidhānaṃ🔽viya pahīnapāpadhammassa kalyāṇadhammasamāyogo sampannarūpo hoti, tasmā sedamalajallikkaṃ🔽viya pahātabbaṃ paṭhamaṃ anācāraṃ ācikkhitvā, pahīnasedamalajallikassa mālāgandhavilepanādivibhūsanavidhānaṃ
analyzed: yasmai vā sa sīsam nahānena pahīna seda mala jallikassa purisassa mālā gandha vilepana ādi vibhūsana vidhānam  viya pahīna pāpa dhammassa kalyāṇa dhamma samāyogaḥ sampanna rūpaḥ hoti tasmai sā idam alajallikkam  viya pahātabbam paṭhamam anācāram ācikkhitvā pahīna seda mala jallikassa mālā gandha vilepana ādi vibhūsana vidhānam
translated: Or just as the adorning of a man who has bathed and removed the dirt, sweat and stains from his body with garlands, scents, unguents, etc.,🔽is fitting, so too the yoking of good states to one who has removed evil states is fitting. So after first pointing out misconduct to be abandoned like the dirt, sweat and stains,

original: viya pacchā ācāraṃ ācikkhitukāmopi tattha katamo anācārotiādimāha. Tattha kāyiko
analyzed: viya pacchā ācāram ācikkhitu kāmaḥ api tattha katamaḥ anācāraḥ ti ādim āha tattha kāyiko
translated: he then said “What is misconduct? ” in order to point out good conduct to be undertaken like the adorning of one who has removed the dirt, sweat and stains. Herein, transgression by body is the three kinds of bodily misconduct;

original: vītikkamoti tividhaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ; vācasiko vītikkamoti catubbidhaṃ vacīduccaritaṃ;
analyzed: vītikkamoti tividham kāya duccaritam vācasikaḥ vītikkamo ti catubbidham vacī duccaritam
translated: transgression by speech is the four kinds of verbal misconduct;

original: kāyikavācasiko vītikkamoti tadubhayaṃ. Evaṃ ājīvaṭṭhamakasīlasseva vītikkamaṃ dassesi.
analyzed: kāyika vācasikaḥ vītikkamaḥ ti tat ubhayam evam ājīva ṭṭhamaka sīlassa iva vītikkamam dassesi
translated: transgression by body and speech is both of these. So he has shown transgression of the virtue consisting in the first eight rules of training.

original: Yasmā pana na kevalaṃ kāyavācāhi eva anācāraṃ ācarati, manasāpi ācarati eva, tasmā
analyzed: na kevalam eva anācāram ācarati manasā api ācarati eva tasmai
translated: But since one does not misbehave only by body and speech but also by mind,

original: taṃ dassetuṃ “sabbampi dussīlyaṃ anācāro”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha ekacciyaṃ anācāraṃ vibhajitvā
analyzed: tam dassetum sabbam pi dussīlyam anācāraḥ ti vuttam tattha ekacciyam anācāram vibhajitvā
translated: To show this, the Blessed One said: “All immorality is wrong conduct.”🔽Herein, in order to show a certain kind of wrong conduct, he said: “Here someone gives a gift of bamboo.”

original: dassento idhekacco veḷudānenātiādimāha. Tattha veḷudānenāti paccayahetukena veḷudānena.🔽Vihāre uṭṭhitañhi araññato vā āharitvā rakkhitagopitaṃ veḷuṃ ‘evaṃ me paccayaṃ dassantī’ti
analyzed: dassentaḥ idha ekaccaḥ veḷu dānena ati ādim āha tattha veḷu dānena ati paccaya hetukena veḷu dānena  vihāre uṭṭhitam hi araññataḥ vā āharitvā rakkhita gopitam veḷum evam me paccayam dassanti iti
translated: Herein, by a gift of bamboo is meant a gift of bamboo as a means of support.🔽For it is not allowable for a bhikkhu to give to his supporters bamboo that he has had brought from the forest and stored up, thinking, “In this way they will give me requisites.”

original: upaṭṭhākānaṃ dātuṃ na vaṭṭati. Evañhi jīvitaṃ kappento anesanāya micchājīvena jīvati.
analyzed: upaṭṭhākānam dātum na vaṭṭati evam hi jīvitam kappentaḥ an esanāya micchājīvena jīvati
translated: For by so doing he lives by a wrong means of livelihood, namely, by hoarding.

original: So diṭṭheva dhamme garahaṃ pāpuṇāti, samparāye ca apāyaparipūrako hoti. Attano puggalikaveḷuṃ🔽kulasaṅgahatthāya dadanto kuladūsakadukkaṭamāpajjati; parapuggalikaṃ theyyacittena🔽dadamāno bhaṇḍagghena kāretabbo. Saṅghikepi eseva nayo. Sace pana taṃ issaravatāya
analyzed: so diṭṭhā iva dhamme garaham pāpuṇāti samparāye ca apāya paripūrakaḥ hoti attanaḥ puggalika veḷum  kula saṅga hatthāya dadantaḥ kula dūsaka dukkaṭam āpajjati parapuggalikam theyya cittena  dadamānaḥ bhaṇḍagghena kāretabbo saṅghike pi esā iva nayaḥ sace pana tam issaravatāya
translated: He incurs blame in the present life and he fills up the future with suffering.🔽If he gives his own bamboo🔽for the sake of winning a family, he commits a defiling wrong-doing. If he gives another’s bamboo, he is to be dealt with for theft according to the value of the bamboo.

original: deti garubhaṇḍavissajjanamāpajjati.
analyzed: deti garu bhaṇḍa vissajjanam āpajjati
translated: The same method applies in the case of that belonging to the Community. But if he gives it as a favour, he commits a wrong-doing in giving away what is not his own to give.

original: Kataro pana veḷu garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti, kataro na hotīti? Yo tāva aropimo sayaṃjātako,
analyzed: kataraḥ pana hoti kataraḥ na hoti iti sayaṃjātako
translated: But which kind of bamboo is heavy goods and which is not?

original: so saṅghena paricchinnaṭṭhāneyeva garubhaṇḍaṃ, tato paraṃ na garubhaṇḍaṃ; ropitaṭṭhāne
analyzed: so saṅghena garu bhaṇḍam tatas param na garu bhaṇḍam ropita ṭṭhāne
translated: That which is planted by oneself is heavy goods only in the place defined by the Sangha. Beyond that it is not heavy goods.

original: sabbena sabbaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ. So pana pamāṇena paricchinno telanāḷippamāṇopi garubhaṇḍaṃ,
analyzed: sabbena sabbam garubhaṇḍam saḥ pana pamāṇena paricchinnaḥ garubhaṇḍam
translated: In the place where it is planted, all of it is heavy goods. But that is defined by its size. Even a bamboo shoot the size of a sesame stalk is heavy goods.

original: na tato heṭṭhā. Yassa pana bhikkhuno telanāḷiyā vā kattaradaṇḍena vā attho, tena
analyzed: na tatas heṭṭhā yassa pana bhikkhuno tela nāḷiyā vā kattaradaṇḍena vā attho tena
translated: It is not heavy goods if it is smaller than that. But if a bhikkhu needs a bamboo shoot for a sesame-oil tube or for a bamboo walking stick,

original: phātikammaṃ katvā gahetabbo. Phātikammaṃ tadagghanakaṃ vā atirekaṃ vā vaṭṭati, ūnakaṃ
analyzed: phāti kammam katvā gahetabbaḥ phāti kammam tad agghanakam vā atirekam vā vaṭṭati ūnakam
translated: he should get it by means of a transaction. A transaction is allowable for the price of that or more than that. It is not allowable for less.

original: na vaṭṭati. Hatthakammampi udakāharaṇamattaṃ vā appaharitakaraṇamattaṃ vā na vaṭṭati,🔽taṃ thāvaraṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭati. Tasmā pokkharaṇito vā paṃsuṃ uddharitvā sopānaṃ vā attharāpetvā
analyzed: na vaṭṭati hattha kammam pi udaka āharaṇa mattam vā appaharita karaṇa mattam vā na vaṭṭati  tam thāvaram kātum vaṭṭati tasmai pokkharaṇitaḥ vā paṃsum uddharitvā sopānam vā
translated: Manual work, such as carrying water or doing a little weeding, is not allowable.🔽But it is allowable to make it firm. Therefore it is allowable to dig up soil from a pond and to make a stairway or to level an uneven place and to take it. If it is taken without a transaction, it is allowable for one who lives there

original: visamaṭṭhānaṃ vā samaṃ katvā gahetuṃ vaṭṭati. Phātikammaṃ akatvā gahito tattha vasanteneva
analyzed: visama ṭṭhānam vā samam katvā gahetum vaṭṭati phāti kammam a katvā gahitaḥ tattha vasantena iva
translated: to use it.

original: paribhuñjitabbo; pakkamantena saṅghikaṃ katvā ṭhapetvā gantabbaṃ. Asatiyā gahetvā
analyzed: paribhuñjitabbaḥ pakkamantena saṅghikam katvā ṭhapetvā gantabbam asatiyā gahetvā
translated: He should use it. When he is going away, he should leave it in the Sangha’s ownership. If there is no one to tell, he should take it with him.

original: gatena yattha gato sarati, tato paccāharitabbo. Sace antarā bhayaṃ hoti, sampattavihare ṭhapetvā gantabbaṃ.
analyzed: gatena yattha gataḥ sarati tatas paccāharitabbo sace antarā bhayam hoti sampatta vihare ṭhapetvā gantabbam
translated: When he has gone, he should return it to the place where he got it. If there is danger on the way, he should leave it in the dwelling where he arrives.

original: Manussā vihāraṃ gantvā veḷuṃ yācanti. Bhikkhū ‘saṅghiko’ti dātuṃ na visahanti. Manussā
analyzed: manussāḥ vihāram gantvā veḷum yācanti bhikkhū saṅghikā uti dātum na visahanti manussā
translated: People come to the monastery and ask for bamboo. The monks, thinking it belongs to the Sangha, do not dare to give it.

original: punappunaṃ yācanti vā tajjenti vā. Tadā bhikkhūhi ‘daṇḍakammaṃ katvā gaṇhathā’ti🔽vattuṃ vaṭṭati; veḷudānaṃ nāma na hoti. Sace te daṇḍakammatthāya vāsipharasuādīni
analyzed: punappunam yācanti vā tajjenti vā tadā bhikkhūhi daṇḍa kammam katvā gaṇhatha ati  vattum vaṭṭati veḷudānam nāma na hoti sace te daṇḍa kammatthāya
translated: The people ask again and again or they complain. In that case the monks should be told to take it after doing the penalty.🔽Bamboo is not to be given. If they give a spade, a hatchet, or other tools,

original: vā khādanīyabhojanīyaṃ vā denti, gahetuṃ na vaṭṭati. Vinayaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “daḍḍhagehā🔽manussā gaṇhitvā gacchantā na vāretabbā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vā khādanīya bhojanīyam vā denti gahetum na vaṭṭati vinaya ṭṭha kathā ayam pana daḍḍha gehā  manussāḥ gaṇhitvā gacchantā na vāretabbā iti vuttam
translated: or food, it is not to be accepted. But in the Vinaya commentary it is said that people who are taking away a burnt house should not be stopped.

original: Sace saṅghassa veḷugumbe veḷudūsikā uppajjanti, taṃ akoṭṭāpentānaṃ veḷu nassati,
analyzed: sace saṅghassa veḷu gumbe veḷu dūsikā uppajjanti tam a koṭṭāpentānam veḷu nassati
translated: If the bamboo grove of the Sangha is damaged by bamboo disease, and the bamboo is dying because it is not being cut,

original: kiṃ kātabbanti? Bhikkhācāre manussānaṃ ācikkhitabbaṃ. Sace koṭṭetuṃ na icchanti ‘samabhāgaṃ
analyzed: kim kātabbanti bhikkhācāre manussānam ācikkhitabbam sace koṭṭetum na icchanti sama bhāgam
translated: What should be done? The alms-round should be announced to the people. If they do not want to cut, they should be told, “You will get an equal share.”

original: labhissathā’ti vattabbā; na icchantiyeva ‘dve koṭṭhāse labhissathā’ti vattabbā. Evampi🔽anicchantesu ‘naṭṭhena attho natthi, tumhākaṃ khaṇe sati daṇḍakammaṃ karissatha,
analyzed: labhissatha ati vattabbā na icchantiyā iva dve koṭṭhāse labhissatha ati vattabbā evam pi  an icchantesu naṭṭhena atthaḥ natthi tumhākam khaṇe sati daṇḍa kammam karissatha
translated: If they still do not want to, they should be told, “You will get two shares.”🔽If they still do not want to, they should be told, “We have no use for what is lost. If you have time, you can do the punishment work. Cut and take it.”

original: koṭṭetvā gaṇhathā’ti vattabbā; veḷudānaṃ nāma na hoti. Veḷugumbe aggimhi uṭṭhitepi,
analyzed: koṭṭetvā gaṇhatha ati vattabbā veḷu dānam nāma na hoti veḷu gumbe aggimhi uṭṭhite pi
translated: There is no such thing as a gift of bamboo. The same method applies even if a fire breaks out in a bamboo grove

original: udakena vuyhamānaveḷūsupi eseva nayo. Rukkhesupi ayameva kathāmaggo. Rukkho pana
analyzed: udakena vuyhamāna veḷūsu pi esa eva nayaḥ rukkhesu pi ayam eva kathā maggo rukkho pana
translated: or if the bamboo is being carried away by water. The same method applies to trees.

original: sūcidaṇḍakappamāṇo garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti. Saṅghike rukkhe koṭṭāpetvā saṅghaṃ anāpucchitvāpi
analyzed: sūci daṇḍa kappamāṇaḥ garubhaṇḍam hoti saṅghike rukkhe koṭṭāpetvā saṅgham an āpucchitvā api
translated: But a tree the size of a sugarcane stalk or a bamboo stalk is heavy goods. After cutting a tree belonging to the Sangha, one may build a dwelling belonging to the Sangha without informing the Sangha.

original: saṅghikaṃ āvāsaṃ kātuṃ labbhati. Vacanapathacchedanatthaṃ pana āpucchitvāva kātabbo.
analyzed: saṅghikam āvāsam kātum labbhati vacana patha chedana attham pana āpucchitvā ava kātabbaḥ
translated: But it should be built only after informing the Sangha, in order to avoid having to go back over the path.

original: Puggalikaṃ kātuṃ labbhati, na labbhatīti? Na labbhati. Hatthakammasīsena pana ekasmiṃ
analyzed: puggalikam kātum labbhati na labbhati iti na labbhati hattha kamma sīsena pana ekasmin
translated: Is it allowable to make it one’s own? It is not allowable. But if one has it cut by one’s own labor,

original: gehe mañcaṭṭhānamattaṃ labbhati, tīsu gehesu ekaṃ gehaṃ labhati. Sace dabbhasambhārā
analyzed: gehe mañcaṭṭhāna mattam labbhati tīsu gehesu ekam geham labhati sace dabbha sambhārā
translated: If there is room for a bed in a house, he gets one house in three. If the materials for the thatch are🔽the property of individuals and the land is the property of the Sangha, he gets one house in three. If the materials for the thatch and the land are

original: puggalikā honti, bhūmi saṅghikā, ekaṃ gehaṃ katvā samabhāgaṃ labhati, dvīsu gehesu🔽ekaṃ gehaṃ labhati. Saṅghikarukkhe saṅghikaṃ āvāsaṃ bādhente saṅghaṃ anāpucchā hāretuṃ
analyzed: puggalikāḥ honti bhūmi saṅghikāḥ ekam geham katvā sama bhāgam labhati dvīsu gehesu  ekam geham labhati saṅghika rukkhe saṅghikam āvāsam bādhente saṅgham an āpucchā hāretum
translated: the property of individuals, he gets one house in two.🔽Is it allowable to remove a tree belonging to the Sangha that is damaging a dwelling belonging to the Sangha without informing the Sangha?

original: vaṭṭati, na vaṭṭatīti? Vaṭṭati. Vacanapathacchedanatthaṃ pana āpucchitvāva hāretabbo.🔽Sace rukkhaṃ nissāya saṅghassa mahanto lābho hoti, na hāretabbo. Puggalikarukkhe
analyzed: vaṭṭati na vaṭṭati iti vaṭṭati vacana patha chedana attham pana āpucchitvā ava hāretabbaḥ  sace rukkham nissāya saṅghassa mahantaḥ lābhaḥ hoti na hāretabbo puggalika rukkhe
translated: It is allowable. But it should be removed after informing the Sangha, in order to avoid a charge of theft.🔽If the Sangha is getting a large amount of almsfood because of the tree, it should not be removed.

original: saṅghikaṃ āvāsaṃ bādhente rukkhasāmikassa ācikkhitabbaṃ. Sace harituṃ na icchati,
analyzed: saṅghikam āvāsam bādhente rukkha sāmikassa ācikkhitabbam sace haritum naḥ icchati
translated: If a tree belonging to an individual is damaging a dwelling belonging to the Sangha, the owner of the tree should be informed. If he does not want to remove it,

original: chedāpetvā hāretabbo. ‘Rukkhaṃ me dethā’ti codentassa rukkhaṃ agghāpetvā mūlaṃ dātabbaṃ.
analyzed: chedāpetvā hāretabbaḥ rukkham me detha ati codentassa rukkham agghāpetvā mūlam dātabbam
translated: the tree should be cut down and removed. If the owner demands, “Give me the tree,” he should be given its value after it has been assessed.

original: Saṅghike rukkhe puggalikāvāsaṃ, puggalike ca puggalikāvāsaṃ bādhentepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: saṅghike rukkhe puggalikā vāsam puggalike ca puggalikā vāsam bādhente pi esā iva nayaḥ
translated: The same method applies if a dwelling belonging to an individual is damaging a tree belonging to the Sangha, or if a dwelling belonging to an individual is damaging a dwelling belonging to an individual.

original: Valliyampi ayameva kathāmaggo. Valli pana yattha vikkāyati, dullabhā hoti, tattha
analyzed: valliyam pi ayam eva kathā maggaḥ vallī pana yattha vikkāyati dullabhā hoti tattha
translated: And so is creepers. But where creepers are rare,

original: garubhaṇḍaṃ. Sā ca kho upaḍḍhabāhuppamāṇato paṭṭhāya; tato heṭṭhā vallikhaṇḍaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ na hoti.
analyzed: garubhaṇḍam sā ca kho upaḍḍha bāhu ppamāṇataḥ paṭṭhāya tatas heṭṭhā valli khaṇḍam garubhaṇḍam na hoti
translated: then they are heavy goods. And they are so only if they are as big as an armspan; below that they are not heavy goods.

original: Pattadānādīsupi pattadānenāti paccayahetukena pattadānenātiādi sabbaṃ veḷudāne vuttanayeneva
analyzed: patta dāna ādīsu pi patta dānena ati paccaya hetukena patta dānena ati ādi sabbam veḷu dāne vutta nayena iva
translated: In the case of the giving of a bowl, etc., the giving of a bowl is the giving of a bowl as a requisite, and so on. All should be understood in the way already stated under the giving of bamboo.

original: veditabbaṃ. Garubhaṇḍatāya panettha ayaṃ vinicchayo. Pattampi hi yattha vikkāyati,
analyzed: veditabbam garu bhaṇḍa tāya pana ittha ayam vinicchayo pattam pi hi yattha vikkāyati
translated: But the following is the decision here. A bowl is heavy goods only where it is rare,

original: gandhikādayo gandhapaliveṭhanādīnaṃ atthāya gaṇhanti, tādise dullabhaṭṭhāneyeva garubhaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: gandhika ādayaḥ gandha paliveṭhana ādīnam atthāya gaṇhanti tādise dullabha ṭṭhāneyā iva garu bhaṇḍam
translated: and people take it for the sake of its scent, etc., to use as a perfume, etc., in the place where it is not available.

original: hoti. Esa tāva kiṃsukapattakaṇṇapiḷandhanatālapattādīsu vinicchayo.🔽Tālapaṇṇampi imasmiṃyeva ṭhāne kathetabbaṃ. Tālapaṇṇampi hi sayaṃjāte tālavane saṅghena
analyzed: hoti esa tāva kiṃsuka patta kaṇṇa piḷandhana tāla patta ādīsu vinicchayaḥ  tāla paṇṇam pi imasmiṃ yeva ṭhāne kathetabbam tāla paṇṇam pi hi sayaṃjāte tāla vane saṅghena
translated: This is the decision in the case of a kiṃsuka leaf, a betel leaf, a fan, a palm leaf, and so on.🔽And a palm leaf should be mentioned in this place too. For a palm leaf is heavy goods only in a place assigned to the Sangha, in a palm grove that has grown up by itself,

original: paricchinnaṭṭhāneyeva garubhaṇḍaṃ, na tato paraṃ. Ropimatālesu sabbampi garubhaṇḍaṃ.
analyzed: paricchinna ṭṭhāneyā iva garu bhaṇḍam na tato param ropima tālesu sabbam pi garu bhaṇḍam
translated: not beyond that. In the case of planted palm groves, all are heavy goods.

original: Tassa pamāṇaṃ heṭṭhimakoṭiyā aṭṭhaṅgulappamāṇopi rittapotthako. Tiṇampi ettheva pakkhipitvā
analyzed: tassa pamāṇam heṭṭhima koṭiyā aṭṭha aṅgula ppamāṇaḥ api ritta potthako tiṇam pi ettha iva pakkhipitvā
translated: The measure of it is this: a piece of wood, even if eight fingerbreadths long, is called a “piece of wood” here. Grass should be included here too.

original: kathetabbaṃ. Yattha pana tiṇaṃ natthi tattha muñjapalālanāḷikerapaṇṇādīhipi chādenti.
analyzed: kathetabbam yattha pana tiṇam natthi tattha chādenti
translated: But where there is no grass, they cover it with muñja grass, palmyra palm-leaf, bamboo, leaves, and so on.

original: Tasmā tānipi tiṇeneva saṅgahitāni. Iti muñjapalālādīsu yaṃkiñci muṭṭhippamāṇaṃ tiṇaṃ,🔽nāḷikerapaṇṇādīsu ca ekapaṇṇampi saṅghassa dinnaṃ vā tatthajātakaṃ vā bahiārāme saṅghassa
analyzed: tasmā tāni api tiṇena iva saṅgahitāni iti muñja palāla ādīsu yaṃkiñci muṭṭhippamāṇam tiṇam  nāḷikera paṇṇa ādīsu ca eka paṇṇam pi saṅghassa dinnam vā tattha jātakam vā bahi ārāme saṅghassa
translated: So these are included by the word “grass.” Thus any handful of muñja grass, palmyra palm-leaf, and so on,🔽or even a single leaf of bamboo, palm-leaf, and so on, given to the Sangha or grown there, is heavy property outside the monastery zone.

original: tiṇavatthumhi jātatiṇaṃ vā rakkhitagopitaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti. Taṃ pana saṅghakamme
analyzed: tiṇa vatthumhi jāta tiṇam vā rakkhita gopitam garu bhaṇḍam hoti tam pana saṅgha kamme
translated: The grass that grows in the site for grass and the like is protected and guarded property. But when a monastery building or a shrine has been built,

original: ca cetiyakamme ca kate atirekaṃ puggalikakamme dātuṃ vaṭṭati. Heṭṭhā vuttaveḷumhipi eseva nayo.🔽Pupphadāne “ettakesu rukkhesu pupphāni vissajjetvā yāgubhattavatthe upanentu, ettakesu
analyzed: ca cetiya kamme ca kate atirekam puggalika kamme dātum vaṭṭati heṭṭhā vutta veḷumhi pi esa eva nayo  puppha dāne ettakesu rukkhesu pupphāni vissajjetvā yāgu bhatta vatthe upanentu ettakesu
translated: it is allowable to give the surplus to an individual for his personal use. The same method applies to bamboo and so on mentioned above.

original: senāsanapaṭisaṅkharaṇe upanentū”ti evaṃ niyamitaṭṭhāne eva pupphāni garubhaṇḍāni
analyzed: senāsana paṭisaṅkharaṇe upanentu uti evam niyamita ṭṭhāne eva pupphāni garubhaṇḍāni
translated: As regards the giving of flowers, flowers are heavy property when they are restricted to a particular place in this way: “Use these flowers in making offerings in such-and-such a number of monasteries, and use the rest for making offerings in the rest.”

original: honti. Paratīre sāmaṇerā pupphāni ocinitvā rāsiṃ karonti, pañcaṅgasamannāgato pupphabhājako
analyzed: honti para tīre sāmaṇerā pupphāni ocinitvā rāsim karonti pañcaṅga samannāgato puppha bhājako
translated: The novices on the other side of the river pick the flowers and make a heap. The flower distributor, who is endowed with five qualities,

original: bhikkhusaṅghaṃ gaṇetvā koṭṭhāse karoti, so sampattaparisāya saṅghaṃ anāpucchitvāva🔽dātuṃ labhati; asammatena pana āpucchitvāva dātabbaṃ. Bhikkhu pana kassa pupphāni
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgham gaṇetvā koṭṭhāse karoti saḥ sampatta parisāya saṅgham an āpucchitvā ava  dātum labhati asammatena pana āpucchitvā ava dātabbam bhikkhu pana kassa pupphāni
translated: counts the Sangha of monks and divides them into groups. He gives flowers to the group that arrives first without asking the Sangha for permission.🔽But if he is not agreed upon, he should give them after asking for permission. But to whom may a monk give flowers? And to whom may he not?

original: dātuṃ labhati, kassa na labhatīti? Mātāpitūnaṃ gehaṃ haritvāpi gehato pakkosāpetvāpi
analyzed: dātum labhati kassa na labhati iti mātā pitūnam geham haritvā api gehataḥ pakkosāpetvā api
translated: He may give them to his mother and father after taking them to their house or after having them brought from the house,

original: ‘vatthupūjaṃ karothā’ti dātuṃ labhati, piḷandhanatthāya dātuṃ na labhati; sesañātīnaṃ
analyzed: vatthu pūjam karotha ati dātum labhati piḷandhana tthāya dātum na labhati sesa ñātīnam
translated: saying, ‘Make an offering with these flowers.’ He may not give them for the purpose of making a garland. But to other people,

original: pana haritvā na dātabbaṃ, pakkosāpetvā ‘pūjaṃ karothā’ti dātabbaṃ; sesajanassa pūjanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pana haritvā na dātabbam pakkosāpetvā pūjam karotha ati dātabbam sesa janassa pūjana ṭhānam
translated: he may not give them after taking them to their house. He should give them after having them brought, saying, ‘Make an offering.’ To other people who have come to a place for making an offering,

original: sampattassa apaccāsīsantena dātabbaṃ; pupphadānaṃ nāma na hoti. Vihāre bahūni pupphāni
analyzed: sampattassa a paccāsīsantena dātabbam puppha dānam nāma na hoti vihāre bahūni pupphāni
translated: he should give them if they are not related to him. It is not a giving of flowers.🔽Many flowers bloom in the monastery. A monk who is walking for almsfood sees people and says,

original: pupphanti. Bhikkhunā piṇḍāya carantena manusse disvā ‘vihāre bahūni pupphāni, pūjethā’ti
analyzed: pupphanti bhikkhunā piṇḍāya carantena manusse disvā vihāre bahūni pupphāni pūjetha ati
translated: ‘There are many flowers in the monastery. Make an offering.’

original: vattabbaṃ. Vacanamatte doso natthi. ‘Manussā khādanīyabhojanīyaṃ ādāya āgamissantī’ti
analyzed: vattabbam vacana matte dosaḥ natthi manussā khādanīya bhojanīyam ādāya āgamissanti iti
translated: But he should not say, “People will come bringing fresh or cooked food.”

original: cittena pana na vattabbaṃ. Sace vadati, khādanīyabhojanīyaṃ na paribhuñjitabbaṃ.🔽Manussā attano dhammatāya ‘vihāre pupphāni atthī’ti pucchitvā ‘asukadivase vihāraṃ
analyzed: cittena pana na vattabbam sace vadati khādanīya bhojanīyam na paribhuñjitabbam  manussāḥ attanaḥ dhamma tāya vihāre pupphāni atthi iti pucchitvā asuka divase vihāram
translated: If he does say this, he should not eat the fresh or cooked food.

original: āgamissāma, sāmaṇerānaṃ pupphāni ocinituṃ mā dethā’ti vadanti. Bhikkhū sāmaṇerānaṃ
analyzed: āgamissāma sāmaṇerānam pupphāni ocinitum mā detha iti vadanti bhikkhū sāmaṇerānam
translated: If people come to the monastery on their own initiative, asking, “Are there flowers in the monastery?” and then saying, “We will come to the monastery on such-and-such a day. Please don’t let the novices pick flowers,”🔽the monks may forget to tell the novices.

original: kathetuṃ pamuṭṭhā. Sāmaṇerehi pupphāni ocinitvā ṭhapitāni. Manussā bhikkhū upasaṅkamitvā🔽“bhante, mayaṃ tumhākaṃ asukadivaseyeva ārocayimha – ‘sāmaṇerānaṃ pupphāni ocinituṃ
analyzed: kathetum pamuṭṭhā sāmaṇerehi pupphāni ocinitvā ṭhapitāni manussāḥ bhikkhū upasaṅkamitvā  bhante mayam tumhākam ārocayimha sāmaṇerānam pupphāni ocinitum
translated: The novices pick the flowers and put them aside. The people then approach the monks🔽and say, “Venerables, we informed you on such-and-such a day not to let the novices pick flowers. Why didn’t you stop them?”

original: mā dethā’ti. Kasmā na vārayitthā”ti? “Sati me pamuṭṭhā, pupphāni ocinitamattāneva,🔽tāva na pūjā katā”ti vattabbaṃ. “Gaṇhatha pūjethā”ti na vattabbaṃ. Sace vadati, āmisaṃ
analyzed: mā detha iti kasmai na vārayittha ati sati me pamuṭṭhā pupphāni  tāva na pūjā katā ati vattabbam gaṇhatha pūjetha ati na vattabbam sace vadati āmisam
translated: “I forgot. The flowers have just been picked,

original: na paribhuñjitabbaṃ.
analyzed: na paribhuñjitabbam
translated: but they haven’t yet been used for worship.” “Take them and worship with them.” He should not say this. If he does say this, he should not eat the fresh or cooked food.

original: Aparo bhikkhu sāmaṇerānaṃ ācikkhati “asukagāmavāsino pupphāni mā ocinitthā”ti āhaṃsūti.
analyzed: aparaḥ bhikkhu sāmaṇerānaṃ ācikkhati asuka gāma vāsino pupphāni mā ocinittha ati āhaṃsu iti
translated: Another monk told novices, “Don’t pick flowers from the village.”

original: Manussāpi āmisaṃ āharitvā dānaṃ datvā vadanti – “amhākaṃ manussā na bahukā, sāmaṇere
analyzed: manussā api āmisam āharitvā dānam da tvā vadanti amhākam manussāḥ na bahukā sāmaṇere
translated: People brought gifts and said, “We don’t have many people.🔽Please tell the novices to pick flowers with us.”

original: amhehi saha pupphāni ocinituṃ āṇāpethā”ti. “Sāmaṇerehi bhikkhā laddhā; ye bhikkhācāraṃ
analyzed: amhehi saha pupphāni ocinitum āṇāpetha ati sāmaṇerehi bhikkhā laddhā ye bhikkhācāram
translated: “The novices have received alms. Those who don’t go on alms round🔽will know for themselves.”

original: na gacchanti, te sayameva jānissanti, upāsakā”ti vattabbaṃ. Ettakaṃ nayaṃ labhitvā
analyzed: na gacchanti te sayam eva jānissanti upāsakā ati vattabbam ettakam nayam labhitvā
translated: Having obtained this permission,

original: sāmaṇere putte vā bhātike vā katvā pupphāni ocināpetuṃ doso natthi; pupphadānaṃ nāma na hoti.
analyzed: sāmaṇere putte vā bhātike vā katvā pupphāni ocināpetum dosaḥ natthi puppha dānam nāma na hoti
translated: there is no offense in making novices one’s sons or brothers and then having them pick flowers. But this is not a flower offering.🔽In the case of a fruit offering, fruit is also a restricted heavy article, just like flowers.

original: Phaladāne phalampi pupphaṃ viya niyamitameva garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti. Vihāre bahukamhi phalāphale
analyzed: phala dāne phalam pi puppham viya niyamitam eva hoti vihāre bahukamhi phala aphale
translated: When there is a lot of fruit in the monastery,

original: sati aphāsukamanussā āgantvā yācanti. Bhikkhū ‘saṅghika’nti dātuṃ na ussahanti. Manussā
analyzed: sati a phāsuka manussāḥ āgantvā yācanti bhikkhū dātum na ussahanti manussā
translated: uncomfortable people come and ask for it. The monks do not dare to give it, saying, “It belongs to the Sangha.”

original: vippaṭisārino akkosanti paribhāsanti. Tattha kiṃ kātabbanti? Phalehi vā rukkhehi
analyzed: vippaṭisārino akkosanti paribhāsanti tattha kim kātabbanti phalehi vā rukkhehi
translated: The people complain and criticize them. What should be done in such a case?🔽If the fruit trees belong to the Sangha,

original: vā paricchinditvā katikā kātabbā – ‘asukesu ca rukkhesu ettakāni phalāni gaṇhantā,🔽ettakesu vā rukkhesu phalāni gaṇhantā na vāretabbā’ti. Corā pana issarā vā balakkārena🔽gaṇhantā na vāretabbā; kuddhā te sakalavihārampi nāseyyuṃ. Ādīnavo pana kathetabboti.
analyzed: vā paricchinditvā katikā kātabbā asukesu ca rukkhesu ettakāni phalāni gaṇhantā  ettakesu vā rukkhesu phalāni gaṇhantā na vāretabbā ati corā pana issarā vā balakkārena  gaṇhantā na vāretabbā kuddhā te sakala vihāram pi na āseyyuṃ ādīnavaḥ pana kathetabbaḥ ti
translated: Or else, having marked them off, a limit can be set on the number of fruits to be taken: ‘So many fruits may be taken from such and such trees,🔽but not more than that.’ But if thieves or powerful people take them by force, they should not be prevented, for they might destroy the whole monastery in their anger. But the disadvantages should be made known.

original: Sinānadāne sinānacuṇṇāni koṭṭitāni na garubhaṇḍāni. Akoṭṭito rukkhattacova garubhaṇḍaṃ.🔽Cuṇṇaṃ pana agilānassa rajananipakkaṃ vaṭṭati. Gilānassa yaṃkiñci cuṇṇaṃ vaṭṭatiyeva.
analyzed: sināna dāne sināna cuṇṇāni koṭṭitāni na garubhaṇḍāni a koṭṭitaḥ garubhaṇḍam  cuṇṇam pana agilānassa rajana nipakkam vaṭṭati gilānassa yaṃkiñci cuṇṇam vaṭṭati yeva
translated: As regards the giving of bathing powder, the lumps of powder that have been pressed together are not a heavy article. But the loose powder is a heavy article, like a tree-spray.🔽But as regards the powder, only unmixed powder is allowable for one who is not sick. Any kind of powder is allowable for one who is sick.

original: Mattikāpi ettheva pakkhipitvā kathetabbā. Mattikāpi yattha dullabhā hoti, tattheva🔽garubhaṇḍaṃ. Sāpi heṭṭhimakoṭiyā tiṃsapalaguḷapiṇḍappamāṇāva tato heṭṭhā na garubhaṇḍanti.
analyzed: mattikā api ettha iva pakkhipitvā kathetabbā mattikā api yattha dullabhā hoti tattha eva  garu bhaṇḍam sā api heṭṭhima koṭiyā tiṃsa palaguḷa piṇḍa ppamāṇā ava tatas heṭṭhā na garu bhaṇḍanti
translated: The clay should be mentioned here too. The clay is a heavy article only where it is difficult to get;🔽but if it is easily available, it is not a heavy article even if it is less than the size of a jujube-fruit.

original: Dantakaṭṭhadāne dantakaṭṭhaṃ acchinnakameva garubhaṇḍaṃ. Yesaṃ sāmaṇerānaṃ saṅghato
analyzed: dantakaṭṭha dāne dantakaṭṭham acchinnakam eva garubhaṇḍam yesam sāmaṇerānam saṅghato
translated: As regards the giving of tooth sticks, only uncut tooth sticks are a heavy article. If the novices have cut them and made them into tooth sticks, they are not a heavy article.

original: dantakaṭṭhavāro pāpuṇāti, te attano ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ dātuṃ na labhanti.
analyzed: dantakaṭṭhavāro pāpuṇāti te attanaḥ ācariya upajjhāyānam pāṭiyekkam dātum na labhanti
translated: If the turn comes for the tooth-stick, they do not get any to give to their own preceptors and teachers.

original: Yehi pana ‘ettakāni dantakaṭṭhāni āharitabbānī’ti paricchinditvā vāraṃ gahitāni,🔽te atirekāni ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ dātuṃ labhanti. Ekena bhikkhunā dantakaṭṭhamāḷakato
analyzed: yehi pana ettakāni dantakaṭṭhāni āharitabbāni iti paricchinditvā vāram gahitāni  te atirekāni ācariya upajjhāyānam dātum labhanti ekena bhikkhunā danta kaṭṭha māḷakato
translated: But those who have taken the turn after deciding that so many tooth-sticks are to be brought🔽can give the surplus to their preceptors and teachers. A single bhikkhu should not take many tooth-sticks from the tooth-stick store;

original: bahūni dantakaṭṭhāni na gahetabbāni, devasikaṃ ekekameva gahetabbaṃ. Pāṭiyekkaṃ vasantenāpi🔽bhikkhusaṅghaṃ gaṇayitvā yattakāni attano pāpuṇanti tattakāneva gahetvā gantabbaṃ;
analyzed: bahūni dantakaṭṭhāni na gahetabbāni devasikam ekekam eva gahetabbam pāṭiyekkam vasantena api  bhikkhu saṅgham gaṇayitvā yattakāni attanaḥ pāpuṇanti tattakān eva gahetvā gantabbam
translated: he should take only one a day. One who is living alone🔽should take as many as he needs after counting the bhikkhus and then go.

original: antarā āgantukesu vā āgatesu disaṃ vā pakkamantena āharitvā gahitaṭṭhāneyeva ṭhapetabbāni.🔽Cāṭukamyatāyātiādīsu cāṭukamyatā vuccati attānaṃ dāsaṃ viya nīcaṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā parassa
analyzed: antarā āgantukesu vā āgatesu disam vā pakkamantena āharitvā gahita ṭṭhāneya iva ṭhapetabbāni  cāṭu kamyatāya ati ādīsu cāṭu kamyatā vuccati attānam dāsam viya nīca ṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā parassa
translated: If other bhikkhus arrive in the meantime or if he himself leaves for another quarter, he should leave the tooth-sticks where he took them from,

original: khalitavacanampi saṇṭhapetvā piyakāmatāya paggayhavacanaṃ. Muggasūpyatāyāti muggasūpasamānāya
analyzed: khalita vacanam pi saṇṭhapetvā piya kāma tāya paggayha vacanam mugga sūpya tāya ati mugga sūpa samānāya
translated: in the place for tooth-sticks. The state of being a flatterer is the state of speaking in a way that is intended to please others by keeping silent about their faults and by praising them as if one were a slave who has to stand in an abject position. The state of being a bean-souper is the state of being like a bean soup.

original: saccālikena jīvitakappanatāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Yathā hi muggasūpe paccante bahū muggā🔽pākaṃ gacchanti, thokā na gacchanti; evameva saccālikena jīvitakappake puggale bahu
analyzed: adhivacanam yathā hi mugga sūpe paccante bahū muggā  pākam gacchanti thokāḥ na gacchanti evam eva saccālikena jīvita kappake puggale bahu
translated: This is a term for the state of living by lying. For just as when mung-bean curry is being cooked, the mung beans🔽are cooked and a few are not cooked, so too, in the case of a person who lives by lying, his lying is much and his truthfulness is little.

original: alikaṃ hoti, appakaṃ saccaṃ. Yathā vā muggasūpassa appavisanaṭṭhānaṃ nāma natthi,🔽evameva saccālikavuttino puggalassa appaviṭṭhavācā nāma natthi; siṅghāṭakaṃ viya
analyzed: alikam hoti appakam saccam yathā vā mugga sūpassa appavisana ṭṭhānam nāma natthi  evam eva saccālika vuttino puggalassa appaviṭṭha vācā nāma natthi siṅghāṭakam viya
translated: Or just as there is no place for mung beans in mung-bean curry,

original: icchiticchitadhārāya patiṭṭhāti. Tenassa sā musāvāditā muggasūpyatāti vuttā. Pāribhaṭayatāti
analyzed: icchiti chita dhārāya patiṭṭhāti tena assa sā musāvāditā mugga sūpya tā ati vuttā pāribhaṭaya tā ati
translated: so too, in the case of a person who lives by lying, there is no speech that is not a lie; it is established as a stream of lies, like a continuous flow of water. That is why it is called “mung-bean curry.”

original: paribhaṭakammabhāvo. Paribhaṭassa hi kammaṃ pāribhaṭayaṃ, tassa bhāvo pāribhaṭayatā;🔽alaṅkārakaraṇādīhi dārakakīḷāpanassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: paribhaṭa kamma bhāvaḥ paribhaṭassa hi kammam pāribhaṭayam tassa bhāvaḥ pāribhaṭaya tā  alaṅkāra karaṇa ādīhi dāraka kīḷāpanassa itam adhivacanam
translated: As a pimp: the state of being a pimp. For a pimp’s work is pimping, and the state of that is pimping.🔽This is a term for the work of making up and dressing dolls and teaching them to play.

original: Jaṅghapesanikanti gāmantaradesantarādīsu tesaṃ tesaṃ gihīnaṃ sāsanapaṭisāsanaharaṇaṃ.
analyzed: gāmantara desantara ādīsu tesam tesam gihīnam sāsana paṭisāsana haraṇam
translated: As a messenger: running errands for householders here and there, in villages, towns, cities, and the countryside.

original: Idañhi jaṅghapesanikaṃ nāma attano mātāpitūnaṃ, ye cassa mātāpitaro upaṭṭhahanti,🔽tesaṃ sāsanaṃ gahetvā katthaci gamanavasena vaṭṭati. Cetiyassa vā saṅghassa vā attano
analyzed: idam hi jaṅghapesanikam nāma attanaḥ mātā pitūnam ye ca assa mātā pitaraḥ upaṭṭhahanti  tesam sāsanam gahetvā katthaci gamana vasena vaṭṭati cetiyassa vā saṅghassa vā attano
translated: For this messenger is called a leg-runner because he is sent on foot by his parents or by those who support his parents,

original: vā kammaṃ karontānaṃ vaḍḍhakīnampi sāsanaṃ harituṃ vaṭṭati. Manussā “dānaṃ dassāma,
analyzed: vā kammam karontānam vaḍḍhakīnam pi sāsanam haritum vaṭṭati manussāḥ dānam dassāma
translated: or because he is sent to go somewhere to take a message from builders who are building a shrine or a dwelling for the Community or for himself. It is proper for him to take a message from people who say, “We will give a gift,

original: pūjaṃ karissāma, bhikkhusaṅghassa ācikkhathā”ti vadanti; “asukattherassa nāma dethā”ti🔽piṇḍapātaṃ vā bhesajjaṃ vā cīvaraṃ vā denti; “vihāre pūjaṃ karothā”ti mālāgandhavilepanādīni
analyzed: pūjam karissāma bhikkhu saṅghassa ācikkhatha ati vadanti asuka ttherassa nāma detha ati  piṇḍapātam vā bhesajjam vā cīvaram vā denti vihāre pūjam karotha ati mālā gandha vilepana ādīni
translated: we will do an offering. Tell the Community of Bhikkhus.” Or they say, “Give to such-and-such an elder.”

original: vā dhajapatākādīni vā nīyyādenti, sabbaṃ harituṃ vaṭṭati; jaṅghapesanikaṃ nāma na
analyzed: vā dhaja patākā ādīni vā sabbam haritum vaṭṭati jaṅghapesanikam nāma na
translated: Or they give him alms food, medicine, or a robe, or they say, “Do an offering in the monastery,” and they send him garlands, scents, unguents, etc., or flags, banners, etc. It is proper for him to take all this. But he is not a leg-runner.

original: hoti. Sesānaṃ sāsanaṃ gahetvā gacchantassa padavāre padavāre doso.
analyzed: hoti sesānam sāsanam gahetvā gacchantassa padavāre padavāre doso
translated: If he goes taking a message for others, there is an offence of wrong-doing for every step.

original: Aññataraññatarenāti etesaṃ vā veḷudānādīnaṃ aññataraññatarena vejjakammabhaṇḍāgārikakammaṃ
analyzed: aññatara aññatarena ati etesam vā veḷu dāna ādīnam aññatara aññatarena vejja kamma bhaṇḍa āgārika kammam
translated: By one or other of these means, i.e. by one or other of these means beginning with the gift of bamboo. He is a messenger for medical treatment or for the store-keeper’s work.

original: piṇḍapaṭipiṇḍakammaṃ saṅghuppādacetiyuppādaupaṭṭhāpanakammanti evarūpānaṃ vā micchājīvena🔽jīvitakappanakakammānaṃ yena kenaci. Buddhapaṭikuṭṭhenāti buddhehi garahitena paṭisiddhena.🔽Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ sabbopi anācāro nāma kathīyati. Ācāraniddeso vuttapaṭipakkhanayeneva veditabbo.🔽514. Gocaraniddesepi paṭhamaṃ agocarassa vacane kāraṇaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.

original: upasaṅkamanto vesiyāgocaro nāma hoti. Tasmā evaṃ upasaṅkamituṃ na vaṭṭati. Kiṃ kāraṇā?🔽Ārakkhavipattito. Evaṃ upasaṅkamantassa hi ciraṃ rakkhitagopitopi samaṇadhammo katipāheneva

original: upaṭṭhāpetvā upasaṅkamitabbaṃ. Vidhavā vuccanti matapatikā vā pavutthapatikā vā.🔽Thullakumāriyoti mahallikā aniviṭṭhakumāriyo. Paṇḍakāti lokāmisanissitakathābahulā
