original: ussannakilesā avūpasantapariḷāhā napuṃsakā. Tesaṃ sabbesampi upasaṅkamane ādīnavo🔽vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Bhikkhunīsupi eseva nayo. Apica bhikkhū nāma ussannabrahmacariyā
analyzed: ussanna kilesāḥ a vūpasanta pariḷāhāḥ napuṃsakā tesam sabbesam pi upasaṅkamane ādīnavaḥ  vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ bhikkhunīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ apica bhikkhū nāma ussanna brahmacariyā
translated: A wanton woman is an elderly unmarried woman. A paṇḍaka is a eunuch who is full of lust but has no virility and is not at peace because of his passions. The danger in approaching all these should be understood in the way already described.🔽The same method applies also in the case of bhikkhunīs. Moreover, bhikkhus are full of zeal for the higher life,

original: honti, tathā bhikkhuniyo. Te aññamaññaṃ santhavavasena katipāheneva rakkhitagopitasamaṇadhammaṃ

translated: and so are bhikkhunīs. If they converse together, in a few days their recluse-ship will be ruined and lost,

translated: But it is allowable to go if one is sent for as a sick-attendant. And it is allowable for a bhikkhu to go if he gets flowers for the purpose of worship or

original: ovādadānatthāyapi gantuṃ vaṭṭatiyeva.
analyzed: gantum

original: Pānāgāranti surāpānagharaṃ. Taṃ brahmacariyantarāyakarehi surāsoṇḍehi avivittaṃ hoti.
analyzed: surā pāna gharam tam brahmacariya antarāya karehi surā soṇḍehi a vivittam hoti
translated: A drinking-house is a place where spirits are sold. It is not secluded from those who are drunkards and are an obstacle to the celibate life.

original: Tattha tehi saddhiṃ saha soṇḍavasena upasaṅkamituṃ na vaṭṭati; brahmacariyantarāyo

translated: He is socializing: with kings means that whether they are anointed or unanointed,

original: ye rajjaṃ anusāsanti. Rājamahāmattāti rājūnaṃ issariyasadisāya mahatiyā issariyamattāya🔽samannāgatā. Titthiyāti viparītadassanā bāhiraparibbājakā. Titthiyasāvakāti bhattivasena

translated: With ascetics means with outside sectarians who have perverted views. With sectarians’ disciples means with those who give them their requisites. The meaning is that he is one who has become associated with them.

original: Ananulomikena saṃsaggenāti ananulomikasaṃsaggo nāma tissannaṃ sikkhānaṃ ananulomo
analyzed: ananulomikena saṃsaggena ati ananulomika saṃsaggaḥ nāma tissannam sikkhānam ananulomo

original: paccanīkasaṃsaggo, yena brahmacariyantarāyaṃ paññattivītikkamaṃ sallekhaparihāniñca
analyzed: paccanīka saṃsaggaḥ yena brahmacariya antarāyam paññatti vītikkamam sallekha parihāniñca
translated: Association with the opposite sex is that with kings, princes, ministers, etc., and with women, etc., which leads to the hindrance of the celibate life, to transgression of the rules, and to the loss of meditation.

original: pāpuṇāti, seyyathidaṃ – rājarājamahāmattehi saddhiṃ sahasokitā, sahananditā, samasukhadukkhatā,🔽uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu attanāva yogaṃ āpajjanatā, titthiyatitthiyasāvakehi saddhiṃ

translated: It is association with kings, princes, ministers, etc., in sorrow and in joy, in happiness and in suffering,

analyzed: tattha rāja rāja mahāmattehi saddhim saṃsaggaḥ brahmacariya antarāyam karoti itarehi  titthiya sāvakehi tesam laddhi gahaṇam tesam pana vādam bhinditvā attanaḥ laddhim gaṇhāpetum
translated: Herein, association with kings, princes, ministers, etc., hinders the celibate life.🔽Association with sectarians and their disciples leads to the acceptance of their doctrines.

original: samatthena upasaṅkamituṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: samatthena upasaṅkamitum vaṭṭati
translated: But it is allowable to approach them with the intention of breaking down their doctrines and making them accept one’s own.

original: Idāni aparenapi pariyāyena agocaraṃ dassetuṃ yāni vā pana tāni kulānītiādi āraddhaṃ.

analyzed: tattha assaddhāni iti buddha ādīsu saddhā virahitāni buddhaḥ sabbaññū dhammaḥ niyyānikaḥ

analyzed: saṅghaḥ suppaṭipannaḥ ti na saddahanti appasannāni iti cittam pasannam anāvilam kātum

translated: a blockhead, a beast, a brute, an ox, an ass, a hell being, an animal, a ghost;🔽there is no good destiny for you; you can expect only a bad destiny.’ They revile by showing fear thus: ‘Wait, now we’ll hit you, we’ll bind you, we’ll kill you.’

original: idāni taṃ paharissāma, bandhissāma, vadhissāmā’ti evaṃ bhayadassanena paribhāsanti🔽cāti attho. Anatthakāmānīti atthaṃ na icchanti, anatthameva icchanti. Ahitakāmānīti

translated: The meaning is: they are reproving and reviling.🔽Wishing harm means they do not wish welfare; they wish only for harm. Wishing ill means

original: ahitameva icchanti, hitaṃ na icchanti. Aphāsukakāmānīti phāsukaṃ na icchanti, aphāsukameva
analyzed: ahitam eva icchanti hitam naḥ icchanti a phāsuka kāmāni iti phāsukam naḥ icchanti a phāsukam eva
translated: they wish only for ill; they do not wish for welfare. Wishing suffering means they do not wish for happiness; they wish only for suffering.

original: icchanti. Ayogakkhemakāmānīti catūhi yogehi khemaṃ nibbhayaṃ na icchanti, sabhayameva
analyzed: icchanti a yoga kkhema kāmāni iti catūhi yogehi khemam nibbhayam na icchanti sa bhayam eva

analyzed: icchanti sāmaṇerāḥ api saṅgaham gacchanti bhikkhunīnam ti ettha
translated: Bhikkhus: novices are included here. Bhikkhunis: probationers and female novices are included here.

original: sikkhamānasāmaṇeriyopi. Sabbesampi hi bhagavantaṃ uddissa pabbajitānañceva saraṇagatānañca

original: catunnampi parisānaṃ tāni anatthakāmāniyeva. Tathārūpāni kulānīti evarūpāni khattiyakulādīni
analyzed: catunnam pi parisānam tāni tathārūpāni kulāni iti evarūpāni khattiya kula ādīni

original: kulāni. Sevatīti nissāya jīvati. Bhajatīti upasaṅkamati. Payirupāsatīti punappunaṃ🔽upasaṅkamati. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ vesiyādigocarassa vesiyādiko, rājādisaṃsaṭṭhassa
analyzed: kulāni sevati iti nissāya jīvati bhajati iti upasaṅkamati payirupāsati iti punappunam  upasaṅkamati ayam vuccati iti ayam vesiya ādi gocarassa vesiya ādikaḥ rāja ādi saṃsaṭṭhassa

original: rājādiko, assaddhakulādisevakassa assaddhakulādiko cāti tippakāropi ayuttagocaro
analyzed: rāja ādikaḥ assaddha kula ādi sevakassa assaddha kula ādiko ca ati tippakāraḥ pi ayutta gocaro
translated: This is called: this is called the improper resort of the three kinds, that of the harlot, etc., that of the king, etc., and that of the faithless family, etc.

original: agocaroti veditabbo.
analyzed: agocaraḥ iti veditabbaḥ
translated: It should be understood as a resort that is not a resort.

original: Tassa iminā pariyāyena agocaratā veditabbā. Vesiyādiko tāva pañcakāmaguṇanissayato
analyzed: tassa iminā pariyāyena agocara tā veditabbā tāva pañca kāmaguṇa nissayato
translated: This is how his lack of proper resort should be understood. The prostitute, etc., are the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: agocaroti veditabbo, yathāha – “ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno agocaro paravisayo? Yadidaṃ🔽pañca kāmaguṇā”ti rājādiko jhānānuyogassa anupanissayato lābhasakkārāsanicakkanipphādanato
analyzed: agocaraḥ iti veditabbaḥ yathā āha kaḥ ca bhikkhave bhikkhuno agocaraḥ para visayaḥ yat idam  pañca kāmaguṇā ti rāja ādikaḥ jhāna anuyogassa an upanissayataḥ lābha sakkāra āsani cakka nipphādanato
translated: This is how his “unlawful resort” should be understood. The harlot, etc., are unlawful resorts because of their dependence on the five strands of sense pleasure, according to the text: “What, bhikkhus, is the bhikkhu’s unlawful resort, his enemy’s domain?

original: diṭṭhivipattihetuto ca, assaddhakulādiko saddhāhānicittasantāsāvahanato agocaroti.
analyzed: diṭṭhi vipatti hetutaḥ ca assaddha kula ādiko saddhā hāni citta santāsa avahanataḥ agocaro ti
translated: It is the five strands of sense pleasure” . The king, etc., are unlawful resorts because they are not the support for the practice of jhāna, because they produce gain and honour, and because they are a cause for the perversion of view. The families of the faithless, etc., are unlawful resorts because they produce a stream of thought lacking in faith.🔽In the description of the “lawful resort” the words “not the harlot’s resort” and so on should be understood in the opposite sense to the above.

original: Gocaraniddese na vesiyagocarotiādīni vuttapaṭipakkhavasena veditabbāni. Opānabhūtānītiādīsu🔽pana opānabhūtānīti udapānabhūtāni; bhikkhusaṅghassa, cātumahāpathe khatapokkharaṇī
analyzed: gocara niddese na vesiya gocaraḥ ti ādīni vutta paṭipakkha vasena veditabbāni opāna bhūtāni iti ādīsu  pana opāna bhūtāni iti udapāna bhūtāni bhikkhu saṅghassa cātumahāpathe khata pokkharaṇī
translated: As to the words “like a public tank” , etc.,

original: viya, yathāsukhaṃ ogāhanakkhamāni cittamahāmattassa gehasadisāni. Tassa kira gehe
analyzed: viya yathāsukham ogāhana khamāni citta mahā mattassa geha sadisāni tassa kira gehe
translated: a public tank is a tank for the public use. It is a lawful resort because it is accessible to the bhikkhu-saṅgha for bathing in just as they like, like a public tank in a crossroad. It is like the house of the treasurer Citta.

original: kālatthambho yuttoyeva. Gharadvāraṃ sampattānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paccayavekallaṃ nāma natthi.
analyzed: kāla tthambhaḥ ghara dvāram sampattānam bhikkhūnam paccaya vekallam nāma natthi
translated: It seems that in his house a water-clock was set up. There was no lack of requisites for the bhikkhus who arrived at the door of the house.

original: Ekadivasaṃ bhesajjavattameva saṭṭhi kahāpaṇāni nikkhamanti. Kāsāvapajjotānīti bhikkhubhikkhunīhi
analyzed: eka divasam bhesajja vattam eva saṭṭhi kahāpaṇāni nikkhamanti kāsāva pajjotāni iti bhikkhu bhikkhunīhi
translated: Sixty kahāpaṇas were spent on medicine each day. “The light of the yellow robes”: the light of the yellow robes worn by the bhikkhus and bhikkhunīs.

original: nivatthapārutānaṃ kāsāvānaṃyeva pabhāya ekobhāsāni bhūtapālaseṭṭhikulasadisāni. Isivātapaṭivātānīti
analyzed: nivattha pārutānam pabhāyaḥ ekobhāsāni bhūtapāla seṭṭhi kula sadisāni isivāta paṭivātāni iti
translated: They were like the house of the chief of the bhūtas. “The wind of the ascetics, the wind of the rain and the wind of the sun”:

original: gehaṃ pavisantānaṃ nikkhamantānañca bhikkhubhikkhunīsaṅkhātānaṃ isīnaṃ cīvaravātena🔽ceva samiñjanapasāraṇādijanitasarīravātena ca paṭivātāni pavāyitāni viniddhutakibbisāni vā.
analyzed: geham pavisantānam nikkhamantānam ca bhikkhu bhikkhunī saṅkhātānam isīnam cīvara vātena  ca iva samiñjana pasāraṇa ādi janita sarīra vātena ca paṭivātāni pavāyitāni viniddhuta kibbisāni vā
translated: the wind of the robes of the ascetics, the bhikkhus and bhikkhunīs, who enter the house and leave it,🔽and the wind of the body produced by the bending and stretching of the limbs, etc.

original: 515. Aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvitāniddese aṇumattānīti aṇuppamāṇā. Vajjāti dosā.🔽Yāni tāni vajjānīti yāni tāni garahitabbaṭṭhena vajjāni. Appamattakānīti parittamattakāni
analyzed: aṇumattesu vajjesu aṇumattāni iti aṇu ppamāṇā vajjā ti dosā  yāni tāni vajjāni iti yāni tāni garahitabbaṭṭhena vajjāni appamattakāni iti paritta mattakāni
translated: In the description of “seeing fear in the slightest fault,” “slightest” means the smallest. “Fault” means evil.🔽“Those faults”: those things that are to be blamed, called “faults.” “Trivial”: small.

original: khuddakappamāṇāni. Oramattakānīti parittatopi orimappamāṇattā oramattakāni. Lahusānīti
analyzed: khuddaka ppamāṇāni oramattakāni iti parittataḥ pi orima ppamāṇa ttā oramattakāni lahusāni iti
translated: “Minor”: of small measure. “Slight”: because of being less than small, they are slight. “Trivial” means

original: lahukāni. Lahusammatānīti lahūti sammatāni. Saṃyamakaraṇīyānīti saṃyamena kattabbapaṭikammāni.🔽Saṃvarakaraṇīyānīti saṃvarena kātabbāni saṃvarena kattabbapaṭikammāni. Cittuppādakaraṇīyānīti
analyzed: lahukāni lahu sammatāni iti lahu uti sammatāni saṃyama karaṇīyāni iti saṃyamena kattabba paṭikammāni  saṃvara karaṇīyāni iti saṃvarena kātabbāni saṃvarena kattabba paṭikammāni cittuppāda karaṇīyāni iti
translated: They are light. Are considered light: are considered light. They are to be done by restraint: they are to be done by restraint, they are to be done by the action of restraint.🔽They are to be done by restraint: they are to be done by restraint, they are to be done by the action of restraint. They are to be done by the arising of consciousness:

original: cittuppādamattena kattabbapaṭikammāni. Manasikārapaṭibaddhānīti manasā āvajjitamatteneva🔽kattabbapaṭikammāni. Kāni pana tānīti? Divāvihāravāsī sumatthero tāva āha – “anāpattigamanīyāni🔽cittuppādamattakāni yāni ‘na puna evarūpaṃ karissāmī’ti manasā āvajjitamatteneva
analyzed: cittuppāda mattena kattabba paṭikammāni manasikāra paṭibaddhāni iti manasā āvajjita mattena iva  kattabba paṭikammāni kāni pana tāni iti divāvihāra vāsī suma theraḥ tāva āha anāpatti gamanīyāni  cittuppāda mattakāni yāni na punar evarūpam karissāmi iti manasā āvajjita mattena iva
translated: they are to be done by the mere arising of consciousness, they are to be done by the action of the arising of consciousness. They are bound up with attention:🔽they are to be done by the mere adverting of consciousness to them with the mind, they are to be done by the action of the adverting of consciousness to them with the mind. But what are they?🔽The elder Sumana, who lived in the Divāvihāra, said: “They are those to be done by the mere arising of consciousness, by the mere adverting of consciousness to them with the mind, by thinking ‘I will not do such a thing again,’ and by which one is purified. This is called ‘restraint by non-transgression’ and ‘restraint by resoluteness.’ ”

original: sujjhanti. Adhiṭṭhānāvikammaṃ nāmetaṃ kathita”nti. Antevāsiko panassa tipiṭakacūḷanāgatthero
analyzed: sujjhanti adhiṭṭhānāvikammam nāma etam kathitanti antevāsikaḥ panassa tipiṭakacūḷanāga thero
translated: But his pupil, the elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷanāga, said:

original: panāha – “idaṃ pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlasseva bhājanīyaṃ. Tasmā sabbalahukaṃ dukkaṭadubbhāsitaṃ
analyzed: pana āha idam pātimokkha saṃvara sīlassa iva bhājanīyam tasmā sabba lahukam dukkaṭa dubbhāsitam
translated: “This is a matter for the virtue consisting in the Pātimokkha restraint. Therefore the less serious offences of wrong-doing and wrong-speech are

original: idha vajjanti veditabbaṃ. Vuṭṭhānāvikammaṃ nāmetaṃ kathita”nti. Itiimesūti evaṃpakāresu🔽imesu. Vajjadassāvīti vajjato dosato dassanasīlo. Bhayadassāvīti catubbidhassa bhayassa
analyzed: idha vajjanti veditabbam vuṭṭhānāvikammam nāma etam kathitam ti iti imesu iti evaṃpakāresu  imesu vajja dassāvī iti vajjataḥ dosataḥ dassana sīlaḥ bhaya dassāvī iti catubbidhassa bhayassa
translated: Thus in these: in these of the kind already described.🔽Seeing the danger: having the habit of seeing the danger, the defect, in a transgression.🔽Seeing fear: having the habit of seeing fear in the fourfold fear.

original: kāraṇattā bhayato dassanasīlo. Ādīnavadassāvīti idha nindāvahanato, āyatiṃ dukkhavipākato,
analyzed: kāraṇa ttā bhayataḥ dassana sīlaḥ ādīnava dassāvī iti idha nindā vahanataḥ āyatim dukkha vipākato
translated: Seeing the risk: having the habit of seeing the risk in the various ways, namely, as blame here and now, as ripening in suffering in the life to come,

original: upariguṇānaṃ antarāyakaraṇato, vippaṭisārajananato ca etena nānappakārena ādīnavato dassanasīlo.
analyzed: upari guṇānaṃ antarāya karaṇataḥ vippaṭisāra jananataḥ ca etena nānā pakārena ādīnavataḥ dassana sīlaḥ
translated: as an impediment to attaining noble qualities, and as a cause of remorse.

original: Nissaraṇadassāvīti yaṃ tattha nissaraṇaṃ tassa dassanasīlo. Kiṃ panettha nissaraṇanti?🔽Ācariyattheravāde tāva “anāpattigamanīyatāya sati adhiṭṭhānāvikammaṃ nissaraṇa”nti
analyzed: nissaraṇa dassāvī iti yam tattha nissaraṇam tassa dassana sīlo kim pana ittha nissaraṇanti  ācariya tthera vāde tāva anāpatti gamanīya tāya sati adhiṭṭhāna avikammam nissaraṇam ti
translated: Seeing the escape: having the habit of seeing the escape from it. But what is the escape here?🔽In the Elder Ācariya’s reading of the text, it is said that the escape is the non-doing of the resolution-making when there is no offence.

original: kathitaṃ. Antevāsikattheravāde tāva “āpattigamanīyatāya sati vuṭṭhānāvikammaṃ nissaraṇa”nti kathitaṃ.
analyzed: kathitam antevāsika tthera vāde tāva āpatti gamanīya tāya sati vuṭṭhāna avikammam nissaraṇan ti kathitam
translated: In the Elder Antevāsika’s reading of the text, it is said that the escape is the non-doing of the emerging when there is an offence.

original: Tattha tathārūpo bhikkhu aṇumattāni vajjāni vajjato bhayato passati nāma. Taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: tattha tathārūpaḥ bhikkhu aṇumattāni vajjāni vajjataḥ bhayataḥ passati nāma tam dassetuṃ
translated: Herein, a bhikkhu who sees even the slightest faults as faults and as fearful is one who sees them thus.🔽To illustrate this, the following is said:

original: ayaṃ nayo kathito – paramāṇu nāma, aṇu nāma, tajjārī nāma, rathareṇu nāma, likkhā
analyzed: ayam nayo kathito paramāṇu nāma aṇu nāma tajjārī nāma rathareṇu nāma likkhā
translated: The atom, the mote of dust, the sunmotes dancing in a sunbeam, the raindrop,🔽the bubble, the grain of rice, the mung-bean, the barleycorn, the digit of the moon, the finger’s width, the span, the cubit,

original: nāma, ūkā nāma, dhaññamāso nāma, aṅgulaṃ nāma, vidatthi nāma, ratanaṃ nāma, yaṭṭhi🔽nāma, usabhaṃ nāma, gāvutaṃ nāma, yojanaṃ nāma. Tattha ‘paramāṇu’ nāma ākāsakoṭṭhāsiko
analyzed: nāma ūkā nāma dhaññamāsaḥ nāma aṅgulam nāma vidatthi nāma ratanam nāma yaṭṭhi  nāma usabham nāma gāvutam nāma yojanam nāma tattha paramāṇu nāma ākāsakoṭṭhāsiko
translated: the ell, the fathom, the usabha, the gavuta, the yojana—🔽Herein, the atom is the smallest of all material things. It is not within the range of the fleshly eye. It is only visible to the divine eye.🔽The mote of dust is the size of a louse. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The sunmotes dancing in a sunbeam are the size of a flea. They are visible to the fleshly eye.

original: maṃsacakkhussa āpāthaṃ nāgacchati, dibbacakkhusseva āgacchati. ‘Aṇu’ nāma bhitticchiddatālacchiddehi
analyzed: maṃsa cakkhussa āpātham na āgacchati dibba cakkhussa iva āgacchati aṇu nāma bhitti chidda tāla chiddehi
translated: The raindrop is the size of a myrobalan plum. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The bubble is the size of a cow’s hoofprint. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The grain of rice is the size of a grain of rice. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The mung-bean is the size of a mung-bean. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The barleycorn is the size of a barleycorn. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The digit of the moon is the size of a digit of the moon. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The finger’s width is the size of a finger’s width. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The span is the size of a span. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The cubit is the size of a cubit. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The ell is the size of an ell. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The fathom is the size of a fathom. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The usabha is the size of an usabha. It is visible to the fleshly eye.🔽The gavuta is the size of a gavuta. It is visible to the fleshly eye.

original: paviṭṭhasūriyarasmīsu vaṭṭi vaṭṭi hutvā paribbhamanto paññāyati. ‘Tajjārī’ nāma gopathamanussapathacakkapathesu🔽chijjitvā ubhosu passesu uggantvā tiṭṭhati. ‘Rathareṇu’ nāma tattha tattheva allīyati.
analyzed: paviṭṭha sūriya rasmīsu vaṭṭi vaṭṭi hutvā paribbhamanto paññāyati tajjārī nāma gopatha manussapatha cakka pathesu 🔽chijjitvā ubhosu passesu uggantvā tiṭṭhati rathareṇu nāma tattha tattha iva allīyati
translated: The yojana is the size of a yojana. It is visible to the fleshly eye.

original: Likkhādayo pākaṭā eva. Etesu pana chattiṃsa paramāṇavo ekassa aṇuno pamāṇaṃ. Chattiṃsa
analyzed: likkha ādayaḥ pākaṭāḥ eva etesu pana chattiṃsa paramāṇavaḥ ekassa aṇuno pamāṇam chattiṃsa
translated: Thirty-six atoms make one “minute particular” .🔽Thirty-six minute particulars make one “lion” .

original: aṇū ekāya tajjāriyā pamāṇaṃ. Chattiṃsa tajjāriyo eko rathareṇu. Chattiṃsa rathareṇū
analyzed: aṇū ekāya tajjāriyā pamāṇam chattiṃsa tajjāriyaḥ ekaḥ ratha reṇu chattiṃsa ratha reṇū
translated: Thirty-six lions make one “louse” .🔽Seven lice make one “ barley grain” .

original: ekā likkhā. Satta likkhā ekā ūkā. Satta ūkā eko dhaññamāso. Sattadhaññamāsappamāṇaṃ
analyzed: ekā likkhā satta likkhāḥ ekā ūkā satta ūkāḥ ekaḥ dhañña māsaḥ satta dhañña māsa ppamāṇam
translated: Seven barley grains make one “finger-width” .🔽Twelve finger-widths make one “span” .

original: ekaṃ aṅgulaṃ. Tenaṅgulena dvādasaṅgulāni vidatthi. Dve vidatthiyo ratanaṃ. Satta🔽ratanāni yaṭṭhi. Tāya yaṭṭhiyā vīsati yaṭṭhiyo usabhaṃ. Asīti usabhāni gāvutaṃ. Cattāri
analyzed: ekam aṅgulam tena aṅgulena dvādasa ṅgulāni vidatthi dve vidatthiyaḥ ratanam satta  ratanāni usabham asīti usabhāni gāvutam cattāri
translated: Two spans make one “hand” .🔽Seven hands make one “cubit” .🔽Twenty cubits make one “usabha” .🔽Eighty usabhas make one “gāvuta” .🔽Four gāvutas make one “league” .

original: gāvutāni yojanaṃ. Tena yojanena aṭṭhasaṭṭhiyojanasatasahassubbedho sinerupabbatarājā.🔽Yo bhikkhu aṇumattaṃ vajjaṃ aṭṭhasaṭṭhiyojanasatasahassubbedhasinerupabbatasadisaṃ
analyzed: gāvutāni yojanam tena yojanena aṭṭha saṭṭhi yojana sata sahassa ubbedhaḥ sineru pabbata rājā  yaḥ bhikkhu aṇumattam vajjam aṭṭha saṭṭhi yojana sata sahassa ubbedha sineru pabbata sadisam
translated: Sineru, the king of mountains, is eighty-four thousand leagues high.

original: katvā daṭṭhuṃ sakkoti – ayaṃ bhikkhu aṇumattāni vajjāni bhayato passati nāma. Yopi
analyzed: katvā daṭṭhum sakkoti ayam bhikkhu aṇumattāni vajjāni bhayataḥ passati nāma yo pi
translated: A bhikkhu who can see a fault as small as an atom as big as Sineru is said to “see danger in what is blameless.”

original: bhikkhu sabbalahukaṃ dukkaṭadubbhāsitamattaṃ paṭhamapārājikasadisaṃ katvā daṭṭhuṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu sabba lahukam dukkaṭa dubbhāsita mattam paṭhama pārājika sadisam katvā daṭṭhum
translated: If a monk can see a minor offense, such as an act of wrong conduct or wrong speech, as being like the first offense entailing expulsion,

original: sakkoti – ayaṃ aṇumattāni vajjāni vajjato bhayato passati nāmāti veditabbo.
analyzed: sakkoti ayam aṇumattāni vajjāni vajjataḥ bhayataḥ passati nāma ati veditabbo
translated: then he is said to see the minor offenses as being as fearful as the major offenses.

original: 516. Samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesūtipadaniddese bhikkhusikkhāti bhikkhūhi sikkhitabbasikkhā.
analyzed: samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu uti pada niddese bhikkhu sikkhā ati bhikkhūhi sikkhitabba sikkhā
translated: In the description of the words “he trains in the training rules he has undertaken”: the training of the monks is the training to be trained in by the monks.

original: Sā bhikkhunīhi sādhāraṇāpi asādhāraṇāpi bhikkhusikkhā eva nāma. Bhikkhunīsikkhāti🔽bhikkhunīhi sikkhitabbasikkhā. Sāpi bhikkhūhi sādhāraṇāpi asādhāraṇāpi bhikkhunīsikkhā🔽eva nāma. Sāmaṇerasikkhamānasāmaṇerīnaṃ sikkhāpi ettheva paviṭṭhā. Upāsakasikkhāti
analyzed: sā bhikkhunīhi sādhāraṇā api asādhāraṇā api bhikkhusikkhā eva nāma bhikkhunī sikkhā ati  bhikkhunīhi sikkhitabba sikkhā sā api bhikkhūhi sādhāraṇā api asādhāraṇā api bhikkhunī sikkhā  eva nāma sāmaṇera sikkhamāna sāmaṇerīnam sikkhā api ettha iva paviṭṭhā upāsaka sikkhā ati
translated: That training is shared with the nuns, but it is called the training of the monks. The training of the nuns is the training to be trained in by the nuns.

original: upāsakehi sikkhitabbasikkhā. Sā pañcasīladasasīlavasena vaṭṭati. Upāsikāsikkhāti
analyzed: upāsakehi sikkhitabba sikkhā sā pañca sīla dasa sīla vasena vaṭṭati upāsikā sikkhā ati
translated: That training is shared with the monks, but it is called the training of the nuns. The training of the male novices, female novices, and female probationers is also included here. The training of the male lay followers is the training to be trained in by the male lay followers. It is of two kinds: the five training rules and the ten training rules. The training of the female lay followers is the training to be trained in by the female lay followers.

original: upāsikāhi sikkhitabbasikkhā. Sāpi pañcasīladasasīlavasena vaṭṭati. Tattha bhikkhubhikkhunīnaṃ
analyzed: upāsikāhi sikkhitabba sikkhā sā api pañca sīla dasa sīla vasena vaṭṭati tattha bhikkhu bhikkhunīnam
translated: That is also of two kinds: the five training rules and the ten training rules. Herein, the training of the monks and nuns

original: sikkhā yāva arahattamaggā vaṭṭati. Upāsakaupāsikānaṃ sikkhā yāva anāgāmimaggā. Tatrāyaṃ
analyzed: sikkhā yāva arahatta maggā vaṭṭati upāsaka aupāsikānam sikkhā yāva anāgāmi maggā tatra ayam
translated: The training is valid as far as the path of arahantship. The training of the male and female lay followers is valid as far as the path of non-return. Herein,

original: bhikkhu attanā sikkhitabbasikkhāpadesu eva sikkhati. Sesasikkhā pana atthuddhāravasena
analyzed: bhikkhu attanā sikkhitabba sikkhāpadesu eva sikkhati sesa sikkhā pana attha uddhāra vasena
translated: a bhikkhu trains only in the training precepts that he himself should train in. But the other training precepts are stated

original: sikkhāpadassa atthadassa dassanatthaṃ vuttā. Iti imāsu sikkhāsūti evaṃpakārāsu etāsu
analyzed: sikkhāpadassa attha dassa dassana attham vuttāḥ iti imāsu sikkhāsu iti evaṃpakārāsu etāsu
translated: for the purpose of showing the meaning of the training precepts by way of the elucidation of their meaning. So in these training precepts, in these training precepts of this kind,

original: sikkhāsu. Sabbena sabbanti sabbena sikkhāsamādānena sabbaṃ sikkhaṃ. Sabbathā sabbanti🔽sabbena sikkhitabbākārena sabbaṃ sikkhaṃ. Asesaṃ nissesanti sesābhāvato asesaṃ; satisammosena
analyzed: sikkhāsu sabbena sabbanti sabbena sikkhā samādānena sabbam sikkham sabbathā sabbanti  sabbena sikkhitabba ākārena sabbam sikkham asesam nissesanti sesa abhāvataḥ asesam sati sammosena
translated: in all the training precepts, by all the undertaking of the training, in all the training. In every way, in all the training,

original: bhinnassāpi sikkhāpadassa puna pākatikakaraṇato nissesaṃ. Samādāya vattatīti samādiyitvā
analyzed: bhinnassa api sikkhāpadassa puna pākatika karaṇataḥ nissesam samādāya vattati iti samādiyitvā
translated: by all the modes of training. Without reserve, without remainder: without remainder because there is nothing left over; without remainder because even a broken training precept is restored to its original condition.

original: gahetvā vattati. Tena vuccatīti yena kāraṇena etaṃ sabbaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ sabbena sikkhitabbākārena
analyzed: gahetvā vattati tena vuccati iti yena kāraṇena etam sabbam sikkhāpadam sabbena sikkhitabba ākārena
translated: He trains in accordance with the rules of training: he trains in accordance with the training precepts that he has undertaken and accepted.

original: samādiyitvā sikkhati pūreti, tena vuccati “samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesū”ti.
analyzed: samādiyitvā sikkhati pūra iti tena vuccati samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu iti
translated: He trains in undertaking them, he fulfills them: hence ‘he trains in the training precepts by undertaking them’ is said.

original: 517-8. Indriyesu guttadvāro bhojane mattaññūtipadadvayassa niddese kaṇhapakkhassa
analyzed: indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ bhojane mattaññūti pada dvayassa niddese kaṇha pakkhassa
translated: In the description of the two terms ‘guarded as to the doors of the sense faculties’ and ‘knowing the measure in eating’ the purpose of the first statement in the dark side

original: paṭhamavacane payojanaṃ ācāraniddese vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Tattha katamā indriyesu
analyzed: paṭhama vacane payojanam ācāra niddese vutta nayena iva veditabbam tattha katamāḥ indriyesu
translated: should be understood in the way given in the description of conduct. Herein, what is meant by ‘he is not guarded as to the doors of the sense faculties’?

original: aguttadvāratātiādīsu pana yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ nikkhepakaṇḍavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttameva.
analyzed: agutta dvāra tā ti ādīsu pana yam vattabbam tat sabbam nikkhepa kaṇḍa vaṇṇanāyam vuttam eva
translated: But all that is to be said has already been said in the description of the Introduction.

original: 519. Jāgariyānuyoganiddese pubbarattāpararattanti ettha aḍḍharattasaṅkhātāya rattiyā
analyzed: jāgariya anuyoga niddese pubba ratta apara rattan ti ettha aḍḍha ratta saṅkhātāya rattiyā
translated: In the description of ‘waking up to the profit of the night’ the words ‘the first watch and the last watch of the night’ are to be understood as follows.🔽The first watch is before the middle of the night;

original: pubbe pubbarattaṃ; iminā paṭhamayāmañceva pacchābhattañca gaṇhāti. Rattiyā pacchā🔽apararattaṃ; iminā pacchimayāmañceva purebhattañca gaṇhāti. Majjhimayāmo panassa
analyzed: pubbe pubbarattam iminā paṭhama yāmañca iva pacchābhattañca gaṇhāti rattiyā pacchā  apararattam iminā pacchima yāmañca iva purebhattam ca gaṇhāti majjhima yāmaḥ panassa
translated: by this he includes the first and the after-supper watches. The last watch is after the middle of the night;

original: bhikkhuno niddākilamathavinodanokāsoti na gahito. Jāgariyānuyoganti jāgariyassa asupanabhāvassa
analyzed: bhikkhuno niddā kilamatha vinodana ukāsaḥ ti na gahitaḥ jāgariya anuyoganti jāgariyassa a supana bhāvassa
translated: by this he includes the last watch and the before-breakfast watch. But the middle watch is the bhikkhu’s opportunity for resting from walking up and down and sitting, so it is not included. ‘Waking up to the profit of the night’ is the state of not sleeping, of being awake, in the first and last watches of the night.

original: anuyogaṃ. Anuyutto hotīti taṃ anuyogasaṅkhātaṃ āsevanaṃ bhāvanaṃ anuyutto hoti sampayutto.
analyzed: anuyogam anuyuttaḥ hoti iti tam anuyoga saṅkhātam āsevanam bhāvanam anuyuttaḥ hoti sampayuttaḥ
translated: He is devoted to that means he is devoted to, associated with, that repetition which is called devotion.

original: Niddese panassa idha bhikkhu divasanti pubbaṇho, majjhanho, sāyanhoti tayopi divasakoṭṭhāsā
analyzed: niddese panassa idha bhikkhu divasanti pubbaṇhaḥ majjhanhaḥ sāyanhaḥ ti tayaḥ api divasakoṭṭhāsā
translated: But in the description here the bhikkhu’s day is taken as consisting of three periods, namely, the morning, the middle of the day, and the evening.

original: gahitā. Caṅkamena nisajjāyāti sakalampi divasaṃ iminā iriyāpathadvayeneva viharanto.🔽Cittassa āvaraṇato āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi pañcahipi nīvaraṇehi sabbākusaladhammehi
analyzed: gahitā caṅkamena divasam iminā iriyāpatha dvayena iva viharantaḥ  cittassa āvaraṇataḥ āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi pañcahi pi nīvaraṇehi sabba akusala dhammehi
translated: He is devoted to walking meditation and to sitting means that he spends the whole day in these two postures.🔽He purifies his mind of obstructions means that he purifies his mind of the five hindrances, which are obstructions to it, or of all unprofitable things.

original: vā cittaṃ parisodheti. Tehi dhammehi visodheti parimoceti. Ṭhānaṃ panettha kiñcāpi🔽na gahitaṃ, caṅkamanisajjāsannissitaṃ pana katvā gahetabbameva. Paṭhamayāmanti sakalasmimpi
analyzed: vā cittam parisodheti tehi dhammehi visodheti parimoceti ṭhānam pana ittha kiñcā api  na gahitam pana katvā gahetabbam eva paṭhama yāman ti sakalasmim pi
translated: He purifies his mind from them, he liberates it from them. But although this is not mentioned here,🔽it should be included as dependent on walking meditation and sitting.

original: paṭhamayāme. Majjhimayāmanti rattindivassa chaṭṭhakoṭṭhāsasaṅkhāte majjhimayāme.
analyzed: paṭhama yāme majjhima yāmanti rattindivassa chaṭṭha koṭṭhāsa saṅkhāte majjhima yāme
translated: In the first watch of the night means in the whole of the first watch. In the middle watch of the night means in the middle watch of the night, which is called the sixth period of the day and night.

original: Sīhaseyyanti ettha kāmabhogīseyyā, petaseyyā, sīhaseyyā, tathāgataseyyāti catasso
analyzed: sīha seyyanti ettha kāmabhogīseyyā peta seyyā sīha seyyā tathāgata seyyā ati catasso
translated: In the lion’s posture means that there are four postures, namely, the lustful man’s posture, the corpse’s posture, the lion’s posture, and the Tathāgata’s posture.

original: seyyā. Tattha “yebhuyyena, bhikkhave, kāmabhogī vāmena passena sentī”ti ayaṃ kāmabhogīseyyā.
analyzed: seyyā tattha yebhuyyena bhikkhave kāma bhogī vāmena passena senti iti ayaṃ kāma bhogīseyyā
translated: This is the sleeping posture of the sensualist.

original: Tesu hi yebhuyyena dakkhiṇapassena sayāno nāma natthi. “Yebhuyyena, bhikkhave, petā
analyzed: tesu hi yebhuyyena dakkhiṇa passena sayānaḥ nāma natthi yebhuyyena bhikkhave petā
translated: “Bhikkhus, recluses and brahmins who are sensualists, for the most part, sleep on their left side.🔽“Bhikkhus, ghosts, for the most part, sleep face downwards.

original: uttānā sentī”ti ayaṃ petaseyyā; appamaṃsalohitattā hi aṭṭhisaṅghāṭajaṭitā ekena passena
analyzed: uttānā senti iti ayam petaseyyā appa maṃsa lohita ttā hi aṭṭhi saṅghāṭa jaṭitā ekena passena
translated: For, being devoid of flesh and blood, they are a mass of veins and sinews, and they cannot sleep on their side.🔽“Bhikkhus, the lion, king of beasts, sleeps in the night in the day he is watchful and alert.🔽He sleeps in the posture of a lion.🔽He is pleased and satisfied.

original: sayituṃ na sakkonti, uttānāva senti. Sīho, bhikkhave, migarājā dakkhiṇena passena🔽seyyaṃ kappeti…pe… attamano hotī”ti ayaṃ sīhaseyyā; tejussadattā hi sīho migarājā🔽dve purimapāde ekasmiṃ ṭhāne dve pacchimapāde ekasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhapetvā naṅguṭṭhaṃ antarasatthimhi
analyzed: sayitum na sakkonti uttānā ava senti sīhaḥ bhikkhave miga rājā dakkhiṇena passena  seyyam kappetipe atta manaḥ hoti iti ayam sīha seyyā tejussa dattā hi sīhaḥ miga rājā  dve purima pāde ekasmim ṭhāne dve pacchima pāde ekasmim ṭhāne ṭhapetvā naṅguṭṭham antara satthimhi
translated: For the lion, king of beasts, being endowed with great strength and power,

original: pakkhipitvā purimapādapacchimapādanaṅguṭṭhānaṃ ṭhitokāsaṃ sallakkhetvā dvinnaṃ purimapādānaṃ
analyzed: pakkhipitvā purima pāda pacchima pāda naṅguṭṭhānam ṭhita ukāsam sallakkhetvā dvinnam purima pādānam
translated: places his two fore-paws one under the other and lays his large head thereon, and stretching out his four legs, he sleeps.

original: matthake sīsaṃ ṭhapetvā sayati; divasampi sayitvā pabujjhamāno na uttasanto pabujjhati,
analyzed: matthake sīsam ṭhapetvā sayati divasam pi sayitvā pabujjhamānaḥ na uttasantaḥ pabujjhati
translated: He lies down placing his head where his head should be. He sleeps all day and wakes up without fear.

original: sīsaṃ pana ukkhipitvā purimapādādīnaṃ ṭhitokāsaṃ sallakkheti; sace kiñci ṭhānaṃ vijahitvā🔽ṭhitaṃ hoti ‘nayidaṃ tuyhaṃ jātiyā na sūrabhāvassa anurūpa’nti anattamano hutvā tattheva
analyzed: sīsam pana ukkhipitvā purima pāda ādīnam ṭhita ukāsam sallakkheti sace kiñci ṭhānam vijahitvā  ṭhitam hoti nayidam tuyham jātiyā na sūra bhāvassa anurūpanti anatta manaḥ hutvā tattha eva
translated: He raises his head and looks for the place where his forefeet should be. If any place is left out,

original: sayati, na gocarāya pakkamati; avijahitvā ṭhite pana ‘tuyhaṃ jātiyā ca sūrabhāvassa
analyzed: sayati na gocarāya pakkamati a vijahitvā ṭhite pana tuyham jātiyā ca sūra bhāvassa
translated: he is not satisfied, thinking, “This is not suitable for your birth or your fragrance.” He lies down right there and does not go out for alms. But if it is not left out, he is pleased, thinking, “This is suitable for your birth and your fragrance.”

original: ca anurūpamida’nti haṭṭhatuṭṭho uṭṭhāya sīhavijambhitaṃ vijambhitvā kesarabhāraṃ
analyzed: ca anurūpam idam ti haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ uṭṭhāya sīha vijambhitam vijambhitvā kesara bhāram
translated: He gets up, yawns like a lion, shakes his mane,

original: vidhunitvā tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ naditvā gocarāya pakkamati. Catutthajjhānaseyyā pana
analyzed: vidhunitvā tikkhattum sīha nādam naditvā gocarāya pakkamati catuttha jhāna seyyā pana
translated: roars his lion’s roar three times, and then goes out for alms. But the sleep of one who has attained the fourth jhāna

original: tathāgataseyyāti vuccati. Tāsu idha sīhaseyyā āgatā. Ayañhi tejussadairiyāpathattā uttamaseyyā nāma.
analyzed: tathāgataseyyā ti vuccati tāsu idha sīha seyyā āgatā ayam hi tejussa dairiyā pathattā uttamaseyyā nāma
translated: is called the sleep of a Buddha. Of these, the sleep of a lion is what is meant here. For this is called the supreme sleep because it is the sleep of one who has the supreme state of being.

original: Pāde pādanti dakkhiṇapāde vāmapādaṃ. Accādhāyāti atiādhāya īsakaṃ atikkamma ṭhapetvā
analyzed: pāde pādanti dakkhiṇa pāde vāma pādam accādhāya ati atiādhāya īsakam atikkamma ṭhapetvā
translated: ‘Placing one foot on the other’: placing the left foot on the right foot. ‘Having bent the body right down upon the feet’: having bent the body right down upon the feet, having placed the body right down upon the feet, having gone right down upon the feet.

original: gopphakena hi gopphake jāṇunā vā jāṇumhi saṅghaṭṭiyamāne abhiṇhaṃ vedanā uppajjati,🔽cittaṃ ekaggaṃ na hoti, seyyā aphāsukā hoti; yathā pana na saṅghaṭṭeti, evaṃ atikkamma
analyzed: gopphakena hi gopphake jāṇunā vā jāṇumhi saṅghaṭṭiyamāne abhiṇham vedanā uppajjati  cittam ekaggam na hoti seyyā a phāsukā hoti yathā pana na saṅghaṭṭeti evam atikkamma
translated: For if the ankle or the knee is pressed, pain arises frequently,🔽the mind is not concentrated, and the posture is uncomfortable. But if the body is placed down upon the feet without pressing,

original: ṭhapite vedanā nuppajjati, cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, seyyā phāsukā hoti. Tena vuttaṃ “pāde
analyzed: ṭhapite vedanā nuppajjati cittam ekaggam hoti seyyā phāsukā hoti tena vuttam pāde
translated: pain does not arise, the mind becomes concentrated, and the posture is comfortable. That is why it is said above ‘having bent the body right down upon the feet.’

original: pādaṃ accādhāyā”ti. Sato sampajānoti satiyā ceva sampajānapaññāya ca samannāgato
analyzed: pādam accādhāya ati sataḥ sampajānoti satiyā ca iva sampajāna paññāya ca samannāgato
translated: ‘Mindful and clearly comprehending’: endowed with mindfulness and the understanding that is conjoined with mindfulness.

original: hutvā. Iminā supariggāhakaṃ satisampajaññaṃ kathitaṃ. Uṭṭhānasaññaṃ manasikaritvāti
analyzed: hutvā iminā su pariggāhakam sati sampajaññam kathitam uṭṭhāna saññam manasikaritvā iti
translated: This shows that the mindfulness and the clear comprehension are well-established. ‘Giving attention to the perception of rising up’:

original: asukavelāya nāma uṭṭhahissāmī’ti evaṃ uṭṭhānavelāparicchedakaṃ uṭṭhānasaññaṃ citte
analyzed: asuka velāya nāma uṭṭhahissāmi iti evam uṭṭhāna velā paricchedakam uṭṭhāna saññam citte
translated: having given attention to the perception of rising up, which is the perception that defines the time for rising thus, ‘At such a time I shall rise up.’

original: upetvā. Evaṃ katvā nipanno hi yathāparicchinnakāleyeva uṭṭhātuṃ yutto.
analyzed: upetvā evam katvā nipannaḥ hi uṭṭhātum yuttaḥ
translated: For one who lies down to sleep in this way is fit to rise up at the defined time.

original: 520-521. Sātaccaṃ nepakkanti satataṃ pavattayitabbato sātaccasaṅkhātaṃ vīriyañceva🔽paripākagatattā nepakkasaṅkhātaṃ paññañca yutto anuyutto pavattayamānoyeva jāgariyānuyogaṃ
analyzed: sātaccam nepakkam ti satatam sātacca saṅkhātam vīriyam ca iva  paripāka gata ttā nepakka saṅkhātam paññam ca yuttaḥ anuyuttaḥ pavattayamāno yā iva jāgariya anuyogam
translated: He is possessed of and provided with constant on-looking-equanimity and with understanding that is bright,🔽and he is possessed of and provided with the practice of being watchful.

original: anuyutto viharatīti attho. Ettha ca vīriyaṃ lokiyalokuttaramissakaṃ kathitaṃ, paññāpi
analyzed: anuyuttaḥ viharati iti attho ettha ca vīriyam lokiya lokuttara missakam kathitam paññāpi
translated: The meaning is that he is possessed of and provided with the practice of the practice of being watchful. And here energy is called “constant on-looking-equanimity” because it should be constantly occurring,🔽and understanding is called “bright” because it has reached maturity.🔽And the meaning is that energy is mundane and supramundane, and so is understanding,

original: vīriyagatikā eva; vīriye lokiyamhi lokiyā, lokuttare lokuttarāti attho.
analyzed: vīriya gatikāḥ eva vīriye lokiyamhi lokiyāḥ lokuttare lokuttarā ati attho
translated: which is classed as energy.

original: 522. Bodhipakkhiyānaṃ dhammānanti catusaccabodhisaṅkhātassa maggañāṇassa pakkhe bhavānaṃ🔽dhammānaṃ. Ettāvatā sabbepi sattatiṃsa bodhipakkhiyadhamme samūhato gahetvā lokiyāyapi
analyzed: bodhi pakkhiyānam dhammānam ti catu sacca bodhi saṅkhātassa magga ñāṇassa pakkhe bhavānam  dhammānam ettāvatā sabbe pi sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhamme samūhataḥ gahetvā lokiyāya api
translated: The ideas that are enlightenment factors: of the ideas that are a condition for the knowledge of the path called “enlightenment” consisting in the three kinds of enlightenment.

original: bhāvanāya ekārammaṇe ekato pavattanasamatthe bojjhaṅgeyeva dassento satta bojjhaṅgātiādimāha.
analyzed: bhāvanāya eka ārammaṇe ekatas pavattana samatthe dassentaḥ satta bojjhaṅgā ti ādim āha
translated: So far he has taken all the thirty-seven ideas that are enlightenment factors together and he now says “seven enlightenment factors” showing that the enlightenment factors are capable of occurring together in one object in the development of the mundane kind too.

original: Te lokiyalokuttaramissakāva kathitāti veditabbā. Sesamettha heṭṭhā vuttanayattā uttānatthameva.
analyzed: te kathitā ati veditabbā sesam ettha heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā uttāna attham eva
translated: And they should be understood as mundane and supramundane. The rest is evident in meaning since it is in the way already stated .

original: 523. Abhikkantetiādiniddese abhikkante paṭikkanteti ettha tāva abhikkantaṃ vuccati
analyzed: abhikkanta iti ādi niddese abhikkante paṭikkantā iti ettha tāva abhikkantam vuccati
translated: Going forward is said

original: purato gamanaṃ. Paṭikkantanti nivattanaṃ. Tadubhayampi catūsu iriyāpathesu labbhati.🔽Gamane tāva purato kāyaṃ abhiharanto abhikkamati nāma, paṭinivattanto paṭikkamati
analyzed: puratas gamanam nivattanam tat ubhayam pi catūsu iriyāpathesu labbhati  gamane tāva puratas kāyam abhiharantaḥ abhikkamati nāma paṭinivattantaḥ paṭikkamati
translated: to be going in front; coming back is said to be turning back. Both are found in the four postures.🔽In going, in other words, one goes forward when one advances the body in front; one comes back when one turns back.

original: nāma. Ṭhānepi ṭhitakova kāyaṃ purato onāmento abhikkamati nāma, pacchato apanāmento🔽paṭikkamati nāma. Nisajjāyapi nisinnakova āsannassa purimaaṅgābhimukho saṃsaranto
analyzed: nāma ṭhāne pi ṭhitakaḥ uva kāyam puratas onāmentaḥ abhikkamati nāma pacchatas apanāmentaḥ  paṭikkamati nāma āsannassa purima aṅga abhimukho saṃsarantaḥ
translated: In standing, in other words, one goes forward when one bends the body forward; one comes back when one bends it backwards.

original: abhikkamati nāma, pacchimaaṅgappadesaṃ paccāsaṃsaranto paṭikkamati nāma. Nipajjāyapi eseva nayo.
analyzed: abhikkamati nāma pacchima aṅga ppadesam paccā saṃsaranto paṭikkamati nāma esa iva nayo
translated: In sitting, in other words, one goes forward when one moves the body forward, turning the front part towards what is in front; one comes back when one moves the back part backwards. The same method applies to lying down.

original: Sampajānakārī hotīti sampajaññena sabbakiccakārī, sampajaññasseva vā kārī. So hi
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti iti sampajaññena sabba kicca kārī sampajaññassa iva vā kārī saḥ hi
translated: He is one who acts with clear comprehension: he is one who does all his actions with clear comprehension, or he is one who acts with clear comprehension only.

original: abhikkantādīsu sampajaññaṃ karoteva, na katthaci sampajaññavirahito hoti. Taṃ pana
analyzed: abhikkanta ādīsu sampajaññam karotā iva na katthaci sampajañña virahitaḥ hoti tam pana
translated: For he acts with clear comprehension in going forward, etc., and he is never without clear comprehension at any time.

original: sampajaññaṃ yasmā satisampayuttameva hoti, tenassa niddese “sato sampajāno abhikkamati,
analyzed: sampajaññam yasmā sati sampayuttam eva hoti tena assa niddese sataḥ sampajānaḥ abhikkamati
translated: since clear comprehension is only associated with mindfulness, therefore, in the description of it, it is said: “Mindfully he walks,

original: sato sampajāno paṭikkamatī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sataḥ sampajānaḥ paṭikkamati iti vuttam
translated: mindfully he stands, mindfully he sits, mindfully he lies down” .

original: Ayañhi abhikkamanto vā paṭikkamanto vā na muṭṭhassatī asampajāno hoti; satiyā pana
analyzed: ayan hi abhikkamantaḥ vā paṭikkamantaḥ vā na muṭṭha satī asampajāno hoti satiyā pana
translated: For when he walks, stands, sits or lies down, he is not forgetful or confused, but

original: samannāgato paññāya ca sampajānoyeva abhikkamati ceva paṭikkamati ca; sabbesu abhikkamādīsu🔽catubbidhaṃ sampajaññaṃ otāreti. Catubbidhañhi sampajaññaṃ – sātthakasampajaññaṃ,
analyzed: samannāgataḥ paññāya ca sampajāno yeva abhikkamati ca iva paṭikkamati ca sabbesu abhikkama ādīsu  catubbidham sampajaññam otāreti catubbidham hi sampajaññam sātthaka sampajaññam
translated: endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension he walks, stands, sits and lies down. In all the activities of walking, etc.,

original: sappāyasampajaññaṃ, gocarasampajaññaṃ, asammohasampajaññanti. Tattha abhikkamanacitte
analyzed: sa pāya sampajaññam gocara sampajaññam a sammoha sampajaññanti tattha abhikkamana citte
translated: he applies the fourfold clear comprehension, for the fourfold clear comprehension is: clear comprehension of meaning, clear comprehension of the Teaching, clear comprehension of the letter, and clear comprehension of the time. Herein, when the mind is occupied with walking, etc.,

original: uppanne cittavaseneva agantvā ‘kinnu me ettha gatena attho atthi, natthī’ti atthānatthaṃ
analyzed: uppanne citta vasena iva a gantvā kin nu me ettha gatena atthaḥ atthi natthi iti attha anattham
translated: he does not go by the impulse of the mind alone, but he considers: “What is the purpose of my going?”

original: pariggahetvā atthapariggaṇhanaṃ ‘sātthakasampajaññaṃ’. Tattha ca ‘attho’ti cetiyadassanabodhidassanasaṅghadassanatheradassanaasubhadassanādivasena
analyzed: pariggahetvā attha pariggaṇhanam sa atthaka sampajaññam tattha ca attho ti cetiya dassana bodhi dassana saṅgha dassana thera dassana asubha dassana ādi vasena
translated: Herein, “meaning” is prosperity in the True Idea.

original: dhammato vaḍḍhi. Cetiyaṃ vā bodhiṃ vā disvāpi hi buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ, saṅghadassanena
analyzed: dhammataḥ vaḍḍhi cetiyam vā bodhim vā disvā api hi buddha ārammaṇam pītim saṅgha dassanena
translated: For by seeing a shrine or a Bodhi Tree or the Community or an elder bhikkhu or a skeleton,🔽he arouses happiness with the Enlightened One as object by seeing the shrine,🔽with the Community as object by seeing the Community,

original: saṅghārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ uppādetvā tadeva khayavayato sammasanto arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: saṅgha ārammaṇam pītim uppādetvā tat eva khaya vayataḥ sammasantaḥ arahattam pāpuṇāti
translated: and then he reaches Arahantship by comprehending that same happiness as liable to destruction and to fall.🔽By seeing an elder bhikkhu he establishes himself in the advice of elders,

original: There disvā tesaṃ ovāde patiṭṭhāya, asubhaṃ disvā tattha paṭhamajjhānaṃ uppādetvā
analyzed: there disvā tesam ovāde patiṭṭhāya asubham disvā tattha paṭhamajjhānam uppādetvā
translated: and by seeing a skeleton he arouses the first jhana there,

original: tadeva khayavayato sammasanto arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tasmā etesaṃ dassanaṃ sātthaṃ.
analyzed: tat eva khaya vayataḥ sammasantaḥ arahattam pāpuṇāti tasmai etesam dassanam sāttham
translated: and then he reaches Arahantship by comprehending that same jhana as liable to destruction and to fall. That is why seeing these things is “meaningful.”

original: Keci pana “āmisatopi vaḍḍhi atthoyeva; taṃ nissāya brahmacariyānuggahāya paṭipannattā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: keci pana āmisataḥ pi vaḍḍhi attho yeva tam nissāya brahmacariya anuggahāya paṭipanna ttā ti vadanti
translated: But some say that “prosperity in the material sense is also meaning, since it is a help to the life of purity because it is the support for it.”

original: Tasmiṃ pana gamane sappāyāsappāyaṃ pariggahetvā sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ ‘sappāyasampajaññaṃ’,
analyzed: tasmim pana gamane sappāya asappāyam pariggahetvā sappāya pariggaṇhanam sappāya sampajaññam
translated: And the discerning of what is suitable in that journey is “understanding of what is suitable.”

original: seyyathidaṃ – cetiyadassanaṃ tāva sātthaṃ. Sace pana cetiyassa mahatiyā pūjāya dasadvādasayojanantare
analyzed: sā iyyathā idam cetiya dassanam tāva sa attham sace pana cetiyassa mahatiyā pūjāya dasa dvādasa yojana antare
translated: For instance, the sight of a shrine is beneficial. But if a crowd of people gather there from a distance of ten or twelve leagues to worship the shrine on a grand scale,

original: parisā sannipatanti, attano vibhavānurūpaṃ itthiyopi purisāpi alaṅkatapaṭiyattā cittakammarūpakāni🔽viya sañcaranti, tatra cassa iṭṭhe ārammaṇe lobho, aniṭṭhe paṭigho, asamapekkhane
analyzed: parisā sannipatanti attanaḥ vibhava anurūpam itthiyaḥ api purisā api alaṅkata paṭiyattā citta kamma rūpakāni  viya sañcaranti tatra ca ssa iṭṭhe ārammaṇe lobhaḥ aniṭṭhe paṭighaḥ a samapekkhane
translated: and men and women go about in festive array, like pictures in a magic display,

original: moho uppajjati, kāyasaṃsaggāpattiṃ vā āpajjati, jīvitabrahmacariyānaṃ vā antarāyo
analyzed: mohaḥ uppajjati kāya saṃsagga āpattim vā āpajjati jīvita brahmacariyānam vā antarāyaḥ
translated: then greed arises in him about the objects that please him, resentment about those that displease him, and delusion about those that he does not examine. Or he may commit an offense entailing immediate expulsion by making physical contact. Or he may create an obstacle to his life or to his celibacy.

original: hoti. Evaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ asappāyaṃ hoti. Vuttappakāraantarāyābhāve sappāyaṃ. Bodhidassanepi🔽eseva nayo. Saṅghadassanampi sātthaṃ. Sace pana antogāme mahāmaṇḍapaṃ kāretvā sabbarattiṃ
analyzed: hoti evam tat ṭhānam asappāyam hoti vutta ppakāra antarāya abhāve sappāyam bodhi dassane pi  esa iva nayaḥ saṅgha dassanam pi sa attham sace pana antogāme mahā maṇḍapam kāretvā sabbarattim
translated: In this way that place is not suitable. It is suitable if there is no such obstacle. The same method applies to the sight of the Bodhi tree.🔽The sight of the Sangha is beneficial. But if a large pavilion is erected in a village and people gather there all night listening to the Dhamma,

original: dhammassavanaṃ karontesu manussesu vuttappakāreneva janasannipāto ceva antarāyo ca
analyzed: dhammassavanam karontesu manussesu vutta ppakārena iva jana sannipātaḥ ca iva antarāyaḥ ca
translated: then the gathering of people and the obstacle are as described.

original: hoti. Evaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ asappāyaṃ hoti; antarāyābhāve sappāyaṃ hoti. Mahāparisaparivārānaṃ
analyzed: hoti evam tam ṭhānam asappāyam hoti antarāya abhāve sappāyam hoti
translated: That is how the place is unsuitable. It is suitable if there is no obstruction.

original: therānaṃ dassanepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: therānam dassane pi esa iva nayo
translated: The same method applies to the sight of elder bhikkhus who have a large retinue.

original: Asubhadassanampi sātthaṃ. Tadatthadīpanatthañca idaṃ vatthu – eko kira daharabhikkhu
analyzed: asubha dassanam pi sa attham tad attha dīpana attham ca idam vatthu ekaḥ kira dahara bhikkhu
translated: The sight of foulness is beneficial. And the following story is told in order to illustrate this:

original: sāmaṇeraṃ gahetvā dantakaṭṭhatthāya gato. Sāmaṇero maggā okkamitvā purato gacchanto🔽asubhaṃ disvā paṭhamajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā tadeva pādakaṃ katvā saṅkhāre sammasanto
analyzed: sāmaṇeram gahetvā dantakaṭṭhatthāya gataḥ sāmaṇeraḥ maggā okkamitvā puratas gacchantaḥ  asubham disvā paṭhamajjhānam nibbattetvā tat eva pādakam katvā saṅkhāre sammasantaḥ
translated: A young bhikkhu went with a novice pupil to get tooth wood. The novice went down a path and walked in front.

original: tīṇi phalāni sacchikatvā uparimaggatthāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariggahetvā aṭṭhāsi. Daharo🔽taṃ apassanto “sāmaṇerā”ti pakkosi. So ‘mayā pabbajitadivasato paṭṭhāya bhikkhunā
analyzed: tīṇi phalāni sacchikatvā upari magga tthāya kammaṭṭhānam pariggahetvā aṭṭhāsi daharaḥ  tam a passanto sāmaṇera ati pakkosi saḥ mayā pabbajita divasataḥ paṭṭhāya bhikkhunā
translated: He saw some foulness, and after developing it to absorption, he made it the preliminary work and by comprehending formations reached the three fruitions. Then he stood there taking up meditation subjects for the higher paths.🔽The young bhikkhu, not seeing him, called out “Novice!”

original: saddhiṃ dve kathā nāma na kathitapubbā, aññasmiṃ divase uparivisesaṃ nibbattessāmī’ti
analyzed: saddhim dve kathā nāma na kathita pubbā aññasmin divase upari visesam nibbattessāmi iti
translated: The novice thought, “Since the day I went forth I have never had a conversation with a bhikkhu, let alone two. I shall attain the higher distinction on another day.”

original: cintetvā “kiṃ, bhante”ti paṭivacanaṃ adāsi. “Ehī”ti ca vutto ekavacaneneva āgantvā
analyzed: cintetvā kim bhante iti paṭivacanam adāsi ehi iti ca vuttaḥ eka vacanena iva āgantvā
translated: and when he had thought it out he gave his answer. “Come,” said the Elder, and when he had come with the single word “Come,”

original: “bhante, iminā tāva maggena gantvā mayā ṭhitokāse muhuttaṃ puratthābhimukho ṭhatvā
analyzed: bhante iminā tāva maggena gantvā mayā ṭhita ukāse muhuttam purattha abhimukhaḥ ṭhatvā
translated: he said, “Venerable sir, go by this path and stand facing east for a moment at the place where I stand.

original: olokethā”ti āha. So tathā katvā tena pattavisesameva pāpuṇi. Evaṃ ekaṃ asubhaṃ dvinnaṃ
analyzed: āha saḥ tathā katvā tena patta visesam eva pāpuṇi evam ekam asubham dvinnam
translated: Then look up.” He did so, and he saw only the difference in the bowl. So one meditation subject arose for the benefit of two people.

original: janānaṃ atthāya jātaṃ. Evaṃ sātthampi panetaṃ purisassa mātugāmāsubhaṃ asappāyaṃ,
analyzed: janānam atthāya jātam evam sa attham pi pana itam purisassa mātu gāma asubham a sappāyam
translated: So too, although this foulness is beneficial, it is unsuitable for a man to meditate upon the foulness of a woman,

original: mātugāmassa ca purisāsubhaṃ, sabhāgameva sappāyanti. Evaṃ sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ nāma.
analyzed: mātugāmassa ca purisa asubham sa bhāgam eva sappāyanti evam sappāya pariggaṇhanam sappāya sampajaññam nāma
translated: and it is unsuitable for a woman to meditate upon the foulness of a man. It is only suitable for them to meditate upon the foulness of what is of the same sex. This is what is called “knowledge of what is suitable.”

original: Evaṃ pariggahitasātthasappāyassa pana aṭṭhatiṃsāya kammaṭṭhānesu attano cittaruciyaṃ
analyzed: evam pariggahita sāttha sappāyassa pana aṭṭhatiṃsāya kammaṭṭhānesu attano citta ruciyam
translated: When he has thus discerned what is beneficial and what is suitable, he should choose one of the thirty-eight meditation subjects according to his own bent and according to the teacher’s directions.🔽This is what is called “knowledge of what is beneficial.”

original: kammaṭṭhānasaṅkhātaṃ gocaraṃ uggahetvā bhikkhācāragocare taṃ gahetvāva gamanaṃ ‘gocarasampajaññaṃ’
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna saṅkhātam gocaram uggahetvā bhikkhācāra gocare tam gahetvā ava gamanam gocara sampajaññam
translated: When he has chosen it, he should learn the meditation subject by heart in the teacher’s presence, and he should go to a lodging for the purpose of undertaking the meditation subject. This is what is called “knowledge of what is suitable.”

original: nāma. Tassāvibhāvanatthaṃ idaṃ catukkaṃ veditabbaṃ –
analyzed: nāma tassa a vibhāvana attham idam catukkam veditabbam
translated: This tetrad should be understood as the explanation of that.

original: Idhekacco bhikkhu harati na paccāharati, ekacco na harati paccāharati, ekacco pana
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu harati na paccāharati ekaccaḥ na harati paccāharati ekaccaḥ pana
translated: Herein, one bhikkhu may take and not return; another may not take and yet return;

original: neva harati na paccāharati, ekacco harati ca paccāharati ca. Tattha yo bhikkhu divasaṃ
analyzed: na iva harati na paccāharati ekaccaḥ harati ca paccāharati ca tattha yaḥ bhikkhu divasam
translated: another may neither take nor return; and another may both take and return.

original: caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṃ parisodhetvā, tathā rattiyā paṭhamayāme
analyzed: caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittam parisodhetvā tathā rattiyā paṭhama yāme
translated: Herein, the bhikkhu who, after purifying his mind from obstructive states by a day’s practice of walking and sitting meditation,

original: majjhimayāme seyyaṃ kappetvā pacchimayāmepi nisajjācaṅkamehi vītināmetvā pageva cetiyaṅgaṇabodhiyaṅgaṇavattaṃ
analyzed: majjhima yāme seyyam kappetvā pacchima yāme pi nisajja ācaṅkamehi vītināmetvā pagā iva cetiyaṅgaṇa bodhiyaṅgaṇa vattam
translated: does likewise in the first watch of the night, and in the middle watch of the night prepares his bed in his own room and lies down on his right side in the last watch of the night, passing the time in the postures of walking and sitting, and after doing the duties of the shrine terrace and the Bodhi tree,

original: katvā bodhirukkhe udakaṃ āsiñcitvā pānīyaṃ paribhojanīyaṃ paccupaṭṭhāpetvā ācariyupajjhāyavattādīni
analyzed: katvā bodhi rukkhe udakam āsiñcitvā pānīyam paribhojanīyam paccupaṭṭhāpetvā ācariya upajjhāya vatta ādīni
translated: after watering the Bodhi tree and setting out drinking water and water for washing, and after doing the duties to teachers and preceptors, etc.,

original: sabbāni khandhakavattāni samādāya vattati, so sarīraparikammaṃ katvā senāsanaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: sabbāni khandhaka vattāni samādāya vattati so sarīra parikammam katvā senāsanam pavisitvā
translated: and after undertaking all the duties of the chapter, does his bodily duties, and after entering his living room,

original: dve tayo pallaṅke usumaṃ gāhāpento kammaṭṭhānaṃ anuyuñjitvā, bhikkhācāravelāya uṭṭhahitvā
analyzed: dve tayo pallaṅke usumam gāhāpento kammaṭṭhānam anuyuñjitvā bhikkhā cāra velāya uṭṭhahitvā
translated: and after warming his two feet on two embers, practices his meditation subject, and after rising at the time of the alms round,

original: kammaṭṭhānasīseneva pattacīvaramādāya senāsanato nikkhamitvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontova
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva patta cīvaram ādāya senāsanataḥ nikkhamitvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ uva
translated: he should leave his lodging and go to the shrine terrace, giving attention to his meditation subject all the while.🔽If his meditation subject is the recollection of the Buddha, he should enter the shrine terrace without hurrying,

original: cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ gantvā, sace buddhānussatikammaṭṭhānaṃ hoti taṃ avissajjetvāva cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ
analyzed: cetiya ṅgaṇam gantvā sace buddha anussati kammaṭṭhānam hoti tam a vissajjetvā ava cetiya ṅgaṇam
translated: and after he has closed the door he should put aside his meditation subject and take up the recollection of the Buddha.🔽He should then sit down and do his reviewing.🔽If he is able to arouse absorption, he should do the paying of homage while in that state.

original: pavisati, aññaṃ ce kammaṭṭhānaṃ hoti sopānamūle ṭhatvā hatthena gahitabhaṇḍaṃ viya
analyzed: pavisati aññam ce kammaṭṭhānam hoti sopāna mūle ṭhatvā hatthena gahita bhaṇḍam viya
translated: But if he is not able to do so, he should arouse the happiness and bliss of tranquillity and do the paying of homage while in that state.🔽If he is not able to do that either, he should arouse the happiness and bliss of access and do the paying of homage while in that state.

original: taṃ ṭhapetvā buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ gahetvā cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ āruyha mahantaṃ cetiyaṃ ce,🔽tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditabbaṃ, khuddakaṃ ce, tatheva padakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: tam ṭhapetvā buddha ārammaṇam pītim gahetvā cetiyaṅgaṇam āruyha mahantam cetiyam ce  tikkhattum padakkhiṇam katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditabbam khuddakam ce tathā iva padakkhiṇam
translated: If he is not able to do that either, he should arouse the happiness and bliss of the divine abodes and do the paying of homage while in that state.🔽If he is not able to do that either, he should arouse the happiness and bliss of the jhānas and do the paying of homage while in that state.

original: katvā aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu vanditabbaṃ. Cetiyaṃ vanditvā bodhiyaṅgaṇaṃ pattenāpi buddhassa
analyzed: katvā aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu vanditabbam cetiyam vanditvā bodhi yaṅgaṇam pattena api buddhassa
translated: If he is not able to do that either, he should arouse the happiness and bliss of the paths and fruits and do the paying of homage while in that state.

original: bhagavato sammukhā viya nipaccākāraṃ dassetvā bodhi vanditabbā.
analyzed: bhagavato sammukhā viya nipacca ākāram dassetvā bodhi vanditabbā
translated: If he is not able to do that either, he should arouse the happiness and bliss of the divine abodes and do the paying of homage while in that state.🔽If he is not able to do that either, he should arouse the happiness and bliss of the jhānas and do the paying of homage while in that state.

original: So evaṃ cetiyañca bodhiñca vanditvā paṭisāmitaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā, paṭisāmitaṃ bhaṇḍakaṃ
analyzed: saḥ evam cetiyam ca bodhim ca vanditvā paṭisāmita ṭṭhānam gantvā paṭisāmitam bhaṇḍakam
translated: If he is not able to do that either, he should arouse the happiness and bliss of the paths and fruits and do the paying of homage while in that state.

original: hatthena gaṇhanto viya, nikkhittakammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā gāmasamīpe kammaṭṭhānasīseneva
analyzed: hatthena gaṇhantaḥ viya nikkhitta kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā gāma samīpe kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva
translated: He puts on his sarong evenly all round,🔽and then he puts on his upper robe evenly all over,🔽and taking his bowl, he enters the village or town for alms.

original: cīvaraṃ pārupitvā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisati. Atha naṃ manussā disvā ‘ayyo no āgato’ti🔽paccuggantvā pattaṃ gahetvā āsanasālāya vā gehe vā nisīdāpetvā yāguṃ datvā yāva bhattaṃ
analyzed: cīvaram pārupitvā gāmam piṇḍāya pavisati atha nam manussāḥ disvā ayyaḥ naḥ āgataḥ iti  paccuggantvā pattam gahetvā āsana sālāya vā gehe vā nisīdāpetvā yāgum datvā yāva bhattam
translated: When people see him, they go out to meet him, thinking, “The venerable one has come,”🔽and they take his bowl to set it down, and they take his outer robe to fold it and put it away, and they take his seat to set it up.

original: na niṭṭhāti tāva pāde dhovitvā telena makkhetvā purato nisīditvā pañhaṃ vā pucchanti🔽dhammaṃ vā sotukāmā honti. Sacepi na kathāpenti “janasaṅgahatthaṃ dhammakathā nāma
analyzed: na pāde dhovitvā telena makkhetvā puratas nisīditvā pañham vā pucchanti  dhammam vā sotu kāmāḥ honti sace pi na kathāpenti jana saṅga hattham dhammakathā nāma
translated: They give him rice gruel and they wash his feet, and they anoint his feet with oil, and they sit in front of him to listen to the Dhamma.🔽If they do not ask for a Dhamma talk, the teachers of the commentaries say that he should give them one, thinking “This is for the purpose of winning people over.”

original: kātabbāyevā”ti aṭṭhakathācariyā vadanti. Dhammakathā hi kammaṭṭhānavinimuttā nāma
analyzed: kātabbāya eva ati aṭṭhakathā cariyāḥ vadanti dhammakathā hi kammaṭṭhāna vinimuttā nāma
translated: For there is no Dhamma talk outside the meditation subject.

original: natthi. Tasmā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva āhāraṃ paribhuñjitvā anumodanaṃ vatvā nivattiyamānehipi
analyzed: natthi tasmai kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva āhāram paribhuñjitvā anumodanam vatvā
translated: So he should eat his food with the meditation subject as his primary concern, and after the meal he should give the blessing and then depart.

original: manussehi anugatova gāmato nikkhamitvā tattha te nivattetvā maggaṃ paṭipajjati.
analyzed: manussehi anugataḥ eva gāmataḥ nikkhamitvā tattha te nivattetvā maggam paṭipajjati
translated: Even when people follow after him, he should turn back and go his way.

original: Atha naṃ puretaraṃ nikkhamitvā bahigāme katabhattakiccā sāmaṇeradaharabhikkhū disvā
analyzed: atha nam puretaram nikkhamitvā bahigāme kata bhatta kiccā sāmaṇera dahara bhikkhū disvā
translated: Then, when the young bhikkhus and probationers who had gone out earlier had finished their meal in the village and returned,

original: paccuggantvā pattacīvaramassa gaṇhanti. Porāṇakabhikkhū kira ‘amhākaṃ upajjhāyo,
analyzed: paccuggantvā patta cīvaram assa gaṇhanti porāṇaka bhikkhū kira amhākam upajjhāyaḥ
translated: they saw him and went out to meet him, taking his bowl and robe. The senior bhikkhus did not look at his face, thinking: ‘He is our preceptor,

original: amhākaṃ ācariyo’ti na mukhaṃ oloketvā vattaṃ karonti, sampattaparicchedeneva karonti.🔽Te taṃ pucchanti “bhante, ete manussā tumhākaṃ kiṃ honti? Mātipakkhato sambandhā
analyzed: amhākam ācariyo ti na mukham oloketvā vattam karonti sampatta paricchedena iva karonti  te tam pucchanti bhante ete manussā tumhākam kim honti māti pakkhato sambandhā
translated: he is our teacher,’ but they did the duties by the rule of priority of arrival.

original: pitipakkhato”ti? “Kiṃ disvā pucchathā”ti? “Tumhesu etesaṃ pemaṃ bahumāna”nti. “Āvuso,
analyzed: piti pakkhato ti kim disvā pucchatha ati tumhesu etesam āvuso
translated: They asked him: ‘Venerable sir, what are these people to you? Are they your relatives on your mother’s side or on your father’s side?’—‘Why do you ask?’—‘Because of your affection and respect for them.’—‘Friends,

original: yaṃ mātāpitūhipi dukkaraṃ taṃ ete manussā amhākaṃ karonti. Pattacīvarampi no etesaṃ🔽santakameva, etesaṃ ānubhāvena neva bhaye bhayaṃ, na chātake chātakaṃ jānāma. Edisā
analyzed: yam mātā pitūhi pi dukkaram tam ete manussāḥ amhākam karonti pattacīvaram pi no etesam  santakam eva ānubhāvena na iva bhaye bhayam na chātake chātakam jānāma edisā
translated: these people do for us what is difficult to do even by mother and father. Our bowl and robe are theirs.

original: nāma amhākaṃ upakārino natthī”ti tesaṃ guṇe kathento gacchati. Ayaṃ vuccati ‘harati na paccāharatī’ti.
analyzed: nāma amhākam upakārinaḥ natthi iti tesam guṇe kathentaḥ gacchati ayam vuccati harati na paccāharati iti
translated: By their power we know no fear in the forest, nor cold in winter, nor heat in summer. There are none who have done so much for us as these.’ And he went on praising them. This is called ‘he carries but does not bring back.’

original: Yassa pana pageva vuttappakāraṃ vattapaṭipattiṃ karontassa kammajatejo pajjalati,🔽anupādinnakaṃ muñcitvā upādinnakaṃ gaṇhāti, sarīrato sedā muccanti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽vīthiṃ nārohati, so pageva pattacīvaramādāya vegasāva cetiyaṃ vanditvā gorūpānaṃ
analyzed: yassa pana pagā iva vutta ppakāram vatta paṭipattim karontassa kamma ja tejaḥ pajjalati  an upādinnakam muñcitvā upādinnakam gaṇhāti sarīrataḥ sedāḥ muccanti kammaṭṭhānam  vīthim na ārohati saḥ pagā iva patta cīvaram ādāya cetiyam vanditvā go rūpānam
translated: But if the fire of his kamma breaks out even while he is doing the duties in the way stated,🔽and if he finds that he cannot hold on to the in-breath, but has to let it go and take the out-breath instead, and if sweat breaks out on his body, and if his meditation subject does not go well with him,🔽then he should go to the shrine, taking bowl and robe, and worship the shrine quickly without sitting down in the place of worship.

original: nikkhamanavelāyameva gāmaṃ yāgubhikkhāya pavisitvā yāguṃ labhitvā āsanasālaṃ gantvā🔽pivati. Athassa dvattikkhattuṃ ajjhoharaṇamatteneva kammajatejodhātu upādinnakaṃ🔽muñcitvā anupādinnakaṃ gaṇhāti, ghaṭasatena nhāto viya tejodhātupariḷāhanibbānaṃ
analyzed: nikkhamana velāyam eva gāmam yāgu bhikkhāya pavisitvā yāgum labhitvā āsana sālam gantvā  pivati athassa dvatti kkhattum ajjhoharaṇa mattena iva kamma ja tejaḥ dhātu upādinnakam  muñcitvā anupādinnakam gaṇhāti ghaṭa satena nhātaḥ viya tejodhātu pariḷāha nibbānam
translated: Then he should go to the village for alms without returning to the lodging.🔽When he has got alms food, he should go to the reception hall and drink rice gruel.🔽Then, as soon as he has drunk the gruel, the fire element in his body, instead of burning up the in-breath, burns up the out-breath,

original: patvā kammaṭṭhānasīsena yāguṃ paribhuñjitvā pattañca mukhañca dhovitvā antarābhatte
analyzed: patvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena yāgum paribhuñjitvā pattam ca mukham ca dhovitvā antarābhatte
translated: and he attains quenching by extinguishing the fire of the fire element, as it were, with water.🔽After that he can eat his meal with his meditation subject as his only concern.

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikatvā avasesaṭṭhāne piṇḍāya caritvā kammaṭṭhānasīsena āhāraṃ paribhuñjitvā
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam manasikatvā avasesa ṭṭhāne piṇḍāya caritvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena āhāram paribhuñjitvā
translated: Then, after washing his bowl and his mouth, he should give attention to his meditation subject during the last watch of the night too.

original: tato paṭṭhāya poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ upaṭṭhahamānaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvāva āgacchati. Ayaṃ
analyzed: tatas paṭṭhāya poṅkha anupoṅkham upaṭṭhahamānam kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā ava āgacchati ayam
translated: From then on he comes back taking the meditation subject with him, keeping it in mind, reviewing it.

original: vuccati ‘na harati paccāharatī’ti. Edisā ca bhikkhū yāguṃ pivitvā vipassanaṃ ārabhitvā🔽buddhasāsane arahattaṃ pattā nāma gaṇanapathaṃ vītivattā. Sīhaḷadīpeyeva tesu tesu
analyzed: vuccati na harati paccāharati iti edisā ca bhikkhū yāgum pivitvā vipassanam ārabhitvā  buddha sāsane arahattam pattā nāma gaṇana patham vītivattā tesu tesu
translated: This is called ‘he does not carry back but carries forward.’🔽Monks of this sort, after drinking rice gruel, begin insight and reach Arahantship in the Dispensation.

original: gāmesu āsanasālāya na taṃ āsanaṃ atthi, yattha yāguṃ pivitvā arahattaṃ pattā bhikkhū natthīti.
analyzed: gāmesu āsana sālāya na tat āsanam atthi yattha yāgum pivitvā arahattam pattā bhikkhū na atthi iti
translated: In the Island of Sri Lanka there is no sitting-hall in any village where there is no monk who has reached Arahantship after drinking rice gruel.🔽He who lives in negligence,

original: Yo pamādavihārī hoti nikkhittadhuro sabbavattāni bhinditvā pañcavidhacetokhīlavinibandhabaddhacitto
analyzed: yaḥ pamāda vihārī hoti nikkhitta dhuraḥ sabbavattāni bhinditvā pañcavidha cetaḥ khīla vinibandha baddha cittaḥ
translated: who breaks all the rules of good conduct, whose mind is bound by the fivefold bondage of the mind,

original: viharanto ‘kammaṭṭhānaṃ nāma atthī’tipi saññaṃ akatvā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisitvā ananulomikena
analyzed: viharantaḥ kammaṭṭhānam nāma atthi itipi saññam a katvā gāmam piṇḍāya pavisitvā ananulomikena
translated: who does not even think ‘There is a meditation subject’ but enters the village for alms without restraint,

original: gihīsaṃsaggena saṃsaṭṭho caritvā ca bhuñjitvā ca tuccho nikkhamati – ayaṃ vuccati
analyzed: gihī saṃsaggena saṃsaṭṭhaḥ caritvā ca bhuñjitvā ca tucchaḥ nikkhamati ayam vuccati
translated: who goes about and eats alms food entangled in worldly talk, and who comes away from the village empty-minded—

original: ‘neva harati na paccāharatī’ti.
analyzed: na iva harati na paccāharati iti
translated: this is called ‘he neither carries back nor carries forward.’

original: Yo panāyaṃ “harati ca paccāharati cā”ti vutto, so gatapaccāgatikavattavasena veditabbo🔽– atthakāmā hi kulaputtā sāsane pabbajitvā dasampi vīsampi tiṃsampi cattārīsampi
analyzed: yaḥ pana ayam harati ca paccāharati ca ati vuttaḥ saḥ gatapaccāgatika vatta vasena veditabbaḥ  attha kāmā hi kula puttā sāsane pabbajitvā dasam pi vīsam pi tiṃsam pi cattārīsam pi
translated: The one described as “one who steals and steals back” should be understood as follows:🔽Young men of good family who have gone forth in the Dispensation, being desirous of welfare, live in community, observing the proper conduct, to the number of ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, or a hundred,

original: paññāsampi satampi ekato vasantā katikavattaṃ katvā viharanti – “āvuso, tumhe na
analyzed: paññāsam pi satam pi ekatas vasantā katikavattam katvā viharanti āvuso tumhe na
translated: and they make a rule thus: “Friends, we have gone forth

original: iṇaṭṭā, na bhayaṭṭā, na ājīvikāpakatā pabbajitā; dukkhā muñcitukāmā panettha pabbajitā.
analyzed: iṇaṭṭā na bhayaṭṭā na ājīvikā pakatā pabbajitā dukkhā muñcitu kāmā pana ittha pabbajitā
translated: not because we are in debt, not through fear of kings, not because our livelihood is threatened, but we have gone forth seeking after the state of peace, seeking after the supreme good.

original: Tasmā gamane uppannakilesaṃ gamaneyeva niggaṇhatha. Ṭhāne, nisajjāya, sayane uppannakilesaṃ
analyzed: tasmai gamane uppanna kilesam gamaneya iva niggaṇhatha ṭhāne nisajjāya sayane uppanna kilesam
translated: So when defilements arise in walking, let them be suppressed in walking; when they arise in standing, sitting, or lying down,

original: sayaneyeva niggaṇhathā”ti.
analyzed: sayaneya iva niggaṇhatha ati
translated: let them be suppressed in lying down.”

original: Te evaṃ katikavattaṃ katvā bhikkhācāraṃ gacchantā, aḍḍhausabhausabhaaḍḍhagāvutagāvutantaresu
analyzed: te evam katikavattam katvā bhikkhācāram gacchantā aḍḍhausabha ausabha aḍḍhagāvutagāvuta antaresu
translated: When they go on their alms round observing this rule, there are stones in the road at intervals of a cubit, a span, a hand- ful, a cart-load, a cart-wheel’s width,

original: pāsāṇā honti, tāya saññāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontāva gacchanti. Sace kassaci gamane
analyzed: pāsāṇāḥ honti tāya saññāya kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontā ava gacchanti sace kassaci gamane
translated: and they go on their alms round keeping their attention on the meditation subject by means of the sign of the stones. If any defilements arise in walking,

original: kileso uppajjati, tattheva naṃ niggaṇhāti. Tathā asakkonto tiṭṭhati. Athassa pacchato
analyzed: kilesaḥ uppajjati tattha eva nam niggaṇhāti tathā a sakkontaḥ tiṭṭhati atha assa pacchatas
translated: and if defilement arises, he suppresses it right there. If he is unable to do so, he remains (aware of that fact),🔽and then,

original: āgacchantopi tiṭṭhati. So ‘ayaṃ bhikkhu tuyhaṃ uppannaṃ vitakkaṃ jānāti, ananucchavikaṃ
analyzed: āgacchantaḥ api tiṭṭhati saḥ ayam bhikkhu tuyham uppannam vitakkam jānāti ananucchavikam
translated: If he cannot do so, he stands still. Then the other stands still too. He thinks, “This bhikkhu knows the thought that has arisen in me. It is not proper for me to go on.

original: te eta’nti attānaṃ paṭicodetvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā ariyabhūmiṃ okkamati. Tathā asakkonto
analyzed: te etat ti attānam paṭicodetvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā ariya bhūmim okkamati tathā a sakkontaḥ
translated: ” He confesses his faults, develops insight, and attains the supramundane state. If he cannot do so,

original: nisīdati. Athassa pacchato āgacchantopi nisīdatīti so eva nayo. Ariyabhūmiṃ okkamituṃ🔽asakkontopi taṃ kilesaṃ vikkhambhetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontova gacchati, na kammaṭṭhānavippayuttena
analyzed: nisīdati athassa pacchatas āgacchantaḥ api nisīdati iti saḥ eva nayaḥ ariya bhūmim okkamitum  a sakkontaḥ api tam kilesam vikkhambhetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ eva gacchati na kammaṭṭhāna vippayuttena
translated: he sits down. Then the other sits down too. The same method applies. If he cannot attain the supramundane state,

original: cittena pādaṃ uddharati, uddharati ce paṭinivattitvā purimapadesaññeva eti, ālindakavāsī
analyzed: cittena pādam uddharati uddharati ce paṭinivattitvā eti ālindaka vāsī
translated: he should suppress the defilement and go on with his meditation subject in mind. He should not lift up his foot with a mind that is not associated with his meditation subject. If he does so, he should return and go back to the place he has left behind. He should be like the Elder Mahā-Phussadeva of Āḷavaka.

original: mahāphussadevatthero viya. So kira ekūnavīsati vassāni gatapaccāgatavattaṃ pūrento
analyzed: mahāphussa deva ttheraḥ viya saḥ kira ekūnavīsati vassāni gata paccāgata vattam pūrento
translated: It seems that he spent nineteen years fulfilling the duties of going and returning.

original: eva vihāsi. Manussāpi antarāmagge kasantā ca vapantā ca maddantā ca kammāni ca karontā
analyzed: eva vihāsi manussā api antarāmagge kasantā ca vapantā ca maddantā ca kammāni ca karontā
translated: and so he went on. People who were ploughing and sowing and doing other work on the road saw him going in this way.

original: theraṃ tathāgacchantaṃ disvā “ayaṃ thero punappunaṃ nivattitvā gacchati, kiṃ nu kho
analyzed: theram tathāgacchantam disvā ayam thero punappunam nivattitvā gacchati kim nu kho
translated: They said to one another, “This elder goes on turning round and round. What is the matter?🔽Is he lost on the road? Or is he confused about something? ”

original: maggamūḷho udāhu kiñci pamuṭṭho”ti samullapanti. So taṃ anādiyitvā kammaṭṭhānayuttacitteneva
analyzed: magga mūḷhaḥ udāhu kiñci pamuṭṭhaḥ iti samullapanti saḥ tam an ādiyitvā kammaṭṭhāna yutta cittena iva
translated: But the elder paid no attention to them. He was intent on his meditation subject and was doing his spiritual work.

original: samaṇadhammaṃ karonto vīsativassabbhantare arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Arahattapattadivase🔽cassa caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ adhivatthā devatā aṅgulīhi dīpaṃ ujjāletvā aṭṭhāsi. Cattāropi
analyzed: samaṇa dhammam karontaḥ vīsati vassa abbhantare arahattam pāpuṇi arahatta patta divase  cassa caṅkamana koṭiyam adhivatthā devatā aṅgulīhi dīpam ujjāletvā aṭṭhāsi cattāro pi
translated: Within twenty years he reached Arahantship.

original: mahārājāno sakko ca devānamindo brahmā ca sahampati upaṭṭhānaṃ āgamiṃsu. Tañca obhāsaṃ
analyzed: mahā rājāno sakko ca devānamindaḥ brahmā ca sahampati upaṭṭhānam āgamiṃsu tat ca obhāsam
translated: On the day he reached Arahantship a deity who lived at the end of the walk dwelt on by the elder lit a torch with her finger-nails. The four Great Kings, Sakka Ruler of Gods, and Brahma Sahampati all came to wait on him.🔽When the elder Mahā Tissa, who lived in the forest, saw that light,

original: disvā vanavāsī mahātissatthero taṃ dutiyadivase pucchi – “rattibhāge āyasmato santike
analyzed: disvā vana vāsī mahā tissa theraḥ tam dutiya divase pucchi ratti bhāge āyasmato santike
translated: he asked the elder about it on the following day, saying, “Venerable sir, there was a light in your presence last night.

original: obhāso ahosi. Kiṃ so obhāso”ti? Thero vikkhepaṃ karonto “obhāso nāma dīpobhāsopi
analyzed: obhāsaḥ ahosi kim saḥ obhāsaḥ ti thero vikkhepam karonto obhāsaḥ nāma dīpa ubhāsaḥ api
translated: What was that light? ” The elder prevaricated, saying, “There are lights called ‘ fireflies ’, ‘ glow-worms ’,

original: hoti, maṇiobhāsopī”ti evamādimāha. Tato “paṭicchādetha tumhe”ti nibaddho “āmā”ti
analyzed: evamādim āha tatas tumhā iti nibaddhaḥ
translated: and the light of the jewel.” Then he said, “Conceal yourselves.” They replied, “Yes,” and they concealed themselves.

original: paṭijānitvā ārocesi.
analyzed: paṭijānitvā ārocesi
translated: He then confessed.
