original: Kāḷavallimaṇḍapavāsī mahānāgatthero viya ca. Sopi kira gatapaccāgatavattaṃ pūrento
analyzed: kāḷavalli maṇḍapa vāsī mahā nāga ttheraḥ ca saḥ api kira gata paccāgata vattam pūrento
translated: And like the Elder Mahānāga who lived in the Kāḷavellī Monastery. It seems that he was fulfilling the duties of going and coming.

original: ‘paṭhamaṃ tāva bhagavato mahāpadhānaṃ pūjessāmī’ti satta vassāni ṭhānacaṅkamameva
analyzed: paṭhamam tāva bhagavataḥ mahāpadhānam pūjessāmi iti satta vassāni ṭhāna caṅkamam eva
translated: Thinking, “First I shall fulfill the Great Sage’s Dispensation,” he remained for seven years in the posture of walking and standing.

original: adhiṭṭhāsi; puna soḷasa vassāni gatapaccāgatavattaṃ pūretvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. So
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāsi puna soḷasa vassāni gata paccāgata vattam pūretvā arahattam pāpuṇi so
translated: Again, for sixteen years he fulfilled the duties of going and coming and then attained arahatship.

original: kammaṭṭhānayutteneva cittena pādaṃ uddharanto vippayuttena cittena uddhate pāde paṭinivattento
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna yuttena iva cittena pādam uddharantaḥ vippayuttena cittena uddhate pāde paṭinivattentaḥ
translated: He raised his foot with a consciousness associated with a meditation subject, and he turned back his raised foot with an unassociated consciousness.

original: gāmasīmaṃ gantvā ‘gāvī nu kho, pabbajito nu kho’ti āsaṅkanīyappadese ṭhatvā cīvaraṃ
analyzed: gāma sīmam gantvā gāvī nu kho pabbajitaḥ nu kho ti āsaṅkanīya ppadese ṭhatvā cīvaram
translated: When he reached the village boundary, he stood in a place where it might be doubted whether he was an ox or a monk. He put on his waistband,

original: pārupitvā kacchakantarato udakena pattaṃ dhovitvā udakagaṇḍūsaṃ karoti. Kiṃ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kaccha kantarataḥ udakena pattam dhovitvā udaka gaṇḍūsam karoti kim kāraṇā
translated: washed his bowl in the water in the waistband, and made a water strainer. Why?

original: ‘Mā me bhikkhaṃ dātuṃ vā vandituṃ vā āgate manusse ‘dīghāyukā hothā’ti vacanamattenāpi
analyzed: mā me bhikkham dātum vā vanditum vā āgate manusse dīgha āyukāḥ hotha ati vacana mattena api
translated: “So that when people come to give me alms or to pay homage, I may at least wish them ‘May you live long.’

original: kammaṭṭhānavikkhepo ahosī’ti. ‘Ajja, bhante, katimī’ti divasaṃ vā bhikkhugaṇanaṃ
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna vikkhepaḥ ahosi iti ajja bhante katimī iti divasam vā bhikkhu gaṇanam
translated: and he was distracted by his meditation subject. ‘What day is it today, venerable sir? ’ or he counted the bhikkhus or asked a question,

original: vā pañhaṃ vā pucchito pana udakaṃ gilitvā āroceti; sace divasādipucchakā na honti,
analyzed: vā pañham vā pucchitaḥ pana udakam gilitvā āroca iti sace divasa ādi pucchakāḥ na honti
translated: but when he was asked he would swallow the water and then tell them. If no one asked him what day it was,

original: nikkhamanavelāyaṃ gāmadvāre niṭṭhubhitvāva yāti.
analyzed: nikkhamana velāyam gāma dvāre niṭṭhubhitvā ava yāti
translated: he would go out of the village at the time for taking food and go on his way, spitting out the water at the village gate.

original: Kalambatitthavihāre vassūpagatā paññāsa bhikkhū viya ca. Te kira āsāḷhipuṇṇimāyaṃ🔽katikavattaṃ akaṃsu – “arahattaṃ appatvā aññamaññaṃ nālapissāmā”ti. Gāmañca piṇḍāya
analyzed: kalamba tittha vihāre vassūpagatā paññāsa bhikkhū ca te kira āsāḷhipuṇṇimāyam  katikavattam akaṃsu arahattam a patvā aññam aññam na ālapissāma ati gāmam ca piṇḍāya
translated: And fifty bhikkhus who had entered upon the rains at the Kalambaka Landing did likewise. They made an agreement on the full-moon day of July🔽that they would not speak to one another until they had attained arahantship. And when they entered the village for alms they did so with their mouths closed.

original: pavisantā udakagaṇḍūsaṃ katvā pavisiṃsu, divasādīsu pucchitesu vuttanayena paṭipajjiṃsu.🔽Tattha manussā niṭṭhubhanaṭṭhānaṃ disvā jāniṃsu – ‘ajja eko āgato, ajja dve’ti; evañca
analyzed: pavisantāḥ udaka gaṇḍūsam katvā pavisiṃsu divasa ādīsu pucchitesu vutta nayena paṭipajjiṃsu  tattha manussāḥ niṭṭhubhana ṭṭhānam disvā jāniṃsu ajja ekaḥ āgataḥ ajja dve iti evam ca
translated: And when they were asked what day it was, they behaved as described.

original: cintesuṃ – ‘kinnu kho ete amheheva saddhiṃ na sallapanti udāhu aññamaññampi? Yadi
analyzed: cintesum kinnu kho ete amhehi iva saddhim na sallapanti udāhu aññam aññam pi yadi
translated: The people there noticed where they spat out the water and they knew when there was one, when two, and so on. And they thought, ‘Why do they not talk to us? Do they not talk to one another either?

original: aññamaññampi na sallapanti, addhā vivādajātā bhavissanti; etha ne aññamaññaṃ khamāpessāmā’ti
analyzed: aññam aññam pi na sallapanti addhā vivāda jātāḥ bhavissanti etha ne aññam aññam khamāpessāma ati
translated: They do not speak to one another. They must have had a dispute. Come, let us make them reconcile.”

original: sabbe vihāraṃ gantvā paññāsāya bhikkhūsu dvepi bhikkhū ekokāse nāddasaṃsu. Tato yo
analyzed: sabbe vihāram gantvā paññāsāya bhikkhūsu dve api bhikkhū ekokāse na addasaṃsu tatas yo
translated: When they had all gone to the monastery, they saw that in the company of fifty bhikkhus there were not even two who sat in the same place.

original: tesu cakkhumā puriso so āha – “na, bho, kalahakārakānaṃ vasanokāso īdiso hoti. Susammaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: tesu cakkhumā puriso saḥ āha na bho kalahakārakānam vasanokāsaḥ īdisaḥ hoti su sammaṭṭham
translated: Then the man who was the most discerning of them said, “Friends, the place where those who have had a dispute live is not like this.

original: cetiyaṅgaṇabodhiyaṅgaṇaṃ, sunikkhittā sammajjaniyo, sūpaṭṭhitaṃ pānīyaparibhojanīya”nti.
analyzed: cetiya aṅgaṇa bodhiya aṅgaṇam su nikkhittā sammajjaniyaḥ su upaṭṭhitam pānīya paribhojanīyanti
translated: The shrine terrace and the Bo tree terrace are well swept, the resting places are well arranged, and the drinking water and washing water are well set out.”

original: Te tatova nivattā. Tepi bhikkhū antotemāseyeva arahattaṃ patvā mahāpavāraṇāya visuddhipavāraṇaṃ pavāresuṃ.🔽Evaṃ kāḷavallimaṇḍapavāsī mahānāgatthero viya, kalambutitthavihāre vassūpagatabhikkhū🔽viya ca kammaṭṭhānayutteneva cittena pādaṃ uddharanto gāmasamīpaṃ gantvā udakagaṇḍūsaṃ
analyzed: te tatas va nivattā te api bhikkhū antotemāseya iva arahattam patvā mahāpavāraṇāya visuddhipavāraṇam pavāresuṃ 🔽evam kāḷavalli maṇḍapa vāsī mahā nāga ttheraḥ kalambu tittha vihāre vassu upagata bhikkhū 🔽viya ca kammaṭṭhāna yuttena iva cittena pādam uddharantaḥ gāma samīpam gantvā udaka gaṇḍūsam
translated: So they turned back then and there. And those bhikkhus reached Arahantship within the same half-month and they invited the Observance and gave purification.

original: katvā vīthiyo sallakkhetvā yattha surāsoṇḍadhuttādayo kalahakārakā caṇḍahatthiassādayo🔽vā natthi, taṃ vīthiṃ paṭipajjati. Tattha piṇḍāya caramāno na turitaturito viya javena
analyzed: katvā vīthiyaḥ sallakkhetvā yattha surā soṇḍa dhutta ādayo kalahakārakā caṇḍahatthiassa ādayo  vā na atthi tam vīthim paṭipajjati tattha piṇḍāya caramānaḥ na turita turitaḥ viya javena
translated: He should choose a street where there are no drunkards, gamblers, or other noisy people, and where there are no fierce dogs or bulls.

original: gacchati, na hi javanapiṇḍapātikadhutaṅgaṃ nāma kiñci atthi, visamabhūmibhāgappattaṃ
analyzed: gacchati na hi javanapiṇḍapātikadhutaṅgam nāma kiñci atthi visama bhūmi bhāga ppattam
translated: He should not go too fast, as if in a race, for there is no such virtue as the virtue of a fast alms round.

original: pana udakasakaṭaṃ viya niccalo hutvā gacchati, anugharaṃ paviṭṭho ca dātukāmaṃ vā🔽adātukāmaṃ vā sallakkhetuṃ tadanurūpaṃ kālaṃ āgamento bhikkhaṃ gahetvā antogāme vā🔽bahigāme vā vihārameva vā āgantvā, yathāphāsuke patirūpe okāse nisīditvā, kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pana udaka sakaṭam viya niccalaḥ hutvā gacchati ca dātu kāmam vā  a dātu kāmam vā sallakkhetum tad anurūpam kālam āgamentaḥ bhikkham gahetvā antogāme vā  bahigāme vā vihāram eva vā āgantvā yathāphāsuke pati rūpe okāse nisīditvā kammaṭṭhānam
translated: But he should go as steadily as a water carrier does when he has filled his water pot.🔽He should not go to the house of someone who is not disposed to give alms, but he should wait until the right moment and then go to the house of someone who is disposed to give alms.

original: manasikaronto āhāre paṭikūlasaññaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā, akkhabbhañjanavaṇālepanaputtamaṃsūpamavasena
analyzed: manasikarontaḥ āhāre paṭikūla saññam upaṭṭhapetvā akkhabbhañjana vaṇa ālepana putta maṃsūpama vasena
translated: Having received alms in the village or town, he should return to his dwelling place, and after washing his bowl and his feet, he should sit down cross-legged in a secluded place.🔽He should then reflect on the repulsiveness of the body and on the food, and he should contemplate the body as a vessel for the elements.

original: paccavekkhanto aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ āhāraṃ āhāreti neva davāya, na madāya, na maṇḍanāya,
analyzed: paccavekkhantaḥ aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam āhāram āhāreti na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya
translated: He should eat his food without vanity, without disparaging others, without delighting in self-praise, without despising others, without desiring worldly gain, honor, or fame.

original: na vibhūsanāya…pe… phāsuvihāro cāti. Bhuttāvī ca udakakiccaṃ katvā muhuttaṃ bhattakilamathaṃ
analyzed: na phāsu vihāro ca ati bhuttāvī ca udaka kiccam katvā muhuttam bhatta kilamatham
translated: not for the sake of beauty, etc., and he has ease in his bodily activities. After eating, he performs the cleansing with water, and then he removes any fatigue due to eating by sitting for a while in one position.

original: paṭippassambhetvā yathā purebhattaṃ, evaṃ pacchābhattaṃ purimayāmaṃ pacchimayāmañca
analyzed: paṭippassambhetvā yathā purebhattam evam pacchābhattam purima yāmam pacchima yāmam ca
translated: Then, as before the meal, so after the meal, he devotes himself to the meditation subject during the first and last watches of the night.

original: kammaṭṭhānameva manasikaroti. Ayaṃ vuccati ‘harati ca paccāharati cā’ti.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam eva manasikaroti ayam vuccati harati ca paccāharati ca ati
translated: This is called “one who both imports and exports.”

original: Imaṃ pana haraṇapaccāharaṇasaṅkhātaṃ gatapaccāgatavattaṃ pūrento, yadi upanissayasampanno
analyzed: imam pana haraṇa paccāharaṇa saṅkhātam gata paccāgata vattam pūrentaḥ yadi upanissaya sampannaḥ
translated: One who is fulfilling this practice called “importing and exporting” should, if he has the requisite supporting conditions,

original: hoti, paṭhamavaye eva arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti, no ce paṭhamavaye pāpuṇāti atha majjhimavaye,
analyzed: hoti paṭhama vaye eva arahattam pāpuṇāti no ce paṭhama vaye pāpuṇāti atha majjhima vaye
translated: attain Arahantship in the first stage of life. If not, then in the middle stage of life.

original: no ce majjhimavaye pāpuṇāti atha pacchimavaye, no ce pacchimavaye pāpuṇāti atha maraṇasamaye,🔽no ce maraṇasamaye pāpuṇāti atha devaputto hutvā, no ce devaputto hutvā pāpuṇāti
analyzed: no ce majjhima vaye pāpuṇāti atha pacchima vaye no ce pacchima vaye pāpuṇāti atha maraṇa samaye  no ce maraṇa samaye pāpuṇāti atha devaputtaḥ hutvā no ce devaputtaḥ hutvā pāpuṇāti
translated: If not, then in the last stage of life. If not, then at the time of death.

original: anuppanne buddhe nibbatto paccekabodhiṃ sacchikaroti, no ce paccekabodhiṃ sacchikaroti
analyzed: an uppanne buddhe nibbattaḥ pacceka bodhim sacchikaroti no ce pacceka bodhim sacchikaroti
translated: If not, then as a god. If not, then when the Enlightened One has not yet arisen, he is reborn in a suitable family and realizes the enlightenment of a Paccekabuddha. If not, then he becomes a universal monarch.

original: atha buddhānaṃ sammukhībhāve khippābhiñño vā hoti – seyyathāpi thero bāhiyo dārucīriyo,
analyzed: atha buddhānam sammukhībhāve khippa abhiññaḥ vā hoti seyyathā api theraḥ bāhiyaḥ dārucīriyaḥ
translated: Then, when the Buddhas are present, he is one of quick understanding, like the Elder Bāhiya of the Bark-cloth,

original: mahāpañño vā – seyyathāpi thero sāriputto, mahiddhiko vā – seyyathāpi thero mahāmoggallāno,
analyzed: mahā paññaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ sāriputto mahiddhikaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ mahāmoggallāno
translated: or he is one of great wisdom, like the Elder Sāriputta, or he is one of great spiritual power, like the Elder Mahāmoggallāna,

original: dhutaṅgadharo vā – seyyathāpi thero mahākassapo, dibbacakkhuko vā – seyyathāpi thero🔽anuruddho, vinayadharo vā – seyyathāpi thero upāli, dhammakathiko vā – seyyathāpi🔽thero puṇṇo mantāṇiputto, āraññiko vā – seyyathāpi thero revato, bahussuto vā – seyyathāpi
analyzed: dhutaṅgadharaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ mahākassapaḥ dibbacakkhukaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ  anuruddhaḥ vinaya dharaḥ vā seyyathāpi theraḥ upāli dhamma kathikaḥ vā seyyathāpi  theraḥ puṇṇaḥ mantāṇi putto āraññikaḥ vā seyyathāpi theraḥ revataḥ bahussuto vā seyyathāpi
translated: or he is one who bears the ascetic practices, like the Elder Mahā Kassapa, or he is one with the divine eye, like the Elder Anuruddha,🔽or he is one who has learned the Monastic Law, like the Elder Upāli, or he is a preacher of the Dhamma, like the Elder Puṇṇa Mantāṇiputta,

original: thero ānando, sikkhākāmo vā – seyyathāpi thero rāhulo buddhaputtoti. Iti imasmiṃ
analyzed: theraḥ ānandaḥ sikkhā kāmaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ rāhulaḥ buddha putto ti iti imasmin
translated: or he is a forest-dweller, like the Elder Revata, or he is one of great learning, like the Elder Ānanda, or he is one who is eager for training, like the Elder Rāhula, the Enlightened One’s son.

original: catukke yvāyaṃ harati ca paccāharati ca, tassa gocarasampajaññaṃ sikhāppattaṃ hoti.
analyzed: catukke yvā ayam harati ca paccāharati ca tassa gocara sampajaññam sikhāppattam hoti
translated: So in this tetrad, the one who both takes and returns has reached the peak in the clear comprehension of resort.🔽But the non-delusion in the case of the going out, etc., is clear comprehension of non-delusion. That should be understood as follows.

original: Abhikkamādīsu pana asammuyhanaṃ asammohasampajaññaṃ. Taṃ evaṃ veditabbaṃ – idha bhikkhu
analyzed: abhikkama ādīsu pana a sammuyhanam a sammoha sampajaññam tam evam veditabbam idha bhikkhu
translated: Herein, a bhikkhu

original: abhikkamanto vā paṭikkamanto vā yathā andhabālaputhujjanā abhikkamādīsu ‘attā abhikkamati,
analyzed: abhikkamantaḥ vā paṭikkamantaḥ vā yathā andha bāla puthujjanāḥ abhikkama ādīsu attā abhikkamati
translated: When he is going out or coming in, he does not misapprehend what is happening as do the blind, foolish ordinary persons who misapprehend the going out and coming in as ‘the self goes out and comes in,

original: attanā abhikkamo nibbattito’ti vā ‘ahaṃ abhikkamāmi, mayā abhikkamo nibbattito’ti🔽vā sammuyhanti, tathā asammuyhanto ‘abhikkamāmī’ti citte uppajjamāne teneva cittena
analyzed: attanā abhikkamaḥ nibbattito ti vā aham abhikkamāmi mayā abhikkamaḥ nibbattito ti  vā sammuyhanti tathā a sammuyhantaḥ abhikkamāmi iti citte uppajjamāne tena iva cittena
translated: the self is produced by the going out and coming in,’ or ‘I go out and come in, I am produced by the going out and coming in.’

original: saddhiṃ cittasamuṭṭhānavāyodhātu viññattiṃ janayamānā uppajjati. Iti cittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphāravasena
analyzed: saddhim citta samuṭṭhāna vāyodhātu viññattim janayamānā uppajjati iti citta kiriyā vāyodhātu vipphāra vasena
translated: When the thought ‘I am going out’ arises in him, then the air element that is the cause of the movement of consciousness arises together with that thought and generates the intimation.🔽So this so-called body, a mass of bones, goes out by the power of the air element’s movement as consciousness’s cause.

original: ayaṃ kāyasammato aṭṭhisaṅghāto abhikkamati. Tassevaṃ abhikkamato ekekapāduddharaṇe🔽pathavīdhātu āpodhātūti dve dhātuyo omattā honti mandā, itarā dve adhimattā honti
analyzed: ayam kāya sammataḥ aṭṭhi saṅghātaḥ abhikkamati tassa ivam abhikkamataḥ ekeka pāda uddharaṇe  pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu uti dve dhātuyaḥ omattāḥ honti mandāḥ itarāḥ dve adhimattāḥ honti
translated: When it goes out in this way, in the taking up of each step🔽two elements, the earth element and the water element, are diminished and weak, while the other two, the fire element and the air element, are increased and strong.🔽So too in the taking up and in the putting down.

original: balavatiyo; tathā atiharaṇavītiharaṇesu. Vossajjane tejodhātu vāyodhātūti dve dhātuyo
analyzed: tathā atiharaṇa vītiharaṇesu vossajjane tejaḥ dhātu vāyaḥ dhātu iti dve
translated: In the case of the putting down, the earth element and the fire element are diminished and weak, while the other two, the water element and the air element, are increased and strong.

original: omattā honti mandā, itarā dve adhimattā honti balavatiyo; tathā sannikkhepanasannirujjhanesu
analyzed: omattāḥ honti mandāḥ itarāḥ dve adhimattāḥ honti balavatiyaḥ tathā sannikkhepana sannirujjhanesu
translated: So too, with the depositing and the stopping.

original: tattha uddharaṇe pavattā rūpārūpadhammā atiharaṇaṃ na pāpuṇanti; tathā atiharaṇe
analyzed: tattha uddharaṇe pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ atiharaṇam na pāpuṇanti tathā atiharaṇe
translated: Herein, the material and immaterial states occurring in the lifting up do not reach the carrying away; so too,

original: pavattā vītiharaṇaṃ, vītiharaṇe pavattā vossajjanaṃ, vossajjane pavattā sannikkhepanaṃ,🔽sannikkhepane pavattā sannirujjhanaṃ na pāpuṇanti; tattha tattheva pabbaṃ pabbaṃ
analyzed: pavattā vītiharaṇam vītiharaṇe pavattā vossajjanam vossajjane pavattā sannikkhepanam  sannikkhepane pavattā sannirujjhanam na pāpuṇanti tattha tattha iva pabbam pabbam
translated: those occurring in the carrying away do not reach the putting down; those occurring in the putting down do not reach the depositing;

original: sandhi sandhi odhi odhi hutvā tattakapāle pakkhittatilaṃ viya paṭapaṭāyantā bhijjanti.
analyzed: sandhi sandhi odhi odhi hutvā tatta kapāle pakkhitta tilam viya paṭapaṭāyantāḥ bhijjanti
translated: those occurring in the depositing do not reach the stopping. They break up there, in each case, like a mustard seed on the point of an awl, and they go on breaking up, each in its own place, like sesamum seeds on a heated pan.

original: Tattha ko eko abhikkamati? Kassa vā ekassa abhikkamanaṃ? Paramatthato hi dhātūnaṃyeva
analyzed: tattha kaḥ ekaḥ abhikkamati kassa vā ekassa abhikkamanam paramatthataḥ hi dhātūnam yeva
translated: Herein, who is it that goes forward? Or whose going forward is there? For in the ultimate sense it is the elements that go forward,

original: gamanaṃ, dhātūnaṃ ṭhānaṃ, dhātūnaṃ nisajjā, dhātūnaṃ sayanaṃ, tasmiṃ tasmiñhi koṭṭhāse saddhiṃ rūpehi –
analyzed: gamanam dhātūnam ṭhānam dhātūnam nisajjā dhātūnam sayanam tasmin tasmin hi koṭṭhāse saddhim rūpehi
translated: the elements that stand still, the elements that sit down, the elements that lie down. For in each case, together with the materiality,

original: Aññaṃ uppajjate cittaṃ, aññaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati;
analyzed: aññam uppajjate cittam aññam cittam nirujjhati
translated: Another cognizance arises, And another ceases.

original: Avīcimanusambandho, nadīsotova vattatīti.
analyzed: avīci manu sambandhaḥ nadī sotaḥ uva vattati iti
translated: And it goes on revolving like a river in the Avīci hell.

original: Evaṃ abhikkamādīsu asammuyhanaṃ asammohasampajaññaṃ nāmāti.
analyzed: evam abhikkama ādīsu a sammuyhanam a sammoha sampajaññam nāma ati
translated: So non-delusion about going forwards and so on is called “clear comprehension of non-delusion.”

original: Niṭṭhito abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hotītipadassa attho.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ abhikkante paṭikkante sampajāna kārī hoti iti padassa attho
translated: The meaning of the clause “he is one who acts with clear comprehension in looking ahead and behind” has now been explained.

original: Ālokite vilokiteti ettha pana ālokitaṃ nāma purato pekkhanaṃ, vilokitaṃ nāma anudisāpekkhanaṃ.
analyzed: ālokite vilokita iti ettha pana ālokitam nāma puratas pekkhanam vilokitam nāma anudisā apekkhanam
translated: As to “in looking straight on and in looking away” , looking straight on is looking in front, and looking away is looking to the left and right.

original: Aññānipi heṭṭhā upari pacchato pekkhanavasena olokitaullokitāpalokitāni nāma honti.
analyzed: aññāni api heṭṭhā upari pacchatas pekkhana vasena olokita aullokita apalokitāni nāma honti
translated: And there are also looking up, looking down, and looking around by looking above, below, and behind.

original: Tāni idha na gahitāni. Sāruppavasena pana imāneva dve gahitāni. Iminā vā mukhena
analyzed: tāni idha na gahitāni sāruppa vasena pana imāneva dve gahitāni iminā vā mukhena
translated: But these are not included here. Or alternatively, these two are included by the words “in looking straight on and in looking away”

original: sabbānipi tāni gahitānevāti.
analyzed: sabbāni api tāni gahitāni eva ati
translated: because they are included under that heading.

original: Tattha ‘ālokessāmī’ti citte uppanne cittavaseneva anoloketvā atthapariggaṇhanaṃ ‘sātthakasampajaññaṃ’. Taṃ āyasmantaṃ nandaṃ kāyasakkhiṃ katvā veditabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: tattha ālokessāmi iti citte uppanne citta vasena iva anoloketvā attha pariggaṇhanam sātthaka sampajaññam tam āyasmantam nandam kāya sakkhim katvā veditabbam vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: Herein, “clear comprehension of purpose” is the discerning of the purpose in looking straight on and in looking away that occurs when the thought of looking has arisen, without looking simply as a result of the state of being a living being. It should be understood as the “witness in one’s own person” of the venerable Nanda. For this is said:

original: “Sace, bhikkhave, nandassa puratthimā disā āloketabbā hoti, sabbaṃ cetasā samannāharitvā🔽nando puratthimaṃ disaṃ āloketi – ‘evaṃ me puratthimaṃ disaṃ ālokayato na abhijjhādomanassā
analyzed: sace bhikkhave nandassa puratthimā disā āloketabbā hoti sabbam cetasā samannāharitvā  nando puratthimam disam āloketi evam me puratthimam disam ālokayataḥ na abhijjhā domanassā
translated: “If the eastern direction should be investigated, he investigates it with all his mind thus:

original: pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssavissantī’ti. Itiha sātthakasampajāno hoti. “Sace, bhikkhave,
analyzed: pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ anvāssavissanti iti iti ha sātthaka sampajānaḥ hoti sace bhikkhave
translated: ‘As I investigate the eastern direction thus, no evil unwholesome states will beset me.’ Thus he is one who is clearly aware of the meaning.

original: nandassa pacchimā disā, uttarā disā, dakkhiṇā disā, uddhaṃ, adho, anudisā anuviloketabbā
analyzed: nandassa pacchimā disā uttarā disā dakkhiṇā disā uddham adhas anudisā anuviloketabbā
translated: If the western direction, the northern direction, the southern direction,

original: hoti, sabbaṃ cetasā samannāharitvā nando anudisaṃ anuviloketi – evaṃ me anudisaṃ
analyzed: hoti sabbam cetasā samannāharitvā nandaḥ anudisam evam me anudisam
translated: the nadir, the zenith, and the intermediate directions should be investigated, he investigates them with all his mind thus:

original: anuvilokayato…pe… sampajāno hotī”ti.
analyzed: anuvilokayata upe sampajānaḥ hoti iti
translated: ‘As I investigate the intermediate directions thus, no evil unwholesome states will beset me.’ Thus he is one who is clearly aware of the meaning.”

original: Apica idhāpi pubbe vuttacetiyadassanādivaseneva sātthakatā ca sappāyatā ca veditabbā.
analyzed: apica idha api pubbe vutta cetiya dassana ādi vasena iva sātthaka tā ca sappāya tā ca veditabbā
translated: Moreover, here too the meaningfulness and the profitable nature can be understood in the way already described in the case of seeing the shrine terrace, etc.

original: Kammaṭṭhānassa pana avijahanameva ‘gocarasampajaññaṃ’. Tasmā khandhadhātuāyatanakammaṭṭhānikehi
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānassa pana a vijahanam eva gocara sampajaññam tasmā khandha dhātu āyatana kammaṭṭhānikehi
translated: But the mere fact of not abandoning the meditation subject is the “clear comprehension of resort.” Therefore,

original: attano kammaṭṭhānavaseneva, kasiṇādikammaṭṭhānikehi vā pana kammaṭṭhānasīseneva ālokanavilokanaṃ kātabbaṃ.
analyzed: attano kammaṭṭhāna vasena iva kasiṇa ādi kammaṭṭhānikehi vā pana kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva ālokana vilokanam kātabbam
translated: Or else, if he is a kasiṇa-jhāna worker, he should look and see with the kasiṇa-jhāna as his theme.

original: Abbhantare attā nāma āloketā vā viloketā vā natthi. ‘Ālokessāmī’ti pana citte uppajjamāne
analyzed: abbhantare attā nāma āloketā vā viloketā vā natthi ālokessāmi iti pana citte uppajjamāne
translated: There is no self inside looking or seeing. But when the thought arises, “I shall look,”

original: teneva cittena saddhiṃ cittasamuṭṭhānā vāyodhātu viññattiṃ janayamānā uppajjati.
analyzed: tena iva cittena saddhim citta samuṭṭhānā vāyodhātu viññattim janayamānā uppajjati
translated: then the air element that is the outcome of that thought arises generating intimation.

original: Iti cittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphāravasena heṭṭhimaṃ akkhidalaṃ adho sīdati, uparimaṃ
analyzed: iti citta kiriyā vāyodhātu vipphāra vasena heṭṭhimam akkhi dalam adhas sīdati uparimam
translated: So the lower eyelid sinks down and the upper eyelid bulges out by the impact of the current of air that is the outcome of the mind’s activity.

original: uddhaṃ laṅgheti. Koci yantakena vivaranto nāma natthi. Tato cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dassanakiccaṃ
analyzed: uddham laṅgheti koci yantakena vivarantaḥ nāma na atthi tatas cakkhu viññāṇam dassana kiccam
translated: No one opens the eyes by means of a contrivance. Then eye-consciousness arises accomplishing its function of seeing.

original: sādhentaṃ uppajjatī’ti evaṃ pajānanaṃ panettha ‘asammohasampajaññaṃ’ nāma.
analyzed: sādhentam uppajjati iti evam pajānanam pana ittha asammoha sampajaññam nāma
translated: This is what is called “clear comprehension of non-delusion.”🔽Moreover, clear comprehension of non-delusion should be understood here as the clear comprehension of the thorough knowledge of the root, of the adventitious character, and of the state of being due to a condition.

original: Apica mūlapariññāāgantukatāvakālikabhāvavasena panettha asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ. Mūlapariññāvasena tāva –
analyzed: apica mūla pariññā āgantuka tāvakālika bhāva vasena pana ittha asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam mūla pariññā vasena tāva
translated: As to the clear comprehension of the thorough knowledge of the root:

original: Bhavaṅgāvajjanañceva, dassanaṃ sampaṭicchanaṃ;
analyzed: dassanam sampaṭicchanam
translated: The adverting to the life-continuum, The seeing, the receiving,

original: Santīraṇaṃ voṭṭhabbanaṃ, javanaṃ bhavati sattamaṃ.
analyzed: santīraṇam voṭṭhabbanam javanam bhavati sattamam
translated: Searching, determining, and impulsion are the seventh.

original: Tattha bhavaṅgaṃ upapattibhavassa aṅgakiccaṃ sādhayamānaṃ pavattati; taṃ āvattetvā
analyzed: tattha bhavaṅgam upapatti bhavassa aṅga kiccam sādhayamānam pavattati tam āvattetvā
translated: Herein, the life-continuum occurs accomplishing the function of a factor of the existence in which rebirth-linking occurs. After that,

original: kiriyamanodhātu āvajjanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā; tannirodhā cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dassanakiccaṃ
analyzed: kiriya manaḥ dhātu āvajjana kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā cakkhu viññāṇam dassana kiccam
translated: the functional mind element accomplishes the function of adverting. After that ceases, eye-consciousness accomplishes the function of seeing.

original: sādhayamānaṃ; tannirodhā vipākamanodhātu sampaṭicchanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā; tannirodhā🔽vipākamanoviññāṇadhātu santīraṇakiccaṃ sādhayamānā; tannirodhā kiriyamanoviññāṇadhātu
analyzed: sādhayamānam tad nirodhā vipāka manaḥ dhātu sampaṭicchana kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā  vipāka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu santīraṇa kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā kiriya manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: After that ceases, resultant mind element accomplishes the function of receiving. After that ceases,

original: voṭṭhabbanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā; tannirodhā sattakkhattuṃ javanaṃ javati. Tattha paṭhamajavanepi
analyzed: voṭṭhabbana kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā satta kkhattum javanam javati tattha paṭhama javane pi
translated: resultant mind-consciousness element accomplishes the function of investigating. After that ceases, the functional mind-consciousness element accomplishes the function of determining. After that ceases, impulsion impels seven times. Herein, in the first impulsion

original: ‘ayaṃ itthī, ayaṃ puriso’ti rajjanadussanamuyhanavasena ālokitavilokitaṃ na hoti;
analyzed: ayam itthī ayam purisaḥ ti rajjana dussana muyhana vasena ālokita vilokitam na hoti
translated: there is no looking here and there and no looking away, as there is in the case of the thought “This is a woman,” “This is a man.”

analyzed: dupaṭṭam viparītam asappāyam yassa kassaci jiṇṇam asappāyam eva aggaḷa ādi dānena
translated: and the opposite kind is unsuitable. Any that is old is unsuitable. And if it is given with a bolt or something like that,

original: hissa taṃ palibodhakaraṃ hoti. Tathā paṭṭuṇṇadukūlādibhedaṃ corānaṃ lobhanīyacīvaraṃ.
analyzed: hissa tam palibodha karam hoti tathā paṭṭuṇṇa dukūla ādi bhedam corānam lobhanīya cīvaram
translated: it is an obstruction. So too, a robe that tempts thieves, such as a fine blanket, etc.,

original: Tādisañhi araññe ekakassa nivāsantarāyakaraṃ jīvitantarāyakarañcāpi hoti. Nippariyāyena🔽pana yaṃ nimittakammādimicchājīvavasena uppannaṃ, yañcassa sevamānassa akusalā dhammā
analyzed: tādisam hi araññe ekakassa nivāsa antarāya karam jīvita antarāya karam ca api hoti nippariyāyena  pana yam nimitta kamma ādim icchājīva vasena uppannam yam ca assa sevamānassa akusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: is unsuitable for one who lives in the forest alone. And it can be a hindrance to life.

original: abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, taṃ asappāyaṃ; viparītaṃ sappāyaṃ. Tassa
analyzed: abhivaḍḍhanti kusalāḥ dhammāḥ parihāyanti tam a sappāyam viparītam sa ppāyam tassa
translated: But in the strict sense of the word, what is unsuitable is that which arises through wrong livelihood, such as by using a sign, etc., and what increases unprofitable things and diminishes profitable things in one who uses it. The opposite of that is suitable.

original: vasenettha ‘sappāyasampajaññaṃ’ kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva ca ‘gocarasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vasena ittha sappāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva ca gocara sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: “Skill in the desirable” should be understood here as skill in the desirable object of meditation, and “skill in pasture” as skill in not abandoning the meditation subject.🔽There is no self at all inside that puts on the robe.

original: Abbhantare attā nāma koci cīvaraṃ pārupanto natthi. Vuttappakāracittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphāreneva
analyzed: abbhantare attā nāma koci cīvaram pārupantaḥ natthi vutta ppakāra citta kiriyā vāyodhātu vipphārena iva
translated: It is only by the diffusion of the materiality process that is the action of consciousness that

original: pana cīvarapārupanaṃ hoti. Tattha cīvarampi acetanaṃ, kāyopi acetano. Cīvaraṃ na
analyzed: pana cīvara pārupanam hoti tattha cīvaram pi acetanam kāyaḥ api acetanaḥ cīvaram na
translated: the robe is put on. Herein, the robe is without consciousness, and the body is without consciousness. The robe

original: jānāti – ‘mayā kāyo pārupito’ti, kāyopi na jānāti – ‘ahaṃ cīvarena pārupito’ti. Dhātuyova
analyzed: jānāti mayā kāyaḥ pārupitaḥ iti kāyaḥ api na jānāti aham cīvarena pārupitaḥ iti
translated: does not know, “I am put on the body,” nor does the body know, “A robe is put on me.”

original: dhātusamūhaṃ paṭicchādenti, paṭapilotikāya potthakarūpapaṭicchādane viya. Tasmā neva
analyzed: dhātu samūham paṭicchādenti paṭa pilotikāya potthaka rūpa paṭicchādane tasmā na iva
translated: The material instances merely cover a collection of material instances,

original: sundaraṃ cīvaraṃ labhitvā somanassaṃ kātabbaṃ, na asundaraṃ labhitvā domanassaṃ.🔽Nāgavammikacetiyarukkhādīsu hi keci mālāgandhadhūpavatthādīhi sakkāraṃ karonti, keci
analyzed: sundaram cīvaram labhitvā somanassam kātabbam na a sundaram labhitvā domanassam  nāga vammika cetiya rukkha ādīsu hi keci mālā gandha dhūpa vattha ādīhi sakkāram karonti keci
translated: as a piece of cloth covers a piece of wood. So there is no reason to be glad when one gets a fine robe or to be miserable when one gets a poor one.🔽For some people honour a termite-mound, a tree, a shrine, etc., with garlands, scents, perfumes, etc.,

original: gūthamuttakaddamadaṇḍasatthappahārādīhi asakkāraṃ. Na tehi nāgavammikarukkhādayo
analyzed: gūtha muttaka ddama daṇḍa sattha ppahāra ādīhi asakkāram na tehi nāga vammika rukkha ādayaḥ
translated: while others do not honour them with such things but mistreat them with abuse, clods, sticks, and so on. But the termite-mounds, trees, shrines, etc.,

original: somanassaṃ vā domanassaṃ vā karonti. Evameva neva sundaraṃ cīvaraṃ labhitvā somanassaṃ
analyzed: somanassam vā domanassam vā karonti evam eva na iva sundaram cīvaram labhitvā somanassam
translated: He should not be glad if he gets a beautiful one or sad if he gets an ugly one. So too, if he gets a beautiful robe, he should not be glad;

original: kātabbaṃ, na asundaraṃ labhitvā domanassanti. Evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha
analyzed: kātabbam na asundaram labhitvā evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha
translated: if he gets an ugly one, he should not be sad.

original: ‘asammohasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ.🔽Pattadhāraṇepi pattaṃ sahasāva aggahetvā ‘imaṃ gahetvā piṇḍāya caramāno bhikkhaṃ
analyzed: a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  patta dhāraṇe pi pattam sahasāva aggahetvā imam gahetvā piṇḍāya caramānaḥ bhikkham
translated: The “unconfused knowledge” should be understood here as the reflection that occurs in this way.

original: labhissāmī’ti evaṃ pattaggahaṇapaccayā paṭilabhitabbaatthavasena ‘sātthakasampajaññaṃ’
analyzed: labhissāmi iti evam patta ggahaṇa paccayā paṭilabhitabba attha vasena sa atthaka sampajaññam
translated: As regards the carrying of the bowl, he should not take it up all of a sudden, thinking, “I shall go for alms with this.” He should do so only after examining whether the alms food will be obtained by taking it. Thus the “knowledge of what is beneficial” should be understood here as the benefit that is obtained by the act of taking the bowl.

original: veditabbaṃ. Kisadubbalasarīrassa pana garupatto asappāyo; yassa kassaci catupañcagaṇṭhikāhato🔽dubbisodhanīyo asappāyova. Duddhotapatto hi na vaṭṭati; taṃ dhovantasseva cassa palibodho
analyzed: veditabbam kisa dubbala sarīrassa pana garu pattaḥ asappāyaḥ yassa kassaci catu pañca gaṇṭhikā hataḥ  dubbisodhanīyaḥ asappāyaḥ iva duddhota pattaḥ hi na vaṭṭati tam dhovantassa iva ca assa palibodhaḥ
translated: But a heavy bowl is unsuitable for one whose body is weak. One that is chipped or cracked is unsuitable for anyone.🔽A bowl that is difficult to clean is unsuitable. For it is not proper to use a bowl that is dirty. And it is a hindrance to him if he has to wash it carefully.

original: hoti. Maṇivaṇṇapatto pana lobhanīyova cīvare vuttanayeneva asappāyo. Nimittakammādivasena
analyzed: hoti maṇi vaṇṇa patto pana lobhanīyaḥ uva cīvare vutta nayena iva asappāyaḥ nimitta kamma ādi vasena
translated: A gem-studded bowl is a temptation to thieves, and it is unsuitable for the reasons already given in the case of the robe.

original: pana laddho, yañcassa sevamānassa akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti,
analyzed: pana laddhaḥ yat cassa sevamānassa akusalāḥ dhammāḥ abhivaḍḍhanti kusalāḥ dhammāḥ parihāyanti
translated: but when it is obtained, and when unwholesome states increase and wholesome states diminish in one who cultivates it,

original: ayaṃ ekantāsappāyova viparīto sappāyo. Tassa vasenettha ‘sappāyasampajaññaṃ’ kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva
analyzed: ayam ekanta a sappāyaḥ iva viparīto sappāyo tassa vasena ittha sappāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva
translated: it is only a wholly disadvantageous resort. The opposite of that is an advantageous resort. Herein, ‘knowledge of advantageous resorts’ should be understood as ‘knowledge of resorts’ in the sense of not abandoning the meditation subject.

original: ‘gocarasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ.🔽Abbhantare attā nāma koci pattaṃ gaṇhanto natthi. Vuttappakāracittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphāravaseneva
analyzed: gocara sampajaññam veditabbam  abbhantare attā nāma koci pattam gaṇhantaḥ natthi vutta ppakāra citta kiriyā vāyodhātu vipphāra vasena iva
translated: ‘Knowledge of danger’ should be understood as ‘knowledge of resorts’ in the sense of the meditation subject’s being a danger.🔽There is no self called “the inner being” that takes the bowl.

original: pana pattaggahaṇaṃ nāma hoti. Tattha pattopi acetano, hatthāpi acetanā. Patto na
analyzed: pana patta gahaṇam nāma hoti tattha pattaḥ api acetanaḥ hatthā api acetanā pattaḥ na
translated: It is only by the influence of the process of oscillation in the form of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants that there comes to be what is called “taking the bowl.” Herein, the bowl is without consciousness, and the hands are without consciousness.

original: jānāti – ‘ahaṃ hatthehi gahito’ti. Hatthāpi na jānanti – ‘patto amhehi gahito’ti.
analyzed: jānāti aham hatthehi gahito ti hatthā api na jānanti pattaḥ amhehi gahito ti
translated: The bowl does not know “I am being taken with hands,” nor do the hands know “A bowl is being taken with us.”

original: Dhātuyova dhātusamūhaṃ gaṇhanti, saṇḍāsena aggivaṇṇapattagahaṇe viyāti. Evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha
analyzed: dhātuyāḥ iva dhātu samūham gaṇhanti saṇḍāsena aggi vaṇṇa patta gahaṇe viyā ti evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha
translated: It is only the elements that take the collection of elements, as in the case of the taking of the bowl by the hand-element and the bowl-element.

original: ‘asammohasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: So ‘knowledge of non-delusion’ should be understood here as the act of reviewing that occurs in this way.

original: Apica yathā chinnahatthapāde vaṇamukhehi paggharitapubbalohitakimikule nīlamakkhikasamparikiṇṇe
analyzed: apica yathā chinna hattha pāde vaṇa mukhehi paggharita pubba lohita kimi kule nīla makkhika samparikiṇṇe
translated: Furthermore, just as a man with cut-off hands and feet, lying in his own excrement and urine, in a pool of blood, infested with worms, covered with blue-bottles,

original: anāthasālāyaṃ anāthamanusse disvā dayālukā purisā tesaṃ vaṇabandhapaṭṭacoḷakāni ceva🔽kapālādīhi ca bhesajjāni upanāmenti. Tattha coḷakānipi kesañci saṇhāni kesañci thūlāni
analyzed: anātha sālāyam anātha manusse disvā dayālukā purisā tesam vaṇa bandha paṭṭa coḷakāni ca iva  kapāla ādīhi ca bhesajjāni upanāmenti tattha coḷakāni pi kesañci saṇhāni kesañci thūlāni
translated: Furthermore, just as when compassionate people see a helpless man in a public hospital ward with his limbs cut off, with pus and blood oozing from his wounds, with maggots appearing, covered with green and bluebottles,🔽and they bring him bandages and cloths for his wounds and medicines in pots and so on, and the cloths reach some of him that is smooth and some that is rough,

original: pāpuṇanti. Bhesajjakapālakānipi kesañci susaṇṭhānāni kesañci dussaṇṭhānāni pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: pāpuṇanti bhesajja kapālakāni pi kesañci su saṇṭhānāni kesañci dussaṇṭhānāni pāpuṇanti
translated: and the pots of medicine reach some of him that is well formed and some that is ill formed,

original: Na te tattha sumanā vā honti dummanā vā. Vaṇapaṭicchādanamatteneva hi coḷakena, bhesajjapariggahaṇamatteneva🔽ca kapālakena tesaṃ attho. Evameva yo bhikkhu vaṇacoḷakaṃ viya cīvaraṃ, bhesajjakapālakaṃ
analyzed: na te tattha sumanāḥ vā honti dummanāḥ vā vaṇa paṭicchādana mattena iva hi coḷakena bhesajja pariggahaṇa mattena iva  ca kapālakena tesam atthaḥ evam eva yaḥ bhikkhu vaṇa coḷakam viya cīvaram bhesajja kapālakam
translated: he is neither pleased nor displeased about that, but he wants only to have his wounds bandaged and to get medicine,🔽so too, if a bhikkhu regards the robe as a bandage for the wounds of the defilements, and the bowl as a pot for medicine, and the alms food as medicine,

original: viya ca pattaṃ, kapāle bhesajjamiva ca patte laddhabhikkhaṃ sallakkheti – ayaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe
analyzed: viya ca pattam kapāle bhesajjam iva ca patte laddha bhikkham sallakkheti ayam saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇe
translated: he is called a bhikkhu who has understood the wearing of the triple robe, the use of the bowl, and the receiving of alms food.

original: asammohasampajaññena uttamasampajānakārīti veditabbo.
analyzed: asammoha sampajaññena uttama sampajāna kārī iti veditabbo
translated: He should be understood as one who has the highest kind of clear vision in that he has non-delusion as clear vision.

original: Asitādīsu asiteti piṇḍapātādibhojane. Pīteti yāguādipāne. Khāyiteti piṭṭhakhajjakādikhādane.
analyzed: asita ādīsu asita iti piṇḍapāta ādi bhojane pīta iti yāgu ādi pāne khāyita iti piṭṭhakhajjaka ādi khādane
translated: As to what is eaten, etc., he eats what is eaten, namely, the alms food consisting of lumps, etc.; he drinks what is drunk, namely, the drinks consisting of rice gruel, etc.; he chews what is chewed, namely, the betel, etc.;

original: Sāyiteti madhuphāṇitādisāyane. Tattha “neva davāyā”tiādinā nayena vutto aṭṭhavidhopi
analyzed: sāyita iti madhu phāṇita ādi sāyane tattha na iva davāya ati ādinā nayena vutto aṭṭhavidhaḥ api
translated: he swallows what is swallowed, namely, the honey, molasses, etc. Herein, the eight kinds of meaning stated in the way beginning, “Not for amusement” are called “meaning.”

original: attho ‘attho’ nāma. Tassa vasena ‘sātthakasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ atthaḥ nāma tassa vasena sa atthaka sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: He should be understood as one who has clear vision of meaning in virtue of that.

original: Lūkhapaṇītatittamadhurādīsu pana yena bhojanena yassa aphāsu hoti, taṃ tassa asappāyaṃ.
analyzed: lūkha paṇīta titta madhura ādīsu pana yena bhojanena yassa hoti tam tassa asappāyam
translated: But as regards what is coarse, etc., and what is suitable, etc., what is unsuitable for one is what is unwholesome for him.

original: Yaṃ pana nimittakammādivasena paṭiladdhaṃ, yañcassa bhuñjato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti,
analyzed: yam pana nimitta kamma ādi vasena paṭiladdham yat ca assa bhuñjato akusalāḥ dhammāḥ abhivaḍḍhanti
translated: But what is obtained by means of signs, etc., and what increases unprofitable ideas and diminishes profitable ideas in one who uses it,

original: kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, taṃ ekantaṃ asappāyameva; viparītaṃ sappāyaṃ. Tassa vasenettha
analyzed: kusalāḥ dhammā parihāyanti tam ekantam asappāyam eva viparītam sappāyam tassa vasena ittha
translated: is entirely unsuitable for him; what is the opposite of that is suitable. He should be understood as one who has clear vision of what is suitable in virtue of that.

original: ‘sappāyasampajaññaṃ’ kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva ca ‘gocarasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sa ppāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva ca gocara sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: And he should be understood as one who has clear vision of the right course of conduct in virtue of not abandoning the meditation subject.

original: Abbhantare attā nāma koci bhuñjako natthi. Vuttappakāracittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphāreneva🔽pana pattapaṭiggahaṇaṃ nāma hoti. Cittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphāreneva hatthassa patte
analyzed: abbhantare attā nāma koci bhuñjakaḥ natthi vutta ppakāra citta kiriyā vāyodhātu vipphārena iva  pana patta paṭiggahaṇam nāma hoti citta kiriyā vāyodhātu vipphārena iva hatthassa patte
translated: There is no such thing as a self inside that eats.

original: otāraṇaṃ nāma hoti. Cittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphāreneva ālopakaraṇaṃ, ālopauddharaṇaṃ,
analyzed: otāraṇam nāma hoti citta kiriyā vāyodhātu vipphārena iva ālopa karaṇam ālopa auddharaṇam
translated: It is only by the diffusion of the wind element that is the action of consciousness that there is the taking up of the bowl,

original: mukhavivaraṇañca hoti. Na koci kuñcikāya, na yantakena hanukaṭṭhiṃ vivarati. Cittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphāreneva🔽ālopassa mukhe ṭhapanaṃ, uparidantānaṃ musalakiccasādhanaṃ, heṭṭhādantānaṃ udukkhalakiccasādhanaṃ,🔽jivhāya hatthakiccasādhanañca hoti. Iti naṃ tattha aggajivhāya tanukakheḷo mūlajivhāya
analyzed: mukha vivaraṇam ca hoti na koci kuñcikāya na yantakena hanu kaṭṭhim vivarati citta kiriyā vāyodhātu vipphārena iva  ālopassa mukhe ṭhapanam upari dantānam musala kicca sādhanam heṭṭhā dantānam udukkhala kicca sādhanam  jivhāya hattha kicca sādhanam ca hoti iti nam tattha agga jivhāya tanuka kheḷaḥ mūla jivhāya
translated: the lowering of it into the alms-bowl, the taking out of it, the opening of the mouth, and the putting of the mouthful into the mouth. No one opens the jaw with a key or with a pulley.🔽It is only by the diffusion of the wind element that is the action of consciousness that there is the placing of the mouthful in the mouth, the performance of the function of the pestle by the upper row of teeth, the performance of the function of the mortar by the lower row of teeth,

original: bahalakheḷo makkheti. Taṃ heṭṭhādantaudukkhale jivhāhatthaparivattitaṃ kheḷaudakatemitaṃ
analyzed: bahala kheḷaḥ makkheti tam heṭṭhā danta odukkhale jivhā hattha parivattitam kheḷa audaka temitam
translated: and the performance of the function of the hand by the tongue. So the thin saliva on the tip of the tongue and the thick saliva in the root of the tongue🔽mix it up. The saliva in the mortar of the lower teeth, churned by the hand of the tongue,

original: uparidantamusalasañcuṇṇitaṃ koci kaṭacchunā vā dabbiyā vā anto pavesento nāma natthi;🔽vāyodhātuyāva pavisati. Paviṭṭhaṃ paviṭṭhaṃ koci palālasanthāraṃ katvā dhārento nāma🔽natthi; vāyodhātuvaseneva tiṭṭhati. Ṭhitaṃ ṭhitaṃ koci uddhanaṃ katvā aggiṃ jāletvā
analyzed: upari danta musala sañcuṇṇitam koci kaṭacchunā vā dabbiyā vā antar pavesento nāma natthi  pavisati paviṭṭham paviṭṭham koci palāla santhāram katvā dhārentaḥ nāma  natthi vāyo dhātu vasena iva tiṭṭhati ṭhitam ṭhitam koci uddhanam katvā aggim jāletvā
translated: No one puts what has been pounded to dust by the upper millstone inside with a spade or a basket.🔽It enters by means of the air element. No one spreads out what has entered and gone inside and carries it off with a mat of straw.🔽It remains by means of the air element. No one makes a furnace and lights a fire and bakes what has remained and gone inside.

original: pacanto nāma natthi; tejodhātuyāva paccati. Pakkaṃ pakkaṃ koci daṇḍakena vā yaṭṭhiyā
analyzed: pacantaḥ nāma natthi tejodhātuyā ava paccati pakkam pakkam koci daṇḍakena vā
translated: It bakes by means of the fire element. No one carries off what has baked and gone inside with a stick or a ladle.

original: vā bahi nīhārako nāma natthi; vāyodhātuyeva nīharati. Iti vāyodhātu atiharati ca🔽vītiharati ca dhāreti ca parivatteti ca sañcuṇṇeti ca visoseti ca nīharati ca. Pathavīdhātu🔽dhāreti ca parivatteti ca sañcuṇṇeti ca visoseti ca nīharati ca. Āpodhātu sineheti
analyzed: vā bahi nīhārakaḥ nāma natthi vāyodhātuyā iva nīharati iti vāyodhātu atiharati ca  vītiharati ca dhāreti ca parivatteti ca sañcuṇṇā iti ca visoseti ca nīharati ca pathavī dhātu  dhārā iti ca parivattā iti ca sañcuṇṇā iti ca visosā iti ca nīharati ca āpodhātu sinehā iti
translated: There is no one who carries it off. It is carried off by the air element itself. Thus the air element carries off,🔽carries away, supports, turns round, pounds, sorts, and carries off. The earth element🔽supports, turns round, pounds, sorts, and carries off. The water element wets

original: ca allattañca anupāleti. Tejodhātu antopaviṭṭhaṃ paripāceti. Ākāsadhātu añjaso hoti.
analyzed: ca anupāleti tejaḥ dhātu anta upaviṭṭham paripāca iti ākāsa dhātu añjasas hoti
translated: and holds together. The fire element bakes what has gone inside. The space element is the space that is inside.

original: Viññāṇadhātu tattha tattha sammāpayogamanvāya ābhujatīti. Evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha
analyzed: viññāṇa dhātu tattha tattha sammā apayogam anvāya ābhujati iti evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha
translated: And the consciousness element occurs there in the way stated.

original: ‘asammohasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ.🔽Apica gamanato, pariyesanato, paribhogato, āsayato, nidhānato, aparipakkato, paripakkato,🔽phalato, nissandanato, sammakkhanatoti evaṃ dasavidhapaṭikūlabhāvapaccavekkhaṇatopettha
analyzed: a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  apica gamanato pariyesanato paribhogato āsayataḥ nidhānataḥ a paripakkato paripakkato  phalataḥ nissandanataḥ sammakkhanataḥ ti evam dasavidha paṭikūla bhāva paccavekkhaṇatā upa ittha
translated: This is how the knowledge of unforgettingness should be understood here.🔽Furthermore, it should be understood as the knowledge of unforgettingness here in the sense of the reflection on the tenfold aspect of repulsiveness, that is to say, in the sense of reflection on repulsiveness as movement, as search, as use, as receptacle, as storage, as unprepared, as prepared,

original: ‘asammohasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ. Vitthārakathā panettha visuddhimagge āhārapaṭikūlasaññāniddesato gahetabbā.🔽Uccārapassāvakammeti uccārassa ca passāvassa ca karaṇe. Tattha pakkakāle uccārapassāvaṃ
analyzed: asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam vitthāra kathā pana ittha visuddhi magge āhāra paṭikūla saññā niddesato gahetabbā  uccāra passāva kamma iti uccārassa ca passāvassa ca karaṇe tattha pakka kāle uccāra passāvam
translated: as result, as smearing, and as smearing and being smeared. The detailed explanation should be understood according to the description of the perception of repulsiveness in nutriment in the Path of Purity .

original: akarontassa sakalasarīrato sedā muccanti, akkhīni bhamanti, cittaṃ na ekaggaṃ hoti,
analyzed: a karontassa sakala sarīrataḥ sedāḥ muccanti akkhīni bhamanti cittam na ekaggam hoti
translated: In the process of evacuation: in the process of passing faeces and urine. Herein, when one who does not pass faeces and urine at the proper time gets a dribbling of the bowels, his eyes roll, his mind becomes distraught,

original: aññe ca rogā uppajjanti; karontassa pana sabbaṃ taṃ na hotīti ayamettha attho. Tassa
analyzed: aññe ca rogā uppajjanti karontassa pana sabbam tam na hoti iti ayam ettha attho tassa
translated: and various diseases arise in him, but when he does so there is none of this. This is the meaning here.

original: vasena ‘sātthakasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vasena sātthaka sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: This should be understood as “clear comprehension of what is beneficial.”

original: Aṭṭhāne uccārapassāvaṃ karontassa pana āpatti hoti, ayaso vaḍḍhati, jīvitantarāyo
analyzed: aṭṭhāne uccāra passāvam karontassa pana āpatti hoti ayasaḥ vaḍḍhati jīvita antarāyo
translated: But if one does so in an unsuitable place, one becomes guilty of an offense, one’s disrepute increases, and one may even come to ruin one’s life.

original: hoti; patirūpe ṭhāne karontassa sabbaṃ taṃ na hotīti idamettha sappāyaṃ. Tassa vasena
analyzed: hoti patirūpe ṭhāne karontassa sabbam tam na hoti iti idam ettha sappāyam tassa vasena
translated: But if one does so in a suitable place, none of this happens. This is the suitable place.

original: ‘sappāyasampajaññaṃ’ kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva ca ‘gocarasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sa ppāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva ca gocara sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: This should be understood as “clear comprehension of a suitable place.” And “clear comprehension of resort” should be understood as the non-abandoning of the meditation subject.🔽There is no such being as a self that does the act of defecation or urination.

original: Abbhantare attā nāma koci uccārapassāvakammaṃ karonto natthi. Cittakiriyāvāyodhātuvipphāreneva🔽pana uccārapassāvakammaṃ hoti. Yathā pana pakke gaṇḍe gaṇḍabhedena pubbalohitaṃ akāmatāya
analyzed: abbhantare attā nāma koci uccāra passāva kammam karontaḥ natthi citta kiriyā vāyodhātu vipphārena iva  pana uccāra passāva kammam hoti yathā pana pakke gaṇḍe gaṇḍa bhedena pubba lohitam a kāma tāya
translated: But by the diffusion of the air element that is the function of consciousness,🔽the act of defecation or urination occurs. Just as, when a boil has ripened, pus oozes out through the bursting of the boil,🔽and just as, when a water vessel is overfull, water overflows from it,

original: nikkhamati, yathā ca atibharitā udakabhājanā udakaṃ akāmatāya nikkhamati, evaṃ pakkāsayamuttavatthīsu🔽sannicitā uccārapassāvā vāyuvegasamuppīḷitā akāmatāyapi nikkhamanti. So panāyaṃ evaṃ
analyzed: nikkhamati yathā ca ati bharitā udaka bhājanā udakam akāmatāya nikkhamati evam pakkāsaya mutta vatthīsu 🔽sannicitāḥ uccāra passāvāḥ vāyu vega samuppīḍitāḥ nikkhamanti saḥ pana ayam evam
translated: so too, when the receptacle of feces and urine is full, the feces and urine come out by squeezing,🔽whether one likes it or not.

original: nikkhamanto uccārapassāvo neva tassa bhikkhuno attano hoti na parassa; kevalaṃ pana🔽sarīranissandova hoti. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā udakatumbhato purāṇaudakaṃ chaḍḍentassa neva
analyzed: nikkhamantaḥ uccāra passāvo na eva tassa bhikkhuno attanaḥ hoti na parassa kevalam pana  sarīra nissandaḥ uva hoti yathā kim yathā udaka tumbhataḥ purāṇa audakam chaḍḍentassa na iva
translated: When he goes out, the urine and excrement are not his, nor are they anyone else’s;🔽they are just the outcome of the body. How is it like that? It is like the case of a man who throws away old water from a water-pot:

original: taṃ attano hoti na paresaṃ, kevalaṃ paṭijagganamattameva hoti, evanti. Evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha
analyzed: tam attanaḥ hoti na paresam kevalam paṭijagganam attam eva hoti evam ti evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha
translated: that water is not his, nor is it anyone else’s; he just gets rid of it. So too,

original: ‘asammohasampajaññaṃ’ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: the urine and excrement. This is how the “clear comprehension of non-delusion” should be understood here.

original: Gatādīsu gateti gamane. Ṭhiteti ṭhāne. Nisinneti nisajjāya. Sutteti sayane. Tattha abhikkantādīsu vuttanayeneva sampajānakāritā veditabbā.🔽Ayaṃ panettha aparopi nayo – eko hi bhikkhu gacchanto aññaṃ cintento aññaṃ vitakkento
analyzed: gata ādīsu gatā iti gamane ṭhitā iti ṭhāne nisinnā iti nisajjāya suttā iti sayane tattha abhikkanta ādīsu vutta nayena iva sampajāna kāri tā veditabbā  ayam pana ittha aparaḥ api nayaḥ ekaḥ hi bhikkhu gacchantaḥ aññam cintentaḥ aññam vitakkentaḥ
translated: As to “going” and the rest: “going” is walking, “standing” is standing, “sitting” is sitting down, “lying down” is lying down. Herein, the function of clear comprehension should be understood as stated in the case of “going out” and so on.🔽But there is another method: One bhikkhu goes thinking one thing and reflecting on another,

original: gacchati. Eko kammaṭṭhānaṃ avissajjetvāva gacchati. Tathā eko bhikkhu tiṭṭhanto,
analyzed: gacchati ekaḥ kammaṭṭhānam a vissajjetvā ava gacchati tathā ekaḥ bhikkhu tiṭṭhantaḥ
translated: and he does not give attention to the meditation subject. Another goes without giving attention to the meditation subject. So too, one bhikkhu stands …

original: nisīdanto, sayanto aññaṃ cintento aññaṃ vitakkento sayati. Eko kammaṭṭhānaṃ avissajjetvāva sayati.
analyzed: nisīdantaḥ sayantaḥ aññam cintentaḥ aññam vitakkentaḥ sayati ekaḥ kammaṭṭhānam a vissajjetvā ava sayati
translated: He lies down thinking one thing and he lies down reflecting on something else. He lies down without giving up his meditation subject.

original: Ettakena pana na pākaṭaṃ hotīti caṅkamena dīpayiṃsu. Yo hi bhikkhu caṅkamanaṃ otaritvā
analyzed: ettakena pana na pākaṭam hoti iti caṅkamena dīpayiṃsu yaḥ hi bhikkhu caṅkamanaṃ otaritvā
translated: But it is not evident to this extent. They point it out by means of walking up and down. For when a bhikkhu comes down from his lodging and

original: caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ ṭhito pariggaṇhāti; ‘pācīnacaṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ pavattā rūpārūpadhammā🔽pacchimacaṅkamanakoṭiṃ appatvā ettheva niruddhā, pacchimacaṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ pavattāpi🔽pācīnacaṅkamanakoṭiṃ appatvā ettheva niruddhā, caṅkamanavemajjhe pavattā ubho koṭiyo🔽appatvā ettheva niruddhā, caṅkamane pavattā rūpārūpadhammā ṭhānaṃ appatvā ettheva
analyzed: caṅkamana koṭiyam ṭhitaḥ pariggaṇhāti pācīna caṅkamana koṭiyam pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ  pacchima caṅkamana koṭim ap patvā etthā iva niruddhā pacchima caṅkamana koṭiyam pavattā api  pācīna caṅkamana koṭim ap patvā ettha iva niruddhā caṅkamana vemajjhe pavattāḥ ubho koṭiyaḥ  a patvā ettha iva niruddhā caṅkamane pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ṭhānam a patvā ettha iva
translated: stands at the end of the walk, he discerns thus: ‘The material and immaterial phenomena occurring at the eastern end of the walk

original: niruddhā, ṭhāne pavattā nisajjaṃ, nisajjāya pavattā sayanaṃ appatvā ettheva niruddhā’ti
analyzed: niruddhā ṭhāne pavattā nisajjam nisajjāya pavattā sayanam a patvā etthā iva niruddhā iti
translated: cease there without reaching the western end; those occurring at the western end cease there without reaching the eastern end; those occurring in the middle of the walk cease there without reaching the two ends; the material and immaterial phenomena occurring in the open space cease there without reaching the walk; those occurring in the lodging cease there without reaching the walk; those occurring in the open space cease there without reaching the seats; those occurring on the seats cease there without reaching the beds; those occurring on the beds cease there without reaching the seats.’

original: evaṃ pariggaṇhanto pariggaṇhantoyeva bhavaṅgaṃ otāreti; uṭṭhahanto kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvāva
analyzed: evam pariggaṇhantaḥ pariggaṇhantaḥ yā iva bhavaṅgam otāreti uṭṭhahantaḥ kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā ava
translated: As he discerns thus, he enters upon the threshold of insight. When he gets up, he grasps his meditation subject and goes to his lodging.

original: uṭṭhāti – ayaṃ bhikkhu gatādīsu sampajānakārī nāma hotīti.
analyzed: uṭṭhāti ayam bhikkhu gata ādīsu sampajāna kārī nāma hoti iti
translated: He gets up: this bhikkhu is called one who acts with clear comprehension in going and so on.

original: Evaṃ pana sutte kammaṭṭhānaṃ avibhūtaṃ hoti. Kammaṭṭhānaṃ avibhūtaṃ na kātabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam pana sutte kammaṭṭhānam avibhūtam hoti kammaṭṭhānam avibhūtam na kātabbam
translated: But the meditation subject is not explained in the sutta. The meditation subject should not be left unexplained.

original: Tasmā yo bhikkhu yāva sakkoti tāva caṅkamitvā ṭhatvā nisīditvā sayamāno evaṃ pariggahetvā
analyzed: tasmā yaḥ bhikkhu yāva sakkoti tāva caṅkamitvā ṭhatvā nisīditvā sayamānaḥ evam pariggahetvā
translated: So the bhikkhu should discern it thus while he is able to do so, whether he is walking, standing, sitting, lying down, keeping awake or sleeping.

original: sayati – ‘kāyo acetano, mañco acetano. Kāyo na jānāti – ahaṃ mañce sayitoti. Mañcopi
analyzed: sayati kāyaḥ acetanaḥ mañcaḥ acetanaḥ kāyaḥ na jānāti aham mañce sayitā iti mañcaḥ upi
translated: He should discern it thus: ‘The body is in- sentient; the bed is sentient. The body does not know, “I am lying on a bed,”🔽nor does the bed know, “A body is lying on me.” A sentient body is lying on an insentient bed.’

original: na jānāti – mayi kāyo sayitoti. Acetano kāyo acetane mañce sayito’ti. Evaṃ pariggaṇhanto
analyzed: na jānāti mayi kāyo sayito ti acetanaḥ kāyo acetane mañce sayito ti evam pariggaṇhanto
translated: As he discerns thus,

original: pariggaṇhantoyeva cittaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ otāreti, pabujjhamāno kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvāva pabujjhati.
analyzed: pariggaṇhantaḥ yā iva cittam bhavaṅgam otāreti pabujjhamāno kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā ava pabujjhati
translated: he brings the mind to the life-continuum; and when he wakes up, he wakes up taking the meditation subject with him.

original: Ayaṃ sutte sampajānakārī nāma hotīti.🔽Jāgariteti jāgaraṇe. Tattha ‘kiriyāmayapavattassa appavattiyā sati jāgaritaṃ nāma
analyzed: ayam sutte sampajānakārī nāma hoti iti  jāgarita iti jāgaraṇe tattha kiriyā āmaya pavattassa appavattiyā sati jāgaritam nāma
translated: This bhikkhu is called one who acts with clear comprehension in keeping awake.🔽In keeping awake: in the state of keeping awake. Herein, when the occurrence of the kinds of consciousness classed as inoperative is absent, there is no keeping awake;

original: na hoti; kiriyāmayapavattavaḷañje pavattante jāgaritaṃ nāma hotī’ti pariggaṇhanto
analyzed: na hoti kiriyā āmaya pavatta vaḷañje pavattante jāgaritam nāma hoti iti pariggaṇhanto
translated: but when the occurrence of the kinds of consciousness classed as operative is manifest, there is keeping awake.

original: bhikkhu jāgarite sampajānakārī nāma hoti. Apica rattindivaṃ cha koṭṭhāse katvā pañca
analyzed: bhikkhu jāgarite sampajānakārī nāma hoti apica rattindivam cha koṭṭhāse katvā pañca
translated: a monk is said to be “fully aware while awake.” Moreover, having divided the day and night into six periods,

original: koṭṭhāse jaggantopi jāgarite sampajānakārī nāma hoti.🔽Bhāsiteti kathane. Tattha ‘upādārūpassa saddāyatanassa appavatte sati bhāsitaṃ nāma
analyzed: koṭṭhāse jaggantaḥ api jāgarite sampajānakārī nāma hoti  bhāsitā iti kathane tattha upādā rūpassa sadda āyatanassa appavatte sati bhāsitam nāma
translated: A bhikkhu is said to be “fully aware of the state of being awake” when he is awake. Furthermore, he is said to be “fully aware of the state of being awake” when he is awake during five of the six periods of the day and night.

original: na hoti; tasmiṃ pavattante hotī’ti pariggāhako bhikkhu bhāsite sampajānakārī nāma🔽hoti. Vimuttāyatanasīsena dhammaṃ desentopi bāttiṃsa tiracchānakathā pahāya dasakathāvatthunissitaṃ
analyzed: na hoti tasmin pavattante hoti iti pariggāhakaḥ bhikkhu bhāsite sampajānakārī nāma  hoti vimutta āyatana sīsena dhammam desentaḥ api bāttiṃsa tiracchāna kathāḥ pahāya dasa kathā vatthu nissitam
translated: “Speaking”: in speaking. Herein, a bhikkhu is said to be “fully aware of the state of speaking” when he discerns thus: “When there is no occurrence of the sound base consisting of the sound-process that is clung to, then speaking does not exist; when there is its occurrence, it does exist.”

original: kathaṃ kathentopi bhāsite sampajānakārī nāma hoti.🔽Tuṇhībhāveti akathane. Tattha ‘upādārūpassa saddāyatanassa pavattiyaṃ sati tuṇhībhāvo
analyzed: katham kathentaḥ api bhāsite sampajāna kārī nāma hoti  tuṇhībhāva iti a kathane tattha upādā rūpassa sadda āyatanassa pavattiyam sati tuṇhībhāvaḥ
translated: He is said to be “fully aware of the state of speaking” when he teaches the Dhamma by way of the door of the liberations and when he speaks the kind of talk based on the ten examples of talk that should be cultivated, avoiding the thirty-two kinds of talk of the animals.

original: nāma natthi; appavattiyaṃ hotī’ti pariggāhako bhikkhu tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī nāma
analyzed: nāma natthi a pavattiyam hoti iti pariggāhakaḥ bhikkhu tuṇhībhāve sampajāna kārī nāma
translated: “Silence”: in not speaking. Herein, a bhikkhu is said to be “fully aware of the state of silence” when he discerns thus: “When there is the occurrence of the sound base consisting of the sound-process that is clung to, then silence does not exist; when there is its non-occurrence, it exists.”

original: hoti. Aṭṭhatiṃsāya ārammaṇesu cittaruciyaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā nisinnopi dutiyajjhānaṃ
analyzed: hoti aṭṭhatiṃsāya ārammaṇesu citta ruciyam kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā nisinnaḥ api dutiya jhānam
translated: and he is able to enter upon the second jhāna in the thirty-eight objects. He can also enter upon it after he has taken a meditation subject and sat down.

original: samāpannopi tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārīyeva nāma hoti.🔽Ettha ca eko iriyāpatho dvīsu ṭhānesu āgato. So heṭṭhā abhikkante paṭikkanteti ettha
analyzed: samāpannaḥ api tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārīyā iva nāma hoti  ettha ca ekaḥ iriyāpathaḥ dvīsu ṭhānesu āgataḥ saḥ heṭṭhā abhikkante paṭikkante iti ettha
translated: He is called “fully aware of the state of composure” when he has taken up a meditation subject in one of the thirty-eight objects of contemplation and is sitting down, and also when he has attained the second jhāna.🔽. The four postures are mentioned in two places. The first is in the passage beginning, “On going forward or back” .

original: bhikkhācāragāmaṃ gacchato ca āgacchato ca addhānagamanavasena kathito. Gate ṭhite
analyzed: bhikkhācāra gāmam gacchato ca āgacchato ca addhāna gamana vasena kathitaḥ gate ṭhite
translated: Here the posture is mentioned in the sense of the going and coming of one who is going to and coming back from the village for alms. The second is in the passage beginning, “On looking straight on or looking away” .

original: nisinneti ettha vihāre cuṇṇikapāduddhārairiyāpathavasena kathitoti veditabbo.
analyzed: nisinnā iti ettha vihāre cuṇṇika pāduddhāra airiyāpatha vasena kathito ti veditabbo
translated: Here the posture is mentioned in the sense of the postures of sitting, standing, etc., in the monastery.

original: 524. Tattha katamā satītiādi sabbaṃ uttānatthameva.🔽526. So vivittanti iminā kiṃ dasseti? Etassa bhikkhuno upāsanaṭṭhānaṃ yogapathaṃ
analyzed: tattha katamā satī itiādi sabbam uttāna attham eva  saḥ vivitta nti iminā kim dasseti etassa bhikkhuno upāsana ṭhānam yogapatham
translated: . The meaning of the words of the rest is clear.🔽. What does the phrase “in an isolated place” show? It shows the place for devotion, the path of endeavour,

original: sappāyasenāsanaṃ dasseti. Yassa hi abbhantare ettakā guṇā atthi, tassa anucchaviko
analyzed: sa pāyasena āsanam dasseti yassa hi abbhantare ettakāḥ guṇāḥ atthi tassa anucchaviko
translated: and the suitable dwelling-place for this bhikkhu. For it is suitable for one who possesses these special qualities to live in an isolated place.

original: araññavāso. Yassa panete natthi, tassa ananucchaviko. Evarūpassa hi araññavāso kāḷamakkaṭaacchataracchadīpimigādīnaṃ🔽aṭavīvāsasadiso hoti. Kasmā? Icchāya ṭhatvā paviṭṭhattā. Tassa hi araññavāsamūlako
analyzed: arañña vāsaḥ yassa pana ete natthi tassa an anucchavikaḥ evarūpassa hi arañña vāsaḥ kāḷa makkaṭa acchata raccha dīpi miga ādīnam  aṭavī vāsa sadisaḥ hoti kasmai icchāya ṭhatvā paviṭṭha ttā tassa hi arañña vāsa mūlako
translated: and living in the forest. For one who does not have these qualities, it is not suitable. For such a person, living in the forest is like the forest life of the black wild buffalo, the wild cow, the wild boar, the monkey, the deer, and so on.

original: koci attho natthi; araññavāsañceva āraññake ca dūseti; sāsane appasādaṃ uppādeti.🔽Yassa pana abbhantare ettakā guṇā atthi, tasseva so anucchaviko. So hi araññavāsaṃ🔽nissāya vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ gaṇhitvā parinibbāti, sakalaaraññavāsaṃ
analyzed: koci atthaḥ natthi arañña vāsam ca iva āraññake ca dūseti sāsane appasādam uppādeti  yassa pana abbhantare ettakāḥ guṇāḥ atthi tassa iva so anucchaviko so hi arañña vāsam  nissāya vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam gaṇhitvā parinibbāti sakala arañña vāsam
translated: Why? Because he entered the forest out of desire. For he has no purpose in living in the forest; he defiles both the forest and the forest-dweller, and he causes lack of confidence in the dispensation.

original: upasobheti, āraññikānaṃ sīsaṃ dhovati, sakalasāsanaṃ pasāreti. Tasmā satthā evarūpassa
analyzed: upasobheti āraññikānam sīsam dhovati sakala sāsanam pasāreti tasmā satthā evarūpassa
translated: But for one who has these qualities, it is suitable. For he establishes insight by depending on the forest life, attains arahatship, and attains final Nibbāna. He adorns the entire forest life, he washes the heads of the forest-dwellers, and he causes confidence in the entire dispensation.

original: bhikkhuno upāsanaṭṭhānaṃ yogapathaṃ sappāyasenāsanaṃ dassento so vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhuno upāsana ṭṭhānam yogapatham sa pāyasena āsanam dassento so vivittam senāsanam
translated: Therefore, the Teacher, showing a suitable place for worship, a path of practice, and a suitable lodging for a bhikkhu of this kind, said: “He seeks a lodging in the forest.”

original: bhajatītiādimāha. Tattha vivittanti suññaṃ appasaddaṃ appanigghosaṃ. Etameva hi atthaṃ
analyzed: bhajati itiādim āha tattha vivittam ti suññam appa saddam appa nigghosam etam eva hi attham
translated: He said, “He frequents,” and so on. Herein, secluded means empty, with little noise, with little sound. For the purpose of showing this very meaning,

original: dassetuṃ tañca anākiṇṇantiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha anākiṇṇanti asaṅkiṇṇaṃ asambādhaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: dassetum tat ca an ākiṇṇa nti ādi vuttam tattha an ākiṇṇa nti a saṅkiṇṇam a sambādham tattha
translated: “Uncrowded” is said. Herein, uncrowded means unfrequented, unconfined. Herein,

original: yassa senāsanassa sāmantā gāvutampi aḍḍhayojanampi pabbatagahanaṃ vanagahanaṃ nadīgahanaṃ
analyzed: yassa senāsanassa sāmantā gāvutam pi aḍḍha yojanam pi pabbata gahanam vana gahanam nadī gahanam
translated: if there is a mountain forest, a jungle forest, a river forest, within a league or half a league of a dwelling place,

original: hoti, na koci avelāya upasaṅkamituṃ sakkoti – idaṃ santikepi anākiṇṇaṃ nāma. Yaṃ
analyzed: hoti na koci avelāya upasaṅkamitum sakkoti idam santike pi an ākiṇṇam nāma yam
translated: no one can approach at the wrong time — this is called uncrowded even if it is near. But

original: pana aḍḍhayojanikaṃ vā yojanikaṃ vā hoti – idaṃ dūratāya eva anākiṇṇaṃ nāma hoti.
analyzed: pana aḍḍhayojanikam vā yojanikam vā hoti idam dūratāya eva an ākiṇṇam nāma hoti
translated: if it is a league or half a league away, this is called uncrowded because of its distance.

original: 527. Seti ceva āsati ca etthāti senāsanaṃ. Tassa pabhedaṃ dassetuṃ mañco pīṭhantiādi
analyzed: seti ca iva āsati ca ettha ati senāsanam tassa pabhedam dassetum mañcaḥ pīṭha nti ādi
translated: . A dwelling place is where one sits and lies down. For the purpose of showing its classification, “A bed, a chair” is said.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha mañcoti cattāro mañcā – masārako, bundikābaddho, kuḷīrapādako, āhaccapādakoti.
analyzed: vuttam tattha mañco ti cattāraḥ mañcāḥ masārakaḥ bundikābaddhaḥ kuḷīrapādakaḥ āhaccapādakaḥ ti
translated: Herein, a bed is four kinds of beds: a bed of bamboo, a bed of bundles, a bed of strips, a bed of wood.

original: Tathā pīṭhaṃ. Bhisīti pañca bhisiyo – uṇṇābhisi, coḷabhisi, vākabhisi, tiṇabhisi,
analyzed: tathā pīṭham bhisī iti pañca bhisiyaḥ uṇṇā bhisi coḷa bhisi vāka bhisi tiṇa bhisi
translated: Likewise, a chair. A mat is five kinds of mats: a mat of cotton, a mat of silk, a mat of wool, a mat of grass,

original: paṇṇabhisīti. Bimbohananti sīsupadhānaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃ vitthārato vidatthicaturaṅgulaṃ
analyzed: paṇṇabhisī iti bimbohanam ti sīsa upadhānam vuttam tam vitthārataḥ vidatthi catur aṅgulam

analyzed: vaṭṭati dīghataḥ mañca vitthāra ppamāṇam vihāroti samantā parihāra patham  ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhānāni dassetvā kata senāsanam aḍḍha yogo ti su paṇṇa vaṅka geham pāsādaḥ ti  dve kaṇṇikāni gahetvā kataḥ dīgha pāsādaḥ aṭṭo ti paṭirāja ādi paṭibāhana attham
translated: It is allowable to make it as long as the width of the bed and as wide as the bed. ‘Hut’ is a dwelling that has a space all round inside for walking up and down in.🔽‘Roofed with thatch’ means roofed with thatch mats. ‘Roofed with tiles’ means roofed with tiles. ‘Roofed with slabs’ means roofed with slabs. ‘Roofed with planks’ means roofed with planks. ‘Roofed with leaves’ means roofed with leaves. ‘Roofed with grass’ means roofed with grass mats. It is allowable to make a mat of grass, spreading it out flat, four fingerbreadths thick.

original: kato bahalabhittiko catupañcabhūmiko patissayaviseso. Māḷoti bhojanasālasadiso maṇḍalamāḷo;
analyzed: kataḥ bahala bhittiko catu pañca bhūmiko patissaya visesaḥ māḷaḥ ti bhojana sāla sadisaḥ maṇḍalamāḷaḥ
translated: ‘Roofed with straw’ means roofed with straw mats. It is allowable to make a mat of straw, spreading it out flat, four fingerbreadths thick. It is allowable to make it as long as the width of the bed and as wide as the bed. ‘Hut’ is a dwelling that has a space all round inside for walking up and down in.🔽‘Roofed with thatch’ means roofed with thatch mats. ‘Roofed with tiles’ means roofed with tiles. ‘Roofed with slabs’ means roofed with slabs. ‘Roofed with planks’ means roofed with planks. ‘Roofed with leaves’ means roofed with leaves. ‘Roofed with grass’ means roofed with grass mats. It is allowable to make a mat of grass, spreading it out flat, four fingerbreadths thick.

original: vinayaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana ekakūṭasaṅgahito caturassapāsādoti vuttaṃ. Leṇanti pabbataṃ🔽khaṇitvā vā pabbhārassa appahonakaṭṭhāne kuṭṭaṃ uṭṭhāpetvā vā katasenāsanaṃ. Guhāti
analyzed: vinaya ṭṭhakathā ayam pana eka kūṭa saṅgahito catur assa pāsādaḥ ti vuttam leṇam ti pabbatam  khaṇitvā vā pabbhārassa appahonaka ṭṭhāne kuṭṭam uṭṭhāpetvā vā kata senāsanam guhāti
translated: ‘Roofed with straw’ means roofed with straw mats. It is allowable to make a mat of straw, spreading it out flat, four fingerbreadths thick. It is allowable to make it as long as the width of the bed and as wide as the bed. ‘Hut’ is a dwelling that has a space all round inside for walking up and down in.

original: bhūmidari vā yattha rattindivaṃ dīpaṃ laddhuṃ vaṭṭati, pabbataguhā vā bhūmiguhā vā.
analyzed: vā yattha rattindivam dīpam laddhum vaṭṭati pabbata guhā vā bhūmi guhā vā
translated: ‘Roofed with thatch’ means roofed with thatch mats. ‘Roofed with tiles’ means roofed with tiles. ‘Roofed with slabs’ means roofed with slabs. ‘Roofed with planks’ means roofed with planks. ‘Roofed with leaves’ means roofed with leaves. ‘Roofed with grass’ means roofed with grass mats. It is allowable to make a mat of grass, spreading

original: Rukkhamūlanti rukkhassa heṭṭhā parikkhittaṃ vā aparikkhittaṃ vā. Veḷugumboti veḷugaccho.
analyzed: rukkha mūlanti rukkhassa heṭṭhā parikkhittam vā a parikkhittam vā veḷugumbaḥ ti veḷugacchaḥ
translated: “The foot of a tree” means either inside or outside an enclosure. “A thicket” means a bamboo thicket.🔽“Wherever monks gather” means except for the bed, etc., mentioned above, wherever

original: Yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamantīti ṭhapetvā vā etāni mañcādīni yattha bhikkhū🔽sannipatanti, yaṃ tesaṃ sannipātārahaṭṭhānaṃ, sabbametaṃ senāsanaṃ.🔽528. Bhajatīti upeti. Sambhajatīti tattha abhirativasena anukkaṇṭhito suṭṭhu upeti.
analyzed: yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamanti iti ṭhapetvā vā etāni mañca ādīni yattha bhikkhū  sannipatanti yam tesam sannipāta araha ṭṭhānam sabbam etam senāsanam  bhajati iti upeti sambhajati iti tattha abhirati vasena anukkaṇṭhito suṭṭhu upeti
translated: monks gather,🔽all that is a dwelling.🔽“Uses” means approaches. “Frequents” means approaches well, without being dissatisfied with the place.

original: Sevatīti nivāsanavasena sevati nisevatīti anukkaṇṭhamāno sannisito hutvā sevati.
analyzed: sevati iti nivāsana vasena sevati nisevati iti an ukkaṇṭhamānaḥ sannisitaḥ hutvā sevati
translated: “Resorts to” means uses by way of living in. “Frequents” means uses without being dissatisfied, using it as one’s own.

original: Saṃsevatīti senāsanavattaṃ sampādento sammā sevati.🔽529. Idāni yaṃ taṃ vivittanti vuttaṃ, tassa pabhedaṃ dassetuṃ araññaṃ rukkhamūlantiādi
analyzed: saṃsevati iti senāsana vattam sampādento sammā sevati  idāni yam tam vivittan ti vuttam tassa pabhedam dassetum araññam rukkha mūlam tiādi
translated: “Frequents” means uses properly by fulfilling the duties towards the dwelling.🔽Now, in order to show the different kinds of dwellings mentioned above as “secluded,” the text is stated thus: “A forest, the foot of a tree” , etc.

original: āraddhaṃ. Tattha araññanti vinayapariyāyena tāva “ṭhapetvā gāmañca gāmūpacārañca
analyzed: āraddham tattha vinaya pariyāyena tāva ṭhapetvā gāmam ca gāmūpacāram ca
translated: Herein, “a forest” means, according to the Vinaya method, “having set aside a village and the vicinity of a village,”

original: avasesaṃ arañña”nti āgataṃ. Suttantapariyāyena āraññikaṃ bhikkhuṃ sandhāya “āraññakaṃ
analyzed: avasesam araññanti āgatam suttanta pariyāyena āraññikam bhikkhum sandhāya āraññakam
translated: The rest is forest.🔽The forest-dweller’s dwelling is five hundred bow-lengths away” .

original: nāma senāsanaṃ pañcadhanusatikapacchima”nti āgataṃ. Vinayasuttantā pana ubhopi pariyāyadesanā🔽nāma. Abhidhammo nippariyāyadesanāti abhidhammapariyāyena araññaṃ dassetuṃ nikkhamitvā
analyzed: nāma senāsanam āgatam vinaya suttantā pana ubho pi pariyāya desanā  nāma abhidhammaḥ nippariyāya desanā ati abhidhamma pariyāyena araññam dassetum nikkhamitvā
translated: But the Suttas and the Vinaya are called “the teaching by way of the Thread” .🔽The Abhidhamma is called “the teaching by way of the ultimate sense” .

original: bahi indakhīlāti vuttaṃ; indakhīlato bahi nikkhamitvāti attho.🔽530. Rukkhamūlādīnaṃ pakatiyā ca suviññeyyabhāvato rukkhamūlaṃyeva rukkhamūlantiādi
analyzed: bahi inda khīlā ati vuttam inda khīlataḥ bahi nikkhamitvā iti attho  rukkha mūla ādīnam pakatiyā ca su viññeyya bhāvataḥ rukkha mūlam yeva rukkha mūlam tiādi
translated: So in order to show the forest by way of the Abhidhamma, “having gone out beyond the boundary” is said; the meaning is that he has gone out beyond the boundary post.🔽The root of a tree, etc., are easy to recognize in their normal state, so “the root of a tree” is said to be the root of a tree, and so on.

original: vuttaṃ. Apicettha rukkhamūlanti yaṃkiñci sītacchāyaṃ vivittaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ. Pabbatanti
analyzed: vuttam apica ittha rukkha mūlam ti yaṃkiñci sīta chāyam vivittam rukkha mūlam pabbatanti
translated: And here the “root of a tree” is any secluded place with cool shade. “A mountain” is a rock.

original: selaṃ. Tattha hi udakasoṇḍīsu udakakiccaṃ katvā sītāya rukkhacchāyāya nisinnassa
analyzed: selam tattha hi udaka soṇḍīsu udaka kiccam katvā sītāya rukkha chāyāya nisinnassa
translated: For when one has done one’s washing in a rock pool and is sitting in the cool shade of a tree,

original: nānādisāsu khāyamānāsu sītena vātena bījiyamānassa cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti. Kandaranti
analyzed: nānādisāsu khāyamānāsu sītena vātena bījiyamānassa cittam ekaggam hoti kandaranti
translated: and the cool wind is blowing from the different directions, one’s mind becomes unified. “A cave” is a rock-cave.

original: kaṃ vuccati udakaṃ, tena daritaṃ udakena bhinnaṃ pabbatappadesaṃ; yaṃ nitumbantipi
analyzed: kam vuccati udakam tena daritam udakena bhinnam pabbata ppadesam yam
translated: “What is called water? It is the place in the mountain cleft that is broken through by water. They call it a “water-fall”

original: nadīkuñjantipi vadanti. Tattha hi rajatapaṭṭasadisā vālikā honti, matthake maṇivitānaṃ🔽viya vanagahanaṃ, maṇikkhandhasadisaṃ udakaṃ sandati. Evarūpaṃ kandaraṃ oruyha pānīyaṃ
analyzed: vadanti tattha hi rajata paṭṭa sadisāḥ vālikāḥ honti matthake maṇi vitānam  viya vana gahanam maṇi kkhandha sadisam udakam sandati evarūpam kandaram oruyha pānīyam
translated: or a “mountain stream.” For there the sand is like a silver plate, the trees are like a canopy of gems,

original: pivitvā gattāni sītaṃ katvā vālikaṃ ussāpetvā paṃsukūlacīvaraṃ paññapetvā nisinnassa
analyzed: pivitvā gattāni sītam katvā vālikam ussāpetvā paṃsukūla cīvaram paññapetvā nisinnassa
