translated: and the water flows like a mass of gems. Having gone down to such a waterfall and drunk the water and cooled his limbs and body, and having spread out his cast-off hempen rag-robe,

original: samaṇadhammaṃ karoto cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti. Giriguhanti dvinnaṃ pabbatānaṃ antaraṃ,
analyzed: samaṇa dhammam karotaḥ cittam ekaggam hoti giri guhanti dvinnam pabbatānam antaram
translated: and having sat down, if he practices the ascetic practices, his mind becomes concentrated. “A mountain cave” is the space between two mountains,

original: ekasmiṃyeva vā umaṅgasadisaṃ mahāvivaraṃ. Susānalakkhaṇaṃ visuddhimagge vuttaṃ.🔽531. Vanapatthanti gāmantaṃ atikkamitvā manussānaṃ anupacāraṭṭhānaṃ, yattha na kasanti
analyzed: ekasmin yeva vā umaṅga sadisam mahā vivaram su sāna lakkhaṇam visuddhi magge vuttam  vana pattham ti gāmantam atikkamitvā manussānam an upacāra ṭhānam yattha na kasanti
translated: or a large opening in one mountain like a cave. The characteristics of a charnel ground are given in the Path of Purification.🔽“A forest” is a place beyond the boundary of a village where people do not go about, where they do not sow and cultivate.

original: na vapanti. Tenevassa niddese “vanapatthanti dūrānametaṃ senāsanānaṃ adhivacana”ntiādi
analyzed: na vapanti tena iva assa niddese dūrānam etam senāsanānam
translated: In the description of this it is said: “Forest: this is a designation for a place a long way from anywhere, a place where there are no human beings.”

original: vuttaṃ. Yasmā vā rukkhamūlādīsu idamevekaṃ bhājetvā dassitaṃ, tasmāssa nikkhepapaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: vuttam yasmā vā rukkha mūla ādīsu idam eva ekam bhājetvā dassitam tasmā assa nikkhepa paṭipāṭiyā
translated: This is said. Or since this is the only one among the tree-root, etc., that is shown by dividing it up,

original: niddesaṃ akatvā sabbapariyante niddeso katoti veditabbo. Abbhokāsanti acchannaṃ.🔽Ākaṅkhamāno panettha cīvarakuṭiṃ katvā vasati. Palālapuñjanti palālarāsi. Mahāpalālapuñjato
analyzed: niddesam a katvā sabba pariyante niddeso kato ti veditabbaḥ abbhokāsanti acchannam  ākaṅkhamānaḥ pana ittha cīvara kuṭim katvā vasati palāla puñjanti palāla rāsi mahā palāla puñjataḥ
translated: it should be understood that its description is given by way of the whole, not by way of the division, as in the case of the “refuse-rag” .🔽Open-air: uncovered.🔽But if he wishes, he can make a hut of leaves and live there. A heap of sticks: a pile of sticks.

original: hi palālaṃ nikkaḍḍhitvā pabbhāraleṇasadise ālaye karonti, gacchagumbādīnampi upari🔽palālaṃ pakkhipitvā heṭṭhā nisinnā samaṇadhammaṃ karonti; taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: hi palālam nikkaḍḍhitvā pabbhāraleṇa sadise ālaye karonti gaccha gumba ādīnam pi upari  palālam pakkhipitvā heṭṭhā nisinnā samaṇa dhammam karonti tam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: For from a big heap of sticks they take away the sticks and make a shelter like a cave in a bank,🔽and they sit underneath and do their ascetic practice, covering themselves above with sticks, creepers, and leaves, and with grass and so on.

original: Vanapatthaniddese salomahaṃsānanti yattha paviṭṭhassa lomahaṃso uppajjati; evarūpānaṃ
analyzed: vanapattha niddese sa lomahaṃsānam ti yattha paviṭṭhassa lomahaṃso uppajjati evarūpānam
translated: In the description of the forest-dweller’s site: with hair-raising beasts: in such a place as that the hair of one who enters it stands on end.🔽With hair-raising abodes: with such terrifying abodes.

original: bhīsanakasenāsanānaṃ. Pariyantānanti dūrabhāvena pariyante ṭhitānaṃ. Na manussūpacārānanti
analyzed: bhīsanaka senāsanānam dūra bhāvena pariyante ṭhitānam na manussu upacārānanti
translated: With a perimeter: with a perimeter that is far away. Not frequented by men:

original: kasanavapanavasena manussehi upacaritabbaṃ vanantaṃ atikkamitvā ṭhitānaṃ. Durabhisambhavānanti
analyzed: kasana vapana vasena manussehi upacaritabbam vanantam atikkamitvā ṭhitānam durabhisambhavānam ti
translated: beyond the forest frequented by men by reason of its being ploughed and sown. Hard to get to:

original: aladdhavivekassādehi abhibhuyya vasituṃ nasakkuṇeyyānaṃ.
analyzed: a laddha vivekaḥ sādehi abhibhuyya vasitum
translated: and so they are unable to live by overcoming the delight in the unanalyzed.

original: 532. Appasaddādiniddese appasaddanti vacanasaddena appasaddaṃ.
analyzed: appasadda ādi niddese appasaddanti vacana saddena appasaddam
translated: In the description of “seclusion by absence of noise” the words “absence of noise” mean absence of the noise of speech.

original: 533. Appanigghosanti nagaranigghosasaddena appanigghosaṃ. Yasmā pana ubhayampetaṃ
analyzed: appa nigghosanti nagara nigghosa saddena appa nigghosam yasmā pana ubhayampetam
translated: “Absence of clamour” means absence of the noise of a town’s clamour. But since both these terms are🔽identical in being terms for sound,

original: saddaṭṭhena ekaṃ, tasmāssa niddese “yadeva taṃ appasaddaṃ tadeva taṃ appanigghosa”nti🔽vuttaṃ. Vijanavātanti anusañcaraṇajanassa sarīravātena virahitaṃ. Vijanavādantipi
analyzed: sadda ṭṭhena ekam tasmā assa niddese yat eva tam appa saddam tat eva tam  vuttam vijana vātanti anusañcaraṇa janassa sarīra vātena virahitam
translated: “That which is absence of noise is absence of clamour” is said in the description.

original: pāṭho; antojanavādena virahitanti attho. Yasmā pana yaṃ appanigghosaṃ, tadeva janasañcaraṇena🔽ca janavādena ca virahitaṃ hoti, tasmāssa niddese “yadeva taṃ appanigghosaṃ tadeva
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ antar janavādena virahitanti atthaḥ yasmā pana yam appa nigghosam tat eva jana sañcaraṇena  ca janavādena ca virahitam hoti tasmā assa niddese yat eva tam appa nigghosam tat eva
translated: “Absence of people” means devoid of the body-wind of people who move about. The reading “vijanavāta” is also allowable; the meaning is: devoid of the wind of people inside. But since that which is absence of clamour is also devoid of people moving about and of the noise of people,🔽“That which is absence of clamour is absence of people” is said in the description.

original: taṃ vijanavāta”nti vuttaṃ. Manussarāhaseyyakanti manussānaṃ rahassakiriyaṭṭhāniyaṃ.
analyzed: tam vijana vātam ti vuttam manussa rāhaseyyakanti manussānam rahassa kiriya ṭṭhāniyam
translated: “A place for a man to be alone” is a place for a man to make love.

original: Yasmā pana taṃ janasañcaraṇarahitaṃ hoti, tenassa niddese “yadeva taṃ vijanavātaṃ
analyzed: yasmā pana tam jana sañcaraṇa rahitam hoti tena assa niddese yat eva tam vijana vātam
translated: But since it is devoid of the coming and going of people, it is described in the Niddesa thus: “What is the lonely place?

original: tadeva taṃ manussarāhaseyyaka”nti vuttaṃ. Paṭisallānasāruppanti vivekānurūpaṃ. Yasmā
analyzed: tat eva tam manussa rāhaseyyakanti vuttam paṭisallāna sāruppam ti viveka anurūpam yasmā
translated: It is where there is no coming and going of people” .🔽“Conducive to seclusion” : suitable for seclusion.

original: pana taṃ niyameneva manussarāhaseyyakaṃ hoti, tasmāssa niddese “yadeva taṃ manussarāhaseyyakaṃ
analyzed: pana tam niyamena iva manussa rāhaseyyakam hoti tasmā assa niddese yat eva tam manussa rāhaseyyakam
translated: But since it is necessarily devoid of the coming and going of people, it is described in the Niddesa thus: “What is conducive to seclusion?

original: tadeva taṃ paṭisallānasāruppa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tat eva tam paṭisallāna sāruppan ti vuttam
translated: It is where there is no coming and going of people” .

original: 534. Araññagatādiniddese araññaṃ vuttameva. Tathā rukkhamūlaṃ. Avasesaṃ pana sabbampi senāsanaṃ suññāgārena saṅgahitaṃ.🔽535. Pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvāti samantato ūrubaddhāsanaṃ bandhitvā. Ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāyāti
analyzed: arañña gata ādi niddese araññam vuttam eva tathā rukkha mūlam avasesam pana sabbam pi senāsanam suññāgārena saṅgahitam  pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ati samantataḥ ūru baddha āsanam bandhitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya ati
translated: In the description of the “forest” , etc., the “forest” has already been explained. So too the “root of a tree.” But all the rest of the dwellings are included in the “empty place.”🔽“Having folded his legs crosswise”: having bound the legs crosswise.

original: uparimaṃ sarīraṃ ujuṃ ṭhapetvā aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭake koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭipādetvā.
analyzed: uparimam sarīram ujum ṭhapetvā aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭake koṭiyā koṭim paṭipādetvā
translated: “Set his body erect”: having placed the upper part of the body erect.

original: Evañhi nisinnassa cammamaṃsanhārūni na paṇamanti. Athassa yā tesaṃ paṇamanapaccayā
analyzed: evam hi nisinnassa camma maṃsa nhārūni na paṇamanti athassa yā tesam paṇamana paccayā
translated: For when he sits thus, his skin, flesh and sinews are not bent down. Then, because of the absence of bending,🔽his mindfulness is established without disturbance.

original: khaṇe khaṇe vedanā uppajjeyyuṃ, tā nuppajjanti. Tāsu na uppajjamānāsu cittaṃ ekaggaṃ
analyzed: khaṇe khaṇe vedanāḥ uppajjeyyum tāḥ na uppajjanti tāsu na uppajjamānāsu cittam ekaggam
translated: Feelings would arise moment after moment, but they do not arise. When they do not arise, the mind becomes unified,

original: hoti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ na paripatati, vuḍḍhiṃ phātiṃ upagacchati.
analyzed: hoti kammaṭṭhānam na paripatati vuḍḍhim phātim upagacchati
translated: the meditation subject does not disintegrate, and it advances to success.

original: 536. Ujuko hoti kāyo ṭhito paṇihitoti idampi hi imamevatthaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ujukaḥ hoti kāyaḥ ṭhito paṇihito ti idam api hi imam eva attham sandhāya vuttam
translated: “The body is held erect and well-knit” is said with reference to the same meaning.

original: 537. Parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvāti kammaṭṭhānābhimukhaṃ satiṃ ṭhapayitvā, mukhasamīpe🔽vā katvāti attho. Teneva vuttaṃ “ayaṃ sati upaṭṭhitā hoti sūpaṭṭhitā nāsikagge vā
analyzed: parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā ati kammaṭṭhāna abhimukham satim ṭhapayitvā mukha samīpe  vā katvā iti atthaḥ tena iva vuttam ayam sati upaṭṭhitā hoti su upaṭṭhitā nāsikagge vā
translated: “Having established mindfulness in front of him” means having placed mindfulness facing the meditation subject,

original: mukhanimitte vā”ti. Mukhanimittanti cettha uttaroṭṭhassa vemajjhappadeso daṭṭhabbo,
analyzed: mukha nimitte vā ati mukha nimittam ti ca ittha uttara uṭṭhassa vemajjha ppadeso daṭṭhabbo
translated: or having made it in front of the face, is the meaning. That is why it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “This mindfulness is established, well established, at the nose-tip or in the forehead” .🔽And here the middle of the upper lip should be regarded as the sign of the face,

original: yattha nāsikavāto paṭihaññati; atha vā parīti pariggahaṭṭho, mukhanti niyyānaṭṭho,
analyzed: yattha nāsika vāto paṭihaññati atha vā pari iti pariggaha aṭṭhaḥ mukhanti niyyāna ṭṭhaḥ
translated: where the air-flow is checked. Or alternatively, pari means “having taken up,” mukha means “the outlet,”

original: satīti upaṭṭhānaṭṭho; tena vuccati “parimukhaṃ sati”nti evaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttanayenapettha
analyzed: satī iti upaṭṭhāna aṭṭho tena vuccati parimukham satin ti evam paṭisambhidā ayam vutta nayena pa ittha
translated: and sati means “the establishment”: thus “having established mindfulness in front of the face” is what is said.

original: attho daṭṭhabbo. Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepo “pariggahitaniyyānaṃ satiṃ katvā”ti.🔽538. Abhijjhāniddeso uttānatthoyeva. Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepavaṇṇanā – abhijjhaṃ loke🔽pahāyāti lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena pañcupādānakkhandhā loko. Tasmā pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu
analyzed: atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ tatra ayam saṅkhepaḥ pariggahita niyyānam satim katvā iti  abhijjhā niddeso uttāna atthaḥ yeva ayam pana ittha saṅkhepa vaṇṇanā abhijjham loke  pahāya āti lujjana palujjana ṭṭhena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ tasmā pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu
translated: The meaning should be seen. Herein, this is a brief explanation: “having made relinquishment the resort, mindfulness is established” .

original: rāgaṃ pahāya kāmacchandaṃ vikkhambhetvāti ayamettha attho.
analyzed: rāgam pahāya kāmacchandam vikkhambhetvā iti ayam ettha attho
translated: The description of covetousness is self-evident. But here is a brief comment: “in the world” : the five aggregates as objects of clinging are the world in the sense of being subject to crushing and being a crusher . Therefore the meaning here is this: “having abandoned greed for the five aggregates as objects of clinging, having suppressed sensual desire” .

original: 539. Vigatābhijjhenāti vikkhambhanavasena pahīnattā vigatābhijjhena, na cakkhuviññāṇasadisenāti attho.🔽541. Abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodhetīti abhijjhāto cittaṃ parisodheti; yathā naṃ sā🔽muñcati ceva, muñcitvā ca na puna gaṇhāti, evaṃ karotīti attho. Niddesapadesu panassa
analyzed: vigata abhijjhena ati vikkhambhana vasena pahīna ttā vigata abhijjhena na cakkhu viññāṇa sadisena ati attho  abhijjhāya cittam parisodheti iti abhijjhātaḥ cittam parisodheti yathā nam sā  muñcati ca iva muñcitvā ca na puna gaṇhāti evam karoti iti atthaḥ niddesa padesu panassa
translated: “With a mind free from covetousness” : with a mind free from covetousness by way of suppression; the meaning is, not like eye-consciousness.

original: āsevanto sodheti, bhāvento visodheti, bahulīkaronto parisodhetīti evamattho veditabbo.
analyzed: āsevantaḥ sodheti bhāventaḥ visodheti bahulīkarontaḥ parisodheti iti evamatthaḥ veditabbo
translated: “He purifies his mind from covetousness” : he purifies his mind from covetousness; the meaning is, he acts in such a way that it is released from covetousness and, being released, does not grasp again. But in the passages of the description, the meaning should be understood thus: “he purifies by development, he purifies by practice, he purifies by repetition” .

original: Mocetītiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: moca iti iti ādīsupi esā iva nayoḥ
translated: The same method of explanation applies to the passages beginning “he liberates his mind from ill will” .

original: 542-543. Byāpādadosaṃ pahāyātiādīnampi imināva nayena attho veditabbo. Byāpajjati
analyzed: byāpāda dosam pahāya ati ādīnam pi iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ byāpajjati
translated: Byāpādadosaṃ pahāyātiādīnampi imināva nayena attho veditabbo. Byāpajjati

original: iminā cittaṃ pūtikummāsādayo viya pakatiṃ jahatīti byāpādo. Vikārappattiyā padussati,
analyzed: iminā cittam pūti kummāsa ādayaḥ viya pakatim jahati iti byāpādaḥ vikāra ppattiyā padussati
translated: iminā cittaṃ pūtikummāsādayo viya pakatiṃ jahatīti byāpādo. Vikārappattiyā padussati,

original: paraṃ vā padūseti vināsetīti padoso. Ubhayametaṃ kodhassevādhivacanaṃ. Teneva vuttaṃ
analyzed: param vā padūseti vināseti iti padosaḥ ubhayam etam kodhassa iva adhivacanam tena iva vuttam
translated: paraṃ vā padūseti vināsetīti padoso. Ubhayametaṃ kodhassevādhivacanaṃ. Teneva vuttaṃ

original: “yo byāpādo so padoso; yo padoso so byāpādo”ti. Yasmā cesa sabbasaṅgāhikavasena niddiṭṭho,
analyzed: yaḥ byāpādo so padosaḥ yaḥ padoso so byāpādo ti yasmā ca isa sabbasaṅgāhika vasena niddiṭṭho
translated: “yo byāpādo so padoso; yo padoso so byāpādo”ti. Yasmā cesa sabbasaṅgāhikavasena niddiṭṭho,

original: tasmā “sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī”ti avatvā “abyāpannacitto”ti ettakameva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī iti avatvā a byāpanna cittaḥ ti ettakam eva vuttam
translated: tasmā “sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī”ti avatvā “abyāpannacitto”ti ettakameva vuttaṃ.

original: 546. Thinaṃ cittagelaññaṃ, middhaṃ cetasikagelaññaṃ; thinañca middhañca thinamiddhaṃ.
analyzed: thinam citta gelaññam middham cetasika gelaññam thinam ca middham ca thina middham
translated: . Thinaṃ cittagelaññaṃ, middhaṃ cetasikagelaññaṃ; thinañca middhañca thinamiddhaṃ.

original: Santā hontīti ime dvepi dhammā nirodhasantatāya santā hontīti. Idaṃ sandhāyettha vacanabhedo kato.
analyzed: santā honti iti ime dve pi dhammā nirodha santatāya santā honti iti idam sandhāya ittha vacana bhedo kato
translated: Santā hontīti ime dvepi dhammā nirodhasantatāya santā hontīti. Idaṃ sandhāyettha vacanabhedo kato.

original: 549. Ālokasaññīti rattimpi divāpi diṭṭhālokasañjānanasamatthāya vigatanīvaraṇāya parisuddhāya saññāya samannāgato.
analyzed: āloka saññī iti rattimpi divā api diṭṭha āloka sañjānana samatthāya vigata nīvaraṇāya parisuddhāya saññāya samannāgataḥ
translated: He is one who possesses the perception of light, which is purified from hindrances and is capable of apprehending light as light both by day and by night.

original: 550. Sato sampajānoti satiyā ca ñāṇena ca samannāgato. Idaṃ ubhayaṃ ālokasaññāya upakārakattā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sataḥ sampajānoti satiyā ca ñāṇena ca samannāgataḥ idam ubhayam āloka saññāya upakāraka ttā vuttam
translated: He is one who possesses mindfulness and full awareness. This is said because these two are helpful to the perception of light.

original: 553. Vigatathinamiddhatāya pana ālokasaññāya niddesapadesu cattattātiādīni aññamaññavevacanāneva.
analyzed: vigata thinam iddha tāya pana āloka saññāya niddesa padesu catta tta ati ādīni aññamañña vevacanāni eva
translated: But the words “without losing the perception of light” are synonyms for the words “without losing the state of being free from sloth and torpor” in the description of the jhāna.

original: Tattha cattattāti cattakāraṇā. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Cattattāti idaṃ panettha🔽sakabhāvapariccajanavasena vuttaṃ. Vantattāti idaṃ puna anādiyanabhāvadassanavasena.
analyzed: tattha catta ttā ati catta kāraṇā sesa padesu pi esā iva nayaḥ catta ttā ati idam pana ittha  saka bhāva pariccajana vasena vuttam vanta ttā ati idam puna an ādiyana bhāva dassana vasena
translated: Herein, “four reasons” is the same as “four causes” . The same method of explanation applies in the other passages.🔽But the words “four reasons” are said here🔽in order to show the abandoning of one’s own person. The words “four abandonings” are said in order to show the non-taking of anything.

original: Muttattāti idaṃ santatito vinimocanavasena. Pahīnattāti idaṃ muttassāpi katthaci
analyzed: mutta ttā ati idam santatitaḥ vinimocana vasena pahīna ttā ati idam muttassa api katthaci
translated: The words “four relinquishments” are said in order to show the deliverance from bondage by means of serenity. The words “fournesses” are said in order to show that what is relinquished is not to be found anywhere.

original: ṭhānābhāvavasena. Paṭinissaṭṭhattāti idaṃ pubbe ādinnapubbassa nissaggadassanavasena.
analyzed: ṭhāna abhāva vasena paṭinissaṭṭha ttā ti idam pubbe ādinna pubbassa nissagga dassana vasena
translated: The words “four givings up” are said in order to show the giving up of what has been taken up previously.

original: Paṭimuñcato vā nissaṭṭhattā bhāvanābalena abhibhuyya nissaṭṭhattāti attho. Pahīnapaṭinissaṭṭhattāti🔽yathāvikkhambhanavaseneva pahānaṃ hoti, punappunaṃ santatiṃ na ajjhāruhati, tathā
analyzed: paṭimuñcataḥ vā nissaṭṭha ttā bhāvanā balena abhibhuyya nissaṭṭha ttā ati attho pahīna paṭinissaṭṭha ttā ati  yathā vikkhambhana vasena iva pahānam hoti punappunam santatim na ajjhāruhati tathā
translated: Or ‘he has relinquished’ means that he has relinquished by conquering with the strength of development. The meaning is that he has relinquished by conquering with the strength of development. ‘He has abandoned and relinquished’ means🔽that he has abandoned in the way already described under ‘he has abandoned’ and that he has relinquished in the way already described under ‘he has relinquished’ and that he has abandoned by suppression in the way already described under ‘he has abandoned by suppression’ and that he has relinquished by abandoning in the way already described under ‘he has relinquished by abandoning’ and that he has abandoned by substitution of opposites in the way already described under ‘he has abandoned by substitution of opposites’ and that he has relinquished by non-restraint of the continuity in the way already described under ‘he has relinquished by non-restraint of the continuity’ and that he has abandoned by substitution of opposites and by non-restraint of the continuity in the way already described under ‘he has abandoned by substitution of opposites and by non-restraint of the continuity’ and that he has relinquished by substitution of opposites and by non-restraint of the continuity in the way already described under ‘he has relinquished by substitution of opposites and by non-restraint of the continuity.’

original: paṭinissaṭṭhattāti. Ālokā hotīti sappabhā hoti. Nirāvaraṇaṭṭhena vivaṭā. Nirupakkilesaṭṭhena🔽parisuddhā. Pabhassaraṭṭhena pariyodātā.
analyzed: paṭinissaṭṭha ttā ati ālokā hoti iti sa ppabhā hoti nirāvaraṇa ṭṭhena vivaṭā nirupakkilesa ṭṭhena  parisuddhā pabhassaraṭṭhena pariyodātā
translated: ‘There is light’ means there is illumination. ‘It is open’ means it is free from obstruction. ‘It is clear’ means it is free from defilement. ‘It is bright’ means it is radiant.

original: 556. Uddhaccakukkuccanti ettha uddhatākāro uddhaccaṃ, ārammaṇe anicchayatāya vatthujjhācāro kukkuccaṃ. Idhāpi “santā hontī”ti purimanayeneva vacanabhedo veditabbo.
analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccanti ettha uddhata ākāraḥ uddhaccam ārammaṇe anicchaya tāya kukkuccam idha api santā honti iti purima nayena iva vacana bhedaḥ veditabbo
translated: ‘Restlessness and worry’: here restlessness is the state of being restless, and worry is the state of being dissatisfied with the object. Herein, the analysis should be understood in the way already given under ‘he has abandoned … by suppression’ and ‘he has relinquished … by abandoning.’

original: 558. Tiṇṇavicikicchoti vicikicchaṃ taritvā atikkamitvā ṭhito. Niddesepissa tiṇṇoti
analyzed: tiṇṇa vicikiccho ti vicikiccham taritvā atikkamitvā ṭhitaḥ tiṇṇaḥ ti
translated: ‘He has crossed over doubt’: he has crossed over and gone beyond doubt. In the Niddesa, ‘he has crossed over’ is said

original: idaṃ vicikicchāya animuggabhāvadassanavasena vuttaṃ. Uttiṇṇoti idaṃ tassā atikkamadassanavasena.
analyzed: idam vicikicchāya a nimugga bhāva dassana vasena vuttam uttiṇṇaḥ ti idam tassāḥ atikkama dassana vasena
translated: with reference to the seeing of the non-attachment of doubt. ‘He has come to the conclusion’: this is said with reference to the seeing of the transcending of doubt.

original: Nittiṇṇoti idaṃ bhāvanābalena abhibhuyya upaddave tiṇṇabhāvadassanavasena. Pāraṅgatoti
analyzed: nittiṇṇo ti idam bhāvanā balena abhibhuyya upaddave tiṇṇa bhāva dassana vasena
translated: “He has crossed over and gone beyond”: he has crossed over and gone beyond by seeing the state of having crossed over and gone beyond the dangers by the power of development. “He has reached the farther shore”:

original: nibbicikicchābhāvasaṅkhātaṃ vicikicchāpāraṃ gato. Pāramanuppattoti tadeva pāraṃ bhāvanānuyogena
analyzed: nibbicikicchā bhāva saṅkhātam vicikicchā pāram gataḥ pāram anuppatto ti tat eva pāram bhāvanā anuyogena
translated: he has reached the farther shore called freedom from doubt, which is the opposite of doubt. “He has attained the utmost attainment”:

original: pattoti. Evamassa paṭipattiyā saphalataṃ dasseti.
analyzed: patto ti evam assa paṭipattiyā saphala tam dasseti
translated: he has reached that farther shore by the practice of development. Thus he shows the success of his practice.

original: 559. Akathaṃkathīti ‘kathamidaṃ kathamida’nti evaṃ pavattāya kathaṃkathāya virahito.
analyzed: akathaṃkathī iti katham idam katham idam ti evam pavattāya kathaṃkathāya virahitaḥ
translated: “He is not a doubter”: he is free from doubt, which occurs as “How is this? How is this?”

original: Kusalesu dhammesūti anavajjadhammesu. Na kaṅkhatīti ‘ime nu kho kusalā’ti kaṅkhaṃ
analyzed: kusalesu dhammesu iti anavajja dhammesu na kaṅkhati iti ime nu kho kusalā ati kaṅkham
translated: “In regard to wholesome states”: in regard to blameless states. “He does not doubt”: he does not arouse doubt, thinking, “Are these wholesome?”

original: na uppādeti. Na vicikicchatīti te dhamme sabhāvato vinicchetuṃ na kicchati, na kilamati.
analyzed: na uppādeti na vicikicchati iti te dhamme sabhāvataḥ vinicchetum na kicchati na kilamati
translated: “He does not hesitate”: he does not strive to determine the individual essences of those states.

original: Akathaṃkathī hotīti ‘kathaṃ nu kho ime kusalā’ti kathaṃkathāya rahito hoti. Nikkathaṃkathī
analyzed: akathaṃkathī hoti iti katham nu khalu ime kusalā ati kathaṃkathāya rahitaḥ hoti nikkathaṃkathī
translated: “He is not a doubter”: he is free from doubt, thinking, “How are these wholesome?” “He is not a doubter”

original: vigatakathaṃkathoti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Vacanattho panettha kathaṃkathāto nikkhantoti
analyzed: vigata kathaṃkathā iti tassa iva vevacanam vacana atthaḥ pana ittha kathaṃkathātaḥ nikkhanto ti
translated: “He is free from doubt”: this is a synonym for the same thing. But the meaning of the words is this: he has gone out from doubt,

original: nikkathaṃkatho. Vigatā kathaṃkathā assāti vigatakathaṃkatho.
analyzed: nikkathaṃkathaḥ vigatā kathaṃkathā assa ati vigata kathaṃkatho
translated: He is one who has no more discussion, thus he is without discussion.🔽He is one who has no more questioning, thus he is without questioning.

original: 562. Upakkileseti upakkilesabhūte. Te hi cittaṃ upagantvā kilissanti. Tasmā upakkilesāti vuccanti.
analyzed: upakkileseti upakkilesa bhūte te hi cittam upagantvā kilissanti tasmai upakkilesā ati vuccanti
translated: The hindrances are called “defilements” because they defile by defiling the mind.

original: 563. Paññāya dubbalīkaraṇeti yasmā ime nīvaraṇā uppajjamānā anuppannāya lokiyalokuttarāya🔽paññāya uppajjituṃ na denti, uppannā api aṭṭha samāpattiyo pañca vā abhiññāyo upacchinditvā
analyzed: paññāya dubbalīkaraṇa iti yasmai ime nīvaraṇāḥ uppajjamānāḥ an uppannāya lokiya lokuttarāya  paññāya uppajjitum na denti uppannāḥ api aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ pañca vā abhiññāyaḥ upacchinditvā
translated: They are called “weaknesses of understanding” because when they arise they prevent the arising of mundane and supramundane understanding that has not arisen,🔽and they break up and destroy the eight meditative attainments and the five kinds of direct knowledge that have arisen. That is why they are called “weaknesses of understanding.”

original: pātenti, tasmā ‘paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā’ti vuccanti. ‘Anuppannā ceva paññā na uppajjati,
analyzed: tasmā paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā ati vuccanti anuppannā ca iva paññā na uppajjati
translated: And also this is said: “Understanding does not arise that has not arisen,

original: uppannā ca paññā nirujjhatī’ti idampi hi imamevatthaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Sesamettha
analyzed: uppannā ca paññā nirujjhati iti idam pi hi imam eva attham sandhāya vuttam sesam ettha
translated: and understanding that has arisen is destroyed” .

original: sabbaṃ heṭṭhā tattha tattha pakāsitattā uttānatthameva.
analyzed: sabbam heṭṭhā tattha tattha pakāsita ttā uttāna attham eva
translated: The rest is all clear in meaning and has been explained already here and there.

original: 564. Vivicceva kāmehītiādīsupi niddesesu yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ heṭṭhā cittuppādakaṇḍe
analyzed: vivicca iva kāmehi iti ādīsu pi niddesesu yam vattabbam siyā tat heṭṭhā cittuppāda kaṇḍe
translated: As regards the expositions beginning with “quite secluded from sense desires,” what should be said has already been said in the section on the kinds of consciousness .

original: rūpāvacaraniddese idheva ca tattha tattha vuttameva. Kevalañhi dutiyatatiyacatutthajjhānaniddesesupi
analyzed: rūpāvacara niddese idha iva ca tattha tattha vuttam eva kevalañ hi dutiya tatiya catuttha jjhāna niddesesu pi
translated: For in the description of the second, third, and fourth jhānas too,

original: yathā tāni jhānāni heṭṭhā ‘tivaṅgikaṃ jhānaṃ hoti, duvaṅgikaṃ jhānaṃ hotī’ti vuttāni,🔽evaṃ avatvā “ajjhattaṃ sampasādana”ntiādivacanato pariyāyena sampasādādīhi saddhiṃ
analyzed: yathā tāni jhānāni heṭṭhā tivaṅgikam jhānam hoti duvaṅgikam jhānam hoti iti vuttāni  evam avatvā ajjhattam sampasādana nti ādi vacanataḥ pariyāyena sampasāda ādīhi saddhim
translated: instead of saying as in the first jhāna, “The jhāna that is accompanied by happiness and bliss is twofold, being divided up into that accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought and that accompanied by sustained thought only,”🔽without saying this, the jhāna is described by means of the factors of applied thought, etc., taken together with confidence, etc., in the way beginning, “When he has given up the tendency to lust … he achieves and remains …” ,

original: tāni aṅgāni gahetvā “jhānanti sampasādo pītisukhaṃ cittassekaggatā”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: tāni aṅgāni gahetvā jhānanti sampasādaḥ pīti sukham cittassa ekagga tā iti ādinā nayena
translated: and the jhāna is described in the way beginning, “Jhāna is confidence, bliss, happiness, and unification of mind” .

original: taṃ taṃ jhānaṃ niddiṭṭhanti ayamettha viseso.
analyzed: tam tam jhānam niddiṭṭhanti ayam ettha visesaḥ
translated: This is the difference here.

original: 588. Yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhantītipadaniddese pana kiñcāpi ‘ācikkhanti desentī’tiādīni
analyzed: yam tam ariyāḥ ācikkhanti iti pada niddese pana kiñcā api ācikkhanti desenti iti ādīni
translated: As regards the passage beginning “What the Noble Ones declare,” although “declare,” “teach,” and so on

original: sabbāneva aññamaññavevacanāni, evaṃ santepi ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’tiādiuddesavasena
analyzed: sabbāna eva aññamañña vevacanāni evam sante pi upekkhakaḥ satimā sukha vihārī iti ādi uddesa vasena
translated: are all synonyms for each other, nevertheless they are used in order to show the difference in the meaning of the words “declare,” etc.,

original: ācikkhanti, niddesavasena desenti, paṭiniddesavasena paññāpenti, tena tena pakārena
analyzed: ācikkhanti niddesa vasena desenti paṭiniddesa vasena paññāpenti tena tena pakārena
translated: in the way beginning “They declare it, teach it, describe it, set it forth, reveal it, expound it, make it plain” .

original: atthaṃ ṭhapetvā paṭṭhapenti, tassa tassatthassa kāraṇaṃ dassentā vivaranti, byañjanavibhāgaṃ
analyzed: attham ṭhapetvā paṭṭhapenti tassa tassa atthassa kāraṇam dassentāḥ vivaranti byañjana vibhāgam
translated: They elaborate by showing the analysis of the phrasing.

original: dassentā vibhajanti, nikkujjitabhāvaṃ gambhīrabhāvañca nīharitvā vā sotūnaṃ ñāṇassa🔽patiṭṭhaṃ janayantā uttāniṃ karonti, sabbehipi imehi ākārehi sotūnaṃ aññāṇandhakāraṃ
analyzed: dassentāḥ vibhajanti nikkujjita bhāvam gambhīra bhāvam ca nīharitvā vā sotūnam ñāṇassa  patiṭṭham janayantāḥ uttānim karonti sabbehi pi imehi ākārehi sotūnam aññāṇa ndhakāram
translated: They make clear by removing the obscurity and profundity and so producing a footing for the knowledge of the listeners.

original: vidhamentā pakāsentīti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: vidhamentā pakāsentī iti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: And the meaning should be regarded as being shown in this way by their removing the darkness of the listeners’ unknowing in all these ways.

original: Samatikkamaniddesepi tattha tattha tehi tehi dhammehi vuṭṭhitattā atikkamanto, uparibhūmippattiyā vītikkanto, tato aparihānibhāvena samatikkantoti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: samatikkama niddese pi tattha tattha tehi tehi dhammehi vuṭṭhita ttā atikkamantaḥ upari bhūmi ppattiyā vītikkantaḥ tatas aparihāni bhāvena samatikkantaḥ ti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: And in the Description of Surmounting, the meaning should be regarded as follows: he surmounts by emerging from this or that state; he overgrows by reaching the next higher state; he surmounts by not falling back from that.

original: Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
translated: The Description of the Suttas as a Requisite

original: 2. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Abhidhamma as a Requisite

original: 623. Abhidhammabhājanīye heṭṭhā cittuppādakaṇḍe āgatanayeneva tanti ṭhapitā. Tasmā
analyzed: abhidhamma bhājanīye heṭṭhā cittuppāda kaṇḍe āgata nayena iva tanti ṭhapitā tasmai
translated: The Thread is placed in the Description of the Abhidhamma as a Requisite in the way already stated in the Description of the Arising of a Thought in the first part of the Description of the Requisites for Enlightenment .

original: tattha sabbesampi kusalavipākakiriyavasena niddiṭṭhānaṃ jhānānaṃ tattha vuttanayeneva
analyzed: tattha sabbesam pi kusala vipāka kiriya vasena niddiṭṭhānam jhānānam tattha vutta nayena iva
translated: So in the case of all the jhānas stated there as profitable, resultant, and functional,

original: attho veditabbo. Suddhikanavakādibhedopi sabbo tattha vuttasadisoyevāti.
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ suddhika navaka ādi bhedaḥ api sabbaḥ tattha vutta sadisaḥ yeva āti
translated: the meaning should be understood. And all the rest of the ninefold, etc., classification should be understood in the way already stated there.

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Requisites of the Abhidhamma is ended.

original: 3. Pañhāpucchakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañhāpucchaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Questions

original: 638. Pañhāpucchake pāḷianusāreneva jhānānaṃ kusalādibhāvo veditabbo. Ārammaṇattikesu
analyzed: pañhāpucchake pāḷi anusārena iva jhānānam kusala ādi bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ ārammaṇa attikesu
translated: The profitable, etc., state of the jhānas should be understood according to the text of the questions themselves.

original: pana tiṇṇaṃ jhānānaṃ nimittārammaṇattā parittārammaṇādibhāvena navattabbatā veditabbā.
analyzed: pana tiṇṇam jhānānam nimitta ārammaṇa ttā paritta ārammaṇa ādi bhāvena navattabba tā veditabbā
translated: But in the case of the questions on object, the first three jhānas should be understood as not classifiable as to object consisting of a limited or exalted or measureless or surpassing-the-worldly object because they have a sign as object.

original: Lokuttarā panettha maggakāle phalakāle vā siyā appamāṇārammaṇā. Catutthaṃ jhānaṃ
analyzed: lokuttarā pana ittha magga kāle phala kāle vā siyā appamāṇa ārammaṇā catuttham jhānam
translated: But the fourth jhāna may have a limited object, or it may have an exalted object, or it may have a measureless object, or it may have an object surpassing the worldly, according as it is mundane or supramundane.

original: siyā parittārammaṇanti ettha kusalato terasa catutthajjhānāni sabbatthapādakacatutthaṃ,🔽iddhividhacatutthaṃ, dibbasotañāṇacatutthaṃ, cetopariyañāṇacatutthaṃ, pubbenivāsañāṇacatutthaṃ,
analyzed: siyā paritta ārammaṇan ti ettha kusalato terasa catuttha jhānāni sabbattha pādaka catuttham  iddhividha catuttham dibba sota ñāṇa catuttham cetas upariya ñāṇa catuttham pubbenivāsa ñāṇa catuttham
translated: The profitable fourth jhāna is of thirteen kinds as “with happiness” and so on.

original: dibbacakkhuñāṇacatutthaṃ, yathākammūpagañāṇacatutthaṃ, anāgataṃsañāṇacatutthaṃ, ākāsānañcāyatanādicatutthaṃ,🔽lokuttaracatutthanti.
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇa catuttham yathā kammūpaga ñāṇa catuttham anāgataṃsa ñāṇa catuttham ākāsa anañcāyatana ādi catuttham 🔽
translated: The fourth jhāna of the kinds called “with happiness” and so on is of thirteen kinds as “with happiness,” “with bliss,” “with equanimity,” “as the fourth,” “as the basis for direct- knowledge,” “as the basis for the supernormal powers,” “as the divine abiding,” “as the divine abidings in the fourfold method,” “as the divine abidings in the sixfold method,” “as the divine abidings in the eighteenfold method,” “as the divine abidings in the thirty-sixfold method,” “as the divine abidings in the hundred-and-fourfold method,” and “as the divine abidings in the hundred-and-eightfold method.”🔽The fourth jhāna of the kinds called “with happiness” and so on is of thirteen kinds as “with happiness,” “with bliss,” “with equanimity,” “as the fourth,” “as the basis for direct-knowledge,” “as the basis for the supernormal powers,” “as the divine abiding,” “as the divine abidings in the fourfold method,” “as the divine abidings in the sixfold method,” “as the divine abidings in the eighteenfold method,” “as the divine abidings in the thirty-sixfold method,” “as the divine abidings in the hundred-and-fourfold method,” and “as the divine abidings in the hundred-and-eightfold method.”

original: Tattha sabbatthapādakacatutthaṃ navattabbārammaṇameva hoti.
analyzed: tattha sabbattha pādaka catuttham nava ttabba ārammaṇam eva hoti
translated: Herein, the fourth jhāna of the base consisting of boundless space is only of limited object.

original: Iddhividhacatutthaṃ cittavasena kāyaṃ pariṇāmentassa adissamānena kāyena pāṭihāriyakaraṇe🔽kāyārammaṇattā parittārammaṇaṃ, kāyavasena cittaṃ pariṇāmentassa dissamānena kāyena🔽pāṭihāriyaṃ katvā brahmalokaṃ gacchantassa samāpatticittārammaṇattā mahaggatārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: iddhividha catuttham citta vasena kāyam pariṇāmentassa a dissamānena kāyena pāṭihāriya karaṇe  kāya ārammaṇa ttā paritta ārammaṇam kāya vasena cittam pariṇāmentassa dissamānena kāyena  pāṭihāriyam katvā brahma lokam gacchantassa samāpatti citta ārammaṇa ttā mahaggata ārammaṇam
translated: The fourth jhāna of the base consisting of boundless consciousness is of exalted object when one who has extended his mind to the base consisting of boundless consciousness and is exercising mastery in that makes a wonder-working display by becoming many, or by becoming invisible, or by going by air, or by going through a wall, or by going unhindered through earth, or by diving in and out of the earth as though in water, or by walking on water without breaking through it as though on earth, or by sitting cross-legged in the air, or by sending forth water and fire from the body, or by causing thunder to sound from the body, or by causing the four great kings’ regents to quake the earth, or by mastering the various kinds of psychic potency and showing various kinds of psychic wonder-working.

original: Dibbasotañāṇacatutthaṃ saddārammaṇattā parittārammaṇaṃ.🔽Cetopariyañāṇacatutthaṃ kāmāvacaracittajānanakāle parittārammaṇaṃ, rūpāvacarārūpāvacaracittajānanakāle
analyzed: dibba sota ñāṇa catuttham sadda ārammaṇa ttā paritta ārammaṇam  cetas upariya ñāṇa catuttham kāmāvacara citta jānana kāle paritta ārammaṇam rūpāvacara arūpāvacara citta jānana kāle
translated: It is of limited object when one who has extended his mind to the base consisting of boundless consciousness and is exercising mastery in that makes a wonder-working display by becoming many, or by becoming invisible, or by going by air, or by going through a wall, or by going unhindered through earth, or by diving in and out of the earth as though in water, or by walking on water without breaking through it as though on earth, or by sitting cross-legged in the air, or by sending forth water and fire from the body, or by causing thunder to sound from the body, or by causing the four great kings’ regents to quake the earth, or by mastering the various kinds of psychic potency and showing various kinds of psychic wonder-working, and then by means of the fourth jhāna in the base consisting of boundless consciousness he goes to the Brahmā-world and makes a wonder-working display there.

original: mahaggatārammaṇaṃ, lokuttaracittajānanakāle appamāṇārammaṇaṃ. Cetopariyañāṇalābhī🔽pana puthujjano puthujjanānaṃyeva cittaṃ jānāti, na ariyānaṃ. Sotāpanno sotāpannassa
analyzed: mahaggata ārammaṇam lokuttara citta jānana kāle appamāṇa ārammaṇam cetas pariyañāṇa lābhī 🔽pana puthujjanaḥ puthujjanānam yeva cittam jānāti na ariyānam sotāpannaḥ sotāpannassa
translated: The fourth jhāna of the base consisting of boundless consciousness is of limited object when one who has extended his mind to the base consisting of boundless consciousness and is exercising mastery in that makes a wonder-working display by becoming many, or by becoming invisible, or by going by air, or by going through a wall, or by going unhindered through earth, or by diving in and out of the earth as though in water, or by walking on water without breaking through it as though on earth, or by sitting cross-legged in the air, or by sending forth water and fire from the body, or by causing thunder to sound from the body,

original: ceva puthujjanassa ca; sakadāgāmī sakadāgāmino ceva heṭṭhimānañca dvinnaṃ; anāgāmī
analyzed: ca iva puthujjanassa ca sakadāgāmī sakadāgāmino ca iva heṭṭhimānam ca dvinnam anāgāmī
translated: and of an ordinary man.🔽The once-returner knows the once-returner’s and the two lower fruitions,🔽the non-returner knows the non-returner’s and the three lower fruitions,

original: anāgāmino ceva heṭṭhimānañca tiṇṇaṃ; khīṇāsavo sabbesampi jānāti.
analyzed: anāgāmino ca iva heṭṭhimānam ca tiṇṇam khīṇāsavaḥ sabbesam pi jānāti
translated: and the one whose cankers are destroyed knows all.🔽The knowledge of recollection of past lives has a limited object when it recollects the aggregates of the sensual-sphere planes,

original: Pubbenivāsañāṇacatutthaṃ kāmāvacarakkhandhānussaraṇakāle parittārammaṇaṃ, rūpāvacarārūpāvacarakkhandhānussaraṇakāle
analyzed: pubbenivāsa ñāṇa catuttham kāmāvacara khandha anussaraṇa kāle paritta ārammaṇam rūpāvacara arūpāvacara kkhandha anussaraṇa kāle
translated: a great object when it recollects the aggregates of the fine-material and immaterial planes,

original: mahaggatārammaṇaṃ, “atīte buddhapaccekabuddhakhīṇāsavā maggaṃ bhāvayiṃsu, phalaṃ
analyzed: mahaggata ārammaṇam atīte buddha paccekabuddha khīṇa āsavāḥ maggam bhāvayiṃsu phalam
translated: and an immeasurable object when it recollects the past Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples who have destroyed the cankers, and their development of the path and realization of the fruition.

original: sacchikariṃsū”ti anussaraṇakāle appamāṇārammaṇaṃ, nāmagottānussaraṇakāle navattabbārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: sacchikariṃsu iti anussaraṇa kāle appamāṇa ārammaṇam nāma gotta anussaraṇa kāle navattabba ārammaṇam
translated: It has a non-classifiable object when it recollects names and clans.

original: Dibbacakkhuñāṇacatutthaṃ vaṇṇārammaṇattā parittārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇa catuttham vaṇṇa ārammaṇa ttā paritta ārammaṇam
translated: The knowledge of the divine eye has a limited object because it has visible form as its object.🔽The knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings has a limited object when it cognizes the kamma and reappearance of beings in the sensual-sphere planes,

original: Yathākammūpagañāṇacatutthaṃ kāmāvacarakammānussaraṇakāle parittārammaṇaṃ, rūpāvacarārūpāvacarakammānussaraṇakāle mahaggatārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: yathā kammūpaga ñāṇa catuttham kāmāvacara kamma anussaraṇa kāle paritta ārammaṇam rūpāvacara arūpāvacara kamma anussaraṇa kāle mahaggata ārammaṇam
translated: and a great object when it cognizes the kamma and reappearance of beings in the fine-material and immaterial planes.

original: Anāgataṃsañāṇacatutthaṃ anāgate kāmadhātuyā nibbattijānanakāle parittārammaṇaṃ, rūpārūpabhavesu🔽nibbattijānanakāle mahaggatārammaṇaṃ, “anāgate buddhapaccekabuddhakhīṇāsavā maggaṃ
analyzed: anāgataṃsañāṇa catuttham anāgate kāmadhātuyāḥ nibbatti jānana kāle paritta ārammaṇam rūpa arūpa bhavesu  nibbatti jānana kāle mahaggata ārammaṇam anāgate buddha paccekabuddha khīṇa āsavāḥ maggam
translated: The fourth knowledge of the future has a limited object when it knows future rebirth-linking in the sense-desire element.🔽It has a great object when it knows rebirth-linking in the fine-material and immaterial elements.

original: bhāvessanti, phalaṃ sacchikarissantī”ti jānanakāle appamāṇārammaṇaṃ, “anāgate saṅkho
analyzed: bhāvessanti phalam sacchikarissanti iti jānana kāle appamāṇa ārammaṇam anāgate saṅkho
translated: It has an infinite object when it knows that in the future there will be Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples who will develop the path and realize the fruition.

original: nāma rājā bhavissatī”tiādinā nayena nāmagottānussaraṇakāle navattabbārammaṇaṃ.🔽Ākāsānañcāyatanaākiñcaññāyatanacatutthaṃ navattabbārammaṇaṃ. Viññāṇañcāyatananevasaññānāsaññāyatanacatutthaṃ mahaggatārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: nāma rājā bhavissati itiādinā nayena nāma gotta anussaraṇa kāle nava ttabba ārammaṇam  ākāsānañcāyatana ākiñcaññāyatana catuttham navattabba ārammaṇam viññāṇañcāyatana nevasaññānāsaññāyatana catuttham mahaggata ārammaṇam
translated: It has a non-existent object when it recalls names and clans in the way beginning, “In the future there will be a king named so-and-so of such-and-such a clan.”🔽The fourth immaterial jhāna has a non-existent object.

original: Lokuttaracatutthaṃ appamāṇārammaṇaṃ.🔽Kiriyatopi tesaṃ dvādasannaṃ jhānānaṃ idameva ārammaṇavidhānaṃ. Tīṇi jhānāni namaggārammaṇāti
analyzed: kiriyataḥ api tesam dvādasannam jhānānam idam eva ārammaṇa vidhānam tīṇi jhānāni na magga ārammaṇā ti
translated: The fourth of the supramundane jhānas has an infinite object.🔽This is how the object is defined in the case of these twelve jhānas.🔽Three jhānas have the path as their object.

original: paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ vā cetopariyādiñāṇaṃ vā maggaṃ ārammaṇaṃ kareyya, tīṇi jhānāni
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam vā cetas pariyādi ñāṇam vā maggam ārammaṇam kareyya tīṇi jhānāni
translated: The knowledge of the reviewing of the path or the knowledge of penetration of minds has the path as its object.

original: tathā appavattito namaggārammaṇā, sahajātahetuvasena pana siyā maggahetukā; vīriyajeṭṭhikāya
analyzed: tathā appavattitaḥ na magga ārammaṇā sahajāta hetu vasena pana siyā magga hetukā vīriya jeṭṭhikāya
translated: and it is not to be spoken of as object of the path since it does not occur in the way of the path. But it may be spoken of as path- due to cause since it is the conascent cause of the path.

original: vā vīmaṃsājeṭṭhikāya vā maggabhāvanāya maggādhipatino; chandacittajeṭṭhakakāle phalakāle ca navattabbā.
analyzed: vā vīmaṃsā jeṭṭhikāya vā magga bhāvanāya magga adhipatino chanda citta jeṭṭhaka kāle phala kāle ca
translated: It is not to be spoken of as path- dominated since it is the path- dominated jhāna that is the chief in the development of the path.

original: Catutthaṃ jhānanti idhāpi kusalato terasasu catutthajjhānesu sabbatthapādakaiddhividhadibbasotadibbacakkhuyathākammūpagañāṇacatutthañceva🔽catubbidhañca āruppacatutthaṃ maggārammaṇādibhāvena na vattabbaṃ. Cetopariyapubbenivāsaanāgataṃsañāṇacatutthaṃ
analyzed: catuttham jhānanti idha api kusalato terasasu catuttha jjhānesu sabbattha pādaka eddhividha dibba sota dibba cakkhu yathā kammu upaga ñāṇa catuttham ca eva  catubbidham ca āruppa catuttham magga ārammaṇa ādi bhāvena na vattabbam cetaḥ pariya pubbenivāsa anāgataṃsañāṇa catuttham
translated: The fourth jhāna: here too, of the thirteen kinds of fourth jhāna, namely, the profitable, the four of the fine-material sphere, the four of the immaterial sphere, and the four supramundane, the profitable and the four of the fine-material sphere are not to be spoken of as object of the path, etc.,🔽and the four of the immaterial sphere are not to be spoken of as object of the path, etc., in the way stated. But the fourth jhāna of the supramundane kinds is object of the path.🔽It is not to be spoken of as path-due or path-dominated.

original: pana maggārammaṇaṃ hoti. Na vattabbaṃ maggahetukaṃ maggādhipatīti vā; lokuttaracatutthaṃ
analyzed: pana magga ārammaṇam hoti na vattabbam magga hetukam magga adhipati iti vā lokuttara catuttham
translated: The supramundane fourth jhāna is not object of the path. But at the time of the path it is path-due since it is the conascent cause of the path.

original: maggārammaṇaṃ na hoti; maggakāle pana sahajātahetuvasena maggahetukaṃ; vīriyavīmaṃsājeṭṭhikāya
analyzed: magga ārammaṇam na hoti magga kāle pana sahajāta hetu vasena magga hetukam vīriya vīmaṃsā jeṭṭhikāya
translated: It is not to be spoken of as path-dominated since it is the path- dominated jhāna that is the chief in the development of the path.

original: maggabhāvanāya maggādhipati; chandacittajeṭṭhikāya ceva maggabhāvanāya phalakāle
analyzed: magga bhāvanāya magga adhipati chanda citta jeṭṭhikāya ca iva magga bhāvanāya phala kāle
translated: and by the development of the path, the path is dominant.🔽And by the development of the path, the fruit is dominant at the time of the fruit.

original: ca na vattabbaṃ. Kiriyatopi dvādasasu jhānesu ayameva nayo.
analyzed: ca na vattabbam kiriyataḥ pi dvādasasu jhānesu ayam eva nayaḥ
translated: and by development of the path it is the path’s dominant condition. And it is not to be spoken of as the cause of the fruit either by development of the path or at the time of the fruit. The same method applies in the case of the twelve jhānas of the kinds of direct-knowledge.

original: Tīṇi jhānāni na vattabbāti atītādīsu ekadhammampi ārabbha appavattito navattabbāti veditabbā.
analyzed: tīṇi jhānāni na vattabbā ati atīta ādīsu eka dhammam pi ārabbha appavattitaḥ na vattabbā ati veditabbā
translated: The three jhānas are not to be spoken of: it should be understood that they are not to be spoken of since they do not occur with respect to any one thing among the past, etc.,

original: Catutthaṃ jhānanti kusalato terasasu catutthajjhānesu sabbatthapādakacatutthaṃ navattabbārammaṇameva.
analyzed: catuttham jhānanti kusalataḥ terasasu catuttha jjhānesu sabbattha pādaka catuttham navattabba ārammaṇam eva
translated: The fourth jhāna: in the case of the profitable, the basic fourth jhāna in the thirteen kinds of fourth jhāna is not to be spoken of as to object.

original: Iddhividhacatutthaṃ kāyavasena cittapariṇāmane samāpatticittārammaṇattā atītārammaṇaṃ;
analyzed: iddhividha catuttham kāya vasena citta pariṇāmane samāpatti citta ārammaṇa ttā atīta ārammaṇam
translated: The fourth jhāna of the kinds of supernormal power, since it is the jhāna of concentration that is the basis for the transformation of the mind and the body, has a past object when it has the consciousness of the attainment as its object.

original: “anāgate imāni pupphāni mā milāyiṃsu, dīpā mā nibbāyiṃsu, eko aggikkhandho samuṭṭhātu,
analyzed: anāgate imāni pupphāni mā milāyiṃsu dīpāḥ mā nibbāyiṃsu ekaḥ aggi khandhaḥ samuṭṭhātu
translated: When he resolves thus, “Let these flowers not fade, let the lights not go out, let one flame of fire be produced from another, let a rock rise up” , it has a future object.

original: pabbato samuṭṭhātū”ti adhiṭṭhānakāle anāgatārammaṇaṃ; cittavasena kāyapariṇāmanakāle
analyzed: pabbataḥ samuṭṭhātu uti adhiṭṭhāna kāle anāgata ārammaṇam citta vasena kāya pariṇāmana kāle
translated: When he resolves, “Let the body be transformed into the mind,” it has a present object, since the body is the object at the time of the transformation of the body into the mind.

original: kāyārammaṇattā paccuppannārammaṇaṃ. Dibbasotañāṇacatutthaṃ saddārammaṇattā paccuppanārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: kāya ārammaṇa ttā paccuppanna ārammaṇam dibba sota ñāṇa catuttham sadda ārammaṇa ttā paccuppanna ārammaṇam
translated: The fourth jhāna of the knowledge of the divine ear has a present object since sound is the object.

original: Cetopariyañāṇacatutthaṃ atīte sattadivasabbhantare uppajjitvā niruddhacittajānanakāle
analyzed: cetas upariya ñāṇa catuttham atīte satta divasa bbhantare uppajjitvā niruddha citta jānana kāle
translated: The fourth, knowledge of penetration of minds, has a past object when it arises and ceases within the past seven days and cognizes a mind that has already arisen and ceased;

original: atītārammaṇaṃ; anāgate sattadivasabbhantare uppajjanakacittajānanakāle anāgatārammaṇaṃ.🔽“Yathā imassa bhoto manosaṅkhārā paṇihitā imassa cittassa anantarā amuṃ nāma vitakkaṃ
analyzed: atīta ārammaṇam anāgate satta divasa bbhantare uppajjanaka citta jānana kāle anāgata ārammaṇam  yathā imassa bhoto manaḥ saṅkhārā paṇihitāḥ imassa cittassa anantarā amum nāma vitakkam
translated: it has a future object when it arises and ceases within the future seven days and cognizes a mind that will arise and cease.🔽“As this venerable one’s mental formations are now disposed, he will think such thoughts.” And even if he speaks much, it is just this that he knows.

original: vitakkessatīti. So bahuñcepi ādisati, tatheva taṃ hoti no aññathā”ti iminā hi suttena
analyzed: vitakkessati iti saḥ bahun ca api ādisati tathā iva tam hoti no aññathā ti iminā hi suttena
translated: For this sutta passage shows only the occurrence of knowledge of penetration of minds.

original: cetopariyañāṇasseva pavatti pakāsitā. Addhānapaccuppannasantatipaccuppannavaseneva🔽paccuppannaṃ ārabbha pavattikāle paccuppannārammaṇaṃ. Vitthārakathā panettha heṭṭhāaṭṭhakathākaṇḍavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: cetaḥ pariya ñāṇassa iva pavatti pakāsitā addhāna paccuppanna santati paccuppanna vasena iva  paccuppannam ārabbha pavatti kāle paccuppanna ārammaṇam vitthāra kathā pana ittha heṭṭhā aṭṭhakathā kaṇḍa vaṇṇanā ayam
translated: It has a present object when it arises and ceases in the present and cognizes a mind that has just arisen and not yet ceased.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbā.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbā
translated: The detailed explanation should be understood as given in the section on the Path of Sovereignty in the Commentarial Method .

original: Pubbenivāsañāṇacatutthaṃ atītakkhandhānussaraṇakāle atītārammaṇaṃ, nāmagottānussaraṇakāle
analyzed: pubbenivāsa ñāṇa catuttham atīta kkhandha anussaraṇa kāle atīta ārammaṇam nāma gotta anussaraṇa kāle
translated: The fourth, knowledge of recollecting past lives, has a past object when it recollects past aggregates;

original: navattabbārammaṇaṃ. Dibbacakkhuñāṇacatutthaṃ vaṇṇārammaṇattā paccuppannārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: navattabba ārammaṇam dibba cakkhu ñāṇa catuttham vaṇṇa ārammaṇa ttā paccuppanna ārammaṇam
translated: The fourth has a non-existent object. The fourth of the divine eye has a visible-data object, so it has a present object.

original: Yathākammūpagañāṇacatutthaṃ atītakammameva ārammaṇaṃ karotīti atītārammaṇaṃ. Anāgataṃsañāṇacatutthaṃ
analyzed: yathā kammūpaga ñāṇa catuttham atīta kammam eva ārammaṇam karoti iti atīta ārammaṇam anāgataṃsa ñāṇa catuttham
translated: The fourth of the knowledge of faring according to deeds has only past kamma as its object, so it has a past object. The fourth of the knowledge of the future has

original: anāgatakkhandhānussaraṇakāle anāgatārammaṇaṃ, nāmagottānussaraṇakāle navattabbārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: anāgata kkhandha anussaraṇa kāle anāgata ārammaṇam nāma gotta anussaraṇa kāle navattabba ārammaṇam
translated: a future object when it recollects future aggregates, and a non-existent object when it recollects names and clans.

original: Ākāsānañcāyatanaākiñcaññāyatanacatutthaṃ navattabbārammaṇameva. Viññāṇañcāyatananevasaññānāsaññāyatanacatutthaṃ🔽atītārammaṇameva. Lokuttaracatutthaṃ navattabbārammaṇameva. Kiriyatopi dvādasasu
analyzed: ākāsa anañcāyatana ākiñcaññāyatana catuttham navattabba ārammaṇam eva viññāṇañcāyatana nevasaññānāsaññāyatana catuttham  atīta ārammaṇam eva lokuttara catuttham nava ttabba ārammaṇam eva kiriyataḥ api dvādasasu
translated: The fourth of the base consisting of boundless space and the base consisting of nothingness has only a non-existent object. The fourth of the base consisting of boundless consciousness and the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception

original: catutthajjhānesu eseva nayo.
translated: has only a past object. The fourth of the supramundane has only a non-existent object. The same method applies to the four immaterial states in the twelve paths of the four jhānas.

original: Tīṇi jhānāni bahiddhārammaṇāti ajjhattato bahiddhābhūtaṃ nimittaṃ ārabbha pavattito bahiddhārammaṇā.
analyzed: tīṇi jhānāni bahiddhā ārammaṇā ati ajjhattataḥ bahiddhā bhūtam nimittam ārabbha pavattitaḥ bahiddhā ārammaṇā
translated: The three jhānas have an external object because they occur in dependence on a sign that is external in the sense of being not internal to oneself.

original: Catutthaṃ jhānanti idhāpi kusalato terasasu catutthajjhānesu sabbatthapādakacatutthaṃ bahiddhārammaṇameva.🔽Iddhividhacatutthaṃ kāyavasena cittapariṇāmanepi cittavasena kāyapariṇāmanepi attanova
analyzed: catuttham jhānanti idha api kusalato terasasu catuttha jhānesu sabbattha pādaka catuttham bahiddha ārammaṇam eva  iddhividha catuttham kāya vasena citta pariṇāmane api citta vasena kāya pariṇāmane api
translated: The fourth jhāna: here too, in the thirteen kinds of profitable fourth jhāna, the basic jhāna is the fourth jhāna in all instances.🔽The fourth jhāna in the case of the kinds of supernormal power is the object of transformation of the mind by means of the body, and of transformation of the body by means of the mind, only in one’s own person.

original: kāyacittārammaṇattā ajjhattārammaṇaṃ; “bahiddhā hatthimpi dassetī”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: kāya citta ārammaṇa ttā ajjhatta ārammaṇam bahiddhā hatthim pi dasseti itiādinā nayena
translated: So it is an internal object. But when it occurs in the mode of showing an elephant, etc., externally,

original: pavattakāle bahiddhārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: pavatta kāle bahiddha ārammaṇam
translated: then it is an external object.

original: Dibbasotañāṇacatutthaṃ attano kucchigatasaddārammaṇakāle ajjhattārammaṇaṃ, parassa saddārammaṇakāle bahiddhārammaṇaṃ, ubhayavasenāpi ajjhattabahiddhārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: dibba sota ñāṇa catuttham attanaḥ kucchi gata sadda ārammaṇa kāle ajjhatta ārammaṇam parassa sadda ārammaṇa kāle bahiddha ārammaṇam ubhaya vasena api ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇam
translated: The fourth jhāna in the case of the knowledge of the divine ear element is an internal object when the object is sounds in one’s own belly, and it is an external object when the object is another’s sounds. It is an internal and external object when the object is both.

original: Cetopariyañāṇacatutthaṃ bahiddhārammaṇameva.
analyzed: cetas upariya ñāṇa catuttham bahiddha ārammaṇam eva
translated: The fourth jhāna in the case of knowledge of penetration of minds is an external object only.

original: Pubbenivāsañāṇacatutthaṃ attano khandhānussaraṇakāle ajjhattārammaṇaṃ, parassa khandhānañceva nāmagottassa ca anussaraṇakāle bahiddhārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: pubbenivāsa ñāṇa catuttham attanaḥ khandha anussaraṇa kāle ajjhatta ārammaṇam parassa khandhānaṃ ca iva nāma gottassa ca anussaraṇa kāle bahiddha ārammaṇam
translated: The fourth jhāna in the case of knowledge of recollecting past lives is an internal object when the object is one’s own past aggregates, and it is an external object when the object is another’s past aggregates and the past aggregates of animals.

original: Dibbacakkhuñāṇacatutthaṃ attano rūpārammaṇakāle ajjhattārammaṇaṃ, parassa rūpārammaṇakāle bahiddhārammaṇaṃ, ubhayavasenāpi ajjhattabahiddhārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇa catuttham attanaḥ rūpa ārammaṇa kāle ajjhatta ārammaṇam parassa rūpa ārammaṇa kāle bahiddha ārammaṇam ubhaya vasena api ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇam
translated: The fourth, the knowledge of the divine eye, is internal object when it is one’s own materiality that is the object, external object when it is another’s materiality that is the object, and both when it is both’s materiality that is the object.

original: Yathākammūpagañāṇacatutthaṃ attano kammajānanakāle ajjhattārammaṇaṃ, parassa kammajānanakāle bahiddhārammaṇaṃ, ubhayavasenāpi ajjhattabahiddhārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: yathā kammūpaga ñāṇa catuttham attanaḥ kamma jānana kāle ajjhatta ārammaṇam parassa kamma jānana kāle bahiddha ārammaṇam ubhaya vasena api ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇam
translated: The fourth, the knowledge of the way of penetration of kamma, is internal object when it is one’s own kamma that is known, external object when it is another’s kamma that is known, and both when it is both’s kamma that is known.

original: Anāgataṃsañāṇacatutthaṃ attano anāgate nibbattijānanakāle ajjhattārammaṇaṃ, parassa
analyzed: anāgataṃsañāṇa catuttham attanaḥ anāgate nibbatti jānana kāle ajjhatta ārammaṇam parassa
translated: The fourth, the knowledge of the future, is internal object when it is one’s own future rebirth that is known, external object when it is another’s future rebirth that is known, and both when it is both’s future rebirth that is known.

original: khandhānussaraṇakāle ceva nāmagottānussaraṇakāle ca bahiddhārammaṇaṃ, ubhayavasenāpi🔽ajjhattabahiddhārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: khandha anussaraṇa kāle ca iva nāma gotta anussaraṇa kāle ca bahiddhā ārammaṇam ubhaya vasena api  ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇam
translated: When it is the aggregates of the past that are known, it is external object. When it is the name and race of the past that are known, it is external object. When it is both the aggregates and the name and race of the past that are known, it is both.

original: Ākāsānañcāyatanacatutthaṃ bahiddhārammaṇaṃ. Ākiñcaññāyatanacatutthaṃ navattabbārammaṇaṃ. Viññāṇañcāyatananevasaññānāsaññāyatanacatutthaṃ ajjhattārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: ākāsānañcāyatana catuttham bahiddha ārammaṇam ākiñcaññāyatana catuttham navattabba ārammaṇam viññāṇañcāyatana nevasaññānāsaññāyatana catuttham ajjhatta ārammaṇam
translated: The fourth, the base consisting of boundless space, is external object. The fourth, the base consisting of nothingness, is not to be stated as object. The fourth, the base consisting of boundless consciousness, and the fourth, the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, are internal object.

original: Lokuttaracatutthaṃ bahiddhārammaṇameva. Kiriyatopi dvādasasu jhānesu ayameva nayoti.
analyzed: lokuttara catuttham bahiddhā ārammaṇam eva dvādasasu jhānesu ayam eva
translated: The supramundane fourth is only external object. This is the method in the twelve meditations.

original: Imasmiṃ pana jhānavibhaṅge sammāsambuddhena suttantabhājanīyepi lokiyalokuttaramissakāneva🔽jhānāni kathitāni; abhidhammabhājanīyepi pañhāpucchakepi. Tayopi hi ete nayā tebhūmakadhammamissakattā
analyzed: imasmin pana jhāna vibhaṅge sammāsambuddhena suttanta bhājanīye pi lokiya lokuttara missakān eva  jhānāni kathitāni abhidhamma bhājanīye pi pañhāpucchake pi tayaḥ api hi ete nayā tebhūmaka dhamma missaka ttā
translated: But in this exposition of the jhānas the jhānas are spoken of as mixed mundane and supramundane in the Suttas as well as in the Abhidhamma and in the Questions.🔽For these three methods are all included in a single section because they are mixed with the states of the three planes.

original: ekaparicchedā eva. Evamayaṃ jhānavibhaṅgopi teparivaṭṭaṃ nīharitvāva bhājetvā dassitoti.
analyzed: eka paricchedā eva evam ayam jhāna vibhaṅgaḥ api nīharitvā ava bhājetvā dassito ti
translated: So this exposition of the jhānas is given by taking the three methods and dividing them up.

original: Sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sammoha vinodaniyā vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The exposition of the jhānas in the text-commentaries

original: Jhānavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: jhāna vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is ended.

original: 13. Appamaññāvibhaṅgo
analyzed: appamaññā vibhaṅgaḥ
translated: The exposition of the measureless states

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the text

original: 642. Idāni tadanantare appamaññāvibhaṅge catassoti gaṇanaparicchedo. Appamaññāyoti
analyzed: idāni tad anantare appamaññā vibhaṅge catasso ti gaṇana paricchedaḥ
translated: Now, in the exposition of the measureless states that follows next, “Four” is the definition by number. “Measureless states”:

original: pharaṇaappamāṇavasena appamaññāyo. Etā hi ārammaṇavasena appamāṇe vā satte pharanti,
analyzed: pharaṇa appamāṇa vasena appamaññāyaḥ etāḥ hi ārammaṇa vasena appamāṇe vā satte pharanti
translated: they are measureless through the measurelessness of their extension. For these pervade beings that are measureless in the sense of being unlimited.

original: ekasattampi vā anavasesapharaṇavasena pharantīti pharaṇaappamāṇavasena appamaññāyoti
analyzed: ekasattam pi vā anavasesa pharaṇa vasena pharanti iti pharaṇa appamāṇa vasena
translated: Or alternatively, they are called “immeasurables” because of the measurelessness of the object, since they pervade an immeasurable number of beings, a hundred, a thousand, etc., without exception.

original: vuccanti. Idha bhikkhūti imasmiṃ sāsane bhikkhu. Mettāsahagatenāti mettāya samannāgatena.
analyzed: vuccanti idha bhikkhū ti imasmin sāsane bhikkhu mettā sahagatena ati mettāya samannāgatena
translated: Herein, a bhikkhu is a bhikkhu in this Dispensation. Associated with loving- kindness: possessed of loving-kindness.

original: Cetasāti cittena. Ekaṃ disanti ekissā disāya. Paṭhamapariggahitaṃ sattaṃ upādāya🔽ekadisāpariyāpannasattapharaṇavasena vuttaṃ. Pharitvāti phusitvā ārammaṇaṃ katvā.🔽Viharatīti brahmavihārādhiṭṭhitaṃ iriyāpathavihāraṃ pavatteti. Tathā dutiyanti yathā🔽puratthimādīsu disāsu yaṃ kiñci ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tatheva tadanantaraṃ
analyzed: cetasā iti cittena ekam disanti ekissā disāya paṭhama pariggahitam sattam upādāya  eka disā pariyāpanna satta pharaṇa vasena vuttam pharitvā iti phusitvā ārammaṇam katvā  viharati iti brahmavihāra dhiṭṭhitam iriyāpatha vihāram pavattā iti tathā dutiyanti yathā  puratthima ādīsu disāsu yam kiñci ekam disam viharati tathā iva tad anantaram
translated: With his heart: with his mind. One direction: beginning with the direction in front,🔽which is the first direction to be taken. He dwells: he causes to be.

original: dutiyaṃ tatiyaṃ catutthañcāti attho.
analyzed: dutiyam tatiyam catuttham ca ati
translated: In the first jhana: in the first of the jhanas. In the same way the second, the third, and the fourth: the meaning is that he pervades the second direction, the third, and the fourth in the same way.

original: Iti uddhanti teneva ca nayena uparimaṃ disanti vuttaṃ hoti. Adho tiriyanti adhodisampi
analyzed: iti uddhan ti tena iva ca nayena uparimam disanti vuttam hoti adhas tiriyanti adhodisam pi
translated: Thus above: and in the same way he pervades the upper direction. Below and around:

original: tiriyaṃdisampi evameva. Ettha ca adhoti heṭṭhā, tiriyanti anudisā. Evaṃ sabbadisāsu
analyzed: tiriyaṃdisam pi evam eva ettha ca adhas ti heṭṭhā tiriyanti anudisā evam sabba disāsu
translated: And so too in the other directions. Herein, below means downwards, and across means in the intermediate directions.

original: assamaṇḍale assamiva mettāsahagataṃ cittaṃ sāretipi paccāsāretipīti ettāvatā ekamekaṃ
analyzed: assa maṇḍale assam iva mettā sahagatam cittam sāreti pi ettāvatā ekam ekam
translated: So he sends his mind full of loving-kindness to all quarters in this way.🔽And he sends it back again. This is how the pervasion by means of loving-kindness is shown by taking each direction separately.

original: disaṃ pariggahetvā odhiso mettāpharaṇaṃ dassitaṃ. Sabbadhītiādi pana anodhiso dassanatthaṃ
analyzed: disam pariggahetvā odhisaḥ mettā pharaṇam dassitam sabbadhi iti ādi pana anodhisaḥ dassana attham
translated: But the words “everywhere in the world” and so on are said for the purpose of showing the pervasion without distinction.🔽Herein, everywhere means in all places.🔽With a heart endued with loving-kindness means with a heart possessed of loving-kindness.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha sabbadhīti sabbattha. Sabbattatāyāti sabbesu hīnamajjhimukkaṭṭhamittasapattamajjhattādippabhedesu
analyzed: vuttam tattha sabbadhi iti sabbattha sabbattatāya ati sabbesu hīna majjhi mukkaṭṭha mitta sapatta majjhatta ādi ppabhedesu
translated: With a heart that is abundant means with a heart that is abundant, that is to say, with a heart that is great in the sense of having no meanness, and with a heart that is wide in the sense of having no narrowness.

original: attatāya ‘ayaṃ parasatto’ti vibhāgaṃ akatvā attasamatāyāti vuttaṃ hoti; atha vā sabbattatāyāti
analyzed: atta tāya ayam para sattaḥ iti vibhāgam a katvā atta samatāya iti vuttam hoti atha vā sabbatta tāya ati
translated: Or alternatively, with a heart endued with loving-kindness means with a heart possessed of loving-kindness.🔽With a heart that is abundant means with a heart that is abundant, that is to say, with a heart that has no deficiency, with a heart that has no leakage.

original: sabbena cittabhāvena īsakampi bahi avikkhipamānoti vuttaṃ hoti. Sabbāvantanti sabbasattavantaṃ,🔽sabbasattayuttanti attho. Lokanti sattalokaṃ.
analyzed: sabbena citta bhāvena īsakam pi bahi a vikkhipamānaḥ ti vuttam hoti sabbāvantam ti sabba sattavantam  sabba satta yuttam ti attho lokam ti satta lokam
translated: For when loving-kindness is being developed, the mind does not go outside, and so it is said that it has no deficiency.🔽And when it is being developed, it does not ooze out , and so it is said that it has no leakage.🔽Or alternatively, with a heart endued with loving-kindness means with a heart possessed of loving-kindness.🔽With a heart that is abundant means with a heart that is abundant, that is to say, with a heart that is abundant in loving-kindness.

original: Vipulenātievamādipariyāyadassanato panettha puna “mettāsahagatenā”ti vuttaṃ. Yasmā
analyzed: vipulena ati evamādi pariyāya dassanato pana ittha puna mettā sahagatena ati vuttam yasmā
translated: Or alternatively, with a heart that is abundant means with a heart that is abundant, that is to say, with a heart that is abundant in loving-kindness.🔽With a heart that is measureless means with a heart that has no measure in the sense of having no meanness, and with a heart that has no measure in the sense of having no narrowness.🔽Or alternatively, with a heart that is abundant means with a heart that is abundant, that is to say, with a heart that is abundant in loving-kindness.🔽With a heart that is measureless means with a heart that has no measure in the sense of having no meanness, and with a heart that has no measure in the sense of having no narrowness.🔽Or alternatively, with a heart that is abundant means with a heart that is abundant

original: vā ettha odhiso pharaṇe viya puna ‘tathā’saddo ‘iti’saddo vā na vutto, tasmā puna
analyzed: vā ettha odhisaḥ pharaṇe viya puna tathā saddo iti saddo vā na vutto tasmā puna
translated: or the word ‘thus’ or the word ‘so’ has not been used here as in the case of the spreading of the robe, therefore again🔽

original: “mettāsahagatena cetasā”ti vuttaṃ; nigamanavasena vā etaṃ vuttaṃ. Vipulenāti ettha
analyzed: mettā sahagatena cetasā iti vuttam nigamana vasena vā etam vuttam vipulena ati ettha
translated: Or else, as in the case of the word ‘again’, the word ‘thus’ is not repeated here, as in the case of the word ‘again’ in the passage ‘Again, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu dwells pervading one direction with his heart endued with loving- kindness … thus …’ . So ‘again’ is said by way of conclusion.

original: ca pharaṇavasena vipulatā daṭṭhabbā. Bhūmivasena pana taṃ mahaggataṃ, paguṇavasena
analyzed: ca pharaṇa vasena vipula tā daṭṭhabbā bhūmi vasena pana tam mahaggatam paguṇa vasena
translated: As to ‘vast extent’: the vast extent should be understood as the pervading. But as to ‘height’: that is lofty by reason of the plane .

original: appamāṇaṃ, sattārammaṇavasena ca appamāṇaṃ, byāpādapaccatthikappahānena averaṃ, domanassappahānato🔽abyāpajjhaṃ, niddukkhanti vuttaṃ hoti. Ayaṃ tāva “mettāsahagatena cetasā”tiādinā
analyzed: appamāṇam satta ārammaṇa vasena ca appamāṇam byāpāda paccatthika ppahānena averam domanassa ppahānato  abyāpajjham niddukkham ti vuttam hoti ayam tāva mettā sahagatena cetasā ati ādinā
translated: As to ‘measureless’: it is measureless as to measureless object, and it is measureless as to measureless purification. As to ‘friendliness’: it is without enmity by reason of the abandoning of hate and ill will.

original: nayena ṭhapitāya mātikāya attho.
analyzed: nayena ṭhapitāya mātikāya attho
translated: As to ‘kindness’: it is without unkindness by reason of the abandoning of grief and dejection. It is free from grief, is what is meant. This, in the first place, is the meaning of the matrix stated in the way beginning, ‘With a mind … endowed with loving-kindness’ .

original: 643. Idāni yadetaṃ “kathañca, bhikkhave, mettāsahagatena cetasā”tiādinā nayena vuttaṃ
analyzed: idāni yat etam katham ca bhikkhave mettā sahagatena cetasā ati ādinā nayena vuttam
translated: Now, as to the analysis of the terms in the way beginning, ‘And how, bhikkhus, is a bhikkhu … with a mind … endowed with loving-kindness? ’,

original: padabhājanīyaṃ, tattha yasmā idaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ dosacaritassa sappāyaṃ, tasmā yathārūpe
analyzed: pada bhājanīyam tattha yasmai idam kammaṭṭhānam dosa caritassa sappāyam tasmai yathārūpe
translated: herein, since this meditation subject is suitable for one of hating temperament,

original: puggale ayaṃ mettā appanaṃ pāpuṇāti, taṃ mettāya vatthubhūtaṃ puggalaṃ tāva dassetuṃ🔽seyyathāpi nāma ekaṃ puggalantiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha seyyathāpi nāmāti opammatthe nipāto,
analyzed: puggale ayam mettā appanam pāpuṇāti tam mettāya vatthu bhūtam puggalam tāva dassetuṃ  seyyathā api nāma ekam puggala ntiādi vuttam tattha seyyathā api nāma ati opamma atthe nipātaḥ
translated: The person in regard to whom loving-kindness reaches absorption is called a “person of the measure of a person.”🔽In order to show that person who is the object of loving-kindness, it is said: “Just as with a person dear, etc.” Herein, just as with a person dear is a particle in the sense of a simile;

original: yathā ekaṃ puggalanti attho. Piyanti pemanīyaṃ. Manāpanti hadayavuḍḍhikaraṃ. Tattha
analyzed: yathā ekam puggalanti attho piyanti pemanīyam manāpanti hadaya vuḍḍhi karam tattha
translated: the meaning is, just as with a single person. Dear is lovable. Agreeable is pleasing. Herein,

original: pubbeva sannivāsena paccuppannahitena vā piyo nāma hoti, sīlādiguṇasamāyogena manāpo
analyzed: pubbā iva sannivāsena paccuppanna hitena vā piyaḥ nāma hoti sīla ādi guṇa samāyogena manāpaḥ
translated: one is called dear through having lived together in the past, or through present helpfulness. One is called agreeable through possessing such special qualities as virtue, etc.

original: nāma; dānasamānattatāhi vā piyatā, piyavacanaatthacariyatāhi manāpatā veditabbā.
analyzed: nāma dāna samānatta tāhi vā piya tā piya vacana attha cariya tāhi manāpa tā veditabbā
translated: Or alternatively, dearness should be understood as being due to equality of generosity, etc., and agreeableness as being due to equality of virtue, etc.

original: Yasmā cettha piyatāya imassa byāpādassa pahānaṃ hoti, tato mettā sukhaṃ pharati,
analyzed: yasmā ca itthā piya tāya imassa byāpādassa pahānam hoti tatas mettā sukham pharati
translated: But since the abandoning of this hate is due to dearness, loving-kindness extends easily,🔽and since it is due to agreeableness, neutrality does not persist, and shame and moral dread assert themselves. Then,

original: manāpatāya udāsīnatā na saṇṭhāti, hirottappañca paccupaṭṭhāti, tato hirottappānupālitā
analyzed: udāsīna tā na saṇṭhāti hirottappam ca paccupaṭṭhāti tatas hirottappa anupāli tā
translated: since loving-kindness is preserved by the support of shame and moral dread,

original: mettā na parihāyati, tasmā taṃ upamaṃ katvā idaṃ vuttaṃ – piyaṃ manāpanti. Mettāyeyyāti
analyzed: mettā na parihāyati tasmā tam upamam katvā idam vuttam piyam manāpanti mettāyeyya iti
translated: it is said with reference to that simile: “With a person dear, or a person agreeable.”

original: mettāya phareyya; tasmiṃ puggale mettaṃ kareyya pavatteyyāti attho. Evameva sabbe
analyzed: mettāya phareyya tasmin puggale mettam kareyya pavatteyya ati attho evam eva sabbe
translated: he should suffuse him with loving-kindness; the meaning is that he should generate loving-kindness towards that person.

original: satteti yathā piyaṃ puggalaṃ mettāyeyya, evaṃ tasmiṃ puggale appanāppattāya vasībhāvaṃ🔽upagatāya mettāya majjhattaverisaṅkhātepi sabbe satte anukkamena pharatīti attho.
analyzed: satta iti yathā piyam puggalam mettāyeyya evam tasmin puggale appanā appattāya vasībhāvam  upagatāya mettāya majjhatta veri saṅkhāte api sabbe satte anukkamena pharati iti attho
translated: He should suffuse him with loving-kindness: he should make loving-kindness towards that person occur, is the meaning. So too, all beings: just as he would suffuse a dear person, so too he should suffuse all beings beginning with that person, who is neutral or hostile, with loving-kindness that has reached absorption and become mastered.🔽He suffuses: the meaning is that he pervades.

original: Metti mettāyanātiādīni vuttatthāneva.
translated: He suffuses with thoughts of loving-kindness: the meaning of this is stated in the way beginning, “He should suffuse just this person with thoughts of loving-kindness” .

original: 644. Vidisaṃ vāti padaṃ tiriyaṃ vāti etassa atthavibhāvanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vidisam vāti padam tiriyam vāti etassa attha vibhāvana attham vuttam
translated: He suffuses the direction that is in front: this is said in order to make known the meaning of the word “direction” .

original: 645. Pharitvāti ārammaṇakaraṇavasena phusitvā. Adhimuñcitvāti adhikabhāvena muñcitvā, yathā muttaṃ sumuttaṃ hoti suppasāritaṃ suvitthataṃ tathā muñcitvāti attho.
analyzed: pharitvā iti ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena phusitvā adhimuñcitvā iti adhika bhāvena muñcitvā yathā muttam su muttam hoti su pasāritam su vitthatam tathā muñcitvā iti attho
translated: Having suffused: having touched by making them an object. Having resolved upon: having released by a superior state, in such wise that the loving-kindness is well released, well resolved upon, well extended.

original: 648. Sabbadhiādiniddese yasmā tīṇipi etāni padāni sabbasaṅgāhikāni, tasmā nesaṃ ekatova atthaṃ dassetuṃ sabbena sabbantiādi vuttaṃ. Tassattho heṭṭhā vuttoyeva.
analyzed: sabba dhi ādi niddese yasmā etāni padāni sabba saṅgāhikāni tasmā na īsam ekatas va attham dassetum sabbena sabba nti ādi vuttam tassa atthaḥ heṭṭhā vuttaḥ yeva
translated: In the description of “all round” and so on, since these three terms are all inclusive, therefore “all in all ways” and so on are said in order to show their meaning collectively. Their meaning has already been given above .

original: 650. Vipulādiniddese yasmā yaṃ appanāppattaṃ hutvā anantasattapharaṇavasena vipulaṃ,
analyzed: vipula ādi niddese yasmai yam appanā appattam hutvā ananta satta pharaṇa vasena vipulam
translated: In the description of the extensive, etc., kinds, it is because it is extensive in being applied to infinite beings by reaching absorption that it is limited by plane to be exalted;

original: taṃ niyamato bhūmivasena mahaggataṃ hoti. Yañca mahaggataṃ taṃ appamāṇagocaravasena
analyzed: tam niyamataḥ bhūmi vasena mahaggatam hoti yam ca mahaggatam tam appamāṇa gocara vasena
translated: and what is exalted is immeasurable in having an immeasurable domain;🔽and what is immeasurable is without enmity in being the opposite of enmity, which is a term for the defilements;

original: appamāṇaṃ. Yaṃ appamāṇaṃ taṃ paccatthikavighātavasena averaṃ. Yañca averaṃ taṃ vihatabyāpajjatāya
analyzed: appamāṇam yam appamāṇam tam paccatthika vighāta vasena averam yam ca averam tam vihata byāpajja tāya
translated: and what is without enmity is without ill will in being the opposite of ill will.

original: abyāpajjaṃ. Tasmā “yaṃ vipulaṃ taṃ mahaggata”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Avero abyāpajjoti cettha🔽liṅgavipariyāyena vuttaṃ. Manena vā saddhiṃ yojanā kātabbā – yaṃ appamāṇaṃ cittaṃ,
analyzed: a byāpajjam tasmai yam vipulam tam mahaggata ntiādi vuttam a veraḥ a byāpajjaḥ ti ca ittha  liṅga vipariyāyena vuttam manena vā saddhim yojanā kātabbā yam appamāṇam cittam
translated: So it is said: “What is extensive is exalted” and so on. Herein, “without enmity, without ill will” is said with a reversal of the literal form;🔽or alternatively, it can be construed with the mind thus: “What is immeasurable is the mind without enmity;

original: so avero mano; yo avero so abyāpajjoti. Apicettha heṭṭhimaṃ heṭṭhimaṃ padaṃ uparimassa
analyzed: saḥ averaḥ manaḥ yaḥ averaḥ saḥ a byāpajjaḥ ti apica ittha heṭṭhimam heṭṭhimam padam uparimassa
translated: what is without enmity is the mind without ill will.”
