original: uparimassa, uparimaṃ vā uparimaṃ heṭṭhimassa heṭṭhimassa atthotipi veditabbo.
analyzed: uparimassa uparimam vā uparimam heṭṭhimassa heṭṭhimassa veditabbaḥ
translated: And here the meaning of each subsequent term should be understood as the meaning of the preceding one.🔽As, for example, in the case of the words “one person, two persons,” etc.,🔽and “one house, two houses,” etc.,🔽and “one ox, two oxen,” etc.,🔽and “one man, two men,” etc.,

original: 653. Seyyathāpi nāma ekaṃ puggalaṃ duggataṃ durupetanti idampi karuṇāya vatthubhūtaṃ
analyzed: sā iyyathā api nāma ekam puggalam duggatam durupetam ti idam api karuṇāya vatthu bhūtam

original: puggalaṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Evarūpasmiñhi puggale balavakāruññaṃ uppajjati. Tattha
analyzed: puggalam dassetum vuttam evarūpasmin hi puggale balava kāruññam uppajjati tattha
translated: It is said in order to show the kind of person. For it is in regard to such a person that strong aversion arises. Herein,

original: duggatanti dukkhena samaṅgībhāvaṃ gataṃ. Durupetanti kāyaduccaritādīhi upetaṃ. Gatikulabhogādivasena
analyzed: duggatanti dukkhena samaṅgībhāvam gatam durupetanti kāya duccarita ādīhi upetam gati kula bhoga ādi vasena
translated: “one who has gone to a bad bourn” has gone to a bourn accompanied by suffering. “One who has gone to a bourn that is not good” has gone to a bourn that is not good in respect of destiny, family, wealth, etc.,🔽or he is one who stands in the absence of that. “One who has gone to a bourn that is not excellent” has gone to a bourn that is not excellent in respect of destiny, family, wealth, etc.,

original: vā tamabhāve ṭhito puggalo duggato, kāyaduccaritādīhi upetattā tamaparāyaṇabhāve🔽ṭhito durupetoti evamettha attho veditabbo.🔽663. Ekaṃ puggalaṃ piyaṃ manāpanti idampi muditāya vatthubhūtaṃ puggalaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: vā tama bhāve ṭhitaḥ puggalaḥ duggataḥ kāya duccarita ādīhi upeta tā tama parāyaṇa bhāve  ṭhitaḥ durupetaḥ iti evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbo  ekam puggalam piyam manāpanti idam api muditāya vatthu bhūtam puggalam dassetuṃ
translated: or he is one who stands in the absence of that. “One who has gone to a bourn that is not noble” has gone to a bourn that is not noble in respect of destiny, family, wealth, etc.,🔽or he is one who stands in the absence of that. “One who has gone to a bourn that is not worthy” has gone to a bourn that is not worthy in respect of destiny, family, wealth, etc.,🔽or he is one who stands in the absence of that. “One who has gone to a bourn that is not excellent” has gone to a bourn that is not excellent in respect of destiny, family, wealth, etc.,

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha gatikulabhogādivasena jotibhāve ṭhito piyo, kāyasucaritādīhi upetattā🔽jotiparāyaṇabhāve ṭhito manāpoti veditabbo.🔽673. Neva manāpaṃ na amanāpanti idampi upekkhāya vatthubhūtaṃ puggalaṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam tattha gati kula bhoga ādi vasena joti bhāve ṭhitaḥ piyaḥ kāya su carita ādīhi upeta ttā  joti parāyaṇa bhāve ṭhitaḥ manāpaḥ iti veditabbo  na iva manāpam na amanāpam ti idam api upekkhāya vatthu bhūtam puggalam dassetum vuttam
translated: or he is one who stands in the absence of that. “One who has gone to a bourn that is not superior” has gone to a bourn that is not superior in respect of destiny, family, wealth, etc.,🔽or he is one who stands in the absence of that. “One who has gone to a bourn that is not sublime” has gone to a bourn that is not sublime in respect of destiny, family, wealth, etc.,🔽or he is one who stands in the absence of that. “One who has gone to a bourn that is not peaceful” has gone to a bourn that is not peaceful in respect of destiny, family, wealth, etc.,

original: Tattha mittabhāvaṃ asampattatāya neva manāpo, amittabhāvaṃ asampattatāya na amanāpoti
analyzed: tattha mitta bhāvam a sampattatāya na iva manāpaḥ amitta bhāvam a sampattatāya na amanāpaḥ ti
translated: or he is one who stands in the absence of that. “One who has gone to a bourn that is not excellent” has gone to a bourn that is not excellent in respect of destiny, family, wealth, etc.,🔽or he is one who stands in the absence of that. “One who has gone to a bourn that is not noble” has gone to a bourn that is not noble in respect of destiny,

original: veditabbo. Sesamettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ sabbaṃ heṭṭhā cittuppādakaṇḍe vuttameva.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ sesam ettha yat vattabbam siyā tat sabbam heṭṭhā cittuppāda kaṇḍe vuttam eva
translated: and should be understood. And what has to be said beyond this has all been said in the Description of the Arising of Consciousness.

original: Bhāvanāvidhānampi etesaṃ kammaṭṭhānānaṃ visuddhimagge vitthārato kathitamevāti.
analyzed: bhāvanā vidhānam pi etesam kammaṭṭhānānam visuddhi magge vitthārato kathitam eva ati
translated: And the method of development of these meditation subjects has been given in detail in the Path of Purification.

original: Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
translated: The Description of the Suttas and the Contemplations is ended.

original: 2. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Abhidhamma

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyaṃ kusalatopi vipākatopi kiriyatopi heṭṭhā cittuppādakaṇḍe bhājitanayeneva bhājitaṃ. Atthopissa tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: abhidhamma bhājanīyam kusalataḥ api vipākataḥ api kiriyataḥ api heṭṭhā cittuppāda kaṇḍe bhājita nayena iva bhājitam atthaḥ pi ssa tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: The Abhidhamma is divided according to profitable, etc., and according to root cause, etc., in the way already described under the Description of the Arising of Consciousness. And its meaning should be understood in the way already described there too.

original: 3. Pañhāpucchakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañhāpucchaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Questions

original: Pañhāpucchake pāḷianusāreneva mettādīnaṃ kusalādibhāvo veditabbo. Ārammaṇattikesu
analyzed: pañhāpucchake pāḷi anusārena iva mettā ādīnam kusala ādi bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ ārammaṇa attikesu
translated: In the Description of the Questions the profitable, etc., state of loving- kindness, etc., should be understood according to the text of the Abhidhamma.

original: pana sabbāpi tīsu tikesu navatabbārammaṇā eva. Ajjhattārammaṇattike bahiddhārammaṇāti.
analyzed: pana sabbā api tīsu tikesu nava tabba ārammaṇā eva ajjhatta ārammaṇa ttike bahiddha ārammaṇā ti
translated: But in the three Triads beginning with “Object” all have nine objects. In the triad “Internal or External Object” the external object is the external earth kasiṇa, etc.,

original: Imasmiṃ pana appamaññāvibhaṅge sammāsambuddhena suttantabhājanīyepi lokiyā eva appamaññāyo
analyzed: imasmin pana appamaññā vibhaṅge sammāsambuddhena suttanta bhājanīye pi lokiyāḥ eva appamaññāyo
translated: But in this Vibhaṅga of the measureless states only the mundane measureless states are given in the Suttas and the Contemplations.

original: kathitā, abhidhammabhājanīyepi pañhāpucchakepi. Tayopi hi ete nayā lokiyattā ekaparicchedā
analyzed: kathitāḥ abhidhammabhājanīye pi pañhāpucchake pi tayaḥ api hi ete nayāḥ lokiya ttā eka paricchedā
translated: and in the Questions of Discussion in the Abhidhamma. For these three methods are of the mundane only, and so they are classed together in one section.

original: eva. Evamayaṃ appamaññāvibhaṅgopi teparivaṭṭaṃ nīharitvāva bhājetvā dassitoti.
analyzed: eva evam ayam appamaññā vibhaṅgaḥ api te parivaṭṭam nīharitvā ava bhājetvā dassito ti
translated: So this exposition of the measureless has been demonstrated by taking it in order and dividing it up.

original: Sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sammoha vinodaniyā vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the Commentary on the Description of the Clearing Up of Confusion

original: Appamaññāvibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: appamaññā vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the measureless is ended.

original: 14. Sikkhāpadavibhaṅgo
analyzed: sikkhāpada vibhaṅgo
translated: The Description of the Training Precepts

original: 1. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā🔽703. Idāni tadanantare sikkhāpadavibhaṅge pañcāti gaṇanaparicchedo. Sikkhāpadānīti🔽sikkhitabbapadāni; sikkhākoṭṭhāsāti attho. Apica upari āgatā sabbepi kusalā dhammā
analyzed: idāni tad anantare sikkhāpada vibhaṅge pañca ati gaṇana paricchedaḥ sikkhāpadāni iti  sikkhitabba padāni sikkhākoṭṭhāsā ti attho apica upari āgatā sabbe pi kusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: The Description of the Questions of Discussion in the Abhidhamma

original: sikkhitabbato sikkhā. Pañcasu pana sīlaṅgesu yaṃkiñci aṅgaṃ tāsaṃ sikkhānaṃ patiṭṭhānaṭṭhena
analyzed: sikkhitabbataḥ sikkhā pañcasu pana sīlaṅgesu yaṃkiñci aṅgam tāsam sikkhānam patiṭṭhāna aṭṭhena
translated: Now, in the following Description of the Training Precepts, the number is defined as five. The training precepts are the terms to be trained in; the meaning is that they are the sections of the training. Moreover, all the profitable ideas that occur above are training because they are to be trained in. But any one of the five training principles is a term in the sense of a footing for those trainings.

original: padanti sikkhānaṃ padattā sikkhāpadāni. Pāṇātipātāti pāṇassa atipātā ghātanā māraṇāti
analyzed: sikkhānam padattā sikkhāpadāni pāṇa atipātā ati pāṇassa atipātā ghātanā māraṇā ati
translated: Because they are terms for the trainings, they are training precepts. Killing breathing things: breathing things’ killing, their slaughter, their murder,

original: attho. Veramaṇīti virati. Adinnādānāti adinnassa ādānā; parapariggahitassa haraṇāti
analyzed: atthaḥ veramaṇī iti virati adinna ādānā ati adinnassa ādānā para pariggahitassa haraṇā ati
translated: Meaning: abstention. Taking what is not given: taking what is not given, taking away what belongs to another;

original: attho. Kāmesūti vatthukāmesu. Micchācārāti kilesakāmavasena lāmakācārā. Musāvādāti
analyzed: kāmesu uti vatthu kāmesu micchā ācārā ati kilesa kāma vasena lāmaka ācārā musāvādā ati
translated: this is the meaning. In regard to sense desires: in regard to sense desires as objects. Misconduct: misconduct in the sense of defilement of sense desire. False speech:

original: abhūtavādato. Surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānāti ettha surāti piṭṭhasurā, pūvasurā, odanasurā,🔽kiṇṇapakkhittā, sambhārasaṃyuttāti pañca surā. Merayanti pupphāsavo, phalāsavo, guḷāsavo,
analyzed: abhūta vādato ettha surā ti piṭṭha surā pūva surā odana surā  kiṇṇa pakkhittā sambhāra saṃyuttā ati pañca surāḥ merayanti pupphāsavaḥ phalāsavaḥ guḷāsavaḥ
translated: from speaking what is not so. Intoxicants: here, surā means the five kinds of surā, namely, surā made from flour, surā made from molasses, surā made from rice,🔽surā made from honey, and surā made from a combination of ingredients. Meraya means the five kinds of asava, namely, asava made from flowers, asava made from fruits, asava made from molasses,

original: madhvāsavo, sambhārasaṃyuttoti pañca āsavā. Tadubhayampi madanīyaṭṭhena majjaṃ. Yāya
analyzed: madhu āsavaḥ sambhāra saṃyutto ti pañca āsavā tat ubhayam pi madanīya ṭṭhena majjam yāya
translated: asava made from honey, and asava made from a combination of ingredients. Both of these are called majja in the sense of intoxicating.

original: cetanāya taṃ pivanti, sā pamādakāraṇattā pamādaṭṭhānaṃ; tasmā surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: cetanāya tam pivanti sā pamāda kāraṇattā pamāda ṭṭhānam tasmā surā meraya majja pamāda ṭṭhānā
translated: The volition by which one drinks it is called pamādaṭṭhāna because it is the cause of heedlessness. Therefore, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhāna.

original: Ayaṃ tāvettha mātikānikkhepassa attho.
analyzed: ayam tāva ettha mātikā nikkhepassa attho
translated: This, firstly, is the meaning of the exposition of the mātikā.

original: 704. Padabhājanīye pana yasmiṃ samaye kāmāvacarantiādi sabbaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayattā
analyzed: pada bhājanīye pana yasmin samaye kāma avacaranti ādi sabbam heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā
translated: In the word-by-word commentary, however, the passage beginning “On an occasion when he is in the sensuous plane of existence” is commented upon in the same way as the corresponding passage in the Visuddhimagga .

original: uttānatthameva. Yasmā pana na kevalaṃ viratiyeva sikkhāpadaṃ, cetanāpi sikkhāpadameva,
analyzed: uttāna ttham eva yasmā pana na kevalam viratiyā iva sikkhāpadam cetanā api sikkhāpadam eva
translated: But since restraint is not the only training precept, volition is also a training precept,🔽therefore the second method is shown in order to point out that.

original: tasmā taṃ dassetuṃ dutiyanayo dassito. Yasmā ca na kevalaṃ eteyeva dve dhammā sikkhāpadaṃ,
analyzed: tasmā tam dassetum dutiya nayaḥ dassitaḥ yasmā ca na kevalam dve dhammā sikkhāpadam
translated: And since not only these two things are training precepts,

original: cetanāsampayuttā pana paropaṇṇāsadhammāpi sikkhitabbakoṭṭhāsato sikkhāpadameva, tasmā
analyzed: cetanā sampayuttā pana paropaṇṇāsa dhammā api sikkhitabba koṭṭhāsato sikkhāpadam eva tasmā
translated: but also the other forty-two mental states associated with volition are training precepts in the sense of being subject to training,

original: tatiyanayopi dassito.
analyzed: tatiya nayaḥ api dassito
translated: therefore the third method is shown.

original: Tattha duvidhaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ pariyāyasikkhāpadaṃ nippariyāyasikkhāpadañca. Tattha
analyzed: tattha duvidham sikkhāpadam pariyāya sikkhāpadam nippariyāya sikkhāpadam ca tattha
translated: Herein, a training precept is twofold, namely, literal training precepts and non-literal training precepts.

original: virati nippariyāyasikkhāpadaṃ. Sā hi “pāṇātipātā veramaṇī”ti pāḷiyaṃ āgatā, no cetanā.
analyzed: virati nippariyāya sikkhāpadam sā hi pāṇātipātā veramaṇī iti pāḷiyam āgatā no cetanā
translated: Herein, restraint is a non-literal training precept. For that is stated in the texts as “abstinence from killing breathing things,” not as volition.

original: Viramanto ca tāya eva tato tato viramati, na cetanāya. Cetanaṃ pana āharitvā dassesi.🔽Tathā sesacetanāsampayuttadhamme. Vītikkamakāle hi veracetanā dussīlyaṃ nāma. Tasmā
analyzed: viramanto ca tāya eva tatas tatas viramati na cetanāya cetanam pana āharitvā dassesi  tathā sesa cetanā sampayutta dhamme vītikkama kāle hi vera cetanā dussīlyam nāma tasmā
translated: And it is by means of that that one abstains from such and such things, not by means of volition. But he showed volition by bringing it in.🔽So too with the other mental states associated with volition. For at the time of transgression the volition of hate is called evil conduct.

original: sā viratikālepi susīlyavasena vuttā. Phassādayo taṃsampayuttattā gahitāti.
analyzed: sā virati kāle pi susīlya vasena vuttā phassa ādayaḥ tad sampayutta ttā gahitā ati
translated: So it is called good conduct at the time of abstinence. And contact, etc., are included because they are associated with it.

original: Idāni etesu sikkhāpadesu ñāṇasamuttejanatthaṃ imesaṃ pāṇātipātādīnaṃ dhammato, koṭṭhāsato, ārammaṇato, vedanāto, mūlato, kammato, sāvajjato, payogato ca vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: idāni etesu sikkhāpadesu ñāṇa samuttejana attham imesam pāṇātipāta ādīnam dhammataḥ koṭṭhāsataḥ ārammaṇataḥ vedanātaḥ mūlataḥ kammataḥ sāvajjataḥ payogataḥ ca vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: Now, in order to stimulate knowledge of these training precepts, the exposition of killing breathing things, etc., should be understood as to nature, as to category, as to object, as to feeling, as to root, as to door, as to source, as to near and far, as to past, future and present, as to internal and external, as to formed and unformed, as to seen, heard, sensed, and cognized, as to greed, etc., as to how to abandon them, as to skill in aggregates, etc., as to how they are unbeneficial, as to how they are blameworthy, and as to how they are suffering.

original: Tattha ‘dhammato’ti pañcapete pāṇātipātādayo cetanādhammāva honti. ‘Koṭṭhāsato’ pañcapi kammapathā eva.
analyzed: tattha dhammato ti honti koṭṭhāsato kamma pathāḥ eva
translated: Herein, as to nature: these five beginning with killing breathing things are simply natures consisting in volition. As to category: all five are courses of kamma.

original: ‘Ārammaṇato’ pāṇātipāto jīvitindriyārammaṇo. Adinnādānaṃ sattārammaṇaṃ vā saṅkhārārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇataḥ pāṇātipātaḥ jīvitindriya ārammaṇaḥ adinnādānam satta ārammaṇam vā saṅkhāra ārammaṇam
translated: As to object: killing breathing things has the life faculty as its object. Taking what is not given has either a living being as object or formations as object.

original: vā. Micchācāro itthipurisārammaṇo. Musāvādo sattārammaṇo vā saṅkhārārammaṇo vā. Surāpānaṃ saṅkhārārammaṇaṃ.🔽‘Vedanāto’ pāṇātipāto dukkhavedano. Adinnādānaṃ tivedanaṃ. Tañhi haṭṭhatuṭṭhassa
analyzed: vā micchācāraḥ itthi purisa ārammaṇaḥ musāvādaḥ satta ārammaṇaḥ vā saṅkhāra ārammaṇaḥ vā surā pānam saṅkhāra ārammaṇam  vedanātaḥ pāṇātipātaḥ dukkha vedanaḥ adinnādānam ti vedanam tat hi haṭṭha tuṭṭhassa
translated: Misconduct has a woman or a man as object. False speech has a living being as object or formations as object. Drinking strong drink has formations as object.🔽As to feeling: killing breathing things has pain as its feeling-tone. Taking what is not given has three kinds of feeling. For when one who is pleased and satisfied takes what is not given, it has pleasure as its feeling-tone. When one is afraid, it has pain as its feeling-tone.

original: adinnaṃ ādiyato sukhavedanaṃ hoti, bhītakāle dukkhavedanaṃ, majjhattassa hutvā gaṇhato
analyzed: adinnam ādiyataḥ sukha vedanam hoti bhīta kāle dukkha vedanam majjhattassa hutvā gaṇhato
translated: When one takes it without being either pleased and satisfied or afraid, it has neither pain nor pleasure as its feeling-tone.

original: adukkhamasukhavedanaṃ. Micchācāro sukhavedano vā adukkhamasukhavedano vā. Musāvādo
analyzed: adukkham asukha vedanam micchācāraḥ sukha vedanaḥ vā adukkham asukha vedanaḥ vā musāvādaḥ
translated: and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling. Wrong conduct is either pleasant feeling or neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling. False speech

original: adinnādānaṃ viya tivedano. Surāpānaṃ sukhamajjhattavedanaṃ.
analyzed: adinna ādānam viya ti vedano surā pānam sukham ajjhatta vedanam
translated: is threefold as feeling. Drinking strong drink is pleasant and neutral feeling.

original: ‘Mūlato’ pāṇātipāto dosamohamūlo. Adinnādānaṃ kiñcikāle lobhamohamūlaṃ, kiñcikāle🔽dosamohamūlaṃ. Micchācāro lobhamohamūlo. Musāvādo kiñcikāle lobhamohamūlo, kiñcikāle
analyzed: mūlatas pāṇa atipātaḥ dosa moha mūlaḥ adinnādānam kiñcikāle lobha moha mūlam kiñcikāle  dosa moha mūlam micchā ācāraḥ lobha moha mūlaḥ musāvādo kiñcikāle lobha moha mūlaḥ kiñcikāle
translated: As to root: killing breathing things has hate and delusion as its roots. Taking what is not given has greed and delusion as its roots at one time,🔽and hate and delusion as its roots at another. Wrong conduct has greed and delusion as its roots. False speech has greed and delusion as its roots at one time,

original: dosamohamūlo. Surāpānaṃ lobhamohamūlaṃ.
analyzed: surā pānam lobha moha mūlam
translated: and hate and delusion as its roots at another. Drinking strong drink has greed and delusion as its roots.

original: ‘Kammato’ musāvādo cettha vacīkammaṃ. Sesā kāyakammameva.
analyzed: kammataḥ musāvādaḥ ca ittha vacī kammam sesā kāya kammam eva
translated: As to action: here false speech is verbal action. The rest are bodily action only.

original: ‘Sāvajjato’ pāṇātipāto atthi appasāvajjo, atthi mahāsāvajjo. Tathā adinnādānādīni. Tesaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ heṭṭhā dassitameva.
analyzed: sāvajjato pāṇātipātaḥ atthi appasāvajjo atthi mahāsāvajjo tathā adinnādāna ādīni tesam nānākaraṇam heṭṭhā dassitam eva
translated: As to blame: killing breathing things is blameworthy in some cases and very blameworthy in other cases. So too are taking what is not given and the rest. The distinction between them has already been given below .

original: Ayaṃ pana aparo nayo – kunthakipillikassa hi vadho appasāvajjo, tato mahantatarassa
analyzed: ayam pana aparaḥ nayo kuntha kipillikassa hi vadhaḥ appasāvajjaḥ tatas mahantatarassa
translated: But there is this other way: the killing of a cripple or a louse is blameworthy, and the killing of one bigger than that is

original: mahāsāvajjo; sopi appasāvajjo, tato mahantatarāya sakuṇikāya mahāsāvajjo; tato godhāya,
analyzed: mahā sāvajjaḥ saḥ api appasāvajjaḥ tatas mahantatarāya sakuṇikāya mahā sāvajjaḥ tatas godhāya
translated: killing a small bird is less blameworthy than killing a large one; killing a goat is less blameworthy than killing a bird;

original: tato sasakassa, tato migassa, tato gavayassa, tato assassa, tato hatthissa vadho🔽mahāsāvajjo, tatopi dussīlamanussassa, tato gorūpasīlakamanussassa, tato saraṇagatassa,
analyzed: tatas sasakassa tatas migassa tatas gavayassa tatas assassa tatas hatthissa vadho  mahā sāvajjaḥ tatas api dussīla manussassa tatas go rūpa sīlaka manussassa tatas saraṇa gatassa
translated: killing a deer is less blameworthy than killing a goat; killing a gayal is less blameworthy than killing a deer; killing a horse is less blameworthy than killing a gayal; killing an elephant is less blameworthy than killing a horse.

original: tato pañcasikkhāpadikassa, tato sāmaṇerassa, tato puthujjanabhikkhuno, tato sotāpannassa,
analyzed: tatas pañca sikkhāpadikassa tatas sāmaṇerassa tatas puthujjana bhikkhuno tatas sotāpannassa
translated: Killing an immoral person is less blameworthy than killing a person of good behavior; killing a person of good behavior who has gone for refuge is less blameworthy than killing an immoral person; killing a person of good behavior who has gone for refuge and undertakes the five precepts is less blameworthy than killing a person of good behavior who has gone for refuge; killing a novice monk is less blameworthy than killing a person of good behavior who has gone for refuge and undertakes the five precepts; killing an ordinary monk is less blameworthy than killing a novice monk; killing a stream-enterer is less blameworthy than killing an ordinary monk;

original: tato sakadāgāmissa, tato anāgāmissa, tato khīṇāsavassa vadho atimahāsāvajjoyeva.🔽Adinnādānaṃ dussīlassa santake appasāvajjaṃ, tato gorūpasīlakassa santake mahāsāvajjaṃ;
analyzed: tatas sakadāgāmissa tatas anāgāmissa tatas khīṇāsavassa vadhaḥ  adinnādānam dussīlassa santake appasāvajjam tatas gorūpa sīlakassa santake mahāsāvajjam
translated: killing a once-returner is less blameworthy than killing a stream-enterer; killing a non-returner is less blameworthy than killing a once-returner; killing a perfected one is extremely blameworthy.

original: tato saraṇagatassa, tato pañcasikkhāpadikassa, tato sāmaṇerassa, tato puthujjanabhikkhuno,
analyzed: tatas saraṇa gatassa tatas pañca sikkhāpadikassa tatas sāmaṇerassa tatas puthujjana bhikkhuno
translated: Stealing from an immoral person is less blameworthy than stealing from a person of good behavior; stealing from a person of good behavior who has gone for refuge is more blameworthy than stealing from an immoral person; stealing from a person of good behavior who has gone for refuge and undertakes the five precepts is more blameworthy than stealing from a person of good behavior who has gone for refuge; stealing from a novice monk is more blameworthy than stealing from a person of good behavior who has gone for refuge and undertakes the five precepts; stealing from an ordinary monk is more blameworthy than stealing from a novice monk;

original: tato sotāpannassa, tato sakadāgāmissa, tato anāgāmissa santake mahāsāvajjaṃ, tato
analyzed: tatas sotāpannassa tatas sakadāgāmissa tatas anāgāmissa santake mahā sāvajjam tatas
translated: stealing from a stream-enterer is more blameworthy than stealing from an ordinary monk; stealing from a once-returner is more blameworthy than stealing from a stream-enterer; stealing from a non-returner is more blameworthy than stealing from a once-returner; stealing from a perfected one is extremely blameworthy.

original: khīṇāsavassa santake atimahāsāvajjaṃyeva.
analyzed: khīṇāsavassa santake
translated: and in a nun whose cankers are destroyed, it is extremely reprehensible.

original: Micchācāro dussīlāya itthiyā vītikkame appasāvajjo, tato gorūpasīlakāya mahāsāvajjo;
analyzed: micchā ācāraḥ dussīlāya itthiyā vītikkame appasāvajjaḥ tatas gorūpasīlakāya mahā sāvajjaḥ
translated: Misconduct: in a woman who is immoral, it is less reprehensible to have intercourse with her; in one who has the virtue of animals, it is more reprehensible;

original: tato saraṇagatāya, pañcasikkhāpadikāya, sāmaṇeriyā, puthujjanabhikkhuniyā, sotāpannāya,🔽sakadāgāminiyā, tato anāgāminiyā vītikkame mahāsāvajjo, khīṇāsavāya pana bhikkhuniyā
analyzed: tatas saraṇa gatāya pañca sikkhāpadikāya sāmaṇeriyā puthujjana bhikkhuniyā sotāpannāya  sakadāgāminiyā tatas anāgāminiyā vītikkame mahāsāvajjaḥ khīṇāsavāya pana bhikkhuniyā
translated: in one gone for refuge, in one who has undertaken the five training precepts, in a probationer nun, in an ordinary nun, in a stream-enterer,🔽in a once-returner, it is more reprehensible; in a nun who is a non-returner, it is extremely reprehensible;

original: ekantamahāsāvajjova.
analyzed: ekanta mahā sāvajja uva
translated: but in a nun whose cankers are destroyed, it is only extremely reprehensible.

original: Musāvādo kākaṇikamattassa atthāya musākathane appasāvajjo, tato aḍḍhamāsakassa, māsakassa,
analyzed: musāvādaḥ kākaṇika mattassa atthāya musā kathane appasāvajjaḥ tatas aḍḍha māsakassa māsakassa
translated: False speech: in telling a lie for the sake of a trifle worth less than a kākṇika, it is less reprehensible; for the sake of a half-penny, a penny,

original: pañcamāsakassa, aḍḍhakahāpaṇassa, kahāpaṇassa, tato anagghaniyabhaṇḍassa atthāya
analyzed: pañca māsakassa aḍḍha kahāpaṇassa kahāpaṇassa tatas anaggha niya bhaṇḍassa atthāya
translated: a half-māsaka coin, a māsaka coin, a half-kahāpaṇa coin, a kahāpaṇa coin,

original: musākathane mahāsāvajjo, musā kathetvā pana saṅghaṃ bhindantassa ekantamahāsāvajjova.
analyzed: musā kathane mahā sāvajjaḥ musā kathetvā pana saṅgham bhindantassa ekanta mahā sāvajjaḥ uva
translated: for the sake of something worth more than a kahāpaṇa coin, it is more reprehensible; but in telling a lie to cause a schism in the Sangha, it is only extremely reprehensible.

original: Surāpānaṃ pasatamattassa pāne appasāvajjaṃ, añjalimattassa pāne mahāsāvajjaṃ; kāyacālanasamatthaṃ pana bahuṃ pivitvā gāmaghātanigamaghātakammaṃ karontassa ekantamahāsāvajjameva.
analyzed: surā pānam pasata mattassa pāne appasāvajjam añjali mattassa pāne mahāsāvajjam kāya cālana samattham pana bahum pivitvā gāma ghāta nigama ghāta kammam karontassa ekanta mahāsāvajjam eva
translated: Drinking liquor is less blameworthy when one drinks a mere mouthful than when one drinks a handful. But when one drinks a lot and is able to walk and do other things, and one kills a village or a town, then it is very blameworthy.

original: Pāṇātipātañhi patvā khīṇāsavassa vadho mahāsāvajjo; adinnādānaṃ patvā khīṇāsavasantakassa
analyzed: pāṇa atipātam hi patvā khīṇāsavassa vadhaḥ mahā sāvajjaḥ adinnādānam patvā khīṇāsava santakassa
translated: For the killing of a person whose cankers are destroyed is very blameworthy, as is the stealing of the property of one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: haraṇaṃ, micchācāraṃ patvā khīṇāsavāya bhikkhuniyā vītikkamanaṃ, musāvādaṃ patvā🔽musāvādena saṅghabhedo, surāpānaṃ patvā kāyacālanasamatthaṃ bahuṃ pivitvā gāmanigamaghātanaṃ
analyzed: haraṇam micchācāram patvā khīṇāsavāya bhikkhuniyāḥ vītikkamanam musāvādam patvā  musāvādena saṅgha bhedaḥ surā pānam patvā kāya cālana samattham bahum pivitvā gāma nigama ghātanam
translated: The sexual misconduct of violating a bhikkhunī whose cankers are destroyed is very blameworthy, as is the telling of conscious lies about one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽The schism in the Sangha by means of conscious lies is very blameworthy, as is the killing of a village or a town after drinking a lot of liquor and being able to walk and do other things.

original: mahāsāvajjaṃ. Sabbehipi panetehi musāvādena saṅghabhedanameva mahāsāvajjaṃ. Tañhi
analyzed: mahāsāvajjam sabbehi pi panetehi musāvādena saṅgha bhedanam eva mahāsāvajjam tat hi
translated: But of all these, the schism in the Sangha is the most blameworthy.

original: kappaṃ niraye pācanasamatthaṃ mahākibbisaṃ.
analyzed: kappam niraye pācana samattham mahā kibbisam
translated: For that is a great evil that can cause one to be roasted in hell for an eon.

original: ‘Payogato’ti pāṇātipāto sāhatthikopi hoti āṇattikopi. Tathā adinnādānaṃ. Micchācāramusāvādasurāpānāni sāhatthikānevāti.
analyzed: payogataḥ ti pāṇātipāto sāhatthikaḥ api hoti āṇattikaḥ api tathā adinnādānam micchācāra musāvāda surā pānāni sāhatthikān eva ati
translated: “By means of an instrument” means that killing is done by one’s own hand or by incitement. So too is stealing. Sexual misconduct, lying, and drinking liquor are done by one’s own hand.

original: Evamettha pāṇātipātādīnaṃ dhammādivasena vinicchayaṃ ñatvā pāṇātipātā veramaṇītiādīnampi🔽dhammato, koṭṭhāsato, ārammaṇato, vedanāto, mūlato, kammato, khaṇḍato, samādānato,
analyzed: evam ettha pāṇātipāta ādīnam dhamma ādi vasena vinicchayam ñatvā pāṇātipātā veramaṇī iti ādīnam pi  dhammataḥ koṭṭhāsataḥ ārammaṇataḥ vedanātaḥ mūlataḥ kammataḥ khaṇḍataḥ samādānato
translated: And the exposition of the virtue of refraining from killing living beings, etc.,🔽should be understood in terms of ideas, in terms of sections, in terms of object, in terms of feeling, in terms of root, in terms of action, in terms of breach and non-breach, in terms of undertaking,

original: payogato ca vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: payogataḥ ca vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: and in terms of observance.

original: Tattha ‘dhammato’ti pariyāyasīlavasena paṭipāṭiyā pañca cetanādhammāva. ‘Koṭṭhāsato’ti🔽pañcapi kammapathā eva. ‘Ārammaṇato’ti pāṇātipātā veramaṇī parassa jīvitindriyaṃ🔽ārammaṇaṃ katvā attano veracetanāya viramati. Itarāsupi eseva nayo. Sabbāpi hi etā
analyzed: tattha dhammato ti pariyāya sīla vasena paṭipāṭiyā pañca cetanā dhammā va koṭṭhāsato ti  pañca api kamma pathāḥ eva ārammaṇato ti pāṇa atipātā veramaṇī parassa jīvitindriyam  ārammaṇam katvā attanaḥ vera cetanāya viramati itarāsu pi esa iva nayaḥ sabbā api hi etā
translated: Herein, in terms of ideas: in the case of the five abstinences, which are the virtue of the category of virtue consisting in limited purification, they are five ideas, namely, the five volitions. In terms of sections:

original: vītikkamitabbavatthuṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā veracetanāhiyeva viramanti. ‘Vedanāto’ti sabbāpi
analyzed: vītikkamitabba vatthum ārammaṇam katvā vera cetanā hiyā iva viramanti vedanāto ti sabbā api
translated: they are five courses of action. In terms of object: the abstinence from killing living beings is the refraining by one’s own volition from killing living beings, which is the life faculty in another, having made it the object. The rest are to be construed in the same way. For all of them are refraining by one’s own volition from an object that should not be done. In terms of feeling: all are either associated with pleasant feeling or with neutral feeling. In terms of root:

original: sukhavedanā vā honti majjhattavedanā vā. ‘Mūlato’ti ñāṇasampayuttacittena viramantassa
analyzed: sukha vedanāḥ vā honti majjhatta vedanāḥ vā mūlato ti ñāṇa sampayutta cittena viramantassa
translated: when one refrains with knowledge-accompanied consciousness, then the abstinence is associated with non-hate and non-delusion, and it is of the fine-material sphere or the supramundane.

original: alobhaadosaamohamūlā honti, ñāṇavippayuttacittena viramantassa alobhaadosamūlā honti.
analyzed: alobha a dosa a moha mūlāḥ honti ñāṇa vippayutta cittena viramantassa alobha a dosa mūlāḥ honti
translated: They have non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion as their roots. When one abstains through a consciousness not associated with knowledge, they have non-greed and non-hate as their roots.🔽As to action: here the abstention from false speech is verbal action; the rest are bodily action.

original: ‘Kammato’ti musāvādā veramaṇīyevettha vacīkammaṃ; sesā kāyakammaṃ. ‘Khaṇḍato’ti gahaṭṭhā
analyzed: kammatas ti musāvādāḥ vacī kammam sesā kāya kammam khaṇḍatas ti gahaṭṭhā
translated: As to breach: for householders

original: yaṃ yaṃ vītikkamanti, taṃ tadeva khaṇḍaṃ hoti bhijjati, avasesaṃ na bhijjati. Kasmā?
analyzed: yam yam vītikkamanti tam tat eva khaṇḍam hoti bhijjati avasesam na bhijjati kasmā
translated: whatever they transgress is a breach, is broken, but the rest is not broken. Why is that?

original: Gahaṭṭhā hi anibaddhasīlā honti, yaṃ yaṃ sakkonti taṃ tadeva gopenti. Sāmaṇerānaṃ
analyzed: gahaṭṭhāḥ hi a nibaddha sīlāḥ honti yam yam sakkonti tam tat eva gopenti sāmaṇerānam
translated: Because householders are not bound by the virtue of monks. Whatever they are able to they guard. But for novices

original: pana ekasmiṃ vītikkamante sabbāni bhijjanti. Na kevalañca etāni, sesasīlānipi bhijjantiyeva.
analyzed: pana ekasmin vītikkamante sabbāni bhijjanti na kevalam ca etāni sesa sīlāni pi bhijjanti yeva
translated: when they transgress one training rule all the others are broken. And not only these, but the other virtues are also broken.

original: Tesaṃ pana vītikkamo daṇḍakammavatthuko. ‘Puna evarūpaṃ na karissāmī’ti daṇḍakamme
analyzed: tesam pana vītikkamaḥ daṇḍa kamma vatthuko puna evarūpam na karissāmi iti daṇḍa kamme
translated: But their transgression is the basis for the punishment. When the punishment is carried out with the words, “I will not do so again,”

original: kate sīlaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ hoti. ‘Samādānato’ti sayameva ‘pañca sīlāni adhiṭṭhahāmī’ti
analyzed: kate sīlam paripuṇṇam hoti samādānato ti sayam eva pañca sīlāni adhiṭṭhahāmi iti
translated: the virtue is fulfilled. As to undertaking: they are undertaken by one who resolves thus, “I undertake the five training rules,”

original: adhiṭṭhahantenapi, pāṭiyekkaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ samādiyantenapi samādiṇṇāni honti. Aññassa
analyzed: adhiṭṭhahantena api pāṭiyekkam pāṭiyekkam samādiyantena api samādiṇṇāni honti aññassa
translated: or by one who undertakes each one separately. They are undertaken by another

original: santike nisīditvā ‘pañca sīlāni samādiyāmī’ti samādiyantenapi, pāṭiyekkaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ
analyzed: santike nisīditvā pañca sīlāni samādiyāmi iti samādiyantena api pāṭiyekkam pāṭiyekkam
translated: and by one who has undertaken them while sitting near, saying, “I undertake the five training precepts,” and by one who has undertaken them one by one,

original: samādiyantenapi samādinnāneva honti. ‘Payogato’ sabbānipi sāhatthikapayogānevāti veditabbāni.🔽712. Idāni yāsaṃ sikkhānaṃ koṭṭhāsabhāvena imāni pañca sikkhāpadāni vuttāni, tāni
analyzed: samādiyantena api samādinnāni eva honti payogato sabbāni pi sāhatthika payogāni eva ati veditabbāni  idāni yāsam sikkhānam koṭṭhāsa bhāvena imāni pañca sikkhāpadāni vuttāni tāni
translated: they are undertaken. “By means of the act” : all of them should be understood as undertaken by means of one’s own bodily and verbal acts.🔽Now, in order to show the training precepts as they are stated in the form of a section of the trainings,

original: dassetuṃ katame dhammā sikkhāti ayaṃ sikkhāvāro āraddho. Tattha yasmā sabbepi catubhūmakakusalā🔽dhammā sikkhitabbabhāvato sikkhā, tasmā te dassetuṃ yasmiṃ samaye kāmāvacarantiādi
analyzed: dassetum katame dhammā sikkhā ti ayam sikkhāvāraḥ āraddho tattha yasmā sabbe pi catu bhūmaka kusalā  dhammā sikkhitabba bhāvato sikkhā tasmā te dassetum yasmin samaye kāma avacaranti ādi
translated: the training chapter has been begun with the words, “What are the states that are training? ” Herein, since all the profitable states in the four planes are training in the sense of something to be trained in,

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha heṭṭhā cittuppādakaṇḍe vuttanayeneva pāḷiṃ vitthāretvā attho veditabbo.
analyzed: vuttam tattha heṭṭhā cittuppāda kaṇḍe vutta nayena iva pāḷim vitthāretvā atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: therefore, in order to show them, it is said: “When he is in the sensuous universe” , and so on. Herein, the meaning should be understood in detail according to the method of explanation in the chapter on the kinds of consciousness .

original: Idha pana mukhamattameva dassitanti.🔽Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: idha pana mukha mattam eva dassitanti  abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā
translated: But only the bare headings are shown here.🔽The Description of the Requisites of the True Idea

original: 3. Pañhāpucchakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañhāpucchaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Questioner

original: 714. Pañhāpucchake pāḷianusāreneva sikkhāpadānaṃ kusalādibhāvo veditabbo. Ārammaṇattikesu
analyzed: pañhāpucchake pāḷi anusārena iva sikkhāpadānam kusala ādi bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ ārammaṇa attikesu
translated: The profitable, etc., state of the training precepts should be understood by the method of the questions and answers in the text.🔽But as regards the “object” section,

original: pana yāni sikkhāpadāni ettha sattārammaṇānīti vuttāni, tāni yasmā sattoti saṅkhaṃ
analyzed: pana yāni sikkhāpadāni ettha satta ārammaṇāni iti vuttāni tāni yasmā satto ti
translated: the training precepts stated there as having a “living being as object” make a “formation that is a living being” their object,

original: gate saṅkhāreyeva ārammaṇaṃ karonti, yasmā ca sabbānipi etāni sampattavirativaseneva
analyzed: gate saṅkhāreya iva ārammaṇam karonti yasmā ca sabbāni pi etāni sampatta virati vasena iva
translated: and all of them are demonstrated by way of what is present,

original: niddiṭṭhāni, tasmā “parittārammaṇā”ti ca “paccuppannārammaṇā”ti ca vuttaṃ. Yato pana
analyzed: niddiṭṭhāni tasmā paritta ārammaṇā ti ca paccuppanna ārammaṇā ti ca vuttam yatas pana
translated: so it is said that they have a “limited” object and a “present” object.

original: viramati tassa vatthuno accantabahiddhattā sabbesampi bahiddhārammaṇatā veditabbāti.
analyzed: viramati tassa vatthuno accanta bahiddha tā sabbesam pi bahiddha ārammaṇa tā veditabbā ati
translated: But since they are refrained from because of the extreme nearness of the object, their object should be understood as external in all cases.

original: Imasmiṃ pana sikkhāpadavibhaṅge sammāsambuddhena abhidhammabhājanīyepi pañhāpucchakepi
analyzed: imasmin pana sikkhāpada vibhaṅge sammāsambuddhena abhidhamma bhājanīye pi pañhāpucchake pi
translated: But in this analysis of the training precepts the training precepts are stated by the Fully Enlightened One in the Abhidhamma and in the questions and answers

original: lokiyāneva sikkhāpadāni kathitāni. Ubhopi hi ete nayā lokiyattā ekaparicchedā eva.
analyzed: sikkhāpadāni kathitāni ubho api hi ete nayāḥ lokiya ttā eka paricchedāḥ eva
translated: only as mundane, for both these methods are confined to the mundane.

original: Evamayaṃ sikkhāpadavibhaṅgo dveparivaṭṭaṃ nīharitvāva bhājetvā dassitoti.
analyzed: evam ayam sikkhāpada vibhaṅgaḥ dve parivaṭṭam nīharitvā ava bhājetvā dassito ti
translated: So this analysis of the training precepts is given after extracting them by two turnings and then dividing them up.

original: Sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sammoha vinodaniyā vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the Commentary on the Vibhaṅga called Sammohavinodani

original: Sikkhāpadavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sikkhāpada vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the chapter on the training rules is finished.

original: 15. Paṭisambhidāvibhaṅgo🔽1. Suttantabhājanīyaṃ
analyzed: paṭisambhidā vibhaṅgaḥ  suttanta bhājanīyam
translated: The Patisambhidāmagga🔽The Suttantabhājanīya

original: 1. Saṅgahavāravaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṅgaha vāra vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the chapter on the summary🔽Now, in the Patisambhidāmagga, which comes next, the number is “four.”

original: 718. Idāni tadanantare paṭisambhidāvibhaṅge catassoti gaṇanaparicchedo. Paṭisambhidāti🔽pabhedā. Yasmā pana parato atthe ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidātiādimāha, tasmā na aññassa
analyzed: idāni tad anantare paṭisambhidā vibhaṅge gaṇana paricchedaḥ paṭisambhidā ti  pabhedāḥ yasmā pana paratas atthe ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā iti ādim āha tasmā na aññassa
translated: The analysis is🔽because it is said below, “Knowledge of the meaning is the discrimination of meaning,” and so on. Therefore it should be understood that the analysis is not of anything else

original: kassaci pabhedā, ñāṇasseva pabhedāti veditabbā. Iti “catasso paṭisambhidā”ti padena
analyzed: kassaci pabhedāḥ ñāṇassa iva pabhedā ati veditabbāḥ iti catasso paṭisambhidā iti padena
translated: but of knowledge. So by the phrase “four discriminations”

original: cattāro ñāṇappabhedāti ayamattho saṅgahito. Atthapaṭisambhidāti atthe paṭisambhidā;🔽atthappabhedassa sallakkhaṇavibhāvanāvavatthānakaraṇasamatthaṃ atthe pabhedagataṃ
analyzed: cattāro ñāṇa ppabhedā ti ayam atthaḥ saṅgahitaḥ attha paṭisambhidā ati atthe paṭisambhidā  attha ppabhedassa sat lakkhaṇa vibhāvanā vavatthāna karaṇa samattham atthe pabheda gatam
translated: the meaning of “four kinds of knowledge” is included. The discrimination of meaning is the discrimination in the meaning;

original: ñāṇanti attho. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Dhammappabhedassa hi sallakkhaṇavibhāvanāvavatthānakaraṇasamatthaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇam ti attho sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ dhamma ppabhedassa hi sat lakkhaṇa vibhāvanā vavatthāna karaṇa samattham
translated: the meaning is that it is knowledge in the meaning that has arrived at the analysis, which is able to discern, to analyze, to define, the analysis of the meaning. The same method of explanation applies in the other cases. For it is knowledge that is able to discern, to analyze, to define, the analysis of the teaching.

original: dhamme pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ dhammapaṭisambhidā nāma. Niruttippabhedassa sallakkhaṇavibhāvanāvavatthānakaraṇasamatthaṃ
analyzed: dhamme pabheda gatam ñāṇam dhamma paṭisambhidā nāma nirutti ppabhedassa sat lakkhaṇa vibhāvanā vavatthāna karaṇa samattham
translated: It is able to discern, to discriminate, to define the division in the sense of expression.

original: niruttābhilāpe pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ niruttipaṭisambhidā nāma. Paṭibhānappabhedassa
analyzed: nirutta abhilāpe pabheda gatam ñāṇam nirutti paṭisambhidā nāma paṭibhāna ppabhedassa
translated: Knowledge of the division in the sense of inspired speech is called the discrimination of inspired speech.🔽It is able to discern, to discriminate, to define the division in the sense of ready speech.

original: sallakkhaṇavibhāvanāvavatthānakaraṇasamatthaṃ paṭibhāne pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ paṭibhānapaṭisambhidā nāma.
analyzed: sat lakkhaṇa vibhāvanā vavatthāna karaṇa samattham paṭibhāne pabheda gatam ñāṇam paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā nāma
translated: Knowledge of the division in the sense of ready speech is called the discrimination of ready speech.

original: Idāni yathānikkhittā paṭisambhidā bhājetvā dassento atthe ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidātiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni yathā nikkhittā paṭisambhidā bhājetvā dassentaḥ atthe ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā ti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show the discrimination as it is set forth by dividing it, he said: “Knowledge of the meaning, the discrimination of meaning” .

original: Tattha atthoti saṅkhepato hetuphalaṃ. Tañhi hetuvasena araṇīyaṃ gantabbaṃ pattabbaṃ,
analyzed: tattha atthaḥ ti saṅkhepataḥ hetu phalam tat hi hetu vasena araṇīyam gantabbam pattabbam
translated: Herein, in brief, the meaning is cause and fruit. For that should be gone to and reached by way of cause,

original: tasmā atthoti vuccati. Pabhedato pana yaṃkiñci paccayasamuppannaṃ, nibbānaṃ, bhāsitattho,
analyzed: tasmai atthaḥ ti vuccati pabhedato pana yaṃ kiñci paccaya samuppannam nibbānam bhāsita tthaḥ
translated: therefore it is called meaning. But by way of division, whatever is originated by conditions, Nibbāna, the meaning of what is said,

original: vipāko, kiriyāti ime pañca dhammā atthoti veditabbā. Taṃ atthaṃ paccavekkhantassa
analyzed: vipākaḥ kiriyā ati ime pañca dhammā atthaḥ ti veditabbā tam attham paccavekkhantassa
translated: ripening, and function—these five things should be understood as meaning. To one who reviews that meaning,

original: tasmiṃ atthe pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidā.
analyzed: tasmin atthe pabheda gatam ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā
translated: knowledge of the division in the sense of meaning is the discrimination of meaning.

original: Dhammoti saṅkhepato paccayo. So hi yasmā taṃ taṃ vidahati pavatteti ceva pāpeti ca,
analyzed: dhammaḥ ti saṅkhepato paccayaḥ saḥ hi yasmā tam tam vidahati pavatta iti ca iva pāpa iti ca
translated: “Dhamma” in brief is condition. For it is said of it: “It burns that and that, it sets that and that going on, it brings that and that about” .

original: tasmā dhammoti vuccati. Pabhedato pana yo koci phalanibbattako hetu, ariyamaggo,
analyzed: tasmā dhammaḥ ti vuccati pabhedato pana yaḥ koci phala nibbattakaḥ hetu ariya maggo
translated: But in detail, any cause that produces a fruit, the Noble Path,🔽speech, profitable, unprofitable, and neither-profitable-nor-unprofitable are what should be understood as “dhamma.”

original: bhāsitaṃ, kusalaṃ, akusalanti ime pañca dhammā dhammoti veditabbā. Taṃ dhammaṃ paccavekkhantassa
analyzed: bhāsitam kusalam akusalanti ime pañca dhammā dhammaḥ ti veditabbā tam dhammam paccavekkhantassa
translated: When he reviews that dhamma,

original: tasmiṃ dhamme pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ dhammapaṭisambhidā.🔽Tatra dhammaniruttābhilāpe ñāṇanti tasmiṃ atthe ca dhamme ca yā sabhāvanirutti, tassā
analyzed: tasmin dhamme pabheda gatam ñāṇam dhamma paṭisambhidā  tatra dhamma nirutta abhilāpe tasmin atthe ca dhamme ca yā sabhāva nirutti tassā
translated: the knowledge of the kinds of categories in that dhamma is the discrimination of dhammas.🔽“Knowledge of the expression by synonyms for that dhamma”: the individual essence of that meaning and that dhamma is the individual essence description.

original: abhilāpe taṃ sabhāvaniruttiṃ saddaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā paccavekkhantassa tasmiṃ sabhāvaniruttābhilāpe
analyzed: abhilāpe tam sabhāva niruttim saddam ārammaṇam katvā paccavekkhantassa tasmin sabhāva nirutta abhilāpe
translated: When he reviews that individual essence description by making the sound that is the individual essence description its object,

original: pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ niruttipaṭisambhidā. Evamayaṃ niruttipaṭisambhidā saddārammaṇā
analyzed: pabheda gatam ñāṇam nirutti paṭisambhidā evam ayam nirutti paṭisambhidā sadda ārammaṇā
translated: the knowledge of the kinds of categories in that individual essence description is the discrimination of language.🔽So this discrimination of language is called “having sound as its object”

original: nāma jātā, na paññattiārammaṇā. Kasmā? Yasmā saddaṃ sutvā “ayaṃ sabhāvanirutti, ayaṃ
analyzed: nāma jātā na paññatti ārammaṇā kasmai yasmai saddam sutvā ayam ayam
translated: and not “having description as its object.” Why? Because, after hearing the sound, he knows “This is the individual essence description, this is the description of the class.”

original: na sabhāvaniruttī”ti jānanti. Paṭisambhidāppatto hi “phasso”ti vutte “ayaṃ sabhāvaniruttī”ti
analyzed: na sabhāva nirutti iti jānanti paṭisambhidā appatto hi phassaḥ ti vutte ayam sabhāva nirutti iti
translated: They know that it is not the natural language. For one who has attained the discrimination of language knows that when the word “contact” is spoken, this is the natural language,

original: jānāti, “phassā”ti vā “phassa”nti vā vutte pana “ayaṃ na sabhāvaniruttī”ti jānāti.
analyzed: jānāti vā phassanti vā vutte pana ayam na sabhāva niruttī iti jānāti
translated: and when the word “contacts” or “contact” is spoken, this is not the natural language.

original: Vedanādīsupi eseva nayo. Aññaṃ panesa nāmaākhyātaupasaggabyañjanasaddaṃ jānāti na🔽jānātīti? Yadaggena saddaṃ sutvā “ayaṃ sabhāvanirutti, ayaṃ na sabhāvaniruttī”ti
analyzed: vedanā ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ aññam pana isa nāma ākhyāta aupasagga byañjana saddam jānāti na  jānāti iti yat aggena saddam sutvā ayam sabhāva nirutti ayam na sabhāva nirutti iti
translated: The same method applies to feeling, and so on. But does he know the other words that are formed by adding a nominal suffix to a verbal base or not?🔽If he knows the verbal base, then he will know that when the word “contact” is spoken, this is the natural language, and when the words “contacts” or “contact” are spoken, this is not the natural language.

original: jānāti, tadaggena tampi jānissatīti. Taṃ pana nayidaṃ paṭisambhidākiccanti paṭikkhipitvā
analyzed: jānāti tad aggena tam pi jānissati iti tam pana na idam paṭisambhidā kiccanti paṭikkhipitvā
translated: But this is not the discrimination of language, it was said.

original: idaṃ vatthu kathitaṃ –
analyzed: idam vatthu kathitam
translated: This is the story.

original: Tissadattatthero kira bodhimaṇḍe suvaṇṇasalākaṃ gahetvā aṭṭhārasasu bhāsāsu ‘katarabhāsāya
analyzed: tissadatta thero kira bodhimaṇḍe suvaṇṇa salākam gahetvā aṭṭhārasasu bhāsāsu katara bhāsāya
translated: The Elder Tissa, it seems, took a golden casket to the Bodhi Tree and asked in eighteen languages, “In which language shall I recite the Patimokkha?”

original: kathemī’ti pavāresi. Taṃ pana tena attano uggahe ṭhatvā pavāritaṃ, na paṭisambhidāya
analyzed: kathemi iti pavāresi tam pana tena attanaḥ uggahe ṭhatvā pavāritam na paṭisambhidāya
translated: But he asked in his own language, not in the discrimination of language.

original: ṭhitena. So hi mahāpaññatāya taṃ taṃ bhāsaṃ kathāpetvā kathāpetvā uggaṇhi; tato uggahe
analyzed: ṭhitena saḥ hi mahā pañña tāya tam tam bhāsam kathāpetvā kathāpetvā uggaṇhi tatas uggahe
translated: He was a man of great understanding. He learned the various languages by having them spoken to him. Then he learned the language of the gods by listening to the gods.

original: ṭhatvā evaṃ pavāresi.
analyzed: ṭhatvā evam pavāresi
translated: And he announced his name in this way.

original: Bhāsaṃ nāma sattā uggaṇhantīti vatvā ca panettha idaṃ kathitaṃ. Mātāpitaro hi daharakāle
analyzed: bhāsam nāma sattāḥ uggaṇhanti iti vatvā ca pana itthā idam kathitam mātā pitaraḥ hi dahara kāle
translated: It is said that beings learn languages.

original: kumārake mañce vā pīṭhe vā nipajjāpetvā taṃ taṃ kathayamānā tāni tāni kiccāni karonti.
analyzed: kumārake mañce vā pīṭhe vā nipajjāpetvā tam tam kathayamānā tāni tāni kiccāni karonti
translated: For when their children are small, parents put them to bed on a couch or on a chair and do their various duties while talking to them in this way or that.

original: Dārakā tesaṃ taṃ taṃ bhāsaṃ vavatthāpenti – iminā idaṃ vuttaṃ, iminā idaṃ vuttanti.
analyzed: tesam tam tam bhāsam vavatthāpenti iminā idam vuttam iminā idam vuttam ti
translated: The children distinguish their various languages, thinking, “This is the language of this one, this is the language of that one.”

original: Gacchante gacchante kāle sabbampi bhāsaṃ jānanti. Mātā damiḷī, pitā andhako. Tesaṃ🔽jāto dārako sace mātukathaṃ paṭhamaṃ suṇāti, damiḷabhāsaṃ bhāsissati; sace pitukathaṃ
analyzed: gacchante gacchante kāle sabbam pi bhāsam jānanti mātā damiḷī pitā andhako tesam  jātaḥ dārako sace mātu katham paṭhamam suṇāti damiḷa bhāsam bhāsissati sace pitu katham
translated: As time goes on, they come to know all languages. The mother was a Dāmili woman, the father an Andhaka man.

original: paṭhamaṃ suṇāti, andhakabhāsaṃ bhāsissati. Ubhinnampi pana kathaṃ assuṇanto māgadhabhāsaṃ bhāsissati.
analyzed: paṭhamam suṇāti andhaka bhāsam bhāsissati ubhinnam pi pana katham assuṇantaḥ māgadha bhāsam bhāsissati
translated: The child born to them would speak the Dāmili language if he first heard his mother’s speech; he would speak the Andhaka language if he first heard his father’s speech; but if he did not hear the speech of either, he would speak the Magadha language.

original: Yopi agāmake mahāraññe nibbatto, tattha añño kathento nāma natthi, sopi attano dhammatāya🔽vacanaṃ samuṭṭhāpento māgadhabhāsameva bhāsissati. Niraye, tiracchānayoniyaṃ, pettivisaye,
analyzed: yaḥ api agāmake mahāraññe nibbatto tattha aññaḥ kathento nāma natthi so pi attanaḥ dhamma tāya  vacanam samuṭṭhāpentaḥ māgadha bhāsam eva bhāsissati niraye tiracchānayoniyam petti visaye
translated: And even one born in a great forest in the jungle where there is no one else to talk to will speak the Magadhan language by his own nature.🔽In hell, in the animal kingdom, in the realm of ghosts,

original: manussaloke, devaloketi sabbattha māgadhabhāsāva ussannā. Tattha sesā oṭṭakirātaandhakayonakadamiḷabhāsādikā🔽aṭṭhārasa bhāsā parivattanti. Ayamevekā yathābhuccabrahmavohāraariyavohārasaṅkhātā
analyzed: manussa loke deva loke ti sabbattha māgadha bhāsā ava ussannā tattha sesā oṭṭa kirāta andhaka yonaka damiḷa bhāsa ādikā  aṭṭhārasa bhāsā parivattanti ayam eva ekā yathābhucca brahmavohāra ariya vohāra saṅkhātā
translated: in the human world, and in the world of the gods, the Magadhan language is everywhere prevalent. There the other languages, such as the Oṭṭha, the Kirāta, the Andhaka, the Yona, the Kāṇḍa, the Dambha,🔽and the eighteen languages, are all derived from it. But the Magadhan language alone, which is called the language of the Brahmins, the language of the Noble Ones,

original: māgadhabhāsā na parivattati. Sammāsabuddhopi tepiṭakaṃ buddhavacanaṃ tantiṃ āropento
analyzed: māgadha bhāsā na parivattati sammāsabuddhaḥ api tepiṭakam buddha vacanam tantim āropentaḥ
translated: the Buddha, the Fully Enlightened One, when he was compiling the Tipiṭaka, the Buddha-word,

original: māgadhabhāsāya eva āropesi. Kasmā? Evañhi atthaṃ āharituṃ sukhaṃ hoti. Māgadhabhāsāya
analyzed: māgadha bhāsāya eva āropesi kasmai evañhi attham āharitum sukham hoti māgadha bhāsāya
translated: compiled it in the Magadhan language. Why? Because it is easy to understand the meaning in this way.

original: hi tantiṃ āruḷhassa buddhavacanassa paṭisambhidāppattānaṃ sotapathāgamanameva papañco;
analyzed: hi tantim āruḷhassa buddha vacanassa paṭisambhidā appattānam sota patha āgamanam eva
translated: For the Buddha-word, which is compiled in the Magadhan language, is a mere trifle for those who have attained the analytical knowledges to understand when it comes within the range of their ears.

original: sote pana saṅghaṭṭitamatteyeva nayasatena nayasahassena attho upaṭṭhāti. Aññāya pana
analyzed: sote pana saṅghaṭṭita matteya iva naya satena naya sahassena atthaḥ upaṭṭhāti aññāya pana
translated: but as soon as the ear has contacted the sound, the meaning appears with a hundred and a thousand ways.

original: bhāsāya tantiṃ āruḷhaṃ pothetvā pothetvā uggahetabbaṃ hoti. Bahumpi uggahetvā pana
analyzed: bhāsāya tantim āruḷham pothetvā pothetvā uggahetabbam hoti bahum pi uggahetvā pana
translated: But as soon as the ear has made contact with the sound, the meaning appears with a hundred and a thousand implications. But it must be learned by repeating it again and again, as if climbing a palm-tree by means of the bunches of palm fruits. And although he may learn much,

original: puthujjanassa paṭisambhidāppatti nāma natthi. Ariyasāvako no paṭisambhidāppato nāma natthi.
analyzed: puthujjanassa paṭisambhidā appatti nāma natthi ariyasāvako no paṭisambhidā appataḥ nāma natthi
translated: there is no acquisition of the discriminations for an ordinary man. But there is no ariyan disciple who has not acquired the discriminations.

original: Ñāṇesu ñāṇanti sabbatthakañāṇaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā ñāṇaṃ paccavekkhantassa pabhedagataṃ🔽ñāṇaṃ paṭibhānapaṭisambhidāti. Imā pana catassopi paṭisambhidā dvīsu ṭhānesu pabhedaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇesu ñāṇanti sabbatthaka ñāṇam ārammaṇam katvā ñāṇam paccavekkhantassa pabheda gatam  ñāṇam paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā ti imāḥ pana catasso api paṭisambhidāḥ dvīsu ṭhānesu pabhedam
translated: “Knowledge of knowledge”: when he reviews knowledge with a knowledge that is all-purpose, the knowledge that is classed as discrimination of perspicuity

original: gacchanti, pañcahi kāraṇehi visadā hontīti veditabbā. Katamesu dvīsu? Sekkhabhūmiyañca🔽asekkhabhūmiyañca. Tattha sāriputtattherassa mahāmoggallānattherassa mahākassapattherassa
analyzed: gacchanti pañcahi kāraṇehi visadāḥ honti iti veditabbā katamesu dvīsu sekkha bhūmiyam ca  asekkha bhūmiyam ca tattha sāriputta therassa mahāmoggallāna therassa mahākassapa therassa
translated: arises. But these four discriminations are to be understood as falling into two classes and as being clear in five ways. In what two classes?🔽In the class of the learner’s plane and in the class of the Arahant’s plane. Herein, the four discriminations of the venerable Sāriputta, the venerable Mahā Moggallāna, the venerable Mahā Kassapa,

original: mahākaccāyanattherassa mahākoṭṭhitattherassāti asītiyāpi mahātherānaṃ paṭisambhidā
analyzed: mahākaccāyana therassa mahākoṭṭhita therassa ati asītiyā api mahā therānam paṭisambhidā
translated: the venerable Mahā Kaccāna, and the venerable Mahā Koṭṭhita, and of the eighty great elders beginning with them,

original: asekkhabhūmiyaṃ pabhedaṃ gatā. Ānandattherassa cittassa gahapatino dhammikassa upāsakassa
analyzed: asekkha bhūmiyam pabhedam gatāḥ ānanda therassa cittassa gahapatino dhammikassa upāsakassa
translated: Ānanda, the Elder, the householder Citta, the lay devotee Dhammika,🔽the householder Upāli, the lay devotee Khujjuttarā, and so on.

original: upālissa gahapatino khujjuttarāya upāsikāyāti evamādīnaṃ paṭisambhidā sekkhabhūmiyaṃ
analyzed: upālissa gahapatino khujjuttarāya upāsikāya ati evamādīnam paṭisambhidā sekkha bhūmiyam
translated: The analytical insights of these two kinds of persons are found in the learner plane.

original: pabhedaṃ gatāti imāsu dvīsu bhūmīsu pabhedaṃ gacchanti.
analyzed: pabhedam gatā ati imāsu dvīsu bhūmīsu pabhedam gacchanti
translated: They are found in these two planes.🔽Why are the analytical insights clear?

original: Katamehi pañcahi kāraṇehi paṭisambhidā visadā hontīti? Adhigamena, pariyattiyā, savanena,
analyzed: katamehi pañcahi kāraṇehi paṭisambhidāḥ visadāḥ honti iti adhigamena pariyattiyā savanena
translated: They are clear because of attainment, learning, hearing,🔽questioning, and previous effort.

original: paripucchāya, pubbayogenāti. Tattha ‘adhigamo’ nāma arahattaṃ. Tañhi pattassa paṭisambhidā🔽visadā honti. ‘Pariyatti’ nāma buddhavacanaṃ. Tañhi uggaṇhantassa paṭisambhidā visadā🔽honti. ‘Savanaṃ’ nāma dhammassavanaṃ. Sakkaccañhi dhammaṃ suṇantassa paṭisambhidā
analyzed: paripucchāya pubba yogena ati tattha adhigamaḥ nāma arahattam tat hi pattassa paṭisambhidā  visadāḥ honti pariyatti nāma buddha vacanam tat hi uggaṇhantassa paṭisambhidā visadā  honti savanam nāma dhammassavanam sakkaccan hi dhammam suṇantassa paṭisambhidā
translated: Herein, ‘attainment’ is Arahantship. For when one has attained that,🔽the analytical insights are clear. ‘Learning’ is the Buddha’s word. For when one has learned that,🔽the analytical insights are clear. ‘Hearing’ is hearing the True Idea. For when one hears the True Idea with eagerness,

original: visadā honti. ‘Paripucchā’ nāma aṭṭhakathā. Uggahitapāḷiyā atthaṃ kathentassa hi
analyzed: visadāḥ honti paripucchāḥ nāma aṭṭhakathāḥ uggahita pāḷiyā attham kathentassa hi
translated: the analytical insights are clear. ‘Questioning’ is the commentaries. For when one has learned the text and is being taught the meaning,

original: paṭisambhidā visadā honti. ‘Pubbayogo’ nāma pubbayogāvacaratā, atītabhave haraṇapaccāharaṇanayena
analyzed: paṭisambhidāḥ visadāḥ honti pubbayogaḥ nāma pubbayoga avacaratā atīta bhave haraṇa paccāharaṇa nayena
translated: and the analytical insights are clear. ‘Previous application’ means previous application, the state of being one who has applied himself in the past, the state of being one who has carried out the removal and replacement in past lives,

original: pariggahitakammaṭṭhānatā; pubbayogāvacarassa hi paṭisambhidā visadā honti. Tattha
analyzed: pariggahita kammaṭṭhāna tā pubba yoga avacarassa hi paṭisambhidāḥ visadāḥ honti tattha
translated: The analytical knowledges are clear. ‘Previous application’ means previous practice. It is the taking up of a meditation subject by the carrying out of the duties of a bhikkhu in the past. For the analytical knowledges are clear to one who has practiced previously. Herein,

original: arahattappattiyā punabbasukuṭumbikaputtassa tissattherassa paṭisambhidā visadā ahesuṃ.🔽So kira tambapaṇṇidīpe buddhavacanaṃ uggaṇhitvā paratīraṃ gantvā yonakadhammarakkhitattherassa🔽santike buddhavacanaṃ uggaṇhitvā āgacchanto nāvaṃ abhiruhanatitthe ekasmiṃ pade uppannakaṅkho
analyzed: arahatta ppattiyā punabba sukuṭumbika puttassa tissa therassa paṭisambhidāḥ visadāḥ ahesuṃ  saḥ kira tambapaṇṇi dīpe buddha vacanam uggaṇhitvā para tīram gantvā yonakadhammarakkhita therassa  santike buddha vacanam uggaṇhitvā āgacchantaḥ nāvam abhiruhana titthe ekasmin pade uppanna kaṅkhaḥ
translated: the analytical knowledges were clear to the Elder Tissattherā of the Bhasatthambaka family after he had attained Arahantship.🔽It seems that he learned the Buddha’s word in Tambapaṇṇi Island, went to the other side , and learned the Buddha’s word from the Elder Yonakadhammarakkhita.🔽When he was returning, he had a doubt about a line in the passage he was reciting.

original: yojanasatamaggaṃ nivattitvā ācariyassa santikaṃ gacchanto antarāmagge ekassa kuṭumbikassa
analyzed: yojana sata maggam nivattitvā ācariyassa santikam gacchantaḥ antarāmagge ekassa kuṭumbikassa
translated: He turned back from the place where he had embarked on the ship and went to his teacher. On the way he answered a question of a certain householder.

original: pañhaṃ kathesi. So pasīditvā satasahassagghanikaṃ kambalaṃ adāsi. Sopi taṃ āharitvā
analyzed: pañham kathesi saḥ pasīditvā sata sahassa ghanikam kambalam adāsi saḥ api tam āharitvā
translated: The householder was pleased and gave him a blanket worth a hundred thousand pieces. He took it and went on to his teacher.

original: ācariyassa adāsi. Thero vāsiyā koṭṭetvā nisīdanaṭṭhāne paribhaṇḍaṃ kāresi. Kimatthāyāti?
analyzed: ācariyassa adāsi theraḥ vāsiyā koṭṭetvā nisīdana ṭhāne paribhaṇḍam kāresi kimatthāya ati
translated: He gave it to his teacher. The Elder cut the bamboo with the knife, and made a mat of it to sit upon. What was the purpose?

original: Pacchimāya janatāya anuggahatthāyāti. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi – “amhākaṃ gatamaggaṃ āvajjetvā
analyzed: pacchimāya janatāya anuggaha tthāya ati evam kirassa ahosi amhākam gata maggam āvajjetvā
translated: “For the sake of helping the people of the future.” He thought thus: “Let the people of the future, after remembering the path we have gone,

original: anāgate sabrahmacārino paṭipattiṃ pūretabbaṃ maññissantī”ti. Tissattheropi ācariyassa
analyzed: anāgate sabrahmacārino paṭipattim pūretabbam maññissanti iti tissa theraḥ api ācariyassa
translated: think that they should fulfil the practice of the life of a monk.” Tissatthero also, after having removed his doubts in the presence of his teacher,

original: santike kaṅkhaṃ chinditvā jambukolapaṭṭane oruyha cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ sammajjanavelāya vālikavihāraṃ🔽patvā sammajji. Tassa sammajjitaṭṭhānaṃ disvā ‘idaṃ vītarāgassa bhikkhuno sammaṭṭhaṭṭhāna’nti
analyzed: santike kaṅkham chinditvā jambu kola paṭṭane oruyha cetiyaṅgaṇam sammajjana velāya vālika vihāram  patvā sammajji tassa sammajjita ṭṭhānam disvā idam vīta rāgassa bhikkhuno sammaṭṭha ṭṭhānanti
translated: came down at Jambukolapaṭṭana, and after having swept the courtyard of the Bo-tree,

original: therassa vīmaṃsanatthāya pañhaṃ pucchiṃsu. Thero paṭisambhidāppattatāya pucchitapucchite pañhe kathesīti.
analyzed: therassa vīmaṃsana tthāya pañham thero paṭisambhidā appatta tāya pucchita pucchite pañhe kathesi iti
translated: he went to the Vālikārāma and swept it. After having seen the place swept by him, they asked a question for the purpose of testing the Elder, thinking: “This is the place swept by a monk who is free from passion.” The Elder, after having attained the analytical knowledge, explained the questions asked one by one.

original: Pariyattiyā pana tissadattattherassa ceva nāgasenattherassa ca paṭisambhidā visadā
analyzed: pariyattiyā pana tissadatta therassa ca iva nāgasena therassa ca paṭisambhidā visadā
translated: But in the case of the Elders Tissadatta and Nāgasena, the analytical knowledge was clear

original: ahesuṃ. Sakkaccadhammasavanena sudhammasāmaṇerassa paṭisambhidā visadā ahesuṃ. So
analyzed: ahesum sakkacca dhamma savanena sudhamma sāmaṇerassa paṭisambhidā visadā ahesum so
translated: The knowledge of the Elder Sudhamma the novice became clear by listening to the Dhamma with respect.

original: kira talaṅgaravāsī dhammadinnattherassa bhāgineyyo khuraggeyeva arahattaṃ patto mātulattherassa
analyzed: kira talaṅgara vāsī dhammadinna ttherassa bhāgineyyaḥ arahattam pattaḥ mātula ttherassa
translated: It is said that he was the nephew of the Elder Dhammadinna of Talaṅgara. He reached Arahantship at the age of eight.

original: dhammavinicchayaṭṭhāne nisīditvā suṇantoyeva tīṇi piṭakāni paguṇāni akāsi. Uggahitapāḷiyā
analyzed: dhamma vinicchaya ṭṭhāne nisīditvā tīṇi piṭakāni paguṇāni akāsi uggahita pāḷiyā
translated: While sitting in the place of the Elder’s exposition of the Dhamma and listening to it, he made the three Piṭakas easy to understand.

original: atthaṃ kathentassa pana tissadattattherassa eva paṭisambhidā visadā ahesuṃ. Gatapaccāgatavattaṃ🔽pana pūretvā yāva anulomaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ ussukkāpetvā āgatānaṃ visadabhāvappattapaṭisambhidānaṃ
analyzed: attham kathentassa pana tissadatta ttherassa eva paṭisambhidāḥ visadāḥ ahesum gata paccāgata vattam  pana pūretvā yāva anulomam kammaṭṭhānam ussukkāpetvā āgatānam visada bhāva patta paṭisambhidānam
translated: But the knowledge of the Elder Tissadatta, who was expounding the meaning of the texts he had learnt, became clear.

original: pubbayogāvacarānaṃ anto natthi.
analyzed: pubba yoga avacarānam antaḥ na atthi
translated: But there is no one among those who have previously practised meditation and have reached the state of clear knowledge of the knowledge of the analytical insights who has not fulfilled the duties of going and coming and has not made the meditation subject successful up to conformity.

original: Etesu pana kāraṇesu pariyatti, savanaṃ, paripucchāti imāni tīṇi pabhedasseva balavakāraṇāni.
analyzed: etesu pana kāraṇesu savanam imāni tīṇi pabhedassa iva balava kāraṇāni
translated: But among these causes, the three, namely, the tradition, hearing, and questioning, are the strong causes for the distinction.

original: Pubbayogo adhigamassa balavapaccayo, pabhedassa hoti na hotīti? Hoti, na pana tathā.
analyzed: pubba yogaḥ adhigamassa balava paccayaḥ pabhedassa hoti na hoti iti hoti na pana tathā
translated: Is previous practice a strong condition for the attainment? It is for the distinction, but not in the same way.

original: Pariyattisavanaparipucchā hi pubbe hontu vā mā vā, pubbayogena pubbe ceva etarahi
analyzed: pariyatti savana paripucchāḥ hi pubbe hontu vā mā vā pubba yogena pubbe ca iva etarahi
translated: For whether or not there is prior learning and questioning about the text, prior practice is necessary.🔽And without the prior practice of investigating formations, there is no discernment.

original: ca saṅkhārasammasanaṃ vinā paṭisambhidā nāma natthi. Ime pana dvepi ekato hutvā paṭisambhidā
analyzed: ca saṅkhāra sammasanam vinā paṭisambhidā nāma natthi ime pana dve pi ekatas hutvā paṭisambhidā
translated: But these two together, by becoming consolidated,

original: upatthambhetvā visadā karontīti.
analyzed: upatthambhetvā visadā karonti iti
translated: make discernment stand out clear.

original: Saṅgahavāravaṇṇanā.🔽2. Saccavārādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṅgaha vāra vaṇṇanā
translated: The section on the “summary” is ended.🔽The section on the “truths,” etc.,

original: 719. Idāni ye saṅgahavāre pañca atthā ca dhammā ca saṅgahitā, tesaṃ pabhedadassananayena🔽paṭisambhidā vibhajituṃ puna catassotiādinā nayena pabhedavāro āraddho. So saccavārahetuvāradhammavārapaccayākāravārapariyattivāravasena
analyzed: idāni ye saṅgaha vāre pañca atthā ca dhammā ca saṅgahitā tesam pabheda dassana nayena  paṭisambhidā vibhajitum puna catasso ti ādinā nayena pabheda vāraḥ āraddho saḥ sacca vāra hetu vāra dhamma vāra paccaya ākāra vāra pariyatti vāra vasena
translated: Now, in order to analyse the five kinds of “things” and the five kinds of “ideas” included in the “summary” section by showing their differentiation,🔽the “differentiation” section is begun with the words “Again, four” , etc. That section is fivefold as the section on the “truths,” the section on the “cause,” the section on the “ideas,” the section on the “conditions,” and the section on the “text.”

original: pañcavidho. Tattha paccayasamuppannassa dukkhasaccassa paccayena pattabbassa nibbānassa
analyzed: pañcavidhaḥ tattha paccaya samuppannassa dukkha saccassa paccayena pattabbassa nibbānassa
translated: Herein, the “truth of suffering” is a “thing” that is a condition, and Nibbāna, which is attained by means of the condition, is a “thing” that is a fruit.

original: ca atthabhāvaṃ, phalanibbattakassa samudayassa nibbānasampāpakassa ariyamaggassa
analyzed: ca attha bhāvam phala nibbattakassa samudayassa nibbāna sampāpakassa ariya maggassa
translated: And the “truth of origin” that generates the fruit is a “thing” that is a cause, and the noble path that brings about the attainment of Nibbāna is a “thing” that is a condition.

original: ca dhammabhāvañca dassetuṃ ‘saccavāro’ vutto. Yassa kassaci pana hetuphalanibbattakassa
analyzed: ca dhamma bhāvañca dassetum sacca vāraḥ vuttaḥ yassa kassaci pana hetu phala nibbattakassa
translated: and the meaning of the states, is called the “Chapter on Truths.”🔽The “Chapter on Causes” is called that because it shows the meaning of the cause that produces the cause and fruit,

original: hetuno dhammabhāvaṃ, hetuphalassa ca atthabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ ‘hetuvāro’ vutto. Tattha
analyzed: hetuno dhamma bhāvam hetu phalassa ca attha bhāvam dassetum hetuvāraḥ vuttaḥ tattha
translated: and the meaning of the cause and fruit.

original: ca hetuphalakkamavasena uppaṭipāṭiyā paṭhamaṃ dhammapaṭisambhidā niddiṭṭhā. Ye pana
analyzed: ca hetu phala kkama vasena uppaṭi pāṭiyā paṭhamam dhamma paṭisambhidā niddiṭṭhāḥ ye pana
translated: And here the discernment of states is demonstrated first in the order of arising, according to the order of cause and fruit.🔽The “Chapter on States” is called that because it shows the meaning of those states that are born from this or that kind of materiality or immateriality, and the meaning of the materiality or immateriality,

original: dhammā tamhā tamhā rūpārūpappabhedā hetuto jātā, tesaṃ atthabhāvaṃ, tassa tassa ca
analyzed: dhammā tamhā tamhā rūpa arūpa ppabhedāḥ hetutaḥ jātā tesam attha bhāvam tassa tassa ca
translated: and the meaning of the states that are the cause of that materiality or immateriality.

original: rūpārūpadhammappabhedassa hetuno dhammabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ ‘dhammavāro’ vutto. Jarāmaraṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: rūpa arūpa dhamma ppabhedassa hetuno dhamma bhāvam dassetum dhammavāraḥ vuttaḥ jarā maraṇa ādīnam
translated: The “Chapter on Conditions” is called that because it shows the meaning of aging-and-death, etc.,

original: pana atthabhāvaṃ, jarāmaraṇādisamudayasaṅkhātānaṃ jātiādīnañca dhammabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: pana attha bhāvam jarā maraṇa ādi samudaya saṅkhātānam jāti ādīnam ca dhamma bhāvam dassetuṃ
translated: and the meaning of the states that are the origin of aging-and-death, etc., namely, birth, etc.

original: ‘paccayākāravāro’ vutto. Tato pariyattisaṅkhātassa tassa tassa bhāsitassa dhammabhāvaṃ,
analyzed: paccaya ākāra vāraḥ vuttaḥ tatas pariyatti saṅkhātassa tassa tassa bhāsitassa dhamma bhāvam
translated: The “Chapter on Modes of Conveying” is called that because it shows the meaning of the teaching called the scriptures,

original: bhāsitasaṅkhātena paccayena pattabbassa bhāsitatthassa ca atthabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ ‘pariyattivāro’ vutto.🔽Tattha ca yasmā bhāsitaṃ ñatvā tassattho ñāyati, tasmā bhāsitabhāsitatthakkamena
analyzed: bhāsita saṅkhātena paccayena pattabbassa bhāsita atthassa ca attha bhāvam dassetum pariyatti vāraḥ vuttaḥ  tattha ca yasmā bhāsitam ñatvā tassa atthaḥ ñāyati tasmā bhāsita bhāsita ttha kkamena
translated: The section on the scriptures is stated to show the existence of the meaning of what is spoken and of what is to be reached by the condition of what is spoken.🔽And since the meaning is known when the speaking is known, the first of the four discriminations, that on the True Idea, is demonstrated by the order of speaking and the meaning of what is spoken.

original: uppaṭipāṭiyā paṭhamaṃ dhammapaṭisambhidā niddiṭṭhā. Pariyattidhammassa ca pabhedadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: uppaṭipāṭiyā paṭhamam dhamma paṭisambhidā niddiṭṭhā pariyatti dhammassa ca pabheda dassana ttham
translated: And in order to show the division of the True Idea as the subject of the scriptures,

original: “tattha katamā dhammapaṭisambhidā”ti pucchāpubbaṅgamo paṭiniddesavāro vutto. Tattha
analyzed: tattha katamā dhamma paṭisambhidā ti pucchā pubbaṅgamaḥ paṭiniddesa vāro vutto tattha
translated: the section on the demonstration is stated with the question “Herein, what is the discrimination of the True Idea?” as its preamble.

original: suttantiādīhi navahi aṅgehi nippadesato tanti gahitā. Ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho,
analyzed: suttanti ādīhi navahi aṅgehi nippadesataḥ tanti gahitā ayam imassa bhāsitassa attho
translated: Herein, the scriptures are included by indication under the nine terms beginning with “discourse” . This is the meaning of this speaking,

original: ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa atthoti imasmimpi ṭhāne bhāsitavasena nippadesato tanti eva gahitāti.
analyzed: ayam imassa bhāsitassa attho ti imasmim pi ṭhāne bhāsita vasena nippadesataḥ tanti eva gahitā ati
translated: this is the meaning of this speaking. In this case too the scriptures are included by indication under the speaking.

original: Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
translated: The commentary on the “Discourse-basket”.

original: 2. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the “Higher-morality-basket”.

original: 725. Tattha tisso paṭisambhidā lokiyā. Atthapaṭisambhidā lokiyalokuttaramissakā.
analyzed: tattha tissaḥ paṭisambhidāḥ lokiyāḥ attha paṭisambhidā lokiya lokuttara missakā
translated: Herein, three discriminations are mundane. The discrimination of the meaning is mixed mundane and supramundane.

original: Sā hi nibbānārammaṇānaṃ maggaphalañāṇānaṃ vasena lokuttarāpi hoti. Abhidhammabhājanīye
analyzed: sā hi nibbāna ārammaṇānam magga phala ñāṇānam vasena lokuttarā api hoti abhidhammabhājanīye
translated: For that is supramundane too, in the case of the knowledge of the path and of fruition with Nibbāna as object.

original: kusalākusalavipākakiriyānaṃ vasena catūhi vārehi vibhattaṃ. Tattha yattakāni heṭṭhā
analyzed: kusala akusala vipāka kiriyānam vasena catūhi vārehi vibhattam tattha yattakāni heṭṭhā
translated: In the Abhidhamma it is classed in four ways as profitable, unprofitable, resultant, and indeterminate.

original: cittuppādakaṇḍe kusalacittāni vibhattāni, tesaṃ sabbesampi vasena ekekasmiṃ cittaniddese
analyzed: cittuppāda kaṇḍe kusala cittāni vibhattāni tesam sabbesam pi vasena ekekasmin citta niddese
translated: Herein, in each of the descriptions of consciousness,

original: catasso catasso paṭisambhidā vibhattāti veditabbā. Akusalacittesupi eseva nayo. Vipākakiriyavāresu🔽vipākakiriyānaṃ atthena saṅgahitattā, dhammapaṭisambhidaṃ chaḍḍetvā, ekekasmiṃ vipākacitte
analyzed: catasso catasso paṭisambhidā vibhattā ati veditabbā akusala cittesu pi esa iva nayaḥ vipāka kiriya vāresu  vipāka kiriyānaṃ atthena saṅgahita ttā dhamma paṭisambhidam chaḍḍetvā ekekasmim vipāka citte
translated: the four kinds of discrimination should be understood to be given in terms of all the kinds of profitable consciousness classed🔽under the heading of the production of consciousness given above.🔽The same method applies in the case of the unprofitable consciousnesses.🔽In the case of the resultant and the indeterminate classes,🔽only three kinds of discrimination are given in each of the descriptions of resultant consciousness and of indeterminate consciousness, because the discrimination of ideas is included in the meaning of the remaining three.

original: ca kiriyacitte ca tisso tissova paṭisambhidā vibhattā. Pāḷi pana mukhamattameva dassetvā
analyzed: ca kiriya citte ca tissaḥ tissā uva paṭisambhidā vibhattā pana mukha mattam eva dassetvā
translated: But the text is given in brief, showing only the headings.

original: saṃkhittā. Sā heṭṭhā āgatavitthāravaseneva veditabbā.
analyzed: saṃkhittā sā heṭṭhā āgata vitthāra vasena iva veditabbā
translated: It should be understood in detail according to the method given above.

original: Kasmā pana yathā kusalākusalavāresu “tesaṃ vipāke ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidā”ti vuttaṃ,
analyzed: kasmā pana yathā kusala akusala vāresu tesam vipāke ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā ti vuttam
translated: But why is it said in the case of the profitable and unprofitable classes, “Knowledge of their result is the discrimination of meaning” ,

original: evamidha “yesaṃ dhammānaṃ ime vipākā, tesu ñāṇaṃ dhammapaṭisambhidā”ti evaṃ na vuttanti?
analyzed: evam idha yesam dhammānam ime vipākā tesu ñāṇam dhamma paṭisambhidā ti evam na vuttam ti
translated: So why is it not said here, “Knowledge of those ideas whose fruits these are is the discrimination of perspicuity of ideas”?

original: Heṭṭhā vuttattā. Yadi evaṃ, “tesaṃ vipāke ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidā”ti heṭṭhā vuttattā
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta ttā yadi evam tesam vipāke ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā ti heṭṭhā vutta ttā
translated: Because it was said above. If that is so, then since it was said above, “Knowledge of their fruits is the discrimination of perspicuity of meaning” ,🔽this discrimination of perspicuity of meaning should not be mentioned here.

original: ayaṃ atthapaṭisambhidāpi idha na vattabbā siyāti? No na vattabbā. Kasmā? Heṭṭhā vipākakiriyacittuppādavasena
analyzed: ayam attha paṭisambhidā api idha na vattabbā siyā ati no na vattabbā kasmā heṭṭhā vipāka kiriya cittuppāda vasena
translated: It is not not mentioned. Why not? Because it was not said above in terms of resultant and functional consciousnesses.

original: avuttattā. Kiriyavāre ca “yesaṃ dhammānaṃ ime kiriyā”ti vacanameva na yujjatīti dvīsupi
analyzed: a vutta ttā kiriya vāre ca yesam dhammānam ime kiriyā ati vacanam eva na yujjati iti dvīsupi
translated: And in the functional class it is not proper to say, “These are functional ideas” .

original: imesu vāresu tisso tissova paṭisambhidā vibhattā.🔽Tattha yāya niruttiyā tesaṃ dhammānaṃ paññatti hotīti yāya niruttiyā tesaṃ phasso🔽hotītiādinā nayena vuttānaṃ dhammānaṃ “ayaṃ phasso, ayaṃ vedanā”ti evaṃ paññatti
analyzed: imesu vāresu tissā tissā uva paṭisambhidā vibhattā  tattha yāya niruttiyā tesam dhammānam paññatti hoti iti yāya niruttiyā tesam phasso  hoti itiādinā nayena vuttānam dhammānam ayam phassaḥ ayam vedanā ti evam paññatti
translated: So in both these classes the three discriminations are distributed as three each.🔽Herein, by whatever phrasing the description of those ideas comes about: by whatever phrasing the description of those ideas comes about in the way beginning, “Contact is this, feeling is this” ,🔽then knowledge of the description of those ideas in that phrasing is knowledge of perspicuity of description.

original: hoti. Tattha dhammaniruttābhilāpe ñāṇanti tasmiṃ atthe dhamme ca pavattamānāya tassā
analyzed: hoti tattha dhamma nirutta abhilāpe ñāṇan ti tasmin atthe dhamme ca pavattamānāya tassā
translated: Herein, knowledge of perspicuity of description of ideas in that description of ideas is knowledge of perspicuity of description of ideas.
