original: dhammaniruttiyā sabhāvapaññattiyā abhilāpe ñāṇaṃ. Abhilāpasaddaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā
analyzed: dhamma niruttiyā sabhāva paññattiyā abhilāpe ñāṇam abhilāpa saddam ārammaṇam katvā
translated: Knowledge of the expression of the individual essences of dhammas by means of the language of the Dhamma is called the discrimination of perspicuity.🔽The knowledge that arises making as its object the sound of the expression is what is called the discrimination of perspicuity here.

original: uppannañāṇameva idhāpi kathitaṃ. Yena ñāṇenāti yena paṭibhānapaṭisambhidāñāṇena.
analyzed: uppanna ñāṇam eva idha api kathitam yena ñāṇena ati yena paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā ñāṇena
translated: By means of which knowledge: by means of the knowledge of the discrimination of perspicuity.

original: Tāni ñāṇāni jānātīti itarāni tīṇi paṭisambhidāñāṇāni jānāti.
analyzed: tāni ñāṇāni jānāti iti itarāni tīṇi paṭisambhidā ñāṇāni jānāti
translated: He knows those knowledges: he knows the other three discriminations.

original: Idāni yathā yaṃ ñāṇaṃ tāni ñāṇāni jānāti, tathā tassa tesu pavattiṃ dassetuṃ imāni🔽ñāṇāni idamatthajotakānīti vuttaṃ. Tattha idamatthajotakānīti imassa atthassa jotakāni
analyzed: idāni yathā yam ñāṇam tāni ñāṇāni jānāti tathā tassa tesu pavattim dassetuṃ imāni  ñāṇāni idam attha jotakāni iti vuttam tattha idam attha jotakāni iti imassa atthassa jotakāni
translated: Now, in order to show how that knowledge knows those knowledges and how it occurs in regard to them, it is said:

original: pakāsakāni; imaṃ nāma atthaṃ jotenti pakāsenti paricchindantīti attho. Iti ñāṇesu🔽ñāṇanti iminā ākārena pavattaṃ tīsu ñāṇesu ñāṇaṃ paṭibhānapaṭisambhidā nāma.
analyzed: pakāsakāni imam nāma attham jotenti pakāsenti paricchindanti iti attho iti ñāṇesu  ñāṇanti iminā ākārena pavattam tīsu ñāṇesu ñāṇam paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā nāma
translated: These knowledges are illuminating this meaning. Herein, illuminating this meaning is illuminating, making to shine, this meaning; the meaning of this is that they illuminate, make to shine, define, this meaning. Thus in regard to the knowledges🔽knowledge is called the discrimination of perspicuity.

original: Tattha kiñcāpi ayaṃ paṭibhānapaṭisambhidā ‘imissā idaṃ kiccaṃ, imissā idaṃ kicca’nti
analyzed: tattha kiñca api ayam paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā imissā idam kiccam imissā idam kiccanti
translated: Herein, although this discrimination of perspicuity is the knowledge that occurs in this way in the three knowledges, still it is called the discrimination of perspicuity because it is the cause for the occurrence of perspicuity in the three knowledges.

original: itarāsaṃ paṭisambhidānaṃ kiccaṃ jānāti, sayaṃ pana tāsaṃ kiccaṃ kātuṃ na sakkoti,🔽bahussutadhammakathiko viya appassutadhammakathikassa. Dve kira bhikkhū. Eko bahussuto,🔽eko appassuto. Te ekatova ekaṃ dhammakathāmaggaṃ uggaṇhiṃsu. Tattha appassuto sarasampanno
analyzed: itarāsam paṭisambhidānam kiccam jānāti sayam pana tāsam kiccam kātum na sakkoti  bahussuta dhamma kathikaḥ viya appassuta dhamma kathikassa dve kira bhikkhū ekaḥ bahussutaḥ  ekaḥ appassutaḥ te ekatas va ekam dhamma kathā maggam uggaṇhiṃsu tattha appassutaḥ sara sampanno
translated: He knows the function of the other kinds of direct knowledge, but he is unable to perform their function himself,🔽like a learned and eloquent bhikkhu who is unable to stir the assembly with his talk on the Dhamma as can a bhikkhu who is unlearned but has the special qualities of a good preacher.🔽Two bhikkhus, it seems, were going along a road together. One was learned and eloquent,🔽but the other was unlearned. They had both learned a discourse on the way. The unlearned bhikkhu was one who remembered well,

original: ahosi, itaro mandassaro. Tesu appassuto gatagataṭṭhāne attano sarasampattiyā sakalaparisaṃ🔽khobhetvā dhammaṃ kathesi. Dhammaṃ suṇamānā haṭṭhatuṭṭhamānasā hutvā – ‘yathā esa
analyzed: ahosi itaraḥ mandassaro tesu appassutaḥ gata gata ṭṭhāne attano sara sampattiyā sakala parisam  khobhetvā dhammam kathesi dhammam suṇamānā haṭṭha tuṭṭha mānasā hutvā yathā esa
translated: but the other was slow in taking things in. The unlearned bhikkhu, wherever he went, stirred the whole assembly with his talk on the Dhamma because of his good memory.🔽Those who listened to his Dhamma thought, “He must be a master of the three Piṭakas, to talk like that.”

original: dhammaṃ kathesi, eko tipiṭakadharo maññe bhavissatī’ti vadanti. Bahussutabhikkhu🔽pana – ‘dhammasavane jānissatha ayaṃ tipiṭakadharo vā no vā’ti āha. So kiñcāpi evamāha,
analyzed: dhammam kathesi ekaḥ tipiṭaka dharaḥ maññe bhavissati iti vadanti bahu ssuta bhikkhu  pana dhammasavane jānissatha ayam tipiṭaka dharaḥ vā no vā iti āha saḥ kiñcā api evam āha
translated: But the learned bhikkhu said, “You will know whether he is a master of the three Piṭakas or not when he preaches the discourse he has learned.”🔽Although he said this,

original: yathā pana sakalaparisaṃ khobhetvā dhammaṃ kathetuṃ sakkoti, evamassa kathanasamatthatā
analyzed: yathā pana sakala parisam khobhetvā dhammam kathetum sakkoti evam assa kathana samattha tā
translated: he was unable to stir the whole assembly with his talk on the Dhamma as the other bhikkhu did.

original: natthi. Tattha kiñcāpi paṭibhānapaṭisambhidā, bahussuto viya appassutassa, itarāsaṃ
analyzed: natthi tattha kiñcā api paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā bahu ssutaḥ viya appassutassa itarāsam
translated: There is none. Herein, although the analytical knowledge of perspicuity is like the learning of one who has much learning for one who has little learning,

original: kiccaṃ jānāti, sayaṃ pana taṃ kiccaṃ kātuṃ na sakkotīti veditabbaṃ. Sesaṃ uttānatthameva.🔽746. Evaṃ kusalacittuppādādivasena paṭisambhidā vibhajitvā idāni tāsaṃ uppattiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ🔽khettaṃ dassetuṃ puna catasso paṭisambhidātiādimāha. Tattha tisso paṭisambhidā kāmāvacarakusalato
analyzed: kiccam jānāti sayam pana tam kiccam kātum na sakkoti iti veditabbam sesam uttāna ttham eva  evam kusala cittuppāda ādi vasena paṭisambhidāḥ vibhajitvā idāni tāsam uppatti ṭṭhāna bhūtam  khettam dassetum puna catasso paṭisambhidā ti ādim āha tattha tissaḥ paṭisambhidā kāmāvacara kusalato
translated: it should be understood that it knows the function of the others but is unable itself to perform that function. The rest is clear.🔽Having thus analyzed the analytical knowledges according to the kinds of consciousness in which they occur, he now says “Again, four analytical knowledges,” etc., in order to point out the plane of their origination.🔽Herein, the three analytical knowledges in the four kinds of consciousness associated with knowledge, which are of the sense sphere and profitable,

original: catūsu ñāṇasampayuttesu cittuppādesūti idaṃ sekkhānaṃ vasena vuttaṃ. Tesañhipi dhammapaccavekkhaṇakāle🔽heṭṭhā vuttaṃ pañcappakāraṃ dhammaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā catūsu ñāṇasampayuttakusalacittesu
analyzed: catūsu ñāṇa sampayuttesu cittuppādesu iti idam sekkhānam vasena vuttam tesam hi pi dhamma paccavekkhaṇa kāle  heṭṭhā vuttam pañca ppakāram dhammam ārammaṇam katvā catūsu ñāṇa sampayutta kusala cittesu
translated: This is said with reference to the trainer. For the latter, too, when he is reviewing the True Idea,🔽having made the fivefold True Idea stated above his object, the analytical knowledge of the True Idea arises in the four kinds of profitable consciousness associated with knowledge.

original: dhammapaṭisambhidā uppajjati. Tathā niruttipaccavekkhaṇakāle saddaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā
analyzed: dhamma paṭisambhidā uppajjati tathā nirutti paccavekkhaṇa kāle saddam ārammaṇam katvā
translated: Likewise, when he is reviewing the language, having made sound his object,

original: niruttipaṭisambhidā; ñāṇaṃ paccavekkhaṇakāle sabbatthakañāṇaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā paṭibhānapaṭisambhidāti.
analyzed: nirutti paṭisambhidā ñāṇam paccavekkhaṇa kāle sabbatthaka ñāṇam ārammaṇam katvā paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā ti
translated: The knowledge of the expression of dhammas is the discernment of language. The knowledge of the discernment of perspicuity is the discernment of perspicuity.🔽From the functional: in four,

original: Kiriyato catūsūti idaṃ pana asekkhānaṃ vasena vuttaṃ. Tesañhi dhammaṃ paccavekkhaṇakāle🔽heṭṭhā vuttaṃ pañcappakāraṃ dhammaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā catūsu ñāṇasampayuttakiriyacittesu
analyzed: kiriyato catūsu iti idam pana asekkhānam vasena vuttam tesam hi dhammam paccavekkhaṇa kāle  heṭṭhā vuttam pañca ppakāram dhammam ārammaṇam katvā catūsu ñāṇa sampayutta kiriya cittesu
translated: This is said with reference to the adepts. For when they review dhamma,🔽taking as their object the five kinds of dhamma mentioned above,🔽the discernment of dhammas arises in the four functional consciousnesses associated with knowledge.

original: dhammapaṭisambhidā uppajjati. Tathā niruttipaccavekkhaṇakāle saddaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā
analyzed: dhamma paṭisambhidā uppajjati tathā nirutti paccavekkhaṇa kāle saddam ārammaṇam katvā
translated: Similarly, when they review language, taking sound as their object,🔽the discernment of language arises. When they review knowledge, taking the all-purpose knowledge as their object,

original: niruttipaṭisambhidā; ñāṇaṃ paccavekkhaṇakāle sabbatthakañāṇaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā paṭibhānapaṭisambhidāti.🔽Atthapaṭisambhidā etesu ceva uppajjatīti idaṃ pana sekkhāsekkhānaṃ vasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nirutti paṭisambhidā ñāṇam paccavekkhaṇa kāle sabbatthaka ñāṇam ārammaṇam katvā paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā ti  attha paṭisambhidā etesu ca iva uppajjati iti idam pana sekkha asekkhānam vasena vuttam
translated: the discernment of perspicuity arises.🔽The discernment of meaning arises in these,🔽This is said with reference to the trainers and adepts.

original: Tathā hi sekkhānaṃ atthapaccavekkhaṇakāle heṭṭhā vuttappabhedaṃ atthaṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: tathā hi sekkhānam attha paccavekkhaṇa kāle heṭṭhā vutta ppabhedam attham ārammaṇam
translated: For when the trainers review meaning, taking as their object the meaning of the kinds mentioned above,

original: katvā catūsu ñāṇasampayuttakusalacittesu ayaṃ uppajjati, maggaphalakāle ca maggaphalesu.🔽Asekkhassa pana atthaṃ paccavekkhaṇakāle heṭṭhā vuttappabhedameva atthaṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: katvā catūsu ñāṇa sampayutta kusala cittesu ayam uppajjati magga phala kāle ca magga phalesu  asekkhassa pana attham paccavekkhaṇa kāle heṭṭhā vutta ppabhedam eva attham ārammaṇam
translated: It arises in the four profitable consciousnesses accompanied by knowledge and in the path and fruition consciousness.🔽But in the case of the adept, it arises in the four functional consciousnesses accompanied by knowledge, taking as its object the meaning of the kinds already mentioned,

original: katvā catūsu ñāṇasampayuttakiriyacittesu uppajjati, phalakāle ca uparime sāmaññaphaleti.
analyzed: katvā catūsu ñāṇa sampayutta kiriya cittesu uppajjati phala kāle ca uparime sāmañña phala iti
translated: and it arises in the higher fruition of asceticism when that arises.

original: Evametā sekkhāsekkhānaṃ uppajjamānā imāsu bhūmīsu uppajjantīti bhūmidassanatthaṃ
analyzed: evam etā sekkhā sekkhānam uppajjamānāḥ imāsu bhūmīsu uppajjanti iti bhūmi dassana attham
translated: So when these are occurring in the learner and the adept, they occur in these planes.

original: ayaṃ nayo dassitoti.
analyzed: ayam nayaḥ dassito ti
translated: This is the method shown for the purpose of showing the planes.

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Abhidhamma.

original: 3. Pañhāpucchakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañhāpucchaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the questions

original: 747. Pañhāpucchake pāḷianusāreneva catunnaṃ paṭisambhidānaṃ kusalādibhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: pañhāpucchake pāḷi anusārena iva catunnam paṭisambhidānam kusala ādi bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: The four kinds of discrimination should be understood as profitable, etc., in accordance with the text of the questions.

original: Ārammaṇattikesu pana niruttipaṭisambhidā saddameva ārammaṇaṃ karotīti parittārammaṇā.
analyzed: ārammaṇa ttikesu pana nirutti paṭisambhidā saddam eva ārammaṇam karoti iti paritta ārammaṇā

analyzed: vuttehi terasahi tathā dutiya padena tatiya padena niyamita paññā vasena vuttehi dvādasahi iti  aṭṭhāsītiyā tikehi tika mātikā nikkhittā
translated: and with thirteen stated by way of limited understanding and with the second word of the “gladness” triad, and with twelve stated by way of limited understanding and with the third word of the “gladness” triad.

original: Catukkamātikā pana ‘kammassakatañāṇa’ntiādīhi ekavīsatiyā catukkehi, pañcakamātikā🔽dvīhi pañcakehi, chakkamātikā ekena chakkena, sattakamātikā “sattasattati ñāṇavatthūnī”ti
analyzed: catukka mātikā pana ekavīsatiyā catukkehi pañcaka mātikā  dvīhi pañcakehi chakka mātikā ekena chakkena sattaka mātikā satta sattati ñāṇa vatthūni iti
translated: The triad of tetrads is set out with twenty-one tetrads, that is to say, with “Knowledge of what is one’s own action” and so on.🔽The triad of pentads is set out with two pentads.🔽The triad of hexads is set out with one hexad.🔽The triad of septads is set out with eleven septads stated in brief thus “Seventy-seven instances of knowledge” .

original: evaṃ saṅkhepato vuttehi ekādasahi sattakehi, aṭṭhakamātikā ekena aṭṭhakena, navakamātikā ekena navakena.🔽10. Dasakamātikāvaṇṇanā🔽760. Dasakamātikā “dasa tathāgatassa tathāgatabalānī”tiādinā ekeneva dasakena nikkhittā.
analyzed: evam saṅkhepataḥ vuttehi ekādasahi sattakehi aṭṭhaka mātikā ekena aṭṭhakena navaka mātikā ekena navakena  dasaka mātikā vaṇṇanā  dasaka mātikā dasa tathāgatassa tathāgata balāni iti ādinā ekena iva dasakena nikkhittā
translated: The triad of octads is set out with one octad. The triad of nonads is set out with one nonad.🔽The triad of decades is set out with one decade stated thus “The Tathāgata has ten powers of a Tathāgata” .

original: Tattha dasāti gaṇanaparicchedo. Tathāgatassāti yathā vipassīādayo pubbakā isayo āgatā
analyzed: tattha dasā ati gaṇana paricchedo tathāgatassa ati yathā vipassī ādayo pubbakāḥ isayaḥ āgatā
translated: Herein, ten is a numeral. The Tathāgata’s is a possessive indication referring to the powers that are the Tathāgata’s.

original: tathā āgatassa; yathā ca te gatā tathā gatassa. Tathāgatabalānīti aññehi asādhāraṇāni
analyzed: tathā āgatassa yathā ca te gatā tathā gatassa tathāgata balāni iti aññehi asādhāraṇāni
translated: The powers of a Perfect One are powers not shared by others;

original: tathāgatasseva balāni; yathā vā pubbabuddhānaṃ balāni puññussayasampattiyā āgatāni
analyzed: tathāgatassa iva balāni yathā vā pubba buddhānam balāni puññussaya sampattiyāḥ āgatāni
translated: or else the meaning is that they are powers that have come in the way the powers of former Buddhas came, through the fulfilment of merit.

original: tathā āgatabalānītipi attho. Tattha duvidhaṃ tathāgatassa balaṃ – kāyabalañca ñāṇabalañca.
analyzed: tathā āgata balāni iti pi tattha duvidham tathāgatassa balam kāya balañca ñāṇa balañca
translated: Herein, the Perfect One’s power is of two kinds, that is to say, physical power and knowledge power.

original: Tesu kāyabalaṃ hatthikulānusāreneva veditabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ porāṇehi –
analyzed: tesu kāya balam hatthi kula anusārena iva veditabbam vuttam ha etam porāṇehi
translated: Herein, the physical power can be understood from the “Lineage of Elephant-Herders” . For this is said:

original: Kāḷāvakañca gaṅgeyyaṃ, paṇḍaraṃ tambapiṅgalaṃ;
analyzed: kāḷāvakam ca gaṅgeyyam paṇḍaram tamba piṅgalam
translated: The Kāḷāvaka, the Gaṅgeyya, The Paṇḍara, the Tambapiṅgala,

original: Gandhamaṅgalahemañca, uposathachaddantime dasāti. –
analyzed: gandha maṅgala hemañcaḥ uposatha chaddantime dasāti
translated: The Gandhamaṅgala, the Hemañca, The Uposatha, the Chaddantime, the Dasas.

original: Imāni hi dasa hatthikulāni.🔽Tattha ‘kāḷāvaka’nti pakatihatthikulaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yaṃ dasannaṃ purisānaṃ kāyabalaṃ
analyzed: imāni hi dasa hatthi kulāni  tattha kāḷāvakam ti pakati hatthi kulam daṭṭhabbam yam dasannam purisānam kāya balam
translated: These are the ten lineages of elephants.

original: taṃ ekassa kāḷāvakahatthino. Yaṃ dasannaṃ kāḷāvakānaṃ balaṃ taṃ ekassa gaṅgeyassa.
analyzed: tam ekassa kāḷāvaka hatthinaḥ yam dasannam kāḷāvakānam balam tam ekassa gaṅgeyassa
translated: Herein, the Kāḷāvaka should be regarded as the ordinary elephant lineage. The physical power of ten men is equal to that of one Kāḷāvaka elephant. The power of ten Kāḷāvakas is equal to that of one Gaṅgeyya elephant.

original: Yaṃ dasannaṃ gaṅgeyyānaṃ taṃ ekassa paṇḍarassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ paṇḍarānaṃ taṃ ekassa
analyzed: yam dasannam gaṅgeyyānam tam ekassa paṇḍarassa yam dasannam paṇḍarānam tam ekassa
translated: What is the strength of ten Ganges elephants is the strength of one Pāṇḍava elephant. What is the strength of ten Pāṇḍava elephants is the strength of one

original: tambassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ tambānaṃ taṃ ekassa piṅgalassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ piṅgalānaṃ taṃ🔽ekassa gandhahatthino. Yaṃ dasannaṃ gandhahatthīnaṃ taṃ ekassa maṅgalassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ
analyzed: tambassa yam dasannam tambānam tam ekassa piṅgalassa yam dasannam piṅgalānam tam  ekassa gandhahatthinaḥ yam dasannam gandhahatthīnam tam ekassa maṅgalassa yam dasannam
translated: Tambapaṇṇi elephant. What is the strength of ten Tambapaṇṇi elephants is the strength of one Piṅgala elephant. What is the strength of ten Piṅgala elephants is the strength of one🔽Gandhahastin elephant. What is the strength of ten Gandhahastin elephants is the strength of one Maṅgala elephant. What is the strength of ten Maṅgala elephants is the strength of one

original: maṅgalānaṃ taṃ ekassa hemavatassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ hemavatānaṃ taṃ ekassa uposathassa.
analyzed: maṅgalānam tam ekassa hemavatassa yam dasannam hemavatānam tam ekassa uposathassa
translated: Hemavat elephant. What is the strength of ten Hemavat elephants is the strength of one Uposatha elephant.

original: Yaṃ dasannaṃ uposathānaṃ taṃ ekassa chaddantassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ chaddantānaṃ taṃ ekassa🔽tathāgatassa. Nārāyanasaṅkhātabalantipi idameva vuccati. Tadetaṃ pakatihatthīnaṃ
analyzed: yam dasannam uposathānam tam ekassa chaddantassa yam dasannam chaddantānam tam ekassa  tathāgatassa nārāyana saṅkhāta balam ti pi idam eva vuccati tat etam pakati hatthīnam
translated: What is the strength of ten Uposatha elephants is the strength of one Chaddanta elephant. What is the strength of ten Chaddanta elephants is the strength of one

original: gaṇanāya hatthikoṭisahassānaṃ, purisagaṇanāya dasannaṃ purisakoṭisahassānaṃ balaṃ
analyzed: gaṇanāya hatthi koṭi sahassānam purisa gaṇanāya dasannam purisa koṭi sahassānam balam
translated: Tathāgata elephant. This is also called the strength of Nārāyaṇa. This is the strength of ten thousand elephants of the ordinary kind, which is the strength of one thousand men of the ordinary kind.

original: hoti. Idaṃ tāva tathāgatassa kāyabalaṃ.
analyzed: hoti idam tāva tathāgatassa kāya balam
translated: This is the physical strength of the Tathāgata.

original: Ñāṇabalaṃ pana idha tāva pāḷiyaṃ āgatameva dasabalañāṇaṃ. Mahāsīhanāde dasabalañāṇaṃ,
analyzed: ñāṇa balam pana idha tāva pāḷiyam āgatam eva dasa bala ñāṇam mahāsīhanāde dasa bala ñāṇam
translated: But the power of knowledge is the ten powers of knowledge given in the text here. The ten powers of knowledge given in the Mahā-Sihanāda Sutta,

original: catuvesārajjañāṇaṃ, aṭṭhasu parisāsu akampanañāṇaṃ, catuyoniparicchedakañāṇaṃ, pañcagatiparicchedakañāṇaṃ,🔽saṃyuttake āgatāni tesattati ñāṇāni, sattasattati ñāṇānīti evaṃ aññānipi anekāni
analyzed: catu vesārajja ñāṇam aṭṭhasu parisāsu akampana ñāṇam catu yoni paricchedaka ñāṇam pañca gati paricchedaka ñāṇam  saṃyuttake āgatāni tesattati ñāṇāni sattasattati ñāṇāni iti evam aññāni api anekāni
translated: the four kinds of fearlessness, the knowledge of being unmoved by eight worldly ideas, the knowledge of discerning the four castes, the knowledge of discerning the five destinies,🔽the seventy-three kinds of knowledge given in the Saṃyutta Nikāya, and other such kinds of knowledge,

original: ñāṇasahassāni – etaṃ ñāṇabalaṃ nāma. Idhāpi ñāṇabalameva adhippetaṃ ñāṇañhi akampiyaṭṭhena🔽upatthambhakaṭṭhena ca balanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ñāṇa sahassāni etam ñāṇa balam nāma idha api ñāṇa balam eva adhippetam ñāṇam hi a kampiya ṭṭhena  upatthambhaka ṭṭhena ca balan ti vuttam
translated: such as the many thousands of kinds of knowledge, are called the power of knowledge. Here too it is the power of knowledge that is intended. For knowledge is called “power” in the sense of being unshakable and in the sense of being a support.

original: Yehi balehi samannāgatoti yehi dasahi ñāṇabalehi upeto samupeto. Āsabhaṃ ṭhānanti
analyzed: yehi balehi samannāgato ti yehi dasahi ñāṇa balehi upeto samupetaḥ āsabham
translated: “Endowed with powers” : furnished, provided with, endowed with the ten powers of knowledge.

original: seṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ uttamaṭṭhānaṃ; āsabhā vā pubbabuddhā, tesaṃ ṭhānanti attho. Api ca
analyzed: seṭṭha ṭṭhānam uttama ṭṭhānam āsabhāḥ vā pubbabuddhā tesam ṭhānan ti atthaḥ api ca
translated: “The place of the mighty ones” : the place of the best, the place of the supreme. Or alternatively, the place of the mighty ones is the place of the former Buddhas.

original: gavasatajeṭṭhako usabho, gavasahassajeṭṭhako vasabho; vajasatajeṭṭhako vā usabho,
analyzed: gava sata jeṭṭhakaḥ usabhaḥ gava sahassa jeṭṭhakaḥ vasabhaḥ vaja sata jeṭṭhakaḥ vā usabhaḥ
translated: Moreover, the bull is the chief of a hundred cows, the vasabha is the chief of a thousand cows, and the usabha is the chief of a hundred bulls.

original: vajasahassajeṭṭhako vasabho; sabbagavaseṭṭho sabbaparissayasaho seto pāsādiko mahābhāravaho
analyzed: vaja sahassa jeṭṭhakaḥ vasabhaḥ sabbagavaseṭṭhaḥ sabba parissaya sahaḥ setaḥ pāsādikaḥ mahā bhāra vahaḥ
translated: The bull is the chief of a thousand bulls, the best of all cattle, able to endure all hardships, white, inspiring confidence, bearing a great load.

original: asanisatasaddehipi akampanīyo nisabho. So idha usabhoti adhippeto. Idampi hi tassa🔽pariyāyavacanaṃ. Usabhassa idanti āsabhaṃ. Ṭhānanti catūhi pādehi pathaviṃ uppīḷetvā
analyzed: a sani sata saddehi pi a kampanīyaḥ nisabhaḥ saḥ idha usabhaḥ ti adhippetaḥ idam pi hi tassa  pariyāya vacanam usabhassa idam ti āsabham ṭhānam ti catūhi pādehi pathavim uppīḍetvā
translated: He is unshakable even by the sound of a hundred thunderclaps. He is the bull. He is intended here. For this is🔽a figurative expression for him. The place of the bull is āsabhaṃ. Ṭhāna means a place that is unshakable,

original: acalaṭṭhānaṃ. Idaṃ pana āsabhaṃ viyāti āsabhaṃ. Yatheva hi nisabhasaṅkhāto usabho
analyzed: acala ṭṭhānam idam pana āsabham viyāti āsabham yathā iva hi nisabha saṅkhātaḥ usabhaḥ
translated: having pressed down on the earth with its four feet. But this is like the place of the bull, thus it is āsabhaṃ. For just as the bull called the bull,

original: usabhabalena samannāgato catūhi pādehi pathaviṃ uppīḷetvā acalaṭṭhānena tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: usabha balena samannāgataḥ catūhi pādehi pathavim uppīḍetvā acala ṭṭhānena tiṭṭhati
translated: endowed with the strength of a bull, stands in an unshakable place, having pressed down on the earth with its four feet,

original: evaṃ tathāgatopi dasahi tathāgatabalehi samannāgato catūhi vesārajjapādehi aṭṭhaparisapathaviṃ
analyzed: evam tathāgataḥ api dasahi tathāgata balehi samannāgataḥ catūhi vesārajja pādehi aṭṭha parisa pathavim
translated: so too the Tathāgata, endowed with the ten Tathāgata powers, having pressed down on the earth of the assembly of the four assemblies with the four grounds of self-confidence,

original: uppīḷetvā sadevake loke kenaci paccatthikena paccāmittena akampiyo acalaṭṭhānena
analyzed: uppīḍetvā sa devake loke kenaci paccatthikena pacca amittena akampiyaḥ acala ṭṭhānena
translated: stands in an unshakable place, unshakable by any opponent or rival in the world with its gods.

original: tiṭṭhati. Evaṃ tiṭṭhamāno ca taṃ āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, upagacchati, na paccakkhāti,
analyzed: tiṭṭhati evam tiṭṭhamāno ca tam āsabham ṭhānam paṭijānāti upagacchati na paccakkhāti
translated: Standing thus, he acknowledges, accepts, and does not deny that place of the bull.

original: attani āropeti. Tena vuttaṃ “āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānātī”ti.
analyzed: attani āropeti tena vuttam āsabham ṭhānam paṭijānāti iti
translated: he has raised himself up. Hence it is said: “He claims the place of the chief bull.”🔽In the assemblies: in the eight assemblies.

original: Parisāsūti aṭṭhasu parisāsu. Sīhanādaṃ nadatīti seṭṭhanādaṃ abhītanādaṃ nadati, sīhanādasadisaṃ🔽vā nādaṃ nadati. Ayamattho sīhanādasuttena dīpetabbo. Yathā vā sīho sahanato ca hananato
analyzed: parisāsu iti aṭṭhasu parisāsu sīha nādam nadati iti seṭṭha nādam abhīta nādam nadati sīha nāda sadisam  vā nādam nadati ayam atthaḥ sīhanāda suttena dīpetabbaḥ yathā vā sīhaḥ sahanataḥ ca hananataḥ
translated: He roars his lion’s roar: he utters his supreme roar, his fearless roar. Or else he utters a roar similar to a lion’s roar.🔽This meaning should be illustrated by the Lion’s Roar Discourse .

original: ca sīhoti vuccati, evaṃ tathāgato lokadhammānaṃ sahanato parappavādānañca hananato🔽sīhoti vuccati. Evaṃ vuttassa sīhassa nādaṃ sīhanādaṃ. Tattha yathā sīho sīhabalena
analyzed: ca sīhaḥ ti vuccati evam tathāgataḥ loka dhammānam sahanataḥ para ppavādānam ca hananataḥ  sīhaḥ iti vuccati evam vuttassa sīhassa nādam sīha nādam tattha yathā sīhaḥ sīha balena
translated: Or just as a lion is called a lion because he endures and kills, so the Tathāgata is called a lion because he endures the worldly states and kills opposing doctrines.

original: samannāgato sabbattha visārado vigatalomahaṃso sīhanādaṃ nadati, evaṃ tathāgatasīhopi
analyzed: samannāgataḥ sabbattha visāradaḥ vigata loma haṃsaḥ sīha nādam nadati evam tathāgata sīhaḥ pi
translated: The roar of such a lion is a lion’s roar. Therein, just as a lion endowed with the strength of a lion is confident everywhere, his hair bristling in delight, and he roars his lion’s roar, so the Tathāgata-lion, too,

original: tathāgatabalehi samannāgato aṭṭhasu parisāsu visārado vigatalomahaṃso “iti rūpa”ntiādinā
analyzed: tathāgata balehi samannāgataḥ aṭṭhasu parisāsu visāradaḥ vigata lomahaṃsaḥ iti
translated: endowed with the Tathāgata’s powers, is confident in the eight assemblies, his hair bristling in delight, and he roars his lion’s roar, which is endowed with the grace of various kinds of teachings, beginning with “This is suffering.”

original: nayena nānāvidhadesanāvilāsasampannaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati. Tena vuttaṃ “parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadatī”ti.
analyzed: nayena nānāvidha desanā vilāsa sampannam sīha nādam nadati tena vuttam parisāsu sīha nādam nadati iti
translated: Hence it is said: “He roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies.”

original: Brahmacakkaṃ pavattetīti ettha brahmanti seṭṭhaṃ uttamaṃ visuddhaṃ. Cakkasaddo ca panāyaṃ –
analyzed: brahma cakkam pavatteti iti ettha brahmanti seṭṭham uttamam visuddham cakka saddo ca pana ayam
translated: He sets in motion the Wheel of the Dhamma: here, “Brahma” is the best, the highest, the purified. And this word “wheel” is found in the following senses:

original: Sampattiyaṃ lakkhaṇe ca, rathaṅge iriyāpathe;
analyzed: sampattiyam lakkhaṇe ca rathaṅge iriyāpathe
translated: In excellence, in a mark, in a chariot-part, in a posture,

original: Dāne ratanadhammūra, cakkādīsu ca dissati;
analyzed: dāne ca dissati
translated: In giving, in a jewel, in a doctrine, in a wheel, and so on.

original: Dhammacakke idha mato, tañca dvedhā vibhāvaye.
analyzed: dhammacakke idha mataḥ tat ca dvedhā vibhāvaye
translated: It is held to be in the Dhamma wheel here, and that is twofold.

original: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, cakkāni yehi samannāgatānaṃ devamanussāna”ntiādīsu hi ayaṃ🔽sampattiyaṃ dissati. “Heṭṭhā pādatalesu cakkāni jātānī”ti ettha lakkhaṇe. “Cakkaṃva🔽vahato pada”nti ettha rathaṅge. “Catucakkaṃ navadvāra”nti ettha iriyāpathe. “Dadaṃ🔽bhuñja mā ca pamādo, cakkaṃ pavattaya sabbapāṇina”nti ettha dāne. “Dibbaṃ cakkaratanaṃ
analyzed: cattāri imāni bhikkhave cakkāni yehi samannāgatānam deva manussānam ti ādīsu hi ayam  sampattiyam dissati heṭṭhā pāda talesu cakkāni jātāni iti ettha lakkhaṇe cakkaṃ va  vahataḥ ettha rathaṅge catu cakkam nava dvāranti ettha iriyāpathe  bhuñja mā ca pamādo cakkam pavattaya sabba pāṇinan ti ettha dāne dibbam cakka ratanam
translated: For in such passages as “Bhikkhus, there are these four wheels, possessed with which the devas and humans are subject to gradual change” ,

original: pāturahosī”ti ettha ratanacakke. “Mayā pavattitaṃ cakka”nti ettha dhammacakke. “Icchāhatassa
analyzed: pātuḥ ahosi iti ettha ratana cakke mayā pavattitam cakkam ti ettha dhamma cakke icchā hatassa
translated: it is found in the sense of excellence. In the passage “The wheels appeared on the soles of his feet” , it is in the sense of a mark. In the passage “The wheel-marks on the soles of his feet” , it is in the sense of a chariot-part. In the passage “The wheel-marks on the soles of his feet” , it is in the sense of a posture. In the passage “Giving, enjoy, and do not be negligent, Set the wheel rolling for all beings” , it is in the sense of giving. In the passage “The divine wheel-gem appeared” , it is in the sense of a jewel-wheel. In the passage “The wheel has been set rolling” , it is in the sense of the Dhamma wheel. In the passage “The wheel-gem disappeared” , it is in the sense of a wheel.🔽In the passage “The wheel-gem disappeared” , it is in the sense of a wheel.

original: posassa cakkaṃ bhamati matthake”ti ettha uracakke. “Khurapariyantena cepi cakkenā”ti🔽ettha paharaṇacakke. “Asanivicakka”nti ettha asanimaṇḍale. Idha panāyaṃ dhammacakke mato.
analyzed: posassa cakkam bhamati matthake iti ettha ura cakke khura pariyantena cepi cakkena ati  ettha paharaṇa cakke ettha asani maṇḍale idha pana ayam dhamma cakke mataḥ
translated: and the wheel of the True Idea turns for him on the head.🔽Here it is a wheel of the True Idea.

original: Taṃ pana dhammacakkaṃ duvidhaṃ hoti – paṭivedhañāṇañca desanāñāṇañca. Tattha paññāpabhāvitaṃ
analyzed: tam pana dhamma cakkam duvidham hoti paṭivedha ñāṇam ca desanā ñāṇam ca tattha paññā apabhāvitam
translated: But that wheel of the True Idea is of two kinds, namely, as knowledge of penetration and as knowledge of teaching. Herein, knowledge of penetration is that which is manifested by understanding and which brings about the noble fruitions in oneself.

original: attano ariyaphalāvahaṃ paṭivedhañāṇaṃ; karuṇāpabhāvitaṃ sāvakānaṃ ariyaphalāvahaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ ariya phala āvaham paṭivedha ñāṇam karuṇā pabhāvitam sāvakānam ariya phala āvaham
translated: Knowledge of teaching is that which is manifested by compassion and which brings about the noble fruitions in disciples.

original: desanāñāṇaṃ. Tattha paṭivedhañāṇaṃ uppajjamānaṃ uppannanti duvidhaṃ. Tañhi abhinikkhamanato🔽yāva arahattamaggā uppajjamānaṃ, phalakkhaṇe uppannaṃ nāma; tusitabhavanato vā yāva
analyzed: desanā ñāṇam tattha paṭivedha ñāṇam uppajjamānam uppannanti duvidham tat hi abhinikkhamanato  yāva arahatta maggā uppajjamānam phala kkhaṇe uppannam nāma tusita bhavanataḥ vā yāva
translated: Herein, knowledge of penetration is of two kinds, namely, as occurring and as arisen. For that is called ‘ occurring ‘ from the time of going forth until the path of arahantship,🔽and it is called ‘ arisen ‘ at the moment of fruition. Or alternatively, it is called ‘ occurring ‘ from the time of the Tusita heaven down to the Great Enlightenment Tree seat and the path of arahantship,

original: mahābodhipallaṅke arahattamaggā uppajjamānaṃ, phalakkhaṇe uppannaṃ nāma; dīpaṅkarabyākaraṇato
analyzed: mahā bodhi pallaṅke arahatta maggā uppajjamānam phala kkhaṇe uppannam nāma dīpaṅkara byākaraṇato
translated: and it is called ‘ arisen ‘ at the moment of fruition. From the time of the prophecy by Dīpaṅkara,

original: paṭṭhāya vā yāva arahattamaggā uppajjamānaṃ, phalakkhaṇe uppannaṃ nāma. Desanāñāṇampi
analyzed: paṭṭhāya vā yāva arahatta maggā uppajjamānam phala kkhaṇe uppannam nāma desanā ñāṇam pi
translated: Or it is called “arisen” when it arises from the path of arahatship onwards and at the moment of its fruit.

original: pavattamānaṃ pavattanti duvidhaṃ. Tañhi yāva aññākoṇḍaññassa sotāpattimaggā pavattamānaṃ,
analyzed: pavattamānam pavattanti duvidham tat hi yāva aññākoṇḍaññassa sotāpatti maggā pavattamānam
translated: The knowledge of teaching is of two kinds as occurring and as occurred. For that is called “occurring” when it occurs up to the time of Aññā Koṇḍañña’s path of stream-entry,🔽and it is called “occurred” at the moment of its fruit.

original: phalakkhaṇe pavattaṃ nāma. Tesu paṭivedhañāṇaṃ lokuttaraṃ, desanāñāṇaṃ lokiyaṃ. Ubhayampi
analyzed: phala kkhaṇe pavattam nāma tesu paṭivedha ñāṇam lokuttaram desanā ñāṇam lokiyam ubhayam pi
translated: Of these, the penetration knowledge is supramundane, and the knowledge of teaching is mundane.

original: panetaṃ aññehi asādhāraṇaṃ buddhānaṃyeva orasañāṇaṃ.🔽Idāni yehi dasahi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, yāni āditova
analyzed: pana itam aññehi asādhāraṇam buddhānam yeva orasa ñāṇam  idāni yehi dasahi balehi samannāgataḥ tathāgataḥ āsabham ṭhānam paṭijānāti yāni āditas uva
translated: But both are the special knowledge of Buddhas, not shared by others.

original: “dasa tathāgatassa tathāgatabalānī”ti nikkhittāni, tāni vitthārato dassetuṃ katamāni🔽dasa? Idha tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānatotiādimāha. Tattha ṭhānañca ṭhānatoti kāraṇañca
analyzed: dasa tathāgatassa tathāgata balāni iti nikkhittāni tāni vitthārataḥ dassetum katamāni  dasa idha tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato ti ādim āha tattha ṭhānañca ṭhānato ti kāraṇañca
translated: Now, the ten powers with which the Tathāgata claims the herd-leader’s place and roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and which are stated thus: “The Tathāgata is possessed of the Tathāgata’s ten powers. Possessed of these ten powers, the Tathāgata claims the herd-leader’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and sets rolling the Wheel of Brahmā” ,🔽are now shown in detail.

original: kāraṇato. Kāraṇañhi yasmā tattha phalaṃ tiṭṭhati tadāyattavuttitāya uppajjati ceva
analyzed: kāraṇato kāraṇam hi yasmā tattha phalam tiṭṭhati tad āyatta vutti tāya uppajjati ca iva
translated: What are the ten? Here the Tathāgata understands as it actually is: “Herein, ‘Ground and non-ground’ is ‘Cause and non-cause.’ For a fruit is called ‘ground’ because it stands there, and it arises there because of its dependence on that.

original: pavattati ca, tasmā ṭhānanti vuccati. Taṃ bhagavā “ye ye dhammā yesaṃ yesaṃ dhammānaṃ🔽hetū paccayā uppādāya taṃ taṃ ṭhāna”nti ca ‘ye ye dhammā yesaṃ yesaṃ dhammānaṃ na
analyzed: pavattati ca tasmā ṭhānam ti vuccati tam bhagavā ye ye dhammāḥ yesam yesam dhammānam  hetū paccayā uppādāya tam tam ṭhānam ti ca ye ye dhammā yesam yesam dhammānam na
translated: and it occurs, thus it is called a ‘ground.’ The Blessed One said: ‘Whatever is the cause, whatever is the condition, for the arising of a thing, from that very cause, from that very condition, that thing arises. Whatever is the cause, whatever is the condition, for the cessation of a thing, from the cessation of that very cause, from the cessation of that very condition, that thing ceases.’

original: hetū na paccayā uppādāya taṃ taṃ aṭṭhāna’nti ca pajānanto ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca
analyzed: hetū na paccayā uppādāya tam tam aṭṭhānanti ca pajānantaḥ ṭhānam ca ṭhānataḥ aṭṭhānañca
translated: and it occurs, thus it is called a ground. The Blessed One understands that any ideas that are the cause and condition for the arising of any ideas are a ground for those ideas, and that any ideas that are not the cause and condition for the arising of any ideas are not a ground for those ideas. So he understands grounds as grounds and nongrounds as nongrounds.

original: aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. Yampīti yena ñāṇena. Idampi tathāgatassāti idampi
analyzed: aṭṭhānataḥ yathābhūtam pajānāti yam pi iti yena ñāṇena idam pi tathāgatassa ati idam pi
translated: And by this knowledge: by this knowledge of grounds and nongrounds. This too is a Tathagata’s power,

original: ṭhānāṭṭhānañāṇaṃ tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ nāma hotīti attho. Evaṃ sabbapadesu yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: ṭhānāṭṭhāna ñāṇam tathāgatassa tathāgata balam nāma hoti iti atthaḥ evam sabba padesu yojanā veditabbā
translated: meaning that this knowledge of grounds and nongrounds is a Tathagata’s power in the case of a Tathagata. The construction should be understood in each case.

original: Kammasamādānānanti samādiyitvā katānaṃ kusalākusalakammānaṃ; kammameva vā kammasamādānaṃ.
analyzed: kamma samādānānam ti samādiyitvā katānam kusala akusala kammānam kammam eva vā kamma samādānam
translated: As to undertaking of action: as to profitable and unprofitable actions undertaken after being undertaken; or else the undertaking of action is action itself.

original: Ṭhānaso hetusoti paccayato ceva hetuto ca. Tattha gatiupadhikālapayogā vipākassa
analyzed: ṭhānaso hetuso ti paccayato ca iva hetuto ca tattha gati upadhi kāla payogāḥ vipākassa
translated: As to the way and as to cause: as to the way and as to the cause. Herein, the destiny, the life period, the province, and the application are the way for the result of action;

original: ṭhānaṃ, kammaṃ hetu.
analyzed: ṭhānam kammam hetu
translated: action is the cause.

original: Sabbattha gāmininti sabbagatigāminiñca agatigāminiñca. Paṭipadanti maggaṃ. Yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: sabbattha gāminin ti sabba gati gāminin ca agati gāminin ca paṭipadanti maggam yathābhūtam
translated: “In all ways” means in all destinations and in the non-destination. “Path” means the path.

original: pajānātīti bahūsupi manussesu ekameva pāṇaṃ ghātentesu ‘imassa cetanā nirayagāminī🔽bhavissati, imassa tiracchānayonigāminī’ti iminā nayena ekavatthusmimpi kusalākusalacetanāsaṅkhātānaṃ
analyzed: pajānāti iti bahūsu pi manussesu ekam eva pāṇam ghātentesu imassa cetanā niraya gāminī  bhavissati imassa tiracchānayoni gāminī iti iminā nayena eka vatthusmim pi kusala akusala cetanā saṅkhātānam
translated: “He understands as they really are”: in the case of many people killing a living being, he understands as they really are the individual volitions of each one, which are the causes for rebirth in hell or as an animal, etc.

original: paṭipattīnaṃ aviparītato sabhāvaṃ pajānāti.🔽Anekadhātunti cakkhudhātuādīhi kāmadhātuādīhi vā dhātūhi bahudhātuṃ. Nānādhātunti
analyzed: paṭipattīnam a viparītataḥ sabhāvam pajānāti  aneka dhātum ti cakkhu dhātu ādīhi kāmadhātu ādīhi vā dhātūhi bahu dhātum nānā dhātum ti
translated: In this way, he understands as they really are the individual wholesome and unwholesome volitions, which are the causes for rebirth in the different destinations.

original: tāsaṃyeva dhātūnaṃ vilakkhaṇatāya nānappakāradhātuṃ. Lokanti khandhāyatanadhātulokaṃ.
analyzed: tāsam yeva dhātūnam vilakkhaṇa tāya nānā pakāra dhātum khandha āyatana dhātu lokam
translated: “The manifold elements”: the manifold elements of the eye, etc., or the elements of the sense-desire realm, etc. “The various elements”: the various elements of the eye, etc., which are different in their characteristics. “The world”: the world of aggregates, bases, and elements.

original: Yathābhūtaṃ pajānātīti tāsaṃ tāsaṃ dhātūnaṃ aviparītato sabhāvaṃ paṭivijjhati.
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti iti tāsam tāsam dhātūnam a viparītataḥ sabhāvam paṭivijjhati
translated: “He understands as they really are”: he penetrates the individual natures of the various elements without confusion.

original: Nānādhimuttikatanti hīnādīhi adhimuttīhi nānādhimuttikabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: nānā adhimuttika tanti hīna ādīhi adhimuttīhi nānā adhimuttika bhāvam
translated: “The many and varied elements of aspiration”: the many and varied aspirations for the inferior, etc.

original: Parasattānanti padhānasattānaṃ. Parapuggalānanti tato paresaṃ hīnasattānaṃ; ekatthameva🔽vā etaṃ padadvayaṃ veneyyavasena pana dvedhā vuttaṃ. Indriyaparopariyattanti saddhādīnaṃ
analyzed: para sattānam ti padhāna sattānam para puggalānam ti tatas paresam hīna sattānam ekattham eva  vā etam pada dvayam veneyya vasena pana dvedhā vuttam saddhā ādīnam
translated: “The minds of other beings”: the minds of beings of the same level as oneself. “The hearts of other persons”: the minds of other beings of lower kinds. But these two terms have the same meaning.

original: indriyānaṃ parabhāvañca aparabhāvañca vuḍḍhiñca hāniñcāti attho.🔽Jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnanti paṭhamādīnaṃ catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ, “rūpī rūpāni passatī”tiādīnaṃ🔽aṭṭhannaṃ vimokkhānaṃ, savitakkasavicārādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ samādhīnaṃ, paṭhamajjhānasamāpattiādīnañca
analyzed: indriyānam para bhāvañca apara bhāvañca vuḍḍhiñca hāniñca ati attho  jhāna vimokkha samādhi samāpattīnam ti paṭhama ādīnam catunnam jhānānam rūpī rūpāni passati itiādīnam  aṭṭhannam vimokkhānam sa vitakka sa vicāra ādīnam tiṇṇam samādhīnam paṭhama jhāna samāpatti ādīnam ca
translated: “The higher and lower faculties of others”: the meaning is: the higher and lower faculties of faith, etc., of others.🔽“The penetrations”: the four noble truths. “The attainment of the various jhānas, liberations, concentrations, and meditational attainments”: the four jhānas beginning with the first, the eight liberations beginning with “possessing form, he sees forms” , the three concentrations beginning with “accompanied by thought and examination” , and the nine successive cessations beginning with the attainment of the first jhāna.

original: navannaṃ anupubbasamāpattīnaṃ. Saṃkilesanti hānabhāgiyadhammaṃ. Vodānanti visesabhāgiyadhammaṃ.
analyzed: navannam anupubba samāpattīnam saṃkilesanti hāna bhāgiya dhammam vodānanti visesa bhāgiya dhammam
translated: “The defilement and purification of these states”: the states that lead to decline and the states that lead to distinction.

original: Vuṭṭhānanti yena kāraṇena jhānādīhi vuṭṭhahanti, taṃ kāraṇaṃ.🔽Pubbenivāsānussatinti pubbe nivutthakkhandhānussaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: vuṭṭhānam ti yena kāraṇena jhāna ādīhi vuṭṭhahanti tam kāraṇam  pubbenivāsa anussatim ti pubbe nivuttha kkhandha anussaraṇam
translated: “The emergence from these states”: the reason for emerging from the jhānas, etc.🔽“The recollection of past abodes”: the recollection of past aggregates that existed in the past.

original: Cutūpapātanti cutiñca upapātañca.
analyzed: cutūpapātanti cutiñca upapātañca
translated: “The knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings”: the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

original: Āsavānaṃ khayanti kāmāsavādīnaṃ khayasaṅkhātaṃ āsavanirodhaṃ nibbānaṃ.
analyzed: āsavānam khayanti kāma āsava ādīnam khaya saṅkhātam āsava nirodham nibbānam
translated: “The destruction of cankers”: Nibbāna, which is called the “destruction” of the cankers beginning with sensuality.🔽“These”: the ten powers of a Tathāgata mentioned above.

original: Imānīti yāni heṭṭhā “dasa tathāgatassa tathāgatabalānī”ti avoca, imāni tānīti appanaṃ
analyzed: imāni iti yāni heṭṭhā dasa tathāgatassa tathāgata balāni iti avoca imāni tāni iti appanam
translated: “He has”: he makes them his object.

original: karotīti. Evamettha anupubbapadavaṇṇanaṃ ñatvā idāni yasmā tathāgato paṭhamaṃyeva🔽ṭhānāṭṭhānañāṇena veneyyasattānaṃ āsavakkhayādhigamassa ceva anadhigamassa ca ṭhānāṭṭhānabhūtaṃ
analyzed: karoti iti evam ettha anupubba pada vaṇṇanam ñatvā idāni yasmai tathāgataḥ  ṭhāna aṭṭhāna ñāṇena veneyya sattānam āsava kkhaya adhigamassa ca iva anadhigamassa ca ṭhāna aṭṭhāna bhūtam
translated: Having understood the explanation of the words in this way, we shall now comment on the meaning.🔽The Tathāgata first sees, by means of the knowledge of the possible and impossible, the absence of the defilement-hindrance, which is the possible and impossible in regard to the attainment of the destruction of the cankers in the case of beings who are his disciples.

original: kilesāvaraṇābhāvaṃ passati, lokiyasammādiṭṭhiṭhānadassanato niyatamicchādiṭṭhiṭhānābhāvadassanato
analyzed: kilesa āvaraṇa abhāvam passati lokiya sammādiṭṭhi ṭhāna dassanataḥ niyatam icchādiṭṭhi ṭhāna abhāva dassanataḥ
translated: He sees the absence of the possible and impossible in regard to the attainment of the destruction of the cankers in the case of beings who are not his disciples.

original: ca. Atha nesaṃ kammavipākañāṇena vipākāvaraṇābhāvaṃ passati, tihetukapaṭisandhidassanato.
analyzed: ca atha nesam kamma vipāka ñāṇena vipāka āvaraṇa abhāvam passati ti hetuka paṭisandhi dassanato
translated: Then he sees, by means of knowledge of the kamma-result, the absence of the kamma-result-hindrance, because he sees the rebirth-linking of the three roots of unprofit.

original: Sabbatthagāminīpaṭipadāñāṇena kammāvaraṇābhāvaṃ passati, ānantariyakammābhāvadassanato.
analyzed: sabbattha gāminī paṭipadā ñāṇena kamma āvaraṇa abhāvam passati ānantariya kamma abhāva dassanato
translated: He sees the absence of the kamma-hindrance, by means of knowledge of the way leading to the cessation of the suffering of the round, because he sees the absence of the ten courses of kamma that are immediately ripening.

original: Evaṃ anāvaraṇānaṃ anekadhātunānādhātuñāṇena anukūladhammadesanatthaṃ cariyāvisesaṃ
analyzed: evam anāvaraṇānam aneka dhātu nānā dhātu ñāṇena anukūla dhamma desana ttham cariyā visesam
translated: Thus, by means of knowledge of the diversity of elements, he sees the diversity of inclinations in those who are free from hindrances, in order to teach them the Dhamma in accordance with their inclinations.

original: passati, dhātuvemattadassanato. Atha nesaṃ nānādhimuttikatāñāṇena adhimuttiṃ passati,
analyzed: passati dhātu vematta dassanataḥ atha nesam nānā adhimuttika tā ñāṇena adhimuttim passati
translated: he sees their diversity of elements. Then he sees their different persuasions by means of knowledge of their different persuasions,

original: payogaṃ anādiyitvāpi adhimuttivasena dhammadesanatthaṃ. Athevaṃ diṭṭhādhimuttīnaṃ
analyzed: payogam an ādiyitvā api adhimutti vasena dhamma desana attham atha ivam diṭṭha adhimuttīnam
translated: without taking their practice into account, for the purpose of teaching them the Dhamma according to their persuasions. Then, having seen their views and persuasions,🔽he sees their different aptitudes by means of knowledge of the disposition of creatures’ faculties,

original: yathāsatti yathābalaṃ dhammaṃ desetuṃ indriyaparopariyattañāṇena indriyaparopariyattaṃ🔽passati, saddhādīnaṃ tikkhamudubhāvadassanato. Evaṃ pariññātindriyaparopariyattāpi
analyzed: yathāsatti yathābalam dhammam desetum indriya paropariyatta ñāṇena indriya paropariyattam  passati saddhā ādīnam tikkha mudu bhāva dassanataḥ evam
translated: for the purpose of teaching them the Dhamma according to their capacity and strength. Having thus seen their faculties and aptitudes,

original: panete sace dūre honti, atha jhānādipariññāṇena jhānādīsu vasībhūtattā iddhivisesena
analyzed: pana ete sace dūre honti atha jhāna ādi pariññāṇena jhāna ādīsu vasībhūta ttā iddhi visesena
translated: if they are far away, then he goes to them quickly by means of the various kinds of supernormal power, which is achieved by the development of the jhānas, etc.,

original: khippaṃ upagacchati. Upagantvā ca nesaṃ pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇena pubbajātibhāvanaṃ,🔽dibbacakkhānubhāvato pattabbena cetopariyañāṇena sampatticittavisesaṃ passanto āsavakkhayañāṇānubhāvena
analyzed: khippam upagacchati upagantvā ca nesam pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇena pubba jāti bhāvanam  dibba cakkha anubhāvataḥ pattabbena cetaḥ pariya ñāṇena sampatti citta visesam passantaḥ āsava kkhaya ñāṇa anubhāvena
translated: and having gone, he sees their state of development in a previous birth by means of knowledge of previous existences,

original: āsavakkhayagāminiyā paṭipadāya vigatasammohattā āsavakkhayāya dhammaṃ deseti. Tasmā
analyzed: āsava khaya gāminiyā paṭipadāya vigata sammoha ttā āsava kkhayāya dhammam deseti tasmā
translated: and he sees the particular state of mind that is capable of being attained by means of knowledge of the divine eye, and he teaches them the Dhamma leading to the destruction of the defilements, being himself free from delusion as to the way leading to the destruction of the defilements by means of knowledge of the destruction of the defilements. Therefore it is said:

original: iminā anukkamena imāni dasabalāni vuttānīti veditabbāni. Ayaṃ tāva mātikāya atthavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: iminā anukkamena imāni dasa balāni vuttāni iti veditabbāni ayam tāva mātikāya attha vaṇṇanā
translated: So it should be understood that these ten powers are stated in this order. This, firstly, is the commentary on the letter-enumerate d section of the mātikā.

original: (1.) Ekakaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: 1.1. The exposition of the single terms

original: 761. Idāni yathānikkhittāya mātikāya “pañcaviññāṇā na hetumevā”tiādinā nayena āraddhe🔽niddesavāre na hetumevāti sādhāraṇahetupaṭikkhepaniddeso. Tattha “hetuhetu, paccayahetu,
analyzed: idāni yathā nikkhittāya mātikāya pañca viññāṇāḥ na hetum eva ati ādinā nayena āraddhe  niddesa vāre na hetum eva ti sādhāraṇa hetu paṭikkhepa niddesaḥ tattha hetu hetu paccaya hetu
translated: Now, in the case of the mātikā as set out in the way beginning, “The five kinds of consciousness are not a condition, etc.,”🔽in the exposition section, “They are not a condition, etc.,” is the exposition of the denial of a common condition. Herein, “There are four kinds of conditions, namely, root-cause condition, decisive-support condition,

original: uttamahetu, sādhāraṇahetūti catubbidho hetū”tiādinā nayena yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ
analyzed: uttama hetu sādhāraṇa hetū iti catubbidhaḥ hetu uti ādinā nayena yam vattabbam siyā tam
translated: foremost-state condition, and common condition” , and so on, and whatever else should be said here,🔽all that has been said already in the Description of the Root-Cause Mode in the passage beginning, “All materiality is not a root-cause” .

original: sabbaṃ rūpakaṇḍe “sabbaṃ rūpaṃ na hetumevā”tiādīnaṃ atthavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttameva. Ahetukamevātiādīsu
analyzed: sabbam rūpa kaṇḍe sabbam rūpam na hetum eva ati ādīnam attha vaṇṇanāyam vuttam eva ahetukam eva ati ādīsu
translated: In the case of the terms “They are not root-causes, etc.,”

original: byañjanasandhivasena makāro veditabbo; ahetukā evāti attho. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: byañjana sandhi vasena makāraḥ veditabbaḥ ahetukā evā ti attho sesa padesu pi esa iva nayo
translated: the letter m should be understood as a ligature; the meaning is: they are not root-causes. The same method of explanation applies in the other cases.

original: Apica “hetū dhammā nahetū dhammā”tiādīsu dhammakoṭṭhāsesu pañcaviññāṇāni hetū dhammāti
analyzed: apica hetū dhammā na hetū dhammā ti ādīsu dhammakoṭṭhāsesu pañca viññāṇāni hetū dhammā ti
translated: Besides, in the cases of the terms “Ideas that are root-causes, ideas that are not root-causes,” etc., the five kinds of consciousness are ideas that are not root-causes,

original: vā sahetukā dhammāti vā na honti. Ekantena pana na hetūyeva, ahetukā yevāti imānipi
analyzed: vā sa hetukāḥ dhammā ati vā na honti ekantena pana na ahetukāḥ yeva ati imāni pi
translated: or as having a cause, or as not having a cause. But they are exclusively not causes, and they are exclusively without a cause.🔽In this way the meaning should be understood in all the terms.

original: nayenettha sabbapadesu attho veditabbo. Abyākatamevāti padaṃ vipākābyākatavasena🔽vuttaṃ. Sārammaṇamevāti olubbhārammaṇavasena. Paccayārammaṇaṃ olubbhārammaṇanti hi
analyzed: nayena ittha sabba padesu atthaḥ veditabbaḥ abyākatam evā ti padam vipāka abyākata vasena  vuttam sa ārammaṇam eva ati olubbha ārammaṇa vasena paccaya ārammaṇam olubbha ārammaṇanti hi
translated: The term “indeterminate” is stated in the sense of the indeterminate resultants.🔽“With object” means with an object that is a condition.🔽For there are two kinds of object: the object that is a condition and the object that is not a condition.

original: duvidhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne olubbhārammaṇameva dhuraṃ, paccayārammaṇampi
analyzed: duvidham ārammaṇam imasmim pana ṭhāne olubbha ārammaṇam eva dhuram paccaya ārammaṇam pi
translated: But in this context the object that is a condition is the principal one, while the object that is not a condition is also found.

original: labbhatiyeva. Acetasikamevāti padaṃ cittaṃ, rūpaṃ, nibbānanti tīsu acetasikesu cittameva
analyzed: acetasikam eva ati padam cittam rūpam nibbānam tīsu acetasikesu cittam eva
translated: The term “without consciousness” is stated with reference to the consciousness among the three kinds of things that are without consciousness, namely, consciousness, materiality, and Nibbāna.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. No apariyāpannamevāti gatipariyāpannacutipariyāpannasaṃsāravaṭṭabhavapariyāpannabhāvato
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam no a pariyāpannam eva iti gati pariyāpanna cuti pariyāpanna saṃsāra vaṭṭa bhava pariyāpanna bhāvato
translated: “Not included” means included in the destiny, included in death, included in the round of existence, included in the round of rebirths, included in the round of becoming.

original: pariyāpannā eva, no apariyāpannā. Lokato vaṭṭato na niyyantīti aniyyānikā. Uppannaṃ
analyzed: pariyāpannāḥ eva no a pariyāpannāḥ lokataḥ vaṭṭataḥ na niyyanti iti aniyyānikā uppannam
translated: They are included, not not included. They do not go beyond the world, they do not go beyond the round of existence. Thus they are not beyond the world, not beyond the round of existence.

original: manoviññāṇaviññeyyamevāti rūpakaṇḍe cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ paccuppannāneva rūpādīni ārabbha
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa viññeyyam eva ati rūpa kaṇḍe cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam paccuppannāni eva rūpa ādīni ārabbha
translated: “Cognizable by the mind that has arisen” means that they are cognizable by the eye-consciousness, etc., that have arisen.

original: pavattito atītādivisayaṃ manoviññāṇampi pañcaviññāṇasotapatitameva katvā “upapannaṃ🔽chahi viññāṇehi viññeyya”nti vuttaṃ. Pañcaviññāṇā pana yasmā paccuppannāpi cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: pavattitaḥ atīta ādi visayam manaḥ viññāṇam pi pañca viññāṇa sota patitam eva katvā upapannam  chahi viññāṇehi viññeyyanti vuttam pañca viññāṇā pana yasmā paccuppannā api cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam
translated: And because of occurrence, mind-consciousness too, when included in the five-door process, is said to be “cognizable by six kinds of consciousness” .

original: ārammaṇā na honti, manoviññāṇasseva honti, tasmā “manoviññāṇaviññeyyamevā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇāḥ na honti manaḥ viññāṇassa iva honti tasmā manaḥ viññāṇa viññeyyam eva ati vuttam
translated: But since the five consciousnesses are not objects of eye-consciousness, etc., which are present, but are objects of mind-consciousness only, therefore it is said that they are “cognizable by mind-consciousness only.”

original: Aniccamevāti hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena aniccāyeva. Jarābhibhūtamevāti jarāya abhibhūtattā jarābhibhūtā eva.🔽762. Uppannavatthukā uppannārammaṇāti anāgatapaṭikkhepo. Na hi te anāgatesu vatthārammaṇesu uppajjanti.🔽Purejātavatthukā purejātārammaṇāti sahuppattipaṭikkhepo. Na hi te sahuppannaṃ vatthuṃ
analyzed: aniccam eva ati hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena aniccāya iva jarā abhibhūtam eva ati jarāya abhibhūta ttā jarā abhibhūtā eva  uppanna vatthukāḥ uppanna ārammaṇā ti anāgata paṭikkhepaḥ na hi te anāgatesu vattha ārammaṇesu uppajjanti  purejāta vatthukā purejāta ārammaṇā ati sahuppatti paṭikkhepaḥ na hi te sahuppannam vatthum
translated: “Impermanent only”: impermanent in the sense of non-existence after having been. “Overcome by ageing only”: overcome by ageing.🔽“Having an arisen object”: this excludes the future. For they do not arise with respect to future objects.

original: vā ārammaṇaṃ vā paṭicca uppajjanti, sayaṃ pana pacchājātā hutvā purejātesu vatthārammaṇesu uppajjanti.
analyzed: vā ārammaṇam vā paṭicca uppajjanti sayam pana pacchājātāḥ hutvā purejātesu vattha ārammaṇesu uppajjanti
translated: “Having a pre-arisen object”: this excludes simultaneous arising. For they do not arise with respect to a simultaneous object or basis. But rather, having themselves arisen later, they arise with respect to a pre-arisen object or basis.

original: Ajjhattikavatthukāti ajjhattajjhattavasena vuttaṃ. Tāni hi ajjhattike pañca pasāde
analyzed: ajjhattika vatthukā ti ajjhatta ajjhatta vasena vuttam tāni hi ajjhattike pañca pasāde
translated: “With internal base” is said with reference to the internal and the internal as object. For these arise with the five internal sensitive matter as their base.

original: vatthuṃ katvā uppajjanti. Bāhirārammaṇāti bāhirarūpādiārammaṇā. Tattha catukkaṃ veditabbaṃ
analyzed: vatthum katvā uppajjanti bāhira ārammaṇā ati bāhira rūpa ādi ārammaṇā tattha catukkam veditabbam
translated: “With external object” is with external visible data, etc., as object. Herein, the following four cases should be understood:

original: – pañcaviññāṇā hi pasādavatthukattā ajjhattikā ajjhattikavatthukā, manoviññāṇaṃ hadayarūpaṃ
analyzed: pañca viññāṇāḥ hi pasāda vatthuka ttā ajjhattikāḥ ajjhattika vatthukāḥ manaḥ viññāṇam hadaya rūpam
translated: The five consciousnesses are internal and have an internal base because they have sensitive matter as their base.🔽When mind-consciousness arises with the heart-basis as its base, it is internal and has an external base.

original: vatthuṃ katvā uppajjanakāle ajjhattikaṃ bāhiravatthukaṃ, pañcaviññāṇasampayuttā tayo🔽khandhā bāhirā ajjhattikavatthukā, manoviññāṇasampayuttā tayo khandhā hadayarūpaṃ
analyzed: vatthum katvā uppajjana kāle ajjhattikam bāhira vatthukam pañca viññāṇa sampayuttā tayo  khandhāḥ bāhirāḥ ajjhattika vatthukāḥ manaḥ viññāṇa sampayuttā tayo khandhāḥ hadaya rūpam
translated: The three aggregates associated with the five consciousnesses are external and have an internal base.

original: vatthuṃ katvā uppajjanakāle bāhirā bāhiravatthukā.
analyzed: vatthum katvā uppajjana kāle bāhirā bāhira vatthukā
translated: When the three aggregates associated with mind-consciousness arise with the heart-basis as their base, they are external and have an external base.

original: Asambhinnavatthukāti aniruddhavatthukā. Na hi te niruddhaṃ atītaṃ vatthuṃ paṭicca uppajjanti. Asambhinnārammaṇatāyapi eseva nayo.
analyzed: asambhinna vatthukā ati aniruddha vatthukā na hi te niruddham atītam vatthum paṭicca uppajjanti esa eva nayo
translated: “With undestroyed base” is with an undestroyed base. For they do not arise with a ceased, past base as object. The same method applies to “with undestroyed object.”

original: Aññaṃ cakkhuviññāṇassa vatthu ca ārammaṇañcātiādīsu cakkhuviññāṇassa hi aññaṃ vatthu,
analyzed: aññam cakkhu viññāṇassa vatthu ca ārammaṇam ca ati ādīsu cakkhu viññāṇassa hi aññam vatthu
translated: “With a different base and object from eye-consciousness, etc.”: the base of eye-consciousness is different from its object.

original: aññaṃ ārammaṇaṃ. Aññaṃ sotaviññāṇādīnaṃ. Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ sotapasādādīsu aññataraṃ
analyzed: aññam ārammaṇam aññam sota viññāṇa ādīnam cakkhu viññāṇam sota pasāda ādīsu aññataram
translated: and the other is the object. The other is the ear-consciousness, etc.,

original: vatthuṃ, saddādīsu vā aññataraṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā kappato kappaṃ gantvāpi na uppajjati;
analyzed: vatthum sadda ādīsu vā aññataram ārammaṇam katvā kappataḥ kappam gantvā api na uppajjati
translated: and the object is the sound, etc. Eye-consciousness does not arise even when it has gone on for an aeon with a certain physical basis and a certain object.

original: cakkhupasādameva pana vatthuṃ katvā rūpañca ārammaṇaṃ katvā uppajjati. Evamassa vatthupi
analyzed: cakkhu pasādam eva pana vatthum katvā rūpam ca ārammaṇam katvā uppajjati evam assa vatthu pi
translated: But it arises when it has a certain eye-sensitivity as physical basis and a visible datum as object. So its physical basis

original: dvārampi ārammaṇampi nibaddhaṃ, aññaṃ vatthuṃ vā dvāraṃ vā ārammaṇaṃ vā na saṅkamati,
analyzed: dvāram pi ārammaṇam pi nibaddham aññam vatthum vā dvāram vā ārammaṇam vā na saṅkamati
translated: and its door and its object are restricted. It does not pass over to another physical basis or door or object.

original: nibaddhavatthu nibaddhadvāraṃ nibaddhārammaṇameva hutvā uppajjati. Sotaviññāṇādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽763. Na aññamaññassa gocaravisayaṃ paccanubhontīti ettha aññamaññassa cakkhu sotassa,🔽sotaṃ vā cakkhussāti evaṃ ekaṃ ekassa gocaravisayaṃ na paccanubhotīti attho. Sace
analyzed: nibaddha vatthu nibaddha dvāram nibaddha ārammaṇam eva hutvā uppajjati sota viññāṇa ādīsu pi esa iva nayo  na aññamaññassa gocara visayam paccanubhonti iti ettha aññamaññassa cakkhu sotassa  sotam vā cakkhussa ati evam ekam ekassa gocara visayam na paccanubhoti iti attho sace
translated: It arises with a restricted physical basis, a restricted door, and a restricted object. So too with the ear-consciousness, and so on.🔽They do not experience the domain and scope of each other’s activity: here the eye does not experience the domain and scope of the ear’s activity,

original: hi nīlādibhedaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ samodhānetvā sotindriyassa upaneyya ‘iṅgha tāva naṃ
analyzed: hi nīla ādi bhedam rūpa ārammaṇam samodhānetvā sotindriyassa upaneyyaḥ tāva naṃ
translated: nor does the ear that of the eye. The meaning is that each does not experience the domain and scope of the other’s activity. For if the object consisting of visible data of the kind classed as blue, etc., were brought into the province of the ear faculty, then the eye faculty would be useless,🔽and if the object consisting of sound were brought into the province of the eye faculty, then the ear faculty would be useless.

original: vavatthāpehi vibhāvehi – kiṃ nāmetaṃ ārammaṇa’nti, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ vināpi mukhena
analyzed: vavatthāpehi vibhāvehi kim nāma etam ārammaṇanti cakkhu viññāṇam vinā api mukhena
translated: “Define and make it clear what this is that has the eye as its object.”🔽🔽

original: attano dhammatāya evaṃ vadeyya – ‘are andhabāla, vassasatampi vassasahassampi paridhāvamāno🔽aññatra mayā kuhiṃ etassa jānanakaṃ labhissasi; āhara naṃ cakkhupasāde upanehi; ahametaṃ🔽ārammaṇaṃ jānissāmi – yadi vā nīlaṃ yadi vā pītakaṃ. Na hi eso aññassa visayo; mayhameveso
analyzed: attanaḥ dhamma tāya evam vadeyya are andha bāla vassa satam pi vassa sahassam pi paridhāvamānaḥ  aññatra mayā kuhim etassa jānanakam labhissasi āhara nam cakkhu pasāde upanehi aham etam  ārammaṇam jānissāmi yadi vā nīlam yadi vā pītakam na hi esaḥ aññassa visayaḥ mayham eva iso
translated: “Define and make clear what this object is,” then eye-consciousness would say without a mouth: “Hey, you blind fool, even if you ran about for a hundred or a thousand years,

original: visayo’ti. Sesaviññāṇesupi eseva nayo. Evamete aññamaññassa gocaravisayaṃ na paccanubhonti nāma.
analyzed: visayo ti sesa viññāṇesu pi esa iva nayaḥ evam ete aññam aññassa gocara visayam na paccanubhonti nāma
translated: where else would you find a knower of this apart from me? Bring it, put it in the eye door, I will know this object, whether it is blue or yellow. This is not another’s province, this is my province.” And so with the other kinds of consciousness. This is how they do not experience each other’s domain and province.

original: 764. Samannāharantassāti āvajjaneneva samannāharantassa.
analyzed: samannāharantassa ati āvajjanena iva samannāharantassa
translated: ‘When he adverts’: when he adverts by means of adverting consciousness.

original: Manasikarontassāti āvajjaneneva manasikarontassa. Etāni hi cittāni āvajjanena samannāhaṭakāle manasikatakāleyeva ca uppajjanti.
analyzed: manasikarontassa ati āvajjanena iva manasikarontassa etāni hi cittāni āvajjanena ca uppajjanti
translated: ‘When he gives attention’: when he gives attention by means of the five kinds of giving attention . For these kinds of consciousness arise only at the time of adverting and at the time of giving attention.

original: Na abbokiṇṇāti aññena viññāṇena abbokiṇṇā nirantarāva nuppajjanti. Etena tesaṃ anantaratā paṭikkhittā.
analyzed: na abbokiṇṇā ati aññena viññāṇena abbokiṇṇāḥ nirantarāḥ ava nuppajjanti etena tesam anantara tā paṭikkhittā
translated: Not interrupted by another consciousness: they do not arise interrupted by another kind of consciousness. This rejects their being next to each other.

original: 765. Na apubbaṃ acarimanti etena sabbesampi sahuppatti paṭikkhittā. Na aññamaññassa samanantarāti etena samanantaratā paṭikkhittā.
analyzed: na apubbam acariman ti etena sabbesam pi sahuppatti paṭikkhittā na aññamaññassa samanantarā ti etena samanantara tā paṭikkhittā
translated: Not previously un-traversed: this rejects their being born together. Not one another’s proximate cause: this rejects their being next to each other.

original: 766. Āvaṭṭanā vātiādīni cattāripi āvajjanasseva nāmāni. Tañhi bhavaṅgassa āvaṭṭanato
analyzed: āvaṭṭanā vāti ādīni cattāri pi āvajjanassa iva nāmāni tat hi bhavaṅgassa āvaṭṭanato
translated: The four terms beginning with “revolving” are names for adverting. For that is called “revolving” because it revolves the mind from the life-continuum;

original: āvaṭṭanā, tasseva ābhujanato ābhogo, rūpādīnaṃ samannāharaṇato samannāhāro, tesaṃyeva🔽manasikaraṇato manasikāroti vuccati. Evamettha saṅkhepato pañcannaṃ viññāṇānaṃ āvajjanaṭṭhāne
analyzed: āvaṭṭanā tassa iva ābhujanataḥ ābhogaḥ rūpa ādīnam samannāharaṇataḥ samannāhāraḥ tesam yeva  manasikaraṇataḥ manasikāraḥ ti vuccati evam ettha saṅkhepato pañcannam viññāṇānaṃ āvajjana ṭṭhāne
translated: it is called “absorption” because it absorbs the mind on to the object; it is called “accumulation” because it accumulates the visible data, etc.,

original: ṭhatvā āvajjanādikiccaṃ kātuṃ samatthabhāvo paṭikkhitto.
analyzed: ṭhatvā āvajjana ādi kiccam kātum samattha bhāvaḥ paṭikkhittaḥ
translated: and it is called “attention” because it attends to the object. So in this way the ability of the five consciousnesses to perform the functions of adverting, etc., is rejected in brief by placing them in the position of adverting.

original: Na kañci dhammaṃ paṭivijānātīti “manopubbaṅgamā dhammā”ti evaṃ vuttaṃ ekampi kusalaṃ vā akusalaṃ vā na paṭivijānāti.
analyzed: na kañci dhammam paṭivijānāti iti manaḥ pubbaṅgamāḥ dhammā ti evam vuttam ekam pi kusalam vā akusalam vā na paṭivijānāti
translated: He does not cognize any state: he does not cognize any profitable or unprofitable state described thus, “Ideas are preceded by mind” .

original: Aññatra abhinipātamattāti ṭhapetvā rūpādīnaṃ abhinipātamattaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti –
analyzed: aññatra abhinipāta mattā ati ṭhapetvā rūpa ādīnam abhinipāta mattam idam vuttam hoti
translated: Except for the mere impact: except for the mere impact of visible data, etc.,

original: supaṇḍitopi puriso, ṭhapetvā āpāthagatāni rūpādīni, aññaṃ kusalākusalesu ekadhammampi
analyzed: su paṇḍitaḥ api purisaḥ ṭhapetvā āpātha gatāni rūpa ādīni aññam kusala akusalesu eka dhammam pi
translated: What is meant is this: even a very clever man, apart from visible data, etc., that have come into focus, does not cognize any single one of the states classed as profitable, etc.,

original: pañcahi viññāṇehi na paṭivijānāti. Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ panettha dassanamattameva hoti.
analyzed: pañcahi viññāṇehi na paṭivijānāti cakkhu viññāṇam pana ittha dassana mattam eva hoti
translated: with the five consciousnesses. For here eye-consciousness is mere seeing,

original: Sotaviññāṇādīni savanaghāyanasāyanaphusanamattāneva. Dassanādimattato pana muttā
analyzed: sota viññāṇa ādīni dassana ādi mattataḥ pana muttā
translated: and ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body-consciousness are mere hearing, smelling, tasting, and touching respectively. But apart from mere seeing, etc.,

original: aññā etesaṃ kusalādipaṭiviññatti nāma natthi.
analyzed: aññā etesam kusala ādi paṭiviññatti nāma natthi
translated: there is no other intimation of profitable states, etc.,

original: Manodhātuyāpīti sampaṭicchanamanodhātuyāpi. Sampiṇḍanattho cettha pikāro. Tasmā manodhātuyāpi
analyzed: manaḥ dhātuyā api iti sampaṭicchana manaḥ dhātuyā api sampiṇḍana attho ca ittha pikāro tasmā manaḥ dhātuyā api
translated: With the mind element too: with the receiving-of-impressions mind element too. The word “too” is meant to include the registering mind element. So with the mind element too,

original: tato parāhi manoviññāṇadhātūhipīti sabbehipi pañcadvārikaviññāṇehi na kañci kusalākusalaṃ
analyzed: tatas manaḥ viññāṇa dhātūhi pi iti sabbehi pi pañcadvārika viññāṇehi na kañci kusala akusalam
translated: and with the mind-consciousness element too: with all the five-door-consciousnesses too, he does not cognize any profitable or unprofitable state.

original: dhammaṃ paṭivijānātīti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: dhammam paṭivijānāti iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: This is how the meaning should be regarded here.

original: Na kañci iriyāpathaṃ kappetītiādīsupi eseva nayo. Na hi pañcadvārikaviññāṇehi gamanādīsu
analyzed: na kañci iriyāpatham kappeti itiādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ na hi pañca dvārika viññāṇehi gamana ādīsu
translated: In the case of the phrases “he does not make any bodily act,” etc., the method is the same. For with the five-door consciousnesses there is no making of a bodily act, etc., in going, etc.,

original: kañci iriyāpathaṃ kappeti, na kāyakammaṃ na vacīkammaṃ paṭṭhapeti, na kusalākusalaṃ🔽dhammaṃ samādiyati, na samādhiṃ samāpajjati lokiyaṃ vā lokuttaraṃ vā, na samādhito
analyzed: kañci iriyāpatham kappeti na kāya kammam na vacī kammam paṭṭhapeti na kusala akusalam  dhammam samādiyati na samādhim samāpajjati lokiyam vā lokuttaram vā na samādhito
translated: He does not perform any bodily or verbal action, he does not undertake any profitable or unprofitable action,

original: vuṭṭhāti lokiyā vā lokuttarā vā, na bhavato cavati, na bhavantare upapajjati. Sabbampi🔽hetaṃ kusalākusaladhammapaṭivijānanādivacanapariyosānaṃ kiccaṃ manodvārikacitteneva🔽hoti, na pañcadvārikenāti sabbassāpetassa kiccassa karaṇe sahajavanakāni vīthicittāni
analyzed: vuṭṭhāti lokiyā vā lokuttarā vā na bhavataḥ cavati na bhavantare upapajjati sabbam pi  kusala akusala dhamma paṭivijānana ādi vacana pariyosānam kiccam manodvārika cittena iva  hoti na pañcadvārikena ati sabbassa apetassa kiccassa karaṇe sahaja vanakāni vīthi cittāni
translated: he does not enter upon any mundane or supramundane concentration, he does not emerge from any mundane or supramundane concentration, he does not die in any mundane or supramundane concentration, he does not pass away to reappear ,🔽and all this is done by the mind-door adverting consciousness, not by the five-door adverting consciousness.🔽So the impulsions that occur in the doing of all this are excluded from the cognitive series.

original: paṭikkhittāni. Yathā cetesaṃ etāni kiccāni natthi, evaṃ niyāmokkamanādīnipi. Na hi
analyzed: paṭikkhittāni yathā ca etesam etāni kiccāni natthi evam niyāma ukkamana ādīni pi na hi
translated: And just as these things are not done by the five-door impulsions, so neither are the determining of the life-continuum, etc.,

original: pañcadvārikajavanena micchattaniyāmaṃ okkamati, na sammattaniyāmaṃ; na cetaṃ javanaṃ
analyzed: pañcadvārika javanena micchatta niyāmam okkamati na sammatta niyāmam na ca itam javanam
translated: for one does not enter upon the wrong or the right life-continuum by means of the five-door impulsions. Nor does this impulsion

original: nāmagottamārabbha javati, na kasiṇādipaṇṇattiṃ; na lakkhaṇārammaṇikavipassanāvasena
analyzed: nāma gottam ārabbha na kasiṇa ādi paṇṇattim na lakkhaṇa ārammaṇika vipassanā vasena
translated: impel with regard to name-and-surname, nor with regard to the description of the kasiṇa, etc., nor with regard to the object of insight that is characterized by the characteristics of impermanence, etc.

original: pavattati, na vuṭṭhānagāminībalavavipassanāvasena; na rūpārūpadhamme ārabbha javati,
analyzed: pavattati na vuṭṭhāna gāminī balava vipassanā vasena na rūpa arūpa dhamme ārabbha javati
translated: It does not run towards material and immaterial states,

original: na nibbānaṃ; na cetena saddhiṃ paṭisambhidāñāṇaṃ uppajjati, na abhiññāñāṇaṃ, na sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ,
analyzed: na nibbānam na ca etena saddhim paṭisambhidā ñāṇam uppajjati na abhiññā ñāṇam na sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam
translated: nor towards Nibbāna. It does not arise together with the knowledge of the analytical insights, nor with the knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power, nor with the knowledge of the perfection of the disciple,

original: na paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ, na sabbaññutañāṇaṃ. Sabbopi panesa pabhedo manodvārikajavaneyeva labbhati.🔽Na supati na paṭibujjhati na supinaṃ passatīti sabbenāpi ca pañcadvārikacittena neva🔽niddaṃ okkamati, na niddāyati, na paṭibujjhati, na kiñca supinaṃ passatīti imesu
analyzed: na pacceka bodhi ñāṇam na sabbaññuta ñāṇam sabbaḥ api pana esa pabhedaḥ manodvārika javaneya iva labbhati  na supati na paṭibujjhati na supinam passati iti sabbena api ca pañca dvārika cittena na eva  niddam okkamati na niddāyati na paṭibujjhati na kiñca supinam passati iti imesu
translated: nor with the knowledge of the individual enlightenment, nor with the knowledge of omniscience. But all these kinds of knowledge are found in the impulsions of the mind door.

original: tīsu ṭhānesu saha javanena vīthicittaṃ paṭikkhittaṃ.🔽Niddāyantassa hi mahāvaṭṭiṃ jāletvā dīpe cakkhusamīpe upanīte paṭhamaṃ cakkhudvārikaṃ
analyzed: tīsu ṭhānesu saha javanena vīthi cittam paṭikkhittaṃ  niddāyantassa hi mahā vaṭṭim jāletvā dīpe cakkhu samīpe upanīte paṭhamam cakkhudvārikam
translated: “He neither falls asleep nor wakes up nor dreams a dream”: in all these three places the consciousness of the cognitive series together with the impulsions is excluded.

original: āvajjanaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ na āvaṭṭeti, manodvārikameva āvaṭṭeti. Atha javanaṃ javitvā bhavaṅgaṃ
analyzed: āvajjanam bhavaṅgam naḥ āvaṭṭeti manodvārikam eva āvaṭṭeti atha javanam javitvā bhavaṅgam
translated: For when one is falling asleep, when a large net is spread over a light, and a lamp is brought near the eyes, the adverting of eye-door adverting does not advert to the life-continuum; it adverts only to the mind-door adverting. Then, after the impulsions have run their course, the life-continuum arises again.

original: otarati. Dutiyavāre cakkhudvārikaṃ āvajjanaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ āvaṭṭeti. Tato cakkhuviññāṇādīni
analyzed: otarati dutiya vāre cakkhu dvārikam āvajjanam bhavaṅgam āvaṭṭeti tatas cakkhu viññāṇa ādīni
translated: It descends. In the second moment the adverting at the eye-door turns the life-continuum over. Then eye-consciousness, etc.,

original: javanapariyosānāni pavattanti. Tadanantaraṃ bhavaṅgaṃ pavattati. Tatiyavāre manodvārikaāvajjanena🔽bhavaṅge āvaṭṭite manodvārikajavanaṃ javati. Tena cittena ñatvā ‘kiṃ ayaṃ imasmiṃ
analyzed: javana pariyosānāni pavattanti tad anantaram bhavaṅgam pavattati tatiya vāre manodvārika āvajjanena  bhavaṅge āvaṭṭite manodvārika javanam javati tena cittena ñatvā kim ayam imasmin
translated: arise in due succession ending with impulsion. Immediately next to that the life-continuum arises again. In the third moment the adverting at the mind-door

original: ṭhāne āloko’ti jānāti.🔽Tathā niddāyantassa kaṇṇasamīpe tūriyesu paggahitesu, ghānasamīpe sugandhesu vā duggandhesu
analyzed: ṭhāne jānāti  tathā niddāyantassa kaṇṇa samīpe tūriyesu paggahitesu ghāna samīpe sugandhesu vā duggandhesu
translated: turns the life-continuum over. Then the impulsion at the mind-door impels. The bhikkhu knows with that consciousness, and he understands: “There is light in this place.”

original: vā pupphesu upanītesu, mukhe sappimhi vā phāṇite vā pakkhitte, piṭṭhiyaṃ pāṇinā pahāre🔽dinne paṭhamaṃ sotadvārikādīni āvajjanāni bhavaṅgaṃ na āvaṭṭenti, manodvārikameva
analyzed: vā pupphesu upanītesu mukhe sappimhi vā phāṇite vā pakkhitte piṭṭhiyam pāṇinā pahāre  dinne paṭhamam sotadvārika ādīni āvajjanāni bhavaṅgam na āvaṭṭenti manodvārikam eva
translated: Similarly, when one who is sleepy hears the sound of a tabor beaten near his ear, or when fragrant or foul flowers are brought near his nose, or when ghee or molasses is put in his mouth, or when his back is stroked with a creeper,

original: āvaṭṭeti. Atha javanaṃ javitvā bhavaṅgaṃ otarati. Dutiyavāre sotadvārikādīni āvajjanāni
analyzed: āvaṭṭeti atha javanam javitvā bhavaṅgam otarati dutiya vāre sotadvārikā ādīni āvajjanāni
translated: in the first place the ear-door adverting, etc., do not turn the life-continuum over; only the mind-door adverting does so. Then the impulsion impels, and it descends into the life-continuum. In the second moment the ear-door adverting, etc.,

original: bhavaṅgaṃ āvaṭṭenti. Tato sotaghānajivhākāyaviññāṇādīni javanapariyosānāni pavattanti.
analyzed: bhavaṅgam āvaṭṭenti tatas sota ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇa ādīni javana pariyosānāni pavattanti
translated: and it is the life-continuum that is turned back by them. Then the kinds of impulsion ending in adverting with ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body- consciousness occur.

original: Tadanantaraṃ bhavaṅgaṃ pavattati. Tatiyavāre manodvārikaāvajjanena bhavaṅge āvaṭṭite🔽manodvārikajavanaṃ javati. Tena cittena ñatvā ‘kiṃ ayaṃ imasmiṃ ṭhāne saddo – saṅkhasaddo,🔽bherisaddo’ti vā ‘kiṃ ayaṃ imasmiṃ ṭhāne gandho – mūlagandho, sāragandho’ti vā ‘kiṃ🔽idaṃ mayhaṃ mukhe pakkhittarasaṃ – sappīti vā phāṇita’nti vā ‘kenamhi piṭṭhiyaṃ pahato,
analyzed: tad anantaram bhavaṅgam pavattati tatiya vāre manodvārika āvajjanena bhavaṅge āvaṭṭite  manaḥ dvārika javanam javati tena cittena ñatvā kim ayam imasmin ṭhāne saddo saṅkha saddo  bheri saddo ti vā kim ayam imasmin ṭhāne gandhaḥ mūla gandho sāra gandho ti vā kim  idam mayham mukhe pakkhitta rasam sappi iti vā phāṇitanti vā kenamhi piṭṭhiyam pahato
translated: Next to that the life-continuum occurs. In the third turn of the wheel, when the life-continuum is turned back by the adverting belonging to the mind door,

original: atithaddho me pahāro’ti vā vattāro honti. Evaṃ manodvārikajavaneneva paṭibujjhati,
analyzed: atithaddhaḥ me pahāraḥ iti vā vattāraḥ honti evam manodvārika javanena iva paṭibujjhati
translated: the impulsion belonging to the mind door impels. When he has cognized with that consciousness, he says, “What is this sound in this place, the sound of a drum or the sound of a horn? ” or “What is this smell in this place, the smell of roots or the smell of heartwood? ” or “What is this taste that I have put in my mouth, honey or molasses? ” or “Who is tapping me on the back, is it a man or a woman? ” or “The tap is very light.

original: na pañcadvārikena. Supinampi teneva passati, na pañcadvārikena.
analyzed: na pañcadvārikena supinam pi tena eva passati na pañcadvārikena
translated: ” So he wakes up by means of the impulsion belonging to the mind door, not by means of that belonging to the five doors. And he sees the dream by means of the impulsion belonging to the mind door, not by means of that belonging to the five doors.

original: Tañca panetaṃ supinaṃ passanto catūhi kāraṇehi passati – dhātukkhobhato vā anubhūtapubbato
analyzed: tat ca pana itam supinam passantaḥ catūhi kāraṇehi passati dhātu kkhobhataḥ vā anubhūta pubbataḥ
translated: And he who sees the dream sees it for one of four reasons, namely, through disturbance of the elements, or through what was seen formerly, or through aspiration, or through supernormal power.

original: vā devatopasaṃhārato vā pubbanimittato vāti. Tattha pittādīnaṃ khobhakaraṇapaccayayogena
analyzed: vā devatā upasaṃhārataḥ vā pubba nimittataḥ vā ati tattha pitta ādīnam khobha karaṇa paccaya yogena
translated: or by the appearance of a sign from the gods. Herein, by the disturbance of bile, etc., is the way of the disturbance of the four primary elements.

original: khubhitadhātuko ‘dhātukkhobhato’ supinaṃ passati. Passanto ca nānāvidhaṃ supinaṃ
analyzed: khubhita dhātukaḥ dhātu khobhataḥ supinam passati passantaḥ ca nānāvidham supinam
