translated: A boil appeared on the Elder’s finger. The king went to the monastery, thinking, “I will see the Elder.” With great force he took the finger in his mouth.🔽The boil burst in his mouth, and pus and blood flowed out. The king swallowed it, as if it were the deathless Nibbāna, out of his love for the Elder.

original: sinehena amataṃ viya ajjhohari. Soyeva thero aparabhāge maraṇamañce nipajji. Rājā
analyzed: sinehena amatam viya theraḥ apara bhāge maraṇa mañce nipajji rājā
translated: Later the Elder lay down on his deathbed. The king went there,

original: gantvā asucikapallakaṃ sīse ṭhapetvā ‘dhammasakaṭassa akkho bhijjati akkho bhijjatī’ti
analyzed: gantvā asuci kapallakam sīse ṭhapetvā dhamma sakaṭassa akkhaḥ bhijjati akkhaḥ bhijjati iti
translated: put a piece of betel leaf in his mouth, and said, “The axle of the cart of the Dhamma is broken, the axle of the cart of the Dhamma is broken.”

original: paridevamāno vicari. Pathavissarassa asucikapallakaṃ sīsena ukkhipitvā vicaraṇaṃ
analyzed: paridevamānaḥ vicari pathavissarassa asuci kapallakam sīsena ukkhipitvā vicaraṇam
translated: and he wandered about lamenting. The story of the man who carried on his head a pot of excrement and wandered about

original: nāma kassa gatamaggo? Sammāpayogassa gatamaggoti. Evaṃ payogavipattipaṭibāhitattā🔽vipākaṃ dātuṃ asakkontāni payogasampattiṃ āgamma vipaccantīti pajānāti. Evaṃ catūhi
analyzed: nāma kassa gata maggo sammāpayogassa gata maggo ti evam payoga vipatti paṭibāhita ttā  vipākam dātum a sakkontāni payoga sampattim āgamma vipaccanti iti pajānāti evam catūhi
translated: whose way is it? It is the way of one who has made a right application. Thus he understands that,🔽being unable to give their fruit because they are obstructed by the four kinds of failure, they come to fruition when there is success in application.

original: vipattīhi paṭibāhitaṃ kalyāṇakammaṃ vipākaṃ adatvā catasso sampattiyo āgamma deti.
analyzed: vipattīhi paṭibāhitam kalyāṇa kammam vipākam a datvā catasso sampattiyaḥ āgamma deti
translated: So he understands that good kamma, being obstructed by the four kinds of failure, gives its fruit not without but only with the four kinds of success.

original: Tatridaṃ bhūtamatthaṃ katvā opammaṃ – eko kira mahārājā ekassa amaccassa appamattena🔽kujjhitvā taṃ bandhanāgāre bandhāpesi. Tassa ñātakā rañño kuddhabhāvaṃ ñatvā kiñci
analyzed: tatra idam bhūtam attham katvā opammam ekaḥ kira mahā rājā ekassa amaccassa appamattena  kujjhitvā tam bandhanāgāre bandhāpesi tassa ñātakāḥ rañño kuddha bhāvam ñatvā kiñci
translated: Here is a simile to illustrate the matter. A certain king, it seems, was angry with a certain minister🔽and had him put into prison without giving any reason. The minister’s relatives,

original: avatvā caṇḍakope vigate rājānaṃ tassa niraparādhabhāvaṃ jānāpesuṃ. Rājā muñcitvā
analyzed: avatvā caṇḍa kope vigate rājānam tassa niraparādha bhāvam rājā muñcitvā
translated: knowing that the king was angry, said nothing but waited until the king’s anger had subsided, and then they made the king understand that the minister was innocent. The king released him

original: tassa ṭhānantaraṃ paṭipākatikaṃ akāsi. Athassa tato tato āgacchantānaṃ paṇṇākārānaṃ
analyzed: tassa ṭhāna antaram paṭipākatikam akāsi athassa tatas tatas āgacchantānam paṇṇa ākārānam
translated: and gave him a position higher than the one he had before. Then, as reports of his virtues came in from all quarters,

original: pamāṇaṃ nāhosi. Manussā sampaṭicchituṃ nāsakkhiṃsu. Tattha rañño appamattakena kujjhitvā🔽tassa bandhanāgāre bandhāpitakālo viya puthujjanassa niraye nibbattakālo. Athassa🔽ñātakehi rājānaṃ saññāpetvā ṭhānantarassa paṭipākatikakaraṇakālo viya tassa sagge🔽nibbattakālo. Paṇṇākāraṃ sampaṭicchituṃ asamatthakālo viya catasso sampattiyo āgamma
analyzed: pamāṇam na ahosi manussā sampaṭicchitum na asakkhiṃsu tattha raññaḥ appamattakena kujjhitvā  tassa bandhanāgāre bandhāpita kālaḥ viya puthujjanassa niraye nibbatta kālaḥ  ñātakehi rājānam saññāpetvā ṭhāna antarassa paṭipāka tika karaṇa kālaḥ viya tassa sagge  nibbatta kālaḥ paṇṇākāram sampaṭicchitum asamattha kālaḥ viya catasso sampattiyaḥ āgamma
translated: and there was no limit to it. People could not accept it all. Then the king, being displeased with the man’s small amount,

original: kalyāṇakammānaṃ devalokato manussalokaṃ, manussalokato devalokanti evaṃ sukhaṭṭhānato
analyzed: kalyāṇa kammānam deva lokataḥ manussa lokam manussa lokataḥ deva lokan ti evam sukha ṭṭhānato
translated: had him put into prison. The time when the worldling is reborn in hell is like the time when the man was put into prison. Then the time when he is reborn in heaven is like the time when the man’s relatives persuaded the king and had him released from prison. The time when he is unable to accept the reward is like the time when the man was unable to accept the reward of the leaf. The time when the doers of good are brought from the world of the gods to the human world and from the human world to the world of the gods, enjoying the four kinds of success,

original: sukhaṭṭhānameva netvā kappasatasahassampi sukhavipākaṃ datvā nibbānasampāpanaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Evaṃ tāva pāḷivaseneva dutiyaṃ balaṃ dīpetvā puna “ahosi kammaṃ ahosi kammavipāko”ti
analyzed: sukha ṭṭhānam eva netvā kappa sata sahassam pi sukha vipākam da tvā nibbāna sampāpanam veditabbam  evam tāva pāḷi vasena iva dutiyam balam dīpetvā puna ahosi kammam ahosi kamma vipāko ti
translated: is like the time when the man was brought from place of happiness to place of happiness, and was given the results of his good actions for a hundred thousand aeons, and was then established in extinction.

original: iminā paṭisambhidānayenāpi dīpetabbaṃ. Tattha ‘ahosi kamma’nti atīte āyūhitaṃ kammaṃ
analyzed: iminā paṭisambhidā nayena api dīpetabbam tattha ahosi kamman ti atīte āyūhitam kammam
translated: This is how the second strength should be illustrated by the method of the text. It should also be illustrated by the method of the analytical exposition thus: “There was action, there was result” . Herein, “there was action” refers to the action accumulated in the past.

original: atīteyeva ahosi. Yena pana atīte vipāko dinno, taṃ sandhāya ‘ahosi kammavipāko’ti
analyzed: atīte iya iva ahosi yena pana atīte vipākaḥ dinno tam sandhāya ahosi kamma vipāko ti
translated: but it was only in the past. But it was said: ‘There was kamma result’ with reference to that which gave result in the past.

original: vuttaṃ. Diṭṭhadhammavedanīyādīsu pana bahūsupi āyūhitesu ekaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ🔽vipākaṃ deti, sesāni avipākāni. Ekaṃ upapajjavedanīyaṃ paṭisandhiṃ ākaḍḍhati, sesāni
analyzed: vuttam diṭṭhadhamma vedanīya ādīsu pana bahūsu api āyūhitesu ekam diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyaṃ  vipākam deti sesāni avipākāni ekam upapajja vedanīyam paṭisandhim ākaḍḍhati sesāni
translated: And among the many kinds of kamma that have been stored up, such as that ripening in this present existence, etc.,🔽one gives result in this present existence, while the rest do not.🔽One that ripens in the next existence draws rebirth-linking in the next existence, while the rest do not.🔽One that is immediately effective causes rebirth in hell, while the rest do not.

original: avipākāni. Ekenānantariyena niraye upapajjati, sesāni avipākāni. Aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu
analyzed: avipākāni ekena ānantariyena niraye upapajjati sesāni avipākāni aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu
translated: Among the eight attainments,

original: ekāya brahmaloke nibbattati, sesā avipākā. Idaṃ sandhāya ‘nāhosi kammavipāko’ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ekāya brahma loke nibbattati sesāḥ avipākāḥ idam sandhāya na ahosi kamma vipāko ti vuttam
translated: one causes rebirth in the Brahmā-world, while the rest do not. It is with reference to this that it was said: ‘There was no kamma result.’

original: Yo pana bahumpi kusalākusalaṃ kammaṃ katvā kalyāṇamittaṃ nissāya arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti,🔽etassa kammavipāko ‘nāhosi’ nāma. Yaṃ atīte āyūhitaṃ etarahi vipākaṃ deti taṃ ‘ahosi
analyzed: yaḥ pana bahum pi kusala akusalam kammam katvā kalyāṇa mittam nissāya arahattam pāpuṇāti  etassa kamma vipākaḥ nāma yam atīte āyūhitam etarahi vipākam deti tam ahosi
translated: But when someone who has done much profitable and unprofitable kamma comes to reach Arahantship by means of good friends,🔽his kamma result is called ‘there was none.’🔽That which was stored up in the past and gives result now is called ‘there was kamma, there is kamma result.’

original: kammaṃ atthi kammavipāko’ nāma. Yaṃ purimanayeneva avipākataṃ āpajjati taṃ ‘ahosi
analyzed: kammam atthi kamma vipākaḥ nāma yam purima nayena iva avipāka tam āpajjati tam ahosi
translated: That which does not give result in the way already stated is called ‘there was kamma, there will be kamma result.’

original: kammaṃ natthi kammavipāko’ nāma. Yaṃ atīte āyūhitaṃ anāgate vipākaṃ dassati taṃ ‘ahosi
analyzed: kammam natthi kamma vipākaḥ nāma yam atīte āyūhitam anāgate vipākam dassati tam ahosi
translated: ‘There is kamma, but there is no result of kamma.’🔽What was done in the past and will give its result in the future is called🔽‘There was kamma, but there will be no result of kamma.’

original: kammaṃ bhavissati kammavipāko’ nāma. Yaṃ purimanayena avipākataṃ āpajjissati taṃ
analyzed: kammam bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ nāma yam purima nayena avipāka tam āpajjissati tam
translated: What is not giving its result in the way described above is called

original: ‘ahosi kammaṃ na bhavissati kammavipāko’ nāma.
analyzed: ahosi kammam na bhavissati kamma vipāko nāma
translated: ‘There was kamma, but there will be no result of kamma.’🔽What is done now and gives its result now is called

original: Yaṃ etarahi āyūhitaṃ etarahiyeva vipākaṃ deti taṃ ‘atthi kammaṃ atthi kammavipāko’
analyzed: yam etarahi āyūhitam etarahiyā iva vipākam deti tam atthi kammam atthi kamma vipāko
translated: ‘There is kamma, and there is result of kamma.’🔽What is not giving its result in the way described above is called

original: nāma. Yaṃ purimanayeneva avipākataṃ āpajjati taṃ ‘atthi kammaṃ natthi kammavipāko’
analyzed: nāma yam purima nayena iva avipāka tam āpajjati tam atthi kammam na atthi kamma vipāko
translated: ‘There is kamma, but there is no result of kamma.’🔽What is done now and will give its result in the future is called

original: nāma. Yaṃ etarahi āyūhitaṃ anāgate vipākaṃ dassati taṃ ‘atthi kammaṃ bhavissati kammavipāko’
analyzed: nāma yam etarahi āyūhitam anāgate vipākam dassati tat atthi kammam bhavissati kamma vipāko
translated: ‘There will be kamma, and there will be result of kamma.’🔽What is not giving its result in the way described above is called

original: nāma. Yaṃ purimanayeneva avipākataṃ āpajjissati taṃ ‘atthi kammaṃ na bhavissati kammavipāko’ nāma.
analyzed: nāma yam purima nayena iva avipāka tam āpajjissati tat atthi kammam na bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ nāma
translated: ‘There will be kamma, but there will be no result of kamma.’🔽What is in the future, and the result of which is also in the future, is called

original: Yaṃ sayampi anāgataṃ, vipākopissa anāgato taṃ ‘bhavissati kammaṃ bhavissati kammavipāko’
analyzed: yam sayam pi anāgatam anāgataḥ tam bhavissati kammam bhavissati kamma vipāko
translated: ‘There will be kamma, and there will be result of kamma.’

original: nāma. Yaṃ sayaṃ bhavissati, purimanayeneva avipākataṃ āpajjissati taṃ ‘bhavissati
analyzed: nāma yam sayam bhavissati purima nayena iva avipāka tam āpajjissati tam bhavissati
translated: What will be will be, and it will be non-resultant according to the method stated above.

original: kammaṃ na bhavissati kammavipāko’ nāma.
analyzed: kammam na bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ nāma
translated: “There will be kamma, there will not be result” means: what will be itself will be kamma, and it will not be result in the way already stated.

original: Idaṃ tathāgatassāti idaṃ sabbehipi etehi ākārehi tathāgatassa kammantaravipākantarajānanañāṇaṃ akampiyaṭṭhena dutiyabalaṃ veditabbanti.
analyzed: idam tathāgatassa ati idam sabbehi pi etehi ākārehi tathāgatassa kamma antara vipāka antara jānana ñāṇam akampiya ṭṭhena dutiya balam veditabbanti
translated: This is the Tathagata’s knowledge of the kamma and the result of kamma of beings, past, future, and present, in all their modes, in all their manifoldness, as they are, in the manner of their actuality.🔽This is the second power of the Tathagata, the power of knowledge of the possible and the impossible, which he has rightly penetrated by supassing it with his own knowledge.

original: Dutiyabalaniddesavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: dutiya bala niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the second power is ended.

original: Tatiyabalaniddeso
translated: The third power

original: 811. Tatiyabalaniddese maggoti vā paṭipadāti vā kammassevetaṃ nāmaṃ. Nirayagāminītiādīsu
analyzed: tatiya bala niddese maggo ti vā paṭipadā ati vā kammassa iva etam nāmam niraya gāminī tiādīsu
translated: In the explanation of the third power, “path” and “way” are names for kamma.

original: nirassādaṭṭhena niratiatthena ca nirayo. Uddhaṃ anugantvā tiriyaṃ añcitāti tiracchānā;
analyzed: nirassāda aṭṭhena ca nirayaḥ uddham anugantvā tiriyam añcitā ati tiracchānā
translated: Hell is a place of no delight and no enjoyment.🔽The animal world is so called because of going about on all fours.

original: tiracchānāyeva tiracchānayoni. Petatāya petti; ito pecca gatabhāvenāti attho. Pettiyeva
analyzed: tiracchānāya iva tiracchāna yoni petatāya petti itas pecca gata bhāvena ati attho pettiyā iva
translated: The realm of hungry ghosts is so called because of going away from here after dying.🔽The human world is so called because of the abundance of thought .

original: pettivisayo. Manassa ussannatāya manussā; manussāva manussaloko. Dibbanti pañcahi
analyzed: pettivisayaḥ manassa ussanna tāya manussāḥ manussā ava manussa lokaḥ dibbanti pañcahi
translated: The divine world is so called because of the abundance of bliss .

original: kāmaguṇehi adhimattāya vā ṭhānasampattiyāti devā; devāva devaloko. Vānaṃ vuccati🔽taṇhā; taṃ tattha natthīti nibbānaṃ. Nirayaṃ gacchatīti nirayagāmī. Idaṃ maggaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: kāma guṇehi adhimattāya vā ṭhāna sampattiyā ati devāḥ devāḥ ava deva lokaḥ vānam vuccati  taṇhā tam tattha natthi iti nibbānam nirayam gacchati iti niraya gāmī idam maggam sandhāya
translated: Or else ‘gods’ is a term for the five strands of sense pleasure, and ‘the Brahmā-world’ is a term for the attainment of the jhānas. Craving is called ‘the dart of craving’;🔽Nibbāna is where that does not exist. ‘He goes to hell’ is said with reference to the path.

original: vuttaṃ. Paṭipadā pana nirayagāminī nāma hoti. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Idaṃ sabbampi
analyzed: vuttam paṭipadā pana niraya gāminī nāma hoti sesa padesu pi esā iva nayaḥ idam sabbam pi
translated: But the practice is called ‘going to hell.’ The same method applies in the other cases.

original: paṭipadaṃ tathāgato pajānāti.
analyzed: paṭipadam tathāgataḥ pajānāti
translated: The Tathāgata understands all this practice.

original: Kathaṃ? Sakalagāmavāsikesupi hi ekato ekaṃ sūkaraṃ vā migaṃ vā jīvitā voropentesu
analyzed: katham hi ekatas ekam sūkaram vā migam vā
translated: How? When all the inhabitants of a village, for instance, kill a single pig,

original: sabbesampi cetanā parassa jīvitindriyārammaṇāva hoti. Taṃ pana kammaṃ tesaṃ āyūhanakkhaṇeyeva🔽nānā hoti. Tesu hi eko ādarena chandajāto karoti. Eko ‘ehi tvampi karohī’ti parehi
analyzed: sabbesam pi cetanā parassa jīvitindriya ārammaṇā ava hoti tam pana kammam tesam  nānā hoti tesu hi ekaḥ ādarena chanda jāto karoti ekaḥ ehi tvam pi karohi iti parehi
translated: the volition of all is the same in having the life faculty of another being as its object. But that kamma is different for each of them at the very moment they are accumulating it.🔽For one of them does it out of respect and with a willing mind; another does it because he is pressed by others; ‘Come on, do it too’;

original: nippīḷitattā karoti. Eko samānacchando viya hutvā appaṭibāhiyamāno vicarati. Tesu
analyzed: nippīḍita ttā karoti ekaḥ samāna chandaḥ viya hutvā a paṭibāhiyamānaḥ vicarati tesu
translated: another goes along with the others as if he were of the same mind, but he does not protest. Of these,

original: eko teneva kammena niraye nibbattati, eko tiracchānayoniyaṃ, eko pettivisaye. Taṃ🔽tathāgato āyūhanakkhaṇeyeva ‘iminā nīhārena āyūhitattā esa niraye nibbattissati,
analyzed: ekaḥ tena iva kammena niraye nibbattati ekaḥ tiracchānayoniyam ekaḥ petti visaye tam  tathāgataḥ āyūhana kkhaṇe iva iminā nīhārena āyūhita ttā esa niraye nibbattissati
translated: One of them is reborn in hell, one in the animal realm, and one in the realm of ghosts.

original: esa tiracchānayoniyaṃ, esa pettivisaye’ti pajānāti. Niraye nibbattamānampi ‘esa aṭṭhasu
analyzed: tiracchānayoniyam esa petti visaya iti pajānāti niraye nibbattamānam pi esa aṭṭhasu
translated: The Tathāgata knows that by this kind of action one will be reborn in hell, by this kind of action in the animal realm, and by this kind of action in the realm of ghosts.

original: mahānirayesu nibbattissati, esa soḷasasu ussadanirayesu nibbattissatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: mahānirayesu nibbattissati esa soḷasasu ussada nirayesu nibbattissati iti pajānāti
translated: When one is being reborn in hell, he knows that one will be reborn in the eight great hells, and in the sixteen branch hells.

original: Tiracchānayoniyaṃ nibbattamānampi ‘esa apādako bhavissati, esa dvipādako, esa catuppādako,🔽esa bahuppādako’ti pajānāti. Pettivisaye nibbattamānampi ‘esa nijjhāmataṇhiko bhavissati,
analyzed: tiracchānayoniyam nibbattamānam pi esa a pādakaḥ bhavissati esa dvi pādakaḥ esa catuppādako  esa bahu ppādakaḥ ti pajānāti petti visaye nibbattamānam pi esa nijjhāma taṇhikaḥ bhavissati
translated: When one is being reborn in the animal realm, he knows that one will be without legs, with two legs, with four legs, or with many legs.🔽When one is being reborn in the realm of ghosts, he knows that one will be one who is hungry for his own flesh, one who is thirsty for his own blood, or one who lives on what others give.

original: esa khuppipāsiko, esa paradattūpajīvī’ti pajānāti. Tesu ca kammesu ‘idaṃ kammaṃ paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: esa khuppipāsikaḥ esa para dattūpajīvī iti pajānāti tesu ca kammesu idam kammam paṭisandhim
translated: And he knows that by this kind of action one will be reborn in this kind of destiny, by this kind of action in that kind of destiny.

original: ākaḍḍhituṃ na sakkhissati, dubbalaṃ dinnāya paṭisandhiyā upadhivepakkaṃ bhavissatīti pajānāti.
analyzed: ākaḍḍhitum na sakkhissati dubbalam dinnāya paṭisandhiyā upadhi vepakkam bhavissati iti pajānāti
translated: he knows that it will be a rebirth-linking of little strength, and that it will be a rebirth-linking that will ripen in suffering.

original: Tathā sakalagāmavāsikesu ekato piṇḍapātaṃ dadamānesu sabbesampi cetanā piṇḍapātārammaṇāva
analyzed: tathā sakala gāmavāsikesu ekatas piṇḍapātam dadamānesu sabbesam pi cetanā piṇḍapāta ārammaṇā ava
translated: So too, when all the inhabitants of a whole village give alms together, the volition of them all is still only one in regard to the alms.

original: hoti. Taṃ pana kammaṃ tesaṃ āyūhanakkhaṇeyeva purimanayena nānā hoti. Tesu keci devaloke🔽nibbattissanti, keci manussaloke. Taṃ tathāgato āyūhanakkhaṇeyeva ‘iminā nīhārena🔽āyūhitattā esa manussaloke nibbattissati, esa devaloke’ti pajānāti. Devaloke nibbattamānānampi
analyzed: hoti tam pana kammam tesam āyūhanakkhaṇeya iva purima nayena nānā hoti tesu keci deva loke  nibbattissanti keci manussa loke tam tathāgataḥ āyūhana kkhaṇeya iva iminā nīhārena  āyūhita ttā esa manussa loke nibbattissati esa deva loke iti pajānāti deva loke nibbattamānānam pi
translated: But that kamma is different in each case, as already explained. Some of them will be reborn in the deva world,🔽some in the human world. The Tathāgata knows at the very moment of their accumulation: ‘By this kind of kamma these beings will be reborn in the human world, and these in the deva world.’

original: ‘esa paranimmitavasavattīsu nibbattissati, esa nimmānaratīsu, esa tusitesu, esa yāmesu,
analyzed: esa para nimmita vasavattīsu nibbattissati esa nimmāna ratīsu esa tusitesu esa yāmesu
translated: And of those who are reborn in the deva world, he knows: ‘This one will be reborn in the Paranimmitavasavatti devas, this in the Nimmānarati devas, this in the Tusita devas, this in the Yāma devas,

original: esa tāvatiṃsesu, esa cātumahārājikesu, esa bhummadevesu; esa pana jeṭṭhakadevarājā
analyzed: esa tāvatiṃsesu esa cātumahārājikesu esa bhummadevesu esa pana jeṭṭhaka deva rājā
translated: this in the Tāvatiṃsa devas, this in the Cātumahārājika devas, this in the earth-bound devas; but this one will be the chief of the devas,

original: hutvā nibbattissati, esa etassa dutiyaṃ vā tatiyaṃ vā ṭhānantaraṃ karonto paricārako
analyzed: hutvā nibbattissati esaḥ etassa dutiyam vā tatiyam vā karonto paricārako
translated: and will be reborn as his attendant, either as his second or third in command.’

original: hutvā nibbattissatī’ti pajānāti. Manussesu nibbattamānānampi ‘esa khattiyakule nibbattissati,
analyzed: hutvā nibbattissati iti pajānāti manussesu nibbattamānānam pi esa khattiya kule nibbattissati
translated: He knows of those being reborn among human beings: ‘He will be reborn in a Noble clan,

original: esa brāhmaṇakule, esa vessakule, esa suddakule; esa pana manussesu rājā hutvā nibbattissati,
analyzed: esa brāhmaṇa kule esa vessa kule esa sudda kule esa pana manussesu rājā hutvā nibbattissati
translated: in a Brahmin clan, in a merchant clan, in a worker clan; and he will be reborn as a human king,

original: esa etassa dutiyaṃ vā tatiyaṃ vā ṭhānantaraṃ karonto paricārako hutvā nibbattissatī’ti
analyzed: esaḥ etassa dutiyam vā tatiyam vā ṭhāna ntaram karonto paricārakaḥ hutvā nibbattissati iti
translated: and he will be reborn as his attendant, either as his second or third in command.’

original: pajānāti. Tesu ca kammesu ‘idaṃ kammaṃ paṭisandhiṃ ākaḍḍhituṃ na sakkhissati, dubbalaṃ
analyzed: pajānāti tesu ca kammesu idam kammam paṭisandhim ākaḍḍhitum na sakkhissati dubbalam
translated: And he knows of those deeds: ‘This deed will not be able to bring about rebirth, it is weak,

original: dinnāya paṭisandhiyā upadhivepakkaṃ bhavissatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: dinnāya paṭisandhiyā upadhi vepakkam bhavissati iti pajānāti
translated: but it will be the cause of suffering when it has rebirth-linking.’

original: Tathā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapentesuyeva yena nīhārena vipassanā āraddhā, ‘esa arahattaṃ
analyzed: tathā vipassanam yena nīhārena vipassanā āraddhā esa arahattam
translated: And he knows of those who are developing insight: ‘By this method of insight he will reach Arahantship,

original: pāpuṇissati, esa arahattaṃ pattuṃ na sakkhissati, esa anāgāmīyeva bhavissati, esa
analyzed: pāpuṇissati esa arahattam pattum na sakkhissati esa anāgāmīyā iva bhavissati esa
translated: he will not be able to reach Arahantship, he will be a Non-Returner,

original: sakadāgāmīyeva, esa sotāpannoyeva; esa pana maggaṃ vā phalaṃ vā sacchikātuṃ na sakkhissati,
analyzed: sakadāgāmīya iva esa sotāpannoya iva esa pana maggam vā phalam vā sacchikātum na sakkhissati
translated: He is only a once-returner, he is only a stream-enterer, but he will not be able to realize the path or fruition.

original: lakkhaṇārammaṇāya vipassanāyameva ṭhassati; esa paccayapariggaheyeva, esa nāmarūpapariggaheyeva,
analyzed: lakkhaṇa ārammaṇāya vipassanāyam eva ṭhassati esa paccaya pariggaheyya iva esa nāma rūpa pariggaheyya iva
translated: He will only stand on insight with characteristics as object, he will only stand on the discernment of conditions, he will only stand on the discernment of mentality-materiality,

original: esa arūpapariggaheyeva, esa rūpapariggaheyeva ṭhassati, esa mahābhūtamattameva vavatthāpessati,
analyzed: esa a rūpa pariggaheya iva esa rūpa pariggaheya iva ṭhassati esa mahābhūta mattam eva vavatthāpessati
translated: he will only stand on the discernment of the immaterial, he will only stand on the discernment of the material, he will only define the mere elements,

original: esa kiñci sallakkhetuṃ na sakkhissatī’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: esa kiñci sallakkhetum na sakkhissati iti pajānāti
translated: he will not be able to discern anything else.’

original: Kasiṇaparikammaṃ karontesupi ‘etassa parikammamattameva bhavissati, nimittaṃ uppādetuṃ
analyzed: kasiṇa parikammam karontesu pi etassa parikamma mattam eva bhavissati nimittam uppādetum
translated: When they are doing the preliminary work on a kasiṇa, he knows ‘His will only be preliminary work; he will not be able to arouse the jhāna.

original: na sakkhissati; esa pana nimittaṃ uppādetuṃ sakkhissati, appanaṃ pāpetuṃ na sakkhissati;
analyzed: na sakkhissati esa pana nimittam uppādetum sakkhissati appanam pāpetum na sakkhissati
translated: But he will be able to arouse the jhāna but will not be able to reach absorption;

original: esa appanaṃ pāpetvā jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ gaṇhissatī’ti pajānātīti.
analyzed: esa appanam pāpetvā jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam gaṇhissati iti pajānāti iti
translated: but he will reach absorption, make the jhāna the basis for direct-knowledge, and then he will take up insight and reach Arahantship.’

original: Tatiyabalaniddesavaṇṇanā.
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the third power is ended.

original: Catutthabalaniddeso
translated: Exposition of the fourth power

original: 812. Catutthabalaniddese khandhanānattanti ‘ayaṃ rūpakkhandho nāma…pe… ayaṃ viññāṇakkhandho🔽nāmā’ti evaṃ pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ pajānāti. Tesupi ‘ekavidhena rūpakkhandho…pe…🔽ekādasavidhena rūpakkhandho. Ekavidhena vedanākkhandho…pe… bahuvidhena vedanākkhandho…pe…🔽ekavidhena saññākkhandho…pe… ekavidhena saṅkhārakkhandho…pe… ekavidhena viññāṇakkhandho…pe…
analyzed: catuttha bala niddese khandha nānattanti ayam rūpa kkhandho nāma pe ayam viññāṇa kkhandho  nāma ati evam pañcannam khandhānam nānākaraṇam pajānāti tesu pi ekavidhena rūpa kkhandha upe  ekādasavidhena rūpa kkhandhaḥ ekavidhena vedanā khandha upe bahuvidhena vedanā khandha upe  ekavidhena saññā kkhandha upe ekavidhena saṅkhāra kkhandha upe ekavidhena viññāṇa kkhandha upe
translated: In the description of the fourth strength, the discernment of the variety of elements: he discerns the variety of the five aggregates as follows: ‘This is the materiality aggregate … this is the consciousness aggregate.🔽The materiality aggregate is of one kind as form, of two kinds as the eye and forms …🔽of eleven kinds as the earth element and so on. The feeling aggregate is of one kind as pleasant, unpleasant, and neither, of two kinds as bodily and mental, of three kinds as past, future, and present, of four kinds as connected with the four kinds of happiness, of five kinds as classified according to the five feeling tones, of six kinds as classified according to eye-contact and so on, of eighteen kinds as classified according to the eighteen elements, of thirty-eight kinds as classified according to the thirty-eight bases, of one hundred and eight kinds as classified according to the faculties, jhāna factors, and so on, of infinite kinds as classified according to the infinite kinds of becoming, of infinite kinds as classified according to the infinite kinds of generation, of infinite kinds as classified according to the infinite kinds of destiny, of infinite kinds as classified according to the infinite kinds of station of consciousness, of infinite kinds as classified according to the infinite kinds of animal birth, of infinite kinds as classified according to the infinite kinds of permutation.🔽The perception aggregate is of one kind as the act of perceiving, of two kinds as classified according to the eye and mental phenomena, of three kinds as classified according to the three kinds of understanding, of four kinds as classified according to the four foundations of mindfulness, of five kinds as classified according to the five kinds of spiritual faculties, of six kinds as classified according to the six kinds of knowledge, of seven kinds as classified according to the seven kinds of enlightenment factors, of eight kinds as classified according to the eight kinds of path factors, of nine kinds as classified according to the nine successive abidings, of ten kinds as classified according to the ten kinds of knowledge of spheres, of eleven kinds as classified according to the eleven kinds of knowledge of spheres, of twelve kinds as classified according to the twelve kinds of dependent origination, of sixteen kinds as classified according to the sixteen kinds of knowledge of spheres, of eighteen kinds as classified according to the eighteen elements, of thirty-eight kinds as classified according to the thirty-eight bases, of one hundred and eight kinds as classified according to the faculties, jhāna factors, and so on, of infinite kinds as classified according to

original: bahuvidhena viññāṇakkhandho’ti evaṃ ekekassa khandhassa nānattaṃ pajānāti. Āyatananānattanti🔽‘idaṃ cakkhāyatanaṃ nāma…pe… idaṃ dhammāyatanaṃ nāma. Tattha dasāyatanā kāmāvacarā,🔽dve catubhūmakā’ti evaṃ āyatananānattaṃ pajānāti. Dhātunānattanti ‘ayaṃ cakkhudhātu
analyzed: bahuvidhena viññāṇa kkhandho ti evam ekekassa khandhassa nānattam pajānāti āyatana nānattam ti 🔽idam cakkhāyatanam nāma pe idam dhammāyatanam nāma tattha dasa āyatanā kāmāvacarā 🔽dve catu bhūmakā ti evam āyatana nānattam pajānāti dhātu nānattam ti ayam cakkhu dhātu
translated: In the description of the fourth strength, the discernment of ideas as various and as not-self is the discernment of the five aggregates as various and as not-self. The discernment of the variousness of the aggregates is the discernment of the five aggregates as various in the way beginning ‘This is the materiality aggregate, this is the feeling aggregate, this is the perception aggregate, this is the formations aggregate, this is the consciousness aggregate’ . And the discernment of the variousness of each aggregate is the discernment of the materiality aggregate as various in the eleven ways beginning with the one given in the description of the first strength, and the discernment of the feeling aggregate as various in the many ways beginning with the one given in the description of the first strength, and the discernment of the perception aggregate as various in the many ways beginning with the one given in the description of the first strength, and the discernment of the formations aggregate as various in the many ways beginning with the one given in the description of the first strength, and the discernment of the consciousness aggregate as various in the many ways beginning with the one given in the description of the first strength. The discernment of the variousness of the bases is the discernment of the variousness of the twelve bases in the way beginning ‘This is the eye base, this is the form base, this is the ear base, this is the sound base, this is the nose base, this is the odour base, this is the tongue base, this is the flavour base, this is the body base, this is the tangible-data base, this is the mind base, this is the idea base’ . And the discernment of the variousness of each base is the discernment of the variousness of the ten sense-desire-element bases in the way beginning ‘This is the eye base, this is the ear base, this is the nose base, this is the tongue base, this is the body base, this is the femininity faculty, this is the masculinity faculty, this is the life faculty, this is bodily pleasure, this is bodily pain’ , and the discernment of the variousness of the two form-element bases in the way beginning ‘This is the eye base, this is the ear base’ , and the discernment of the variousness of the two formless-element bases in the way beginning ‘This is the mind base, this is the idea base’ . The discernment of the variousness of the elements is the discernment of the variousness of the eighteen elements in the way beginning ‘This is

original: nāma…pe… ayaṃ manoviññāṇadhātu nāma. Tattha soḷasa dhātuyo kāmāvacarā, dve catubhūmakā’ti
analyzed: ayam manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu nāma tattha soḷasa dhātuyaḥ kāma avacarā dve catu bhūmakā ati
translated: Herein, sixteen elements are of the sense sphere, and two are of four planes.’

original: evaṃ dhātunānattaṃ pajānāti.
analyzed: evam dhātu nānattam pajānāti
translated: This is how he discerns the diversity of elements.

original: Puna anekadhātunānādhātulokanānattanti idaṃ na kevalaṃ upādinnakasaṅkhāralokasseva
analyzed: puna idam na kevalam upādinnaka saṅkhāra lokassa iva
translated: Again, ‘the world’s diversity of elements and multiple elements’ is not only the diversity of the world of formations that are clung to.

original: nānattaṃ tathāgato pajānāti, anupādinnakasaṅkhāralokassāpi nānattaṃ tathāgato pajānātiyevāti🔽dassetuṃ gahitaṃ. Paccekabuddhā hi dve ca aggasāvakā upādinnakasaṅkhāralokassāpi🔽nānattaṃ ekadesatova jānanti no nippadesato, anupādinnakalokassa pana nānattaṃ na
analyzed: nānattam tathāgataḥ pajānāti an upādinnaka saṅkhāra lokassa api nānattam tathāgataḥ pajānāti yeva ati  dassetum gahitam paccekabuddhāḥ hi dve ca aggasāvakāḥ upādinnaka saṅkhāra lokassa api  nānattam ekadesataḥ va jānanti no nippadesataḥ anupādinnaka lokassa pana nānattam na
translated: The Tathāgata also discerns the diversity of the world of formations that are not clung to.🔽This is stated in order to show that. For the Paccekabuddhas and the chief disciples discern the diversity of the world of formations that are clung to only in part, not in all its aspects, and they do not discern the diversity of the world of formations that are not clung to.

original: jānanti. Sabbaññubuddho pana ‘imāya nāma dhātuyā ussannāya imassa nāma rukkhassa
analyzed: jānanti sabbaññu buddhaḥ pana imāya nāma dhātuyā ussannāya imassa nāma rukkhassa
translated: But the Enlightened One, who is omniscient, knows the diversity of the world of formations that are clung to in all its aspects and also the diversity of the world of formations that are not clung to.

original: khandho seto hoti, imassa kāḷako, imassa maṭṭo; imassa bahalattaco, imassa tanuttaco;
analyzed: khandho setaḥ hoti imassa kāḷakaḥ imassa maṭṭaḥ imassa bahalattacaḥ imassa tanuttacaḥ
translated: ‘When this element is predominant, the trunk of this tree is white, of that tree black, of that one mottled; the bark of that one is thick, of that one thin;

original: imāya nāma dhātuyā ussannāya imassa rukkhassa pattaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena evarūpaṃ
analyzed: imāya nāma dhātuyā ussannāya imassa rukkhassa pattam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādi vasena evarūpam
translated: “When this element is prominent, the leaf of this tree is such and such in colour, shape, etc.,

original: nāma hoti; imāya pana dhātuyā ussannāya imassa rukkhassa pupphaṃ nīlakaṃ hoti, pītakaṃ,🔽lohitakaṃ, odātaṃ, sugandhaṃ, duggandhaṃ hoti; imāya nāma dhātuyā ussannāya phalaṃ
analyzed: nāma hoti imāya pana dhātuyā ussannāya imassa rukkhassa puppham nīlakam hoti pītakam  lohitakam odātam sugandham duggandham hoti imāya nāma dhātuyāḥ ussannāya phalam
translated: “When this element is prominent, the flower of this tree is blue, yellow,🔽red, white, fragrant, or foul-smelling;

original: khuddakaṃ hoti, mahantaṃ, dīghaṃ, rassaṃ, vaṭṭaṃ, susaṇṭhānaṃ, dussaṇṭhānaṃ, maṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: khuddakam hoti mahantam dīgham rassam vaṭṭam su saṇṭhānam dussaṇṭhānam maṭṭham
translated: “When this element is prominent, the fruit of this tree is small, large, long, round, well-shaped, ill-shaped, smooth,

original: pharusaṃ, sugandhaṃ, duggandhaṃ, madhuraṃ, tittakaṃ, ambilaṃ, kaṭukaṃ, kasāvaṃ hoti;🔽imāya nāma dhātuyā ussannāya imassa rukkhassa kaṇṭako tikhiṇo hoti, atikhiṇo, ujuko,
analyzed: pharusam sugandham duggandham madhuram tittakam ambilam kaṭukam kasāvam hoti  imāya nāma dhātuyā ussannāya imassa rukkhassa kaṇṭako tikhiṇaḥ hoti atikhiṇaḥ ujukaḥ
translated: rough, fragrant, foul-smelling, sweet, sour, sharp, bitter, or astringent;

original: kuṭilo, tambo, kāḷako, nīlo, odāto hotī’ti evaṃ anupādinnakasaṅkhāralokassa nānattaṃ
analyzed: kuṭilaḥ tambaḥ kāḷakaḥ nīlaḥ odātaḥ hoti iti evam an upādinnaka saṅkhāra lokassa nānattam
translated: “When this element is prominent, the thorns of this tree are sharp, very sharp, straight, crooked, twisted, black, blue, or white.”🔽Thus he discerns the diversity of the inanimate world that is not clung to by the kamma-born formations.

original: pajānāti. Sabbaññubuddhānaṃyeva hi etaṃ balaṃ, na aññesanti.
analyzed: pajānāti sabbaññu buddhānam yeva hi etam balam na aññesanti
translated: This is a power of the all-knowing Buddhas only, not of others.

original: Catutthabalaniddesavaṇṇanā.
translated: The explanation of the fourth power is ended.

original: Pañcamabalaniddeso
translated: Description of the fifth blessing

original: 813. Pañcamabalaniddese hīnādhimuttikāti hīnajjhāsayā. Paṇītādhimuttikāti kalyāṇajjhāsayā.
analyzed: pañcama bala niddese hīna adhimuttikā ati hīna ajjhāsayā paṇīta adhimuttikā ati kalyāṇa ajjhāsayā
translated: In the description of the fifth blessing, those of low resolve are those of low inclination. Those of noble resolve are those of good inclination.

original: Sevantīti nissayanti allīyanti. Bhajantīti upasaṅkamanti. Payirupāsantīti punappunaṃ
analyzed: sevanti iti nissayanti allīyanti bhajanti iti upasaṅkamanti payirupāsanti iti punappunam
translated: They serve: they rely on, they cling to. They attend on: they approach. They honour: they approach again and again.

original: upasaṅkamanti. Sace hi ācariyupajjhāyā na sīlavanto honti, saddhivihārikā sīlavanto
analyzed: upasaṅkamanti sace hi ācariya upajjhāyāḥ na sīlavantaḥ honti saddhivihārikā sīlavanto
translated: For if the teachers and preceptors are not virtuous, the pupils and students, if they are virtuous,

original: honti, te attano ācariyupajjhāyepi na upasaṅkamanti, attanā sadise sāruppabhikkhūyeva🔽upasaṅkamanti. Sace ācariyupajjhāyā sāruppabhikkhū, itare asāruppā, tepi na ācariyupajjhāye
analyzed: honti te attano ācariya upajjhāye pi na upasaṅkamanti attanā sadise  upasaṅkamanti sace ācariya upajjhāyā sāruppa bhikkhū itare asāruppā te pi na ācariya upajjhāye
translated: do not approach their teachers and preceptors, but approach only suitable fellow monks similar to themselves.

original: upasaṅkamanti, attanā sadise hīnādhimuttike eva upasaṅkamanti.
analyzed: upasaṅkamanti attanā sadise hīna adhimuttike eva upasaṅkamanti
translated: And if the teachers and preceptors are suitable, but the pupils and students are unsuitable, they do not approach their teachers and preceptors, but approach only those of low resolve similar to themselves.

original: Evaṃ upasaṅkamanaṃ pana na kevalaṃ etaraheva, atītānāgatepīti dassetuṃ atītampi addhānantiādimāha.
analyzed: evam upasaṅkamanam pana na kevalam etarahā iva atīta anāgate pi iti dassetum atītam pi addhā ananti ādim āha
translated: But this kind of approaching is not only now, it was so in the past and future too. To show this, he said, “In the past too,” and so on.

original: Taṃ uttānatthameva. Idaṃ pana dussīlānaṃ dussīlasevanameva, sīlavantānaṃ sīlavantasevanameva,
analyzed: tat uttāna attham eva idam pana dussīlānam dussīla sevanam eva sīlavantānam sīlavanta sevanam eva
translated: This is quite clear. But who is it that determines that the unvirtuous should keep company with the unvirtuous, the virtuous with the virtuous,

original: duppaññānaṃ duppaññasevanameva, paññavantānaṃ paññavantasevanameva ko niyāmetīti?
analyzed: duppaññānam duppañña sevanam eva pañavantānam paññavanta sevanam eva kaḥ niyāmeti iti
translated: the witless with the witless, and the wise with the wise?

original: Ajjhāsayadhātu niyāmeti. Sambahulā kira bhikkhū ekaṃ gāmaṃ gaṇabhikkhācāraṃ caranti.
analyzed: sambahulā kira bhikkhū ekam gāmam gaṇa bhikkhā cāram caranti
translated: The underlying tendency determines this. It is said that a number of bhikkhus were going on a communal alms round in a certain village.

original: Manussā bahubhattaṃ āharitvā pattāni pūretvā “tumhākaṃ yathāsabhāgena paribhuññathā”ti
analyzed: manussāḥ bahu bhattam āharitvā pattāni pūretvā tumhākam yathā sabhāgena paribhuññatha ati
translated: The people brought them much food, filled their bowls, and said, “Eat as much as you want and take away the rest.”

original: datvā uyyojesuṃ. Bhikkhūpi āhaṃsu “āvuso, manussā dhātusaṃyuttakamme payojentī”ti.
analyzed: datvā uyyojesum bhikkhū api āhaṃsu āvuso manussā dhātu saṃyutta kamme payojenti iti
translated: So the bhikkhus took it and left.

original: Tipiṭakacūḷābhayattheropi nāgadīpe cetiyaṃ vandanāya pañcahi bhikkhusatehi saddhiṃ🔽gacchanto ekasmiṃ gāme manussehi nimantito. Therena ca saddhiṃ eko asāruppabhikkhu
analyzed: tipiṭakacūḷābhaya theraḥ api nāgadīpe cetiyam vandanāya pañcahi bhikkhu satehi saddhiṃ  gacchantaḥ ekasmin gāme manussehi nimantitaḥ therena ca saddhim ekaḥ a sāruppa bhikkhu
translated: The Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa Abhaya was going to the shrine at Nāgadīpa to worship with five hundred bhikkhus.🔽He was invited by the people in a certain village. There was a certain unseemly bhikkhu with him.🔽There was also a certain unseemly bhikkhu in the monastery.

original: atthi. Dhuravihārepi eko asāruppabhikkhu atthi. Dvīsu bhikkhusaṅghesu gāmaṃ osarantesu
analyzed: atthi dhura vihāre pi ekaḥ asāruppa bhikkhu atthi dvīsu bhikkhu saṅghesu gāmam osarantesu
translated: When the two bhikkhu groups entered the village for alms,

original: te ubhopi janā, kiñcāpi āgantukena nevāsiko nevāsikena vā āgantuko na diṭṭhapubbo,
analyzed: te ubho pi janā kiñcā api āgantukena nevāsikaḥ nevāsikena vā āgantukaḥ na diṭṭhapubbaḥ
translated: and the incoming monk had never seen the resident monk before,

original: evaṃ santepi, ekato hutvā hasitvā hasitvā kathayamānā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Thero disvā
analyzed: evam sante api ekatas hutvā hasitvā hasitvā kathayamānāḥ eka mantam theraḥ disvā
translated: nevertheless, after laughing together and talking together, they sat down to one side. The elder said,

original: “sammāsambuddhena jānitvā dhātusaṃyuttaṃ kathita”nti āha.
analyzed: sammāsambuddhena jānitvā dhātu saṃyuttam kathitan ti āha
translated: “The Fully Enlightened One, knowing, has spoken about the elements in the Linked Discourses.”

original: Evaṃ ‘ajjhāsayadhātu niyāmetī’ti vatvā dhātusaṃyuttena ayamevattho dīpetabbo. Gijjhakūṭapabbatasmiñhi
analyzed: evam vatvā dhātu saṃyuttena ayam eva atthaḥ dīpetabbaḥ gijjhakūṭa pabbatasmin hi
translated: So after saying, “The element of intention determines,” the meaning of this should be illustrated by the Linked Discourses.

original: gilānaseyyāya nipanno bhagavā ārakkhaṇatthāya parivāretvā vasantesu sāriputtamoggallānādīsu🔽ekamekaṃ attano attano parisāya saddhiṃ caṅkamantaṃ oloketvā bhikkhū āmantesi “passatha
analyzed: gilāna seyyāya nipannaḥ bhagavā ārakkhaṇa atthāya parivāretvā vasantesu sāriputta moggallāna ādīsu  ekam ekam attano attano parisāya saddhim caṅkamantam oloketvā bhikkhū āmantesi passatha
translated: For the Blessed One, while lying down on his last illness on the Vulture Peak,🔽saw the venerable Sāriputta and the venerable Moggallāna, etc., walking up and down in meditation surrounded by their own retinues,

original: no tumhe, bhikkhave, sāriputtaṃ sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ caṅkamanta”nti? “Evaṃ,
analyzed: no tumhe bhikkhave sāriputtam sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhim evam
translated: and he addressed the bhikkhus: “Bhikkhus, do you see Sāriputta walking up and down with a number of bhikkhus? ”

original: bhante”ti. “Sabbe kho ete, bhikkhave, bhikkhū mahāpaññā”ti sabbaṃ vitthāretabbanti.
analyzed: bhante ti sabbe kho ete bhikkhave bhikkhū mahā paññā ati sabbam vitthāretabbanti
translated: “Yes, venerable sir.” “All these bhikkhus are of great wisdom.” All should be quoted in detail.

original: Pañcamabalaniddesavaṇṇanā.
translated: Description of the fifth power.

original: Chaṭṭhabalaniddeso
translated: Description of the sixth power

original: 814. Chaṭṭhabalaniddese āsayanti yattha sattā āsayanti nivasanti, taṃ tesaṃ nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ🔽diṭṭhigataṃ vā yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ vā. Anusayanti appahīnānusayitaṃ kilesaṃ. Caritanti
analyzed: chaṭṭha bala niddese āsayanti yattha sattāḥ āsayanti nivasanti tam tesam nivāsa ṭṭhānam  diṭṭhi gatam vā yathābhūtam ñāṇam vā anusayanti appahīna anusayitam kilesam caritanti
translated: . In the description of the sixth power, “abode” is the place where beings dwell.

original: kāyādīhi abhisaṅkhataṃ kusalākusalaṃ. Adhimuttanti ajjhāsayaṃ. Apparajakkhetiādīsu
analyzed: kāya ādīhi kusala akusalam adhimuttanti ajjhāsayam apparajakkha iti ādīsu
translated: Or it is wrong view or knowledge of the way things really are. “Tendency” is a defilement that has not been abandoned. “Practice” is what is done by body, etc., that is, wholesome and unwholesome action. “Inclination” is the underlying tendency. “Little dust” and so on are as follows.

original: paññāmaye akkhimhi appaṃ parittaṃ rāgadosamoharajaṃ etesanti apparajakkhā. Tasseva
analyzed: paññā maye akkhimhi appam parittam rāga dosa moha rajam etesanti apparajakkhā tassa iva
translated: Those who have little dust, that is, little passion, hatred, and delusion, in the eye of wisdom are of little dust.

original: mahantatāya mahārajakkhā. Ubhayenāpi mandakilese mahākilese ca satte dasseti. Yesaṃ
analyzed: mahantatāya mahārajakkhā ubhayena api manda kilese mahā kilese ca satte dasseti yesam
translated: Those who have much dust are of much dust. Both terms refer to those with weak and strong defilements respectively.

original: saddhādīni indriyāni tikkhāni, te tikkhindriyā. Yesaṃ tāni mudūni, te mudindriyā.
analyzed: saddhā ādīni indriyāni tikkhāni te tikkhindriyāḥ yesam tāni mudūni te mudindriyā
translated: Those whose faculties of faith, etc., are sharp are of sharp faculties. Those whose faculties are weak are of weak faculties.

original: Yesaṃ āsayādayo koṭṭhāsā sundarā, te svākārā. Viparītā dvākārā. Ye kathitakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: āsaya ādayaḥ koṭṭhāsā sundarā te su ākārāḥ viparītāḥ dvi ākārāḥ ye kathita kāraṇam
translated: Those whose abodes, etc., are beautiful are of beautiful appearance. Those whose abodes, etc., are ugly are of ugly appearance. Those who have the reason stated are of stated reason.

original: sallakkhenti, sukhena sakkā honti viññāpetuṃ, te suviññāpayā. Viparītā duviññāpayā.
analyzed: sallakkhenti sukhena sakkāḥ honti viññāpetum te su viññāpayā viparītāḥ du viññāpayā
translated: They are easy to make understand if they are capable of being understood easily. They are difficult to make understand if they are capable of being understood with difficulty.

original: Ye ariyamaggapaṭivedhassa anucchavikā upanissayasampannā, te bhabbā. Viparītā abhabbā.🔽815. Evaṃ chaṭṭhabalassa mātikaṃ ṭhapetvā idāni yathāpaṭipāṭiyā bhājento katamo ca
analyzed: ye ariya magga paṭivedhassa anucchavikāḥ upanissaya sampannā te bhabbāḥ viparītāḥ abhabbā  evam chaṭṭha balassa mātikam ṭhapetvā idāni yathā paṭipāṭiyā bhājento katamo ca
translated: They are capable if they are endowed with the requisite conditions for the penetration of the noble path. They are incapable if they are not so endowed.🔽Having thus set forth the table of contents of the sixth power, he now divides it according to the order of the text, asking: “What is the inclination of beings?”

original: sattānaṃ āsayotiādimāha. Tattha sassato lokotiādīnaṃ attho heṭṭhā nikkhepakaṇḍavaṇṇanāyaṃ🔽vuttoyeva. Iti bhavadiṭṭhisannissitā vāti evaṃ sassatadiṭṭhiṃ vā sannissitā. Sassatadiṭṭhi
analyzed: sattānam āsayo tiādim āha tattha sassataḥ loko ti ādīnam atthaḥ heṭṭhā nikkhepa kaṇḍa vaṇṇanā ayam  vuttā yā iva iti bhava diṭṭhi sannissitā vā ati evam sassata diṭṭhim vā sannissitā sassata diṭṭhi
translated: The meaning of “the world is eternal,” etc., has been given in the commentary on the Introduction.🔽Thus they are dependent on the view of existence, etc. They are dependent on the view of eternalism or on the view of annihilationism.

original: hi ettha bhavadiṭṭhīti vuttā; ucchedadiṭṭhi ca vibhavadiṭṭhīti. Sabbadiṭṭhīnañhi
analyzed: hi ettha bhava diṭṭhī iti vuttā uccheda diṭṭhi ca vibhava diṭṭhī iti sabba diṭṭhīnam hi
translated: For the view of eternalism is called here the view of existence, and the view of annihilationism the view of non-existence.🔽For all views are included in the views of eternalism and annihilationism.

original: sassatucchedadiṭṭhī hi saṅgahitattā sabbepi diṭṭhigatikā sattā imāva dve diṭṭhiyo🔽sannissitā honti. Vuttampi cetaṃ – “dvayasannissito kho panāyaṃ, kaccāna, loko yebhuyyena
analyzed: hi saṅgahita ttā sabbe pi diṭṭhi gatikā sattā imā va dve diṭṭhiyaḥ 🔽sannissitāḥ honti vuttam pi ca itam dvaya sannissitaḥ kho pana ayam kaccāna lokaḥ yebhuyyena
translated: For all beings who hold views are dependent on these two views.

original: – atthitañceva natthitañcā”ti. Ettha hi atthitāti sassataṃ, natthitāti ucchedo. Ayaṃ
analyzed: atthitam ca iva na atthitam ca ati ettha hi atthitā ati sassatam na atthitā ati ucchedaḥ ayam
translated: and non-existence” . Here “existence” is eternalism and “non-existence” is annihilationism. This is the

original: tāva vaṭṭasannissitānaṃ puthujjanasattānaṃ āsayo.
analyzed: tāva vaṭṭa sannissitānam puthujjana sattānam āsayaḥ
translated: disposition of ordinary beings who are attached to the round of rebirths.

original: Idāni vivaṭṭasannissitānaṃ suddhasattānaṃ āsayaṃ dassetuṃ ete vā pana ubho ante anupagammātiādi
analyzed: idāni vivaṭṭa sannissitānam suddha sattānam āsayam dassetuṃ ete vā pana ubho ante an upagamma itiādi
translated: Now, in order to show the disposition of pure beings who are attached to the cessation of the round of rebirths, the text says: “Or else, not approaching either of these two extremes, the Tathagata teaches you a doctrine by the middle” .

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha ete vā panāti eteyeva. Ubho anteti sassatucchedasaṅkhāte dve ante.
analyzed: vuttam tattha ete vā pana ati ubho ante iti sassatu cheda saṅkhāte dve ante
translated: Herein, “or else” : these very . “Two extremes” : the two extremes called eternalism and annihilationism.

original: Anupagammāti anallīyitvā. Idappaccayatā paṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesūti idappaccayatāya🔽ceva paṭiccasamuppannadhammesu ca. Anulomikā khantīti vipassanāñāṇaṃ. Yathābhūtaṃ🔽vā ñāṇanti maggañāṇaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yā paṭiccasamuppāde ceva paṭiccasamuppannadhammesu
analyzed: an upagamma ati an allīyitvā idappaccaya tā paṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu iti idappaccaya tāya  ca iva paṭiccasamuppanna dhammesu ca anulomikā khanti iti vipassanā ñāṇam yathābhūtam  vā ñāṇam ti magga ñāṇam idam vuttam hoti yā paṭiccasamuppāde ca iva paṭiccasamuppanna dhammesu
translated: “Not approaching” : not adhering to. “In the dependently- arisen states” : in the dependently arisen states that are the conditionality of this .

original: ca ete ubho sassatucchedaante anupagantvā vipassanā paṭiladdhā, yañca tato uttarimaggañāṇaṃ
analyzed: ca ete ubho an upagantvā vipassanā paṭiladdhā yat ca tatas uttari magga ñāṇaṃ
translated: “Conforming acquiescence” : insight knowledge. “Knowledge of the way things are” : path knowledge. This is the meaning: not approaching either of these two extremes of eternalism and annihilationism in regard to dependent origination and the dependently arisen states, one acquires insight. And what is further than that, namely, path knowledge,

original: – ayaṃ sattānaṃ āsayo, ayaṃ vaṭṭasannissitānañca vivaṭṭasannissitānañca sabbesampi

Just as when a man is submerged in water, there is only water below him,

Conceit, false view, and uncertainty: conceit is of nine kinds, false view is of sixty-two kinds,

original: aṭṭhavatthukā ca vicikicchā. Bhavarāgānusayo panettha kāmarāgānusayeneva saṅgahitoti veditabbo.
