original: 817. Caritaniddese terasa cetanā puññābhisaṅkhāro, dvādasa apuññābhisaṅkhāro, catasso🔽āneñjābhisaṅkhāro. Tattha kāmāvacaro parittabhūmako, itaro mahābhūmako. Tīsupi vā
analyzed: carita niddese terasa cetanā puñña abhisaṅkhāro dvādasa apuñña abhisaṅkhāro catasso  āneñja abhisaṅkhāro tattha kāmāvacaro paritta bhūmakaḥ itaraḥ mahā bhūmakaḥ vā
translated: In the description of the doing: the thirteen volitions are a formation of merit, the twelve are a formation of demerit, and the four🔽are an imperturbable formation. Herein, the one in the sense-desire element is of the limited basis, and the other is of the great basis.

original: etesu yo koci appavipāko parittabhūmako, bahuvipāko mahābhūmakoti veditabbo.
analyzed: etesu yaḥ koci appa vipākaḥ paritta bhūmakaḥ bahu vipākaḥ mahā bhūmakaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: Or alternatively, in all three of these, whichever has little result is of the limited basis, and whichever has much result is of the great basis.🔽The description of the resolve has already been given above.

original: 818. Adhimuttiniddeso heṭṭhā pakāsitova. Kasmā panāyaṃ adhimutti heṭṭhā vuttāpi puna
analyzed: adhimutti niddesaḥ heṭṭhā pakāsitaḥ uva kasmā pana ayam adhimutti heṭṭhā vuttā api puna
translated: But why is this resolve mentioned again here after being mentioned above?

original: gahitāti? Ayañhi heṭṭhā pāṭiyekkaṃ baladassanavasena gahitā, idha sattānaṃ tikkhindriyamudindriyabhāvadassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: gahitā ti ayam hi heṭṭhā pāṭiyekkam bala dassana vasena gahitā idha sattānam tikkhindriya mud indriya bhāva dassana attham
translated: For this was mentioned above in order to show the strength separately, but here it is mentioned in order to show the keenness and dullness of beings’ faculties.

original: 819. Mahārajakkhaniddese ussadagatānīti vepullagatāni. Pahānakkamavasena cesa uppaṭipāṭiyā niddeso kato.
analyzed: mahārajakkha niddese ussada gatāni iti vepulla gatāni pahāna kkama vasena ca isa uppaṭi pāṭiyā niddeso kato
translated: In the description of the great king’s command: “the risen” are the increased. This description is given in order to show the abandoning by means of the supramundane path.

original: 820. Anussadagatānīti avepullagatāniṃ. Tikkhindriyamudindriyaniddese upanissayaindriyāni nāma kathitāni. Uppaṭipāṭiyā niddese panettha payojanaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: anussada gatāni iti tikkhindriya mudindriya niddese upanissaya aindriyāni nāma kathitāni uppaṭipāṭiyāḥ niddese pana ittha payojanam heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: “Gone to the end” means “gone to the end of the flood” . The faculties of keenness and weakness are called the faculties of support. But the purpose of the order of the exposition here should be understood in the way already stated.

original: 823. Tathā dvākāraniddesādīsu pāpāsayāti akusalāsayā. Pāpacaritāti apuññābhisaṅkhāraparipūrakā. Pāpādhimuttikāti sakkāyābhiratā vaṭṭajjhāsayā.
analyzed: tathā dvi ākāra niddesa ādīsu pāpa āsayā ati akusala āsayā pāpa caritā ati apuñña abhisaṅkhāra paripūrakā pāpa adhimuttikā ati sakkāya abhiratā vaṭṭajjhāsayā
translated: “Bad ways” are bad latent tendencies. “Bad conduct” is the fulfilling of the formations of demerit. “Bent on badness” are those who delight in personality view and are set on the round of rebirths.

original: 824. Svākāraniddese yasmā kalyāṇako nāma anusayo natthi, tasmā kalyāṇānusayāti na vuttaṃ. Sesaṃ vuttavipariyāyena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: su ākāra niddese yasmā kalyāṇakaḥ nāma anusayaḥ natthi tasmā kalyāṇa anusayā ti na vuttam sesam vutta vipariyāyena veditabbam
translated: In the explanation of the good ways, since there is no such latent tendency as “goodness,” it is not said “good latent tendencies.” The rest should be understood in the opposite sense to the bad ways.

original: 826. Bhabbābhabbaniddese kammāvaraṇenāti pañcavidhena ānantariyakammena. Kilesāvaraṇenāti🔽niyatamicchādiṭṭhiyā. Vipākāvaraṇenāti ahetukapaṭisandhiyā. Yasmā pana duhetukānampi
analyzed: bhabba abhabba niddese kamma āvaraṇena ati pañcavidhena ānantariya kammena kilesa āvaraṇena ati  niyatam icchā diṭṭhiyā vipāka āvaraṇena ati ahetuka paṭisandhiyā yasmai pana
translated: In the explanation of the faculties of capacity and incapacity, “obstacle of kamma” is the five crimes with immediate result. “Obstacle of defilement” is the fixed wrong view.🔽“Obstacle of result” is rebirth without the possibility of knowing the noble path. But since there is no penetration of the noble path for those with two roots,

original: ariyamaggapaṭivedho natthi, tasmā duhetukapaṭisandhipi vipākāvaraṇamevāti veditabbā.
analyzed: ariya magga paṭivedhaḥ natthi tasmā du hetuka paṭisandhi pi vipāka āvaraṇam eva ti veditabbā
translated: rebirth with two roots should be understood as an obstacle of result too.

original: Assaddhāti buddhādīsu saddhārahitā. Acchandikāti kattukamyatākusalacchandarahitā.
analyzed: assaddhā ati buddha ādīsu saddhā rahitā acchandikā ati kattu kamyatā akusala chanda rahitā
translated: “Lacking in faith” means lacking in faith in the Buddha, etc. “Lacking in keenness” means lacking in the unwholesome keenness of desire to act.

original: Uttarakurukā manussā acchandikaṭṭhānaṃ paviṭṭhā. Duppaññāti bhavaṅgapaññāya parihīnā.
analyzed: uttarakurukāḥ manussāḥ acchandika ṭṭhānam paviṭṭhāḥ duppaññā ati bhavaṅga paññāya parihīnā
translated: The human beings of Uttarakuru are lacking in keenness. “Lacking in understanding” means lacking in the understanding of the life-continuum.

original: Bhavaṅgapaññāya pana paripuṇṇāyapi yassa bhavaṅgaṃ lokuttarassa pādakaṃ na hoti,🔽so duppaññoyeva nāma. Abhabbā niyāmaṃ okkamituṃ kusalesu dhammesu sammattanti kusalesu
analyzed: bhavaṅga paññāya pana yassa bhavaṅgam lokuttarassa pādakam na hoti  so duppaññaḥ yā iva nāma abhabbā niyāmam okkamitum kusalesu dhammesu kusalesu
translated: But even though the understanding of the life-continuum may be fulfilled, if it does not serve as a footing for the supramundane,🔽he is called lacking in understanding. “Incapable of entering into the certainty” of the path called “the certainty of conformity” in regard to profitable states,

original: dhammesu sammattaniyāmasaṅkhātaṃ maggaṃ okkamituṃ abhabbā.🔽827. Na kammāvaraṇenātiādīni vuttavipariyāyena veditabbāni. Idaṃ dvinnaṃ ñāṇānaṃ
analyzed: dhammesu sammatta niyāma saṅkhātam maggam okkamitum abhabbā  na kamma āvaraṇena ati ādīni vutta vipariyāyena veditabbāni idam dvinnam ñāṇānam
translated: incapable of entering into the path called “the certainty of conformity” in regard to profitable states.🔽“Not by the hindrance of kamma” and so on should be understood in the opposite sense. This is the province of

original: bhājanīyaṃ – indriyaparopariyattiñāṇassa ca āsayānusayañāṇassa ca. Ettha hi āsayānusayañāṇena
analyzed: bhājanīyam indriya paropariyatti ñāṇassa ca āsaya anusaya ñāṇassa ca ettha hi āsaya anusaya ñāṇena
translated: two kinds of knowledge, namely, knowledge of the differences in the higher and lower faculties of others and knowledge of the range of the thaumaturge. For by the latter

original: indriyaparopariyattiñāṇampi bhājitaṃ. Iti imāni dve ñāṇāni ekato hutvā ekaṃ balañāṇaṃ nāma jātanti.
analyzed: bhājitam iti imāni dve ñāṇāni ekatas hutvā ekam balañāṇam nāma jātanti
translated: knowledge the former is also included. So these two kinds of knowledge together make up one kind of knowledge, that is, knowledge of the range of the thaumaturge.

original: Chaṭṭhabalaniddesavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: chaṭṭha bala niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the sixth power.

original: Sattamabalaniddeso
analyzed: sattama bala niddeso
translated: Description of the seventh base

original: 828. Sattamabalaniddese jhāyatīti jhāyī. Cattāro jhāyīti jhāyino cattāro janā vuccanti.🔽Tattha paṭhamacatukke tāva paṭhamo samāpattilābhī samānoyeva ‘na lābhīmhī’ti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: sattama bala niddese jhāyati iti jhāyī cattāraḥ jhāyī iti jhāyino cattāro janāḥ vuccanti  tattha paṭhama catukke tāva paṭhamaḥ samāpatti lābhī samāno yeva na kammaṭṭhānaṃ
translated: In the description of the seventh base, a meditator is a jhāyī . The four kinds of meditators are the four kinds of persons called jhāyīs.

original: samānaṃyeva ‘na kammaṭṭhāna’nti saññī hoti. Ayaṃ appaguṇajjhānalābhīti veditabbo.🔽Dutiyo samāpattiyā alābhīyeva ‘lābhīmhī’ti, akammaṭṭhānaṃ samānaṃyeva ‘kammaṭṭhāna’nti🔽saññī hoti. Ayaṃ niddājhāyī nāma. Niddāyitvā paṭibuddho evaṃ maññati. Tatiyo samāpattilābhī
analyzed: samānam yeva na kammaṭṭhānan ti saññī hoti ayam appaguṇa jhāna lābhī iti veditabbo  dutiyaḥ samāpattiyā a lābhīya iva lābhīmhi iti akammaṭṭhānam samānam yeva kammaṭṭhānam ti  saññī hoti ayam niddājhāyī nāma niddāyitvā paṭibuddhaḥ evam maññati tatiyaḥ samāpatti lābhī
translated: Herein, firstly, in the first tetrad the first is one who has attained jhāna but who thinks, “I have not attained it,” and who thinks, “I am not practicing the meditation subject,” though he is practicing it. He should be understood as one who has attained inferior jhāna.

original: samāno ‘samāpattilābhīmhī’ti, kammaṭṭhānameva samānaṃ ‘kammaṭṭhāna’nti saññī hoti.
analyzed: samānaḥ samāpatti lābhīmhi iti kammaṭṭhānam eva samānam kammaṭṭhānam ti saññī hoti
translated: The second is one who has not attained jhāna but who thinks, “I have attained it,” and who thinks, “I am practicing the meditation subject,” though he is not practicing it. He is called a “meditator on sleep,” for he thinks thus when he wakes up after going to sleep. The third is one who has attained jhāna and who thinks, “I have attained it,” and who thinks, “I am practicing the meditation subject,” though he is not practicing it.

original: Ayaṃ paguṇajjhānalābhīti veditabbo. Catuttho alābhīyeva ‘alābhīmhī’ti, akammaṭṭhānaṃyeva
analyzed: ayam paguṇa jhāna lābhī iti veditabbo catutthaḥ alābhīya iva alābhīmhi iti
translated: He should be understood as one who has attained superior jhāna. The fourth is one who has not attained jhāna and who thinks, “I have not attained it,” and who thinks, “I am not practicing the meditation subject,” though he is practicing it.

original: ‘akammaṭṭhāna’nti saññī hoti. Evamettha dve janā ajjhāyinova jhāyīnaṃ anto paviṭṭhattā jhāyīti vuttā.
analyzed: a kammaṭṭhānam ti saññī hoti evam ettha dve janā ajjhāyinaḥ iva jhāyīnam antar paviṭṭhattā jhāyī iti vuttā
translated: He is one who has the perception of what is not the meditation subject. So it is these two who are called meditators because they have gone inside among the meditators.

original: Dutiyacatukke sasaṅkhārena sappayogena samādhipāribandhikadhamme vikkhambhento dandhaṃ
analyzed: dutiya catukke sa saṅkhārena sa payogena samādhi pāribandhika dhamme vikkhambhentaḥ dandham
translated: In the second tetrad, when he suppresses the things that obstruct concentration with applied thought and sustained thought, he enters upon it slowly.

original: samāpajjati nāma. Ekaṃ dve cittavāre ṭhatvā sahasā vuṭṭhahantā khippaṃ vuṭṭhahati
analyzed: samāpajjati nāma ekam dve citta vāre ṭhatvā sahasā vuṭṭhahantā khippam vuṭṭhahati
translated: When he enters upon it and then emerges suddenly after one or two turns of consciousness, he emerges quickly.

original: nāma. Sukheneva pana samādhipāribandhikadhamme sodhento khippaṃ samāpajjati nāma.
analyzed: nāma sukhena iva pana samādhi pāribandhika dhamme sodhento khippam samāpajjati nāma
translated: But when he purifies the things that obstruct concentration easily, he enters upon it quickly.

original: Yathāparicchedena avuṭṭhahitvā kālaṃ atināmetvā vuṭṭhahanto dandhaṃ vuṭṭhāti nāma.
analyzed: yathā paricchedena a vuṭṭhahitvā kālam atināmetvā vuṭṭhahantaḥ dandham vuṭṭhāti nāma
translated: When he emerges after letting time pass without emerging at the right moment as delimited by himself, he emerges slowly.

original: Itare dvepi imināva nayena veditabbā. Ime cattāropi janā samāpattilābhinova.
analyzed: itare dve pi iminā ava nayena veditabbā ime cattāraḥ api janā samāpatti lābhinaḥ va
translated: The other two should be understood in the same way. These four are only obtainers of jhāna.

original: Tatiyacatukke ‘idaṃ jhānaṃ pañcaṅgikaṃ, idaṃ caturaṅgika’nti evaṃ aṅgavavatthānaparicchede
analyzed: tatiya catukke idam jhānam pañcaṅgikam idam catur aṅgikam ti evam aṅga vavatthāna paricchede
translated: In the third tetrad, one who is skilled in concentration in the sense of being expert about the parts of the jhāna, thus: “This jhāna has five parts, this four parts,”

original: cheko samādhismiṃ samādhikusalo nāma. Nīvaraṇāni pana vikkhambhetvā cittamañjūsāya
analyzed: chekaḥ samādhismim samādhi kusalaḥ nāma nīvaraṇāni pana vikkhambhetvā citta mañjūsāya
translated: and so on, is called “one skilled in concentration.” But when he suppresses the hindrances and gladdens his mind,

original: cittaṃ ṭhapetuṃ acheko no samādhismiṃ samāpattikusalo nāma. Itarepi tayo imināva
analyzed: cittam ṭhapetum achekaḥ no samādhismim samāpatti kusalaḥ nāma itare pi tayo
translated: and is unable to stabilize his mind, is called “not skilled in attaining concentration.” The other three are called “skilled in attaining concentration” because they are able to stabilize their mind.

original: nayena veditabbā. Imepi cattāro samāpattilābhinoyeva.
analyzed: nayena veditabbāḥ ime pi cattāraḥ samāpatti lābhinaḥ yā iva
translated: He is not called “skilled in attaining concentration” because he is not skilled in steadying the mind. The other three should be understood in the same way. And all four are only for one who has attained jhāna.

original: Idāni yāni jhānāni nissāya ime puggalā ‘jhāyī’ nāma jātā, tāni dassetuṃ cattāri jhānānītiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni yāni jhānāni nissāya ime puggalāḥ jhāyī nāma jātā tāni dassetum cattāri jhānāni iti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show the jhānas on which these persons are called “jhāyis,” he said “four jhānas” and so on.

original: Tattha cattāri jhānāni tayo ca vimokkhā atthato heṭṭhā dhammasaṅgahaṭṭhakathāyameva
analyzed: tattha cattāri jhānāni tayo ca vimokkhā atthataḥ heṭṭhā dhamma saṅgaha ṭṭhakathā ayam eva
translated: Herein, the four jhānas and the three emancipations are explained in the Description of the Aggregates in the Dhammasaṅgaṇi.

original: pakāsitā. Sesānampi vimokkhaṭṭho tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Apicettha paṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: pakāsitā sesānam pi vimokkha ṭṭho tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ api ca ittha paṭipāṭiyā
translated: The meaning of the rest of the emancipations should be understood in the way already stated there.

original: satta appitappitakkhaṇe paccanīkadhammehi vimuccanato ca ārammaṇe ca adhimuccanato
analyzed: satta appita ppita khaṇe paccanīka dhammehi vimuccanato ca ārammaṇe ca adhimuccanato
translated: And here “emancipation” is so called because of the momentary emancipation from opposing states and because of the emancipation of the object in each of the first seven cases.

original: vimokkho nāma. Aṭṭhamo pana sabbaso saññāvedayitehi vimuttattā apagatavimokkho nāma.
analyzed: vimokkhaḥ nāma aṭṭhamaḥ pana sabbaso saññā vedayitehi vimutta ttā apagatavimokkhaḥ nāma
translated: But the eighth is called “emancipation” because of complete emancipation from perception and feeling.

original: Samādhīsu catukkanayapañcakanayesu paṭhamajjhānasamādhi savitakkasavicāro nāma. Pañcakanaye
translated: As regards the kinds of concentration, the first-jhāna concentration in the fourfold reckoning and the first-jhana and second-jhāna concentrations in the fivefold reckoning are called “accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought.”

original: dutiyajjhānasamādhi avitakkavicāramattasamādhi nāma. Catukkanayepi pañcakanayepi
analyzed: dutiya jhāna samādhi avitakkavicāramattasamādhi nāma catukka naye pi pañcaka naye pi
translated: Concentration in the second jhāna is called concentration accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought.🔽In the fourfold reckoning there is concentration in the three higher jhānas, which is called concentration without applied thought and with sustained thought only.

original: upari tīsu jhānesu samādhi avitakka avicārasamādhi nāma. Samāpattīsu hi paṭipāṭiyā🔽aṭṭhannaṃ samāpattīnaṃ ‘samādhī’tipi nāmaṃ ‘samāpattī’tipi. Kasmā? Cittekaggatāsabbhāvato.
analyzed: upari tīsu jhānesu samādhi avitakka avicārasamādhi nāma samāpattīsu hi paṭipāṭiyā  aṭṭhannam samāpattīnam samādhi itipi nāmam samāpatti itipi kasmā citta ekagga tā sabbhāvato
translated: In the fivefold reckoning there is concentration in the three higher jhānas, which is called concentration without applied thought and without sustained thought.🔽For in the fivefold reckoning the first jhāna is called concentration accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought, the second is called concentration accompanied by happiness and bliss, the third is called concentration accompanied by equanimity, and the fourth, fifth and sixth jhānas are called concentration without applied thought and without sustained thought.

original: Nirodhasamāpattiyā tadabhāvato na samādhīti nāmaṃ.🔽Hānabhāgiyo dhammoti appaguṇehi paṭhamajjhānādīhi vuṭṭhitassa saññāmanasikārānaṃ
analyzed: nirodha samāpattiyā tad abhāvataḥ na samādhi iti  hāna bhāgiyaḥ dhammo ti appaguṇehi paṭhamajjhāna ādīhi vuṭṭhitassa saññā manasikārānaṃ
translated: But in the eightfold reckoning the first jhāna is called concentration accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought, the second is called concentration without applied thought and with sustained thought only, the third is called concentration accompanied by happiness and bliss, and the fourth, fifth and sixth jhānas are called concentration without applied thought and without sustained thought.🔽The “state of change” is the occurrence of the first jhāna, etc., as a succession of instants.🔽The “state of alteration” is the occurrence of the first jhāna, etc., as a succession of instants that is progressive or digressive.🔽The “state of change” is the occurrence of the first jhāna, etc., as a succession of instants.🔽The “state of alteration” is the occurrence of the first jhāna, etc., as a succession of instants that is progressive or digressive.

original: kāmādianupakkhandanaṃ. Visesabhāgiyo dhammoti paguṇehi paṭhamajjhānādīhi vuṭṭhitassa🔽saññāmanasikārānaṃ dutiyajjhānādianupakkhandanaṃ. Vodānampi vuṭṭhānanti iminā paguṇavodānaṃ
analyzed: kāma ādi anupakkhandanam visesa bhāgiyaḥ dhammo ti paguṇehi paṭhama jhāna ādīhi vuṭṭhitassa  saññā manasikārānam dutiya jhāna ādi an upakkhandanam vodānam pi vuṭṭhānam ti iminā paguṇa vodānam
translated: The “state of change” is the occurrence of the first jhāna, etc., as a succession of instants.

original: vuṭṭhānaṃ nāma kathitaṃ. Heṭṭhimaṃ heṭṭhimañhi paguṇajjhānaṃ uparimassa uparimassa
analyzed: vuṭṭhānam nāma kathitam heṭṭhimam heṭṭhimam hi paguṇa jhānam uparimassa uparimassa
translated: The “state of alteration” is the occurrence of the first jhāna, etc., as a succession of instants that is progressive or digressive.

original: padaṭṭhānaṃ hoti. Tasmā vodānampi vuṭṭhānanti vuttaṃ. Tamhā tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhānampi
analyzed: padaṭṭhānam hoti tasmā vodānam pi vuṭṭhānam ti vuttam tamhā tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhānam pi
translated: So it is said that purification is emergence. And emergence from this or that concentration is also emergence.

original: vuṭṭhānanti iminā bhavaṅgavuṭṭhānaṃ nāma kathitaṃ. Bhavaṅgena hi sabbajjhānehi vuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: vuṭṭhānam ti iminā bhavaṅga vuṭṭhānam nāma kathitam bhavaṅgena hi sabba jjhānehi vuṭṭhānam
translated: So it is said that the emergence of the life-continuum is called emergence. For the emergence from all the kinds of jhāna is by means of the life-continuum.

original: hoti. Nirodhato pana phalasamāpattiyāva vuṭṭhahanti. Idaṃ pāḷimuttakavuṭṭhānaṃ nāmāti.
analyzed: hoti nirodhato pana phala samāpattiyā ava vuṭṭhahanti idam pāḷimuttakavuṭṭhānam nāma ati
translated: But the emergence from the attainment of cessation is by means of fruition. This is called emergence in the texts.

original: Sattamabalaniddesavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: sattama bala niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the seventh power

original: Aṭṭhamabalādiniddeso
analyzed: aṭṭhama bala ādi niddeso
translated: Description of the eighth power, etc.

original: 829. Aṭṭhamabalaniddese anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsantiādi sabbampi visuddhimagge vitthāritameva. Navamabalaniddesepi dibbena cakkhunātiādi sabbaṃ tattheva vitthāritaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhama bala niddese aneka vihitam pubbenivāsa nti ādi sabbam pi visuddhi magge vitthāritam eva navama bala niddese pi dibbena cakkhunā atiādi sabbam tattha eva vitthāritam
translated: As regards the description of the eighth power, “He recollects in various ways the many different kinds of his past lives” and so on, all is as given in detail in the Path of Purification . And in the description of the ninth power, “With the divine eye … he sees beings passing away and reappearing” and so on, all is as given in detail there too .

original: Navamabalaniddesavaṇṇanā.
translated: Description of the ninth power

original: Dasamabalaniddeso
analyzed: dasama bala niddeso
translated: Description of the tenth power

original: 831. Dasamabalaniddese cetovimuttinti phalasamādhiṃ. Paññāvimuttinti phalañāṇaṃ.
analyzed: dasama bala niddese cetaḥ vimuttin ti phala samādhim paññā vimuttin ti phala ñāṇam
translated: As regards the description of the tenth power, “mind-deliverance” is the concentration that is fruition; “understanding-deliverance” is the knowledge that is fruition.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthameva. Ayaṃ tāvettha ācariyānaṃ samānatthakathā. Paravādī
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ayam tāva ettha ācariyānam samāna attha kathā paravādī
translated: The rest is clear in meaning everywhere. This, firstly, is the teachers’ commentary on the meaning in brief. The opponent’s case

original: panāha – “dasabalañāṇaṃ nāma pāṭiyekkaṃ natthi, sabbaññutañāṇassevāyaṃ pabhedo”ti.🔽Taṃ na tathā daṭṭhabbaṃ. Aññameva hi dasabalañāṇaṃ, aññaṃ sabbaññutañāṇaṃ. Dasabalañāṇañhi
analyzed: pana āha dasa bala ñāṇam nāma pāṭiyekkam natthi sabbaññuta ñāṇassa iva ayam pabhedaḥ ti  tam na tathā daṭṭhabbam aññam eva hi dasa bala ñāṇam aññam sabbaññuta ñāṇam dasa bala ñāṇam hi
translated: He says: “There is no knowledge called knowledge of the ten powers; this is a classification of the knowledge of omniscience.”🔽But that should not be regarded in that way. For the knowledge of the ten powers is one thing, the knowledge of omniscience is another.

original: sakasakakiccameva jānāti. Sabbaññutañāṇaṃ pana tampi tato avasesampi jānāti. Dasabalañāṇesupi
analyzed: sakasaka kiccam eva jānāti sabbaññuta ñāṇam pana tam pi tatas avasesam pi jānāti dasa bala ñāṇesu pi
translated: For the knowledge of the ten powers knows only the respective functions of the powers. But the knowledge of omniscience knows that too and besides it knows everything else.

original: hi paṭhamaṃ kāraṇākāraṇameva jānāti, dutiyaṃ kammantaravipākantarameva, tatiyaṃ kammaparicchedameva,
analyzed: hi paṭhamam kāraṇa akāraṇam eva jānāti dutiyam kamma antara vipāka antaram eva tatiyam kamma paricchedam eva
translated: For the first power knows only causes and non-causes; the second, only kamma and its ripening; the third, only the delimitation of kammas;

original: catutthaṃ dhātunānattakaraṇameva, pañcamaṃ sattānaṃ ajjhāsayādhimuttimeva, chaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: catuttham dhātu nānatta karaṇam eva pañcamam sattānam ajjhāsaya adhimuttim eva chaṭṭham
translated: the fourth, only the diversity of element- kinds; the fifth, only the resolution of beings’ aspirations and inclinations; the sixth,

original: indriyānaṃ tikkhamudubhāvameva, sattamaṃ jhānādīhi saddhiṃ tesaṃ saṃkilesādimeva,
analyzed: indriyānam tikkha mudu bhāvam eva sattamam jhāna ādīhi saddhim tesam saṃkilesa ādim eva
translated: only the keenness and dullness of faculties; the seventh, only the defilement, etc., of jhānas, etc.;

original: aṭṭhamaṃ pubbenivutthakhandhasantatimeva, navamaṃ sattānaṃ cutipaṭisandhimeva, dasamaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhamam pubbenivuttha khandha santatim eva navamam sattānam cuti paṭisandhim eva dasamam
translated: the eighth, only the continuity of aggregates in various past lives; the ninth, only the passing away and reappearance of beings; the tenth,🔽only the way leading to the cessation of suffering.

original: saccaparicchedameva. Sabbaññutañāṇaṃ pana etehi jānitabbañca tato uttaritarañca pajānāti.
analyzed: sacca paricchedam eva sabbaññuta ñāṇam pana etehi jānitabbam ca tatas uttaritarañca pajānāti
translated: But the knowledge of omniscience knows what is to be known by these and what is higher than they.

original: Etesaṃ pana kiccaṃ na sabbaṃ karoti. Tañhi jhānaṃ hutvā appetuṃ na sakkoti, iddhi
analyzed: etesam pana kiccam na sabbam karoti tat hi jhānam hutvā appetum na sakkoti iddhi
translated: But it does not perform all their functions. For that jhāna is unable to become inceptive,🔽and that supernormal power is unable to become a transformer,

original: hutvā vikubbituṃ na sakkoti, maggo hutvā kilese khepetuṃ na sakkoti.
analyzed: hutvā vikubbitum na sakkoti maggaḥ hutvā kilese khepetum na sakkoti
translated: and that path is unable to become a remover of defilements.

original: Apica paravādī evaṃ pucchitabbo – “dasabalañāṇaṃ nāma etaṃ savitakkasavicāraṃ, avitakkavicāramattaṃ,
analyzed: apica paravādī evam pucchitabbaḥ dasa bala ñāṇam nāma etam sa vitakka sa vicāram a vitakka vicāra mattam
translated: Besides, the opponent’s view can be questioned thus: “Is the knowledge of the ten powers with applied thought and sustained thought, or without applied thought but with sustained thought,

original: avitakkāvicāraṃ, kāmāvacaraṃ, rūpāvacaraṃ, arūpāvacaraṃ, lokiyaṃ, lokuttara”nti?🔽Jānanto “paṭipāṭiyā satta ñāṇāni savitakkasavicārānī”ti vakkhati; tato “parāni dve
analyzed: a vitakka a vicāram kāmāvacaram rūpāvacaram arūpāvacaram lokiyam lokuttaranti  jānantaḥ paṭipāṭiyā satta ñāṇāni sa vitakka sa vicārāni iti vakkhati tatas parāni dve
translated: or without applied thought and without sustained thought? Is it of the sense sphere, or of the fine-material sphere, or of the immaterial sphere? Is it mundane, or supramundane?”

original: ñāṇāni avitakkāvicārānī”ti vakkhati; “āsavakkhayañāṇaṃ siyā savitakkasavicāraṃ, siyā
analyzed: ñāṇāni a vitakka a vicārāni iti vakkhati āsava kkhaya ñāṇam siyā sa vitakka sa vicāram siyā
translated: If he knows, he will say, “The first seven kinds of knowledge are with applied thought and sustained thought,” and then, “The next two kinds of knowledge are without applied thought but with sustained thought,” and then, “The knowledge of the destruction of cankers may be with applied thought and sustained thought,

original: avitakkavicāramattaṃ, siyā avitakkavicāra”nti vakkhati. Tathā “paṭipāṭiyā satta kāmāvacarāni,
analyzed: avitakka vicāra mattam siyā avitakka vicāranti vakkhati tathā paṭipāṭiyā satta kāmāvacarāni
translated: or without applied thought but with sustained thought, or without applied thought and without sustained thought.” And so too with the rest.🔽The first seven kinds of knowledge are of the sense sphere,

original: tato dve rūpāvacarāni, avasāne ekaṃ lokuttara”nti vakkhati; “sabbaññutañāṇaṃ pana
analyzed: tatas dve rūpāvacarāni avasāne ekam lokuttaranti vakkhati sabbaññuta ñāṇam pana
translated: and then two of the fine-material sphere, and lastly one supramundane.🔽But the knowledge of omniscience is only accompanied by applied and sustained thought, it is only of the sense sphere, and it is only mundane.”

original: savitakkasavicārameva, kāmāvacarameva, lokiyamevā”ti vakkhati. Iti aññadeva dasabalañāṇaṃ,
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicāram eva kāmāvacaram eva lokiyam eva ati vakkhati iti aññat eva dasa bala ñāṇam
translated: So the ten powers’ knowledge is one thing,

original: aññaṃ sabbaññutañāṇanti.
analyzed: aññam sabbaññuta ñāṇan ti
translated: and the knowledge of omniscience is another.

original: Sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sammoha vinodaniyā vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the Commentary on the Vibhaṅga called Sammohavinodani

original: Ñāṇavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ñāṇa vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the knowledge section is ended.

original: 17. Khuddakavatthuvibhaṅgo
analyzed: khuddaka vatthu vibhaṅgaḥ
translated: The Vibhanga on the Minor Key Terms

original: 1. Ekakamātikādivaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the First Section of the Triad, etc.

original: 832. Idāni tadanantare khuddakavatthuvibhaṅgepi paṭhamaṃ mātikaṃ ṭhapetvā nikkhittapadānukkamena
analyzed: idāni tad anantare khuddaka vatthu vibhaṅge pi paṭhamam mātikam ṭhapetvā nikkhitta pada anukkamena
translated: Now, in the Vibhanga on the Minor Key Terms, which comes next, the exposition is given in the order of the terms as set out, after first setting forth the triad.🔽Here is the analysis of the terms as set out:

original: niddeso kato. Tatrāyaṃ nikkhepaparicchedo. Ādito tāva jātimadotiādayo tesattati ekakā🔽nikkhittā, tato kodho ca upanāho cātiādayo aṭṭhārasa dukā, akusalamūlādayo pañcatiṃsa
analyzed: niddeso kataḥ tatra ayam nikkhepa paricchedaḥ āditaḥ tāva ekakā  nikkhittā tatas kodho ca upanāhaḥ ca ati ādayo aṭṭhārasa dukāḥ akusala mūla ādayo pañcatiṃsa
translated: First of all, the seventy-three terms beginning with “clan-conceit” are set out singly;🔽then the eighteen terms beginning with “anger and enmity” are set out in dyads;🔽then the thirty-five terms beginning with “unprofitable roots” are set out in triads;🔽then the fourteen terms beginning with “the four corruptions” are set out in tetrads;

original: tikā, āsavacatukkādayo cuddasa catukkā, orambhāgiyasaṃyojanādayo pannarasa pañcakā,
analyzed: tikāḥ āsava catukka ādayo cuddasa catukkāḥ orambhāgiya saṃyojana ādayo pannarasa pañcakā
translated: then the fifteen terms beginning with “the fetters that are lower fetters” are set out in penads;

original: vivādamūlādayo cuddasa chakkā, anusayādayo satta sattakā, kilesavatthuādayo aṭṭha🔽aṭṭhakā, āghātavatthuādayo nava navakā, kilesavatthuādayo satta dasakā, ajjhattikassa
analyzed: vivāda mūla ādayo cuddasa chakkāḥ anusaya ādayo satta sattakā kilesa vatthu ādayo aṭṭha  aṭṭhakāḥ āghāta vatthu ādayaḥ nava navakā kilesa vatthu ādayaḥ satta dasakāḥ ajjhattikassa
translated: The fourteen wheels beginning with the root of disputes, the seven sets of seven beginning with inherent tendencies, the eight🔽sets of eight beginning with the bases for fermentations,

original: upādāya aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritānītiādayo cha aṭṭhārasakāti sabbānipi etāni aṭṭha
analyzed: upādāya aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni iti ādayo cha aṭṭhārasakā ati sabbāni pi etāni aṭṭha
translated: the nine sets of nine beginning with the grounds for annoyance, the seven sets of ten beginning with the bases for fermentations, the eighteen kinds of craving based on the internal, and so on, and the six sets of eighteen beginning with the eighteen principal insights: all these

original: kilesasatāni nikkhittānīti veditabbāni. Ayaṃ tāva nikkhepaparicchedo.
analyzed: kilesa satāni nikkhittāni iti veditabbāni ayam tāva nikkhepa paricchedaḥ
translated: should be understood as the eight hundred defilements set forth. This, firstly, is the Description of the Setting Forth.

original: (1.) Ekakaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: 1. Description of the Single Terms

original: 843-844. Idāni yathānikkhittāya mātikāya tattha katamo jātimadotiādinā nayena āraddhe🔽niddesavāre jātiṃ paṭiccāti jātiṃ nissāya. Ettha ca atthipaṭiccaṃ nāma kathitaṃ,
analyzed: idāni yathā nikkhittāya mātikāya tattha katamaḥ jāti madaḥ ti ādinā nayena āraddhe  niddesa vāre jātim paṭicca ati jātim nissāya ettha ca atthi paṭiccam nāma kathitam
translated: Now, in the Description Section, which begins with the question, “What is conceit based on birth?” in order to show the meaning of the terms in the Schedule as set forth,🔽herein, “With birth as condition” means with birth as the ground. And here the word “with” is said to be “with the existence of” ,

original: tasmā jātiyā satīti ayamettha attho. Gottaṃ paṭiccātiādīsupi eseva nayo. Madanavasena
analyzed: tasmā jātiyā sati iti ayam ettha atthaḥ gottam esa iva nayaḥ madana vasena
translated: so the meaning here is “with the existence of birth.” The same method of interpretation applies in the case of “with clan” and so on.

original: mado. Majjanākāro majjanā. Majjitabhāvo majjitattaṃ. Māno maññanātiādīni heṭṭhā dhammasaṅgahaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: madaḥ majjana ākāraḥ majjanā majjita bhāvaḥ majjitattam mānaḥ maññanā ati ādīni heṭṭhā dhamma saṅgaha ṭṭhakathā iyam
translated: The meaning of the rest is as follows. “Conceit” is the conceiving of oneself as greater, or the conceiving of oneself as equal, or the conceiving of oneself as less, in such and such a way according to the kind of conceit. “Drunkenness” is the state of being drunk. “Intoxication” is the act of being drunk. “Intoxicatedness” is the state of being intoxicated. “Conceit” is the conceiving of oneself as greater, or the conceiving of oneself as equal, or the conceiving of oneself as less, in such and such a way according to the kind of conceit. “Pride” is the state of being proud. “Arrogance” is the state of being arrogant. “Haughtiness” is the state of being haughty. “Conceit” is the conceiving of oneself as greater, or the conceiving of oneself as equal, or the conceiving of oneself as less, in such and such a way according to the kind of conceit. “Self-inflation” is the state of being self-inflated. “Self-importance” is the state of being self-important. “Self-satisfaction” is the state of being self-satisfied. “Self-satisfaction” is the state of being self-satisfied. “Self-satisfaction” is the state of being self-satisfied. “Self-

original: vuttatthāneva. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ evaṃ jātiyā sati taṃ jātiṃ nissāya uppanno majjanākārappavatto
analyzed: vutta tthānā iva ayam vuccati iti ayam evam jātiyā sati tam jātim nissāya uppannaḥ majjana ākāra ppavatto
translated: It is just this that is called: when there is birth, the arising of conceit in the form of immersion, dependent on that birth,

original: māno jātimadoti vuccati. Svāyaṃ khattiyādīnaṃ catunnampi vaṇṇānaṃ uppajjati. Jātisampanno
analyzed: mānaḥ jāti mado ti vuccati svāyam khattiya ādīnam catunnam pi vaṇṇānam uppajjati jāti sampanno
translated: is called “birth-intoxication.” This arises in all four castes, in nobles, brahmans, merchants, and workers.

original: hi khattiyo ‘mādiso añño natthi. Avasesā antarā uṭṭhāya khattiyā jātā. Ahaṃ pana
analyzed: hi khattiyo mādisaḥ aññaḥ natthi avasesāḥ antarā uṭṭhāya khattiyāḥ jātāḥ aham pana
translated: For a noble who is endowed with birth thinks: “There is no one like me. The rest of the nobles are born after rising up from between my thighs.🔽I am a noble by birth in the lineage.” A brahman thinks: “I am a brahman by birth. I am a brahman by lineage.”

original: vaṃsāgatakhattiyo’ti mānaṃ karoti. Brāhmaṇādīsupi eseva nayo. Gottamadaniddesādīsupi
analyzed: mānam karoti brāhmaṇa ādīsupi esā iva nayaḥ gotta mada niddesa ādīsupi
translated: The same method applies to merchants and workers.

original: imināvupāyena attho veditabbo. Khattiyopi hi ‘ahaṃ koṇḍaññagotto, ahaṃ ādiccagotto’ti
analyzed: iminau upāyena atthaḥ veditabbo khattiyaḥ api hi aham koṇḍañña gottaḥ aham ādicca gotto ti
translated: In the description of the intoxication of clan, etc., the meaning should be understood in this way. For a noble thinks: “I am of the Koṇḍañña clan. I am of the solar clan.”

original: mānaṃ karoti. Brāhmaṇopi ‘ahaṃ kassapagotto, ahaṃ bhāradvājagotto’ti mānaṃ karoti.
analyzed: mānam karoti brāhmaṇaḥ api aham kassapa gottaḥ aham bhāradvāja gottaḥ iti mānam karoti
translated: A brahman thinks: “I am of the Kassapa clan. I am of the Bhāradvāja clan.”

original: Vessopi suddopi attano attano kulagottaṃ nissāya mānaṃ karoti. Aṭṭhārasāpi seṇiyo
analyzed: vessaḥ api suddaḥ api attanaḥ attanaḥ kula gottam nissāya mānam karoti aṭṭhārasā api seṇiyaḥ
translated: Merchants and workers think: “We are of such and such a clan.” The eighteen clans of seers

original: ‘ekissā seṇiyā jātamhā’ti mānaṃ karontiyeva.
analyzed: ekissā seṇiyā mānam karontiyā iva
translated: think: “We are born from one seer.”

original: Ārogyamadādīsu ‘ahaṃ arogo, avasesā rogabahulā, gadduhanamattampi mayhaṃ byādhi nāma natthī’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno ārogyamado nāma.
analyzed: ārogya mada ādīsu aham arogaḥ avasesāḥ roga bahulāḥ mayham byādhi nāma natthi iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ ārogya madaḥ nāma
translated: Conceit in the form of self-satisfaction in one’s health, etc., is called “conceit due to health,” “conceit due to youth,” “conceit due to life,” “conceit due to gain,” and “conceit due to honour.”

original: ‘Ahaṃ taruṇo, avasesasattānaṃ attabhāvo papāte ṭhitarukkhasadiso, ahaṃ pana paṭhamavaye ṭhito’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno yobbanamado nāma.
analyzed: aham taruṇaḥ avasesa sattānam atta bhāvo papāte ṭhita rukkha sadisaḥ aham pana paṭhama vaye ṭhitaḥ ti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ yobbana madaḥ nāma
translated: Conceit in the form of self-satisfaction in the thought, “I am young; the bodies of other beings are like trees on a cliff-face, but I am in the first stage of life,” is called “conceit due to youth.”

original: ‘Ahaṃ ciraṃ jīviṃ, ciraṃ jīvāmi, ciraṃ jīvissāmi; sukhaṃ jīviṃ, sukhaṃ jīvāmi, sukhaṃ jīvissāmī’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno jīvitamado nāma.
analyzed: aham ciram jīvim ciram jīvāmi ciram jīvissāmi sukham jīvim sukham jīvāmi sukham jīvissāmi iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ jīvita madaḥ nāma
translated: Conceit in the form of self-satisfaction in the thought, “I have lived long; I am living long; I shall live long; I have lived happily; I am living happily; I shall live happily,” is called “conceit due to life.”

original: ‘Ahaṃ lābhī, avasesā sattā appalābhā, mayhaṃ pana lābhassa pamāṇaṃ nāma natthī’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno lābhamado nāma.
analyzed: aham lābhī avasesā sattāḥ appalābhāḥ mayham pana lābhassa pamāṇam nāma natthi iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ lābhamadaḥ nāma
translated: Conceit in the form of self-satisfaction in the thought, “I am successful; other beings are unsuccessful; there is no limit to my success,” is called “conceit due to gain.”

original: ‘Avasesā sattā yaṃ vā taṃ vā labhanti, ahaṃ pana sukataṃ paṇītaṃ cīvarādipaccayaṃ labhāmī’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno sakkāramado nāma.
analyzed: avasesā sattā yam vā tam vā labhanti aham pana su katam paṇītam cīvara ādi paccayam labhāmi iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ sakkāramadaḥ nāma
translated: Conceit in the form of self-satisfaction in the thought, “Other beings get this or that, but I get only well-made, fine robes, etc.,” is called “conceit due to honour.”

original: ‘Avasesabhikkhūnaṃ pādapiṭṭhiyaṃ akkamitvā gacchantā manussā ayaṃ samaṇotipi na vandanti,
analyzed: avasesa bhikkhūnam pāda piṭṭhiyam akkamitvā gacchantāḥ manussāḥ ayam samaṇaḥ ti pi na vandanti
translated: ‘People walk over the backs of the other bhikkhus’ feet, and they do not even pay homage to them, saying, “That is an ascetic.”

original: maṃ pana disvāva vandanti, pāsāṇacchattaṃ viya garuṃ katvā aggikkhandhaṃ viya ca
analyzed: mam pana disvā ava vandanti pāsāṇa chattam viya garum katvā aggi kkhandham viya ca
translated: But when they see me, they pay homage to me, thinking that I am venerable,

original: durāsadaṃ katvā maññantī’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno garukāramado nāma.
analyzed: durāsadam katvā maññanti iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ garukāra madaḥ nāma
translated: like a stone umbrella, or like a mass of fire that is hard to approach.” The conceit that arises in this way is called “conceit due to respect.”

original: ‘Uppanno pañho mayhameva mukhena chijjati, bhikkhācāraṃ gacchantāpi mameva purato katvā parivāretvā gacchantī’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno purekkhāramado nāma.
analyzed: uppannaḥ pañhaḥ mayham eva mukhena chijjati bhikkhācāram gacchantā api mama eva puratas katvā parivāretvā gacchanti iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ purekkhāramadaḥ nāma
translated: ‘The question that has arisen is settled by my own mouth. When they go on their alms round, they surround me, putting me in front.’ The conceit that arises in this way is called “conceit due to pre-eminence.”

original: Agārikassa tāva mahāparivārassa ‘purisasatampi purisasahassampi maṃ parivāreti,’
analyzed: agārikassa tāva mahā parivārassa purisa satam pi purisa sahassam pi mam parivāreti
translated: ‘I have a large retinue. A hundred men or a thousand men surround me.’

original: anagāriyassa pana ‘samaṇasatampi samaṇasahassampi maṃ parivāreti, sesā appaparivārā,
analyzed: anagāriyassa pana samaṇa satam pi samaṇa sahassam pi mam parivāreti sesāḥ appa parivārā
translated: ‘I have a large retinue. A hundred ascetics or a thousand ascetics surround me. The others have a small retinue.

original: ahaṃ mahāparivāro ceva suciparivāro cā’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno parivāramado nāma.
analyzed: aham mahā parivāraḥ ca iva suci parivāraḥ ca ati majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ parivāramadaḥ nāma
translated: I have a large retinue and a pure retinue.” The conceit that arises in this way is called “conceit due to retinue.”

original: Bhogo pana kiñcāpi lābhaggahaṇeneva gahito hoti, imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne nikkheparāsi🔽nāma gahito; tasmā ‘avasesā sattā attano paribhogamattampi na labhanti, mayhaṃ pana
analyzed: bhogo pana kiñcā api lābha ggahaṇena iva gahito hoti imasmim pana ṭhāne  nāma gahitaḥ tasmai avasesāḥ sattāḥ attano paribhogam attam pi na labhanti mayham pana
translated: But though pride of possession is included in the pride of gain, here it is included in the pride of store.

original: nidhānagatasseva dhanassa pamāṇaṃ natthī’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno bhogamado nāma.
analyzed: nidhāna gatassa iva dhanassa pamāṇam natthi iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ bhogamadaḥ nāma
translated: So this is the kind of conceit that occurs as “Others do not get even the use of their own property, but as for me, there is no limit to my wealth, which is like a treasure trove” .

original: Vaṇṇaṃ paṭiccāti sarīravaṇṇampi guṇavaṇṇampi paṭicca. ‘Avasesā sattā dubbaṇṇā durūpā,
analyzed: vaṇṇam paṭicca ati sarīra vaṇṇam pi guṇa vaṇṇam pi paṭicca avasesā sattā dubbaṇṇā durūpā
translated: “On account of beauty”: on account of bodily beauty and on account of the beauty of special qualities. “Others are ugly, ill-formed,

original: ahaṃ pana abhirūpo pāsādiko; avasesā sattā nigguṇā patthaṭaakittino, mayhaṃ pana
analyzed: aham pana abhirūpaḥ pāsādikaḥ avasesā sattā nigguṇā patthaṭa akittinaḥ mayham pana
translated: but I am beautiful, handsome. Others are devoid of special qualities, are uncelebrated, unknown, but

original: kittisaddo devamanussesu pākaṭo – itipi thero bahussuto, itipi sīlavā, itipi dhutaguṇayutto’ti
analyzed: kitti saddaḥ deva manussesu pākaṭaḥ iti pi theraḥ bahu ssutaḥ itipi sīlavā itipi dhuta guṇa yutto ti
translated: my fame and renown are well proclaimed among gods and men. He is a senior elder, he is learned, he is virtuous, he is possessed of special qualities” .

original: majjanavasena uppanno māno vaṇṇamado nāma.
analyzed: majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ vaṇṇamadaḥ nāma
translated: This is the kind of conceit that occurs as “I am superior” .🔽“Others are ignorant, but I am learned” .

original: ‘Avasesā sattā appassutā, ahaṃ pana bahussuto’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno sutamado nāma.
analyzed: avasesā sattā appassutā aham pana bahu ssutaḥ ti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ sutamadaḥ nāma
translated: This is the kind of conceit that occurs as “I am superior” .

original: ‘Avasesā sattā appaṭibhānā, mayhaṃ pana paṭibhānassa pamāṇaṃ natthī’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno paṭibhānamado nāma.
analyzed: avasesā sattā appaṭibhānā mayham pana paṭibhānassa pamāṇam natthi iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ paṭibhānamadaḥ nāma
translated: Arrogance in the form of self-satisfaction in one’s eloquence is the conceiving of conceit in the form of self-satisfaction in the thought: “Other beings are without eloquence, but there is no limit to my eloquence.”

original: ‘Ahaṃ rattaññū asukaṃ buddhavaṃsaṃ, rājavaṃsaṃ, janapadavaṃsaṃ, gāmavaṃsaṃ, rattindivaparicchedaṃ, nakkhattamuhuttayogaṃ jānāmī’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno rattaññumado nāma.
analyzed: aham rattaññū asukam buddha vaṃsam rāja vaṃsam janapada vaṃsam gāma vaṃsam ratti indiva paricchedam nakkhatta muhutta yogam jānāmi iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ rattaññumadaḥ nāma
translated: Arrogance in the form of self-satisfaction in one’s seniority is the conceiving of conceit in the form of self-satisfaction in the thought: “I am senior in this Dispensation, in this lineage, in this clan, in this craft, in this art, in this profession, in this occupation, in this family, in this group, in this order, in this spiritual order.”

original: ‘Avasesā bhikkhū antarā piṇḍapātikā jātā, ahaṃ pana jātipiṇḍapātiko’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno piṇḍapātikamado nāma.🔽‘Avasesā sattā uññātā avaññātā, ahaṃ pana anuññāto anavaññāto’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno anavaññātamado nāma.
analyzed: avasesāḥ bhikkhū antarā piṇḍapātikāḥ jātāḥ aham pana jāti piṇḍapātikaḥ iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ piṇḍapātika madaḥ nāma  avasesā sattā uññātā avaññātā aham pana anuññātaḥ anavaññātaḥ ti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ anavaññātamadaḥ nāma
translated: Arrogance in the form of self-satisfaction in one’s alms-food is the conceiving of conceit in the form of self-satisfaction in the thought: “Other bhikkhus are recipients of alms-food given by chance, but I am a recipient of choice alms-food.”🔽Arrogance in the form of self-satisfaction in one’s freedom from blame is the conceiving of conceit in the form of self-satisfaction in the thought: “Other beings are blamed, but I am not blamed.”

original: ‘Avasesānaṃ iriyāpatho apāsādiko, mayhaṃ pana pāsādiko’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno iriyāpathamado nāma.
analyzed: avasesānam iriyāpathaḥ apāsādikaḥ mayham pana pāsādikaḥ iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ iriyāpatha madaḥ nāma
translated: Arrogance in the form of self-satisfaction in one’s deportment is the conceiving of conceit in the form of self-satisfaction in the thought: “The deportment of other beings is unseemly, but mine is seemly.”

original: ‘Avasesā sattā chinnapakkhakākasadisā, ahaṃ pana mahiddhiko mahānubhāvo’ti vā ‘ahaṃ yaṃ yaṃ kammaṃ karomi, taṃ taṃ ijjhatī’ti vā majjanavasena uppanno māno iddhimado nāma.
analyzed: avasesā sattā chinna pakkha kāka sadisā aham pana mahiddhikaḥ mahā anubhāvaḥ ti vā aham yam yam kammam karomi tam tam ijjhati iti vā majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ iddhi madaḥ nāma
translated: ‘Other beings are like a one-winged bird, but I am powerful and mighty’ or ‘Whatever I undertake succeeds’—this is the kind of conceit called ‘conceit of success.’

original: Heṭṭhā parivāraggahaṇena yaso gahitova hoti. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne upaṭṭhākamado nāma🔽gahito. So agārikenapi anagārikenapi dīpetabbo. Agāriko hi ekacco aṭṭhārasasu seṇīsu🔽ekissā jeṭṭhako hoti, tassa ‘avasese purise ahaṃ paṭṭhapemi, ahaṃ vicāremī’ti; anagārikopi🔽ekacco katthaci jeṭṭhako hoti, tassa ‘avasesā bhikkhū mayhaṃ ovāde vattanti, ahaṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhā parivāra ggahaṇena yasaḥ gahitaḥ iva hoti imasmin pana ṭhāne upaṭṭhākamadaḥ nāma  gahitaḥ saḥ agārikena api anagārikena api dīpetabbaḥ agārikaḥ hi ekaccaḥ aṭṭhārasasu seṇīsu  ekissā jeṭṭhakaḥ hoti tassa avasese purise aham paṭṭhapemi aham vicāremi iti anagārikaḥ pi  ekacco katthaci jeṭṭhakaḥ hoti tassa avasesā bhikkhū mayhaṃ ovāde vattanti aham
translated: ‘Conceit of gain’ is included in the ‘surroundings’ mentioned above. But in this place ‘conceit of attendants’ is included.

original: jeṭṭhako’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno yasamado nāma.
analyzed: jeṭṭhako ti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ yasamadaḥ nāma
translated: This can be illustrated by both a layman and a monk. For a layman, for instance, who is the head of a guild of eighteen corporations, thinks: ‘I am the one who appoints and dismisses these people, I am the one who gives them their wages.’ And a monk who is the head of a large community of monks thinks: ‘These monks are under my guidance, I am the head of the community.’ This is the kind of conceit called ‘conceit of attendants.’

original: ‘Avasesā sattā dussīlā, ahaṃ pana sīlavā’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno sīlamado nāma.
analyzed: avasesā sattā dussīlā aham pana sīlavāti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ sīlamadaḥ nāma
translated: ‘Conceit of virtue’ is the kind of conceit that arises when one thinks: ‘Other beings are immoral, but I am virtuous.’

original: ‘Avasesasattānaṃ kukkuṭassa udakapānamattepi kāle cittekaggatā natthi, ahaṃ pana
analyzed: avasesa sattānam kukkuṭassa udaka pāna matte pi kāle citta ekagga tā natthi aham pana
translated: ‘Other beings have no unification of mind even for the time it takes to drink a mouthful of water, but I am

original: upacārappanānaṃ lābhī’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno jhānamado nāma.🔽‘Avasesā sattā nissippā, ahaṃ pana sippavā’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno sippamado
analyzed: upacāra ppanānam lābhī iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ jhānamadaḥ nāma  avasesāḥ sattāḥ nissippāḥ aham pana sippavā āti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ sippa madaḥ
translated: a gainer of access and absorption concentration,’ the conceit that arises in this way is called ‘conceit in jhāna.’🔽‘Other beings are unskilful, but I am skilful,’ the conceit that arises in this way is called ‘conceit in skill.’

original: nāma. ‘Avasesā sattā rassā, ahaṃ pana dīgho’ti majjanavasena uppanno māno ārohamado🔽nāma. ‘Avasesā sattā rassā vā honti dīghā vā, ahaṃ nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo’ti majjanavasena🔽uppanno māno pariṇāhamado nāma. ‘Avasesasattānaṃ sarīrasaṇṭhānaṃ virūpaṃ bībhacchaṃ,
analyzed: nāma avasesā sattā rassāḥ aham pana dīghaḥ ti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ āroha madaḥ  nāma avasesā sattā rassāḥ vā honti dīghā vā aham majjana vasena  uppannaḥ mānaḥ pariṇāha madaḥ nāma avasesa sattānam sarīra saṇṭhānam virūpam bībhaccham
translated: ‘Other beings are short, but I am tall,’ the conceit that arises in this way is called ‘conceit in height.’🔽‘Other beings are either short or tall, but I am well-proportioned like a nyagrodha tree,’ the conceit that arises in this way is called ‘conceit in being well-proportioned.’

original: mayhaṃ pana manāpaṃ pāsādika’nti majjanavasena uppanno māno saṇṭhānamado nāma. ‘Avasesānaṃ
analyzed: mayham pana manāpam pāsādikam ti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ saṇṭhāna madaḥ nāma avasesānam
translated: ‘The bodily shape of other beings is ugly and repulsive, but mine is pleasing and inspiring,’ the conceit that arises in this way is called ‘conceit in shape.’

original: sattānaṃ sarīre bahū dosā, mayhaṃ pana sarīre kesaggamattampi vajjaṃ natthī’ti majjanavasena
analyzed: sattānam sarīre bahū dosāḥ mayham pana sarīre kesagga mattam pi vajjam natthi iti majjana vasena
translated: ‘In the bodies of other beings there are many imperfections, but in my body there is not even as much as a hair’s end of anything to be blamed,’ the conceit that arises in this way is called ‘conceit in blamelessness.’

original: uppanno māno pāripūrimado nāma.
analyzed: uppannaḥ mānaḥ pāripūrimadaḥ nāma
translated: Conceit that has arisen is called “conceit of fulfilment”.

original: 845. Iminā ettakena ṭhānena savatthukaṃ mānaṃ kathetvā idāni avatthukaṃ nibbattitamānameva dassento tattha katamo madotiādimāha. Taṃ uttānatthameva.
analyzed: iminā ettakena ṭhānena sa vatthukam mānam kathetvā idāni avatthukam nibbattita mānam eva dassentaḥ tattha katamaḥ mada iti ādim āha tam uttāna attham eva
translated: Having thus described conceit with a basis in the first part of this chapter, the Master now shows conceit without a basis, beginning with the words “What is conceit? “ The meaning is clear.

original: 846. Pamādaniddese cittassa vossaggoti imesu ettakesu ṭhānesu satiyā aniggaṇhitvā🔽cittassa vossajjanaṃ; sativirahoti attho. Vossaggānuppadānanti vossaggassa anuppadānaṃ;
analyzed: pamāda niddese cittassa vossaggo ti imesu ettakesu ṭhānesu satiyā a niggaṇhitvā  cittassa vossajjanam sati virahaḥ ti attho vossagga anuppadānam ti vossaggassa anuppadānam
translated: In the description of negligence, “giving up of mindfulness” means giving up of the mind to these things without being restrained by mindfulness.🔽“Non-arising of giving up” means non-arising of giving up;🔽the meaning is: not giving up again and again. “Negligence” means the state of being negligent.🔽“Non-diligence” means the state of being non-diligent.🔽“Non-diligence” means the state of being non-diligent.

original: punappunaṃ vissajjananti attho. Asakkaccakiriyatāti etesaṃ dānādīnaṃ kusaladhammānaṃ🔽bhāvanāya puggalassa vā deyyadhammassa vā asakkaccakaraṇavasena asakkaccakiriyā.🔽Satatabhāvo sātaccaṃ. Na satatabhāvo asātaccaṃ. Na sātaccakiriyatā asātaccakiriyatā.
analyzed: punappunam vissajjananti atthaḥ etesam dāna ādīnam kusala dhammānam  bhāvanāya puggalassa vā deyya dhammassa vā asakkacca karaṇa vasena asakkacca kiriyā  satata bhāvaḥ sātaccam na satata bhāvaḥ asātaccam na
translated: “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast. “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast.🔽“Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast. “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast.🔽“Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast. “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast.🔽“Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast. “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast.🔽“Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast. “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast.🔽“Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast. “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast.🔽“Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast. “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast.🔽“Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast. “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast.🔽“Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast. “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast.🔽“Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast. “Non-steadfastness” means the state of being non-steadfast.

original: Anaṭṭhitakaraṇaṃ anaṭṭhitakiriyatā. Yathā nāma kakaṇṭako thokaṃ gantvā thokaṃ tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: an aṭṭhita karaṇam an aṭṭhita kiriya tā yathā nāma kakaṇṭakaḥ thokam gantvā thokam tiṭṭhati
translated: “Non-stead

original: na nirantaraṃ gacchati, evameva yo puggalo ekadivasaṃ dānaṃ vā datvā pūjaṃ vā katvā
analyzed: na nirantaram gacchati evam eva yaḥ puggalaḥ eka divasam dānam vā da tvā pūjam vā katvā
translated: Just as a man who has gone a certain distance and then returns does not go on without a break, so too, when a person gives a gift or performs a rite of worship or listens to the Dhamma or practises the Dhamma in some such way on one day,

original: dhammaṃ vā sutvā samaṇadhammaṃ vā katvā puna cirassaṃ karoti, na nirantaraṃ pavatteti,
analyzed: dhammam vā sutvā samaṇa dhammam vā katvā puna cirassam karoti na nirantaram pavatteti
translated: and then does not do so for a long time afterwards, but only does it again after a considerable interval,

original: tassa sā kiriyā anaṭṭhitakiriyatāti vuccati. Olīnavuttitāti nirantarakaraṇasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: tassa sā kiriyā anaṭṭhita kiriya tā ti vuccati olīna vutti tā ti nirantara karaṇa saṅkhātassa
translated: then his action is called “not continuous.” “Unstable” : because there is no development of the action by uninterrupted performance.

original: vipphārasseva abhāvena līnavuttitā. Nikkhittachandatāti kusalakiriyāya vīriyachandassa
analyzed: vipphārassa iva abhāvena līna vutti tā nikkhitta chanda tā ati kusala kiriyāya vīriya chandassa
translated: “Lacking in devoted effort” : the state of not having devoted effort for the performance of profitable action.

original: nikkhittabhāvo. Nikkhittadhuratāti vīriyadhurassa oropanaṃ, osakkitamānasatāti attho.
analyzed: nikkhitta bhāvaḥ nikkhitta dhura tā ati vīriya dhurassa oropanam osakkita mānasa tā ati attho
translated: “Lacking in energy” : the state of letting the energy for the performance of profitable action drop, the state of having a slack mind, is what is meant.

original: Anadhiṭṭhānanti kusalakaraṇe patiṭṭhābhāvo. Ananuyogoti ananuyuñjanaṃ. Pamādoti pamajjanaṃ.🔽Yo evarūpo pamādoti idaṃ atthapariyāyassa byañjanapariyāyassa ca pariyantābhāvato
analyzed: an adhiṭṭhāna nti kusala karaṇe patiṭṭhā bhāvaḥ an anuyogaḥ uti an anuyuñjanam pamādaḥ iti pamajjanam  yaḥ evarūpaḥ pamādaḥ ti idam attha pariyāyassa byañjana pariyāyassa ca pariyanta abhāvato
translated: “Lacking in determination” : the state of not being determined to perform profitable action. “Lacking in application” : the state of not applying oneself. “Negligence” : the state of being negligent.

original: ākāradassanaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yvāyaṃ ādito paṭṭhāya dassito pamādo, yo aññopi
analyzed: ākāra dassanam idam vuttam hoti yvā ayam āditaḥ paṭṭhāya dassitaḥ pamādaḥ yaḥ aññaḥ api
translated: “This kind of negligence” : this is the seeing of the mode of this kind of negligence, which has no end either as to the variety of its meanings or as to the variety of its phrasing. This is what is meant:

original: evamākāro evaṃjātiko pamādo pamajjanākāravasena pamajjanā, pamajjitabhāvavasena pamajjitattanti
analyzed: evam ākāraḥ evaṃjātikaḥ pamādaḥ pamajjana ākāra vasena pamajjanā pamajjita bhāva vasena
translated: Thus the characteristic of negligence is the state of being negligent, the state of being negligent by way of the mode of being negligent, the state of being negligent by way of the mode of negligence. The state of being negligent is called negligence.

original: saṅkhaṃ gato – ayaṃ vuccati pamādoti. Lakkhaṇato panesa pañcasu kāmaguṇesu sativossaggalakkhaṇo,🔽tattheva satiyā vissaṭṭhākāro veditabbo.🔽847. Thambhaniddese thaddhaṭṭhena thambho; khaliyā thaddhasāṭakassa viya cittassa
analyzed: saṅkham gataḥ ayam vuccati pamādaḥ ti lakkhaṇato pana esa pañcasu kāmaguṇesu sati vossagga lakkhaṇo  tattha iva satiyāḥ vissaṭṭha ākāraḥ veditabbo  thambha niddese thaddha aṭṭhena thambho khaliyā thaddha sāṭakassa viya cittassa
translated: But by way of its characteristic, it is the characteristic of the relinquishing of mindfulness in regard to the five strands of sense pleasure.🔽The mode of being negligent should be understood as the mode of being negligent by way of the relinquishing of mindfulness in regard to the five strands of sense pleasure.🔽In the description of stiffness, stiffness is in the sense of rigidity. The rigidity of the mind is spoken of here as it is of a stiff cloth.

original: thaddhatā ettha kathitā. Thambhanākāro thambhanā. Thambhitassa bhāvo thambhitattaṃ.
analyzed: ettha kathitā thambhana ākāraḥ thambhanā thambhitassa bhāvaḥ thambhita ttam
translated: The mode of stiffness is stiffness. The state of being stiff is stiffness.

original: Kakkhaḷassa puggalassa bhāvo kakkhaḷiyaṃ. Pharusassa puggalassa bhāvo phārusiyaṃ.
analyzed: kakkhaḷassa puggalassa bhāvaḥ kakkhaḷiyam pharusassa puggalassa bhāvaḥ phārusiyam
translated: The state of a harsh person is harshness. The state of a rough person is roughness.

original: Abhivādanādisāmīcirahānaṃ tassā sāmīciyā akaraṇavasena ujumeva ṭhapitacittabhāvo
analyzed: abhivādana ādi sāmīci rahānam tassā sāmīciyāḥ akaraṇa vasena ujum eva ṭhapita citta bhāvaḥ
translated: The state of mind that is set in its own way, by not doing what is proper such as paying respect, etc.,

original: ujucittatā. Thaddhassa amuduno bhāvo amudutā. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ thambho nāma vuccati,
analyzed: uju citta tā thaddhassa amudunaḥ bhāvaḥ amudu tā ayam vuccati iti ayam thambho nāma vuccati
translated: is crookedness of mind. The state of being stiff, not being pliable, is unpliancy. This is called stiffness.

original: yena samannāgato puggalo gilitanaṅgalasīso viya ajagaro, vātabharitā viya bhastā
analyzed: yena samannāgataḥ puggalo gilita naṅgala sīsaḥ viya ajagaraḥ vāta bharitā viya bhastā
translated: A person possessed of this vice is like a snake with its hood spread, or like a bellows full of wind.

original: cetiyaṃ vā vuḍḍhatare vā disvā onamituṃ na sakkoti, pariyanteneva carati. Svāyaṃ
analyzed: cetiyam vā vuḍḍhatare vā disvā onamitum na sakkoti pariyantena iva carati svāyam
translated: When he sees a shrine or a senior monk, he is unable to bow down; he goes about with his head held high.

original: cittassa uddhumātabhāvalakkhaṇoti veditabbo.
analyzed: cittassa uddhumāta bhāva lakkhaṇo ti veditabbo
translated: This vice should be understood as the bloatedness of the mind.

original: 848. Sārambhaniddese sārambhanavasena sārambho. Paṭippharitvā sārambho paṭisārambho.🔽Sārambhanākāro sārambhanā. Paṭippharitvā sārambhanā paṭisārambhanā. Paṭisārambhitassa
analyzed: sārambha niddese sārambhana vasena sārambho paṭippharitvā sārambho paṭisārambho  sa ārambhana ākāraḥ sā ārambhanā paṭippharitvā sā ārambhanā paṭisārambhanā paṭisārambhitassa
translated: In the description of the agitated, the agitated is so called because of agitation. The agitated is the agitated after agitation.🔽The agitated aspect is agitation. The agitated after agitation is agitation after agitation.

original: bhāvo paṭisārambhitattaṃ. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ sārambho nāma vuccati. Svāyaṃ lakkhaṇato🔽karaṇuttariyalakkhaṇo nāma vuccati, yena samannāgato puggalo taddiguṇaṃ taddiguṇaṃ
analyzed: bhāvaḥ paṭisārambhi tattam ayam vuccati iti ayam sārambhaḥ nāma vuccati svāyam lakkhaṇato  karaṇa uttariya lakkhaṇo nāma vuccati yena samannāgataḥ puggalo tad diguṇam tad diguṇam
translated: The state of being agitated after agitation is agitation after agitation. This is called the agitated: this vice called the agitated is called the vice of agitation.

original: karoti. Agāriko samāno ekenekasmiṃ gharavatthusmiṃ sajjite aparo dve vatthūni sajjeti,
analyzed: karoti agāriko samānaḥ ekena ekasmim ghara vatthusmim sajjite aparaḥ dve vatthūni sajjeti
translated: A person possessed of this vice is like a monkey that has caught hold of a branch and lets go of it only to catch hold of another;🔽or like a fish that darts this way and that. A person possessed of this vice is like a man who has been given a hundred thousand but who, instead of being satisfied, wants a million.

original: aparo cattāri, aparo aṭṭha, aparo soḷasa. Anagāriko samāno ekenekasmiṃ nikāye gahite,
analyzed: aparo cattāri aparaḥ aṭṭha aparaḥ soḷasa anagāriko samāno ekena ekasmin nikāye gahite
translated: Another four, another eight, another sixteen. When he is not a monastic, he may take up one,

original: ‘nāhaṃ etassa heṭṭhā bhavissāmī’ti aparo dve gaṇhāti, aparo tayo, aparo cattāro,
analyzed: na aham etassa heṭṭhā bhavissāmi iti aparaḥ dve gaṇhāti aparaḥ tayaḥ aparaḥ cattāraḥ
translated: ‘I will not be below this,’ another two, another three, another four,

original: aparo pañca. Sārambhavasena hi gaṇhituṃ na vaṭṭati. Akusalapakkho esa nirayagāmimaggo.
analyzed: aparaḥ pañca sa ārambha vasena hi gaṇhitum na vaṭṭati akusala pakkhaḥ esa niraya gāmi maggo

translated: Here are the stories of the three. A young bhikkhu was fond of cakes. Then his mother,

original: vīmaṃsamānā ‘sace me putto paṭiggahaṇe mattaṃ jānāti, sakalampi naṃ temāsaṃ pūveheva
analyzed: vīmaṃsamānā sace me putto paṭiggahaṇe mattam jānāti sakalam pi nam
translated: testing him, thought: ‘If my son knows the right amount to take, I shall attend on him for the three months with cakes alone.’

original: tasmiṃ niṭṭhite dutiyaṃ, tasmimpi niṭṭhite tatiyaṃ. Daharo ‘ala’nti avatvā khādiyeva.
analyzed: tasmin niṭṭhite dutiyam tasmin pi niṭṭhite tatiyam daharaḥ avatvā khādiya iva
translated: and when he had finished that, a second, and when he had finished that, a third. The young bhikkhu did not say, ‘That is enough,’ but he ate them all.

original: Mātā tassa amattaññubhāvaṃ ñatvā ‘ajjeva me puttena sakalatemāsassa pūvā khāditā’ti
analyzed: mātā tassa amattaññu bhāvam ñatvā ajjā iva me puttena sakalatemāsassa pūvā khāditā ati
translated: His mother, realizing that he did not know the right amount, thought, ‘Today my son has eaten cakes for the whole three months,’

original: dutiyadivasato paṭṭhāya ekapūvampi na adāsi.
analyzed: dutiya divasato paṭṭhāya na adāsi
translated: and from the next day she gave him not even one cake.

original: Tissamahārājāpi devasikaṃ cetiyapabbate bhikkhusaṅghassa dānaṃ dadamāno ‘mahārāja,
analyzed: tissa mahārājā api devasikam cetiyapabbate bhikkhu saṅghassa dānam dadamānaḥ mahā rāja
translated: And King Tissa, who was giving a daily gift to the Community of Bhikkhus on Cetiya Mountain,

analyzed: kim ekam eva ṭhānam bhajasi kim aññattha dātum na vaṭṭati iti jānapadehi vuttaḥ dutiya divase

analyzed: paṭiggahitam khādanīya bhojanīyam dve tayaḥ janāḥ ukkhipiṃsu rājā dutiya divase cetiyapabbate
translated: Each monk accepted food and drink, and two or three people had to carry it away. On the following day, the king

original: bhikkhusaṅghaṃ nimantāpetvā rājantepuraṃ āgatakāle “pattaṃ dethā”ti āha. “Alaṃ, mahārāja,
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgham nimantāpetvā rājantepuram āgata kāle pattam detha iti āha alam mahā rāja
translated: invited the Community of monks to the Jetavana Monastery. When they arrived at the royal palace, he said, “Give them bowls.” “There is no need, great king.

original: attano pamāṇena bhikkhaṃ gaṇhissatī”ti ekabhikkhupi pattaṃ na adāsi. Sabbe pamāṇayuttakameva
analyzed: attanaḥ pamāṇena bhikkham gaṇhissati iti pattam na adāsi sabbe pamāṇa yuttakam eva
translated: They will take alms according to their own measure.” Not a single monk gave a bowl. All of them accepted only what they could measure.

original: paṭiggahesuṃ. Atha rājā āha – “passatha tumhākaṃ bhikkhūsu ekopi mattaṃ na jānāti.
analyzed: paṭiggahesuṃ atha rājā āha passatha tumhākam bhikkhūsu ekaḥ api mattam na jānāti
translated: Then the king said, “Look! Not a single one of your monks knows moderation.

original: Hiyyo kiñci avasesaṃ nāhosi. Ajja gahitaṃ mandaṃ, avasesameva bahū”ti tesaṃ mattaññutāya
analyzed: hiyyas kiñci avasesam na ahosi ajja gahitam mandam avasesam eva bahu ti tesam mattaññu tāya
translated: Yesterday there was nothing left over. Today what has been accepted is slow, and there is much left over.” He was pleased with their moderation

original: 851. Pāpicchatāniddese assaddho samāno saddhoti maṃ jano jānātūtiādīsu evaṃ icchanto

analyzed: kim karoti assaddhaḥ saddhā ākāram dasseti dussīla ādayaḥ sīlavanta ādīnam ākāram dassenti  katham assaddhaḥ tāva mahā maha divase manussānam vihāram āgamana velāya sammajjanim

original: ayameva imaṃ vihāraṃ paṭijaggati, saddho thero’ti gamanakāle nimantetvā gacchanti.

translated: He alone looks after it. He is a faithful elder.” When they go to invite him,

analyzed: dussīlaḥ upi upaṭṭhākānam sammukhe vinaya dharam upasaṅkamitvā pucchati bhante mayi
translated: The unvirtuous approaches a vinaya expert in the presence of his supporters and asks him,

analyzed: caṅkamantassa me pāṇakāḥ mīyanti kheḷam pātentassa asatiyā tiṇa matthake patati tattha

translated: When told this, he said, “Venerables,

analyzed: ayyo ettake pi kukkuccāyati aññasmin oḷārike kim nāma karissati na atthi iminā sadiso

translated: So-and-so is a master of the four Nikāyas. So-and-so is my pupil. He learned the Teaching from me.”

analyzed: manussāḥ amhākam ayyena sadisaḥ bahu ssutaḥ natthi etassa kira santike asukena ca asukena
translated: People said, “There is no one as learned as our Venerable. It is said that so-and-so and so-and-so

translated: People, saying, “There is no one more learned than our venerable,” show their appreciation by making offerings to him.

analyzed: rukkhamūle divāvihāram nisīdati manussāḥ āgantvā theraḥ kuhinti pucchanti gaṇṭhika puttā  nāma gaṇṭhikāḥ eva honti tena theraḥ evarūpe kāle idha na nisīdati vihāra paccante
translated: under a tree, for his daytime rest. People come and ask, “Where is the elder?” “The sons of Gaṇṭhi,

analyzed: divāṭṭhāne dīghacaṅkame viharati iti vadanti saḥ api divasa bhāgam nalāṭe

analyzed: makkaṭa suttam alliyāpetvā pīṭham gāhāpetvā āgamma pariveṇa dvāre nisīdati manussā

analyzed: kaham bhante gatatthe āgantvā na vadanti upāsakāḥ antovihāraḥ ākiṇṇaḥ
translated: People say, “Where did you go, venerable sir? We didn’t see you.” “Lay followers, the monastery was crowded;

analyzed: vicaraṇa ṭhānam etam saṭṭhi hattha caṅkame divāṭṭhāne nisīdimha ati
translated: “This is the place where young novices walk up and down. We sat down in the pavilion, which is sixty cubits long.”

original: attano pavivittabhāvaṃ jānāpeti.
analyzed: attanaḥ pavivitta bhāvam jānāpeti
translated: In this way he makes it known that he is living in solitude.

original: Kusītopi upaṭṭhākamajjhe nisinno “upāsakā, tumhehi ukkāpāto diṭṭho”ti vadati. “Na
analyzed: kusītaḥ api upaṭṭhāka majjhe nisinnaḥ upāsakā tumhehi ukkāpātaḥ diṭṭho ti vadati na
translated: The lazy one, sitting in the midst of the attendants, says, “Lay followers, have you seen a shooting star?”🔽“No, venerable sir. What time was it?”

original: passāma, bhante; kāya velāya ahosī”ti ca puṭṭho “amhākaṃ caṅkamanavelāyā”ti vatvā
analyzed: passāma bhante kāya velāya ahosi iti ca puṭṭhaḥ amhākam caṅkamana velāya ati vatvā
translated: “It was at the time of our walking up and down.”🔽“Have you heard the sound of an earthquake?”

analyzed: bhūmicāla saddam pucchati na suṇāma bhante kāya velāya ati puṭṭhaḥ

analyzed: majjhima yāme amhākam ālambana phalakam a passāya ṭhita kālā iti vatvā mahā obhāsaḥ ahosi
translated: “There was a great flash of lightning.🔽Have you seen it?”🔽“What time was it, venerable sir?”

original: so vo diṭṭho”ti pucchati. “Kāya velāya, bhante”ti ca vutte “mayhaṃ caṅkamamhā otaraṇakāle”ti
analyzed: saḥ vaḥ diṭṭhā uti pucchati kāya velāya bhante iti ca vutte mayham caṅkamamhā otaraṇa kāle iti
translated: “It was at the time of my coming down from my walk.”

analyzed: vadati manussāḥ amhākam thero tīsu pi yāmesu hoti natthi ayyena sadisaḥ
translated: The people think, “Our elder is always walking up and down in the three watches of the night. There is no one equal to him in being energetic.”

original: āraddhavīriyo’ti pasannā sakkāraṃ karonti.
analyzed: pasannā sakkāram karonti
translated: They have confidence and do him honour.

original: Muṭṭhassatīpi upaṭṭhākamajjhe nisinno “mayā asukakāle nāma dīghanikāyo uggahito,
analyzed: upaṭṭhāka majjhe nisinnaḥ mayā asuka kāle nāma dīgha nikāyaḥ uggahitaḥ
translated: He is absent-minded, but when he is sitting in the midst of his attendants he says, “At such and such a time I learned the Dīgha Nikāya,

original: asukakāle majjhimo, saṃyuttako, aṅguttariko; antarā olokanaṃ nāma natthi, icchiticchataṭṭhāne
analyzed: asuka kāle majjhimaḥ saṃyuttakaḥ aṅguttarikaḥ antarā olokanam nāma natthi icchiticchata ṭṭhāne
translated: at such and such a time the Majjhima, the Saṃyutta, the Aṅguttara; there is nothing I have not looked at.

analyzed: mukha āruḷhaḥ iva tanti āgacchati ime pana aññe bhikkhū eḷakāḥ viya mukham phandāpentā viharanti iti

analyzed: vadati manussāḥ na atthi ayyena sadisaḥ upaṭṭhita satī iti pasannā sakkāram karonti
translated: The people are pleased and say, “There is no one so mindful as the venerable one.” They show him respect.

original: Asamāhitopi upaṭṭhākānaṃ sammukhe aṭṭhakathācariye pañhaṃ pucchati – ‘kasiṇaṃ nāma
analyzed: asamāhitaḥ api upaṭṭhākānam sammukhe aṭṭhakathā cariye pañham pucchati kasiṇam nāma
translated: He is not concentrated, but when he is in the presence of his attendants he asks the teachers of the commentaries questions about the meditation subject: “How is the kasiṇa developed?

original: kathaṃ bhāveti? Kittakena nimittaṃ uppannaṃ nāma hoti? Kittakena upacāro? Kittakena
analyzed: katham bhāveti kittakena nimittam uppannam nāma hoti kittakena upacāraḥ kittakena
translated: At what point does the sign arise? At what point is there access?

original: appanā? Paṭhamassa jhānassa kati aṅgāni? Dutiyassa tatiyassa catutthassa jhānassa
analyzed: appanā paṭhamassa jhānassa kati aṅgāni dutiyassa tatiyassa catutthassa jhānassa
translated: At what point is there absorption? How many factors has the first jhāna? The second? The third? The fourth? ”

original: kati aṅgāni”ti pucchati. Tehi attano uggahitānurūpena kathitakāle sitaṃ katvā ‘kiṃ,
analyzed: kati aṅgāni iti pucchati tehi attanaḥ uggahita anurūpena kathita kāle sitam katvā kim
translated: When they have told him what they have learned, he says, “Is that so?

analyzed: āvuso evam na hosi iti vutte vaṭṭati bhante iti attanaḥ samāpatti lābhitam sūceti
translated: If he is told, “You should not do so, friend,” he says, “It is allowable, venerable sir,” and so he reveals his attainment of jhāna.

original: Manussā ‘samāpattilābhī ayyo’ti pasannā sakkāraṃ karonti.
analyzed: manussā samāpatti lābhī pasannā sakkāram karonti
translated: People, thinking that he has attained jhāna, show him respect.

original: Duppaññopi upaṭṭhākānaṃ majjhe nisinno ‘majjhimanikāye me pañcattayaṃ olokentassa
analyzed: duppaññaḥ api upaṭṭhākānam majjhe nisinnaḥ majjhima nikāye me pañcattayam olokentassa
translated: If a man of little learning sits in the midst of his attendants and says, “When I was looking into the Fives in the Majjhima Nikāya,

original: sahiddhiyāva maggo āgato. Pariyatti nāma amhākaṃ na dukkarā. Pariyattivāvaṭo pana
analyzed: maggo āgataḥ pariyatti nāma amhākam na dukkarā pariyatti vāvaṭaḥ pana
translated: the path came right up to my lips. It is not difficult for us to learn the texts by heart. But the path
