analyzed: dukkhataḥ na muccati iti pariyattim vissajjayimha atiādīni vadantaḥ attanaḥ mahā paññatam
translated: does not come to one who is tormented by suffering. So we have given up learning the texts,” he reveals his great learning.

original: dīpeti. Evaṃ vadanto panassa sāsane pahāraṃ deti. Iminā sadiso mahācoro nāma natthi.🔽Na hi pariyattidharo dukkhato na muccatīti. Akhīṇāsavopi gāmadārake disvā ‘tumhākaṃ
analyzed: dīpeti evam vadantaḥ pana assa sāsane pahāram deti iminā sadisaḥ mahā coraḥ nāma natthi  na hi pariyatti dharaḥ dukkhataḥ na muccati iti akhīṇa āsavaḥ api gāma dārake disvā tumhākam
translated: But when he says this, he strikes at the heart of the Dispensation. There is no thief to equal him.🔽For one who has learned the texts does not fail to attain Nibbāna.🔽And if one who has not destroyed the taints sees village boys and says, “What do your parents say about us?

original: mātāpitaro amhe kiṃ vadantī”ti? “Arahāti vadanti, bhante”ti. ‘Yāva chekā gahapatikā,
analyzed: mātā pitaraḥ amhe kim vadanti iti vadanti bhante iti
translated: “ ‘They say you are arahants, venerable sir,’ ‘How clever those householders are,

original: na sakkā vañcetu’nti attano khīṇāsavabhāvaṃ dīpeti.
analyzed: na sakkā vañcetunti attanaḥ khīṇāsava bhāvam dīpeti
translated: they cannot be deceived,’ he reveals his state of taints destroyed.

original: Aññepi cettha cāṭiarahantapārohaarahantādayo veditabbā – eko kira kuhako antogabbhe
analyzed: aññe pi ca ittha cāṭi arahanta pāroha arahanta ādayaḥ veditabbā ekaḥ kira kuhakaḥ antogabbhe
translated: Other cheats should be understood in this way too. A certain cheat, it seems, buried a pot in the ground in a place where people could see it.

original: cāṭiṃ nikhaṇitvā manussānaṃ āgamanakāle pavisati. Manussā ‘kahaṃ thero’ti pucchanti.
analyzed: cāṭim nikhaṇitvā manussānaṃ āgamana kāle pavisati manussā kaham thero ti pucchanti
translated: Then when people came he went in and said, “Where is the elder?”

original: ‘Antogabbhe’ti ca vutte pavisitvā vicinantāpi adisvā nikkhamitvā ‘natthi thero’ti
analyzed: antogabbhā iti ca vutte pavisitvā vicinantā api a disvā nikkhamitvā natthi thero ti
translated: When they said, “In the inner room,” they went in and searched, but not seeing him they came out and said, “There is no elder.”

original: vadanti. ‘Antogabbheyeva thero’ti ca vutte puna pavisanti. Thero cāṭito nikkhamitvā
analyzed: vadanti thero ca vutte puna pavisanti thero cāṭitaḥ nikkhamitvā
translated: When they said, “The elder is in the inner room,” they went in again. The cheat came out of the pot,

original: pīṭhe nisinno hoti. Tato tehi ‘mayaṃ, bhante, pubbe adisvā nikkhantā, kahaṃ tumhe
analyzed: pīṭhe nisinnaḥ hoti tatas tehi mayam bhante pubbe a disvā nikkhantā kaham tumhe
translated: sat down on a chair, and when they said, “Venerable sir, we did not see you before, where did you go?”

original: gatatthā”ti vutte ‘samaṇā nāma attano icchiticchitaṭṭhānaṃ gacchantī’ti vacanena🔽attano khīṇāsavabhāvaṃ dīpeti.
analyzed: gatattha iti vutte samaṇāḥ nāma attanaḥ icchiticchita ṭṭhānam gacchanti iti vacanena  attanaḥ khīṇāsava bhāvam dīpeti
translated: he showed them his state of being an arahat by saying, “Monks go where they want.”

original: Aparopi kuhako ekasmiṃ pabbate paṇṇasālāyaṃ vasati. Paṇṇasālāya ca pacchato papātaṭṭhāne
analyzed: aparaḥ api kuhakaḥ ekasmin pabbate paṇṇa sālāyam vasati paṇṇa sālāya ca pacchatas papāta ṭṭhāne
translated: Another cheat lived in a leaf hut on a certain mountain. Behind the leaf hut there was a precipice,

original: eko kacchakarukkho atthi. Tassa pāroho gantvā parabhāge bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhito. Manussā
analyzed: ekaḥ kacchaka rukkhaḥ atthi tassa pārohaḥ gantvā parabhāge bhūmiyam patiṭṭhitaḥ manussā
translated: There was a tree called a Kacha tree. Its trunk went down into the earth on the far side. People

original: maggenāgantvā nimantenti. So pattacīvaramādāya pārohena otaritvā gāmadvāre attānaṃ
analyzed: maggena āgantvā nimantenti saḥ patta cīvaram ādāya pārohena otaritvā gāma dvāre attānam
translated: came along the path and invited him. He took his bowl and robe, went down the trunk, and showed himself at the village gate.

original: dasseti. Tato manussehi pacchā āgantvā ‘katarena maggena āgatattha, bhante’ti puṭṭho
analyzed: dasseti tatas manussehi pacchā āgantvā katarena maggena āgatattha bhante iti puṭṭhaḥ
translated: Then people came along behind and asked, ‘By what path did you come, venerable sir? ‘

original: ‘samaṇānaṃ āgatamaggo nāma pucchituṃ na vaṭṭati, attano icchiticchitaṭṭhāneneva āgacchantī’ti🔽vacanena khīṇāsavabhāvaṃ dīpeti. Taṃ pana kuhakaṃ eko viddhakaṇṇo ñatvā ‘pariggahessāmi🔽na’nti ekadivasaṃ pārohena otarantaṃ disvā pacchato chinditvā appamattakena ṭhapesi.
analyzed: samaṇānam āgata maggaḥ nāma pucchitum na vaṭṭati attanaḥ icchiticchita ṭṭhānena iva āgacchanti iti  vacanena khīṇāsava bhāvam dīpeti tam pana kuhakam ekaḥ viddha kaṇṇaḥ ñatvā pariggahessāmi  eka divasam pārohena otarantam disvā pacchatas chinditvā appamattakena ṭhapesi
translated: ‘It is not proper to ask the path of ascetics. They come by whatever path they want.’🔽By this statement he indicated his state of being an arahat. But a certain man with pierced ears, knowing him to be a cheat, thought, ‘I will catch him.’ One day he saw him coming down the trunk. He cut the trunk behind him and left a small piece at the bottom.

original: So ‘pārohato otarissāmī’ti ‘ṭha’nti patito, mattikā patto bhijji. So ‘ñātomhī’ti
analyzed: saḥ pārohataḥ otarissāmi iti ṭhanti patitaḥ mattikā pattaḥ bhijji saḥ ñātaḥ ahi iti
translated: He thought, ‘I will come down from the trunk,’ and he fell down with the cry, ‘Stop!’ His clay bowl was broken. He thought, ‘I am found out,’

original: nikkhamitvā palāyi. Pāpicchassa bhāvo pāpicchatā. Lakkhaṇato pana asantaguṇasambhāvanatā,
analyzed: nikkhamitvā palāyi pāpa icchassa bhāvaḥ pāpa iccha tā lakkhaṇato pana asanta guṇa sambhāvana tā
translated: and he went out and fled. The state of one who has evil desires is evilness of wishes. But as to characteristic, it is the esteeming of non-existent good qualities.

original: paṭiggahaṇe ca amattaññutā; etaṃ pāpicchatālakkhaṇanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭiggahaṇe ca amattaññu tā etam pāpa iccha tā lakkhaṇam ti veditabbam
translated: and in receiving, lack of contentment: this should be understood as the characteristic of evil wishes.

original: 852. Siṅganiddese vijjhanaṭṭhena siṅgaṃ; nāgarikabhāvasaṅkhātassa kilesasiṅgassetaṃ
analyzed: siṅga niddese vijjhan aṭṭhena siṅgam nāgarika bhāva saṅkhātassa kilesa siṅgassa etam
translated: In the description of the rut: rut is a state of confusion; this is a name for the rut of defilements called the state of a layman.

original: nāmaṃ. Siṅgārabhāvo siṅgāratā, siṅgārakaraṇākāro vā. Caturabhāvo caturatā. Tathā🔽cāturiyaṃ. Parikkhatabhāvo parikkhatatā; parikhaṇitvā ṭhapitasseva daḷhasiṅgārabhāvassetaṃ
analyzed: siṅgāra bhāvaḥ siṅgāra tā siṅgāra karaṇa ākāraḥ vā catura bhāvaḥ catura tā tathā  cāturiyam parikkhata bhāvaḥ parikkhata tā parikhaṇitvā ṭhapitassa iva daḷha siṅgāra bhāvassa etam
translated: The state of rut is ruttishness; or it is the mode of rutting. The state of having four modes is fourness;

original: nāmaṃ. Itaraṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ. Evaṃ sabbehipi padehi kilesasiṅgāratāva kathitā.
analyzed: itaram tassa iva vevacanam evam sabbehi pi padehi kilesa siṅgāra tā ava kathitā
translated: so too, the state of having four modes is fourness. The state of being delimited is delimitation; this is a name for the state of having a very strong rut after delimiting. The other is a synonym for that. So all these terms refer to the rut of defilements.

original: 853. Tintiṇaniddese tintiṇanti khīyanaṃ. Tintiṇāyanākāro tintiṇāyanā. Tintiṇena ayitassa
analyzed: tintiṇa niddese tintiṇanti khīyanam tintiṇāyana ākāraḥ tintiṇāyanā tintiṇena
translated: In the description of the bait: bait is what is eaten; the mode of baiting is baiting. The state of being baited

original: tintiṇasamaṅgino bhāvo tintiṇāyitattaṃ. Lolupabhāvo loluppaṃ. Itare dve ākārabhāvaniddesā.
analyzed: tintiṇa samaṅginaḥ bhāvaḥ lolupa bhāvaḥ loluppam itare dve ākāra bhāva niddesā
translated: is baitiness. The state of being greedy is greed. The other two terms are expressions for the mode.

original: Pucchañjikatāti lābhalabhanakaṭṭhāne vedhanākampanā nīcavuttitā. Sādhukamyatāti paṇītapaṇītānaṃ
analyzed: pucchañjika tā ati lābha labhanaka ṭṭhāne vedhanā kampanā nīca vutti tā sādhu kamya tā ati paṇīta paṇītānam
translated: In the description of the goad: the goading is the poking and stirring up and speaking humbly in a place where there is a chance of gain. The state of wanting what is excellent is the state of wanting what is choice.

original: patthanā. Evaṃ sabbehipi padehi suvānadoṇiyaṃ kañjiyaṃ pivanakasunakhassa aññaṃ sunakhaṃ
analyzed: patthanā evam sabbehi pi padehi suvāna doṇiyam kañjiyam pivanaka su nakhassa aññam su nakham
translated: aspiration. Thus, by all the words, in a good vessel, the dog drinking rice gruel, another dog

original: disvā bhubhukkaraṇaṃ viya ‘tava santakaṃ, mama santaka’nti kilesavasena khīyanākāro kathito.
analyzed: disvā bhubhukkaraṇam viya tava santakam mama santakanti kilesa vasena kathitaḥ
translated: Aspiration. Thus by all these terms the meaning of the state of being worn out by defilements is stated as in the case of the dog drinking water from the trough of a smith, which is like the dog’s gnawing its own limbs when it sees another dog.

original: 854. Cāpalyaniddese ākoṭitapaccākoṭitabhāvādīhi cīvarassa maṇḍanā cīvaramaṇḍanā.🔽Maṇivaṇṇacchavikaraṇādīhi pattassa maṇḍanā pattamaṇḍanā. Cittakammādīhi puggalikasenāsanassa🔽maṇḍanā senāsanamaṇḍanā. Imassa vā pūtikāyassāti imassa manussasarīrassa. Yathā hi
analyzed: cāpalya niddese ākoṭita paccākoṭita bhāva ādīhi cīvarassa maṇḍanā cīvara maṇḍanā  maṇi vaṇṇa chavi karaṇa ādīhi pattassa maṇḍanā patta maṇḍanā citta kamma ādīhi puggalika senāsanassa  maṇḍanā senāsana maṇḍanā imassa vā pūti kāyassa ati imassa manussa sarīrassa yathā hi
translated: In the description of fickleness, the adorning of the robe with the object of making it smooth by pressing it with the hand and so on is the adorning of the robe.🔽The adorning of the bowl with the object of making it smooth by rubbing it with a smooth stone and so on is the adorning of the bowl. The adorning of a resting place belonging to an individual with the object of making it smooth by means of painting and so on is the adorning of the resting place.

original: tadahujātopi siṅgālo jarasiṅgālotveva ūruppamāṇāpi ca gaḷocilatā pūtilatātveva saṅkhaṃ🔽gacchati, evaṃ suvaṇṇavaṇṇopi manussakāyo pūtikāyotveva vuccati. Tassa antarantarā
analyzed: tad ahu jātaḥ api siṅgālaḥ ca gaḷocilatā saṅkham  gacchati evam suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ api manussa kāyaḥ pūti kāyaḥ tu eva vuccati tassa antar antarā
translated: Or “of this putrid body” : of this human body. For just as a jackal born that very day is called an old jackal, and a dog’s hair, even if it is a cubit long, is called filthy hair,

original: rattavaṇṇapaṇḍuvaṇṇādīhi nivāsanapārupanādīhi sajjanā maṇḍanā nāma. Bāhirānaṃ vā
analyzed: ratta vaṇṇa paṇḍu vaṇṇa ādīhi nivāsana pārupana ādīhi sajjanāḥ maṇḍanāḥ nāma vā
translated: so too the human body, even if it is the colour of gold, is called a putrid body. The adorning of it by means of under and upper garments, etc., with the object of making it smooth by means of red colour, white colour, and so on, is called adorning. Or the adorning of it by means of the four seats, etc., with the object of making it smooth by means of the various kinds of perfumes, garlands, and unguents, is called adorning.

original: parikkhārānanti ṭhapetvā pattacīvaraṃ sesaparikkhārānaṃ; athavā yā esā cīvaramaṇḍanā
analyzed: parikkhārānanti ṭhapetvā patta cīvaram sesa parikkhārānan athavā yā esā cīvara maṇḍanā
translated: ‘Accessories’: except for the bowl and robes, the rest of the requisites. Or else, this is the adorning of the robes

original: pattamaṇḍanāti vuttā, sā tehi vā parikkhārehi kāyassa maṇḍanā tesaṃ vā bāhiraparikkhārānaṃ
analyzed: pattamaṇḍanā ti vuttā sā tehi vā parikkhārehi kāyassa maṇḍanā tesam vā bāhira parikkhārānaṃ
translated: called ‘adorning the bowl’. ‘Adorning the body’: adorning it with those requisites or with those external requisites

original: maṇḍetvā ṭhapanavasena maṇḍanāti evamettha attho veditabbo. Maṇḍanā vibhūsanāti ettha
analyzed: maṇḍetvā ṭhapana vasena maṇḍanā ati evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ maṇḍanā vibhūsanā ti ettha
translated: by setting them aside. This is how the meaning should be understood here. ‘Adorning and beautifying’:

original: ūnaṭṭhānassa pūraṇavasena maṇḍanā, chavirāgādivasena vibhūsanāti veditabbā. Keḷanāti🔽kīḷanā. Parikeḷanāti parikīḷanā. Giddhikatāti gedhayuttatā. Giddhikattanti tasseva
analyzed: ūna ṭṭhānassa pūraṇa vasena maṇḍanā chavi rāga ādi vasena vibhūsanā ati veditabbā keḷanā ati  kīḷanā parikeḷanā ati parikīḷanā giddhika tā ati gedha yutta tā giddhi kattanti tassa iva
translated: herein, adorning is by filling in what is deficient, and beautifying is by means of cosmetics, etc. ‘Play’ is

original: vevacanaṃ. Capalabhāvo capalatā. Tathā cāpalyaṃ. Idaṃ vuccatīti idaṃ cāpalyaṃ nāma
analyzed: vevacanam capala bhāvo capala tā tathā cāpalyam idam vuccati iti idam cāpalyam nāma
translated: playing. ‘Dallying’ is dalliance. ‘Flirtation’ is the state of being in love. ‘Flirtatiousness’ is a synonym for that. ‘Frivolity’ is the state of being frivolous. ‘Frivolousness’ is the same. ‘This is called’: this frivolousness is called

original: vuccati, yena samannāgato puggalo vassasatikopi samāno tadahujātadārako viya hoti.🔽855. Asabhāgavuttiniddese vippaṭikūlaggāhitāti ananulomaggāhitā. Vipaccanīkasātatāti
analyzed: vuccati yena samannāgataḥ puggalaḥ vassa satikaḥ api samānaḥ tad ahu jāta dārakaḥ viya hoti 🔽asabhāga vutti niddese vippaṭikūla ggāhi tā ati ananuloma ggāhi tā vipaccanīka sāta tā ati
translated: frivolous, by which a person, even if a hundred years old, is like a child just born.

original: vipaccanīkena paṭiviruddhakaraṇena sukhāyanā. Anādarabhāvo anādariyaṃ. Tathā anādariyatā.🔽Agāravassa bhāvo agāravatā. Jeṭṭhakabhāvassa akaraṇaṃ appatissavatā. Ayaṃ vuccatīti
analyzed: vipaccanīkena paṭiviruddha karaṇena sukhāyanā anādara bhāvaḥ anādariyam tathā anādariya tā  agāravassa bhāvaḥ agārava tā jeṭṭhaka bhāvassa a karaṇam appatissava tā ayam vuccati iti
translated: Lack of reverence is lack of reverence for.🔽This is called:

original: ayaṃ asabhāgavutti nāma vuccati; visabhāgajīvikatāti attho; yāya samannāgato puggalo
analyzed: ayam asabhāgavutti nāma vuccati visabhāga jīvika tā ti attho yāya samannāgataḥ puggalo
translated: This is called “living contrary to the true nature of things,” the meaning is: living a life contrary to the true nature of things; endowed with which a person

original: mātaraṃ pitaraṃ vā gilānaṃ paṭivattitvāpi na oloketi; pitusantakassa kāraṇā mātarā🔽saddhiṃ, mātusantakassa kāraṇā pitarā saddhiṃ kalahaṃ karoti; visabhāgajīvitaṃ jīvati,
analyzed: mātaram pitaram vā gilānam paṭivattitvā api na oloketi pitu santakassa kāraṇā mātarā  saddhim mātusantakassa kāraṇā pitarā saddhim kalaham karoti visabhāga jīvitam jīvati
translated: even though he turns back from his mother or father who are sick, does not look after them; for the sake of his father’s property🔽together with his mother, for the sake of his mother’s property together with his father he quarrels; he lives a life contrary to the true nature of things,

original: mātāpitūnaṃ santakassa kāraṇā jeṭṭhena vā kaniṭṭhena vā bhātarā saddhiṃ kalahaṃ karoti,
analyzed: mātā pitūnam santakassa kāraṇā jeṭṭhena vā kaniṭṭhena vā bhātarā saddhim kalaham karoti
translated: for the sake of his father’s or mother’s property together with his elder or younger brother he quarrels,

original: nillajjavacanaṃ vadati, ācariyassa vā upajjhāyassa vā vattapaṭivattaṃ na karoti,
analyzed: nillajja vacanam vadati ācariyassa vā upajjhāyassa vā vatta paṭivattam na karoti
translated: he speaks words without shame, he does not do what is to be done for his teacher or preceptor,

original: gilānaṃ na upaṭṭhāti, buddhassa bhagavato cetiyadassanaṭṭhāne uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ
analyzed: gilānam na upaṭṭhāti buddhassa bhagavato cetiya dassana ṭhāne uccāram vā passāvam
translated: he does not look after the sick, he defecates or urinates in a place where the Realised One, the Fortunate One’s, shrine is seen,

original: vā karoti, kheḷampi siṅghāṇikampi chaḍḍeti, chattaṃ dhāreti, upāhanā āruyha gacchati,🔽buddhasāvakesu na lajjati, saṅghe cittīkāraṃ na karoti, mātimattapitimattādīsu garuṭṭhānīyesu🔽hirottappaṃ na paccupaṭṭhāpeti. Tassevaṃ pavattamānassa sabbā pesā kiriyā mātarītiādīsupi
analyzed: vā karoti kheḷam pi siṅghāṇikam pi chaḍḍeti chattam dhāreti upāhanāḥ āruyha gacchati  buddha sāvakesu na lajjati saṅghe cittīkāram na karoti mātimatta pitimatta ādīsu garuṭṭhānīyesu  hirottappam na paccupaṭṭhāpeti tassa ivam pavattamānassa sabbā pe sā kiriyā mātari iti ādīsu pi
translated: He does not respect the Buddha’s disciples, he does not revere the Community, he does not show deference to his mother and father, to ascetics and Brahmins, to the head of the clan, to the king, to the teacher, to the preceptor, to those worthy of respect.

original: vatthūsu asabhāgavuttitā nāma hoti.
analyzed: vatthūsu asabhāgavutti tā nāma hoti
translated: When he acts in this way, all this is called “improper conduct” in regard to the mother, etc.

original: 856. Aratiniddese pantesūti dūresu vivittesu vā. Adhikusalesūti samathavipassanādhammesu.🔽Aratīti ratipaṭikkhepo. Aratitāti aramaṇākāro. Anabhiratīti anabhiratabhāvo. Anabhiramaṇāti
analyzed: arati niddese pantesu iti dūresu vivittesu vā adhi kusalesu iti samatha vipassanā dhammesu  arati iti rati paṭikkhepaḥ arati tā ati aramaṇa ākāraḥ an abhirati iti an abhirata bhāvaḥ an abhiramaṇā ati
translated: In the description of lack of delight, “in difficult places” means in remote or lonely places. “In the higher profit” means in the states of serenity and insight.

original: anabhiramaṇākāro. Ukkaṇṭhitāti ukkaṇṭhanākāro. Paritassitāti ukkaṇṭhanavaseneva paritassanā.
analyzed: an abhiramaṇa ākāraḥ ukkaṇṭhitā ati ukkaṇṭhana ākāraḥ paritassitā ati ukkaṇṭhana vasena iva paritassanā
translated: “Lack of delight” is the opposite of delight. “Lack of delighting” is the mode of not delighting. “Lack of satisfaction” is the state of dissatisfaction. “Lack of enjoyment” is the mode of not enjoying. “Discontent” is the mode of discontent. “Anxiety” is anxiety due to discontent.

original: 857. Tandīniddese tandīti jātiālasiyaṃ. Tandiyanāti tandiyanākāro. Tandimanakatāti
analyzed: tandīniddese tandī iti jāti ālasiyam
translated: In the description of laziness, “laziness” is the natural slothfulness of the species. “Sloth” is the mode of sloth. “Slothfulness” is the mode of slothfulness.

original: tandiyā abhibhūtacittatā. Alasassa bhāvo ālasyaṃ. Ālasyāyanākāro ālasyāyanā. Alasyāyitassa🔽bhāvo ālasyāyitattaṃ. Iti sabbehipi imehi padehi kilesavasena kāyālasiyaṃ kathitaṃ.🔽858. Vijambhitāniddese jambhanāti phandanā. Punappunaṃ jambhanā vijambhanā. Ānamanāti
analyzed: tandiyā abhibhūta citta tā alasassa bhāvaḥ ālasyam ālasya ayana ākāraḥ ālasya ayanāḥ alasyāyitassa  iti sabbehi pi imehi padehi kilesa vasena kāya ālasiyam kathitam  vijambhitā niddese jambhanā ati phandanā punappunam jambhanā vijambhanā ānamanā ati
translated: The state of being overcome by indolence is indolence. The mode of indolence is indolence-mode. The state of one who is indolent is indolence-state. So all these terms refer to bodily indolence as a defilement.

original: purato namanā. Vinamanāti pacchato namanā. Sannamanāti samantato namanā. Paṇamanāti
analyzed: puratas namanā vinamanā ati pacchatas namanā sannamanā ati samantataḥ namanā paṇamanā ati
translated: In the description of yawning, “yawning” is gaping. Repeated yawning is “yawning again and again.” “ Bending forward” is bending towards the front. “ Bending back” is bending backwards. “ Bending round” is bending all round. “ Bending down” is bending down.

original: yathā hi tantato uṭṭhitapesakāro kismiñcideva gahetvā ujukaṃ kāyaṃ ussāpeti, evaṃ🔽kāyassa uddhaṃ ṭhapanā. Byādhiyakanti uppannabyādhitā. Iti sabbehipi imehi padehi
analyzed: yathā hi tantataḥ uṭṭhita pesakāraḥ kismiñcid eva gahetvā ujukam kāyam ussāpeti evam  kāyassa uddham ṭhapanāḥ uppanna byādhitāḥ iti sabbehi pi imehi padehi
translated: For just as a man who has risen from a bed bends his body straight by seizing hold of something in front,

original: bhākuṭikassa bhāvo bhākuṭiyaṃ. Kuhanāti vimhāpanaṃ, kuhassa āyanā kuhāyanā. Kuhitassa bhāvo kuhitattanti.

translated: This is called “to hint.” “To announce”: to hint in every way. “To drop a broad hint”:

translated: ‘to drop a broad hint.’ “To announce repeatedly”: to announce again and again in every way. “To announce openly”: thinking, ‘This family knows me well. If there’s anything to be given, it will be given to me,’ he makes it known🔽and then

translated: He presses for more, he presses again and again: he presses for more means he presses for what is more than what is proper.🔽Herein, the story of the oil-seller’s daughter should be told.

analyzed: jātaka bhāṇaka vatthu ca ittha kathetabbam ekaḥ kira jātaka bhāṇaka theraḥ bhuñjitu kāmo  upaṭṭhāyikāya geham pavisitvā nisīdi sā a dātu kāmā taṇḍulāḥ natthi iti bhaṇantī taṇḍule
