Or alternatively, ‘rejection’ is rejecting by saying ‘Oh, he is a donor’ and so on. ‘Complete rejection’ is rejecting well by saying ‘He is a great donor’ and so on. ‘Ridicule’ is ridiculing by saying ‘What is the life of this one who eats the seed?’ ‘Slighting’ is saying ‘Why do you say he is a non-giver when he is always giving

original: sabbesampi natthīti vacanaṃ detī’ti evaṃ suṭṭhutaraṃ uppaṇḍanā. Pāpanāti adāyakattassa🔽avaṇṇassa vā pāpanaṃ. Sabbatobhāgena pāpanā sampāpanā. Avaṇṇahārikāti ‘evaṃ me avaṇṇabhayāpi
analyzed: sabbesam pi na atthi iti vacanam deti iti evam suṭṭhutaram uppaṇḍanā pāpanā ati a dāyaka ttassa  avaṇṇassa vā pāpanam sabbatobhāgena pāpanā sampāpanā avaṇṇa hārikā ati evam me avaṇṇa bhayā api
translated: This is the most thorough kind of mockery.🔽Slanderers:🔽they spread the bad report of his ungenerosity.🔽They spread it all round: they spread it everywhere.

original: dassatī’ti gehato gehaṃ, gāmato gāmaṃ, janapadato janapadaṃ avaṇṇaharaṇaṃ. Parapiṭṭhimaṃsikatāti
analyzed: dassati iti gehataḥ geham gāmataḥ gāmam janapadataḥ janapadam avaṇṇa haraṇam parapiṭṭhimaṃsikatā ati
translated: They are bearers of ill repute: thinking, ‘Because of the fear of ill repute he will give,’ they go from house to house, from village to village, from town to town, bearing ill repute.🔽They are backbiters:

original: purato madhuraṃ bhaṇitvā parammukhe avaṇṇabhāsitā. Esā hi abhimukhaṃ oloketuṃ asakkontassa
analyzed: puratas madhuram bhaṇitvā parammukhe avaṇṇa bhāsitā esā hi abhimukham oloketum a sakkontassa
translated: having spoken sweetly to his face, they speak dispraise of him behind his back. For this is like the eating of the flesh of the back of someone who cannot look in the face of those who eat it.

original: parammukhānaṃ piṭṭhimaṃsakhādanaṃ viya hoti. Tasmā parapiṭṭhimaṃsikatāti vuttā. Ayaṃ🔽vuccati nippesikatāti ayaṃ yasmā veḷupesikā viya abbhaṅgaṃ parassa guṇaṃ nippeseti🔽nipuñchati, yasmā vā gandhajātaṃ nipisitvā gandhamagganā viya paraguṇe nipisitvā
analyzed: parammukhānam piṭṭhi maṃsa khādanam viya hoti tasmā parapiṭṭhimaṃsikatā ati vuttā ayam  vuccati nippesika tā ti ayam yasmā veḷu pesikā viya abbhaṅgam parassa guṇam nippeseti  nipuñchati yasmai vā gandha jātam nipisitvā gandha magganā viya para guṇe nipisitvā
translated: That is why they are called backbiters.🔽This is called a mock-giver:🔽because he mocks, he mocks away, the other’s merit as a sugar-cane striver mocks away a sugar-cane;

original: vicuṇṇetvā esā lābhamagganā hoti, tasmā nippesikatāti vuccatīti.
analyzed: vicuṇṇetvā esā lābha magganā hoti tasmā nippesikatā ati vuccati iti
translated: or because he grinds the other’s merit as a perfume-maker grinds perfume, and then he gets the reward of merit for himself by means of the ground-up merit, that is why he is called a mock-giver.

original: 865. Lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsanatāniddese nijigīsanatāti magganā. Ito laddhanti imamhā🔽gehā laddhaṃ. Amutrāti amukamhi gehe. Eṭṭhīti icchanā. Gaveṭṭhīti magganā. Pariyeṭṭhīti🔽punappunaṃ magganā. Ādito paṭṭhāya laddhaṃ laddhaṃ bhikkhaṃ tatra tatra kuladārakānaṃ🔽datvā ante khīrayāguṃ labhitvā gatabhikkhuvatthu cettha kathetabbaṃ. Esanātiādīni
analyzed: lābhena lābham nijigīsana tā niddese nijigīsana tā ati magganā itas  gehā laddham amutra ati amukamhi gehe eṭṭhī iti icchanā gaveṭṭhī iti magganā pariyeṭṭhī iti  punappunam magganā āditas paṭṭhāya laddham laddham bhikkham tatra tatra kula dārakānam  datvā ante khīra yāgum labhitvā gata bhikkhu vatthu ca ittha kathetabbam esanā ti ādīni
translated: In the description of “seeking gain with gain” : seeking is seeking out;🔽from here: what is got from this house;🔽there: in that house;🔽wanting is wishing;🔽seeking is seeking out;🔽seeking again and again is seeking out again and again.🔽After giving here and there to young men of families the alms got here and there from the beginning, a bhikkhu who has got milk gruel at the end goes away. The story of the bhikkhu who got milk gruel at the end should be told here.🔽Seeking is seeking out;🔽

original: eṭṭhītiādīnaṃ vevacanāni, tasmā eṭṭhīti esanā, gaveṭṭhīti gavesanā, pariyeṭṭhīti🔽pariyesanā. Iccevamettha yojanā veditabbā.🔽866. Seyyamānaniddese jātiyāti khattiyabhāvādijātisampattiyā. Gottenāti gotamagottādinā
analyzed: eṭṭhī iti ādīnam vevacanāni tasmai eṭṭhī iti esanā gaveṭṭhī iti gavesanā pariyeṭṭhī iti  pariyesanā icca evam ettha yojanā veditabbā  seyyamāna niddese jātiyā ati khattiya bhāva ādi jāti sampattiyā gottena ati gotama gotta ādinā
translated: In the description of “seeking gain with gain” : seeking is seeking for, searching for, searching about, seeking about, seeking out, seeking after, seeking for the sake of, seeking by way of, seeking by means of. From here means from this house. There means in that house. Seeking is wishing. Seeking for is seeking for the sake of. Seeking about is seeking by way of. Seeking out is seeking by means of. Again and again is seeking by way of. Giving alms food obtained from the beginning to young men of families here and there, and then going off after getting milk-rice at the end, is the story of the bhikkhu who did this that should be told here. Seeking, etc., are synonyms for seeking, seeking for, seeking about, and seeking out. Therefore seeking is seeking, seeking for the sake of; seeking for is seeking for the sake of; seeking about is seeking by way of; seeking out is seeking by means of. This is how the construction should be understood here.

original: ukkaṭṭhagottena. Kolaputtiyenāti mahākulabhāvena. Vaṇṇapokkharatāyāti vaṇṇasampannasarīratāya.
analyzed: ukkaṭṭha gottena kola puttiyena ati mahā kula bhāvena vaṇṇa pokkhara tāya ati vaṇṇa sampanna sarīra tāya
translated: In the description of “lying in a luxurious couch” : birth is the excellence of being a warrior, etc. Lineage is the excellence of a high-class lineage such as the Gotama lineage, etc. Family means high-class family. Nobility of complexion means excellence of the body’s complexion.

original: Sarīrañhi pokkharanti vuccati, tassa vaṇṇasampattiyā abhirūpabhāvenāti attho. Dhanenātiādīni
analyzed: sarīram hi pokkharanti vuccati tassa vaṇṇa sampattiyā abhirūpa bhāvena ati atthaḥ dhanena atiādīni
translated: “Body” is called “paddy-field” : the meaning is that it is beautiful because of the beauty of its colour. “Wealth” and the rest are

original: uttānatthāneva. Mānaṃ jappetīti etesu yena kenaci vatthunā ‘seyyohamasmī’ti mānaṃ pavatteti karoti.
analyzed: uttāna tthānā iva mānam jappeti iti etesu yena kenacid vatthunā seyya uham asmi iti mānam pavattā iti karoti
translated: in the obvious sense. “He exalts himself” : he makes conceit occur, he does, by means of some ground or other, “I am superior.”

original: 867. Sadisamānaniddese mānaṃ jappetīti etesu yena kenaci vatthunā ‘sadisohamasmī’ti mānaṃ pavatteti. Ayamettha atthato viseso. Pāḷiyaṃ pana nānākaraṇaṃ natthi.
analyzed: sadisa māna niddese mānam jappeti iti etesu yena kenacid vatthunā sadisaḥ ham asmi iti mānam pavatteti ayam ettha atthataḥ visesaḥ pāḷiyam pana nānākaraṇam natthi
translated: In the description of “equality” , “he exalts himself” : he makes conceit occur, he does, by means of some ground or other, “I am equal.” This is the difference in meaning here. But there is no difference in the texts.

original: 868. Hīnamānaniddese omānaṃ jappetīti heṭṭhāmānaṃ pavatteti. Omānoti lāmako heṭṭhāmāno.
analyzed: hīna māna niddese omānam jappeti iti heṭṭhāmānam pavatteti omānaḥ ti lāmakaḥ heṭṭhāmānaḥ
translated: In the description of “inferiority” , “he exalts himself” : he makes low conceit occur. “Low” is inferior, low.

original: Omaññanā omaññitattanti ākārabhāvaniddeso. Hīḷanāti jātiādīhi attajigucchanā. Ohīḷanāti
analyzed: ākāra bhāva niddesaḥ hīḷanā ati jāti ādīhi atta jigucchanā ohīḷanā ati
translated: “Contempt” and “contemptuousness” are descriptions of the mode. “Disdain” is self-disparagement through birth, etc. “Disdainful” is

original: atirekato hīḷanā. Ohīḷitattanti tasseva bhāvaniddeso. Attuññāti attānaṃ hīnaṃ katvā
analyzed: atirekataḥ hīḷanā tassa iva bhāva niddeso attuññā ti attānam hīnam katvā
translated: disdaining in excess. “Disdainfully” is a description of that. “Self-contempt” is

original: jānanā. Attāvaññāti attānaṃ avajānanā. Attaparibhavoti jātiādisampattināmameva jātāti
analyzed: jānanā attāvaññā ati attānam avajānanā atta paribhavā iti jāti ādi sampatti nāmam eva jātā ati
translated: knowing oneself to be low. “Self-disparagement” is disparaging oneself. “Self-reproach” is the mere fact of being born, etc., that is, the mere fact of the possession of birth, etc.

original: attānaṃ paribhavitvā maññanā. Evamime tayo mānā puggalaṃ anissāya jātiādivatthuvaseneva
analyzed: attānam paribhavitvā maññanā evam ime tayo mānā puggalam a nissāya jāti ādi vatthu vasena iva
translated: and when he exalts himself, it is conceit. So these three kinds of conceit are stated in this way according to the person and according to the grounds for conceit consisting in the ideas of being superior, etc.,

original: kathitā. Tesu ekeko tiṇṇampi seyyasadisahīnānaṃ uppajjati. Tattha ‘seyyohamasmī’ti🔽māno seyyasseva yāthāvamāno, sesānaṃ ayāthāvamāno. ‘Sadisohamasmī’ti māno sadisasseva
analyzed: kathitā tesu ekekaḥ tiṇṇam pi seyya sadisa hīnānam uppajjati tattha seyyā uham asmi iti  mānaḥ seyyassa iva yāthāvamānaḥ sesānam a yāthāvamānaḥ sadisaḥ ham asmi iti mānaḥ sadisassa iva
translated: and each of them occurs in all three of the kinds of persons, that is, the superior, the average, and the inferior. Herein, the conceit “I am superior”🔽is the right kind of conceit in the case of the superior person, and it is the wrong kind of conceit in the case of the other two. The conceit “I am equal”🔽is the right kind of conceit in the case of the equal person, and it is the wrong kind of conceit in the case of the other two. The conceit “I am inferior”

original: yāthāvamāno, sesānaṃ ayāthāvamāno. ‘Hīnohamasmī’ti māno hīnasseva yāthāvamāno, sesānaṃ ayāthāvamāno.
analyzed: yāthāvamānaḥ sesānam a yāthāvamānaḥ hīnaḥ aham asmi iti mānaḥ hīnassa iva yāthāvamānaḥ sesānam a yāthāvamānaḥ
translated: is the right kind of conceit in the case of the inferior person, and it is the wrong kind of conceit in the case of the other two.

original: 869. Tattha katamo seyyassa seyyohamasmītiādayo pana nava mānā puggalaṃ nissāya kathitā.
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ seyyassa seyyā uham asmi iti ādayo pana nava mānā puggalam nissāya kathitā
translated: Herein, the nine kinds of conceit beginning with “I am superior” are stated according to the person.

original: Tesu tayo tayo ekekassa uppajjanti. Tattha dahatīti ṭhapeti. Taṃ nissāyāti taṃ seyyato🔽dahanaṃ nissāya. Ettha pana seyyassa seyyohamasmīti māno rājūnañceva pabbajitānañca
analyzed: tesu tayo tayo ekekassa uppajjanti tattha dahati iti ṭhapeti tam nissāya ati tam seyyataḥ  dahanam nissāya ettha pana seyyassa seyyā uham asmi iti mānaḥ rājūnam ca iva pabbajitānam ca
translated: And of these nine, three occur in each one. Herein, “he burns” is the same as “he scorches.” “According as” is the same as “according to.” “According as he scorches” is the same as “according as he scorches another.”🔽Herein, the conceit “I am superior” occurs in kings and in those gone forth into homelessness.

original: uppajjati. Rājā hi ‘raṭṭhena vā dhanena vā vāhanehi vā ko mayā sadiso atthī’ti etaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati rājā hi raṭṭhena vā dhanena vā vāhanehi vā kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ atthi iti etam
translated: For a king thinks “Who is my equal in the realm, in wealth, in vehicles, in clothes, in food, in jewels, in gems, in pearls, in sapphires, in beryl, in gold, in silver, in coral, in cats-eye?”

original: mānaṃ karoti. Pabbajitopi ‘sīladhutaṅgādīhi ko mayā sadiso atthī’ti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti.🔽870. Seyyassa sadisohamasmīti mānopi etesaṃyeva uppajjati. Rājā hi ‘raṭṭhena vā dhanena
analyzed: mānam karoti pabbajitaḥ api sīla dhutaṅga ādīhi kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ atthi iti etam mānam karoti  seyyassa sadisaḥ ham asmi iti mānaḥ api etesam yeva uppajjati rājā hi raṭṭhena vā dhanena
translated: He thinks: ‘With the country, the wealth, the chariots, the horses, the other kings, what difference is there between me and a Wheel-turning Monarch?’🔽The conceit ‘I am equal to a noble one’ also arises in the same way.

original: vā vāhanehi vā aññarājūhi saddhiṃ mayhaṃ kiṃ nānākaraṇa’nti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti. Pabbajitopi
analyzed: vā vāhanehi vā añña rājūhi saddhim mayham kim nānākaraṇam ti etam mānam karoti pabbajitaḥ api
translated: The king thinks: ‘With the country, the wealth, the chariots, the horses, the other kings, what difference is there between me and a Wheel-turning Monarch?’

original: ‘sīladhutaṅgādīhi aññena bhikkhunā saddhiṃ mayhaṃ kiṃ nānākaraṇa’nti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti.
analyzed: sīla dhutaṅga ādīhi aññena bhikkhunā saddhim mayham kim nānākaraṇan ti etam mānam karoti
translated: The monk thinks: ‘With the virtue, observances, etc., what difference is there between me and the other bhikkhu?’

original: 871. Seyyassa hīnohamasmīti mānopi etesaṃyeva uppajjati. Yassa hi rañño raṭṭhaṃ vā
analyzed: seyyassa hīnaḥ ham asmi iti mānaḥ api etesam yeva uppajjati yassa hi raññaḥ raṭṭham vā
translated: The conceit ‘I am inferior to a noble one’ also arises in the same way.

original: dhanaṃ vā vāhanāni vā sampannāni na honti, so ‘mayhaṃ rājāti vohārasukhamattameva;
analyzed: dhanam vā vāhanāni vā sampannāni na honti saḥ mayham rājā ati vohāra sukham attam eva
translated: When a king’s country, wealth, chariots, horses, etc., are not prosperous, he thinks: ‘I have only the mere pleasant experience of being called “king.”🔽What is a king? What am I? ‘

original: kiṃ rājā nāma aha’nti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti. Pabbajitopi ‘appalābhasakkāro ahaṃ. Dhammakathiko
analyzed: kim rājā nāma aham ti etam mānam karoti pabbajitaḥ api appa lābha sakkāraḥ aham dhamma kathikaḥ
translated: The monk thinks: ‘I have little gain and honour. I am a preacher of the Dhamma, a man of great learning, a great elder.

original: bahussuto mahātheroti kathāmattameva. Kiṃ dhammakathiko nāmāhaṃ, kiṃ bahussuto nāmāhaṃ,
analyzed: bahussutaḥ mahā thero ti kathā mattam eva kim dhammakathikaḥ nāma aham kim bahussutaḥ nāma aham
translated: That is all. What am I, a preacher of the Dhamma? What am I, a man of great learning? What am I, a great elder?

original: kiṃ mahāthero nāmāhaṃ yassa me lābhasakkāro natthī’ti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti.
analyzed: kim mahātheraḥ nāma aham yassa me lābha sakkāro na atthi iti etam mānam karoti
translated: “What is a great elder? I am one, and yet I have no gains and honors.”

original: 872. Sadisassa seyyohamasmīti mānādayo amaccādīnaṃ uppajjanti. Amacco hi raṭṭhiyo
analyzed: sadisassa seyya uham asmi iti māna ādayaḥ amacca ādīnam uppajjanti amaccaḥ hi raṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: “I am equal to my equal,” etc., arise in ministers, and so on. For a minister thinks thus:

original: vā ‘bhogayānavāhanādīhi ko mayā sadiso añño rājapuriso atthī’ti vā ‘mayhaṃ aññehi🔽saddhiṃ kiṃ nānākaraṇa’nti vā ‘amaccoti nāmamattameva mayhaṃ; ghāsacchādanamattampi
analyzed: vā bhoga yāna vāhana ādīhi kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ aññaḥ rāja purisaḥ atthi iti vā mayham aññehi  vai nānākaraṇanti vai nāma mattam eva ghāsa chādana mattam pi
translated: “What other royal officer is there who is my equal in wealth, vehicles, clothes, ornaments, and so on?” Or he thinks:🔽“What difference is there between me and the king? The mere fact that I am called ‘minister’ and he ‘king’ is no difference. I have food and clothing,

original: me natthi. Kiṃ amacco nāmāha’nti ete māne karoti.🔽875. Hīnassa seyyohamasmīti mānādayo dāsādīnaṃ uppajjanti. Dāso hi ‘mātito vā pitito
analyzed: me natthi kim amaccaḥ nāma ahanti ete māne karoti  hīnassa seyyā uham asmi iti māna ādayaḥ dāsa ādīnam uppajjanti dāsaḥ hi mātitaḥ vā pititaḥ
translated: and so has he. What is a king? What is a minister?”🔽“I am superior to my inferior,” etc., arise in slaves, and so on. For a slave thinks thus:

original: vā ko mayā sadiso añño dāso nāma atthi’ aññe jīvituṃ asakkontā kucchihetu dāsā nāma
analyzed: vā kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ aññaḥ dāsaḥ nāma atthi aññe jīvitum a sakkontā kucchi hetu dāsāḥ nāma
translated: “What other slave is there who is my equal in mother or father or family? Other slaves have become slaves because they could not otherwise make a living.

original: jātā. Ahaṃ pana paveṇīāgatattā seyyo’ti vā ‘paveṇīāgatabhāvena ubhatosuddhikadāsattena
analyzed: jātā aham pana paveṇī āgata ttā vā paveṇī āgata bhāvena ubhatosuddhika dāsattena
translated: But I am a slave by choice.” Or he thinks: “Because I am a slave by choice, I am a pure slave, a good slave,

original: asukadāsena nāma saddhiṃ kiṃ mayhaṃ nānākaraṇa’nti vā ‘kucchivasenāhaṃ dāsabyaṃ upagato.
analyzed: asuka dāsena nāma saddhim kim vā kucchi vasena aham dāsabyam upagataḥ
translated: “What difference is there between me and so-and-so a slave? ” or “I have become a slave because of my own fault.

original: Mātāpitukoṭiyā pana me dāsaṭṭhānaṃ natthi. Kiṃ dāso nāma aha’nti vā ete māne karoti.
analyzed: mātā pitu koṭiyā pana me dāsa ṭṭhānam natthi kim dāsaḥ nāma ahanti vā ete māne karoti
translated: But I am not a slave in the eyes of my mother and father. What is a slave? ”

original: Yathā ca dāso evaṃ pukkusacaṇḍālādayopi ete māne karontiyeva.
analyzed: yathā ca dāsaḥ evam pukkusa caṇḍāla ādayaḥ api ete māne
translated: And just as he does in the case of a slave, so also he does in the case of a rubbish-heap dweller, a beggar, a day-labourer, a red-robe, a black-job holder, a tree-root dweller, a charnel-ground dweller, a refuse-rag wearer, a sitter, a frequenter of the open air, a triple-robe wearer, and a sitter-in-the-open-air-wearer-of-the-triple-robe.

original: Ettha ca ‘seyyassa seyyohamasmī’ti uppannamānova yāthāvamāno, itare dve ayāthāvamānā.
analyzed: ettha ca seyyassa seyyā uham asmi iti uppanna mānā iva itare dve a yāthāvamānā
translated: And here, the conceit “I am better than my superior” is a form of the right kind of conceit as soon as it arises, while the other two are wrong kinds of conceit.

original: Tathā ‘sadisassa sadisohamasmī’ti ‘hīnassa hīnohamasmī’ti uppannamānova yāthāvamāno,
analyzed: tathā sadisassa sadisaḥ uham asmi iti hīnassa hīnaḥ uham asmi iti uppanna mānaḥ uva yāthāvamānaḥ
translated: And likewise the conceit “I am the equal of my equal” and the conceit “I am worse than my superior” are a form of the right kind of conceit as soon as they arise,

original: itare dve ayāthāvamānā. Tattha yāthāvamānā arahattamaggavajjhā, ayāthāvamānā sotāpattimaggavajjhā.
analyzed: itare dve ayāthāvamānā tattha yāthāvamānā arahatta magga vajjhā ayāthāvamānā sotāpatti magga vajjhā
translated: while the other two are wrong kinds of conceit. Herein, the right kinds of conceit are an impediment to the path of arahantship, and the wrong kinds of conceit are an impediment to the path of stream-entry.

original: 878. Evaṃ savatthuke māne kathetvā idāni avatthukaṃ nibbattitamānameva dassetuṃ tattha katamo mānotiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: evam sa vatthuke māne kathetvā idāni avatthukam nibbattita mānam eva dassetum tattha katamaḥ mānaḥ tiādi vuttaṃ
translated: Having thus shown conceit with a ground, he now said, “Herein, what is conceit? ” in order to show conceit without a ground.

original: 879. Atimānaniddese seyyādivasena puggalaṃ anāmasitvā jātiādīnaṃ vatthuvaseneva niddiṭṭho. Tattha atimaññatīti ‘jātiādīhi mayā sadiso natthī’ti atikkamitvā maññati.
analyzed: atimāna niddese seyyā ādi vasena puggalam an āmasitvā jāti ādīnam vatthu vasena iva niddiṭṭhaḥ tattha atimaññati iti jāti ādīhi mayā sadisaḥ natthi iti atikkamitvā maññati
translated: In the description of over- looking, the person is not mentioned by way of bed, etc., but the description is given by way of the bases of birth, etc. Herein, he overlooks is he conceives himself to be superior, thinking: “There is no one equal to me in birth, etc.”

original: 880. Mānātimānaniddese yo evarūpoti yo eso ‘ayaṃ pubbe mayā sadiso, idāni ahaṃ seṭṭho,
analyzed: māna atimāna niddese yaḥ evarūpaḥ ti yaḥ esaḥ ayam pubbe mayā sadisaḥ idāni aham seṭṭhaḥ
translated: In the description of pride and overlooking, he who is such is he who has arisen with the pride thinking: “This one was formerly equal to me, but now I am superior,

original: ahaṃ hīnataro’ti uppanno māno. Ayaṃ bhārātibhāro viya purimaṃ sadisamānaṃ upādāya🔽mānātimānoti dassetuṃ evamāha.
analyzed: aham hīnataraḥ iti uppannaḥ mānaḥ ayam bhāra atibhāraḥ viya purimam upādāya  māna atimānaḥ ti dassetum evam āha
translated: I am inferior.” This is a burden is said in order to show that pride and overlooking are like a burden,🔽in comparison with the former equal one.

original: 881. Omānaniddeso hīnamānaniddesasadisoyeva. Veneyyavasena pana so ‘hīnohamasmī’ti
analyzed: omāna niddesaḥ veneyya vasena pana saḥ hīnaḥ uham asmi iti
translated: The description of lack of pride is similar to the description of lack of overlooking. But because of the disciples, the pride thinking: “I am inferior”

original: māno nāma vutto – ayaṃ omāno nāma. Apicettha ‘tvaṃ jātimā, kākajāti viya te jāti;
analyzed: mānaḥ nāma vuttaḥ ayam omānaḥ nāma apica ittha tvam jātimā kāka jāti viya te jāti
translated: is called lack of pride. And here, “You are of birth, your birth is like a crow’s birth;

original: tvaṃ gottavā, caṇḍālagottaṃ viya te gottaṃ; tuyhaṃ saro atthi, kākassaro viya te
analyzed: tvam caṇḍāla gottam viya te gottam tuyham saraḥ atthi kākassaraḥ viya te
translated: you have a family, your family is like a caṇḍāla’s family; you have a voice, your voice is like a crow’s voice,”

original: saro’ti evaṃ attānaṃ heṭṭhā katvā pavattanavasena ayaṃ omānoti veditabbo.
analyzed: saroti evam attānam heṭṭhā katvā pavattana vasena ayam omāno ti veditabbo
translated: thus, by way of the occurrence of making oneself inferior, this is called lack of pride.

original: 882. Adhimānaniddese appatte pattasaññitāti cattāri saccāni appatvā pattasaññitāya.
analyzed: adhimāna niddese appatte patta saññi tā ati cattāri saccāni ap patvā patta saññi tāya
translated: In the description of conceit, “conceit in the unobtainable”: in the four noble truths, which are unobtainable in the sense of not being got by way of the fourfold search.

original: Akateti catūhi maggehi kattabbakicce akateyeva. Anadhigateti catusaccadhamme anadhigate.
analyzed: akatā iti catūhi maggehi kattabba kicce akatā iya iva anadhigatā iti catu sacca dhamme anadhigate
translated: “In the unaccomplished”: in the task to be done by the four paths, which is not yet accomplished. “In the unattained”: in the four noble truths, which are not yet attained.

original: Asacchikateti arahattena apaccakkhakate. Ayaṃ vuccati adhimānoti ayaṃ adhigatamāno nāma vuccati.
analyzed: asacchikatā iti arahattena apaccakkhakate ayam vuccati adhimāno ti ayam adhigata māno nāma vuccati
translated: “In the un-realized”: in the state of arahantship, which is not yet realized. This is called conceit: this is called “conceit in the unobtainable,” etc.

original: Ayaṃ pana kassa uppajjati, kassa nuppajjatīti? Ariyasāvakassa tāva nuppajjati. So
analyzed: ayam pana kassa uppajjati kassa nuppajjati iti ariya sāvakassa tāva nuppajjati so
translated: But who is it that conceives in this way and who is it that does not? The noble disciple does not conceive in this way.

original: hi maggaphalanibbānapahīnakilesāvasiṭṭhakilesapaccavekkhaṇena sañjātasomanasso ariyaguṇapaṭivedhe
analyzed: hi magga phala nibbāna pahīna kilesa avasiṭṭha kilesa paccavekkhaṇena sañjāta somanassaḥ ariya guṇa paṭivedhe
translated: For he is delighted by reviewing the defilements abandoned by the path, the fruit, and Nibbāna, and the defilements remaining in him that have not yet been abandoned.

original: nikkaṅkho. Tasmā sotāpannādīnaṃ ‘ahaṃ sakadāgāmī’tiādivasena māno nuppajjati; dussīlassāpi
analyzed: nikkaṅkho tasmā sotāpanna ādīnam aham sakadāgāmī iti ādi vasena mānaḥ nuppajjati dussīlassa api
translated: He is confident in the noble qualities he has penetrated. Therefore conceit does not arise in the stream-enterer, etc., in the form “I am a once-returner,” etc. It does not arise in the unvirtuous either,🔽for he is utterly devoid of hope for the attainment of the noble qualities.

original: nuppajjati; so hi ariyaguṇādhigame nirāsova. Sīlavatopi pariccattakammaṭṭhānassa🔽niddārāmatādimanuyuttassa nuppajjati.
analyzed: nuppajjati saḥ hi ariya guṇa adhigame nirāsaḥ uva sīlavataḥ pi pariccatta kammaṭṭhānassa 🔽niddā rāma tā ādi manuyuttassa nuppajjati
translated: It does not arise in the virtuous one either, if he is negligent and given to sensual pleasures, etc.,

original: Parisuddhasīlassa pana kammaṭṭhāne appamattassa nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapetvā paccayapariggahena
analyzed: parisuddha sīlassa pana kammaṭṭhāne appamattassa nāma rūpam vavatthapetvā paccaya pariggahena
translated: But when a man of purified virtue, who is diligent in the meditation subject, has defined mentality and materiality and has penetrated the three characteristics,

original: vitiṇṇakaṅkhassa tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā saṅkhāre sammasantassa āraddhavipassakassa
analyzed: vitiṇṇa kaṅkhassa ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā saṅkhāre sammasantassa āraddha vipassakassa
translated: and when he is discerning formations in the way beginning with the contemplation of rise and fall, and insight has been aroused in him,

original: uppajjati; uppanne ca suddhasamathalābhī vā suddhavipassanālābhī vā antarā ṭhapeti.🔽So hi dasapi vīsampi tiṃsampi vassāni kilesasamudācāraṃ apassanto ‘ahaṃ sotāpanno’ti
analyzed: uppajjati uppanne ca suddha samatha lābhī vā suddha vipassanā lābhī vā antarā ṭhapeti  so hi dasa pi vīsam pi tiṃsam pi vassāni kilesa samudācāram a passantaḥ aham sotāpannaḥ ti
translated: then it arises. And when it has arisen, one who has obtained serenity alone or serenity and insight together sets it aside.

original: vā ‘sakadāgāmī’ti vā ‘anāgāmī’ti vā maññati. Samathavipassanālābhī pana arahatteyeva
analyzed: vā sakadāgāmī iti vā anāgāmī iti vā maññati samatha vipassanā lābhī pana
translated: For he does not see the defilements stirring for ten years, twenty years, thirty years. He thinks, “I am a stream-enterer,” or “I am a once-returner,” or “I am a non-returner,”

original: ṭhapeti. Tassa hi samādhibalena kilesā vikkhambhitā, vipassanābalena saṅkhārā supariggahitā.🔽Tasmā saṭṭhipi vassāni asītipi vassāni vassasatampi kilesā na samudācaranti; khīṇāsavasseva
analyzed: ṭhapeti tassa hi samādhi balena kilesāḥ vikkhambhitāḥ vipassanā balena saṅkhārā su pariggahitā  tasmā saṭṭhi pi vassāni asīti pi vassāni vassa satam pi kilesāḥ na samudācaranti khīṇāsavassa iva
translated: and he sets it aside in the state of Arahantship. For the defilements are suppressed in him by the power of concentration, and formations are well discerned in him by the power of insight.🔽So for sixty years, for seventy years, for a hundred years the defilements do not stir in him. His mental process is like that of one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: cittacāro hoti. So evaṃ dīgharattaṃ kilesasamudācāraṃ apassanto antarā aṭṭhatvāva
analyzed: citta cāraḥ hoti saḥ evam dīgharattam kilesa samudācāram a passantaḥ antarā aṭṭhatvā ava
translated: He does not set it aside after a long time,

original: ‘arahā aha’nti maññati, uccamālaṅkavāsī mahānāgatthero viya, haṅkanakavāsī mahādattatthero
analyzed: arahā ahanti maññati haṅkanaka vāsī mahādatta tthero
translated: like the Elder Mahādatta, who wore a fine cloth and a fine mantle,

original: viya, cittalapabbate niṅkapoṇṇapadhānagharavāsī cūḷasumatthero viya ca.🔽Tatridaṃ ekavatthuparidīpanaṃ – talaṅgaravāsī dhammadinnatthero kira nāma eko pabhinnapaṭisambhido
analyzed: viya cittala pabbate niṅka poṇṇa padhāna ghara vāsī cūḷasuma theraḥ ca  tatra idam eka vatthu paridīpanam talaṅgara vāsī dhammadinna theraḥ kira nāma ekaḥ pabhinna paṭisambhidaḥ
translated: and like the Elder Cūḷasuman, who lived in the meditation house of Niṅkapoṇa on the Citta Pass.

original: mahākhīṇāsavo mahato bhikkhusaṅghassa ovādadāyako ahosi. So ekadivasaṃ attano divāṭṭhāne
analyzed: mahākhīṇāsavaḥ mahataḥ bhikkhu saṅghassa ovāda dāyakaḥ ahosi saḥ eka divasam attanaḥ divāṭṭhāne
translated: Here is an illustration of the kind of person he is. The Elder Dhammadinna, it seems, who lived at Talaṅgara, was a monk who had penetrated the mind-deliverance of loving- kindness and was a great expert in the Vinaya. He was a teacher of a large community of monks. One day, after sitting down in his day-quarters,

original: nisīditvā ‘kinnu kho amhākaṃ ācariyassa uccataliṅkavāsīmahānāgattherassa samaṇakiccaṃ🔽matthakaṃ patto, no’ti āvajjanto puthujjanabhāvamevassa disvā ‘mayi agacchante puthujjanakālakiriyameva
analyzed: nisīditvā kinnu kho amhākam ācariyassa uccataliṅka vāsī mahānāga ttherassa samaṇa kiccam  matthakam pattaḥ no ti āvajjanto puthujjana bhāvam eva assa disvā mayi agacchante puthujjana kālakiriyam eva
translated: he asked himself, “Has my teacher, the Elder Mahānāga, who wore a fine cloth and a fine mantle, reached the summit of the monk’s state?

original: karissatī’ti ca ñatvā iddhiyā vehāsaṃ uppatitvā divāṭṭhāne nisinnassa therassa samīpe
analyzed: karissati iti ca ñatvā iddhiyā vehāsam uppatitvā divāṭṭhāne nisinnassa therassa samīpe
translated: ” He saw that his teacher was still an ordinary man. He thought, “If I do not go to him, he will die an ordinary man’s death.” So he rose up in the air by his psychic power and stood in the Elder’s presence.

original: orohitvā vanditvā vattaṃ dassetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. ‘Kiṃ, āvuso dhammadinna, akāle🔽āgatosī’ti ca vutto ‘pañhaṃ, bhante, pucchituṃ āgatomhī’ti āha.
analyzed: orohitvā vanditvā vattam dassetvā ekamantam nisīdi kim āvuso dhammadinna akāle  āgato asi iti ca vuttaḥ pañham bhante pucchitum āgataḥ amhi iti āha
translated: and after paying homage to the Elder, he stood at one side and asked: ‘Why have you come at this time, friend Dhammadinna? ‘🔽‘To ask a question, venerable sir,’ he replied.🔽Then the Elder said: ‘Ask, friend, if you have any question, and I will answer it.’

original: Tato ‘pucchāvuso, jānamāno kathayissāmī’ti vutto pañhāsahassaṃ pucchi. Thero pucchitapucchitaṃ
analyzed: tatas puccha āvuso jānamāno kathayissāmi iti vutto pañhā sahassam pucchi thero pucchita pucchitam
translated: So he asked a thousand questions, and the Elder answered them all without hesitation.

original: pañhaṃ asajjamānova kathesi. Tato ‘atitikkhaṃ te, bhante, ñāṇaṃ. Kadā tumhehi ayaṃ
analyzed: pañham a sajjamānaḥ iva kathesi tatas atitikkham te bhante ñāṇam kadā tumhehi ayam
translated: Then he said: ‘Your knowledge is very keen, venerable sir. When did you attain this knowledge? ‘

original: dhammo adhigato’ti vutto ‘ito saṭṭhivassakāle, āvuso’ti āha. ‘Samādhimpi, bhante,
analyzed: dhammaḥ adhigataḥ ti vuttaḥ itas saṭṭhivassa kāle āvuso ti āha samādhim pi bhante
translated: ‘Sixty years ago, friend,’ he replied. ‘But your concentration must have decayed, venerable sir.’

original: vaḷañjethā’ti? ‘Na idaṃ, āvuso, bhāriya’nti. ‘Tena hi, bhante, ekaṃ hatthiṃ māpethā’ti.🔽Thero sabbasetaṃ hatthiṃ māpesi. ‘Idāni, bhante, yathā ayaṃ hatthī añcitakaṇṇo pasāritanaṅguṭṭho
analyzed: vaḷañjetha ati naḥ idam āvuso bhāriyanti tena hi bhante ekam hatthim māpetha ati  theraḥ sabbasetam hatthim māpesi idāni bhante yathā ayam hatthī añcita kaṇṇaḥ pasārita naṅguṭṭhaḥ
translated: ‘No, friend, it has not decayed.’ ‘Well then, venerable sir, let a single elephant be brought up.’

original: soṇḍaṃ mukhe pakkhipitvā bheravaṃ koñcanādaṃ karonto tumhākaṃ abhimukho āgacchati
analyzed: soṇḍam mukhe pakkhipitvā bheravam koñca nādam karonto tumhākam abhimukhaḥ āgacchati
translated: The Elder had a white elephant brought up. ‘Now, venerable sir, let this elephant come towards you trumpeting and with his ears and his trunk outstretched.’

original: tathā taṃ karothā’ti. Thero tathā katvā vegena āgacchato hatthissa bheravaṃ ākāraṃ
analyzed: tathā tam karotha ati theraḥ tathā katvā vegena āgacchataḥ hatthissa bheravam ākāram
translated: “Do so.” The elder did as he was told. But when the elephant came quickly, the elder saw his terrible appearance

original: disvā uṭṭhāya palāyituṃ āraddho. Tamenaṃ khīṇāsavatthero hatthaṃ pasāretvā cīvarakaṇṇe
analyzed: disvā uṭṭhāya palāyitum āraddhaḥ tam enam khīṇāsava theraḥ hattham pasāretvā cīvara kaṇṇe
translated: and started to run away. The elder of the Arahants extended his hand, seized the corner of the elder’s robe,

original: gahetvā ‘bhante, khīṇāsavassa sārajjaṃ nāma hotī’ti āha. So tasmiṃ kāle attano puthujjanabhāvaṃ🔽ñatvā ‘avassayo me, āvuso dhammadinna, hohī’ti vatvā pādamūle ukkuṭikaṃ nisīdi. ‘Bhante,
analyzed: gahetvā bhante khīṇāsavassa sārajjam nāma hoti iti āha saḥ tasmin kāle attanaḥ puthujjana bhāvam  ñatvā avassayaḥ me āvuso dhammadinna hohi iti vatvā pāda mūle ukkuṭikam nisīdi bhante
translated: and said, “Venerable sir, there is no fear in one whose cankers are destroyed.” The elder realized that he was still an ordinary man,

original: tumhākaṃ avassayo bhavissāmiccevāhaṃ āgato, mā cintayitthā’ti kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: tumhākam avassayaḥ bhavissāmi icca eva aham āgataḥ mā cintayittha ati kammaṭṭhānam kathesi
translated: and he sat down at the elder’s feet, saying, “Help me, friend Dhammadinna.” “I came only to help you, venerable sir. Do not worry.” And he gave him a meditation subject.

original: Thero kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā caṅkamaṃ āruyha tatiye padavāre aggaphalaṃ arahattaṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: thero kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā caṅkamam āruyha tatiye padavāre agga phalam arahattam pāpuṇi
translated: The elder took the meditation subject, went to the walking-path, and reached Arahantship at the end of the third watch of the night.

original: Thero kira dosacarito ahosi.
analyzed: theraḥ kira dosa caritaḥ ahosi
translated: The elder was of greedy temperament.

original: 883. Asmimānaniddese rūpaṃ asmīti mānoti ‘ahaṃ rūpa’nti uppannamāno. Chandoti mānaṃ anugatacchandova. Tathā anusayo. Vedanādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: rūpam asmi iti māno ti aham uppanna māno chando ti mānam anugata chandaḥ uva tathā anusayaḥ vedanā ādīsu pi esa iva nayo
translated: In the Description of Conceit based on the Five Factors of Existence, “He conceives form as self” is the conceiving of conceit that has arisen thus “I am form.” “Longing” is the longing that follows on conceit. So too with the underlying tendency. The same method applies to feeling, and so on.

original: 884. Micchāmānaniddese pāpakena vā kammāyatanenāti ādīsu pāpakaṃ kammāyatanaṃ nāma🔽kevaṭṭamacchabandhanesādādīnaṃ kammaṃ. Pāpakaṃ sippāyatanaṃ nāma macchajālakhipanakuminakaraṇesu
analyzed: micchāmāna niddese pāpakena vā kamma āyatanena ati ādīsu pāpakam kamma āyatanam nāma  kevaṭṭa macchabandha nesāda ādīnam kammam pāpakam sippāyatanam nāma maccha jāla khipana kumina karaṇesu
translated: In the description of wrong intention, “with a bad resort to action” and so on:

original: ceva pāsaoḍḍanasūlāropanādīsu ca chekatā. Pāpakaṃ vijjāṭṭhānaṃ nāma yā kāci parūpaghātavijjā.
analyzed: ca iva pāsa oḍḍana sūla āropana ādīsu ca cheka tā pāpakam vijjāṭṭhānam nāma yā kāci para upaghāta vijjā
translated: Bad resort to action is the action of fishermen, hunters, butchers, etc. Bad resort to craft is skill in such things as making fish-hooks, making bows, setting snares, impaling meat on spits, etc. Bad resort to knowledge is any knowledge that is harmful to others.

original: Pāpakaṃ sutaṃ nāma bhāratayuddhasītāharaṇādipaṭisaṃyuttaṃ. Pāpakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ nāma
analyzed: pāpakam sutam nāma bhārata yuddha sītā haraṇa ādi paṭisaṃyuttam pāpakam paṭibhānam nāma
translated: Bad resort to talk is talk connected with the Bhārata war, with the story of Sītā, etc. Bad resort to views is any view included among the sixty-two views.

original: dubbhāsitayuttaṃ kappanāṭakavilappanādipaṭibhānaṃ. Pāpakaṃ sīlaṃ nāma ajasīlaṃ gosīlaṃ.
analyzed: dubbhāsita yuttam kappa nāṭaka vilappana ādi paṭibhānam pāpakam sīlam nāma aja sīlam go sīlam
translated: Bad resort to virtue is the virtue of goats, the virtue of cattle, the virtue of dogs, the virtue of ascetics, the virtue of kings, and the virtue of thieves.

original: Vatampi ajavatagovatameva. Pāpikā diṭṭhi pana dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhigatesu yā kāci diṭṭhi.
analyzed: vatam pi ajavata govatam eva pāpikā diṭṭhi pana dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi gatesu yā kāci diṭṭhi
translated: The virtue of goats is the habit of some goats that when they have eaten short grass they go and plunge into a pond and then come out and stand in a line before eating. The virtue of cattle is the habit of some cattle that when they have eaten long grass they lie down. The virtue of dogs is the habit of some dogs that when they have eaten fine food they lie down. The virtue of ascetics is the habit of some ascetics that when they have eaten fine food they lie down. The virtue of kings is the habit of some kings that when they have eaten fine food they lie down. The virtue of thieves is the habit of some thieves that when they have eaten fine food they lie down. Bad resort to virtue is the same as the bad virtue of goats, cattle, dogs, ascetics, kings, and thieves. But bad resort to views is any view included among the sixty-two views.

original: 885. Ñātivitakkaniddesādīsu ‘mayhaṃ ñātayo sukhajīvino sampattiyuttā’ti evaṃ pañcakāmaguṇasannissitena
analyzed: ñāti vitakka niddesa ādīsu mayham ñātayo sukha jīvino sampatti yuttāḥ ti evam pañca kāmaguṇa sannissitena
translated: In the description of the kinds of thinking beginning with thinking of kinsmen, “My kinsmen are happy, prosperous, and so on” is thinking of kinsmen that is based on the five cords of sense desire.

original: gehasitapemena ñātake ārabbha uppannavitakkova ñātivitakko nāma. ‘Khayaṃ gatā vayaṃ
analyzed: geha sitapemena ñātake ārabbha uppanna vitakkaḥ va ñātivitakkaḥ nāma khayam gatāḥ vayam
translated: The thought that occurs in one who is attached to his relatives through the love of the house life, taking his relatives as object, is called “relatives-as-object thought.” But the thought that occurs thus, “We have lost our relatives,

original: gatā saddhā pasannā’ti evaṃ pavatto pana ñātivitakko nāma na hoti.🔽886. ‘Amhākaṃ janapado subhikkho sampannasasso’ti tuṭṭhamānassa gehasitapemavaseneva🔽uppannavitakko janapadavitakko nāma. ‘Amhākaṃ janapade manussā saddhā pasannā khayaṃ
analyzed: gatā saddhā pasannā ti evam pavattaḥ pana ñāti vitakkaḥ nāma na hoti  amhākam janapadaḥ subhikkhaḥ sampanna sassaḥ ti tuṭṭhamānassa geha sita pema vasena iva  uppanna vitakkaḥ janapada vitakkaḥ nāma amhākam janapade manussā saddhā pasannā khayaṃ
translated: our faith and confidence are gone,” is not called “relatives-as-object thought.”

original: gatā vayaṃ gatā’ti evaṃ pavatto pana janapadavitakko nāma na hoti.🔽887. Amaratthāya vitakko, amaro vā vitakkoti amaravitakko. Tattha ‘ukkuṭikappadhānādīhi🔽dukkhe nijjiṇṇe samparāye attā sukhī hoti amaro’ti dukkarakārikaṃ karontassa tāya
analyzed: gatāḥ vayam gatāḥ iti evam pavattaḥ pana janapada vitakkaḥ nāma na hoti  amara atthāya vitakkaḥ amaraḥ vā tattha ukkuṭika ppadhāna ādīhi  dukkhe nijjiṇṇe samparāye attā sukhī hoti dukkara kārikam karontassa tāya
translated: The thought that occurs in one who is pleased with the thought, “Our country is prosperous and has good harvests,” through the love of the house life is called “country-as-object thought.” But the thought that occurs thus, “In our country people are faithful and confident, but now they have lost their faith and confidence and are gone,” is not called “country-as-object thought.”

original: dukkarakārikāya paṭisaṃyutto vitakko amaratthāya vitakko nāma. Diṭṭhigatiko pana
analyzed: dukkara kārikāya paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ amara atthāya vitakkaḥ nāma diṭṭhi gatikaḥ pana
translated: The thought that is for immortality or the thought that is immortal is called “immortality-as-object thought.” Herein, the thought associated with the practice of austerities that occurs in one who is practising austerities, thinking, “When I have worn away this body by means of these austerities, in some future existence I shall obtain immortality and be happy,” is called “thought that is for immortality.” But the thought of one who is a theorist is called

original: ‘sassataṃ vadesī’tiādīni puṭṭho ‘evantipi me no, tathātipi me no’ aññathātipi me
analyzed: sassatam vadesi itiādīni puṭṭhaḥ evam iti pi me no tathā atipi me no aññathā atipi me
translated: When asked, ‘Do you say that the world is eternal? ‘ he falls back on evasive statements: ‘It is not so, it is not thus, it is not otherwise, it is not non-existent’ .

original: no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti vikkhepaṃ āpajjati, tassa so diṭṭhigatapaṭisaṃyutto
analyzed: no no tipi me no no no tipi me no ti vikkhepam āpajjati tassa so diṭṭhigata paṭisaṃyutto
translated: The thought associated with his view is ‘the thought of the undying’ .

original: vitakko. Yathā amaro nāma maccho udake gahetvā māretuṃ na sakkā, ito cito ca dhāvati,
analyzed: vitakkaḥ yathā amaraḥ nāma macchaḥ udake gahetvā māretum na sakkā itas citas ca dhāvati
translated: Just as a fish called ‘undying’ cannot be caught and killed in water, but keeps darting this way and that,

original: gāhaṃ na gacchati; evameva ekasmiṃ pakkhe asaṇṭhahanato na maratīti amaro nāma hoti.
analyzed: gāham na gacchati evam eva ekasmin pakkhe a saṇṭhahanataḥ na marati iti amaraḥ nāma hoti
translated: and does not come to the hook, so too, because it does not settle down on any one side, it does not die.

original: Taṃ duvidhampi ekato katvā ayaṃ vuccati amaravitakkoti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tam duvidham pi ekatas katvā ayam vuccati amara vitakkaḥ ti vuttam
translated: And both these are called ‘the thought of the undying’ taken together.

original: 888. Parānuddayatāpaṭisaṃyuttoti anuddayatāpatirūpakena gehasitapemena paṭisaṃyutto.🔽Sahanandītiādīsu upaṭṭhākesu nandantesu socantesu ca tehi saddhiṃ diguṇaṃ nandati,
analyzed: para anuddaya tā paṭisaṃyuttaḥ ti anuddaya tā patirūpakena geha sita pemena paṭisaṃyuttaḥ  saha nandi iti ādīsu upaṭṭhākesu nandantesu socantesu ca tehi saddhim diguṇam nandati
translated: ‘Associated with the absence of resentment’ means associated with the absence of resentment in the form of affection for the household life.🔽‘In sympathy’ , etc.: when the attendants are glad or sorry, he is twice as glad or sorry as they are;

original: diguṇaṃ socati; tesu sukhitesu diguṇaṃ sukhito hoti, dukkhitesu diguṇaṃ dukkhito
analyzed: diguṇam socati tesu sukhitesu diguṇam sukhitaḥ hoti dukkhitesu diguṇam dukkhitaḥ
translated: when they are happy he is twice as happy as they are, and when they are miserable he is twice as miserable as they are;

original: hoti. Uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesūti tesu mahantesu vā khuddakesu vā kammesu uppannesu.🔽Attanā vā yogaṃ āpajjatīti tāni tāni kiccāni sādhento paññattiṃ vītikkamati, sallekhaṃ
analyzed: hoti uppannesu kicca karaṇīyesu iti tesu mahantesu vā khuddakesu vā kammesu uppannesu  attanā vā yogam āpajjati iti tāni tāni kiccāni sādhentaḥ paññattim vītikkamati sallekham
translated: When there is work to be done: when there is work to be done, whether great or small.🔽He applies himself: he transgresses the directions for the work he is doing in order to get things done, and he breaks into his meditation.

original: kopeti. Yo tatthāti yo tasmiṃ saṃsaṭṭhavihāre, tasmiṃ vā yogāpajjane gehasito vitakko
analyzed: kopeti yaḥ tattha ati yaḥ tasmin saṃsaṭṭha vihāre tasmin vā yoga āpajjane geha sitaḥ vitakko
translated: The thought that occurs to him: the thought that occurs to him in the company of the lay people, or in the application to the work.

original: – ayaṃ parānuddayatāpaṭisaṃyutto vitakko nāma.
analyzed: ayam para anuddaya tā paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ nāma
translated: This is called thought connected with non-offence:

original: 889. Lābhasakkārasilokapaṭisaṃyuttoti cīvarādilābhena ceva sakkārena ca kittisaddena ca saddhiṃ ārammaṇakaraṇavasena paṭisaṃyutto.🔽890. Anavaññattipaṭisaṃyuttoti ‘aho vata maṃ pare na avajāneyyuṃ, na pothetvā viheṭhetvā
analyzed: lābha sakkāra siloka paṭisaṃyuttaḥ ti cīvara ādi lābhena ca iva sakkārena ca kitti saddena ca saddhim ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena paṭisaṃyuttaḥ  an avaññatti paṭisaṃyuttaḥ ti aho vata mama pare na avajāneyyum na pothetvā viheṭhetvā
translated: Connected with gain, honour, and fame: connected with gain, etc., by making them the object.

original: katheyyu’nti evaṃ anavaññātabhāvapatthanāya saddhiṃ uppajjanavitakko. Yo tattha gehasitoti🔽yo tasmiṃ ‘mā maṃ pare avajāniṃsū’ti uppanne citte pañcakāmaguṇasaṅkhātagehanissito
analyzed: katheyyunti evam anavaññāta bhāva patthanāya saddhim uppajjana vitakko yaḥ tattha geha sito ti 🔽yaḥ tasmin mā mama pare avajāniṃsu iti uppanne citte pañca kāmaguṇa saṅkhāta geha nissitaḥ
translated: Connected with not being consulted: the thought that occurs to him in the hope of not being consulted, thinking, “Oh, that people would not despise me, would not make me regret it, would not make me give up what I want to do!”🔽The thought that occurs to him: the thought that occurs to him in the company of the lay people, or in the application to the work.

original: hutvā uppannavitakko. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭamevāti.
analyzed: hutvā uppanna vitakkaḥ sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva ati
translated: and arisen thinking. The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Ekakaniddesavaṇṇanā.
translated: The commentary on the section on single terms.

original: (2.) Dukaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: duka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the section on double terms

original: 891. Dukesu kodhaniddesādayo heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva veditabbā. Heṭṭhā anāgatesu pana
analyzed: dukesu kodha niddesa ādayaḥ heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva veditabbā heṭṭhā anāgatesu pana
translated: . The two terms beginning with “resentment” should be understood in the way already stated under the single terms. But in the case of the terms not stated there,

original: upanāhaniddesādīsu pubbakālaṃ kodhaṃ upanayhatīti aparakālakodho upanāho nāma. Upanayhanākāro🔽upanayhanā. Upanayhitassa bhāvo upanayhitattaṃ. Aṭṭhapanāti paṭhamuppannassa anantaraṭṭhapanā🔽mariyādaṭṭhapanā vā. Ṭhapanāti pakatiṭhapanā. Saṇṭhapanāti sabbatobhāgena punappunaṃ🔽āghātaṭṭhapanā. Anusaṃsandanāti paṭhamuppannena kodhena saddhiṃ antaraṃ adassetvā
analyzed: upanāha niddesa ādīsu pubba kālam kodham upanayhati iti apara kāla kodhaḥ upanāhaḥ nāma upanayhana ākāraḥ  upanayhanā upanayhitassa bhāvaḥ upanayhitattam aṭṭhapanā ti paṭhama uppannassa anantaraṭṭhapanā  mariyāda ṭhapanā vā ṭhapanā ati pakati ṭhapanā saṇṭhapanā ati sabbatobhāgena punappunam  āghāta ṭṭhapanā anusaṃsandanā ti paṭhama uppannena kodhena saddhim antaram a dassetvā
translated: that is to say, “bearing ill will” , etc., “bearing ill will” is the state of being resentful at a later time after being angry at first. The way of bearing ill will is

original: ekībhāvakaraṇā. Anuppabandhanāti purimena saddhiṃ pacchimassa ghaṭanā. Daḷhīkammanti🔽thirakaraṇaṃ. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ upanandhanalakkhaṇo veraṃ appaṭinissajjanaraso
analyzed: ekībhāva karaṇā an uppabandhanā ti purimena saddhim pacchimassa ghaṭanā daḷhīkammanti 🔽thira karaṇam ayam vuccati iti ayam upanandhana lakkhaṇaḥ veram appaṭinissajjana rasaḥ
translated: bearing ill will. The state of one who bears ill will is bearing ill will. “Suppressing” is the state of suppressing what has arisen first, or it is the state of suppressing by setting a limit. “Keeping suppressed” is the state of keeping to the normal. “Keeping on a leash” is the state of suppressing again and again by all means. “Grudging” is the state of not giving up what has arisen first, and not looking to what comes later. “Concealing” is the state of not showing what is in the mind. “Not giving up” is the state of not giving up what has arisen first. “Not letting go” is the state of not relinquishing what has arisen first. “Not forgiving” is the state of not forgiving what has arisen first. “Not clearing up” is the state of not clearing up what has arisen first. “Not making amends” is the state of not making amends for what has arisen first. “Not making rehabilitation” is the state of not making rehabilitation for what has arisen first. “Not letting be” is the state of not letting be what has arisen first. “Not letting go” is the state of not letting go what has arisen first. “Not giving up” is the state of not giving up what has arisen first. “Not relinquishing” is the state of not relinquishing what has arisen first. “Not forgiving” is the state of not forgiving what has arisen first. “Not clearing up” is the state of not clearing up what has arisen first. “Not making amends” is the state of not making amends for what has arisen first. “Not making rehabilitation” is the state of not making rehabilitation for what has arisen first. “Not letting be” is the state of not letting be what has arisen first. “Not letting go” is the state of not letting go what has arisen first. “Not giving up” is the state of not giving up what has arisen first

original: upanāhoti vuccati; yena samannāgato puggalo veraṃ nissajjituṃ na sakkoti; ‘evaṃ nāma
analyzed: upanāhaḥ ti vuccati yena samannāgataḥ puggalaḥ veram nissajjitum na sakkoti evam nāma
translated: is called resentment. A person who has this does not let go of a grudge.

original: maṃ esa vattuṃ ananucchaviko’ti aparāparaṃ anubandhati; ādittapūtialātaṃ viya jalateva;
analyzed: mama apara aparam anubandhati apara aparam
translated: is what is meant. When a person is possessed of this, he cannot give up his enmity. He goes on and on thinking, ‘It is not proper for him to speak to me like that,’ and he burns up like a burning charcoal pit.

original: dhoviyamānaṃ acchacammaṃ viya, vasātelamakkhitapilotikā viya ca na parisujjhati.
analyzed: dhoviyamānam accha cammam viya vasā tela makkhita pilotikā viya ca na parisujjhati
translated: He is not purified like a clean cloth being washed, or like a rag soaked in oil that is not cleaned.

original: 892. Makkhanabhāvavasena makkho; paraguṇamakkhanāya pavattentopi attano kāraṇaṃ,
analyzed: makkhana bhāva vasena makkho para guṇa makkhanāya pavattentaḥ api attanaḥ kāraṇam
translated: It is a stain because of the state of being a stain. Even though it occurs in order to stain the good qualities of others, it is one’s own business.

original: gūthapaharaṇakaṃ gūtho viya, paṭhamataraṃ makkhetīti attho. Tato parā dve ākārabhāvaniddesā.
analyzed: gūtha paharaṇakam gūthaḥ viya paṭhamataram makkheti iti attho tatas parā dve ākāra bhāva niddesā
translated: It is like a dung-carrier’s dung. The meaning is that it stains first of all. The next two are expositions of the two modes.

original: Niṭṭhurabhāvo niṭṭhuriyaṃ; ‘taṃ nissāya ettakampi natthī’ti kheḷapātananti attho.
analyzed: niṭṭhura bhāvaḥ niṭṭhuriyam tam nissāya ettakam pi natthi iti kheḷa pātanam ti attho
translated: It is harshness because of the state of being harsh. The meaning is that it is the casting out of spittle, thinking ‘Because of him there is not even that much.’

original: Niṭṭhuriyakammanti niṭṭhuriyakaraṇaṃ. Gahaṭṭho vā hi gahaṭṭhaṃ, bhikkhu vā bhikkhuṃ
analyzed: niṭṭhuriya kammanti niṭṭhuriya karaṇam gahaṭṭhaḥ vā hi gahaṭṭham bhikkhu vā bhikkhum
translated: The action of harshness is the doing of harshness. For a householder or a monk,

original: nissāya vasanto appamattakeneva kujjhitvā ‘taṃ nissāya ettakampi natthī’ti kheḷaṃ
analyzed: nissāya vasantaḥ appamattakena iva kujjhitvā tam nissāya ettakam pi natthi iti kheḷam
translated: living in dependence on a householder or a monk, gets angry at the slightest thing and casts out spittle, thinking ‘Because of him there is not even that much.’

original: pātetvā pādena maddanto viya niṭṭhuriyaṃ nāma karoti. Tassa taṃ kammaṃ niṭṭhuriyakammanti
analyzed: pātetvā pādena maddantaḥ viya niṭṭhuriyam nāma karoti tassa tat kammam niṭṭhuriya kammanti
translated: He makes it as if he were crushing it with his foot. This is called “grinding” .

original: vuccati. Lakkhaṇādito panesa paraguṇamakkhanalakkhaṇo makkho, tesaṃ vināsanaraso,
analyzed: vuccati lakkhaṇa āditaḥ pana esa para guṇa makkhana lakkhaṇaḥ makkhaḥ tesam vināsana raso
translated: Its characteristic is the disparaging of others’ good qualities. Its function is to destroy them.

original: parena sukatānaṃ kiriyānaṃ avacchādanapaccupaṭṭhāno.
analyzed: parena su katānam kiriyānam avacchādana paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: It is manifested as the concealing of others’ good deeds.

original: Paḷāsatīti paḷāso; parassa guṇe dassetvā attano guṇehi samaṃ karotīti attho. Paḷāsassa🔽āyanā paḷāsāyanā. Paḷāso ca so attano jayāharaṇato āhāro cāti paḷāsāhāro. Vivādaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: paḷāsati iti paḷāsaḥ parassa guṇe dassetvā attanaḥ guṇehi samam karoti iti attho paḷāsassa  āyanā paḷāsa ayanā paḷāso ca so attano jaya āharaṇato āhāro ca ati paḷāsa āhāro vivāda ṭhānanti
translated: It makes others afraid, thus it is fear (paḷāsa). The meaning is that it makes others equal to oneself by showing their good qualities.🔽The cause of fear is fear-causing . Fear is a nutriment because it takes away one’s victory. The basis for dispute is

original: vivādakāraṇaṃ. Yugaggāhoti samadhuraggahaṇaṃ. Appaṭinissaggoti attanā gahitassa appaṭinissajjanaṃ.
analyzed: vivāda kāraṇam yuga ggāho ti samadhura ggahaṇam appaṭinissaggo ti attanā gahitassa appaṭinissajjanam
translated: the cause for dispute. Grasping at a pair is the grasping of a pair of opposites. Non-abandonment is the non-abandoning of what one has grasped.

original: Lakkhaṇādito panesa yugaggāhalakkhaṇo paḷāso, paraguṇehi attano guṇānaṃ samakaraṇaraso,🔽paresaṃ guṇappamāṇena upaṭṭhānapaccupaṭṭhāno. Paḷāsī hi puggalo dutiyassa dhuraṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇa āditaḥ pana isa yuga ggāha lakkhaṇaḥ paḷāsaḥ para guṇehi attanaḥ guṇānam sama karaṇa rasaḥ 🔽paresam guṇa ppamāṇena upaṭṭhāna paccupaṭṭhāno paḷāsī hi puggalo dutiyassa dhuram
translated: Its characteristic is the grasping of a pair of opposites. Its function is to make one’s own good qualities equal to others’ good qualities.🔽It is manifested as the service rendered to others by measuring oneself against them. For the person who is fearful, when another is carrying a heavy load, he thinks: “He is carrying a heavy load. I too am carrying a heavy load.”

original: na deti, samaṃ pasāretvā tiṭṭhati, sākacchamaṇḍale aññena bhikkhunā bahūsu suttesu
analyzed: na deti samam pasāretvā tiṭṭhati sākaccha maṇḍale aññena bhikkhunā bahūsu suttesu
translated: If he does not give, he stands his ground. In a discussion circle, when a number of suttas and reasons have been brought forward,

original: ca kāraṇesu ca ābhatesupi ‘tava ca mama ca vāde kiṃ nāma nānākaraṇaṃ? Nanu majjhe
analyzed: ca kāraṇesu ca tava ca mama ca vāde kim nāma nānākaraṇam nanu majjhe
translated: he says, “What is the difference between your statement and mine? Aren’t they the same, like gold in the middle? ”

original: bhinnasuvaṇṇaṃ viya ekasadisameva amhākaṃ vacana’nti vadati. Issāmacchariyaniddesā vuttatthā eva.🔽894. Māyāniddese vācaṃ bhāsatīti jānaṃyeva ‘paṇṇattiṃ vītikkamantā bhikkhū bhāriyaṃ
analyzed: bhinna suvaṇṇam viya eka sadisam eva amhākam vacananti vadati issā macchariya niddesāḥ vutta tthāḥ eva  māyā niddese vācam bhāsati iti jānaṃya iva paṇṇattim vītikkamantāḥ bhikkhū bhāriyam
translated: The explanations of envy and avarice are the same as before.

original: karonti, amhākaṃ pana vītikkamaṭṭhānaṃ nāma natthī’ti upasanto viya bhāsati. Kāyena
analyzed: karonti amhākam pana vītikkama ṭṭhānam nāma natthi iti upasantaḥ viya bhāsati kāyena
translated: In the description of deceit, he speaks with his tongue: knowing, he says, “The monks who transgress the rules commit a serious offense, but we don’t have anything to transgress.” He speaks as if he were calm.

original: parakkamatīti ‘mayā kataṃ idaṃ pāpakammaṃ mā keci jāniṃsū’ti kāyena vattaṃ karoti.
analyzed: parakkamati iti mayā katam idam pāpa kammam mā keci jāniṃsu iti kāyena vattam karoti
translated: He acts with his body: “Let no one know that I have done this evil deed.” He acts with his body.

original: Vijjamānadosapaṭicchādanato cakkhumohanamāyā viyāti māyā. Māyāvino bhāvo māyāvitā.
analyzed: vijjamāna dosa paṭicchādanato cakkhu mohana māyā viyāti māyā māyāvinaḥ bhāvaḥ māyāvi tā
translated: Because it conceals the real state of affairs, it is a deception, like an eye-deceiving trick. The state of being a deceiver is deceitfulness.

original: Katvā pāpaṃ puna paṭicchādanato aticca āsaranti etāya sattāti accāsarā. Kāyavācākiriyāhi
analyzed: katvā pāpam puna paṭicchādanataḥ aticca āsaranti etāya sattā ati accāsarā
translated: Because it conceals evil that has been done, it is a cover-up, because it covers over, because it is used to cover over. Because it is done with the body and speech, it is bodily and verbal action.

original: aññathā dassanato vañcetīti vañcanā. Etāya sattā nikarontīti nikati; micchākarontīti
analyzed: aññathā dassanataḥ vañceti iti vañcanā etāya sattā nikaronti iti nikati micchā karonti iti
translated: It is deception because it deceives by showing otherwise than is the case. It is craft because by it beings are led into crooked ways; the meaning is, they are led into wrong ways. It is guile because of the concealing of evil by the thought, “I am not doing anything wrong”;

original: attho. ‘Nāhaṃ evaṃ karomī’ti pāpānaṃ vikkhipanato vikiraṇā. ‘Nāhaṃ evaṃ karomī’ti
analyzed: atthaḥ na aham evam karomi iti pāpānam vikkhipanataḥ vikiraṇāḥ na aham evam karomi iti
translated: it is dissimulation because of the avoiding of evil by the thought, “I am not doing anything wrong”;

original: parivajjanato pariharaṇā. Kāyādīhi saṃvaraṇato gūhanā. Sabbatobhāgena gūhanā parigūhanā.
analyzed: parivajjanato pariharaṇā kāya ādīhi saṃvaraṇato gūhanā sabbatobhāgena gūhanā parigūhanā
translated: it is concealment because of the concealing by means of body and speech; it is thorough concealment because of the concealing by all means;

original: Tiṇapaṇṇehi viya gūthaṃ kāyavacīkammehi pāpaṃ chādetīti chādanā. Sabbatobhāgena chādanā
analyzed: tiṇa paṇṇehi viya gūtham kāya vacī kammehi pāpam chādeti iti chādanā sabbatobhāgena chādanā
translated: it is covering up because of the covering up of evil by means of bodily and verbal action as if by grass and leaves; it is complete covering up because of the covering up by all means;🔽it is not making plain because of not making plain by showing up;

original: paṭicchādanā. Na uttānaṃ katvā dassetīti anuttānīkammaṃ. Na pākaṭaṃ katvā dassetīti
analyzed: paṭicchādanā na uttānam katvā dasseti iti an uttānīkammam na pākaṭam katvā dasseti iti
translated: it is not making evident because of not making evident by making clear;

original: anāvikammaṃ. Suṭṭhu chādanā vocchādanā. Katapaṭicchādanavasena punapi pāpassa karaṇato
analyzed: an āvikammam suṭṭhu chādanā vocchādanā kata paṭicchādana vasena puna api pāpassa karaṇato
translated: it is thorough covering up because of covering up well; it is doing evil because of doing evil again by way of concealing what has been done;

original: pāpakiriyā. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ katapaṭicchādanalakkhaṇā māyā nāma vuccati; yāya
analyzed: pāpa kiriyā ayam vuccati iti ayam kata paṭicchādana lakkhaṇā māyā nāma vuccati yāya
translated: this is called: this so-called deceit, which has the characteristic of concealing what has been done, is called “māyā” ;

original: samannāgato puggalo bhasmāpaṭicchanno viya aṅgāro, udakapaṭicchanno viya khāṇu, pilotikāpaliveṭhitaṃ
analyzed: samannāgataḥ puggalaḥ bhasma apaṭicchannaḥ viya aṅgāro udaka paṭicchannaḥ viya khāṇu pilotikā paliveṭhitam
translated: by which a person is like a charcoal covered with ashes, like a stump covered with water, like a razor smeared with honey,

original: viya ca satthaṃ hoti.
analyzed: viya ca sattham hoti
translated: and it is a weapon.🔽In the description of deceit, a deceiver is one who speaks not in accordance with fact by showing nonexistent good qualities.

original: Sāṭheyyaniddese saṭhoti asantaguṇaparidīpanato na sammā bhāsitā. Sabbatobhāgena saṭho
analyzed: sāṭheyya niddese saṭho ti asanta guṇa paridīpanato na sammā bhāsitā sabbatobhāgena saṭho
translated: A deceiver in every way is a complete deceiver.

original: parisaṭho. Yaṃ tatthāti yaṃ tasmiṃ puggale. Saṭhanti asantaguṇadīpanaṃ kerāṭiyaṃ.
analyzed: yam tattha ati yam tasmin puggale saṭhanti asanta guṇa dīpanam kerāṭiyam
translated: What is there? What is in that person. Deceit is the showing of nonexistent good qualities, the kerāṭiya .

original: Saṭhatāti saṭhākāro. Kakkaratāti padumanālissa viya aparāmasanakkhamo kharapharusabhāvo.
analyzed: saṭha tā ati saṭhākāro kakkara tā ati paduma nālissa viya a parāmasana khamaḥ khara pharusa bhāvo
translated: Deceitfulness is the state of being a deceiver. Sharpness is the state of being sharp and rough, like the stalk of a lotus, and incapable of being grasped.

original: Kakkariyantipi tasseva vevacanaṃ. Parikkhattatā pārikkhattiyanti padadvayena nikhaṇitvā
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam parikkhatta tā pārikkhattiyanti pada dvayena nikhaṇitvā
translated: Kerāṭiya is also a synonym for that. The two words “concealment” and “concealer” refer to a firm kerāṭiya, as if it were buried and placed .

original: ṭhapitaṃ viya daḷhakerāṭiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Idaṃ vuccatīti idaṃ attano avijjamānaguṇappakāsanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapitam viya daḷha kerāṭiyam vuttam idam vuccati iti idam attanaḥ a vijjamāna guṇa ppakāsana lakkhaṇam
translated: This is called deceit: this is called deceit, which has the characteristic of showing nonexistent good qualities that are not in oneself;

original: sāṭheyyaṃ nāma vuccati; yena samannāgatassa puggalassa kucchiṃ vā piṭṭhiṃ vā jānituṃ na sakkā.🔽Vāmena sūkaro hoti, dakkhiṇena ajāmigo;
analyzed: sāṭheyyam nāma vuccati yena samannāgatassa puggalassa kucchim vā piṭṭhim vā jānitum na sakkā  vāmena sūkaraḥ hoti dakkhiṇena ajāmigo
translated: by which one cannot know the belly or back of a person who possesses it.🔽On the left he is a pig, on the right a goat,

original: Sarena nelako hoti, visāṇena jaraggavoti.
analyzed: sarena nelakaḥ hoti visāṇena jaraggavaḥ ti
translated: In his voice he is a heron, in his horns a gāvī .

original: Evaṃ vuttayakkhasūkarasadiso hoti. Avijjādiniddesā vuttatthā eva.
analyzed: evam vutta yakkha sūkara sadisaḥ hoti avijja ādi niddesāḥ vutta tthāḥ eva
translated: He is like the yakkha and the pig mentioned in the sutta. The words ignorance, etc., have the same meaning as before.

original: 902. Anajjavaniddese anajjavoti anujutākāro. Anajjavabhāvo anajjavatā. Jimhatāti
analyzed: anajjava niddese anajjavā iti anujuta ākāraḥ anajjava bhāvaḥ anajjava tā
translated: In the description of unbending: unbending is the state of being unbent. The quality of being unbent is unbendingness. Crookedness is

original: candavaṅkatā. Vaṅkatāti gomuttavaṅkatā. Kuṭilatāti naṅgalakoṭivaṅkatā. Sabbehipi
analyzed: canda vaṅka tā vaṅka tā ati gomutta vaṅka tā kuṭila tā ati naṅgala koṭi vaṅka tā sabbehi pi
translated: crookedness like the moon’s digit. Crookedness like a cow’s horn is crookedness. Crookedness like the end of a plough is crookedness. All these

original: imehi padehi kāyavacīcittavaṅkatāva kathitā.
analyzed: imehi padehi kathitā
translated: words refer to crookedness of body, speech, and mind.

original: Amaddavaniddese na mudubhāvo amudutā. Amaddavākāro amaddavatā. Kakkhaḷabhāvo kakkhaḷiyaṃ.🔽Maddavakarassa sinehassa abhāvato pharusabhāvo phārusiyaṃ. Anīcavuttitāya ujukameva🔽ṭhitacittabhāvo ujucittatā. Puna amudutāgahaṇaṃ tassā visesanatthaṃ ‘amudutāsaṅkhātā
analyzed: amaddava niddese na mudu bhāvaḥ amudu tā a maddava ākāraḥ a maddava tā kakkhaḷa bhāvaḥ kakkhaḷiyam  maddava karassa sinehassa abhāvataḥ pharusa bhāvaḥ phārusiyam anīca vutti tāya ujukam eva  ṭhita citta bhāvaḥ uju citta tā puna amudu tā gahaṇam tassāḥ visesana attham amudu tā saṅkhātā
translated: In the description of unpliancy: the absence of pliancy is unpliancy. The state of being unpliant is unpliableness. The quality of being hard is hardness.

original: ujucittatā, na ajjavasaṅkhātā ujucittatā’ti.
analyzed: uju citta tā na ajjava saṅkhātā uju citta tā ati
translated: The state of being rough, because of the absence of the oil of pliancy, is roughness. The state of being upright, because of the absence of crookedness, is uprightness. The state of mind that remains upright, because of the absence of crookedness, is uprightness of mind. The repetition of the word unpliancy is for the purpose of distinguishing it as follows: “Uprightness of mind is called unpliancy, not uprightness of mind in the sense of uprightness.”

original: 903. Akkhantiniddesādayo khantiniddesādipaṭipakkhato veditabbā.
analyzed: akkhanti niddesa ādayaḥ khanti niddesa ādi paṭipakkhataḥ veditabbā
translated: The descriptions of intolerance, etc., should be understood as the opposites of the descriptions of tolerance, etc.

original: 908. Saṃyojananiddese ajjhattanti kāmabhavo. Bahiddhāti rūpārūpabhavo. Kiñcāpi hi🔽sattā kāmabhave appaṃ kālaṃ vasanti kappassa catutthameva koṭṭhāsaṃ, itaresu tīsu
analyzed: saṃyojana niddese kāma bhavaḥ bahiddhā ati rūpa arūpa bhavaḥ kiñca api hi  sattā kāma bhave appam kālam vasanti kappassa catuttham eva koṭṭhāsam itaresu tīsu
translated: In the description of fetters, “internal” is the sensual-desire realm. “External” is the fine-material and immaterial realms.🔽Although beings live in the sensual-desire realm for only a quarter of an eon, and the other three quarters of the eon are empty and void of beings,

original: koṭṭhāsesu kāmabhavo suñño hoti tuccho, rūpārūpabhave bahuṃ kālaṃ vasanti, tathāpi
analyzed: koṭṭhāsesu kāma bhavaḥ suññaḥ hoti tucchaḥ rūpa arūpa bhave bahum kālam vasanti tathā api
translated: and although they live in the fine-material and immaterial realms for a long time,

original: nesaṃ yasmā kāmabhave cutipaṭisandhiyo bahukā honti, appā rūpārūpabhavesu, yattha
analyzed: na isam kāma bhave cuti paṭisandhiyaḥ bahukāḥ honti rūpa arūpa bhavesu
translated: nevertheless, since there are many deaths and rebirths in the sensual-desire realm and few in the other two,

original: ca cutipaṭisandhiyo bahukā tattha ālayopi patthanāpi abhilāsopi bahu hoti, yattha
analyzed: ca cuti paṭisandhiyaḥ bahukā tattha ālayaḥ pi patthanā api abhilāso pi bahu hoti yattha
translated: and since attachment, aspiration, and desire are many where there are many deaths and rebirths and few where they are few,

original: appā tattha appo, tasmā kāmabhavo ajjhattaṃ nāma jāto, rūpārūpabhavā bahiddhā nāma.
analyzed: appā tattha appaḥ tasmā kāma bhavaḥ ajjhattam nāma jātaḥ rūpa arūpa bhavāḥ bahiddhā nāma
translated: the sensual-desire realm is called “internal” and the fine-material and immaterial realms are called “external.”

original: Iti ajjhattasaṅkhāte kāmabhave bandhanaṃ ajjhattasaṃyojanaṃ nāma, bahiddhāsaṅkhātesu
analyzed: iti ajjhatta saṅkhāte kāma bhave bandhanam ajjhatta saṃyojanam nāma bahiddhā saṅkhātesu
translated: Thus the fetter in the sensual-desire realm, which is called “internal,” is a fetter in the internal,

original: rūpārūpabhavesu bandhanaṃ bahiddhāsaṃyojanaṃ nāma. Tattha ekekaṃ pañcapañcavidhaṃ
analyzed: rūpa arūpa bhavesu bandhanam bahiddhāsaṃyojanam nāma tattha ekekam pañca pañcavidham
translated: and the fetter in the fine-material and immaterial realms, which is called “external,” is a fetter in the external. Each of these is fivefold.

original: hoti. Tena vuttaṃ “pañcorambhāgiyāni pañcuddhambhāgiyānī”ti. Tatrāyaṃ vacanattho
analyzed: hoti tena vuttam pañca orambhāgiyāni pañca uddhambhāgiyāni iti tatra ayam vacana atthaḥ
translated: So it is said that there are five lower fetters and five higher fetters. Here is the word meaning:

original: – oraṃ vuccati kāmadhātu, tattha upapattinipphādanato taṃ oraṃ bhajantīti orambhāgiyāni.
analyzed: oram vuccati kāmadhātu tattha upapatti nipphādanato tam oram bhajanti iti orambhāgiyāni
translated: The word ora means the sense-desire element. They belong to that ora because they bring about rebirth there.

original: Uddhaṃ vuccati rūpārūpadhātu, tattha upapattinipphādanato taṃ uddhaṃ bhajantīti uddhambhāgiyānīti.
analyzed: uddham vuccati rūpa arūpa dhātu tattha upapatti nipphādanato tam uddham bhajanti iti uddhambhāgiyāni iti
translated: The word uddhaṃ means the fine-material and immaterial elements. They belong to that uddhaṃ because they bring about rebirth there.

original: Dukaniddesavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: duka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the dyads is ended.

original: (3.) Tikaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tika niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the triads

original: 909. Tikaniddese tīhi akusalamūlehi vaṭṭamūlasamudācāro kathito. Akusalavitakkādīsu
analyzed: tika niddese tīhi akusala mūlehi vaṭṭa mūla samudācāraḥ kathitaḥ akusala vitakka ādīsu
translated: In the triad of the three roots of unprofit, the root of unprofit is stated by the way of the three roots of unprofit.

original: vitakkanavasena vitakko, sañjānanavasena saññā, sabhāvaṭṭhena dhātūti veditabbā.
analyzed: vitakkana vasena vitakko sañjānana vasena saññā sabhāva ṭṭhena dhātu uti veditabbā
translated: In the unprofitable thought and so on, the unprofitable thought should be understood as thought by way of thinking, as perception by way of perceiving, and as elements by way of individual essence.

original: Duccaritaniddese paṭhamanayo kammapathavasena vibhatto, dutiyo sabbasaṅgāhikakammavasena,
analyzed: duccarita niddese paṭhama nayaḥ kammapatha vasena vibhattaḥ dutiyaḥ sabba saṅgāhika kamma vasena
translated: In the triad of the three kinds of misconduct, the first method is classed by way of the courses of action, the second by way of the three kinds of action that include all,

original: tatiyo nibbattitacetanāvaseneva.
analyzed: tatiyaḥ nibbattita cetanā vasena iva
translated: and the third by way of the volition that is generated.

original: 914. Āsavaniddese suttantapariyāyena tayova āsavā kathitā.
analyzed: āsava niddese suttanta pariyāyena āsavā kathitā
translated: In the triad of the three taints, only three taints are stated in the text of the sutta.

original: 919. Esanāniddese saṅkhepato tattha katamā kāmesanāti ādinā nayena vutto kāmagavesanarāgo
translated: In the description of searches, the search for sensual desires is the lust for the search for sensual desires stated in the way beginning, “What, bhikkhus, is the search for sensual desires? Here someone, a householder or one gone forth, is a sensualist …” .

original: kāmesanā. Yo bhavesu bhavacchandotiādinā nayena vutto bhavagavesanarāgo bhavesanā.
analyzed: kāma īsanā yaḥ bhavesu bhava chandaḥ iti ādinā nayena vuttaḥ bhava gavesana rāgaḥ bhavesanā
translated: The search for being is the lust for the search for being stated in the way beginning, “The wish for existence, the wish for being …” .

original: Sassato lokotiādinā nayena vuttā diṭṭhigatikasammatassa brahmacariyassa gavesanā
analyzed: sassataḥ lokaḥ iti ādinā nayena vuttā diṭṭhigatika sammatassa brahmacariyassa gavesanā
translated: The search for a rite and ritual is the search for a rite and ritual considered to be a holy life stated in the way beginning, “The world is eternal” .

original: diṭṭhi brahmacariyesanāti veditabbā. Yasmā ca na kevalaṃ rāgadiṭṭhiyo eva esanā,
analyzed: diṭṭhi brahmacariya isanā ti veditabbā yasmā ca na kevalam rāga diṭṭhiyaḥ eva esanā
translated: And because it is not only lust and views that are searches,

original: tadekaṭṭhaṃ pana kammampi esanā eva, tasmā taṃ dassetuṃ dutiyanayo vibhatto. Tattha
analyzed: tad ekaṭṭham pana kammam pi esanā eva tasmā tam dassetum dutiya nayaḥ vibhattaḥ tattha
translated: but also kamma that is of the same nature as they is a search, the second method is given in order to show that. Herein,

original: tadekaṭṭhanti sampayuttekaṭṭhaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tattha kāmarāgekaṭṭhaṃ kāmāvacarasattānameva
analyzed: tat ekaṭṭham ti sampayutta ikaṭṭham veditabbam tattha kāma rāga ekaṭṭham kāmāvacara sattānam eva
translated: of the same nature should be understood as of the same nature as the associated . Herein, that of the same nature as lust for sensual desires occurs only in beings of the sense sphere;

original: pavattati; bhavarāgekaṭṭhaṃ pana mahābrahmānaṃ. Samāpattito vuṭṭhāya caṅkamantānaṃ
analyzed: pavattati bhava rāga ekaṭṭham pana mahābrahmānam samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya caṅkamantānam
translated: but that of the same nature as lust for being occurs in the Brahmās. And when they come out of jhāna and are walking about,

original: jhānaṅgānaṃ assādanakāle akusalakāyakammaṃ hoti, ‘aho sukhaṃ aho sukha’nti vācaṃ
analyzed: jhāna aṅgānam assādana kāle akusala kāya kammam hoti aho sukham aho sukhanti vācam
translated: at the time when they are enjoying the jhāna factors, there is unprofitable bodily action, and they say, “Ah, what bliss! Ah, what bliss!”

original: bhinditvā assādanakāle vacīkammaṃ, kāyaṅgavācaṅgāni acopetvā manasāva assādanakāle
analyzed: bhinditvā assādana kāle vacī kammam kāyaṅga vācaṅgāni a copetvā manasā ava assādana kāle
translated: At the time of savouring after breaking the precepts, it is verbal action. At the time of savouring without moving the body or speech, it is mental action.

original: manokammaṃ. Antaggāhikadiṭṭhivasena sabbesampi diṭṭhigatikānaṃ caṅkamanādivasena tāni hontiyeva.
analyzed: manaḥ kammam antaggāhika diṭṭhi vasena sabbesam pi diṭṭhi gatikānam caṅkamana ādi vasena tāni
translated: The views of the eternalists and the annihilationists are all included in the views of the eternalists and the annihilationists.

original: 920. Vidhāniddese “kathaṃvidhaṃ sīlavantaṃ vadanti, kathaṃvidhaṃ paññavantaṃ vadantī”tiādīsu
analyzed: vidhā niddese kathaṃvidham sīlavantam vadanti kathaṃvidham paññavantam vadanti itiādīsu
translated: In the description of the kinds of, the kinds of virtue are asked about thus: “What kind of virtue do they call virtue? What kind of wisdom do they call wisdom?”

original: ākārasaṇṭhānaṃ vidhā nāma. “Ekavidhena ñāṇavatthū”tiādīsu koṭṭhāso. “Vidhāsu na vikampatī”tiādīsu🔽māno. Idhāpi mānova vidhā nāma. So hi seyyādivasena vidahanato vidhāti vuccati. Ṭhapanaṭṭhena🔽vā vidhā. Tasmā ‘seyyohamasmī’ti evaṃ uppannā mānavidhā mānaṭhapanā seyyohamasmīti
analyzed: ākāra saṇṭhānam vidhā nāma ekavidhena ñāṇa vatthu uti ādīsu koṭṭhāsaḥ vidhāsu na vikampati iti ādīsu  mānaḥ idha api mānaḥ uva vidhā nāma saḥ hi seyyā ādi vasena vidahanataḥ vidhā ati vuccati ṭhapana ṭṭhena  vā vidhā tasmā seyyā uham asmi iti evam uppannā māna vidhā māna ṭhapanā seyyā uham asmi iti
translated: The form and shape is called the kind. In the passage: “The basis of knowledge is of one kind” , it is a section. In the passage: “He does not tremble in the kinds” ,🔽it is pride. Here too it is pride that is called the kind. For that is called the kind because it is divided into better and so on. Or the kind is in the sense of a basis.

original: vidhāti veditabbā. Sesapadadvayesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: vidhāti veditabbā sesa pada dvayesu pi esā iva nayaḥ
translated: Therefore the kind of pride that arises thus: “I am better” is the kind of pride called “I am better.” The same method applies in the case of the other two terms.

original: 921. Bhayaniddese jātiṃ paṭicca bhayanti jātipaccayā uppannabhayaṃ. Bhayānakanti
analyzed: bhaya niddese jātim paṭicca bhayanti jāti paccayā uppanna bhayam bhayānakam ti
translated: In the description of fear, fear based on birth is fear that has arisen with birth as condition.

original: ākāraniddeso. Chambhitattanti bhayavasena gattacalanaṃ. Lomahaṃsoti lomānaṃ haṃsanaṃ,
analyzed: ākāra niddeso bhaya vasena gatta calanam lomahaṃso ti lomānam haṃsanam
translated: This is the description of the mode of apprehension. “Fear” is the trembling of the body through fear. “Hairs standing on end” is the standing up of the hairs.

original: uddhaggabhāvo. Iminā padadvayena kiccato bhayaṃ dassetvā puna cetaso utrāsoti sabhāvato dassitaṃ.
analyzed: iminā pada dvayena kiccataḥ bhayam dassetvā puna cetasaḥ sabhāvataḥ dassitam
translated: This is the upward movement. Having shown fear by way of its function through these two terms, he shows it by way of its individual essence through the words “mental anguish.”

original: 922. Tamaniddese vicikicchāsīsena avijjā kathitā. “Tamandhakāro sammoho, avijjogho
translated: In the description of darkness, ignorance is stated by way of doubt. For ignorance is called darkness because of the statement: “Darkness, delusion, ignorance,

analyzed: mahabbhayo ti vacanataḥ hi avijjā tamaḥ nāma tiṇṇam pana addhānam vasena desanā sukhatāya  vicikicchā sīsena desanā katā tattha kim nu kho aham atīte khattiyaḥ ahosim udāhu  brāhmaṇaḥ vessaḥ suddaḥ kāḷaḥ odātaḥ rassaḥ dīghaḥ iti kaṅkhantaḥ atītam addhānam ārabbha

analyzed: kaṅkhati nāma kim nu kho aham anāgate khattiyaḥ bhavissāmi udāhu brāhmaṇaḥ vessope 🔽kaṅkhantaḥ anāgatam addhānam ārabbha kaṅkhati nāma kim nu kho aham etarahi

translated: “Is one a noble or a brahmin, a merchant or a worker? Or what am I in form, or in feeling, or in perception, or in mental formations,

analyzed: viññāṇanti kaṅkhantaḥ paccuppannam addhānam ārabbha kaṅkhati nāma  tattha kiñca api khattiyaḥ vā attanaḥ khattiya bhāvam brāhmaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇa bhāvam vessaḥ
translated: or in consciousness?” One who is doubtful thus is said to be doubtful about the present.

analyzed: vā vessa bhāvam suddaḥ vā sudda bhāvam ajānanakaḥ nāma natthi jīva laddhikaḥ pana satto
translated: Herein, although there is no one who does not know that he is a noble or a brahmin, a merchant or a worker, a being who is desirous of life,
