translated: Is it blue, or is it yellow, or red, or white, or is it four-cornered or six-sided or eight-sided?”

original: nāma dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo. Titthiyā nāma yesaṃ tā diṭṭhiyo ruccanti khamanti. Āyatanaṭṭho
analyzed: nāma dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ titthiyāḥ nāma yesam tāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ ruccanti khamanti āyatanaṭṭho
translated: “Sects” : places of sects, or the places of sectarians. Herein, a sect is the sixty-two views. Sectarians are those who approve of and acquiesce in those views. The meaning of “place” is

original: heṭṭhā vuttoyeva. Tattha yasmā sabbepi diṭṭhigatikā sañjāyamānā imesuyeva tīsu ṭhānesu🔽sañjāyanti, samosaramānāpi etesuyeva samosaranti sannipatanti, diṭṭhigatikabhāve🔽ca nesaṃ etāniyeva kāraṇāni, tasmā titthāni ca tāni sañjātānītiādinā atthena āyatanāni
analyzed: heṭṭhā vuttaḥ yeva tattha yasmā sabbe pi diṭṭhi gatikā sañjāyamānāḥ imesu yeva tīsu ṭhānesu  sañjāyanti samosaramānā api samosaranti sannipatanti diṭṭhigatika bhāve  ca kāraṇāni tasmā titthāni ca tāni sañjātāni itiādinā atthena āyatanāni
translated: The rest is as already stated. Herein, all those who hold views arise in these three instances,🔽and when they are gathered together they are gathered together in these three instances. And these three instances are the causes for their being those who hold views.🔽Therefore they are “bases” in the sense of “places where they arise,” etc.;

original: cāti titthāyatanāni; tenevatthena titthiyānaṃ āyatanānītipi titthāyatanāni. Purisapuggaloti
analyzed: ca ati titthāyatanāni āyatanāni iti pi titthāyatanāni purisa puggalaḥ ti
translated: hence they are “bases of argument” . And in the sense of “places where those who hold views resort,”🔽“person” means a being. And although “man” and “person” are the same, still “person” is said in order to include women.

original: satto. Kāmañca purisotipi puggalotipi vutte sattoyeva vutto, ayaṃ pana sammutikathā
analyzed: satto kāmañca purisaḥ tipi puggalaḥ tipi vutte sattaḥ yā eva vuttaḥ ayam pana sammuti kathā
translated: But this is a conventional expression.

original: nāma yo yathā jānāti tassa tathā vuccati. Paṭisaṃvedetīti attano santāne uppannaṃ🔽jānāti, paṭisaṃviditaṃ karoti anubhavati vā. Pubbekatahetūti pubbe katakāraṇā, pubbe
analyzed: nāma yaḥ yathā jānāti tassa tathā vuccati paṭisaṃvedeti iti attano santāne uppannam  jānāti paṭisaṃviditam karoti anubhavati vā pubbekata hetū ti pubbe kata kāraṇā pubbe
translated: “He experiences” means he knows, makes known, and feels what has arisen in his own continuity.

original: katakammapaccayeneva paṭisaṃvedetīti attho. Ayaṃ nigaṇṭhasamayo. Evaṃvādino pana
analyzed: kata kamma paccayena iva paṭisaṃvedeti iti atthaḥ ayam nigaṇṭha samayaḥ evaṃvādinaḥ pana
translated: “Because of his past action” means because of his past action as a cause. The meaning is: he experiences it only because of the kamma he has done in the past. This is the doctrine of the Jains.🔽But those who hold this view

original: te kammavedanañca kiriyavedanañca paṭikkhipitvā ekaṃ vipākavedanameva sampaṭicchanti.
analyzed: te kamma vedanañca kiriya vedanañca paṭikkhipitvā ekam vipāka vedanam eva sampaṭicchanti
translated: They reject the kamma-resultant and the functional and admit only the resultant of kamma-born materiality.

original: Pittasamuṭṭhānādīsu ca aṭṭhasu ābādhesu satta paṭikkhipitvā aṭṭhamaṃyeva sampaṭicchanti,
analyzed: pitta samuṭṭhāna ādīsu ca aṭṭhasu ābādhesu satta paṭikkhipitvā sampaṭicchanti
translated: And in the case of the eight sicknesses beginning with those due to bile, they reject seven and admit only the eighth.

original: diṭṭhadhammavedanīyādīsu ca tīsu kammesu dve paṭikkhipitvā ekaṃ aparāpariyavedanīyameva
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma vedanīya ādīsu ca tīsu kammesu dve paṭikkhipitvā ekam apara apariya vedanīyam eva
translated: And in the case of the three kinds of kamma, that is, kamma to be experienced here and now, etc., they reject two and admit only that to be experienced in some future life.

original: sampaṭicchanti, kusalākusalavipākakiriyasaṅkhātāsu ca catūsu cetanāsu vipākacetanaṃyeva sampaṭicchanti.
analyzed: sampaṭicchanti kusala akusala vipāka kiriya saṅkhātāsu ca catūsu cetanāsu vipāka cetanaṃyā iva sampaṭicchanti
translated: And in the case of the four kinds of volition, namely, profitable, unprofitable, resultant, and functional, they reject three and admit only the resultant.

original: Issaranimmānahetūti issaranimmānakāraṇā; brahmunā vā pajāpatinā vā issarena nimmitattā
analyzed: issara nimmāna hetū ti issara nimmāna kāraṇā brahmunā vā pajāpatinā vā issarena nimmita ttā
translated: Because of being created by a supreme being: because of being created by a supreme being, by Brahmā or Pajāpati.

original: paṭisaṃvedetīti attho. Ayaṃ brāhmaṇasamayo. Ayañhi nesaṃ adhippāyo – imā tisso vedanā
analyzed: paṭisaṃvedeti iti atthaḥ ayam brāhmaṇa samayaḥ ayam hi nesam adhippāyaḥ imāḥ tissaḥ vedanā
translated: The meaning is that he experiences. This is the brahmin theory. For this is their intention: these three kinds of feeling

original: paccuppanne attanā katamūlakena vā āṇattimūlakena vā pubbe katena vā ahetuappaccayā
analyzed: paccuppanne attanā kata mūlakena vā āṇatti mūlakena vā pubbe katena vā ahetu appaccayā
translated: are not caused by what is done by oneself in this life or by what is done by another or by what is done by oneself and another or by a supreme being’s act of creation or without cause.

original: vā paṭisaṃvedetuṃ nāma na sakkā; issaranimmānakāraṇā eva pana imā paṭisaṃvedetīti.
analyzed: vā paṭisaṃvedetum nāma na sakkā issara nimmāna kāraṇāḥ eva pana imāḥ paṭisaṃvedeti iti
translated: and it is not possible to experience them by oneself; but it is only because of the reason of being created by a ruler that one experiences them.

original: Evaṃvādino panete heṭṭhā vuttesu aṭṭhasu ābādhesu ekampi asampaṭicchitvā sabbaṃ paṭibāhanti.
analyzed: evaṃvādinaḥ pana ete heṭṭhā vuttesu aṭṭhasu ābādhesu ekam pi a sampaṭicchitvā sabbam paṭibāhanti
translated: But those who say this deny all eight kinds of sickness mentioned above without exception.

original: Tathā diṭṭhadhammavedanīyādīsupi sabbakoṭṭhāsesu ekampi asampaṭicchitvā sabbaṃ paṭibāhanti.
analyzed: tathā diṭṭhadhamma vedanīya ādīsu pi sabba koṭṭhāsesu ekam pi a sampaṭicchitvā sabbam paṭibāhanti
translated: And so too in the case of all the sections beginning with “to be felt here and now.”

original: Ahetu appaccayāti hetuñca paccayañca vinā akāraṇeneva paṭisaṃvedetīti attho. Ayaṃ🔽ājīvakasamayo. Evaṃ vādino etepi heṭṭhā vuttesu kāraṇesu ca byādhīsu ca ekampi asampaṭicchitvā
analyzed: ahetu appaccayā ti hetuñca paccayañca vinā akāraṇena iva paṭisaṃvedeti iti atthaḥ ayam  ājīvaka samayaḥ evam vādinaḥ ete api heṭṭhā vuttesu kāraṇesu ca ca ekam pi a sampaṭicchitvā
translated: Without cause, without reason: the meaning is that one experiences them without a cause or reason.🔽This is the Ājīvaka view.

original: sabbaṃ paṭikkhipanti.
analyzed: sabbam paṭikkhipanti
translated: But those who say this deny all the reasons and sicknesses mentioned above without exception.

original: 924. Kiñcanāti palibodhā. Rāgo kiñcananti rāgo uppajjamāno satte bandhati palibundheti,
analyzed: kiñcana ati palibodhā rāgaḥ kiñcana nti rāgaḥ uppajjamānaḥ satte bandhati palibundhā iti
translated: What is the fetter? The hindrance. Lust is the fetter: lust, occurring, fetters and hinders beings,

original: tasmā kiñcananti vuccati. Dosamohesupi eseva nayo. Aṅgaṇānīti “udaṅgaṇe tattha papaṃ
analyzed: tasmā kiñcana nti vuccati dosa mohesu pi esa iva nayaḥ aṅgaṇāni iti udaṅgaṇe tattha
translated: therefore it is called the fetter. The same method applies in the case of hate and delusion. The snares: “In the east a snare, in the south a snare,

original: avindu”nti āgataṭṭhāne bhūmippadeso aṅgaṇaṃ. “Tasseva rajassa vā aṅgaṇassa vā pahānāya
analyzed: avindunti āgata ṭṭhāne bhūmi ppadesaḥ aṅgaṇam tassa iva rajassa vā aṅgaṇassa vā pahānāya
translated: The place where the words “without a drop” occur is the courtyard. For the abandoning of that dust and that courtyard,

original: vāyamatī”ti āgataṭṭhāne yaṃ kiñci malaṃ vā paṅko vā. “Sāṅgaṇova samāno”ti āgataṭṭhāne
analyzed: āgata ṭṭhāne yam kiñci malam vā paṅkaḥ vā āgata ṭṭhāne
translated: The place where the words “without a stain” occur is the courtyard. The place where the words “he strives to abandon that stain or that courtyard of dust” occur is any kind of dirt or mud. The place where the words “while still possessing a courtyard” occur is

original: nānappakāro tibbakileso. Idhāpi tadeva kilesaṅgaṇaṃ adhippetaṃ. Teneva rāgo aṅgaṇantiādimāha.
analyzed: nānā pakāraḥ tibba kilesaḥ idha api tat eva kilesa ṅgaṇam adhippetam tena iva rāgaḥ aṅgaṇa nti ādim āha
translated: a strong defilement of various kinds. Here too the courtyard of defilement is intended. Hence he says “lust is a courtyard,” etc.

original: Malānīti malinabhāvakaraṇāni. Rāgo malanti rāgo uppajjamāno cittaṃ malinaṃ karoti, malaṃ gāhāpeti, tasmā malanti vuccati. Itaresupi dvīsu eseva nayo.
analyzed: malāni iti malina bhāva karaṇāni rāgaḥ malanti rāgaḥ uppajjamānaḥ cittam malinam karoti malam gāhāpeti tasmā malanti vuccati itaresu pi dvīsu esa eva nayaḥ
translated: “Stains” are what make the mind stained. Lust is a stain because when it arises it makes the mind stained, it causes it to take on a stain, and therefore it is called a stain. The same method applies in the other two cases.

original: Visamaniddese yasmā rāgādīsu ceva kāyaduccaritādīsu ca sattā pakkhalanti, pakkhalitā ca pana sāsanatopi sugatitopi patanti, tasmā pakkhalanapātahetuto rāgo visamantiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: visama niddese yasmā rāga ādīsu ca iva kāya duccarita ādīsu ca sattā pakkhalanti pakkhalitā ca pana sāsanataḥ pi sugatitaḥ pi patanti tasmā pakkhalana pāta hetutaḥ rāgaḥ visama tiādi vuttam
translated: In the description of the uneven, since beings slip up in regard to lust, etc., and in regard to bodily misconduct, etc., and having slipped up they fall from the Dispensation and from a good destination, therefore lust is uneven, etc., is said because it is the cause for the occurrence of slipping up and falling.

original: Aggīti anudahanaṭṭhena aggi. Rāgaggīti rāgo uppajjamāno satte anudahati jhāpeti,
analyzed: aggi iti anudahana ṭṭhena aggi rāga aggi iti rāgaḥ uppajjamānaḥ satte anudahati jhāpeti
translated: “Fire” is fire in the sense of burning. The fire of lust is lust that burns, that consumes, beings.

original: tasmā aggīti vuccati. Dosamohesupi eseva nayo. Tattha vatthūni – ekā kira daharabhikkhunī
analyzed: tasmai aggi iti vuccati dosa mohesu pi esā iva nayaḥ tattha vatthūni ekā kira dahara bhikkhunī
translated: So it is called “fire.” The same method applies to hate and delusion. Herein, the story of the young bhikkhu is the basis for the statement about greed. It seems that a young bhikkhu

original: cittalapabbatavihāre uposathāgāraṃ gantvā dvārapālakarūpaṃ olokayamānā ṭhitā. Athassā🔽anto rāgo uppanno. Sā teneva jhāyitvā kālamakāsi. Bhikkhuniyo gacchamānā ‘ayaṃ daharā
analyzed: cittala pabbata vihāre uposatha āgāram gantvā dvārapālaka rūpam olokayamānā ṭhitā athassā  antar rāgaḥ uppanno sā tena iva jhāyitvā kālam akāsi bhikkhuniyaḥ gacchamānāḥ ayam daharā
translated: went to the Uposatha house at the Cittalapabbata Monastery and stood looking at the door-keeper’s face. Then

original: ṭhitā, pakkosatha na’nti āhaṃsu. Ekā gantvā ‘kasmā ṭhitāsī’ti hatthe gaṇhi. Gahitamattā🔽parivattitvā patitā. Idaṃ tāva rāgassa anudahanatāya vatthu. Dosassa pana anudahanatāya
analyzed: ṭhitā āhaṃsu ekā gantvā kasmā ṭhitā asi iti hatthe gaṇhi gahita mattā  parivattitvā patitā idam tāva rāgassa anudahana tāya vatthu dosassa pana anudahana tāya
translated: greed arose in him. He died of that. The bhikkhunīs said to those who were going to the monastery, “That young bhikkhu is standing there. Send someone to call him.” One went and took him by the arm, saying, “Why do you stand there?” As soon as he was touched,

original: manopadosikā devā daṭṭhabbā. Mohassa anudahanatāya khiḍḍāpadosikā devā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: manas upadosikāḥ devāḥ daṭṭhabbāḥ mohassa anudahana tāya khiḍḍā padosikāḥ devāḥ daṭṭhabbā
translated: he fell over. This is the basis for the statement about greed. But for the statement about hate, the gods who offend against deities should be understood. And for the statement about delusion, the gods who offend against deities through play should be understood.

original: Mohanavasena hi tesaṃ satisammoso hoti. Tasmā khiḍḍāvasena āhārakālaṃ ativattitvā
analyzed: mohana vasena hi tesam sati sammosaḥ hoti tasmā khiḍḍā vasena āhāra kālam ativattitvā
translated: For their mindfulness is confused through delusion. Therefore they die through over-indulgence in play,

original: kālaṃ karonti. Kasāvāti kasaṭā nirojā. Rāgādīsu ca kāyaduccaritādīsu ca ekampi paṇītaṃ
analyzed: kālam karonti rāga ādīsu ca kāya duccarita ādīsu ca ekam pi paṇītam
translated: passing the time of eating. “Dirty-mouths”: their mouths are dirty, filthy. And among greed, etc., and among bodily misconduct, etc., there is not one that is good.

original: ojavantaṃ natthi, tasmā rāgo kasāvotiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ojavantam na atthi tasmā rāgo kasāvaḥ ti ādi vuttaṃ
translated: “There is no swiftness,” thus lust is called “the mud.”

original: 925. Assādadiṭṭhīti assādasampayuttā diṭṭhi. Natthi kāmesu dosoti kilesakāmena vatthukāmapaṭisevanadoso🔽natthīti vadati. Pātabyatanti pātabbabhāvaṃ paribhuñjanaṃ ajjhoharaṇaṃ. Evaṃvādī🔽hi so vatthukāmesu kilesakāmaṃ pivanto viya ajjhoharanto viya paribhuñjati. Attānudiṭṭhīti🔽attānaṃ anugatā diṭṭhi. Micchādiṭṭhīti lāmakā diṭṭhi. Idāni yasmā ettha paṭhamā sassatadiṭṭhi
analyzed: assāda diṭṭhi iti assāda sampayuttā diṭṭhi natthi kāmesu doso ti kilesa kāmena vatthu kāma paṭisevana doso  na atthi iti vadati pātabba tanti pātabba bhāvam paribhuñjanam ajjhoharaṇam evaṃvādī  hi so vatthu kāmesu kilesa kāmam pivantaḥ viya ajjhoharantaḥ viya paribhuñjati attā anudiṭṭhī iti  attānam anugatā diṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhi iti lāmakā diṭṭhi idāni yasmai ettha paṭhamā sassata diṭṭhi
translated: “The view of self-enjoyment”: the view associated with enjoyment. “There is no fault in sensual desires”: he says there is no fault in the enjoyment of sensual objects by the defilement of sensual desire.🔽“The state of being drunk”: the state of being drunk, the drinking, the swallowing.🔽For he who holds this view drinks, as it were, the defilement of sensual desire in the sensual objects, swallows them, as it were, and enjoys them, as it were. “The view of self”: the view that follows the self.

original: hoti, dutiyā sakkāyadiṭṭhi, tatiyā ucchedadiṭṭhi, tasmā tamatthaṃ dassetuṃ sassatadiṭṭhi🔽assādadiṭṭhītiādimāha.
analyzed: hoti dutiyā sakkāya diṭṭhi tatiyā uccheda diṭṭhi tasmā tam attham dassetum sassata diṭṭhi  assāda diṭṭhi itiādim āha
translated: “The wrong view”: the inferior view. Now, since here the first is the eternalist view, the second is the personality view, and the third is the annihilationist view, in order to show their meaning he says “the eternalist view is the view of self-enjoyment,” etc.

original: 926. Aratiniddeso ca vihesāniddeso ca vuttatthoyeva. Adhammassa cariyā adhammacariyā,
analyzed: arati niddeso ca vihesā niddeso ca adhammassa cariyā adhamma cariyā
translated: The explanation of “discontent” and “harming” is the same as above. “Conduct contrary to the Dhamma”: the conduct of what is contrary to the Dhamma;

original: adhammakaraṇanti attho. Visamā cariyā, visamassa vā kammassa cariyāti visamacariyā.
analyzed: adhamma karaṇanti atthaḥ visamā cariyā visamassa vā kammassa cariyā ati visama cariyā
translated: the meaning is, the doing of what is contrary to the Dhamma. “Conduct contrary to right conduct”: the conduct of what is contrary to right conduct, or the conduct of what is contrary to right action.

original: Dovacassatāpāpamittatā niddesā vuttatthā eva. Puthunimittārammaṇesu pavattito nānattesu
analyzed: niddesāḥ vuttatthāḥ eva puthu nimitta ārammaṇesu pavattitaḥ nānattesu
translated: The diversity of perception is the occurrence in the diversity of the signs of the new.

original: saññā nānattasaññā. Yasmā vā aññāva kāmasaññā, aññā byāpādādisaññā, tasmā nānattā🔽saññātipi nānattasaññā. Kosajjapamādaniddesesu pañcasu kāmaguṇesu vissaṭṭhacittassa
analyzed: saññā nānatta saññā yasmā vai aññā ava kāma saññā aññā byāpāda ādi saññā tasmā nānattā  nānatta saññā kosajja pamāda niddesesu pañcasu kāmaguṇesu vissaṭṭha cittassa
translated: Or else, because the perception of sensual desire is one thing and the perception of ill will, etc., is another, therefore it is the diversity of perception.🔽The description of idleness and negligence should be understood as follows: Idleness is the state of being sluggish in the sense of not undertaking the development of profitable states of consciousness, in one whose mind is dissipated in the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: kusaladhammabhāvanāya ananuyogavasena līnavuttitā kosajjaṃ, pamajjanavasena pamattabhāvo
analyzed: kusala dhamma bhāvanāya ananuyoga vasena līna vutti tā kosajjam pamajjana vasena pamatta bhāvo
translated: Negligence is the state of being negligent in the sense of being heedless.

original: pamādoti veditabbo. Asantuṭṭhitādiniddesā vuttatthā eva.
analyzed: pamādaḥ ti veditabbaḥ asantuṭṭhita ādi niddesāḥ vutta tthāḥ eva
translated: The description of discontent, etc., is in the same sense as the meaning stated.🔽In the description of disrespect, the state of being disrespectful is disrespect in the sense of not respecting advice.

original: 931. Anādariyaniddese ovādassa anādiyanavasena anādarabhāvo anādariyaṃ. Anādariyanākāro
analyzed: anādariya niddese ovādassa anādiyana vasena anādara bhāvaḥ anādariyam
translated: The mode of being disrespectful is disrespectfulness.🔽The state of being without deference is lack of deference in the sense of not deferring to the venerable.

original: anādaratā. Sagaruvāsaṃ avasanaṭṭhena agāravabhāvo agāravatā. Sajeṭṭhakavāsaṃ avasanaṭṭhena
analyzed: an ādara tā sa garu vāsam a vasana ṭṭhena agārava bhāvaḥ agārava tā sa jeṭṭhaka vāsam a vasana ṭṭhena
translated: The state of being without deference is lack of deference in the sense of not deferring to the senior.🔽Not deferring is not respecting.

original: appatissavatā. Anaddāti anādiyanā. Anaddāyanāti anādiyanākāro. Anaddāya ayitassa
analyzed: appatissavatā anaddā ati an ādiyanā anaddāyanā ati an ādiyana ākāraḥ anaddāya
translated: The mode of not deferring is the mode of not respecting.

original: bhāvo anaddāyitattaṃ. Asīlassa bhāvo asīlyaṃ. Acittīkāroti garucittīkārassa akaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvaḥ a sīlassa bhāvaḥ a sīlyam garu cittīkārassa a karaṇam
translated: The state of not giving is ungenerosity. The state of being without virtue is unvirtuousness. The state of not being respectful is disrespect.🔽The state of being without faith is lack of faith. The state of not believing is disbelief. The state of not being confident is non-confidence.🔽The state of not being free from greed is ungraciousness.🔽The state of not being able to bear is impatience.🔽The state of not being able to endure is inability to endure.

original: 932. Assaddhabhāvo assaddhiyaṃ. Asaddahanākāro asaddahanā. Okappetvā anupavisitvā aggahaṇaṃ anokappanā. Appasīdanaṭṭhena anabhippasādo.🔽Avadaññutāti thaddhamacchariyavasena ‘dehi, karohī’ti vacanassa ajānatā.🔽934. Buddhā ca buddhasāvakā cāti ettha buddhaggahaṇena paccekabuddhāpi gahitāva.
analyzed: assaddha bhāvaḥ assaddhiyam asaddahana ākāraḥ asaddahanā okappetvā an upavisitvā aggahaṇam an okappanā appasīdana ṭhena anabhippasādaḥ  avadaññu tā ti dehi karohi iti vacanassa a jānatā  buddhā ca buddha sāvakā ca ati ettha buddha ggahaṇena paccekabuddhā api gahitā ava
translated: The state of not being able to tolerate is inability to tolerate.🔽The state of not being able to put up with is inability to put up with.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.

original: Asametukamyatāti tesaṃ samīpaṃ agantukāmatā. Saddhammaṃ asotukamyatāti sattatiṃsa
analyzed: a sametu kamya tā ati tesam samīpam a gantu kāma tā saddhammam a sotu kamya tā ati sattatiṃsa
translated: The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.🔽The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.

original: bodhipakkhiyadhammā saddhammo nāma, taṃ asuṇitukāmatā. Anuggahetukamyatāti na uggahetukāmatā.
analyzed: bodhi pakkhiya dhammā saddhammaḥ nāma tam a suṇitu kāma tā an ugga hetu kamyatā ati na ugga hetu kāma tā
translated: The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive.

original: Upārambhacittatāti upārambhacittabhāvo. Yasmā pana so atthato upārambhova hoti, tasmā
analyzed: upārambha citta tā ati upārambha citta bhāvaḥ yasmā pana saḥ atthato upārambhaḥ uva hoti tasmā
translated: The state of not being able to forgive is inability to forgive

original: taṃ dassetuṃ tattha katamo upārambhotiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha upārambhanavasena upārambho.🔽Punappunaṃ upārambho anupārambho upārambhanākāro upārambhanā. Punappunaṃ upārambhanā
analyzed: tam dassetum tattha katamaḥ upārambha iti ādi vuttam tattha upārambhana vasena upārambho  punar punar upārambhaḥ an upārambhaḥ upārambhana ākāraḥ upārambhanā punar punar upārambhanā
translated: In order to show that he said: “Herein, what is finding fault? ” and so on. Herein, finding fault is by way of finding fault.🔽Repeated finding fault is non-finding-fault. The mode of finding fault is finding-faultness. Repeated finding fault is non-finding-faultness. The state of one who is not finding fault is non-finding-faultness.

original: anupārambhanā. Anupārambhitassa bhāvo anupārambhitattaṃ. Uññāti heṭṭhā katvā jānanā.
analyzed: an upārambhanā an upārambhitassa bhāvaḥ an upārambhi tattam uññā ati heṭṭhā katvā jānanā
translated: Contempt is the knowing of someone as inferior.

original: Avaññāti avajānanā. Paribhavanaṃ paribhavo. Randhassa gavesitā randhagavesitā. Randhaṃ
analyzed: avaññā ati avajānanā paribhavanam paribhavaḥ randhassa gavesitā randha gavesitā randham
translated: Disdain is the despising of him. Reproach is reproachfulness. Seeking for a weakness is the seeking for a flaw.🔽Or he seeks a flaw, thus he is a seeker of flaws. The state of that is seeking for a weakness.

original: vā gavesatīti randhagavesī, tassa bhāvo randhagavesitā. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ paravajjānupassanalakkhaṇo
analyzed: vā gavesati iti randha gavesī tassa bhāvaḥ randha gavesitā ayam vuccati iti ayam para vajja anupassana lakkhaṇo
translated: This is called finding fault: this characteristic of seeing another’s faults is called finding fault. Endowed with this, a person

original: upārambho nāma vuccati, yena samannāgato puggalo, yathā nāma tunnakāro sāṭakaṃ pasāretvā
analyzed: upārambhaḥ nāma vuccati yena samannāgataḥ puggalaḥ yathā nāma tunnakāraḥ sāṭakam pasāretvā
translated: just as a weaver, having stretched out a cloth,

original: chiddameva oloketi, evameva parassa sabbepi guṇe makkhetvā aguṇesuyeva patiṭṭhāti.
analyzed: chiddam eva oloketi evam eva parassa sabbe api guṇe makkhetvā aguṇesu yeva patiṭṭhāti
translated: looks only for a flaw, so he too, having disregarded all the other’s virtues, stands only on his faults.

original: 936. Ayoniso manasikāroti anupāyamanasikāro. Anicce niccanti anicceyeva vatthusmiṃ
analyzed: ayonisaḥ manasikāro ti anupāya manasikāro anicce niccanti anicceya iva vatthusmiṃ
translated: Unreasoned attention: attention that is not a means. In the impermanent: in a basis that is impermanent,

original: ‘idaṃ nicca’nti evaṃ pavatto. Dukkhe sukhantiādīsupi eseva nayo. Saccavippaṭikulena🔽cāti catunnaṃ saccānaṃ ananulomavasena. Cittassa āvaṭṭanātiādīni sabbānipi āvajjanasseva
analyzed: idam niccanti evam pavattaḥ dukkhe sukham ti ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ sacca vippaṭikulena  ca ati catunnam saccānam ananuloma vasena cittassa āvaṭṭana ati ādīni sabbāni pi āvajjanassa iva
translated: ‘This is permanent’ is the kind of attention that occurs thus. The same method applies in the case of ‘In the painful: pleasant’ and so on.🔽Contrary to truth: contrary to the four truths.🔽Turning away the mind: all these terms beginning with ‘turning away the mind’ are synonyms for adverting.🔽For adverting turns the mind away from the life-continuum;

original: vevacanāneva. Āvajjanañhi bhavaṅgacittaṃ āvaṭṭetīti cittassa āvaṭṭanā. Anuanu āvaṭṭetīti🔽anāvaṭṭanā. Ābhujatīti ābhogo. Bhavaṅgārammaṇato aññaṃ ārammaṇaṃ samannāharatīti🔽samannāhāro. Tadevārammaṇaṃ attānaṃ anubandhitvā uppajjamāne manasikarotīti manasikāro.
analyzed: āvajjanan hi bhavaṅga cittam āvaṭṭeti iti cittassa āvaṭṭanāḥ anu anu āvaṭṭeti iti  an āvaṭṭanā ābhujati iti ābhogaḥ bhavaṅga ārammaṇataḥ aññam ārammaṇam samannāharati iti  samannāhāraḥ tat eva ārammaṇam attānam anubandhitvā uppajjamāne manasikaroti iti manasikāraḥ
translated: it turns it away from that again and again;🔽it makes it come to presence; it brings the object to presence;🔽it causes the mind to be occupied with the object;

original: Karotīti ṭhapeti. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ anupāyamanasikāro uppathamanasikāralakkhaṇo🔽ayonisomanasikāro nāma vuccati. Tassa vasena puggalo dukkhādīni saccāni yāthāvato
analyzed: karoti iti ayam vuccati iti ayam an upāya manasikāraḥ uppatha manasikāra lakkhaṇo  ayonisomanasikāro nāma vuccati tassa vasena puggalo dukkha ādīni saccāni yāthāvato
translated: it makes it stay there. This is called: this unreasoned attention, which has the characteristic of being a wrong course of thought,

original: āvajjituṃ na sakkoti.
analyzed: āvajjitum na sakkoti
translated: is called ‘unreasoned attention.’ Because of it a person is unable to advert to the truths, suffering and the rest, as they really are.

original: Kummaggasevanāniddese yaṃ kummaggaṃ sevato sevanā kummaggasevanāti vuccati, taṃ dassetuṃ tattha katamo kummaggoti dutiyapucchā katā. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: kummagga sevanā niddese yam kummaggam sevato sevanā kummagga sevanā ti vuccati tam dassetum tattha katamaḥ kummaggaḥ ti dutiya pucchā katā sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: In the description of the wrong way, the second question “What is the wrong way?” is asked in order to show what is called “the wrong way” that is “gone by way of resorting to” when it is said, “The wrong way is gone by way of resorting to.” The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Tikaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽(4.) Catukkaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tika niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the three kinds is finished.

original: 939. Catukkaniddese taṇhuppādesu cīvarahetūti ‘kattha manāpaṃ cīvaraṃ labhissāmī’ti🔽cīvarakāraṇā uppajjati. Itibhavābhavahetūti ettha itīti nidassanatthe nipāto; yathā
analyzed: catukka niddese taṇhuppādesu cīvara hetū ti kattha manāpam cīvaram labhissāmi iti  cīvara kāraṇā uppajjati iti bhava abhava hetu iti ettha iti iti nidassana tthe nipātaḥ yathā
translated: In the description of the four kinds, in the case of the four kinds of arising of craving, “for the sake of robes” means that craving arises “thinking, ‘Where shall I get a desirable robe?’”

original: cīvarādihetu evaṃ bhavābhavahetūtipi attho. Bhavābhavoti cettha paṇītapaṇītatarāni🔽telamadhuphāṇitādīni adhippetāni. Imesaṃ pana catunnaṃ taṇhuppādānaṃ pahānatthāya
analyzed: cīvara ādi hetu evam atthaḥ bhava abhava iti ca ittha paṇīta paṇītatarāni  tela madhu phāṇita ādīni adhippetāni imesam pana catunnam taṇhuppādānam pahāna tthāya
translated: “For the sake of becoming and continuation of becoming” : here the particle iti has the meaning of indication; the meaning is that just as for the sake of robes, etc., so also for the sake of becoming and continuation of becoming. Herein, “becoming and continuation of becoming” refers to the more and more refined kinds of becoming, such as oil, honey, molasses, etc.

original: paṭipāṭiyāva cattāro ariyavaṃsā desitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā ava cattāro ariya vaṃsā desitā ati veditabbā
translated: These four kinds of arising of craving should be understood as taught in the four noble lineages in order to abandon them.

original: Agatigamanesu chandāgatiṃ gacchatīti chandena pemena agatiṃ gacchati, akattabbaṃ
analyzed: agati gamanesu chanda agatim gacchati iti chandena pemena agatim gacchati a kattabbam
translated: In the case of the four kinds of going by way of the wrong path, “he goes by way of the wrong path by inclination” means that he goes by way of the wrong path by affection, by love.

original: karoti. Parapadesupi eseva nayo. Tattha yo ‘ayaṃ me mitto vā sandiṭṭho vā sambhatto🔽vā ñātako vā lañjaṃ vā pana me detī’ti chandavasena assāmikaṃ sāmikaṃ karoti – ayaṃ🔽chandāgatiṃ gacchati nāma. Yo ‘ayaṃ me verī’ti pakativeravasena vā taṅkhaṇuppannakodhavasena🔽vā sāmikaṃ assāmikaṃ karoti – ayaṃ dosāgatiṃ gacchati nāma. Yo pana mandattā momūhattā
analyzed: karoti para padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ tattha yaḥ ayam me mittaḥ vā sandiṭṭhaḥ vā sambhatto  vā ñātakaḥ vā lañjam vā pana me deti iti chanda vasena assāmikam sāmikam karoti ayam  chandāgatim gacchati nāma yaḥ ayam me verī iti pakati vera vasena vā taṅkhaṇa uppanna kodha vasena  vā sāmikam assāmikam karoti ayam dosāgatim gacchati nāma yaḥ pana mandattā momūhattā
translated: The same method applies in the case of the other three. Herein, one who makes what is not one’s own to be one’s own through desire, thinking, “This is my friend’s or my acquaintance’s or my relative’s or this will give me a reward,” goes by desire. One who makes what is one’s own not one’s own through anger, thinking, “This is my enemy’s,” either through enmity towards an enemy or through the anger arisen at the moment, goes by hate. But one who does so through delusion, being confused and muddle-headed, goes by delusion.

original: yaṃ vā taṃ vā vatvā assāmikaṃ sāmikaṃ karoti – ayaṃ mohāgatiṃ gacchati nāma. Yo pana🔽‘ayaṃ rājavallabho vā visamanissito vā anatthampi me kareyyā’ti bhīto assāmikaṃ sāmikaṃ🔽karoti – ayaṃ bhayāgatiṃ gacchati nāma. Yo vā pana bhājiyaṭṭhāne kiñci bhājento ‘ayaṃ🔽me mitto vā sandiṭṭho vā sambhatto vā’ti pemavasena atirekaṃ deti, ‘ayaṃ me verī’ti
analyzed: yam vā tam vā vatvā assāmikam sāmikam karoti ayam moha āgatim gacchati nāma yaḥ pana 🔽ayam rāja vallabhaḥ vā visama nissitaḥ vā anattham pi me kareyya ati bhītaḥ a sāmikam sāmikam 🔽karoti ayam bhayāgatim gacchati nāma yaḥ vā pana bhājiya ṭṭhāne kiñci bhājentaḥ ayam 🔽me mittaḥ vā sandiṭṭhaḥ vā sambhattaḥ vā ati pema vasena atirekam deti ayam me verī iti
translated: The same method applies in the case of the other terms. Herein, one who makes what is not one’s own wife into one’s own wife through desire, thinking, “This is a friend of mine, or a known woman, or a woman who gives me something, or a relative,” goes by desire. One who makes one’s own wife into what is not one’s own wife through hate, thinking, “This is my enemy,” either because of enmity towards a clan or because of anger arisen on that occasion, goes by hate. One who makes what is not one’s own wife into one’s own wife through delusion, thinking, “Any woman will do,” because of dullness and stupidity, goes by delusion. One who makes one’s own wife into what is not one’s own wife through fear, thinking, “This woman is a king’s favorite or is well connected; she might do me some harm,” goes by fear. Or alternatively, one who, when it is his turn, gives more than his share to a woman, thinking, “This is a friend of mine, or a known woman, or a woman who gives me something, or a relative,” out of affection, goes by desire. One who gives less than his turn to a woman, thinking, “This is my enemy,” goes by hate.

original: dosavasena ūnakaṃ deti, momūhattā dinnādinnaṃ ajānamāno kassaci ūnakaṃ kassaci adhikaṃ
analyzed: dosa vasena ūnakam deti momūhattā dinna a dinnam a jānamānaḥ kassaci ūnakam kassaci adhikam
translated: He gives less through hate. He gives more to some and less to others through delusion, not knowing what he has given and what he has not.

original: deti, ‘ayaṃ imasmiṃ adīyamāne mayhaṃ anatthampi kareyyā’ti bhīto kassaci atirekaṃ🔽deti, so catubbidhopi yathānukkamena chandāgatiādīni gacchati nāma. Ariyā etāya na🔽gacchantīti agati, anariyā iminā agatiṃ gacchantīti agatigamanaṃ. Imaṃ dvayaṃ catunnampi
analyzed: deti ayam imasmin a dīyamāne mayham anattham pi kareyya ati bhīto kassaci atirekam  deti saḥ catubbidhaḥ api yathā anukkamena chandāgati ādīni gacchati nāma ariyāḥ etāya na  gacchanti iti agati anariyāḥ iminā agatim gacchanti iti agati gamanam imam dvayam
translated: He gives more through fear, thinking, “If I do not give to this one, he might harm me.”🔽All these four kinds of giving are called “going by favour of desire,” etc., in accordance with their nature.🔽The ariyans do not go by this, thus it is not going by favour of desire, etc. The ariyans go by favour of view, thus it is going by favour of view.

original: sādhāraṇavasena vuttaṃ. Chandena gamanaṃ chandagamanaṃ. Idaṃ dosādīnaṃ asādhāraṇavasena🔽vuttaṃ. Sakapakkharāgañca parapakkhadosañca purakkhatvā asamaggabhāvena gamanaṃ vaggagamanaṃ.
analyzed: sādhāraṇa vasena vuttam chandena gamanam chanda gamanam idam dosa ādīnam asādhāraṇa vasena  vuttam saka pakkha rāgañca para pakkha dosañca purakkhatvā asamagga bhāvena gamanam vagga gamanam
translated: This pair is stated in common for all four.🔽Going by favour of desire is going by favour of desire. This is stated in common for hate, etc.🔽Going by favour of faction is going by favour of faction. This is stated in common for desire and hate.

original: Idaṃ chandadosasādhāraṇavasena vuttaṃ. Vārino viya yathāninnaṃ gamananti vārigamanaṃ.
analyzed: idam chanda dosa sādhāraṇa vasena vuttam vārinaḥ viya yathā ninnam gamanan ti vāri gamanam
translated: Going by favour of water is going by favour of water.

original: Idaṃ catunnampi sādhāraṇavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idam catunnam api sādhāraṇa vasena vuttam
translated: This is stated in common for all four.

original: Vipariyāsesu aniccādīni vatthūni niccantiādinā nayena viparītato esantīti vipariyāsā,🔽saññāya vipariyāso saññāvipariyāso. Itaresupi dvīsu eseva nayo. Evamete catunnaṃ
analyzed: vipariyāsesu anicca ādīni vatthūni niccanti ādinā nayena viparītataḥ esanti iti vipariyāsā  saññāya vipariyāso saññā vipariyāso itaresu pi dvīsu esa iva nayo evam ete catunnam
translated: In the case of the perversions, they are perversions because they go by the way of perversion in the way beginning “The impermanent is looked upon as permanent” .🔽The perversion of perception is saññāvipallāso. The same method applies in the other two cases. So there are four in all in respect of the four instances, and in respect of the instances there are twelve with the perversions of perception, etc.

original: vatthūnaṃ vasena cattāro, yesu vatthūsu saññādīnaṃ vasena dvādasa honti. Tesu aṭṭha🔽sotāpattimaggena pahīyanti. Asubhe subhanti saññācittavipallāsā sakadāgāmimaggena
analyzed: vatthūnam vasena cattāro yesu vatthūsu saññā ādīnam vasena dvādasa honti tesu aṭṭha  sa utāpatti maggena pahīyanti asubhe saññā citta vipallāsā sakadāgāmi maggena
translated: Of these, eight🔽are given up by the path of stream-entry. The perversions of perception and cognizance that there is beauty in what is foul are weakened by the path of once-returner and

original: tanukā honti, anāgāmimaggena pahīyanti. Dukkhe sukhanti saññācittavipallāsā arahattamaggena
analyzed: tanukāḥ honti anāgāmi maggena pahīyanti dukkhe sukhanti saññā citta vipallāsāḥ arahatta maggena
translated: given up by the path of non-returner. The perversions of perception and cognizance that there is pleasure in what is pain are given up by the path of Arahantship.

original: pahīyantīti veditabbā.
analyzed: pahīyanti iti veditabbā
translated: This is how they should be understood.

original: Anariyavohāresu anariyavohārāti anariyānaṃ lāmakānaṃ vohārā. Diṭṭhavāditāti ‘diṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: anariya vohāresu anariya vohārā ati anariyānam lāmakānam vohārāḥ diṭṭha vādi tā ati diṭṭham
translated: In the case of the ignoble verbal utterances, the ignoble verbal utterances are the utterances of the ignoble, the low-down. The verbal utterances of one who has seen are those uttered by one who says “I have seen” .

original: mayā’ti evaṃ vāditā. Ettha ca taṃ taṃ samuṭṭhāpikacetanāvasena attho veditabbo. Saha
analyzed: mayā iti evam vāditā ettha ca tam tam samuṭṭhāpika cetanā vasena attho veditabbo saha
translated: And here the meaning should be understood according to the volition that is the instigator of each case. It is said that the volition is stated with the word “together” .

original: saddena cetanā kathitātipi vuttameva. Dutiyacatukkepi eseva nayo. Ariyo hi adisvā
analyzed: saddena cetanā kathitā ati pi vuttam eva dutiya catukke pi esā iva nayaḥ ariyaḥ hi a disvā
translated: The same method applies in the case of the second tetrad. For the noble have no such utterances.

original: vā ‘diṭṭhaṃ mayā’ti disvā vā ‘na diṭṭhaṃ mayā’ti vattā nāma natthi; anariyova evaṃ
analyzed: vā diṭṭham mayā ati disvā vā na diṭṭham mayā ati vattā nāma natthi anariyaḥ uva evam
translated: There is no one who, having seen, says, “I have seen” or who, having not seen, says, “I have not seen.” Only a non-noble person speaks thus.

original: vadati. Tasmā evaṃ vadantassa etā saha saddena aṭṭha cetanā anariyavohārāti veditabbā.
analyzed: vadati tasmai evam vadantassa etā saha saddena aṭṭha cetanāḥ anariya vohārā ti veditabbā
translated: Therefore, it should be understood that these eight intentions together with the voice are the unnoble speech of one who speaks thus.

original: Duccaritesu paṭhamacatukkaṃ veracetanāvasena vuttaṃ, dutiyaṃ vacīduccaritavasena.
analyzed: duccaritesu paṭhama catukkam vera cetanā vasena vuttam dutiyam vacī duccarita vasena
translated: In the case of the bad conduct, the first tetrad is stated according to the intention of enmity, the second according to verbal bad conduct.

original: Bhayesu paṭhamacatukke jātiṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ bhayaṃ jātibhayaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Dutiyacatukke rājato uppannaṃ bhayaṃ rājabhayaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: bhayesu paṭhama catukke jātim paṭicca uppannam bhayam jāti bhayam sesesu pi esa iva nayaḥ dutiya catukke rājataḥ uppannam bhayam rāja bhayam sesesu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: In the case of the fears, in the first tetrad, the fear arisen dependent on birth is the fear of birth. The same method applies to the rest. In the second tetrad, the fear arisen from the king is the fear of the king. The same method applies to the rest.

original: Tatiyacatukke cattāri bhayānīti mahāsamudde udakaṃ orohantassa vuttabhayāni. Mahāsamudde🔽kira mahindavīci nāma saṭṭhi yojanāni uggacchati. Gaṅgāvīci nāma paṇṇāsa. Rohaṇavīci
analyzed: tatiya catukke cattāri bhayāni iti mahā samudde udakam orohantassa vutta bhayāni mahā samudde  kira mahindavīci nāma saṭṭhi yojanāni uggacchati gaṅgāvīci nāma rohaṇavīci
translated: In the third tetrad, the four fears are the fears mentioned in the passage on one who goes down into the great ocean.

original: nāma cattālīsa yojanāni uggacchati. Evarūpā ūmiyo paṭicca uppannaṃ bhayaṃ ūmibhayaṃ
analyzed: nāma cattālīsa yojanāni uggacchati evarūpāḥ ūmiyaḥ paṭicca uppannam bhayam ūmi bhayam
translated: It is said that in the great ocean there is a whirlpool called Mahindavīci, which rises sixty leagues. The whirlpool called Gaṅgā rises fifty leagues. The whirlpool called Rohaṇa rises forty leagues. The fear arisen dependent on such waves is the fear of waves.

original: nāma. Kumbhīlato uppannaṃ bhayaṃ kumbhīlabhayaṃ. Udakāvaṭṭato bhayaṃ āvaṭṭabhayaṃ.
analyzed: nāma kumbhīlataḥ uppannam bhayam kumbhīla bhayam udaka avaṭṭataḥ bhayam āvaṭṭa bhayam
translated: The fear that arises from a snake is the fear of a snake. The fear that arises from a pot is the fear of a pot. The fear that arises from a whirlpool is the fear of a whirlpool.

original: Susukā vuccati caṇḍamaccho; tato bhayaṃ susukābhayaṃ.
analyzed: susukā vuccati caṇḍamacchaḥ tatas bhayam susukābhayam
translated: A shark is called a susuka; the fear that arises from it is the fear of a susuka.

original: Catutthacatukke attānuvādabhayanti pāpakammino attānaṃ anuvadantassa uppajjanakabhayaṃ.
analyzed: catuttha catukke atta anuvāda bhayanti pāpa kamminaḥ attānam anuvadantassa uppajjanaka bhayaṃ
translated: In the fourth tetrad, the fear of self-reproach is the fear that arises in one who has done evil when he reproaches himself.

original: Parānuvādabhayanti parassa anuvādato uppajjanakabhayaṃ. Daṇḍabhayanti agārikassa
analyzed: para anuvāda bhayanti parassa anuvādataḥ uppajjanaka bhayam daṇḍa bhayanti agārikassa
translated: The fear of blame by others is the fear that arises from the blame of others. The fear of punishment is the fear that arises in a householder

original: raññā pavattitadaṇḍaṃ, anagārikassa vinayadaṇḍaṃ paṭicca uppajjanakabhayaṃ. Duggatibhayanti
analyzed: raññā pavattita daṇḍam anagārikassa vinaya daṇḍam paṭicca uppajjanaka bhayam duggati bhayanti
translated: from the punishment meted out by the king, and in one who is not a householder from the punishment of the Dhamma. The fear of a bad destination is the fear

original: cattāro apāye paṭicca uppajjanakabhayaṃ. Iti imehi catūhi catukkehi soḷasa mahābhayāni nāma kathitāni.🔽Diṭṭhicatukke timbarukadiṭṭhi nāma kathitā. Tattha sayaṃkataṃ sukhadukkhanti vedanaṃ
analyzed: cattāraḥ apāye paṭicca uppajjanaka bhayam iti imehi catūhi catukkehi soḷasa mahābhayāni nāma kathitāni  diṭṭhi catukke timbarukadiṭṭhi nāma kathitā tattha sayaṃkatam sukha dukkhanti vedanaṃ
translated: that arises from the four lower worlds. Thus, by means of these four tetrads, the sixteen great fears are mentioned.🔽In the tetrad on views, the view of Timbaruka is mentioned. There, when one regards feeling as self, the view arises: “Feeling is made by me.”

original: attato samanupassato vedanāya eva vedanā katāti uppannā diṭṭhi. Evañca sati tassā
analyzed: attataḥ samanupassato vedanāya eva vedanā katā ati uppannā diṭṭhi evañca sati tassā
translated: And when this is so, that view is a fetter for him.

original: vedanāya pubbepi atthitā āpajjatīti ayaṃ sassatadiṭṭhi nāma hoti. Saccato thetatoti
analyzed: vedanāya pubbe pi atthi tā āpajjati iti ayam sassatadiṭṭhi nāma hoti saccataḥ thetato ti
translated: As to truth and as to time:🔽as to truth and as to time.

original: saccato thirato. Paraṃkatanti paccuppannavedanato aññaṃ vedanākāraṇaṃ vedanattānaṃ
analyzed: saccataḥ thirataḥ paraṃkatanti paccuppanna vedanataḥ aññam vedanā kāraṇam vedanā ttānam
translated: By another: he regards the cause of the feeling, which is other than the present feeling, as the feeling’s self.

original: samanupassato ‘aññāya vedanāya ayaṃ vedanā katā’ti uppannā diṭṭhi. Evaṃ sati purimāya🔽kāraṇavedanāya ucchedo āpajjatīti ayaṃ ucchedadiṭṭhi nāma hoti. Sayaṃkatañca paraṃkatañcāti
analyzed: samanupassato aññāya vedanāya ayam vedanā katā ati uppannā diṭṭhi evam sati purimāya  kāraṇa vedanāya ucchedaḥ āpajjati iti ayam ucchedadiṭṭhi nāma hoti sayaṃkatam ca paraṃkatam ca ati
translated: The view that arises thus: “This feeling is made by another feeling different from it” is called the annihilationist view.

original: yathāvutteneva atthena ‘upaḍḍhaṃ sayaṃkataṃ, upaḍḍhaṃ parena kata’nti gaṇhato uppannā
analyzed: yathā vuttena iva atthena upaḍḍham sayaṃkatam upaḍḍham parena katanti gaṇhataḥ uppannā
translated: By self and by another: the view that arises in one who takes the meaning stated thus: “Half is made by self and half by another” is called the eternalist- annihilationist view.

original: diṭṭhi – ayaṃ sassatucchedadiṭṭhi nāma. Catutthā akāraṇā eva sukhadukkhaṃ hotīti
analyzed: diṭṭhi ayam nāma catutthā akāraṇā eva sukha dukkham hoti iti
translated: The fourth view is called the view that feeling is due to no cause.

original: gaṇhato uppannā diṭṭhi. Evaṃ sati ayaṃ ahetukadiṭṭhi nāma. Sesamettha heṭṭhā vuttanayattā uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: gaṇhataḥ uppannā diṭṭhi evam sati ayam ahetuka diṭṭhi nāma sesam ettha heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā uttāna attham eva ati
translated: The rest here is evident in meaning since the method is the same as that already stated above.

original: Catukkaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catukka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the tetrad is ended.

original: (5.) Pañcakaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: Exposition of the pentad

original: 940. Pañcakaniddese yasmā yesaṃ sakkāyadiṭṭhiādīni appahīnāni, te bhavaggepi nibbatte
analyzed: pañcaka niddese yasmā yesam sakkāya diṭṭhi ādīni appahīnāni te bhava gge pi nibbatte
translated: In the pentad division, those in whom personality view, etc., are not abandoned are reborn in the realms of existence.

original: etāni ākaḍḍhitvā kāmabhaveyeva pātenti, tasmā orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanānīti vuttāni.
analyzed: etāni ākaḍḍhitvā tasmai orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni iti vuttāni
translated: But these drag them down and throw them into the sense-desire element. That is why they are called “fetters that belong to the lower shore” .

original: Iti etāni pañca gacchantaṃ na vārenti, gataṃ pana ānenti. Rūparāgādīnipi pañca gacchantaṃ
analyzed: iti etāni pañca gacchantam na gatam pana ānenti pañca gacchantam
translated: So these five do not prevent one going, but they do draw one back when one has gone. The five beginning with lust for the fine material do not prevent one going,

original: na vārenti, āgantuṃ pana na denti. Rāgādayo pañca lagganaṭṭhena saṅgā, anupaviṭṭhaṭṭhena pana sallāti vuttā.
analyzed: na vārenti āgantum pana na denti rāga ādayaḥ pañca laggana ṭṭhena saṅgāḥ anupaviṭṭha ṭṭhena pana vuttā
translated: but they do not allow one to come back. The five beginning with lust are called “bonds” in the sense of binding, and “barbs” in the sense of sticking into.

original: 941. Cetokhilāti cittassa thaddhabhāvā kacavarabhāvā khāṇukabhāvā. Satthari kaṅkhatīti🔽satthu sarīre vā guṇe vā kaṅkhati. Sarīre kaṅkhamāno ‘dvattiṃsavaralakkhaṇapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ
analyzed: cetokhilā ati cittassa thaddha bhāvā kacavara bhāvā khāṇuka bhāvā satthari kaṅkhati iti  satthu sarīre vā guṇe vā kaṅkhati sarīre kaṅkhamānaḥ dvattiṃsa vara lakkhaṇa paṭimaṇḍitam
translated: “Mental barrenness” is the hardness, the unyieldingness, the unworkability of the mind. “He is doubtful about the Teacher”🔽means that he is doubtful either about the Enlightened One’s material body or about his special qualities. Doubtful about the material body, he wonders whether or not the Enlightened One’s body is adorned with the thirty-two marks of a great man.

original: nāma sarīraṃ atthi nu kho natthī’ti kaṅkhati. Guṇe kaṅkhamāno ‘atītānāgatapaccuppannajānanasamatthaṃ
analyzed: nāma sarīram atthi nu kho natthi iti kaṅkhati guṇe kaṅkhamānaḥ atīta anāgata paccuppanna jānana samattham
translated: Doubtful about the special qualities, he wonders whether or not the Enlightened One is able to know and see what is past, future, and present.

original: sabbaññutañāṇaṃ atthi nu kho natthī’ti kaṅkhati. Vicikicchatīti vicinanto kicchati,🔽dukkhaṃ āpajjati, vinicchetuṃ na sakkoti. Nādhimuccatīti ‘evameta’nti adhimokkhaṃ🔽na paṭilabhati. Na sampasīdatīti guṇesu otaritvā nibbicikicchabhāvena pasīdituṃ anāvilo
analyzed: sabbaññuta ñāṇam atthi nu kho na atthi iti kaṅkhati vicikicchati iti vicinantaḥ kicchati  dukkham āpajjati vinicchetum na sakkoti na adhimuccati iti evam etat ti adhimokkham  na paṭilabhati na sampasīdati iti guṇesu otaritvā nibbicikiccha bhāvena pasīditum anāvilaḥ

analyzed: buddha vacanam catur āsīti dhammakkhandha sahassāni iti vadanti atthi nu kho etam na atthi iti  kaṅkhati paṭivedha dhamme kaṅkhamānaḥ vipassanā nissandaḥ maggaḥ nāma magga nissandaḥ
translated: He is doubtful, uncertain, undecided, and unconfident about whether the knowledge of omniscience exists or not. He is doubtful, uncertain, undecided, and unconfident about whether the knowledge of omniscience exists or not.

analyzed: phalam nāma sabba saṅkhāra paṭinissaggo nibbānam nāma ati vadanti tam atthi nu kho natthi iti kaṅkhati
