He is doubtful, uncertain, undecided, and unconfident about whether the knowledge of omniscience exists or not.🔽He is doubtful, uncertain, undecided, and unconfident about whether the knowledge of omnis

original: Saṅghe kaṅkhatīti ‘ujuppaṭipannotiādīnaṃ padānaṃ vasena evarūpaṃ paṭipadaṃ paṭipannā
analyzed: saṅghe kaṅkhati iti ujuppaṭipannaḥ ti ādīnam padānam vasena evarūpam paṭipadam paṭipannā
translated: He is doubtful about the Community: he is doubtful about the words beginning with “he has entered upon the way that is verified here and now” .🔽

original: cattāro maggaṭṭhā cattāro phalaṭṭhāti aṭṭhannaṃ puggalānaṃ samūhabhūto saṅgho nāma🔽atthi nu kho natthī’ti kaṅkhati. Sikkhāya kaṅkhamāno ‘adhisīlasikkhā nāma adhicittasikkhā
analyzed: cattāraḥ magga ṭṭhā cattāro phala ṭṭhā ti aṭṭhannam puggalānam samūha bhūtaḥ saṅghaḥ nāma  atthi nu kho na atthi iti kaṅkhati sikkhāya kaṅkhamānaḥ adhi sīla sikkhā nāma adhi citta sikkhā
translated: He is doubtful about the Community: he is doubtful whether there is a Community called a Community of eight persons, namely, four who are on the paths and four who are in the fruitions,🔽in the sense of the terms ‘one who has entered upon the way rightly’ and so on.🔽He is doubtful about the training: he is doubtful whether there is a training called the training in the higher virtue, the training in the higher consciousness,

original: nāma adhipaññā sikkhā nāmāti vadanti, sā atthi nu kho natthī’ti kaṅkhati.
analyzed: nāma adhipaññā sikkhā nāma ati vadanti sā atthi nu kho natthi iti kaṅkhati
translated: and the training in the higher wisdom, which they say is the training.

original: Cetasovinibandhāti cittaṃ bandhitvā muṭṭhiyaṃ katvā viya gaṇhantīti cetasovinibandhā.
analyzed: cetasovinibandhā iti cittam bandhitvā muṭṭhiyam katvā gaṇhanti iti cetasovinibandhā
translated: He is bound by the bond of desire: he is bound by the bond of desire, he is bound by the bond of ill will, he is bound by the bond of confusion, he is bound by the bond of craving for sense desires, he is bound by the bond of craving for becoming, he is bound by the bond of craving for non-becoming, he is bound by the bond of conceit, he is bound by the bond of excessive conceit, he is bound by the bond of conceit ‘I am’, he is bound by the bond of view, he is bound by the bond of doubt, he is bound by the bond of misapprehension of virtue and duty, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to lust, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to hate, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to confusion, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to craving for sense desires, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to craving for becoming, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to craving for non-becoming, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to conceit, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to excessive conceit, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to conceit ‘I am’, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to view, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to doubt, he is bound by the bond of the agitation due to misapprehension of virtue and duty.🔽He is desirous of sense desires: he is desirous of sense desires as objects and he is desirous of sense desires as defilements. He is desirous of his own body. He is desirous of visible forms externally. As far as he likes:

original: Kāmeti vatthukāmepi kilesakāmepi. Kāyeti attano kāye. Rūpeti bahiddhā rūpe. Yāvadatthanti
analyzed: kāme iti vatthu kāme pi kilesa kāme pi kāye iti attano kāye rūpe iti bahiddhā rūpe yāvat atthanti
translated: as much as he wants. As far as his belly will comfortably hold:

original: yattakaṃ icchati tattakaṃ. Udarāvadehakanti udarapūraṃ. Tañhi udaraṃ avadehanato🔽udarāvadehakanti vuccati. Seyyasukhanti mañcapīṭhasukhaṃ utusukhaṃ vā. Passasukhanti
analyzed: icchati tattakam udara avadehakanti udara pūram tat hi udaram 🔽udara avadehakam ti vuccati seyya sukham ti mañca pīṭha sukham utu sukham vā passa sukham
translated: that is called ‘as far as his belly will comfortably hold’ because it is what his belly will comfortably hold. The pleasure of

original: yathā samparivattakaṃ sayantassa dakkhiṇapassavāmapassānaṃ sukhaṃ hoti, evaṃ uppannasukhaṃ.
analyzed: yathā samparivattakam sayantassa dakkhiṇa passa vāma passānam sukham hoti evam uppanna sukham
translated: The pleasure that arises is like the pleasure of one who sleeps in the manner described.

original: Middhasukhanti niddāsukhaṃ. Anuyuttoti yuttapayutto viharati. Paṇidhāyāti patthayitvā.
analyzed: middha sukham ti niddā sukham anuyuttaḥ ti yutta payuttaḥ viharati paṇidhāya ati patthayitvā
translated: The pleasure of sloth is the pleasure of sleep. Is devoted to is devoted to and engaged in. Has resolved upon is has resolved upon and is intent upon.

original: Sīlenātiādīsu sīlanti catupārisuddhisīlaṃ. Vatanti vatasamādānaṃ. Tapoti tapacaraṇaṃ.🔽Brahmacariyanti methunavirati. Devo vā bhavissāmīti mahesakkhadevo vā bhavissāmi.
analyzed: catu pārisuddhi sīlam vatanti tapa caraṇam  devaḥ vā bhavissāmi iti mahesakkha devaḥ vā bhavissāmi
translated: As regards virtue, etc.: virtue is the virtue of the fourfold purity. Observance is the undertaking of the observance. Austerity is the practice of austerity.

original: Devaññataro vāti appesakkhadevesu vā aññataro. Kusaladhamme āvaranti nivārentīti nīvaraṇāni.
analyzed: devaññataraḥ vā ati appesakkha devesu vā aññataraḥ kusala dhamme āvaranti nivārenti iti nīvaraṇāni
translated: The life of purity is abstinence from sexual intercourse. I shall become a god is I shall become a great god. Or one of the gods is I shall become one of the minor gods. Hindrances are what obstruct the wholesome .

original: Mātā jīvitā voropitā hotīti manusseneva sakajanikā manussamātā jīvitā voropitā hoti. Pitāpi manussapitāva. Arahāpi manussaarahāva. Duṭṭhena cittenāti vadhakacittena.
analyzed: mātā jīvitā voropitā hoti iti manussena iva saka janikā manussa mātā jīvitā voropitā hoti pitā api manussa pitā ava arahā api manussa arahā ava duṭṭhena cittena ati vadhaka cittena
translated: A mother is a human mother who is one’s own natural mother. A father is a human father who is one’s own natural father. An arahant is a human arahant. With a mind possessing hate is with a mind to kill.

original: Saññīti saññāsamaṅgī. Arogoti nicco. Ittheke abhivadantīti itthaṃ eke abhivadanti,
analyzed: saññī iti saññā samaṅgī arogo ti nicco itthā ike abhivadanti iti ittham eke abhivadanti
translated: Conscious is possessed of consciousness. Eternal is permanent. Some say thus is some say thus.

original: evameke abhivadantīti attho. Ettāvatā soḷasa saññīvādā kathitā. Asaññīti saññāvirahito.
analyzed: evam eke abhivadanti iti attho ettāvatā soḷasa saññīvādā kathitā asaññī iti saññā virahito
translated: This is the meaning. So far, sixteen kinds of eternalist theories have been stated.

original: Iminā padena aṭṭha asaññīvādā kathitā. Tatiyapadena aṭṭha nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā kathitā.
analyzed: iminā padena aṭṭha asaññī vādā kathitā tatiya padena aṭṭha nevasaññī nāsaññī vādā kathitā
translated: The word “non-percipient” refers to the eight theories of non-percipient immortality. The third phrase refers to the eight theories of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient immortality.

original: Sato vā pana sattassāti athavā pana vijjamānasseva sattassa. Ucchedanti upacchedaṃ.
analyzed: sataḥ vā pana sattassa ati athavā pana vijjamānassa iva sattassa ucchedam upacchedam
translated: The phrase “or of a being who exists” refers to the annihilationist theories.

original: Vināsanti adassanaṃ. Vibhavanti bhāvavigamaṃ. Sabbānetāni aññamaññavevacanāneva.
analyzed: vināsanti a dassanam vibhavanti bhāva vigamam sabbān etāni aññamañña vevacanāni eva
translated: “Annihilation” means the cutting off of the continuity of aggregates. “Destruction” means non-appearance. “Disappearance” means the dissolution of the aggregates. All these terms are synonyms.

original: Tattha dve janā ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhanti – lābhī ca alābhī ca. Tattha lābhī arahato🔽dibbena cakkhunā cutiṃ disvā upapattiṃ apassanto, yo vā cutimattameva daṭṭhuṃ sakkoti
analyzed: tattha dve janāḥ uccheda diṭṭhim gaṇhanti lābhī ca alābhī ca tattha lābhī arahato  dibbena cakkhunā cutim disvā upapattim a passantaḥ yaḥ vā cutimattam eva daṭṭhum sakkoti
translated: Two kinds of people hold annihilationist views: those who have attained the jhānas and those who have not.

original: na upapātaṃ, so ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti. Alābhī ‘ko paralokaṃ jānātī’ti kāmasukhagiddhatāya
analyzed: na upapātam saḥ uccheda diṭṭhim gaṇhāti alābhī kaḥ para lokam jānāti iti kāma sukha giddha tāya
translated: Those who have attained the jhānas, having seen death with the divine eye, do not see rebirth. Or, if they are able to see only death and not rebirth, they hold annihilationist views. Those who have not attained the jhānas think: “Who knows about the next world?” Or, because of their infatuation with sensual pleasures,

original: vā ‘yathā rukkhato paṇṇāni patitāni na puna viruhanti, evaṃ sattā’tiādinā vitakkena
analyzed: vā yathā rukkhataḥ paṇṇāni patitāni na puna viruhanti evam satta ati ādinā vitakkena
translated: they think: “Just as leaves fall from a tree and do not grow again, so it is with beings.”

original: vā ucchedaṃ gaṇhāti. Idha pana taṇhādiṭṭhīnaṃ vasena tathā ca aññathā ca vikappetvāva
analyzed: vā ucchedam gaṇhāti idha pana taṇhā diṭṭhīnam vasena tathā ca aññathā ca vikappetvā ava
translated: Or he takes up annihilationism. But here seven annihilationists are mentioned who, by misconstruing things in various ways through craving and views,

original: uppannā satta ucchedavādā kathitā. Tesañhi idaṃ saṅgahavacanaṃ. Diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ
analyzed: uppannā satta uccheda vādā kathitā tesam hi idam saṅgaha vacanam diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam
translated: have arisen. This is a collective reference to them.

original: vā paneketi ettha diṭṭhadhammoti paccakkhadhammo vuccati. Tattha tattha paṭiladdhattabhāvassetaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ. Diṭṭhadhamme nibbānaṃ diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ; imasmiṃyeva attabhāve dukkhā
analyzed: vā pana eke iti ettha diṭṭha dhammo ti paccakkha dhammo vuccati tattha tattha paṭiladdha tta bhāvassa etam  adhivacanam diṭṭhadhamme nibbānam diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam imasmin yeva atta bhāve dukkhā
translated: Or in this very life to the bliss of stilling: here the visible here and now is called the visible state;

original: vūpasammanti attho. Idaṃ pañcannaṃ diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādānaṃ saṅgahavacanaṃ.
analyzed: vūpasammanti atthaḥ idam pañcannam diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādānam saṅgaha vacanaṃ
translated: it is a designation for the individual essence obtained here and there. The bliss of stilling in the visible here and now is the bliss of stilling in the visible here and now; the meaning is that suffering comes to rest in this very individual essence. This is a collective reference to the five kinds of annihilationism that hold to the bliss of stilling in the visible here and now.

original: 942. Verāti veracetanā. Byasanāti vināsā. Akkhantiyāti anadhivāsanāya. Appiyoti dassanasavanapaṭikūlatāya
analyzed: verā ati vera cetanā byasanā ati vināsā akkhantiyā ati anadhivāsanāya appiyā ti dassana savana paṭikūla tāya
translated: “Hate” is the volition of hate. “Harm” is destruction. “Unforbearance” is non-forbearance. “Unlovely” is that which should not be loved because it is unlovely to see and hear.

original: na piyāyitabbo. Cintetumpi paṭikūlattā mano etasmiṃ na appetīti amanāpo. Verabahuloti🔽bahuvero. Vajjabahuloti bahudoso.
analyzed: na piyāyitabbaḥ cintetum pi paṭikūla ttā manaḥ etasmin na appeti iti amanāpaḥ vera bahulaḥ ti 🔽bahu veraḥ bahu dosaḥ
translated: The mind does not incline to it because it is unlovely to think about. “Full of hate” is full of hate. “Full of enmity” is full of enmity.

original: Ājīvakabhayanti ājīvaṃ jīvitavuttiṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ bhayaṃ. Taṃ agārikassapi hoti
analyzed: ājīvaka bhayam ti ājīvam jīvita vuttim paṭicca uppannam bhayam tam agārikassa api hoti
translated: ‘Fear of the Ājīvakas’ is fear arisen because of livelihood, because of the means of living. That is for the one who is a householder

original: anagārikassapi. Tattha agārikena tāva ājīvahetu bahuṃ akusalaṃ kataṃ hoti. Athassa
analyzed: anagārikassa api tattha agārikena tāva ājīva hetu bahum akusalam katam hoti athassa
translated: and for the one who is not a householder. Herein, first for the one who is a householder, because of livelihood, much unwholesome is done. Then

original: maraṇasamaye niraye upaṭṭhahante bhayaṃ uppajjati. Anagārikenāpi bahu anesanā katā
analyzed: maraṇa samaye niraye upaṭṭhahante bhayam uppajjati anagārikena api bahu anesanā katā
translated: at the time of death, when hell appears, fear arises. Also for the one who is not a householder, much searching is done

original: hoti. Athassa maraṇakāle niraye upaṭṭhahante bhayaṃ uppajjati. Idaṃ ājīvakabhayaṃ🔽nāma. Asilokabhayanti garahabhayaṃ parisasārajjabhayanti katapāpassa puggalassa sannipatitaṃ🔽parisaṃ upasaṅkamantassa sārajjasaṅkhātaṃ bhayaṃ uppajjati. Idaṃ parisasārajjabhayaṃ
analyzed: hoti athassa maraṇa kāle niraye upaṭṭhahante bhayam uppajjati idam ājīvaka bhayam  nāma asi loka bhayanti garaha bhayam parisa sārajja bhayanti kata pāpassa puggalassa sannipatitam  parisam upasaṅkamantassa sārajja saṅkhātam bhayam uppajjati idam parisa sārajja bhayam
translated: and then at the time of death, when hell appears, fear arises. This is called🔽‘fear of the Ājīvakas.’ ‘Fear of bad reputation’ is fear of blame. ‘Fear of being ashamed in the assembly’ is fear called shame that arises for a person who has done bad deeds when approaching an assembled

original: nāma. Itaradvayaṃ pākaṭameva.
analyzed: nāma itara dvayam pākaṭam eva
translated: assembly. This is called ‘fear of being ashamed in the assembly.’ The other two are obvious.

original: 943. Diṭṭhadhammanibbānavāresu pañcahi kāmaguṇehīti manāpiyarūpādīhi pañcahi kāmakoṭṭhāsehi
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vāresu pañcahi kāmaguṇehi iti manāpiya rūpa ādīhi pañcahi kāma koṭṭhāsehi
translated: . In the section on the Nibbāna element visible here and now, with the five strands of sense pleasure means with the five parts of sense pleasure that are agreeable, such as visible forms.

original: bandhanehi vā. Samappitoti suṭṭhu appito allīno hutvā. Samaṅgībhūtoti samannāgato.
analyzed: bandhanehi vā samappito ti suṭṭhu appitaḥ allīnaḥ hutvā samaṅgībhūto ti samannāgataḥ
translated: or by fetters. He is bound by them: he is bound by them well, he is stuck fast. He is fettered by them: he is possessed of them.

original: Paricāretīti tesu kāmaguṇesu yathāsukhaṃ indriyāni cāreti sañcāreti ito cito ca upaneti;
analyzed: paricāreti iti tesu kāmaguṇesu yathāsukham indriyāni cāreti sañcāreti itas citas ca upaneti
translated: He enjoys himself: he enjoys himself with the faculties in the five strands of pleasure as he likes, he enjoys himself with them, he indulges in them, he revels in them, he delights in them, he enjoys them again and again.

original: atha vā pana laḷati ramati kīḷatīti. Ettha ca duvidhā kāmaguṇā – mānussakā ceva dibbā
analyzed: atha vā pana laḷati ramati kīḷati iti ettha ca duvidhā kāma guṇā mānussakā ca iva dibbā
translated: Or else he delights, he enjoys, he delights in, he enjoys himself. And here the strands of sensual desire are of two kinds: human and divine.

original: ca. Mānussakā mandhātukāmaguṇasadisā daṭṭhabbā; dibbā paranimmitavasavattidevarājassa
analyzed: ca mānussakā man dhātu kāma guṇa sadisā daṭṭhabbā dibbā para nimmitavasavatti devarājassa
translated: The human kind should be regarded as like the strands of sensual desire of Mandhatu, and the divine kind as like those of the divine king of the Paranimmitavasavatti gods.

original: kāmaguṇasadisāti. Evarūpe kāme upagatañhi te paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānappatto hotīti
analyzed: kāma guṇa sadisā ati evarūpe kāme upagatam hi te parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna ppattaḥ hoti iti
translated: For they say that one who has gone to such sensual desires as these has reached the supreme form of extinction here and now.

original: vadanti. Tattha paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānanti paramaṃ diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ, uttamanti attho.
analyzed: vadanti tattha parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānanti paramam diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam uttamanti attho
translated: Herein, the supreme form of extinction here and now is the supreme extinction here and now; the meaning is, the best.

original: Dutiyavāre hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena aniccā; paṭipīḷanaṭṭhena dukkhā; pakatijahanaṭṭhena
analyzed: dutiya vāre hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena aniccā paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena dukkhā pakati jahana ṭṭhena
translated: In the second case, they are impermanent in the sense of non-existence, painful in the sense of oppression, and subject to change in the sense of nature-disappearance.

original: vipariṇāmadhammāti veditabbā. Tesaṃ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvāti tesaṃ kāmānaṃ vipariṇāmasaṅkhātā
analyzed: vipariṇāma dhammā ti veditabbā tesam vipariṇāma aññathābhāvā ti tesam kāmānam vipariṇāma saṅkhātā
translated: Their change and alteration: their change called “dissolution”🔽and

original: aññathābhāvā. ‘Yampi me ahosi tampi me natthī’ti vuttanayena uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.🔽Tattha antonijjhāyanalakkhaṇo soko; tannissitalālappalakkhaṇo paridevo; kāyapaṭipīḷanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: aññathābhāvā yam pi me ahosi tam pi me natthi iti vutta nayena uppajjanti soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsā  tattha antar nijjhāyana lakkhaṇo soko tad nissita lālappa lakkhaṇo paridevo kāya paṭipīḷana lakkhaṇam
translated: and the non-existence of what was. The sorrow, etc., are stated in the way beginning, “What was mine is not” .🔽Herein, sorrow has the characteristic of inward burning; lamentation has the characteristic of outward burning; grief has the characteristic of the manifestation of physical distress;

original: dukkhaṃ; manovighātalakkhaṇaṃ domanassaṃ; vighātalakkhaṇo upāyāso.🔽Vitakkitanti abhiniropanavasena pavatto vitakko. Vicāritanti anumajjanavasena pavatto
analyzed: dukkham manaḥ vighāta lakkhaṇam domanassam vighāta lakkhaṇaḥ upāyāsaḥ  vitakkitanti abhiniropana vasena pavattaḥ vitakkaḥ vicāritanti anumajjana vasena pavattaḥ
translated: despair has the characteristic of mental distress.🔽It was thought: the applied thought that occurred as a resolution. It was explored: the sustained thought that occurred as a re-exploration.🔽By that: by that applied thought and that sustained thought. This first jhāna appears gross: it appears gross with the grossness consisting in the five factors that have gone and with the grossness consisting in the remaining factors.

original: vicāro. Etena etanti etena vitakkena ca vicārena ca etaṃ paṭhamajjhānaṃ oḷārikaṃ🔽sakaṇṭakaṃ viya khāyati.
analyzed: vicāraḥ etena etat ti etena vitakkena ca vicārena ca etam paṭhamajjhānam oḷārikam  sa kaṇṭakam viya khāyati
translated: It is had disturbance: it is had because it is gross, and it is disturbance because it disturbs the mind by the occurrence of applied thought and so on.🔽It is a void: it is void because it is void of the gross factors consisting in applied thought, etc., that have gone.🔽It is a seclusion: it is a seclusion because of the seclusion of the mind that has gone into those states.

original: Pītigatanti pītimeva. Cetaso uppilāvitanti cittassa uppilabhāvakaraṇaṃ. Cetaso ābhogoti
analyzed: pīti gatanti pītim eva cetasaḥ cittassa uppila bhāva karaṇam cetasaḥ
translated: It is a base for the enlightenment factors: it is a base for the enlightenment factors because it is the state that is the proximate cause for the arising of the enlightenment factors.🔽It is a base for the path factors: it is a base for the path factors because it is the state that is the proximate cause for the arising of the path factors.🔽It is a base for happiness: it is a base for happiness because it is the state that is the proximate cause for the arising of the happiness consisting in the jhāna’s profitable root.

original: jhānā vuṭṭhāya tasmiṃ sukhe punappunaṃ cittassa ābhogo manasikāroti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: jhānā vuṭṭhāya tasmim sukhe punappunam cittassa ābhogaḥ manasikāraḥ iti sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: It is a base for concentration: it is a base for concentration because it is the state that is the proximate cause for the arising of the concentration consisting in the jhāna’s unification.🔽It is a base for the jhāna factors: it is a base for the jhāna factors because it is the state that is the proximate cause for the arising of the jhāna factors.🔽It is a base for the path: it is a base for the path because it is the state that is the proximate cause for the arising of the path.🔽It is a base for the fruits: it is a base for the fruits because it is the state that is the proximate cause for the arising of the fruits.

original: Pañcakaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: It is a base for the taints’ ending: it is a base for the

original: (6.) Chakkaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: 6. Description of the six roots of disputes

original: 944. Chakkaniddese yasmā kuddho vā kodhavasena, sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī vā sandiṭṭhiparāmāsitāya kalahaṃ viggahaṃ vivādaṃ āpajjati, tasmā kodhādayo ‘vivādamūlānī’ti vuttā.🔽Chandarāganiddese kāmagehasitattā chandarāgā gehassitā dhammāti saṅgahato vatvā puna
analyzed: chakka niddese yasmā kuddhaḥ vā kodha vasena sandiṭṭhi parāmāsī vā sandiṭṭhi parāmāsitāya kalaham viggaham vivādam āpajjati tasmā kodha ādayaḥ vivāda mūlāni iti vuttā  chandarāga niddese kāma geha sitattā chanda rāgāḥ geha ssitāḥ dhammā ti saṅgahataḥ vatvā puna
translated: In the description of the six roots of disputes, since one who is angry or one who is under the sway of anger, or one who is devoted to his own views or one who is devoted to his own views and is attached to his own views, enters into a dispute, a quarrel, a contention, therefore anger, etc., are called the roots of disputes.

original: pabhedato dassetuṃ manāpiyesu rūpesūtiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha manāpiyesūti manavaḍḍhanakesu
analyzed: pabhedataḥ dassetum manāpiyesu rūpesu utiādi vuttam tattha manāpiyesu ti mana vaḍḍhanakesu
translated: In the description of desire and lust, after stating that desire and lust are attached to the house because of the statement “Desire and lust are attached to the house,” in order to show the divisions, “in regard to agreeable forms,” etc., are stated. Therein, in regard to agreeable forms means in regard to those that increase the mind,

original: iṭṭhesu. Virodhā eva virodhavatthūni. Amanāpiyesūti aniṭṭhesu.
analyzed: iṭṭhesu virodhāḥ eva virodha vatthūni amanāpiyesu iti aniṭṭhesu
translated: in regard to those that are desirable. Oppositions are the bases of opposition. In regard to disagreeable forms means in regard to those that are undesirable.

original: 945. Agāravesu agāravoti gāravavirahito. Appatissoti appatissayo anīcavutti. Ettha
analyzed: agāravesu agāravaḥ ti gārava virahitaḥ appatissaḥ ti appatissayaḥ anīca vutti ettha
translated: In regard to those who are without respect means without respect. In regard to those who are without deference means without deference, without dignity. Herein,

original: pana yo bhikkhu satthari dharamāne tīsu kālesu upaṭṭhānaṃ na yāti, satthari anupāhane
analyzed: pana yaḥ bhikkhu satthari dharamāne tīsu kālesu upaṭṭhānam na yāti satthari an upāhane
translated: however, a bhikkhu who does not attend upon the Teacher in the three periods of the day, and who, when the Teacher is not available,

original: caṅkamante saupāhano caṅkamati, nīce caṅkame caṅkamante ucce caṅkame caṅkamati, heṭṭhā
analyzed: caṅkamante saupāhano caṅkamati nīce caṅkame caṅkamante ucce caṅkame caṅkamati heṭṭhā
translated: walks up and down with his sandals on, walks up and down on the higher walk when the other bhikkhus are walking up and down on the lower walk, and

original: vasante upari vasati, satthudassanaṭṭhāne ubho aṃse pārupati, chattaṃ dhāreti, upāhanaṃ🔽dhāreti, nhāyati, uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ vā karoti, parinibbute vā pana cetiyaṃ vandituṃ
analyzed: vasante upari vasati satthu dassana ṭṭhāne ubho aṃse pārupati chattam dhāreti upāhanam  dhāreti nhāyati uccāram vā passāvam vā karoti parinibbute vā pana cetiyam vanditum
translated: if he is staying above him; if he covers both shoulders in a place where the teacher is expected; if he holds a sunshade; if he holds sandals; if he bathes; if he defecates or makes water; if he worships a shrine after the teacher has passed away;

original: na gacchati, cetiyassa paññāyanaṭṭhāne satthudassanaṭṭhāne vuttaṃ sabbaṃ karoti –
analyzed: na gacchati cetiyassa paññāyana ṭhāne satthu dassana ṭhāne vuttam sabbam karoti
translated: if he wears the upper robe over both shoulders while the Teacher is living, if he wears the upper robe over both shoulders in a place where the Teacher is seen, if he carries an umbrella, if he carries sandals, if he bathes, if he urinates or defecates, if he does not go to worship a shrine when the Teacher has attained final Nibbāna, if he does all the things mentioned in the section on “in a place where the Teacher is seen” in the section on “in a place where the Teacher is seen,”

original: ayaṃ satthari agāravo nāma. Yo pana dhammasavane saṅghuṭṭhe sakkaccaṃ na gacchati,
analyzed: ayam satthari agāravaḥ nāma yaḥ pana dhammasavane saṅghuṭṭhe sakkaccam na gacchati
translated: this is called “lack of respect for the Teacher.” If, when the recitation of the Teaching is announced, one does not go with eagerness,

original: sakkaccaṃ dhammaṃ na suṇāti, samullapanto nisīdati, na sakkaccaṃ gaṇhāti, na sakkaccaṃ
analyzed: sakkaccam dhammam na suṇāti samullapantaḥ nisīdati na sakkaccam gaṇhāti na sakkaccam
translated: if one does not listen to the Teaching with eagerness, if one sits with one’s mind elsewhere, if one does not grasp with eagerness, if one does not recite with eagerness,

original: vāceti – ‘ayaṃ dhamme agāravo nāma. Yo pana therena bhikkhunā anajjhiṭṭho dhammaṃ🔽deseti, pañhaṃ katheti, vuḍḍhe bhikkhū ghaṭṭento gacchati, tiṭṭhati, nisīdati, dussapallatthikaṃ
analyzed: vācā iti ayam dhamme agāravaḥ nāma yaḥ pana therena bhikkhunā an ajjhiṭṭhaḥ dhammaṃ  deseti pañham katheti vuḍḍhe bhikkhū ghaṭṭentaḥ gacchati tiṭṭhati nisīdati dussa pallatthikam
translated: this is called “lack of respect for the Teaching.” If one teaches the Teaching,

original: vā hatthapallatthikaṃ vā karoti, saṅghamajjhe ubho aṃse pārupati, chattupāhanaṃ dhāreti
analyzed: vā hattha pallatthikam vā karoti saṅgha majjhe ubho aṃse pārupati chattu pāhanam dhāreti
translated: if one answers questions, if one walks, stands, sits, or lies down obstructing the senior monks, if one wears the upper robe over both shoulders in the midst of the Sangha, if one carries an umbrella and sandals,

original: – ayaṃ saṅghe agāravo nāma. Ekabhikkhusmimpi hi agārave kate saṅghe agāravo katova
analyzed: ayam saṅghe agāravaḥ nāma eka bhikkhusmim pi hi agārave kate saṅghe agāravaḥ kataḥ uva
translated: This is called lack of respect for the Community. For when it is done to even one bhikkhu, it is done to the Community.🔽But one who does not fulfil the three trainings is called “lacking in respect for the training.”

original: hoti. Tisso sikkhā pana apūrayamānova sikkhāya agāravo nāma. Appamādalakkhaṇaṃ ananubrūhayamāno
analyzed: hoti tissaḥ sikkhā pana a pūrayamānaḥ iva sikkhāya agāravaḥ nāma appamāda lakkhaṇam an anubrūhayamānaḥ
translated: One who does not maintain heedfulness as a distinguishing mark is called “lacking in respect for heedfulness.”

original: appamāde agāravo nāma. Duvidhaṃ paṭisanthāraṃ akaronto paṭisanthāre agāravo nāma.🔽Parihāniyā dhammāti parihānakarā dhammā. Kammārāmatāti navakamme vā cīvaravicāraṇādīsu
analyzed: appamāde agāravaḥ nāma duvidham paṭisanthāram a karontaḥ paṭisanthāre agāravaḥ nāma  parihāniyāḥ dhammā ti parihāna karāḥ dhammā kamma ārāma tā ti nava kamme vā cīvara vicāraṇā ādīsu
translated: One who does not perform the two kinds of ministrations is called “lacking in respect for ministrations.”🔽“Things that lead to decline”: things that cause decline. “Fond of work”: devoted to and engaged in the various kinds of work such as new building projects, or in the various kinds of work such as the examination of robes.

original: vā kammesu abhirati yuttapayuttatā. Bhassārāmatāti tiracchānakathāvasena bhasse yuttapayuttatā.
analyzed: vā kammesu yutta payutta tā bhassa ārāma tā ati tiracchāna kathā vasena bhasse yutta payutta tā
translated: “Fond of talk”: devoted to and engaged in talk consisting of speculations.

original: Niddārāmatāti niddāya yuttapayuttatā. Saṅgaṇikārāmatāti saṅgaṇikāya yuttapayuttatā.
analyzed: niddā ārāma tā ati niddāya yutta payutta tā saṅgaṇika ārāma tā ati saṅgaṇikāya yutta payutta tā
translated: “Fond of sleep”: devoted to and engaged in sleep. “Fond of company”: devoted to and engaged in the company of others.

original: Saṃsaggārāmatāti savanasaṃsagge, dassanasaṃsagge, samullāpasaṃsagge, paribhogasaṃsagge,
analyzed: saṃsagga ārāma tā ati savana saṃsagge dassana saṃsagge samullāpa saṃsagge paribhoga saṃsagge
translated: “Fond of society”: devoted to and engaged in the society of the following kinds: the society of what is heard, the society of what is seen, the society of conversation, the society of enjoyment.

original: kāyasaṃsaggeti pañcavidhe saṃsagge yuttapayuttatā. Papañcārāmatāti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhipapañcesu yuttapayuttatā.
analyzed: kāya saṃsagga iti pañcavidhe saṃsagge yutta payutta tā papañca ārāma tā ati taṇhā māna diṭṭhi papañcesu yutta payutta tā
translated: “Bodily contact” is the state of being joined with the five kinds of contact. “Fond of proliferation” is the state of being joined with the proliferation of craving, conceit, and views.

original: 946. Somanassupavicārādīsu somanassena saddhiṃ upavicarantīti somanassupavicārā.🔽Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvāti cakkhuviññāṇena rūpaṃ passitvā. Somanassaṭṭhāniyanti somanassassa
analyzed: somanassupavicāra ādīsu somanassena saddhim upavicaranti iti somanassupavicārā  cakkhunā rūpam disvā ati cakkhu viññāṇena rūpam passitvā somanassa ṭṭhāniyanti somanassassa
translated: “Ruminations on joy” are the ruminations that occur together with joy.

original: ārammaṇavasena kāraṇabhūtaṃ. Upavicaratīti tattha vicārappavattanena upavicarati.
analyzed: ārammaṇa vasena kāraṇa bhūtam upavicarati iti tattha vicāra ppavattanena upavicarati
translated: “Having seen a visible form with the eye”: having seen a visible form with eye-consciousness. “Joyful” is the cause of joy by way of object. “Ruminates” is the occurrence of the rumination there.

original: Vitakko pana taṃsampayutto vāti iminā nayena tīsupi chakkesu attho veditabbo.
analyzed: vitakkaḥ pana tad sampayuttaḥ vā ti iminā nayena tīsu pi chakkesu atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: “Thinking” is the thinking associated with that. In this way the meaning should be understood in the case of the other three sense doors as well.

original: 947. Gehasitānīti kāmaguṇanissitāni. Somanassānīti cetasikasukhāni. Domanassānīti cetasikadukkhāni. Upekkhāti aññāṇasampayuttā upekkhā vedanā, aññāṇupekkhātipi etāsaṃyeva nāmaṃ.
analyzed: geha sitāni iti kāmaguṇa nissitāni somanassāni iti cetasika sukhāni domanassāni iti cetasika dukkhāni upekkhā ati aññāṇa sampayuttā upekkhā vedanā aññāṇupekkhā atipi etāsam yeva nāmaṃ
translated: “Household things” are things connected with the five strands of sense pleasure. “Joyful” is mental pleasure. “Sad” is mental pain. “Equanimity” is the feeling of equanimity associated with ignorance. “Ignorance” is also a name for this.

original: 948. Atthi me attāti vāti sabbapadesu vā-saddo vikappattho; evaṃ vā diṭṭhi uppajjatīti
analyzed: atthi me attā ati vā ati sabba padesu vā saddaḥ vikappa atthaḥ evam vā diṭṭhi uppajjati iti
translated: “The thought occurs: ‘I am, I am’” : the word “or” in the text has the meaning of “alternative.” The thought occurs thus:

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Atthi me attāti cettha sassatadiṭṭhi sabbakālesu attano atthitaṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: vuttam hoti atthi me attā ati ca ittha sassata diṭṭhi sabba kālesu attanaḥ atthitam gaṇhāti
translated: “I have a self” is eternalism, since it holds that the self exists at all times.

original: Saccato thetatoti bhūtato ca thirato ca; idaṃ saccanti suṭṭhu daḷhabhāvenāti vuttaṃ
analyzed: saccataḥ thetataḥ ti bhūtataḥ ca thirataḥ ca idam saccanti suṭṭhu daḷha bhāvena ati vuttam
translated: “In truth and in reality”: in the sense of being and in the sense of permanence.

original: hoti. Natthi me attāti ayaṃ pana ucchedadiṭṭhi, sato sattassa tattha tattha vibhavaggahaṇato.
analyzed: hoti natthi me attā ati ayam pana uccheda diṭṭhi sato sattassa tattha tattha vibhava ggahaṇato
translated: “I have no self” is annihilationism, since it holds that the existent being is annihilated here and there.

original: Atha vā purimāpi tīsu kālesu atthīti gahaṇato sassatadiṭṭhi, paccuppannameva atthīti🔽gaṇhantī ucchedadiṭṭhi. Pacchimāpi atītānāgatesu natthīti gahaṇato ‘bhasmantā āhutiyo’ti
analyzed: atha vā purimā api tīsu kālesu atthi iti gahaṇato sassata diṭṭhi paccuppannam eva atthi iti  gaṇhantī uccheda diṭṭhi pacchimā api atīta anāgatesu natthi iti gahaṇataḥ bhasmantā āhutiyo ti
translated: Or alternatively, the former view is eternalism, since it holds that the self exists in the three periods of time. The latter view is annihilationism, since it holds that the self exists only in the present.🔽The latter view is annihilationism, since it holds that the self does not exist in the past and future, like the view of those who hold that offerings are consumed by being reduced to ashes.

original: gahitadiṭṭhikānaṃ viya ucchedadiṭṭhi, atīteyeva natthīti gaṇhantī adhiccasamuppannikasseva🔽sassatadiṭṭhi. Attanā vā attānaṃ sañjānāmīti saññākkhandhasīsena khandhe attāti gahetvā
analyzed: gahita diṭṭhikānam viya uccheda diṭṭhi atītā iya iva natthi iti gaṇhantī adhiccasamuppannikassa iva  attanā vā attānam sañjānāmi iti saññā khandha sīsena khandhe attā ati gahetvā
translated: The former view is eternalism, since it holds that the self does not exist in the past alone, like the view of the fortuitous originationists.🔽“I perceive the self by the self” is the view that the aggregates are the self, taking the aggregate of perception as the chief factor.

original: saññāya avasesakkhandhe sañjānanato ‘iminā attanā imaṃ attānaṃ sañjānāmī’ti evaṃ
analyzed: saññāya avasesa kkhandhe sañjānanataḥ iminā attanā imam attānam sañjānāmi iti evam
translated: “I perceive this self by this self” is the view that the remaining aggregates are the self.

original: hoti. Attanā vā anattānanti saññākkhandhaṃyeva attāti gahetvā itare cattāro khandhe🔽anattāti gahetvā saññāya tesaṃ jānanato evaṃ hoti. Anattanā vā attānanti saññākkhandhaṃ
analyzed: hoti attanā vā anattā ananti saññā khandham yā iva attā ati gahetvā itare cattāro khandhe  anattā ati gahetvā saññāya tesam jānanataḥ evam hoti anattanā vā attānan ti saññā kkhandham
translated: “With regard to self and not-self”: having taken the perception-aggregate as self, he takes the other four aggregates🔽as not-self. Thus it is because he knows them. “With regard to not-self and self”: having taken the perception-aggregate as🔽not-self,

original: anattāti itare ca cattāro khandhe attāti gahetvā saññāya tesaṃ jānanato evaṃ hoti.
analyzed: anattā ati itare ca cattāro khandhe attā ati gahetvā saññāya tesam jānanato evam hoti
translated: “With self as self” : taking the perception aggregate as self, he knows the other four aggregates as not self. Thus it is. “With not-self as self” : taking the perception aggregate as not self, he knows the other four aggregates as self. Thus it is.

original: Sabbāpi sassatucchedadiṭṭhiyova.
analyzed: sabbā api
translated: All these views are eternalism and annihilationism.

original: Vado vedeyyoti ādayo pana sassatadiṭṭhiyā eva abhinivesākārā. Tattha vadatīti vado;
analyzed: vado vedeyyo ti ādayo pana sassata diṭṭhiyā eva abhinivesa ākārā tattha vadati iti vado
translated: “The speaker, the feeler,” etc., are modes of adherence to eternalism. Herein, “the speaker” is one who speaks;

original: vacīkammassa kārakoti vuttaṃ hoti. Vedayatīti vedeyyo; jānāti anubhavati cāti vuttaṃ🔽hoti. Idāni yaṃ so vedeti taṃ dassetuṃ tatra tatra dīgharattaṃ kalyāṇapāpakānantiādi
analyzed: vacī kammassa kārako ti vuttam hoti vedayati iti vedeyyaḥ jānāti anubhavati ca ati vuttam  hoti idāni yam saḥ veda iti tam dassetum tatra tatra dīgharattam kalyāṇa pāpaka ananti ādi
translated: he is said to be the doer of verbal action. “The feeler” is one who feels; he is said to know and experience.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha tatra tatrāti tesu tesu yonigatiṭhitinivāsanikāyesu ārammaṇesu vā.
analyzed: vuttam tattha tatra tatra ati tesu tesu yoni gati ṭhiti nivāsa nikāyesu ārammaṇesu vā
translated: Now, in order to show what he feels, “there, there for a long time,” etc., is said. Herein, “there, there” : in those destinies, in those abodes, in those objects.

original: Dīgharattanti cirarattaṃ. Paccanubhotīti paṭisaṃvedayati. Na so jāto nāhosīti so
analyzed: dīgharattanti cirarattam paccanubhoti iti paṭisaṃvedayati na saḥ jātaḥ na ahosi iti so
translated: For a long time: for a long period. He experiences: he feels. He was not born and did not exist:

original: attā ajātidhammato na jāto nāma; sadā vijjamāno yevāti attho. Teneva atīte nāhosi,
analyzed: attā a jāti dhammataḥ na jātaḥ nāma sadā vijjamānaḥ tena iva atīte
translated: that self, which is not subject to birth, was not born, that is, it was always existent, is the meaning. Therefore it did not exist in the past,

original: anāgatepi na bhavissati. Yo hi jāto so ahosi, yo ca jāyissati so bhavissatīti. Athavā🔽‘na so jāto nāhosī’ti so sadā vijjamānattā atītepi na jātu nāhosi, anāgatepi na jātu
analyzed: anāgate pi na bhavissati yaḥ hi jātaḥ saḥ ahosi yaḥ ca jāyissati saḥ bhavissati iti athavā  na saḥ jātaḥ na ahosi iti saḥ sadā atīte api na jātu na ahosi anāgate api na jātu
translated: and it will not exist in the future. For he who was born was, and he who will be born will be. Or else,

original: na bhavissati. Niccoti uppādavayarahito. Dhuvoti thiro sārabhūto. Sassatoti sabbakāliko.
analyzed: na bhavissati niccaḥ ti uppāda vaya rahitaḥ dhuvaḥ ti thiraḥ sāra bhūto sassatoti sabbakāliko
translated: ‘He was not born and did not exist’ means that it was never non-existent in the past or in the future because it is always existent. Permanent: devoid of arising and dissolution. Eternal: firm, substantial. Im- mutable: all-inclusive.

original: Avipariṇāmadhammoti attano pakatibhāvaṃ avijahanadhammo kakaṇṭako viya nānappakārattaṃ
analyzed: a vipariṇāma dhammo ti attanaḥ pakati bhāvam a vijahana dhammo kakaṇṭakaḥ viya nānā pakāra ttam
translated: Not subject to change: not subject to the state of having abandoned its own natural condition, like a thorn is not subject to the state of having lost its sharpness for a long time.

original: nāpajjati. Evamayaṃ sabbāsavadiṭṭhi nāma kathitā. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.🔽Chakkaniddesavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: na āpajjati evam ayam sabbāsavadiṭṭhi nāma kathitā sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati  chakka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Thus this is called the view of all taints. The rest is clear in all instances.🔽The commentary on the section on sixes.

original: (7.) Sattakaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the section on sevens.

original: 949. Sattakaniddese thāmagataṭṭhena appahīnaṭṭhena ca anusentīti anusayā. Vaṭṭasmiṃ
analyzed: sattaka niddese thāma gata ṭṭhena appahīna ṭṭhena ca anusenti iti anusayāḥ vaṭṭasmin
translated: In the section on the seven kinds of craving, they are “inherent tendencies” because they pursue their object by way of the mode of persistence and by way of the mode of non-abandonment.🔽They are “fetters” because they fetter beings to the round of rebirths.

original: satte saṃyojenti ghaṭentīti saṃyojanāni. Samudācāravasena pariyuṭṭhahantīti pariyuṭṭhānāni.
analyzed: satte saṃyojenti ghaṭenti iti saṃyojanāni samudācāra vasena pariyuṭṭhahanti iti pariyuṭṭhānāni
translated: They are “adherences” because they adhere by way of the mode of occurrence.

original: Kāmarāgova pariyuṭṭhānaṃ kāmarāgapariyuṭṭhānaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo.🔽950. Asataṃ dhammā, lāmakaṭṭhena vā asantā dhammāti asaddhammā. Rāgādīhi dosehi duṭṭhāni caritānīti duccaritāni. Tena tenākārena maññantīti mānā.🔽951. Diṭṭhiniddese rūpīti rūpavā. Cātumahābhūtikoti catumahābhūtamayo. Mātāpitūnaṃ🔽etanti mātāpettikaṃ. Kintaṃ? Sukkasoṇitaṃ. Mātāpettike sambhūto jātoti mātāpettikasambhavo.
analyzed: kāma rāgaḥ uva pariyuṭṭhānam kāma rāga pariyuṭṭhānam sesesu pi esa iva nayo  asatam dhammā lāmakaṭṭhena vā asantā dhammā ati asat dhammāḥ rāga ādīhi dosehi duṭṭhāni caritāni iti duccaritāni tena tena ākārena maññanti iti mānā  diṭṭhi niddese rūpī iti rūpavā cātumahābhūtikaḥ iti catu mahābhūta mayaḥ mātā pitūnam  etat ti mātāpettikam kintam sukka soṇitam mātāpettike sambhūtaḥ jātaḥ iti mātāpettika sambhavaḥ
translated: The adherence of sensual lust is the adherence that is sensual lust. The same method applies in the case of the other adherences.

original: Idha rūpakāyasīsena manussattabhāvaṃ attāti vadati. Dutiyo taṃ paṭikkhipitvā dibbattabhāvaṃ
analyzed: idha rūpa kāya sīsena manussa atta bhāvam attā ati vadati dutiyaḥ tam paṭikkhipitvā dibba tta bhāvam
translated: The bad things are bad in the sense of being contemptible. The bad things are bad in the sense of being blameworthy. The bad things are bad in the sense of being painful. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of disadvantage. The bad things are bad in the sense of being perishable. The bad things are bad in the sense of being unwholesome. The bad things are bad in the sense of being unbeneficial. The bad things are bad in the sense of being undesirable. The bad things are bad in the sense of being disagreeable. The bad things are bad in the sense of being unlovely. The bad things are bad in the sense of being unpleasurable. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be abandoned. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be relinquished. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be comprehended. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be fully understood. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be abandoned. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be realized. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be developed. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be resorted to. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be cultivated. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be directly known. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be realized. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be attained. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be experienced. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be touched. The bad things are bad in the sense of being of a nature to be comprehended. The bad things are

original: vadati. Dibboti devaloke sambhūto. Kāmāvacaroti chakāmāvacaradevapariyāpanno. Kabaḷīkāraṃ
analyzed: vadati dibbaḥ iti deva loke sambhūto kāmāvacaro ti cha kāmāvacara deva pariyāpanno kabaḷīkāram
translated: He speaks. Divine: arisen in the divine world. Sense-desire-world: included in the six divine worlds of the sense-desire world. He eats

original: bhakkhayatīti kabaḷīkārabhakkho. Manomayoti jhānamanena nibbatto. Sabbaṅgapaccaṅgīti🔽sabbaṅgapaccaṅgayutto. Ahīnindriyoti paripuṇṇindriyo; yāni brahmaloke atthi tesaṃ🔽vasena, itaresañca saṇṭhānavasenetaṃ vuttaṃ. Ākāsānañcāyatanūpagoti ākāsānañcāyatanabhāvaṃ
analyzed: bhakkhayati iti kabaḷīkāra bhakkhaḥ manaḥ mayaḥ ti jhāna manena nibbattaḥ sabbaṅga paccaṅgī iti  sabbaṅga paccaṅga yuttaḥ paripuṇṇa indriyaḥ yāni brahmaloke atthi tesam  vasena itaresam ca saṇṭhāna vasena itam vuttam ākāsa anañcāyatana upagaḥ ti ākāsa anañcāyatana bhāvam
translated: food by lumps: he is a lump-eater. Mind-made: produced by jhana-mind. Complete-limbed:🔽endowed with complete limbs. Not lacking in any faculty: he has complete faculties; this is said

original: upagato. Itaresupi eseva nayo. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: upagataḥ itaresu pi esa iva nayaḥ sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: with reference to those that exist in the Brahma-world and with reference to the shape of the others. He has attained the base consisting of boundless space: he has attained the state of the base consisting of boundless space. The same method applies in the other cases. The rest is self-evident in all cases.

original: Sattakaniddesavaṇṇanā.
translated: Commentary on the Description of the Seven

original: (8.) Aṭṭhakaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽952. Aṭṭhakaniddese kilesāyeva kilesavatthūni. Kusītavatthūnīti kusītassa alasassa
analyzed: aṭṭhaka niddesa vaṇṇanā  aṭṭhaka niddese kilesāya iva kilesa vatthūni kusīta vatthūni iti kusītassa alasassa
translated: . Commentary on the Description of the Eight

original: vatthūni, patiṭṭhā, kosajjakāraṇānīti attho. Kammaṃ kātabbaṃ hotīti cīvaravicāraṇādikammaṃ
analyzed: vatthūni patiṭṭhā kosajja kāraṇāni iti attho kammam kātabbam hoti iti cīvara vicāraṇā ādi kammam
translated: In the Description of the Eight, the defilements are the bases of the defilements. The bases of laziness are the bases, the foundations, the reasons for laziness, for indolence. Work has to be done: work such as the consideration of robes, etc.

original: kātabbaṃ hoti. Na vīriyaṃ ārabhatīti duvidhampi vīriyaṃ nārabhati. Appattassāti jhānavipassanāmaggaphaladhammassa🔽appattassa pattiyā. Anadhigatassāti tasseva anadhigatassa adhigamatthāya. Asacchikatassāti
analyzed: kātabbam hoti na vīriyam ārabhati iti duvidham pi vīriyam na ārabhati appattassa āti jhāna vipassanā magga phala dhammassa  appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa ati tassa iva anadhigatassa adhigama tthāya a sacchikatassa ati
translated: He does not make an effort. He does not make a double effort. He has not attained: he has not attained the states of jhāna, insight, path, and fruit.

original: tasseva asacchikatassa sacchikaraṇatthāya. Idaṃ paṭhamanti ‘idaṃ handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti
analyzed: tassa iva a sacchikatassa sacchikaraṇa atthāya idam paṭhamanti idam handa aham nipajjāmi iti
translated: He has not reached: he has not reached the states of jhāna, insight, path, and fruit. He has not realized: he has not realized the states of jhāna, insight, path, and fruit. This is the first: this is the first of the unprofitable things that are grounds for laziness.

original: evaṃ osīdanaṃ paṭhamaṃ kusītavatthu. Iminā nayena sabbattha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: evam osīdanam paṭhamam kusīta vatthu iminā nayena sabbattha attho veditabbo
translated: Thinking: “I will lie down,” he lies down. This is the first unprofitable thing that is a ground for laziness. In this way the meaning should be understood in all cases.

original: Māsācitaṃ maññeti ettha pana māsācitaṃ nāma tintamāso; yathā tintamāso garuko hoti, evaṃ garukoti adhippāyo. Gilānā vuṭṭhito hotīti gilāno hutvā pacchā vuṭṭhito hoti.
analyzed: māsācitam maññeti ettha pana māsācitam nāma tinta māsaḥ yathā tinta māsaḥ garukaḥ hoti evam garukaḥ iti adhippāyaḥ gilānā vuṭṭhitaḥ hoti iti gilānaḥ hutvā pacchā vuṭṭhitaḥ hoti
translated: Thinking: “I am heavy,” etc.: here “heavy” is intended as heavy as a month-old calf, as heavy as a month-old calf is. He has recovered from illness: he has been ill and then he recovers.

original: 954. Aṭṭhasu lokadhammesūti ettha lokassa dhammāti lokadhammā. Etehi vimutto nāma
analyzed: aṭṭhasu loka dhammesu iti ettha lokassa dhammā ati loka dhammā etehi vimuttaḥ nāma
translated: As to the eight worldly ideas: here “ideas of the world” are worldly ideas . One who is free from these is called

original: natthi, buddhānampi honti eva. Tasmā ‘lokadhammā’ti vuccanti. Paṭighātoti paṭihaññanākāro.
analyzed: natthi buddhānam pi honti eva tasmā loka dhammā ti vuccanti paṭighāto ti paṭihaññanā ākāro
translated: Hostility is the mode of opposition.

original: Lābhe sārāgoti ‘ahaṃ lābhaṃ labhāmī’ti evaṃ gehasitasomanassavasena uppanno sārāgo;
analyzed: lābhe sārāgaḥ ti aham lābham labhāmi iti evam geha sita somanassa vasena uppanno sārāgaḥ
translated: Clinging to lust for gains is the delight that arises in one who thinks, “I am getting gains” and is due to the mundane joy of gain;🔽it is a hindrance to the mind.

original: so cittaṃ paṭihanati. Alābhe paṭivirodhoti ‘ahaṃ lābhaṃ na labhāmī’ti domanassavasena🔽uppannavirodho; sopi cittaṃ paṭihanati. Tasmā ‘paṭighāto’ti vutto. Yasādīsupi ‘ahaṃ
analyzed: saḥ cittam paṭihanati alābhe paṭivirodhaḥ ti aham lābham na labhāmi iti domanassa vasena  uppanna virodhaḥ saḥ api cittam paṭihanati tasmā paṭighāto ti vuttaḥ yasa ādīsu pi aham
translated: Clinging to resentment is the opposition that arises in one who thinks, “I am not getting gains” and is due to the displeasure of non-gain;

original: mahāparivāro, ahaṃ appaparivāro, ahaṃ pasaṃsappatto, ahaṃ garahappatto, ahaṃ sukhappatto,🔽ahaṃ dukkhappato’ti evametesaṃ uppatti veditabbā. Anariyavohārāti anariyānaṃ vohārā.
analyzed: mahā parivāraḥ aham appa parivāraḥ aham pasaṃsa ppatto aham garaha ppatto aham sukha ppatto  aham dukkha ppato ti evam etesam uppatti veditabbā anariya vohārā ati anariyānam vohārā
translated: it is also a hindrance to the mind. That is why it is called “hostility.” The arising of the others should be understood in this way: “I have a large following,” “I have a small following,” “I am praised,” “I am honoured,” “I am comfortable,” “I am in pain.”🔽Un-noble speech is the speech of the ignoble.

original: 957. Purisadosāti purisānaṃ dosā. Na sarāmīti ‘mayā etassa kammassa kataṭṭhānaṃ na🔽sarāmi na sallakkhemī’ti evaṃ assatibhāvena nibbeṭheti moceti. Codakaṃyeva paṭippharatīti
analyzed: purisa dosā ati purisānam dosā na sarāmi iti mayā etassa kammassa kata ṭṭhānam na 🔽sarāmi na sallakkhemi iti evam assati bhāvena nibbeṭheti moceti ca udakam yā iva paṭippharati iti
translated: Men’s faults are the faults of men. I do not remember is the meaning of “I do not recall, I do not recollect.” He dismisses, he releases, by means of non-recollection. He retaliates against the accuser.

original: paṭiviruddho hutvā pharati, paṭibhāṇitabhāvena tiṭṭhati. Kiṃ nu kho tuyhanti ‘tuyhaṃ🔽bālassa abyattassa bhaṇitena nāma kiṃ’ yo tvaṃ neva vatthunā āpattiṃ, na codanaṃ
analyzed: paṭiviruddhaḥ hutvā pharati paṭibhāṇita bhāvena tiṭṭhati kim nu kho tuyhanti tuyham  bālassa abyattassa bhaṇitena nāma kim na iva vatthunā āpattim na codanam
translated: He is in conflict and he speaks. He stands by what he has said. What is the use of your speaking?

original: jānāsī’ti dīpeti; ‘tvaṃ pi nāma evaṃ kiñci ajānanto bhaṇitabbaṃ maññissasī’ti ajjhottharati.
analyzed: jānāsi iti dīpeti tvam pi nāma evam kiñci a jānantaḥ bhaṇitabbam maññissasi iti ajjhottharati
translated: He shows that there is no point in the speech of one who is ignorant and incompetent, who does not know the action that constitutes an offense, nor the accusation, nor the reply. He is exasperated, thinking, “You think that you should speak, not knowing anything.”

original: Paccāropetīti ‘tvaṃ pi khosī’tiādīni vadanto paṭiāropeti. Paṭikarohīti desanāgāminiṃ

analyzed: kam bhaṇatha kim bhaṇatha ati vadati evarūpam kiñci tayā diṭṭhanti vutte na suṇāmi iti
