original: Atibāḷhanti atidaḷhaṃ atippamāṇaṃ. Mayi byāvaṭāti mayi byāpāraṃ āpannā. Hīnāyāvattitvāti
analyzed: ati bāḷhanti ati daḷham ati ppamāṇam mayi mayi byāpāram āpannā hīnāya avattitvā iti
translated: Excessively : very, extremely. They have turned back to the inferior : they have turned back to the inferior state of a house- dweller.

original: hīnassa gihibhāvassa atthāya āvattitvā; gihī hutvāti attho. Attamanā hothāti tuṭṭhacittā🔽hotha, ‘mayā labhitabbaṃ labhatha, mayā vasitabbaṭṭhāne vasatha, phāsuvihāro vo mayā
analyzed: hīnassa gihi bhāvassa atthāya āvattitvā gihī hutvā ati attho attamanāḥ hotha ati tuṭṭha cittā  hotha mayā labhitabbam labhatha mayā vasitabba ṭṭhāne vasatha phāsu vihāraḥ vaḥ mayā
translated: They have become house-dwellers, is the meaning. Be satisfied : be pleased.

original: kato’ti adhippāyena vadati.
analyzed: kato ti adhippāyena vadati
translated: The meaning is: ‘You have got what you could get from me, you have lived where you could live with me, I have made your living easy for you.’

original: 958. Asaññīti pavatto vādo asaññīvādo; so tesaṃ atthīti asaññīvādā. Rūpī attātiādīsu🔽lābhino kasiṇarūpaṃ attāti gahetvā rūpīti diṭṭhi uppajjati; alābhino takkamatteneva,
analyzed: asaññī iti pavattaḥ vādaḥ asaññīvādo so tesam atthi iti asaññīvādāḥ rūpī attā ati ādīsu  lābhino kasiṇa rūpam attā ati gahetvā rūpī iti diṭṭhi uppajjati alābhino takka mattena iva
translated: The view that there is no consciousness after death is the doctrine of the non-percipient. Those who hold that doctrine are called non-percipient.

original: ājīvakānaṃ viya. Lābhinoyeva ca pana arūpasamāpattinimittaṃ attāti gahetvā arūpīti
analyzed: ca pana arūpa samāpatti nimittam attā ati gahetvā arūpī iti
translated: As regards the view that the self is possessed of form, etc., those who have attained the kasiṇa of form take it as the self, and the view arises that the self is possessed of form. Those who have not attained it take it as the self merely on hearsay, like the Ājīvakas.

original: diṭṭhi uppajjati; alābhino takkamatteneva, nigaṇṭhānaṃ viya. Asaññībhāve panettha
analyzed: diṭṭhi uppajjati alābhinaḥ takka mattena iva nigaṇṭhānam viya asaññībhāve pana ittha
translated: But only those who have attained the formless jhānas take the sign of the formless jhāna as the self, and the view arises that the self is formless. Those who have not attained it take it as the self merely on hearsay, like the Nigaṇṭhas.🔽As regards the view that the self is non-percipient, etc.,

original: ekanteneva kāraṇaṃ na pariyesitabbaṃ. Diṭṭhigatiko hi ummattako viya yaṃ vā taṃ vā🔽gaṇhāti. Rūpī ca arūpī cāti rūpārūpamissakagāhavasena vuttaṃ. Ayaṃ diṭṭhi rūpāvacarārūpāvacarasamāpattilābhinopi🔽takkikassāpi uppajjati. Neva rūpī nārūpīti pana ekantato takkikadiṭṭhiyeva. Antavāti🔽parittakasiṇaṃ attato gaṇhantassa diṭṭhi. Anantavāti appamāṇakasiṇaṃ. Antavā ca anantavā🔽cāti uddhamadho sapariyantaṃ tiriyaṃ apariyantaṃ kasiṇaṃ attāti gahetvā uppannadiṭṭhi.
analyzed: ekantena iva kāraṇam na pariyesitabbam diṭṭhi gatikaḥ hi ummattakaḥ viya yam vā tam vā  gaṇhāti rūpī ca arūpī ca ati rūpa arūpa missaka gāha vasena vuttam ayam rūpāvacara arūpāvacara samāpatti lābhinaḥ api  takkikassa api uppajjati na iva rūpī na arūpī iti pana ekantato takkika diṭṭhiyā iva  paritta kasiṇam attataḥ gaṇhantassa diṭṭhi anantavā ti appamāṇa kasiṇam antavā ca anantavā  ca ati uddham adhas sa pariyantam tiriyam apariyantam kasiṇam attā ati gahetvā uppanna diṭṭhi
translated: He should not seek a reason at all. For the theorist, like a madman, seizes on anything. “With form and formless” is said with reference to the grasping of a mixture of form and the formless. This view arises in one who has attained the fine-material and immaterial jhānas,🔽and also in a theorist. “Neither with form nor formless” is a view of a theorist only. “Finite” is a view that arises in one who grasps a limited kasiṇa as the self. “Infinite” is a view that arises in one who grasps an immeasurable kasiṇa. “Both finite and infinite” is a view that arises in one who grasps a kasiṇa with a limit above and below but without a limit across. “Neither finite nor infinite” is a view that arises in one who grasps a kasiṇa without a limit in any way.

original: Nevantavā nānantavāti takkikadiṭṭhiyeva. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: na iva antavā na anantavā ti takkika diṭṭhiyā iva sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: He should not seek a reason at all. For the theorist, like a madman, seizes on anything or nothing. “ Possessing material form and immaterial” is said with reference to the grasping of a mixture of material and immaterial. This view arises in one who has attained jhāna in the fine-material and immaterial spheres, and in a theorist. “ Neither possessing material form nor immaterial” is a theorist’s view only. “ Finite” is a view that arises in one who apprehends a limited kasiṇa as the self. “ Infinite” is a view that arises in one who apprehends an immeasurable kasiṇa. “ Both finite and infinite” is a view that arises in one who apprehends a kasiṇa with a limit above and below and without a limit across. “ Neither finite nor infinite” is a theorist’s view only. The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Aṭṭhakaniddesavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: aṭṭhaka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the section on eights is completed.

original: (9.) Navakaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the section on nines.

original: 960. Navakaniddese nava āghātavatthūnīti sattesu uppattivaseneva kathitāni. Purisānaṃ malānīti purisamalāni. Navavidhāti navakoṭṭhāsā navappabhedā vā.🔽963. Taṇhaṃ paṭiccāti taṇhaṃ nissāya. Pariyesanāti rūpādiārammaṇapariyesanā. Sā hi
analyzed: navaka niddese nava āghāta vatthūni iti sattesu uppatti vasena iva kathitāni purisānam malāni iti purisa malāni navavidhā ati nava koṭṭhāsāḥ nava ppabhedāḥ vā  taṇham paṭicca ati taṇham nissāya pariyesanā ati rūpa ādi ārammaṇa pariyesanā sā hi
translated: In the nine-factored description, the nine grounds for resentment are stated only as to their arising in beings. The men’s stains are the men’s defilements. Ninefold: of nine sections, or of nine kinds.

original: taṇhāya sati hoti. Lābhoti rūpādiārammaṇapaṭilābho. So hi pariyesanāya sati hoti.🔽Vinicchayo pana ñāṇataṇhādiṭṭhivitakkavasena catubbidho. Tattha “sukhavinicchayaṃ
analyzed: taṇhāya sati hoti lābho ti rūpa ādi ārammaṇa paṭilābho saḥ hi pariyesanāya sati hoti  vinicchayaḥ pana ñāṇa taṇhā diṭṭhi vitakka vasena catubbidhaḥ tattha sukha vinicchayam
translated: With craving as condition: depending on craving. Searching: searching for objects such as visible forms, etc. For that is when there is craving. Finding: finding objects such as visible forms, etc. For that is when there is searching.

original: jaññā, sukhavinicchayaṃ ñatvā ajjhattaṃ sukhamanuyuñjeyyā”ti ayaṃ ñāṇavinicchayo.
analyzed: jaññā sukha vinicchayam ñatvā ajjhattam sukham anuyuñjeyya iti ayam ñāṇa vinicchayaḥ
translated: Decision is fourfold as knowledge, craving, view, and thinking. Herein, “He should know the decision on pleasure. Having known the decision on pleasure, he should practice in conformity with pleasure internally” . This is decision by knowledge.

original: “Vinicchayoti dve vinicchayā – taṇhāvinicchayo ca diṭṭhivinicchayo cā”ti evaṃ āgatāni
analyzed: vinicchayā iti dve vinicchayā taṇhā vinicchayo ca diṭṭhi vinicchayo ca ati evam āgatāni
translated: “Decision: there are two kinds of decision, decision by craving and decision by view” .

original: aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritāni taṇhāvinicchayo. Dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo diṭṭhivinicchayo. “Chando
analyzed: aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicaritāni taṇhā vinicchayaḥ dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ diṭṭhi vinicchayo chando
translated: The eighty-four hundredfold activities of craving are decision by craving. The sixty-two views are decision by view. “Desire,

original: kho, devānaminda, vitakkanidāno”ti imasmiṃ pana sutte idha vinicchayoti vutto vitakkoyeva🔽āgato. Lābhaṃ labhitvā hi iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ sundarāsundarañca vitakkeneva vinicchināti
analyzed: kho devānaminda vitakka nidānaḥ ti imasmim pana sutte idha vinicchayaḥ ti vuttaḥ  āgataḥ lābham labhitvā hi iṭṭha aniṭṭham sundara asundaram ca vitakkena iva vinicchināti
translated: But in this sutta the word “consideration” is used for the kind of thinking called “reflection” .

original: – ‘ettakaṃ me rūpārammaṇatthāya bhavissati, ettakaṃ saddādiārammaṇatthāya, ettakaṃ
analyzed: ettakam me rūpa ārammaṇa tthāya bhavissati ettakam sadda ādi ārammaṇa tthāya ettakam
translated: For when he has obtained gain, he considers what is desirable and undesirable, beautiful and ugly, by means of reflection: “So much will be for the purpose of sense desires, so much for the purpose of sound, etc.,

original: mayhaṃ bhavissati, ettakaṃ parassa, ettakaṃ paribhuñjissāmi, ettakaṃ nidahissāmī’ti.
analyzed: mayham bhavissati ettakam parassa ettakam paribhuñjissāmi ettakam nidahissāmi iti
translated: so much will be for me, so much for others, so much I shall use, so much I shall store up.”

original: Tena vuttaṃ “lābhaṃ paṭicca vinicchayo”ti.🔽Chandarāgoti evaṃ akusalavitakkena vitakkite vatthusmiṃ dubbalarāgo ca balavarāgo🔽ca uppajjati. Idañhi idha chandoti dubbalarāgassādhivacanaṃ. Ajjhosānanti ahaṃ mamanti
analyzed: tena vuttam lābham paṭicca vinicchayaḥ ti  chanda rāgaḥ ti evam akusala vitakkena vitakkite vatthusmim dubbala rāgo ca balava rāgo  ca uppajjati idam hi idha chando ti dubbala rāgassa adhivacanam aham mama nti
translated: That is why it is said: “Consideration due to gain.”

original: balavasanniṭṭhānaṃ. Pariggahoti taṇhādiṭṭhivasena pariggahakaraṇaṃ. Macchariyanti
analyzed: balava sanniṭṭhānam pariggaho ti taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena pariggaha karaṇam macchariyanti
translated: “Desire and lust”: when a thing is reflected upon by means of unwholesome thinking, weak lust and strong lust arise. For here “desire” is a term for weak lust, and “clinging” is the strong determination of “I” and “mine.” “Avarice” is the making of hoarding by way of craving and views. “Misery” is the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: parehi sādhāraṇabhāvassa asahanatā. Tenevassa porāṇā evaṃ vacanatthaṃ vadanti – “idaṃ🔽acchariyaṃ mayhameva hotu, mā aññassa acchariyaṃ hotūti pavattattā macchariyanti🔽vuccatī”ti. Ārakkhoti dvārapidahanamañjusagopanādivasena suṭṭhu rakkhaṇaṃ. Adhikarotīti🔽adhikaraṇaṃ; kāraṇassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Ārakkhādhikaraṇanti bhāvanapuṃsakaṃ; ārakkhahetūti
analyzed: parehi sādhāraṇa bhāvassa a sahana tā porāṇāḥ evam vacana attham vadanti idam  acchariyam mayham eva hotu mā aññassa acchariyam hotu uti pavatta ttā macchariyanti  vuccati iti ārakkho ti dvāra pidahana mañju sagopana ādi vasena suṭṭhu rakkhaṇam adhikaroti iti  adhikaraṇam kāraṇassa itam nāmam ārakkha adhikaraṇanti bhāva napuṃsakam ārakkha hetu uti
translated: It is the inability to bear sharing with others. That is why the ancients gave this explanation of the meaning: “It is called ‘miserliness’🔽because it occurs thus: ‘Let this wonder be mine alone, let no other have a wonder’” .🔽Guarding is guarding well by such means as locking the door, keeping a watch, and so on.🔽A cause is a reason.🔽The compound ārakkhādikaraṇaṃ is a copulative compound. The meaning is: “because of the reason of guarding.”

original: attho. Daṇḍādānādīsu paranisedhanatthaṃ daṇḍassa ādānaṃ daṇḍādānaṃ. Ekatodhārādino🔽satthassa ādānaṃ satthādānaṃ. Kalahoti kāyakalahopi vācākalahopi. Purimo purimo virodho🔽viggaho, pacchimo pacchimo vivādo. Tuvaṃ tuvanti agāravavacanaṃ, tvaṃ tvanti attho.
analyzed: atthaḥ daṇḍa ādāna ādīsu para nisedhana attham daṇḍassa ādānam daṇḍa ādānam ekatodhāra ādino  satthassa ādānam sattha ādānam kalaho ti kāya kalaho pi vācā kalaho pi purimaḥ purimaḥ virodho  viggahaḥ pacchimaḥ pacchimaḥ vivādaḥ tuvam tuvanti agārava vacanam tvam tuvanti attho
translated: It is the inability to bear sharing with others. That is why the ancients gave this explanation of the meaning of the word: “It is called ‘miserliness’ (macchariya) because it occurs thus: ‘Let this wonder (acchariya) be mine alone, let it not be another’s wonder (macchariya).’” Guarding: guarding well by such means as locking the door, covering the bed, etc. A cause is called an “instrument” (adhikaraṇa). “Guarding as an instrument” is a feminine substantive formed by adding -ā to the masculine substantive; the meaning is: “a cause for guarding.” Taking up a stick: taking up a stick for the purpose of restraining others in such matters as taking what is not given, etc. Taking up a weapon: taking up a sword, etc. Quarrel: a quarrel by body or by speech. Dispute: the first opposition is a dispute, the later opposition is a quarrel. “You” and “you”: a disrespectful form of address; the meaning is “you” and “you.”

original: 964. Iñjitānīti iñjanāni calanāni. Asmīti iñjitametantiādīhi sabbapadehi mānova kathito.
analyzed: iñjitāni iti iñjanāni calanāni asmi iti iñjitam etat ti ādīhi sabba padehi mānaḥ uva kathitaḥ
translated: Shakings: tremblings. In all these terms beginning with “I am” the self is referred to.

original: Ahanti pavattopi hi māno iñjitameva, ayamahanti pavattopi, nevasaññīnāsaññī bhavissanti
analyzed: ahanti pavattaḥ api hi mānaḥ iñjitam eva ayam ahanti pavattaḥ api na ivasaññī nāsaññī bhavissanti
translated: For the occurrence of “I am” is conceit, and the occurrence of “I am this” is also conceit.🔽The occurrence of “I shall be” is also conceit. In the rest of the section conceit is spoken of.

original: pavattopi. Sesanavakehipi mānova kathito. Māno hi iñjanato iñjitaṃ, maññanato maññitaṃ,
analyzed: pavattaḥ api sesa navakehi pi mānaḥ iva kathitaḥ mānaḥ hi iñjanataḥ iñjitam maññanataḥ maññitam
translated: For conceit is “I-making” because of making “I am,” “conceiving” because of conceiving “I am this,”

original: phandanato phanditaṃ, papañcanato papañcitaṃ. Tehi tehi kāraṇehi saṅkhatattā saṅkhatanti
analyzed: phandanataḥ phanditam papañcanataḥ papañcitam tehi tehi kāraṇehi saṅkhatattā saṅkhatanti
translated: “wavering” because of wavering, “proliferation” because of proliferating. It is called “formed” because of being formed by these and those conditions.

original: ca vuccati. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: ca vuccati sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: The rest is clear in meaning everywhere.

original: Navakaniddesavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: navaka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the nine kinds of conceit is ended.

original: (10.) Dasakaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dasaka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Exposition of the ten kinds of conceit

original: 966. Dasakaniddese kilesā eva kilesavatthūni. Āghātavatthūni panettha “anatthaṃ me acarī”tiādīnaṃ vasena avikopetabbe khāṇukaṇṭakādimhipi aṭṭhāne uppannāghātena saddhiṃ vuttāni.
analyzed: dasaka niddese kilesāḥ eva kilesa vatthūni āghāta vatthūni pana ittha anattham me acari iti ādīnam vasena avikopetabbe khāṇu kaṇṭaka ādimhi pi aṭṭhāne uppanna āghātena saddhim vuttāni
translated: In the exposition of the ten kinds of conceit the defilements themselves are the bases of the defilements. But the grounds for annoyance are stated here together with the annoyance that arises in an unsuitable place such as a stump or a thorn, on account of such thoughts as “It does me harm.”

original: 970. Micchattesu micchāñāṇanti pāpakiriyāsu upāyacintāvasena pāpaṃ katvā ‘sukataṃ
analyzed: pāpa kiriyāsu upāya cintā vasena pāpam katvā su katam
translated: In the ten wrongnesses, wrong knowledge is evil thinking in the way beginning “Having done evil” after doing evil deeds.

original: mayā’ti paccavekkhaṇākārena uppanno moho. Micchāvimuttīti avimuttasseva sato vimuttasaññitā.
analyzed: mayā ti paccavekkhaṇa ākārena uppannaḥ mohaḥ micchāvimuttī iti avimuttassa iva sataḥ vimutta saññi tā
translated: Delusion is the delusion arisen in the aspect of reviewing. Wrong liberation is the perception of liberation in one who is not liberated.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.🔽Dasakaniddesavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati  dasaka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The rest is clear in all instances.🔽The commentary on the section on tenfold.

original: Taṇhāvicaritaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: taṇhāvicarita niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the section on the modes of propagation of craving.

original: 973. Taṇhāvicaritaniddese taṇhāvicaritānīti taṇhāsamudācārā taṇhāpavattiyo. Ajjhattikassa
analyzed: taṇhā vicarita niddese taṇhā vicaritāni iti taṇhā samudācārāḥ taṇhā pavattiyaḥ ajjhattikassa
translated: In the section on the modes of propagation of craving, the modes of propagation of craving are the manifestations of craving, the occurrences of craving.

original: upādāyāti ajjhattikaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ upādāya. Idañhi upayogatthe sāmivacanaṃ. Asmīti🔽hotīti yadetaṃ ajjhattaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ upādāya taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena samūhagāhato
analyzed: upādāya ati ajjhattikam khandha pañcakam upādāya idam hi upayoga tthe sāmi vacanam asmi iti  hoti iti yat etam ajjhattam khandha pañcakam upādāya taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena samūha gāhato
translated: Taking as a basis what is internal: taking as a basis the five aggregates of clinging internally. For this is a genitive of cause.

original: ‘asmī’ti hoti, tasmiṃ satīti attho. Itthasmīti hotītiādīsu pana evaṃ samūhato ‘aha’nti
analyzed: asmi iti hoti tasmin sati iti attho itthasmi iti hoti itiādīsu pana evam samūhataḥ
translated: The thought “I am” occurs: the thought “I am” occurs through the apprehension of a mass by way of craving, conceit, and views, taking as a basis the five aggregates of clinging internally. The meaning is: when that exists.

original: gahaṇe sati tato anupanidhāya ca upanidhāya cāti dvidhā gahaṇaṃ hoti. Tattha anupanidhāyāti
analyzed: gahaṇe sati tatas an upanidhāya ca upanidhāya ca ati dvidhā gahaṇam hoti an upanidhāya ati
translated: In the case of the thought “I am this” and so on, however, the apprehension is twofold: without making a distinction and by making a distinction.

original: aññaṃ ākāraṃ anupagamma sakabhāvameva ārammaṇaṃ katvā ‘itthasmī’ti hoti; khattiyādīsu
analyzed: aññam ākāram an upagamma saka bhāvam eva ārammaṇam katvā itthasmi iti hoti khattiya ādīsu
translated: Herein, without making a distinction: without taking up another mode, making one’s own being alone the object, the thought “I am this” occurs.🔽In the case of the khattiyas, etc.

original: ‘idaṃpakāro aha’nti evaṃ taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena hotīti attho. Idaṃ tāva anupanidhāya
analyzed: idaṃpakāraḥ aham ti evam taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena hoti iti attho idam tāva an upanidhāya
translated: The meaning is that it occurs by way of craving, conceit, and views, thinking, “I am of such and such a kind.” This is the kind of apprehension that does not take something as a basis.

original: gahaṇaṃ. Upanidhāya gahaṇaṃ pana duvidhaṃ hoti – samato ca asamato ca. Taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: gahaṇam upanidhāya gahaṇam pana duvidham hoti samatas ca asamatas ca tam dassetuṃ
translated: But the kind that takes something as a basis is twofold: equal and unequal. To illustrate this,

original: evasmīti ca aññathāsmīti ca vuttaṃ. Tattha evasmīti idaṃ samato upanidhāya gahaṇaṃ;
analyzed: evasmi iti ca aññathā asmi iti ca vuttam tattha evasmi iti idam samatas upanidhāya gahaṇam
translated: the text says, “I am” and “I am otherwise.” Herein, “I am” is the kind of apprehension that takes something as a basis by way of equality,

original: yathā ayaṃ khattiyo, yathā ayaṃ brāhmaṇo, evaṃ ahampīti attho. Aññathāsmīti idaṃ🔽pana asamato gahaṇaṃ; yathāyaṃ khattiyo, yathāyaṃ brāhmaṇo, tato aññathā ahaṃ hīno
analyzed: yathā ayam khattiyaḥ yathā ayam brāhmaṇaḥ evam aham pi iti atthaḥ aññathā asmi iti idam  pana asamataḥ gahaṇam yathā ayam khattiyaḥ yathā ayam brāhmaṇaḥ tatas aññathā aham hīnaḥ
translated: the meaning being, “Just as this man is a warrior, just as this man is a brahmin, so am I.” “I am otherwise” is the kind of apprehension

original: vā adhiko vāti attho. Imāni tāva paccuppannavasena cattāri taṇhāvicaritāni. Bhavissantiādīni
analyzed: vā adhikaḥ vā ti attho imāni tāva paccuppanna vasena cattāri taṇhā vicaritāni bhavissanti ādīni
translated: that takes something as a basis by way of inequality, the meaning being, “Just as this man is a warrior, just as this man is a brahmin, I am inferior to them or superior to them.” These are the four kinds of activity of craving in the present.

original: pana cattāri anāgatavasena vuttāni. Sesaṃ purimacatukke vuttanayeneva attho veditabbo.
analyzed: pana cattāri anāgata vasena vuttāni sesam purima catukke vutta nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The four beginning with “will be” are stated by way of the future. The meaning of the rest should be understood in the way already stated in the first tetrad.🔽“I am” is eternalism. “I am happy” is annihilationism. The reading is also “I am not” and “I am happy.”

original: Asmīti sassato asmi. Sātasmīti asassato asmi. Asasmīti satasmīti vā pāṭho. Tattha
analyzed: asmi iti sassataḥ asmi sātasmi iti a sassataḥ asmi a sasmi iti satasmi iti vā pāṭhaḥ tattha
translated: Herein,

original: atthīti asaṃ; niccassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Sīdatīti sataṃ; aniccassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: atthi iti asam niccassa etam adhivacanam sīdati iti satam aniccassa etam adhivacanam
translated: “It is” is eternalism, a term for permanence. “It perishes” is annihilationism, a term for impermanence.

original: Iti imāni dve sassatucchedavasena vuttānīti veditabbāni. Ito parāni siyantiādīni🔽cattāri saṃsayaparivitakkavasena vuttāni. Tāni purimacatukke vuttanayeneva atthato🔽veditabbāni. Apāhaṃ siyantiādīni pana cattāri “api nāmāhaṃ bhaveyya”nti evaṃ patthanākappanavasena
analyzed: iti imāni dve vuttāni iti veditabbāni itas parāni siyanti ādīni  cattāri saṃsaya parivitakka vasena vuttāni tāni purima catukke vutta nayena iva atthato  veditabbāni apāham siyanti ādīni pana cattāri api nāma aham bhaveyyanti evam patthanā kappana vasena
translated: So these two are stated in terms of eternalism and annihilationism. The next four, beginning with “I may be” ,🔽are stated in terms of doubt and wavering. They should be understood in the same way as the first four. The next four, beginning with “I may not be” ,

original: vuttāni. Tāni purimacatukke vuttanayeneva veditabbāni. Evametesu –
analyzed: vuttāni tāni purima catukke vutta nayena iva veditabbāni evam etesu
translated: are stated in terms of the wish and the assumption “I might exist.” They should be understood in the same way as the first four. Thus,

original: Dve diṭṭhisīsā cattāro, suddhasīsā sīsamūlakā;
analyzed: dve diṭṭhisīsā cattāro suddhasīsā sīsamūlakā
translated: Two with views for their heads, four pure-headed, and headed with the root,

original: Tayo tayoti etāni, aṭṭhārasa vibhāvaye.
analyzed: etāni aṭṭhārasa vibhāvaye
translated: Three, three—these should be analyzed As eighteen in this way.

original: Etesu hi sassatucchedavasena vuttā dve diṭṭhisīsā nāma. Asmīti, bhavissanti, siyanti,
analyzed: etesu hi sassatu cheda vasena vuttā dve diṭṭhisīsā nāma asmi iti bhavissanti siyanti
translated: Herein, the two stated in terms of eternalism and annihilationism are called “with views for their heads.” “I am” , “I will be” , “I may be” ,

original: apāhaṃ siyanti ete cattāro suddhasīsāeva. Itthasmīti ādayo tayo tayoti dvādasa sīsamūlakā
analyzed: ete cattāro ete cattāro suddha sīsā eva itthasmi iti ādayo tayo tayo ti dvādasa sīsa mūlakā
translated: and “I may not be” are the four pure-headed . “Thus I am” , etc., are the three, three, that is, the twelve headed with the root.

original: nāmāti. Evamete dve diṭṭhisīsā, cattāro suddhasīsā, dvādasa sīsamūlakāti aṭṭhārasa
analyzed: nāma ati evam ete dve diṭṭhi sīsā cattāro suddha sīsā dvādasa sīsa mūlakā ati aṭṭhārasa
translated: thus these two with the view-head make three, and with the four pure-head and twelve root-head make fifteen.

original: taṇhāvicaritadhammā veditabbā.
analyzed: taṇhā vicarita dhammā veditabbā
translated: These are the eighteen dhammas that occur in the three rounds of relishing.

original: 974. Idāni paṭipāṭiyāva te dhamme bhājetvā dassetuṃ kathañca asmīti hotītiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: idāni paṭipāṭiya ava te dhamme bhājetvā dassetum kathañca asmi iti hoti itiādi āraddham
translated: Now, in order to show them by dividing them into two sets, the text begins with the words, “And how is it that there is ‘I am’? ”

original: Tattha kañci dhammaṃ anavakāriṃ karitvāti rūpavedanādīsu kañci ekadhammampi avinibbhogaṃ🔽katvā, ekekato aggahetvā, samūhatova gahetvāti attho. Asmīti chandaṃ paṭilabhatīti
analyzed: tattha kañci dhammam anavakārim karitvā ati rūpa vedanā ādīsu kañci eka dhammam pi a vinibbhogam  katvā ekekataḥ aggahetvā samūhataḥ iva gahetvā ati atthaḥ asmi iti chandam paṭilabhati iti
translated: Herein, having made some dhamma unseparated means having made some single dhamma among the forms, feelings, etc., unseparated,

original: pañcakkhandhe niravasesato gahetvā ‘aha’nti taṇhaṃ paṭilabhati. Mānadiṭṭhīsupi eseva
analyzed: pañca kkhandhe niravasesataḥ gahetvā ahanti taṇham paṭilabhati māna diṭṭhīsu pi esā eva
translated: having taken it without dividing it into ones, the meaning is, having taken it as a whole. He obtains will in “I am” means he obtains craving in “I am” by taking the five aggregates without remainder. The same method applies in the case of conceit and views.

original: nayo. Tattha kiñcāpi ayaṃ taṇhāvicaritaniddeso, mānadiṭṭhiyo pana na vinā taṇhāya,
analyzed: tattha kiñcā api ayam taṇhā vicarita niddeso māna diṭṭhiyaḥ pana na vinā taṇhāya
translated: Herein, although this is a description of the rounds of relishing, still conceit and views do not occur without craving,

original: tasmā tadekaṭṭhavasena idha vuttā. Taṇhāsīsena vā papañcattayampi uddiṭṭhaṃ. Taṃ
analyzed: tasmā tad eka aṭṭha vasena idha vuttā taṇhā sīsena vā uddiṭṭham taṃ
translated: and so they are mentioned here as a unity. Or the three kinds of insistence are also mentioned by the head of craving.

original: uddesānurūpeneva niddisitumpi mānadiṭṭhiyo gahitā. Taṇhāpapañcaṃ vā dassento teneva🔽saddhiṃ sesapapañcepi dassetuṃ evamāha.🔽Tasmiṃ sati imāni papañcitānīti tasmiṃ “asmīti chandaṃ paṭilabhatī”tiādinā nayena vutte papañcattaye sati puna imāni “itthasmīti vā”tiādīni papañcitāni hontīti attho.
analyzed: uddesa anurūpena iva niddisitum pi māna diṭṭhiyaḥ gahitā taṇhā papañcam vā dassento tena iva  saddhim sesa papañce pi dassetum evam āha  tasmin sati imāni papañcitāni iti tasmin asmi iti chandam paṭilabhati itiādinā nayena vutte papañcattaye sati punar imāni itthasmi iti vā ati ādīni papañcitāni honti iti atthaḥ
translated: and the conceit-ridden views are included by the description in terms of the three conceivings.🔽Or else, showing the proliferation of craving, he says this in order to show the rest of the proliferation together with that.🔽The meaning is: with the existence of that, these are proliferated. With the existence of the triad of conceivings stated in the way beginning, “He conceives on account of desire,” these are further proliferated as “I am such and such.”

original: Khattiyosmītiādīsu abhisekasenāmaccādinā ‘khattiyo ahaṃ’, mantajjhena porohiccādinā🔽‘brāhmaṇo ahaṃ’, kasigorakkhādinā ‘vesso ahaṃ’, asitabyābhaṅgitāya ‘suddo ahaṃ’,🔽gihibyañjanena ‘gahaṭṭho aha’nti iminā nayena attho veditabbo. Evaṃ itthasmīti hotīti
analyzed: khattiyaḥ asmi itiādīsu abhiseka senā macca ādinā khattiyaḥ aham porohit ca ādinā  brāhmaṇaḥ aham kasi gorakkha ādinā vessaḥ aham asita byābhaṅgi tāya suddo aham  gihi byañjanena gahaṭṭhaḥ aham ti iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbo evam itthasmi iti hoti iti
translated: In the passage beginning, “I am a warrior-noble,” etc., the meaning should be understood in this way: “I am a warrior-noble” by virtue of the consecration, the army, the ministers, etc.;🔽“I am a brahmin” by virtue of the sacrificial bath, the sacrificial cord, etc.;

original: evaṃ khattiyādīsu khattiyādippakāraṃ attani uppādayitvā ‘itthaṃpakāro aha’nti hoti.
analyzed: evam khattiya ādīsu khattiya ādi ppakāram attani uppādayitvā itthaṃpakāraḥ ahanti hoti
translated: “I am a merchant” by virtue of buying and selling, etc.; “I am a worker” by virtue of the craft of wood-working, etc.; “I am a divine” by virtue of the divine ancestry, etc.; “I am a human” by virtue of the human ancestry, etc.; “I am a householder” by virtue of the householder’s characteristics, etc.; “I am a monastic” by virtue of the monastic’s characteristics, etc.; “I am a woman” by virtue of the female sex, etc.; “I am a man” by virtue of the male sex, etc.; “I am young” by virtue of the youthfulness, etc.; “I am old” by virtue of the agedness, etc.; “I am healthy” by virtue of the state of health, etc.; “I am sick” by virtue of the state of sickness, etc.; “I am happy” by virtue of the state of happiness, etc.; “I am miserable” by virtue of the state of misery, etc.; “I am a non-returner” by virtue of the non-returner’s characteristics, etc.; “I am a once-returner” by virtue of the once-returner’s characteristics, etc.; “I am a stream-enterer” by virtue of the stream-enterer’s characteristics, etc.; “I am a worldling” by virtue of the worldling’s characteristics, etc.; “I am a Buddha” by virtue of the Buddha’s characteristics, etc.; “I am a paccekabuddha” by virtue of the paccekabuddha’s characteristics,

original: Yathā so khattiyotiādīsu ‘yathā so abhisekasenāmaccādinā khattiyo, tathā ‘ahampi🔽khattiyo’ti iminā nayena attho veditabbo. Dutiyanaye ‘yathā so abhisekasenāmaccādinā🔽khattiyo, nāhaṃ tathā khattiyo; ahaṃ pana tato hīno vā seṭṭho vā’ti iminā nayena
analyzed: yathā saḥ khattiyaḥ iti ādīsu yathā saḥ abhiseka senā macca ādinā khattiyaḥ tathā aham pi  khattiyaḥ ti iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ dutiya naye yathā saḥ abhiseka senā macca ādinā  khattiyaḥ na aham tathā khattiyaḥ aham pana tatas hīnaḥ vā seṭṭhaḥ vā ati iminā nayena
translated: As in the case of the khattiya, etc., the meaning should be understood in the way in which it is stated in the following passage: “Just as he is a khattiya because of his consecration with the sprinkling of water, so am I a khattiya. ” In the second method, the meaning should be understood in the way in which it is stated in the following passage: “Just as he is a khattiya because of his consecration with the sprinkling of water, so am I not a khattiya; but I am either inferior or superior to him. ” In the third method, the meaning should be understood in the way in which it is stated in the following passage: “Just as he is a khattiya because of his consecration with the sprinkling of water, so am I a khattiya. ”

original: attho veditabbo. Bhavissantiādiniddesādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽975. Evaṃ ajjhattikassa upādāya taṇhāvicaritāni bhājetvā idāni bāhirassa upādāya🔽taṇhāvicaritāni bhājetuṃ tattha katamānītiādimāha. Tattha bāhirassa upādāyāti bāhiraṃ🔽khandhapañcakaṃ upādāya. Idampi hi upayogatthe sāmivacanaṃ. Imināti iminā rūpena
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ bhavissanti ādi niddesa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ  evam ajjhattikassa upādāya taṇhā vicaritāni bhājetvā idāni bāhirassa upādāya  taṇhā vicaritāni bhājetum tattha katamāni iti ādim āha tattha bāhirassa upādāya ati bāhiram  khandha pañcakam upādāya idam pi hi upayoga tthe sāmi vacanam iminā ati iminā rūpena
translated: As in the case of the khattiya, etc., the meaning should be understood in this way: “Just as he is a khattiya by birth, by a title of respect, by insig-nia, by a portion of the property, and by the chief queen’s son, so am I too a khattiya.” In the second method the meaning should be understood in this way: “Just as he is a khattiya by birth, by a title of respect, by insignia, by a portion of the property, and by the chief queen’s son, so I am not a khattiya in all these ways; but I am either inferior to him in all these ways or superior to him in all these ways.” The same method should be applied to the exposition beginning with “there will be” .

original: vā…pe… viññāṇena vā. Avasesaṃ pana uddesavāre tāva vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vāpe viññāṇena vā avasesam pana uddesa vāre tāva vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: Having thus distinguished the kinds of craving in the case of the internal as object, he now said, “Herein, what is craving in the case of the external as object? “ in order to distinguish the kinds of craving in the case of the external as object. Herein, in the case of the external as object: in the case of the external five aggregates as object. This too is a possessive adjective. By this: by this visible form, etc., or by this consciousness. The rest should be understood in the way already stated in the section on the exposition .

original: 976. Niddesavāre pana avakāriṃ karitvāti vinibbhogaṃ katvā. Iminā asmīti chandaṃ🔽paṭilabhatītiādīsu iminā rūpena vā…pe… viññāṇena vāti evaṃ pañcakkhandhe ekadesato🔽gahetvā iminā ‘aha’nti chandādīni paṭilabhatīti evamattho veditabbo.
analyzed: niddesavāre pana avakārim karitvā ati vinibbhogam katvā iminā asmi iti chandam  paṭilabhati iti ādīsu iminā rūpena vāpe viññāṇena vā ati evam pañca kkhandhe ekadesato  gahetvā iminā ahanti chanda ādīni paṭilabhati iti evamatthaḥ veditabbo
translated: In the passages beginning, “He obtains will in this,”🔽the meaning should be understood as follows: “Having taken the five aggregates as one lump in this way, ‘by this form, etc., or by this consciousness,’ he obtains will, etc., in this ‘I am’ ” .

original: Iminā khattiyosmītiādīsu ‘iminā chattena vā khaggena vā abhisekasenāmaccādinā vā khattiyo aha’nti evaṃ purimanayeneva attho veditabbo. Imināti padamattameva hettha viseso.
analyzed: iminā khattiyaḥ asmi iti ādīsu iminā chattena vā khaggena vā abhiseka senā macca ādinā vā khattiyaḥ ahan ti evam purima nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbaḥ iminā ti pada mattam eva ha ittha visesaḥ
translated: In the passages beginning, “He is of the will in this I am a warrior,” etc., the meaning should be understood in the same way as before, thus: “By this umbrella, by this sword, by this consecration, by this retinue of soldiers, by this state of being a commander, I am a warrior.” The only difference is the word “this.”🔽In the passages beginning, “As he is a warrior,” etc., the only difference is the word “this” that is used. Therefore,

original: Yathā so khattiyotiādīsupi imināti vuttapadameva viseso. Tasmā tassa vasena yathā
analyzed: yathā saḥ khattiyaḥ ti ādīsu pi iminā ati vutta padam eva viseso tasmā tassa vasena yathā
translated: as he is a warrior,

original: khattiyo, evaṃ ahampi iminā khaggena vā chattena vā abhisekasenāmaccādinā vā khattiyoti
analyzed: khattiyaḥ evam aham pi iminā khaggena vā chattena vā abhiseka senā macca ādinā vā khattiya iti
translated: so by this sword, by this umbrella, by this consecration, by this retinue of soldiers, by this state of being a commander, I am a warrior.

original: evaṃ yojetvā sabbapadesu attho veditabbo. Iminā niccosmīti pañcakkhandhe anavakāriṃ
analyzed: evam yojetvā sabba padesu atthaḥ veditabbaḥ iminā niccaḥ asmi iti pañca kkhandhe anavakārim
translated: Having thus combined the passages, the meaning should be understood in all the passages. In the passages beginning, “He is of the will in this I am permanent,” etc., the five aggregates are not made into a basis.

original: katvā rūpādīsu ekameva dhammaṃ ‘aha’nti gahetvā ‘iminā khaggena vā chattena vā ahaṃ
analyzed: katvā rūpa ādīsu ekam eva dhammam ahanti gahetvā iminā khaggena vā chattena vā aham

analyzed: niccaḥ dhuvaḥ ti maññati uccheda diṭṭhiyam pi esa iva nayo sesam sabbattha vutta nayena iva veditabbam  iti evarūpāni atītāni chattiṃsā ati ekekassa puggalassa atīte chattiṃsa anāgatāni  chattiṃsa ati ekekassa iva anāgate chattiṃsa paccuppannāni chattiṃsa ati ekekassa vā puggalassa
translated: Having done so, he apprehends one of the dhammas beginning with visible form as the self, and he thinks: “By means of this sword or umbrella I am permanent, stable, eternal, not subject to change.” The same method applies to the annihilation view. The rest should be understood by the method stated everywhere.

original: yathālābhavasena bahunaṃ vā paccuppanne chattiṃsa. Sabbasattānaṃ pana ekaṃseneva🔽atīte chattiṃsa, anāgate chattiṃsa, paccuppanne chattiṃsāti veditabbāni. Anantā hi🔽asadisataṇhāmānadiṭṭhibhedā sattā. Aṭṭhataṇhāvicaritasataṃ hotīti ettha pana aṭṭhasatasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: yathā lābha vasena bahunam vā paccuppanne chattiṃsa sabba sattānam pana ekaṃsena eva  atīte chattiṃsa anāgate chattiṃsa paccuppanne chattiṃsa ati veditabbāni anantāḥ hi  asadisa taṇhā māna diṭṭhi bhedā sattā aṭṭha taṇhā vicarita satam hoti iti ettha pana aṭṭha sata saṅkhātam
translated: Thus there are thirty-six in the past for each individual. Thirty-six in the future are for each individual in the future. Thirty-six in the present are for each individual in the present, or for many according to the circumstances. But for all beings, without exception,🔽there are thirty-six in the past, thirty-six in the future, and thirty-six in the present. For beings are infinite in their differences of craving, conceit, and views.

original: taṇhāvicaritaṃ hotīti evamattho daṭṭhabbo. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.

translated: There are one hundred and eight kinds of craving for sensual pleasure. Here the meaning should be regarded in this way: there are one hundred and eight kinds of craving for sensual pleasure. The rest is clear everywhere.

original: 1. Sabbasaṅgāhikavāravaṇṇanā

translated: The third section is called the “section on the inclusion and non-inclusion of these dhammas in the sense spheres” . The fourth section is called the “section on the presence and absence of dhammas that arise at the moment of arising in the three planes” . The fifth section is called the “section on the presence and absence of these dhammas in the other planes” . The sixth section is called the “section on the kamma that produces the destinies, and on the measure of life in the destinies” .

original: diṭṭhasutādivasena saṅgahetvā dassanavāro nāma. Dasamo kusalattikādivasena saṅgahetvā dassanavāro nāma.
analyzed: diṭṭha suta ādi vasena saṅgahetvā dassanavāraḥ nāma dasamaḥ kusala ttika ādi vasena saṅgahetvā dassanavāraḥ nāma
translated: The seventh section is called the “section on the dhammas to be directly known, etc.” . The eighth section is called the “section on the objects and non-objects of the supramundane dhammas” . The ninth section is called the “section on the inclusion of the aggregates, etc., dhammas in the seen, heard, sensed, and cognized” . The tenth section is called the “section on the inclusion of the aggregates, etc., dhammas in the wholesome triad, etc.” .

original: 979. Evaṃ dasahi vārehi paricchinnāya pāḷiyā paṭhame tāva sabbasaṅgāhikavāre “avīcito

analyzed: puccha anurūpam vissajjanam āha yathāpuccham vissajjanam hi sabbaññu byākaraṇam nāma ati  vuccati dvādasa āyatanāni iti ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ rūpa kkhandha ādīnam pabhedaḥ khandha vibhaṅga ādīsu
translated: The answer to the question is called the answer of the Omniscient One.🔽The same method applies to the questions on the twelve bases, etc.

analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ

analyzed: vuttam rūpa dhātu ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ yasmā pana rūpa dhātu pariyāpannānam sattānam

analyzed: āyatanāni nava vuttam yasmā ca okāsa vasena vā sattu ppatti vasena  vā apariyāpanna dhātu nāma na atthi tasmai apariyāpanna dhātuyā ati avatvā yam yam a pariyāpannam

analyzed: tam tat eva dassetum apariyāpanne kati khandhā tiādi vuttam  pariyāpanna apariyāpanna vāra vaṇṇanā  tatiya vāre kāmadhātu pariyāpannā ati kāmadhātu bhajana ṭhena pariyāpannā tad nissitā  tad anta gadhā kāmadhātu tvā iva saṅkham gatā ati attho sesa padesu pi esā iva nayo pariyāpannā ti
translated: And since there is no element that is not included either as a location or as a rebirth-linking, therefore, instead of saying “In the not-included dhammas there are …,” it is shown by the words “In the not-included aggregates, etc.”🔽The exposition of the included and not-included

analyzed: bhava vasena okāsa vasena ca tathā aparicchinnā
translated: In the third section, “in the dhammas included in the sense sphere” means in the dhammas included in the sense sphere as the physical basis. The meaning is: in the sense sphere itself, which is so called because it is dependent on that and is included within it. The same method applies to the other terms. “Included” means limited by the occurrence of becoming and by the location. “Not included” means not so limited.

original: 4. Dhammadassanavāravaṇṇanā🔽1007. Catutthavāre ekādasāyatanānīti saddāyatanavajjāni. Tañhi ekantena paṭisandhiyaṃ🔽nuppajjati. Iminā nayena sabbattha attho veditabbo. Sattake “devānaṃ asurāna”nti🔽gativasena avatvā avisesena gabbhaseyyakānanti vuttaṃ. Tasmā yattha yattha gabbhaseyyakā🔽sambhavanti tattha tattha tesaṃ sattāyatanāni veditabbāni. Tathā dhātuyo. Sesamettha
analyzed: dhamma dassana vāra vaṇṇanā  catuttha vāre ekādasa āyatanāni iti sadda āyatana vajjāni tat hi ekantena paṭisandhiyam  nuppajjati iminā nayena sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ sattake devānam asurānam ti  gati vasena avatvā avisesena gabbhaseyyakānam ti vuttam tasmā yattha yattha gabbhaseyyakā  sambhavanti tattha tattha tesam satta āyatanāni veditabbāni tathā dhātuyaḥ sesam ettha
translated: 4. The exposition of the section on seeing ideas

original: uttānatthameva. Pañcamavāre yaṃ vattabbaṃ taṃ dhammasaṅgahaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttameva.
analyzed: uttāna attham eva pañcama vāre yam vattabbam tat dhammasaṅgahaṭṭhakathāyam vuttam eva
translated: In the fourth section, “the eleven bases” are the eye, etc., omitting the sound base. For that arises only in rebirth-linking. Therefore the eleven bases of those who are born in the womb should be understood wherever they are appropriate. So too the elements. The rest is clear in meaning. What should be said about the fifth section has already been said in the Description of the Compendium of Ideas.

analyzed: sammuti devā ati devaḥ devī iti evam loka sammutiyāḥ devāḥ upapatti devāḥ ati deva loke uppanna ttā

analyzed: upapattiyāḥ devāḥ visuddhi devā ti sabbesam devānam pūjā rahā sabba kilesa visuddhiyāḥ devāḥ
translated: Gods by rebirth: gods by rebirth in the divine world. Pure gods: gods purified from all defilements, worthy of offerings from all.

analyzed: rājānoti muddha abhisitta khattiyāḥ deviyoti tesam mahesiyaḥ kumārāḥ ati abhisitta rājūnam  kucchismiṃ uppanna kumārā
translated: Kings: kings anointed on the head. Queens: their chief wives. Princes: princes born from the womb of an anointed king’s anointed queen.

original: Uposathakammaṃ katvāti cātuddasādīsu aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā. Idāni
analyzed: uposatha kammam katvā ati cātuddasa ādīsu aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam uposatham upavasitvā idāni
translated: Having performed the Uposatha duties: having observed the Uposatha with its eight factors on the fourteenth day of the lunar half-month, etc. Now,

analyzed: yasmai paritta dāna ādi puñña kammam manussa sobhagya tāya paccayaḥ mattasaḥ katam manussa sobhagya tāya

analyzed: adhimattam adhimatta bhāve pi nānā pakāra bhedataḥ nānā pakārassa khattiya mahāsāla ādi bhāvassa

analyzed: paccayaḥ tasmā tassa vasena upapatti bhedam dassentaḥ appekacce gahapati mahāsālānaṃ ti ādim āha
translated: Therefore, in order to show the different kinds of rebirth that are due to that, he said: “Some, as great land-owners,” etc.

original: Tattha mahāsāro etesanti mahāsārā; ra-kārassa pana la-kāraṃ katvā mahāsālāti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tattha mahāsāro etesan ti mahāsārā rakārassa pana lakāram katvā mahāsālā ati vuttam
translated: Herein, they have great wealth, thus they are great land-owners . But by changing the ra to la, they are called great land-owners .

analyzed: gahapatiyaḥ iva mahāsālā gahapatīsu vā mahāsālā ati gahapati mahāsālā sesesu pi esā iva  tattha yassa gehe pacchimantena cattālīsa koṭi dhanam nidhāna gatam hoti  pañca ambaṇāni divasa vaḷañjaḥ nikkhamati ayam gahapatimahāsālaḥ nāma yassa pana  gehe pacchimantena asīti koṭi dhanam nidhāna gatam hoti dasa ambaṇāni
translated: The great house-owners are the great house-holders, or the great house-holders are among the house-holders. The same method in the rest. But one who has at least eighty koṭis of treasure stored away in his house, and who has ten ambaṇas of kahāpaṇas coming in daily as interest,

original: divasavaḷañjo nikkhamati – ayaṃ brāhmaṇamahāsālo nāma. Yassa pana gehe pacchimantena🔽koṭisatadhanaṃ nidhānagataṃ hoti, kahāpaṇānañca vīsati ambaṇāni divasavaḷañjo nikkhamati🔽– ayaṃ khattiyamahāsālo nāma.
analyzed: divasa vaḷañjaḥ nikkhamati ayam brāhmaṇamahāsālaḥ nāma yassa pana gehe pacchimantena  koṭi sata dhanam nidhāna gatam hoti vīsati ambaṇāni divasa vaḷañjaḥ nikkhamati  ayam khattiyamahāsālaḥ nāma

Herein, one who has at least forty koṭis of treasure stored away in his house and who has at least five ambaṇas of kahāpaṇas coming in daily as interest is called a great house-father. But one who has at least eighty koṭis of treasure stored away in his house and who has at least ten ambaṇas of kahāpaṇas coming in daily as interest is called a great brahmin. But one who has at least a hundred koṭis of treasure stored away in his house and who has at least twenty ambaṇas of kahāpaṇas coming in daily as interest is called a great noble.

original: Sahabyatanti sahabhāvaṃ; sabhāgā hutvā nibbattantīti attho. Cātumahārājikānantiādīsu
analyzed: sahabyatanti sahabhāvam sabhāgāḥ hutvā nibbattanti iti attho cātumahārājikānanti ādīsu
translated: ‘Companionship’ is the state of being a companion; the meaning is that they are reborn sharing the same fortune. In the case of the ‘Four Kings’ gods and so on,

original: cātumahārājikā nāma sinerupabbatassa vemajjhe honti. Tesu pabbataṭṭhakāpi atthi,🔽ākāsaṭṭhāpi; tesaṃ paramparā cakkavāḷapabbataṃ pattā. Khiḍḍāpadosikā, manopadosikā,
analyzed: cātumahārājikāḥ nāma sineru pabbatassa vemajjhe honti tesu pabbata ṭṭhakā api atthi  ākāsaṭṭhā api tesam paramparā cakkavāḷa pabbatam pattā khiḍḍā padosikā manaḥ padosikā
translated: The Four Great Kings are in the middle of Sineru. Some of them live in the mountains,🔽some in the air. Their line extends to the Cakkavāḷa mountains. The following are all in the world of the Four Great Kings: the Kīḷā, Padosika, Manopadosika,

original: sītavalāhakā, uṇhavalāhakā, candimā devaputto, sūriyo devaputtoti ete sabbepi cātumahārājikadevalokaṭṭhakā eva.
analyzed: sītavalāhakāḥ uṇhavalāhakā candimā devaputto sūriyo devaputto ti ete sabbe pi cātumahārājika deva loka ṭṭhakāḥ eva
translated: Sītavalāhaka, Uṇhavalāhaka, Canda, and Sūriya gods.

original: Tettiṃsa janā tattha upapannāti tāvatiṃsā. Apica tāvatiṃsāti tesaṃ devānaṃ nāmamevāti
analyzed: tettiṃsa janā tattha upapannā ati tāvatiṃsāḥ apica tāvatiṃsā ati tesam devānam nāmam eva ati
translated: Thirty-three persons arose there, thus they are Tāvatiṃsas. Moreover, Tāvatiṃsa is the name of those gods.

original: vuttaṃ. Tepi atthi pabbataṭṭhakā, atthi ākāsaṭṭhakā. Tesaṃ paramparā cakkavāḷapabbataṃ🔽pattā. Tathā yāmādīnaṃ. Ekadevalokepi hi devānaṃ paramparā cakkavāḷapabbataṃ appattā
analyzed: vuttam te pi atthi pabbata ṭṭhakāḥ atthi ākāsa ṭṭhakā tesam paramparā cakkavāḷa pabbatam  pattā tathā yāma ādīnam eka deva loke pi hi devānam paramparā cakkavāḷa pabbatam appattā
translated: Some of them live in the mountains, some in the air. Their line extends to the Cakkavāḷa mountains.🔽So it is with the Yāma gods and the rest. In fact, there is no single god in any of the worlds who does not extend his line to the Cakkavāḷa mountains.

original: nāma natthi. Tattha dibbaṃ sukhaṃ yātā payātā sampattāti yāmā. Tuṭṭhā pahaṭṭhāti
analyzed: nāma na atthi tattha dibbam sukham yātā payātā sampattā ati yāmā tuṭṭhā pahaṭṭhā ati
translated: Here, the Yāma gods have gone, are going, and will go to divine bliss, thus they are Yāma. They are satisfied, thus they are Tuṭṭha.

original: tusitā. Pakatipaṭiyattārammaṇato atirekena ramitukāmakāle yathārucite bhoge nimminitvā🔽ramantīti nimmānaratī. Cittācāraṃ ñatvā parehi nimmitesu bhogesu vasaṃ vattentīti
analyzed: tusitā pakati paṭiyatta ārammaṇataḥ atirekena ramitu kāma kāle yathā rucite bhoge nimminitvā  ramanti iti nimmāna ratī citta ācāram ñatvā parehi nimmitesu bhogesu vasam vattenti iti
translated: The Tusita gods. They delight in creating and using for themselves, at the time of their desire for more than the natural creation, the kinds of enjoyments they choose.🔽They delight in creating and using for themselves the kinds of enjoyments created by others, after knowing the mental behaviour of others.

original: paranimmitavasavattī.
analyzed: para nimmita vasa vattī
translated: They are called Paranimmitavasavatti gods because they are masters of the creations of others.

original: (2.) Āyuppamāṇaṃ
analyzed: āyu pamāṇam
translated: The measure of life

original: 1022. Appaṃ vā bhiyyoti dutiyaṃ vassasataṃ appatvā vīsāya vā tiṃsāya vā cattālīsāya🔽vā paññāsāya vā saṭṭhiyā vā vassehi adhikampi vassasatanti attho. Sabbampi hetaṃ
analyzed: appam vā bhiyyo ti dutiyam vassa satam appatvā vīsāya vā tiṃsāya vā cattālīsāya  vā paññāsāya vā saṭṭhiyā vā vassehi adhikam pi vassa satam ti attho sabbam pi ha etam
translated: . The meaning is that it is not less than a hundred years, but it is less than two hundred years, and it is not less than twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, or sixty years.

original: dutiyaṃ vassasataṃ appattattā appanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dutiyam vassa satam appattattā appanti vuttam
translated: And all this is said to be “less” because it is less than two hundred years.🔽The Brahmapārisajja gods are the attendants of the Great Brahmās.

original: 1024. Brahmapārisajjādīsu mahābrahmānaṃ pārisajjā paricārikāti brahmapārisajjā. Tesaṃ
analyzed: brahma pārisajja ādīsu mahābrahmānam pārisajjā paricārikā ati brahmapārisajjā tesam
translated: They are called Brahmapārisajja gods because they are the attendants of the Great Brahmās.🔽They are called Brahmapurohita gods because they are the chaplains of the Great Brahmās.

original: purohitabhāve ṭhitāti brahmapurohitā. Vaṇṇavantatāya ceva dīghāyukatāya ca mahanto
analyzed: purohita bhāve brahma purohitāḥ vaṇṇavanta tāya ca iva dīghāyuka tāya ca mahantaḥ
translated: The Great Brahmās are called Great Brahmās because they are of great beauty and have a long life.

original: brahmāti mahābrahmā, tesaṃ mahābrahmānaṃ. Ime tayopi janā paṭhamajjhānabhūmiyaṃ ekatale
analyzed: brahmā ati mahābrahmā tesam mahābrahmānam ime janā eka tale
translated: These three kinds of gods are on the same plane as the first jhāna.

original: vasanti; āyuantaraṃ pana nesaṃ nānā.
analyzed: vasanti āyu antaram pana nānā
translated: but their life-span is different.

original: 1025. Parittā ābhā etesanti parittābhā. Appamāṇā ābhā etesanti appamāṇābhā. Daṇḍadīpikāya🔽acci viya etesaṃ sarīrato ābhā chijjitvā chijjitvā patantī viya sarati visaratīti
analyzed: parittāḥ ābhāḥ etesanti paritta ābhāḥ appamāṇāḥ ābhāḥ etesanti appamāṇa ābhāḥ daṇḍadīpikāya  acci viya etesam sarīrataḥ ābhā chijjitvā chijjitvā patantī viya sarati visarati iti
translated: They have limited radiance, thus they are Limited Radiance. They have immeasurable radiance, thus they are Immeasurable Radiance. Like a torch🔽flared up with a stick, their radiance goes forth, goes away, from their bodies, as if falling away and falling away, thus they are Radiant Ones. These three kinds of beings live on the same plane, namely, the plane of the second jhāna,

original: ābhassarā. Imepi tayo janā dutiyajjhānabhūmiyaṃ ekatale vasanti; āyuantaraṃ pana nesaṃ nānā.
analyzed: ābhassarāḥ ime pi tayaḥ janāḥ dutiya jhāna bhūmiyam eka tale vasanti āyu antaram pana nānā
translated: but their life-span is different.

original: 1026. Parittā subhā etesanti parittasubhā. Appamāṇā subhā etesanti appamāṇasubhā.🔽Subhena okiṇṇā vikiṇṇā, subhena sarīrappabhāvaṇṇena ekagghanā, suvaṇṇamañjusāya ṭhapitasampajjalitakañcanapiṇḍasassirīkāti
analyzed: parittā subhā etesanti paritta subhā appamāṇā subhā etesanti appamāṇa subhā  subhena okiṇṇā vikiṇṇā subhena sarīra ppabhā vaṇṇena ekagghanā ṭhapita sampajjalita kañcana piṇḍa sassirīkā ati
translated: They have limited beauty, thus they are Limited Beauty. They have immeasurable beauty, thus they are Immeasurable Beauty.🔽They are filled with beauty, pervaded by beauty, of one kind with beauty, like a mass of gold that is bright, pure, and well smelted, thus they are Beautiful Ones. These three kinds of beings live on the same plane, namely, the plane of the third jhāna,

original: subhakiṇhā. Imepi tayo janā tatiyajjhānabhūmiyaṃ ekatale vasanti; āyuantaraṃ pana nesaṃ nānā.
analyzed: ime api tayaḥ janā eka tale vasanti āyu antaram pana nānā
translated: but their life-span is different.

original: 1027. Ārammaṇanānattatāti ārammaṇassa nānattabhāvo. Manasikāranānattatādīsupi eseva
analyzed: ārammaṇa nānatta tā ti ārammaṇassa nānatta bhāvaḥ manasikāra nānatta tā ādīsu pi esā eva
translated: The diversity of objects: the diversity of the object.

original: nayo. Ettha ekassa pathavīkasiṇaṃ ārammaṇaṃ hoti…pe… ekassa odātakasiṇanti idaṃ ārammaṇanānattaṃ.🔽Eko pathavīkasiṇaṃ manasi karoti…pe… eko odātakasiṇanti idaṃ manasikāranānattaṃ.🔽Ekassa pathavīkasiṇe chando hoti…pe… ekassa odātakasiṇeti idaṃ chandanānattaṃ. Eko🔽pathavīkasiṇe patthanaṃ karoti…pe… eko odātakasiṇeti idaṃ paṇidhinānattaṃ. Eko pathavīkasiṇavasena
analyzed: ettha ekassa pathavī kasiṇam ārammaṇam hoti pe ekassa odāta kasiṇam ti idam ārammaṇa nānattam  ekaḥ pathavī kasiṇam manasi karoti pe ekaḥ odāta kasiṇanti idam manasikāra nānattam  ekassa pathavī kasiṇe chandaḥ hoti pe ekassa odāta kasiṇā iti idam chanda nānattam ekaḥ  pathavī kasiṇe patthanam karoti pe odāta kasiṇa iti idam paṇidhi nānattam
translated: One gives attention to the earth kasiṇa … one gives attention to the white kasiṇa. This is how there is diversity of giving attention.

original: adhimuccati…pe… eko odātakasiṇavasenāti idaṃ adhimokkhanānattaṃ. Eko pathavīkasiṇavasena
analyzed: ekaḥ odāta kasiṇa vasena ati idam adhimokkha nānattam ekaḥ pathavī kasiṇa vasena
translated: One has desire for the earth kasiṇa … one has desire for the white kasiṇa. This is how there is diversity of desire. One makes the wish for the earth kasiṇa … one makes the wish for the white kasiṇa. This is how there is diversity of wish. One resolves upon the earth kasiṇa … one resolves upon the white kasiṇa. This is how there is diversity of resolve. One directs the mind to the earth kasiṇa … one directs the mind to the white kasiṇa. This is how there is diversity of direction of the mind. One has understanding of the defining of the earth kasiṇa … one has understanding of the defining of the white kasiṇa. This is how there is diversity of understanding.🔽Herein, the diversity of object and the diversity of giving attention are the cause for the diversity of desire.

original: cittaṃ abhinīharati…pe… eko odātakasiṇavasenāti idaṃ abhinīhāranānattaṃ. Ekassa pathavīkasiṇaparicchindanakapaññā🔽hoti…pe… ekassa odātakasiṇaparicchindanakapaññāti idaṃ paññānānattaṃ. Tattha ārammaṇamanasikārā
analyzed: cittam abhinīharati pe ekaḥ odāta kasiṇa vasena ati idam abhinīhāra nānattam ekassa pathavī kasiṇa paricchindanaka paññā 🔽ekassa odāta kasiṇa paricchindanaka paññā ti idam paññā nānattam tattha ārammaṇa manasikārā
translated: The diversity of desire is the cause for the diversity of wish. The diversity of wish is the cause for the diversity of resolve. The diversity of resolve is the cause for the diversity of direction of the mind. The diversity of direction of the mind is the cause for the diversity of understanding.

original: pubbabhāgena kathitā. Chandapaṇidhiadhimokkhābhinīhārā appanāyapi vattanti upacārepi.
analyzed: pubba bhāgena kathitā chanda paṇidhi adhimokkha abhinīhārāḥ vattanti upacāre pi
translated: The first part is said of the access and of the absorption.

original: Paññā pana lokiyalokuttaramissakā kathitā.🔽Asaññasattānanti saññāvirahitānaṃ sattānaṃ. Ekacce hi titthāyatane pabbajitvā ‘cittaṃ
analyzed: paññā pana lokiya lokuttara missakā kathitā  asañña sattānam ti saññā virahitānam sattānam ekacce hi titthāyatane pabbajitvā cittam
translated: But understanding is said to be mundane and supramundane mixed.🔽In the case of the “beings without perception”: there are some who, after going forth in a sect of the Ājīvakas, see the danger in perception thus, “Lust, hatred, and delusion are rooted in perception;

original: nissāya rajjanadussanamuyhanāni nāma hontī’ti citte dosaṃ disvā ‘acittakabhāvo nāma
analyzed: nissāya rajjana dussana muyhanāni nāma honti iti citte dosam disvā acittaka bhāvaḥ nāma
translated: when there is perception, lust, hatred, and delusion occur; when there is no perception, lust, hatred, and delusion do not occur.

original: sobhano, diṭṭhadhammanibbānameta’nti saññāvirāgaṃ janetvā tatrūpagaṃ pañcamaṃ samāpattiṃ
analyzed: sobhanaḥ diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam etat ti saññā virāgam janetvā tatrūpagam pañcamam samāpattim
translated: The state without perception is peaceful, the state without perception is sublime,” and they generate the fifth kind of craving for the attainment of the non-percipient existence,

original: bhāvetvā tattha nibbattanti. Tesaṃ upapattikkhaṇe eko rūpakkhandhoyeva nibbattati.
analyzed: bhāvetvā tattha nibbattanti tesam upapatti kkhaṇe ekaḥ rūpakkhandho yeva nibbattati
translated: and they are reborn there. At the moment of their rebirth there only arises in them one material aggregate,

original: Ṭhatvā nibbatto ṭhitako eva hoti, nisīditvā nibbatto nisinnakova nipajjitvā nibbatto
analyzed: ṭhatvā nibbattaḥ ṭhitakaḥ eva hoti nisīditvā nibbattaḥ nisinnakaḥ va nipajjitvā nibbattaḥ
translated: and they remain there in that same posture in which they were reborn. If they were reborn sitting down, they remain there sitting; if they were reborn lying down, they remain there lying.

original: nipannova. Cittakammarūpakasadisā hutvā pañca kappasatāni tiṭṭhanti. Tesaṃ pariyosāne
analyzed: nipannaḥ uva citta kamma rūpaka sadisā hutvā pañca kappa satāni tiṭṭhanti tesam pariyosāne
translated: They are like a statue of a man made by an artist. They remain there for five hundred eons.

original: so rūpakāyo antaradhāyati, kāmāvacarasaññā uppajjati; tena idha saññuppādena te devā
analyzed: saḥ rūpa kāyaḥ antaradhāyati kāmāvacara saññā uppajjati tena idha saññuppādena te devā
translated: the material body disappears and perception of the sense-sphere arises.

original: tamhā kāyā cutāti paññāyanti.
analyzed: tamhā kāyā cutā ati paññāyanti
translated: By the arising of this perception, these gods are known as “departed from that body.”

original: Vipulā phalā etesanti vehapphalā. Attano sampattiyā na hāyanti na vihāyantīti avihā.
analyzed: vipulā phalā etesanti vehapphalā attanaḥ sampattiyā na hāyanti na vihāyanti iti a vihā
translated: The fruit of these is extensive: Vehapphala. They do not diminish, do not fail, in their own excellence: Aviha.

original: Na kañci sattaṃ tappantīti atappā. Sundarā dassanā abhirūpā pāsādikāti sudassā. Suṭṭha
analyzed: na kañci sattam tappanti iti atappā sundarā dassanā abhirūpā pāsādikā ati su dassā suṭṭha
translated: They do not torment any being: Atappa. They are beautiful to see, lovely, comely: Sudassa. They are seen

original: passanti, sundarametesaṃ vā dassananti sudassī. Sabbehi eva guṇehi ca bhavasampattiyā🔽ca jeṭṭhā, natthettha kaniṭṭhāti akaniṭṭhā.
analyzed: passanti sundaram etesam vā sudassī sabbehi eva guṇehi ca bhava sampattiyā  ca jeṭṭhā nattha ittha kaniṭṭhā ati akaniṭṭhā
translated: well, beautifully: Sudassi. They are the most excellent in all good qualities and in excellence of existence: Akanittha.

original: 1028. Ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upagatāti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā. Itaresupi eseva nayo. Iti
analyzed: ākāsa anañca āyatanam upagatā ati ākāsa anañca āyatana upagā itaresu pi iti
translated: They have attained the base consisting of boundless space: they have gone to the base consisting of boundless space. The same method applies in the other cases.

original: cha kāmāvacarā, nava brahmalokā, pañca suddhāvāsā, cattāro arūpā asaññasattavehapphalehi
analyzed: cha kāmāvacarā nava brahmalokā pañca suddhāvāsā cattāro arūpā asaññasatta vehapphalehi
translated: Thus there are twenty-six divine worlds: six sense-sphere divine worlds, nine Brahma worlds, five Pure Abodes, and four immaterial states, together with the Vehapphala gods.

original: saddhiṃ chabbīsati devalokā; manussalokena saddhiṃ sattavīsati.
analyzed: saddhim chabbīsati deva lokāḥ manussa lokena saddhim sattavīsati
translated: Together with the human world, there are twenty-seven.

original: Tattha sammāsambuddhena manussānaṃ devānañca āyuṃ paricchindamānena catūsu apāyesu
analyzed: tattha sammāsambuddhena manussānam devānam ca āyum paricchindamānena catūsu apāyesu
translated: Herein, when the Fully Enlightened One was delimiting the life-span of human beings and gods, he delimited the life-span in the four lower worlds of misery,

original: bhummadevesu ca āyu paricchinnaṃ taṃ kasmāti? Niraye tāva kammameva pamāṇaṃ. Yāva
analyzed: bhumma devesu ca āyu paricchinnam tam kasmāti niraye kammam eva pamāṇam yāva
translated: and among the earth gods, in this way. Why was that? In the hells, firstly, the life-span is a matter of kamma. As long as the kamma lasts,

original: kammaṃ na khīyati, na tāva cavanti. Tathā sesaapāyesu. Bhummadevānampi kammameva
analyzed: kammam na khīyati na tāva cavanti tathā sesa apāyesu bhumma devānam pi kammam eva
translated: so long do they not die. So too in the other worlds of misery. Among the earth gods the life-span is a matter of kamma.

original: pamāṇaṃ. Tattha nibbattā hi keci sattāhamattaṃ tiṭṭhanti, keci addhamāsaṃ, keci māsaṃ,
analyzed: pamāṇam tattha nibbattāḥ hi keci satta aha mattam tiṭṭhanti keci addha māsam keci māsam
translated: For some beings there are born there who live for a week, and some for a fortnight, and some for a month,

original: kappaṃ tiṭṭhamānāpi atthiyeva.
analyzed: kappam tiṭṭhamānā api atthiyā iva
translated: and some who live for an eon.

original: Tattha manussesu gihibhāve ṭhitāyeva sotāpannāpi honti, sakadāgāmiphalampi anāgāmiphalampi
analyzed: tattha manussesu gihi bhāve ṭhitāya iva sotāpannāḥ api honti sakadāgāmi phalam pi anāgāmi phalam pi
translated: Herein, among human beings, some become stream-enterers while still in the house-holder state, and they reach the fruit of once-returner, the fruit of non-returner,

original: arahattaphalampi pāpuṇanti. Tesu sotāpannādayo yāvajīvaṃ tiṭṭhanti. Khīṇāsavā pana
analyzed: arahatta phalam pi pāpuṇanti tesu sotāpanna ādayaḥ yāvajīvam tiṭṭhanti khīṇa āsavā pana
translated: and the fruit of arahantship. Of these, the stream-enterers and the others live as long as they have to do. But those whose cankers are destroyed

original: parinibbāyanti vā pabbajanti vā. Kasmā? Arahattaṃ nāma seṭṭhaguṇo, gihiliṅgaṃ hīnaṃ,
analyzed: parinibbāyanti vā pabbajanti vā kasmai arahattam nāma seṭṭha guṇaḥ gihi liṅgam hīnam
translated: either attain extinction or go forth. Why is that? The fruit of arahantship is the best quality,🔽and the mark of a layman is inferior.

original: taṃ hīnatāya uttamaṃ guṇaṃ dhāretuṃ na sakkoti. Tasmā te parinibbātukāmā vā pabbajitukāmā vā honti.
analyzed: tam hīna tāya uttamam guṇam dhāretum na sakkoti tasmā te parinibbātu kāmāḥ vā pabbajitu kāmāḥ vā honti
translated: and so they are unable to bear the highest quality, which is the noble fruit of arahantship. That is why they want to attain extinction or to go forth.

original: Bhummadevā pana arahattaṃ patvāpi yāvajīvaṃ tiṭṭhanti. Chasu kāmāvacaradevesu sotāpannasakadāgāmino
analyzed: bhummadevā pana arahattam patvā api yāvajīvam tiṭṭhanti chasu kāmāvacara devesu sotāpanna sakadāgāmino
translated: But the earth deities, even though they have reached arahantship, live on as long as they can. In the six sense-sphere divine worlds stream-enterers and once-returners

original: yāvajīvaṃ tiṭṭhanti; anāgāminā rūpabhavaṃ gantuṃ vaṭṭati, khīṇāsavena parinibbātuṃ.
analyzed: yāvajīvam tiṭṭhanti anāgāminā rūpa bhavam gantum vaṭṭati khīṇāsavena parinibbātum
translated: live on as long as they can, but non-returners can go to the fine-material world, and those whose cankers are destroyed can attain extinction.

original: Kasmā? Nilīyanokāsassa abhāvā. Rūpāvacarārūpāvacaresu sabbepi yāvajīvaṃ tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: kasmā nilīyana ukāsassa abhāvā rūpāvacara arūpāvacaresu sabbe pi yāvajīvam tiṭṭhanti
translated: Why? Because there is no place for seclusion there. But in the fine-material and immaterial worlds all of them live on as long as they can.

original: Tattha rūpāvacare nibbattā sotāpannasakadāgāmino na puna idhāgacchanti, tattheva
analyzed: tattha rūpāvacare nibbattā sotāpanna sakadāgāminaḥ na puna idha āgacchanti tattha eva
translated: Herein, stream-enterers and once-returners reborn in the fine-material world do not come back here again;

original: parinibbāyanti. Ete hi jhānaanāgāmino nāma.🔽Aṭṭhasamāpattilābhīnaṃ pana kiṃ niyameti? Paguṇajjhānaṃ. Yadevassa paguṇaṃ hoti,
analyzed: parinibbāyanti ete hi jhāna anāgāminaḥ nāma  aṭṭha samāpatti lābhīnam pana kim niyameti paguṇa jhānam paguṇam hoti
translated: they attain extinction there. These are called “non-returners by way of jhāna.”🔽But what determines those who have attained the eight attainments? The familiar jhāna. They are reborn in whichever jhāna is familiar to them.

original: tena uppajjati. Sabbesu pana paguṇesu kiṃ niyameti? Patthanā. Yattha upapattiṃ pattheti
analyzed: tena uppajjati sabbesu pana paguṇesu kim niyameti patthanā yattha upapattim pattheti
translated: But what determines those who have all the jhānas as familiar? The aspiration. They are reborn in whichever plane they aspire to.

original: tattheva upapajjati. Patthanāya asati kiṃ niyameti? Maraṇasamaye samāpannā samāpatti.
analyzed: tattha iva upapajjati patthanāya asati kim niyameti maraṇa samaye samāpannā samāpatti
translated: and he is reborn there. If there is no resolve, what determines his rebirth? The attainment he has entered at the time of death.

original: Maraṇasamaye samāpannā natthi, kiṃ niyameti? Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpatti. Ekaṃsena
analyzed: maraṇa samaye samāpannā na atthi kim niyameti nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpatti ekaṃsena
translated: If there is no attainment entered at the time of death, what determines his rebirth? The attainment of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. For he is reborn in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: hi so nevasaññānāsaññāyatane upapajjati. Navasu brahmalokesu nibbattaariyasāvakānaṃ
analyzed: hi so nevasaññānāsaññāyatane upapajjati navasu brahmalokesu nibbatta ariya sāvakānam
translated: But in the case of noble disciples reborn in the nine brahma-worlds,

original: tatrūpapattipi hoti uparūpapattipi na heṭṭhūpapatti. Puthujjanānaṃ pana tatrūpapattipi
analyzed: tatrūpapatti pi hoti uparūpapatti pi na heṭṭhūpapatti puthujjanānam pana tatrūpapatti pi
translated: there is rebirth there and rebirth higher up, not rebirth lower down. But in the case of ordinary men,

original: hoti uparūpapattipi heṭṭhūpapattipi. Pañcasu suddhāvāsesu catūsu ca arūpesu ariyasāvakānaṃ🔽tatrūpapattipi hoti uparūpapattipi. Paṭhamajjhānabhūmiyaṃ nibbatto anāgāmī nava brahmaloke
analyzed: hoti heṭṭhūpapatti pi pañcasu suddhāvāsesu catūsu ca arūpesu ariya sāvakānaṃ  hoti uparu upapatti pi paṭhama jhāna bhūmiyam nibbattaḥ anāgāmī nava brahmaloke
translated: there is rebirth there, there is rebirth higher up, and there is rebirth lower down. In the case of noble disciples reborn in the five Pure Abodes and in the four immaterial states,

original: sodhetvā matthake ṭhito parinibbāti. Vehapphalā, akaniṭṭhā, nevasaññānāsaññāyatananti
analyzed: sodhetvā matthake ṭhitaḥ parinibbāti vehapphalā akaniṭṭhā nevasaññānāsaññāyatananti
translated: there is rebirth there and rebirth higher up. But when a non-returner is reborn in the plane of the first jhāna, he attains Nibbāna after purifying the crest. The Vehapphala, the Akaniṭṭha, and the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception—🔽these three divine worlds are called the “best existences.” Non-returners reborn in these three places have no rebirth

original: ime tayo devalokā seṭṭhabhavā nāma. Imesu tīsu ṭhānesu nibbattaanāgāmino neva uddhaṃ
analyzed: ime tayaḥ deva lokā seṭṭhabhavāḥ nāma imesu tīsu ṭhānesu nibbatta anāgāminaḥ na iva uddham
translated: higher up.

original: gacchanti, na adho, tattha tattheva parinibbāyantīti. Idamettha pakiṇṇakaṃ.🔽7. Abhiññeyyādivāravaṇṇanā
analyzed: gacchanti na adhas tattha tattha iva parinibbāyanti iti idam ettha pakiṇṇakam
translated: they do not go down, but they are extinguished there and then. This is the excursus here.🔽The explanation of the section on what is to be directly known, etc.,

original: 1030. Sattamavāre salakkhaṇapariggāhikāya abhiññāya vasena abhiññeyyatā veditabbā.🔽Ñātatīraṇapahānapariññānaṃ vasena pariññeyyatā. Sā ca rūpakkhandho abhiññeyyo pariññeyyo
analyzed: sattama vāre sa lakkhaṇa pariggāhikāya abhiññāya vasena abhiññeyya tā veditabbā  ñāta tīraṇa pahāna pariññānam vasena pariññeyya tā sā ca rūpakkhandhaḥ abhiññeyyaḥ pariññeyyaḥ
translated: In the seventh section the state of being directly knowable should be understood in terms of the direct knowledge that is the act of discerning the specific characteristics .🔽The state of being fully understood should be understood in terms of the full-understanding as the act of discerning as suffering, as the act of discerning as arising, and as the act of discerning as abandoning.

original: na pahātabbotiādīsu ñātatīraṇapariññāvaseneva veditabbā. Samudayasaccaṃ abhiññeyyaṃ
analyzed: na pahātabbā uti ādīsu ñāta tīraṇa pariññā vasena iva veditabbā samudaya saccam abhiññeyyam
translated: And that should be understood in terms of the full-understanding as the act of discerning as suffering, as the act of discerning as arising, and as the act of discerning as abandoning, respectively, in the passages: “The form aggregate is to be directly known … is to be fully understood … is not to be abandoned” , etc.;

original: pariññeyyaṃ pahātabbantiādīsu pahānapariññāvasena.
analyzed: pariññeyyam pahātabbam tiādīsu pahāna pariññā vasena
translated: in terms of the full-understanding as the act of discerning as abandoning, in the passages: “The truth of suffering is to be directly known … is to be fully understood … is to be abandoned” , etc.;

original: Aṭṭhamavāre rūpādiārammaṇānaṃ cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ vasena sārammaṇānārammaṇatā veditabbā.
analyzed: aṭṭhama vāre rūpa ādi ārammaṇānam cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam vasena sārammaṇa anārammaṇa tā veditabbā
translated: In the eighth section the state of having an object and the state of being without an object should be understood in terms of eye-consciousness, etc., which have visible data, etc., as their objects.

original: Navamavāro uttānatthoyeva. Dasamavārepi yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā taṃ sabbaṃ tattha tattha
analyzed: navama vāraḥ uttāna tthaḥ yā iva dasama vāre pi yat vattabbam siyā tat sabbam tattha tattha
translated: The ninth section is self-evident. And in the tenth section whatever needs to be said has already been said here and there

original: pañhāpucchakavāre vuttamevāti.🔽Sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: pañhāpucchaka vāre vuttam eva ati  sammoha vinodaniyā vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya
translated: in the section on the questions.🔽The commentary on the exposition of the Dhamma-body

original: Dhammahadayavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dhamma hadaya vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: Nigamanakathā
analyzed: nigamana kathā
translated: The summing up

original: Ettāvatā ca –
analyzed: ettāvatā ca
translated: And thus far:

original: Abhidhammaṃ desento, dhammagaru dhammagāravayuttānaṃ;
analyzed: abhidhammam desentaḥ dhamma garu dhamma gārava yuttānam
translated: The Teacher of the Abhidhamma, the One Who Respects the Dhamma, the One Who Has the Dhamma as His Refuge,

original: Devānaṃ devapure, devagaṇasahassaparivāro.
analyzed: devānam deva pure deva gaṇa sahassa parivāro
translated: Surrounded by a thousand groups of gods, in the city of the gods,

original: Dutiyaṃ adutiyapuriso, yaṃ āha vibhaṅgapakaraṇaṃ nātho;
analyzed: dutiyam a dutiya purisaḥ yam āha vibhaṅga pakaraṇam
translated: The Second Man, the Lord, who spoke the Vibhaṅga-book,

original: Aṭṭhārasahi vibhaṅgehi, maṇḍitamaṇḍapeyyaguṇo.
analyzed: aṭṭhārasahi vibhaṅgehi maṇḍita maṇḍapeyya guṇaḥ
translated: Adorned with eighteen Vibhaṅgas, with the quality of being a jewel-like discourse,

original: Atthappakāsanatthaṃ, tassāhaṃ yācito ṭhitaguṇena;
analyzed: attha ppakāsana ttham tassa aham yācitaḥ ṭhita guṇena
translated: At the request of the One Who Stands Firm, the One Who Has the Good Qualities,

original: Yatinā adandhagatinā, subuddhinā buddhaghosena.
analyzed: yatinā adandhagatinā subuddhinā buddhaghosena
translated: The Sage, the One Who Has Gone Beyond, the One With Good Understanding, Buddhaghosa,

original: Yaṃ ārabhiṃ racayituṃ, aṭṭhakathaṃ sunipuṇesu atthesu;
analyzed: yam ārabhim racayitum aṭṭha katham su nipuṇesu atthesu
translated: I began to compose this commentary on the meaning of the very subtle meaning,

original: Sammohavinodanato, sammohavinodaniṃ nāma.
analyzed: sammohavinodanataḥ sammohavinodanim nāma
translated: In order to remove confusion, called the Sammohavinodani.

original: Porāṇaṭṭhakathānaṃ, sāraṃ ādāya sā ayaṃ niṭṭhaṃ;
analyzed: porāṇa aṭṭhakathānam sāram ādāya sā ayam niṭṭham
translated: Having taken the essence of the old commentaries, this was completed

original: Pattā anantarāyena, pāḷiyā bhāṇavārehi.
analyzed: pattāḥ anantarāyena pāḷiyāḥ bhāṇa vārehi
translated: Without hindrance, by the recitation of the text,

original: Cattālīsāya yathā, ekena ca evameva sabbepi;
analyzed: yathā ekena ca evam eva sabbe pi
translated: In forty chapters, just as in the case of the first, so too in the case of all,

original: Niṭṭhaṃ vajantu vimalā, manorathā sabbasattānaṃ.🔽Saddhammassa ṭhitatthaṃ, yañca imaṃ racayatā mayā puññaṃ;
analyzed: niṭṭham vajantu vimalāḥ manorathāḥ sabba sattānam  saddhammassa ṭhita ttham yat ca imam racayatā mayā puññam
translated: May the pure wishes of all beings be fulfilled.🔽And may the world together with the gods attain the fruit🔽Of the merit that has been made by me in composing this,

original: Pattaṃ tena samattaṃ, pāpuṇatu sadevako loko.
analyzed: pattam tena sa mattam pāpuṇatu sa devakaḥ lokaḥ
translated: For the sake of the establishment of the True Dhamma.

original: Suciraṃ tiṭṭhatu dhammo, dhammābhirato sadā bhavatu loko;
analyzed: su ciram tiṭṭhatu dhammaḥ dhamma abhirataḥ sadā bhavatu lokaḥ
translated: May the Dhamma endure long, and may the world always delight in the Dhamma.

original: Niccaṃ khemasubhikkhādi-sampadā janapadā hontūti.
analyzed: niccam khema subhikkha ādi sampadāḥ janapadāḥ hontu iti
translated: May the country be prosperous, peaceful, and so on.🔽He was adorned with the most pure faith, understanding, and energy.

original: Paramavisuddhasaddhābuddhivīriyapaṭimaṇḍitena sīlācārajjavamaddavādiguṇasamudayasamuditena
analyzed: parama visuddha saddhā buddhi vīriya paṭimaṇḍitena sīla ācāra java maddava ādi guṇa samudaya samuditena
translated: He was endowed with the qualities of virtue, conduct, speed, gentleness, and so on.

original: sakasamayasamayantaragahanajjhogāhaṇasamatthena paññāveyyattiyasamannāgatena tipiṭakapariyattippabhede🔽sāṭṭhakathe satthusāsane appaṭihatañāṇappabhāvena mahāveyyākaraṇena karaṇasampattijanitasukhaviniggatamadhurodāravacanalāvaṇṇayuttena
analyzed: saka samaya samaya antara gahana ajjhogāhaṇa samatthena paññā veyyattiya samannāgatena ti piṭaka pariyat tippa bhede  sa aṭṭhakathe satthu sāsane appaṭihata ñāṇa ppabhāvena mahā veyyākaraṇena karaṇa sampatti janita sukha viniggata madhura udāra vacana lāvaṇṇa yuttena
translated: He was capable of diving into his own time, other times, and the depths of the scriptures. He possessed the fullness of wisdom. He was a great expounder of the three baskets of the scriptures, divided into the nine divisions of the sutta.🔽His knowledge and splendor were unimpeded regarding the eight kinds of reasoning and the teachings of the Teacher.🔽He was a great poet, a master of speech, endowed with the beauty of sweet and noble words that arose from the perfection of his actions.

original: yuttamuttavādinā vādīvarena mahākavinā pabhinnapaṭisambhidāparivāre chaḷabhiññāpaṭisambhidādippabhedaguṇapaṭimaṇḍite
analyzed: yutta mutta vādinā vādīvarena mahā kavinā pabhinna paṭisambhidā parivāre chaṣ abhiññā paṭisambhidā ādi ppabheda guṇa paṭimaṇḍite
translated: He was a great sage, adorned with the qualities of the six higher knowledges, the analytical knowledges, and so on, which are included in the retinue of the discriminations that are developed.

original: uttarimanussadhamme suppatiṭṭhitabuddhīnaṃ theravaṃsappadīpānaṃ therānaṃ mahāvihāravāsīnaṃ
analyzed: uttari manussa dhamme su patiṭṭhita buddhīnam thera vaṃsa ppadīpānam therānam mahāvihāra vāsīnam
translated: He was a great elder who lived in the Mahavihara, a lamp for the lineage of elders, whose understanding was well-established in the supermundane Dhamma.

original: vaṃsālaṅkārabhūtena vipulavisuddhabuddhinā buddhaghosoti garūhi gahitanāmadheyyena
analyzed: vaṃsa alaṅkāra bhūtena vipula visuddha buddhinā buddha ghosaḥ iti garūhi gahita nāmadheyyena
translated: by the one who is an ornament of the lineage, of vast and pure understanding, by the Elder called Buddhaghosa,

original: therena katā ayaṃ sammohavinodanī nāma vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathā.
analyzed: therena katā ayam sammohavinodanī nāma vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathā
translated: this commentary on the Dhammasanganī called The Clearing of Confusion.

original: Tāva tiṭṭhatu lokasmiṃ, lokanittharaṇesinaṃ;
analyzed: tāva tiṭṭhatu lokasmim loka nittharaṇa īsinam
translated: Let it remain as long as the world remains,

original: Dassentī kulaputtānaṃ, nayaṃ paññāvisuddhiyā.🔽Yāva buddhoti nāmampi, suddhacittassa tādino;
analyzed: dassentī kula puttānam nayam paññā visuddhiyā  yāva buddhaḥ ti nāmam pi suddhacittassa tādinaḥ
translated: showing the way to purity of understanding to the young men of good family,🔽who are seeking to cross over the world,🔽as long as the name “Buddha” remains in the world,🔽of the Great Sage, the world’s chief,

original: Lokamhi lokajeṭṭhassa, pavattati mahesinoti.
analyzed: lokamhi loka jeṭṭhassa pavattati mahesino ti
translated: of the one of pure heart and of such great virtue.

original: Sammohavinodanī nāma vibhaṅga-aṭṭhakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sammohavinodanī nāma vibhaṅga aṭṭhakathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Dhammasanganī called The Clearing of Confusion is finished.
